https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/22/busin.body_text: **********Brazil suspended all new coffee sales today and said it was considering a push for a fresh international agreement to limit exports and increase prices. Traders said the move would send coffee prices sharply higher. Producers and exporters alike were astonished by the news, announced by Economy Secretary Edgard Pereira and the ministry's coffee chief, Ricardo Mesquita, at a news conference in the capital, Brasilia. "The Government has decided to suspend coffee export registrations from tomorrow while Brazil re-evaluates its position on economic clauses," Pereira said. Earlier, he had been quoted in today's editions of the financial daily Gazeta Mercantil as saying that Brazil would not consider new limits on exports as part of a new international coffee pact.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/world.main_headline: U.S. Issues Warning of Obstacles In Adopting Romanian Children
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/world.print_headline: U.S. Issues Warning of Obstacles In Adopting Romanian Children
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/world.body_text: **********Americans seeking to adopt Romanian children were warned by the State Department today that they face formidable legal obstacles both in this country and in Romania, where foreign adoptions are to be suspended pending completion of new legislation. **********After the Communist dictatorship was overthrown in December 1989, the wretched existence of 140,000 Romanian children, many of them orphans in state institutions, was given wide publicity. As a result, many Western European and American couples went there seeking children for adoption. And a small but profitable illegal market in children for sale was created. **********Recently, scores of prospective American parents have found themselves having to spend weeks at a time in Bucharest trying to untangle both Romanian and American red tape in obtaining proper documents for adoption and for United States visas for the newly adopted children. This month about 50 of these Americans picketed the United States Embassy in Bucharest to protest delays in paperwork. **********A Romanian spokesman said in Bucharest today that on June 1 foreign adoptions would be suspended until the semi-governmental Committee for Adoptions established comprehensive new procedures. The head of the committee, Alexandra Zugravesvu, said the suspension would probably last until September. **********Last week the Chamber of Deputies of the National Assembly approved legislation aimed at halting illegal adoptions. Traian Chelebeu, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said the Senate, or upper house, was expected to approve the legislation next week. **********Since the overthrow of the dictatorship of President Nicolae Ceausescu, close to 7,000 Romanian children have been adopted. A State Department official said that as of May 6, Americans had adopted 1,443 Romanian children -- 480 of them in 1990. **********In that period, the pool of children eligible for adoption has shrunk considerably. In the Ceausescu era, abortions and birth control devices were illegal and, as a result, thousands of unwanted children were born. Since then, birth control devices have become widely available, and the number of abortions now greatly exceeds births. **********In recent months, foreigners have sought Romanian children for adoption both privately and through the Adoption Committee. **********Prospective American parents have encountered difficulties on both tracks. Privately offered children have been supplied with fraudulent papers that American consular officials have rejected. Children considered adoptable by the official committee have turned out not to have been legally abandoned. **********The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, which has become involved in the issue, insists that under American law, in order for foreign children to be eligible for American visas, it must be established that they are either orphans or were clearly abandoned by both parents. **********Still, a spokesman, Duke Austin, said the I.N.S. had issued 20 waivers for privately acquired Romanian children on "humanitarian" grounds and was considering 80 more waiver applications. **********The State Department's warning today, directed to "all prospective parents contemplating travel to Romania," strongly urged them to contact the department before departure. **********It said general information on the adoption issue was available by calling (202) 647-8444; a travel advisory on Romania, at 647-5225, and information on American visas, at 647-0510.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/busin.body_text: **********COMPANIES A Giant Killer Stumbles and Takes a Big Fall **********Joseph R. Canion, president of the Compaq Computer Corporation, has to be more careful when he speaks. Last week, before the company's annual meeting, he predicted that Compaq's earnings would be down 79 percent this quarter. The analysts did not have to run those numbers through their laptops. The market value of the stock tumbled by $1.2 billion on the news. Share prices fell from $49.25 to $36. It finished the week at 35.75. Back in 1982, when Mr. Canion started the company, it was the giant killer. But inexpensive computers, some with more features, ate into its market share. Inventories built up. Last April, Compaq was forced to cut prices, which hurt profits, and Mr. Canion sold 20 percent of his stock, which hurt morale. Compaq announced that it will buy back up to 10 million shares of its stock. Good for the stock, but what about the company? Compaq should invest in high-end products, analysts say. Putting a Price on T.W.A.'s Debt  Trans World Airlines missed several payments on its $1.2 billion in debt, and now its creditors are threatening to repossess 10 airplanes and dozens of engines. That would cripple the airline. Carl C. Icahn, who owns T.W.A., wants to keep it in the air, so he is offering his creditors a deal. Mr. Icahn is willing to buy back T.W.A.'s debt, but at a deep discount -- 17.5 cents to 73 cents on the dollar, depending of what they hold. Not bad, he says, since some T.W.A. paper is trading at just 15 cents on the dollar. The creditors are understandably angry. But Mr. Icahn has leverage. He can put the airline under the protection of Chapter 11. Or, since he sold his stock in the USX Corporation last week for $1.02 billion, he could buy T.W.A.'s debt at full price. School Construction at a Profit? The man who brought advertising into the classroom now wants to build schools -- 200 of them beginning in 1996. Christopher Whittle, chairman of Whittle Communications Inc., in Knoxville, Tenn., expects his schools to make a profit, but he vows not to line the hallways with billboards. He wants to blend technology with traditional methods, all for $4,300 per pupil a year -- about the national average. To build the schools, Mr. Whittle still needs to raise $2.5 billion to $3 billion. Education Secretary Lamar Alexander sits on the company's board, but Mr. Whittle claims he does not want government money. However, he will accept payment vouchers, as proposed by the Bush Administration, if that program ever gets off the ground. S&L Properties by the Bundle L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolutution Trust Corporation, figured it would take 300 years to sell off all the properties remaining from the savings and loan bailout. So he came up with a plan: Bundle the properties together, sell them to big developers and let the buyers pay the government out of earnings. Congress wants cash. **********Buying Loyalty from Viewers People used to watch CBS voluntarily. Now they need to be paid off. The network unveiled a plan last week to build viewer loyalty that is based on the frequent flyer programs of the airlines. The more you watch, the more you win, said CBS. But the network's experience with buying viewers with promotions has been almost as bad as the airlines'. Shoppers who see the CBS promotions at K-Mart stores are still going home to watch reruns on cable TV.  The End of a Fight They fought for 10 weeks, taking out advertisements in newspapers around the country, but in the end they made a deal. France's Groupe Schneider S.A., the giant electrical equipment company, acquired the Square D Company for $2.23 billion. Square D makes electrical controls for factories and the home market. So does Schneider. With the acquisition, Schneider will become the world's largest producer of electrical control products, with more than 30 percent of the American market. In the dim days of the past -- before the Reagan and Bush Administrations, that is -- that much concentration might have raised an eyebrow at the Justice Department. But Justice has given the deal a nod. A Costly Way to Increase Sales  The Saturn Corporation is trying desperately to run rings around its competition with better service and a better car. It is the General Motors Corporation's import fighter.When it mistakenly put the wrong coolant into the engines of 1,100 Saturn cars, it decided to replace the cars at no cost. A pretty good deal. But last week, G.M. said it will count each of the cars it replaces as a new-car sale. With sales like that, how long can the Saturn last? THE ECONOMY **********Housing Starts Rise Sharply . . .  The housing industry is sending signals that the end of the slump is near. The first three months were erratic, with sharp ups and downs. But April, the Commerce Department said last week, was a relief, especially for the nation's home builders. Housing starts climbed by 6.2 percent, quite a nice jump. "The way recoveries begin is with an upturn in housing," said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. Does this upturn say the recession is nearing its end? "Growth by the end of the year could be a positive 3.5 percent," he said. . . .  as Consumer Prices Inch Up  Consumer prices crept up, but only by a smidgeon. They rose by 0.2 percent in April, according to the Labor Department. "Commodity prices are falling, and prices are rising mainly in the services," said Kevin Logan, chief economist at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. Medical services were up. So were personal and educational services like college and private school tuition. Health club memberships cost more, too. A concern, yes, but nothing that the economy cannot sustain. "My overall outlook is for a decline in the rate of inflation," he said.  INTERNATIONAL **********A Defender of the Mark Resigns  Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, has a line in its charter saying it must defend the mark. Karl Otto Pohl,who said that he will resign in October as the bank's president, did that job well. The mark never varied as Europe's strongest currency during his 10-year tenure. But lately Mr. Pohl has despaired. The economic merger between the two Germanys is a disaster -- his word. Economists agree. "Since the merger, there has been no true price stability." said Carl Weinberg of High Frequency Economics in New York. "I give Hans Tietmeyer, who's on the bank council, 70 percent odds of getting the job." Burning Renoirs and van Goghs?  Last week the badly slumping art market received a jolt. Ryoei Saito, the Japanese industrialist who controls Daishowa Paper Manufacturing Company, said his paintings would be cremated with him when he dies. Mr. Saito owns van Gogh's "Portrait of Dr. Gachet," which he bought for $82.5 million last year, and "At the Moulin de la Galette" by Renoir. Having the paintings burned would cut inheritance taxes, Mr. Saito said. When the art world gasped, Mr. Saito reconsidered. Maybe the masterpieces would go into storage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/14/busin.main_headline: A Page From Fast Food's Menu
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/14/busin.print_headline: A Page From Fast Food's Menu
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/14/busin.body_text: **********Inspiration recently struck George Loesch during breakfast at Denny's. In scouting the competition, Mr. Loesch frequently holds breakfast meetings at fast-food restaurants, where he picks apart the sausage biscuits and eagerly devours new menu items. **********Mr. Loesch works not for a rival restaurant chain, as his fast-food fieldwork might imply, but for the Campbell Soup Company, best known for its home heat-and-serve offerings. Inspired by the popularity of a large-portion breakfast on the Denny's menu, Mr. Loesch recently shepherded to market a line of "Big Start" home breakfasts. The meals, which offer such entrees as pancakes with scrambled eggs and bacon, are the newest addition to the Great Start brand sold by Swanson's, a division of Campbell Soup. Boasting About Borrowing **********Mr. Loesch freely acknowledges that he got the idea from Denny's, a restaurant chain owned by TW Services Inc. He even boasts of it in a sales brochure for grocers that invites them to "take a bite out of the restaurant business" by stocking the new Swanson product line, which was introduced in July. **********More and more makers of packaged foods are taking cues from fast-food menus. In addition to breakfasts like eggs and sausages on biscuits, the supermarket freezer case is filled these days with products like the Geo. A. Hormel & Company's Bacon Cheeseburger, Swanson's Chicken Nuggets and Tyson Foods Inc.'s Hot 'n' Spicy chicken wings -- all products that food experts say were prompted by the success of similar offerings in restaurants. **********Such are the tactics in the fierce fight over "share of stomach," the food industry term for the consumer's food dollar. Americans spend more than $500 billion a year on food, and restaurants account for an increasingly larger portion of the total. **********Consumers' restaurant spending will reach $262 billion this year, or 48.5 percent of total food spending, according to estimates by Technomic, a Chicago food consulting firm, while grocery store food sales will reach $278 billion, or 51.5 percent. **********For packaged-food retailers, that is a disturbing drop from 1980, when supermarkets attracted nearly 60 percent of food spending. The trend reflects the growth of single-parent households and of households where both parents work -- situations that create a time squeeze that has benefited fast-food chains in particular. **********To fight back, supermarkets are devoting more and more space to salad bars and deli sections. And increasingly, food companies are offering grocers packaged foods that mimic items popular in restaurant settings. **********"Instead of having a breakfast sandwich at McDonald's, you can pick one up from the freezer of your grocery store," said Ron Paul, president of Technomic, who predicted that many more fast-food products will show up on the grocers' shelves and freezers. **********In recent weeks, for example, Conagra Inc. and the Quaker Oats Company have joined other food companies by introducing low-fat ground beef products. The Conagra offering, which is sold at the meat counter of grocery stores, has only 4 percent fat, compared with the 20 percent or so typically found in regular ground beef.  Stalking the Mclean Deluxe **********The lean-beef trend follows McDonald's introduction last spring of Mclean Deluxe, a 91 percent fat-free hamburger that has received widespread attention. **********"McDonald's stirred up an awful lot of interest," said Bill O'Neill, vice president of sales and marketing at Fairbank Farms, a maker of low-fat ground beef in Ashville, N.Y., 75 miles southwest of Buffalo. "We piggybacked off that, big time," he said gleefully. **********As McDonald's introduced its Mclean in various parts of the country, Mr. O'Neill's sales force was there at every turn. "We tried to get the scoop on where they were moving next and take the information to retailers," Mr. O'Neill said. That allowed retailers to tie their advertising to McDonald's Mclean introduction. **********In the case of Conagra, however, executives said their company had been working on low-fat ground beef for a year, and the timing of its introduction had nothing to do with McDonald's. With its Healthy Choice line of low-fat, low-sodium frozen dinners, Conagra has proved a nimble innovator in recent years. **********But the influence of McDonald's on the packaged-food industry is clearly evident. Mary Adolf of the Beef Industry Council in Chicago said she was deluged by calls from meat buyers at large supermarket chains seeking the names of suppliers of low-fat ground beef after the McDonald's announcement. **********"Retailers and food service operators are duking it out for consumer dollars," she said. "The move by McDonald's prompted retailers to want to market a similar type product for home use." **********Tim Hammonds, senior vice president for the Food Marketing Institute, a supermarket trade group in Washington, acknowledged that the growth of the fast-food chains over the last 20 years had hurt grocers. "That industry has gained largely at the expense of the supermarket industry," he said. **********Recently, he said, there are indications that the weak economy has led people to eat out less and buy more food at grocery stores. With the new products, Mr. Hammonds said, "There is a real opportunity for us to hold on to some of those customers as the economy improves." **********Armed with stocked freezers, supermarkets are ready to do battle with the Egg McMuffin. Although McDonald's introduced the Egg McMuffins in 1975, it was not until the company expanded its menu with a variety of breakfast sandwiches in 1986 that the category caught fire -- and the food companies' attention. 'Clones of Fast Food' **********"We've had a tremendous onslaught of frozen breakfast products that are the clones of fast food," said Martin Friedman, editor of the Chicago newsletter, Gorman's New Product News. **********Executives at large food companies, however, reject the notion that fast-food restaurants act as product development labs for packaged food makers. And they argue that their companies have done a better job than restaurants of making healthy food availble. **********"It's a real race to see who is picking up on these trends and responding," said William Zick, a vice president with International Flavors and Fragrances Inc., a company that makes flavorings for the prepared-food industry. **********For several reasons, restaurants tend to be more nimble. Introducing a product can cost a major packaged-food company up to $30 million, because it involves retooling production lines, creating television advertisements and new packaging. **********To test a breakfast burrito, however, McDonald's can simply ask a few stores to start serving the product. **********"The cost of trying a new item is very small for restaurants," said Mr. Paul of Technomic. "They can literally change production runs everyday."  Blurring the Boundaries **********Based on the number of restaurants now experimenting with skinless fried chicken, Mr. Paul expects such products to show up soon at the grocery store. **********The very boundaries between supermarkets and restaurants are becoming increasingly blurred. In a striking illustration of the overlap, Taco Bell, the fast-food Mexican restaurant operator, opened a small kiosk in a supermarket in Phoenix earlier this month. **********"The lines between the segments are starting to come down," said John E. Martin, president and chief executive of Taco Bell, a unit of Pepsico Inc. **********"Everybody is looking at everybody else," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/04/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Logistics; From Bombs to Burgers, Gulf War Involves Biggest Supply Effort Ever
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/04/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Logistics; From Bombs to Burgers, Gulf War Involves Biggest Supply Effort Ever
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/04/world.body_text: **********The two-lane highways snaking through the desert north and east of here look like American expressways at rush hour these days. **********Tan-painted military trucks, fuel tankers, the big, gaily decorated Mercedes cargo haulers that ply the Middle East, and the odd-looking "humvees" (the high-mobility multi-purpose wheeled vehicles that replaced the military jeep) are bumper to bumper as they head to the front lines in the last stage of the biggest, fastest deployment in military history. **********Where the roads cross at Hafr al Baten, an American military policeman in a fluorescent red vest stands on a platform resting on giant tires and smartly waves the trucks toward their destinations, occasionally flashing a V-sign at a driver. **********The allied military force here grew to more than 500,000 this week. With elements of the American VII Corps from Germany, the heavy tank force that would be a spearhead of any ground action, still arriving, full readiness would be likely toward the end of the month. **********Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said last week that all American ground troops would be in position for action by late this month, but President Bush said on Friday that the United States would open a ground attack only "if necessary and when we decide that the time is right." **********What the military calls the "beans and bullets," the logistics that support an army, are increasingly in place in a huge distribution of ammunition, fuel, water and almost everything else imaginable down to batteries for Walkman tape players.  Bombing May Be a Record **********The statistics are numbing. The air forces, which consume 12 million gallons of fuel a day, refuse to say how many tons of bombs have been dropped on Iraq and Kuwait, but the amount is generally believed to exceed what was used in all of World War II. **********"It's almost at a point where there is no comparison," said the man in charge, Maj. Gen. William (Gus) Pagonis, when asked in an interview for a reference point from previous wars. "This is the largest logistical move in history." **********The soft-spoken general first learned about logistics working in his Greek-American family's all-night restaurant in the steel-mill town of Charleroi, Pa. He remembered that one of his major thrills was the day he graduated from sweeping floors to flipping hamburgers on the short-order grill.  What Troops Really Want **********It is an experience he has not forgotten. A growing network of aluminum-sided "Wolfburger" stands -- named for his warrant officer -- is being set up near American positions to provide what General Pagonis says the troops really want: "hamburgers, french fries and hot dogs." **********He compares the effort mounted in the desert here with the battle in North Africa between the British and Gen. Erwin Rommel's Afrika Korps during World War II. **********"The Germans lost in the desert because of logistics," he said. "Rommel had a super fighting force. But when their tanks advanced, they had to go back for their resupplies. The British brought their logistics with them. They defeated Rommel by building 'log' bases forward as they went and not having to go back. That's what we will do." **********General Pagonis, the deputy commander for logistics of the American-led operation in the Persian Gulf, said he had begun with "me and two other guys" after a phone call on Aug. 3, the day after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, from the headquarters of the joint rapid deployment force in Tampa, Fla. **********Since then, the size of the logistics force has grown to about 40,000, with about 60 percent from the Reserves or National Guard. There are 92 different shoulder patches worn by the various units.  Saudi Infrastructure **********The military was fortunate that the deployment was mounted in Saudi Arabia because "the infrastructure is so good," General Pagonis said, adding, "The ports are the best in the world." **********Huge amounts of construction equipment and trucks, a legacy of the oil boom, were available to be rented, and hundreds of Pakistani, Filipino, Korean and other expatriate drivers and operators have been hired. This meant the Americans did not have to bring this heavy equipment with them. **********General Pagonis says his logistical problems are small compared with those of Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein. **********"I know where all his 'log' bases are," the general said. "We study what his supply routes are, where his fuel points are, where he's building new ones. **********"We're planning, if he crumbles and we have to go forward, what we have to do to sustain the operation," he said. "We can use his fuel, if the Air Force leaves any and doesn't bomb it. We can use his roads, his railways, his depots and his facilities.  Hussein's Stockpiles **********"He's built up stockpiles. But the Air Force is sure helping to blow some of that up. That's why the air campaign is so important. The air war will shape the battlefield. **********"He has to be having tremendous problems. His repair parts for his tanks and all his equipment were from the Soviets and different places, and all that was cut off." He added: **********"That doesn't mean the tanks aren't ready to fight. Just like your automobile, you may have an oil leak, but the car will still run. But can he sustain his operation? That is where the difference will come in."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/04/busin.body_text: **********The chief executive of Emery Worldwide and members of his management team have unexpectedly resigned from the money-losing air-freight concern. **********Arthur C. Bass, a former executive of Federal Express, a leading rival of Emery, will be succeeded by W. Roger Curry, a marketing vice president of Emery's parent company, Consolidated Freightways Inc. **********Mr. Bass, who is 58 years old, left the Wilton, Conn., company on Friday after less than six months in the post. The company declined to explain why he departed. **********When Mr. Bass was named to the post in September, some industry experts had questioned whether his free-wheeling style would mesh with the no-nonsense approach of Consolidated Freightways. **********Consolidated, the big trucking company based in Menlo Park, acquired Emery in 1989 for $478 million, landing itself in a cutthroat business in which it had limited experience. **********Though Mr. Bass has had a long association with the freight industry, he had recently served as chief executive of the Cooper Companies, a health-care concern, which he was credited with restoring to profitability. Before joining Cooper in March 1989, he was vice chairman and president of Federal Express. He is also a former chairman and chief executive of Midway Airlines. **********Also leaving Emery were Mr. Bass's management team, including Michael Fitzgerald, the executive vice president, and Tucker Taylor, the vice president of marketing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.body_text: **********A judge here today blocked the liquidation of the operations of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International after the bank's Abu Dhabi owners agreed to set up a fund to allow British depositors to borrow against their frozen deposits. **********The Abu Dhabi owners also agreed to pay salaries and expenses of bank employees at least for a while. **********The Abu Dhabi owners made their proposal for the $:50 million ($84 million) fund in court here to stave off the liquidation sought by the Bank of England, Britain's banking regulator. Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahayan, the ruler of Abu Dhabi, and the Abu Dhabi Government, had asked for more time to assess the scope of the bank's problems and to devise a plan to salvage as much of its global operations as possible.  Hearing Set for Dec. 2 **********The High Court judge, Sir Nicolas Browne-Wilkinson, said he would reconsider whether to liquidate the bank at a hearing scheduled for Dec. 2. He noted that depositors in Britain -- and throughout the world -- stood a better chance of recovering their money if the Abu Dhabi owners could devise a rescue plan. **********In granting the adjournment, Sir Nicolas noted that the Abu Dhabi owners had said that they would not be willing to help compensate depositors if the bank were immediately liquidated. The Bank of England refused to contribute to the relief fund. **********The deposit proposal of the Abu Dhabi owners applies only to customers of the bank in Britain. Cooperation Cited **********Michael Crystal, a lawyer for Touche Ross & Company, the court-appointed provisional liquidator of the bank, supported the delay and said the Abu Dhabi authorities were now cooperating by giving Touche Ross some 6,000 files that authorities believe contain important information about the scope of the bank's losses and reputed wrongdoings. **********"Together, the effect of these developments gives us and those entrusted with the various component parts of the group around the world a period of comparative calm in which to take whatever steps we can" to save any viable parts of the bank and to preserve the value of the group's assets, said Brian Smouha, the Touche Ross partner appointed by a Luxembourg court to handle the bank's affairs. **********In a statement, he added that, "in this way, we can carry out to the best effect our assignment on behalf of the depositors and creditors worldwide to maximize the value of their interests." **********If the court eventually orders a liquidation, Touche Ross would be in charge of raising money from the sale of what remains of the bank's assets, including its investments, securities, loans and real estate. Those funds would be used to pay off, at least partially, the bank's creditors, including its depositors. **********Last week, the judge adjourned the first hearing until today and indicated that he might grant the Abu Dhabi owners a longer adjournment if a relief plan for small depositors and the 1,200 British employees of the bank could be arranged and if the Abu Dhabi owners would release the files. Seized by Regulators **********Regulators around the world seized most of the bank's global operations early this month after an investigation ordered by the Bank of England uncovered what was said to be evidence of large concealed losses and widespread fraud. **********On Monday, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, announced that a New York grand jury had indicted the bank; its founder, Aga Hassan Abedi, and a former chief, Swaleh Naqvi, on 12 counts stemming from schemes that were part of a fraud that may have resulted in a loss of up to $5 billion worldwide. **********The London courtroom was packed today with crowds of lawyers, reporters, bank employees and depositors. It was so hot inside that Sir Nicolas gave the lawyers permission to follow his example and remove their wigs. **********Raihan Mahmud, the 49-year-old manager of the bank's Brompton Road branch in London, which the Bank of England closed along with the rest of the British operations on July 5, reflected the jubilation of the employees when the judge announced the decision. "I'm overjoyed," he said. "It's absolutely wonderful. It means that people are going to survive." **********"I'm full of hope I'll get my job back; there's a very good chance for very many people to be kept," said Mr. Mahmud, who was born in Pakistan but who has lived in Britain for 25 years and is a British citizen. "The Bank of England has not acted out of anyone's interest, while the majority shareholders are fully committed to making this bank survive." **********Depositors have about $3.25 billion at the British branches of the Luxembourg-incorporated bank. About $1.1 billion of that are sterling deposits held by 48,400 depositors throughout Britain. **********Britain's deposit insurance plan, which is financed by the banks and administered by the Bank of England, only covers sterling deposits. It will reimburse 75 percent of deposits up to a maximum compensation of $:15,000 ($25,200). The seized bank's depositors would only be able to collect from the insurance plan after a judicial liquidation order. **********Of the $:50 million ($84 million) to be provided by the Abu Dhabi owners, about $:43 million ($72.24 million) will be earmarked for the depositors' relief fund. Under the program, depositors will be able to borrow an amount equal to 75 percent of their deposits, or a maximum loan of $:5,000 ($8,400). The loans would be repaid by either the deposit insurance plan or the Bank of Credit, if it is revived.  Reasons for Request **********The Bank of England said it sought the liquidation because wrongdoing at the bank made its continued operation damaging to the public interest. Other reasons given were that the bank was insolvent and there was no prospect of it surviving as a going concern and being able to compensate depositors and give employees severance pay. **********Robin Leigh-Pemberton, governor of the Bank of England, has said that he sees little likelihood that the central bank would give the seized bank permission to reopen under its present name and form in Britain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Alfa Romeo Aid Repayment Urged
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/busin.body_text: **********The Attorney General of the European Court recommended that the former owner of Alfa Romeo repay $700 million in state aid. The Attorney General, Walter Van Gerven, recommended that the court uphold a 1989 European Commission order that Finmeccanica, an Italian holding company, repay aid received in 1985 and 1986. **********Mr. Van Gerven said the aid did not meet a European Community standard that a "reasonable private investor" would have made a similar investment. The commission said the aid must be repaid because it was a subsidy and incompatible with community competition rules. If it is forced to repay the aid, Finmeccanica will lose most of the profit it made when it sold Alfa Romeo to Fiat S.p.A. in 1986. The Court of Justice will make a final ruling in March or April.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/busin.main_headline: F.D.I.C. Role Questioned In Case of Failed S.& L.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/busin.print_headline: F.D.I.C. Role Questioned In Case of Failed S.& L.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/busin.body_text: **********Former regulators at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation told a Congressional hearing today that their superiors thwarted for more than a year their efforts to recover large losses from the billionaire owner of a Phoenix savings and loan that failed. **********The owner is Daniel K. Ludwig, who is influential in national Republican circles. Officials of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the sister agency of the F.D.I.C., which inherited the case, said yesterday that the delays reflected manpower shortages and jurisictional disputes. **********The testimony of the former requlators was the second time in two weeks that the competence of the F.D.I.C. was questioned on Capitol Hill. Last week, a report by the staff of a House Budget Committee group said the F.D.I.C., which is responsible for dealing with failed banks, had mishandled the two costliest bank failures in history, using unfair selection procedures and overly generous subsidies. In Contrast to Reputation **********These complaints about the agency are a sharp contrast to its generally high regard among legislators. **********At today's hearing of the Senate Subcommittee on Antitrust, Monopolies and Business Rights, David Noffsinger, an assistant director for investigations at the Resolution Trust Corporation, said an inquiry was begun in July into a possible lawsuit against the former directors and officers of Mr. Ludwig's Southwest Savings and Loan Association. **********Only a few weeks earlier, the F.D.I.C. had dismissed Mark A. Blanchietti Hollander, a junior lawyer handling actions involving Southwest Savings and Loan, after he sent a memo to senior F.D.I.C. officials. **********The memo, released by the panel, raised questions about roadblocks in the Southwest case and recommended that the case be referred to more independent investigators. **********Caryl Austrian, a spokeswoman for the F.D.I.C., said Mr. Hollander was let go because "he was unable to follow the structure of the program." **********Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, the Ohio Democrat who is chairman of the subcommittee, said the subcommittee had been unable to explore what happened to Mr. Hollander or what kind of investigation was being conducted in part because the R.T.C. declined to provide documents requested by the panel. **********The R.T.C. official supervising the inquiry told the subcommittee staff in November that the agency did not know of any interviews, the staff report said. **********Referring to the inquiry, Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, asked, "Why wasn't the matter pursued at an earlier time, because we all know leads grow cold?" **********Mr. Ludwig, a reclusive 93-year-old shipping and real estate businessman from New York, controlled several savings and loans taken over by the Government. He did not return a call placed to his New York office. **********The losses at Southwest, which Mr. Metzenbaum estimated at more than $250 million, stemmed from a number of questionable real estate deals, some of which involved Mr. Ludwig's companies, according to a subcommittee staff report. **********Documents show that Mr. Ludwig had indemnified the directors and officers against any liability. The F.D.I.C. often sues former officers and directors, but it is rare for an owner to indemnify them.  Interviews Are Blocked **********In early 1989, soon after Southwest was taken over by the F.D.I.C., Kenneth J. Webb, an F.D.I.C. investigator, went to Phoenix to gather information for a possible lawsuit. Mr. Webb told the subcommittee that he was precluded from doing any interviews by Anthony Scalzi, the F.D.I.C. official in charge. **********Mr. Scalzi, recently named the acting director of Resolution Trust's resolutions and operations division, told the panel: "I wasn't trying to block anything. In retrospect I probably should have let him go ahead." **********Later that year Mr. Webb was asked to restart the investigation by Mr. Hollander, who had been assigned to the case after joining the F.D.I.C. legal department in Washington as part of an honors program. **********Mr. Webb and Mr. Hollander told the panel they encountered a lack of interest by their superiors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.main_headline: Technology; New Techniques to Turn an Oil Spill Into a Collectible
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.print_headline: Technology; New Techniques to Turn an Oil Spill Into a Collectible
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.body_text: **********If there had been any doubt, recent scientific studies of the environmental impact of the Exxon Valdez spill have demonstrated that the toxic effect of oil on animals and plant life persists for years. **********With that in mind, several small companies are working on new approaches designed to clean up oil spills more thoroughly. **********Conventional methods for dealing with oil discharged into the water focus on physical means like containment booms, skimmers and absorbent materials. But such approaches inevitably miss some oil and lose elements of it to evaporation. **********Another approach, favored by oil companies, is to use dispersant chemicals, which break up a slick and make it appear to go away faster. But some of the chemicals used are believed to be more toxic than oil itself, and many states have banned them. **********Some of the alternative methods under development appear to overcome these disadvantages. They are intended to recover all the oil in a spill, rather than spread it around in the environment. All tend to reduce the formation of an oil-water mixture known as mousse. And all come from small companies that are struggling to gain acceptance of their technology by skeptical regulatory agencies, clean-up organizations and the oil companies. **********One interesting approach is a mix of chemicals called Elastol, made by General Technology Applications Inc. of Manassas, Va. The principal ingredient is a synthetic rubber, polyisobutylene. **********Sprayed on an oil slick, Elastol dissolves in the oil and increases its viscosity, or thickness. Since the additive is not soluble in water, it pulls the oil into a compact mat, which can be recovered with suction equipment or a skimmer. Thus, it is the opposite of a dispersant -- it binds the oil together for removal. **********Thomas Scambos, the chairman of General Technology, said the polyisobutylene molecules are made up of long strings of atoms wrapped in tight rows, like a ball of twine. But as they dissolve in oil, the molecules relax and stretch out, creating filaments that tend to interlock with one another, holding the combined mass together. Indeed, company officials say if too much of the material is applied to an oil slick, the mixture may become too thick to pump. **********Mr. Scambos said polyisobutylene is also used in chewing gum, so it is available in food-grade purities. The other ingredients are nontoxic as well, he said. **********Unlike some oil recovery approaches that pull in large amounts of water with the oil, this process keeps the oil separate. **********At a recent demonstration at a fire training facility in Westchester County, heating oil was spread on a pool of water. A slurry of Elastol and water was sprayed on the oil and given about half an hour to dissolve. Then a floating skimmer, which had a rotating, oil-attracting polypropylene drum, was placed in the pool and attached to a truck with a large vacuum chamber. The oil was picked up by the drum, scraped off with a flexible blade and pulled into the truck by the vacuum pressure. The oil coming off the roller appeared to include little water. **********Company officials say running the mixture through a pump with a high shearing action breaks the molecular bond and that the oil can be used as originally intended. Heating oil recovered from New Haven harbor last year using this method was simply pumped back into the barge that had spilled it. **********The Elastol approach would probably not be effective against a big spill at sea, where the wave action would impede the formation of a thick mat of oil. But it could be useful in coping with smaller spills in harbors or near marshlands, said Richard Golob, publisher of Golob's Oil Pollution Bulletin in Boston. "This is a technology that has a place in the oil spill response arsenal and may also have some value in dealing with hydrocarbon contamination in waste water," he said. **********But Mr. Golob said the Elastol concept has "encountered tremendous resistance" in the oil industry because in general this approach -- like the other new techniques under development -- is more expensive than using dispersants. Stephen Dorrler, general manager of the Northeast region of the Marine Spill Response Corporation -- the spill clean-up organization set up by the oil industry in the wake of the Exxon Valdez accident -- refused even to discuss the technology. **********Another chemical approach to oil spills has been developed by Liquid Waste Technologies of Blackwood, N.J. It uses a coagulating agent that turns liquid oil into a flexible solid that can be lifted off water. **********The oil thickener is a polymer, said William Gannon, a vice president of the company. "The oil is absorbed into the polymer and joins in long chain molecules to form a sheet of rubber," he said. "If you put this stuff in No. 2 oil, in an hour you can bounce it on the ground." **********He said the product, which has been used mostly for small industrial spills, can be burned or buried in landfills. "It will not release oil, so it can go in a landfill," Mr. Gannon said. **********Thomas B. Reed, a research professor at the Colorado School of Mines, thinks activated sawdust is the answer. After proper heat treatment, he said, sawdust will float indefinitely and absorb oil in much the same way that activated charcoal absorbs chemicals. **********"You can sprinkle it on the oil, wait a minute or two and then take it up with a screen or suction device," he said. "When you get it ashore, you can squeeze the oil out or just burn it generate power." **********But, he said, it has been impossible to do a real-world test of the product, called Sea Sweep. "The vice president for the environment of one oil company turned us over to their laboratory group," he said. "But once we got there, it became clear they were not the least bit interested." **********Yet another new absorbent approach is San Sorb, which is being marketed by C&E Environmental Supplies in Sumner, Wash. Connie Nobles, a partner in C&E, describes it as a petrochemical-derived powder that is made up of many thin, hollow tubes, known as capillaries. Mixed in as well are fertilizers intended to promote the growth of microorganisms that naturally consume oil. **********"When oil is spilled, the first thing you do is contain it with a boom," she said. "Then you sprinkle on our product and it encapsulates the oil so the volatiles are not going into the air and other parts into the water." The material can then be collected disposal on land, where it gradually biodegrades.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/busin.main_headline: End of Slump In Magazines Is Foreseen
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; End of Slump In Magazines Is Foreseen
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/busin.body_text: **********Four prominent magazine executives predicted yesterday that their business would soon start climbing out of the worst advertising slump in nearly two decades and would achieve renewed prominence among marketers by emphasizing editorial quality and new methods of reaching readers. **********"The unvarnished truth about the magazine business is: This has been the toughest 18 months of my 25 years in the magazine business," said Thomas O. Ryder,the president of the publishing and direct marketing group of American Express Travel Related Services, which publishes Travel & Leisure, Food & Wine and other magazines. "Most of us have seen our advertising pages decline. We've seen weak franchises fold. It's been scary." **********But Mr. Ryder said he thought that a turnaround in advertising would start this fall, and that by the end of the decade magazines would be thriving by "doing much more individualized editorial, leading to great targeting opportunities" for advertisers. A Slump Last Year **********In 1990, the 173 consumer magazines tracked by the Publishers Information Bureau, an arm of the magazine industry, had 171,689 pages of advertising, a drop of 3.7 percent from 1989. Advertising revenue was $6.75 billion, up only 1.9 percent from 1989. **********Mr. Ryder and three competitors addressed a luncheon yesterday sponsored by the Advertising Women of New York. Also speaking were Reginald K. Brack Jr., the head of Time Warner's publishing division; D. Claeys Bahrenburg, the president of Hearst Magazines, and Bernard H. Leser, the president of Conde Nast Publications. The speakers' prominence attracted an unusually large audience of 550 people to the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza Hotel. **********The audience included a star-studded list of magazine editors and publishers, among them Betsy Carter, the editor of New York Woman; Michael Clinton, the publisher of GQ; John Mack Carter, the editor of Good Housekeeping; Ellen Levine, the new editor of Redbook, and W. Randall Jones, who recently left Esquire, where he was publisher, to become chief executive of Fidelity Publishing. **********Mr. Brack agreed with Mr. Ryder that "the future of communications is narrowcasting," or targeting. He predicted that magazines would flourish by selling advertising packages in tandem with cable television companies. Both media, he said, can help marketers take aim at specific groups of consumers. **********Mr. Brack, whose company has been aggressive in packaging magazine ads with advertising in other media owned by Time Warner, said publishers who sell packages must guard the editorial quality and the individuality of their magazines. He drew a laugh from the audience when he recited what he called one of marketing's biggest lies: "Dear, if you pass a newsstand, make sure to pick me up a Hearst magazine."  A Dose of Optimism **********The way the speakers saw the magazine business was rosier than one might expect. Mr. Leser, for example, dismissed much of the criticism he said had been tossed at Conde Nast for repositioning Details as a young men's magazine and for introducing a new women's magazine, Allure, in the face of the advertising slump. **********"Great ideas don't always strike at the most opportune time," he said, urging others to follow their entrepreneurial instincts and not simply their wallets. **********In an interview, Mr. Leser said good ideas could be successful, even in bad times. The first issue of the British edition of Vanity Fair, which has the same articles as the American version but British advertising, sold 70,000 copies in March, "far more than expected," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/busin.main_headline: Money-Fund Yields Mixed, But Analysts Expect Decline
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/busin.print_headline: CONSUMER RATES; Money-Fund Yields Mixed, But Analysts Expect Decline
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/busin.body_text: **********The yields on money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report remained mixed for the second straight seven-day period, which ended yesterday. **********Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's said investors should see more declines in yields in the coming weeks as a result of the Federal Reserve's reduction Tuesday in its discount rate, the rate the Fed charges on loans to banks, to 5 1/2 percent from 6 percent. **********"This move was a surprise to the market," said Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue's, "and we can't rule out another move by the central bank at a later date. We always live with one more move, whether it's up or down."  Tax-Exempt Yields Rise **********Analysts said they did not expect yields on money market funds to decline by more than about a quarter of a percentage point. **********Yields on tax-exempt money funds increased for the second consecutive week, as supplies of new issues continue to overwhelm investor demand. The average number of days to maturity of securities held in portfolios declined by a day, to 45, while their total assets fell by $1.6 billion, to a total of $87.6 billion. **********For the period ended yesterday, the average seven-day compounded yield rose 16 basis points, to 4.44 percent, while the seven-day simple yield increased 15 basis points, to 4.34 percent. The 30-day compounded average yield fell one basis point, to 4.29 percent, and the 30-day simple yield dropped four basis points, to 4.20 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point. **********The taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-exempt compunded yield is 6.16 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket and 6.62 percent in the 33 percent tax bracket.  Taxable Fund Assets Drop **********Among the tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million that are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the General California Municipal money market fund, distributed by the Dreyfus Service Corporation of Garden City, L.I., had the best return for the week at 5.32 percent. **********The assets of taxable money market funds declined $4.5 billion, to a total of $456.9 billion, with the assets of consumer funds down by $2.9 billion, to $342.8 billion. The assets of institutional funds fell by $1.6 billion, to $114.1 billion. **********The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell six basis points, to 5.90 percent, while the 30-day yield fell seven basis points, to 6 percent. **********For the fourth consecutive week ended yesterday, the taxable fund with the best return on investment was the Olde Premium Money Market Series with a yield of 6.84 percent. The distributor is the Olde Discount Corporation of Detroit. **********By comparison, the average yield on money market accounts at banks, which compete with money market funds, fell one basis point, to 5.43 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/03/busin.main_headline: U.S. and Panama Agree On Access to Bank Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/03/busin.print_headline: U.S. and Panama Agree On Access to Bank Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/03/busin.body_text: **********United States and Panamanian negotiators have reached an accord that will open bank records in Panama for American criminal investigators to develop evidence on money laundering and drug crimes, Administration officials said today. **********The officials said the agreement, reached on Saturday in Panama City, appeared to end a bitter dispute that moved Congress to freeze $84 million in economic assistance to Panama since early last year. **********They expressed satisfaction that the treaty, the Mutual Legal Assistance Agreement, would help Federal and state efforts prosecute those involved in a broad range of crimes. 'An Excellent Arrangement' **********"Finally, the United States will realize we want to cooperate," said a senior Panamanian official who spoke on condition of anonymity. **********Still, American officials cautioned that the accord was not a panacea that would completely cleanse Panama's banks or eliminate illicit drug trading involving Panama. One official said the agreement would "be useful, though not decisive" in the war on South American cocaine traffickers. The treaty requires the approval of the Senate and the Panamanian National Assembly. **********Some American law enforcement officials have said that opening a window into bank accounts may provide only limited assistance in tracking down money launderers, because Panama's corporation laws act as a virtually impenetrable shield that prevents the identification of the true owners and managers of companies. **********Money laundering is a process by which illegally earned money is deposited in bank accounts or in other legitimate businesses, and is then withdrawn as "clean money." A 1989 Senate report listed Panama as one of the six nations most widely used to launder illegal profits. **********Negotiations on the agreement began almost immediately after the invasion of Panama by United States forces in December 1989 and the replacement of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's military dictatorship with President Guillermo Endara's civilian Government. A preliminary draft was initialed in August, but Mr. Endara rescinded his support for the accord under intense pressure from Panamanian bankers. **********Executives of Panama's 120 banks then argued that the treaty would neutralize the benefits of secrecy laws that give them a competitive advantage over other regional banking centers like the Cayman Islands and the Bahamas. Panamanian banks contain deposits of more than $15 billion and play a pervasive role in Panamanian society, forming the glassy skyline of Panama City and employing 10,000 workers. **********United States and Panamanian officials noted that several influential bankers had reversed their position on the accord in recent weeks and had encouraged Mr. Endara's negotiators to sign a draft almost identical to the August version. **********The final details were worked out when the chief United States negotiator, Michael Kozak, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, made a visit to Panama City last week. **********Senior Panamanian officials have said that they expect a formal signing of the treaty by April 11.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/20/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Trade Group Gets New Head
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/20/busin.body_text: **********Anyone familiar with Alex Kroll's exploits as a college and pro football star would not be surprised to learn that he will have a "blocking and tackling" agenda during his term as chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies. **********Mr. Kroll, the chairman and chief executive of Young & Rubicam Inc., became the chairman today as the 73d annual meeting of the organization ended. He succeeds Keith Reinhard, chairman and chief executive of DDB Needham Worldwide, New York. **********On the blocking front, Mr. Kroll, who played for Rutgers and the New York Titans, said in an interview that he would lead the association's continuing efforts to fight state and Federal attempts to impose taxes or additional regulations on advertising. **********On the tackling front, Mr. Kroll elaborated on his proposals to reform political advertising, first disclosed by Advertising Age last month. So that "we can begin to drive a lot of this sludge out of the system," Mr. Kroll said he would recommend a voluntary code of fair advertising for candidates and exploration of ways to offer free time on public television for political messages.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/30/busin.main_headline: JMB Real Estate Venture Is Battered in London
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/30/busin.print_headline: JMB Real Estate Venture Is Battered in London
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/30/busin.body_text: **********A closely watched $425 million European real estate venture involving the JMB Realty Corporation and several big American pension funds has been battered by falling property values in London and for a second time in less than a year is hard pressed for cash. **********Randsworth Trust P.L.C., which JMB bought in 1989 with the pension funds' help, stumbled last year because of Britain's high interest rates and falling property values. Last June, JMB told about 15 of the funds that Randsworth was paying out too much on its floating-rate debt and that the partnership would need some fresh capital. JMB got some of the money, but it has not proved enough. Another Infusion Needed **********JMB is once again asking some of the funds to help recapitalize the investment because although British rates have fallen, appraised property values have been falling faster. The Randsworth portfolio was bought at a high point in the London market, and the idea was to sell a few big properties to pay down the debt used for the purchase and provide working capital. But property values started to slide, and the partners decided not to sell into a falling market, which meant that the tens of millions of dollars needed would have to come from somewhere else. **********"I am not suggesting that there has not been a further diminution of values based on current appraisals," said Neil G. Bluhm, JMB's president, who said that because so few transactions were being completed in London there was a growing spread between bids and asking prices. The appraisers, he said, are using the low bid prices. **********Two years ago the Randsworth deal was heralded as a big entry of American pension funds into Europe's real estate markets, and the venture has been watched carefully since. In 1989, and to a lesser extent last year, American institutional investors and developers were scrambling to invest in European property because returns outpaced those in this country. But because of high interest rates and slowing economies some of those investments have stumbled. **********Several real estate executives noted that Randsworth's poor performance to date would make pension funds less willing to put money in European property ventures. Apparently, the funds' investment managers are displeased that the portfolio's value has dropped dramatically so soon after the investment was made. **********With more than $22 billion worth of property under management for its own account and for institutional clients, JMB is one of the nation's largest privately held real estate concerns, and has one of the strongest followings among institutional investors. Portfolio Is Downgraded **********Randsworth's portfolio of about 650,000 square feet of office space and 300,000 of retail was appraised and downgraded about 11 percent by the end of last year. Although most of the properties are in west London, which has not been hurt as badly as the City district, and have low vacancies, the downgraded when appraised again this year. Land P.L.C., a Brithsh property company with big West End holdings, recently had to downgrade the value of its portfolio by 17 percent just since last year. **********Algemeen Burgerlijk Pensioenfonds, known as ABP, a big Dutch pension fund and invester in Randsworth, is one institution expected to provide more moneyfor the company. But Mr. Bluhm said the Dutch giant and JMB were studying the Randsworth portfolio to determine just how much would be needed. **********"ABP has certainly expressed an interest in putting additional capital in the company but they haven't said they would do it because we are in the middle of studying it," Mr. Bluhm said, adding that all investors would get the chance to put in more money on a pro-rated basis. **********Some real estate executives suggest that much of the investors' equity in the Randsworth venture had been wiped out, but Mr. Bluhm said that no one knew how much equity was left because a full assessment had not yet been completed. Still, it is clear that the equity has been significantly diluted, if not wiped out. Whether that will change depends on future property values. Half Equity, Half Debt **********The original investments in the deal were half equity and half debt, with the investors providing about $:95 million ($166 million at today's exchange rate) of equity and the same amount of debt to finance the acquisition. **********A $:185 million Citibank loan helped finance the acquisition and that loan requires more cash than the properties are generating. The properties yield only about 6 percent. London rates are down from about 14 percent to 12 percent. So either the partners chip in more or properties must be sold to service Randsworth's debt. **********Randsworth would have trouble raising other kinds of financing because capitalization rates have gone up. The portfolio already carries about $:320 million of debt, with $:135 million of that at fixed rates. **********Last June, JMB Acquisition Partners, the limited partnership that holds about 16 percent of Randsworth, called on its institutional partners to ante up $34 million that they had earlier agreed to provide. But JMB also sought an additional $100 million form the partners. **********Some of the pension funds balked at putting more money in last year, but JMB was still able to raise about $:57 million in the fall.
