https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/world.main_headline: G.I.'s Scout a Kurdish City Beyond the Allied Zone; Iraqi Police Cause Unease
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; G.I.'s Scout a Kurdish City Beyond the Allied Zone; Iraqi Police Cause Unease
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/world.body_text: **********The continued presence of the Iraqi secret police in a key Kurdish area of Iraq has dissuaded refugees from returning to their homes, a senior Pentagon official said today. **********The official, Lieut. Gen. Martin Brandtner, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, acknowledged before a Senate subcommittee that the allied forces stationed in northern Iraq have had difficulty in controlling the Iraqi security police in the city of Zakho, which is within the allied security zone. **********In Zakho there are reports that we receive on a daily basis that there have been security forces identified by the Kurdish residents," General Brandtner told the Senate Subcommittee on Immigration and Refugee Affairs. "As these persons are pointed out, they are removed from the vicinity." **********But when Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat and chairman of the subcommittee, remarked that the secret police then return to question and harass the population, General Brandtner agreed, saying: "Well, it's difficult to control them, yes sir. And there is no question that there is indeed both a perception and the reality of the secret service presence there." **********The general's remarks highlighted the difficulty that the allied forces have had in assuring the Kurds that they will not be threatened by the Government of President Saddam Hussein after they return home. General Brandtner said he could not give a timetable for the departure of the more than 10,000 allied troops from Iraq, who are ultimately to be replaced by about 500 lightly armed United Nations guards. **********To drive home the point that the United Nations guards will not replace the Iraqi authorities in protecting the Kurds, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, Iraq's chief representative at the United Nations, said today that the guards would be a symbolic presence. **********"I believe it is going to be a symbolic presence rather than actual international guards or international force," he told reporters after a brief meeting of the Security Council.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/08/busin.body_text: **********The McDonnell Douglas Corporation plans to shift 1,600 jobs to Missouri from California to work on military and commerical jet parts, The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported today. **********The Post-Dispatch said the aerospace company would assign more work for the McDonnell C-17 Air Force cargo jet and the MD-11 and MD-80 commercial airliners to St. Louis from Long Beach, Calif. **********About 710 of the 23,000 McDonnell workers in St. Louis already work on parts for the planes. **********The newspaper said the shift would be announced on Monday, citing an unidentified source. Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri has scheduled a news conference at the McDonnell Douglas plant on Monday. **********McDonnell Douglas will receive about $14 million worth of low-interest loans and job retraining funds from the State of Missouri to relocate the jobs, the newspaper said. **********The work transferred from the Douglas Aircraft division in Long Beach will partly offset the loss of almost 10,000 McDonnell jobs in the St. Louis area in recent months because of company and Pentagon budget cuts. **********McDonnell Douglas officials could not be reached for comment today, and calls to a spokesman for Governor Ashcroft were unanswered.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.main_headline: Latest on the Assembly Line: Prison Cells
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; Latest on the Assembly Line: Prison Cells
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.body_text: **********Taking its cue from Detroit, a company in New Jersey is using a computerized assembly line to mass produce low-cost steel jail cells. These can be added to existing prisons, placed into gutted buildings to turn them into prisons or bolted together in a prison courtyard. **********The company, Mark Correctional Systems of Maywood, says its modular cells cost on average $12,000 each -- about half the price of cells in traditional concrete prisons. Each weighs 6,000 pounds, compared with 32,000 pounds for a standard prison cell, said Michael J. Rosenberg, a vice president at the company. **********The price depends on the plumbing, fixtures, doors, windows, bunks, desks, wiring and size that the buyers choose. Most cells are 70 to 80 square feet. At the company's factory, a computer monitors each order on an assembly line, making it easier to install and keep track of the many options. **********"The breakthrough," Mr. Rosenberg said, "is the computerization that has allowed us to build these cells with such efficiency that nothing is left to be done at the job site." The company's earlier modular cells cost more and took substantially longer to produce. **********The newest cells, which meet specifications set by the American Correctional Association, are lifted into place by cranes. The prison needs only to connect the plumbing and electricity. **********Mr. Rosenberg said it would take three or four months to turn an empty building into a prison by installing the prefabricated cells. **********Mark began selling the cells this month. An earlier, more expensive model was sold to prisons in New Jersey, Michigan, Missouri and Idaho, he said. **********Hardy Rauch, an officer at the American Correctional Association, said many states began buying modular cells as their prison populations rapidly expanded. "There has been a consistent search for some type of modular system that can be thrown up as cheaply as possible," he said. "They seem to be working very, very well, particularly for short-term incarceration and for minimum security." **********Although some prison officials might prefer maximum security cells with concrete walls eight inches thick to modular cells with steel walls two inches thick, Mr. Rosenberg said his cells met all the association's standards for maximum security.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/busin.main_headline: The Executive Life; Competitive Croquet? You Better Believe It
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/busin.print_headline: The Executive Life; Competitive Croquet? You Better Believe It
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Twilight settled over the manicured greensward in Central Park that serves as headquarters for the New York Croquet Club. Dressed in fresh-pressed whites -- polo shirt, Bermuda shorts, socks and sneakers -- Mike Gibbons concentrated hard on his last shot. "Yellow's dead on red and blue's dead on black," explained Mr. Gibbons, who is an executive vice president of Estee Lauder, the New York-based cosmetics giant.  "I'm going for a rush." **********Click. A tap of his mallet sent the red ball rolling. Click. It hit the blue ball, sending blue through the final wicket. He raised his mallet in victory. "This game is all about summing up a situation and making a quick decision," said Mr. Gibbons, a nationally ranked croquet player. "That's why executives are good at it. We're always strategizing." **********Competitive croquet is a darling of the business set. The United States Croquet Association says there are 350 croquet clubs in 48 states today, up from just five in 1977. In a recent survey, it found that 88 percent of its 5,000 or so members identified themselves as businesspeople. "Croquet has been likened to warfare on the corporate battlefield," said Jack Osborn, founder and president of the Palm Beach-based U.S.C.A. "That's why it attracts so many executive types." **********Warfare? In a Great Gatsby-style game that's played while sipping champagne and nibbling caviar? Where sweat is caused solely by the sun? "In golf, you play against the course," said Mr. Osborn. "In croquet, you try to destroy your opponent." Hence, for executives, the game's charm: a sadistic streak belies its genteel veneer. "Croquet mimics office politics," said Tim Quinlan, an executive at Tesco, a Long Island-based direct marketing company. "You can really screw someone over if you want to." **********Serious enthusiasts are quick to contrast competitive croquet and backyard croquet.  It's like comparing the Yankees to a Little League team. Competitive croquet, either a singles or doubles match, is properly played on one-quarter-inch bentgrass with a time clock allowing 45 seconds per shot. The object seems simple: to get two different-colored balls through the six-wicket course before the other side does. But the rules -- and tactics -- are highly complex, requiring the concentration of chess and the coordination of billiards. "It helps if you're good at problem-solving," said Mr. Quinlan. "Then you can learn pretty fast." **********For example, Will Hiltz, an executive vice president in Smith Barney's corporate finance department, learned to play in 1980.  The next year, he made it to the United States championships -- where he came close to beating the defending champion. "I don't think there are many other sports where I could be nationally ranked after playing for a year," he said. "I could play golf my whole life and I'd never make it to Augusta." **********Having a national ranking makes ribbing easier to take. "I get a lot of grief from my friends about playing croquet," said Bill Duncan, chairman of the First American Bank of New York. "But there's definitely a bit of agressiveness to it. You have to know when to advance and when to retreat. You have to map out a plan." **********Since mental agility is valued over muscular prowess, gender makes little difference.  "I beat men all the time," said Jean Arrington, secretary of the U.S.C.A. In fact, croquet was the first game that allowed women in Victorian England to compete directly with men. It's the quintessential "level playing field" -- which helps account for its growing popularity among convention planners. **********When Levi Strauss and Transamerica, both based in San Francisco, held management meetings last fall at the Meadowood Resort in St. Helena, Calif., croquet was on the agenda. The Breakers hotel in Palm Beach conducts clinics for beginners on business trips. "It's not like golf, where it takes up the whole afternoon," says Gretchen Deweese, publicity director for the Breakers.  "You can play a game in an hour or two, and get back to work." **********Like golf, however, croquet can be addictive. Robert Clayton, retired chief executive officer of the New York securities firm of Laidlaw Adams & Peck, became so enthralled that he installed a state-of-the-art court at his Long Island beach house. Several of his cronies -- including Charles Lazarus, C.E.O. of New Jersey-based Toys 'R' Us -- followed suit. "Maintaining a court is a big commitment," said Mr. Clayton. "You have to water it every day and mow it several times a week." The U.S.C.A. estimates that it costs about $4,000 a year to care for a standard 105-by-84-foot court. A set of top-quality equipment can run $3,500. **********While croquet has long been associated with the rich and powerful, advertisers like Rolex and BMW have only lately discovered its allure. One selling point: a 1987 U.S.C.A. study that found members had an average income of $125,000 and that 25 percent were millionaires. "The demographics of the sport are extremely upscale," said Mr. Gibbons. **********But even croquet can't escape the lingering recession. Two major sponsors -- menswear manufacturer Gieves & Hawkes and retailer Abercrombie & Fitch -- have abandoned plans to host upcoming U.S.C.A. tournaments. "They've suspended promotions for this summer due to the downturn in their industry," said Mr. Osborn. "When the economy picks up, they'll be back." **********By then, with more public courts available and popularity on the rise, the game may have a more egalitarian following. "I think it's losing the elitist image," said Ms. Arrington of the U.S.C.A. "Some of our younger players are construction workers and machinists. They don't all drive around in Jaguars."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/04/busin.body_text: **********James Garrity Jr., the chief of the tax unit in the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan, has been named a judge to fill a vacancy in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York. The seven judges of the court, based in Manhattan, handle some of the most complex corporate bankruptcy cases. **********The choice was announced on Monday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, which said the appointment would take effect as soon as the Federal Bureau of Investigation completed a routine background check on Mr. Garrity, who is 36 years old. **********The judgeship, which requires 10 years of legal experience, pays $115,000 a year and is for a 14-year term. **********Mr. Garrity, a graduate of Holy Cross College in Worcester, Mass., received his law degree from St. John's University in 1980. He then worked for the New York City law firm of Anderson, Kill, Olick & Oshinsky. **********In January 1986, he received a master's degree in taxation from New York University and in the fall joined the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan. He became head of its tax unit in 1988, and has worked on or supervised more than 1,500 bankruptcy cases. **********Mr. Garrity, who declined to comment on his appointment, will fill the vacancy caused by the resignation on Jan. 11 of Judge Howard C. Buschman 3d, who had overseen the bankruptcy of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/23/world.main_headline: U.S. Aides Hold Talks With Premier of Russia
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/23/world.print_headline: U.S. Aides Hold Talks With Premier of Russia
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/23/world.body_text: **********Displaying their readiness to expand ties with reformist leaders of the Soviet republics, senior Administration officials met today with the Prime Minister of Russia, Ivan S. Silayev, to discuss how to improve the investment climate there for American business. **********The officials emphasized that their meetings with Mr. Silayev, an ally of Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian republic's leader, was not intended as a slap at President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********American officials last year cautiously began to meet with leaders of the Russian republic, who have demanded increasing autonomy from the Kremlin. These meetings have become more open and frequent. **********Today, after meeting at the White House with the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Silayev said: "We feel the readiness of the American Administration to conduct a relationship with the Soviet republics. We had very interesting meetings." **********The session coincided with a growing Administration realization that Mr. Gorbachev faces severe political troubles and that Washington must therefore widen its relations with Soviet leaders. **********Former President Richard M. Nixon, though an admirer of Mr. Gorbachev, is believed to have driven home the same point at a lunch today with President Bush and other officials, during which he briefed them on his recent trip to the Soviet Union.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/04/busin.main_headline: Plan to Limit Deposit Insurance Is Defended
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/04/busin.print_headline: Plan to Limit Deposit Insurance Is Defended
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/04/busin.body_text: **********The Treasury Department's plan to curtail deposit insurance at the nation's banks was described yesterday by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady as an attempt "to make the system safe for savers, but yet to make sure the taxpayer does not have to pay enormous bills when banks fail." **********The Treasury proposal, details of which were disclosed on Saturday, will be formally announced on Tuesday. It would limit the number of federally insured accounts that one person could have at a single institution. Under the proposal, each person would be limited to one $100,000 account at a single institution, as well as one $100,000 retirement account. **********"Don't worry," Mr. Brady said in an interview on the ABC television program "Business World." "Savers are going to be presented with plenty of opportunity to put their money in places that they consider absolutely safe."  Response to Criticism **********After a series of meetings, and after hearing strong criticism recently from many bankers on a plan for sharper restrictions, senior officials at the White House and the Treasury Department agreed on Saturday about how to limit the coverage. **********People could still have multiple accounts of $100,000 at different institutions, each covered by the Government's deposit insurance. **********The plan needs the approval of Congress. **********The Treasury is also contemplating a second, more stringent part of the plan. It would call for a $100,000 insurance limit on each individual regardless of how many different banks the money is kept in. **********The Treasury proposed that such a systemwide limit be phased in after five years, after a study on the costs of adminstering such a program is conducted by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. 'A Good Approach' **********"This seems to be a good approach," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, a member of the House Banking Committee. "Insured deposits have to be limited in one way or another." Telephone calls to members of the Senate Banking Committee last night were not answered. **********If it is approved by Congress, the Treasury's proposed limit on accounts at a single institution would be phased in over a year, Bush Administration officials say. The curb is intended to encourage large depositors to open accounts at different banks. **********The Treasury plan will also eliminate the insurance protection provided to pension funds and other institutional investors that are able to get insurance for their huge deposits by breaking them into accounts of $100,000 or less. **********The proposed limitations on deposit insurance come at a difficult time for the nation's banks. The deposit insurance fund administered by the F.D.I.C. and financed through premiums paid by banks has been drained by numerous bank failures, a process likely to continue during the recession. Skepticism From Bankers **********Some bankers contacted yesterday were skeptical of the impact of the proposed changes. **********Richard H. Deihl, chairman and chief executive of H. F. Ahmanson & Company, a savings and loan association in Irwindale, Calif., said the limits on institutional depositors were more significant than the curbs on individuals' deposit insurance. He called the proposed changes in the deposit insurance "window dressing," adding, "They are attacking the wrong enemy." **********Richard D. Parsons, chairman of the Dime Savings Bank of New York, said the limits on individuals' insurance would be a difficult administrative task. **********"This thing they are talking about creating is a nightmare," he said. "I am not sure that it is going to be practical at an operational level." Cost-Benefit Analysis **********Regulators concluded last week that a systemwide limit of $100,000 an individual might cost as much as $1 billion to enforce. **********"We wanted to make sure that the benefits offset the costs," said an Administration official who spoke on the condition that he would not be identified. **********The official said there was very poor data on the impact of the proposed restriction or more severe limitations. **********"It has been very, very difficult to determine how much can be saved by limiting the coverage," he said. **********The official added that less than 6 percent of the nation's households have more than $100,000 in the nation's insured banks, savings associations and credit unions.  Diversification Encouraged **********In its plan, the Administration will also propose the elimination of laws going back to the Great Depression that prohibit the mergers of investment banks and commercial banks and also sharply limit interstate banking. It will propose the repeal of a law that bars industrial enterprises from owning commercial banks. **********Administration officials say these changes will permit banks to diversify and become more profitable, and thus fewer will have to rely on assistance from the bank insurance fund. They also hope that such measures will make banks more attractive to investors. **********The plan also substantially modifies the current policy of rescuing all depositors, no matter how large, at banks that officials consider too big to fail, by placing the decision primarily in the hands of the Treasury department and the Federal Reserve Board, instead of the F.D.I.C. **********The too-big-to-fail policy, which has been strongly criticized by lawmakers who say it is unevenly applied, was most recently invoked last month with the failure of the Bank of New England and two affiliated banks. The F.D.I.C. has estimated that those three failures will ultimately cost the bank insurance fund at least $2.3 billion, which would make it one of the most expensive bailouts in history.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/27/busin.main_headline: 7 Oscars for 'Wolves' Lift a Troubled Studio
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/27/busin.print_headline: 7 Oscars for 'Wolves' Lift a Troubled Studio
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/27/busin.body_text: **********The seven Oscars won by "Dances With Wolves" Monday night at the Academy Awards ceremonies, including Best Picture, will undoubtedly give a lift to the faltering Orion Pictures Corporation. **********The awards will draw bigger crowds for the movie, which stars and was directed by Kevin Costner, even though it has been in theaters for four months. But the awards will also increase the film's value in other markets, including the eventual videocassette release. And they vindicate Orion's decision to distribute a 3-hour-10-minute Western that the conventional wisdom in Hollywood held would be a flop. **********"What it will do for us is to give us enough impetus to keep the film in the marketplace a little longer," said David Forbes, Orion's head of marketing and distribution. **********What the awards will not do is clear the financial clouds that have been hovering over Orion in recent months, threatening the company's ability to survive. As Billy Crystal joked during the Oscar broadcast, "Awakenings" is a film about people coming out of coma; "Reversal of Fortune" is about someone going into a coma, and "Dances With Wolves" was made by a studio in a coma. **********Orion, in fact, has reached a critical point in its 13-year history. Despite the success of "Dances With Wolves" and, more recently, "The Silence of the Lambs," starring Jodie Foster and Anthony Hopkins, Orion is reeling from a string of flops ("Hot Spot," "State of Grace," "Eve of Destruction") and from the expenses of trying to break into the television production business. **********In its third fiscal quarter, which ended last Nov. 30, Orion lost $15.6 million on revenues of $134.9 million, in contrast to a $1.8 million profit on revenues of $104.4 million a year earlier. Orion has not released its results for its fourth quarter, which ended on Feb. 28. **********"They can probably find a way to survive," said Emanual Gerard, an analyst at Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company in New York. "Whether they can prosper is another question." **********Even a few hit films will not be enough to pull Orion out of trouble. The company's long-term debt has increased to $509 million from $351 million in the last year, leaving Orion burdened with huge interest payments. Desperate for cash, it has started selling movie projects and distribution rights to other studios at what analysts consider distress-sale prices, keeping the company solvent but leaving it with few sources of new revenue in coming months and years. **********Earlier this month, for example, Orion sold one of its most promising projects, "The Addams Family," based on the Charles Addams cartoons and the 1960's-era television show, to Paramount Pictures for about $20 million. Paramount is planning to make the movie, which stars Anjelica Huston as Morticia and Raul Julia as Gomez, one its major releases for the next Christmas season.  Investor Is Sought **********The company has been casting around for an investor to inject new funds into the company, and Orion's majority owner, John W. Kluge, has put his 68 percent stake in the company up for sale. The company hired Salomon Brothers last year to help it find new financing. Orion might also get some help from Michael Ovitz, the chairman of the Creative Artists Agency and Hollywood's leading deal maker. Mr. Ovitz is said to be considering seeking new investors on the company's behalf. **********But so far no one has expressed much interest in buying all or part of the company. The Sony Corporation has denied reports that it is interested in a deal, although there is considerable speculation that Castle Rock Entertainment, a production company partly owned by Sony's Columbia Pictures Entertainment unit, might strike a deal to take over Orion. Orion's stock closed on the New York Stock Exchange today at $10.375, down 87.5 cents, giving the company a market value of about $200 million. **********Orion is one of two Hollywood studios struggling to survive. The other is MGM-Pathe Communications, formed last year when Giancarlo Parretti, an Italian investor, acquired the MGM-UA film studio. Mr. Parretti is scrambling to line up additional financing to advertise and distribute the studio's movies and to pay the interest on its nearly $1 billion in bank debt and high-yield "junk bonds." **********But while MGM has been fading as a movie-making force for years, Orion even now enjoys a reputation in Hollywood's creative community as a good place for actors, directors and producers to work. Its chairman, Arthur B. Krim, and its chief executive, Eric Pleskow, have forged long-term deals with Woody Allen, Ms. Foster and Mr. Costner, among others. **********"There are many good people in the studio, but things have not gone well for them," Mr. Costner said Monday night after receiving the Best Picture and Best Director awards for "Dances With Wolves." **********The seven Oscars won by his film, Mr. Costner said, give Orion executives a chance "to hold their heads up and walk a step faster." **********Mr. Forbes, Orion's marketing and distribution chief, said, "Historically over the past four or five years a picture does more business after it wins a Best Picture award in particular." He estimated that the seven awards won by the film could add 20 percent to its domestic box office revenue, currently at $136.7 million. That means it will soon surpass "Platoon," which grossed $138.5 million and won the Best Picture award in 1986, as the studio's most successful film. **********But it is debatable how much of the film's success should be attributed to Orion. When Mr. Costner first proposed the film, Orion passed on it, feeling that its commercial prospects were too limited. Mr. Costner and a partner, Jim Wilson, produced the film on their own, with only partial financial support from Orion. The studio's primary involvement has been to advertise the film and distribute it to theaters, a service for which it charges an undisclosed percentage of the film's box office revenues. The studio also shares in an undisclosed percentage of the film's profits. **********The Oscar awards will probably give "Dances With Wolves" its biggest box office boost in foreign markets, where it has not been showing as long as in the United States. But Orion decided not to acquire the foreign rights to the movie when it made its investment in the film, so it will not benefit. The foreign rights are owned by Majestic Films International, a distribution company. **********The limits on Orion's ability to dig itself out of its hole are also illustrated by deals it made on two other recent films, "Silence of the Lambs" and "Mermaids," starring Cher. **********Needing cash last year, Orion received an infusion of $23 million from Mr. Kluge, who is chairman of Metromedia Inc. Orion agreed to repay Mr. Kluge with profits from "Mermaids," which was moderately successful, taking in $34.7 million at the domestic box office. In the event Mr. Kluge is not fully repaid from the profits on "Mermaids," he will get a cut of the profits from "Silence of the Lambs," which so far has grossed $78.7 million in the United States. **********Still, in the afterglow of the Academy Awards, and despite the coma joke, Orion executives seem confident that they are on the path to recovery. **********" 'Dances With Wolves,' 'Silence of the Lambs' and even 'Mermaids' are an indication that we have the ability to produce, market and distribute commercial successes," Mr. Forbes said. "The fact that these films have gotten great critical acclaim is an indication that there is quality and prestige in what we do here.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/14/busin.main_headline: Newspapers Raising Prices as Advertising Falls
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/14/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Newspapers Raising Prices as Advertising Falls
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/14/busin.body_text: **********Across the country, newspaper prices have been increasing in a trend that has not been seen since the early 1980's, when prices jumped to their current levels. **********While nearly 90 percent of the nation's newspapers now sell on newsstands or in racks for 25 cents or 35 cents apiece, several industry executives said they expect most papers to sell for at least 35 cents or even 50 cents within two years. **********Similarly, although about 62 percent of the nation's Sunday papers now sell for less than $1, some executive predict that most Sunday papers will soon cost $1, $1.25 or even $1.50. **********Yesterday, The Los Angeles Times raised the price of its Sunday paper to $1.25, up from $1, which had been the price since 1983. **********A week ago, 11 newspapers owned by the Gannett Company raised the price of their Sunday issues to $1.50. Moves by Three Dailies **********In the last three months, The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, The Kansas City Star and The Belleville News-Democrat in Illinois -- all owned by Capital Cities/ABC Inc. -- increased the single-copy price of their daily papers to 50 cents. Both the Fort Worth and Belleville papers had been sold for 25 cents and The Kansas City Star had cost 35 cents. **********In early December, The Wall Street Journal raised its price to 75 cents from 50 cents. **********Today, The New York Times raised the price of its national edition to 75 cents in the Midwest and the Southwest. It had cost 50 cents in the Midwest and 60 cents in the Southwest. As a test, The Times has been selling for 75 cents in the Southeast since September, but remains at 50 cents in the Far West and Northeast, and 40 cents in the New York City area. **********Industry executives said circulation rates were rising because of the depressed advertising market and increased publishing costs. For example, the price of newsprint has gone up twice in the last seven months. **********"The newspaper is still one of the best deals in town," said Jeffrey S. Klein, assistant to the publisher of The Los Angeles Times. **********But in an industry that perceives increasing readership as a key to its future, there has been considerable reluctance to charge more for a newspaper because sales almost always drop, at least temporarily. Ads vs. Circulation **********Publishers must weigh the appeal of higher revenues against the effects of lost circulation on advertisers. At the very least, newspapers that raise their prices must struggle to regain their former circulation. **********Through most of the 1980's, both the total amount of advertising and the ad rates -- which generate about 75 percent of the revenue at most papers -- were increasing steadily and there was less pressure to raise prices. **********In recent months, however, many newspapers have seen stunning drops in advertising because of the recession. Historically, when advertising revenue flags, publishers demand more money from circulation. **********"People are likely to be more emboldened when they haven't got anyplace else to go," said Phillip J. Meek, president of the publishing group for Capital Cities/ABC. The Payoff in Fort Worth **********The financial returns can be substantial, even if fewer copies are sold. **********For instance, Weldon Whiteman, circulation director of The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, said his paper lost 24 percent of its single-copy sales after it doubled its price to 50 cents in November. About 25,000 copies, out of a daily circulation of 259,000, are sold in racks and at newstands. **********But while The Star-Telegram received 16 cents a copy from wholesalers when the price was 25 cents, it now gets 32 cents a copy. Even with a 24 percent drop in the number of papers sold, annual revenues from single-copy sales would increase by about $650,000, to nearly $2 million. **********When the single-copy price was increased, The Star-Telegram also raised the price of home-delivery subscriptions to $10.95 a month from $9.95. Mr. Whiteman said the paper's home-delivery circulation of roughly 230,000 dropped by only 1,000. Though some subscribers canceled, the single-copy price increase had apparently pushed some other people to subscribe rather than pay more to buy the paper each day. Earlier Price Increases **********In the early 1980's, the last time that newspaper prices surged industrywide, most papers moved from 15 cents or 20 cents a copy to 25 cents and some crept up later to 35 cents. The most popular price for Sunday papers in 1980 was 50 cents or less; by 1985, almost half of them were selling for 75 cents or $1. **********Similarly, in the mid-1970's,, most papers increased to 15 cents from 10 cents and Sunday papers to 50 cents from 25 cents. **********In each case, the newspaper industry was in an advertising slump.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/13/world.main_headline: Reporter's Notebook; Mindful of History, Congress Agonizes Over Going to War
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/13/world.print_headline: Reporter's Notebook; Mindful of History, Congress Agonizes Over Going to War
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/13/world.body_text: **********These have not been glory years for Congress. Ethical storms, budget squabbling and the chronic appearance of political deadlock have all left their mark on the image of this proud institution. **********But over the last few days, as the House and Senate debated whether to authorize the President to go to war in the Persian Gulf, the lawmakers have struggled to step up to what the framers of the Constitution had in mind. **********One by one, congressmen and senators took the floor and reached for the legacy of history, for Kennedy and Roosevelt and Churchill. They spoke, too, of their children, and the children of their constituents, and of past wars and the lessons they taught. Throughout the debate was the wrenching, sobering consciousness of their own responsibility. **********The lights burned late on Capitol Hill. The Senate did not adjourn until 2:39 A.M. Saturday, and returned by 8 A.M.; the House was in session until 4:08 A.M. "In 26 years in the House of Representatives, I have never seen this House more serious nor more of Representatives, its heart and mind on a question than they are at this time, on this day," said Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House. **********Both the press and the public galleries were full, and the lines stretched round the halls. Aides in the Senate said they could not recall the galleries so full since the debate over the Panama Canal Treaties in 1978. Sue Sexton, a 24-year-old teacher in Washington was among those waiting to enter the galleries. "The last war was when I was six years old," she said. "This is the first time I've ever experienced a crisis like this and it's very frightening." **********Nearby was Bob Scalese, visiting from Montana, who said simply, "I think we've got to go to Iraq and kick some butt." **********In Congressional offices, the phones kept ringing: more than 3,000 calls to Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole's office on Friday, more than 100 calls to Representative Les Aspin's office this morning alone. **********The floor of the House and Senate is often virtually deserted when debate is waged on one piece of legislation or another. Not so today. The senators sat in their seats, quiet and subdued, as their colleagues concluded debate over the Persian Gulf resolutions. **********At 11:35, when the voting began, Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia and proud guardian of the Senate's tradition and prerogatives, rose to ask that the clerk repeat each senator's name and vote so "that their responses may be clearly audible." But the members and senators already knew there was no hiding, no ducking this moment. **********The Speaker of the House rarely votes, but Mr. Foley broke with that custom today to take the floor in support of a resolution urging continued reliance on sanctions. "I would not feel it right to stand behind the usual custom -- not to speak and not to vote," the Democrat from Washington said, his craggy face reflecting the grim nature of the moment. **********Earlier, he had delivered an impassioned defense of Congress's right to debate the President's policy without being open to the charge of giving comfort to Saddam Hussein. It would be tragic, the Speaker said, if Saddam Hussein were given the capacity "to cripple our own Constitutional institutions." The Prism of War **********The burden of history was heavy in these halls, not just in what was said but in the lives of many of the men who were waging this debate. In the Senate, for example, a visitor could look across the floor this morning and see Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who lost a leg in Vietnam; Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, who suffered grievous injuries in World War II; Senator John McCain of Arizona, who spent five years as a prisoner of war in Vietnam, and Senator Daniel Inouye, who lost his arm in Italy in World War II. **********Many of the lawmakers brought the prism of their own war, the war that they experienced, in service or outside it, to this debate. "I guess younger members are tired of hearing World War II types always using the prelude to that war as a model for foreign policy," Representative Robert H. Michel, the Republican leader, told the House this afternoon. "For so many of you, your war was the Vietnam war. That war shaped your thinking, one way or the other. Different war, different lessons." **********But there was anguished debate over how these lessons applied to the Persian Gulf, and gnawing fear that the wrong lessons would be drawn. When the Debate Ended **********In the end, when the votes were over, the lawmakers somberly filed out. Senator Sam Nunn, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, who led the fight to give sanctions more time to work, said as he left the floor today, "If the President decides to go to war, I will be backing the military men and women in the field."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/19/world.main_headline: Text of a Letter From Bush: 'Deception and Concealment'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/19/world.print_headline: Text of a Letter From Bush: 'Deception and Concealment'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/19/world.body_text: **********Following is the text of a letter, dated Sept. 16, from President Bush to the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President Pro Tempore of the Senate: **********Dear Mr. Speaker: (Dear Mr. President:) **********Consistent with the Authorization for the Use of Military Force Against Iraq Resolution (Public Law 102-1), and as part of my continuing effort to keep the Congress fully informed, I am again reporting on the status of efforts to obtain compliance by Iraq with the resolutions adopted by the U.N. Security council. **********Since my last report, the International Atomic Energy Agency (I.A.E.A.) and the Special Commission created under Resolution 687 have continued to conduct inspections and other activities related to Iraqi weapons of mass destruction and ballistic missiles. With strong support from the United States, these bodies have been working actively under difficult conditions to identify, inspect and arrange for the elimination of these weapons and related items. As a result, Iraq has permitted some access to facilities related to these weapons, and inspectors have viewed the destruction of some ballistic missiles and chemical munitions, and catalogued large volumes of equipment related to Iraq's nuclear and other programs. **********Iraq continues, however, to misrepresent the scope of its programs in these areas, to use deception and concealment to prevent inspection teams from locating equipment subject to elimination under Resolution 687, and to deny inspection teams full and unrestricted access to facilities associated with weapons of mass destruction and ballistic missiles. This pattern of behavior, as well as other Iraqi violations of the requirements of Resolution 687, resulted in the adoption on August 15 of Resolution 707, which condemns Iraq for these actions and holds it in material breach of its obligations. **********In addition, the IAEA Board of Governors voted on July 18 to find Iraq in violation of its Safeguards Agreement and thus of the Non-Proliferation Treaty. Recently, Iraq has refused to permit the U.N. to base helicopters inside Iraq for these purposes, contrary to an explicit Security Council demand contained in Resolution 707. The United States will not tolerate the continuation of this situation, and if necessary will take action to ensure Iraqi compliance with the Council's decisions so as to fully implement Resolution 687's call for the restoration of international peace and security to the Persian Gulf region. Compensation Fund **********Significant progress has been made since my last report toward implementation of the resolution of the Security Council concerning compensation for the victims of the unlawful invasion and occupation of Kuwait. The first session of the Governing Council of the new U.N. Compensation Commission met from July 22-Aug. 2 in Geneva, and adopted criteria for the first category of claims to be considered by the Commission -- namely, claims of individuals for up to $100,000. **********The Executive Secretary of the Commission and his two deputies have been appointed, as well as a number of experts on the oil industry, banking and claims processing. The next session of the Governing Council will begin on Oct. 14, and will focus on the adoption of a mechanism for collection and monitoring of Iraqi oil export revenues, as well as criteria for other categories of claims. **********On Aug. 15, the U.N. Security Council adopted Resolution 705, which approved the earlier recommendation of the Secretary General that the ceiling on contributions to the Compensation Fund be set at 30 percent of Iraqi annual oil export revenues. **********On the same date, the Security Council adopted Resolution 706, which authorized sales of up to $1.6 billion of Iraqi oil, the proceeds of which would be paid to a U.N. escrow account and used as follows: (1) 30 percent would go to the Compensation Fund; (2) the U.N. would retain the amounts necessary for costs incurred by the Special Commission, the Boundary Commission, and other U.N. efforts pursuant to Resolution 687; and (3) the remainder would be used for the food, medicine and other items for essential civilian needs, which would be provided under strict U.N. supervision to insure their equitable distribution in Iraq. **********We are currently working with the Secretary General and other Security Council members to implement this resolution as soon as possible. **********As I stated in my previous reports, the United States remains concerned about the situation of the Kurds and other internal population groups that have been the object of repressive measures by the Government of Iraq. We have informed the Government of Iraq that we will continue to monitor carefully the treatment of its citizens, and that we remain prepared to take appropriate steps if the situation requires. To this end, an appropriate level of forces will be maintained in the region for as long as required by the situation in Iraq. **********I remain grateful for the support of Congress for these efforts, and I look forward to continued cooperation toward achieving our mutual objectives. **********Sincerely, **********GEORGE BUSH

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/01/world.body_text: **********"This film is my personal contribution to the Ukrainian independence referendum," said Oles Yanchuk, who worked for two years to produce his first feature film on a subject that was until recently erased from Soviet history. **********Called "Famine 33," the film chronicles Stalin's forced collectivization of agriculture and the famine it caused in 1933. More than seven million people in the central and eastern Ukraine died in the famine. **********Shown through the eyes of a young boy, the film made its debut on republic-wide television today, on the eve of a referendum in which Ukrainians are expected to vote overwhelmingly for independence from the Soviet Union. **********"I wanted people to see what life was like in a colony, the inhabitants of which were mercilessly exploited in the name of a utopian ideology," Mr. Yanchuk said. **********The Central Committee of the Ukrainian Communist Party only last year issued a resolution that officially admitted that the famine was caused by the seizure of crops. Previously, all accounts of the famine were either omitted from history books or referred to as a glorious triumph of Communism. Many Contributed Money **********The 35-year-old Mr. Yanchuk said people throughout the Ukraine had donated a little over 400,000 rubles to help finance the film. Witnesses' accounts of the famine were often enclosed with the contributions. **********The idea for the film originated when Mr. Yanchuk read a screenplay on the famine written by the Ukrainian playwright Serhy Diachenko. "As soon as I read the screenplay, I knew this was a film that had to be made," he recalled. **********Others who helped in the writing of the film were Vasyl Barka, a Ukrainian emigre writer whose book, "The Yellow Prince," has become the classic novel about the famine, and Les Taniuk, a former director of the Moscow Art Theater. **********James Mace, staff director of the United States Commission on the Ukraine Famine, was visiting the Ukraine when he heard about Mr. Yanchuk's plans to produce the film. He advised Mr. Yanchuk to go to the Harvard Ukrainian Research Institute to find material he was denied access to in his own country's archives. Eventually, Mr. Yanchuk was able to get into Ukrainian archives, but only after a long wait. **********Working on the film was an emotionally wrenching experience for Mr. Yanchuk and his crew. The film was shot in regions that had experienced the famine in the 1930's. Harrowing scenes from the film recreate the terror, fear and desperation of those years. **********Mr. Yanchuk acknowledged that the film's existence was evidence of how much the Ukraine has changed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Weapons; Pentagon Said to Authorize U.S. Use of Nonlethal Gas
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Weapons; Pentagon Said to Authorize U.S. Use of Nonlethal Gas
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/world.body_text: **********The Pentagon has authorized the United States commander in the Persian Gulf to use nonlethal riot-control gases in certain circumstances against Iraqi forces and prisoners of war, Administration officials said today. **********These officials said the Bush Administration's intense desire to limit American casualties in the conflict prompted senior officials to add the nonlethal gas weapon to the "tool box" of weapons that the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin L. Powell, said this week would be available to his field commander, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf. **********The Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, said in response to a question that the decision was driven by a desire to "save lives." **********"We think the commander should have the authority to use tear gas in search and rescue operations is the reason," Mr. Williams said. "This is not chemical warfare on the battlefield. It is basically tear gas." **********Mr. Williams added that the United States would use such gases "only in very specific instances. **********"Tear gas is intended to save lives," he said. "It's a way of avoiding having to shoot people." Some Experts Question Decision **********The decision was immediately questioned by some chemical-warfare experts who said that even the introduction of nonlethal gases could give President Saddam Hussein of Iraq a pretext to escalate in any retaliation by using the lethal chemical weapons that are already deployed with his elite forces. **********"I don't buy that at all," Mr. Williams said. "That's ridculous." **********Military officials and some members of the multinational military coalition who have been briefed on the decision, which was made in recent days and transmitted to General Schwarzkopf, said the rationale for granting the authority was to give the military the capability to use a weapon that is commonly employed by police forces in many countries. **********Some officials also expressed the frustration that the threat of Iraqi chemical-weapons attacks has forced United States and allied forces, as well as thousands of civilians, to spend many hours a day in cumbersome gas masks and protective clothing while no similiar allied threat has encumbered Iraqi forces. Possible Pretext for Hussein **********But some of these officials and coalition members acknowledged what one called the "worrisome" potential that even the use of tear gases by United States forces would hand Mr. Hussein a propaganda weapon and a pretext to escalate to something worse. **********"One real problem is that the first use of nonlethal chemicals can then lead to escalation up the ladder," said Elisa D. Harris, a chemical-warfare specialist at the Brookings Institution. "World War I began with irritant chemicals. The French began with riot control agents, then the Germans went to chlorine, then back and forth until mustard gas was the last lethal agent introduced." **********It is unclear whether the United States would be able to use tear gas, nausea-inducing agents or other nonlethal substances in offensive military operations, but existing regulations set forth by executive order during the Ford Administration may be interpreted for the first time in battle under the authority granted to General Schwarzkopf. **********Mr. Williams said the authority to use riot control agents was granted to United States forces during the invasion of Panama. Example of Possible Use **********One senior official from an Arab country participating in the military coalition said after a briefing by United States officials that "a good example" of how nonlethal gases could be used by allied forces would be in urban combat. He said the gases could be used in an operation designed to retake the Kuwaiti capital, where house-to-house combat could otherwise produce high casualties. **********In addition to tear gas, the United States inventory of nonlethal chemical agents has included vomiting agents such as Adamite that can immobilize victims. More persistent forms of tear gas have been produced that remain in the environment for weeks. The chemical agents can be delivered by hand grenades and mortar shells and from aerial bombs. **********"Instead of killing people, you would immobilize them and save lives," the official said. **********International criticism over the use of herbicides and nonlethal chemical warfare agents by the United States during the Vietnam War resulted in a five-year effort to draft acceptable regulations for future military uses. It culminated in a April 8, 1975, executive order that accompanied the United States acceptance of the 1925 Geneva Protocal banning the use in war time of "asphyxiating, poisonous or other gases and of all analogous liquids." Document Specified Exceptions **********In the document issued by President Ford, the United States renounced the "first use of riot control agents in war except in defensive military modes to save lives. . . ." **********The order authorizes the use of non-lethal gases "in situations in which civilians are used to mask or screen attacks and civilian casualties can be reduced or avoided." The gases could also be used "in rescue missions in remotely isolated areas of downed air crews and passengers." **********Further use is allowed "in rear echelon areas outside the zone of immediate combat to protect convoys" from attack. The order also allows nonlethal gassing of escaping or rioting prisoners of war. **********Earlier this week, United States air forces conducted a search-and-rescue operation to extract an American pilot downed in Iraqi territory. During the operation, the rescuers opened fire on an Iraqi truck that was approaching the rescue site. Mr. Williams suggested that United States forces could have immobilized the occupants of the truck using tear gas instead of gunfire under the authority that was subsequently granted to General Schwarzkopf.  U.S. Holds Minority View **********At the Brookings Institution, Ms. Harris said that the United States has held a minority view in the United Nations that tear gas and other nonlethal agents are not prohibited by the 1925 Geneva Protocal. **********In United Nations debate, Ms. Harris said, "the international community has said that tear gases are covered by the protocal and if we use them first in this war, Saddam can use that as justification to use more lethal weapons. And that is the last thing we want to do, is give him the legal justification for what we suspect he will do in any event." **********During the course of the Persian Gulf crisis, the United States has declined to state publicly whether it would retaliate using lethal chemical weapons in response to a chemical weapons attack by Iraqi forces. **********But during a daily Pentagon briefing on Thursday, Maj. Gen. Martin L. Brandtner responded to a query about United States policy by saying, "To this point in time, we do not intend to use chemical weapons." **********At that point in the briefing, Mr. Williams stepped to the podium and interrupted General Brandtner to say, "We would never commit or not commit ourselves to any future use of any kind of force." **********"If the Iraqis were to use chemical or biological weapons," he continued, "the United States would respond in the strongest way -- and we're obviously not going to take it any further than that."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/12/busin.main_headline: Small Fax Newspaper Shakes Up Its Press Rivals
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/12/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Small Fax Newspaper Shakes Up Its Press Rivals
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/12/busin.body_text: **********In two small Illinois towns, a one-page fax newspaper called Fax Today has challenged the local daily with some success, prompting predictions that similar fax papers could spread like a virus across the country and pose a threat to newspapers. **********In recent years, a number of newspapers have experimented with delivering news via facsimile machines in various formats, but thus far with only limited commercial success. **********What makes Fax Today different is that it is free to subscribers and supported by advertising. It was started in 1989 in Effingham, Ill., by Jack M. Schultz, an entrepreneur with no newspaper experience. He expanded the service to Bloomington in 1990. The enterprise is profitable, Mr. Schultz said, and he sees significant potential for growth. **********His rival in Effingham agrees. **********"I think we're going to see this kind of thing springing up in every corner if we don't watch out for our own interests," said Chris Kade, marketing director of The Effingham Daily News, which started its own free fax newspaper. **********Mr. Kade said newspapers would do well to head off such competition by starting their own fax products, which cost very little to produce because the information and sales staff are already in place. **********The last two years have seen a flurry of experiments in delivering news by fax. For instance, The Chicago Tribune, The Knoxville News-Sentinel in Tennessee and The Minneapolis Star Tribune abandoned fax papers that charged a subscription fee for a one-page afternoon update of business news. "There was interest in the product, but not enough to make it profitable," said Harry Moskos, editor of The News-Sentinel. Re-examination in Hartford **********The Hartford Courant continues to offer such a product, but Dennis Schain, a spokesman, said the concept was being re-examined. **********The Los Angeles Times provides a free summary of news via fax to government officials and diplomats in Moscow as a promotional vehicle. **********About 50 subscribers in foreign countries pay from $21 to $80 a month for a daily sports update via fax from USA Today, and David Mazzarella, president of Gannett International, says the venture "covers its costs." **********The New York Times has three fax news products aimed at areas where the newspaper is not readily available: a six-page fax newspaper for hotels in Japan, which emphasizes Japanese news; a six-page international edition for Australia and other foreign countries, and an eight-page edition for cruise ships. **********Nancy Nielsen, a spokeswoman for The Times, declined to say whether the fax program was profitable. But she said that it was growing and that fax newspapers would be available at hotels in the Caribbean and Brazil in the next two months. **********The St. Paul Pioneer Press provides prices of up to 15 stocks in its afternoon fax paper. And The Washington Post, Dow Jones & Company and The Atlanta Journal and Constitution will fax certain information for a fee. **********Mr. Schultz's fax papers are a variation on the daily business summary concept. He sends his first edition, Fax Today Daybreak, at 6 A.M. It is a summary of international, national and business news, with late sports scores from Western states. His second edition, Fax Today, goes out at 9:30 A.M. and includes local items. **********At the bottom of both products are six small boxes for ads and a larger box with six lunch specials from local restaurants, which pay about $7 for the listing. Fax Today goes to about 180 businesses in Effingham and 380 in Bloomington. Success in Bloomington **********Mr. Schultz said he was doing best in Bloomington, where the local paper, The Pantagraph, has not started a competing fax product. Monthly revenues have increased to about $4,500 there, he said, from $2,500 six months ago. **********He said that the break-even point for such an operation was about $3,000 a month, and that at the current ad rates the potential revenues for Fax Today in Bloomington exceeded $100,000 a year. **********But Mr. Schultz foresees even higher revenues. Indeed, he has already begun trying to sell franchises in exchange for 10 percent of revenues and a $15,000 fee.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/21/busin.body_text: **********The European Community has started a drive to cut the cost and increase the speed of the millions of money transfers that banks process daily in its 12 member nations, the community's executive body said today. **********"There is widespread recognition of the need for rapid improvement in our systems of payment," Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community commissioner in charge of financial services, said in a statement. **********Two committees set up by the European Community Executive Commission, the executive body, will seek ways to cut the cost and time taken to transfer money across borders so that millions of small businesses can run more efficiently, Sir Leon said. **********Bankers, consumers and industry representatives will meet in the coming months to try to agree on what improvements are needed. **********But the commission said it would make its own proposals if the committees did not agree on sufficiently wide-reaching reforms.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Earnings Drop At Affiliated
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/busin.body_text: **********Affiliated Publications Inc., the parent of The Boston Globe, says its net profits dropped 58 percent in the second quarter. The company cited continuing decreases in advertising revenues. **********Net income was $3.1 million, or 4 cents a share, for the three- month period that ended on June 30. That compared with earnings of $7.4 million, or 11 cents a share, in the comparable period of last year. Revenues totaled $130.9 million, compared with $132.1 million. **********The company said on Friday that the recession in New England had caused The Globe's ad volume to shrink. Other newspapers have also been suffering financial strains. **********Affiliated said the poor advertising climate had also hurt another subsidiary, BPI Communications Inc., which produces arts and design publications as well as Adweek, a trade magazine that experienced an operating loss. **********Advertising revenue during the quarter totaled $91.3 million, a 6 percent drop from the period a year earlier. **********The company's shares closed unchanged on Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, at $8.875 a share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/11/busin.main_headline: Credit Data Suit Settled By TRW
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/11/busin.print_headline: Credit Data Suit Settled By TRW
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/11/busin.body_text: **********TRW Inc. agreed to broad changes in its credit-monitoring unit today that are intended to give consumers less costly, faster and more accurate readings on their past use of debt. The action ended a lawsuit brought by 19 states and the Federal Trade Commission. **********"This is an issue of huge importance," said Robert Abrams, the Attorney General of New York, whose office investigated hundreds of consumer complaints against TRW and other credit-reporting companies for two years before the lawsuit against TRW was filed here, where the company has its consumer assistance office, in July. **********"Three-quarters of the population are covered by these credit reporting agencies," Mr. Abrams said, and many have complained that TRW's credit reports are full of errors and that attempts to correct them have been ignored. "As a consequence, many New Yorkers have been unfairly denied home mortgages, loans, auto financing and credit cards." Seeking to End Errors **********In the settlement approved today by Judge Barefoot Sanders, in Federal District Court here, TRW said it would record more complete information about individuals to eliminate errors caused by confusing credit information about different people. **********The company, which said in October that it would provide each consumer a free annual copy of his or her credit report, also agreed today to reduce the price for a second copy each year to $7.50, from $15. **********Mr. Abrams said the reports mailed to consumers in the past were nearly worthless because they contained more than 170 different codes, symbols and abbreviations. As part of today's agreement, the company said it would simplify language explaining credit histories. 170 Million Are Watched **********TRW Information Systems and Services of Orange, Calif., along with two large competitors, Equifax of Atlanta and Trans Union of Chicago, gather reports on the personal financial transactions of 170 million adults in the United States. They compete to sell the information to retailers, banks, mortgage companies and other credit providers. **********The credit-reporting industry has been under fire in Congress and in the Federal courts this year not only for what critics said was a pattern of credit histories riddled with errors, but also for sales of private data to companies that send out junk mail and what consumers have called callous indifference to their complaints. **********"It affects the whole cross section of America," Mr. Abrams said. "I think the settlement is a harbinger of what is coming for this industry." **********Among the 18 attorneys general who joined Mr. Abrams in the court action against TRW are those representing California, Texas and Florida. **********Mr. Abrams said Equifax agreed earlier this year not to sell consumer data to marketing firms after the attorneys general raised the threat of a lawsuit. That issue was not part of the settlement today, but TRW and the F.T.C. agreed to continue to negotiate on it, Mr. Abrams said. **********TRW's announcement in October that it would allow consumers to obtain free copies of their credit histories each year came two days before Senate hearings on a possible revision of the 1970 Fair Credit Reporting Act, which regulates the industry. **********The revised reports it agreed to provide to consumers today will include full first and last names, middle initials, full street addresses, dates of birth and other identifying facts. TRW has been marketing similar histories to consumers for a $39 fee under its Credentials program, which also notifies consumers when credit providers seek access to their records. **********TRW also agreed to complete its investigations of disputed information within 30 days and to inform consumers of the results. Credit reports are to be mailed within four days of requests, and consumers can call the company's consumer assistance office here on a toll-free telephone line. **********The cost of complying with the settlement will be minimal for TRW, said John McGee, a spokesman. The information services unit plans to spend $26 million next year for improvements that cover many of the changes, he said. It spent $18 million this year and $12 million in 1990 on related projects. **********The changes included in the settlement "are either current business practices or things that we expected to do," Mr. McGee said. **********TRW has 60,000 subscribers who pay $1 to $2 for each report request, a spokesman said. The information services unit does not disclose revenues or the volume of report requests. TRW Inc., based in Cleveland, is a leading supplier of electronics to the space and military industries and of auto parts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/world.main_headline: AFTER THE WAR: Iraq; Iraqi Loyalists Pound Shiite Mosques, Rebels Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: Iraq; Iraqi Loyalists Pound Shiite Mosques, Rebels Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/world.body_text: **********Troops loyal to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq shelled Shiite Muslim rebels in mosques in the holy city of Karbala, and Iraqi soldiers defected by the tens of thousands elsewhere, opposition leaders said today. **********They said that the Shiite fighters and civilians trapped in the crossfire were being slaughtered, and that 500 had been killed or wounded since Friday. **********An organization of rebels in Iraq's Kurdish region, the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, said the Government had rounded up 5,000 Kurds, mostly women and children, and was using them as human shields to forestall an attack on the oil industry city of Kirkuk. **********The group also said rebels had seized the strategic oil town of Khanaqin, about 90 miles northeast of Baghdad.  Kurds Meet With Turks **********Jalal Talabani, leader of the Patriotic Union, and Mesut Barzani of the allied Kurdish Democratic Party met secretly last week with Turkish officials, Turkey announced today. The meeting apparently represented a change in Turkey's policy of trying to block Kurdish autonomy in northern Iraq. Turkey has feared that a Kurdish state would encourage Kurdish separatists in Turkey. **********The Kurds have battled for years for autonomy for their mountainous homeland, which also includes parts of Iran, Syria and the Soviet Union. **********Officials in Baghdad who spoke on condition of anonymity said that Republican Guard troops had re-established control of Karbala, 60 miles south of the Iraqi capital. **********They gave no details. But President Hussein's forces appear to have been isolating centers of resistance like Karbala and the southern port city of Basra and pounding them with artillery and tank fire. **********Karbala, renowned for its mosques, is revered by Shiites as the burial place of Imam Hussein, a grandson of the Prophet Mohammed and one of the sect's principal saints. It had a peacetime population of about 120,000. **********At a meeting of Iraqi opposition leaders in Beirut, Ayatollah Taqi al-Mudaressi, leader of the Shiite Islamic Action Organization, said the Republican Guard was "ruthlessly and indiscriminately shelling the holy city of Karbala." **********"They're massacring the people there," he said. "I have sent letters to the world's religious leaders, including the Pope, to prevent Saddam's criminal regime from massacring the Iraqi people." **********There was no independent confirmation of the reports on the rebellions by the Shiites in the south and by Kurds in the north. Fighting also was reported in another Shiite holy city, Najaf, and in Basra and low-income Shiite suburbs of Baghdad. **********The Kurds have claimed major advances since the uprising began March 1 after Mr. Hussein's military defeat.  Loyalists Said to Join Revolt **********Mr. Talabani said in Beirut that at least three Iraqi Army divisions -- 30,000 to 36,000 men -- had "joined the people," bringing their weapons. **********Kurdish officials said the Patriotic Union and the Kurdistan Democratic Party had seized large areas of the northern provinces and were poised to attack Kirkuk, 100 miles north of Baghdad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/world.main_headline: Gorbachev's Pleas for Aid Not Expected to Bear Fruit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/world.print_headline: Gorbachev's Pleas for Aid Not Expected to Bear Fruit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will not get more than a few billion dollars in aid from the economic summit meeting of industrial democracies here in July, Government officials and economic experts say. **********This would be true even if he reached agreement by then with the leaders of the 15 Soviet republics on the latest plan to introduce a market economy and received an invitation to pitch his appeal to the summit conference, a wide range of officials and experts from participating countries agree. **********A spokesman for Prime Minister John Major, the host of the gathering, said that an invitation had not been ruled out despite reports that President Bush was skeptical. The British spokesman said a decision would not be made until closer to the date, by all the participants: the United States, Canada, Japan, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and the European Community. Officials in France and Italy say they would be happy to have Mr. Gorbachev come to London. **********British officials said that if the Soviets made the breakthrough on economic transformation that seemed to be promised by a plan Mr. Gorbachev's advisers will soon present to President Bush in Washington, aid projects that were in the pipeline before Mr. Gorbachev's crackdown on Lithuania in January could be quickly unblocked. Mostly Agricultural Aid **********But they said the summit participants and the international financial institutions they control showed little inclination to pledge large new amounts of aid. **********The sums that have been blocked since January amount only to a few billion dollars in agricultural loan guarantees and credits from the United States and the European Community, which pledged $600 million in food credits and $480 million in technical assistance to Moscow last December. The European Community agreed today to begin a separate $300 million emergency food shipment program by July, officials in Brussels said. **********Until the events in Lithuania, Mr. Bush and other Western leaders seemed ready to approve associate member status for the Soviet Union in the International Monetary Fund, and some officials say the summit leaders might go ahead by July. **********"If the Soviet Union became an associate member, the I.M.F. and the World Bank could provide the technical assistance necessary to get reforms implemented and moving," a spokesman for the I.M.F. in Washington said, but Moscow would not be eligible for direct financial aid from these institutions until it became a full member. **********"The basic apparatus of a market economy would have to be in place and well advanced before a move to full membership could be contemplated," the I.M.F. spokesman said. **********Even Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, which has made aid and credit pledges of $33.7 billion to the Soviet Union since the cold war ended, told reporters on Wednesday on the flight back from talks with Mr. Bush in Washington that it would be senseless to pour more money into a bottomless pit before long-promised Soviet economic reforms actually took hold. **********A year from now, when the 1992 economic summit meeting is held in Munich, things could look different, Mr. Kohl said, and Mr. Gorbachev might attend then. But with a recession afflicting the United States, Britain and France, and Germany overextended by the burdens of last year's unification, governments seem unlikely to be able to provide the kind of investment capital Mr. Gorbachev needs. **********"You have to mobilize private capital for that order of magnitude," said Francis Heisbourg, director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies here. "Gorbachev might get money from the international capital markets if they see convincing ventures to invest in, but these will not exist as long as they haven't seriously gone into a market economy, particularly in energy." Oil Production **********If Mr. Gorbachev did come to London for the summit meeting, Mr. Heisbourg said, "One area he'll be listened to very seriously is oil production, which could produce serious returns financially. Oil companies have money, big money, but where are the assurances they would have the power to run the show?" **********Oil production in the Soviet Union, long the world's biggest producer, has been declining and some experts predict it will soon become a net importer unless it gets substantial investment and technology from the West. **********A group of 24 industrial nations has pledged about $24 billion in aid to countries in Eastern Europe that have already begun the transition to market economies, and a European Bank for Reconstruction and Development based here has $12 billion to help investments in both Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. **********"If first a serious Soviet market economic plan is elaborated and implemented with the agreement of the republics, the Soviet Union could benefit from a G-24 type of effort," Mr. Heisbourg said. "By Marshall Plan standards, the $24 billion is actually not dissimilar."
