https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/busin.main_headline: Can Skim Milk Taste Like Whole Milk?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; Can Skim Milk Taste Like Whole Milk?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/busin.body_text: **********All that the scientists at the Electric Power Research Institute were trying to do was find a way to conserve power in the dairy industry. But, inadvertently, they may have developed a process that makes skim milk taste like whole milk. **********Instead of heating milk to drive off water to produce concentrate or powder, as is usually done, institute researchers and representatives of the Dairy Research Foundation chilled it. Some of the water formed ice crystals, which were filtered out. The resulting concentrate was reconstituted by adding water. **********The researchers were surprised to find that the resulting skim milk tasted better than normal skim milk. "We put the water back in, and it tasted like whole milk," said Robert D. Jeffress, a program manager at the Palo Alto, Calif., institute, which is supported by electric utilities. **********"We are not sure why that is, but we have blindfolded taste tests that say so," he added. The difference could be that the milk proteins are preserved when frozen, but partly broken down when heated, changing the taste, he said. **********Other advantages of freeze-concentrated milk include less volume, so it is cheaper to ship, and a longer shelf life in stores or home freezers. To test the economics of the process, the institute is backing a commercial-scale operation for removing 700 pounds of water an hour at the Galloway West Company in Fond du Lac, Wis., starting in the fall. **********According to officials of the institute, freezing is a more energy-efficient means of concentrating milk and other dairy products than heat evaporation. The most common type of evaporator takes 118 kilowatt- hours to remove one metric ton, or 2,204 pounds, of water, compared with 65 kilowatt-hours for freezing. A typical dairy could save $100,000 a year in power costs by switching methods, they said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.main_headline: Vodka Rivals Compete On Film and in Print
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Vodka Rivals Compete On Film and in Print
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.body_text: **********Two rivals in the highly competitive imported vodka market are each introducing an innovative ad. **********TBWA Advertising, New York, has created the first Absolut vodka commercial for the United States. Beginning in November, the 70-second spot for the Swedish import will appear during in-flight programming on MGM Grand Air's flights between Los Angeles and New York. **********The spot, called "Absolut Subliminal -- The Movie," is based on an Absolut magazine ad that spoofs subliminal ads. Rapid-fire color shots of an Absolut bottle are edited into footage from "Colossus of New York," a 1958 black-and-white horror movie. **********"I suspect this will not be the last little film for Absolut," said Richard Lewis, a senior vice president at TBWA. He emphasized that the agency did not intend to run the spot on television, which would violate a self-imposed industrywide ban on broadcast liquor advertising. **********Meanwhile, Calet, Hirsch & Spector, New York, has created a heat-sensitive magazine ad for Stolichnaya vodka. The ad, part of the continuing "Russian phenomenon" campaign for that import, will appear in the October issues of Omni magazine distributed in such markets as California, Chicago and New York. **********The ad, produced through a process called Chromicolor, is treated with a heat-sensitive coated ink. When a reader places a hand on a blacked-out picture of a Stolichnaya bottle, the picture changes to reveal the bottle's colorful label.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/busin.body_text: **********The Government expanded a program today that allows elderly homeowners to receive a monthly check by tapping their home equity through a "reverse mortgage." **********The Government's action also allows the thousands of lenders authorized to make Federal Housing Administration-insured loans to offer reverse mortgages. **********The Federal National Mortgage Association said it had agreed to purchase at least 25,000 of the mortgages through September 1995, amounting to about $2 billion. Under a pilot program begun in November 1989, 23 lenders made 2,500 reverse mortgages. **********In a reverse mortgage, homeowners who either own their property free and clear or have only a minimal mortgage debt take out a new mortgage. Instead of receiving a lump sum, they either draw on a line of credit or get monthly payments. When they die or move, the loan is repaid by selling the home. **********The program is designed to give people over 62 years old the income they need to pay property taxes and to maintain their home. Borrowers under the program cannot be forced to move even if the amount they owe eventually exceeds the worth of their property.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.snippet: Business failures have increased dramatically -- up about 50 percent in the first six months of 1991 over the year-earlier period, according to the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation. And the vast majority of those failures are small businesses, many of...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.main_headline:
Your Own Account;
Why Small Businesses Are Failing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.print_headline:
Your Own Account;
Why Small Businesses Are Failing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.body_text: **********Business failures have increased dramatically -- up about 50 percent in the first six months of 1991 over the year-earlier period, according to the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation. And the vast majority of those failures are small businesses, many of them started during the entrepreneurial decade of the 80's. **********The problem is that too many entrepreneurs know how to produce a product or deliver a service but do not have expertise in finance and administration. When hard times hit, the lack of management experience often throws small companies into chaos. **********"Most small businesses are managed out of the owner's personal checkbook," said Peter Collins, director of emerging business services for Coopers & Lybrand in New York. "The majority don't even have a business plan. And when something goes wrong, they don't have a plan for what to do next." **********Worse yet, small companies are vulnerable to a single bad decision: they might begin to founder simply because of a mistake in the advertising campaign or one bad hire. "The smaller the company, the more precarious because there's less margin for error," said Abraham E. Getzler, a turnaround specialist in New York. **********Yet small companies make up the bulk of American business: 85 percent to 90 percent of the businesses in the United States employ fewer than 20 people, according to Reid Gearhart, an analyst at Dun & Bradstreet. "When you look at the number of business failures, the impact of the large companies is insignificant," he said. **********When they run into trouble, though, small companies usually do not have access to the best technical help, let alone the means to pay for it. Turnaround experts offer advice on management and marketing changes, as well as ways to obtain new financing or to restructure. **********"Eighty percent of the talent available in the turnaround business is soaked up by big corporations," said Cameron Adair, a turnaround consultant in Atlanta. **********And the evidence suggests that many embattled business owners just give up the ship. For example, 42 percent of the companies that filed for bankruptcy in 1990 had outstanding liabilities of less than $5,000, Mr. Gearhart said. **********If you are the owner of a business that appears to be foundering, what should you do? Above all else, don't wait too long to get help, the experts say. "We often don't get a call for help until the businessman runs out of money," said Mr. Getzler. "Running out of money is not the problem. It's only a symptom of the problem." **********The problem is generally inexperienced management. Studies by the Turnaround Management Association, an industry group based in Chantilly, Va., have found that "between 70 and 75 percent of business failures are due to bad management," according to James A. Schuping, executive vice president. **********The credit crunch that accompanied the 1990-91 recession exacerbated the problem, these experts say. Yet trouble signs typically start showing up in a business as long as two years in advance of the crisis, said Scott G. Neill, vice president for marketing at Buccino & Associates, turnaround specialists in Chicago. **********Small-business owners are often not willing to face reality, Mr. Neill said. "To them, every sales shortfall is simply a blip. They never see it as the harbinger of a trend." **********Here are some of the warning signs: *********** Double-digit growth turns into single-digit growth. *********** Product quality and customer satisfaction decline. *********** Receivables begin to lag. *********** Employees quit. *********** You accept very low margin work just so you have something to do. *********** Overhead is up. *********** Unit volume or dollar volume are down. **********You can track down some of the reasons for these symptoms yourself, and start to deal with them. For example, if your sales volume and order backlog are way down, ask yourself some questions: Which customers made up the backlog last year? Have they disappeared? Can you try to get more business from them? **********If your business is in serious trouble, however, you probably need the help of a professional turnaround specialist. But there are a couple of places you can go first to get some advice without charge. **********Small Business Development Centers, which are underwritten by the Small Business Administration and the states, provide counseling. Counselors will also help you write a business plan, according to Timothy A. Dixon, information manager at the Small Business Development Center Connection in Athens, Ga. The Association of Small Business Development Centers in Omaha will refer you to the nearest office. **********The Service Corps of Retired Executives (Score) is another resource group that operates without charge. Contact Score in Washington to find the nearest office.BRINGING IN THE CRISIS EXPERTS **********Finding a turnaround expert qualified to rescue a small business can be difficult. One of the problems is that many out-of-work executives with no special background in turnarounds are hanging out shingles as crisis managers because it has become a hot growth area. **********The Turnaround Management Association has recently published a directory of its 500 members. The directory, which costs $95, is available in many libraries. The association acknowledges, though, that it does nothing to screen its members, so you will have to interview them yourself. **********You may also be able to get a reference from your banker, lawyer or accountant or from the trade association that represents your industry. **********When interviewing a likely candidate, ask these questions: *********** How many companies have you helped turn around? What were their problems -- and how did you work through them? *********** Have you had experience as a "hands on" manager? *********** Have you had profit and loss responsibility in operating a company? *********** Who are your references? Do not expect to get the names of client companies, said Scott Neill at Buccino & Associates. But do get the names of lawyers and bankers the manager has worked with. *********** How does your fee schedule work? Some consultants work strictly on an hourly basis, which typically ranges from $150 to perhaps $300. Others may take an equity position in the company. *********** How have you dealt with companies that went into liquidation? How did the creditors make out and why? **********Some consultants are experts in finding financing for the company; others are predisposed to liquidate. You should try to get a feel for the consultant's specialties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/15/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Nova Pharmaceutical Names New Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/15/busin.body_text: **********The Nova Pharmaceutical Corporation, a drug research and development company based in Baltimore, said yesterday that it had appointed Donald E. O'Neill as chairman. Mr. O'Neill, who retired earlier this year as a senior executive of the Warner-Lambert Company, succeeds John Lloyd Huck, a former chairman of Merck & Company, who is staying on as a Nova director. **********Mr. O'Neill, 65, was an executive vice president and head of international operations with Warner-Lambert, which requires its senior executives to retire at 65. Hans Mueller, Nova's president and chief executive, said the new chairman would be "a strong addition to Nova's management team" because of his experience with product development, marketing and international operations, and contacts in the pharmaceutical industry. **********Mr. O'Neill, who had been chairman of the international section of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a trade group, said he would try "to develop some kind of alliance with a major American or foreign pharmaceutical or biotechnology firm" to help finance Nova's research program. **********Nova had $25 million in sales in the first half of 1991, up sharply from $9.3 million in the 1990 period. The gain reflected a June 1990 agreement with the SmithKline Beecham Company, which had been a big investor in Nova, to market SmithKline's psychiatric products. Nova's net loss for the six months was $7.5 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with a loss of $6.8 million, or 26 cents a share, in the first half of 1990. Nova, is working with Solomon Snyder, chairman of the department of neurosciences at The Johns Hopkins University, and other Johns-Hopkins scientists to develop drugs and drug delivery systems to treat disorders in the brain and central nervous system. **********Samuel Isaly of Mehta & Isaly Worldwide Research, securities analysts, said Nova has some "promising leads" and might show profits in the mid-1990's. It was founded in 1982 by David and Isaac Blech, Brooklyn, brothers and venture capitalists who have been involved in a number of science-based startups. One was Genetics Systems, which was sold to the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company in 1985 for $294 million in Bristol-Myers stock. **********Mr. O'Neill joined Warner-Lambert in 1971 as president of the Chilcott drug divison. He later headed the Parke-Davis drug unit, the professional products group, and the Warner-Lambert/Parke-Davis research divison. Before joining Warner-Lambert he was a sales and marketing executive with the G.D. Searle Company for 21 years. **********He is a graduate of the University of Washington and an avid golfer. Mr. O'Neill and his wife Elizabeth have homes in Harding Township, N.J. and John's Island, Fla. They have three married daughters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/09/world.main_headline: Haiti's New Leader Takes on the Army
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/09/world.print_headline: Haiti's New Leader Takes on the Army
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/09/world.body_text: **********Within hours of being sworn in on Thursday as President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide said that all but two of the army's eight generals would be given a "well-earned retirement." **********Other governments have foundered or been toppled for undertaking much less ambitious changes in Haiti's military. But analysts say the popular new President decided that the time was right for a radical restructuring of a force regarded here as repressive and corrupt. It is not yet clear how the military will respond. **********In his first speech from the presidential palace, Father Aristide stunned many Haitians when he announced the resignations amid a playful prayer and response with the audience. In the same speech, he lavished praise on the army and spoke of its irrevocable "marriage" with the people. **********Lieut. Gen. Herard Abraham, commander in chief of the 6,000-man army, was asked to stay on and oversee the retirement of his peers. Col. Raoul Cedras, who oversaw the country's peaceful elections last December, was promoted to army chief of staff with the rank of brigadier general. Failure to Arrest Lafontant **********A political scientist who asked not to be identified said the generals had been "very reluctant about the democratic process." He also noted that they had tolerated the presence of Dr. Roger Lafontant, a former Interior Minister who once headed a brutal militia under the Duvalier family's dictatorship. Despite arrest warrants, the army failed to arrest Dr. Lafontant until he tried unsuccessfully to seize power in January. **********Another important question is who Father Aristide will name as prime minister, the official responsible for forming the Government and running it from day to day. Some Haitians have urged him to choose someone with a more conventional political background than his own, even someone from a rival political group, to help broaden the Government's appeal. **********But some of Father Aristide's closest backers are urging him to select someone he trusts, with a similar if not identical political outlook. **********The speculation has centered on Rene Preval, a left-of-center Belgian-trained engineer and baker who, like Father Aristide, has scant political experience but is trusted because of his early support of the priest's candidacy. The Associated Press said Father Aristide disclosed in an interview that he had chosen Mr. Preval.  Passing Up an Opportunity **********Some of Father Aristide's supporters said that in choosing an intimate like Mr. Preval, the President would be passing up an opportunity to strengthen his ties with the grass-roots organizations that backed his candidacy, or with rival politicians who have put aside their differences with Father Aristide to give him crucial parliamentary support. **********"To me it is unbelievable that Aristide has not even called me to ask my opinion on how the country should be run," said Louis Dejoie Jr., a veteran left-of-center politician who placed third in the presidential race. Mr. Dejoie has pledged the support of his party's members in Parliament to the new Government, giving it a majority. **********"What I am afraid of is, if we go back to the old tradition, we are kaput," Mr. Dejoie said in an interview. "That's what happens when one party dominates everything."  134 Barred From Leaving **********Radio Haiti Inter, an independent station in the capital, reported that 134 people, including Father Aristide's predecessor, the former interim President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, and many civil servants from her Government had been barred from leaving Haiti pending an investigation of her government's management of public funds. **********The station said the former officials who had been prevented from leaving were "not necessarily people who have siphoned funds."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/20/busin.main_headline: Bundesbank Increases Rates To Highest Level Since 1948
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/20/busin.print_headline: Bundesbank Increases Rates To Highest Level Since 1948
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/20/busin.body_text: **********Germany's central bank raised its two key interest rates today to their highest levels since 1948. The action, which was meant to stem rising domestic inflation and reaffirm German hegemony over European monetary policy, caught financial markets and economists off guard. **********The Bundesbank had not been expected to raise rates just eight days after the European Community nations agreed at a summit meeting in Maastricht, the Netherlands, to create a single European monetary policy and currency by 1999. **********But today, in a surprising display of financial power and political independence, it increased the Lombard and discount rates one-half percentage point to, 9.75 percent and 8 percent, respectively, even though the move puts pressure on nations like the United States and Britian. They are trying to stimulate their economies by keeping rates low. **********"This is the Bundesbank's way of showing they will use their power and independence without regard to the economic conditions in the rest of Europe," said Peter Pietsch, an economist with Commerzbank A.G. in Frankfurt. "I was surprised at how strong the move was -- it's a somewhat daring move." **********The German rate rise also caused the dollar to tumble on foreign-exchange markets in New York today to 1.5575 marks, compared with 1.5715 on Wednesday, and is expected to undermine the dollar further, because investors are likely to switch to mark-denominated holdings for the higher yield. **********"Given the differential against the dollar and European currencies, it's hard to see why any investor would not want to be in Deutsche marks," said Brendan Brown, chief economist for Mitsubishi Finance International P.L.C. in London. "Begining in early January, there could be an almost unstoppable flow from other currencies, particularly the lire and the pound sterling." **********If Germany's trading partners respond to the Bundesbank move by putting upward pressures on their interest rates to prevent a capital flight to the mark, their recoveries could stall. **********On the plus side, however, a lower dollar lowers the price of American exports, making them more competitive in foreign markets. **********The rate increases were intended primarily to ease domestic inflationary pressures, but an outburst of public concern in Germany over plans to scrap the mark by 1999 also played a role, said Hermann Remsperger, chief economist at BHF Bank A.G. in Frankfurt. "Politicians completely overlooked what the Deutsche mark meant to the man in the street," he said. "Then a lot of people woke up. Now the Bundesbank is telling them it's still there." **********Recession has bypassed Germany. Buoyed by reunification, the German economy has kept growing. Although the pace has slowed over the last six months, Germany's economy is expected to expand by at least 3 percent this year, and the country's financial strength is unrivaled in Europe. **********Theo Waigel, Germany's Finance Minister, said in Bonn that the Bundesbank's decision was a clear signal to unions and employers to keep wage increases moderate. **********Bundesbank officials made it clear that the highest German interest rates since the present currency was created in 1948, were intended to avert a wage-price spiral that could push German inflation well above its current annual rate of 4.2 percent. **********The Bundesbank's policy-setting central bank council raised Germany's short-term Lombard rate to 9.75 percent from 9.25 percent and the discount rate to 8 percent from 7.50 percent, effective Friday. The rates were previously changed on Aug. 15, when the discount rate was raised one full percentage point and the Lombard was lifted by one-quarter of a point. **********The Netherlands, Belgium and Austria, which peg their monetary policies to the Bundesbank's, also raised their key lending rates. **********The Bundesbank wants to push inflation down to an annual rate of 2 percent rate as soon as possible. Economists said that cannot happen before 1993. "We'll see 5 percent inflation next year, not 2 percent," said Mr. Remsperger of BHF Bank. **********-------------------- **********Outlook for Economy **********PARIS, Dec. 19 -- The American economy is likely to remain sluggish until spring, and high debt levels for businesses and consumers will dampen any rebound, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a report issued today. **********Economists from the Paris-based organization said economic growth in the United States would be small in the fourth quarter and the first quarter of next year. One senior O.E.C.D. economist, Rick Imai, said at a news conference that there was a "30 to 40 percent chance" that the American economy could slide into a double-dip recession. **********The organization forecast that American economic output would fall by five-tenths of 1 percent this year, but would grow by 2.2 percent next year and 3.8 percent in 1993. It forecast growth of 1.4 percent in the second half of 1991, 1.8 percent in the first half of 1992 and 3.7 percent in the second half of 1992.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/16/busin.main_headline:
Your Own Account;
When a Private Banker Can Help
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/16/busin.print_headline:
Your Own Account;
When a Private Banker Can Help
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/16/busin.body_text: **********Eleanor K. H. Blayney, a McLean, Va., financial planner, has a client with a problem: he needs to come up with $250,000 in 45 days to pay for a piece of raw land that he bought at a bankruptcy auction. Undeveloped land is often difficult to finance, particularly on such short notice. But Ms. Blayney has a solution: using a private banker. The client's financial background is strong enough to meet the banker's guidelines, Ms. Blayney said, and a check should be available in a matter of days. **********Getting loans quickly and with a minimum of red tape is perhaps the most useful service provided by private banking departments, which exist at most commercial banks and some savings banks. At their most elaborate, the departments are designed to pull all the disparate resources of a bank together in one place to help clients with all of their financial needs. In return for being assigned to a specific banker and given access to a range of financial experts, the client is expected to generate a certain amount of business or pay a minimum annual fee. **********But the level of wealth needed to qualify for private banking -- as well as the type of services provided -- now varies widely, a reflection of how competitive the highly profitable field has become. **********"Private banking today means many different things in the marketplace, ranging from the services at J. P. Morgan to the Dime Savings Bank," said Bill Friesell, head of the private banking division at Citibank in New York. **********Some financial planners, like Steven B. Enright of River Vale, N.J., suggest that you still need a cool million in liquid assets to benefit fully from private banking. Others, like Barbara J. Pope, partner in charge of personal financial services for Price Waterhouse in Chicago, say clients with as little as $25,000 to deposit can find it advantageous. "Banks also may make private banking available to you simply because of your position in the company, you are a partner in a professional firm or a small-business owner with good prospects," she said. **********Ms. Pope uses a private banker. She likes the convenience of being able to do a transaction -- like getting a mortgage -- simply by making a phone call. "They just send you something to sign and that's it," she said. **********Lynn Shostack, an entrepreneur who runs Joyce International Inc., an office furniture manufacturer in New York, uses one, too. Ms. Shostack, who developed the private banking division at the Bankers Trust Company in New York 10 years ago, has two financial relationships, one with a major broker for investment ideas, the other with a private banker "for everything else." **********"My investment approach is quite conservative because I take all my risks in my business," Ms. Shostack said. "But a private banker gives you access to large personal loans based on your balance sheet." **********Experts say that the crucial thing in picking a private banker is a fit between your needs and the products and services offered. Obviously, the more money you have, the more options. But don't pick a bank where you are on the lower fringe of acceptability. **********"If you're at the bank's minimum, you're at the wrong place," said Barbara S. Thomas, a private banking consultant in New York. "Look around for a place where the amount of money you have is important to the bank." **********Once you've identified a couple of candidates, expect to spend some time interviewing the person who would handle your account at each bank. If a private banker is to provide value, you must be able to establish a personal relationship. "Finding a private banker is like finding a physician," Ms. Shostack said. "You need to interview a lot of them. Talk to them about what their orientation is, what they think they do well." **********Some private banking departments are more oriented to investments, some to lending; some have a domestic focus, others international. For example, the Swiss private banks excel in global management. "For managing liquidity worldwide, the Swiss are very, very good," Ms. Shostack said. On the other hand, these conservative bankers are not particularly interested in high-risk loans to entrepreneurs or in making home mortgages. "Mortgages are best handled by a local bank," said Hanspeter A. Walder, vice president in the New York office of the Swiss Bank Corporation. **********Mr. Enright uses a private bank for the cash management needs of some clients who don't like the anonymity of money market mutual funds. "Some people want to deal with a face, someone they can sit down and have lunch with," Mr. Enright said. "Private banks are much more accommodating than a mutual fund family. I've never had a bad meal in a private bank dining room." **********But you should expect something beyond what Mr. Friesell of Citibank calls "fuzzy hand-holding services." Getting a free cup of coffee while your check is cashed is not enough. "Your wealth, income and life style should be such that there is sufficient complexity in your life to make this worthwhile," he said.CUTTING THROUGH THE RED TAPE **********Here are some products and services you can expect to find when dealing with a private banking department. **********Personal loans. **********You should be able to get fast service, quick approval and an interest rate close to the prime rate. "A very good private banking customer could borrow at prime; no problem," said Barbara J. Pope at Price Waterhouse. **********Mortgages. **********Many private bankers will work out the terms of a mortgage to suit your needs rather than offering a product off the shelf. For example, if you plan to be in a home for a short time, you may want a five-year balloon mortgage with no points. **********Personalized services. **********If you are an entrepreneur trying to build your business, an active investor who needs big chunks of money for three to six months at a time, or perhaps a heavy traveler who needs to have financial details taken care of while you are out of town, a good private banker could do the job. **********Flexibility. **********You should get a banker who can cut through red tape and bring all the bank's services together in one place. "The typical banker is very inflexible," said Steven B. Enright, a River Vale, N.J., financial planner. "A private banker will work things out for you." **********Price. **********Banks price their services differently, but it boils down to the same thing: They have to make enough money on your business to make it worth their while. If you make a lot of transactions, like frequent loans, you will get a good interest rate, they will make money and everyone will be happy. If you just park your money in certificates of deposit, though, you may not be an ideal candidate for private banking. Some banks may have a minimum annual fee for those who do not generate enough transaction-related income. Others may simply turn you away.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/27/busin.body_text: **********The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it would increase its minority interest in Vortech Data Inc., and have an option to assume controlling interest in the company in 1993. **********Kodak, based in Rochester, did not disclose how much of a stake it has or would have after the transaction in Vortech, a supplier of systems used to manage medical images. Other terms were also not disclosed. **********Kodak said it had initially invested in Vortech in September 1990. Vortech, based in Reston, Va., is co-developer and co-marketer of the Kodak Ektascan Imagelink system, which allows hospitals to store, display and print electronically captured images such as ultrasounds and computed tomography scans. Kodak said the system is being used in the United States and will be available in Europe next year. **********Allan R. Griebenow, Vortech's president and chief executive, said Kodak's additional investment would enable Vortech to satisfy increased market demand for the companies' jointly developed products. **********On the New York Stock Exchange today, Kodak's shares rose 75 cents each to close at $46.50.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/21/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices held steady yesterday, withstanding strong computerized sell programs and weakness in I.B.M. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 1.56 points, to 2,953.94, but most other averages, on which I.B.M. pulls less weight, struggled to slight gains. **********The Standard & Poor's index of 500 mostly blue-chip stocks closed up 0.33, at 375.42. The New York Stock Exchange's composite index edged up 0.09, to 205.87, and the Nasdaq composite rose 0.52, to 485.88. **********S.& P.'s new index of 400 midrange capitalized stocks dipped 0.06 from its opening-day close of 123.48.  Programs Trim 8 Points **********The program traders mounted two buy programs and three sell programs, lasting a total of 53 minutes, and Birinyi Associates said the net result was to pare 8.06 points from the Dow. **********The increased program trading activity may have accounted for much of the increase in volume on the New York Stock Exchange to 164 million shares, from 159.7 million on Wednesday. On the Big Board, 658 stocks advanced and 858 declined. **********As for today's "triple witching hour," Donald M. Selkin, chief stock index analyst at Prudential Securities, observed: "Whether or not the expiration Friday of several index futures, options on these futures and the June options on individual stocks unsettles the market depends mainly on what happens overnight in Tokyo's stock market." **********The reason, Mr. Selkin noted, is the June futures on the S.& P. 500 index actually expired yesterday. But the prices of the 500 issues in the index will be determined at the opening this morning. "Thus if there are no large changes in the prices of these shares overnight in Tokyo," it should not unsettle our market Friday, he said. **********What could roil the market today, Mr. Selkin continued, is the behavior of the June Value Line and Major Market Index futures. As he explained: "The June Value Line index futures, some 1,700 issues, have been trading below the price of the actual index all week. If enough program traders buy the cheaper futures and sell enough stocks in the actual index, it could put pressure on the entire stock market." **********After all, most program trades involve the simultaneous selling or buying of index futures and the key issues that move the underlying actual index.  I.B.M. Slips Below 100 **********One of the most prominent index-moving stocks is I.B.M., which not only dipped below 100 by falling 1 7/8, to 99 1/8, but was also the Big Board's second-most-active issue, on a volume of 4.1 million shares. I.B.M. warned analysts yesterday that earnings would be lower than expected for the quarter. The most active issue was Waste Management, which lost 2 1/8, to 37 1/4, on a turnover of nearly 4.3 million shares. Waste Management was also depressed by a lower earnings estimate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/busin.main_headline: Patents; Speaker-Phone Allows a Listener to Interrupt
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/busin.print_headline: Patents; Speaker-Phone Allows a Listener to Interrupt
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/busin.body_text: **********Researchers at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories obtained a patent this week on telephone speaker-phones that allow people to carry on more normal conversations. **********Speaker-phones are common, but they are often poor in allowing people to interrupt, as they would in normal conversation, because the units effectively cut off the signals from the listening side of the conversation. The person with the strongest voice signal is given a clear talking path, and the other person has to wait for a pause before being able to jump in. **********To deal with this, speaker-phone switches are set to change directions when receiving a strong voice signal. But the devices are still slow because they are set to exclude noise present in some situations. Because some rooms have strong echoes, for example, switches are often set so that the echo generated by voices on the speaker-phone does not interrupt the person talking. But for rooms that have no echo, the delay allowed for the echo simply makes it difficult for the listener to break into the conversation. **********"This allows the speaker-phone to work in the way that's right for you," said Richard H. Erving, one of the inventors. The technology has already been incorporated into some expensive equipment used in business, but the researchers said the underlying computer software could eventually be put into household units as the cost of microprocessors declines. **********Mr. Erving and William A. Ford and Robert R. Miller 2d, Bell researchers, obtained patent 5,007,046.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/busin.main_headline: How Railroads Cut Jobs Without Drawing Blood
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/busin.print_headline: How Railroads Cut Jobs Without Drawing Blood
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/busin.body_text: **********When Jerry Dyneck Jr. was given the choice of moving to Little Rock to keep his Union Pacific Railroad job or leaving the company, he was apprehensive. **********"I lived there all my life," he recalled. "My father had lived in Omaha. These were real roots. I was looking forward to retirement in three to four years." **********Mr. Dyneck, a 57-year-old electrician, could have become a victim of the turmoil wrought by huge cutbacks at Union Pacific. Instead, he is happily at work in Little Rock, where he lives on a lake just outside the city. Fortunately for the nation's railroads, what it took to get him there, content with the way he was treated, is not an isolated story. **********Tens of thousands of workers at the major freight railroads have been similarly affected in the last five years as the companies, seeking lower costs, made huge job cuts in almost every line and management operation. Not all their experiences were as positive as Mr. Dyneck's, but the changes have been made without the protracted battles seen in other industries. **********Some airlines, for example, endured long, bitter strikes over work changes and layoffs designed to cut costs. One such conflict ended in the liquidation of Eastern Airlines. **********Since 1980, employment has been cut by half among the major freight railroads. That comes to about 230,000 workers in all categories, from executives to train crews. **********In Mr. Dyneck's case, his union, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, made sure he knew he would get help if he relocated. That included $15,000 for moving expenses and reimbursement of any money he lost between the sale of his Omaha house and the purchase of one in Little Rock. He also got a job paying at least as much as the one he left. **********To ease the social transition, the company moved him with other workers from Omaha so they would have some co-workers they already knew. Shortly after they arrived, the company threw a big bash so they could make new acquaintances. **********"I don't say this very often," said Lennie Bauman, general chairman of the Brotherhood of Carmen. "The Union Pacific went the extra mile with me on seeing that our people got what they had coming to them under our agreement and gave some things that were not even in the agreement.  "Generally, there was hard, nose-to-nose bargaining," he said. "But when everything was said and done, we were pleased with the deal we got." **********For most railroads, transferring and retraining workers and using new technology has led to vast increases in productivity. Cutting train crews from four to three has also helped. The Union Pacific, for example, has cut its work force to 29,000, from 45,000 in 1984. Even so, it hauled 4,158,000 cars of freight in 1990, compared with 3,188,000 in 1985. **********Productivity has soared. Million gross ton miles per employee has gone from 6.08 to 11.50, an 89 percent increase. A gross ton mile equals one ton of freight hauled for one mile. The labor cost per 1,000 gross ton miles has dropped 38 percent, from $7.26 in 1984 to $4.53 in 1990. **********The productivity gains were combined with a big capital spending program, a shakeup of lower management and a drive to computerize such tasks as the control of trains. **********Mike Walsh, who had been general manager of Cummins Engine, was brought in as chairman in 1986. Under his firm hand, the railroad has been moving away from a rigid hierarchy that focused mainly on running the trains. Under the new, looser structure, managers with more autonomy take a broader view toward satisfying customers. **********"The name of the game is to be able to compete with truckers," said Graeme Lidgerwood, a railroad analyst for First Boston. "You have to provide service that's very responsive. They are now a very customer-driven railroad." **********Richard K. Davidson, the chairman and chief executive officer who took over from Mr. Welch last August, said the Union Pacific was beginning to get some freight business that had been handled by trucks. Specifically, he said, the double-stack service under which rail cars are loaded with pairs of truck containers, running mostly from the West Coast to Chicago, is taking cargo from trucks. **********But the transformation has not come easy at a company that ran without major changes for decades. Mr. Walsh's proposals brought uneasiness at first, Mr. Davidson recalled. **********Mr. Davidson, who joined the railroad as a brakeman in 1960, had a bellyful of the old style. Still, he was uncertain what the changes would bring. "I had lived with the structure for 25 years. I was scared to death that the railroad was going to collapse," he said. "But it ran better." **********One of the first steps was to eliminate 1,650 management and professional jobs, a cut of about 28 percent. Then the regional dispatching centers were consolidated under one roof in Omaha, resulting in further large cuts in jobs. Customer service was also centralized, and regional supervisors were given a lot of authority to deal with customers and decide how to spend their budgets. When the dust settled, nine layers of management had been reduced to three. **********Along with the cuts came a dismantling of the old military-style hierarchy. "Just the very sight of a superintendant was intimidating," Mr. Davidson recalled. "It was Mr. this and Mr. that. Today there is more of a cooperative philosophy." **********At the same time, Tom Watts, vice president of labor relations, began the monumental task of negotiating with 15 craft unions to cut uneconomical jobs and plants left over from the railroad's 1982 merger with the Missouri Pacific and Western Pacific.  The merger agreement, overseen by the Interstate Commerce Commission, provided for cutting jobs. However, the cuts could not begin until agreements had been worked out with the unions on protection and benefits for laid-off and displaced workers. **********Initially, there was suspicion and fear. "Our industry is not the kind that has embraced change on the spot," Mr. Watts recalled. There were numerous meetings with about 70 general chairmen of the unions and some 1,000 local chairmen. **********He said the company made every attempt to relocate and retrain workers who wanted to stay, but when not enough workers chose to take buyouts, it had to make cuts. Workers generally got from 15 to 17 months' pay if they chose to leave. They also got some money to pay for retraining and going back to school. **********Conductors, brakemen, engineers and other crew members had an additional benefit. Those who chose to leave were put on a reserve board, where they got 70 percent of their pay until the company found jobs for them or they left for jobs elsewhere. **********"We tried to give everyone an opportunity to retrain," Mr. Watts recalled. "The aim was to keep the hard feelings down."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/04/world.body_text: **********On the eve of the scheduled resumption of Middle East peace talks, the Israeli Government took steps today toward starting a new settlement on the site where snipers killed two Jews recently in the occupied West Bank. **********Soldiers from the army's Nahal unit moved into mobile homes that Israeli settlers had put overnight at Kefar Tappuah, 25 miles north of Jerusalem. **********Just before the start of the first peace conference in Madrid on Oct. 30, unidentified gunmen fired on a busload of settlers at an intersection near that town, killing two adults and wounding half a dozen children. A small group of angry settlers quickly pitched tents, and they have since occupied the site, invoking what they call a Zionist imperative to establish new communities wherever Jewish blood is shed. Killings and Settlements **********By moving Nahal soldiers there, the Government is now suggesting that that will become a permanent civilian settlement. That has been the normal pattern, and even though Defense Minister Moshe Arens said the purpose of the latest action was to "guarantee security in the area," he acknowledged that a new full-time community was likely. **********The Government move came two days after another ambush attack, in which a Jewish settler, Zvi Klein, was fatally shot while driving through the town of el-Bira, six miles north of Jerusalem. Israeli radio said that settlers might try to set up yet another community not far from where Mr. Klein was shot. **********For his part, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who is committed to building such communities in the face of Arab demands that they stop, declared today that "these murderous acts will not deter us from founding, expanding and establishing settlements." **********"We will have the upper hand," he told the state-run radio. "The Land of Israel is ours." Effects on Peace Talks **********Left-of-center opposition parties denounced the army move, and warned that it could undermine the peace process, which has already been unsettled by Israel's refusal to show up in Washington Wednesday for the scheduled restart of negotiations with Palestinians and Arab countries. **********But it was not clear how much of an effect the formal start of the new community, called Rachelim, would have, even though a settlement freeze is a Palestinian priority, one that the United States endorses. **********As the Madrid talks ended on Nov. 4, the Israeli Government inaugurated a new settlement for Soviet immigrants on the Golan Heights, territory that Israel had annexed but that Syria wants back. That action was swiftly condemned by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d as not helpful to the peace talks. **********But in this case, there is an emotional component in that the settlement marks the spot where civilians were gunned down. That might make a difference in how Washington and the Arabs react, some Israeli commentators said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/busin.main_headline: Apple Computer to Reduce Staff 10%, Cutting 1,560 Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/busin.print_headline: Apple Computer to Reduce Staff 10%, Cutting 1,560 Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/busin.body_text: **********Apple Computer Inc. confirmed today that it would reduce its work force by 10 percent, or about 1,560 people, as part of the company's efforts to reduce costs. Apple said the work force reduction, the fourth and largest in the company's history, would affect all job classifications worldwide, including contractors and temporary employees. **********Apple shares fell $2 Friday on rumors of the reduction and closed today at $44.25, off an additional $2.75, in over-the-counter trading. Apple made its announcement today after the market's close. **********The work force reduction, which will be accomplished by layoffs and attrition primarily during the current fiscal quarter, is part of a restructuring designed to reflect Apple's new business strategy. Apple said that restructuring costs would be taken in the third quarter, which ends June 28. Barbara Krause, an Apple spokeswoman, declined to comment on the size of the charge or on whether it might result in a loss for the quarter. Need to Cut Costs **********With the introduction of a number of new, lower-priced Macintosh models last fall, Apple shifted from a low-volume maker of high-profit products to a manufacturer seeking a larger market share at lower profits. Historically, Apple charged a premium for its computers and was able to use its high gross profit margins to support a higher level of spending than competitors. Now it must cut costs to remain profitable. **********An 85 percent increase in Macintosh shipments indicates Apple has succeeded in gaining share, but the company has not been able to reduce costs rapidly enough to accommodate the lower profits on each sale. Three weeks ago, Apple announced that in spite of increased revenues, earnings for the current quarter would fall below those of the comparable period a year ago. **********"We must restructure our business to match the economic realities of a market-share strategy," John Sculley, Apple's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. "Even though sales of our midrange and high-end computers, which provide us with higher gross margins, have grown somewhat faster than the industry, the growth is not enough to offset the impact of the dramatic product mix shift towards our low-end models." **********Last week, Apple introduced System 7, the long-awaited upgrading of the Macintosh operating system, which is expected to lift sales of Apple's more expensive machines. But analysts said the new operating system is not likely to increase sales significantly in the near term.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/11/world.main_headline: Italian Soccer: Where Titans and Egos Tread
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/11/world.print_headline: Italian Soccer: Where Titans and Egos Tread
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/11/world.body_text: **********When a big-name auto tycoon jousts in public with a renowned movie and stage director, and talk of free speech mingles with intimations of violence, what else could be stirring but the Italian soccer season? **********In a land that lists among its attributes passion, style and the acquisition of money, soccer provides a synthesis of all three -- the impassioned roar of the fans; the ballet of boot and braggadocio, and increasingly, the purchase, resale, gain and loss of players whose reputations are matched only by their staggering salaries. **********Between them, over the last few years, Silvio Berlusconi, a television and publishing magnate who owns the A. C. Milan team, and Gianni Agnelli, the head of Fiat and owner of Juventus of Turin, have spent a reported $69 million on new talent to bolster teams whose fortunes -- and team jerseys -- help advertise their bosses' other enterprises. It is the complete synergy of sports and salesmanship. **********Such is the intertwining of the game and the barons of big business that a leading commentator, Giorgio Bocca, wrote a column the other day comparing modern Italy's soccer to the practices of ancient Rome, where the "applause of the plebeians" celebrated the ascent of noblemen "to the higher levels of society." **********"The social merit and the historical curiosity of these chairmen," Mr. Bocca continued, "is that they have set back into this rundown republic islands of absolute monarchy." **********And like absolute monarchs, the club owners pay their champions handsomely, offering high sums to lure non-Italian talent. Sometimes there are unhappy results: earlier this year, for example, Diego Maradona, the Argentine World Cup star and captain of Italy's Napoli team, left Italy and Italian soccer after a urine test found traces of cocaine after a game. He has been charged with drug possession in Naples and in Argentina. **********Such is the prevalence of foreign players that a rule limits their number on any club to three. Rome's Lazio team bought an English star, Paul Gascoigne, for an undisclosed but presumably vast sum, but he suffered a knee injury before arriving and will not be able to play this season. Fights and Tear Gas **********This season's recent opening has been far less than exalted. First, when Fiorentina of Florence played the Juventus team, fighting between their fans and the police left 24 people hurt and 5 under arrest -- a common occurrence in a land where the police regularly use tear gas to break up fights between competing fanatics. **********Then things got a bit more arcane. Franco Zeffirelli, the film and opera director and a member of the Florentine' board of directors, made television remarks recalling a soccer disaster six years ago when 39 people, most of them Italians, died in riots at Heysel Stadium in Brussels before a European Cup final game between Liverpool of England and Juventus. **********Juventus, newspapers quoted him as saying, "had to climb over the dead bodies of the Heysel Stadium in win the cup." The Turin team, he said, was "a peril to football." **********That drew a riposte from Juventus's owner, Mr. Agnelli. "Zeffirelli," he said, "is a man of great talent." However, the Fiat industrialist said, Mr. Zeffirelli's comments seemed to show that "soccer can go to anyone's head." **********Other papers took up the cudgels. "Zeffirelli, Dr. Jekyll of Cinema, Mr. Hyde of Soccer," one headline said. **********As in some other countries, Italian soccer has become synonymous with crowd violence, so much so that a team in Modena offers its season ticket-holders free insurance against injury in the stadium. **********"If fans get punched, get bottles smashed on their heads, get bitten by dogs, they now have insurance," the club's president, Francesco Farina, said. His arrangement seemed to reflect the assumption, shared by others, that soccer violence is inevitable. **********"We hope there won't be violence," said Giorgio Chinaglia, a onetime player for Italy's national team and for the New York Cosmos. But "you cannot change society, he said, adding, "Why do people go to war? -- it's human nature."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/28/busin.main_headline: The Economy Lives, but Will It Ever Dance Again?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/28/busin.print_headline: The Economy Lives, but Will It Ever Dance Again?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/28/busin.body_text: **********It May Be a Recovery, But It's Less Than Robust **********The recession is over and the recovery is here, according to everyone from Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan to New York real estate agents. But hold the bubbly and break out the beer. Most economists expect the kind of slow, shuffling climb that will cause many to wonder if the recovery will stick around come Labor Day. **********"The indicators are mixed in any recovery," said Roger E. Brinner, chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill Inc., an economic consulting service. "The weaker the recovery, the greater the proportion of negative reports." Indeed, the news last week that the gross national product grew at a trivial 0.4 percent in the spring fanned fears that the recovery was sputtering. **********The economists at DRI/McGraw-Hill are a shade more upbeat than the blue-chip consensus of economic forecasters. Even so, they expect the economy to expand at a 3.5 percent rate over the next year -- a crawl compared with the 6.5 percent average for the first year of any post-war recovery. **********Three forces will probably hold down the pace of recovery. One is a hawkish Federal Reserve and an Administration that has not seemed inclined to bolster the economy with tax cuts or job programs. Another is the legacy of shaky debts from the overbuilding in many of the nation's commercial real estate markets. Finally, there is no 1980's-style consumer spending spree on the horizon: Households are forming more slowly and saving is already low.  A Battle of Nerves - The Consumers', That Is **********In retrospect, the first stirrings of a recovery began last winter, only a month or two after the Bush Administration, the Federal Reserve and the International Monetary Fund had declared a recession. Though the economy was free-falling, hundreds of thousands of jobs were disappearing each month and the headlines were dire, the forces that first tipped the economy into recession were beginning to recede. **********Alan Greenspan drove down short-term interest rates. Long-term rates eased as well. The money supply, which had barely increased during the fall, took off. Oil prices plunged, taking inflation down with them. The consumer price index, which spurted at a 10 percent rate in October, actually fell in March. **********Most important, the Persian Gulf war ended in victory for the United States. Foreigners snapped up the dollar and investors celebrated by sending the war-bludgeoned stock market back to old highs. **********Because this recession, more than any in memory, was brought on by a case of nerves, a brightening in consumer spirits was critical. Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait caused the biggest one-month plunge in American consumer confidence that had appeared the survey's history. When oil prices surged after the invasion, consumers expected a repeat of the 1973 and 1979 oil crises, a surge in inflation and deep recession. **********Their fears were self-fulfilling. Consumers stopped buying big-ticket items that could be postponed, namely houses and cars, and business panicked too, cutting production last fall at an even faster rate than sales were declining. The better economic mood, in essence, set the stage for a reversal of fortunes. And It's All Coming Out of the Saving Rate **********Consumers, who dragged the economy into the recession, appear to be pulling it out again. That's the indication from Friday's G.N.P. report for the second quarter. **********After falling for two consecutive quarters -- one of the worst retrenchments in post-World War II history -- consumer spending rose at a robust 3.6 percent. Outlays for big-ticket items jumped even faster, by 5.2 percent. "The mood shift led to strong consumer spending, particularly on cars, furniture and other durables whose purchases were postponed when consumers thought the sky was falling, " Mr. Brinner said. **********Spending bottomed out in January, the month the air war against Iraq began and oil prices plunged. Despite the fact that companies were cutting deeply into their payrolls, consumer spending rose in February as employees' worries about layoffs lifted. **********First to recover was home buying. As mortgage rates dipped below 10 percent, housing became more affordable than at almost any time in more than a decade. By February, buyers were straggling back to car dealers' lots, and the traffic really picked up when manufacturers started offering better deals in May and June. Consumers began buying a little more of everything else, too, though the pattern has been erratic from month to month. **********Initially, consumers were not spending because they were any flusher. One indication: Consumers, whose income was falling or stagnant, managed to do more shopping by saving even less of their take-home pay. The saving rate has slipped to less than 4 percent recently, from around 5 percent last summer. So When Will Mores Hands Be Put to Work? **********Consumers may have the will to keep on spending. All they need is the way -- fatter wallets. That will depend on the prospects for jobs and inflation. **********As in past recessions, the labor market has been the last to show signs of improvement. When consumers started spending again, businesses did not immediately rev up production and rehire laid-off workers. Instead, companies filled orders by dipping into stocks on shelves and in storerooms -- to the tune of a $21.2 billion annual rate this spring, not much less than in the fall and winter. Industrial production did not turn up until April. Even then, businesses relied on on overtime, not extra hands, to churn out the goods. **********Companies finally started to add to their payrolls, but not until May. Payroll employment swelled by 119,000 that month, the first increase since last summer, before falling by 50,000 in June. If that net expansion is not revised away in next week's employment report, said Mr. Brinner, the recession's final month may well turn out to have been April. **********A slow recovery is likely to mean, among other things, that job growth will be less robust than after the 1981-82 recession. DRI/McGraw-Hill expects the number of payroll jobs to grow just 1 percent next year, compared with 2.6 percent in 1989. And the forecasters do not see the unemployment rate, which reached 7 percent in June, dropping below 6 percent until after 1992. **********The number of jobs is likely to grow more slowly for another reason. As the continuing stream of layoff announcements shows, companies in the defense, computer and service industries from banking to airlines, are cutting payrolls, consolidating operations and pushing fewer workers to produce more products. **********The good news is that income, especially wages, has been edging up since March. And DRI/McGraw-Hill's forecast is for income after inflation to advance at an average 1.5 percent annual rate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/17/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation announced a $700 rebate on its stripped-down Dodge Shadow and Plymouth Sundance America models on Thursday, cutting the base price for Chrysler's least expensive car below $8,000. The Shadow and Sundance have a base sticker price of $8,184. The cash rebate drops the price to $7,484, among the least expensive new cars. The America models became the No. 3 United States auto maker's only entry in compact cars after it ended production of the Plymouth Horizon and Dodge Omni in February 1990. Chrysler also raised the cash back being offered on a variety of other models by $300 to $500. Financing rates ranging from 2.9 percent to 9.9 percent remain available in lieu of cash, the company said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/14/busin.body_text: **********After the worst and most perplexing Christmas season in more than a decade, American retailers face an agonizing quandary: Should they be cautious and conservative, or aggressive, hoping to force their luck? **********As industry leaders gather in New York today for the annual National Retail Federation meeting, caution seems to be the prevailing mood. **********Many executives say they would like to try more innovative merchandising and marketing and add new kinds of stores. But they quickly point out that now is not the time for drastic changes. They cite the economic uncertainty of the recession, the Middle East crisis and the slow-to-buy mentality of consumers. Stakes Are High **********Perhaps more than in any recent year, the stakes are high in 1991. In recent interviews, every economist and many retailers predicted that sales and earnings would show no gain, or a decline, in the first half of the year, assuming a Middle East war or prolonged stalemate. They said they expected a gradual improvement in the second half of the year, assuming a resolution in the Middle East. **********Retailers find some glimmers of hope in the prospect of lower interest rates. **********The urgency this year is that weak retailers and those with high debts stand to lose local or national market share unless they move to improve their marketing position with new operating concepts. **********"In such a situation, we can either roll over and play dead or be imaginative and aggressive," said Stanley Marcus, the former chairman of Neiman Marcus. "There really isn't much choice this year. There's a danger and hazard no matter what we do." **********Those that have been successful in the last few years, notably general discount merchants like Wal-Mart Stores, specialty outlets like the Circuit City Stores electronics chain and clothing stores like the Limited, have not hesitated to announce strong expansion plans. **********These chains plan to open new stores or make acquisitions to increase the size of their existing units or enter new markets. **********That will make it much harder for several giant retailers already under severe pressure. These include Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, which last week announced it was eliminating 21,000 jobs to cut expenses; Federated Department Stores and the Allied Stores Corporation, two major chains now in voluntary bankruptcy; R. H. Macy & Company, which has been selling equity to reduce debt, and Ames Department Stores, a discounter that is in voluntary bankruptcy. Altered Priorities **********Are there culprits for retailing's distress? One of America's most renowned designers, Geoffrey Beene, criticized the industry's merger and acquisition binge, saying the result had altered priorities to "cater to owners and creditors, not to the customers." **********For now, Kenneth A. Macke, chairman and chief executive of the Dayton Hudson Corporation of Minneapolis, said: "It is a time to execute better all that we do rather than a time for uniqueness. The consumer is restless and has expectations of us that we can't afford to ignore in terms of service, being in stock on desirable goods and offering fair prices. We expect a tough first half and then a gradual pickup. But we are planning to be very cautious so that we don't have a lot of leftover inventory." **********That strategy means strict control over how much and what style of merchandise to order, even to the point of risking running short on some items that customers want. **********But stores that can afford to are trying new concepts in merchandising. Circuit City plans to open many more of its small Impulse stores that sell smaller-size electronics items. **********People who follow the industry say it seems clear that the more "focused" retailer fared the best in 1990 and in the holiday season. For retailers, focused means presenting a clear picture of merchandise and service so that their store becomes a destination for consumers rather than a place to wander into. **********Despite a 1990 that many retailers would rather forget, there were still several successes. Among them was Montgomery Ward, which expects to report record profits for 1990. Executives there mentioned their strategy for selling a four-head videocassette recorder for $248, the amount usually charged for a two-head machine that does not have comparable video or audio quality. **********As Bernard Brennan, Ward's chairman, put it: "This was a way we could focus on particular merchandise. We sat down with some VCR producers, showed them our specs and guaranteed a large order. Last year, we sold almost $40 million worth of those recorders, or 160,000 units. That was about 3 percent of the total U.S. VCR market in sales." **********For 1991, one potentially promising new retailing move is in the works by Frederick Atkins Inc., the New York-based research-merchandising organization owned by 29 large retail chains. It has developed what it calls an environmentally friendly line of sportswear called "Clean Clothes," which is expected to be sold in stores early next month. This 400-item line, which officials hope will tap the growing interest in ecology, is made of all-cotton fabrics with no synthetics. Paper wrappings are recyclable and buttons are made of wood rather than plastic. **********Lee Abraham, chairman of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, a large research-merchandising arm in New York owned by large retailers, said, "One of my chief concerns is that given the current, economic conditions, retailers may resist investing in the technology they need to move forward strategically."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/world.main_headline: The Air or the Ground: A Debate Over Strategy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: STRATEGY; The Air or the Ground: A Debate Over Strategy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/world.body_text: **********With the American Air Force trying to destroy Iraq's military abilities, a debate is developing in Washington over whether the United States should resort to a ground war to drive the Iraqis from Kuwait, considering the large number of American casualties that could result. **********For now this debate appears to be confined to members of Congress and experts outside the Bush Administration. The Administration itself still seems committed to a strategy of using air power first to destroy as much of Iraq's military potential as possible, to weaken the Iraqi Army in Kuwait and sever its communications links with Baghdad, and then to use American, Arab and European ground troops to drive the Iraqis out of Kuwait. **********But this approach is being criticized in two different arguments, and the criticism is mounting each day. One argument is purely military. It contends that over time, air power can force an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait -- even though historically no war has ever been won from the air alone. **********For instance, Edward N. Luttwak, a military historian at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, argues that the air force should focus on bombing all roads, supply lines and supply trucks that connect southern Iraq with the 500,000-strong Iraqi garrison in Kuwait. Eventually, Mr. Luttwak says, the Iraqis will be starved into leaving, since Kuwait is all desert and supplies of food and water for Iraqi troops there are limited; it just takes patience and concentrated bombing of supply lines. Lesson of History **********"There are thousands of Iraqi troops in Kuwait," Mr. Luttwak said. "They require hundreds of trucks each day just to feed them. The war that can force a withdrawal from Kuwait is the air war that attacks those trucks." **********Those who oppose this strategy, Mr. Luttwak said, claim that the Iraqis in Kuwait have stored months of supplies. **********"My answer to that," he said, "is that I don't believe it is true, but even if it is, I would rather bomb them for months from the air rather than have thousands of Americans coming home in wheelchairs." **********Eliot A. Cohen, a professor of strategic studies at the Johns Hopkins School for Advanced International Studies, also argues that an air war alone can produce an Iraqi withdrawal, even though the lesson of history is otherwise. Mr. Cohen said this war is unique because of the scale of the air power deployed, the accuracy of the bombs and the ability of allied air forces to fly at night on a large scale. Over time, he argues, such air power is capable of paralyzing life in Iraq, or administering such a pounding that the Iraqis will have to withdraw from Kuwait. More Even Footing on Ground **********There are two other military reasons for relying on air power rather than a ground campaign, Mr. Cohen maintains. First, it is politically essential for the future standing of America and its allies in the Arab world that the coalition appear to be pummeling the Iraqis without meeting much resistance. The minute a ground war begins, the two sides will be on a much more equal footing and the casualty totals will be much closer. **********Second, it is easier to start a ground war than it is to finish it. Even if the Iraqis are driven from Kuwait, what if they continue shelling Kuwait from the Iraqi side of the border, Mr. Cohen asks. Does the United States really want to be involved in a potential occupation of southern Iraq? **********The other emerging argument against a ground war in Kuwait is a political one. It contends that America's real vital interest in the gulf is destroying Iraq's military potential so that it will not be able to threaten any of its neighbors for the forseeable future. This objective can be achieved at a relatively low cost through air power and sustained bombings. Once it is, Iraq's garrison in Kuwait should be ignored. It is not of vital interest to the United States, the argument goes, to restore the Emir of Kuwait to his throne, which might be achieved only through a very costly ground war. **********"When we start having ground losses and Americans start seeing the Emir of Kuwait and his 80 wives on television and we see the Kuwaiti and Saudi students driving fancy cars at our local community colleges, a lot of people in this country are going to be very unhappy," said Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado and a member of the House Armed Services Committee. "People understand that Saddam Hussein is a threat, that he has an enormous amount of weapons. But restoring the Emir, no, no, no." 'Starve Them Out' **********Arthur Schlesinger Jr., a critic of the Administration's gulf strategy from the beginning, said that now that the United States has committed itself to war, it should adopt a strategy that will result in the fewest casulaties. **********"I am against the whole damn thing," Mr. Schlesinger said. "I don't think anything out there is worth the life of a single American soldier. But if we have to do something, I prefer to rely on air power and a blockade to starve them out." **********While Administration officials say such arguments are made by Democrats who always oppose any use of force, Republican lawmakers are taking them more seriously. **********For instance, after being briefed by the Pentagon on the war effort, the House minority leader, Robert H. Michel, a co-sponsor of the House resolution authorizing the use of force, said on Monday that considering the high cost of a ground war in Kuwait, he would not press the President to take up that option quickly.
