https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/05/world.main_headline: P.L.O. and Lebanon Reach an Accord
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/05/world.print_headline: P.L.O. and Lebanon Reach an Accord
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/05/world.body_text: **********Palestinian guerrillas in the south of Lebanon agreed today to stop fighting army forces and turn over their heavy weapons to the authorities, a Government official and a Palestine Liberation Organization representative said. **********"The war is over and agreement has been reached with our Palestinian brothers," Abdullah al-Amin, a Cabinet minister without portfolio, said today of the agreement, which followed two days of fierce fighting around Sidon, a port 25 miles south of Beirut. **********Zaid Wehbeh, the P.L.O.'s highest-ranking representative in Lebanon, said "the retreat is for the common national interest." The fighters will also give up their arms, the two men said. **********The agreement is a major step in the attempt by the Syrian-backed Lebanese Government to take control of all of Lebanon after the fragmentation of 16 years of civil war. It also strengthens the attempt by the Government of President Elias Hrawi to get Israel to pull out of the strip of southern Lebanese territory that it has occupied. Israel says it needs the area as a buffer against attacks by P.L.O. guerrillas.  P.L.O. Lost Beirut Bases in '82 **********The P.L.O. has had a strong military and political presence in Lebanon for two decades. The P.L.O. fighters lost their bases in Beirut and southern Lebanon after Israel invaded Lebanon in 1982, but they regrouped in Sidon. **********[ In Israel, a senior Israeli military official confirmed that the P.L.O. had told the Lebanese Army it intended "to give up its heavy weapons." But the official said Israel had no more details. **********[ Uri Lubrani, the Defense Ministry's coordinator of activities in Lebanon, said of the Lebanese, "They know it is not our intention to stay here for eternity, but to preserve our interests, and as long as our interests make it necessary we will stay." ] **********Despite the announcement of understanding, sporadic shooting continued this evening between army positions and guerrillas entrenched in two Sidon Palestinian districts, Ain Hilwe and Mieh Mieh. **********The police said that as many as 80 people had been killed since large clashes broke out between Lebanese regular troops and P.L.O. fighters last Monday. Among the dead were 65 guerrillas, three Lebanese soldiers and the rest civilians, according to the police. How the Fighting Began **********The fighting began when Palestinian gunmen, acting on orders from their command in the Tunisian capital of Tunis, decided to oppose the army deployment and refused to pull out of their bases peacefully. By reversing its attitude today, the P.L.O. appeared to have yielded. **********[ In a telephone interview from Tunis, Bassam Abu Sharif, a senior adviser to Yasir Arafat, said of Lebanon, "We didn't think this was a necessary battle for us." Mr. Abu Sharif said that the organization, in agreeing for the first time since 1982 to pull out some of its forces from Lebanon, wanted to "focus our attention and that of the world on the Middle East peace process that is under way and not detract from it."  ] **********Both the Lebanese Government and the P.L.O. agreed that the Palestinian fighters would collect their heavy and medium-size weapons and hand them over, Mr. Amin said, without specifying to whom the arms would be given. Mr. Wehbeh said guerrilla weapons would be placed in trust with Sidon leaders. Security officials said that the P.L.O.'s big guns would be stored for now and then shipped out of Lebanon.  Jobs Opened to Palestinians **********The Government in Beirut also told 400,000 Palestinian civilians living in the country that restrictions on their freedom to hold jobs have been lifted. **********The move is widely seen as an inducement for the Palestinians to accept a back seat to the new national order, under which the central Government in Beirut has been consolidating its powers against armed factions that had turned Lebanon into a patchwork of fiefdoms. **********A Lebanese Government official said the Government would not enter into any further agreements like one concluded with Mr. Arafat in November 1969, which allowed the P.L.O. to establish guerrilla bases in southern Lebanon. The bases were used as jumping-off grounds to cross into northern Israel. **********Mr. Arafat is believed to have enlisted the help of Algeria to mediate the conflict with the Government here. The Algerian Foreign Minister, Lakhdar Ibrahimi, is expected to visit Beirut and Damascus soon for talks. President Chadli Benjedid decided to send Mr. Ibrahimi on the Lebanese mission after meeting with Mr. Arafat in Algiers three days ago. **********The Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak, and the Libyan leader, Muammar el-Qaddafi, meeting in Cairo, said today that they would send a joint delegation to Beirut to meet with President Hrawi.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/01/world.main_headline: Soviets Brace for Less of Less On Eve of Big Price Increases
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/01/world.print_headline: Soviets Brace for Less of Less On Eve of Big Price Increases
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/01/world.body_text: **********Consumer prices across the Soviet Union will soar by an average of 250 percent on Tuesday as the Government begins its long-awaited price reform. Outside the Kremlin, there are not many who believe that the measure will bring more than another spiral of misery. **********The increases, announced on March 19, have long been considered a prerequisite for authentic economic change in the Soviet Union, where centrally set prices long ago lost any relation to the cost of producing the goods. **********But the increases come at a time when many Soviet citizens have lost faith in President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of economic and social restructuring, and they risk being seen as another futile imposition of authority by the central Government. The Usual Skepticism **********Independent economists have voiced skepticism that the increases, in the absence of other moves toward a free market, will have a long-term effect. In two to four months, they predict, inflation and Government spending will swallow up benefits, restoring and perhaps worsening shortages. **********Predictably, people have reacted by hoarding what few goods reach the state stores, emptying shelves even of basic items like salt. For days, parents have formed long lines to buy children's clothing, worrying that it will be unaffordable by the time their children outgrow what they wear now. **********The effect of the new prices will be widespread. The cost of a little more than two pounds of beef will rise from two rubles to seven, and the cost of the same amount of flour will rise from 46 kopecks to 1.40 rubles. A man's suit will go from 107 rubles to 245; a convertible sofa from 188 rubles to 346, and a color television from 755 rubles to 1,218. What's a Ruble Worth? **********At the exchange rate for tourists, a ruble is traded at 6 to the dollar, but on the black market the rate ranges up to 35 rubles to the dollar. A well-paid worker earns about 600 rubles a month, while employees of independent cooperatives generally make in excess of 1,000 rubles. **********To soften the blow of the increases, the Kremlin has promised to give raises of 60 percent to workers at state-owned enterprises and to lift the value of savings accounts at state banks by 40 percent. But most of the new savings have been frozen until 1994, when inflation should eat up most of the increase. The effect for the majority of wage-earning Russians, therefore, will be diminished savings and a sharp drop in buying power. **********The day-to-day effect of the increases, however, is hard to guage. For one thing, Government edicts spelling out the changes raise as many questions as they answer. **********Most people assume that the Government has set aside supplies of products to put on the market immediately after prices go up, to ease the shock and to create the illusion that they are having an immediate effect.  Back-Door Deals **********Everyone agrees that the increases will be painful and confusing. But in a system where survival requires constant improvising and back-door deals, the real effects of the change will not become evident for some time. **********Very few people in this country live entirely from the shelves of state-run stores, where finding anything has come to be regarded as a stroke of luck. Almost all Russians supplement the few products they find there through a variety of channels -- "through the back" from store directors; at commercial prices at cooperative stores; at freely negotiated prices at farmers' markets; on the black market, or through their own labor. **********The cost of beef at a farmers' markets, where the price is set by demand, already goes for 25 to 30 rubles a kilogram, which is a little more than two pounds. Many people manage to pick up several more pounds of beef from the cafeteria at their work places for about three rubles a kilogram. How these other prices react to the official price rise is yet to be seen. **********To further complicate matters, methods of distribution differ widely from city to city and region to region. In Moscow, for example, only vodka, cigarettes and sugar are rationed, but residents must show cards establishing their addresses to shop in certain stores. In Leningrad, by contrast, meat and most other staples are distributed through ration coupons. **********Skepticism is widespread. Kommersant, the respected weekly of the Union of Cooperatives, published a review of the price project under the headline, "Price Reform: Heaven Forbid That It Be the Last One." **********It predicted that the initial effect of the measure will be to reduce consumer sales by 20 to 25 percent as people delve into their hoarded supplies and come to grips with the new prices. The reduction in spending money will also curtail private enterprise, creating more demand for short-term bank credits, it said. **********But in the long run, the paper argued, the shock of the new prices will force the Government to increase its spending, thus undermining the effects of the reform. **********Writing in Moscow News, two economists, Andrei Vavilov and Oleg Vyugin, agreed that the price increases could bring a month or two of relative prosperity, but beyond that, they said, they suggested "no hope for the market's long-term stabilization." **********The only way to avoid hyperinflation, they said, was if the April increases were to become the first step on the way to "radical reform," including a further freeing of prices, extensive privatization and encouragement of free enterprise. **********Out in the streets, the arguments were less over economic effects than the waning credibility of perestroika. A year ago, the Government of then-Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov had been compelled to abandon price increases in the face of a popular outcry. **********Now, Mr. Gorbachev's standing is at a low, and Mr. Ryzhkov's successor as Prime Minister, Valentin Pavlov, had already antagonized citizens with the clumsy withdrawal of large ruble bills last month. Strikes at coal mines were spreading, and the major demand was the ouster of the central Government, **********In this context, the price rises were viewed as another maneuver by the Kremlin that was likely to produce more hardship than benefit. A common assumption in the streets was that the reform had been set for Tuesday instead of Monday so that it would not fall on April Fool's Day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/19/world.main_headline: Europeans Continue to Favor More Generous Financial Help to Soviets
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/19/world.print_headline: Europeans Continue to Favor More Generous Financial Help to Soviets
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/19/world.body_text: **********France, Germany and Italy continued to make clear today that they were willing to go further than their allies in providing direct Western involvement in rescuing the Soviet economy. **********At this week's London summit meeting, these three European countries went along with the the joint statement agreed to by the United States, Britain, Canada and Japan, which offerred Moscow new association with international financial institutions, technical assistance and greater market access, but fell short of what President Mikhail S, Gorbachev had wanted. But the three Continental powers also have stressed they wanted to do more than their their partners in the Group of Seven industrial powers. **********"We formed a sub-group that carried out a job of persuasion," one French official said, noting that France's President Francois Mitterrand, Germany's Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Italy's Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti lunched privately before Mr. Gorbachev met the Group of Seven. **********The official added that, while as host of the summit meeting, Prime Minister John Major of Britain was intent on building a consensus among the Group of Seven, he also left no doubt that he leaned towards the more flexible approach favored by the other three European leaders, but had to go along with the less generous approach favored particularly by Washington. **********The United States has repeatedly stressed that aid should be limited until the Soviet Union has actually taken the hard political moves to take it into a more market-oriented economy. It is always possible, of course, that President Bush, when he goes to Moscow at the end of the month for a summit meeting with Mr. Gorbachev, may loosen up on the question, but American officials say that beyond going ahead with seeking most-favored-nation tariff treatment for Moscow, it it unlikely that Washington will go beyond what was agreed to in London. **********Political experts noted that, because of their proximity to the Soviet Union, the European members of the Group of Seven believe the collapse of Mr. Gorbachev's liberalization effort would affect them much more severely than it would the United States, Japan and Canada.  Early Recognition of Gorbachev **********They also recalled that, after Mr. Gorbachev took office in 1985, Britain, France and Germany were far quicker than Washington in recognizing, in the words of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, that they could "do business" with him. **********Further, no less than President Bush, Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Kohl both believe they have a special relationship with Mr. Gorbachev, with the German leader particularly grateful that he permitted the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe and accepted the unification of Germany. **********France, Germany and Italy backed early Soviet entry to the International Monetary Fund as a full member -- instead of an undefined period of associate membership -- as well as more credit from a new European Development Bank. They were blocked by the United States, Japan and Canada.  Follow-Up in Moscow **********But they considered it a victory that the relationship with Moscow was institutionalized through annual meetings between the rotating president of the Group of Seven and the Soviet President. And they noted that finance ministers from the Seven will soon travel to Moscow for further talks. **********Still more important for Mr. Gorbachev, the three governments have stressed that the London summit is merely the first step. Refering to the decision to give Moscow only associate membership of the I.M.F., Mr. Andreotti noted today: "The problem is not closed of course." **********In Bonn, while German newspapers described the summit as a personal failure for Mr. Kohl, Germany's Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said the Group of Seven had "begun a process which would have as its conclusion the full integration of the Soviet Union in the world economy." **********On Wednesday, Mr. Mitterrand went out of his way to praise Mr. Gorbachev and noted that, when it comes to helping Moscow, "France belongs to those who believe it is better to assume the risk now than to accept the alternative risk that could lead the experience to failure." **********French officials said that the European powers had no plan to launch an independent initiative to step up aid for the Soviet Union, but would continue to work in that direction in other forums, including the 12-nation European Community and international financial organizations. **********The London summit's failure to promise direct aid to Moscow, however, was seen as a setback for Germany. Since the Germans currently provide around 60 percent of all Western aid to the Soviet Union, Mr. Kohl had hoped to persuade his Group of Seven partners to assume a greater share of this burden.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/busin.main_headline: Business and Health; Reshaping Laws On Insurance
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/busin.print_headline: Business and Health; Reshaping Laws On Insurance
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/busin.body_text: **********HEALTH insurers are rushing to formulate their own plans for making coverage available to small businesses and individuals. The insurers hope to shape new laws being drafted that will crack down on practices like the blacklisting of certain occupations, red-lining of neighborhoods and price gouging. **********But the commercial insurers and Blue Cross and Blue Shield groups are fighting one another on some issues. Under the commercial companies' plan, the 10 largest insurers of small groups in each state would pay for a backup reinsurance pool to help cover high-risk customers. But some Blue Cross groups already cover all applicants, albeit at high premiums. So the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association says participation in reinsurance pools should not be compulsory in every state. **********Under both the Blue Cross and the commercial proposals, coverage would be offered to all applicants, regardless of health status, occupation or geographic location. For those labeled as high risks, premiums could still be 50 percent higher than for others. That would be progress, the insurers say, compared with 400 percent differentials charged by some companies. **********The Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group for 300 commercial insurers, is pushing a package with reinsurance in New Jersey, Minnesota and Maine and says it will probably be offered soon in Ohio and Wisconsin. "These are proposals that would greatly restrict our ability to make money in the small group market," said Carl Schramm, the association president. **********But in a policy called open enrollment, Blue Cross plans already accept all comers in 13 states and the District of Columbia. In most cases, they charge the same rates, regardless of occupation or health status, which is called community rating. These associations object to helping the commercial companies with the reinsurance plan. **********Individuals in New York state can obtain Blue Cross coverage at any time, said Albert A. Cardone, chairman of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield. Although new members are not covered during the first 11 months for pre-existing conditions, they are fully covered afterward, even for AIDS. But Empire has stopped covering some professional associations, and their members must now pay the individual rates, which are higher. "Everybody has health insurance accessible to them," Mr. Cardone said. "The problem is they can't all afford it." **********The reinsurance idea is being tested in Connecticut, where the pool will begin on May 1. Connecticut Blue Cross officials said the new law would actually force the association to start "medical underwriting" for the first time, to stay competitive. In medical underwriting, higher premiums are charged to those who have had expensive health problems. **********Mary Nell Lehnhard, a national Blue Cross vice president, said the Connecticut law might raise the cost of all health insurance. "Twenty percent of the people enrolled tpically incur about 80 percent of the costs," she said. "If costs for the 20 percent are reduced, they will have to be raised quickly for a lot of people, which could cause political problems." The issue is being debated by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. The group is drafting a model law, to be recommended to legislatures and regulators in the 50 states. **********In Congress, Pete Stark, chairman of the health subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee, said he favored a bill that would restore tax exemption to Blue Cross plans that offer open enrollment and community rating. **********Only 21 of the 73 Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans might qualify for tax exemption under the bill, which is sponsored by Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan. But the national Blue Cross supports it. The measure will probably be part of the next tax package. **********Mr. Stark is considering taking the Rangel approach a step further. Arguing that the industry's proposals for change would not reach enough of the 37 million uninsured Americans, Mr. Stark said he was thinking of requiring all insurers to offer open enrollment and community rating. The new rules would also apply to self-insured employers, who are exempt from many regulations under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. **********Mr. Stark's plan was criticized by insurance industry spokesmen. "Mr. Stark is in pursuit of a romantic ideal," said Mr. Schramm of the health insurance association. Health-cost inflation would "jump to over 20 percent a year," he said, if rates could not be tied to medical histories. Bernard R. Tresnowski, president of national Blue Cross and Blue Shield, said, "We've got to be able to take demographic factors into account, particularly age."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/busin.main_headline: Businesses Plan a Slim 3% Rise in Spending
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/busin.print_headline: Businesses Plan a Slim 3% Rise in Spending
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/busin.body_text: **********Businesses in the United States plan to increase their investment spending by just 3 percent this year, the smallest rise in five years, the Government reported today. **********Analysts said the recession, in trimming consumer demand, had reduced available cash as well as any immediate need for new plants and equipment. **********The Commerce Department said that a survey conducted in April and May found businesses planning to spend $540.1 billion for expansion and modernization, up from a record $524.2 billion in 1990. **********Many analysts had expected capital spending to slow this year because of the recession. **********The Commerce Department said its survey showed that capital spending rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter after increasing six-tenths of 1 percent in the previous three months. It is expected to rise 1.7 percent in the second quarter, 1.8 percent in the third and five-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth. **********As the effects of the recession fade, plant and equipment spending "will show pretty good growth in 1992," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting organization. **********Still, any increase this year would help stimulate the economy. In addition, spending to replace aging plants and equipment and expand operations helps to increase productivity, an important factor in view of increasingly strong competition from abroad. Productivity is defined as output per hours worked. **********Productivity is also considered vital to improving the nation's standard of living without increasing inflation. Productivity rose just three-tenths of 1 percent at an annual rate in the first quarter of 1991, well below the average growth of 1.6 percent a year between 1982 and 1989. **********Capital investment has risen during each of the last four years, although growth slowed to just 4.5 percent in 1990 as the economy began its downturn. **********Spending had surged by 10.4 percent in 1989 and 9.5 percent in 1988 after rebounding by 3.1 percent in 1987 from a decline of 4.1 percent in 1986. **********Before adjusting for inflation, the survey projected a 2.7 percent rise in business investment, to $547.2 billion, after gains of 5 percent in 1990 and 11.4 percent a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/06/world.main_headline: AFTER THE WAR: Saudi Arabia; Saudi King Says Iraq's President Is Facing the Fate of 'All Tyrants'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/06/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: Saudi Arabia; Saudi King Says Iraq's President Is Facing the Fate of 'All Tyrants'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/06/world.body_text: **********In his first postwar policy declaration, King Fahd took a severe line toward President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today, accusing him of deception and predicting that he would meet with an ominous end as "all tyrants" in the Arab world have before him. **********He asserted that Saudi Arabia was certain that it had been next in line after Kuwait as a potential victim of Iraqi occupation and said that the war was a "good lesson" for those in the Arab world who commit aggression against other Arab nations. **********He said that Saudi Arabia "lost nothing" in the war and that the United States and all the other countries that came to its assistance will now be pulling their armed forces back home "as it has been agreed to from the start."  'The Rule of God' **********In a speech to leaders of the Muslim religious establishment here, the King also reiterated Saudi Arabia's commitment to "follow the rule of God and the Koran" in its domestic policies, suggesting that some Saudis' expectations of liberalization may be premature. **********Recounting an anecdote told to him by the Emir of Kuwait, the King said that the Emir was told jokingly by Mr. Hussein months before the invasion last August that he would make a "surprise" visit to him. **********The King said that this indicated that the Iraqi President had long planned to invade Kuwait. **********He also said that the Iraqi President's ambitions has always been to dominate not only Kuwait but eventually all Arab countries, thus seemingly suggesting that there will be little room for resuming friendly ties with Iraq as long as Mr. Hussein rules the country. **********King Fahd said that if Iraq's assertions were correct that Kuwait belonged to it because of historic geographical claims, then parts of Iraq itself should belong to Turkey, particularly the oil-producing region of Mosul. **********"If we want to split countries, then it must be said that Mosul is not part of Iraq. We must say that Iraq used to consist of only Basra and Baghdad," the King said. **********He said he categorically refused to meet with Mr. Hussein after he invaded Kuwait despite suggestions from other Arab leaders who told him that a meeting with the Iraqi president might resolve the crisis. **********"I know Saddam and I know since 1975 that he is only interested in media publicity so my position was that if he wants to talk to me it is only for this purpose. I said if he wants to talk to me let him put it down in writing that he will leave Kuwait without conditions, then I will talk to him," the King said, adding that in the end he refused such requests because "I know Saddam and Saddam's words."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/06/world.main_headline: White House Accepts Congress Terms for Peru Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/06/world.print_headline: White House Accepts Congress Terms for Peru Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/06/world.body_text: **********The Administration has reluctantly accepted cuts and conditions set by Congress on $34.9 million in military aid to Peru, delaying the arrival of American military trainers and demanding the Peruvian military to improve its human rights performance, officials say. **********The agreement opens the way to a gradual increase in United States involvement in Peru's war against the Maoist guerrillas known as Shining Path, an effort the Administration says is vital for its own war on drugs. Shining Path rebels protect cocaine growers and traffickers in areas they control and attack social workers who try to train coca farmers to cultivate other crops, American officials said. **********The Administration decision to go along with the Congressional conditions ended a seven-week stalemate, during which several Congressional committees froze most of the Administration's aid program for Peru. Plans to Cut $10 Million **********In letters to the State Department, Congressional leaders said they intended to cut $10 million of the Administration's military request and make the remaining $24.9 million conditional on the purging of human rights violators from Peru's security forces, the creation of a central registry of all prisoners held by the authorities and the granting of access to military prisons to international human rights monitors and Peruvian judicial officials. **********Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger replied in a letter to Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, that "the Administration reluctantly accepts the congressionally imposed conditions." But Mr. Eagleburger suggested that the Administration would hold Congress responsible if the war on drugs in Peru fails. **********"We believe that eliminating major elements of security assistance will seriously damage our counternarcotics program in the Andean region," Mr. Eagleburger wrote. "Without adequate security, Peruvian and other aid workers, including Americans, are at risk." Army-Police Coordination **********The Administration originally planned to send dozens of trainers, including Special Forces and Navy personnel, to train two combat battalions, to create river patrols and to refurbish Peruvian army helicopters and air force combat jets. The trainers were to concentrate on improving coordination between the army and police in antidrug operations. The Congressional action will cut the program intended to train the two battalions. **********Some members of Congress said the Peruvian Army, which is regarded by some human rights monitors as having one of the worst records of torture and murder of any military in Latin America, does not deserve American assistance. But several in Congress softened their opposition to military aid for Peru when President Alberto K. Fujimori visited Washington last month and promised to improve his country's human rights record. **********State Department officials said they still needed to meet with Congressional leaders to work out the details of the conditions and the timing of sending the American trainers. Some members of Congress have urged that the training of Peruvian units be done in the United States and not in Peru, to protect American lives and limit American involvement in the war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/24/world.body_text: **********Sir Pao Yue-kong, a Shanghai bank clerk who became one of the world's richest men, died yesterday at his home in Hong Kong after a two-year battle with asthma, a family spokesman said. He was 72 years old. **********Mr. Pao, who was known by the Anglicized version of his name, Y. K. Pao, had several careers. He was a banker in Shanghai until just before the Communist takeover of China in 1949. He fled to Hong Kong and opened an import and export business. **********In 1955 he moved to shipping with a secondhand coal-burning vessel. By 1980 he owned 200 vessels. When the market for tankers plunged, he sold ships, reducing his fleet to about 100 while improving his financial condition. He called the company World-Wide Shipping and Wharf Holdings. **********In 1976 Aristotle S. Onassis and his daughter, Christina, met Mr. Pao in New York to see whether they could learn some of his secrets of success. The entrepreneur talked freely. "Take a thin profit," he said, "and never accept an escalation clause in a shipbuilding contract." From City of Traders **********Forbes Magazine recently estimated Mr. Pao's worth at $1.3 billion. He reportedly never carried money, but preferred to borrow from his chauffeur. **********Mr. Pao was born in Ningbo, a city 100 miles south of Shanghai known for producing shrewd, hard-driving traders. "No market is without Ningbo traders," is an old Chinese saying, and nowhere does it apply more accurately than in Hong Kong. Thousands of Ningbo executives were said to have fled to Hong Kong in advance of the Communists. Today they make up a strong and clannish group of prosperous entrepreneurs. **********Mr. Pao kept close contacts with Ningbo and China, anticipating Hong Kong's absorption into China in 1997.  Beijing made him vice chairman of a committee to draft the basic law under which the territory will be governed when China takes over. **********"Sir Y. K. Pao was one of Hong Kong's leading businessmen and, perhaps, the first to achieve a truly international stature," the colony's Governor, Sir David Wilson, said yesterday.  Jump Rope and Pools **********Mr. Pao had interests in Hong Kong property through his Hongkong and Kowloon Wharf Company. At one point he had a major position in Standard Chartered P.L.C., Britain's fifth-largest bank. **********He was a fitness enthusiast who carried a jump rope in his luggage and tried to stay at hotels with swimming pools. He lived modestly in the Deep Water Bay area of Hong Kong. When Mr. Pao retired in 1986, his son-in-law, Peter Woo, was appointed to succeed him as chairman of World-Wide Shipping and of Kowloon Wharf Holdings. **********Survivors include his wife, Lady Pao; 4 daughters and 10 grandchildren.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/01/busin.main_headline: Bush Plan On Lenders Is Disclosed
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/01/busin.print_headline: Bush Plan On Lenders Is Disclosed
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/01/busin.body_text: **********The Bush Administration today disclosed the details of its plan for a significant increase in the supervision of the Government-sponsored companies that help finance home purchases, higher education and agriculture. **********"The whole purpose here is to avoid another financial mess," said Jerome H. Powell, an assistant Treasury Secretary, referring to the collapse of the Government-sponsored enterprise that protected depositors at savings and loan associations. That collapse will cost taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars. **********In a report to Congress, Treasury officials said an independent bureau should be set up within the Department of Housing and Urban Development to oversee the companies that help finance one in every four residential mortgages. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac **********The companies are the Federal National Mortgage Assocation, known as Fannie Mae, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, which have posted record profits in the last year. **********They are now overseen by fewer than a half-dozen officials at the housing agency, whose authority to control the companies is in dispute, and who insist they are unable to control or monitor the companies effectively. **********The proposed bureau would have the authority to set more stringent regulatory standards and capital levels, which is the cushion that could be drawn upon should financial difficulties occur. Its director would be appointed by the President, with the consent of the Senate, and would report to the Housing Secretary. Tougher Plan Avoided **********The recommendation stops short of a more stringent proposal, the removal of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac from agency supervision to a different regulatory body with greater independence. **********The idea had been considered by the Treasury through last week, and was only recently dropped after being vetoed by the officials at the White House and Office of Management and Budget, which by some accounts had been heavily lobbied by representatives of the Government enterprises. But an independent regulatory agency for the enterprises will soon be recommended by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, which has also been studying the Government-backed lenders. **********The Treasury also recommended tighter control over the other leading Government-sponsored enterprises, or "G.S.E.'s" -- the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, the Federal Agriculture Mortgage Corporation, or Farmer Mac, the Farm Credit System and the Federal Home Loan Bank System. No Imminent Financial Threat **********Treasury officials and independent auditors have emphasized that none of the companies, which hold implicit and explicit Government guarantees of more than $1 trillion, pose an imminent financial threat to the Federal budget. But the report also states that the Government cannot adequately control or monitor the companies now, and that their chance of encountering "financial difficulty is more than a hypothetical possibility." **********Executives at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac said that they were studying the report, which was issued late in the day, but that in general they supported its conclusions, particularly those that would continue to put them under the Department of Housing and Urban Development. **********"In general, our initial reaction is very positive," said David R. Jeffers, a Fannie Mae spokesman. "We've always said we prefer to be under H.U.D. A housing G.S.E. should be regulated by a regulator that has an understanding of housing." **********Leland C. Brendsel, Freddie Mac's chairman and chief executive, said: "We have a responsibility to our stockholders, to our customers, and to the nation's homeowners, and that's what drives this company. It's a mistake to think it is regulation or law that is the only mechanism to ensure responsible behavior."  S.& P. Rates Agencies **********As part of Treasury's report, the Standard & Poor's Corporation assessed the likelihood that a Government-sponsored enterprise might not be able to meet its future obligations from its own resources. Based on the assessment, S.& P. assigned the Farm Credit System a BB rating, or speculative grade; the Federal Home Loan Bank System and Sallie Mae AAA, or top grade; Freddie Mac A+, or medium grade, and Fannie Mae A-, or medium grade. **********The ratings do not supersede the triple-A ratings on the securities of most of the Government-sponsored enterprises, but were an exercise intended to determine the risks to the Government now. **********The Treasury report, which provides the basis for legislation that Mr. Powell, the assistant Treasury Secretary, said would be introduced shortly, noted that the Bush Administration's proposed regulatory structure was intended to avoid the problem of the regulators being "captured" by the entities they regulate, particularly if the enterprises and the Government departments become involved in the same projects.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/13/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Communist Party's top watchdog body today ordered an investigation of former Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze because of his public appeals for creation of a broad democratic party to champion reform. **********The order for a "party investigation" was issued by the Presidium of the party's Control Commission, its chief body for enforcing discipline. **********The Soviet press agency Tass said the investigation resulted from Monday's "public comments of Shevardnadze, a member of the party's Central Committee, on the necessity of a creating a democratic party to act 'parallel to the Communist Party.' " **********Mr. Shevardnadze, in Vienna, discounted the inquiry. "It was a reaction I expected," he said later today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/world.main_headline: U.S. Tells of Retaliation Plan That the Israelis Abandoned
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: ISRAEL; U.S. Tells of Retaliation Plan That the Israelis Abandoned
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/world.body_text: **********When Israel was attacked by Iraqi missiles on Jan. 18, Israeli leaders told Washington that they planned to retaliate with a large air and land incursion into western Iraq to wipe out the missile launchers, Administration officials say. **********The Israeli plan was kept on hold for weeks and ultimately abandoned as Bush Administration officials pressed Israel to stay out of the war. The plan called for an Israeli armed sweep through western Iraq by helicopter gunships and "significant ground forces," including commando teams, all protected by Israeli Air Force planes that would have secured an air corridor through Jordan or Saudi Arabia to support the operation, the officials said. **********Their account provides the first detailed picture of how Israel planned to retaliate for the missile attacks that began with seven rockets on the second day of the war, and led to frantic consultations between American and Israeli leaders. Effort to Persuade Israel **********The intensity and scale of the military operations contemplated by Israel were the primary reasons President Bush and his senior advisers devoted a large amount of time in the first weeks of the air war to persuading Israel to avoid any military action that would threaten the anti-Iraq coalition and play into the hands of President Saddam Hussein by bringing Israel into the war. **********Israel's disclosure of its plan to conduct such a large operation may have prompted the brief discussion among Mr. Bush and his senior advisers, first alluded to in The Washington Post on Monday, about possibly going along with a limited retaliation plan in which Israel would fire a salvo of its Jericho medium-range ballistic missiles at Iraqi targets. But both plans were ultimately opposed by Washington. **********The ambitious Israeli plan for a air-ground operation, which would have been carried out over a number of days, was favored by Israeli military officials who argued that the United States could not guarantee the destruction of all mobile and fixed Scud missile sites in Iraq without inserting ground forces to search for and help destroy the missiles. Agreement Not to Retaliate **********United States officials familiar with the incursion plan described it as the kind of bold and dramatic operation that would have been possible with allied air superiority over Iraq. The plan also explains the great importance Israel attached to obtaining the American aircraft identity codes that would have allowed Israeli air forces to recognize as friend or foe any allied and Iraqi warplanes over Iraq. **********Administration officials said that in order to head off Israeli retaliation, they sent United States special operations forces into Western Iraq to help locate the mobile Scud launchers. **********United States officials believed they had Israel's tacit agreement not to retaliate for Scud attacks after President Bush discussed the Scud threat on Dec. 11 with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and assured him the United States war plan called for aggressive attacks on the Scud sites in Western Iraq. Administration officials said that tacit agreement was reaffirmed when Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger visited Israel in January, five days before the onset of the air war. **********But when Iraq launched the first seven modified Scud-B missiles against Tel Aviv and Haifa on Jan. 18, the tacit agreement was replaced by pressure to respond. The "infrared signature" of the Iraqi boosters were detected by the United States early warning satellites, which simulaneously transmitted the launching warning to the Pentagon, which in turn relayed the warning instantly over a newly established and secure hotline, called "Hammer Rick," to Tel Aviv, officials said. Full-Scale Desert Assault **********United States intelligence also monitored Israel's initial response as it scrambled about a dozen jet fighters -- what one American official described as an "intensive combat air patrol" but not a "strike package." **********Within hours of that launching, Defense Minister Moshe Arens was on the hotline to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who spent that evening at the White House fielding calls with Israeli leaders along with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Mr. Bush. **********Mr. Arens described the plan for a full-scale assault in the Iraqi desert to Mr. Cheney and requested United States military assistance for a full retaliatory raid. Administration officials said the Israeli plan called for flying air transports filled with Israeli troops through Jordan or Saudi Arabia to the Iraqi desert, where they would systematically attack the fixed Scud sites at Iraq's large H-2 and H-3 air bases. **********The Israeli helicopter and ground forces also would conduct search-and-destroy missions for mobile Scud launchers while Israeli warplanes flew strike and reconnaissance missions and held the skies over Western Iraq. 'We Need This Corridor' **********The plan called for Israeli aerial tankers to fly through Saudi Arabia or Jordan to support the air operations, including refueling the large attack helicopter fleet that would set up a temporary base in the Iraqi desert to support the ground forces and attack any challenge from the Iraqi Army, which maintained a large garrison in Western Iraq. **********The operation would have gone on for a number of days, Administration officials said, and would have required Israel's air force to maintain a large "combat air patrol" to secure the corridor through Saudi Arabia or Jordan. **********"They laid out their idea and said, 'This is how we'd do it, and in order to do it, we need this corridor,"' an Administration official said. **********Mr. Arens suggested that if the United States could not secure a corridor for Israeli forces through Saudi Arabia, Israel could seize such a corridor through Jordanian air space, destroying the American-supplied Hawk antiaircraft missile batteries that provide the bulk of Jordan's air defense. **********An administration official said Israel's request for an air corridor through Saudi Arabia was never conveyed to Saudi officials. **********With the promise of additional Patriot missile batteries, Mr. Bush and his senior aides were able to convince the Israelis not to execute any retaliation plan that night, but the threat of Israel's entry into the war did not immediately subside.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/04/busin.main_headline: I.B.M. Rating Cut By Duff & Phelps
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/04/busin.print_headline: I.B.M. Rating Cut By Duff & Phelps
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/04/busin.body_text: **********The Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company announced yesterday that it had downgraded the triple-A debt rating of the International Business Machine Corporation's senior notes and debentures and convertible subordinated debentures. **********Duff & Phelps said the rating change reflected a combination of a less optimistic long-term outlook for I.B.M.'s core business and concern with the rapid growth of customer financing activities. **********Traditionally, the company's business has come from mainframe computer operations, but aggressive mainframe competition and the success of personal computers have eroded profits in this area, the agency said. **********Duff & Phelps lowered the senior debt to AA+, from AAA, adding that while I.B.M.'s pre-eminent position as a mainframe supplier was not threatened, the open-systems environment of the future was likely to result in additional pressure on profits. An open-system market is a market where all companies maintain certain standards in design. **********The computer company responded by saying the downgrading was unwarranted. **********Moody's Investors Service, which had the computer company on credit watch earlier this year, confirmed the Aaa rating on March 28. The Standard & Poor's Corporation, which said it does not have the company under review at this time, rates the senior debt AAA.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/world.main_headline: Missiles Provoke Debate in Tel Aviv: Is It a Patriotic Duty to Stay in City?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: ISRAEL; Missiles Provoke Debate in Tel Aviv: Is It a Patriotic Duty to Stay in City?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/world.body_text: **********For dozens of Israelis jostling in line outside the El Al airline office today, gas-mask boxes bouncing at their sides, the under-the-breath curses were not reserved only for Saddam Hussein, who has rained terror and death on this city for the last 12 days. **********No, many of these people waiting desperately to book seats out of town saved their angriest words for Tel Aviv's longtime Mayor, Shlomo Lahat, who initiated a swelling national debate when he lashed out all those who have fled the city. He called them "deserters" and said all of them should move back right away. **********"He has no right," 34-year-old France Lebeenadan said after waiting more than an hour just to get inside the El Al office door for a booking to Paris. "It's stupid. I'm not hysterical, but I feel a responsibility for my children." **********"This is my country; I love my country," said Dali Saragossi, who was waiting to make bookings to New York for her two teen-age children. "One of the missiles fell very near our house. It makes me very sad, but what are we to do? Their father lives in New York, and he wants them with him now."  'Trying to Find Cover' **********"We're afraid," said her son David, who is 13. "We don't want to die. We're just trying to find cover." **********As if to reinforce the boy's concerns, Iraq fired another missile with a conventional warhead at Tel Aviv tonight, the seventh attack in 12 days. But this time the army said the Scud was defective and disintegrated as it fell back to earth. No one was hurt, and there was no property damage. The missile had fallen apart even before any Patriot air-defense missiles could be fired at it. **********The Mayor's remarks, and those of other prominent Israelis who share his views, set off a broad round of national soul-searching about how Israelis should respond to the continuing missile threat: Are the people who stay in Tel Aviv brave, defiant Jews who are showing Saddam Hussein they can not be cowed? **********Or are they fools, willfully putting themselves and their children in mortal danger, even though they have a clear choice? **********For many people, memories of World War II lie just behind the immediate debate. The threat of attack with poisonous gas makes that memory seem even more relevant. And so several people quoted in the local press today said anyone who stays in Tel Aviv is being as shortsighted as the Jews who stayed in Germany in the late 1930's. **********But Mayor Lahat says he is only being practical.  'It Might Happen Here' **********"Look, it's important to stay, and I want to be very clear about this issue," he said today. "Yes, it's very dangerous to be in Tel Aviv. So people are leaving to other cities. Maybe tomorrow it will be dangerous in the whole country, and so they will leave the country. And I'm not speaking from a theoretical point of view. It might happen here." **********Aviva Marks, an actress who lives in Tel Aviv, agrees and draws her own comparison to World War II. **********"The way that Hitler knew that if he could break London, he could win the war, well that's obviously Saddam's intention. Tel Aviv is the heart of the country. If Saddam Hussein thinks it's important enough to get us, then it's important enough for us to stay here." **********Still, tens of thousands leave the city each night, clogging the highways as they move to hotels in Jerusalem, Beersheba or Eilat.  'People Under Stress' **********"We have about 100 rooms filled" with people from Tel Aviv, said Omri Krongold, deputy manager of Jerusalem's Sheraton-Plaza Hotel. "They're not tourists. They're people under stress. It's very strange to work with them. They don't go to the restaurants. Ninety percent stay in the hotel. They stay in their rooms and watch TV." **********Others leave Israel altogether. At the El Al office, a spokesman for the airline, Nachman Kleiman, said: "We're not in a panic, but we've added flights, and we're using bigger planes." El Al is now the only airline regularly flying in and out of Israel, and it carried 3,200 people away on Sunday. **********"There's a waiting list for every flight," Mr. Kleiman added. In fact, callers asking for a booking to New York today were told there were no seats available before Feb. 10. **********Tonight, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir weighed in with his own opinion about that. **********"I wouldn't put on trial those who move from one city to another in Israel," he said. "There's no shame in that. But I would of course condemn those who leave the country." **********Asa Kasher, a professor of philosophy at Tel Aviv University, represents a large body of public opinion when he says he is staying in town but doesn't blame anyone who chooses to leave.  'My Personal Decision' **********"I think it is a matter of personal decision," he said. "It is my personal decision to stay. I am a full-fledged Israeli, born here, raised here and everything of importance to me in my life happened to me here, and I'm not going to turn myself into a refugee under any condition. **********"On the other hand," he added, "it is a personal decision and I can understand if everyone else does something else. A mayor is in no position to give advice on matters of life and death to citizens." **********Gideon Samet, a columnist in the daily newspaper Haaretz, ridiculed the Mayor's notion that a sense of national duty should compel people to remain in town. **********"It won't take much now so that soon there's a 'revolutionary guard' that will start patrolling Tel Aviv's streets," he wrote. "They'll hang lists on tree trunks of those who've left."  Aftermath of Attack **********But the larger philosophical arguments were irrelevant to many of the people standing in line at the El Al office. Like most everyone else in the country, they watched television last Tuesday night, just after missiles killed one person and wounded more than 50 in Tel Aviv. **********Just after the attack, the fifth one to come at night, a young mother was filmed, sobbing as she stood before her ruined home, telling the television reporter that when the air raid sirens had sounded, her baby daughter had told her: "'Mommy, don't die. Wait, so I can die with you."' **********This afternoon, a woman interviewed by Israeli television outside the El Al office said she was leaving for Canada "because we are afraid. Aren't you afraid?" **********But look around, the television reporter responded. It looks safe here in town now. **********"Now, yes -- during the daytime," she answered. "But what about at night?"

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/30/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A Retirement At Softech
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/30/busin.body_text: **********Softech Inc. said yesterday that its chairman, president, and chief executive, Justus F. Lowe Jr., was retiring, effective immediately. **********Douglas T. Ross, founder of the computer-software company and its chairman emeritus, has been elected chairman. Norman L. Rasmussen, a longtime director of the company, has been appointed interim president and chief executive. **********Mr. Rasmussen is president of Teleprocessing Inc., a Boston systems-integration company. **********Mr. Lowe will continue to be employed by Softech through May 1992 to assist with the management change. **********"It is time to get some new blood in," said Mr. Lowe, who is 63 years old. **********Softech, based in Waltham, Mass., develops computer software for the Government. The company lost $6 million on sales of $54 million for the fiscal year ended May 31.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/09/world.body_text: **********Fearing an epidemic among thousands of Albanian refugees sleeping in the open in squalid conditions at dockside here, the Italian police began rounding them up this evening to move them into local schools for the night. **********The move appeared to be the first step in the Italian Government's pledge earlier in the day to find temporary shelter for about 20,000 Albanians who have sailed on rickety boats and rusty ships across the Adriatic to this and other Italian coastal towns in the last few days to seek work and refuge. **********But a Foreign Ministry spokesman repeated today that those who did not meet requirements for political asylum or have a visa to enter Italy would eventually be repatriated.  Appeal From U.N. Commission **********In a statement issued in Geneva, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees called on Italy to determine whether the Albanians qualified for political refugee status before sending them back. **********The action to shelter the Albanians, some of whom have been here for a week, was the first decisive step taken by the authorities in this southern port town of 92,000, whose narrow streets around the dock area are filled with about 16,000 Albanians, mostly young men in their 20's and 30's but also families with children. **********"During the night we are going to move all of the Albanians into 38 local schools," Raffaele Belardi, Brindisi's regional Minister of Civil Protection, said after an evening meeting with emergency and local officials. "Tomorrow morning between 8 and 9 they will get breakfast, and between 12 and 2, 7,000 will get a hot lunch and the rest will get a cold lunch." **********The police said there were also about 1,700 Albanians at Monopoli, 1,200 at Bari and dozens at other coastal towns. Though officials had earlier said that no more boats would be allowed to dock here, the police said small boats continued to arrive today, dropping off scores of Albanians. **********But the Foreign Ministry spokesman, Alessandro DiFranco, said that the coast guard was trying to turn around ships arriving from Albania and that Italy had called on that country to stop the exodus and to release 215 political prisoners. **********"That would be considered a sign that would tame the high spirit to leave Albania," Mr. DiFranco said. Emergency Aid to Albania **********The Italian Government also pledged to give about $9 million in emergency aid to Tirana in the form of food and medicine in a show of support for the liberalization program of the Albanian President, Ramiz Alia. Last July, Italy received more than 3,000 Albanians who had sought refuge in Western embassies in Tirana, but most of them went on to Germany. **********The scene this evening was one of festive chaos as traffic jams of empty ambulances, freight trucks and police convoys developed in the narrow streets of the port area around clumps of grimy-faced Albanians and curious Italians. Worn-out blue trousers and jackets that seemed to come from another ideology and era litter the back alleys after they are dumped there by Albanians who receive new slacks or sweaters. **********In front of one school, a local Italian woman stood at the locked gate begging a guard to allow an Albanian family with one child to spend the night there. "We want to help, but everything is so disorganized," she said. **********On another corner, a group of young Albanians from the port of Durres, from which most of the ships have left, talked of their 40-hour crossing on a boat someone had commandeered by pointing a pistol at the captain's head. Hoping to Find Work **********"Just imagine, there are only about 100 pistols in private hands in all of Albania and we had 3 on the boat," said Nino Toci, a 27-year-old mechanic who said he had come to Italy with several friends because he believed that it was a rich country and that there was work here. **********A woman in the group looked shocked when told that many Albanians might have to go back if they did not qualify as political refugees under the Geneva Convention. **********"All of us are political refugees," said Elsa Shuka, a 33-year-old mother who said she had spent last night in the open with her husband and her 6- and 11-year-old children. "I am a political and economic migrant." **********As she spoke, a small red Fiat drove up to the curb and an Italian boy rolled down the window and handed the Albanians shaving cream, a razor and some soap. The boy's mother, Irene Cecchini, said, "I don't think they should be allowed to stay in our country, but I and the people of Brindisi are trying to help." **********But tension was visible in other parts of town. The police and relief workers said the hospitals were filled with Albanians who had suffered mild injuries, and the streets are almost constantly being crisscrossed by ambulances.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Wal-Mart Expects Higher Revenues
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/busin.body_text: **********ATLANTA, April 24 **********Wal-Mart Stores Inc. expects revenues in its current fiscal year, ending next January, to be in excess of $43 billion, up from $32.6 billion last year, the company's chief financial officer, Paul R. Carter, said. Mr. Carter told analysts here that the company had also scaled back the number of new Wal-Mart discount stores it would open this year but had raised the number of Sam's Wholesale Club membership outlets it would open. **********The company, he said, expects to open 150 to 155 new Wal-Mart stores this year, compared with previous plans to open 165. It will add 34 to 37 new Sam's stores, "a few more" than previously planned, Mr. Carter said.
