https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/12/busin.main_headline: Talking Deals; Putting a Value On Office Space
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/12/busin.print_headline: Talking Deals; Putting a Value On Office Space
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/12/busin.body_text: **********OLYMPIA & YORK, the giant Toronto-based real estate and energy company, set the New York commercial property markets buzzing recently when it announced one of the only large property deals in the city this year. But the announcement was so short on details that it raised more questions than it answered about the value of lower Manhattan office buildings. **********Now, after an examination of the deal in the six weeks since it was announced, the terms of the transaction and the condition of the downtown office market confirm what many property analysts are saying: that there has been a severe and permanent loss of value in the downtown Manhattan office market, particularly among prewar and early postwar buildings. **********The Olympia & York deal involves 60 Broad Street, a 30-story, one-million-square-foot tower in the heart of the financial district owned by an Olympia & York partnership. In late October, Olympia & York announced that the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-Shing had purchased the building's mortgage from CalFed Inc., a Los Angeles savings and loan, for about $57.5 million. **********The seven-year-old mortgage had originally been $160 million, but after the building's major tennant, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., went bankrupt last year and left the building more than 70 percent vacant, CalFed reassessed the building and wrote the mortgage down to $70 million. **********CalFed, through Jeffrey H. Lyndford, an executive of Wellsford, a California real estate company, and Banque Indosuez of France, contacted Mr. Li, who agreed to pay $57.5 million, forcing CalFed to take another write-down. **********The sharp revaluations of the mortgage indicated at the time the degree of collapse in the value of downtown Manhattan office space, particularly buildings like 60 Broad, put up immediately after World War II or earlier, and now short of income and tennants. **********As part of the deal, Mr. Li acquired 49 percent of the Olympia & York partnership that owned the building. That partnership, Olympia & York executives said at the time, would invest $60 million in the property for asbestos removal and renovations. Olympia & York has said it will provide the partnership with the $60 million, but it is unclear whether Mr. Li will lend Olympia & York any of the money. **********And it remains unknown what Mr. Li paid for his 49 percent interest in the partnership because he has already recouped the $57.5 million he spent to buy the mortgage from CalFed by placing the mortgage, which had a floating rate of return, with another company that has recourse to Olympia & York, which has guaranteed the loan. Mr. Li's return on the deal is really based on how much 60 Broad appreciates. **********Olympia & York executives have suggested that the value of the building could be put in the $117.5 million range, considering the mortgage purchase price and the $60 million in new capital for renovation and asbestos removal. **********"We believe that the value of 60 Broad Street is substantial and that that value will be clearly demonstrated upon the completion of the redevelopment program," said John E. Zuccotti, president of Olympia & York U.S.A. **********But few real estate executives in New York believe that 60 Broad is now worth anything near $117.5 million. It may be worth slightly more than the $57.5 million paid for the mortgage, but before the asbestos removal and renovations, it is not worth much more. And the $60 million contribution for asbestos removal and renovation will be provided over several years, they say, and should not be added to the value of the building as a lump sum. **********In addition, there is a vacancy rate of 26 percent for downtown office buildings built just after World War II, according to Edward S. Gordon Inc., a leading New York property broker. That represents 3.8 million square feet of empty space in a total of 26 buildings. For the prewar buildings, the vacancy rate is even higher, and within the last 10 years, more than 20 million square feet of more modern, efficient space has been added downtown. **********For top-grade space downtown, net rents have fallen to about $9 a square foot from about $15 two years ago, while real estate taxes have risen. **********One widely known property executive, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that even after significant cosmetic upgrading and asbestos removal, rents at 60 Broad would not be low enough to compete with newer buildings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/05/world.main_headline: Europe Offers Plan to Encourage Iraq's Withdrawal From Kuwait
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/05/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF; Europe Offers Plan to Encourage Iraq's Withdrawal From Kuwait
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/05/world.body_text: **********In a move to encourage Iraq to pull its troops out of Kuwait, the 12-nation European Community promised Baghdad today that it would work to resolve all problems of the Middle East if the gulf crisis could be settled peacefully. **********At an emergency meeting here, foreign ministers of the community nations said "Iraq should receive the assurance not to be subject to a military intervention" once it had carried out United Nations Security Council resolutions demanding its withdrawal from Kuwait. **********Welcoming the announcement today that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, would meet in Geneva on Wednesday, the community further invited Mr. Aziz to visit Luxembourg on Thursday for talks with three European foreign ministers.  No Comment on European Plan **********The European Community meeting was interrupted by the news that Iraq had accepted the American offer of talks, a move that President Bush, speaking in Washington, described as a "useful step." But Mr. Bush insisted that the meeting would be used solely to inform the Iraqis that they have to get out of Kuwait or face war. Questioned on the European plan, the President said he had not had a chance to study it and would not comment until he did, but he declined to rule out the terms of the plan.  [ Page 4. ] **********Jacques Poos, the Foreign Minister of Luxembourg, which holds the rotating presidency of the community, said he hoped to meet with Mr. Baker before meeting with Mr. Aziz so the two could coordinate their meetings with the Iraqi. **********"We feel it is important that Iraq get the same message twice," he said. **********He and other foreign ministers said the central issue was still the need for Iraq to withdraw, or commit itself to withdrawing, from Kuwait by the United Nations deadline of Jan. 15. They also stressed repeatedly that they remained in full agreement with the United States on the crisis. **********But while insisting in their statement that there could be no linkage between settlement of the crisis and other problems, it was apparent today that several governments, France and Germany among them, were eager to find some face-saving formula to encourage Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. **********France and Germany called the meeting today in the hope of keeping alive diplomatic efforts to settle the crisis after Washington and Baghdad appeared unable to agree on a date for direct talks. They also favored separate community talks with Baghdad if the United States-Iraqi talks fell through. **********But Britain and the Netherlands feared that an independent community initiative could be misread by Baghdad as evidence of a weakening in the broad anti-Iraqi coalition and seemed determined to block any meeting with Mr. Aziz unless he held talks with Mr. Baker first. **********European officials said that a potentially embarrassing rift in the community was avoided halfway through the closed-door session today when word came that Mr. Aziz had agreed to travel to Geneva next week for talks with Mr. Baker. **********"There was an audible sigh of relief," an official said. **********Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said he was satisfied with the outcome of the meeting because it reaffirmed the community's unity. **********"We are anxious for peace, anxious to go on searching for a peaceful solution," he said. "But this can only come through a reversal of the aggression." **********He said that if Mr. Aziz accepted the invitation to talks with the community he would be given a double message. **********"If Iraq does not comply with U.N. resolutions, it will be forced out of Kuwait," he said. "If it fully and unconditionally withdraws, it will not be attacked." **********Asked whether Iraq was still required to leave by Jan. 15, Mr. Hurd said that "obviously an element of practical common sense is involved, with the decision of member states depending on the situation prevailing at the time." **********Significantly, in a meeting with reporters, Mr. Hurd seemed to echo Washington's more cautious line by not emphasizing the community's offer to help establish "security, stability and development" in the Middle East if Iraq leaves Kuwait. **********But other foreign ministers emphasized that intention, including Mr. Poos, who said he was ready to discuss the "after-crisis scenario" with Mr. Aziz. "The community demonstrated that it is not scared of a dialogue with the person responsible for the crisis," he said. **********If the Iraqi Foreign Minister comes to Luxembourg on Thursday, he will meet with Mr. Poos, as the current President of the Council of Ministers, as well as Italy's Foreign Minister, Gianni de Michelis, who last held the post, and the Netherlands' Foreign Minister, Hans van den Broek, who takes over the position on July 1. **********At the start of today's session, Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France proposed a seven-point plan that served as the basis for today's final statement, including the pledge that Iraq would not be attacked if it withdrew, the community's commitment to tackle other Middle East issues and an invitation to Mr. Aziz. **********The plan, immediately endorsed by Germany and Italy, also welcomed President Bush's new effort Thursday to organize a meeting between Mr. Baker and Mr. Aziz and stressed that there was "neither contradiction nor interference" between the American and European initiatives. **********In a news conference in Paris today, President Francois Mitterrand nonetheless seemed to distance himself from the Bush Administration's recent warnings of an imminent war by suggesting a new meeting of the United Nations Security Council before any military offensive was started against Iraq. He said he would hold talks with Mr. Baker in Paris on Tuesday before the Secretary of State traveled to Geneva for his meeting with Mr. Aziz. **********Mr. Mitterrand also reiterated his call for international conferences to deal with critical Middle East problems and said France would not go beyond the objectives defined by the United Nations. **********"I do not favor preventive war," he said when asked about the need to destroy Iraq's war capacity. "France does not consider itself the world's policeman." **********Germany's Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who in recent days has strongly urged new diplomatic efforts to settle the crisis, told his community colleagues that "war is not inevitable" and warned of the dire consequences a war would have for the economies of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/30/world.main_headline: Bangkok Journal; Thailand Coup Casts Up a Most Reluctant Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/30/world.print_headline: Bangkok Journal; Thailand Coup Casts Up a Most Reluctant Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/30/world.body_text: **********Anand Panyarachun must be one of the world's most ambivalent leaders. His appointment as Thailand's interim Prime Minister is "the biggest accident in Thai history," he says, and he is eager to finish his work, promote new elections and be gone from a post he never wanted in the first place. **********Two months after a military coup, Thais feel secure enough to grumble more loudly about the country's affairs, but Mr. Anand, 58 years old, is not normally the target. He is usually greeted with deference and pleasure, which makes him uncomfortable. **********A worldly figure, he is credited with attracting an experienced Cabinet and exercising a moderating influence on the both the tone and the policy of Thailand's military rulers. **********He and his Cabinet are running the country in partnership with the military until a new Constitution is written and new elections take place. Under an interim Constitution, elections must be held by April 30, 1992; Mr. Anand wants them sooner. If they are later, he said recently, he would resign.  A Politician 'by Chance' **********Mr. Anand, a former Ambassador to the United States and delegate to the United Nations, left diplomacy for business after an earlier generation of coup leaders accused him of Communism. He has become a politician now, he said in an interview, "not by choice, but by chance." **********When told that many people were surprised he accepted the job from the military, Mr. Anand laughed and said, "So was I." Twirling his hands above the lap of an elegantly cut gray suit, he said, "I must have had a temporary lapse of mental awareness," and then he laughed again. **********The coup, which took place on Feb. 23, was much-rumored but still unexpected, because most Thais thought coups outdated in a more democratic age. The ousted Prime Minister, Chatichai Choonhavan, was the first directly elected leader since 1976, and he had a solid parliamentary majority. **********But politics and business were thoroughly and visibly intertwined, and many Thais grew tired of Mr. Chatichai's "no problem" response to criticism. The military felt its own considerable interests under threat.  Thais 'Got Carried Away' **********Thais were wrong to think the generals would do nothing, Mr. Anand said. "In a way, the Thai people got carried away by this total freedom of expression, by this illusion that there was a political or civilian control over the armed forces," he said. "When a country that has gone through decades, centuries of a predominant military role in the ruling of country, you can't just throw them out. They have face, too." **********Political control over the military is still "an essence of a democracy," he said. "But it must be evolutionary. You can't just impose it. It must be agreed to by the military." You have to start with confidence-building measures, he said. "If one side feels manipulated by the other, that's where the conflict arises."  The Ultimate Goal **********Some Thais suggest it is Mr. Anand who is being manipulated by the military, to give the coup an acceptable face, especially to the West. "I haven't lived up until this year in order to be manipulated," he said with some heat. **********He waited a moment, then said, "Every politician, every political leader, even in a fully democratic society, must always be manipulated by circumstances." **********And it so happens in Thailand the military is a factor that must be reckoned with. In other countries it is trade unions, or newspapers, or intellectuals, or the new left or the old right." **********Angry now, he said: "Would they like me to be completely independent? So that I can be a real live dictator?" When it was suggested that some Thais thought he would be preferable to others they could think of, he laughed again. **********The ultimate goal, he said, "is still to achieve a fully democratic regime." But democracy requires evolution and cannot be put into place overnight. "In the past, we've often been preoccupied with the form, rather than the substance of democracy," he said. Adequate political participation is still lacking; so is a full understanding of democratic "rights and responsibilities," which is not just a matter of constitutions. **********"Government of the people, by the people and for the people -- it's easier said than done," Mr. Anand said. "If we want to have democratic rule, we have to earn it." **********It is obvious Mr. Anand has his misgivings, especially over the continuation of martial law, which he says will be lifted early in May. He also seems uncomfortable over some abrupt policy changes the military has pushed through the National Assembly, like the recent dissolution of trade unions at state enterprises. Martial law prevents demonstrations against the new law, but it is not unpopular among many Thais, who regard state workers as highly privileged. **********The military also wants to end the common practice of vote-buying and thinks that can be accomplished by a complete separation of the executive and legislative branches. But for Mr. Anand, vote buying "is merely a symptom of the national system, which is cancerous." There is a "total malady of the society," he said, rooted in greed and distorted social values. **********"It's part of corruption and corrupt practices," he said. "It goes into the Civil Service system, where many are quite capable but not paid enough; it goes into business practices; it goes into every sector. **********"Of course," he added bitingly, "if the top leadership does not set a good example, there is no constraint."  Much to Be Done **********In his short time in office, he said, there is much that can be done to improve the tax system; to toughen penalties against narcotics trafficking, which would gratify Washington, since much of the heroin in America is shipped through Bangkok; to improve the commercial code, and to begin to deal with Thailand's AIDS epidemic through better education. He also wants to defuse a battle with Washington over Thai abuses of intellectual property, with widespread copying of music, videos, software and prescription drugs. **********By 1976, Mr. Anand had risen to the top Civil Service post in the Foreign Ministry, under Mr. Chatichai. After the fall of South Vietnam, he helped negotiate a withdrawal of American forces from Thailand and better relations with Indochina. But after a military coup, he was accused of being a Communist and transferred to an inactive post. **********He was later reinstated, but shipped off to Bonn as Ambassador. He resigned and went into business in 1979, and says he was very surprised when the army commander, Gen. Suchinda Kraprayoon, a junior military attache in Mr. Anand's Washington Embassy in 1972, asked him to become Prime Minister. **********"I had quite a few concerns in my mind," Mr. Anand said, "particularly since I hardly knew them, and they hardly knew me." But General Suchinda's answers were "sincere," Mr. Anand said. Still, when the time limit on his tenure was mentioned, he broke in to say, "Thank God."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/11/busin.body_text: **********The State of Maryland priced $100 million in tax-exempt general obligation bonds yesterday through competitive bidding. The financing was awarded to a group of underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company. **********Unlike many recent offerings that have had to rely on insurance to raise the quality of credit and insure a lower borrowing cost, Maryland is among the few states that retain a triple-A rating, the highest issued by Moody's Investors Service, Standard & Poor's and Fitch Investors Service. **********Underwriters said the issue was priced to yield 5.2 percent in 1994, 5.7 percent in 1996, 6.2 percent in 2001 and 6.6 percent in 2006.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/31/busin.main_headline: Technology; Latest in the Vineyard: Newly Dug Caves
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/31/busin.print_headline: Technology; Latest in the Vineyard: Newly Dug Caves
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/31/busin.body_text: **********The premium wineries of northern California have long demonstrated their devotion to the grape with impressive edifices, from the restored 1885 stone mansion of Far Niente in Oakville to the post-modern temple to wine at Clos Pegase in Calistoga. But in the last few years, vintners have been making a less visible commitment to Bacchus: new caves for the gentle aging of their fine wines. **********Wines age best at a constant, relatively low temperature, particularly while they are in oak barrels before bottling. The insulating properties of tons of earth and stone make caves a wonderfully low-technology alternative to the elaborate air-conditioning needed for above-ground storage. **********Some of the oldest California wineries, like Beringer Vineyards in St. Helena and the Buena Vista Winery in Sonoma, have caves dating to the 19th century, which were dug by Chinese coolies with picks and shovels. But nearly all of the new caves in Napa and Sonoma are the work of Alf Burtleson and his four-man crew, who battle the local geology with a 22-foot-long electric and hydraulic drill made by Hawker Siddeley in England for digging coal mines. **********Trained as a civil engineer, Mr. Burtleson specialized in utility tunnels until he was hired to dig a small wine cave in the hill behind Far Niente in 1979. Since then, the Burtleson Construction Company has completed 22 caves in Napa and Sonoma counties; the company dropped the public works projects in 1986 to concentrate on wine caves. **********Among those completed most recently are 20,000 square feet of caves at Clos Pegase. These were particularly challenging -- first because the rock was soft and crumbly and second because Jan Schrem, the owner of Clos Pegase, wanted the caves to serve as extended galleries for his art collection. **********Mr. Burtleson's crew can mine three feet an hour in hard homogeneous rock, but the workers must proceed more slowly in soft rock, stopping frequently to apply steel mesh and concrete to reinforce the new cave. At each step, the arched shape of the tunnel must be maintained. "We can't let it ever cave in," said Mr. Burtleson. "Once you lose the arch, you've lost it all." **********To display the works of art, small alcoves were carved, and a large open room was mined for slide shows and other gatherings. While a simple tunnel can be left as bare rock with no reinforcement, open rooms require multiple passes with the drilling machine, multiple layers of mesh and concrete and steel rock bolts drilled into the walls. **********Despite the obvious attention to esthetics, the caves at Clos Pegase have very real practical benefits, both in the bottle and on the bottom line, said Bill Pease, Clos Pegase's wine maker. In an air-conditioned warehouse, the air moves at great speed, accelerating evaporation of wine from the barrels. And because most air-conditioning dehumidifies, water evaporates, increasing the wine's alcohol content, he said. Since many California wines start with relatively high alcohol levels, this is a problem. In caves, the opposite happens; the alcohol is evaporated, dropping as much as two-tenths of 1 percent in a year. "That sounds trivial, but the human palate is sensitive to these things," Mr. Pease said. **********He noted that the slower evaporation in a cave saves the winery money, but the biggest saving is in energy cost. "A constant 62 degrees without having to turn on refrigeration compressors is a steal," he said. **********Then too, caves are relatively free from Napa Valley's stringent land-use rules. "In many cases, it's going to be the only alternative if you need more space because in Napa County God help you if you want to add a building," Mr. Pease said. **********In terms of cost, building a cave is competitive with above-ground construction, and any premium is rapidly recouped in savings on energy expenses, Mr. Burtleson said. Many of his projects have been completed for less than $50 a square foot. But as caves come to be vintners' status symbols as well as simple storage facilities, elaborate features can drive the price much higher. A recent 15,000-square-foot addition to the original small cave at Far Niente came in at $100 a square foot, or a total of about $1.5 million. **********Esthetic concerns were an integral part of the design, with recessed lighting, back-lit niches and a large octagonal library room. **********"Caves have esthetics impossible to capture in an above-ground building," said Dirk Hampson, Far Niente's wine maker. "They seem to touch people on an emotional level." **********One novel feature at Far Niente is side tunnels cut at 45 degrees rather than at right angles. "When you walk people through a cave at a different angle, they almost always lose their sense of direction," said Mr. Hampson. "It makes caves seem much larger and more mysterious." **********Perhaps attracted by the waiting list for Mr. Burtleson's services, other construction companies are beginning to get into the cave-construction business. Even so, Mr. Burtleson declines to add a second crew because he does not believe he can adequately oversee two. "Caves are not like regular construction; you can't come back and change it after the fact," he said. **********Meanwhile, not everybody believes caves are the best place to store aging wine, at least not in the Napa Valley. **********Andre Tchelistcheff, the dean of California wine makers and a consultant to Beaulieu Vineyards and Buena Vista Winery, said conditions here are very different from those at the famous Champagne caves of France. The French caves are very deep, in granite and remain quite cold. In light of Napa's proximity to the hot springs of Calistoga, "our stone structures are warm, so the temperature in our tunnels is a little bit above optimal," he said. **********The warmth and moisture also foster mold, which produces a smell that could infiltrate the wine through the barrels, Mr. Tchelistcheff said. "I prefer to build my storage above ground and have control over the atmospheric conditions."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/29/world.main_headline: Even as Bush Counsels Prudence, West Seems Eager to Aid Soviets
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/29/world.print_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL; Even as Bush Counsels Prudence, West Seems Eager to Aid Soviets
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/29/world.body_text: **********Despite the best efforts of the Bush Administration to change the subject, debates over aid to the Soviet Union -- whether to send it, how much to send, when to send it, what kind to send -- are rapidly developing in the Western alliance and among politicians in Washington. **********President Bush said again today in Kennebunkport, Me., where he is on vacation, that it was too early to discuss any major change in the position adopted at the London summit conference last month, where the seven leading industrial powers decided under pressure from the United States to offer no quick cash infusion to Moscow. **********Since that meeting, the Soviet Union has been convulsed by political upheaval and much of the world has hastened to react, but Mr. Bush has maintained his habitual caution. Today, he also rejected any rush to dispatch immediate humanitarian aid, like food and food-distribution teams.  Europeans Favor Aid **********Germany, France and Italy all favor sending large sums of cash as soon as possible to help reduce the possibilities of chaos developing after the failed Soviet coup. Because of Germany's extensive commitments at home, in Eastern Europe and in the Soviet Union, most of any new assistance would have to come from Japan and the United States, the other two richest nations. **********Leading figures on Capitol Hill are joining the argument over what the West should do as a result of the upheaval transforming Soviet life. **********Today, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, who heads the House Armed Services Committee, urged taking $1 billion from the military budget to send food and medicine to the Soviet Union this winter. He argued that fostering stability in the Soviet Union was essential to United States security, but some colleagues challenged his ideas.  [ Page A22. ] 'Potential for Chaos' **********Prime Minister John Major of Britain, the current chairman of the Group of Seven, flew to Maine today and will meet with Mr. Bush on Thursday. Officials traveling with Mr. Major, as well as Western diplomats based here, said they expected the United States and Britain to work out a common position, although Mr. Major appears at the moment to be slightly more open on the question tha Mr. Bush. **********"There's a potential for chaos in the Soviet Union," Mr. Major said in Washington before flying north, defending Mr. Bush's repeated calls for prudence. "Nobody quite knows what will happen. Events there are moving at a most astonishing pace." **********But the British Prime Minister is said by associates to favor a sizable program of food shipments to the Soviet Union, considerably expanded programs of technical assistance and urgent measures to bring Moscow into the International Monetary Fund and other international institutions. **********In each case, he favors a slightly more aggressive policy than Mr. Bush, but he is much more restrained than most of the continental Europeans. **********Talking with reporters today before playing golf, Mr. Bush said he had not yet considered the question of food aid. He said "we want to do our part on that," but called for more study before any decisions are made. **********"It has to be an orderly process," the President said. "You don't just go click off a decision." Concern Among Europeans **********The Netherlands, which holds the rotating presidency of the European Community, reportedly supports the British position. But France, Germany and Italy, the diplomats said, are ready to fight hard for direct financial support, and there is no assurance that the differences can be papered over. **********The representatives of the leaders of the Group of Seven are to meet in London on Thursday to try to do so, but Mr. Major reportedly warned American officials that success could not be guaranteed, especially as President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany have publicly committed themselves to the notion that more money must be sent quickly to insure that democracy prevails. **********Indeed, both have suggested that the failure of the Group of Seven to act boldly in London may have contributed to the attempted coup against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, an idea that Washington rejects and ridicules. **********Germany fears anarchy in the Soviet Union perhaps more than any other country, because it could send Soviet refugees flooding into German territory and make it impossible for the 275,000 Soviet troops still in Germany to go home as scheduled. France holds similar views, and together the two big continental powers may be able to bring smaller countries along with them. **********Japan has sided so far with the United States, but there is widespread speculation that if Mr. Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin, the newly powerful President of the Russian republic, were to agree to cede the Kurile Islands to Japan, as Japan has long asked, Tokyo might make a major aid commitment. **********Canada has also backed Mr. Bush on aid, although Prime Minister Brian Mulroney not only decided to recognize the independence of the Baltic states before the President was ready to do so but also announced his decision at a news conference with Mr. Bush in Kennebunkport this week. **********Mr. Major met Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger during his brief stop in Washington. He reportedly told them that he had no intention of trying to call an immediate meeting of the Group of Seven leaders to discuss the impasse on aid. **********If agreement proves impossible, British officials and others said, Mr. Major will have several options. He might suggest that each member of the Group of Seven follow its own instincts, but that would displease the Germans, who feel they have already carried a disproportionate share of the burden of helping the Soviet Union. **********He might suggest that the issue be bucked to some other organization, like the United Nations. Or he might propose calling a special conference on the issue, at which smaller nations such as the Scandinavian countries, Australia and South Korea might be urged to play some part in a joint effort.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/busin.main_headline: Playing Disney in the Parisian Fields
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/busin.print_headline: Playing Disney in the Parisian Fields
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/busin.body_text: **********With great fanfare, three $150 million amusement parks opened in France in the past three years, but all have fallen flat and two have been forced into bankruptcy. **********Nonetheless, the Walt Disney Company is pushing hard with plans to open Europe's first Disneyland next year, a $4.4 billion extravaganza sprawling over 5,000 acres of former sugar beet fields 20 miles east of Paris. **********No one at the company is even having second thoughts. Disney being Disney, executives instead are worried that Euro Disneyland -- covering an area one-fifth the size of Paris itself -- just might not be big enough to handle the crowds. In a move that would border on hubris at almost any other company, plans are already being drawn for emergency radio and subway announcements to warn people away when the park fills up. **********"My biggest fear," said Robert Fitzpatrick, Euro Disneyland's chairman, "is that we will be too successful." **********With the Disneylands in Florida, California and Japan all going gangbusters, Disney clearly has the highest of hopes for its European park. And with construction here apparently on budget and on schedule for a spring 1992 opening -- and European interest in all things related to Mickey Mouse still high -- Disney may indeed have a sure thing on its hands. **********"I don't think it can miss," said Margo Vignola, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. "They are masters of marketing. When the place opens, it will be perfect. And they know how to make people smile -- even the French." **********To be sure, not everyone is glad that Mickey & Company are coming to the Continent. When Disney's chairman, Michael Eisner, visited Paris's Bourse to launch Euro Disney's stock offering, leftist demonstrators greeted him with eggs, globs of ketchup and "Mickey Go Home" signs. And some French intellectuals have complained that Disney characters will pollute the nation's cultural ambiance; one dubbed Euro Disneyland "a cultural Chernobyl." Indeed, in negotiating with Disney, French officials dropped heavy hints that they would like a little less American kitsch and a little more European culture at France's Magic Kingdom.  Delayed Arrival **********But if some Europeans can't wait to put Euro Disneyland on their must-miss list, far more are eager for the gates to open, say company executives, who predict that 11 million Europeans will plunk down their francs, marks, pounds and lira in the first year alone. **********"Europe is going to be as important as the United States to the Disney company," said Mr. Fitzpatrick. The lanky, 50-year-old sounds almost apologetic that Disney took so long to enter a market that has 120 million more people than the United States in half the land mass. **********Euro Disneyland will come complete with a golf course, a Davy Crockett campground, an ice-skating rink inspired by Rockefeller Center's and six Disney-owned hotels with 5,200 rooms. But Disney's ambitions do not stop there. The company is planning a $3 billion second phase, with a Disney MGM studio and visitors' tour to open in 1994 as well as 13,000 more hotel rooms. It is also weighing a European Epcot. **********"There is tremendous future growth for our company in Europe," Mr. Eisner said in a telephone interview. **********One of the reasons Mr. Eisner is so confident is that Europeans love Disney's American parks; they accounted for 2.7 million visits last year. And they love the Mickey magazines and T-shirts, Little Mermaid records and other Disney paraphernalia, so much that they spent $1.6 billion on Disney merchandise last year. **********Mr. Eisner is so keen on Europe that Disney has taken a 49 percent stake in the Euro Disney project, the maximum the French Government will allow. In contrast, Disney took no ownership interest in Tokyo Disneyland, opting instead for licensing fees and a percentage of revenues. At the time, much of Disney's money was tied up in building Epcot Center in Florida. The company also worried about the special risks of the Tokyo venture, the first non-American and first cold-weather Disneyland. The worries turned out to be misplaced: Tokyo became a smashing success. **********Missing the ownership boat in Tokyo "was a big mistake which they didn't want to repeat," said Salomon's Ms. Vignola. With Disney's domestic growth slowing, she added, "for the near term, Europe will be the primary engine of growth." **********The move has already paid off on paper. Disney spent about $1.90 for each of its 86 million shares in Euro Disney; Euro Disney shares now sell for about $22. **********Once the park opens, the real payoff begins. The company will receive 10 percent of Euro Disney's admission fees and 5 percent of food and merchandise revenues, the same arrangement as in Japan. But in France, it will also receive management fees, incentive fees and 49 percent of the profits. **********Based on current projections, that will amount to a $64 million contribution to Disney profits in the fiscal year ending September 1993, $101 million for 1994 and $199 million for 1995, according to Harold Vogel, a Merrill Lynch analyst. In fiscal 1990, Disney earned $824 million on revenues of $5.84 billion. **********What makes the European numbers even sweeter is that Disney has put up only $160 million for the project. Other investors have pumped in $1.2 billion in equity, the French Government has provided a low-interest $960 million loan and banks have lent another $1.6 billion. The rest -- some $400 million -- comes from special partnerships formed to buy properties and lease them back. **********"This financing arrangement has been possible because Disney has a solid track record," crows John Forsgren, Euro Disney's chief financial officer, expressing a view that analysts do not dispute.  The French Connection **********Disney executives chose the beet fields of the Marne-la-Vallee area outside Paris after examining 200 locations in Europe. Disney loved being near Paris, Europe's biggest magnet for tourism. And France was eager to win the project to help lower its high jobless rate and to fuel its efforts to be the nerve center of Europe. **********"Euro Disney is going to create at least 30,000 jobs," said Christian Cardon, who heads a Government office set up to make things easier for Disney. "And tourists from abroad will spend almost $1 billion a year here." **********In addition to providing a huge loan at subsidized rates, the Government is spending hundreds of millions of dollars on subway and other capital improvements related to the park. Through Euro Disney, France seems to be trying to shed its image as a country where bureaucrats reign supreme and foreign investment is unwelcome. **********The other finalist for the park was Barcelona, which had warmer weather but was rejected because its transportation system was not as good as the one in Paris and because it lacked large, flat tracts of land. **********Disney executives also liked the central location of the French site. "France is the crossroads of Europe," Mr. Eisner said. Seventeen million people live within a two-hour drive of Euro Disney -- 109 million live within six hours.  Extending the Line **********To help get people to the park, the Government is extending Paris's express subway out to Euro Disney; the 35-minute ride from downtown will cost about $2.50. The Government is also building a station for the high-speed Train a Grande Vitesse just 150 yards from the entrance gate. Mickey-lovers will be able to arrive from Brussels in 90 minutes, and from London in three hours and 10 minutes once the tunnel under the English Channel opens in 1993. **********Euro Disney is Europe's second-largest construction project after the tunnel, which is plagued by delays and cost overruns. "There is a big difference between Euro Disney and Eurotunnel," said Robert Miller-Bakewell, an analyst with County Natwest-Wood MacKenzie, a London brokerage. "Euro Disney is very much on time and looks to be on budget." **********Eurotunnel is hostage to one contractor, while Euro Disney has hired 37 so that if one has cost overruns or falls behind, it can easily be dropped. **********Jim Cora, an executive vice president who is the hands-on manager of the construction, spent two years after Tokyo Disneyland opened in 1983 studying how that park's construction could have been improved. Armed with that sort of experience, Disney set such exacting demands on the French that construction companies howled -- before signing right up. **********One thing Mr. Cora learned in Tokyo was the need to do more to protect visitors from problems not usually associated with Disneyland in Anaheim and Disney World in Orlando: wind, rain and cold. Thus Euro Disney's ticket booths will be protected from the elements, as will the waiting areas for attractions and the moving sidewalks from the 12,000-space parking lot. **********"If Tokyo had not taught us that Disney parks are weatherproof, we might have chosen to go to Spain because of the warmer climate," said the French-speaking Mr. Fitzpatrick, who studied medieval French literature in graduate school at Johns Hopkins, and married a Frenchwoman. He was president of the California Institute of the Arts before moving to Euro Disney, where part of his role is to serve as Disney's ambassador to France. To the intellectuals who snicker at Disney, he says there is no reason why the French cannot love opera, the Louvre and Mickey, too. **********In fact, while Euro Disneyland will be similar to its American counterparts, Disney's "imagineers" have not forgotten to add some French accents -- and some British, Italian and German ones as well. The park will have two official languages, English and French, and multilingual guides on hand to help Dutch, German, Spanish and Italian visitors. **********Among the attractions with a local spin will be Discoveryland, inspired by the science fiction of France's Jules Verne, and a theater with a 360-degree screen featuring a movie that spans European history. Snow White will speak German, and the Belle Notte Pizzeria and Pasticceria will be next door to Pinocchio.  'Politically Astute' **********"Europe isn't North America," said Mr. Fitzpatrick, whose office is dominated by a seven-foot-tall Mickey Mouse tapestry. "It seemed appropriate and politically astute to underline that Pinocchio was an Italian boy, Peter Pan used to fly out of London and Cinderella was a French girl. We've tried to re-emphasize the European roots of these stories." **********Still, the new Disneyland will remain far more American than European. "It would have been silly to take Mickey Mouse and try to do surgery to create a transmogrified hybrid, half French and half American," Mr. Fitzpatrick said. **********Euro Disney will borrow many attractions from its American siblings.  There will be Michael Jackson's 3-D movie, "Captain EO," as well as Star Tours, the George Lucas-inspired simulator that catapults visitors into space. There will also be Main Street U.S.A., with nickelodeons and ice-cream parlors, and Frontierland with gun-slinging cowboys. Buccaneers will cross swords in Pirates of the Caribbean -- speaking Spanish, Dutch and French as well as English, just like pirates of yore. **********And Disney has had the audacity to banish wine (and other alcoholic beverages) from France's Magic Kingdom, just as in its other parks. **********"To the untrained eye, this Magic Kingdom will be very similar to Tokyo Disneyland and the Magic Kingdom in Florida," said Mr. Eisner. **********Can the mix of American and European influences attract -- and hold -- an audience? No question, says Mr. Fitzpatrick, who adds that his real concern is that too many people will come at peak times, forcing Euro Disney to shut its gates after its 50,000-person capacity is reached.  Bigger Crowds Yet **********After all, Disney executives say, the attendance target of 11 million could well be a conservative number. Disney parks in the United States, which has a population of 250 million, attract about 41 million visitors a year, according to Amusement Business Magazine, a Nashville publication. If Disney fans in Western Europe, with its 370 million people, visit the new park at the same rate, attendance would reach 60 million. **********Mr. Fitzpatrick adds that attendance can only be helped by the five-week vacations that the French and Germans typically receive, compared with the average of two to three weeks in the United States. The French are expected to account for 55 percent of visitors, Germans 14 percent and the British, 8 percent. **********Euro Disney will thrive, Mr. Fitzpatrick said, despite the failures of other French parks. That's because there is only one Disney. **********"We are spending 22 billion French francs before we open the door, while the other places spent 700 million," he said. "This means we can pay infinitely more attention to details -- to costumes, hotels, shops, trash baskets -- to create a fantastic place. There's just too great a response to Disney for us to fail."  THE HOTEL DIMENSION **********Euro Disney's six hotels, which aim to give Europeans a taste of America, underline how Disney is increasingly becoming a real estate development and hotel management company. Disney executives say that if the hotels do as well as expected, they might be sold for a hefty capital gain. They will cost more than $1 billion to build. **********For the first time at a Disney park, a hotel will be right at the entrance gate. It's Magic Kingdom, a Victorian palace, looking out on Main Street U.S.A. **********Among the others: *********** The Hotel New York, with towers that look borrowed from Central Park West. *********** The Newport Bay Club, painted a cool New England blue, on a lake with a lighthouse and a 70-yard observation deck filled with rocking chairs. *********** The Hotel Cheyenne, inspired by Western frontier towns. **********The architects include such luminaries as Michael Graves and Robert A. M. Stern. **********As American as the hotels are, they owe one touch to a cold, rainy day in Paris. That day, Robert Fitzpatrick, chairman of Euro Disney, and Michael Eisner, chairman of the Walt Disney Company, stepped into the luxurious Hotel La Tremoille, where Mr. Eisner was warmed and heartened by the wood-burning fireplace. **********Then and there, Mr. Fitzpatrick recalled, Mr. Eisner decreed that Euro Disney's hotels should all have such homey fireplaces.  CINDERELLA HITS HER STRIDE IN TOKYO **********TOKYO -- The snack bars dispense hot dogs and hamburgers by the thousands, Cinderella bats her big blue eyes engagingly at the admiring throngs, and when the furry critters in the country bear jamboree open their mechanical mouths to entertain with hillbilly music, out pours -- Japanese. **********What the Japanese wanted in their version of Disneyland was a genuine American experience. What they got was a world that envelops visitors in not one, but two fantasies -- of a dreamy, simplified America, and of a land of flying elephants, talking mice and magical castles. **********And the Japanese owners of Tokyo Disneyland got a gold mine: Nearly 16 million visitors are expected in the fiscal year that ends March 31, leaving the squeaky-clean park and its five official hotels jammed year-round. **********Tokyo Disneyland opened somewhat inauspiciously eight years ago, on 201 acres of land in the eastern suburb of Urayasu. Like much in Japan, the choice of locations had a deep corporate meaning; it was intended to bolster the Keisei Electric Railway Company, which had become heavily indebted from property speculation and needed to sell some of its holdings. **********It was arranged that an entity called Oriental Land would build, own and operate the theme park, with advice from Walt Disney Productions. Oriental Land, owned by Keisei and Mitsui Real Estate, borrowed most of the $650 million needed to realize the fantasy. **********Disney receives 10 percent of the revenues from admission and rides and 5 percent on sales of food, drink and souvenirs. **********After a slow start, Japanese began flocking to the theme park, which serves almost no Japanese food and whose live entertainers are largely American. **********"Cinderella has to be a Caucasian, we decided," said Toshiharu Akiba, the head of international public relations. **********Apologizing for the existence of the single Japanese restaurant inside the park, Mr. Akiba added, "A lot of elderly Japanese came here from outlying parts of Japan, and they were not very familiar with hot dogs and hamburgers." **********In the year that ended last March 31, revenues reached $988 million, with ordinary profits at $150 million. **********Local governments have acquired a stake in the park to enjoy some of those profits. As of late last year, Chiba prefecture, in which Tokyo Disneyland is located, took a 5 percent stake in Oriental Land, and the town of Urayasu acquired a 1 percent share. -- JAMES STERNGOLD

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.main_headline: U.S. Pension Agency Seeks $914 Million From Pan Am
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.print_headline: U.S. Pension Agency Seeks $914 Million From Pan Am
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.body_text: **********The Federal agency that insures pension plans went to bankruptcy court yesterday with claims for $914 million that it contended Pan American World Airways owes to three pension plans. **********The claims were filed by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation in the United States Bankruptcy Court of the Southern District of New York where Pan Am's filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code is being litigated. **********James B. Lockhart, the executive director of the pension agency , said the agency wanted "the cost of providing pension benefits to be borne by the companies that promised them and by creditors that condoned those empty promises." Otherwise, he said, Pan Am's obligations would have to be covered by the other companies that pay insurance premiums to the agency, and perhaps ultimately by the taxpayers.  Variety of Claims **********Most of the claims filed yesterday dealt with underfinancing of the pension plans by Pan Am, the Government said. It also said that Pan Am owed insurance premium payments to the agency. **********A bankruptcy court filing on the severance pay for Pan Am's three top officers was postponed yesterday and is expected to be made today. **********The three top officers are expected to get severance pay equal to two years' salary, according to a person familiar with the filing who did not want to be identified. **********Thomas G. Plaskett, the chairman and chief executive, is expected to get about $1 million, while Richard H. Francis, the chief financial officer, and Peter T. McHugh Jr. the chief operating officer, are expected to get about $600,000 each. **********The pension agency has only $53 million of its claims secured by a pledge of stock in the Pan Am Shuttle, which has been taken over by Delta Air Lines. The rest of the claims are unsecured. **********The agency was dealt a blow last week when a Federal judge in New York ruled that the LTV Corporation's underfinanced pension plans should not get preferential treatment over the claims of other creditors. **********If the ruling is upheld, then the agency would find itself having to share with other creditors in a bankruptcy proceeding. The amount left for creditors in a bankruptcy is often only a fraction of what they are owed. **********Mr. Lockhart said the Labor Department is pursuing an expedited appeal of the LTV ruling, made by Federal Judge Kevin Duffy. He said the agency was also seeking changes in the bankruptcy code that would clarify that it has priority over other creditors. **********The agency was established to guarantee payment of retirement benefits earned by about 40 million American workers and retirees participating in about 95,000 private-sector pension plans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/21/busin.body_text: **********In real estate circles, Westinghouse Electric's real estate lending business is regarded as one of the great disasters of the 1980's, up there with boom-and-bust savings and loans and oil-patch banks. **********And many analysts say the worst is not over. Never mind that twice this year, the big Pittsburgh-based company has been forced to reconcile itself to huge losses from misguided loans by its Westinghouse Credit subsidiary for suburban hotels, motels, apartments and office buldings. Two weeks ago, it earmarked $1.68 billion as a reserve against additional loan losses, bringing to $2.66 billion its total addition to reserves this year. **********"If the economy continues to be one in which real estate values continue to plummet and highly leveraged companies continue to have problems funding themselves, then they could have more problems," said Fred Pastore, a analyst at Moody's Investors Service who has been given access to the mountain of junk bonds and real estate loans in the Westinghouse Credit Corporation's portfolio.  Interest in the Pieces **********With a difficult financing road ahead, more problems could mean that Westinghouse will have to sell several of its non-core businesses and might be significantly changed in a restructuring. Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the powerful New York leveraged buyout firm, is already reviewing some of Westinghouse's businesses. **********More than half the giant conglomerate's real estate loans, amounting to about $3 billion, are not paying all, or any, of the interest they are supposed to pay. Westinghouse Credit's real estate loss reserves equal about 68 percent of its underperforming real estate assets, but the company also has another $1.7 billion of off-balance-sheet credit commitments that it may have to finance if the market continues to trample its investments. **********"We think they may need half a billion to a billion dollars more in reserves," said Nicholas P. Heymann, an analyst with County NatWest. "In order to solve the problem, they are going to have to put the bad loans in a separate, self-funding company." **********In an attempt to buttress the company's cash position and forestall more big losses, Paul E. Lego, Westinghouse's chairman, announced a plan to speed the recovery of the financial services group, which handles the real estate portfolio. **********Mr. Lego has replaced William A. Powe, 54 years old, the high-powered salesman who oversaw most of the failed property investments, with Leo W. Yochum, 64, the company's former chief financial officer, who is coming out of retirement. **********Mr. Lego, who declined to be interviewed, has also begun a financing plan that includes private placement of new equity, reduction of short-term debt and expansion of bank credit facilities. The company hopes to improve its cash flow by $500 million by the end of next year, in part by issuing $400 million in Westinghouse stock instead of cash to the company pension fund. Mr. Lego has refused to rule out the need for yet more loss reserves.  Overvalued Hotel Properties **********How did this corporate giant, better known for making complex electronic equipment, stumble so badly? **********Executives and analysts who have worked with Westinghouse or seen portions of its property portfolio said about 200 loans, or about a quarter of its portfolio, are in limited-service, franchised economy hotels like Hampton Inns, one of its largest borrowers, and Embassy Suites, Days Inn and some Marriott Courtyard motels. These loans, many of which went to small operators, were made on inflated appraisals in the late 1980's and too often represented a high portion of the appraised value, often between 75 percent and 95 percent. **********Sometimes developers who were looking to squeeze a little more cash out of their buildings would get a first mortgage for, say, 70 percent of the property from a bank or insurance company, and then go to Westinghouse Credit for a second mortgage secured by the additional 30 percent of value. **********In this depressed real estate market -- hotel property values have fallen by at least 30 percent in the last four years -- nearly all of Westinghouse's second mortgages have been wiped out, those familiar with Westinghouse's holdings said. Even many first mortgages are worth substantially less. **********Westinghouse Credit, along with the Japanese leasing companies, developed a reputation in the commercial real estate community as a lender of last resort: If you borrowed from them, you would have to pay higher loan fees, but they would make loans that banks would not make. **********In addition, credit companies can often close deals quicker because they are not subject to Government supervision as banks or insurance companies are. As a result, many of the big property syndicators and partnerships, like VMS Realty, the troubled Chicago real estate company, went to Westinghouse. **********"All the credit companies got into the hotel business in the mid-80's, when they saw the great returns they could get and the real estate climbing in value," said Dan W. Daniele, director of hospitality consulting services for Ernst & Young. "So they made five- to seven-year mini-perm loans and thought they could flip the hotels when the values rose. Now every credit company has a large portion of its underperforming assets that are hotels." **********All this has left Westinghouse Credit with a mountain of nonperforming mortgages secured by buildings that cannot, and will not for the forseeable future, support the debt. Meanwhile, its inventory of foreclosed real estate, valued at about $195 million in June, is rising as more developers walk away. **********"Westinghouse viewed it as a business like making lightbulbs or any other business," said a real estate executive. "It doesn't seem to have occurred to them that the reason they got such big fees was because the deals they were financing were incredibly risky." **********If the economy slows further, many of the hundreds of millions of dollars of mortgages that Westinghouse recently renegotiated to give borrowers more manageable terms may nevertheless become delinquent. **********"They were high-value lenders," said a banker who spoke on the condition of anonymity, "and their premise was that even if income were to go down, values would be sustained. But that didn't happen. Westinghouse underwrote income at very small margins, so if the income went down, they were in trouble." Need for More Financing **********Many people in the commercial property business said that Mr. Powe and the go-getters he assembled at Westinghouse Credit were aware of the risks but were counting on ever-increasing property values and Japanese and other willing foreign buyers. Now the Japanese have their own sour real estate investments to fret about, and Mr. Powe is out. **********And even assuming that Westinghouse is successful in its plans to raise $900 million, unknowns loom about the parent company's balance sheet, suggesting it will have a strong, continuing need for large amounts of bank financing. Even before the real estate reserves, the operating profits at the company's businesses were down 30 percent as of September. Last week, about 80 banks that lend to Westinghouse held preliminary discussions on the company's problems and near-term financial needs. **********Westinghouse has about $5 billion in short-term debt and commercial paper that will come due and need to be rolled over next year. The banks that will be asked to provide more credit will want to be certain that the company's liabilities and its real estate problems have been sufficiently provided for. **********Those liabilities include about $1 billion in unfinanced company pension fund charges, an estimated $500 million to $1 billion in environmental cleanup costs for some 57 sites and another estimated $500 million charge related to employee health-care benefits that must be addressed by Jan. 1, 1993. **********With a book value of about $3 billion plus another $900 million if the financing plan goes through, Westinghouse will be squeezed over the next year as some of these charges hit its bottom line. The net present value of the company is difficult to determine with these liabilies, but it seems clear that the banks will have to come to the rescue because the commercial paper market is effectively closed to Westinghouse. **********The company has had repeated downgradings of its credit ratings and has had trouble persuading investors that they should buy its commercial paper, the corporate i.o.u.'s that help manage its cash and liquidity. **********On top of that, Westinghouse Electric faces a class-action suit that contends the company failed to adequately disclose the extent of its real estate problems when it sold 21.5 million shares of common stock in May. At that time, Westinghouse traded at around $28 a share. On Friday, it closed at $16.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.  Nine-Month Loss **********Real estate woes were almost entirely responsible for Westinghouse Electric's $1.25 billion loss for the first nine months of this year on revenues of $9.37 billion. That compares with a net profit of $717 million, or $2.44 a share, on revenues of $9.21 billion for the comparable 1990 period. **********Mr. Heymann, the NatWest analyst, estimated that his previous worst-case prediction for the company's dividend -- that it would be cut in half, to 70 cents a share -- is now the best that can be expected. In fact, he and others believe the dividend may be temporarily eliminated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/busin.main_headline: Rich's Plans To Close Its Main Store
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/busin.print_headline: Rich's Plans To Close Its Main Store
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/busin.body_text: **********Rich's Inc., a landmark in downtown Atlanta for more than a century, announced yesterday that it would close the huge store on July 13 after five years of continuing losses. **********The announcement at 5 P.M. surprised the store staff, competitors and the public. Many had assumed that Rich's would stay put in its flagship location because of its participation in local affairs and continue its brisk competition with Macy's, its rival downtown. **********Rich's is one of nine store divisions of Federated Stores Inc., which filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in January 1990. The company also owns Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus in New York, Jordan Marsh in Boston and Miami, Burdines in Florida, Lazarus in Ohio and the Bon Marche in Seattle. The divisions have also been in Chapter 11 bankruptcy.  A Trend in Retailing **********The 13 Rich's suburban stores will stay open after the downtown flagship is closed, a Rich's statement said, and the 242 full-time and part-time employees in the main store will be offered jobs in the branches. Rich's owns both the store property and the land on which it is situated, according to Federated in Cincinnati. **********The closing of the Rich's main store continues a trend in big cities. **********"The continuing decline in sales in our downtown store, in stark contrast to our success in other locations, has forced us to make this difficult but basic business decision," said Roger Farah, Rich's chairman and chief executive. **********He said Rich's had postponed the decision for several years to "lend support to fledgling downtown development initiatives and the city's effort to stabilize the downtown business district." **********Company officials also said Rich's had hoped that business would return with the opening of Underground Atlanta, a retail and entertainment complex, but the success of the civic project failed to help the retailer.  Pink Pigs and Easy Returns **********For decades, the store lighted a Christmas tree on Thanksgiving night and gave children rides through the store on a miniature train with cars shaped like pink pigs. It offered customers an extremely liberal policy on returns, and its closing will be felt far beyond the loss of sales. **********Judith Webb, a native of Atlanta and an employee of the Chamber of Commerce, said: "I got my wedding dress at Rich's; I got my first prom dress at Rich's. I have amazing memories of coming downtown as a little child, riding the pink pig and getting all my school clothes. It's a sad thing." **********Rich's spent $9 million in 1985 to renovate the downtown store but customer traffic and sales continued to decline, Mr. Farah said. Profits in the location averaged $5 million to $6 million below the level needed to keep the store open. But sales at the downtown store represent only 3.7 percent of Rich's total 1990 sales of $824 million. **********In 1988, Federated merged its Goldsmith stores into Rich's and a headquarters staff was maintained for the combined group in the downtown Atlanta store. That staff of 900, which includes buying, merchandising, marketing, finance and accounting executives and associates, will remain in the building for the time being.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/15/busin.main_headline: The Executive Computer; Hands Off the Keys, Noses Into Books
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/15/busin.print_headline: The Executive Computer; Hands Off the Keys, Noses Into Books
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/15/busin.body_text: **********Not long ago, as part of a national survey, an advertising agency asked computer industry engineers and managers about their favorite leisure activities. **********Among those who responded, reading (18 percent) was by far the most popular choice, with golf (5 percent) a distant second. Other pastimes included: being with the family, travel, music, computer hacking and fishing (all 4 percent); woodworking and gardening (3 percent each), and sex (1 percent). **********So, without drawing any conclusions from the data, here are some suggestions for reading material and gifts. **********"Cyberspace: First Steps" ($24.95, Massachusetts Institute of Technology Press, Boston) is an anthology of essays and musings on one of the most exciting, exotic and least understood frontiers of computing. **********The term cyberspace, popularized in William Gibson's science fiction novel "Neuromancer," refers to the ephemeral otherworld that exists in the global electronic web of computer and communications networks. Although it has its genesis in science fiction, it is a mistake to conclude that it has no significance in the business world. **********If information is indeed the oil of the 21st century, computers are the refineries and networks are the the pipelines. Many companies, especially banks and other financial institutions, exist in the electronic twilight of computer systems. What is the essence of a bank, after all, if not a flow of data? **********Michael Benedikt, a professor of architecture at the University of Texas and editor of the book, refers to cyberspace as an "elusive and future thing," and it remains elusive at the conclusion of the book. Yet the descriptions offered in the book are compelling. The writers work at companies and institutions including the International Business Machines Corporation, Electronic Data Systems, Texas Instruments, Bull Worldwide Information Systems, Stanford and M.I.T. **********"The advent of cyberspace will have profound effects on so-called post-industrial culture," Mr. Benedikt writes, "and the material and economic rewards for those who first and most properly conceive and implement cyberspace systems will be enormous." **********Nearer on the horizon, and also promising rewards for business, are expert systems. "The Rise of the Expert Company" ($19.95, Times Books, New York City), by the artificial intelligence experts Edward Feigenbaum, Pamela McCorduck and H. Penny Nii, is subtitled "How Visionary Companies Are Using Artificial Intelligence to Achieve Higher Productivity and Profits." **********Artificial intelligence is one of those unfortunate terms that promises more than it delivers. Computers are not yet "smart," but they can serve as repositories for the collected wisdom and experience of senior executives. **********Others, then, can extract the intelligence and apply it to problems that range from product development and administration to manufacturing. A new breed of computer experts called knowledge engineers are creating a form of artificial intelligence known as expert systems. **********Expert systems allow companies, not just individual executives, to work smarter, and among the companies profiled are Du Pont, Fujitsu, Navistar, Northrop, Canon, I.B.M. and American Express. **********This book first appeared in 1988. But the vision it describes is perhaps more important today. Tom Peters, a management consultant and author, writes in the forward, "Any senior manager in any business of almost any size who isn't at least learning about artificial intelligence, and sticking a tentative toe or two into A.I.'s waters, is simply out of step, dangerously so." **********And then there is a book for executives and dreamers who are ready to go beyond toe-dipping and take the plunge. **********"High-Tech Ventures, The Guide for Entrepreneurial Success" ($29.95, Addison-Wesley Publishing Company, Reading, Mass.), is by C. Gordon Bell, with John E. McNamara. Mr. Bell, a scientist and engineer, worked 23 years as a research and development director at the Digital Equipment Corporation before becoming a principal in more than 20 high-tech start-up companies. Some succeeded, some failed. The lessons from each are laid down here. **********Anyone thinking of starting a high-tech company, or investing in one, will find this book valuable. Mr. Bell dissects start-ups including Ovation, Analytica, Cirrus Logic, Thinking Machines, Apollo and Sun, in each case offering behind-the-scenes insights into the heady world of high tech. **********"High-Tech Ventures" includes an explanation of the Bell-Mason Diagnostic and Prescriptive Method, developed with Heidi Mason, a specialist in high-tech marketing and sales. The Bell-Mason method is a rule-based tool that systematically assesses the health and wisdom of a start-up at several well-defined stages. **********There are charts and graphs aplenty, a natural given Mr. Bell's background as an engineer. These reveal the relative strengths and weaknesses of four key elements of any high-tech start-up -- technology/product, people, marketing/sales and finance/ control -- at each of four stages of growth. **********Each area, in turn, is measured in three dimensions. For example, the people quadrant is broken down to the chief executive, the directors and the team. A company can be strong in one area and weak in another, but rarely does a fledgling company succeed with the wrong leadership. **********"High-Tech Ventures" concludes with a look ahead, and its predictions are provocative: the United States will continue to lead the world in inventiveness; the Japanese will dominate every market through their strength in innovation. **********One area where American innovation may save the day is in computer programming, especially in an emerging field known as object-oriented programming. **********"Object Oriented Technology, a Manager's Guide" ($19.50, Addison-Wesley, paperback), by David A. Taylor, is one of the first accessible guides to the most important trend in software development. **********Mr. Taylor, a management consultant, has a knack for explaining highly technical concepts in a way that executives, managers and other nonprogrammers can grasp. The simple diagrams and illustrations make it virtually painless. **********Object-oriented programming (OOP) holds the promise of making it easier for executives to get the data they need, and it promises to allow businesses to construct software applications in a fraction of the time now needed. It does so by using software "packets" that contain data and the instructions necessary to act on the data. **********Only a few personal computer software companies, notably Borland International Inc., are pursuing OOP relentlessly. **********Philippe Kahn, the founder and chief executive of Borland, recently made a videotape explaining "The World of Objects" through the medium of Mr. Kahn's jazz band -- an analogy of individual components that know their own data and also how to act on it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/29/busin.body_text: **********For the first time, A.T.& T. and NCR suggested that a negotiated deal between them appeared to be within reach. **********At a news conference after the NCR's Corporation's annual meeting here today, Charles E. Exley Jr., the company's chairman, said the companies were moving closer to an agreement and would soon continue negotiations. He added, "It is not going to happen over the Easter weekend if I have anything to say about it." **********Although Mr. Exley said he still wanted NCR to remain independent, executives at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said they were optimistic about the apparent shift in Mr. Exley's position. "There seems to be a new attitude coming out," said Robert M. Kavner, a group executive with A.T.& T. "The environment, for the first time in four months, has changed to the point where a meeting of the minds is possible. There is no reason that it should take long."  Wall Street's Reaction **********NCR's share price jumped $2 today, to $99.625, on the New York Stock Exchange, while A.T.& T.'s fell 50 cents, to $34.25. **********Neither company would say when the next session of talks was scheduled. Mr. Exley said that future talks would be multilevel and that he expected to talk again with A.T.& T.'s chairman, Robert E. Allen. **********On a more immediate issue for NCR shareholders, A.T.& T. fell short of the 80 percent support from shareholders needed to replace NCR's entire board, a person close to A.T.&T said last night. But that person added that based on preliminary counts, the telephone company had won control of 4 of NCR's 12 board seats. **********The votes from the annual meeting and the special meeting called to conduct the vote on A.T.& T.'s effort to win control of the board will take about 10 days to tally. A.T.& T. needs a majority of the votes to gain the four board seats. **********In addition to the ballot on control of the board, shareholders voted on a nonbinding resolution calling for an end to NCR's anti-takeover devices. **********The companies must now come to terms on price. Mr. Exley confirmed that on Wednesday he authorized his advisers to seek $110 a share, or $7.45 billion, for NCR, a price that A.T.& T. refused to meet. **********A.T.& T. appears to be adopting a tough bargaining position. Mr. Kavner of A.T.& T. said, "The $110 price is not on the radar screen of where we see the values of the company." **********The person close to A.T.& T. said A.T.& T. might be willing to pay $105 a share in a stock deal if a friendly agreement could be consummated quickly. He had previously said that A.T.& T. had been willing to go as high as about $107 as a premium to get the deal done quickly but that it was growing frustrated by the delays. "The willingness to pay up is diminishing," said the person, who insisted on not being identified. **********Before agreeing to a stock transaction, A.T.& T. would want to make sure that accounting methods adopted by NCR would not make the deal financially harmful. A.T.& T. had been hoping to complete the deal before today's annual meeting. **********One analyst said A.T.& T. executives were annoyed by what they felt were bad faith bargaining tactics engaged in by Mr. Exley earlier in the week. After a long session on Monday that focused mainly on NCR's product line. Mr. Allen said in a letter earlier this week that Mr. Exley was not interested in serious negotiations. **********"Mr. Exley's shenanigans may have cost NCR a few bucks a share," said Jack Grubman, an analyst with Paine Webber who added that he expected a deal to be done soon at around $105 a share. **********"Price is the only issue and they are not that far apart," he said. **********A.T.& T. has offered $90 a share in cash for NCR and has said it would raise its bid to $100 in exchange for a negotiated settlement. In its request for $110 a share, NCR did not say whether it was seeking cash or stock.  The Talk of Dayton **********The annual meeting was the talk of the town in Dayton. The local newspaper, The Dayton Daily News, ran an article comparing the sizes of shrimp at A.T.& T. and NCR receptions. **********The meeting itself was orderly and businesslike. Several shareholders did urge NCR to keep fighting A.T.& T. and remain independent. Paul Granzow, an NCR shareholder who described himself as a native Daytonian, urged fellow shareholders to "think about more than just a quick buck." Speaking of NCR's long involvement in Dayton, he said, "There are certain things in our lives that are not for sale." **********The only heated exchange of the meeting came over a proposal that NCR stop doing business in South Africa. The outcome of that issue is also pending.
