https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.body_text: **********The Cray Computer Corporation said its first 16-processor Cray 3 supercomputer, which can perform a calculation in one two-billionths of a second, is scheduled to be shipped this year. Officials at the company's annual meeting said the $30 million computer had been purchased by the Department of Energy's Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in Northern California. **********The company said it had overcome problems caused by a shortage of gallium arsenide, which is used to give the computer's circuits their high speed, by making its own gallium arsenide circuits. Before the supercomputer is completed, however, its 16 processors must be linked together and tested.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/14/busin.body_text: **********Tiffany & Company said yesterday that the costs of new store openings, renovations and other investments to develop its business caused a 9.9 percent decline in fiscal third-quarter earnings. **********The New York jeweler's profits dropped to $8.2 million, or 52 cents a share, from $9.1 million, or 58 cents a share, in the period that ended Oct. 31, compared with the quarter last year. **********Although sales in the third quarter increased 12 percent, to $126.4 million, from $113.2 million in the period a year earlier, Tiffany's chairman, William R. Chaney, said sales were below expectations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/world.main_headline: Man in the News: Leonid Makarovich Kravchuk; Leader-Come-Lately
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/world.print_headline: Man in the News: Leonid Makarovich Kravchuk; Leader-Come-Lately
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/world.body_text: **********The metamorphosis of Leonid M. Kravchuk is something even a butterfly might find impressive. After more than 30 years as a plodding Communist ideologue conditioned to stomp on any manifestations of nationalism, he has abruptly burst forth as the first popularly elected national leader of Ukraine, dedicated to leading it out of the Soviet Union. **********Mr. Kravchuk, of course, is hardly the only former Communist among the leaders of the post-Communist Soviet states. Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Kremlin, Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and Nursultan A. Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan are only three of the better known new leaders who rose to political prominence through Communist ranks. **********But even in this company, Mr. Kravchuk's transformation stands out. While the others were mostly managers or administrators in the old days, Mr. Kravchuk spent the bulk of his party career on ideology. **********In Ukraine, in addition to churning out propaganda, that meant combating any sign of Ukrainian nationalism, which the Communist leadership always regarded as a mortal danger -- with some justification, as it turned out.  On the Fence in Coup **********There is little evidence, however, that Mr. Kravchuk's turnaround was a result of a dramatic change of heart. In fact, during the coup last August, when he was still a card-carrying Communist, he took a cautious fence-straddling stance, neither welcoming nor condemning the coup but only urging Ukrainians to stay calm. **********Mr. Kravchuk's metamorphosis, like that of the butterfly, was a matter of natural adaptation. In his case, it was a pragmatic politician's ability to change his colors and slogans as the Soviet Union and Ukraine moved in stages from totalitarian rule to democracy and national self-assertion. **********"I have read more about Ukraine in the past five years than in all the previous years of my life," Mr. Kravchuk confided to an interviewer recently. **********Recognizing the force of Ukrainian patriotism, perhaps from his years of fighting against it, he was the only high-ranking Communist leader to address the founding congress of Rukh, the umbrella organization of independence-minded Ukrainians, in September 1989. **********As the center of power across the nation shifted from the party to the newly elected parliaments, Mr. Kravchuk moved into the Ukrainian Supreme Soviet, where he was elected chairman in July 1990. He took to speaking only in Ukrainian, and in September 1990 he quit his post as ideology secretary of the Ukrainian party to devote full time to his parliamentary job, in which he soon became the effective leader of Ukraine.  Carrying Ukraine's Banner **********A master of compromise and adaptation, Mr. Kravchuk maneuvered between the growing nationalism of his republic and the machinations in Moscow, joining in negotiations on a new Union Treaty while guiding his parliament to a declaration of independence. **********After the coup, he declared that he had immediately quit the party in protest, and as the drive for independence gathered momentum he increasingly took up its banner, abandoning any efforts to form a new union while maintaining separate ties with Russia. Last month, he made successful visits to Canada and the United States to garner support for an independent Ukraine from emigres and the Governments. **********White-haired, ruddy and convincing as a speaker, Mr. Kravchuk has his most loyal following among the highly conservative rural population of Ukraine, to which he represents both the emotional attraction of independence and a link with the security and familiarity of the past. **********With these and many other voters, he succeeded in bridging the political gap between the nationalist ardor of Rukh and the large and anxious Russian population, which he went out of his way to reassure.  Teacher of Political Economy **********The son of a farmer, Leonid Makarovich Kravchuk was born in 1934 in the west Ukrainian village of Velyky Zhityn. His father was killed in World War II. **********Mr. Kravchuk went from a vocational school to Kiev University, where he studied Marxist political economy. After graduating at the age of 24, he became a teacher of political economy in the city of Chernovtsy. **********Mr. Kravchuk's wife, Antonina, is a teacher of political economy at Kiev University. They have a son and two grandsons. **********Mr. Kravchuk entered party work in Chernovtsy, but his rise was slow. At the onset of Mr. Gorbachev's rule he was still ideology secretary in a provincial party organization. **********With perestroika, however, he was thrust into Kiev, and once on the wave of events he never slipped.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/17/world.main_headline: Exiles From Kuwait Rejoice in Cairo
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/17/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: EGYPT; Exiles From Kuwait Rejoice in Cairo
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/17/world.body_text: **********Hundreds of Kuwaitis drove their cars around the corniche and over briges crossing the Nile River in downtown Cairo, honking and waving flags at around 2 A.M., after news of the American attack against Iraq and Kuwait began to spread here. **********Egyptian television suspended regular programming in the early morning to announce that "the Persian Gulf battle has started." **********Egyptian national radio, which broadcasts around the Arab world, transmitted President Bush's formal announcement of the start of the war at 4 A.M. Cairo time. **********"Thank God! Thank God!" was a cry heard over and over again in the lobby of the Intercontinental Hotel, where some Kuwaitis are staying, as many of them began to drift into the lobby, into the streets and eventually into cars in which they joined others.  30,000 Egyptians Deployed **********In the early morning, most of this city's 13 million people was asleep, unware that a battle in which some 30,000 to 40,000 Egyptian soldiers may take part had just begun. **********An Egyptian taxi driver who toured the city, watching the Kuwaitis demonstrating their enthusiasm, said: "We are worried about our people who are there. I hope the Americans have a good map. They should stay away from the areas where Egyptians live." **********It is estimated that 750,000 Egyptians are still living in Iraq. A senior Egyptian Foreign Ministry official said on Wednesday that efforts were under way to evacuate them via Jordan at a pace that may rise to 50,000 a day. **********But as early reports filtered to Egypt, it appeared that the initial attack against Iraq had largely avoided residential areas, at least in Baghdad, where many of the Egyptians live. Effect on Economy Feared **********Over the last two days, Egyptian newspapers have been filled with commentary warning of the devastating effect that a war will have on the economy of the region. **********Egypt has already suffered the impact of about one million expatriate Egyptians who have returned from Kuwait and Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Most have come back destitute, and are unable to find employment in an economy that cannot employ much of the work force. **********In addition to the new burden they represent, Egypt has been deprived of the remittances they used to send, a loss that has amounted to hundreds of millions of dollars since August. **********Tourism and the Suez Canal, two other major sources of income for Egypt, have been badly affected. The number of tourists in Egypt now is barely a 10th of the normal figure for this time of year, and fewer ships are traversing the canal. Calm Is Seen in Cairo **********The early morning edition of Al Ahram, the semi-official newspaper, declared that war had started in a banner headline that proclaimed the destruction of all missile bases, Iraqi communications centers, the Baghdad airport and the Iraqi broadcast station. **********"The Iraqi Air Force was nowhere in the battle of sky," Al Ahram said, adding that "the bombing aims at the total paralysis of Iraq." **********Cairo seemed calm and authorities said the airport would function normally today and that Government-owned television would continue to broadcast news in a nonstop fashion to cover the gulf war. **********It even seemed that the apparent success of the first strike against Iraq hads motivated some writers to speak of the beginning of a new erar for the Arab world. **********"The tragedy of a large number of the population in the Arab world is that it is living in a fog in which its rulers have been turned to gods who demand thatey their subjects kneel and worships them," wrote Said Senbel, editor in chief of Al Akbar, the largest Egyptian daily, in a front-page editorial today. **********Mr. Senbel went on to say that the era of empty sloaganeering in praise of Arab dictators hads come to end, "and it is its a sorry thing that some people never learn." Castro Criticizes U.N. **********HAVANA, Jan. 16 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Cuban President, Fidel Castro, criticized the United Nations tonight for the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf. **********In remarks to foreign journalists moments after he was told of the outbreak of fighting in the gulf, Mr. Castro said: **********"The Security Council had a great arsenal of measures at its disposal, even economic measures, medical measures without embargoing food measures. There could have been other economic measures. There could have been isolation. There could have been more political condemnation. There were a broad range of measures that they could have taken without resorting to weapons. From the beginning to the end, they had only a declaration to war, not to peace." **********He also said the war could have its most severe consequences for third world nations like Cuba. He feared that an increase in oil prices would drastically hurt his economy, which is already operating under austerity measures imposed five months ago. Japan Considers More Aid **********TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 17 (Special to The New York Times) -- Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu summoned his senior national security advisers into an emergency session this morning amid signs that Japan would make some sort of announcement about providing additional financial assistance to the war against Iraq. **********Japanese officials said they would try to prepare a quick announcement of assistance to try to mute possible worldwide criticism over Japan's decision to help pay for the war but not to go into combat itself. **********The officials said Tokyo also wanted to avoid the delays in announcing aid that led to criticism last summer. **********"The most important message we have right now is that we stand firmly by the United States," Taizo Watanabe, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, said on Wednesday. "We won't have to ask America if they need a contribution. We take it for granted they will need it, and we have got to pay."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/26/busin.main_headline: Panel Asks Bush to Cite 3 Nations
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/26/busin.print_headline: Panel Asks Bush to Cite 3 Nations
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/26/busin.body_text: **********A panel of Cabinet officials has recommended to President Bush that the United States officially cite China, India and Thailand on Friday for tolerating violations of American copyrights and patents, Congressional and Administration officials said today. **********Such a move would require the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills to begin a formal investigation and negotiations with each country. It would also authorize, but not require, her to increase duties or introduce other restrictions on imports from these countries if no improvements were made by December or early next year. **********The United States and American trade associations are concerned about reports that Chinese companies are copying American pharmaceuticals, agricultural chemicals and computer programs without paying any license fees to the inventors. They have also complained that India and Thailand do not protect American patents on pharmaceuticals and copyrights on records, books and movies.  Difficulty Seen in Citing China **********The recommendation of the Economic Policy Council, which includes President Bush's top advisers on economic issues, does not guarantee that China will be cited. A former Ambassador to China, the President has made American relations with China his personal responsibility and has resisted sanctions proposed in the past for Chinese human rights violations. **********Victoria Clarke, a spokeswoman for the Office of the United States Trade Representative, declined to comment. "There's only one desk officer in this town on China, and that's George Bush," she said. **********Wu Jianmin, a spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, warned the United States today that any punitive measures linked to intellectual property rights would hurt relations with China, The Associated Press reported from Beijing. Decision Near on China's Status **********The decision on whether to cite China for failing to protect American intellectual property rights comes almost two years after the Tiananmen Square massacre and less than six weeks before the President must decide whether to renew China's most-favored-nation trading status. This status, granted in 1980, allows Chinese goods to enter the United States at the lowest tariff rates available for each product. **********China's most-favored-nation status is subject to annual renewal by the President with the acquiescence of either house of Congress. When President Bush renewed the status last year, House members angry about Chinese human rights violations voted to cancel the move, but the Senate took no action before going into its summer recess. **********President Bush is required to notify Congress by June 3 of any renewal this year. Opponents of most-favored-nation status for China, who have been led by Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, would then have until Sept. 3 to overturn this step. Special 301 Measure **********The action recommended by the Economic Policy Council on Wednesday night would represent the first time that the United States has cited a country under the so-called Special 301 measure. This measure is a section of the nation's trade law that was amended by the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 to toughen penalties for foreign countries that do not protect American intellectual property rights. **********In 1989 and 1990, the United States put several countries -- including China, India and Thailand -- on a list of countries to be monitored for possible failures to protect American copyrights and patents. **********The Trade Policy Group, an interagency committee of deputies to the members of the Economic Policy Council, recommended last week to the council that Indonesia also be cited, prompting an unusual burst of lobbying by representatives of the Indonesian Government, a Congressional official said today. Indonesia was not included in the final list of countries recommended by the Economic Policy Council, said the Administration officials, who spoke on condition that they not be identified. Thai Official's Comment **********Indonesian and Indian officials declined to comment. A Thai official who insisted on anonymity said trade negotiations between Thai and American officials at the United States consulate in Amsterdam ended earlier this week without an agreement on intellectual property. **********In its recently published annual review of foreign trade barriers, the Office of the United States Trade Representative found that China lacked a copyright law and that a planned law fell short of international standards. The Federal agency also cited industry reports that patented American pharmaceutical and oter chemical products were "being produced in China, without license, for both domestic and export markets." **********The report added that "China, in copying these U.S. products, reaps the benefits without incurring the associated costs" of development. **********The President's response is imminent because under the Special 301 measure, the United States trade representative, who is part of the President's Executive Office, must identify offending countries within 30 days after issuing its annual report on foreign trade barriers. The report was issued this year on March 29, meaning that the last business day before the deadline is Friday.  Discouraging to Investment **********Roger W. Sullivan, the president of the United States-China Business Council, a Washington-based association of American companies with investments in China, said the lack of protection for intellectual property rights there was discouraging investment. **********Mr. Sullivan said American executives had told him, "We're not going to go forward with this investment because the guy who supplied us with the process software won't let us go in there." **********The trade association has favored the citing of China under Special 301, while continuing to oppose any effort to take away China's most-favored-nation status. "Some of the companies, particularly the larger ones, feel that this is the way to address the real problems, and not the blockbuster approach" of removing most-favored-nation status, Mr. Sullivan said. Wider Charges Against China **********China's image in Congress has declined further in recent months because of its ballooning trade surplus with the United States, allegations that it forces political prisoners to produce products for export markets and concerns about its exports of arms and nuclear technology. **********Representative Pelosi plans to introduce a measure next week in the House that would link a renewal of China's most-favored-nation status to its performance on human rights, an aide said today. **********The Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman also said today that linking trade ties to human rights would hurt American relations with China, The Associated Press reported.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/22/busin.main_headline: Technology; Measuring How Fast Computers Really Are
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/22/busin.print_headline: Technology; Measuring How Fast Computers Really Are
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/22/busin.body_text: **********In the world of scientific and technical computing, everyone agrees that computer speeds are increasing at a geometric rate. But measuring that speed is a vexing task. Rival supercomputer and work station manufacturers are prone to hype, choosing the performance figures that make their own machines look best. **********"It's like the Wild West," said David J. Kuck, of the Center for Supercomputing Research and Development at the University of Illinois. "They say whatever they want to." **********In fact, said David H. Bailey, a scientist at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, "It's not really to the point of widespread fraud, but if people aren't a little more circumspect, the entire field could start to get a bad name." **********The matter is complicated by a new generation of computers that have dozens, or even thousands, of separate processors. These parallel computers split problems into small parts and solve them simultaneously to reach greater speeds. **********As a result, dozens of programs for determining benchmarks -- measurements of computer speed -- have been developed by scientists at universities and in government agencies. Some are based on how long a computer takes to solve a certain set of equations, while more sophisticated benchmarks attempt to match the operations required by real-world programs. But each benchmark generally measures only a single aspect of computer performance. **********Just as a car buyer might buy a vehicle with the highest E.P.A. gas mileage rating for the price, a computer buyer could use benchmarks in deciding which machine to buy. But like their counterparts in the auto business, computer makers would do well to remind customers, "Your mileage may vary." The industry has no independent organization, analogous to the Environmental Protection Agency, to establish a single standard. **********The proliferation of benchmarks is particularly problematic among the fastest scientific machines, where more than a dozen start-up companies compete to sell to university, corporate and Government laboratories. **********These machines sell for hundreds of thousands of dollars or more, and the sale of only a few can mean success for a company. Supercomputers and smaller scientific work stations work on problems ranging from designing pharmaceuticals and weapons to weather modeling and the simulated crashing of automobiles. **********Uneasy about the tendency for manufacturers to cite inflated claims, Mr. Bailey of NASA wrote a tongue-in-cheek indictment of performance claims for Supercomputing Review magazine in August. Titled "Twelve Ways to Fool the Masses When Giving Performance Results on Parallel Computers," it pokes fun at the tendency of computer makers to play fast and loose with speed claims. **********It is common practice to "tune" computers and software to score better on benchmarks.  "I know of a couple of companies who have full-time people, and all they do is optimize programs to achieve better benchmark results," said Gary Smaby, president of the Smaby Group, a consulting and market research firm in Minneapolis. **********Such optimization is permissible under the rules established by benchmark designers to insure that computer makers can extract the full capability from their systems. **********But some manufacturers go further and insert modules called "recognizers" into their compilers -- software that translates a programmer's instructions into machine-readable form. When the recognizer finds a clue that points to a benchmark, it employs a specially written program that is designed to run a benchmark as quickly as possible. **********Computer scientists say recognizers can be used to short-circuit the benchmark-measuring process and should be banned. **********Today the most widely cited benchmark is Linpack. It is a set of linear algebra equations that requires a very large number of mathematical calculations to solve. Currently, the highest Linpack by a traditional supercomputer, measured in millions of mathematical calculations per second, is held by a Cray Y/MP. Its record: 403 million floating point calculations per second. **********There is a similar Linpack measure for makers of massively parallel computers, and this summer the lead seesawed back and forth between Intel's Delta supercomputer and Thinking Machines' CM-200 Connection Machine. At the moment the Intel Delta has achieved the highest Linpack measure, 11.9 billion floating point calculations per second. **********The Linpack benchmark results are expressed as several numbers, including the actual speed at solving the equations and another number called "theoretical peak performance," which represents a computer's absolute peak efficiency. In practice, computers generally reach only a small fraction of their theoretical peak speed. **********Linpack was developed as part of an appendix to a book written by a University of Tennessee computer scientist, Jack Dongarra, in 1979. "The original benchmark was an accident," he said. "We were writing a book and were attempting to give the user a feeling for how fast particular computers could solve a problems." **********The problem, Mr. Dongarra said, was chosen so that it could be run on all of the 20 machines that were being compared. There are now Linpack numbers for more than 500 machines, from laptops to supercomputers. **********Mr. Dongarra acknowledges that Linpack is a limited measure, and he is working on a second-generation measure named Lapack. But a number of other researchers have developed alternative benchmarks in an effort to provide a more complete profile of computer performance. **********One recently introduced benchmark is called Slalom, developed by John Gustafson, a mathematician at the Department of Energy's Ames Laboratory. "I worked in industry for several years, and I was frustrated by inaccuracy and general lack of credibility in the ways we had of measuring computer performance," he said. **********Rather than measuring how quickly a computer can solve a particular problem, Slalom attempts to measure how much work a computer can complete in one minute. **********The problem computers must calculate as part of the Slalom benchmark is measuring the interplay of light in a room in which each surface is painted a different color. A particularly powerful computer will obtain higher resolution in one minute of computing time than a slower one. **********One strength of Slalom is that it measures several aspects of computer performance, including the time taken to set up a problem. Hightest on the Slalom scale is the experimental Intel Delta supercomputer, installed at the California Institute of Technology. **********Another approach has been taken by scientists at the Center for Supercomputing Research and Development at the University of Illinois. The group, called the Perfect Club, has composed a set of speed tests it calls the Perfect Benchmarks, a set of programs that are closely patterned after real programs run by scientific computers. **********These benchmarks attempt to get as close as possible to the ultimate test of a computer's performance -- the actual programs that it will run. "The only important benchmark for most customers is the code they intend to run, and there is no substitute for that," Mr. Smaby said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/busin.main_headline: More Ford Layoffs, A Newspaper Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; More Ford Layoffs, A Newspaper Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company plans to lay off 200 more white-collar workers as part of a $3 billion cost-cutting program, according to The Detroit News. The layoffs will be in Ford's North American Automotive Operations division, the newspaper quoted an unidentified top company official as saying. A Ford spokesman, Dick Routh, had no immediate comment. **********The layoffs would be staggered throughout the rest of the year, the newspaper reported. Company officials have said in the past that engineering jobs are exempt as the auto maker focuses on developing new cars and trucks for the mid-1990's. The layoffs would be in addition to to the 250 salaried workers the company laid off earlier this year and the 1,350 white-collar workers who retired early under a special program. Before the cost-cutting began late last year, Ford's North American auto operations had about 50,000 salaried employees.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/13/world.body_text: **********Similar geological processes are responsible for major eruptions of volcanoes in Japan and the Philippines, but they are too far apart to be directly related, geologists say. **********In each case a section of sea floor known as the Philippine Plate is plunging into the deep earth under the islands. That generates the earthquakes common in the region and, when the descending plate reaches a depth of about 60 miles, it produces molten rock that rises to the surface and feeds volcanoes. **********Of 37 volcanoes around the world currently listed as active, 29, including Mount Unzen in Japan and Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines, both of which erupted yesterday, lie on the Pacific "Ring of Fire" and, according to specialists, are products of motion by sections of the Pacific floor. **********Volcanoes in the Japanese islands may be interrelated, they say, but they consider it highly improbable that the Mount Unzen eruption is related to that of Mount Pinatubo, 1,500 miles away. **********The movement of sections of the Pacific floor often leads to explosive eruptions, as in the 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens in Washington State. Such explosions have virtually destroyed an entire mountain, as in the 1912 eruption of Mount Katmai on the Alaska Peninsula, leaving the Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes as its residue. When Mount Mazama blew up 6,700 years ago in what is now southern Oregon, it left Crater Lake.The volcanoes of mid-ocean islands, such as those of Hawaii, Iceland and the Azores, tend to have lava so fluid that it flows long distances, forming a broad, gently sloping volcano. **********A catalogue of worldwide volcanic activity published monthly in the Bulletin of the Smithsonian Institution's Global Volcanism Network lists 5 active volcanoes in Indonesia, 2 in the Mediterranean and 1 in Hawaii in addition to the 29 on the rim of the Pacific. Four of the Indonesian volcanoes are in Java, the other being on the island of Flores. They are aligned where sea floor, riding north with Australia, is believed to be burrowing under the arc of Indonesian islands. **********On the east side of the Pacific ring, seven currently active volcanoes are related to eastward motion by the Pacific floor's Cocos Plate, which is burrowing under Mexico and Central America. Four are in Costa Rica, two in Guatemala and one in Mexico. The Nazca Plate, pushing east under South America, is linked, in Colombia, to the eruption of Nevado del Ruiz, whose 1985 eruption caused mudslides that buried 21,000 people. **********In recent months three volcanoes on the Japanese island of Kyushu have been active. Of those, Mount Unzen has been the most threatening, having already killed 38 people and evoking memories of its last eruption, in 1792. That eruption set off a tsunami, a huge sea wave, that killed 15,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/08/world.main_headline: U.N. AIDES DISCOVER ATOM ARMS CENTER CONCEALED BY IRAQ
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/08/world.print_headline: U.N. AIDES DISCOVER ATOM ARMS CENTER CONCEALED BY IRAQ
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/08/world.body_text: **********United Nations inspectors have discovered a complex of buildings that apparently served as the nerve center of President Saddam Hussein's covert nuclear weapons program but largely escaped allied attack during the Persian Gulf war. **********In a report to the Security Council, United Nations inspectors sent to ferret out Mr. Hussein's nuclear plans said that on their most recent trip to Iraq they had found a top-secret document indicating that the hub of Iraq's weapons-development program was a scientific research installation called Al Atheer, about 40 miles south of Baghdad. **********It was here, the report says, that Mr. Hussein planned "to design and produce a nuclear device," although Iraq has said the installation "had no nuclear connection."  Lightly Bombed in War **********Previous inspection teams decided that Al Atheer was probably intended for the production of components for a nuclear weapon. **********American and other allied intelligence agencies also apparently failed to spot the importance of this plant, officials say. It was only lightly bombed during the gulf war, with about 15 percent of its buildings hit, far fewer than at many other suspected nuclear sites that were almost completely destroyed. **********The allies' failure to destroy this central nuclear installation in the air war against Iraq is a further indication that they underestimated the size of Iraq's nuclear program and overestimated the damage they had inflicted on it. **********On Jan. 23, for instance, a week after the start of the air war, President Bush said, "Our pinpoint attacks have put Saddam out of the nuclear bomb-building business for a long time." **********On different occasions in late January, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the allied commander, said attacks had "destroyed all their nuclear-reactor facilities" and "neutralized their nuclear manufacturing capability." **********The new report summarizes the preliminary findings of the sixth nuclear inspection visit that the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency has made in Iraq under the terms of the Security Council's cease-fire agreement with Baghdad. **********The report is based on a partial examination of more than 25,000 secret Iraqi documents, which the inspectors finally managed to remove from the country last month after twice being expelled from the sites where they were collecting material. **********The whole team was then detained for 96 hours, held in a Baghdad parking lot in Iraq's most serious confrontation with the Security Council since the end of the war. **********The report says the 44-member inspection team, which included American and British nuclear-weapon designers, "obtained conclusive evidence that the Government of Iraq had a program for developing an implosion-type nuclear weapon," which was code-named "Petrochemical Three." **********Documents taken by the inspectors describe "nuclear weapons development experiments" involving, among other things, "neutron initiators, enriched uranium cores, reflectors, high explosive lenses and electronic firing sets." **********One document says Iraq successfully produced nuclear weapons components out of natural uranium. But the Atomic Energy Agency inspectors have still not discovered whether Iraq's ambitious uranium-enrichment program had produced enough nuclear explosive "for an actual explosive device" by the time it was brought to a standstill by the allied raids. **********The report also reveals that Iraqi scientists were working on a "surface-to-surface missile system -- presumably the intended delivery system for their nuclear weapon." **********Besides destroying only part of the Al Atheer plant, the allies failed even to attack a plant at Furat, outside Baghdad, where Iraq was secretly building uranium-enrichment centrifuges, because they did not know it was part of the weapons-development program. The plant's true purpose was discovered by the Atomic Energy Agency only after the end of the war. **********Like earlier disclosures, the report to the Security Council does not identify any foreign companies or experts that helped Iraq with its nuclear ambitions. But it makes clear that the inspectors have gathered evidence of "substantial nuclear weapons-related procurement from foreign sources." **********It says Iraq drew up lists of "approved suppliers whose products would meet the program's technical specification." But in making these foreign purchases, Iraq sometimes used "cover names" to disguise the products' destination. And many of the goods Iraq purchased abroad for its nuclear program were "multi-use items" with innocent applications. **********The report also concludes that Dr. Jaffar Dhia Jaffar, the deputy director of Iraq's Atomic Energy Commission, probably had "the lead technical and administrative responsibility for the nuclear program as a whole, despite his repeated claims that no such program existed." **********The United Nations had been looking for a missing "mastermind" with overall control of the uranium-enrichment and weapons-design program, largely because Dr. Jaffar, a British-trained Iraqi scientist, claimed he knew only about the enrichment side. **********But on the basis of personnel records removed from Baghdad, the inspectors have now concluded Dr. Jaffar was, in effect, managing both the enrichment and the weapons-design program, although they do not rule out the idea that he may have been helped by unknown foreign scientists. **********Finally, the report reveals that the first site raided by the inspectors last month was an installation identified as "the Nuclear Design Center," and that the second was the headquarters of the "Petrochemical Three" project. **********Since neither site had been bombed by the allies, United Nations officials assume that the locations had only recently been discovered by Western intelligence services.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/world.main_headline: Israeli General Is Sentenced To 13 Years in Bribery Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/world.print_headline: Israeli General Is Sentenced To 13 Years in Bribery Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/world.body_text: **********A former chief purchasing officer in the Israeli Air Force was sentenced today to 13 years in prison for receiving $10 million in bribes and kickbacks on purchases of American-made equipment. **********Brig. Gen. Rami Dotan's rank was reduced to private and he will be dishonorably discharged, the military court said. **********Nine other officers have been implicated in the scandal. The officers, with ranks up to lieutenant colonel, reportedly hid incriminating documents and gave false testimony. Several private contractors in Israel have also been implicated. **********In the United States, the Justice Department is conducting an investigation to determine whether employees of the General Electric Company bribed General Dotan. The company has announced its own internal inquiry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/23/busin.main_headline: Making a Difference; The Money Man at Baltia
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/23/busin.print_headline: Making a Difference; The Money Man at Baltia
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/23/busin.body_text: **********About a year ago, Harold J. Pareti, the president of Airline Economics Inc., a Washington-based consulting firm, was asked to help arrange financing for a group that wanted to start an airline. **********Mr. Pareti, who had helped to get People Express and Presidential Airways off the ground, quickly raised a small amount while the owners of the nascent Baltia Air Lines mobilized for hearings at the Department of Transportation. **********Earlier this month, the group, headed by Igor Dmitrowsky, a Latvian immigrant, hit the jackpot: Baltia won the right to fly from New York to Riga, Latvia, to become only the fourth American carrier with routes between the United States and the Soviet Union. **********Now, Mr. Pareti seems on the verge of landing enough money to buy Baltia its first planes. In recent days, he has been working with the Waterford Group, a Texas-based investment concern that has told Baltia it may soon put together a $150 million package of loans. An announcement is expected this week. **********Mr. Pareti left People Express in January 1985 as it was being taken over by Texas Air and helped start Presidential Air that year. Because of a major buildup by United and Continental airlines at Presidential's hub, Dulles International Airport outside Washington, the carrier was forced to liquidate. **********Mr. Pareti, 43, has been named vice chairman and acting vice president of finance for Baltia. But he does not plan to stay with the carrier for long; instead, he said, he would remain at Airline Economics, where he is a principal investor. Baltia has given the firm 4.8 percent of its stock in return for his help.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/24/busin.body_text: **********The First Interstate Bancorp's Texas unit is seeking to buy distressed financial institutions, said Linnet F. Deily, the president of the First Interstate Bank of Texas. The operation recently bought a failed savings and loan association in Houston. Mr. Deily refused to comment when asked if a possible acquisition target was the First City Bancorporation of Texas. First City has said it is seeking a cash infusion or a buyer. In June, First Interstate Bank of Texas bought the defunct Commonwealth Federal Savings Association, which added 33 branches and $1.1 billion in deposits to the Houston-based company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/08/world.main_headline: U.N. Advises Its Non-Essential Staff to Leave Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/08/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF; U.N. Advises Its Non-Essential Staff to Leave Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/08/world.body_text: **********The United Nations advised all its non-essential employees today to leave Israel right away, adding to the throngs of foreigners crowding Ben-Gurion International Airport, fleeing before the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraqi withdraw from Kuwait. **********Airport officials reported that all outgoing flights were sold out for the next several days as many foreign students, businessmen, journalists, diplomats and foreign workers left because of fear of war. **********"A lot of my friends are taking a break or traveling in Europe, just to be safe, but are definitely planning on coming back," said Shamir Kaplan, a visiting college student. **********Joe Smith, another student, said, "The reason students are leaving is that parents are very upset." **********Israelis, too, began further preparing themselves for the possibility that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq will make good on his threat to mount a vast chemical attack on Israel if should American and allied forces attack his forces.  Giving Out More Gas Masks **********The Defense Ministry announced tonight that the Government would distribute an additional 1 million gas masks to residents of rural areas, including those in Israeli-Arab villages in northern Galilee. **********Until now, only residents of Jerusalem, Tel Aviv and other metropolitan areas were given the masks, under a mass-distribution program that began in October. About 3.5 million protective kits were distributed before now. **********Officials believe that any Iraqi missiles would be aimed at cities. But the missiles are known to be inaccurate. And besides, Brig. Gen. Nachman Shai said today, the army wants to be sure "there will be a feeling of justice and equality for everyone." **********Palestinians in the occupied territories were offered the opportunity to buy masks, while Israelis were given the masks free. The Government said Israelis had already paid for the masks with their taxes, though Palestinians pay significant Israeli taxes, too. In any case, few Palestinians have bought masks, and many among them have been openly calling on Mr. Hussein to strike Israel with chemical weapons. **********Today Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and other Government officials said they feared that war was close to inevitable. **********"The logic of facts says there is no way to avoid this," Mr. Shamir said. "The whole matter is so surprising and unbelievable that I would advise ourselves to be prepared for anything." **********Finland and Britain added their names today to the growing list of nations advising their citizens to consider leaving Israel before Jan. 15. At the international airport, an official said the packed planes were carrying some Israelis, too, who left with their children.  Seven Airlines Cut Flights **********The United Nations said its planes would begin evacuating non-essential personnel and family members on Thursday. **********Over the last week, seven foreign airlines have canceled or seriously curtailed their flights to Israel because of rising insurance rates. **********Over the last week, seven foreign airlines have canceled or seriously curtailed their flights to Israel because of rising insurance rates. **********As Transport Minister Moshe Katsav met with foreign airline representatives today, trying to persuade them to resume service, another major airline, Alitalia, announced that it too was canceling its flights to Israel. **********Those planes arriving are at best half full. One of Jerusalem's largest tourist hotels, the Hilton, reported that it had reservations for only four guests on Jan. 15, the deadline. **********Many of the visitors still arriving are members of Jewish "solidarity" groups that visit here to show support whenever Israel faces difficult times.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/18/world.main_headline: Disgruntled India; The Voters Make Clear Their Discontent, Giving No Party a Majority in Low Turnout
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/18/world.print_headline: Disgruntled India; The Voters Make Clear Their Discontent, Giving No Party a Majority in Low Turnout
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/18/world.body_text: **********The political map of India has been redrawn in the turbulent election of 1991, geographically and demographically. Traditional voting patterns have been upset as fewer voters than ever cast ballots in what is the world's most populous democracy and also one of the poorest of nations. **********"I do not think our electorate is very clear about what it wants," said Ashis Nandy, a political scientist at the Center for the Study of Developing Societies in Delhi. "But the lesson of this election is that any party that has been in power has paid for it."  Congress Fares Badly in North **********By early this morning, with 320 of the 511 contested Parliament seats decided, the Congress Party had won 168 and was projected to win 210 to 215, well shy of the 256 it would need to form a government without a coalition partner. The Bharatiya Janata Party, the surging Hindu nationalist party, had won 73 seats and was projected to win 120. In third place, the Janata Dal coalition, which stirred controversy in championing Government affirmative action for lower castes, had won 24 seats. The rest of the decided seats went to smaller parties. **********Denied a clear majority, the century-old Congress Party, in the throes of choosing a new candidate for Prime Minister after the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi, has been evicted from its strongholds among the poor, the Muslims and the upper castes in the northern states, and is now all but totally reliant on the support of allies in the south. **********The Janata Dal coalition, which came to power under Prime Minister V. P. Singh in 1989 on a burst of enthusiasm for clean government and a break from one-party, one-family rule under Congress, now retains a significant presence in only three states, the heavily populated and important states of Uttar Pradesh and Bihar in the north and Orissa, a smaller state in the east. **********Other politicians who had backed Mr. Singh as part of his National Front coalition, only to split with him over his program to aid the most disadvantaged, are battling to carve out constituencies that will enable them to survive. Much of the intellectual middle class, which had asserted itself through the front, was stunned and disappointed when Mr. Singh's promises of modernization turned out to include an expanded affirmative action program for the poorest and weakest castes. **********This energized middle class, so vocal and aggressive in the previous election, is now hard to find within the vote totals being tallied. **********The question is, where did they go? **********A lot of them, their hopes dashed, opted out of political activity. With 53 percent of eligible voters casting ballots, the 1991 election had the lowest turnout of any modern Indian election, although even this was similar to the turnout for recent United States presidential elections. **********"People like us do not vote," said Mr. Nandy, the political scientist. "Only the lower ranks still have faith in the electoral system." **********But parties representing the most underprivileged Indians did not fare too well either. The Bahujan Samaj, appealing to outcastes to use their numerical superiority and seize political power, is teetering on extinction. **********The Bharatiya Janata Party, the new force representing Hindu revivalism and upper caste privilege in a country that is more than 80 percent Hindu, has become the most dynamic national political organization, and in the process is positioning itself as the next hope for that significant part of the Indian middle class that is both Hindu and higher caste. **********The party has captured the country's most populous state, Uttar Pradesh, the home base of the dynasty of Jawaharlal Nehru and the source of all but one of India's Prime Ministers.  Behind the Party's Success **********Mr. Nandy said that the success of the Hindu party had a lot to do with its effectiveness in packaging some of its least attractive appeals to religious chauvinism in the language of nationalism and equality, though equality is oftened defined as the phasing out of minority rights. **********The party, however, also lost ground in states where it had been voted to power a scant year ago, raising questions about whether its success can be sustained. **********The only exception to the "toss the rascals out" rule in this election seemed to be the support shown in the state of West Bengal for the Communist Party of India-Marxist, the larger of two Communist organizations. There, Chief Minister Jyoti Basu, in power for 14 years, obtained another term with a majority in the state assembly. The party was also leading in parliamentary contests. **********The restless middle class has traditionally found other ways of gaining power, Mr. Nandy said, through control of news organizations and dominance of a vast Civil Service, among other methods. Many seem to feel that the overly centralized, openly corrupt political system only gets in the way of economic development. **********A young clothing designer was bluntly direct. "Politicians are all jerks," he said. "There isn't any one of them competent to run this place. They are screwing up business."  Big Turnout of Women **********Mr. Nandy said that the failure of the Janata Dal was its inability to make its long-term development aims clear to the expanding middle class -- up to 150 million people out of more than 817 million -- whose traditional commitment has been to its own privileges in an overpopulated society where resources and jobs are scarce. Mr. Singh's affirmative action plan, which he calls essential to the social and economic growth of the nation, frightened and outraged many of them. **********But politicians say that the poor performance of the Janata Dal coalition and the generally inconclusive verdict delivered by a skeptical electorate could also be explained by other factors without long-term implications. **********Madhu Dandavate, Finance Minister in the Government of Prime Minister Singh and one of a lengthening list of former officials defeated in this election, said today in a television interview that in his Maharashtra constituency the turnout of women had been higher than of men. He said he believed that the women voted "from their hearts" for the party of the slain Mr. Gandhi. **********A similar trend was observed in the southern state of Kerala, where a resilient Communist-led Government was wiped out in a Congress Party surge -- helped, apparently, by a large turnout of women and tacit help from the Bharatiya Janata Party, which knew it did not have much hope of penetrating the electorate on its own in a region remote from its northern power base. **********Prannoy Roy, a political scientist and polling expert, said his data suggested that Congress benefited not so much from a "sympathy wave" after Mr. Gandhi's slaying as from a "re-energizing" of Congress supporters in response to the tragedy that had befallen the party.  Congress Seeking Allies **********Whether this modest resurgence of support for Congress is sustained, however, depends on the party's ability to choose the right prime ministerial candidate, the most effective coalition partner and the most vigorous program for dealing with an impending economic crisis in India. **********Congress Party leaders have been phoning and meeting privately with officials of left-of-center parties as well as regional parties to gather the necessary majority in Parliament. A panel of two dozen Congress leaders is expected to name the party's parliamentary leader, and hence its choice for Prime Minister, in time for presentation to the party's legislators on Thursday. **********After Mr. Gandhi's killing, the party leaders, seeking a sympathy vote and without a natural heir to the leadership, immediately turned to his widow, Sonia Gandhi, to ask her to take over. Mrs. Gandhi's rejection forced the party to turn at least temporarily to an ailing 70-year-old Brahmin, P. V. Narasimha Rao. Mr. Rao had faithfully served under Mr. Gandhi, who was Prime Minister from 1984 to 1989, and under his mother, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/18/world.main_headline: Limerick Journal; An Irish City Bounces Back, in the Spirit of 1691
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/18/world.print_headline: Limerick Journal; An Irish City Bounces Back, in the Spirit of 1691
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/18/world.body_text: **********People living here in Ireland's third-largest city, along the banks of what James Joyce described as "the dark mutinous Shannon waves," have long been accustomed to hearing their town bad-mouthed by the rest of the country. **********To the smart alecks of Cork and Dublin, Limerick is "Stab City," where no one is safe on the streets. It has been a place to ridicule whether or not one has been there or knows very much about it. There is even doubt that the eponymous poetic form really started here. **********In some ways, Limerick's problems reflect Ireland's: its unemployment rate is at the national average of 20 percent; it is ruefully watching young people emigrate to the Dublin area, Britain or America. **********But in recent years the 1,000-year-old town on the Shannon River in western Ireland has been working hard, with some success, to improve not only its image and the physical look of the place but also the quality of life of its 76,000 people.  Foreign Companies Arrive **********An urban renewal program has cleaned out slums, refurbished the city hall area and attracted foreign companies to a clean, landscaped industrial park, providing hundreds of new jobs. As it finishes a year of celebrating its history, the city is arguing the merits of a renovation of its main medieval castle to attract more tourism. **********The Mayor, Jim Kemmy, a 55-year-old stonemason, said: "Limerick has no more crime than any other place. The tabloids named us Stab City. The tabloids go for short words." **********Indeed, none of Ireland's 17 murders in 1990 were committed in Limerick, and officials say there is no statistical proof that the city is worse than other places. **********Mr. Kemmy said he hoped new industry could bring Limerick back to the prosperity it knew in the time of Peter Tate, who started selling shirts to sailors on the riverbank in the 1850's and became the town's leading employer with a factory that produced uniforms for the British Army and both the Union and Confederate armies in the American Civil War. **********Limerick's modest renaissance has been enhanced by the emergence of a native as one of the most powerful national politicians, Desmond O'Malley. He is the head of the Progressive Democratic Party, which provides six crucial parliamentary votes in the coalition Government of Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey. **********"Look out at the Shannon at low tide," Mr. O'Malley said, sitting in the lobby of the Ryan Limerick Hotel on a recent afternoon. "It is one of the superb sights in Ireland. There is a waterfall. It is the crossing point that controls the river for 60 miles east and west." **********Eight hundred years ago, Mr. O'Malley's ancestors settled issues of river control and economy with axes, pikes and catapults that lofted diseased animals into the enemy throng. Now, he says, the success of the city and the area depends largely on regional planning and financing and on the creation of the Shannon Development Corporation. **********In the old days, the problem was invasions by the Vikings and later the Normans. Now the enemy is Dublin, whose business executives and politicians want to end a longstanding arrangement intended to bring money to the west, the requirement that planes from North America land at nearby Shannon airport, with its huge duty-free shopping area. Some here favor reasonable argument and painful negotiations with the capital; others would seem to prefer the catapult. **********King John's Castle in the center of the city was begun in 1210, lay ignored in recent centuries until the authorities had it refurbished for tourism, and it became the center of another battle. **********The new facade, a network of connected pipes, resembles the Pompidou Center in Paris, the huge modern art museum whose exterior is also a set of crossing pipes and tubes. Some people call the castle "The Thing." **********"Visually, the outside was not a success," Mr. O'Malley said. But inside, he said, are excellent displays of three eras, in archeological layers, of Limerick life -- the ancient Celts, topped by the Vikings, topped by the Normans who built the castle. **********This year, the city celebrated its prime moment in history 300 years ago when it withstood a monthlong siege by the forces of William of Orange, the Protestant usurper of the English crown held by his father-in-law, the Catholic James II. The pro-James Catholic forces surrendered, but not before they won the Treaty of Limerick, which promised them religious freedom. **********Some 12,000 Catholic troops were allowed safe passage to the Continent, and became known in Irish history as the Wild Geese, keeping national hopes and military tradition alive in exile. In succeeding centuries, Limerick kept slipping in national esteem, gaining a reputation for political radicalism. **********But what happened to Limerick in 1691, a defeat that produced a kind of victory, is not unlike what is happening here now. **********And so the people who created the commemoration celebration dug into the poetic history of the limerick. It may be that some of the Wild Geese soldiers learned a five-line satiric poem form in France and brought it back home, where it was used by poets writing in Gaelic to zing their English masters. There once was a Wild Goose from France . . . .

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/busin.main_headline: Money Market Yields Mixed After Declines
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/busin.print_headline: CONSUMER RATES; Money Market Yields Mixed After Declines
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/busin.body_text: **********Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report turned mixed for the week that ended yesterday after declining the previous two weeks. **********Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's continue to note a hesitance by the Federal Reserve Board to take action on easing short-term rates further. During the next few weeks, short-term rates are likely to come under upward pressures from a heavy load of Treasury financings, including yesterday's two-year note auction, today's five-year note auction and the coming quarterly refunding. **********After two weeks of declines, yields on tax-exempt money fund yields increased sharply, as investor demand for new securities fell behind supply. The average number of days to maturity of securities held in money managers' portfolios declined by 2, to 46, while assets fell by $2.3 billion, to a total of $89.2 billion. **********For the period that ended yesterday, the average seven-day compounded yield rose by 11 basis points, to 4.28 percent, while the seven-day simple yield increased by 10 basis points, to 4.19 percent. The 30-day compounded average yield fell by 3 basis points, to 4.30 percent, and the 30-day simple yield fell by a similar amount, to 4.24 percent. **********The taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-exempt compounded yield is 5.94 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, and is 6.38 percent for those in the 33 percent tax bracket. **********Of the tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Centennial Tax Exempt Trust, distributed by the Centennial Capital Corporation in Denver, had the best return for the week, 6.07 percent, which likely includes capital gains. **********On the more generally used method of fund accounting, the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund had the best return, with a yield of 5.29 percent. The fund is managed by Strong/ Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. in Milwaukee. **********Assets of taxable funds declined by $2.2 billion, for a total of $461.4 billion, with the consumer sector accounting for most of the drop, as $2 billion flowed out of the funds, for a total of $345.7 billion. The assets of institutional funds fell by $200 million, to a total of $115.7 billion. **********The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell by 3 basis points, to 5.96 percent, while the 30-day yield fell by 7 basis points, to 6.07 percent. **********The taxable fund with the best return on investment was Olde Premium Money Market Series, for the third straight week. Its yield was 6.95 percent. The distributor is the Olde Discount Corporation in Detroit. **********By comparison, the average yield on a bank money market account, which competes with the money funds, fell by a basis point, to 5.44 percent, The Bank Rate Monitor said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/23/busin.main_headline: Dow Gains 5.99 as World Rally Continues
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/23/busin.print_headline: Dow Gains 5.99 as World Rally Continues
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/23/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices kept heading upward yesterday after a big lift on Wednesday from the collapse of the Soviet coup. While the Dow Jones industrial average added only slightly to its previous gains, two other indexes posted record highs. **********Earlier, in Europe, markets rallied strongly, picking up the momentum from Wednesday, when many markets closed before the final reports of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's return to power. **********The Dow gained a slight 5.59 points, to 3,007.38. But the Standard & Poor's 500 index of the most important stocks rose to 391.33, a gain of 0.74 point, and the New York Stock Exchange's composite index rose 0.45 point, to 214.34. **********Volume on the Big Board was down sharply from Wednesday, with 173 million shares changing hands, compared with 232 million the day before. Advances outnumbered declines, 896 to 698, with 127 issues reaching new highs.  Return to Reality **********Several analysts said that the rally that had lofted the Dow 88 points higher on Wednesday had run out of steam and that broader concerns about the domestic economy would again take center stage. **********"This is a return to reality, and the reality is that the economic recovery is anemic," said Alan R. Ackerman, executive vice president at Reich & Company. **********"World markets rallied overnight and gave the market in the United States some spark at the opening," he added. "But euphoria over the return of Gorbachev settled down, and the market got back to business. The market has been locked in the 2,850-to-3,050 trading range for more than five months and has had difficulty breaking through the upper end of that range." **********In London, the Financial Times index of 100 leading shares rose 0.8 percent, the level it was at before the coup, and added a few extra points to set a new closing high of 2,623.01. In France, the CAC-40 jumped 1.5 percent to end at 1,819.13, just a point below its pre-coup level. **********In Germany, the Dax index of leading shares jumped 60 points, or 3.8 percent, to 1,630.83, just 20 points below its pre-coup level and well within its recent trading ranges. **********And in Japan yesterday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 2.1 percent, to 22,515.77, just 300 points from its level last Friday. Today, however, profit-taking pushed the index down 450.43 points, or 2 percent, to 22,065.34.  Day of Gyrations **********The Dow gyrated wildly throughout the day, beginning with a strong rally in the opening minutes of trading. After several rounds of back-and-forth movement however, the Dow stood below its opening level shortly before 4 P.M. for the fourth time in the day before a final, brief rally. **********Oil stocks generally gained, based on the belief that American oil companies might now be able to participate in developing the Soviet Union's vast oil reserves. ARCO gained 1 1/8, to 121 5/8; Exxon rose 1/4, to 58 1/2; Mobil rose 1/2, to 66 7/8, and Shell rose 5/8, to 54 1/4. **********The Nasdaq composite index rose 0.33 point, to 518.3, a gain of less than one-tenth of a percent. The American Stock Exchange's composite index was up 1.8 points yesterday, to 368.08, a gain of nearly half a percent. **********The most active issue on the big board was Salomon, which dropped 2 1/8, to 22 5/8, with four million shares changing hands. The stock is still reeling from the effects of revelations about irregularities at government-debt auctions. **********One of the biggest gainers on the Big Board was Metronic, a maker of pacemakers, which was up 4 5/8, to 129 7/8, on improved first quarter-earnings. **********Another big gainer was IMC Fertilizer, up 4, to 58 7/8, following an analyst's report that the prospects for grain sales to the Soviet Union brightened with the fall of the coup. **********Nearly two-thirds of the Dow's gain yesterday was attributed to three stocks: International Paper, which rose 1 5/8, to 68 3/8, a day after the company completed its acquisition of Leslie Paper; Alcoa, which rose 7/8, to 66 3/8, because analysts said the company was still gaining from news earlier this month of a restructuring, and Chevron, a member of the strong oil group, which rose 3/4, to 71 5/8.
