https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/world.main_headline: U.S. OFFERS A PLAN FOR MIDEAST TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/world.print_headline: U.S. OFFERS A PLAN FOR MIDEAST TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/world.body_text: **********The Bush Administration is exploring the possibility of convening regional peace talks, with the United States and the Soviet Union as hosts, that would serve as the opening for direct negotiations between Israel and its Arab neighbors, Western and Middle East diplomats said today. **********While Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has been very tight lipped about what he is trying to do in his talks with Middle East leaders, an approach that appears to be getting a lot of consideration would be for the United States and the Soviet Union to be hosts for a ceremonial opening "event" that might be the political equivalent of President Anwar el-Sadat's visit to Jerusalem in 1977. **********The event being considered would be a meeting in which the two superpowers would invite Israel, Palestinian representatives, Egypt, Jordan and, ideally, Syria and the six Arab gulf states -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar, Oman, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates -- to a ceremonial opening that would be followed by direct talks. **********The Americans "want to produce some kind of engagement and the critical question is how," said a Western diplomat familiar with the secret discussions. American-Soviet "sponsorship of regional talks is one idea being considered," he said. But the diplomat cautioned that the Bush Administration had not yet settled on exactly which approach it wants to push. Changing the Political Climate **********"Whether anything will work is too early to tell," the Western diplomat said. **********Mr. Baker did not broach the idea in his meetings with Middle East leaders two weeks ago, but confined himself instead to discussing confidence-building measures that might make it easier for Arab and Israeli leaders to attend such talks by changing the political climate. Mr. Baker and his Policy Planning Staff director, Dennis Ross, have discussed the idea in follow-up conversations with various Middle East officials in the last few days, and neither Israelis nor Arabs have committed themselves one way or another, the diplomats said. **********Earlier this week, Mr. Baker saw Osama al-Baz, national security adviser to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt , and Adnan Abu Odeih, foreign policy adviser to King Hussein of Jordan . Mr. Ross met Tuesday with Hanan Ashrawi, a West Bank Palestinian professor who was in the delegation of Palestinians that Mr. Baker met with during his recent visit to Jerusalem. Israel's Minister of Justice, Dan Meridor, one of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's closest advisers, has also been visiting Washington this week. **********In the present Administration deliberations, after the opening the parties would break into separate Israeli-Arab, Israeli-Palestinian negotiations -- much the way Israel, Egypt and Syria did after the 1973 United States-Soviet Geneva conference. Several venues for such talks have been proposed. Justifying Participation **********The confidence-building measures that Mr. Baker discussed on his trip to the Middle East would be intended to provide the participants with the political cover they would need to attend and to buy some time. Some Arab states, particularly the gulf Arabs, have expressed some unease about going to such a regional meeting as long as President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is in power or alive. **********Ideally, confidence-building gestures by Israel to ease the pressure of its occupation of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, and to reaffirm its commitment to implementation of Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338, might be used by the Palestinians and the Arab states to justify taking part in such a conference. **********And if Mr. Baker can persuade the Arab countries to move toward ending their state of belligerency with Israel, and possibly all or part of their boycott, the Israeli Government could better justify its participation in such talks. Prime Minister Shamir could argue that that is not the sort of open-ended, gang-up-on-Israel international conference -- in which all five permanent members of the Security Council would be invited -- but rather direct talks with Arab states that have indicated a willingness to reconcile with Israel. **********Mr. Baker has been highly secretive about what he is doing, because he feels that it will give Arabs and Israelis more room for maneuver if every proposal is not debated in public and because he and his aides say they truly are not sure whether any of it will work, diplomats say. Several Thorny Problems **********What optimism existed immediately after the defeat of Iraqi forces in Kuwait has given way to sobriety in the Administration. Officials dealing with the process say that neither side is itching to make fundamental compromises, like trading land for peace. The whole idea of trying to organize a ceremonial opening for regional talks is based partially on the hope that a dramatic meeting could create some momentum for substantive progress. **********In his private talks with Middle East leaders, Mr. Baker must sort out several thorny problems, including the question of who will represent the Palestinians. **********Also, he must try to establish what would follow the ceremonial opening of such a conference. In 1973, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger already had arranged the Sinai Desert disengagement talks he planned after the Egyptians and Israelis held their Geneva meeting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/busin.body_text: **********For the last decade, downtown Los Angeles stood as a gleaming testament to Southern California's seemingly boundless economic growth. In rapid succession, new office towers sprouted to house banks, law firms, stock brokerages and others that poured into the city as the region boomed. **********But today, downtown Los Angeles stands awash in vacant office space, a grim reminder to developers and lenders that no region, and no real estate market, is immune to economic dowturn. With new buildings still opening and the recession in California showing no signs of ending soon, the vacancy rate here will only worsen in coming months. **********Developers and building owners are already being forced to slash rents, sometimes to unprofitable levels, to attract the few available tenants. And banks are being forced to write off or renegotiate loans that only a few years ago they were competing with each other to make. **********Los Angeles is the largest -- and only the most visible -- example of how the commercial real estate markets throughout California have weakened precipitously, jolting not just the state's own big banks and developers, but lenders and investors from across the country and around the world. **********Citicorp, the largest banking company in the United States, has about $4.2 billion worth of commercial real estate loans in the West, mostly in California, comprising nearly a third of its $13 billion commercial real estate portfolio. **********"The commercial market in California is wallowing in a really severe slump, and I don't see it turning up yet," said Paul R. Alanis, the president of Koar Inc., a development company that recently put off plans to start a new office building in downtown Los Angeles. **********"There was a feeding frenzy here, with significant inflation in property values, partly fueled by foreign capital coming in, especially from Japan," Mr. Alanis said. "It tended to obfuscate what was really happening, which was ever-increasing supply and a softening demand situation."  Small Consolation **********No is predicting that the California market will go the way of some of the great real estate disaster areas of the 1980's, like Boston, Dallas or Austin, Tex. Indeed, many analysts predict that California will eventually bounce back, thanks to its role as financial center for the West, a hub for the booming Pacific rim area and the state's diverse and historically resilient economy. **********But that is small consolation right now to developers with buildings in the area from San Diego to Irvine to Los Angeles. In downtown Los Angeles, nearly a quarter of all offices stood vacant on Sept. 30, an increase from about 15 percent only a year ago, and about 5.5 percentage points higher than a 35-city average compiled by Cushman & Wakefield Inc., the real estate brokerage firm. Midtown Manhattan's vacancy rate was 16.9 percent, Cushman & Wakefield said. **********To make matters worse here, three big office buildings are still being built downtown, offering space almost equivalent to the Empire State Building. **********Already, the slump has shown up on the bottom lines of California's big banks. Most, including the Security Pacific Corporation and First Interstate Bancorp, have greatly increased their reserves for losses on commercial real estate loans in recent months. Analysts think that otherwise strong banks like Wells Fargo & Company could face additional large write-offs in the next quarter or two.  Still Looking for the Bottom **********"Our feeling is that the loss situation probably has not bottomed yet, because you don't see the problems peak in real estate until maybe 18 months after the trough of the recession," an executive of one of California's largest banks said. **********The situation is also threatening the earnings of Japanese and out-of-state banks that lent heavily to California developers in recent years. Citicorp is the main lender on California Plaza II, a 52-story office tower being built in downtown Los Angeles by Metropolitan Structures West Inc. Just a few months before the building's completion, Metropolitan Structures has leased only about 30 percent of its space. **********The slump has already claimed some casualties. The Equitable Life Assurance Company is foreclosing on the Westin Bonaventure, a hotel in downtown Los Angeles owned by a partnership including John C. Portman Jr., the Atlanta developer, and the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan. The First National Bank of Boston foreclosed earlier this year on two office buildings adjacent to the John Wayne Airport in Orange County owned by the McLachan Investment Company. Scores of smaller properties across the state, including office buildings, shopping centers and industrial buildings, have been seized by lenders in recent months. **********"The volume now is enormous," said Kurt DeMeire of County Records Research of Huntington Beach, which tracks property foreclosures in the previously fast-growing Southern California counties of Orange, Riverside and San Bernardino. **********The squeeze is likely to continue for months or even years. "There's no doubt that some owners, whether investors or builder-developers, are experiencing financial problems because cash flows on a lot of properties are insufficient to meet the debt service," said Stan Ross, a managing partner at Kenneth Leventhal & Company, a real estate accounting firm in Los Angeles. "As a result, you're seeing a lot more troubled debt restructurings." **********Amid all the gloom, some new projects appear to be relatively successful. A group that includes Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman turned investor, is putting the finishing touches on an office complex in Santa Monica called the Water Garden. The project, financed by Citicorp and the Bank of America, is 65 percent leased and should be 80 percent leased by the end of the year, executives of the development group said. **********Most of the new construction downtown is backed by insurance companies, pension funds, Japanese real estate companies and other deep-pocketed investors that can afford to ride out years of weak income from buildings without being forced to sell at depressed prices. Those new buildings are aggressively wooing tenants from older buildings by offering not only spanking-new surroundings but also deeply discounted rents and other incentives.  Problems at Older Buildings **********As a result, owners of older buildings are already losing tenants, and analysts said many would be unable to pay their bank loans if they could not find new tenants. **********Jonathan Marine, a broker with CB Commercial Real Estate in downtown Los Angeles, said he was negotiating for a large foreign financial institution, which he declined to identified, that wants to move to a new building from an older one. **********The developer of the new building is willing to pick up the tenant's existing lease, which has six years to run, at a cost of $8 million, Mr. Marine said, in return for a 10-year lease in the new building. The developer is also willing to give as much as two years' free rent in the new building, and provide the tenant at least $60 a square foot in cash -- or $4.5 million for 75,000 square feet -- to finish the office's interiors and add furnishings. **********Those terms are far better than developers were offering just a year or two ago, Mr. Marine said, and much more favorable than anything the owner of the tenant's current building can afford to grant. **********Owners of older or less prestigious buildings "are going to have an impossible time," Mr. Marine said. "There is no demand for those buildings at all."  Virtually No New Construction **********If there is good news for the Los Angeles and California real estate markets, it is that new construction has virtually halted. Most economists expect California's recovery to lag the nation's, but they think that within a few years the state will resume its steady growth, albeit at a slower pace than during the roaring Eighties. Eventually, they said, the backlog of office and industrial space will be whittled away as economic growth picks up, forcing rents higher, allowing loans to be repaid and increasing property values. **********"Longer term, we think the place works," said David Shulman, the head of real estate research at Salomon Brothers. "But in the short run, who knows?"

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/20/world.body_text: **********El Salvador's two top military men today denied the allegation of a panel of United States Congressional Democrats that they took part in planning the killing of six Jesuit priests in 1989. **********"We energetically reject these imputations, which are based on speculation that lacks any evidence," Gen. Rene Emilio Ponce, the Defense Minister, said in a statement he read on behalf of himself and his deputy minister, Gen. Juan Orlando Zepeda. **********The two men asserted that Representative Joe Moakley, Democrat of Massachusetts, who signed the report to members of the Speaker's Special Task Force on El Salvador, was motivated by political considerations and his desire to end military aid to El Salvador. The six-page Moakley memo was sent to the 19 other Democratic representatives on the task force over the weekend. **********"Congressman Moakley is looking for personal political advantage in this," said General Zepeda, who sat beside General Ponce at a news conference today. **********In his memo, Mr. Moakley said the inquiry by his panel had found strong circumstantial evidence to suggest that the killings of the six Jesuits on the grounds of the Central American University on Nov. 16, 1989, was plotted at a meeting attended by Generals Ponce and Zepeda, plus the air force commander at the time, Gen. Juan Rafael Bustillo, and two colonels. **********One of the colonels, Col. Guillermo Alfredo Benavides, former director of the military academy, was found guilty on Sept. 28 of ordering the killings. He and an aide who was also convicted are awaiting sentencing. **********In addition to the six Jesuits, the massacre claimed the lives of the priests' cook and her 15-year-old daughter. **********Generals Ponce and Zepeda, who at the time of the killings were army Chief of Staff and Deputy Chief of Staff, criticized Mr. Moakley for relying on unidentified sources of information and challenged those people to come forward and give their information to the judge who conducted the trial of Colonel Benavides. **********Challenging the Moakley assertion that the planning session for the crime took place at the military academy on Nov. 15, both men denied being at the academy that day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.main_headline: The Vote That Congress Can't Forget
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: WASHINGTON TALK; The Vote That Congress Can't Forget
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.body_text: **********For more than two decades, the Congressional vote that lawmakers most often cite as the one they would like to take back is their 1964 vote for the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, the resolution that was used as authority for the war in Vietnam. Only two Senators and no Representatives voted no. **********Twenty-seven of those lawmakers are still in Congress. And as they prepared for Saturday's vote on what was even more clearly the equivalent of a declaration of war, the resolution to authorize the use of military force in the Persian Gulf, the memories of that earlier vote weighed heavily on the minds of the seven senators and 20 representatives who served then and still serve now. **********Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, was in the House in 1964. He recalled the earlier resolution as one President Johnson had "distorted," and one whose repeal he accomplished as a freshman Senator in 1970. **********Representative Sam M. Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, said caustically, "It was a declaration of war despite the fact that those who stood in the well and who supported it said it was not." He added, "The Gulf of Tonkin Resolution was used as a declaration of war and plunged this country n eight or nine years of really disastrous war in Vietnam." **********Not everyone remembered it quite the same way. Representative Charles E. Bennett, Democrat of Florida, said: "I am 80 years of age. I have been in this chamber 43 years. Out of the 17,000 votes I have cast, the only one I really regret is the one I cast for the Bay of Tonkin Resolution. I particularly regret it, because I knew it was a declaration of war." **********Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, did not offer second thoughts about his old vote, but said the Persian Gulf decision was even more difficult for him. "Today's situation is clearer," he said in a statement in the Congressional Record. "The possibility of armed conflict, casualties and even death is much more apparent." **********In that group of 27, some were silent last week. Among those who spoke, several did not hark back to the 1964 vote. But few avoided comparisons with Vietnam more generally. For example, Representative Frank Horton, Republican of Rochester, recalled his years in Congress during the Vietnam War. **********"From that experience I learned the lesson of what can result from the commitment of troops to a conflict where our interests are not so clear, where objectives are not defined," Mr. Horton said. In the Persian Gulf, he said, those interests were as clear as they had been when he fought as an infantry companmy commander in World War II. **********When it came time to vote, 12 of the Tonkin veterans voted to authorize force and 14 voted against it. Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona, is hospitalized because of a fall and did not vote. **********Among the Republicans, Mr. Dole, Mr. Horton, Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina and Representatives William S. Broomfield of Michigan, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, Joseph M. McDade of Pennsylvania and James H. Quillen of Tennessee voted to authorize President Bush to make war on Iraq. **********Representative Silvio O. Conte of Massachusetts voted no. One of just three House Republicans who deserted President Bush on the issue, he made no speech, but issued a statement recalling his Tonkin vote, and saying the consequence then was "tragedy and needless loss of lives," a result he prayed would not recur. **********The Tonkin Democrats sided against authorizing force. Mr. Gibbons, Mr. Bennett, and Representatives William H. Natcher of Kentucky, Neal Smith of Iowa, Henry B. Gonzalez and J. J. Pickle of Texas, and Don Edwards and Edward R. Roybal of California voted no. So did Senators Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, Quentin N. Burdick of North Dakota, Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts (who did not vote in 1964 but announced support of the resolution) and Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii. **********But five of them -- all powerful committee chairmen -- voted for force. Mr. Rostenkowski did. So did Representatives Jack Brooks of Texas, John D. Dingell of Michigan, Dante B. Fascell of Florida, and Jamie L. Whitten of Mississippi, the only current member of Congress who was also on hand in December 1941, to vote the last formal declarations of war, against Japan, Germany and Italy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/busin.main_headline: Mutual Funds; Alternates as the C.D.'s Go Sour
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/busin.print_headline: Mutual Funds; Alternates as the C.D.'s Go Sour
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/busin.body_text: **********More than $150 billion invested in certificates of deposit are coming due this month, and many holders of these certificates are looking for new homes for their money. The reason: yields on C.D.'s and other short-term investments like money market funds have dropped. **********As of Oct. 1, one-year C.D.'s were yielding just 5.66 percent on average, according to Robert K. Heady, publisher of Bank Rate Monitor in North Palm Beach, Fla. **********The interest rates that banks could pay were deregulated in October 1983, and because C.D.'s are sold mostly in six-month and full-year units, October remains the biggest month for C.D. rollovers. Rates are now at their lowest level since deregulation, and a recent survey by Gallup and Fidelity Investments found that fewer than one-third of the investors with certificates coming due were committed to reinvesting in C.D.'s. **********One easy alternative to C.D.'s is money market funds, but their yields are even lower. The seven-day compound yield for taxable money funds was 5.29 percent as of Oct. 1, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report in Holliston, Mass. **********New Yorkers and investors in other high-tax states can do better with United States Treasury money market funds, where earnings are exempt from state and local taxes. The Dreyfus 100 Percent U.S. Treasury Money Market Fund was yielding 5.80 percent before taxes. This generally produces an after-tax yield of 6.39 percent for California investors and 6.61 percent for New York City investors. **********Anything else involves more risk than C.D. or money fund investors are accustomed to. "To get more yield, you have to take more risk," said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc., a mutual fund research group in Chicago. **********Investors can minimize credit risk -- the risk that issuers will not repay interest or principal -- by staying with high-quality bond funds. Even so, going longer than the 90-day maximum permitted for money funds exposes investors to interest rate risk. Investors in foreign bond funds also assume currency rate risk. **********One way to minimize the overall level of portfolio risk is to mix the various types of risk, Mr. Phillips suggested. That said, what are investors' choices among high-yielding mutual funds? The following are suggestions, with discussions of the risk each entails. *********** Short- and intermediate-term bond funds. Unlike C.D.'s or money market funds, bond funds can lose value if interest rates rise. So while the yield looks good, the total return -- yield plus changes in principal -- may not. In the long term, it is total return that counts. **********To decrease risk, choose funds with shorter maturities. Short-term bond funds invest in securities maturing in one to five years. Among short-term government funds, Mr. Phillips recommends 20th Century U.S. Government, with a yield of 6.95 percent and a total return of 10.89 percent in 1991 through Sept. 30. On the corporate side, he likes T. Rowe Price Short-Term Bond Fund (yield, 7.17; total return, 10.05 percent). **********Intermediate-term funds invest in securities maturing in five to 10 years, so yields are slightly higher. Mr. Phillips likes the Benham Treasury Note Fund (yield, 7.07 percent; total return, 12.97 percent) and the Fidelity Intermediate Bond Fund (yield, 7.64 percent; total return 13.29 percent). *********** Mortgage funds. There are two basic types: adjustable-rate mortgage funds and Ginnie Mae funds. The adjustable-rate funds were developed to compensate for the volatility of the fixed-rate Ginnie Mae funds, whose prices move around to compensate for shifts in market interest rates. **********The tradeoff: monthly dividends fluctuate more than they would with a standard Ginnie Mae fund. And the funds' yields drop when interest rates fall, as the borrowers' rates are adjusted downward. When rates rise, the funds lag because rates on the underlying mortgages are not adjusted immediately. **********In both adjustable-rate and Ginnie Mae funds, when mortgages are prepaid the money is reinvested at lower rates, cutting the funds' yields. Mr. Phillips recommends the Franklin Adjustable U.S. Government Securities Fund (yield, 8.63 percent; total return, 9.59 percent) and the Vanguard G.N.M.A. Portfolio Fund (yield, 8.26 percent; total return, 16.67 percent.) *********** Short-term global income funds. These funds take advantage of foreign interest rates that are higher than United States rates. To minimize credit risk, they hold government securities and high-quality short-term corporate paper. To control currency risk, they rely on sophisticated hedging techniques. For investors who want to go this route, Alliance Short-Term Multi-Market Trust class A (yield 9.95 percent; total return 10.64 percent) is Mr. Phillips's choice. **********Next week: High-yielding stock funds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/world.main_headline: Tunisia Arrests 300 Muslims, Charging Plot to Stage Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/world.print_headline: Tunisia Arrests 300 Muslims, Charging Plot to Stage Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/world.body_text: **********Security forces have arrested nearly 300 Muslim militants, including 100 army men, who planned to overthrow the Tunisian Government and create an Islamic state, Interior Minister Abdallah Kallel said today. **********He said at a news conference all those arrested were members of Nahdha, an outlawed Muslim fundamentalist movement. **********He said that in the final phase of the plot the 100 soldiers, including several officers with the rank of major, were to seize key points when the authorities called in the army to deal with demonstrations organized by Nahdha.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/world.main_headline: Havana Closes Communist Congress to Outsiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/world.print_headline: Havana Closes Communist Congress to Outsiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/world.body_text: **********Faced with a severe economic and political crisis, Cuba has announced that for the first time in the 32-year leadership of President Fidel Castro the coming congress of the island's ruling Communist Party will be closed to foreign delegations and journalists. **********The departure from previous practice, a number of experts on Cuban affairs said, reflects a sense of uncertainty within the Cuban leadership bordering on disorientation after the announcement by the Soviet Union last week that it was withdrawing its troops and ending its economic subsidies to the island. **********But some of the specialists noted that the decision also reflected a growing view in Cuban society and elements of the party that fundamental changes were needed. They pointed out that in announcing the decision to keep the congress closed to outsiders Cuban officials said they were anxious to allow delegates to express their opinions without inhibition. **********"It seems they are intent for the first time in having a serious discussion rather than a simple ratification of the official line," said William LeoGrande, an expert on Cuban affairs at American University in Washington, referring to the congress that begins Oct. 10. "They know they must come out of this with at least a modest program of change." **********With vital Soviet aid to Cuba dwindling and endangered and the Communist system that Havana adopted three decades ago in virtual eclipse around the world, Mr. LeoGrande and other experts said the Cuban leadership now faced the daunting task of formulating a persuasive message of hope to a population whose living standards have sharply plummeted over the last two years. **********"They have got to come out of this congress with some sort of program that convinces the people that things are somehow going to get better," Mr. LeoGrande said. **********Originally scheduled for early this year, the congress, Cuba's fourth since the formal adoption of a socialist, one-party system in 1972, has already been repeatedly delayed as serious shortages of most foods and consumer goods have worsened and events abroad have propelled Cuba further into isolation. **********At preparatory meetings with grass-roots members last year, Cuban officials privately acknowledge, harsh criticism of everything from the country's leaders and system of government to restricted personal freedoms and growing material hardships was voiced by many participants. As the complaints grew more numerous and louder, the local meetings were quietly canceled. **********But as signs of discontent among Cubans have continued to grow in recent months, the 65-year-old Mr. Castro has delivered increasingly stern warnings both to would-be reformers and dissidents against attempts to bring about fundamental changes in Cuba's tightly controlled political system. Particularly strong language has been used to condemn market economics and multiparty pluralism. **********Nonetheless, experts here who closely monitor Cuban developments say that despite these warnings there have been signs that Cuba's dire economic situation is forcing consideration of a number of innovations, among them the limited reintroduction of private enterprise in the agriculture and service sectors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/world.main_headline: U.S. Sending Carrier to Strengthen Security for Force in Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; U.S. Sending Carrier to Strengthen Security for Force in Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/world.body_text: **********The Pentagon said today that it has dispatched the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt and its battle group into the Eastern Mediterranean to strengthen the "quick reaction" forces providing security to the United States and allied task force inside northern Iraq. **********The move came as intelligence reports indicated Iraq's army was trying to avoid a confrontation in the area. **********United States officials said a Marine battalion landing team of about 1,000 has moved into the Zakho area just inside Iraq to protect the first in a series of refugee centers that is being erected to shelter members of Iraq's Kurdish minority. The monthlong flight of the Kurds from Iraqi forces has left more than two million of them stranded on Iraq's borders with Turkey and Iran. **********As the United States commitment of forces to the expanded Kurdish relief operation was approaching 10,000 military personnel in its second week, Bush Administration officials said today that Iran has provided the United States with a list of critically needed relief supplies for Kurdish refugees and Iranian officials have said they would allow United States Government aircraft to deliver refugee aid to Iran. **********The Pentagon said no decision has been made on the Iran relief flights.  'A Shooting Situation' **********In Washington, both Army and Marine Corps officials said their forces in Iraq were conducting anti-terrorist and "force protection" operations out of recognition that Kurdish insurgents might try to draw them into conflict with Iraqi forces. **********"The Kurds might well want to draw us into a shooting situation," said one Marine official. Added an Army official, "The military understands that, and it doesn't necessarily mean we're going to be able to prevent something from happening, but force-protection measures are being taken." **********A Defense Intelligence Agency assessment said today that Iraqi military forces "appear to be departing the Zakho area" and Iraqi commanders are sending more of their troops on leave, thus lessening the possibility of conflict, but there continued to be reports of isolated encounters with Iraqi security forces that were causing some official concern. **********The Iraqi Army is said to have only one "category one" division in northern Iraq, meaning a division the Pentagon rates as combat ready and effective. "Most of their troops are not well trained ," said one Pentagon official. "They are not in any posture that is threatening," he added. **********The Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, declined to say whether the United States would insist that all Iraqi military and paramilitary forces leave the Zakho area to give Kurdish refugees greater confidence to return from the mountainous border region. **********Mr. Williams said the Iraqis were cooperating with American forces by clearing mines near the border. **********"For now they are cooperating; it's not a problem," he said. **********The buildup of American forces was a reflection of official anxiety in Washington over the protection of the operation from a variety of threats that Pentagon officials are still puzzling over. **********Military officials at the Pentagon said today that the bitter memory of the 1983 truck bombing in Lebanon that killed 241 Marines was adding to the heightened tensions in Iraq. The Marines were deployed in Beirut as part of a peacekeeping contingent. **********A combination of factors makes the military challenges in northern Iraq strikingly dissimiliar to those during the gulf war. **********"What I see that is vastly different from Lebanon," a Marine official said, "is that we are doing things that, militarily, are prudent, such as occupying the high ground and bringing in all of the aviation assets we need."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/13/busin.main_headline: U.S. Growth Figures Seen As Lower
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/13/busin.print_headline: U.S. Growth Figures Seen As Lower
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/13/busin.body_text: **********For the second time in a month, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has reportedly revised downward its projection for economic growth in the United States. **********According to Agence France-Presse, the O.E.C.D.'s latest economic report -- which is embargoed for release until next Friday -- says that the American economy will grow by 2.2 percent in 1992. That figure is down from the forecast of a 2.5 percent American growth rate in 1992 that the Paris-based organization made just one month ago. And last month's prediction was significantly lower than the 3.1 percent growth rate for 1992 that the O.E.C.D. had projected six weeks earlier. **********The agency also said that according to the new report, America's economic output for all of 1991 would decline by five-tenths of 1 percent, which is several tenths of a percent less than the forecast made last month. **********The O.E.C.D., a 24-nation organization that promotes economic cooperation, is widely respected for its economic projections, which are based on sophisticated computer models. Nonetheless, its officials say they have repeatedly had to revise downward their forecasts for the United States because the nation's economic doldrums are proving far more stubborn than anticipated. **********Senior O.E.C.D. officials say that the United States will not suffer a double-dip recesson and that the American economy should start to pick up this spring. **********One bright spot for the United States is that the new report projects that the American economy will grow faster in 1993 than had been projected, according to the French news agency. The O.E.C.D., it says, predicts that American economic growth will be 3.5 percent for 1993, up from the forecast of 3 percent for 1993 that the O.E.C.D. made last month. **********O.E.C.D. officials often say that the deeper a recession turns out to be, the more robust the rebound should prove to be. In addition, organization economists say that the Federal Reserve's repeated lowering of interest rates should eventually give growth a boost. **********According to Agence France-Presse, the organization also said that growth in the industrial world would be a tepid 2.2 percent next year, down from the projection of 2.6 percent it made a month ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/23/busin.snippet: LAST week, the Leo Burnett agency in Chicago invited employees to a screening of some of television's best comparative advertising -- commercials that pit one product against another. The hourlong video, culled by the agency from television around...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/23/busin.main_headline:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Leo Burnett Makes the Case For the Comparative Method
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/23/busin.print_headline:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Leo Burnett Makes the Case For the Comparative Method
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/23/busin.body_text: **********LAST week, the Leo Burnett agency in Chicago invited employees to a screening of some of television's best comparative advertising -- commercials that pit one product against another. The hourlong video, culled by the agency from television around the world, brimmed with cleverness and was offered as proof that the approach, often considered negative and unseemly, can instead be creative and effective. **********Coincidentally, Burnett executives have also been giving clients a 24-page report from its research department proffering a similar view: that comparative advertising "can, indeed, result in fresh, different and superior advertising." **********The aim of the Burnett video and paper is to make advertising executives and clients feel more confident and comfortable with the approach, which has often been criticized, particularly in political campaigns. The theme is timely because comparative advertising seems in vogue now. With the country battling recession, many advertisers say they are more inclined to wage aggressive campaigns to topple competitors. **********Executives at Leo Burnett say the video and report do not represent an attempt to persuade clients or copywriters to use comparative advertising more frequently. They were intended merely to stimulate thinking. **********Still, Burnett's actions reflect a continuing debate industrywide about the use of such advertising. Even supporters say it is executed poorly all too often. **********"It's very clear that the term 'comparative advertising' has a very bad connotation among a lot of people," said Babs Thomas, the Leo Burnett executive who wrote the paper and a vice president in the agency's research department. **********"The problem is when you say the term people tend to think of the lowest common denominator: 'Buy this; the other guy's product stinks.' The kind of no-brainer, non-creative approach. But that really is not the only way to execute good comparative advertising." **********The video makes the point graphically in examples of superior comparative advertising from agencies like the old Doyle Dane Bernbach from the 60's. One commercial for the Volkswagen Beetle that uses deadpan humor to make its point shows two cars parked in front of identical suburban homes. A narrator explains that each homeowner has $3,000 to spend on a car. One spends the whole $3,000 on his purchase. The other buys a refrigerator, numerous other appliances -- and a new Volkswagen. **********Burnett's paper says consumers are typically turned off not because they do not approve of naked comparisons but because the actual advertising is often mediocre. **********The problems often include consumer confusion about which product is being advertised and annoyance that such advertising does not explain well why one brand is better. The report says that campaigns that claim product superiority solely on consumer preference are often found to be strident and offensive. **********Even when an advertisement properly explains a difference, consumers often find the argument irrelevant, the report said. For example, Burnett showed one comparison of "our brand's" fresh ingredients and the competition's dry ingredients. But the ingredient comparison ends up having little or nothing to do with how consumers make brand choices. **********"Indeed," the report said, "one competitive user reasoned, 'I never knew that my brand used dry ingredients. That must mean I like the taste of dried ingredients better.' " **********Agency executives said it was wrong to make generalizations about the approach, but they were sure it had its place. **********"It's risky and has a greater tendency to flop," said Tedd Sann, the BBDO vice chairman who wrote "Archeology," the commercial in which Pepsi-drinking students in a future time find a relic so obscure they cannot identify it. It is a Coke bottle. **********"If you don't do it with the right touch and make people appreciate the wit, it's deadly," Mr. Sann said. "But it can also be a sensational tool."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/busin.body_text: **********The Transportation Department approved the transfer today to American Airlines of the route between Seattle and Portland, Ore., and Japan now held by financially ailing Continental Airlines. **********The department said Continental was given permission to serve the route for up to another full year, until American is in position to begin service. **********American has not yet taken delivery of the planes it plans to use on the trans-Pacific route, the department said. **********Jeffrey N. Shane, the department's assistant secretary for international affairs, denied a request by the airlines to extend the authority to serve the routes to five years. The current certificate expires Nov. 23, 1993. **********The two airlines applied for the transfer last month, saying quick action was needed because of Continental's need for cash in the traditional slow travel season in the first quarter of the year. Continental recently filed for bankruptcy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.main_headline: Bond Prices Are Higher in Active Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.print_headline: Bond Prices Are Higher in Active Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.body_text: **********Bond prices moved higher in active trading yesterday, as participants in the Government securities market pared positions of shorter-term maturities in favor of longer-term issues. **********Traders said some of the swapping was done as preparation for next week's auctions of new two-year and five-year notes. In addition, an article in The Wall Street Journal yesterday may have been responsible for some bond purchases. **********The article said weakness in the money supply growth, if it continued, could force the Federal Reserve Board to cut short-term interest rates again soon. It cited the rise in M-2 reported by the Fed on Thursday -- an increase that was smaller than most analysts had expected. **********However, release of the unexpectedly weak money supply figures provoked little or no response on Thursday. **********Whatever the reason, "it seems that people are extending" out the yield curve, one government securities trader said. **********"There was a steady stream of buying," said William V. Sullivan, Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. A favorable inflation outlook, a "sense that the economy could flounder," and low short-term interest rates are compelling arguments for investors to purchase longer-dated issues, Mr. Sullivan said. **********In the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 102 23/32, up 1/4 point, to yield 7.88 percent, compared with 7.91 percent late Thursday and 7.93 percent on Sept. 13. **********With economic fundamentals favoring lower bond yields "it now seems quite likely" that long-term Treasury yields will fall to 7 3/4 percent in the near term, said Maria Fiorini Ramirez, president of Ramirez Capital Consultants. Bond yields have not been that low since August, 1989. **********Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 1/8 late yesterday, up 1/4 point, to yield 7.56 percent. But prices of the 6 3/8 percent two-year notes rose by just 1/32, to 100 13/32, to yield 6.14 percent. **********Short-term Treasury bill rates posted a very slight decline. **********In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.17 percent, down one basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 5.22 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by two basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.22 percent. **********New-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market remained strong, as just under $2 billion worth of securities were priced. **********The pricings were dominated by a $1.5 billion global offering of five-year notes from the World Bank. **********The 7.25 percent notes, which mature Oct. 1, 1996, were priced at $99.897, to yield 7.275 percent, 20 basis points over the prevailing when-issued yield on the new five-year Treasury notes to be auctioned next week. **********Goldman, Sachs & Company and Credit Suisse First Boston acted as co-lead managers for the underwriting. The securities are rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. acted as lead manager on a $200 million offering of 12-year notes from American Brands. **********The 8.50 percent notes, which mature in 2003, were priced at $99.70, to yield 8.54 percent, 98 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing. **********The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's and A-minus by Standard & Poor's. **********In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, market participants said that prices of most issues were little changed in slow trading. **********Municipal bond traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues in the secondary market for tax-exempt bonds rose by about 1/8 point.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/busin.main_headline: Business and the Law; Bank Regulators Losing in Court
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/busin.print_headline: Business and the Law; Bank Regulators Losing in Court
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/busin.body_text: **********A SERIES of Federal court decisions has held that regulators were overzealous in seizing some failed banks and savings and loans and that the Government could be liable for hundreds of millions of dollars in damages to investors. **********In different cases, judges found that regulators overstepped their authority by reneging on promises to buyers of troubled savings and loans, by pushing healthy banks into insolvency, or by illegally trying to squeeze millions of dollars from owners of failed financial institutions. **********Only a score of such lawsuits have been brought against the Government -- a minuscule number compared with the thousands of failed banks and savings and loans seized by regulators each year -- and many rulings are being appealed. But the trend has been against the Government, and some think it points to a disturbing pattern of regulators trying to reduce the cost of Federal bailouts at the expense of the law. **********The validity of that interpretation, however, is still a matter of debate. **********Rosemary Stewart, a lawyer with Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue in Washington and former director of enforcement for the Office of Thrift Supervision, thinks the courts have recognized that regulators "are going too far." **********"In a vengence mentality after the savings and loan crisis," she said, "the Government is trying to get everything it possibly can." **********But Alfred J. T. Byrne, general counsel of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Resolution Trust Corporation, feels the court decisions "reflect either a misunderstanding or a misapplication of the new law, or both." **********"We do not draw any conclusion that there is a tide flowing against the Government agencies," he said. **********No one contests the power of regulators to seize assets of insolvent banks and savings and loans in order to protect depositors' money. But several cases turn on interpretations of the savings and loan industry bailout legislation enacted by Congress in August 1989. **********Two cases test the retroactive application of that law. They involve the seizure by regulators in March 1989 of several healthy Texas banks after their parent banks, MBank in Dallas and the Texas American Bank in Fort Worth, became insolvent. **********Regulators pushed more than a dozen healthy subsidiary banks of the two companies into insolvency by failing to fully repay loans that the subsidiary banks made to the parents. Two courts have said that the subsidiaries are owed full payment under then-prevailing banking laws, but the Government is appealing on the ground that the 1989 bailout law permited only partial repayment. **********The F.D.I.C. has since lobbied successfully to have the 1989 bailout law permit unequal payments to creditors of failed banks. **********In another group of cases, regulators' attempts to abrogate concessions given to entice investors to buy failing savings and loans have been challenged. Eight of these cases have gone against the Government, four have gone in its favor and, in two others, the court said it had no jurisdiction. **********The Government has lost three other cases that involved attempts by regulators to collect money from owners of failed savings and loans by forcing them to put up new capital after institutions were declared insolvent. **********The 1989 bailout law is also being questioned in a group of cases involving concessions given by regulators to buyers of troubled savings and loans before the law's enactment. Regulators contend that the new law permits them to disregard these concessions, which are generally forbearances allowing newly acquired savings and loans to operate with lower capital requirements or more liberal lending policies than permitted by law. **********One of the best known in this group of cases involves Far West Federal Bank, a Portland, Ore., savings and loan that regulators sold to investors in 1987. In return for investing some $27 million of capital, the Government gave the new investors 10 years to meet capital requirements and approved a liberal lending policy. **********But with the 1989 bailout law, regulators told Far West that it was out of compliance with the law and that its owners faced daily fines of up to $1 million. Far West quickly complied, but as a result began losing money; officers and depositors fled and its balance sheet shrank. **********Far West's owners now say the Government can take the institution back -- they just want their $27 million returned, along with $100 million in damages. United States District Judge Owen M. Panner agreed, ruling that regulators violated Fifth Amendment guarantees against illegal seizure of property and that their action was "economic suicide" for Far West." Damages have yet to be set. **********A final batch of rulings against the Government involves attempts by regulators to collect money by enforcing capital requirements after a savings and loan failed. One leading case involves a Texas company named Tetco, which in 1983 bought a Texas savings and loan in San Antonio called the Bexar Savings Association. To get deposit insurance, Tetco agreed to certain capital levels and to add more when necessary. Over time, Tetco sunk some $25 million into Bexar. **********Bexar, however, suffered losses and was declared insolvent and seized by regulators in February 1989, wiping out Tetco's investment. The Government then sued Tetco for $558 million -- the amount needed for Bexar to meet its capital requirements if it were still alive. But United States District Judge Lucius D. Bunton in San Antonio dismissed the Government's claim, as did judges in two similar cases elsewhere.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/29/busin.main_headline: Takeover Talks Begun By Newmont Mining
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/29/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Takeover Talks Begun By Newmont Mining
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/29/busin.body_text: **********The Newmont Mining Corporation, the largest North American gold producer, said yesterday that it had begun talks to be acquired by the American Barrick Resources Corporation, another leading gold producer, in a stock exchange estimated by analysts to be worth about $2.4 billion. **********Under the terms of the proposed agreement, 1.8 shares of American Barrick would be exchanged for each Newmont Mining share. But the companies said that a number of substantive issues needed to be resolved and that the agreement was preliminary. **********Newmont Mining, which is 49.97 percent owned by Sir James Goldsmith, the British-French financier, is a holding company whose largest and most significant asset is Newmont Gold. By acquiring Newmont Gold, American Barrick would nearly double its gold reserves and create the world's second-largest gold mining company after Free State Gold Mining Ltd. in South Africa. **********American Barrick, based in Toronto, has interests in six producing mines in Nevada, Utah, Ontario and Quebec. It has 19.5 million ounces of proven and probable reserves, with 17.9 million ounces of that at the Goldstrike Mine in the Carlin Trend in Nevada. Production is expected to increase by more than 80 percent, to 1.1 million ounces, by next year. **********Newmont Mining, through its interest in Newmont Gold, has reserves totaling 18.9 million ounces in three areas along the Carlin Trend. The company, based in Denver, has shifted gears several times in its 70-year history, from copper to coal to precious metals. **********A year ago, it sold its 54.9 percent stake in the Peabody Coal Company to Hanson P.L.C. of Britain for $725.6 million. Later in the year, it sold a 19.9 percent stake in Newmont Australia to Poseidon Gold of Australia for $137 million. In December, a 49 percent stake of Newmont Mining held by Hanson was sold to investment groups headed by Sir James. **********On the New York Stock Exchange today, Newmont Mining's stock gained $2.75 a share, to $36.125; American Barrick's rose $1, to $20.375, and Newmont Gold's gained $3.25, to $37.375.
