https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/05/busin.main_headline: Coke Sees Marketing Help Of Hollywood's Top Agent
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/05/busin.print_headline: Coke Sees Marketing Help Of Hollywood's Top Agent
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/05/busin.body_text: **********In a highly unusual and somewhat mysterious move, the Coca-Cola Company announced yesterday that it had hired Creative Artists Agency Inc., Hollywood's most powerful talent agency, to help Coca-Cola mold its marketing and media strategies around the world. **********While both companies described their new relationship in only general terms, Coca-Cola executives said Creative Artists and its increasingly influential chairman, Michael S. Ovitz, would help Coca-Cola develop long-term strategies and present a unified message to consumers in the 107 countries where it does business. **********The announcement comes as executives at Coca-Cola face rising pressure to improve the company's domestic advertising and marketing campaigns, which have been criticized by industry analysts as lackluster and outshone this year by the company's age-old rival, the Pepsi-Cola Company. **********The deal is also a new coup for Mr. Ovitz, who has expanded his role from representing actors, writers and directors to become one of the most important deal makers and corporate consultants in Hollywood. **********"American culture broadly defined -- music, film, fashion and food -- has become the culture worldwide," said Peter S. Sealey, Coca-Cola's senior vice president and director of global marketing. "We are in a global village and C.A.A. represents the single greatest source in understanding that culture." **********An executive involved in the discussions between the two companies said Creative Artists had presented more than 50 ideas on how Coca-Cola could promote itself through motion pictures, tie-ins to popular music, television commercials and charitable causes. The executive said Creative Artists would not be directly involved in producing commercials nor would it promote the artists it represents for Coca-Cola productions. **********Mr. Sealey said the deal would not affect the company's relationship with its advertising agencies, including McCann-Erickson, New York, which handles the flagship Coca-Cola Classic brand. A spokeswoman for McCann-Erickson said it would have no comment on the announcement.  'This Is a Wise Choice' **********Several industry analysts praised the new arrangement, saying Coca-Cola needed a new approach to marketing a number of its products. **********"This is a wise choice," said Tom Pirko, president of Bevmark Inc., a beverage consulting company in Los Angeles. "This has been a long, lax period for Coca-Cola. There is now a great deal of anxiety about the most widely known trademark in the world." **********Industry analysts say Pepsi's ads in recent years have often been more memorable than Coca-Cola's. This year in particular, Diet Pepsi scored a success with a television commercials that featured Ray Charles crooning, "You've got the right one, baby, uh-huh." **********Coca-Cola last year made an embarrassing gaffe when a much-heralded promotion featuring special cans with prizes inside them had to be withdrawn when consumers complained that the cans caused the soda to taste bad.  Diet Coke Ads Withdrawn **********Advertising executives also criticized Coca-Cola for withdrawing its humorous Diet Coke commercials from the Super Bowl last January, after Coca-Cola decided that the advertisements clashed with the national mood on the eve of the Persian Gulf war. **********Last July, Coca-Cola's senior vice president and marketing director for the United States, Theodore J. Host, resigned suddenly after 14 months in the job. **********"Coca-Cola doesn't have a clear advertising identity," said Jesse Meyers, the publisher of Beverage Digest, a trade journal. "You never hear consumers quoting their commercials. You never see them parodied on sitcoms." **********Perhaps an even more striking aspect of the deal is the growing role of Mr. Ovitz, who has increasingly played the role of deal broker and investment banker in some of the most important transactions in the entertainment industry. **********Last year, Mr. Ovitz advised the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the Japanese consumer-products giant, in its efforts to acquire MCA Inc. Mr. Ovitz was also involved in the $3.5 billion purchase of Columbia Pictures by the Sony Corporation in 1989. **********Creative Artists counts as its clients more than 650 top Hollywood actors, directors and screen writers, including Paul Newman, Tom Cruise and Kevin Costner. Such pop stars as Madonna and Michael Jackson have also been represented by the agency. **********"The Coca-Cola Company is a communicator's dream," Mr. Ovitz said yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/busin.main_headline: Executive at Sun Co. Moves Into No. 2 Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Executive at Sun Co. Moves Into No. 2 Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/busin.body_text: **********The Sun Company, the nation's largest independent refiner of oil products, named Robert H. Campbell as president and chief operating officer yesterday. The move puts him in the No. 2 spot and makes him heir apparent to the chairman and chief executive, Robert McClements Jr. **********Mr. McClements, 62 years old, formerly also held the title of president. The company does not have a manadatory retirement policy, but its senior executives traditionally retire around 65, a spokesman said. **********In an interview, Mr. Campbell, 53, played down the succession idea. "We're taking this thing one step at a time," he said. "We haven't talked about that." **********Last year, the company, based in Radnor, Pa., spun off to shareholders its domestic exploration and production unit as a separate concern, the Oryx Energy Company. Robert P. Hauptfuhrer, who was president and chief operating officer of Sun, became chairman and chief executive at Oryx. **********Sun strengthened its refining and marketing position in 1988 by purchasing the Atlantic Petroleum Company. It is now seeking to develop its international production and exploration operations, Mr. Campbell said. Sun is also a large coal producer. **********Mr. Campbell has spent 30 years with Sun, joining the company in 1960. He holds a bachelor's degree in chemical engineering from Princeton University and a master's degree in chemical engineering from Carnegie-Mellon University. In the 1970's, he returned to school for a master's degree in management from the Sloan School at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. **********At Sun, he began in research and development, worked in refining and for a time ran, and later sold, the company's shipbuilding unit, Sun Ship. **********In 1988, he was named to the Sun board and made an executive vice president.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/10/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Discount Broker Selects Kirshenbaum & Bond
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/10/busin.body_text: **********Kirshenbaum & Bond, New York, was awarded the $5 million account of Quick & Reilly Inc., New York, yesterday. The agency will create direct-response print and broadcast advertising for the discount brokerage. **********William A. Coppel, the firm's vice president-director of marketing, attributed a decision to leave its agency of 16 years, Arthur Lockard & Company, New York, to a desire to expand its marketing efforts to include aging baby boomers. "We're interested in turning up the volume," Mr. Coppel said, adding that Kirshenbaum & Bond, known for its feisty creative work, was well suited for that task. **********Although the agency is best known for a brash approach to advertising, notably signing Donna Rice for a campaign for No Excuses jeans, in recent months it has won assignments from more conventional advertisers like the Coach Leatherware Company. **********Kirshenbaum & Bond was selected over three other finalists, Mr. Coppe said: Berenter Greenhouse & Webster, Doremus & Company and Grace & Rothschild, all of New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/09/busin.main_headline: Thorn in Bid for Thames TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/09/busin.print_headline: Thorn in Bid for Thames TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/09/busin.body_text: **********The music and home appliance company Thorn EMI P.L.C. said today that it had acquired a majority stake in Thames Television P.L.C and offered to buy the rest of Britain's largest independent television company. **********The offer values Thames at $:149 million, or $297 million. Thames said it would not recommend the offer to its shareholders because the price was unsatisfactory. **********Thorn said it had paid $:34.5 million to acquire the 27.8 percent stake in Thames held by BET P.L.C., which provides cleaning and waste management services. The purchase raised Thorn's stake in Thames to 55.6 percent. **********Derek Hunt, Thames's financial director, said that while Thames supported Thorn's acquisition of BET's holding, "we believe the price isn't one that shareholders should accept." **********Thames also has a video library, production companies and a stake in Europe's Astra TV satellite.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/03/world.body_text: **********The three Palestinian leaders who met for more than four hours today with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said afterward that although they received "some positive answers" to outstanding questions, other vital issues remained unresolved. **********As a result, the leaders said, they put off an acceptance for Palestinian participation at the regional peace conference, planned for October by the United States and the Soviet Union, until they received a written letter of understanding from the United States that would satisfy their conditions. **********They said they hoped to receive the letter "in a few days." **********"Let us say we are not empowered to say 'yes' or 'no,' " said Prof. Hanan Ashrawi, one of the three Palestinians who met with Mr. Baker before he left for Amman, Jordan. "The P.L.O. answer was, let's say, a positive inclination."  Objections Presented to Baker **********However, Professor Ashrawi and Faisal al-Husseini, another of the Palestinian leaders, made clear at a news conference after the meeting that the objections that they presented to the Secretary of State were issues of substance on which the Palestine Liberation Organization would not yield. **********Those issues, the two Palestinians said, centered on Israel's conditions for its acceptance to come to the conference. Mr. Baker obtained a conditional Israeli assent on Thursday. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Israel would come to the peace table if the Palestinian delegation, which is to be joined to Jordan's representatives, contained no members of the P.L.O., no residents of East Jerusalem and no Palestinians living outside the occupied territories. **********The Israeli rationale is that the Palestine Liberation Organization is a terrorist organization dedicated to the destruction of Israel, that East Jerusalem is not occupied territory but an inalienable part of Israel and that Palestinians or their descendants living abroad might present demands to return to their former homes in what is now Israel. **********It is on the same issues that the two Palestinian leaders said today that no negotiation was possible. Without specifying the contents of the promised American letter of understanding, they indicated that it was on these issues that they expected assurances. **********They stated strongly and repeatedly that they would brook no outside interference in their choice of Palestinian representatives nor would they yield on their insistence that East Jerusalem's Arabs must be part of a conference delegation and the status of the city a topic at all phases of the peace process. **********"The Palestinian delegation is a matter concerning the Palestinian people," Mr. al-Husseini said. "We are not going to negotiate this matter with any one." **********Professor Ashrawi elaborated on this. "The delegation is not a matter of names and individuals," she said. "The question is who has the right to form the Palestinian delegation. This is only the P.L.O. and the Palestinian people." **********The third Palestinian who met with Mr. Baker, Zakaria al-Agha, left immediately after the meeting for what Mr. Husseini said was an appointment at his home in Gaza. The other two insisted throughout the news conference that they were acting at the direction of the P.L.O. leadership in Tunis, and that all decisions would be made there. On this, too, they and Israel are in direct confrontation, in view of the Shamir Government's insistence that the P.L.O. play no role in the peace process. **********Professor Ashrawi read a statement issued in Tunis by what she said was an unnamed P.L.O. official that she and her colleagues presented to Mr. Baker. The statement welcomed the American and Soviet call to a conference but attached five demands. They are essential to assure the convening of the conference and the success of the peace process, Mr. Husseini said. **********These were the demands: ***********The application of United Nations Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338 and the withdrawal of Israeli troops from all occupied territories, as well as from East Jerusalem. ***********Recognition of the legitimate rights of Palestinians, especially to self-determination. ***********Recognition of the P.L.O.'s exclusive right to decide on participation at a peace conference and the choice of Palestinian representatives. ***********Discussion of Jerusalem in all phases of the peace process. ***********Immediate end to the building of Israeli settlements in the occupied territories, and in East Jerusalem.  Satisfactory Assurances **********Asked whether the Palestinians would refuse to come to a conference if those demands were not met, Mr. Husseini replied, "We are still working on those issues." Professor Ashrawi drew a distinction between "conditions" and matters "to be clarified." **********The Palestinians said they received satisfactory assurances from Mr. Baker on the American interpretation of the two United Nations resolutions, as well as other issues that they declined to specify. Mr. Husseini also said he understood that the United States did not share Israel's position on which Palestinians should be eligible to participate in peace negotiations. **********Professor Ashrawi added: "Mr. Baker explained that the American position continues to be that there will be no veto and no vetting of the Palestinian delegation by anybody. But they stressed again that the Palestinians will understand the restraints with which the whole process is operating and use utmost responsibility and caution in putting together their negotiators." **********Pressed on the issue, she conceded that Mr. Baker had urged them to form a delegation that would not provoke an Israeli veto. She said only the P.L.O. leadership could make that decision. **********Mr. Husseini said, "I can't say that the atmosphere in the meeting was an optimistic one or a pessimistic one." **********He would cite only one example of a point they could not accept -- "anything that would put the building of the Palestinian delegation under the mercy, or the order, or the authority, or a veto of any other side." **********Mr. Husseini said that if Mr. Baker succeeded in clearing away the obstacles that Israel had put in the way of a conference, a further visit by Mr. Baker to this region before an October conference would be useful.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/world.main_headline: Eavesdropping Scandal Breaks Out in Mexico
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/world.print_headline: Eavesdropping Scandal Breaks Out in Mexico
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/world.body_text: **********Government hopes of easing concern about human rights abuses here have erupted in scandal with the discovery of three apparent eavesdropping devices at the headquarters of a new commission set up to investigate official wrongdoing. **********The discovery of the devices at the National Human Rights Commission has underscored widespread suspicions about the use of eavesdropping devices by Mexican Government agencies and even private companies. It has also set off a public dispute between the human rights commission and the federal Attorney General's office, which is in charge of criminal investigations. **********On Thursday, the Attorney General's office issued a statement saying that the devices discovered, two small microphones and a transmitter, were not functioning bugs, but were rather "disassembled elements of a circuit, and therefore incapable of transmitting any signal." The statement said the devices did not have a battery to power them and said the commission had failed to provide evidence of its charges that its offices and telephones had been the subject of illegal surveillance. **********On Friday, however, the human rights commission said the Attorney General's description of the devices "did not correspond" with the evidence presented by commission officials. The commission, which has been critical of the Attorney General's role in many human rights cases it has investigated, warned that it would not tolerate any attempt to tamper with or cover up the eavesdropping case. **********The statement said the human-rights commission "will wait a reasonable amount of time for clarification of the events that have been denounced, and at the proper time, based on the results that are obtained, will make public its opinion on the matter." **********Commission officials confirmed that the devices had been in working order when discovered and examined by electronics experts retained by the commission. **********According to the formal complaint that was submitted to the Attorney General, the devices were found on March 19 in the offices of the commission's president, Jorge Carpizo. Commission officials also said the office's telephone lines had been tapped. **********The apparent effort to spy on the commission, which was set up last summer by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, has only highlighted the trouble it has had in winning cooperation from agencies like the Attorney General's office, which has ignored the commission's recommendations for action in human-rights cases.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/03/busin.body_text: **********The Fibreboard Corporation said today that it had elected John D.C. Roach chairman, president and chief executive, effectively immediately. Based in Concord, Calif., Fibreboard manufactures lumber, plywood and other building materials, and also owns a ski resort. The company has been the defendant in a long-running series of asbestos suits. **********Mr. Roach, 47 years old, succeeds Lawrence C. Hart, who had announced his intent to resign on April 11, and subsequently tendered his resignation on June 18. Mr. Roach joins Fibreboard from the Manville Corporation in Denver, where he was executive vice president as well as president of the mining and minerals group, the Manville Sales Corporation and the fiberglass and specialty products group. He had been chief financial officer. **********Fibreboard "represents an excellent opportunity for imposing and increasing shareholder value," Mr. Roach said. He said that the company's insulation business was No. 1 in its market, that the wood products division should prosper as the country emerged from the recession, and that Fibreboard had handled a long series of asbestos liability suits well. **********Fibreboard said that the experience with asbestos litigation Mr. Roach gained at Manville was a crucial factor in deciding to hire him. along with his experience in the insulation business and the wood products industry. **********James F. Miller, one of Fibreboard's four directors, issued a statement that he vigorously opposed the selection of Mr. Roach. "In my opinion, I am the only director who truly represents the shareholders of this business," Mr. Miller said. He could not be reached for further comment and did not explain in the statement why he opposed the choice of Mr. Roach.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/15/busin.body_text: **********The California Air Resources Board has introduced rules that reduce the maximum allowable emissions of unburned hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxide, which interact with sunlight to produce ground-level ozone, or smog. The rules also set a lower level for carbon monoxide. **********Experts think the new rules will require that vehicles be equipped with electrically heated catalytic converters to burn off these pollutants as soon as the vehicles are started; the current converters are highly effective, but only after they have warmed up. **********In addition, new vehicles will probably need better fuel injectors, breaking up the fuel into smaller droplets for more efficient burning, and mixing the fuel and air carefully. **********The changes amount to "hanging some stuff on the kind of car we've got now," said Philip A. Lorang of the Environmental Protection Agency. **********But the rules also call for 2 percent of cars sold in 1999 to be "zero-emission vehicles," meaning, most likely, that they be powered by batteries. The proportion of zero-emission vehicles would rise to 5 percent in 2001 and to 10 percent in 2003.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/08/world.main_headline: The Nativity Is Now Legal For Russians
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/08/world.print_headline: The Nativity Is Now Legal For Russians
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/08/world.body_text: **********Today was the first officially celebrated Christmas since 1917 in this rough beast of a city slouching toward an uncertain future. **********"I think things will slowly get better," said Vassily P. Aksyonov, the novelist who now lives in Washington, "if they can just avoid sliding back into authoritarianism." **********Exiled and deprived of his citizenship here more than a decade ago, Mr. Aksyonov had come back home for a round of readings from his once-forbidden novels, now being published here in editions of 200,000, and on Sunday night he went to light candles at the Church of the Holy Trinity in the Lenin Hills. **********Scores of other people were doing the same, including students from the nearby Moscow University and a lieutenant colonel of the Soviet Army. At the Mass a few hours later at 1 A.M., the congregation was mainly students, crossing themselves during the frequent litanies of "Lord, have mercy" and going out into the slushy night afterward to find no star bright pointing the way from there. Holiday in 2 Other Republics **********The Russian Orthodox Christmas falls in January because the Orthodox Church stayed with the old Julian calendar instead of changing over to the Gregorian Calendar proclaimed by Pope Gregory XIII in 1582. This year, for the first time since the post-revolutionary decree separating church from state institutions in 1918, the Russian Republic, along with the Ukraine and Moldavia, also declared today a state holiday. **********Most people observed it simply as just another day off, six days after the New Year holiday that Stalin and his successors had gradually tried to get the people to accept as a sort of ersatz Christmas. Most families, whatever their religious beliefs, have had the traditional fir tree, decorated with colored lights and tinsel, at home since the end of December. **********"Grandfather Frost came to our house New Year's Eve," Yuri Matyushkin, father of 4-year-old Aleksandra, said today as he fashioned a snowman in the park at Novodevichy Monastery. "Sasha gave me a stocking, and her mother and I gave her our gifts then. Today we'll just enjoy a chance to rest." **********Almost everybody did have a day off today, though many were unsure even a week ago that they would, or what they would do with it. The result was a day that for most people was not that different from the day before, or any other winter Sunday in Moscow. Pravda Publishes **********Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, published today -- mentioning Christmas only once, in an article about the spread of pornography in the Soviet Union -- but in Moscow and other places where it was a holiday, the post office did not deliver it, so it went unread. **********Izvestia, the Soviet Government paper, wished its readers "S Rozhdestvom," the Russian equivalent of Merry Christmas, with front-page pictures of an angel lighting candles on a Christmas tree and of the Cathedral of the Epiphany in Moscow. **********There on Sunday night, Patriarch Aleksy II of Moscow and All Russia presided over a Christmas Eve service that was broadcast live on Moscow television. He called upon the worshipers to pray "for the spiritual revival of our people and the recovery of our state." **********On Red Square, the showplace of Soviet state power since the revolution, a Soviet-American charity for victims of AIDS, orphans and other people in adversity was allowed to tuck a modest-sized Christmas tree into an entryway of the big GUM department store opposite Lenin's tomb, lighting it Christmas Eve to the ringing of the bells of St. Basil's Church and two readings from the Gospels. Few Goods to Buy **********Today, most people on the square had their backs turned to the tree, because they were watching the hourly changing of the military guard at Lenin's tomb on the other side. Those who turned around could see a huge banner proclaiming "Merry Christmas, Moscow" in Russian and English, to Lenin and everybody else on the square. **********There was of course no Christmas rush, no orgy of consumerism, with shortages of meat, flour, clothes and other consumer goods now so acute that even today, people were lining up for milk outside the few grocery stores that were open. **********Anatoly Savelev, a 57-year-old man on crutches who said he was recovering from an operation in a nearby hospital, stood inside the door of the church at Novodevichy Monastery today, crossing himself often and accepting donations freely offered by visitors looking for the next service. **********"A blessed Christmas to you," he said to one such donor. "And let me tell you one thing: Don't get sick."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/01/busin.body_text: **********Members of New England's Congressional delegation threatened today to block new spending for the savings and loan bailout until the Bush Administration comes forward with a plan to ease the credit crunch. **********Massachusetts and other New England states were hit early and particularly hard by the recession, and the failure of Bank of New England and two associated banks this month has further shaken the region's already weak banking system. **********The threat to link the credit issue to the bailout could further delay the new financing the Administration has said it will need by the end of February to continue seizing ailing savings and loans. **********The Administrations wants $77 billion this year to dispose of 225 institutions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/busin.body_text: **********Its restaurants will continue to sell fried food under a logo bearing the ubiquitous face of its founder, the late Col. Harland Sanders, but Kentucky Fried Chicken is shortening its name on much of its advertising and packaging materials to KFC. **********Dick Detwiler, a spokesman for the chain of 8,000 restaurants that is part of Pepsico Inc., said the company hoped its new KFC logo would better represent its healthier offerings, which include sandwiches, a fried chicken entree that has no skin and, in some test markets, a broiled chicken entree known as Monterey Broil. **********"We want consumers to think of us not just as a place for fried chicken, but for chicken," Mr. Detwiler said. "We are moving beyond simply serving fried foods."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/busin.main_headline: S.E.C., in Budget Request, Expects 20% Rise in Cases
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/busin.print_headline: S.E.C., in Budget Request, Expects 20% Rise in Cases
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission expects a 20 percent increase in litigation, including cases involving overseas investors, according to a commission budget request scheduled to be released on Thursday. **********The S.E.C. estimate was submitted to three committees of the House of Representantives. Hearings on the budget are to be held on Thursday before a subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. **********The request also proposes changing the way the S.E.C. is financed, giving the regulatory agency more money by tapping into its power to charge fees. A similar proposal was offered in a House plan last year, but did not survive. Under the new S.E.C. proposal, public companies would have to pay an annual fee that would be used to finance the agency.  Bigger Range of Violations **********The increase in the amount of litigation stems in large part from new authority granted to the S.E.C. late last year, which expanded the range of violations that could result in fines. Before the additional powers were granted, the agency frequently settled litigation in exchange for milder sanctions that did not involve fines. Until the new law, only insider trading cases involved fines **********Such defendants now "will probably contest the commission's allegations when monetary penalties or other new forms of relief are sought," the S.E.C. said in its report. **********Contested litigation will require jury trials, with a resulting increase in the complexity of cases, the report says. "To meet the increased demand on litigation, it will be necessary to increase the litigation capability of the agency." **********The agency also said that with the greater involvment of foreign investors and securities issuers in the American marketplace, there would be an increased need for complex cases involving overseas entities. **********While Federal agencies all plead poverty in the face of their tasks when asking Congress for their budgets, the S.E.C. request is likely to be treated as credible. President Bush has already thrown strong support behind the agency's effort to get more money, proposing in his budget released in February a 20.4 percent increase in its appropriation at the same time the overall Federal budget would rise only 2.6 percent. **********The commission, which raises in fees twice what it spends, has again proposed making itself self-financing in hopes of avoiding the political pressures of the budget process and eventually being able to increase the amount of money it gets.  A Trust for S.E.C. Fees **********Under the proposed system, the money collected by the S.E.C. from fees paid by market participants would be deposited in a trust the agency would draw on. Congress and the President would still establish a budget for the agency, and any money collected that exceeded the budget would be turned over to the Treasury. Currently, all fees are sent to the Treasury. **********Also under the S.E.C. proposal, the agency would change its fee structure. The fees are now collected from securities transactions, tender offers and new stock registrations. The S.E.C., in an apparent effort to make its fee income less dependent on market conditions, proposed charging an annual fee to all companies that must report to the agency.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/07/busin.main_headline: A Split Over Machine Tool Imports
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/07/busin.print_headline: A Split Over Machine Tool Imports
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/07/busin.body_text: **********For decades, machine tools have been regarded as a mundane but crucial industry, often figuring in American military and trade politics. They are the behind-the-scenes workhorses of an industrial economy, used for cutting, grinding and boring all sorts of products, including armaments. **********In both World Wars, machine tools were officially earmarked for hurry-up production, regarded as vital to wartime mobilization. And in the 1980's, the decline of the domestic machine tool industry was seen as a symbol of both the plight of American manufacturing and Japan's export offensive. **********Today, the industry is once again at the center of a debate that touches on the larger issues of trade policy and national security. The Bush Administration must soon decide whether to push to extend a five-year-old program of restraints on imported machine tools. And it promises to be a tough choice this time because of the growing complexity of global trade patterns and the recent changes in the geopolitics of national security. Renewal Is Uncertain **********The Commerce Department is expected to make a recommendation within days on whether to renew the five-year program of restraints, which expires at the end of this year. The department's recommendation -- expected to be a call for renewal -- will then be reviewed by the Administration after consulting with other agencies, including the Defense Department and the United States trade representative's office. The outcome of that review is by no means certain, according to Administration officials. **********The advocates and opponents of import restrictions no longer line up in neat camps. A handful of America's most competitive machine tool makers, for example, want the protections for domestic producers dismantled because they have had the curious effect of protecting Japanese market share and driving up the costs for many American producers. **********One problem with the complex system of import curbs, they note, is that it defines an American machine by how much of the rudimentary cast-iron components are American-made but ignores the computer controls, which represent more and more of the cost of a modern machine tool. The largest supplier of such controls is a Japanese company, Fanuc Ltd. **********So the free-traders say that those who favor restraints are taking a backward-looking "Maginot Line" approach to international competition. "The people who want to maintain the restraints are trying to fight a war that is already over," said Brian McLaughlin, president of Hurco Companies, an Indianapolis machine tool producer. "Protectionism doesn't work. The only way to revive this industry is to focus on research and development, to develop leading-edge technology and to compete globally." **********For their part, the Japanese, who were the main targets of the curbs, are officially silent on the matter but would be happy to see the restraints renewed. The so-called voluntary restraint agreement serves to freeze Japan's large share of the American market, while restricting the advance of up-and-coming rivals like Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore.  A Different World **********National security calculations today are also far different than when the Reagan Administration prodded Japan and Taiwan into the voluntary restraint agreement in 1986. Back then, the United States reasoned that it should not depend on foreigners for machine tools to make parts for missiles and bombs. **********But those were still the "evil empire" days, when the Soviet military threat meant just that and before the Berlin wall had been torn down. "All these national security arguments have been deflated enormously because of recent events," said Gary C. Hufbauer, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. **********Most companies in the machine-tool industry and 200 members of Congress eager to protect jobs back home insist that the national security argument still holds. "National security is pre-eminent to commerce," said James Mack, the vice president for government relations at the Association for Manufacturing Technology, the industry's trade group. **********The pure free-traders, Mr. Mack said, "want this country to be the Blanche DuBois of international trade politics -- always dependent on the kindness of strangers," in a reference to the faded Southern belle of Tennessee Williams's "A Streetcar Named Desire." **********The restraint agreement allowed the Japanese producers to hold more than 50 percent of crucial machine tool markets like computerized lathes and machining centers, while warning other countries that they would be slapped with penalties if they rushed to increase their sales in the United States. The Taiwanese were pressured to join the agreement, partly to make it seem that the Japanese alone were not being punished. **********Opponents of renewal argue that the restraint pact has increased their costs by forcing them to buy more expensive domestic-made components, irritated overseas buyers and had the "perverse" effect of protecting the Japanese producers since their share of the market was calculated when the yen was cheap and imports at a peak. **********Yet the experience at Hurco, based in Indianapolis, shows the costs of the voluntary restraint agreement on one high-technology machine-tool maker. With sales of about $100 million a year, Hurco is a company that revived in the late-1980's by investing in research on computer controls and software, increasing productivity and moving aggressively into foreign markets. More than half of its sales are now overseas, including East Asia. **********At Hurco, Mr. McLaughlin estimated that the restraint agreement had forced his company to increase its cost of making a machine tool by more than 10 percent. He said the company it was forced to buy more expensive components domestically, like the cast-iron base and housings on machine tools, instead of buying less expensive ones from Taiwan, Singapore and South Korea. The additional cost in one of the cheaper $70,000 machines would be roughly $7,000, according to Mr. McLaughlin. **********Hurco was also forced to invest $6 million in new patterns and in establishing new sources of supply for machined cast-iron parts so they could qualify as American machines under the restraint accord. That money, Mr. McLaughlin said, would have otherwise been invested in research on the computer controls and software that are Hurco's competitive forte. **********The import restraints brand the United States as protectionist and thus can make selling overseas more difficult for American companies, according to Ray Blakeman, the chairman of the Met-Coil Systems Corporation, a Cedar Rapids, Iowa, company that has a joint venture in Japan and a sales office in Taiwan. **********Mr. Blakeman, a former president of the machine tool trade association, wrote to its board in August to protest the group's support for an extension of the agreement. "We are riding a mule that is crippled and should be out to pasture," he wrote.  Plea for More Time **********Yet the proponents of continuing the import curbs say the agreement has safeguarded the domestic industry, allowing it to increase investment. An extension of three to five years, they add, would give the domestic industry the time it needs to regain competitiveness. The industry's revenues have increased slightly since 1986 to an estimated $2.9 billion this year, while employment has declined more than 8,000 people, to 60,150. **********At K. T. Swasey, a machine tool maker in Milwaukee, Winthrop Cody says the import curbs helped give his company the breathing space it needed to invest heavily in computer-aided design equipment and training for engineers. He estimated that the productivity of his operations increased 25 percent in the last four years. **********Without the import curbs, "countries like Japan and Taiwan would take even more of our market because they will cut prices to gain market share regardless of the cost," said Mr. Cody, president of Swasey, which is a subsidiary of the Cross & Trecker Corporation. **********Economists and trade experts have generally scorned the use of voluntary restraint agreements in industries including autos, specialty steel, textiles and ball bearings as costly to consumers and of little genuine help to the protected industries. At best, the curbs may temporarily slow the shrinkage of a domestic industry and encourage foreign producers to set up factories in the protected country to sidestep the barriers. Indeed, the Japanese machine tool companies including Mazak, Okuma, Toyoda and Amada now have plants in the United States. **********The real hope for the future of the American machine tool makers, some experts say, is to increase their competitiveness in their basic businesses and band together to develop new computer-controls technology to leapfrog the Japanese and other rivals. **********A few such joint research efforts are under way. For example, a next-generation controller program, supported by $20 million from companies, the Air Force and the National Center for Manufacturing Sciences, a research consortium in Ann Arbor, Mich., was begun in 1988. "That effort could have a monumental impact on American manufacturing," said Ed Miller, president of the center. "But it's not going to have an effect today or tomorrow."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/14/world.body_text: **********The long awaited conference of political parties that would lay the groundwork for formal negotiations on South Africa's post-apartheid future looks increasingly likely to get under way by the end of this month. **********"The all-party conference is set down for the 29th and 30th of November," Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress president, said today. Mr. Mandela spoke with reporters after a meeting with the Italian Deputy Foreign Minister, Andrea Borruso, who is visiting South Africa. **********Gerrit Viljoen, the Minister of Constitutional Development, criticized Mr. Mandela's announcement as presumptuous, although he did not say the date was wrong. Mr. Viljoen, whom President F. W. de Klerk designated to open the negotiations, said the date was a target that remained to be approved in forthcoming discussions.  Criticim of Mandela Group **********"His announcement is an improper attempt to create the impression that he or the A.N.C. are unilaterally arranging matters with regard to the multiparty conference," the South African Press Association quoted Mr. Viljoen as saying of Mr. Mandela. **********Another Government official, speaking earlier on condition of anonymity, said preparations were already under way to hold the talks before Nov. 30 and that a site would be offered in Pretoria. **********A congress spokesman, Carl Niehaus, said the dates mentioned by Mr. Mandela looked "fairly definite." He said a formal announcement was expected Friday when some participants gathered to form a steering committee. **********The conference itself is expected to last only two days before its participants split into groups working for consensus on issues put on the agenda. They would reconvene for a second round next year, opening the way to formal talks on a new constitution extending political rights to blacks.  Eagerness for Talks **********Though the Government and the African National Congress have assailed each other with rising stridency, they and other major players seem eager to get the talks under way after months of delay and recrimination. **********Even so, details like the conference site, the agenda and the conference's conveners will have to be worked out within the next two weeks. **********The African National Congress and other black opposition groups want the conference held in the Johannesburg region rather than in Pretoria, which is the seat of the white-dominated Government. Government officials insist that Pretoria has the best facilities for such a conference. **********The Government wants the principal parties to convene the conference, while its opponents prefer the conference to be sponsored by church leaders or other neutral outsiders. And they want the agenda to include the creation of an interim goverment and the election of a popular assembly to draft a new constitution. President de Klerk has said negotiations must come first, though he has spoken of some transitional arrangements. **********The major participants refer to the forthcoming talks by different names. The Government calls it a multiparty conference, the African National Congress an all-party conference and the smaller Pan-Africanist Congress a pre-constituent assembly meeting. **********Mr. Mandela said in August that such a conference must be open to all political groupings and that it must be of a limited duration. **********"We are prepared to sit around the table with everybody who wishes to make a positive contribution," Mr. Mandela said today, according to the South African Press Association. **********"Whatever attitude de Klerk takes, we are prepared for it to succeed," Mr. Mandela said. **********In a tough speech last Thursday, President de Klerk accused the congress of trying to grab power. But he told his supporters that the climate would improve when a multiparty conference got under way.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/04/busin.body_text: **********Stocks in Tokyo were slightly higher today in light trading. Brokers said the market was treading water, uncertain about the prospects for United States economic recovery and interest-rate cuts. **********The Nikkei index of 225 issues finished up 94.45 points, or less than 1 percent, to 25,976.02. At midday, the Nikkei was up 57.65 points, to 25,939.22, with 200 million shares traded. But brokers here said that if the Federal Reserve delayed a further easing of interest rates, an American recovery would be just as much bearish as bullish for Tokyo. **********Midday volume was light compared with 400 million shares traded by midday on Friday. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/23/world.main_headline: Israel Protests, but Library Opens Access to Scrolls
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/23/world.print_headline: Israel Protests, but Library Opens Access to Scrolls
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/23/world.body_text: **********Israeli Government officials warned a major American library today against going ahead with a decision to make photographs of the Dead Sea Scrolls available to all researchers without restriction. **********The Israelis said that the Huntington Library in San Marino, Calif., a suburb of Los Angeles, would be violating longstanding agreements if it carried out its plan. But within hours of the warning, the library opened the collection, declaring its action a blow for academic freedom. **********Earlier in the day, the Israelis charged that the move would set off a stampede by scholars that could prevent a "definitive interpretation" of the ancient documents from emerging. **********"This is not ethical, and they shouldn't do it," said Amir Drori, head of the Israeli Antiquities Authority, a Government agency that has overall direction of archeological work here. The agency also supervises the studies of a small group of scholars who so far have had exclusive access to unpublished segments of the scrolls. **********The documents date as far back as 200 B.C. and are among the great archeological discoveries of this century. The Jewish manuscripts were found four decades ago in caves near the Dead Sea. **********Mr. Drori said in an interview that the Government's displeasure was communicated today to the California library but that no decision had been reached about what Israel might do, if anything, if its objections were ignored. **********Another official, Magen Broshi, a member of the committee supervising the Dead Sea Scroll research, said that legal action was being considered. It is not clear on what legal basis or in which jurisdiction this might occur. **********Library officials disclosed this weekend that they had a set of 3,000 master photographic negatives of the documents, which are written in Hebrew and Aramaic. They said they believed their collection included all the known scroll texts. **********For decades, research control has been held by a tight group of editors, and their monopoly has enraged scholars who have been denied access to unpublished materials. Not surprisingly, those who had been excluded were delighted by the Huntington Library's plans, which one researcher said was the scholarly equivalent to knocking down the Berlin Wall.  Library Defends Action **********Dr. William A. Moffett, the director of the library, denied that any agreement governed the library's right to make its photographic collection broadly available. **********While some of the controlling editors charged that photographs in the library's hands were stolen property, Mr. Drori declined to make a similar accusation. But he told Israel radio that copies of the photographs had been sent years ago to several academic institutions overseas as insurance against the possibility that the scrolls might be destroyed in a war. **********"According to the agreement," he said, "those who received them were to be in charge of only their preservation, and are obviously not permitted to publish them or show them to the public without permission." **********The scrolls consist of about 800 manuscripts and are considered invaluable by researchers looking for insights into the history of Judaism and the origins of Christianity. Nearly all the original documents are kept at the Rockefeller Museum in eastern Jerusalem, which had been in Jordanian hands until Israel captured and then annexed it in 1967. Other texts are displayed here at the Shrine of the Book, a part of the Israel Museum. **********Intact scrolls, among them the oldest known manuscripts from the Old Testament, were published quickly decades ago. But other materials, including non-biblical texts, have not been published. Jordan entrusted them to seven scholars, all Westerners and Christians and all but one of whom have passed along their unfinished work to proteges. Overall direction has been held for years by Israel's Antiquities Authority. **********One set of photographic negatives of the scrolls was given to the Ancient Biblical Manuscript Center in Claremont, Calif., but after the death of that institution's founder, Elizabeth Hay Bechtel, possession passed to the Huntington Library. Mrs. Bechtel, who had had a falling out with the Claremont center, imposed no restrictions on the photographs' use, and Dr. Moffett of the Huntington Library said the other day that scholarly access to them should be the same as for other library holdings. **********But the Israeli view is that the original restrictions still apply. **********Critics of the monopoly system have accused the scrolls' custodians of being deliberately slow in publishing their research and of withholding manuscripts from all but favored colleagues. In turn, the custodians have insisted that much of what remains consists of text fragments and that making them freely available risked having them fall into incompetent hands. **********Essentially, that remains Mr. Drori's argument, and he warned that allowing anyone to study the documents put the possibility of a "definitive interpretation" at risk. **********His opinion was echoed by Mr. Broshi, one of those supervising the research. "It would flood the market and swamp the area with secondary productions," Mr. Broshi said. **********Nonetheless, Mr. Broshi acknowledged that control over the manuscripts might have been too tightly restricted. "But the thing has been reorganized," he said. "Instead of 3 or 4 scholars, we now have about 40 scholars -- young, ambitious people who are hungry for promotion. We expect them to do the work in good order." **********Researchers at Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati this month announced the publication of the first volume of a computer-generated reconstruction of scroll texts. They devised a computer program that used a listing of all the words in one collection of scrolls to reconstruct part of the original text. But one of the controlling editors said the Huntington case involved theft of a scholarly work. **********Mr. Drori said 80 percent of the scrolls had already been published and that the rest was expected to be ready for publication by 1997.                    --------------------       Library Opens Collection **********SAN MARINO, Calif., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Opening the photograph collection of the Dead Sea Scrolls today, Dr. Moffett declared: "When you free the scrolls, you free the scholars. If we had sat quietly we would have violated our own policy of unrestricted access." **********He told a news conference that there was no legal ground for blocking access to the material. He also questioned whether anyone had a legitimate claim over access to the scrolls. He noted that they were found beginning in 1947 in territory not occupied by Israel until the 1967 Arab-Israeli war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/22/busin.main_headline: Housing in Connecticut; Lower-Priced Condos for Stamford
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/22/busin.print_headline: Housing in Connecticut; Lower-Priced Condos for Stamford
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/22/busin.body_text: **********A vacant block sits in a streetscape of bulky commercial buildings and modest wood frame houses in the Waterside section of Stamford, and beginning next month it will be transformed into a condominium community. The project initiates a chapter in the neighborhood's rejuvenation and in the city's efforts to provide affordable housing. **********Seventy-five condominium town houses and apartments are planned on the site at Selleck Street and Southfield Avenue; they will be sold to people with annual earnings of $35,000 to $50,000 who have had difficulty finding a home they could afford in the city. **********Prices are expected to range from $65,000 for the smallest apartment, a one-bedroom unit of 651 square feet, to just under $100,000 for a three-bedroom town house with 1,263 square feet. The average selling price of condominiums in the city, including town houses, is $143,533, said Allen Schaps, president of the Stamford Board of Realtors. **********Called Waterside Green, the $8 million project is being developed by the Stamford Waterside Development Corporation, a joint venture of two nonprofit groups: the countywide Fairfield 2000 Homes Corporation and the local New Neighborhoods Inc. The Connecticut Housing Financing Authority provided a $5 million construction loan at a below-market rate, and $1 million for start-up costs came from New Neighborhood's Revolving Loan Fund -- a pool of money collected through contributions from local businesses. **********Also making the project affordable are low-cost mortgages, with rates of about 8.5 percent. They will be offered to buyers of the 75 Victorian-style units through the housing mortgage finance authority, said John Madeo, executive director of Fairfield 2000. Construction and sales are to start April 15, he said, with completion in about a year. **********The architect for the project is Zane Yost & Associates of Bridgeport, Conn. **********The site used to be home to the John J. Ryle elementary school, and recyling land that once housed public buildings has been a fact of life across the nation since the mid-80's construction frenzy. Such is the case in Stamford, where the Ryle school, which closed a decade ago, is among the city's inventory of unused municipal properties. **********While the city always envisioned having affordable housing built on the site, high land and construction costs blocked the project until now, said Jon A. Smith, director of planning and zoning for the city. Today's depressed housing market, he noted, aided its redevelopment. **********In 1989 the city contracted to sell the site to Waterside for $2 million, $1 million less than its appraised value, Mr. Smith said. Financing for the acquisition came from the State Department of Housing's Land Trust Program, which carries restrictions to keep the units forever affordable. **********The significance of this project for Stamford, Mr. Smith said, is that "it puts land back on the tax roll, stabilizes the neighborhood and produces much-needed middle-income housing." Though Stamford saw extensive commercial development in the mid-80's, residential growth lagged. **********To reverse that trend, Mr. Smith said, a revised city master plan in 1987 called for residential development within Stamford's central business district and the fringe area surrounding it. Two mixed-use projects, together totaling 250 rentals and 400,000 square feet of commercial space, have taken shape there in the last four years, and more than 1,000 additional residences are planned within two blocks of the core. **********Mr. Smith said that Waterside Green supported the city's plan to direct growth into four neighborhoods, including Waterside. Among the oldest parts of the city, Waterside, so named because it edges the west branch of Stamford harbor, began to falter in the 1960's when companies followed by families fled to the suburbs. The lack of new development also took its toll. **********But in the last few years that began to change as private developers took a chance on the mixed-income neighborhood, which has subsidized housing in the northern sections and houses selling for up to $1 million in the south. **********Bruce L. Warwick, chairman of Fairfield 2000, said the hope was that redevelopment of the school site, which he described as a gateway to the Waterside community, would "anchor the neighborhood and spur future development." **********Because it was too costly to renovate the school, it was decided to raze it, Mr. Warwick said. **********He said the partners, working with the city and Waterside Task Force, a local residents' group, designed the project to incorporate features that typical home buyers would want. Among them are private entrances for each of the town houses as well as private backyards that back onto common open space. **********The residences will be grouped in four clusters at the corners of the property, with 17 to 22 units in each cluster, giving the project the feel of a suburban residential enclave despite its urban location.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Northrop Proposes $18 Million Settlement
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/busin.body_text: **********A stockholders' lawsuit accusing officials of the Northrop Corporation of wrongdoing in the 1980's would be settled for $18 million under a proposal by the military contractor. **********Federal District Judge David V. Kenyon, who must approve the settlement, scheduled a June 25 hearing here to review it, as well as the disputes over attorneys' fees that have still not been resolved. **********In a notice mailed to its shareholders this week, Northrop's officers and directors admitted none of the allegations. They included charges that incompetence and mismanagement caused problems with the B-2 Stealth bomber, the MX missile, nuclear cruise missile tests and the ill-fated F-20 Tigershark fighter. **********The lawsuit, filed in 1988, named as defendants Northrop's former chairman, Thomas V. Jones; the current one, Kent Kresa; 12 other company directors; 21 current and former Northrop executives and employees, and 3 independent consultants. **********The $18 million is to be paid by Northrop insurance policies covering the activities of company directors and officers. The money "will go into the corporate coffers," since the suit was filed on behalf of the company, said William S. Lerach, a lawyer in San Diego representing the stockholders. **********Highlighted in the suit was Northrop's failed attempt to sell South Korea the F-20 Tigershark, which had cost $1.2 billion to build. The suit said Northrop paid bribes in 1983 and 1984 to South Korean Government officials in an unsuccessful attempt to entice them to buy the jet fighter. **********Northrop's shares gained 12.5 cents each on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $22.625.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/17/world.main_headline: Search Is Halted for 10 Men Lost on Barge in China Seas
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/17/world.print_headline: Search Is Halted for 10 Men Lost on Barge in China Seas
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/17/world.body_text: **********Officials tonight suspended the search for 10 men still missing after an oil exploration barge sank in the South China Sea with nearly 200 aboard. **********Four of those missing were trapped in a decompression chamber when the barge capsized in a typhoon on Thursday about 65 miles east of Hong Kong. Officials said their air supply would run out on Friday morning. **********The search ended after rescue workers battled high waves and low visibility in the search for the missing. **********At least 174 people, including 11 Americans, were pulled from the sea after the barge sank just below the surface on Thursday. The American skipper, Billy Young, and 12 others were confirmed dead. **********Trevor C. Berry, spokesman for the Hong Kong Maritime Rescue Center, said the chances of finding any of the missing alive were slim, although rescuers were still hoping for a miracle.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/17/busin.main_headline: McDonald's Planning to Reduce Its Garbage
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/17/busin.print_headline: McDonald's Planning to Reduce Its Garbage
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/17/busin.body_text: **********The McDonald's Corporation, under continued criticism from environmentalists, announced more than 40 steps today that it hopes will reduce its daily generation of two million pounds of garbage by 80 percent. **********The company plans to trim the size of its paper napkins, replace ketchup packets with stainless steel dispensers and introduce refillable coffee mugs over the coming months. **********Many of the steps will be trials rather than permanent programs. **********The latest plans follow by six months a McDonald's move to replace the clam shell-shaped foam containers used for its sandwiches with with quilted paper wrappings that some critics say are more difficult to recycle than the foam. **********McDonald's is also giving up its large bleached takeout bags in favor of unbleached recyclable bags. **********McDonald's developed its program with the advice of the Environmental Defense Fund of Washington. **********The company said it needed to use a range of techniques -- recycling, re-use and composting -- because it generates so many types of waste in such large amounts. **********Among other measures, McDonald's plans to eliminate plastic wrappers for plastic knives, forks and spoons, and do without dividers inside boxes used to ship cleaning supplies to restaurants. The corrugated plastic-lined boxes used to ship meat and poultry to restaurants will be replaced with re-usable containers. **********McDonald's will also test re-usable coffee filters, salad lids, breakfast platter lids, coffee mugs and bulk condiment dispensers. And the company will try replacing cardboard french-fry containers with paper bags, eliminating lids for cold drinks consumed at the restaurants and composting food and paper garbage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/busin.main_headline: Economist at Columbia Gets High GATT Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Economist at Columbia Gets High GATT Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/busin.body_text: **********Few economists anywhere in the world are more outspoken in their advocacy of free trade than Prof. Jagdish Bhagwati, or more prolific in writing about its merits. And seldom since World War II have there been greater difficulties in negotiating another round of reductions in tariffs and other trade barriers. **********So it is perhaps only natural that the organization charged with conducting the negotiations -- the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT -- should turn to Professor Bhagwati for help, offering him the newly created post of economic policy adviser. He will report directly to Arthur Dunkel, Director General of the Geneva-based organization. **********The appointment comes in the final months of the Uruguay Round, one of GATT's periodic efforts to lower not only tariffs, but other barriers that prevent products and services from moving easily among GATT's 96-member nations. **********"These negotiations tend to become very political," the 56-year-old Columbia University economics professor said. "But there is a parallel economic analysis for all the issues, and I intend to insert these scientific arguments for free trade." **********He will do this, he said, by literally sitting at delegates' elbows as the talks come to a conclusion in late summer, mostly at GATT headquarters in Geneva. Although Professor Bhagwati is not giving up his post at Columbia, he will spend a week or more a month in Geneva, under a contract that takes him on as a policy adviser at the top of GATT's hierarchy. **********Various obstacles are making an agreement difficult to reach in the Uruguay Round. A big one is the tendency of the Western European countries, on one hand, and the United States, Mexico and Canada, on the other, to create regional trading blocs that give preferential treatment to products produced and sold within each region. **********The Bhagwati view of such trends, briefly stated, is that free trade will produce the greatest wealth over the long run; barriers only divert the flow of goods and services, rather than making them multiply. That is the view set forth in Professor Bhagwati's book "The World Trading System at Risk," just published by the Princeton University Press, which helped get him the GATT job. **********Professor Bhagwati was born and raised in Bombay, India, and educated at Cambridge University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he received his doctorate. He taught economics in New Delhi and then back at M.I.T. before switching to Columbia in 1980 -- making the transfer to be with his wife, Padma Desai, a specialist in Soviet economics at Columbia.
