https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/30/busin.main_headline: 'Harlot's Ghost' Is Revising Fiction's Role as Cheap Date
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/30/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; 'Harlot's Ghost' Is Revising Fiction's Role as Cheap Date
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/30/busin.body_text: **********In the pricing of American books, Hemingway has traditionally taken a back seat to historians, and a reader is likely to spend more for a fix-it book or a collection of inspirational ditties than for a book by Proust. **********But when Norman Mailer's new novel "Harlot's Ghost" hit the bookstores last week with a price tag of $30, readers were put on notice that they may soon have to start paying what novels actually cost to produce. **********The book is the first work of popular fiction to cross the $30 threshold, and it took a leap to get there. The closest-priced novels are selling for a full $5 less. The publisher, Random House, said it had no choice but to charge that much, because at nearly four pounds "Harlot's Ghost" weighs as much as a roast that could feed eight people, and at 1,328 pages it has more heft than the average King James Version. **********"Even at this price, it's underpriced," said Bruce Harris, who is in charge of sales at Random House. "It costs a lot to produce a book this size. It had to be done." **********If Random House gambled correctly and readers make the book a best seller, people in the industry say, other publishers will push up the prices of their novels, even ones that do not match the formidable dimensions of "Harlot's Ghost." **********There does not seem to be a hard and fast reason why nonfiction has traditionally been priced higher than fiction. Publishers say that people buy fewer copies of nonfiction, so the production costs are ultimately higher, and that the audience for nonfiction has generally been more affluent than the fiction audience and thus more willing to spend money. **********Until recent years, moreover, there was a long-held feeling within the industry that publishers are somehow morally obliged to keep novels within the financial reach of most readers -- even at the risk of losing money -- because literature is a "product" that cannot be copied and sold like knockoff suits for a cheaper price. **********But publishers say they can no longer be oblivious to market realities. With the recession and with more and more publishing houses being bought up by multinational corporations that demand balanced budgets, publishers in the last few years have begun to think and act more like business people. 'An Underpriced Commodity' **********The $30 novel is not a statement or a gamble, they say. It is as realistic as a $10,000 economy car, a $7.50 movie ticket and a $2 ice cream cone. **********"Books cost this much to make," said Barry Lippman, publisher at Macmillan Inc. "There's no other place a publisher recoups his money but in the cost of the book. And books are an underpriced commodity from a pure product point of view." **********Mr. Lippman points to a study showing that the price of books had risen very little over the last decade, compared with the price of, say, an Ivy League education, a car, a movie or a house. **********By his calculations, the average price of a house has risen 83 percent, to $140,000 in 1990, from $76,400 in 1980; the price of a Ford Thunderbird has gone up 157 percent, to $17,480 from $6,808, and movie prices have increased 114 percent, to $7.50 from $3.50. Meanwhile, according to Mr. Lippman's chart, hard-cover fiction has risen 64 percent, to $17.95 from $10.95. Likelihood of Discounts **********Many readers who buy the new Mailer book will not even pay the full $30 list price, because the large chain bookstores generally sell books at a discount, particularly if a book either is a best seller or has big expectations. **********A spokeswoman for the Barnes & Noble book chain said its stores would sell "Harlot's Ghost" at a 15 percent discount, or $25.50, and would double the discount if the book made The New York Times best seller list. **********Random House did not come easily to its decision to price the book at a record $30. And despite mixed reviews, executives there are not publicly questioning their choice. They took a similar, much-discussed gamble with a nonfiction volume last year when they priced a book based on the PBS television series "The Civil War" by Ken Burns, at $50, far above the nonfiction standard. It became a best seller. **********Setting the price for the Mailer book was one of the first big decisions for Harold Evans when he took over as publisher at Random House earlier this year. "There was a lot of cold feet about doing it," Mr. Evans recalled, "a feeling that a $30 novel would put people off." 'Unthinkable' Cutbacks **********So, the internal hand-wringing began. Could Mr. Mailer be persuaded to trim the manuscript? The idea was "unthinkable" to the book's editor, Jason Epstein, Mr. Evans said. Could the text be set in smaller type with tighter margins to cut the number of pages? "I thought it was a bad idea," Mr. Evans said. "It's really a beautiful book and very easy to read this way." **********Mr. Evans casually polled booksellers about the price. Some winced, he said, but most said that the $30 novel was an inevitability and that of all contemporary authors, Mr. Mailer was the best one for the gamble. **********"If ever there was a book that you would risk breaking the $30 price barrier with, this is it," said William S. Lofquist, a publishing analyst at the United States Department of Commerce. "You've got the huge size of the book; you have a great, very hot subject -- the C.I.A. -- and you have a dynamite author who's a name brand, like Colgate." **********After running through and rejecting a host of ways to cut the production costs, Random House decided to leap over the $30 breach. "At the end of the day," Mr. Evans concluded, "Mailer is worth it." 200,000 Advance Orders **********Booksellers also seemed to think the risk was worth it. In all, they placed advance orders for 200,000 copies of the book. **********Stuart Applebaum, a vice president at Bantam Doubleday Dell, said he still remembered the "hue and cry" when Delacorte priced James Clavell's novel "Noble House" at $19.95 in 1981. "People were saying then that this is going to destroy the hard-cover fiction industry to have a novel at such a high tariff," Mr. Applebaum said. "And the industry survived, and here we are with a $30 upper limit." **********As pleasures go, reading a novel -- even one with a $30 price tag -- is still relatively cheap. A two-hour movie at $7.50 a ticket ends up costing about 6 cents a minute, while Mr. Mailer's book, read at a pace of about two minutes a page, runs about a penny a minute. And when measured by weight, "Harlot's Ghost" comes out at just under 50 cents an ounce, while the same amount of Beluga caviar fetches about $55.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/17/world.main_headline: European Force Is Proposed for Croatia
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/17/world.print_headline: European Force Is Proposed for Croatia
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/17/world.body_text: **********Alarmed by the increase in fighting in Yugoslavia, Western European countries moved closer today to dispatching a military peacekeeping force with a view to securing a permanent cease-fire in Croatia. **********The Netherlands, which currently holds the presidency of the European Community, proposed today that Western European countries consider deploying a "lightly armed" force in Yugoslavia because an international team of 200 civilian observers had so far been unable to end the fighting. **********Dutch officials said the idea of the force was not to impose a cease-fire but rather to use a European show of arms to discourage a resumption of warfare after a new cease-fire goes into effect. Dispatching a force would require the approval of the parties to the Yugoslav conflict, the officials added. **********Since the community has no military capability, the proposal was directed to the Western European Union, a regional military organization comprising nine of the 12 community members. The foreign and military ministers of the Western European Union nations are to discuss the plan in The Hague on Thursday evening. **********The Dutch move reflects mounting frustration within the community at the repeated failure of its diplomatic efforts to end the fighting. Although a community-sponsored peace conference began nine days ago, hopes for an early breakthrough were dashed by the latest surge in the civil war. **********The chairman of the peace conference, Lord Carrington of Britain, who flew to Belgrade today for talks with the Presidents of Serbia and Croatia and the military minister, is scheduled to resume his negotiations with foreign ministers of Yugoslavia and its six republics in The Hague on Thursday. **********Dutch officials said that after these meetings community foreign ministers would hold an emergency session, also in The Hague, to discuss options. These include the possibility of formally requesting creation of a peace force when the ministers of the Western European Union meet later on the same evening. **********If such a force is formed, it would represent the most important military activity undertaken by Western European countries outside the direct control of the NATO since World War II. The Western European Union coordinated the European naval activities in the gulf crisis, but since it was formed in 1955, it has historically been overshadowed by NATO.  Push for a Common Policy **********Although the community and the regional military organization are not linked, military involvement by Western Europe in Yugoslavia is also expected to strengthen calls by France and some other countries for the European Community to develop a common military policy and create its own rapid reaction force. **********Foreign Ministry officials in Germany, which currently heads the Western European Union, insisted today that no decision had been made to send a military force to Yugoslavia, and they noted that the German and Italian Foreign Ministers had called on Sunday for sending more observers. **********The officials also said it was too early to discuss the size of any multinational contingent and stressed that the dispatch of European troops would require the approval of the Yugoslav Government as well as of the six republics to avoid the risk that the force might be drawn into the war. **********In London, a Foreign Office spokesman said Britain had not ruled out the possibility of participating in a European peace force but noted that it would have to be invited into Yugoslavia by all parties, including Serbian and Croatian guerrilla groups, and that a cease-fire would have to be in effect. **********"We're interested in peacekeeping not peacemaking," the British spokesman said. "The force would need sufficient strength in terms of men and equipment to do the job because it is a very complicated situation. It is not just a question of patrolling a 'green line' because the lines are blurred." **********In Paris, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said France, which already last month proposed the dispatching of troops to Yugoslavia, would back the Dutch initiative at the meetings on Thursday in The Hague and had already so informed the German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/02/busin.main_headline: Citibank Names Head Of Foreign Debt Panel
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/02/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Citibank Names Head Of Foreign Debt Panel
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Citibank, the largest American bank lender to Latin American countries and the leader in negotiations to reorganize those countries' debts, yesterday named Mike de Graffenried chairman of the bank's debt-restructuring committee. **********Mr. de Graffenried, 42 years old, will replace Robert A. McCormack, who moved to a new position in the bank to help resolve its problems with commercial real estate loans. **********The appointment comes as bankers, led by Citibank, are negotiating with Brazil on a package of financial options covering about $40 billion in medium- and long-term debts. Brazil has already begun to make cash interest payments that will cover about $2 billion of its $8 billion in interest arrears, with the remainder of past-due interest to be covered once the country and banks agree on a broader debt package. **********Analysts expect the solution for Brazil to be somewhat similar to that worked out for other countries, where bankers have accepted a package that allows them to choose among making new loans, accepting a market rate of interest on a reduced amount of existing loans, or accepting a below-market interest rate on the existing loans. The packages also include various mixtures of United States Treasury zero-coupon bonds and financial assistance from international organizations to guarantee some principal and interest payments. **********Mr. de Graffenried, who speaks Spanish and Portuguese, is no stranger to the debt talks. After the Mexican loan default in 1982, he joined the Citibank debt-restructuring team led then by William R. Rhodes, now a bank vice chairman, and was deeply involved in earlier loan agreements with Brazil and Argentina. After a tour of duty as Citibank's senior officer in the Persian Gulf region, he returned to New York and the debt-restructuring group. **********"In the 1980's, there was a real sense of crisis, and living moment to moment," Mr. de Graffenried said in an interview yesterday. Currently, he said, the most heavily indebted countries are past the liquidity crises that threatened their ability to pay for imports and interest on their loans. **********He noted that the economic rebound in Mexico, Chile and Venezuela, which followed internal changes and debt restructurings, could make negotiations easier "by showing other countries that there is a benefit to be derived." **********What the solution will be in the cases of Brazil and Argentina, the two largest remaining debtors, remains to be seen. Mr. de Graffenried declined to comment on the current state of negotiations with Brazil. Talks with Argentina, which owes banks about $25 billion but has been making partial interest payments of $60 million a month, could begin later this year. **********Mr. de Graffenried lives in Westport, Conn., with his wife, Pilar, and their 15 year-old son.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/27/busin.main_headline: An Edge for Burnett In Beef Council Review
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/27/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; An Edge for Burnett In Beef Council Review
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/27/busin.body_text: **********Advertising executives speculating as to which of four agencies might win the estimated $25 million-plus Beef Industry Council account are citing two factors that could favor Leo Burnett U.S.A. in the review. **********One is that Bill Engelbrecht, Burnett's executive vice president for administration, is a member of the council. He runs what Wally Petersen, a Burnett spokesman, called "a small cattle ranch" in Henry, Ill., near Peoria. Though Mr. Engelbrecht is not leading Burnett's efforts to win the account, Mr. Petersen said, he has had some involvement in Burnett's pitch. **********The other is that from 1939 to 1954, Burnett worked for a forerunner to the Chicago-based council called the American Meat Board. It was "truly the first national showcase account for Burnett," Mr. Petersen said, adding that old ads from that campaign decorate the walls of one floor of the agency's headquarters in Chicago. **********Burnett is facing three other finalists in the review: the incumbent, Ketchum Advertising San Francisco; GSD & M Advertising, Austin, Tex., and DDB Needham Worldwide, Chicago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/20/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Upward Pressure Seen for Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/20/busin.body_text: **********Wall Street, still struggling to digest a record $37 billion worth of securities sold at the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions this month, is about to be served another heaping pile of paper. **********This week, in what some analysts have called a shadow refunding, the Treasury will sell $37.5 billion worth of securities. Analysts said the auctions would probably put upward pressure on short-term interest rates. **********An important reason these rates may rise is that the Treasury needs to drum up much more demand for the securities to be auctioned this week than it did earlier this month. **********The refunding auctions raised $19.5 billion in new cash. The securities to be sold this week, which include new two-year and five-year notes and $16 billion of cash management bills that have a one-year maturity, will raise $27.5 billion in new cash. **********"These auctions may appeal to a variety of financial institutions, both domestic and foreign, as well as to investors seeking shelter from a nervous bond market," Susan Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers, wrote in the firm's weekly Comments on Credit. "However, the market may need much more help in the form of favorable economic news to absorb this new rush of supply." **********That sort of news is unlikely to emerge this week, as few substantive reports on the economy are expected.  Spread Likely to Flatten **********With the Federal Reserve's target for the overnight Federal funds rate anchored at 5 7/8 percent, short-term rates are not likely to head up sharply, analysts said. But the difference, or spread, between rates on two-year notes and 30-year bonds is likely to flatten from what has been the widest gap in years. At the end of last week the spread between two-year notes and 30-year bonds stood at 1.45 percentage points. **********After this week's auctions, "I would bet that the spread would drop to 135 basis points," said Steven Slifer, a senior vice president and financial market economist at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. "The supply problem will continue to be a focus for the market." A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********In addition to the Treasury auctions, the State of Massachusetts, troubled by the recession, is expected to tap the municipal bond market this week. In its first offering since Gov. William F. Weld took office, Massachusetts, which has the lowest debt rating of any state, will offer investors $475 million worth of securities.  Test of Confidence **********The offering will be a test of investor confidence in the Governor's recently proposed budget for the next fiscal year, which begins July 1. **********To help close a budget gap that may reach $2 billion, Mr. Weld has proposed more than $800 million in spending cuts. Property tax increases are almost certain to follow, analysts said. **********The stern measures will not be unique to Massachusetts, and are an important reason economists say that an economic recovery, when it finally arrives, will be muted. **********"State and local governments were an engine of growth in the 1980's, but I expect they will be a drag on the recovery," said Cynthia Latta, senior financial economist at Data Resources Inc., an economic forecasting firm in Lexington, Mass. **********With some 15 million employees, state and local government spending accounts for slightly more than 10 percent of gross national product. **********In California, where the new Governor, Pete Wilson, has recently proposed a sales tax that would halve a projected $13 billion deficit, "our growth rate is going to be less than half what it was in the prior three years," said Jerry L. Jordan, a senior vice president at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. "That is a very substantial decline. And it is the best we are going to do." **********Aside from cutting spending, layoffs will probably be widespread. And the effects of the layoffs are just beginning. For the first time in many months, employment at state and local governments declined in April,as some 18,000 people lost their jobs. Crisis Called Severe **********"This is probably the most severe state and local government crisis since the Depression," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence Inc. "Operating-budget deficits in the early 1980's were nowhere near as severe as they are now." **********The good news for cash-strapped borrowers is that demand for tax-exempt securities remains very strong. **********Underwriters at the First Boston Corporation, which is acting as lead manager for the negotiated sale of the Massachusetts bonds, would not speculate on what level of interest rates it would take to sell the new securities. At the end of last week, however, yields on outstanding Massachusetts bonds stood at 7.75 percent. The outstanding bonds carry ratings of Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/08/busin.main_headline: Chief Operating Officer Promoted at Medtronic
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chief Operating Officer Promoted at Medtronic
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/08/busin.body_text: **********Medtronic Inc., Minneapolis, a maker of heart pacemakers, has not been shy to draw on other companies for management talent. The company announced yesterday that William W. George, who joined Medtronic from Honeywell Inc. in 1989, would become president and chief executive effective May 1. **********Mr. George, 48, currently president and chief operating officer, is succeeding Winston R. Wallin as chief executive. Mr. Wallin, 65, joined Medtronic in 1985 after 37 years with another Minneapolis organization, the Pillsbury Company. **********Mr. Wallin, who will retire from Medtronic on Sept. 1., will continue as chairman beyond that date. Medtronic said he was responsible for transforming the company from primarily a maker of pacemakers to a medical-products company that operates in 80 countries with 8,000 employees. **********"Our first billion-dollar revenue year seems well within reach," Mr. Wallin said at a meeting of employees yesterday. Under his stewardship, 11 companies were acquired, earnings tripled, and the stock price rose from $14, to about $117 a share. **********Mr. George said in a statement that he expected no major changes in the company's direction under his management. He said that he and Dr. Glen D. Nelson, vice chairman since 1986, planned to try to build on the base laid down by Mr. Wallin. Dr. Nelson, 53, will continue to direct the company's science and technology, strategic planning, business development and new business ventures. **********Mr. Wallin left Pillsbury, where he was vice chairman, to take over Medtronic as president and chief executive in 1985 after having served seven years on the Medtronic board. Four years later, Mr. George left Honeywell after 11 years to work under Mr. Wallin and prepare to succeed him. **********Mr. George was president of Honeywell's space and aviation systems business when he left. Earlier, he ran the company's industrial automation business and was president of Honeywell Europe. **********Before joining Honeywell, he was president of Litton Microwave Cooking Products, a unit of Litton Industries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/26/busin.main_headline: TRW in Venture With Hitachi Ltd.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/26/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; TRW in Venture With Hitachi Ltd.

Others may involve servicing existing satellites, and various improvements to spacecraft. Efforts to handle data returned to earth from spacecraft and systems to be used in spacecraft studies of earth and changes in the global environment are also being considered.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/18/busin.main_headline: Fast Start Replaces a Limp In Some Views of Recovery
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/18/busin.print_headline: Fast Start Replaces a Limp In Some Views of Recovery
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/18/busin.body_text: **********The economic recovery that almost everyone thought would start with a crawl could begin with a dash instead, according to a growing minority of forecasters, including Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. **********But a fast start -- which Fed officials now describe as a reasonable, albeit an unlikely, possibility -- would not presage a sustained boom. **********Still, some Fed officials are struck by the fact that business made sharp cuts in production as sales slid. "Clearly we've had some substantial inventory hits during the recession and in the current quarter," said Wayne Angell, a governor of the Fed. "At some point in time, when you take away a huge negative number, that tends to give you a rather significant rebound." **********More than a month ago, some Wall Sreet firms began raising their forecasts of how much the gross national product would grow in the last half of this year and the first half of 1992. The G.N.P. is the total value of goods and services sold. **********"When we realized how deep a hole we'd dug ourselves into," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, referring to inventory cutbacks, "we realized we'd be digging out faster." **********Just as efforts by businesses to cut production when sales decline can snowball into a recession, attempts to keep shelves filled when sales start to revive can give the economy a powerful kick. As a matter of arithmetic, reducing inventories subtracts from G.N.P. growth while inventory building adds to growth. Even merely trimming at a slower rate gives the economy a lift. **********"There's a legitimate concern that industry is in better shape in this recession than usual, just like services are in worse shape," said Stephen S. Strongin, associate research director at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. "With one part of the economy in better shape than usual and one part worse, it depends on which you emphasize whether you worry about too much versus too little growth." **********Last week's rash of economic reports made the possibility that the economy might shift directly into high gear seem more plausible, though hardly certain. Businesses reported that inventories in April were unusually lean, amounting to 1.5 months worth of sales, compared with the typical 1.65 to 1.75 months. At the same time, retail sales jumped and car buying picked up a bit. **********Lean supplies and a pickup in sales make it more likely that businesses will trim inventories less in coming months. "An inventory kick like that is enough to produce a surge of real income growth next fall and winter," said Art Rolnick, research director at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. "That is especially true if inflation comes down, too. " **********As business pumps up production, there should be gains in hours worked, payrolls and, consequently, income. If inflation edges down for a while, as it almost always does in the first months of a recovery, purchasing power would rise, too. **********A spurt at the start of the recovery does not imply a lasting boom. "An inventory rebound doesn't last for more than a few quarters," Mr. Rolnick said. In other recoveries, economists at the First Boston Corporation report, the swing from inventory reduction to accumulation typically adds a percentage point to G.N.P. growth during the recovery's first year and almost nothing after that. **********Most of the forces that kept growth sluggish before the recession are still around, two examples being well-stocked consumers and a shrinking military industry. A Slower Pace **********"You are likely to get the normal cyclical dynamics, but on top of a very slow trend, " said Richard Rippe, chief economist at Dean Witter. What is more, any speedy start now would be modest by the standards of past recoveries. At most, this rebound might start with a couple of quarters of 4 to 5 percent growth, not the high-single-digits pace registered immediately after some previous recessions. **********Fed officials hasten to add that a bouncy recovery is not being forecast by the Fed, though Mr. Greenspan said two weeks ago that "the probability of a stronger-than-expected recovery is rising slightly." **********Mr. Strongin of the Chicago Fed said: "This recession has a different structure going in, and the recovery has a different structure coming out. Charting its course is especially difficult." **********One of the biggest differences is that alert companies started paring inventories when recession began. In most other recessions, inventories kept piling up for at least one quarter before business brought production into line with slower sales. In the long and deep 1974-75 recession, for example, inventories rose for a year before companies cut production. **********At a forecasters' conference last September, Mr. Greenspan a former business prognosticator, argued that "economic forecasting is really the art of identifying tensions and understanding how they will be resolved over the short to intermediate term." **********When the economy is changing direction, the tension between sales and stocks on shelves and in storerooms -- which no one except forecasters or managers ever think much about -- can provide clues to the future.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/13/busin.main_headline: Wall Street; Keeping Tabs on the Rascals
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/13/busin.print_headline: Wall Street; Keeping Tabs on the Rascals
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/13/busin.body_text: **********Once again, it is time to look at Wall Street's dirty linen, the brokerage industry's disciplinary experience in 1990. It is a sobering pile, ranging from cheating on the broker's exam to outright theft. Even the major sins came in all sizes: One brokerage firm employee stole $312; several others pocketed a thousand times that amount. The humdrum miscreants who made unauthorized trades mingled with the creative souls who used forged paperwork to borrow money against customers' life insurance policies. **********While a few of the largest retail brokerage houses had some major explaining to do, those firms again experienced far fewer disciplinary cases, as a percentage of their work force, than their flimsier brethren. It was a thoroughly disheartening year for the quick-buck crowd, with regulators expanding their attention from penny stocks into areas like price gouging on Government bonds. **********One thing, unfortunately, did not change. It was still a year in which how much you learned about your broker's ethics depended on whom you asked. **********Brokerage firms, as a condition of the licenses they hold, are required to confess their sins on a regular basis, through forms filed with an automated data base called the Central Registration Depository. The depository is a joint project of the National Association of Securities Dealers and the North American Securities Administrators Association. There's the rub. **********The N.A.S.D. believes its members' confessions should be limited to closed cases and final results. State regulators believe the public should be told about pending accusations. Thus, brokers risk trouble with the state watchdogs if they omit pending cases, and face unflattering comparisons with less candid competitors if they include them. **********Difficult as this is for the industry, consider the poor customers. They write the N.A.S.D. to check on "Pat Broker," who has just set up shop in town, and the association edits out pending cases and sends them a clean bill of health. (The association does not advise the customers of the editing; it also sends a copy of the customers' inquiry to the broker.) But if the same query were sent to, say, the securities regulators in Missouri, the customers might learn that state regulators have just filed a case charging good ole Pat with unauthorized trades. True, the charges may be found to be exaggerated or wrong; they may also be proven true -- long after Pat has collected new victims. **********That's the problem. Negotiators from the Securities and Exchange Commission, the securities dealers association and the state group met last week to wrestle with their differences. John R. Perkins, the Missouri securities commission and the new president of the state administrators group, said that, while the divisions are still deep, some progress was made. "One of the biggest problems is coming up with a way to make it clear to someone that some of these are pending actions, to make the data more meaningful and more useful," he said. **********Any guess about when the talks might produce action? "Both the S.E.C. and the N.A.S.A.A. consider this to be a fairly high priority item to be resolved," Mr. Perkins said. "I hope that at least by next year we are ready to have a proposal to take to the commission." Which means, of course, that consumers of Wall Street's services are going to be stuck with the status quo for some time. But they can still learn a good bit about Wall Street's dark side. **********A query to the regulators' computer data base about the 10 largest retail brokers, as one might expect, will show that the largest firms -- Merrill Lynch and Shearson Lehman Brothers -- had more new cases than their smaller rivals. That may be logical, considering their larger volume of business. But there were exceptions. Industry records show that A. G. Edwards of St. Louis is sixth in the retail-business rankings, but the firm reported no new cases last year and several smaller firms did. **********And anomalies abound. While Merrill and Shearson each reported six new cases, Merrill's records show that the firm paid just $10,000 in fines during the year, while Shearon was assessed more than $545,000 in fines and was censured twice. Prudential-Bache Securities reported only three cases -- but one resulted in censure and a $750,000 fine for serious record-keeping and supervisory lapses over several years. **********There are other data sources that can add texture to the careful customer's research. The major stock exchanges and the dealers association report regularly on their disciplinary actions, and those reports provide harrowing and occasionally hilarious details of life in the trenches of Wall Street. **********One aspiring broker was disciplined for writing notes on her palm before going in for her licensing exam. Dozens of brokers were punished for paying arbitration awards with checks that bounced. One busy young man forged orders to earn phony commissions. **********And several firms and 20 individual brokers in Little Rock, Ark., and Memphis, Tenn., were disciplined by the N.A.S.D. last year for selling mortgage securities and other fixed-income investments at "unreasonable and unfair" prices. **********But unfortunately, the most common sin revealed in the dealers association files remains the one that is most devastating to customers: the theft of customer funds. Of the 464 individual brokers across the country who were disciplined by the association last year, nearly 30 percent were sanctioned for simply pocketing their clients' money. In a heartbreaking number of cases, it was money that customers clearly could not spare. **********All of which helps put the regulators' debate over the standards of disclosure that should apply in the brokerage industry's data base in perspective. These well-intentioned partisans are trying to balance efficiency with usefulness, to weigh disclosure against embarrassment, to count the costs against the benefits. But for the customers who encounter the black sheep of Wall Street, the stakes are much, much higher.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/09/busin.main_headline: Kodak Plans Drug Venture With Sanofi
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/09/busin.print_headline: Kodak Plans Drug Venture With Sanofi
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/09/busin.body_text: **********In the latest trans-Atlantic alliance in the steadily consolidating worldwide drug industry, the Eastman Kodak Company and Sanofi S.A. of Paris are pooling resources to create a new company. People familiar with the deal said the company would have $3 billion in combined pharmaceutical sales. **********Kodak and Sanofi, which is controlled by Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine S.A., yesterday confirmed French reports that they were discussing an alliance and said the details would be announced today. **********Kodak's Sterling Drug unit, which has disappointed many Kodak investors, and Sanofi, the 12th-largest drug concern in Europe, each had about $1.5 billion in pharmaceutical sales in 1990. They do not separately report pharmaceutical earnings. Elf Aquitaine, the French Government-owned international oil company, had $30 billion in 1989 sales.  No 'Critical Mass' **********Kodak bought Sterling Drug three years ago for $5.1 billion. Kimberly Ritrievi, an analyst with Paine Webber Securities, said that Kay R. Whitmore, Kodak's chairman, had acknowledged that Sterling did not yield the expected "critical mass" in sales and new product development, as a number of large drug companies formed mergers and created new global giants. **********People familiar with the Sanofi deal said it would bring new products to Sterling's sparse research pipeline and give the French company access to Sterling's 800 American salespeople. Both concerns would be strengthened in the global pharmaceuticals wars. Sanofi products are now sold through licensing arrangements by American companies like Abbott Laboratories, Du Pont, Syntex and the American Home Products Corporation. **********"Sterling Drug has been a big disappointment for Kodak," said Hemant K. Shah, an independent analyst in Warren, N.J. "It has failed to develop any new drugs." The deal does not include Sterling's $200 million X-ray imaging product, which it sells on license from a Norwegian company. **********The new venture follows the acquisition of the Rorer Group, based in Fort Washington, Pa., by the French company Rhone-Poulenc last year and the merger of SmithKline Beckman, based in Philadelphia, with Beecham P.L.C. of Britain in 1989. **********In other recent joint ventures, Merck & Company, the world's largest drug company, joined with Du Pont to created an international research and marketing entity, The Du Pont Merck Pharmaceutical Company, and Merck and Johnson & Johnson established a company to develop and sell over-the-counter versions of Merck prescription drugs. **********Sterling's best-known product, Bayer aspirin, had about $200 million in over-the-counter sales in 1990. But aspirin has been losing ground to Johnson & Johnson's Tylenol and American Home Products' Advil. **********Theresa Gusman, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said the joint venture and accelerated growth in drugs "would be a positive for Kodak, which is doing well in its film and other businesses." **********She also noted that Kodak, which had $18.4 billion in 1989 sales and reported $13.75 billion for the first nine months of 1990, would not be strained financially when it pays $909.4 million for patent infringement to the Polaroid Corporation. A Federal judge ordered the payment to Polaroid last October.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/05/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Fears for Fate of Refugees
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/05/world.body_text: **********More than 15,000 Iraqi civil war refugees being cared for by the United States military will be returned to Baghdad's control when American forces leave Iraq under the United Nations cease-fire plan, a Red Cross official said today. **********The prospect has raised fears for the safety of the refugees, who fled south as Iraqi Government troops crushed a Shiite Muslim rebellion in southern Iraq. Some of them are insurgents and rebel sympathizers, but there are concerns that the Government may retaliate against anyone who crossed into American-controlled territory. **********Under the United Nations plan, American forces will begin leaving Iraq as soon as an observer force arrives to monitor a demilitarized zone along the international boundary between Iraq and Kuwait. **********The United States says it is providing food, water and medical care to 11,000 Iraqi refugees in Safwan, 2,700 in Salman and 2,000 in Al Busaya. But some reports have put the total at more than twice that reported by the United States. **********The United States Central Command has sought to transfer responsibility for the refugees to the Red Cross. But the Red Cross has rebuffed the suggestion **********Arnold Luethold, who heads the Red Cross delegation in Iraq, said that Red Cross involvement with the refugees was due to their being on American-occupied territory, and that the group's mandate ends when the allied forces leave. **********"When the occupation ends, under the Geneva Conventions, our legal mandate will stop," Mr. Luethold said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/busin.main_headline: MOSCOW AND THE MARKETS: Kremlin Shake-Up Jars the Financial World; Stock Prices Drop In Global Selloff; Dollar, Bonds Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/busin.print_headline: MOSCOW AND THE MARKETS: Kremlin Shake-Up Jars the Financial World; Stock Prices Drop In Global Selloff; Dollar, Bonds Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/busin.body_text: **********The world's financial markets reacted quickly and sharply yesterday to the ouster of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, with stock markets around the world falling as much as 9 percent. The American dollar soared 3 percent against some currencies as the uncertainty sent investors looking for a safe harbor. **********The Tokyo market was the first to feel the jolt and ended by losing nearly 6 percent, but as the trading day followed the sun westward and the immediate emotional impact of the coup wore off, some European and American stock markets regained a portion of their lost ground. And in morning trading today in Tokyo, prices were down only slightly at midday. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, after being off 106 points in early trading yesterday, closed down 69.99, or 2.36 percent, at 2,898.03, but military equipment and oil stocks defied the trend, holding steady or rising. The dollar, oil prices and gold came off their highs.  [ Pages D7 and D16. ] Iraqi Effects Cited **********Analysts argued that the impact on world financial markets of Mr. Gorbachev's fall would be less than that from the Iraqi invsion of Kuwait just over a year ago, although major markets fell two, three or even seven times as far yesterday as they did the day after the invasion. **********Oil prices rose, but not nearly as sharply as they did a year ago. The price of crude oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange closed up $1.17, at $22.47 a barrel. Many economies, including the American, are on the verge of recoveries after the recession that began last year. And there is a belief that the crisis in the Soviet Union could lead to lower interest rates as governments try to make money more readily available to help limit the impact. **********The flight from stocks also helped ease the pressure in bond markets, another safe harbor for investors in time of trouble. The move to the United States was reflected in the drop of three-month Treasury bills below 5 percent yesterday for the first time since just after the stock market crash in October 1987. Bond markets in Europe and Japan also fared better than their stock markets. New Opportunities Seen **********And some analysts were looking at the sharp falls in many stock markets as new opportunities to buy quality stocks that are much cheaper than they were a week ago. **********Yet, the economies of many countries, including the United States, Britain and much of Continental Europe, are struggling to begin economic recoveries. In addition, before yesterday, many markets, including Germany's, had not even recovered all the ground lost in the Persian Gulf crisis. **********Some analysts said the latest jolt could trip up the economic recoveries. To have this impact, however, analysts say the Soviet upheaval has to dampen consumer and business confidence, a result that many do not expect unless the Soviet situation deteriorates significantly. **********"The worry that stock markets were reflecting today was that the impact of what happened in the Soviet Union would somehow find its way through and slow down the incipient recoveries" around the world, said Martin Paling, the international investment strategist for James Capel in London. **********"But the only way for that to happen is through falling business and consumer confidence and that is very difficult to forecast," he added. "The real problem is that at this time we haven't got enough to go on but there is a new element of risk." **********All financial markets are likely to continue to be volatile while the new hard-line Government moves to consolidate its control. But markets in the United States and in the Far East, are expected to be hurt less. They are farther away and have little trade or other economic relations that can be disrupted. **********The hardest impact is expected in Germany because of the Government's close role as a financial backer of Mr. Gorbachev; the threat of immigration because of the flight from countries bordering the Soviet Union and the presence of 372,000 Soviet troops in what was East Germany. Germany is also a major importer of natual gas from the Soviet Union. Plunge in Tokyo **********In Tokyo, where the stock market was already weakened by a series of stock and banking scandals, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks was already off about 360 points when the news of the coup arrived. In minutes it was down by 1,000 points and closed down 1,357.61, off 5.95 percent, at 21,456.76. It fell 1.92 percent the day after the Iraqi invasion. At midday today it was off 36.48, at 21,420.28. **********In Germany, the drop was more severe. The DAX index of 30 leading shares plunged 155.40 points or 9.40 percent, to 1,497.93, which exceded the first-day drop after the Iraqi invasion, which was 1.24 percent, and was the largest one-day drop since the small market crash of October 1989. **********Other stock markets falling in Europe included Britain, where the FT-SE 100 dropped 80.5 points, to 2,540.5, its largest one-day drop since October 1989; France, where the CAC-40 fell 132.77 points, to 1,687.54, and Italy, where the Milan Bourse index dropped 79 points, or 7.23 percent, to 1014. The markets in Spain, Switzerland, Beligum, Norway and Sweden also fell sharply. **********The dollar rose the most against the German mark because of the impact the Soviet coup could have on Germany. After jumping to over 1.83 marks to the dollar, the dollar ended in New York at 1.8235, up 3.34 percent on the day. Against the Japanese yen, the dollar rose only 0.57 percent, to 138.15, reflecting the expected smaller imact of the crisis in Japan. **********For the impact of the Soviet coup to change the economic foreces that are pushing the world's economy now there would have to be an abrupt slump in both business and consumer confidence. If this happened, like it did during the Persian Gulf crisis, spending by business and consumers would decline and the economy would slow. **********But many analysts do not expect this to happen. "This crisis is localized," said Michael J. Howell, chief strategist for Salomon Brothers in London. "It will have fewer ramifications for the global economy because the economic fundamentals on the near-term baisis are not that bad." He added that its impact should be more like that of the Tiananmen Square massacre in June of 1989 in China when the Government crushed the democracy movement. **********In the United States, Fabian Linden, the executive director of the consumer research center of the Conference Board, a business research group, said he expected no signficant impact on business or consumer confidence because the Soviet coup should not have the fallout of the Persian Gulf crisis. "With the events in Iraq, we were deeply involved; there was talk of body counts and other dreary forecasts," he said. "There was the impact on taxes, on inflation and on oil prices and the cost of driving to work. These were things that really hit home." **********But George Mangus, the chief strategist at S. G. Warburg in London, said confidence had been hurt, which, he added, meant that Europe, outside of Germany, "could bounce along the bottom of this recession for considerably longer" and that doubts about an American recovery could deepen. **********The big risks now, said Paul Feldman, global strategist at Goldman Sachs & Company in London, was that oil prices could rise, there could be "blood on the streets" in the Soviet Union; American investors could pull money out of European stocks and there could just be a long period of volatility. **********--------------------       HEAVY ASIAN SELLING **********TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 20 (Special to The New York Times) -- Asian financial markets, which were the first to react to the Soviet coup, were hurt on Monday by a heavy wave of selling by nervous investors from Tokyo to Kuala Lumpur. **********The huge Tokyo stock market fell almost 6 percent, while the Hong Kong stock market tumbled 8.4 percent. Stock markets in Singapore and Kuala Lumpur also took steep dives. **********Analysts suggested, however, that as the initial shock wears off, Asia may fare better than markets in the West. Asian economies, while vulnerable to any major shocks to the global political and economic system, generally have fewer direct ties with the Soviet Union, analysts said. **********"There are some ominous signs here, but in the longer term I would rather be in Japan than Germany," said Peter Norton, head of research here for Baring Securities. **********The Soviet shock waves hit an already weakening market in Tokyo and jolted it into a near free-fall just after midday. A series of financial scandals and worries that the economy is slowing have sent the market lower here for weeks. **********The 225-stock Nikkei index was off about 360 points just before the first reports hit Japan. Minutes later, at 1 P.M. the index had fallen by about 700 points. At 1:04 P.M. the Nikkei average had dropped more than 1,000 points, or about 4 percent. **********The closing price of 21,456.76 on Monday, off nearly 6 percent, is close to what is considered the psychologically important 20,000 level. At midday today it was off 36.48, at 21,420.28. **********Mr. Norton of Baring Securities said much of the Monday selling came not from Japanese, but foreign investors worried about the impact of the developments in the Soviet Union. **********In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index had its sharpest decline since the Chinese Government cracked down on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square two years ago. The index fell 340 points, or 8.4 percent, to 3,722. **********In Singapore, the Straits Times Industrial index tumbled 84.51 points, or 6.1 percent, to 1,309.23. Nearby, in Malaysia, the Kuala Lumpur index skidded 36.19 points, or 6.7 percent, to 505.47. **********--------------------       SHOCK IN EUROPE **********BONN, Aug. 19 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Soviet coup shocked Europe's financial markets today. Fearing a reprise of the cold war economic climate, investors sent stocks plunging while driving the dollar's value sharply higher in tumultuous trading. **********Economists said Mr. Gorbachev's removal and subsequent replacement by an emergency committee of Communist hard-liners might continue to roil financial markets until the situation in the Soviet Union stabilizes. Big losses on Wall Street would also weaken European share prices, despite the fact that the sudden change in the Soviet leadership was not seen endangering Western Europe's economic health. **********"I don't see any great economic effect on Western European nations since their ties to the Soviet Union simply aren't that big." said Ulrich Ramm, chief economist at Commerzbank A.G. in Frankfurt. "There could be short-term disruption of Soviet trade, depending on developments. And the markets may suffer because fantasies about the potential for business in the Soviet Union and eastern Europe are really gone right now." **********Should the situation in the Soviet Union deteriorate, the broader consequences of Mr. Gorbachev's fall could include at least a temporary freeze in Western economic aid to the Soviet Union. "There can be no money and know-how from the West for a return to totalitarian thinking," Germany's Economics Minister, Jurgen Mollemann, said. **********Many Western banks and businesses may share that view. They will immediately begin reassessing their strategies in the Soviet Union, said Jonathan Hoffmann, an economist with Credit Suisse-First Boston in London. **********Those factors helped drive prices sharply lower on Western Europe's major stock exchanges. The Frankfurt stock market was hardest hit, with the DAX index of 30 leading German stocks falling 155.40 points, to close down 9.4 percent at 1,497.93. It was the DAX's biggest one-day drop since October 1989 and prompted some comparisons with the global stock crash of October 1987.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/world.main_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL: A Coup Gone Awry/Behind a Classic Soviet Failure/A special report; GORBACHEV QUITS AS PARTY HEAD; ENDS COMMUNISM'S 74-YEAR REIGN: Plotters Who Had  Handcuffs But a Poor Sense of History
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/world.print_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL: A Coup Gone Awry/Behind a Classic Soviet Failure/A special report; GORBACHEV QUITS AS PARTY HEAD; ENDS COMMUNISM'S 74-YEAR REIGN: Plotters Who Had  Handcuffs But a Poor Sense of History
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/world.body_text: **********The abortive coup that finally broke the Communist Party's grip on the Soviet Union was a spasm of desperate nostalgia by a committee of men who saw themselves as patriots of an endangered order. **********In its genesis and failure, it was the most Soviet of coups, the scheme of a gray collective against the new politics of the popular hero. **********The conspirators were so tuned to the plodding rhythms of the Five Year Plan that they thought to order 250,000 pairs of handcuffs from a factory in Pskov and preprint stacks of blank arrest orders, but neglected to detain the man -- Boris N. Yeltsin -- who would inspire the resistance. **********They failed because their bland collective offered neither the charismatic leadership of a Yeltsin nor the single-minded brutality of a Stalin. Plans for Assassinations **********Mr. Yeltsin asserted today that the collaborators had prepared a list of 12 men to be assassinated in the first half-hour of the takeover. Soviet newspapers, citing military sources, said airborne troops had been poised to assault Mr. Yeltsin's government stronghold at 2 A.M. Wednesday. But like decades of Soviet plans, these went unfulfilled, because of indecisiveness and internal division. **********The coup was foreshadowed by a year of intrigues, threats and premonitions, including a January assault on the separatist government of little Lithuania that looks in hindsight like a dress rehearsal for this week's events. **********Incredibly, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, when he was interrupted at his Crimean dacha by the emissaries of the plot, had been working with another writer on a speculative article that included just such a scenario. He told reporters after his rescue that it involved the very conspirators who turned against him. Stranger Than Fiction **********But to Mr. Gorbachev, trusting in the men he had chosen and believing in the ultimate reasonableness of human behavior, it was merely a scenario, not a clear and present danger. **********"My argument was that this would lead to the destruction of society," said Mr. Gorbachev, seeming more bemused by the shortsightedness of his captors than by their treachery. "This would be a dead end." **********Muscovites, who thrive on conspiracy, have been smitten by the theory that Mr. Gorbachev helped organize his own overthrow, calculating that either it would succeed and he would return as a dictator, or it would fail and he would come home a hero. **********Members of the Russian delegation that flew to the Crimea to bring Mr. Gorbachev back after the coup collapsed said their suspicions had dissolved when they had seen the stricken looks on the faces of the Soviet leader and his family. **********Mr. Gorbachev's sin, they said, was not complicity but almost willful misjudgment of the men around him, whom he trusted more than his own public. **********Vitaly Tretyakov, editor of the independent Moscow newspaper Nyezavisimaya Gazeta, said that after what he called the "putsch of fools," Mr. Gorbachev has been pushed to the periphery of his own revolution, a symbol of the legal power that was rescued by others. **********"Evidently during the days of the putsch he was a victim, and for a time the halo of a victim will keep him on the surface," Mr. Tretyakov wrote today. "But today we need him only to personify the resurrection of our constitutional order." The Plot That Failed **********Disorganization And Defections **********It is not known when the conspirators set their plan into motion, but it seems likely that things began to move around Aug. 6. On that day Mr. Gorbachev's spokesman announced Aug. 20 as the date for signing the new union treaty, which promised a radical decentralization of power to the republics. **********Confident in his new partnership with Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Gorbachev had left the previous weekend for his vacation home in the Crimea. **********By Friday, Aug. 16, the plan was unfolding. Komsomolskaya Pravda reported today that on that day a secret memorandum went out to K.G.B. field offices signed by Mr. Kryuchkov. It announced that all K.G.B. agents would have their pay immediately doubled. Two subsequent cables put the K.G.B. bureaus on alert and directed them to begin destroying documents. **********On Sunday, United States intelligence officials said, the Defense Minister, Marshal Dmitri T. Yazov flew to the Crimea, evidently to oversee security arrangements to detain Mr. Gorbachev. Even if true -- it has not been confirmed in Moscow -- the Defense Minister did not join the delegation that confronted Mr. Gorbachev. **********At 10 minutes to 5 that afternoon, Mr. Gorbachev says, he was told of unexpected visitors. When he picked up his phones to inquire, he discovered that all communications were cut off. Gorbachev Rebuffs the Emissaries **********Mr. Gorbachev said the emissaries from the junta were Yuri S. Plekhanov, the chief of security for the K.G.B., and Valery Boldin, the chief of Mr. Gorbachev's staff at the Communist Party Central Committee. Saying later that he indignantly rebuffed their demand that he voluntarily sign over emergency powers to the junta, Mr. Gorbachev began 72 hours of anxious isolation, accompanied by his family and loyal bodyguards. **********On Monday morning, somber announcements on television and radio informed Soviet citizens that they were under "new leadership." Anatoly I. Lukyanov, the Speaker of Parliament, released a statement fiercely critizing the the union treaty and urging that it be postponed. **********With apparent ease, the conspirators managed to enlist, or silence, most of central Soviet officialdom. **********When Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov assembled the Cabinet on Monday night to solicit their approval, only three among the dozens of ministers present expressed reservations, according to notes kept by the liberal Environment Minister, Nikolai N. Vorontsev. **********His minutes record a typical reaction from Vladimir Gusev, head of the state committee on chemistry and biotechnology: "If we step back even an iota, we will sacrifice our jobs, our lives. We will not have another chance." Signs of Disorganization **********The execution of the coup was limited to Moscow, Leningrad and the Baltics.  From the outset, it showed signs of disorganization. **********"The first rule of a coup is isolate and control," said an American intelligence analyst who monitored the takeover from Washington. But this was not happening, he said. K.G.B. units designated for cutting key communications centers were not being deployed. **********Another mystifying mistake was the failure to detain Mr. Yeltsin, who flew back on Sunday from a trip to Kazakhstan and could have been easily detained at the airport. **********On Monday, military armor shuttled back and forth through Moscow, with no clear sign of an objective. **********Almost by sheer force of will, Mr. Yeltsin rallied the resistance. On Monday morning he stepped from his building -- as aides scanned neighboring buildings anxiously for snipers -- and climbed atop a hostile tank to declare his defiance for a gathering crowd of Muscovites. **********By the end of the day, three units sent to surround Mr. Yeltsin's "White House," as it the Parliament building is called, had defected to the Russian government, including a battalion from the Tamanskaya Tank Division whose imposing armor now pointed in defense. Bus Drivers and Boatmen Help **********Trolley-bus drivers surrendered their vehicles to create makeshift tank barriers, Moscow River boatmen barricaded the river with their barges in case of a boat landing and volunteers from two private industrial security firms -- ex-policemen and army veterans who have found profit in the new Soviet freedom -- showed up to help secure the building. **********The Russian Parliament building became a hive of resistance, with a war room, a ham radio center, a printing press. On Tuesday Mr. Yeltsin managed to convene his Parliament in a session that became an inspiring show of legality amid the chaos of the putsch. **********As the conspirators wavered before the resistance, key politicians surfaced to support Mr. Yeltsin, including the leaders of the Ukraine and Kazakhstan. **********Still, as late as Tuesday night, Mr. Yeltsin's team and Western analysts feared that the junta would try to regain the momentum with a show of force. Gen. Konstantin I. Kobets, a member of the Russian Parliament, says that the Russian defense chief, three battalions of K.G.B. troops were to have led the attack on the Parliament building after midnight. **********But the only deaths in the coup were apparently unplanned: three civilians killed when a crowd tried to stop an armored vehicle on the Moscow ring road. Why Parliament Was Never Stormed **********There are conflicting versions of why the storming of the Russian Parliament House never took place. Mr. Gorbachev suggested that the K.G.B. officers refused, but provided no details. Two members of Mr. Gorbachev's National Security Council, Yevgeny Primakov and Vadim Bakatin -- now the post-coup K.G.B. chief -- asserted that the assault was stopped when they intervened with Gen. Mikhail A. Moiseyev, the chief of the general staff. **********From that point, the coup unraveled quickly. **********Gen. Yuri Yashin, a Deputy Defense Minister, told reporters that the 15-member collegium of the Defense Ministry had decided early on Wednesday morning to withdraw its troops. Marshal Yazov listened to the decision in a state of agitation, General Yashin said, and told his colleagues he wanted time to think over his next move. **********"I got into this, and now I have to think about making a declaration on getting out of it," General Yashin said. Later in the day, Marshal Yazov, along with the K.G.B. chief and two other collaborators, flew to the Crimea to plead with Mr. Gorbachev for mercy. **********Mr. Gorbachev, following telephone advice from Mr. Yeltsin, refused to see them. **********"When they came, I said put them in the house, put them under guard," the Soviet leader said upon his return. "They'll have a long lifetime to think about it." The Military and the Police **********To Go Backward Was Their Desire **********A full reconstruction of the plot awaits months of investigation and trial, but to an astonishing degree the conspiracy coalesced in full public view. **********The pretenders to power were men who had made no secret of their alarm at the decline of centralized authority or their willingness to prevent it. They headed institutions whose power was vested in the old order of state ownership, central planning and the coherence of the union. **********"The threat of the collapse of the Soviet Union has emerged," warned Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, the chairman of the K.G.B., in a chilling televised statement last December, one of several public cries of anguish by future coup leaders. **********What was this threat? Ethnic separatists, free-market "profiteers" and ambitious political "adventurists," whom Mr. Kryuchkov and his comrades saw as engaged in a Western-inspired sabotage of the Soviet state. Potential Danger Disregarded **********Mr. Gorbachev told his first post-coup news conference that he was generally aware of the potential danger in the state police agency but had selected and trusted Mr. Kryuchkov for the job because he was an apparatchik, "less professional" than the career spymasters and enforcers in the agency. **********The K.G.B. was the key to the one successful episode in the coup, the capture of Mr. Gorbachev. **********According to Mr. Gorbachev's own account, the conspirators only managed to penetrate his loyal 32-man security guard and deliver their ultimatum because one of the emissaries was Yuri S. Plekhanov, who as the K.G.B. security chief was formally superior to the palace guard. **********Another of the collaborators, Boris K. Pugo, had been the K.G.B. chairman in Latvia. Western Kremlinologists pegged him as more pragmatist than ideologue when Mr. Gorbachev promoted him to a key post overseeing Communist Party discipline in 1988, but since becoming Interior Minister last December he has been a voice of doom and decline. **********The Interior Ministry, responsible for maintaining public order, controls the troops used to put down ethnic violence, including the "black beret" anti-terrorist teams that have been deployed in the Baltic states. **********Mr. Pugo committed suicide on Thursday when authorities arrived to arrest him. **********In the early post-mortems since the coup, Soviet analysts have assigned a more ambivalent role to Marshal Yazov, whom Mr. Gorbachev plucked from obscurity in 1987 to make his Defense Minister. **********"It seems to me that Yazov was sucked into a political game," said General Kobets, who led a battalion that helped put down Czechoslovakia's "Prague Spring" in 1968 and who this week directed Mr. Yeltsin's defenses. "He does not want bloodshed. If he wanted, he could pulverize everything standing in the way of the armed forces." **********Marshal Yazov had been outspoken in defending the military's prestige during a period of cutbacks in the career officer corps, withdrawals from Eastern Europe and scornful slings of a liberated press. He has spoken bitterly against the Baltics and other independence-minded republics, where the army has been vilified as a symbol of imperial power. Division Within the Military **********At the same time, there is a strong reformist streak in the mid-level and junior officer corps, bent on repairing the army's image and professionalism and supportive of broader economic and political reforms in society. And conscripts deployed in Moscow by the Committee for the State of Emergency were admittedly uneasy in the role, even assuring civilians that they would not obey orders to shoot. **********The division in the military was a major factor in the failure of the coup, as mutinies by senior officers and some whole units undermined the conspirators' confidence in their ability to consolidate control. **********General Kobets, who worked on the general staff of the military until he was elected a member of the Russian Parliament last year, drew on his contacts to lure high-level defectors and maintain frequent contact with the military leadership. **********On Monday, Lieut. Gen. Pavel S. Grachev, commander of paratroopers, came over to Mr. Yeltsin's side, a decision rewarded on Friday with an extra star and the post of Deputy Defense Minister. Another, Yevgeny I. Shaposhnikov, commander in chief of the Air Force, who refused to support the coup, is the new Defense Minister. The Central Bureaucracy **********Cabinet Members Feared for Jobs **********But the men who had the most to win from the coup were not the police or military, but the custodians of the central Government. As Mr. Yeltsin pointed out presciently on the eve of the coup, the new union treaty Mr. Gorbachev was preparing to sign with Mr. Yeltsin and other republic leaders would almost surely have swept most of the Cabinet ministers from their jobs. **********Mr. Pavlov, the crew-cut Prime Minister, was a critical though reportedly weak-kneed member of the conspiracy; one Soviet newspaper reported that he spent much of the three-day putsch drinking and was so incapacitated that he had to be hospitalized. **********The most enthusiastic cheerleaders of the takeover were apparently the leaders of the defense industries, which have been in turmoil because of arms treaties and the loosening of central economic controls. Why 500-Day Plan Was Killed **********They were represented in the eight-man Emergency Committee by Oleg D. Baklanov, the Communist Party secretary in charge of the military-industrial complex, and Aleksandr I. Tizyakov, director of a missile factory in Sverdlovsk. **********Last October, the military-industrial complex played the principal role in persuading Mr. Gorbachev to abandon a 500-day economic reform package. They were in open panic at his recent return to the cause of radical change. **********The chief conspirators were linked by overlapping memberships in the Government's main security policy organizations, the Soviet Defense Council and Mr. Gorbachev's National Security Council. They also were part of a hard-line clique in the Communist Party's governing Central Committee and clearly hoped to use the party's surviving network as an instrument of control. The Disregarded Omens **********Ignoring Hard-Line Threat **********Mr. Yeltsin described the arrest of President Gorbachev last Sunday as "the third attempt" by the same cast of conspirators to halt the menace of democracy. That is perhaps putting it too strongly, but there is no doubt that Mr. Gorbachev had repeated omens of the danger confronting him and apparently chose to ignore them. **********Emboldened by their successful campaign to kill the 500-day reform plan last autumn, the hard-liners stepped up their pressure on Mr. Gorbachev, and he responded by trying to appease them. **********At a session of the Congress of Peoples Deputies last December, he named a colorless career Communist apparatchik, Gennadi I. Yanayev, to be his Vice President, a choice that stunned even his closest aides. **********Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze was the first to sound the alarm. Frustrated that Mr. Gorbachev seemed to be letting the military undermine his efforts to negotiate new arms treaties with the United States, and angry that his longtime friend did not defend him against virulent public attacks from the old guard, Mr. Shevardnadze resigned in December with a stunning warning of encroaching dictatorship. **********Four weeks later, in what Mr. Yeltsin described as the first attempted coup, K.G.B. special forces, army paratroopers and "black berets" from the Interior Ministry struck in Lithuania and Latvia. They seized broadcast facilities and used them to announce the transfer of power to mysterious National Salvation Committees based in the headquarters of the Communist Party. Justification for a Crackdown **********Although Mr. Gorbachev professed innocence, Baltic hard-liners involved in planning the attacks say the Soviet leader gave general approval after Mr. Kryuchkov and others convinced him that Baltic separatism threatened the disintegration of the country. **********But when Lithuanians and Latvians rallied to defend their pro-independence governments, the Kremlin lost its resolve. What was to have been Moscow-backed coup in the two republics gave way to stalemate marked by sporadic violence. **********Another premonition of the Kremlin's fecklessness in the face of democratic insurgency came in March, when the Government called out 50,000 troops to prevent a pro-Yeltsin rally in central Moscow. The protesters came anyway, in the tens of thousands, and the troops made no move against them. **********What Mr. Yeltsin calls "the second attempt" against Mr. Gorbachev came in June when, without consulting the President, Prime Minister Pavlov asked the Soviet Parliament to give him additional lawmaking powers. At a closed parliamentary session, Mr. Kryuchkov, Mr. Pugo and Marshal Yazov all chimed in to endorse what the Soviet press described as an attempt to usurp the President. **********Four days later Mr. Gorbachev put down the mini-rebellion. Afterwards he appeared in the parliamentary lobby with Mr. Pugo, Marshal Yazov and Mr. Kryuchkov and joked, "The coup is over." **********Interestingly, another supporter of that power grab was Mr. Lukyanov, the Speaker of Parliament and Mr. Gorbachev's friend since they attended law school together in the 1950's. **********Mr. Lukyanov was suspended this week amid allegations that he had served as "the chief ideologist" for the junta. Those who have worked closely with him say that in the week's events he was less an ideologue than an opportunist. **********Throughout this period of intrigues, Mr. Gorbachev allowed the hard-liners to keep their jobs. **********"We saw it all," Mr. Shevardnadze recalled this week. "We expected what is happening. Unfortunately, Mikhail Sergeyevich did not draw the necessary conclusions. All of this could have been prevented."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/busin.body_text: **********The Chicago Board of Trade has hired former Federal Judge Robert H. Bork to challenge the use of anti-racketeering laws in fraud trials at the world's largest futures exchanges. **********Mr. Bork, whose nomination to the Supreme Court by President Ronald Reagan was rejected by the Senate in 1987, will serve as co-counsel on a friend-of-the-court brief contending that the Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organizations Act is unconstitutional and that the commodities trials on the charges may be invalid. **********David Prosperi, a spokesman for the board of trade, said today that the exchange was not contesting the conviction of several soybean traders charged in an F.B.I. investigation nearly two years ago, but felt that the law should not have been applied against them. **********The law, adopted by Congress in 1970, was intended to fight organized crime, but it has been used in prosecutions ranging from Wall Street trading to corporate wrongdoing. **********Criminal conviction under the statute carries up to 20 years in prison, as well as stiff fines. **********Mr. Bork, who retired from the Federal judiciary in 1988, said today that the law was too vague and had been applied too broadly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/08/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********The Market Watch column (Aug. 18) states that John Gutfreund was "the man who built and ruled Salomon," but anyone familiar with the Street knows that Billy Salomon brought the firm from obscurity to earn it a place as the top market maker and one of the big five investment bankers. Billy was a man of character while John, the opportunist to whom Billy handed the reins, was driven by personal avarice. He was one of those instrumental in putting together the Phibro deal that lined all the Salomon partners' pockets with millions. Wall Street lore has it no members of the cabal had the courtesy to inform Billy of what was afoot. TOM BALLANTYNE  Melbourne Beach, Fla., Aug. 20
