https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/18/world.print_headline: Turkish Election Results May Shift Basic Policies
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/18/world.body_text: **********Burdened by a 70 percent inflation rate and disintegration along its borders with the Soviet Union and Iraq, Turkey is scrambling to redefine itself in the wake of the election defeat of President Turgut Ozal's governing Motherland Party. **********The defeat in the Oct. 20 elections has returned Suleyman Demirel to the Prime Minister's office for the seventh time, and with him the fear that the country could slip back into the violent political infighting that led to a military coup in 1980. Mr. Demirel was ousted in that coup, as he had been once before, in 1971. **********The election appears more likely to result in a shift by the Ankara Government away from the stongly pro-Western policies of Mr. Ozal and the conservative Motherland Party. Mr. Demirel, whose nationalist True Path Party took 180 of the 450 Parliamentary seats, is trying to hammer out a coalition with the left-wing Social Democrat Populist Party, which won 88 seats.  'Atmosphere Is Different' **********"We are entering a political crisis," said Kamran Inan, Mr. Ozal's Minister of State and one of Mr. Demirel's fiercest critics. "We are faced with enormous problems. We must assume a leadership role in the Middle East, the Balkans, Central Asia and beyond. We have economic difficulties and increased terrorism. We need a strong leader, but what we are getting is a man who prefers political survival over political stability." **********Mr. Demirel argues that Turkey has come too far to ever slip back into thepolitical violence of the years before the coup. **********"The atmosphere of the country is different, quite different," the avuncular 68-year-old politician said, seated in his office in Parliament. "The atmosphere of the world is different." **********For the last decade Turkey was dominated by the voluble and high-handed Mr. Ozal, who was appointed Prime Minister by the military in 1983 and oversaw the transition from military dictatorship, propelled the country toward parliamentary democracy and a market economy and gave unreserved support to the West, in particular the United States. During the Persian Gulf crisis, Turkey shut off the pipeline by which Iraq exported most of its oil and allowed American warplanes to make sorties against Iraq from Turkish soil. **********But the cozier President Ozal became with the West, the more he engendered disgust at home, and he was often attacked for his regal way of life and the wealth supposedly accumulated by his family. Mr. Demirel, during his campaign, promised to remove the President, "his crown, his throne and all."  Taking Aim at Presidency **********Mr. Demirel says he is determined to strip the power of the presidency, which he argues is unconstitutional, and give it to the Parliament. He says the new Parliament will take up the legality of Mr. Ozal's election by Parliament to the newly created post of President in 1989. **********It would take a two-thirds majority to oust the President, and the new Parliament still has 113 members of the Motherland Party, enough to block such a move. **********But Mr. Ozal, whose term expires in 1996, seems to have thrown in the towel. "The Ozal era is finished," he recently told a Turkish newspaper. "I don't want any role from now on." **********In fact, the True Path Party and the Motherland Party have many policies in common. Mr. Demirel promised during the campaign to apply more strigent fiscal controls, to give the right to strike to public employees, to create a ministry for human rights and a national health-insurance system, to continue selling off state-owned businesses and to suppress leftist terrorist groups and the Kurdish guerrilla movement in the southeast. Kurdish Violence Is Up **********The Kurdish violence has increased in the last year. The rebels, who have been waging a guerrilla campaign since 1983, want a separate Kurdish state. **********Mr. Demirel has called for "compassion" in dealing with the Kurdish problem, telling Kurdish leaders that he will lift bans on publications in Kurdish. But on economic matters, Mr. Demirel's policies may be influenced by his coalition negotiations with a party whose distrust of market economics is only exceeded by its distrust of the United States. **********The Social Democrats opposed Turkish involvement in the Persian Gulf war and are calling for a halt to the privatization of the public sector, which constitutes about 40 percent of the economy, and the creation of new state enterprises. Austerity May Be Needed **********If he is to rein in the inflation rate, Mr. Demirel must convince the Social Democrats to endorse what could be an unpleasant austerity program, according to Western diplomats. **********There is a budget deficit of $6 billion and a foreign debt of $44 billion. And there is little likelihood that Mr. Demirel will ever begin to deliver on some of his more outlandish campaign promises, including one to give every Turk two keys, one for his car and the other for his house. **********The Social Democrats, moreover, are split by internal power struggles, and fell far short of their aspirations in the last elections. Most acknowledge that the process of economic and political reform, coupled with Turkey's drive to become part of the European Community, has advanced too far to be rolled back. **********"We are part of Europe," Mr. Demirel said, "and we should stay a part of Europe."  Western Diplomats Worried **********Some Western diplomats worry that Mr. Demirel, forced to bend to the Social Democrats, will find himself unable to introduce the economic reforms needed to prod the economy along. **********"The economy needs some major tinkering with and another impulse of privatization," a Western diplomat said. "What we fear is that things will just go on as they are with a few rhetorical statements." **********But for many Turks, for whom this is the third election since the military relinquished power, the democratic transition is in itself a victory, despite all their other worries. **********"Forming a government is a means now, not a goal," Mr. Demirel said. "The goal is what this government will do."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/08/busin.main_headline: Saatchi Reports Progress In Refinancing Bond Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/08/busin.print_headline: Saatchi Reports Progress In Refinancing Bond Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/08/busin.body_text: **********Executives of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company said today that the ailing advertising company was making headway in its efforts to refinance a bond issue that could be converted in 1993. **********"We are making progress," a Saatchi spokesman said. He would give no details. **********But a person familiar with the recapitalization effort who insisted on anonymity said Saatchi executives were optimistic that the refinancing would be completed by the end of March. Shares at 66.7 Cents **********In July 1993, bondholders can demand repayment of the face value of the securities plus a premium, or a total of $:211 million, about $402.1 million, if the company's share price is below $:4.41, or about $8.40. The shares closed today on the London International Stock Exchange at 35 pence, or 66.7 cents. **********But Saatchi faces an earlier deadline: Its $:300 million in credit lines from 19 banks have to be renewed in January 1993. Analysts say it is unlikely that the banks would renew them unless the convertible bonds had already been refinanced. **********The Saatchi spokesman said the banks were not nervous about the refinancing efforts. "The banks are in line and remain so," he said. 'No Immediate Crisis' **********Quintin Price, an analyst at James Capel & Company, the London brokerage, said, "There is no immediate crisis, but clearly the sooner the refinancing is resolved the better." **********Alan J. Gottesman, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc., agreed. "It ain't over until it's over, and I'd like to see this restructured," he said in a telephone interview from New York. "But I don't see this as a crisis." **********Robert Louis-Dreyfus, Saatchi's chief executive, had said that his goal was to refinance the bonds by the end of the year. The company has not given any details about its progress. **********Speculation has arisen that Saatchi has been looking for investors to inject capital into the company. Presumably the money could be used to buy back the bonds, which now have a market value of about $:75 million. Other Options **********Saatchi could also try to persuade its banks, which include Citicorp, Chase Manhattan, Barclays and Midland, to lend more money so the bonds could be purchased. "I would be surprised if the banks came up with more money," Mr. Price said. The company's short-term borrowings, net of cash, total about $:189 million, down from $:277 million in March. **********Saatchi could also try to make a deal with bondholders that eased the burden on the company. Simon Mellor, a Saatchi director, said the company had identified about 75 percent of the bondholders. "But we have not held any talks with them about any restructuring proposal," he added. **********In what appeared to be an attempt to lift investor confidence in Saatchi, Mr. Louis-Dreyfus recently said he planned to invest a significant amount of his own money in the company once its balance-sheet problems were resolved. **********Saatchi's shares closed unchanged today in London.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/10/busin.main_headline: Europeans Propose Cut In Farm Output and Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/10/busin.print_headline: Europeans Propose Cut In Farm Output and Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/10/busin.body_text: **********The executive commission of the European Community today approved a farm proposal that could restart world trade talks that have been stalled since last December. **********The plan, which must still be acted on by the 12 member nations, would revamp the community's agriculture program by slashing production and cutting subsidies to farmers. **********The proposals "represent the most fundamental reshaping" of the common agricultural policy "since its inception 30 years ago," the commission said in a statement. Impasse at Trade Talks **********Lack of an agreement on a farm proposal helped bring an end to the world trade talks last year. The United States and some other farm exporters wanted the community to cut farm supports and eliminate export credits so that farmers in the United States could better compete with their European counterparts. **********But the community proposed less substantial cuts than the United States was looking for, and the four-year, 108-nation effort to lower world trade barriers collapsed. **********The plan announced today is an attempt to sever the link between production and guaranteed prices, which has encouraged farmers to grow more to earn more. This has resulted in millions of tons of surplus crops and soaring budget costs. **********The plan would slash cereal prices by 35 percent, milk prices by 10 percent and beef prices by 15 percent. Farmers would be compensated for the big price cuts, with direct assistance geared more toward small- and medium-sized farmers. **********Farmers who are at least 55 years old would be eligible for a new early retirement program. **********The commission estimated the proposal would cost about $4.2 billion in its first year and less in subsequent years. It would take effect in 1993 and be fully in place by 1996. **********The world trade negotiations are expected to come up at next week's economic summit meeting in London of the leaders of seven industrialized nations. Last month, trade ministers of two dozen nations called for the negotiations to end by December. **********The talks were started in Uruguay in 1986 in an effort to rewrite world trade rules and lower barriers in 15 areas, including textiles, agriculture and manufactured goods and services. The talks are being held under the auspices of the Geneva-based General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a forum for liberalizing world trade.                    --------------------       Split on Patents and Names **********BRUSSELS, July 9 (Reuters) -- Delegates at world trade talks are close to an agreement on an accord to end the piracy of intellectual property, but tough problems still remain. The chief negotiator for the European Community, Hugo Paemen, said today that there were disagreements on whether pharmaceuticals should receive patent protection and whether names for products like wines and foods should be protected against copying.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/01/busin.main_headline: Wall Street; Add Aircraft to the Ailing-Asset List
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/01/busin.print_headline: Wall Street; Add Aircraft to the Ailing-Asset List
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/01/busin.body_text: **********One of the big lessons of the 80's is that trouble travels. Shrinking real estate values in New England can cause bank stocks to fall on Wall Street. Deteriorating junk bonds on Wall Street can send insurance companies into bankruptcy in California. Declining prices at art auctions in New York can leave Tokyo tycoons short of cash. **********With that lesson in mind, two analysts at Fitch Investors Service, a Wall Street credit-rating agency, have spent a good part of the summer tracking the travels of weakening commercial aircraft loans. With unsold and unleased aircraft going begging, Nancy Stroker and Valerie Gerard suspect that many of those idle planes will ultimately be written down -- or written off -- with unhappy consequences for the profitability of the companies that financed them. **********Indeed, they warn, in a draft of a report to be released tomorrow, that airplane loans and leases are about to join third world debt, real estate lending and leveraged takeover loans as "hot spots in the loan portfolios of financial institutions over the next several years." **********Of course, direct investments in commercial aircraft have been going sour for the past 18 months, as the airline industry's health has worsened and several leading carriers have filed for bankruptcy. **********Aircraft limited partnerships, the speculative investment pools set up to purchase airplanes and lease them out to carriers, have cut their dividends and declined sharply in value. Equipment trust certificates, which are publicly traded notes secured by specific airplanes, have also done a nosedive, and hundreds of millions of dollars worth of them have gone into default. **********The culprit has been an old-fashioned glut. There are too many aircraft for sale or lease at a time when air travel is down and ailing carriers are cutting back on their plane-buying plans. The partnerships that planned to pay dividends from lease income are finding their planes are unrented. Noteholders who thought they could recoup their principal by selling their airborne collateral are finding few buyers. **********Seeing all this, Ms. Stroker said, "we began to wonder where the pain is going to be felt next." She added, "So we decided to look at the finance companies that Fitch rates to see what we could find." **********What they found was that the aircraft trouble too had traveled: Commercial finance companies whose loan portfolios include significant levels of debt secured by aircraft are getting caught up in the dizzying collapse in aircraft prices. **********The companies, each of which has issued publicly traded debt or commercial paper that is rated by Fitch, include Chrysler Financial, Concord Leasing, Foothill Capital, General Electric Capital, Greyhound Financial, Household Finance, McDonnell Douglas Finance and Westinghouse Credit. All told, these units have issued about $45.2 billion in public debt; aircraft loans make up about $3.4 billion of their total portfolios. **********The analysts' first stop was at the used aircraft flea market itself, where they checked to see just how bad things are these days. Very bad, it turns out. "Recent market activity has demonstrated an alarming 50 percent increase in the number of commercial aircraft available for sale or re-lease," the Fitch report says. There were 840 planes offered for buyers or renters in June, up from 545 at the end of 1990. **********"Concurrently, there has also been a 50 percent decline in the number of actual completed transactions," the report continues. This suggests that the glut of commercial jet aircraft is likely to remain a fact of life for finance companies for some time to come. **********This trend is having the same effect on the value of finance company assets as the slump in auction prices is having on the estimated net worth of art collectors. Even conservative estimates of probable resale values now look dubious, at least for the short term, the Fitch report warned. **********If aircraft cannot be resold or re-leased, their owners face the same choices as any collector: to let the assets sit idle until the market recovers, to write the assets down to more realistic values or to retire the assets and not wait for a recovery. **********The result of each option, however, is likely to be that the companies Fitch examined will experience near-term increases in their nonperforming assets and in the related carrying costs, the analysts predicted. That, in turn, is likely to put pressure on those companies' profitability. **********The impact will be uneven, she said, depending on the amount of aircraft lending a company has done, and the age and condition of the various aircraft in its portfolio. **********The companies that are expected to feel the most impact going forward, the Fitch report says, are Chrysler Financial, a unit of Chrysler; Concord Leasing, a subsidiary of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation; General Electric Credit, the appliance maker's financial arm; McDonnell Douglas Finance, a unit of the aircraft builder, and Westinghouse Credit, part of Westinghouse Financial Services. Fitch notes that "parent ownership and support" for these subsidiaries could mitigate the damage "in different degrees." **********Except for Concord Leasing, however, these same units are already feeling heat from two other hot spots in the financial community: commercial real estate and loans to heavily indebted companies, called "highly leveraged transaction loans." So the worsening aircraft market simply turns up the voltage a bit, according to Fitch. **********But the aircraft glut is not yet likely to put pressure on those companies' credit ratings, the analysts said. "Ratings are usually projected over a three-year period, and we perceive this glut to be a short-term problem," said Ms. Stroker. "So we don't see a likelihood of any immediate rating changes. But we wanted to warn investors who have a shorter-term horizon that they may be incurring some short-term profitability risks."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.main_headline: The Kremlin Revives an Old Refrain
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.print_headline: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: HISTORY; The Kremlin Revives an Old Refrain
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.body_text: **********The official Soviet explanation for the military intervention in Lithuania, belying President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's recent policies of glasnost, strongly resembles official explanations by his predecessors of the invasions of Hungary in 1956, Czechoslovakia in 1968, and Afghanistan in 1979. **********Mr. Gorbachev may have disavowed Stalinism and neo-Stalinism, but he has clearly not cured Soviet decision-making of its trademark reflex: to clothe the naked assertion of state power with Communist ideology, however transparent. **********So in the official explanations of what happened in Vilnius early Sunday morning, the Soviet Union did not say it had decided to use force to hold the country together against the separatist wishes of the Lithuanian parliament, even though it had been freely elected. It answered a call for help from a National Salvation Committee that nobody had heard of until last Friday. **********Consisting, apparently, mainly of Lithuanian and ethnic Russian Communists loyal to Moscow, the committee asserts, in the way the Communist governments in Eastern Europe used to claim, that it represents the true interests of the ordinary people better than an elected Parliament can. A Sense of Betrayal **********The sense of betrayal and disappointment, the heartsickness, that many people in this country feel at hearing such explanations by high-ranking officials over Soviet television Sunday night comes from their hope that Mr. Gorbachev had put that sort of manipulation of the truth behind them. **********What is different today is that, so far at least, the Soviet Army has not clapped the Lithuanian legislators in jail, arrested President Vytautas Landsbergis, or cut off international telephone and telecommunications links. They are, for the moment, still free to denounce Mr. Gorbachev and the Soviet Army's actions, and international news organizations are still able to report what they see in Vilnius to the world. **********But the pattern, the reflex, is a familiar one. It got the Soviet Union into a bloody 10-year war in Afghanistan that Mr. Gorbachev now realizes is a mistake. On Dec. 27, 1979, Soviet troops helped install Babrak Karmal as the Afghan ruler, replacing President Hafizullah Amin in a coup. **********Probably after the fact, the Soviet Union said that it had acted in response to a request by the Afghan Government for help. President Amin, who had been installed only three months earlier, was denounced as a pro-American agent. Detente on the Rocks **********Later, Soviet officials with access to high-level thinking conceded that this was simply propaganda. The Kremlin acted, they said, because it looked at that point as though detente with the West was in for a rocky period anyway and it had little to lose by protecting its interests on its southern border. **********Mr. Karmal also did not last long. The damage to Soviet relations with the West did -- until well after Mr. Gorbachev came with his new policies and his seeming renunciation of Stalinist methods. Now his use of very similar methods, in a Baltic republic the annexation of which by Stalin in 1940 has never been formally accepted by the West, could cause similar lasting damage. Whether Mr. Gorbachev has resigned himself to this is not clear. **********He acquiesced to the loss of Czechoslovakia and other Eastern European countries from the Soviet bloc in 1989. But his Government's explanation of how it acted in Lithuania is much like the explanation made by the Government of Leonid I. Brezhnev as to why it sent troops and tanks into Prague in the summer of 1968 to put an end to the Communist reform leadership under Alexander Dubcek. **********Moscow said its troops moved into Czechoslovakia at the request of "party and Government leaders of the Czechoslovak Socialist Republic," after Pravda, the official Soviet Communist Party newspaper, warned that the Czechoslovak leadership was "losing control" of the situation -- just what Soviet authorities now are saying about President Landsbergis in Lithuania. Fate of Dissidents **********Mr. Dubcek and his colleagues were flown off to Moscow, interrogated and sternly warned, and returned to Prague for a short while before being replaced by more orthodox and obedient Communist functionaries and disgraced. **********Mr. Dubcek, unlike the Hungarian leader Imre Nagy, lived long enough to make a comeback when his country returned to democracy in 1989. Mr. Nagy, who tried to take his country out of the now defunct Warsaw Pact in 1956, was swept out of power by Soviet tanks that November. The Soviets installed a new "revolutionary worker-peasant government" led by Janos Kadar, acting, of course, at its request. Mr. Nagy was subsequently taken to Romania and executed. **********No one now seriously believes that Mr. Gorbachev would countenance a return to such crude methods. But many who hoped for greater democracy here now despair that he has merely refined them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/busin.main_headline: L.A. Gear Shoe Spurs Nike Suit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/busin.print_headline: L.A. Gear Shoe Spurs Nike Suit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/busin.body_text: **********Nike Inc. filed a lawsuit today against L.A. Gear Inc., charging its rival with incorporating a Nike-patented design in its new Catapult basketball shoe. **********The suit, filed in Federal District Court here, says some elements of L.A. Gear's Catapult cushioning system infringes two Nike patents. The patents, covering what Nike calls a "spring moderator device," are not now used in the company's shoes. Instead, Nike has an air-cushioning system that uses pressurized gas. **********Like Nike's spring moderator, L.A. Gear's Catapult shoe has a cushioning system designed to improve the jumping performance of wearers. **********While Nike, based in Beaverton, Ore., does not use its system on any shoe, Lindsay Stewart, Nike's general counsel, said it was important for the company to protect its designs. "We spend a lot of money on research and development and we don't want to see it abused." **********An L.A. Gear spokesman did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/06/busin.body_text: **********A small chemical company has patented a method for producing a new low-calorie sugar substitute that executives say comes closer to the real thing than alternative sweeteners. **********The search for new sugar substitutes has accelerated sharply in recent years. Aspartame, sold primarily by the Nutrasweet subsidiary of the Monsanto Company, constitutes a $1 billion market. But a number of companies, including Nutrasweet, are working on newer compounds that are thousands of times sweeter than both natural sugar and aspartame and could be cheaper to produce. **********The new product, however, developed by Biospherics Inc. of Beltsville, Md., and called d-tagatose, is a variant on ordinary household sugar and has almost the same degree of sweetness. Company officials said tagatose's advantage is that it provides the same physical bulk as natural sugar, which is an important feature in baking. Sugar substitutes made from high-intensity sweeteners would have to be combined with new bulking agents that might not produce the same texture as foods baked with sugar. **********Like glucose, the sugar in sugar cane, tagatose is a carbohydrate built around six carbon atoms. But its molecular shape differs, causing tagatose to be digested very differently. Tagatose occurs naturally in small quantities, but it has been difficult to purify or to produce in commercial volumes. **********In the new process, tagatose is transformed from a related sugar molecule, called d-galactose, which is found in dairy whey and lactose. Biosphere officials said the process should be cheap enough to compete with high-intensity sweeteners that need bulking agents. **********James R. Beadle, James P. Saunders and Thomas J. Wajda Jr., researchers at Biospherics, received patent 5,002,612.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/busin.main_headline: Channels Court Audiences By Increasing Promotions
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Channels Court Audiences By Increasing Promotions
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/busin.body_text: **********With the growth of cable television slowing and new programming competitors emerging, the established cable networks are redoubling their efforts to locate an ever-scarcer resource: viewers. **********Executives at the basic cable networks that specialize in music videos, comedy shows, old movies, network reruns and women's programs say that the days of simply persuading cable system operators to carry their services are over. **********Rather than asking viewers to call cable system operators and cry, "I want my MTV," cable programmers have been shifting their emphasis to luring viewers, who in turn attract advertisers.  Increased Advertising **********As a result, cable networks are increasing their advertising on broadcast television and radio. The networks are also changing their advertising, focusing less on specific programs and more on image. And they are creating increasingly complex marketing programs to appeal simultaneously to cable operators, advertisers and niche audiences. **********In the early days of a cable network, "the home audience means little next to the cable operators," said Scott M. Sassa, president of Turner Entertainment Networks, which include the TNT and WTBS channels. "As a network matures, distribution becomes a lower priority compared to advertising, and consumers become more important because you need ratings for advertisers." **********Much of the cable networks' efforts are intended to build strong brand images that transcend the reputations of individual programs, in the same way that radio stations and magazines use image campaigns to separate themselves from rivals. **********The purpose, said Whitney Goit 2d, the executive vice president for sales and marketing at the Arts & Entertainment Network, is "to get on the short list of our target viewers, so they'll say, 'I have some time to watch TV, so I think I'll watch    my    network.' " New Lifetime Series **********Lifetime, a cable network aimed at women, first used broadcast television commercials to advertise its made-for-television movies about six months ago, said Douglas W. McCormick, its executive vice president. **********The experiment was successful enough that Lifetime has begun to use broadcast television to promote several original weekly series that make their debut tomorrow night. **********Similarly, A.& E. is increasing its radio advertising. "It's more immediate, it's jazzier, it's quick turnaround and it's highly targeted," Mr. Goit said. **********A.& E., which specializes in documentaries, comedy shows and programs on the performing arts, is also positioning itself as an expert in marketing to light television viewers, who as a group are more educated and affluent than heavy viewers. The network has put together research studies and promotional materials to help cable operators sell subscriptions to these people. More MTV Promotions **********MTV, the music-video channel, has increased its local promotions fivefold over the last five years, said Harriet L. Seitler, senior vice president for marketing and promotion. **********In the past, those promotions almost always involved sweepstakes coordinated with cable operators. Today, the events -- held on college campuses, at video stores and record stores -- usually include a live taping of a show like "Yo! MTV Raps," a dance or rap contest and tie-ins with advertisers, a local radio station and a system operator.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/21/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Another Offer For Child World
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/21/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Another Offer For Child World
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/21/busin.body_text: **********For the second time in less than a year, Child World Inc., the troubled toy retailer that was battered by a disastrous Christmas season, has agreed to be acquired in a transaction that appears to provide a better deal for public shareholders than for the CNC Holding Corporation, the company that controls Child World. **********The tentative agreement yesterday stunned owners of Child World stock, who had bid the shares up on reports of takeover negotiations. Child World's shares fell $1, to $1.625. Under the terms of the deal, public holders will receive $2 a share if it is completed. **********As low as that is, it appears to be better than the amount that will be paid to CNC Holding, formerly the Cole National Corporation, for its 82 percent stake in Child World. The shares owned by CNC are to be acquired first, in a non-cash transaction. **********Jeffrey A. Cole, the chairman of CNC, said that as a result of the deal, some CNC debt held by the First Executive Corporation, the Los Angeles insurance holding company, would be canceled. Asked what that was worth to CNC, he replied, "In my view, it is worth less than $2 per share, a lot less." But Mr. Cole said CNC, which owns 2,000 small retail stores in the gift and optical businesses, would benefit from severing its links to Child World, which have included some cross-guarantees of debt. **********The prospective buyer of Child World is a newly formed company headed by two former officials of Toys "R" Us, the No. 1 toy retailer, and financed by institutional investors whose identities were not disclosed. **********W. John Devine, one of those executives, said negotiations were under way with Child World's banks, which are owed $135 million, and its toy suppliers, which are owed $190 million. He said the company would offer a combination of cash and notes, and perhaps some stock. "They will come out whole, ultimately," he said of the creditors. **********For Child World's public shareholders, the newest deal is a huge step down from the previous one, which was announced last July and collapsed in November. That deal called for a partnership led by Roy Disney's Shamrock Holdings to buy the public shares at $14 each. **********In that deal, CNC was also to get no cash, instead receiving bonds that First Executive had agreed to accept to cancel some of CNC's debts. Mr. Cole said First Executive would cancel less debt under the new agreement than in the first deal. First Executive officials did not return telephone calls. **********Mr. Cole took Cole National private in a 1987 leveraged buyout, leaving it saddled with large debts, including some on which cash interest must begin to be paid next month. Asked about that payment, Mr. Cole responded that "the probability of our making it is low," but said that he believed a bankruptcy filing could be avoided while the company sought to restructure its debt. **********To function, a toy retailer needs credit. "The banks and the trade are very positive about the new prospective buyers, and seem to be willing to finance them going forward," Mr. Cole said, "whereas there has not been a lot of willingness to finance Child World with the existing CNC ownership. We kind of wore out our welcome." Child World suspended payments to toy suppliers in early December. It is now paying its smaller bills, but not its larger ones. **********Yesterday's announcement said that the WC Acquisition Corporation had signed a letter of intent to buy CNC's stake, and that "as promptly as practicable" after that stake is bought, public shareholders would be offered $2 a share. Mr. Devine said he hoped that would occur within two months. **********There are only two million shares in public hands, so the total cash outlay for the shares will be only $24 million to control a company with annual sales of more than $800 million. **********Besides Mr. Devine, the other principal in WC Acquisition is Ronald E. Tuchman, 55 years old, who left Toys "R" Us in 1989 to join an unsuccesful effort to acquire the Lionel Corporation, which operates Kiddie City, the No. 3 toy retailer. He is now an executive of Toy and Sports Warehouse, a chain of five stores that he said might be merged into Child World. **********Mr. Devine, who retired from Toys "R" Us is 1983 at the age of 43, said he was re-entering the toy business at the age of 50 in part because his real estate investments had not worked out as well as he had hoped. **********But he added, "I am now caught up in the challenge" of turning Child World around. "There is so much that can be done here," he said. "If the company even begins to approach the profitability of Toys 'R' Us, there are great opportunities." **********It was those opportunities that led public shareholders to buy Child World shares, paying nearly $20 a share as recently as 1989. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY EARNINGS; Four Investment Firms Report Big Increases in Income
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/busin.body_text: **********The good financial news continued to flow from Wall Street yesterday, as the Morgan Stanley Group Inc., Salomon Inc., Alex. Brown Inc. and Piper Jaffray Inc. all reported sharply higher earnings. **********Like many other Wall Street firms that are reporting successful quarters, the four took advantage of stock and bond market rallies in the first quarter to earn significant trading profits. But, for the most part, investment banking fees, in mergers and corporate finance, remained weak. **********"The industry is definitely not covering all the bases yet," said John Keefe, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Services. But he said that the soft spots "were completely overshadowed by the strong trading results. **********Following are the results of the four financial concerns:  Morgan Stanley **********Morgan Stanley yesterday reported earnings of $120.1 million, or $3.07 a share, in the quarter just ended, compared with $82.1 million, or $2.07 a share, in the first quarter of last year. **********Revenues for the quarter also grew. Revenues for the period were $1.6 billion, up from the $1.4 billion it reported in the first quarter of 1990. **********Richard B. Fisher, Morgan's chairman, said in a statement that the results stemmed in part from strong trading revenues in almost every business. "Revenues during the period benefited from the continued strong performance in our global sales and trading activities, particularly in fixed income, equities, foreign exchange and commodities," Mr. Fisher said. **********The company's investment banking revenues totaled $187 million for the quarter, up from $162.2 million in the first quarter of 1990. Morgan attributed the growth in investment banking to increased underwriting volumes in both the debt and equity markets, which it said offset a decline in the financial advisory business. **********Morgan closed at $87.375 yesterday, up 87.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.  Salomon Inc. **********Salomon yesterday reported record earnings of $273 million, or $2.30 a share, in the quarter just ended, compared with earnings of $119 million, or 88 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1990. Revenues for the quarter were $2.69 billion, up from the $2.35 billion in the first quarter of 1990. **********Salomon Brothers, the company's brokerage subsidiary, reported sharply higher earnings before taxes. The firm earned a record $503 million before taxes, more than double the $227 million earned before taxes in the first quarter of last year. **********Revenues less interest expenses, increased to $1.1 billion in the first quarter, up 70 percent from the $669 million in the first quarter of last year. **********Salomon said that the strong performance of its brokerage subsidiary "was primarily attributable to excellent trading results across virtually all products and geographic areas." **********Trading revenue increased to $968 million, up from $658 million in last year's first quarter. Commissions also rose, up 20 percent, to $60 million, compared with $50 million last year. Investment banking revenues also increased moderately, to $99 million from $84 million. **********The improvement at the full company was achieved without much of a contribution from Phibro Energy Inc., Salomon's oil refining and trading operation. Phibro, which has long been a source of financial stability for Salomon, reported pretax earnings of $5 million in the quarter, down from $7 million a year ago. **********Salomon's shares rose $1.50 yesterday, to $32.75, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.  Alex. Brown Inc. **********Alex. Brown, based in Baltimore, yesterday reported record earnings of $10.6 million, or 71 cents a share, up from $2.5 million, or 16 cents a share, in the first quarter of last year. The firm also reported record revenues for the quarter of $93.6 million, up 37 percent from the $68.5 million in revenues in the comparable period in 1990. **********Revenues increased across the board. But the firm was unusual in reporting strong growth in investment banking revenues, which rose to $28.7 million in the first quarter, up 41 percent from the $20.3 million reported in the first quarter of 1990. **********"The firm that has the most to be proud of is Alex. Brown," said Mr. Keefe of Lipper. "They had the biggest pickup in investment banking revenue." Much of that pickup was related to the firm's strong performance in underwriting equity offerings, particularly in the new issue market. **********The firm also reported a strong increase in its retail and institutional businesses, leading to a 36 percent rise in commission revenue compared with the first quarter of last year. Trading revenues also increased, more than doubling the revenues from the comparable period last year. **********Alex. Brown fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $18.125, in over-the-counter trading.  Piper Jaffray Inc. **********Piper Jaffray, the Minneapolis-based regional brokerage, reported quarterly net income of $4.65 million, or $1.13 a share, more than double the $2.11 million, or 52 cents a share, of a year earlier. Piper Jaffray revenue was $63.3 million, up 28 percent from $49.5 million a year ago. **********Piper Jaffray rose 50 cents, to $22, in over-the-counter trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/09/busin.body_text: **********The Will-Burt Company, a parts maker in Orrville, Ohio, senses the beginnings of an economic recovery. Various customers -- a nearby Volvo truck factory, for example, and AMF Bowling Inc. -- are purchasing a few more fenders, doors, bumpers and finely machined parts. As the pace picks up, Harry E. Featherstone, Will-Burt's chief executive, finds himself with a week's supply of steel. But he wishes the stockpile were smaller. "I'd like to order steel daily," he said. **********Such thinking helps to explain why the heralded recovery from the recession is having trouble getting off the ground. Much depends on whether Mr. Featherstone and thousands of other American executives conclude, more or less simultaneously, that sales are again brisk enough and sustained enough to warrant restocking. When they do, economists say, the jump in production needed to satisfy the surge in new orders will give the economy a kick out of recession.  Not This Month **********"There will come a moment when people will decide that they don't have enough in their warehouses," said Robert Barbera, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Hutton. "But that moment has not arrived yet." **********Almost certainly it will not arrive before Labor Day, interviews with executives, industry experts and economists indicate. Across many industries, sales are indeed rising, but many of those interviewed said they lacked confidence that any improvement would endure. What is more, even if they become confident, summer is the worst of times to fire up a recovery through inventory rebuilding. **********Retailers, for example, normally postpone major apparel orders until late August while they test the appetite for the new fall styles with pre-season sales. Most major chain stores reported yesterday that July sales of summer goods were listless.  [ Page D2. ] **********Similarly, auto sales have clearly outstripped production in recent weeks, but in July and August manufacturers phase out one year's models and begin to make the new lines. While they do so, production is held below par. Then, before setting new production schedules, auto makers must gauge the demand for 1992 models, said Joel Pitcoff, an analyst at the Ford Motor Company.  Just-in-Time Strategy **********Finally, the American economy faces an obstacle in this incipient recovery that did not hinder stockpiling after previous recessions. A surge in orders would undoubtedly prompt Mr. Featherstone's company to stockpile some steel. Nevertheless, he and many others are becoming increasingly adept at the new strategy of just-in-time delivery: moving products quickly from the factory to the customer, with the shortest possible stay in a warehouse. **********Mr. Featherstone, for example, notes that Caterpillar Inc., a big customer, has eliminated a 500,000-square-foot warehouse in Aurora, Ill. "They want us to hold their inventories and make shipments to them weekly and even daily," he said. "But we are also going in the direction of not holding costly inventories." **********Because of the recession, thousands of American companies took to selling from their existing stockpiles, rather than ordering new merchandise they might not have been able to sell. They have lived largely off their stockpiles for nearly nine months now, although the liquidation rate has fallen lately, the Commerce Department reports. Selling from inventory rather than making new merchandise contributed to the recession.  Companies Still Liquidating **********Now, with sales somewhat improved, production is beginning to rise as companies cautiously reorder. The big question, though, is whether the new production will increase to the point that the selling from stockpiles finally ceases in this third quarter. If so, that would be enough to end the recession, economists say. **********"You don't need a vigorous restocking to drive the recovery," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "All you have to do is stop liquidating." **********But many of the executives and industry experts interviewed did not think the inventory liquidation would end before the fourth quarter. And recent surveys conducted by the National Federation of Independent Business, representing small companies, and the National Association of Purchasing Management, representing mostly major corporations, suggest a similar conclusion. In both surveys, substantial percentages of companies said they were still liquidating their inventories.  Gillette Cutting Inventory **********At the Gillette Company, liquidation is likely to remain the order of the day until October, said Milton L. Glass, the company's vice president for finance. Nevertheless, since June, Gillette has been selling more razors and razor blades to retailers. The retailers' inventories had fallen too low to meet the demand from consumers, and for two months retailers have been restocking, Mr. Glass said. But Gillette itself is not. Quite the contrary, it is selling to retailers from its own factory inventories, without increasing production. **********"Our inventories had built up in April and May, and in June they were on the high side," Mr. Glass said. "Now, we are switching them to the retailers." **********Like many of their compatriots, Gillette executives remain skeptical about how long the stronger orders from retailers will last. "You are going to have to wait until October before you can say whether there is a genuine consumer-led recovery or this increase in retail orders is just a flash in the pan," Mr. Glass said. Commerce Department Data **********Some economists optimistically pin their hopes of a production surge on Commerce Department data that show inventories nationwide to be at an unusually low level -- 3.01 months of stocks on hand if production stopped dead today and sales continued at their current pace. That is a decline from 3.06 months last year, on the eve of the recession. **********But while inventories nationwide might be very low, the Commerce Department figures can obscure some important variations. While some major industries are still selling from stock, others are not. Sales of household appliances, for example, have risen sharply and, with inventories lean, production has shot up. Such production increases, in turn, prompt companies to rehire workers or pay more in overtime, and those new wages help pump up the economy. **********The steel industry, however, built up stockpiles early this year, partly in anticipation of a strike at the USX Corporation that did not materialize. Sales then fell, leaving manufacturers and distributors with too much on hand, which has suppressed production, said Walter Carter, a steel industry specialist at DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic consulting firm. **********"We are still in the relatively early stages of reducing the stockpile," he said, adding that the rest of 1991 might be spent in trimming away two million tons of stored steel products. Some Industries Holding Back **********Some industries with lean inventories nevertheless prefer to hold back production until short supplies drive up prices. That is the case among makers of linerboard, the heavy cardboard-like material used to make shipping cartons. Linerboard stockpiles are down to less than six weeks' supply, said Timothy McKenna, a spokesman for the Union Camp Corporation, a major maker of linerboard. But the priority is to get the price toward where it was last January: $370 a ton, compared with $320 today. **********Other, less tangible factors are also discouraging the inventory rebuilding that played a major role in recoveries from past recessions. One is low inflation. Companies stockpiled in the past to avoid paying much higher prices for raw materials, parts and finished goods a few months later. Inflation today, however, is running at a low annual rate, under 3 percent, as measured by the Consumer Price Index. **********"No one is tempted to buy in anticipation of price increases," said Albert T. Sommers, a senior economist at the Conference Board, a business research organization. "This failure to restock in turn helps to keep prices down." **********Imports are also a much greater source of inventories than a decade ago -- a trend that pushes up production abroad but not at home. **********"With production now globalized, companies can 'outsource' overseas as well as domestically," Richard B. Berner, a senior economist at Salomon Brothers, wrote in a recent article. "As a result, imports now substitute for domestic inventories." **********Finally, the credit crunch inhibits stockpiling. Keeping 10,000 pairs of shoes on hand means a retailer must borrow money to buy the shoes and store them until they can be sold to consumers, and then repay the loan. Bankers themselves say they are more cautious than they were in the 1980's about providing such financing. That caution has meant, for example, that the shoe manufacturer and the economy are often deprived of the wealth that comes from producing the extra shoes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/01/busin.main_headline: 'Re-Parent' the Young Workers? Not on Your Life
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/01/busin.print_headline: 'Re-Parent' the Young Workers? Not on Your Life
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/01/busin.body_text: **********In an article on the Forum page on Nov. 17, Morris R. Shechtman wrote that many workers in their 20's and 30's are still adolescents emotionally and are less productive than the workers of other generations. **********He said managers should be prepared to deal with their young workers in the same way they treat their teen-age sons and daughters at home. By using a strategy of "re-parenting," he said, companies may be able to increase self-absorbed workers' productivity to acceptable levels within two or three years instead of the six or seven years that might be required otherwise. **********Here are some of the letters received in response to Mr. Shechtman's advice. **********Dated Practices **********To the Editor: **********Mr. Shechtman's premise that a significant number of working people in their 20's and 30's are "adolescents emotionally" and should be "re-parented" is exactly the kind of thinking that has helped to create the relatively dismal competitive posture of many United States businesses today. **********The advice Mr. Shechtman dispenses -- do not tax employees' attention spans, do not give out more than one task at a time and do not accept any exceptions to the rules -- reeks of dated management practices that have proved highly ineffective for today's fiercely competitive business environment. Following are examples: *********** The principles espoused by the scientific-management pioneer Frederick Taylor, who recommended keeping tasks very simple and straightforward and giving simple directions so there was no room for human error. Workers' reaction to this management philosophy led to the rise and spread of the American labor union movement. *********** The paternalistic, we-know-what's-best-for-the-kids style of management. The response by employees and children to this style is "Well, if Mom and Dad know what's best for us, then we will wait for them to tell us what to do." This treatment by management yields a dependent, lethargic, stagnant work force. *********** The "command and control" theory of management, which says the managers are the experts and will make the rules and create the directives for everyone else. This philosophy creates status barriers, low commitment and a lack of motivation to perform. **********In my 13 years as a management consultant, I have encountered many emotionally immature employees in their 20's and 30's. But I have also worked with just as many, if not more, employees in their 40's, 50's and 60's who are emotionally crippled because of their insatiable need for power, control, status and stability. Stereotyping segments of the work force puts people in boxes, which are very difficult to get out of. **********Given the strenuous demands, conflicting priorities and scarcity of resources that managers have to deal with today, re-parenting is not a legitimate job responsibility. Managers who are expected to watch the bottom line, delight the customer, facilitate technological breakthroughs and serve as quality gurus do not have the time or patience to develop the emotional acumen of the work force. **********Building a competitive, flexible, talented work force can be accomplished only by treating all employees, regardless of age, like adults. In an adult work world, business must do the following things: *********** Insure the right fit between employee and job content. If an employee does not have the skill and ability to perform the job, train him or her. If the employee is not trainable, someone made a mistake in hiring. *********** Set realistically high performance expectations for everyone and ratchet up those expectations as performance improves. *********** Allow all employees freedom to make decisions about the shape, content and context of their work. *********** Encourage employees to "grow the job." As market needs shift and change, so should employees and their job. **********If employees of any age are treated like children, they will respond and perform like children. If employees are treated as mature rational adults, they will respond and perform like mature rational adults. DIANE RIGGAN  Norwalk, Conn., Nov. 19    The author is president of Riggan & Associates, a management-consulting firm.   Insulting and Demeaning **********To the Editor: **********Mr. Shechtman suggests that to increase productivity among young workers, managers should use "strategies not unlike those that you use at home with your teen-agers." Such a recommendation is insulting and demeaning to young workers and will only worsen a productivity problem that many managers unknowingly cause in the first place. **********Today's young workers are collectively more educated than the young employees of previous generations, and they consequently have more confidence in their abilities and greater career expectations. **********Unfortunately, many managers waste this young talent and ambition by providing recent college graduates with unchallenging and unstimulating tasks that require doing, but not thinking. This produces boredom and dissatisfaction, which cause the productivity and motivation problems that Mr. Shechtman erroneously attributes to "adolescent traits like self-absorption, lack of commitment and short attention spans." **********If you want to improve the productivity of your young employees, treat them as you would your more senior personnel. Establish challenging, yet attainable goals. Provide young workers with responsibility and the commensurate authority required to meet objectives. And create a supportive atmosphere that encourages learning and initiative. **********Indeed, young workers will rise above their expected performance levels if their work is interesting and the career prospects are encouraging. That is the key to productivity; re-parenting is not. LAURENCE PLAWSKY  Plainview, L.I., Nov. 20  Lowering Expectations **********To the Editor: **********As a recent college graduate who has held several temporary jobs in the past six months, I realize I am expected to be mature and responsible on the job, no matter what it is. **********Companies do not lower their expectations or make allowances because of my "prolonged adolescence." Instead, I am given projects, brief instructions and advice as to their completion and then turned loose. Often the feedback is minimal or nonexistent, as completing the projects is fulfilling my obligation as an employee. **********Admittedly, my living away from home with partial parental support has forced me to grow up quickly and lose the "work as play" attitude pervasive among many people my age. Pavement pounding and interviewing taught me that employers want employees who are willing to work, learn and carry out assigned tasks with little or no feedback, not employees who need or want baby-sitting. **********I believe Mr. Shechtman's suggestions on how to "raise" young workers will only encourage and prolong adolescent behavior and attitudes among young staff. By lowering their expectations of young workers, companies are effectively lowering the expectations they have for themselves. **********If a project requires three people three days to complete, it should take no longer. Employers should not break up meetings and projects for the benefit of their young staff but should instead expect their young employees to adapt to their management styles, not vice versa. **********The strategies Mr. Shechtman suggests will cause rifts within the office, as older employees may resent supervising and babying young employees who require constant feedback. Older employees who have been with a company for more than 10 years often do not wish to slow productivity so they can explain tasks and provide feedback. **********Young employees should realize that much of what is done in offices is thankless and goes unrecognized unless done badly or incorrectly. If feedback or advice is needed, the employee should be encouraged to seek answers either through his or her own research or by asking a senior employee. **********I do not expect to be "re-parented" in my job. Instead, I expect to be treated as a young adult who wishes to grow in a company and will fulfill expected duties. GILLIAN E. COX  Boston, Nov. 17  Behavioral Triage **********To the Editor: **********Mr. Shechtman addresses one of the most important aspects of our steady economic decline: the prolonging of adolescence and its damaging consequences in work and business. **********But the strategies given for dealing with this problem are pathetic. In effect, Mr. Shechtman suggests that corporations must act as a sort of day-care center, patiently coaxing productivity out of people who despite their advanced education and degrees are little more than spoiled children. **********This is not a cure and it does not address the cultural source of this problem: the "entertainmentization" of America. What good does it do to perform behavioral triage on workers of all levels when television and movies continue to promote irresponsible adolescence as an ideal state of existence? **********As Neil Postman pointed out in "Amusing Ourselves to Death," the power of entertainment has infected many aspects of American life. Its most damaging aspect is on the American character: our addiction to image over substance, our susceptibility to slogans over reasoning, our simple-minded pursuit and adulation of shallow "heroes." **********Until those who wield the economic power in America come to realize that they have a greater responsibility for the larger society than for improving the performance of their companies' stocks, they will find their resources incapable of stemming the tide of immature workers, ethically blind workers, unproductive workers, illiterate workers, substance-dependent workers -- and all of those whose characters are currently being crafted by the massive power of the amusement media and who are the potential workers of the next century. MICHAEL CANUEL  Brooklyn, Nov. 17

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/28/world.body_text: **********Congress moved a step closer today toward a confrontation with President Bush over preferential trading status for China, as the Finance Committee sent to the Senate floor a bill imposing conditions that the President has already rejected as unacceptable. **********But the committee did not officially recommend the bill because a crucial Democratic Senator, Max S. Baucus of Montana, joined Republicans in supporting the President's position that conditions are unnecessary. **********The Senator heads a bipartisan group of 15 senators who would be willing to support the President on an unconditional renewal of continued low tariffs for China in return for other trade and financial sanctions. He told the committee that he could not support the bill until he received a response to a letter he sent to President Bush on June 20. 1989 Crackdown at Issue **********China's most-favored-nation trade status has aroused controversy in Congress because of the military crackdown on the democracy movement there in 1989. China's trade surplus with the United States is also growing, and China refuses to increase its controls over the export of nuclear technologies and ballistic missiles. **********The Finance Committee's actions came hours after Zhu Qizhen, China's Ambassador to the United States, struck a new and more conciliatory position in his remarks on China's most-favored-nation trade status. Adopting an argument used recently by Administration officials appearing before Congressional committees, the Ambassador said Chinese coastal regions now favoring reform would be the first to suffer if trade relations deteriorate. **********"The withdrawal of M.F.N. would inflict a serious blow to China's reform and opening up," he said. **********Lawmakers and Congressional aides disagreed on whether the floor vote in the Senate would be affected by the Finance Committee's decision not to endorse the bill. The Committee is made up predominantly of free-trade advocates, and its action today was widely expected on Capitol Hill. **********Senator Baucus said the most likely scenario remains a confrontation between the Democratic-controlled Congress and the President. **********"I believe that some version of this legislation is almost certain to pass Congress -- perhaps with enough votes to override a veto," he said. **********But a Republican Congressional aide who insisted on anonymity said a bill without the endorsement of the committee of jurisdiction was "damaged goods." **********Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine and the majority leader, sponsored the bill, which won the active support of Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas and the chairman of the Finance Committee. **********Senator Mitchell responded with an unusually direct criticism of a fellow committee member from the same party. Senator Baucus's concerns about possible Chinese retaliation against United States exports were misplaced, the majority leader said, because these exports were small and shrinking quickly, while Chinese exports to the United States were growing. **********If this trend continues, Senator Mitchell said, "I assure the Senator that in a few years there'll be nothing to retaliate against."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/30/busin.main_headline: Make the Free-Trade Vision a Reality
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/30/busin.print_headline: FORUM; Make the Free-Trade Vision a Reality
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/30/busin.body_text: **********With the end of the Cold War, trade has displaced security as the centerpiece of relations between the United States and Latin America.. Yet there is not one organization with the mandate and expertise to exercise leadership on inter-American trade issues. This is a vacuum that now should be filled by the governments of the Americas. **********President Bush set off a flurry of activity a year ago, when he put forth the vision of a Western Hemisphere free-trade area. Country after country in Latin America declared interest in free trade with the United States -- and six have signed bilateral or multilateral "framework agreements" with Washington providing for regular discussion on key issues. The proposal has also reinvigorated existing trade pacts throughout Latin America; prompted Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay to work toward a common market, and spurred other nations to begin free-trade talks. All this activity surely will accelerate now that fast-track authority for United States trade negotiations has been renewed. **********This, then, is the time for the United States and other governments to create, with the private sector, an Americas Commission for Trade and Trade-Related Matters. It would help promote unrestricted hemispheric commerce, serving as: *********** A clearinghouse, to collect, systematize and disseminate trade statistics and information on national trade policies; *********** A think tank, to analyze trade and trade-related issues; *********** A trade monitor, to review and evaluate proposed trade arrangements among nations, and *********** A source of technical assistance, to provide expertise to countries formulating trade policies and negotiating trade agreements. **********Over time, the commission could be entrusted with the more sensitive tasks of defining rules to guide hemispheric trade negotiations, mediating them, investigating alleged violations of trade accords and settling disputes. It could be set up within an established institution like the Inter-American Development Bank or as a free-standing agency. **********Trade is now reshaping hemispheric relations. Expanding commerce could help create a Western Hemisphere economic community along European lines. But burgeoning trade could, just as easily, produce new conflicts in the Americas, as it has in relations between Washington and Tokyo. An effective hemispheric trade organization could help prevent this by injecting order and purpose into the current mosaic of trade negotiations. With some imagination and a small investment by hemispheric governments -- no more than $10 million a year -- the Americas Commission for Trade could be up and running in short order.
