https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/09/busin.body_text: **********The Limited Inc., the specialty retailing company, said yesterday that it had appointed new presidents at its Limited Stores and Victoria's Secret Stores divisions. **********At Limited Stores, with 781 outlets, Howard Gross becomes president, succeeding Verna Gibson, who announced on Monday her decision to leave the business. **********Mr. Gross, who is 47 years old, was president of Victoria's Secret, which operates 438 lingerie shops and 97 bath shops. He is succeeded at Victoria's Secret by Grace Nichols, who is 44, and who was executive vice president and general merchandise manager of the Limited's lingerie division. **********The company declined to comment on Ms. Gibson's departure. While executives told retailing analysts that Ms. Gibson, who is 48, left for personal reasons, analysts said that comparable-store sales had been falling at the Limited chain throughout last year. One reason cited was that some consumers rejected a new line of clothes with a European flair. **********"You probably aren't going to see a major change or improvement until the spring line starts hitting the stores," said Joseph C. Ronning, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company in New York. **********Mr. Ronning said that Mr. Gross had done an excellent job of expanding Victoria's Secret. "He can bring the same management expertise to the Limited division," he said. **********Both Mr. Gross and Ms. Nichols were traveling and were unavailable for comment, a spokesman said. **********Analysts characterized the Limited Inc.'s Christmas season as strong, particularly compared with the weak overall retailing environment. Sales for the four-week Christmas holiday period ended Dec. 29 increased 19 percent from the 1989 season. The company's comparable-store sales for the four-week period increased 4 percent. **********Mr. Gross joined the Limited in 1973 as a trainee and moved on to become a store manager, buyer, merchandise manager and vice president of merchandising in 1982. He became president of Victoria's Secret in 1985. **********Ms. Nichols joined Victoria's Secret as vice president and general merchandise manager in June 1986 after serving for eight years as general merchandise manager for the Broadway department store chain in Southern California and seven years with the Weinstock's chain in Sacramento. **********Mr. Gross, who has an undergraduate degree from the University of Akron, lives with his wife, Marcy, and two children, in Bexley, Ohio. **********Ms. Nichols, who has an undergraduate political science degree and master's degree in history from the University of California at Los Angeles, lives with her husband, John, and two children in Columbus, Ohio.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/01/world.main_headline: Lesotho's Military Leader Ousted by Army Officers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/01/world.print_headline: Lesotho's Military Leader Ousted by Army Officers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/01/world.body_text: **********The head of Lesotho's military junta was forced to resign today after a bloodless coup by rebel army officers. **********The strongman, Maj. Gen. Justin Lekhanya, went on state radio in the capital, Maseru, this morning to announce that he and his colleagues in the six-man military council that runs the country were stepping down in response to national dissatisfaction with his leadership, according to a statement issued here on behalf of the Lesotho Government. **********"It seems to me that the nation has been complaining for some time over my leadership and the performance of some of my colleagues," General Lekhanya was quoted as saying. "I therefore announce my resignation and that of my colleagues." **********Press reports here said armed soldiers had marched the general over to the radio station to make his speech this morning. He was then taken away to the maximum security prison, by one account. **********Col. Elias P. Ramaema replaced General Lekhanya as chairman of the six-member Military Council, according to unofficial reports confirmed by a South African diplomat here. Colonel Ramaema served on the council that has ruled Lesotho since Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan was overthrown in January 1986. **********The naming of a successor was reportedly delayed by disagreement among rebel officers over whether General Lekhanya should be replaced by another military officer or by Lesotho's current constitutional monarch, King Letsie III. **********In a radio interview today with the South African Broadcasting Corporation, Evastius Sekhonyana, a former Finance Minister of Lesotho, said the general had been told "in very strong terms" on Monday night that he and some other Cabinet ministers had to resign. Mr. Sekhonyana said he did not know who had carred out the coup. **********General Lekhanya, a 54-year-old career policeman, took over Lesotho in January 1986 at the head of a junta pledged to eliminate corruption. He subsequently stripped away the powers of King Moshoeshoe and forced him into exile in February 1990, replacing him with his son, now King Letsie, who has no executive authority. **********Last year, the general promised to return civilian rule to Lesotho (pronounced Le-SOO-too) by June 1992 but had not begun any arrangements to do so. There had been increasing complaints about his tenure, prompting the South African black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela and President Sam Nujoma of Namibia to cancel scheduled visits in recent weeks.Mike Taole, general secretary of the Christian Council of Lesotho, told the South African Press Association that the uprising against General Lekhanya's rule began Monday morning, when some military units went on strike for higher pay. By this morning, Mr. Taole said, a battalion of soldiers had surrounded the general's residence and forced his resignation. **********Lesotho, a landlocked mountainous kingdom twice the size of Connecticut, is a former British protectorate that was granted independence on Oct. 4, 1966. It has about 1.5 million people, some of whom work as migrant labor in South Africa. **********Though Lesotho is surrounded by South Africa and is economically dependent on South Africa, there was no evidence of South Africa's involvement in General Lekhanya's ouster.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/29/busin.body_text: **********The economy contracted during the second quarter instead of expanding, revised Government figures showed today, suggesting that the recession lasted longer than had previously been thought. **********Total output of goods and services edged down at an annual rate of a tenth of 1 percent, a tiny decline that nevertheless contrasted with the Commerce Department's estimate a month ago that output rose at a pace of four-tenths of 1 percent in the April-June period. **********Most analysts tended to dismiss the fact that gross national product has now shrunk for the latest three quarters and remained confident that the recovery from recession, although almost certainly a desultory recovery, is now under way. President Is Optimistic **********"It doesn't change the outlook very much -- and might even improve it," said Robert H. Chandross, the chief economist for Lloyds Bank North America in New York. **********President Bush, when asked in Kennebunkport, Me., whether today's report meant continued recession, said he did not think so. "I feel all right about things," he said. "There are some statistics up and some down, but basically I think it's doing all right." **********Most reports on economic activity so far this summer have portrayed an economic rebound, and even skeptics regard growth in G.N.P. for the third quarter to be a near certainty. A number of analysts said they did not expect the Federal Reserve to relax monetary policy further in response to today's revisions of the spring-quarter performance. **********Traders in the financial markets, however, grasped at the prospect that signs of economic weakness might yet mean a new cut in interest rates by the Fed, which also trimmed rates earlier this month to give the economy a lift. That hope helped to inspire the stock market, where the Dow Jones industrial average gained 29.07 points to reach a new high of 3,055.23.  [ Page D8. ]  The G.N.P. report, coupled with a successful auction of new five-year Treasury notes, also helped to push up prices for Treasury securities in the credit market.  [ Page D18. ] Shattering an Illusion **********A minority of private analysts pointed to the latest G.N.P. figures as evidence of lingering weakness that to some implies no significant growth until next year. **********"Today's downward revision of the second-quarter G.N.P. should shatter any remaining illusion of an economic recovery," said Lawrence A. Hunter, deputy chief economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce. "This third consecutive quarter of economic contraction removes all doubt about the continuing economic stagnation." **********A prominent reason for caution, some analysts say, is a wavering of confidence among consumers, the source of two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. The ABC News/ Money Magazine Consumer Index was calculated today at minus 38 on a scale ranging from plus 100 to minus 100. The index, based on consumer ratings of the economy, consumers' personal finances and the buying climate, is down one point for the week and within five points of its record low of minus 43, set on Oct. 28. **********Albert Sindlinger, a longtime pollster, said today that consumer incomes had slumped to a 36-year low, in part because of taxes not included in Government inflation statistics. Depleted Inventories **********The main factors dragging the G.N.P. into negative territory were more rapid reductions in business inventories and lower personal spending. Analysts noted, however, that depleted inventories represent a positive factor for gauging future economic activity, since any increase in demand will quickly require stepped-up production. **********"This sets up the possibility of significant economic growth in the second half of the year," said Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist a Merrill Lynch & Company. **********Businesses cut inventories at a $27.7 billion rate in the April-June quarter instead of the $21.2 billion pace initially estimated, a difference of $6.5 billion, the Commerce Department report showed. **********Analysts also tended to playdown the $5.1 billion downward revision in personal spending, which shrank the annual growth rate to 2.8 percent from 3.6 percent. Much of the reduction reflected what were, in effect, accounting changes that shifted car purchases from individuals to businesses.  Daunting Task for Auto Makers **********Even optimists, however, cautioned that the automobile business faced a daunting sales task in coming months, since it has imposed significant price increases that exceed current rebate programs. **********The biggest upward revisions in today's G.N.P. report were a $4.1 billion improvement in foreign trade -- imports were $3.1 billion lower than first estimated and exports $1 billion higher -- and a $3.4 billion rise in the output of producers' durable equipment. **********Over all, analysts said that while they did not consider the half-point revision in G.N.P. to be large, it was somewhat surprising that it was downward and into negative territory. Based on experience, the department said the chances were two out of three that in the future, revisions of second-quarter G.N.P. would not be worse than a four-tenths of 1 percent rate of decline or better than a five-tenths of 1 percent rate of advance. **********The G.N.P. declined at an annual rate of 2.8 percent in the first quarter of 1991 and 1.6 percent in the fourth quarter of last year.  Inflation at 3 Percent **********Inflation, as gauged by the fixed-weight G.N.P. price index that assumes the composition of output does not change, ran at 3 percent during the quarter, the same pace as estimated in late July. The nation's savings rate, however, is now seen as remaining at 4.2 percent instead of falling a half point as initially estimated in July's advance report. **********G.N.P. in current dollars rather than 1982 dollars fell to a 4.2 annual percent rate of increase in the second quarter from 4.6 percent in last month's report. **********Today's report also included the Government's first calculation of corporate profits for the spring quarter. **********Profits from current production -- before tax with inventory valuation and capital consumption adjustments -- rose $1.7 billion, or six-tenths of 1 percent, to $287.9 billion at an annual rate. This compared with a decline of $2.7 billion, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, in the first quarter. **********Increases were posted in manufacturing, trade and the transportation and public utilities group, while profits fell in other nonmanufacturing industries, the department stated. **********Profits before taxes, but without adjustments, rose seven-tenths of 1 percent after falling 7.4 percent in the first quarter, and profits after taxes fell 1.6 percent, compared with a 6.3 percent drop during the winter. But current-production cash flow, a measure of a company's ability to finance projects internally, edged up only a tenth of 1 percent after rising 3.5 percent in the first quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/10/busin.body_text: **********COMPANIES The Market Get Jittery Over Maxwell's U.S. Holdings **********Though Robert Maxwell spent his career building a business that spans the globe, 90 percent of the profits of the Maxwell Communication Corporation -- about $352 million -- come from the United States. "The businesses have performed more strongly than Maxwell really had any right to expect," said William Reilly, former president of Maxwell Communication. Still, there is nervousness among investors that Mr. Maxwell paid too much for his American holdings and that his heirs would be forced to sell assets. Interest payments last year were $344.96 million, almost entirely offsetting profits. Last week, David Shaffer was named Maxwell chief executive. Though he has experience in American business, as head of Macmillan since 1990, his appointment did not qualm market jitters over Mr. Maxwell's death. Maxwell share prices fell in London to about $1.20, down almost 50 percent for the week. Compaq's New Chief Moves In  Eckhard Pfeiffer is moving swiftly to rewire the ailing Compaq Computer Corporation. After just two weeks on the job as Compaq's chief executive, Mr. Mr. Pfeiffer outlined a new business strategy. Costs will be cut and the company will bring out a new line of cheaper PC's. It will also drop the price on some of its notebook computers by 25 percent and set up a new distribution system. Mr. Pfeiffer said he was also putting a new top-management team in place. Wall Street was pleased with Mr. Pfeiffer's remarks. The company's stock (it was in the $50 range in May) gained a little ground. Its shares rose $1.25, to $27.875, on the announcements and closed the week at $26.50. Another Alliance for I.B.M.  Big Blue was once considered aloof. No more. Last summer, the International Business Machines Corporation announced plans to join forces with Apple Computer Company, Thinking Machines Corporation, Germany's Siemens and Japan's NEC. Last week, I.B.M. announced one more. It formed a 10-year pact to jointly design computer chips for PC's with the Intel Corporation. Intel makes the chips that are at the heart of most PC's. The new pact gives I.B.M. the right to buy Intel's chips first. It also allows I.B.M. to modify them. It gives "I.B.M. the flexibility to build things the other guys don't have," said Michael Slater, the publisher of Microprocessor Report, an industry newsletter.  An Industry Running on Fumes  The automobile industry's octane rating could use a little boost right now. Sales of cars and light trucks built in North America for October were down 8 percent at the end of October. Business has been so bad that Standard & Poor's issued a credit watch "with negative implications" to creditors of the General Motors Corporation and Ford Motor Company.  Can Pepsi Catch Up? When it comes to globalization, no company knows more than the Coca-Cola Company, which gets 80 percent of its profits from abroad. Those profits have been the been the fizz behind Coke's 20 percent annual growth rate over the last five years. For arch-rival Pepsico Inc. -- which outsells Coke in the United States but not elsewhere -- that smarts. So last week Pepsi said it will invest $1 billion in Spain over five years to build plants, fast-food restaurants and distribution system. Is Pepsi trying to be more like Coke? "All companies in the United States are trying to become more like Coke," said David A. Goldman, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. Lockheed's Stock Ploy  The Lockheed Corporation said last week it would purchase 6.3 percent of its outstanding shares of common stock. At current prices, that will cost the company $180 million. The announcement came after the company had pared down its debt and won a number of large Pentagon contracts, including one to build the Air Force's next-generation fighter plane. After a tough proxy battle last year with Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, Lockheed's management said it would do more for investors. Last week, it revealed what it would do: Buy them out.  Rating Off at American Express  A stellar credit rating is something the American Express Company has rarely been without. But last week, Moody's downgraded about $7 billion of Amex's long-term debt. That was a first. The turmoil at its Shearson Lehman Brothers subsidiary did not help the company. Nor did defaults from its Optima credit card holders. While still investment grade, Amex's borrowing costs are expected to rise slightly from the ratings change. Last week, American Express dropped Ogilvy & Mather, its green-card account ad agency, for Chiat/Day/Mojo in New York.  Mr. Olasky's Charity Litmus Test  Each year, Marvin Olasky, a journalism professor at the University of Texas at Austin, grades corporations on their philanthropy. The worst? Dayton Hudson, one of the most generous corporate contributors in America, got an "F" last week. Dayton Hudson gave money to "groups that lobby for increased government welfare, which increases dependency," he said. Which groups are those? The Children's Defense Fund and the Center for Community Change. Top marks -- a "B plus" -- went to the FMC Corporation. It gave money to the conservative Heritage Foundation, where Mr. Olasky was a resident scholar. ECONOMY **********The Fed Gives It a Try  To control the economy, the Fed has two buttons it can push. Last week it pressed them both. First, it lowered the discount rate, the rate it charges member banks to borrow money, to 4 1/2 percent from 5 percent. Then it pulled down the Fed funds rate on overnight loans to 4 3/4 percent from 5 percent. Together, the cuts are designed to add a little pep to the economy. Banks lowered their prime rates to 7 1/2 percent from 8 percent in the aftermath. But some observers remain dubious. "People do not go out and buy a car just because rates are down half a point," said Ezekiel S. Ketchum, of Meridian Bank in Reading, Pa. Hope of a Tax Cut?  To give the lethargic economy a jolt, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, introduced a bill to cut taxes.  The Meaning of Productivity  One side of the argument goes like this: Productivity improvement means workers are adding more value to the nation's economy; wages and living standards increase. But the other side says productivity increases when companies shed workers but still sell as many goods; life becomes harsher. So when the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported last week that productivity grew 2.4 percent in the third quarter which side of the argument was supported? "I'm going out on a limb," said Allen Sinai, of the Boston Company. "This could be the beginning of the process of an increase in the standard of living."  More Gloom for Workers  With the economy's engine ignited, but so far failing to lift off, forecasters are skittish. Once they ignored weekly unemployment statistics. Now they ponder them. When the Labor Department said 14,000 people were added to the jobless lists in late October what did it mean? "We're stagnating." said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities. INTERNATIONAL **********A Real Soviet Bang for the Buck  With the remnants of the Soviet economy spinning closer to the 'abyss' -- a word used by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last week -- everything is for sale. Desperate for hard currency, the Soviets are willing to sell once-secret Mig jets, miniature nuclear reactors and possibly the Mir space station (it's still in orbit). They are also offering services involving underground nuclear explosions. For between $300 to $1,200 a kilogram, the International Chetco Corporation in Moscow is prepared to vaporize toxic waste in an underground explosion. Scientists, environmentalists and weapons-control experts around the world have lodged loud complaints. But so far the Soviet Union is undeterred. According to Vladimir B. Dmitriev, Chetco's president, "it will be possible to export services."  After hesitating for two weeks, the Ukrainian Parliament voted last week to join with Moscow in a new, looser economic union.  Opening More Lines to Europe  Right now, 57,750 conversations can be carried on simultaneously between the United States and Europe, not enough capacity to avoid delays. Next February, capacity will jump to about 150,000 simultaneous calls, still too little capacity for this burgeoning market. So last week, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced it would lay two new fiber-optic cables between the United States and Europe. That would add enough capacity to handle 300,000 simultaneous conversations and data transfers. The project, which will cost about $580 million and take a year to complete, still must be cleared by the Federal Communications Commission. Slow Growth in the Philippines  This has not been a good year for the Philippines. First Mount Pinatubo erupted, causing hundreds of millions of dollars of damage. Then tropical storm Thelma ravaged the islands that make up the country, killing as many as 5,000 people. Nevertheless, growth is still expected to be positive. Last week, President Corazon Aquino said the official estimate is that the Philippines would grow by just less than 1 percent, compared with 3.6 percent last year. One of the reasons for the slowdown is that thousands of Filipino guest workers living abroad who send their salaries home have traveled back to the Philippines to repair their damaged villages.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/world.main_headline: Baker Sees and Hears Kurds' Pain In a Brief Visit at Turkish Border
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Baker Sees and Hears Kurds' Pain In a Brief Visit at Turkish Border
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/world.body_text: **********From afar, it looks like any other meadow in the snow-dusted mountains of Kurdistan. Then bright colors begin to appear, and what seemed like rocks begin to move. Then there is a person. Then two. And then 100, and then a thousand, and suddenly 50,000 people are carpeting the mountainsides like wildflowers almost as far as the eye can see. **********This was the scene today on the border between Iraq and Turkey, just south of the Turkish mountain village of Cukurca. There in the middle of nowhere Kurdish men, women and children are gathering in a throng on the mountainsides as they flee from the army of President Saddam Hussein. **********Of many memorable aspects of this scene, two stand out: The beehive-like hum of 50,000 Kurds all talking at once that suddenly hits the visitor when he rounds the last bend and the scene unfolds in the valley below, and the dazed, deer-caught-in-the-headlights look that seems locked in the eyes of every Kurd there, particularly the barefoot children too gun-shy to even reach for a free stick of chewing gum. **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d flew all the way from Washington to assess this scene on orders from President Bush. He spent only seven minutes in the camp, though, because, his aides said, Turkish Army officers suggested that he leave out of fear that if the crowd got surly they would never be able to control it.  Laundry in a Muddy Stream **********Few of the Kurds had any idea that the American Secretary of State was present or cared that he had actually walked across the Turkish border a few yards into Iraq, where most of the refugees were backed up. The women went about their business of washing clothes in a muddy mountain stream while their menfolk gathered twigs from the hardscrabble mountainsides to make fires that would warm them at night when the temperature dips into the 30's. **********There appeared to be only a dozen tents for 50,000 people, but already the territorial instinct was taking hold. Many families had placed a circle of stones around the plot where they were squatting, apparently assuming that they were going to be there for a while. **********"Mr. Baker! Mr. Baker!" shouted a Kurdish man as he tried to break through the ring of rifle-toting Turkish soldiers surrounding the Secretary, who was wearing his cowboy boots. "Can I talk to you please? Please Mr. Baker. I need to talk to you." **********The Secretary, slightly taken aback, ordered that the man be let through. "We are suffering," the man said in English. "Our children are suffering from starvation. We need doctors, we need medicine, we need water. There was heavy bombing on our heads." **********Mr. Baker nodded, taking it all in. When the man, who said later that he had walked six days from his Kurdish village to this spot, finished his appeal, the Secretary told him, "As you may or may not know, President Bush has ordered a major airlift, which is going on right now." **********But he quickly added, "It is up to the international community as a whole to do something about this tragic crime." U.S. Analysis Is Rejected **********That was the message that Mr. Baker came to deliver, and he did so to the Turkish officials in Ankara and to the Kurdish refugees. The Kurdish problem is a humanitarian issue and requires a humanitarian response by the international community as a whole, Mr. Baker said. The Bush Administration is not going to become embroiled in the civil war in Iraq to resolve the Kurds' political fate. **********Many Turkish officials and commentators, not to mention the Kurdish refugees, rejected this analysis. They said that they expected the number of Kurds fleeing Iraq to swell to one million in the coming weeks and that those are numbers that are simply beyond the scope of any sustained international relief effort, particularly when the refugees are living hundreds of miles from a major city or real hospital. Thirty thousand refugees is a humanitarian problem, but one million, they argued, is a political problem. **********The only solution, said the Kurds and Turkish officials, is a political one that will enable these Kurds to go back to their homes. But they say they will not do that as long as Mr. Hussein remains in power. They say they will never trust his promises of safe passage home in light of his poison gas attack on Kurds in 1988 and of the fact that his army used tanks, helicopters and planes to fire everything from bullets to napalm on refugees fleeing this week. **********Mr. Baker's visit, hastily arranged last week, is part of the Bush Administration's effort to blunt criticism of its failure to help the Kurds militarily by focusing attention on American aid. **********But the visit has inadvertently underscored that the Kurdish problem, because of its scope, is a political issue that cannot be solved with tents and relief supplies alone. It has also raised anew the question of whether the United States should have ended the war with Mr. Hussein still in power. A Refugee's Question **********A 21-year-old Kurdish refugee in Cukurca remarked after Mr. Baker walked by: "Why Bush no help Kurdish people destroy Saddam? Schwarzkopf, he want to destroy Saddam, but Bush no?" **********At a news conference today after his hasty border visit, Mr. Baker declared: "Today we have witnessed the suffering and despair of the Iraqi people. We have seen examples of cruelty and human anguish that really do defy description. Our relief efforts, including airdrops of supplies, have begun, but they alone are not going to be enough." **********"So," Mr. Baker continued, "the international community has to respond quickly and effectively." **********But when Mr. Baker was asked who would protect the Kurds from President Hussein if they did return home, he answered, "You will now have a major humanitarian relief effort undertaken by the international community, and it is hoped that the presence of humanitarian relief workers will act as a deterrent to future harassment and persecution of these people." **********Neither the Turks nor the Kurds seemed to believe that President Hussein would be intimidated by relief workers. The Turks have told the Americans that the Kurdish problem is now a national security question for them. As they see it, President Hussein, by driving the Kurds across the border, is simultaneously solving his Kurdish problem once and for all and obtaining revenge on Turkey for its support for the anti-Iraq coalition. **********As one American diplomat remarked, "It is as though all of northern Iraq has gotten up and walked." Pressure on Turks Seen **********The Turks fear that the addition of the Iraqi Kurds to their own Kurdish population of 20 million will create tremendous political pressure for Turkey, and not Iraq, to cede part of its territory for a Kurdish state. Altogether, there are two million Iraqi Kurds. **********Mr. Baker began his day by flying from Ankara, where he had held talks with Turkey's President, Turgut Ozal, to Diyarbakir, the only city in southeastern Turkey with a runway that could handle his Air Force Boeing 707. From there he and his staff boarded helicopters for a 90-minute flight into the mountains of Kurdistan. **********Before taking off, Mr. Baker inspected an American C-130 loaded with Army rations of chicken a la king and spaghetti with meatballs that were to be parachuted to Kurdish refugees inside Iraq today in hopes of feeding them and thereby keeping them there. **********Mr. Baker's helicopter landed at a small Turkish military base in Cukurca on a plateau guarded by a wall of mountains. Gen. Kamil Basar, the commander at the base, briefed the Secretary on the refugee problem. **********He told him that there were about 280,000 Kurdish refugees in several makeshift camps along the Turkish-Iraqi border and that judging from the numbers that the Turks know are heading in their direction, they expect the figure to reach between 500,000 and 600,000 within a week. **********After the briefing, Mr. Baker met privately with a selected group of Kurdish refugee leaders, including Noori Bireskani, who asked reporters traveling with the Secretary: "Why did they stop the war? If they would have continued only two more days, they would have finished it." **********Then, referring to President Hussein, he said: "We thought they were going to throw him out for everyone's sake. We are all disappointed."                    --------------------       Iran Reopens Border **********NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 8 (Reuters) -- One day after closing its border to Iraqi refugees, Iran reopened it today, but Teheran said it was in urgent need of international help to save the refugees from certain death. **********Interior Ministry officials said 771,850 refugees had arrived by this afternoon. "The figure is expected to rise to one million by the end of the week and to 1.5 million soon," Vahid Dastjeridi, the head of the Red Crescent Society, told the Teheran radio.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/09/world.main_headline: Barring of Press From Military Base Upheld
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/09/world.print_headline: Barring of Press From Military Base Upheld
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/09/world.body_text: **********A Federal judge today upheld military restrictions against news coverage of the return of bodies of American troops killed in the Persian Gulf war. **********The Defense Department has barred the press from Dover Air Force Base, Del., when bodies of servicemen and servicewomen have arrived from the gulf region, saying it wanted to protect the privacy of the troops' families. **********A group of photographers, reporters and other groups filed suit, saying the restrictions violated press freedoms. They said the Pentagon only wanted to prevent unfavorable news. But Federal District Judge Royce Lamberth said the restrictions did not violate freedom of the press. He ruled that a military base was not a public place and that the restrictions were reasonable. **********Dover is the main base used to receive United States military casualties from foreign wars. Pictures of flag-draped coffins of American troops arriving at Dover were allowed during other conflicts as recently as the United States invasion of Panama at the end of 1989. **********"The purpose of the restriction is to prevent stories the Pentagon doesn't want on the TV news -- the return of bodies," said Kate Martin, a lawyer for the plaintiffs. She said the ruling would be appealed. **********The Justice Department said access to military bases was a military decision.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/05/world.main_headline: GERMAN FAR LEFT DOGS NEW AGENCY
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/05/world.print_headline: GERMAN FAR LEFT DOGS NEW AGENCY
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/05/world.body_text: **********Until recently, the privatizing agency known as Treuhand was only the most hated Government agency in eastern Germany. Now it has become a target of deadly terrorism. **********A Treuhand office in Berlin was firebombed on Friday, and three days later the director, Detlev Karsten Rohwedder, was killed by a sniper from the far-left Red Army Faction. The assaults have thrust the Treuhandanstalt, or Public Trustee, to the forefront of political debate. **********The assaults have also added an element of tragedy to the troubled process of German unification, and jolted those who believed unification could be achieved calmly and without conflict. **********In eastern Germany, the name Treuhand is often taken in vain. People there blame the agency for selling and shutting down hundreds of formerly state-owned companies without concern for workers. Unemployment at 9.2% **********As if to underline the deterioration of economic conditions in eastern Germany, officials in Bonn today released figures showing that unemployment there, formerly all but unknown, has reached 9.2 percent. Many analysts believe the true figure is substantially higher, and several political and religious figures have predicted it could reach 50 percent by mid-summer. **********After the killing of Mr. Rohwedder, Government officials have pledged that Treuhand policies will not be altered. **********"No change in direction is needed," Finance Minister Theo Waigel asserted after meeting with Treuhand executives in Berlin on Wednesday. He said terrorism would not force the Government to retreat into "fear and paralysis." **********Nonetheless, the killing threw a pall over the unification process. Financial experts said it might discourage some foreign investors who had been considering buying or establishing companies in eastern Germany. New Director to Be Named **********Mr. Waigel is expected to name a new director for the Treuhand soon. The leading candidate is said to be Birgit Breuel, a Volkswagen board member who has been working for the Treuhand since last year. **********Politicians from eastern Germany joined in condemning Mr. Rohwedder's slaying. But in recent weeks, many had expressed rising frustration with Treuhand policies. **********"The problem is that the Treuhand is part of the Finance Ministry, and the Finance Ministry's job is to worry only about money," Klaus Buttner, the Mayor of Weimar, said in a recent interview. "Nobody is worrying about the human beings whose lives are being thrown into upheaval." **********Treuhand managers are responsible for the liquidation of about 8,000 companies in eastern Germany. They have shut about 300 of the companies and have sold about 1,000 others, many at bargain prices. Treuhand policies emphasize quick action against indigent companies, rather than subsidies to keep them afloat. A Symbol of the Divide **********Before his death, Mr. Rohwedder, who was 58 years old, often acknowledged the anger his policies had provoked in the East. He portrayed himself, however, as a true friend of eastern Germany whose policies would, in the long run, prove to have been economically sound. **********Even in death, Mr. Rohwedder has become a symbol of the cleavage between eastern and western Germany. Officials from the two parts of the country are arguing over how the murder investigation should be conducted. **********The Red Army Faction, which as taken responsibility for the killing, maintained intimate ties to the former East German secret police, the Stasi. Prosecutors want access to Stasi files to search for possible leads. But organizers of the anti-Stasi movement in eastern Germany, suspicious of security agencies after 40 years of police oppression, do not want the files turned over to law enforcement officers. **********In Bonn, Johannes Gerster, a senior member of Parliament from the governing Christian Democratic Union, called for the creation of a special parliamentary commission to investigate ties between the Red Army Faction and the Stasi. **********The police said today that they had no clues to the identity of the sniper who killed Mr. Rohwedder as he sat in his Dusseldorf home shortly before midnight on Monday. They said that the Red Army Faction consisted of about 15 to 20 members, and that many are unknown to the police. **********The rifle used to kill Mr. Rohwedder, the police said, was the same one used to fire shots at the United States Embassy in Bonn in February. That case is still unsolved. So are the three other assaults, two of them fatal, attributed to the Red Army since the Berlin wall fell in 1989.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/world.main_headline: Yugoslavia Perplexed Over Status of Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/world.print_headline: Yugoslavia Perplexed Over Status of Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/world.body_text: **********Yugoslavia's Prime Minister said tonight that he had received implied assurances from President Bush that the United States would not cut off economic aid to his country because of human rights violations. **********The Prime Minister, Ante Markovic, said that in a telephone call tonight, Mr. Bush indicated that there had been no fundamental change in U.S. policy toward this Balkan country of six quarrelsome republics. **********"Mr. Bush underlined support for the unity and territorial integrity of Yugoslavia and the reform efforts of its Government," Mr. Markovic said. But when asked if he took the President's remarks to mean that Yugoslavia could count on receiving all the aid it had expected from the United States, he replied, "I do not know, I cannot guarantee it." **********[ A State Department spokeswoman said the Bush Administration had suspended a $5 million aid program to Yugoslavia and would oppose its loan requests from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, The Associated Press reported. **********[ The spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said the reasons for the aid cutoff were that the Serbian leadership was exercising "severe repression in the Kosovo Province, had not conducted fully free and fair elections, and was now acting to destabilize the Yugoslav presidency." ] Mesic Defiant **********Mr. Markovic stressed in an interview tonight that his Government had moved in to fill a vacuum created last Friday when the eight-member federal presidency became deadlocked over succession of its chairman. **********Meanwhile, Stipe Mesic, the Republic of Croatia's delegate to the presidency, insisted defiantly today that he is the legal chairman and will call for the body to meet this week. **********"All the other coordinators are unconstitutional and do not matter," he said. Mr. Mesic, a longtime anti-Communist, walked out of the presidency meeting on Friday after the members from Serbia and Montenegro, where Communists still dominate political life, thwarted his ascent to the chairmanship, which is prescribed by a predetermined annual rotation. **********Before Mr. Markovic spoke of his conversation with President Bush, Federal and republic officials expressed shock at a report in The New York Times on Sunday that said that the United States was withholding aid and support for Yugoslavia in international lending organizations based on the Nickles Amendment. **********Passed by Congress last November, the law, in essence, gave Yugoslavia until May 6 to end repression of ethnic Albanians in the Kosovo region of Serbia or face a shutoff in assistance. **********Leaders in Croatia and Slovenia, Yugoslavia's richest and most independence-minded republics, expressed dissatisfaction that their republics might suffer economically because of Serbia, but they expressed hopes that a change in U.S. policy would eventually lead to direct aid to individual Yugoslav republics that comply with the Nickles Amendment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/busin.main_headline: Dollar Up in Quiet Trading; Gold Prices Also Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS; Dollar Up in Quiet Trading; Gold Prices Also Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/busin.body_text: **********The dollar rose yesterday in quiet trading as investors were heartened by the results of the Treasury's bond auction. **********Gold prices were mostly higher, rising in all major markets except Zurich. Gold picked up 60 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $357.10 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $357, up 70 cents. **********There were few events to influence domestic currency trading, but the market was reassured by good demand for the $11.96 billion in 10-year notes the Treasury sold yesterday, said Kevin Logan, chief economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. **********If United States bonds are attractive to foreign investors, the dollar gets a lift because overseas buyers must purchase dollars to pay for their new securities. **********The Government sold the bonds as part of its three-day quarterly refunding auction. **********Analysts said the dollar was also helped by news that President Bush suffers not from a heart ailment, but from a treatable thyroid condition. **********In earlier European trading, the dollar rose on news that an American warplane came under antiaircraft fire while flying over northern Iraq Tuesday night. The report was subsequently played down by United States officials. **********The dollar tends to rise in times of international strife because it is seen as a haven for investors. **********Dealers said the United States currency was also helped by unsubstantiated rumors that the president of the German Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, was about to resign. The rumors sent the mark falling. **********The dollar rose to 1.7312 marks in New York from late Tuesday's 1.7175. In Europe, the dollar advanced to 1.7330 German marks, from 1.7210 late Tuesday. **********The British pound fell against the dollar, dropping to $1.7200 in New York, from $1.7265 late Tuesday. In London, sterling fell to $1.7180 from $1.7205. **********The dollar rose against the Japanese yen in New York, closing at 138.30 yen, up from 137.80 late Tuesday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar fell 0.54 yen, to 137.88 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 138.30 yen. **********Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.4630 Swiss francs, up from 1.4530; 5.8585 French francs, up from 5.8155; 1,281.25 Italian lire, up from 1,270.50, and 1.15245 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15105. **********Earlier in London, gold rose to a late bid price of $357.25, from $356 late Tuesday. **********In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $356.65, from $356.85 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.19 to close at a bid of $357.55. **********Silver closed at $4.047 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange, up 1.1 cents. Earlier in London, silver was unchanged at a late bid of $4.05.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/02/busin.main_headline: B.C.C.I. Hearing Is Canceled After U.S. Blocks Testimony
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; B.C.C.I. Hearing Is Canceled After U.S. Blocks Testimony
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/02/busin.body_text: **********The Justice Department has blocked the testimony of two key witnesses scheduled to appear Wednesday at a Senate hearing on the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, causing Senator John F. Kerry, chairman of the panel, to cancel the hearing. **********The cancellation is the latest incident in a dispute between Senate investigators and the Justice Department. The Senate believes that the Justice Department has tried to hamper the Senate investigation, and the Justice Department said it feared that the Congressional inquiry could undermine its own investigation of the bank. **********Senate investigators say they believe that the Justice Department blocked the witnesses, who are employees of the department, because the agency feared that it would be embarrassed by testimony confirming that Justice Department officials were slow off the mark in investigating B.C.C.I. But the agency contends that Senator Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat, simply wants the two witnesses to appear at a public hearing to enhance his personal publicity. **********"Our people have a feeling that Mr. Kerry and his people already have all the information they're going to get," said Doug Tillet, a Justice Department spokesman. **********Mr. Kerry, asked to respond, said, "I'm really surprised that the Justice Department is trying to rekindle a battle here and pick a fight about trying to get to the truth. **********"Maybe Justice has something they don't want made public," the Senator added. "They shouldn't worry about a public hearing if they have nothing to conceal." **********Any attempts by Mr. Kerry to compel the witnesses to testify could be blocked if the Administration invoked "executive privilege." **********The two prospective witnesses are Robert Mazur, who headed the Customs Service's investigation of B.C.C.I. in Tampa, Fla., and Mark Jackowski, an assistant United States attorney who performed the same role for the Justice Department. **********Mr. Mazur led a lengthy undercover operation against B.C.C.I. several years ago that led to several indictments and convictions for money laundering against B.C.C.I. and some of its top employees in the United States. It also led to arrests and successful prosecutions of several drug dealers who were using the bank. **********Mr. Mazur resigned from the Customs Service last April. In his letter of resignation, he reportedly charged that the agency had failed to provide the resources needed for the B.C.C.I. investigation. **********Mr. Mazur had pushed for a broader investigation of B.C.C.I. in America including its apparent ties to Clark M. Clifford, the prominent Washington lawyer, and the bank he headed, the First American Bank of Washington. But his suggestions were never followed. Mr. Mazur is now in training as an agent of the Drug Enforcement Administration, a part of the Justice Department. **********Mr. Jackowksi, who was transferred to the Denver United States Attorney's office, has returned to Tampa on temporary duty. Pushed for Investigation **********Mr. Kerry, who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee's Subcommittee on Terrorism, Narcotics and International Operations, has been the most active member of Congress in investigating B.C.C.I., which was seized last July by financial regulators in seven countries after the Bank of England uncovered evidence of fraud, drug trafficking and money laundering. **********"I don't have all the information by any means," Senator Kerry said. "The Justice Department of all agencies should understand that a good and thorough and fair investigation involves talking to witnesses, not just reading pieces of paper." **********Mr. Tillet, the Justice Department spokesman, said the department had "some concerns about those two guys testifying in an open session." **********He added, however, that "we made some counteroffers about how they could get the information they were seeking without holding an open hearing." **********Mr. Tillet said that in the case of Mr. Jackowski, "We don't make line attorneys available; we send policy people or supervisory personnel to testify." **********As for Mr. Mazur, "He is in training to be a D.E.A. agent," Mr. Tillet said. "There are some concerns for his security." Previous Disclosures **********Mr. Kerry noted, however, that Mr. Mazur had testified publicly in court on his role as an undercover agent investigating B.C.C.I., and also had discussed the case in television appearances. Mr. Kerry said that he had offered to bar both television and radio broadcasts from the public hearing, but hold it open to the print media. **********Mr. Tillet said that Mr. Kerry was requesting unrestricted access. "He wants to go one-on-one with Mazur," Mr. Tillet said, "and we feel that Mazur should have the benefit of a department employee to be present when the interview is conducted." **********But the Senator said that the presence of Justice Department officials could inhibit the witnesses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/14/world.main_headline: Inquiry Has Japan Edgy: Was It an Arms Conduit?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/14/world.print_headline: Inquiry Has Japan Edgy: Was It an Arms Conduit?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/14/world.body_text: **********An investigation into one of Japan's leading military contractors, suspected of illegally exporting millions of dollars worth of missile parts and guidance systems in the 1980's, is forcing the Government to face a deeply uncomfortable question: was Japan a secret conduit for illegal American weapons shipments to Iran? **********The Government prides itself on its virtual ban on arms trading, and at the London summit meeting of seven industrial powers, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is expected to press for an agreement that would force countries to report conventional weapons sales. **********But in the last week, new evidence has emerged suggesting that Japan Aviation Electronics Industry Ltd. secretly funneled far more sophisticated military electronics equipment to Iran than first believed, and worked hand in hand with a Miami company that has long been suspected of other technology diversions to Iran. **********"The timing with the Iran-contra diversions is remarkable, and we are wondering if it can be a coincidence," said a Defense Agency official. "It contravenes everything this country has been saying about the need to stop international arms trade, and makes us look like fools. No one is likely to offer this company much mercy." Sophisticated Gear **********The Japanese-made equipment included gyroscopes, inertial navigation systems and other sophisticated electronic gear, all made under license from American military contractors. The licenses specify that Japan Aviation is permitted to sell the equipment only to the Japanese military, which requires that most of its components be made in Japan. Slightly more than half of Japan Aviation's stock is owned by one of the world's biggest electronics conglomerates, NEC Corporation. **********So far, no arrests have been made. But the Japanese authorities have raided Japan Aviation's offices in Tokyo, and officials familiar with the investigation say they found evidence of more than a dozen separate transactions in which military electronics was apparently sold to agents of the Miami concern, which they identified as Aero Systems Inc. The equipment was allegedly transferred in hotel rooms in Tokyo and transported, in ordinary luggage, to Hong Kong and Singapore, and ultimately to Iran, investigators say. **********Other officials say they are not aware of evidence that the Japanese Government knew of the transactions in advance, or approved sales under pressure from the United States. **********For Japan the case has disturbing similarities to the 1987 Toshiba scandal, when a subsidiary of Toshiba Corporation was discovered to have shipped huge machine tools to the Soviet Union. American officials contend that the tools were used to make special propellers that help Soviet nuclear submarines evade detection. **********In the aftermath of the Toshiba scandal, most of Japan's major companies adapted strict export-control policies, including NEC and Japan Aviation. But the sales to Iran apparently continued until 1989. "It's a mystery to me," said an American executive in Tokyo who had dealings with Japan Aviation. "They are a very conservative company. The amount of money involved in these deals is relatively small. There is no clear reason why they did it."  Police Will Say Little **********So far the police have said little about what Japan Aviation sold to Aero Systems. Most of the equipment seems suited for Sidewinder missiles and American-made fighter. Iran had both, left over from American equipment sold to the Shah of Iran in the 1970's. **********As in the Toshiba case, Japanese investigators apparently knew nothing about the exports until they received queries from American officials. The questions about Japan Aviation apparently arose from a United States Customs Service investigation. Affidavits filed in Miami in December 1989 by Customs officials alleged that Aero Systems circumvented export controls and used a front company in Hong Kong, Hierax Company, to ship aircraft parts to Iran starting in 1981. **********For reasons that are not clear, Aero Systems apparently turned to Japan Aviation to supply equipment that is also made in the United States. Some executives speculate that because export control enforcement has historically been lax in Japan, it is possible that the companies determined that there was little risk of detection. **********Japanese news reports say Japan Aviation sold its goods to Hierax, which in turn sent them to a firm in Singapore. Aero Systems' annual report, filed recently with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington, indicates that it sold an unnamed subsidiary in Hong Kong, which it said dealt in "general consumer products manufactured in the Far East." **********Officials of Japan Aviation and Aero Systems have refused to comment. "We are simply not answering any inquiries about this," a woman in the office of Robert G. Holmes Jr., Aero System's president, said by telephone.  Relations With Honeywell **********Almost all of Japan Aviation's gyroscopes and inertial navigation equipment are produced under a license from Honeywell Inc. The relationship between the companies goes back more than a decade, and at one point they considered a venture in Japan. But there is no evidence that Honeywell was aware of the transactions. **********Japan Aviation is the largest maker of aviation electronics here, with sales of nearly half-a-billion dollars annually. More than 40 percent of its equipment is purchased by the Japanese military and the country's civilian space program. The firm's top executives, many of whom are drawn from NEC, are said to have strong links to the Japanese military establishment. **********Military budgets are slowing in Japan, and the company's competitors say it is possible that the concern felt pressure to find customers outside of Japan. That would be permissible under Japanese law, as long as the equipment is destined for civilian uses, like commercial airliners. "We are guessing that Japan Aviation wanted to expand its market in Southeast Asia through Aero Systems," a Japanese official said. "And then they were seduced to deal with Iran." **********In one case -- the shipment of small "flywheels" that help stabilize the flight of Sidewinder missiles -- officials say employees of Japan Aviation must have known how the equipment would be used. That shipment, in 1989, may be the only one that goes to court. The statute of limitations may have run out on previous transactions. Until the Toshiba scandal, Japan's statute of limitations on export-control violations was three years; it has since been extended to five.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/01/busin.main_headline: Foreign Stocks Gain, But U.S. Investors Lag
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/01/busin.print_headline: Foreign Stocks Gain, But U.S. Investors Lag
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/01/busin.body_text: **********It was a good quarter for investors in foreign stock markets. But it was not so good for Americans. **********Mexico's bourse again led the pack, rising 36.9 percent in local currency, and continuing its recent dominance of world market performance. And stock markets in Europe, even with a relatively weak performance by Germany, outperformed Wall Street, according to the Financial Times index of world markets. European markets rose 15.4 percent, compared with a 14.1 percent rise in the United States. The Tokyo market was up 13 percent in local currency. **********At the same time, the dollar's rally of the last seven weeks cut into the gains of American investors, especially in Europe. Only in markets where the local currency is tied closely to the dollar or follows it, like Mexico, Hong Kong and Singapore, were investors spared this sharp reduction when gains were converted back into dollars. In dollar terms, Europe's local gain was cut to 3.3 percent and Japan's to 9.1 percent. But Mexico slipped to only 35.2 percent. **********The victory in the Persian Gulf war was the common support for all markets. And the hope for an imminent economic recovery in the United States gave a push to Wall Street that seemed to move other markets around the world. Stock markets like France, Spain and Britain also benefited from actual and expected cuts in interest rates.  Gyrations in the Markets **********Some gyrations in the markets were the product of sudden shifts in focus. One day investors would look beyond recessions or economic slowdowns in many countries to recoveries. Then on the next day, a set of disappointing earnings would return them to the bad news of the moment. **********Germany, where the Financial Times index rose 7.7 percent in marks, was the weakest performer of the major stock markets. For Americans, the dollar's rally turned the modest gain into a 5.2 percent loss. While the Frankfurt market rallied on the war victory, thoughts in Germany quickly turned to the growing economic problems in the former East Germany: rising unemployment and political protests. There is even the possibility now that the German central bank, the Bundesbank, could move to raise interest rates again because of the sharp fall of the mark against the dollar. **********After Mexico, which continues to benefit from the opening up of its economy and the possibility of a free-trade zone with the United States, Hong Kong, up 24.8 percent in dollars, and Singapore, up 22.3 percent, were the top performers. Hong Kong has been one of the hottest markets all year. Investment managers plucked what they saw as good values in a market they said was somewhat insulated from the confrontation in the gulf. Singapore also benefited from investors who chose it for its good values and potential growth this year. **********The surprise of the quarter was Sweden, a market that many managers were shying away from at the end of last year. But a decline in interest rates, a credible Government budget proposal packed with spending cuts and the victory in the war helped push the market up 17.2 percent in dollar terms.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/01/busin.body_text: **********The price of the common shares of the LTV Corporation jumped today in heavy trading in the wake of reports earlier in the week that LTV might find a way out of bankruptcy. **********LTV was the most active issue today on the New York Stock Exchange, with 4.4 million shares traded. The shares rose by 75 cents, to $2.375, a gain of 46.2 percent. At the same time, however, most LTV bonds remained deeply discounted, nearly 20 cents for every dollar of face value. LTV has been in bankruptcy reorganization for nearly five years. **********Jay R. Lustig, bond analyst at Drake Capital Securities, in Santa Monica, Calif., said many speculators had sold LTV shares short in recent months because they believed the company would eventually be forced into liquidation and that its common shares would have little or no value. **********But this week's reports caused many investors to reclaim shares they had lent to the short-sellers, Mr. Lustig said. The short-sellers would then have been forced to buy LTV shares in the open market to cover their positions, he added. **********LTV said on Tuesday that it had reached a tentative agreement with the Federal Government on how LTV would replenish three pension plans that were underfunded by more than $1.5 billion. Few details of the agreement were presented today before Judge Burton R. Lifland of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, according a company spokesman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/15/busin.print_headline: Moving Fast to Protect Ozone Layer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/15/busin.body_text: **********The nation's leading electronics companies are moving more rapidly than they expected to phase out the use of industrial cleansers that damage the earth's protective ozone layer. **********Only a few years ago, the companies predicted that no suitable substitute could be found for the chemicals, known as chlorofluorocarbons, used in the vital process of cleaning circuit boards and sensitive electronic components. But to their surprise, they have developed alternatives -- including warm, soapy water -- that in some cases are better and less expensive than CFC's. Some companies have revamped their manufacturing methods to produce circuit boards that need no cleaning at all. **********Environmentalists say the rapid progress demonstrates how unfounded the industry's complaints about the burden of environmental regulations can be. They say the CFC experience shows what can happen when companies stop fighting environmental measures and instead seek to carry them out. **********"This is just another example of how when push comes to shove, you can get beyond the first line of defense," said Ted Smith, the executive director of the Silicon Valley Toxics Coalition, a group that monitors pollution by electronics companies here. "For all the moaning that went on, it really has not been a significant technical problem." **********David Doniger, the senior lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group, said the CFC example had important implications for other concerns, including how much time the industry should have to reduce fossil-fuel use, which contributes to global warming. Environmentalists cite other examples, such as the elimination of CFC from aerosol cans and the formulation of cleaner gasolines. **********Industry executives are divided on whether other environmental goals can be met as readily as the phasing out of CFC's. But some say that with sufficient determination industry can indeed solve other problems. "If the Federal Government set a goal that there would be no fossil fuels sold by 1994, I bet you we would see electric cars by then," said George Allen, the chemist in charge of CFC reduction at Apple Computer Inc. **********The electronics industry's progress is most evident at the International Business Machines Corporation's sprawling disk drive factory here, which in 1987 was the nation's largest source of CFC-113 emissions. The chemical is the main type of chlorofluorocarbon used by the industry. **********I.B.M. said this week that its CFC-113 emissions at the San Jose plant last year were 95 percent below the 1987 level. Officials here also hope they can eliminate the solvent's use by the end of the year, two years ahead of the corporate target date.  High-Tech Car Wash **********I.B.M., which is based in Armonk, N.Y., is replacing chlorofluorocarbons with, of all things, water. In the plant, disk-drive components are dipped in soapy water and are then carried by a moving track through various bays, where they are rinsed and dried with hot air in what resembles a miniature car wash. **********"Some of the things we thought would be really big problems in 1987 turned out to not be such big problems," said June J. Andersen, the plant's manager of environmental programs. "It's hard to imagine in 1991, but in 1987 this was a hotly debated issue of whether you could water-clean the parts." **********Other large companies, including the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Northern Telecom, the Digital Equipment Corporation and Apple, have said they will eliminate CFC's by no later than 1994.  Other Problems Remain **********But some experts say problems remain. Many smaller companies have not yet taken action, for lack of money or interest. Military contractors have not moved as fast as commercial computer and telephone companies, saying that regulations gave them less freedom to alter their production processes. **********"The speed at which the industry as a whole is converting is not the same as those big-name, high-profile companies," said Mr. Doniger of the Natural Resources Defense Council. He added that the electronics industry was moving faster than expected. **********Chlorofluorocarbons have been linked to the deterioration of the ozone layer, which in turn is expected to lead to a sharp rise in certain types of cancer. In an accord reached in Montreal in 1987 and since amended, many nations agreed to eliminate the use of CFC's by the year 2000.  A Big User of CFC's **********The electronics industry accounts for about 20 percent of the use of CFC's in the United States. The largest use, accounting for about 40 percent of consumption, is in air-conditioners and refrigerators. Another primary use is in making foam for insulation and food packaging. **********The executives say all the industries that use CFC's are reconsidering their statements about how hard it would be to eliminate the chemicals. "Our views have changed on how quickly it could be done," said Kevin Fay, the executive director of the Alliance for Responsible CFC Policy, an ndustry lobbying group. **********He said that makers of refrigerators, air-conditioners and foam insulation were shifting toward alternatives, though in some cases these are other fluorocarbon-based chemicals less harmful to the ozone layer than the ones they replace.  Du Pont's Prediction **********But the electronics industry's progress has been particularly fast -- especially considering that a few years ago, an expert at Du Pont, the leading manufacturer of CFC's, predicted that CFC-113 would be the most difficult type to replace. **********CFC-113 is mainly used to clean printed circuit boards of the residue that remains after chips and other components are soldered on. The residue can cause corrosion, leading to a breakdown of the computer. **********Such cleaning is becoming more important, and more difficult, as the industry develops more complex products. Chlorofluorocarbons not only cleaned all the nooks and crannies well, it was also non-toxic, nonflammable and inexpensive. **********While Du Pont and others have developed some alternatives to CFC-113, many electronics companies have not waited. Some use water to clean components, while others have turned to a solvent made from terpenes, chemicals that are extracted from orange rinds.  Modifying the Process **********And other companies, like Northern Telecom and Apple Computer, are modifying their soldering process so that circuit boards do not have to be cleaned at all. This not only eliminates CFC's but also saves a step in manufacturing, and eliminates the need for water and for waste-water disposal, which are drawbacks of the other approaches. **********"When you go to an electronics conference today, people complain that there are so many choices, not that they don't know what to do," said Stephen Andersen, an official of the Environmental Protection Agency who works with electronics companies. "That's a real turnaround from when they were saying 'Goodbye computers.' " **********The industry executives say that cleaning processes must be tailored for each product or assembly line and that no CFC substitutes have been found for some areas. "There is no one magic drop-in solution," said David R. Chittick, A.T.& T.'s vice president for environment and safety. The telephone company is aiming to end its use of CFC's by 1994.  Just as Good, Even Better **********The executives say that in some cases the alternatives clean as well as CFC's or even better. And in some cases, the alternatives are also less expensive, although there can be high initial costs. **********"We've shortened the process, gotten better-quality boards; it's been more helpful to the environmnet, and we've saved money," said Margaret G. Kerr, the vice president of health and safety for Northern Telecom. The Canadian telecommunications equipment manufacturer has pledged to eliminate CFC's by the end of the year, earlier than most companies. **********A I.B.M. spokesman said the company was expected to have spent about $100 million in capital and personnel costs by 1993, its target for eliminating CFC's from its plants worldwide. He said I.B.M. did not expect to save money over all. But at the San Jose plant, Dr. Andersen said she expected savings to pay for the cost of new cleaning equipment in three years.  Reasons for Progress **********There are several reasons for the electronic industry's progress. It is used to rapid change because of technological advances. A Federal tax that has more than doubled the price of CFC's is scheduled to keep rising. And some environmentalists speculate that the industry, which has generally enjoyed a reputation as nonpolluting, was growing uncomfortable being blamed for contributing to ozone destruction. **********But the industry executives say the secret was to consider the goal a challenge, like developing a new product, rather than merely doing the minimum to comply with guidelines. **********"I've never seen a project with this level of grass-roots motivation by the engineering team," said Dr. Andersen of I.B.M. "They got convinced that this was the right thing to do."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/05/busin.main_headline: Patents; Circuit Could Help Computers Mimic Brain
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/05/busin.print_headline: Patents; Circuit Could Help Computers Mimic Brain
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/05/busin.body_text: **********In pursuit of a "neural network" computing system that mimics the human brain, researchers at a California company have patented a new circuit that could serve as an important building block for computers that teach themselves to recognize patterns and images. **********To recognize an image, a computer must make sense of millions of bits of data that stream through a vast number of tiny receptors. Conventional computers try to match patterns of incoming signals with patterns stored in their memories. **********Neural network systems, however, respond to particular patterns in particular ways. The processors send electrical signals, and the computer "rewards" processors that contribute to "correct" responses by increasing the strength of their signals and decreasing the strength of signals from processors that contribute to "incorrect" responses. **********Toward this goal, researchers at Synaptics Inc. of San Jose, Calif., have patented a refinement on what is known as a "winner take all" circuit. First developed by John Lazzaro, a scientist at the University of Colorado, the winner-take-all circuit is something of a gatekeeper that instantly selects the strongest signal from the array of different processors, or neurons, relying on basic principles of physics. **********"It's an amazingly clever circuit," said Timothy P. Allen, a researcher at Synaptics. "The problem comes when you actually go to do it." In a working computer, he said, the electronic neurons are so small that they cannot be made with perfect uniformity. As a result, signals can be biased. **********The new patent, therefore, describes a method for continuously recalibrating the neurons. In essence, the computer tests itself against a reference pattern and then offsets the bias of each individual neuron by giving added weight to those that are weak and discounting those that are overly sensitive. Mr. Allen said the calibration could be done almost instantly, so the computer could readjust itself almost continuously to remain accurate. **********Mr. Allen and Carver A. Mead, chairman and co-founder of Synaptics, received patent 5,049,758.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/21/busin.main_headline: Market Place; A Backwater's Quiet Rewards
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/21/busin.print_headline: Market Place; A Backwater's Quiet Rewards
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/21/busin.body_text: **********DISTRIBUTORS of semiconductors and other electronic components, long regarded on Wall Street as a backwater of the electronics sector, have been quietly rewarding investors this year. **********Avnet Inc., the longtime industry leader, has failed to hang on to most of its sharp gain early in the year, but several of its competitors, led by Arrow Electronics Inc., have fared far better. **********Analysts are split on whether the signs of strength should be interpreted by investors as a portent of even better things to come. Some, like Richard O. Rieger of Ladenburg, Thalmann, dismiss most of the distributors as "uninteresting" companies in an extremely competitive business. "These guys are making less money on much larger revenues than in the early 1980's," Mr. Rieger said. **********True, say others, but the industry has gone through plenty of consolidation since earnings and share prices crashed in the mid-1980's. Some 25 companies have left the business. Most recently, Arrow acquired the North American and European operations of Lex Services P.L.C., a British company that had often been an instigator of costly price wars. "I think we are close to equilibrium again," said Mark Hassenberg, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "If you get some increase in sales volume," he said of the distributor sector, "you will get strong earnings growth." **********Arrow has been the sector's star, with its shares rising on the Big Boad from $3.625 last January to $16 earlier this month. It closed yesterday at $14. The company, based in Melville, L.I., is heavily indebted, having relied on junk bonds to finance its expansion during the 1980's. But Wall Street was impressed with its smooth absorption of its rival Kierulff, acquired four years ago. The betting is that Arrow can do the same with Lex. **********The biggest unknowns are how quickly Arrow can eliminate overlap between its operations and Lex's and how much business the combined company can retain. Some customers who bought from both companies are likely to shift part of their purchasing elsewhere to make sure they have multiple sources of supplies. And some major chip makers may also look for a second distributor. **********Mr. Hassenberg estimates that Arrow will achieve nearly $1.36 billion in revenues in 1992, assuming $130 million less in sales than if Arrow and Lex hold on to all their business. He says the company, with Lex, has overtaken Avnet in total electronic component sales, and is still undervalued. He predicts that the stock will move into the high teens, at which point Arrow will issue new stock to pay down its high-cost debts. And he says the stock could top $30 within 18 months if the economy begins to recover. **********But others say the combined company could lose several hundred million dollars of its current business. And Clarke Walser, who follows the industry for Hamilton Investments in Chicago, said that the Lex's value to Arrow was harder to assess than the Kierulff acquisition because Lex involved overseas operations and more customer overlap. "There's not much margin for error in the current price," Mr. Walser said. **********Analysts say that Avnet's strongest selling points are a healthy balance sheet and the investment it has made in modernizing its distribution system. But the Great Neck, L.I., based company needs more sales volume for those investments to pay off. Most rate the company a hold at $24.875, its close yesterday on the Big Board. In early February it was over $29. **********Perhaps the most admired company in the group at the moment is Anthem Electronics Inc., a specialty distributor that concentrates on higher-priced components. Anthem, based in San Jose, Calif., is also cited as an example of the trend among distributors to raise earnings with value-added services like assembling components or programming memory circuits before delivery. **********Even Mr. Rieger has a buy recommendation on the company. Anthem's shares jumped from $15.75, in early January to $35 over the next three months, then bounced down as far as $27.625 by Oct. 7 and subsequently rallied. It closed yesterday at $33.375 a share on the Big Board. **********Marshall Industries, the one major distributor handling Japanese semiconductors, has had a bumpier ride but closed yesterday at $24.50, up more than 20 percent from its January levels. Two smaller distributors also listed on the Big Board, Wyle Laboratories and Bell Industries, have been less successful. Wyle, based in El Segundo, Calif., rose sharply last winter to a peak of $17 in April but finished trading yesterday at $11, down slightly from its price at the beginning of the year. Los Angeles-based Bell is down from $13.625 at the beginning of the year to $9.75 in yesterday's trading, but Leonard Goldberg, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody, says its prospects are looking up as it expands to the East Coast from its Southern California base. **********Mr. Goldberg sees the whole group as "a less painful way to play the semiconductor cycle" than the semiconductor companies themselves. The stocks have relatively few shares outstanding, he said, but they typically move less dramatically than those of the chip makers.
