https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/01/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; No Madge or Manicures In Palmolive Campaign
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/01/busin.body_text: **********Madge the manicurist, the advertising character who has touted Palmolive dishwashing liquid for more than two decades, may no longer be surprising customers with her trademark line, "You're soaking in it." **********For the first time since the character appeared, the Colgate-Palmolive Company and its agency, FCB/Leber Katz Partners, New York, is introducing a significant campaign without her. The new theme, "You cook, we clean," emphasizes Palmolive's cleaning strength, said Robert A. Murray, a company spokesman, instead of featuring the actress Jan Miner as Madge, talking about how gentle the liquid can be on hands. **********Mr. Murray confirmed a report in this week's issue of Adweek, the trade publication, that Colgate had not decided whether to bring Madge back in future campaigns. Madge's fame has grown beyond Palmolive; a humorous television commercial by Della Femina, McNamee Inc. for A&W soft drinks shows Ms. Miner, as Madge, soaking her fingers in a glass of A&W.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; MGM Grand Sells Casino to Tracinda
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/24/busin.body_text: **********After spending two months searching for a higher bidder, MGM Grand Inc. said today that it had sold its Desert Inn Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas for $130 million to the Tracinda Corporation. Tracinda is owned by the investor Kirk Kerkorian, who also owns 86 percent of MGM Grand. **********Mr. Kerkorian, who is on the board but is not an officer of MGM Grand, made an opening bid of $130 million for the hotel. MGM Grand and Bear, Stearns & Company then spent two months searching for a better price, including talking to 300 potential bidders but did not find a better deal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/busin.main_headline: American Airlines Begins Round Of Discounts to Encourage Travel
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/busin.print_headline: American Airlines Begins Round Of Discounts to Encourage Travel
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/busin.body_text: **********American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier and the airline that is considered a leader in determining fares, initiated a broad range of price cuts yesterday in the hope of attracting travelers put off by the gulf war and the recession. But it also raised some fares in an attempt to compensate for revenue lost through the many reductions. **********American introduced a number of short-term promotions like a $318 round-trip fare between New York and Los Angeles or San Francisco, and the other four biggest airlines -- United, Delta, Northwest and Continental -- said they would match most of them. **********But American went beyond these special offers, altering its pricing structure and hoping the industry will follow. The airline, which along with its competitors had spent two years trying to simplify the fare structure and eliminate many discount rates, is now seeking to reverse that trend. It has brought back the 30-day advanced-purchase fare, which until it was phased out two years ago had been the lowest fare available to travelers. It also added new discount fares aimed at the business traveler. And it is substantially cutting the price of some international tickets.  14-Day Fares to Rise **********But while American revived the 30-day discount fare, it will significantly raise its 14-day advance purchase fares, which have been particularly popular with leisure travelers. The carrier also announced that more of its lowest discount fares will now require travel between noon Monday and noon Thursday, the days when the most seats are available industrywide. The goal is to try to prevent discount passengers from taking away too many seats from higher-fare passengers. American also said it would limit the number of lowest-fare seats that it makes available. **********To these changes, the other major carriers reacted cautiously, saying they needed to study them. **********American will revive the 30-day advance-purchase fare on April 9, after its short-term promotions end. The 30-day fares will for the most part be somewhat lower than the best fares now available except for the short-term offers. For example, a round trip between New York and Los Angeles on weekdays will cost $468 if bought 30 days in advance and on weekends, $518. **********The current 14-day rate on weekdays is $504 and on weekends, $554. But the 14-day fare between these cities will rise to $558 on weekdays, and to $608 on weekends. **********Michael W. Gunn, senior vice president of marketing at American, said the 30-day advance-purchase fare would be the lowest discount fare in the market -- about 8 to 10 percent below the current 14-day fares and from $60 to $90 a round trip below the new, lower 14-day fares. Low Prices Until April 8 **********The savings on the short-term offer are more substantial. For example, the round-trip fare from New York to San Francisco, which was $504 on weekdays on a ticket bought at least 14 days before traveling, will fall to $318 for travel during the spring and to $398 for travel during the summer, as long as the ticket is bought by April 8. The new fare must be purchased seven days in advance, is not refundable and requires a Saturday-night stay. **********American is also trying to respond to the growing resistance of business travelers to pay full coach fares, which have risen substantially in recent years. **********For the short term, it matched Delta's offer of 20 percent off regular coach fare if the trip is booked three days in advance. **********For tickets bought after April 9. American has proposed a seven-day advance purchase fare aimed at business travelers that would have a 25 percent cancellation penalty.  Discounts to Europe **********American is also offering lower fares to Europe, Japan, Hong Kong, Australia and New Zealand. Travel from New York to various European destinations, for example, would be $598 round trip during the peak travel period after June 1, which is 29 to 32 percent lower than the current Eurosaver fare, the main discount fare in the market. **********Some analysts would not characterize American's moves as the beginning of a fare war, because they were not aimed at gaining share in a particular market or against another carrier. Instead, they said, the strategy was broadly aimed at stimulating weak traffic. **********Mr. Gunn said the fare restructuring was intended to encourage people to make their summer reservations early.  Profits Are Expected **********Kevin Murphy, an airline analyst for Morgan Stanley, said the fares would not cut too deeply into the industry's revenues because fares have been driven upward by about 15 percent by a series of fuel surchages since last August. He added that there had also been significant fare increases before then. **********Mr. Murphy said that because of the increases the industry had room to cut and still keep fares high enough to make a profit. **********The industry has been helped recently by a drop in fuel prices to about 70 cents a gallon, from well over $1 last fall. Traffic has also showed signs of recovering now that the Persian Gulf crisis has been resolved although it is still far below normal. **********On the other hand, the carriers have been taking delivery of a large number of new planes and need to bring in more passengers to fill up the new capacity. **********American is preparing to take over the London routes of Trans World Airlines, pending approval from government agencies, and is trying to restore the confidence of travelers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/08/busin.main_headline: Seeking to Stay Out of Proxy Battles
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/08/busin.print_headline: Seeking to Stay Out of Proxy Battles
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/08/busin.body_text: **********Dozens of companies that want to avoid messy proxy battles are quietly accepting the demands of pension funds to lower their takeover defenses and broaden the rights of shareholders. **********The K Mart Corporation has agreed to seek shareholder approval next month to phase out its "poison pill" takeover defenses within four years. **********Avon Products Inc. and Sears, Roebuck & Company have agreed to meet regularly with a shareholder advisory group. The Boise Cascade Corporation revised its rules to give dissident shareholder proposals a better chance of passing. **********Other companies have instituted confidential shareholder voting and eliminated "golden parachutes" that benefit executives in the event of a takeover. **********Many companies are now giving in to stave off shareholder votes that threaten less favorable results, and to develop loyal shareholder followings that can help fend off takeovers. **********The growing sophistication of institutional investors, whose holdings have increased to more than half the stock in American corporations, has also recently made companies more responsive. Public employee pension funds, once passive, have learned how to rally other shareholders. **********"It makes absolutely no sense for a corporation to act in a hostile manner against its shareholders," said Owen F. Knauer, head of investor relations at K Mart. "I don't think large corporations have had much experience with this type of relationship. But our view was: 'Why go through a hassle with a major shareholder? Why not talk things out.' " **********At K Mart, the State of Wisconsin Investment Board submitted a 1990 proxy proposal asking that important takeover defenses require approval by shareholders, not just the board. The measure failed, getting a majority of shares voted but not the required majority of all shares. Subsequent talks yielded the plan that K Mart will present to shareholders next month. **********The Wisconsin fund, with $20 billion, and the California Public Employees Retirement System, known as Calpers, with $61 billion, are the most prominent among those putting pressure on executives and boards to heed shareholder views. **********The United Shareholders Association, a group founded by T. Boone Pickens, the corporate raider, to represent smaller investors, has successfully pursued the same sorts of issues as the pension funds. **********Many companies are now making concessions on issues that public employee funds have pursued for years. Cheaper to Talk **********"We are seeing the early stages of what will be very, very healthy dialogues," said Howard Sherman, a vice president at Institutional Shareholders Services Inc., a Washington proxy advisory firm. "The two sides are looking to find some common ground and a partnership." **********The funds often take aim at poorly performing corporations on the notion that as corporate governance improves, so will performance. Corporations facing a hostile attack are often the most willing to talk. **********Companies find it a lot cheaper to keep big shareholders happy than to protect themselves by finding new, friendly investors. **********"If you take this to the logical conclusion, a corporation can create a class of patient investors through dialogue and not have to resort to the exorbitant prices of private placements and white squires," said Mr. Sherman of Institutional Shareholders Services. "This, in turn, can lower a company's cost of capital and increase profitability." **********Richard Koppes, general counsel for the California employees fund, said the decline in hostile takeovers has actually enhanced the pension funds' influence at many companies. "Things are just snowballing," he said. " The raiders are gone because the money is not there and the power is now in the votes." **********Not all companies, however, are eager to cooperate. "There are still some hard-core boards and C.E.O.'s who have that old Victorian feeling that shareholders should be seen and not heard," said John C. Wilcox, managing director at Georgeson & Company, a New York proxy solicitation firm. "There are still many directors that grew up when shareholders were passive and trusting, and that's no longer the case." **********The Wisconsin Investment Board has filed proxy proposals after failing to convince Pfizer Inc., the United Technologies Corporation and United Telecommunications Inc. to alter their poison pill provisions. The California fund has failed to reach agreements with Hercules Inc., the Northrop Corporation, the Scott Paper Company and the Whirlpool Corporation on a number of issues. **********But the successes are signficant. At Avon, which was recently under attack by a major shareholder, Chartwell Associates, that wanted greater board representation, James E. Preston, Avon's chairman, conferred closely with executives of the California fund. The fund had failed last year to win approval for a proxy proposal seeking a shareholder advisory committee. This year, as the fund prepared to offer the proposal again, Avon agreed to a less formal arrangement, holding semi-annual meetings with several public and corporate pension funds. **********"Boards are now more willing to engage in constructive dialogue with these groups," said W. Thomas Knight, an Avon senior vice president. "We've been through this slavish process of cleaning up our balance sheet and restoring our core business to health and we want to reach out to our owners." Meeting With Shareholders **********At Sears, Edward A. Brennan, the chief executive, pledged to meet with managers of the California fund twice a year after the fund agreed to drop a proxy proposal calling for a nine-member committee to advise the corporate board. "We're always willing to meet with individual large shareholders," said David Shute, Sears's general counsel. **********Boise Cascade accepted a proposal from the California fund that failed in a proxy vote last year. The fund wanted shares not voting to be eliminated from any proxy tallies; the board had counted them as "no" votes. When Boise's chief executive, John B. Fery went to meet with the fund's managers in California after the measure's consideration last year, he "told us it made a lot of sense to him," said Mr. Koppes, the fund's lawyer. **********Vincent Hannity, the Boise director of investor relations, said the company wanted to avoid another battle over the proposal this year. "If there is any way to resolve proxy issues without submitting them to shareholders, we'd prefer to do it that way," he said. "Whenever you take a formal public position, you will have people taking the opposite position and then you have a fight on your hands." **********Shareholder groups besides the pension funds are also exerting pressure. United Shareholders has gained agreements from Baxter International Inc., Consolidated Freightways Inc., the General Signal Corporation, the Unisys Corporation and the Weyerhaeuser Company for confidential voting and the elimination of golden parachutes. Some companies make changes to remove themselves from United Shareholders' Target 50 list of companies said to have poor records on shareholders rights. **********"Five years ago, we couldn't get a phone call returned," said Ralph V. Whitworth, president of United Shareholders, based in Washington . "Now a lot of companies don't want to take proxies to a vote because it could cast a disparaging light on management. So they'd rather deal with us."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/03/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev offered words of welcome today to the new opposition political movement founded by some veterans of his Kremlin team, with his spokesman saying that "it inspires cooperation" from supporters of his liberalization program. **********The new Democratic Reform Movement "can only be welcomed" provided it lives up to its premise of avoiding divisiveness, said the spokesman, Vitaly N. Ignatenko. Mr. Ignatenko added that by stressing cooperation and social accord rather than confrontation, the movement was "a positive fact." **********The brief comments of oblique blessing at the Foreign Ministry only further teased the question of where Mr. Gorbachev stands in regard to the new movement's attempt to build a counterbalance to the Communists and whether he might even some day carry out his oft-repeated threat to quit as leader of the Communist Party. **********"Gorbachev will remain leader of the Communist Party as long as he considers it necessary," Mr. Ignatenko said, denying that the Soviet leader would soon resign. **********He said that Mr. Gorbachev, who has longstanding ties to several of the movement's founders, was aware of the progress of the opposition plan in recent weeks. "He knew what ideas these comrades had because he had regular business dealings with the people," Mr. Ignatenko said. "But he could not be an adviser." **********The organizers of the new group began their task of building a nationwide challenge to the long-entrenched Communist Party. **********"At the first stage, some amorphousness is inevitable," said Mayor Anatoly A. Sobchak of Leningrad, one of the founders. **********He spoke at a news conference at Moscow's city hall in which he and other organizers stressed that this troubled nation can afford no further delay in constructing a party to stand against the Communists nationwide and prevent a return to dictatorship. **********"Such a threat exists in reality and one purpose of our movement is not to allow a return to that past," said former Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who quit the Gorbachev team last winter with a warning about the threat of totalitarianism's return.  Ruling Party Is Denounced **********As the movement organizers tried to field questions about the difficulties of uniting the nation's already considerably splintered and quarrelsome opposition factions, Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, for years one of Mr. Gorbachev's closest advisers, offered some fiery philosophy describing the underpinnings of the movement in a newspaper essay entitled "A New Step Is Necessary." **********"The Communist Party apparatus is incapable of listening to the voice of reason and taking a sober look at life around it," Mr. Yakovlev wrote in the Government newspaper Izvestia. The article included a furious indictment of hard-line Communists as untalented idlers and egotists who he said had been busy lately "eagerly inserting sticks into the wheels of transformation." **********Mr. Yakovlev, a quiet backstage politician, surprised many people here by joining the new movement. He was not present at the news conference. **********A career Communist who has recently stressed his right to quit the party, Mr. Yakovlev wrote in the article: "We must not be hypocritical and honestly admit that the democratic rebirth of the Comninist Party, s s eaeaki w witdidictatoripip'sasast anitittrtranorormation inta a capable lilicaororganization has not tenenlalace. Threrevoluti i in soetethahas not led to a revolution in the party." **********"The party apparatus at all levels is rushing to mobilize party members against democratic reforms, against economic and political freedoms," he wrote. **********The announced strategy of the new opposition movement is to unite insurgents and others, wooing wayward Communist Party members by not being confrontational. Mr. Shevardnadze said he favored the creation of a full-fledged party for this task, one that, if plans proceed well, might be created as soon as the movement's inaugural conference, planned for mid-September.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/busin.body_text: **********The Federal deficit grew by $7.4 billion in December, swelling to $87 billion for the first three months of the 1991 fiscal year, the Treasury Department said today. **********Many analysts had expected a far bigger deficit in December because of expenditures for the Persian Gulf operation and the savings and loan bailout and because of the sluggish economy. But last month's gap was only half as large as the $14.8 billion deficit in December 1989. **********The Government did spend $2.7 billion on the savings and loan bailout in December, more than double the amount spent in December 1989. But military spending fell 9.3 percent, to $25.2 billion. Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets said the Persian Gulf buildup was nearly completed by December. **********Individual income tax receipts were up 24 percent, to $46.5 billion, and corporate tax receipts increased 19 percent, to $22.5 billion. **********The deficit for the first quarter of the 1991 fiscal year was 23 percent larger than a year earlier. Total receipts were up 10.9 percent, to $253.8 billion, while outlays rose 13.8 percent, to $340.7 billion. **********The Bush Administration has acknowledged that the 1991 deficit will set a record. The budget director, Richard Darman, has projected the imbalance at $250 billion to $300 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Intel Planning New Products
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/11/busin.body_text: **********The Intel Corporation, entering a new business, is making a big push into selling products to help connect personal computers into networks. At a news conference here on Wednesday, the company will introduce three families of products to help manage networks and help personal computers communicate. **********Intel, the leading provider of central control chips for personal computers, already makes chips for networking that it sells to computer companies. But the new products will be sold to computer users for use in connecting into networks the millions of personal computers already in use. **********The products include circuit boards to connect computers to networks, tools for managing complex networks, and products to allow computers on a network to send and receive faxes. Intel hopes its size will help it capture a large part of these businesses, which are now the domain of 3Com, Western Digital and other smaller suppliers. **********Andrew Grove, Intel's president and chief executive, said the company hoped its entry into the business would "grease the skids" by making it easier to build and manage networks. Such networks would lead to new uses of computers and in turn, to greater sales of computers and of Intel microprocessors. **********Intel's shares rose 75 cents today, to $47.75, in over-the- counter trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/01/world.main_headline: U.S. Says Iraqis' Uranium Is Still Enough for One Bomb
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/01/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; U.S. Says Iraqis' Uranium Is Still Enough for One Bomb
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/01/world.body_text: **********Despite the intensive allied bombing of Iraq's strategic military sites, Iraq still has enough undamaged weapons-grade uranium to make one nuclear bomb, according to Administration officials and scientists who reviewed an Iraqi letter delivered to the United Nations that details its nuclear holdings. **********"The principal purpose of bombing the nuclear sites was to destroy their fuel, which this document proves was not achieved," said Leonard S. Spector, a nonproliferation analyst and author at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. **********The letter, delivered to the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency on Monday, also shows that at least some of Iraq's critical stockpile of potentially weapon grade fuel had been moved from the country's main nuclear installation at Tuwaitha near Baghdad to an undisclosed site for reasons of safety. **********Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, American commander of the coalition forces in the Persian Gulf war, said in late January that warplanes "have neutralized their manufacturing capabilities, their nuclear manufacturing capability." Officials Pleased With Response **********The Iraqi letter said that nuclear material was shifted during the war from locations known to the International Atomic Energy Agency to "nearby locations, thus avoiding the possibility of a nuclear accident and any risks including radiation contamination." **********Bush Administration and agency officials said they were pleased with the Iraqi response, which followed an earlier letter that was considered insufficient. On April 18, when the Iraqis sent an inventory of all of its weapons of mass destruction to the United Nations as required by the Security Council cease-fire resolution, they denied having nuclear arms or nuclear weapons-grade material. **********Most Western analysts said before the war that Iraq still faced technical problems in developing nuclear weapons and that even with sufficient enriched uranium, it would take Baghdad 5 to 10 years to build and deploy nuclear warheads. **********The latest Iraqi letter informed the United Nations agency based in Vienna that some of the nuclear material that was not hidden away was buried under the rubble of the bombed reactors but the Iraqis asserted that there is no evidence of damage to any of the fuel. **********"This is a total capitulation," said one Administration official who is familiar with Iraq's nuclear programs. "The first letter the Iraqis wrote was completly unforthcoming and revealed nothing. The Iraqis have come back with an extraordinarily detailed account of the status, location and amount of all of the enriched material." **********Administration and I.A.E.A. officials also said they were surprised by the number of Iraq's nuclear research installations. "There was building after building that we didn't really know about," said one senior Administration official. "There were a lot of sites that we suspected were engaged in nuclear activity, but just weren't sure." **********According to the document, most of the 24 installations listed, which include a number of research, production and design laboratories, were completely destroyed. **********Under the terms of the cease-fire resolution, all of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction are to be destroyed or removed.  Uranium in Various Forms **********The inventory submitted by Iraq reveals that it received tons of uranium in various forms from previously undisclosed sources. The imports include six tons of depleted uranium from sources, which remain undisclosed and 1.8 tons of lightly enriched uranium, which Adminsitration officials said was sent from Italy more than a decade ago and which was subject to agency safeguards. The lightly enriched uranium could significantly increase the output of weapons-grade uranium from future Iraqi centrifuges. **********The inventory also shows that Iraq possesses more than the 48 pounds of highly enriched uranium obtained from France and the Soviet Union that nonproliferation experts believed to be under I.A.E.A. inspection. **********The inventory confirms the existence of a site at Al Qaim in northwestern Iraq near the Syrian border that produced yellowcake, uranium concentrate that centrifuges can convert to weapons-grade nuclear fuel. Iraq maintained the installation was completely destroyed. **********But there are significant omissions, Administration officials and nuclear nonproliferation experts said. The inventory fails to list nuclear-weapons development laboratories, like Al Qaqaa, which the officials and experts said may have been conducting high explosives research and assembly before the war. It also does not list the Osirak research reactor near Baghdad bombed by Israel in 1981.  Centrifuges Not Mentioned **********Neither does the letter mention any of Iraq's equipment for producing and testing high-speed centrifuges. Centrifuges, machines that extract the uranium isotope usable in nuclear weapons by rapidly spinning uranium gas, are widely regarded as the key to Iraq's future nuclear potential. **********Despite Iraq's attempt to be more forthcoming on identifying weapons of mass destruction, the United States and Britain have taken the lead in the Security Council in opposing the lifting of sanctions against Iraq, and have resisted Iraqi appeals to sell oil on the world market or to be given access to assets frozen in foreign banks. **********In Washington, the White House said today that it would oppose allowing Iraq to sell its oil or gain access to its frozen assets unless Washington were convinced that the Iraqis would use the money for humanitarian purposes. **********"We don't have a lot of confidence in Saddam Hussein," said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, referring to the Iraqi President. Second Letter From Iraq **********Britain and the United States will try to press Iraq to use what they believe are considerable financial assets and gold reserves in its Central Bank to pay for food and medicine, American and British officials said today. **********In a letter two weeks ago, Iraq asked the Security Council's sanctions committee for permission to sell oil abroad in order to buy $942.5 million worth of food, medicine and other civilian items it said were crucial for its population over the next four months. **********On Monday, Iraq's permanent representative, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, delivered a second letter asking the committee to unfreeze $1 billion of its assets in the United States, Switzerland, Britain and Japan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/world.main_headline: Hussein Is Controlling Plans For Ground War, Report Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: IRAQ; Hussein Is Controlling Plans For Ground War, Report Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/world.body_text: **********Hours after Iraqi troops sought to advance into Saudi Arabia, the Baghdad radio reported that President Saddam Hussein had taken personal charge of preparations for a ground offensive. **********The radio said Iraq would "turn the soil of the pure earth into fire" around United States forces. **********The Baghdad radio reported in that Iraqi forces had "moved to teach the aggressors the lessons they deserve." **********"They have launched their lightning land attack, bearing high the banner saying God is great, and crushed the armies of atheism as they advance, routing those who could run away while cursing the infidels," it declared.  Refugees Under Fire **********In the Jordanian Parliament, Foreign Minister Taher el-Masri said that four Jordanians and an Egyptian had been killed in allied air attacks on the highway between the Jordanian border and Baghdad and that nine Jordanian tanker-trucks carrying crude oil had been destroyed. Jordan has sought to enforce parts of the United Nations trade embargo against Iraq, but has said it cannot cut off crude oil supplies from Baghdad, its only source. **********Foreign Minister Masri said he had summoned the Ambassadors of United States and other permanent members of the United Nations Security Council to protest the highway bombings, which have been widely reported by refugees arriving in Jordan. **********On Iraq's border with Jordan today, the Iraqi authorities finally allowed several hundred exhausted Egyptian refugees to flee the country. The fugitives said they had been beaten and starved as they awaited permission to leave the freezing desert frontier post to go to Jordan on their way home. **********Iraq offered no explanation for its treatment of the Egyptians, which is believed to reflect Baghdad's hostility toward Cairo for backing the coalition against Iraq. Baghdad radio referred to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt as a "midget agent" of the Americans. **********Baghdad seemed to loosen its policy on Western coverage of the gulf war and permitted the return of 15 British, French and other West European reporters who had stayed in Baghdad when the war started on Jan. 17 and were later told to leave. **********Iraqi Embassy officials in Amman said no American news organizations would receive visas, leaving CNN as the only American news organization represented in Baghdad. **********In Amman, around 3,000 Jordanians demonstrated in favor of Iraq, burned American and Israeli flags and urged Mr. Hussein to fire chemical weapons at Israel. The demonstration reflected Jordan's tilt toward Baghdad throughout the gulf crisis. **********"O Saddam, hit, hit Tel Aviv!" some chanted. "With chemical weapons, O Saddam!" others replied. Jordan's population is more than half Palestinian, and many have voiced support for the Iraqi leader as a champion who will lead them to statehood. **********Many were thus heartened by the Baghdad radio's account of today's land fighting around the town of Khafji, apparently the first major ground fighting of the war. "O Saddam, from Khafji to Dammam!" they chanted, referring to a Saudi city 200 miles south of the Saudi-Kuwait border. **********Tonight it made no mention of allied accounts saying the push had been mostly repulsed, and it threatened to "turn the soil of the pure earth into fire that will burn the cowardly remnants fleeing in the face of the determination and might of the Iraqis."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/22/busin.main_headline: Make Room For Daddies, Little Goblins
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/22/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Make Room For Daddies, Little Goblins
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/22/busin.body_text: **********THIS Halloween, advertisers anticipate that the ghoulies and ghosties and long-legged beasties will have very long legs, indeed. The reason is that more of those legs are attached to people who are old enough to drive and vote. **********As more grown-ups take part in a holiday once the exclusive province of children, advertisers, always eager to cash in on a consumer trend, are directing more Halloween-themed advertisements at adults. Research by Hallmark Cards Inc. indicates that one adult in three now takes part in Halloween activities. **********A print ad for Hallmark, created by Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago, typifies the trend. Amid photographs of a cryptful of holiday merchandise for adults, from T-shirts to earrings to lapel pins, the headline reads, "This Halloween, why should the little monsters have all the fun?" **********Behind the adult focus to Halloween, said Dan Fox, the executive vice president of Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago, is that "the baby boomers are taking the things of their childhood into adulthood, and they're unwilling to let go." **********The actress Elvira, who has gained popularity for her campy shtick as the "Mistress of the Dark," is featured in a campaign that Foote, Cone has created for Coors Light beer. In a television commercial, after Elvira crowns Coors Light with a made-up designation as "the official beer of Halloween," she changes the word "right" in the brand's slogan, making it "It's the fright beer now." **********Another explanation as to why adults are adopting Halloween as a holiday comes from Sherry S. Timbrook, a spokeswoman for Hallmark, from the company's offices in Kansas City, Mo. "As we become more hectic and more busy," she said, "Halloween is a day when we can escape and be whoever we want to be." **********"No one laughs at you for being silly, or acting out a fantasy," she added. **********Also influencing the trend is the idea that for decades, Halloween has been for an occasion for adults in the gay community to throw parties and stage parades. Like other trends that begin among homosexuals and enter the mainstream, so, too, have adult-oriented Halloween happenings. **********Among other advertisers seeking to appeal to adults at Halloween are the Pillsbury Company, which in magazine ads urges bakers to "Make them a cake so scary, it's scary!"; Anheuser-Busch Inc., which in television spots has a woman dressed as a vampire telling the celebrants at a Halloween party, "I want to drink your Bud"; the First Brands Corporation, which is introducing King Pumpkin and the Pumpkinettes, decorative orange lawn bags with drawn-on pumpkin faces, and the Kellogg Company, which is advertising its Mrs. Smith's pies in newspapers with the slogan "Mom knows witch's best." **********Some Halloween campaigns are meant to appeal to adults and youngsters alike. One television spot, touting Sega of America's new Joe Montana Football sports video game, shows the San Francisco 49ers quarterback in the clutches of a mad scientist. **********"We're primarily selling to teen-age boys, but we know we also have to sell to the moms and the dads," Robert Botch, Sega's marketing director, said of the spot, created by Della Femina, McNamee Inc. in Los Angeles. **********In previous years, the confluence of adult and child interest in Halloween has led to complaints from activist groups, which have contended that adult-oriented Halloween beer ads are actually also aimed at youngsters. **********Though the breweries have denied such charges, elements in their campaigns for 1991 reflect the activists' concerns. **********In the Coors Light spot, Elvira calls the brand "just what an adult party needs to be a howling success." And the Miller Brewing Company is running a Halloween version of its continuing "Think before you drink" campaign, which encourages moderation in drinking; print ads and posters show Frankenstein's monster under the headline "Keep a level head this Halloween." **********For those wondering how advertisers will try to lift their Halloween sales after they garner the adult and child markets, a newspaper ad from the Quaker Oats Company suggests that its Snausages and Pounce pet products make great Halloween treats for dogs and cats.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/30/busin.main_headline: U.S. Notes and Bonds Up in Light Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/30/busin.print_headline: U.S. Notes and Bonds Up in Light Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/30/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose yesterday, and interest rates moved lower. Traders said prices were lifted by rumors of a possible Soviet coup and expectations that a new round of reports will show that the economy remained weak in November. **********Virtually all the price movement occurred during overnight trading in Asia and then later in European financial markets. Activity in the United States was extremely light, as most domestic participants extended their Thanksgiving holiday. Trading in the United States stopped at 1 P.M., New York time. **********Talk about another Soviet coup attempt had the initial effect of pushing up the value of the dollar on foreign exchange markets, and persuaded some investors to seek a haven in short-term Treasury bills. No Economic Recovery Seen **********Treasury securities also benefited from the widespread belief that key economic reports expected next week, including November employment data, scheduled to be released on Friday, will offer little evidence to suggest the recovery is gaining momentum. Many analysts anticipate the data will reinforce worries that the recession has returned. **********A new round of weak economic statistics will probably heighten anxiety in Washington, but credit market participants will not have to worry about further substantive debate on various proposals to stimulate the economy for six weeks or so. **********"The departure of Congress on Wednesday comes as a welcome relief to the market, and may provide some support over the coming week," analysts at MMS International, an economic information and service company, noted in their daily market commentary. Trading in Secondary Market **********In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at the close of trading at a price of 100 25/32, up 3/8 point, to yield 7.93 percent, compared with 7.96 percent late Wednesday and 7.97 percent on Nov. 22. **********Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 29/32, up 1/4 point, to yield 7.36 percent. The new 6.50 percent five-year notes sold earlier this week were offered at 100 3/32, up 6/ 32, to yield 6.47 percent. And the new 5.50 percent two-year notes auctioned on Monday were offered at 100 1/4, up 3/ 32, to yield 5.36 percent. **********Short-term Treasury bill rates moved lower. **********Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 4.34 percent, down 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.38 percent. **********In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Nov. 18. **********The reported gains, particularly the $5.2 billion increase in M-2, the aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, were a bit larger than most analysts had anticipated. But the report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/01/world.main_headline: U.N. Officials Seek Mastermind in Charge of Iraq's Nuclear Effort
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/01/world.print_headline: U.N. Officials Seek Mastermind in Charge of Iraq's Nuclear Effort
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/01/world.body_text: **********The United Nations officials charged with destroying Iraq's nuclear weapons sites are searching for an unidentified "mastermind" who they think had overall charge of President Saddam Hussein's secret nuclear weapons program, estimated to have cost $10 billion. **********The conviction that there must have be an unknown top official, who could have been a foreigner, in command stems from their belief that none of the Iraqi scientists they have met so far appears to have a full grasp of the complex program that involved both production of enriched uranium explosive and attempts to design a weapon. **********In particular, Jaafar Dhiah Jaafar, formally the No. 2 official on the Iraqi Atomic Energy Commission, appears to know only about the attempt to produce enriched uranium, officials say, while his superior, the head of the commission, is regarded as a figurehead. **********A Special Commission set up by the United Nations Security Council to destroy Iraq's weapons of mass destruction has already established that the authorities in Baghdad were seeking to produce enriched uranium by three separate methods. **********Its latest inspection team has also established that Iraq had some kind of a weapons development program under way by unearthing evidence that it was trying to design a nuclear detonation device. **********But as yet no Iraqi official has been found with overall responsibility for both the enrichment and the weapons programs. "Personally I am rather convinced that there must be someone who links the enrichment and the design sides," said Rolf Ekeus of Sweden, the Special Commission's executive chairman. **********[ In New Orleans today President Bush, in terms starkly similar to those he used last year before the invasion of Iraq, warned that he would not tolerate Saddam Hussein defying the United Nations. **********[ "Any aggression, any defiance of the United Nations resolutions now will not stand," Mr. Bush said at a fund-raiser for Gov. Buddy Roemer. "I am just as determined to see he does not succeed." ] **********The United Nations commission's inspectors, to test their theory on an overall director, raided the Iraqi Atomic Energy Commission's records center last Tuesday and took away personnel files of many of the senior people working there. That raid led to their detention for four days by the Iraqi authorities. **********The commission now wants its inspectors to track down these top Iraqi nuclear officials on the team's next visit to Baghdad. **********Last week, the commission barred the team's American members from sending details of seized documents directly to the State Department instead of reporting only to the United Nations. **********Mr. Ekeus said he sent a general order to the team to suspend all contacts with Washington on Wednesday after he discovered American members had been in direct contact with Washington by satellite phone. However, he denied reports that he had reprimanded them.  Most Were Americans **********The team's leader, David Kay, is an American. He was accompanied on the mission by Robert L. Gallucci, the Special Commission's American deputy executive chairman. Altogether, 25 of the 44 team members were Americans, and they included Government scientists with practical experience in nuclear weapons design. **********In particular, officials say that by sending reports directly to the United States Government, the Americans helped bolster the Iraqis'charge that Mr. Kay is a Central Intelligence Agency spy acting under cover of the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency. **********"We very firmly instructed them not to make such contacts but only to report to the Special Commission and the I.A.E.A.," Mr. Ekeus said today. **********Commission officials say that the Americans argued that they were only trying to get the substance of confiscated material out of the country quickly for fear that the Iraqis would take it back by force. **********At a news conference after the team's arrival in Bahrain today, Mr. Kay said that the inspectors had removed a total of 25,000 pages of documents dealing with Iraq's covert nuclear plans as well as 19 hours of videotape and 70 rolls of film used to photograph documents. **********"I think we collected a lot of valuable information" on Iraq's secret nuclear program," he said, adding: **********"You can't help but be impressed by the sophistication of it. You walk around those sites and you shake your head because they are far better than most I've seen." **********He emphasized that the team had uncovered clear evidence, in the form of designs for building a nuclear detonating device, refuting Iraq's claim that it had no interest in developing a nuclear weapon. **********"The emphasis was on uranium enrichment, virtually every known method," Mr. Kay said. "This for a country without a single power plant requiring enriched uranium. That is a major anomaly." **********The team has also brought out records of nuclear material that Iraq purchased for its program from foreign countries and companies. While Mr. Kay refused to give details he said, "It would be very hard for me to understand, with some of the issues of supply, that they did not know they were going to be used in a nuclear program."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/04/busin.main_headline: Nomura Inquiry Reopened Amid Additional Findings
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/04/busin.print_headline: Nomura Inquiry Reopened Amid Additional Findings
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/04/busin.body_text: **********Amid new disclosures of possibly illegal stock market dealings, Japan's Finance Ministry has reopened an investigation of whether the Nomura Securities Company manipulated a stock on behalf of a well-known organized crime figure. The new developments raise the prospect that the brokerage may face serious new penalties. **********Government officials also say they suspect that Nomura, the world's largest brokerage, provided improper compensation for trading losses to more of its customers than it has disclosed so far. **********The head of the Justice Ministry's criminal division had said in July that an investigation had begun into Nomura's dealings in the shares of the Tokyu Corporation, a big railroad and property group. Finance Ministry officials now say they have broadened their own investigation to examine the trading of Nomura's customers as well as the activities of the brokerage's branch offices, and will share their findings with the prosecutor's office. **********If Nomura is found to have engaged in manipulation, a criminal offense, the individuals involved could be sentenced to three-year prison terms and the firm could face an array of harsh administrative measures, the head of the ministry's enforcement division, Toshihiro Tsuchimochi, said. These include suspensions or even the revocation of its operating license. **********A revocation is considered unlikely, but even a far less harsh penalty could cause customers to flee and seriously damage the firm's reputation. **********One reason the investigations of Nomura have been suddenly upgraded is that the Finance Ministry is itself under growing pressure to demonstrate that it can deal with the issues raised in the scandal, which has damaged the ministry's credibility. **********Facing a barrage of criticism by opposition lawmakers in the Diet, Japan's Parliament, about its handling of the matter, the Finance Ministry has made threatening comments about Nomura even though it acknowledges that it has yet to prove a case. Many of the disclosures that have advanced the investigations have come in newspaper articles. **********The political pressures have created an unpredictable new dynamic in the scandal, as the Finance Ministry itself struggles to survive in its current form. Charges that the ministry has been an ineffective watchdog of the financial industry and that it is going too easy on Nomura and other firms have encouraged those who want to shift regulatory powers to an independent new agency. Disclosures that the ministry knew of some improper activities years ago, and yet did nothing, have made it as much a subject of the scandal as the securities firms. **********"The ministry is really struggling not to come across as the bad guys, so they're trying to reach the correct conclusions before there is a formal conclusion from the investigations," said Robert Zielinski, an analyst at Jardine Fleming Securities here. "They're paying close attention to the political winds. They just want this thing to go away." **********Until recently, ministry officials had spent much of their time describing why they could not prosecute or penalize Nomura and the other major securities brokers.  Promises Are Forbidden **********Japanese law prohibits securities firms from promising to pay compensation to customers to cover losses, but not from actually making such payments. When it was disclosed that more than 20 large firms made improper loss-compensation payments of more than $1.3 billion, the ministry accepted their words that no promises had been offered in advance. **********It was disclosed on Monday that some firms, including Nomura, may have made improper compensation payments to customers that did not lose money. The implication was that the firms had guaranteed the customers a minimum return and that when they came up short, the firms made up the difference. Nobuhiko Matsuno, head of the securities bureau, said that the behavior looked suspicious and that the ministry was investigating. **********Perhaps the most curious case involves the investigation of Nomura's dealings in Tokyu stock.  No Evidence of Manipulation **********Minoru Nagaoka, the president of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, insisted in July that the exchange had investigated trading in Tokyu shares in late 1989 and found nothing amiss. Finance Ministry officials also said that an investigation at that time had turned up no evidence of manipulation. **********Mr. Tsuchimochi, head of the enforcement division, said in a telephone interview today that a new investigation began into the Tokyu trading because of numerous newspaper articles. He said the 1989 inquiry had focused on whether a single customer had tried to manipulate Tokyu's shares, but not whether Nomura had been involved in the scheme. That is a focus of the current inquiry, he said. **********"Basically, we have not found any evidence of a violation yet," he commented. "But the investigation is continuing." **********It had been previously disclosed that Susumu Ishii, who until last year had headed one of Japan's largest organized crime groups, acquired more than 27 million Tokyu shares in the spring of 1989. Nomura and Nikko Securities had each provided more than $100 million in financing to back the purchases of Mr. Ishii, who died today at age 67.  [ Obituary, page B9. ] **********In October 1989, Nomura issued a strong buy recommendation to its branches for Tokyu, sending the stock price soaring. Setsuya Tabuchi, who was forced to resign as Nomura chairman because of the scandal, said in parliamentary testimony last week that Nomura had exceeded for a few days an informal prohibition against securities firms' accounting for more than 30 percent of the trading in a stock. But he denied that the firm had manipulated Tokyu shares. **********An opposition member of Parliament disclosed Monday that he had obtained a ministry report showing Mr. Ishii had earned nearly $6 million in profits by selling a small portion of his holdings near their price peak, when Nomura was recommending Tokyu. It had been reported earlier that Mr. Ishii had kept all of his shares.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/22/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Japanese Paper Closes
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/22/busin.body_text: **********Lady Kong, which appeared three months ago as Japan's first newspaper for women, stopped publication last week because of financial problems. "We could not get as much financial support as we had expected when we started the paper, in part because of the gulf war," said Kyo Moriyama of the Ranka Sha Company, the publisher. The tabloid-size paper was a joint venture of the Japanese publisher and a British brokerage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.main_headline: Making a Difference; Scouting for Cookies
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.print_headline: Making a Difference; Scouting for Cookies
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.body_text: **********Don't think it's easy getting 165 million boxes of cookies. Ask Mary Rose Main. **********Ms. Main, executive director of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., is the final authority in choosing which bakeries will make the familiar boxes of cookies that some 2.5 million Girl Scouts peddle door to door. The sales transpire mostly in the spring and fall, with the campaign in the New York area just winding down. **********This sounds like business any bakery would crave, but in truth the Girl Scouts can't find as many suppliers as they would like. Only two are currently authorized -- Little Brownie Bakers of Louisville, Ky., and Interbake Foods Inc. of Richmond. The Girl Scouts would prefer four or five to give their 333 Girl Scout councils flexibility of choice. At the moment, Ms. Main is busy inspecting candidates to expand the list for next year. **********"At the beginning of this year, we had three," Ms. Main said, "but one dropped out because it felt it was overextended." **********The trouble is a bakery needs enormous capacity. It also must make a sizable upfront investment in special molds to accommodate the cookies. You have to take the long view. **********Interbake has. It has been turning out Girl Scout cookies since 1936, and Little Brownie has been at it since 1975. The cookie sales themselves date back to the 1920's, when no bakeries were needed. Girl Scouts made them in their own homes (often with considerable indulgence from their parents). **********To get the business, Ms. Main said, a bakery must be able to make seven different types of cookies. Bakeries are generally paid 75 to 80 cents a box, while consumers are charged about $2.25 to $2.50. The record 165 million boxes sold last year thus brought the Girl Scouts roughly $250 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/12/world.body_text: **********Algeria's new Prime Minister, Sid Ahmed Ghozali, has told close associates and potential ministerial appointees that he intends to pick a Cabinet of "independent personalities" who are not tied to political parties and will see to it that Algeria holds free parliamentary elections before the end of the year, Algerian officials say. **********These comments and Mr. Ghozali's meetings with Algerian technical experts suggest that he may end up choosing a Cabinet that is fundamentally independent from the ruling National Liberation Front, which has governed Algeria since independence from France in 1962, Algerian officials and Algerian affairs experts say. **********"He means to create a totally independent government that cannot be tainted by the mistakes of the F.L.N., which means he may find his government confronting the ruling party," one Algerian official said in a telephone interview.  A Run for President? **********The official said that Mr. Ghozali may also be contemplating the possibility of running for president himself in elections that are to be moved up from the constitutionally mandated deadline, which is the end of 1993. **********Parliamentary elections also are scheduled, with Islamic fundamentalists hoping to capture a majority of the seats. **********Mr. Ghozali, appointed last week by President Chadli Benjedid after weeks of violent protests organized by the fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front, has the daunting agenda of dealing with Algeria's severe economic and political problems while preparing for genuinely free elections. **********Algeria, with a population of 25 million, is facing a foreign debt of $25 billion and cannot count on much financial assistance any longer from Arab oil producers still angered by Algerian sympathy for Iraq during the recent Gulf crisis. Its own oil income has been hit by the falling prices on the world market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/24/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Front; Soldiers Poised on the Edge of the Unknown
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/24/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Front; Soldiers Poised on the Edge of the Unknown
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/24/world.body_text: **********The soldiers who stand here call it The Berm, the manmade ridge of sand and brush and dirt built along the northern border of Saudi Arabia, all that remains between these anxious young men and the unknown. **********As the deadline passed today for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face a ferocious American-led ground attack, the men of the Third Squadron of the Second Armored Cavalry Regiment did not need to be reminded that they are at the front lines of this war. **********They are the front line. No one, they say, is closer. **********The German-based armored platoon that calls itself "the Merchants of Death" is expected to be among the first to cross The Berm, and its soldiers insisted that they were ready to open the attack that could begin the greatest adventure -- and the most horrifying ordeal -- of their lives. **********Virtually all of these soldiers are young. Many say they are frightened to be so close to the front, and have kept their families ignorant of the platoon's dangerous location. Some say they are eager to fight, if only to have this long-delayed war over with. **********"The Grim Reaper is sort of my mascot," said Sgt. Kirk Alcorn, a 23-year-old gunner aboard one of the Bradley armored vehicles perched along the front lines. **********On his ring is the skull head of the Reaper and his sickle. On his upper right arm is a Grim Reaper tattoo. **********"This is where I wanted to be," Sergeant Alcorn said in the slow drawl of his native Green Cove Springs, Fla. "This is what I wanted to do. I've stopped being nervous. I don't have any worries." **********The five-man Bradleys look much like a tank and carry armor-piercing ammunition, TOW missiles and blocks of deadly C-4 explosives. Because they are lighter and more mobile than a tank, the Bradleys are used here as scouting vehicles.  Out in Front of Tanks **********Army scouts have the treacherous job of setting off before the tanks, searching for the enemy and trying to ward off surprises for the soldiers who follow. They and their Marine counterparts would be the first Americans to encounter -- and fight -- the Iraqis in a ground offensive. **********"I walked into the recruiting office and read about the cavalry scouts, and it sounded romantic," Sergeant Alcorn said, looking off toward the undulating, windswept hills separating him from his foes. "I wanted to be a scout." **********For others on the Bradley, however, there is nothing romantic about what faces them across The Berm, which is so close to this American position along the border that individual shrubs on Iraqi-held land can be made out in the distance. **********They say they are ready for the fight, but at the same time they wonder how fate could have brought them to face death in this bleak desert. **********Cpl. Phillip Gilman, 21, of Flint, Mich., wanted to be an Army welder. But when he was transferred by the Army to Italy three years ago, his orders did not mention welding, and he suddenly found himself assigned as an infantryman. **********"I was 18 and dumb and didn't complain," he said, tugging nervously on the zipper on his flame-retardant, olive-green tanker suit. **********Even though Corporal Gilman says he has come to accept his fate here, his anxiety was transparent as he waited for what appeared to be an imminent order to charge across The Berm. **********Pvt. Michael Anthony O'Donnell of New Hyde Park, L.I., turns 22 next week. He left his job as a truck driver and joined the Army in May, "looking for a little discipline, a little adventure." On the day he graduated from basic training at Fort Knox, Ky., Iraq invaded Kuwait, a faraway country he said he had never heard of. **********Six months later, he was standing on the sandy border of that country, risking his life to liberate it. **********"I can feel it breathing down my neck," he said of the war, his left hand resting near large gray plastic containers of armor-piercing ammunition. "I'd like to come home in one piece. I can't wait to get out of here."  One Combat Veteran on Team **********The one combat veteran on this Bradley team is the commander, 39-year-old Sgt. Ron Mullinix. **********He describes his team as "a good bunch of men" and insists that he is confident of a quick victory against Iraq. **********"I think it's going to be quick and deliberate," he said. "My best guess is that it will take a month. My hope is that it's a week." **********But Sergeant Mullinix served in Vietnam, and he says that in many ways, the war against Iraq "ain't no easier" to fight. **********He said that in Vietnam he learned a difficult lesson about battle, and it applies here, too. "You start pumped up, you go into it scared to death, and you come out of it wondering what you did," he said. **********First Lieut. Paul Calvert, 27, of Athens, Ga., directs the men of the "Merchants of Death," and he does not deny that there is fear in what may be the final hours before battle. **********"There's always a fear factor," he said. "You've got to be cognizant of the fear factor in yourself." **********But he said he chose an assignment in the Second Armored Cavalry, an elite regiment that dates back to the 1830's and led the advance for Patton's Third Army in World War II, and "I feel safer in this unit than any other place in the war." **********Lieutenant Calvert said he knew that battle would be easier for him than for many of his soldiers, if only because he can share his fear with his older brother, Capt. Mark Calvert, 29, who works in the regimental headquarters a short drive south from The Berm. **********"I've always got somebody I can grab hold of," Lieutenant Calvert said. "We've always had so much in common. We've passed for twins."  A New Bond for Brothers **********The war, he said, offers them "the kind of bond a lot of brothers never experience." **********Both brothers are married, and the families live only 45 minutes apart in Germany, where the regiment is based. Mark has two daughters. Paul's wife is pregnant with their first child. **********Their father died years ago. "And my mom's real worried," Lieutenant Calvert said. "I know from letters she is extremely proud of us. She's got faith in us. She's got faith in our abilities." **********As for his brother, Paul says he believes that Mark would prefer to break away from the safer confines of the regimental headquarters and come here to The Berm, to lead the attack, the brothers side by side. **********"I know he'd want to be here," Lieutenant Calvert said proudly of his brother. "He's an outstanding soldier, and this is why we joined the Army. This is where the war will happen."
