https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/09/busin.body_text: **********A lawyer for Charles H. Keating Jr. today shrugged off a complaint from the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has joined the investigation of Mr. Keating's dealings, as "a waste of taxpayer money." **********A letter sent two weeks ago warned Mr. Keating, an Arizona developer and owner of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, that the commission might charge him with violating securities laws in the sale of $250 million in high-yield "junk bonds." **********The letter asked his lawyer, Stephen C. Neal, to respond by today. **********In his response, Mr. Neal said the commission's letter was "basically a waste of taxpayer money" and "doesn't shed a clue on what they are looking for." **********"They don't need to pursue litigation for a single day to keep Keating out of public companies, and there are already a host of government agencies trying to get all the money he's got, which isn't much," he said. **********If the S.E.C. charges were filed, the commission would join at least six other Government agencies in civil and criminal actions generated by bond sales and Lincoln's subsequent collapse. **********Mr. Neal suggested on Thursday that Government officials were using his client as a scapegoat. **********"We are spending an extraordinary amount of taxpayer money on what are essentially duplicate investigations," Mr. Neal said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/03/world.main_headline: A Battle Is Over for Baltic-Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/03/world.print_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL; A Battle Is Over for Baltic-Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/03/world.body_text: **********It was the moment that Americans from the Baltic republics have been awaiting for 50 years: formal recognition of their homelands' independence by their adopted country. **********And when they heard the words from President Bush today, they could finally uncork the champagne, sing national anthems with resolution and unfurl the flags they had saved just for this day. **********"At last it's come," said Regina Narvsis, a Lithuania-born lawyer in Chicago. "Once he said it, there was a sigh of relief. It's a reality. We're beside ourselves."  250,000 in Chicago **********These are the people, about a million Lithuanians, Latvians and Estonians in the United States and more than 250,000 in Chicago alone, who have been praying and protesting and watching with both frustration and awe the roller-coaster revolutions spawned by their distant cousins. **********Many were trying to reach relatives in the Baltics on jammed telephone lines and planning their trips to Vilnius and Riga. In Chicago, the Lithuanian flag hung over the Seklycia Restaurant, and the refrains of "God Bless Latvia" rose from the corridors of a Latvian church. **********It was a day of joy and disbelief, but also one of disappointment that the United States, the embodiment of freedom to so many of their relatives in the Baltics, was among the last of the Western countries to recognize their independence. **********"We would have been happier to see the President lead instead of follow," said the Rev. Vilis Varsbergs of the Latvian Evangelical Lutheran Church. **********"It was so painful for us to watch our cousins standing up to the tanks for freedom," Ms. Narvsis added. "For us not to be first was hard for many of us to take." **********That did not stop them from hugging and toasting themselves. The Lithuanians on the South Side and the Latvians on the North Side had been up since 5 A.M., preparing for the celebration, bracing for the President's words. Soon after the announcement began to sink in, they were beginning to think about what the words really meant.  'Truely Are Independent' **********"It means they truly are independent," said Juris Kins, a Latvia-born lawyer. "It's irreversible. It's joyous. But at the same time, we know that people have to wake up tomorrow and face the reality there: "What do we do now?' " **********Indeed, while all of them were exhilarated, many worried that the ethnic violence that has torn Yugoslavia might sear the Baltics as well. **********"I'm not too optimistic about this," said Joe Galica, who owns a Lithuanian restaurant. "There are more than 100 nations in the Soviet Union. Maybe there will be a civil war. There will be a lot of mess yet." **********He remembered a visit he made to Siberia 12 years ago, where he saw the fruit of division ripe even then. "People were saying, 'We are Ukranians or we are Cossacks.' Never fighting for the Soviet Union." **********For decades now, the Latvians and Lithuanians and Estonians in this country have worked on the same team in the fight for independence, in marches and rallies and in letter-writing campaigns. Today they went their separate ways to celebrate and are likely, some noted, to find themselves rivals for scarce development resources now that freedom has come. **********"Now there may be more competition to decide which country is going to get what and how much," said Dr. Tomas Remeikis, a political science professor who lives in Chicago and is Lithuanian. "Things might even get nasty." **********To avert such an outcome, many say their lobbying efforts will focus on gaining technical and humanitarian aid for the Baltics and pressing the United States to grant their homelands the status of most-favored nations. Some Baltic Americans are already planning trips to reclaim family land that was confiscated and used by the Soviet Government or talking of quitting jobs to help rebuild the countries. **********The day, as joyous as it was, had its sadder moments as well, as these expatriates, many of them survivors of the Red Army purge of intellectuals and capitalist sympathizers after World War II, remembered the relatives who could not share it with them. **********"We survived, but so many didn't," said Olita Kins, Mr. Kins's wife. **********Her grandmother, Marija Kakis, lived for the day when shecould see Latvia free and again touch a son who was exiled to Siberia for 25 years. **********"She always said, 'Someday we'll go back,' " Mrs. Kins said. "She said she couldn't die until she saw her son and Latvia." **********She would not live to see either. She died 10 years ago in Columbus, Ohio, waiting for this day.                    --------------------       Euphoria in Richmond Hill **********Several hundred Lithuanian-born emigres and their families crowded into the Baltija Restaurant in Richmond Hill, Queens, yesterday to celebrate Washington's recognition of their homeland. **********"We are thrilled," said Vida Janukauskas, who was 10 years old when she immigrated to New York in 1947. "There is a God, and He is looking after us. We finally can be rulers of our own land." **********Folk music filled the Lithuanian restaurant, where a place was reserved at the head table for Anicetas Simutis, Lithuania's Consul General in New York City. **********Last week, Mr. Simutis stamped a dozen visas for Lithuania, the first he had issued in decades. Now, with American recognition, he said proudly, he can stamp visas in full diplomatic splendor. **********"Mr. Bush's stamp of approval is the final and most important one," Mr. Simutis said. "We are finally, irrevocably free." **********Mr. Simutis was sent to New York in 1936 as an attache at his then-independent nation's consulate. He never left and has kept the consulate open on West 82d Street, near Central Park West. He has served as Consul General since 1967.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/23/busin.main_headline: Former BMC Chairman Assumes Posts at Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/23/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Former BMC Chairman Assumes Posts at Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/23/busin.body_text: **********Since April, when James K. Ashford resigned unexpectedly as chairman of the J. I. Case Company, the heavy-equipment unit of Tenneco Inc., analysts have wondered who would replace him. And since last week, when Robert J. Carlson, 61, resigned as chairman of BMC Industries, analysts have wondered where he was going. **********Yesterday, both mysteries were solved. Tenneco named Mr. Carlson as Case's new president and chief executive officer, effective immediately. Election to the board is scheduled for the near future. **********"Sure, we had plenty of good young managers in place, but we needed someone with strong industry background, and Carlson fit the bill," said Christine LeLaurin, a Tenneco spokeswoman. Apparently, Case fit the bill for Mr. Carlson, too. As he put it: "I like jumping into alligator ponds." **********That may be an apt description of Case right now. A combination of the recession and mismanagement of inventories resulted in a loss of $147 million in the first quarter. Rick James, a Case spokesman, conceded that the company would probably report a loss for the year. **********Analysts, too, predict losses. "Case has been a problem child for decades, and Tenneco finally realized it had to bring someone in with a strong personality and real industry knowledge to run it," said Eli S. Lustgarten, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc. **********Mr. Carlson's last 12 years have been evenly split between the United Technologies Corporation and BMC, a manufacturer of electronic and optical products. He spent the first 29 years of his career at Deere & Company, Case's much larger, and consistently profitable, competitor. **********Case currently is less concerned with losses than with clearing out its high inventory. The company has been furiously discounting, a practice that has depressed prices but, Mr. Carlson said, is "finally cleaning up the balance sheet." **********Since Tenneco has mandatory retirement at 65, Mr. Carlson has four years to turn Case around and groom his successor. He speaks of "bringing some discipline to procedures" and focusing on "new philosophies in dealer and distributor relationships." **********Mr. Carlson has a bachelor's degree in business administration from the University of Minnesota. He and his wife, Joann, who have four children, recently moved to Racine, Wisc., six minutes from Case's office.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/30/world.main_headline: Algerians Urged to Support A Secular State in Runoffs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/30/world.print_headline: Algerians Urged to Support A Secular State in Runoffs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/30/world.body_text: **********Three days after elections for Parliament gave Islamic fundamentalists a significant victory, the Algerian Government, the press and secular political parties today urged the estimated 40 percent of Algerians who abstained in the first round to turn out for a second round Jan. 16 and vote against turning the country into a religious state. **********While this second round is not expected to prevent the fundamentalist group, the Islamic Salvation Front, from winning a majority, the hope of the secular forces is that they can win enough seats to give them a voice in the new assembly. **********Parliament can pass laws by a simple majority but it needs a two-thirds margin to alter the Constitution, a goal being sought by the fundamentalists. Their program calls for declaring Algeria an Islamic republic and instituting religious law, or sharia. **********The Islamic Salvation Front has already secured 189 seats, and its candidates are leading in 150 other constituencies to be decided in the next round of voting for those who failed to achieve a majority at the polls on Thursday. Socialists Seek Support **********Hocine Ait-Ahmed, who leads the Front for Socialist Forces, which holds a distant second place in the new Parliament with 20 seats, called on supporters and those who did not vote on Thursday to block the fundamentalists. **********At a news conference here today, he appealed for votes for his party from other groups, ethnic and political. The Socialists have much support among those of Berber origin and hope to attract votes from the ruling National Liberation Front and from other secular parties that failed to win any seats. The Socialists did better on Thursday than the National Front, which won only 16 seats. The ruling party's weak performance has been especially striking because it has formed every Algerian Government since independence from France in 1962. **********Officials of the ruling party also called on undecided voters for support on Jan. 16, but they seemed most eager to encourage any vote against the Islamic militants. 45 Parties Eliminated **********The two secular parties are the only ones contesting the next round against the fundamentalists. Forty-five other parties that ran Thursday were eliminated from the contest. **********Many of the 60 percent who did vote were thought to be core adherents of the Islamic fundamentalists. Their party waged a determined campaign for months to register supporters. The fundamentalists, who won control of about 800 municipalities in elections last year, or 55 percent of the total vote, used those offices in towns and villages to mobilize supporters. **********Depending on the final tally, which has yet to be released by the Government, the Islamic opposition may need as few as 27 more seats for a majority in the 430-member Parliament. **********Of the more than 1,000 independent candidates who ran, 50 have filed official complaints to contest the results in their districts on the basis of procedural errors. A council set up by the Government is expected to issue opinions that in some cases could cancel now-recorded victories.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/busin.main_headline: Drug Chain Makes Offer For Revco
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/busin.print_headline: Drug Chain Makes Offer For Revco
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/busin.body_text: **********The Jack Eckerd Corporation, a Florida-based drugstore chain, announced yesterday that it was offering to buy Revco D.S., the large drugstore chain that filed for bankruptcy after a failed leveraged buyout. **********Revco said it had rejected the Eckerd bid, submitted on May 16, at a board meeting on June 6 because the offer was "insufficient in value for further consideration." Revco, based in Twinsburgh, Ohio, said the Eckerd bid was unsolicited. Eckerd offered to buy the company and bring it out of its bankruptcy reorganization effort; Revco filed a plan for reorganization on June 7. **********Despite the rejection, the offer has the support of some of Revco's creditors, and it could still succeed. The offer came about because a committee of one group of Revco's creditors, frustrated with the reorganization's slow pace, asked Eckerd to bid, people involved in the bankruptcy said. Value Not Disclosed **********The total value of the offer was not disclosed. But in a recent court hearing, a Revco lawyer estimated that the company had a value of about $835 million. An adviser to one of the creditor committees, however, said the market was putting the value of all of Revco's securities at about $340 million. **********"While we have not received a formal response to our proposal, we have been told the information requested would not be forthcoming at this time," Eckerd's chairman, Stewart Turley, said in a statement. Revco's management has reportedly refused to turn over financial information Eckard said it would need to proceed with the offer. **********David Supino, a partner in Lazard Freres & Company, Revco's investment banker, said in a statement that "most creditors of Revco have expressed their belief that they would receive more value in a stand-alone reorganization plan" than through an acquisition like the one offered by Eckerd. **********People who have been briefed on the proposed deal said yesterday that Merrill Lynch & Company was helping Eckerd and that Merrill would be taking a financial position in Revco if the deal worked out. **********While it has been protected from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, Revco has turned in a dismal sales performance, racking up losses of about $400 million and compounding its creditors' frustrations. **********A bid for the company would be an added factor in what has evolved into one of the most complex bankruptcies stemming from the wave of mergers in the 1980's. Revco was taken private in 1986 in a deal that increased its debt level by $1.1 billion. A little more than a year later, the company failed to make payments on its debt and filed for bankruptcy.  Earlier Offers **********This is not the first time outside bidders have tried to buy Revco, according to documents filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Akron, Ohio. In 1989 and 1990, the company was approached with a bid of $925 million, which was dimissed at the time as inadequate by investors with a financial stake in Revco. **********Revco's own plan faces difficulty because of the reaction among creditors, court documents show. Revco said it had submitted that plan based on the "hardened positions of the various creditor constituencies" in recent negotiations. **********For Eckerd, the proposed deal would tighten its already close corporate relationship with Revco. Last year, Eckerd bought 223 Revco stores, as Revco tried to emerge from bankruptcy protection. **********But Revco is a much different company from what it was when it began its reorganization three years ago. The company, which operated more than 2,000 drugstores in 30 states in 1986, has sold many of them during the bankruptcy. It now owns 1,100 stores with about $2.5 billion in annual revenues. **********Eckerd, a private company based in Clearwater, Fla., owns 1,680 drugstores in 13 states. It has estimated revenues of about $3 billion a year. It completed a leveraged buyout in the same year as Revco's and survived.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/world.main_headline: Syrian Official Voices Doubt Hussein Will Survive Revolts in Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Syrian Official Voices Doubt Hussein Will Survive Revolts in Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/world.body_text: **********Syria's Foreign Minister said today that he doubted that President Saddam Hussein could survive as ruler of Iraq and expressed confidence that the Iraqi opposition would be able to form a new government. **********"I don't think the people of Iraq would tolerate his continuing, and the other states in the region cannot work with him," said the Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa. "It's wrong to think that Iraq would disintegrate without him or be divided. I'm confident we'll see the opposition parties working together to form a coalition government." Assad-Hussein Rivalry **********Asked about American concerns that any opposition coalition quickly be divided by deep ideological and religious differences, Mr. Sharaa sounded a note of frustration. "The United States criticizes so many countries because they are not democratic, yet when democracy can now come naturally in Iraq, they are not supportive," he said. **********President Hafez al-Assad has long been a regional rival of President Hussein, and Syria has been a base for many Iraqi opposition groups seeking to overthrow Mr. Hussein. Syrian relations with the United States have sharply improved since Damascus joined the anti-Iraq coalition led by the United States. **********Mr. Sharaa spoke in a long interview that concentrated on prospects for Mideast peace and Syria's attitude toward terrorism.  Issue of Terrorism **********Speaking in fluent English, he praised the United States for its stated desire to help bring peace to the turbulent region, but expressed frustration with what he called America's "double standard" and "ugly hypocrisy" in judging Israeli and Arab behavior. **********For example, he said, Syria was kept on Washington's list of countries that sponsor terrorism, despite its help in averting terrorist assaults in Europe and the Mideast during the gulf war and its efforts to obtain freedom for American hostages being held in Lebanon. But Israel, he complained, was omitted from the list. Mr. Sharaa accused Israel of sponsoring "state terrorism." **********Mr. Sharaa denounced what he called "a new media campaign" in the United States to portray Syria as a "new Iraq" that would be Israel's eternal enemy. Saying Syria wanted peace, he said Israel "keeps erecting new obstacles and demands that risk squandering the post-gulf-war peace momentum." **********He said Syria still believes that Israel and its Arab foes should meet under the auspices of an international peace conference, a demand that Israel rejects. But he stressed that Syria was flexible about what kind of a gathering would constitute such a forum in Syrian eyes: a conference co-sponsored by the United States and Soviet Union would qualify; so, too, would a peace conference convened by the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council. **********The United States has said such a conference might be acceptable if "properly structured" and held at an "appropriate time." **********He called upon the Administration to designate such an "appropriate time" and "to begin preparing for it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/15/world.main_headline: Breakthrough Is Reported in Gandhi Murder
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/15/world.print_headline: Breakthrough Is Reported in Gandhi Murder
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/15/world.body_text: **********Government investigators said today that the arrest of a mother and son in Madras on Tuesday night in connection with the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi was a significant breakthrough and that they now believed the killing was a carefully planned conspiracy that may have involved at least a dozen people. **********At the same time, officials said that a bespectacled man photographed at the scene of the assassination is the object of a nationwide search and believed to be the mastermind behind the killing of Mr. Gandhi on May 21. **********Officials said the man, in his 30's, fled the scene of the assassination together with at least two women, believed to be accomplices. **********Government investigators said tonight that the two women, identified only as Nalini and Murugan, were seized late today near Madras. **********Mr. Gandhi's assassination during a campaign trip to southern India delayed national elections. The bulk of the voting will be completed on Saturday, and returns are expected to start coming in by late Sunday. **********The election has been shadowed, in the last three weeks, by the death of Mr. Gandhi, the Congress Party leader. **********An official of India's Central Bureau of Investigation said in an interview late today that hundreds of police officers in the southern state of Tamil Nadu as well as more than a dozen Government agents have converged around Madras in the hunt for accomplices to the assassin, who detonated a bomb as she bowed before Mr. Gandhi at a campaign stop in Sriperumbudur, south of Madras. The blast killed 18 people, including Mr. Gandhi and the assassin. **********The senior official, who requested anonymity, said that the assassin as well as the missing man and other suspects in the case were members of the Tamil ethnic group, which is in the majority in Tamil Nadu. **********The official declined to speculate on the motives for the killing of Mr. Gandhi, and said there was no proof that the suspects were linked to the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, a guerrilla group that seeks a separate homeland for Tamils in neighboring Sri Lanka. But he did say that most of the people under investigation were Tamils from Sri Lanka. **********Mr. Gandhi was hailed by Sri Lankan Tamils when he sent troops to the island in 1987 in an effort to keep the peace between the guerrillas and the Sinhalese-dominated Sri Lankan armed forces. But the Tamil support for Mr. Gandhi quickly turned to anger when the Indian troops tried to disarm the Tamil guerrillas, resulting in clashes in which thousands of Tamils and more than 1,150 Indian troops were killed. The Indian Army was withdrawn at the end of 1989. **********The senior official described as a "breakthrough" the arrest of a 49-year-old woman, who was identified only as Padma, and her 25-year-old son in connection with the assassination. The woman, who works in a private nursing home, and her son, identified as S. Bhagyanathan, have been charged with harboring the assassin. The official said that the two, who lived in central Madras, are under interrogation. **********"We are finally getting close to identifying and catching the people involved in this," said the official. "We believe this was all carefully planned and masterminded by the man." **********"If he is arrested," the official said, "we believe the case will be over."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF; Slain Spies and Syria
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/world.body_text: **********The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said today that he had ordered an inquiry into a report that intelligence agents working inside a Syria-based terrorist group were unmasked and killed after the United States provided information to Syria last year. **********The report in The New York Times today said that two or three agents, said by one Administration official to have been working for Israel, were killed last fall after the Administration sent a series of dispatches on terrorism to President Hafez al-Assad of Syria. The article said terrorists may have obtainedsome of the dispatches. **********The intelligence panel's Democratic chairman, Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma, said in a statement today that the report, if true, "would represent a tragic and indefensible compromise of our intelligence resources and a breach of faith with those who have risked their lives on our behalf." **********The White House said it would not comment on intelligence issues. A spokesman for the Central Intelligence Agency, Mark Mansfield, said that the agency would fully cooperate with the Senate committee's inquiry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; New President Named For Aerospace Corp.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/19/busin.body_text: **********Edward C. Aldridge Jr., the president of McDonnell Douglas Electronic Systems, is leaving the McLean, Va., electronics company in March to join the Aerospace Corporation, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday. A successor will be named later. **********Mr. Aldridge, who is 53 years old, will become the president and chief executive of Aerospace, a federally financed research and development center, based in El Segundo, Calif., that provides engineering and technical support for United States military space systems. **********He should feel at home working for the Government. Over the last 25 years, Mr. Aldridge has held executive positions with various Government agencies, including Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for strategic programs and director of planning and evaluation for the Secretary of Defense. From 1986 until he joined McDonnell Douglas two years later, Mr. Aldridge was the Secretary of the Air Force, making him the top civilian official in that military branch. **********"In the three years he has been with us, he has led the company through its formative stage into a viable position in the highly competitive electronics arena," said John F. McDonnell, the chairman and chief executive of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. **********Along with his administrative responsibilities, Mr. Aldridge worked closely on the development of the C-17 military cargo airplane that McDonnell Douglas has been building for the Air Force. **********McDonnell Douglas's electronic systems division specializes in the design of highly sophisticated aerospace technology, including laser systems, visual simulation systems, and surveillance and detection systems. **********Mr. Aldridge, who has a master's degree in aeronautical engineering from the Georgia Institute of Technology, has been awarded numerous honors, including the Department of Defense distinguished public service award and distinguished service awards from the Army, Navy and Air Force. Most recently, he served on a special advisory committee established by the National Space Council to make recommendations about future space ventures, including a manned mission to Mars. **********Mr. Alridge lives in Vienna, Va., with his wife, Joanne.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/04/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A 3M Vice President Will Become Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/04/busin.body_text: **********The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company yesterday named one of its longtime executives to replace Allen F. Jacobson as chairman and chief executive. Livio D. DeSimone, the executive vice president of the company's information and imaging technologies sector, will take the chairman's job at the end of October, upon Mr. Jacobson's retirement. The 54-year-old Mr. DeSimone, who has been with the company for 33 years, has been a member of its board since 1986. **********The company, a highly diversified maker of industrial, health care and consumer products, has set a goal of a 27 percent return on capital and 10 percent annual earnings growth. Those are especially ambitious goals, particularly in a year of sluggish revenue growth. **********"These are demanding kinds of goals," Mr. DeSimone said in a telephone interview yesterday. "In the last few years we have not met all of those goals all of the time, but we have come pretty close." He added that there was a need to improve the financial results of the company's imaging area, which makes a variety of products ranging from diskettes and videotape to film and micrographic systems. **********That sector last year accounted for a fifth of 3M's sales and nearly a quarter of its income. "The performance in that area is improving but it's not up to the standards of the company," Mr. DeSimone said. Improvment, he added, would come "from having a sharp focus and from having the right product at the right time." Mr. DeSimone said he was not prepared to offer specifics on strategy. **********Mr. DeSimone has headed three of the company's four business sectors. He is a native of Montreal and received a bachelor's degree in chemical engineering from McGill University in Montreal in 1957. He joined 3M's Canadian subsidiary as a process engineer the same year. He later worked at the company's headquarters in St. Paul and in Australia and Brazil, where he became managing director. He later served as area vice president for Latin America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/07/world.main_headline: Kurds Unearthing New Evidence of Iraqi Killings
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/07/world.print_headline: Kurds Unearthing New Evidence of Iraqi Killings
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/07/world.body_text: **********Across northern Iraq, Kurds, freed for now from the harshness of President Saddam Hussein's grip, have been uncovering mass graves, torture chambers, elaborate prison systems and documents from secret police files that attest to the inner workings of one of the region's harshest dictatorships. **********In the city of Sulaimaniya alone, local officials say they have unearthed more than 200 bodies in the last two months, and new sites to be excavated are being discovered every week. **********Kurds have long charged the Hussein Government with human rights abuses. Some especially severe cases have been independently substantiated and widely publicized, including attacks with chemical weapons on Kurdish villagers at Halabja during the war between Iran and Iraq. Relative Freedom **********But the graves and other recent discoveries offer evidence of the wide extent of Baghdad's repression. They are coming to light now that the Kurds have been left relatively free to run their affairs and rebuild their lives in the aftermath of the American-led military effort to protect them from Mr. Hussein's forces. **********Baghdad crushed a Kurdish uprising in the aftermath of its defeat in the Persian Gulf war, forcing hundreds of thousands of Kurds to flee for months into Iran and Turkey. **********"When we first complained about these human rights violations the world did not listen," said Jalal Talabani, one of two top Kurdish guerrilla leaders. "Now that we come forward with the evidence, this information is harder to ignore." Indiscriminate Killing Charged **********Kurdish leaders contend that more than 180,000 people have disappeared in the last decade at the hands of the Iraqi secret police. They say the Iraqis killed anyone, including young children, who they believe supported the outlawed Kurdish guerrilla movement or who belonged to a family that had ties with the Kurdish rebels. **********[ Diplomats at Iraq's mission to the United Nations, its highest-level diplomatic presence in the United States, could not be reached for comment on the new evidence of abuses. Middle East Watch, a New York-based human rights group, said it was planning to send investigators to northern Iraq to look into the Kurds' accusations. ] **********When confronted in the past with charges of mass killings or abuses of Kurds, Iraqi officials have in general denied wrongdoing, saying that any actions in the region would have been carried out against inflitrators from Iran or against traitors. **********Iraqi officials have also pointed to at least one mass killing by Kurdish guerrillas in October, when 60 Iraqi soldiers who surrendered during skirmishes in the Sulaimaniya area were slain by their Kurdish captors, according to the account of a Reuters reporter. Kurdish leaders promised to investigate the killings and bring those guilty to justice, but the investigation has yet to produce any results. **********Of graves being uncovered in northern Iraq, some reflect vilagers' return only now to the ruins of communities destroyed under an Iraqi policy of forced mass relocation begun in 1976. **********More than 4,000 villages -- primarily those near the Turkish or Iranian borders that were regarded as sanctuaries for Kurdish rebels -- are believed to have been demolished under the program, which reached its peak of intensity in 1987 and 1988, toward the end of the Iran-Iraq war. **********Other mass graves are thought to be more recent. At one, on Kalowa Hill here in Sulaimaniya, Pershan Hassan clambered quickly up the dirt track leading to the site. **********As she hurried forward, she clutched to her chest a framed black and white picture of a young boy. At the top of the rise, a crowd that had gathered parted silently as she stumbled forward. 'By His Clothes' **********The 53-year-old woman suddenly stopped and let out a gasp of pain and recognition. Before her, nine years after he disappeared from a schoolyard, lay the skeletal remains of her 13-year-old son, Shafiq. **********A faded blue blindfold was tightly wrapped around his skull and spent bullets were scattered among his now dark brown bones. **********"I know him by his clothes," she whispered, her voice breaking as she lifted the garments and kissed them. "I raised him without a father." **********The mass grave on Kalowa Hill is believed to hold the remains of dozens of people. **********"Prisoners and collaborators who dug the mass graves tell us where they are located," said Aras Mohammed Garib, who is in charge of the digging around the city, "but many have fled or are dead. It will be a long time before we really know the extent of all this." Kurdish Zones **********The Kurdistan Front, umbrella group for eight Kurdish groups in northern Iraq, has domain over most of the area above the 36th parallel. The region, home to about three and a half million, is part of a security zone established in April by American forces. **********The Kurds also control territory below the zone, including the city of Sulaimaniya, although the Iraqis appear to be positioning themselves to take back it and other cities as autonomy talks with the Kurds have bogged down. **********In gathering evidence, Kurdish officials here each morning pore through stacks of documents that they said were seized from police files, including photographs and videotapes of torture and death. **********The long, typewritten lists chronicle killing after killing, sometimes for what seem to be trivial offenses. One man was sentenced to death because he had a picture of a rebel Kurdish leader in his wallet. **********The killing sites are often found a few feet from the mass graves, Kurds say. On Kalowa Hill, five tires filled with cement are all that remain of the spot where apparently many people were shot to death. Earthen embankments border the back and either side of the site. **********Prisoners, apparently blindfolded with their hands tied behind 10-foot metal poles, were planted in the cement and then shot. **********A picture taken from police files shows what appear to be three Iraqi officials squatting like big game hunters next to the slumped body of a man who was recently killed. One of the Iraqis, wearing a beret, is grins while holding a knife to the corpse's neck. **********Those who lived in the vicinity of Kalowa Hill said they often heard screams and volleys of shots, but were threatened with death if they tried to peer into the high-walled compound. **********"The dogs used to come back with human bones, after getting inside the compound," said Yasin Khader Hassan, 25. "Then the guards began to shoot even the dogs." A Woman's Agony **********The hill now draws women looking for lost children or husbands. The plaintive cries of those who recover the remains of their loved ones rise above the murmur of the crowd. **********One woman, Bahia Khader, kneeled over the bones of her son Sirwan, who disappeared in 1982 when he was 15. **********"Sirwan, Sirwan," she cried, swaying over the bones and bits of clothing of her child. "By the hands of these criminals, you have been taken from me." **********Those who survived life inside Iraqi detention centers describe torture, beatings, hunger and the severance of all contact with the outside world. **********Jamal Aziz Amin, a courtly 45-year-old headmaster, stood in a soundproof room in the darkened remains of Sulaimaniya's central security prison, where he spent a year in detention. **********Large hooks hang from the ceiling where Mr. Amin was suspended during torture. He was handcuffed behind his back, he said, and hoisted onto the hooks at the wrist. He said he was stripped, questioned about his ties to Kurdish guerrilla groups, and given electric shocks until he fell unconcious. Revenge Taken **********"You would scream," he said, "and it would sound as if you were yelling from the bottom of a deep, deep well." **********The huge prison, its tiers of cells piled one on top of the other, stands bleak and deserted in the Baghdad suburb of Shorish. When it was attacked in March by Kurdish fighters and enraged civilians, 300 secret policemen and guards, including the warden, held out for three days. None of the defenders survived, Kurds say. **********Mr. Amin and his fellow prisoners, after the attack, had the rare experience of standing over the bodies of many of their torturers. **********"We wanted them to all come back to life," he said, "so we could kill them again." **********At the prison, inmates subsisted on thin soup, bread and weak tea. Mr. Amin said that when he was released, he had lost 60 pounds. Prison Graffiti **********The walls of the cells, many marked with crudely drawn calendars, carry the messages of those who tried to leave some testament of their humanity, some record of their suffering. **********"These were my friends, arrested with me," Ahmed Mohammed wrote, listing five names. "All were executed." **********Another prisoner had written a message to his mother: "Oh, mother," in this dark room my dreams trouble me and I shake. Then comes the kicking against my door and a voice telling me to get up. It is time for my interrogation. I awake to the unconscious." **********Mr. Amin wound his way to the crude latrine, a hole in the cement, at the end of a corridor of cells. **********"I wanted to show you this," he said, a small shaft of light streaming in from a tiny, barred window 14 feet above him. "Here is where we would come at night so we could pull ourselves up the walls to hear the sound of the dogs barking in the distance. To hear the dogs, this was everything for us." **********U.S. EXPRESSES CONCERN **********WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- The United States expressed concern today at a renewed Kurdish refugee crisis in northern Iraq.   The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said: "The United Nations people there on the ground tell us they believe they can handle this situation. It is something that is a concern to us, and something that we are obviously watching closely." **********United Nations officials say about 200,000 Kurds have fled attacks by the Iraqi Army in northern Iraq in recent weeks, straining the resources of relief teams trying to help half a million uprooted people survive an icy winter. **********President Saddam Hussein crushed a Kurdish revolt in the aftermath of Iraq's defeat in the Persian Gulf war earlier this year. Up to two million refugees fled toward Turkey and Iran, and Western troops created safe havens in Iraq for their return. The West wants to avoid another mass refugee exodus.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/12/world.main_headline: Bailing Out Soviets: Bush Is Cautious
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/12/world.print_headline: Bailing Out Soviets: Bush Is Cautious
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/12/world.body_text: **********President Bush demonstrated again today that the game of diminished expectations can be played to advantage in diplomatic affairs as well as domestic politics. **********In fact, he and his Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, seem to have chosen that tactic as a continuing element in their approach to the knotty problem of relations with the new, multi-polar Soviet Union, which bears about as much resemblence to the old monolithic totalitarian state of Stalin and Brezhnev as television-era American politics do to those of Tammany Hall. **********Having hinted for weeks that it strongly opposed inviting President Mikahil S. Gorbachev to the economic summit meeting in London in mid-July, and thus having dampened whatever plans Moscow may have had for stampeding Western leaders into early commitments of enormous financial aid, the Administration dropped its objections to Mr. Gorbachev coming to London next month. Naming of Strauss **********Having said again and again that before settling into a new business relationship with Moscow he wanted more dramatic evidence of the Soviets' commitment to changes leading to a free-market economy, Mr. Bush chose Robert S. Strauss, a symbol of free-market trade if ever there was one, as his new Ambassador to the Soviet Union. **********Casting aside doubts as to whether the feeble Soviet economy still meets the legal definition of a credit-worthy buyer, the President has now authorized the $1.5 billion in agricultural credits Mr. Gorbachev has been seeking, and he has committed himself to sending to Capitol Hill in the next week or so the enabling measure that would grant preferential trade terms to Moscow. **********The effect of this flurry of activity, which has also included the clarification of disputed terms of the new treaty covering conventional forces in Europe, has been to assist the Soviet leader in significant ways while the Administration and Congress ponder the larger question of how much money the United States should provide to help rebuild the Soviet economy. 'Big Bang' Ruled Out **********Mr. Baker said in a speech in Copenhagen last week that the United States has ruled out the so-called "big bang" approach to helping Moscow. **********In each case, Mr. Bush has made himself look more flexible, more generous, than he might have seemed had he not at first held back. Relatively small, relatively inexpensive symbolic acts have assumed added weight. That suits his purposes, because while he is eager to help Mr. Gorbachev, whom he greatly admires, he is not eager to commit the United States too deeply too quickly. **********Resources are scarce. Demands for domestic spending are rising. But most important of all, even the very near-term future in the Soviet Union is hard to read. On Wednesday, for example, Boris N. Yeltsin, Mr. Gorbachev's principal rival, is likely to win election as President of the Russian republic, putting a skilled political operator with a popular mandate at the helm of the most important consitutent unit of the Soviet Union, with all that implies for Mr. Gorbachev, who has no such mandate. **********If he wins, Washington expects a visit from Mr. Yeltsin, an earthy populist, sometime next week. Mr. Bush is reportedly planning to meet with him in the Oval Office -- an act that will be widely and probably correctly read as a hedging of bets. Further hedging will be needed until it is clear what is going to happen in the Baltic states, the republics in central Asia and those along the sensitive southern border of the Soviet Union, all of which have been growing restive. Arms Talks Stalled **********It seems reasonable to ask now whether Mr. Bush is doing the same thing in the long-stalled strategic missile negotiations, which constitute the last major impediment to a summit meeting in Moscow this summer. The White House said on Monday that the meeting would probably have to be held in late July instead of late June, as originally envisioned. Did that reflect a genuine substantive hang-up, an attempt to bring pressure on the Soviets to soften their arms-reduction position in the hope that a Moscow meeting would bring more economic relief, or an attempt to make an eventual breakthrough look more dramatic? Perhaps a bit of each. **********Few in Washington will be suprised, given the startling cascade of events in recent weeks, if an arms agreement suddenly emerges from one of Mr. Baker's talks with his Soviet counterpart, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, such as their meeting in Berlin next week. A summit date would almost surely be set shortly thereafter. But the Administration, ever loath to raise hopes too much, lest it appear to have failed, keeps talking about the difficult path ahead. **********The agricultural credits are similar to those extended last December at a time when famine was a genuine threat in Soviet cities. Like those, they will cost the American taxpayer nothing unless Moscow defaults -- a major plus for the President, who can seem generous while not pushing himself further into a financial corner at home. **********In the six months since December, even credits have become more controversial. The increasingly feeble Soviet economy makes a default seem more likely, and partisans of the Baltic states in this country, including Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican minority leader, have expressed fears that grain bought with the credits might be witheld from the Lithuanians and other critics of the Gorbachev Government. But they are less risky, Mr. Bush clearly concluded, than most other gestures currently available to him.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/14/world.main_headline: Bush Is Said to Hold Off on Israeli Loan Backing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/14/world.print_headline: Bush Is Said to Hold Off on Israeli Loan Backing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/14/world.body_text: **********President Bush told leaders of American Jewish organizations Tuesday that he would not yet commit himself to the $10 billion in loan guarantees that Israel is seeking to help it absorb tens of thousands of Soviet Jewish immigrants. **********But as one of the leaders, Edgar Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress, said, "On every other subject, the President was very positive in addressing our concerns." **********The President assured the leaders of 18 Jewish groups at a 45-minute meeting at the Waldorf Astoria in Manhattan, that he would push for repeal of Resolution 3379 of the United Nations General Assembly that equates Zionism with racism; that he was commited to Israel's "qualitative edge" in armaments, and that he supported an "undivided Jerusalem." **********Mr. Bush, according to four members of the Jewish delegation, also expressed admiration for the performance of Prime Minister Yitzak Shamir of Israel at the Middle East peace talks in Madrid last month. **********And he blamed himself for unwittingly resurrecting "ugly feelings" when, during a news conference on Sept. 12, he asserted that Jewish lobbying to secure a commitment on the loan guarantees represented "powerful political forces" arrayed against "one lonely little guy." **********A White House spokesman, Roman Popadiuk, said the meeting's "main focus was to give an update on the Madrid peace conference." **********"The President also voiced his strong feelings against anti-Semitism." **********Strident debate erupted over the loan guarantees during the last delicate efforts by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to entice all the parties to the Madrid conference. At that time, Mr. Bush said he would defer making a commitment for 120 days. **********Rabbi Marvin Hier, dean of the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles, said the President began Tuesday's meeting "with a sincere expression of regret for the way he had handled his Sept. 12 press conference." 'Upset With Himself' **********"He seemed genuinely upset with himself," Rabbi Hier continued, "and recognized -- these are his words -- that he 'hurt some people' and had 'unwittlingly resurrected ugly feelings.' " **********Alfred Moses, president of the American Jewish Committee, said President Bush had declared "he is in favor of trying to help Israel's absorption of Soviet Jews; but, as to what's going to happen at the end of 120 days, he gave no commitment on the amount of loan guarantees and said the timing would depend on its effects on the peace process." **********Rabbi Hier said: "No one in the room could agree with that. It runs the risk of signaling the Arabs that they have a veto power." **********Shoshonah Cardin, president of the Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations, said her sense was that Mr. Bush was "sincere and positive," particularly when asked about seeking repeal of Resolution 3379, passed in 1975 by the General Assembly. "The President said the time is right and he agreed there is a window of opportunity," Ms. Cardin said. **********Mr. Bronfman was particularly "fascinated by his attitude toward Mr. Shamir." **********"He wasn't sure whether Shamir's decision to go to Madrid was good," Mr. Bronfman said. "But when there were a lot of provocations for Shamir to break it off, and Shamir just stood fast, he really went up in the President's estimation." **********Mr. Moses said the President expressed his "continuing commitment to 'an undivided Jerusalem,' and that as an 'honest broker' the U.S. won't put proposals on the future of Jerusalem on the table and that, like the settlements issue, it will be discussed at some point by the parties." **********The President, Mr. Moses added, also gave assurances that the United States would maintain Israel's "qualitative edge" in weaponry. "It needs to be reiterated," Mr. Moses said, "because there is talk of a big arms package for the Saudis."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/17/world.body_text: **********Senator George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, introduced legislation today that is meant to force President Bush to declare that China has halted a long list of human rights violations if he wants to continue China's favorable trading status. **********Mr. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, was backed by several other Democrats as he attacked Wednesday's remarks by Mr. Bush that he would seek a one-year extension of most-favored-nation status for China. Mr. Bush acknowledged today that the Administration itself might agree to some conditions on the extension. **********Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said the Administration had not yet decided whether to request an extension with no conditions. "There are other possibilities, such as adding conditions or at least expressing our views about human rights progress in China and other matters." Mr. Bush later told reporters, "Marlin put it right." **********There has been growing irritation with China on Capitol Hill in recent months, and the Administration's readiness to say that some conditions might be appropriate appeared to acknowledge a strong possibility that Congress might adopt some, if not necessarily as stringent as Mr. Mitchell's. **********Last year, Mr. Pease proposed a bill that would have allowed a waiver if Mr. Bush certified that China was making "substantial and demonstrable progress" in human rights. Mr. Mitchell's bill would require a declaration that many specific violations had ceased. **********Introduction of outright resolutions of disapproval is also expected, including one on Friday by Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on East Asian and Pacific Affairs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/15/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Prices Inch Up Overseas
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/15/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in thin overseas trading yesterday. **********With banks and other major institutions closed in observance of Columbus Day, the cash market for Government bills, notes and bonds was closed in the United States. **********Trading in bond futures contracts did take place in Chicago, however, although the hours of operation were shortened. Prices of bond contracts dipped modestly at the Board of Trade. **********The bulk of the day's activity was concentrated in short-term Treasury bills. **********After reviewing economic data released on Friday, which included a report on modest inflation and poor retail sales results for September, foreign traders seemed to concur with their American counterparts that signs pointed to a move by the Federal Reserve Board to lower short-term interest rates to help stimulate the economy.  Auction Reset Today **********Because of the holiday, the weekly auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills will be held today. **********At the close of trading in Europe, three-month bill rates were offered at a discount rate of 4.94 percent, down six basis points, or six one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were offered at 4.99 percent, down five basis points. **********Movement in prices of Treasury notes and bonds overseas was minimal. The 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at 102 26/32, up 2/ 32, to yield 7.87 percent, compared with 7.88 percent late Friday. **********Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 102 27/32, unchanged from late Friday, to yield 7.45 percent. And the 6 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 15/ 32, up 1/32, to yield 5.86 percent. **********On the Chicago Board of Trade, the nearby December bond contract closed at 99 25/32, down 3/32. **********Activity in the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt municipal bond markets was nearly invisible, traders said. **********In both markets, prices of most issues were flat.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/13/world.main_headline: Cutting Back in Lebanon, Iran Is Shifting to Sudan
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/13/world.print_headline: Cutting Back in Lebanon, Iran Is Shifting to Sudan
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/13/world.body_text: **********As it diminishes its presence in Lebanon, Iran appears to be shifting its operations to the Sudan. That is causing growing concern in moderate Arab countries like Egypt, Tunisia and Saudi Arabia as well as among Western security officials. **********Saudi, Egyptian and American officials have said in interviews that over the last few months Iran has sent between 1,000 and 2,000 of its Revolutionary Guards to train Sudanese Army and security personnel in the Sudan, even as Teheran continues to reduce the Revolutionary Guards contingent in the Bekaa region of Lebanon. **********Western and Arab intelligence officials say that at least a dozen training camps have been set up in the Sudan over the last few months in which Islamic fundamentalist militants from Algeria, Tunisia, Egypt and the Persian Gulf region are being trained for subversive activities. **********The officials say the Iranian Government has also supplied at least $17 million worth of military equipment to the Sudanese military dictatorship, headed by Lieut. Gen. Omar Hassan al-Bashir, who took power in June 1989. General Bashir is an outspoken advocate of Islamic fundamentalism and has forged a strong relationship with Sheik Hassan al-Tourabi, a Sudanese who is a leading figure in the pan-Arab Islamic movements that thrive in several Arab countries. **********Indeed, many security specialists in the Middle East say Sheik Tourabi, a 59-year-old scholar and militant Muslim fundamentalist, is the real power behind the Sudanese Government. **********The sheik has a long history of association with the fundamentalist Muslim Brotherhood and has emerged over the past two years as the leading Islamic fundamentalist theoretician and advocate of establishing Islamic regimes in all Arab countries. He has a wide following in the Arab world. As the leader of the National Islamic Front Organization and a fervent supporter of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, he is reckoned by Arab and Western intelligence services to have total control of the Government of General Bashir and senior commanders of the Sudanese Army. **********"There is absolutely no question that Tourabi runs the Sudan and that his present tactic rests on pushing his wider ambitions for a pan-Arab and African base," said Elsir Sayed Ahmad, a Sudanese who is a columnist for the Saudi newspaper Asharq Al Awsat. **********Sudanese officials, including the chief of intelligence and security services, Nafei Ali Nafei, often visit Teheran and are known to receive regular training in intelligence and covert operations there, American and Arab intelligence officials said. **********In a move cementing the relationship between the two countries, President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran is heading a delegation of 150 Iranians that is to begin an official visit to the Sudan on Friday. Among the Iranians will be Ali Falahian, the chief of Iranian secret services, and Mohsen Rezai, the head of the Revolutionary Guards. New Geopolitics **********"Iran is trying to find some new friends in the region and Sudan may be it," commented Amir Taheri, an Iranian affairs expert and author of several books on the Iranian revolution and Islamic movements. **********Mr. Taheri and many other experts on Middle East security affairs say that as the Western hostages in Lebanon are released and as Syria tries to forge friendlier ties to the West, there is less leeway for Iran to use Lebanon as a theater of operations. **********It appears, they say, that Damascus wants to limit the Iranian presence in Beirut and elsewhere in Lebanon, and that the Iranians may be building up operations in the Sudan to compensate. **********Tunisia, Egypt and Saudi Arabia have openly accused the Sudanese Government of giving refuge, passports and logistical support to militant fundamentalist groups held responsible for terrorist attacks in those countries. Tunisia has named the Sudan as a principal supporter of the Tunisian Muslim fundamentalist party Al Nahda, which is accused of having tried to overthrow the Government of President Zein al-Abidine Ben Ali.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/08/busin.body_text: **********For years, the personal computer industry has been regarded as one of America's most vibrant businesses. It seemed to embody the American corporation's ability to innovate and to capitalize on cost-cutting research. As the industry brought powerful computers within the reach of businesses and households, bountiful profits were generated for the companies and their investors. **********But now the industry, and particularly its leaders -- Apple Computer, Compaq and I.B.M. -- face a real test. A squeeze at both ends of their market has sent their profits plummeting. The question is whether they can define strategies that will help them break out of the industry stall and produce the kind of growth and profitability they are used to.  'The Desktop Is Dead' **********"The secular problem is the desktop is dead," said Roger McNamee, an industry analyst at T. Rowe Price in Baltimore. "The PC industry is mature, and MS-DOS is aging," he added, referring to the operating system that is used by the majority of I.B.M. and I.B.M.-compatible personal computers. "The only things that are growing are graphical interface, portable computers and network computing. If you don't have two out of three, you're dead." **********Of course, personal computers -- the boxy desktop variety -- continue to sell in some numbers, but they are rapidly becoming commodity products. Buyers are frequently passing up the name brands for less expensive models. This has forced Apple, Compaq and the International Business Machines Corporation, which have commanded premium prices, to slash prices to compete with the likes of the Dell Computer Corporation and AST Research Inc., which make powerful, reliable clones. **********"In the last few months we've started to see little companies like Northgate and Zeos and DTK in our survey questionnaires," said Dan Ness Jr., a researcher at a company that tracks corporate computer buyers, the Computer Intelligence Corporation of La Jolla, Calif. "A year ago if you asked me if it's a commodity market, I would have said, 'no way.' Now that people are realizing that standards are well established they are shifting whom they buy from." **********As the leading desktop makers are being undercut at the bottom, they are also encountering problems at the high end of their lines. The new Intel 486 microprocessor chip has allowed them to produce desktops fast and powerful enough to compete with work stations, which are more powerful desktop computers that in the past have generally been used for engineering and scientific tasks. But the desktops are still losing out to the work stations, since the software and operating systems available for work stations are superior. **********For a while, the slowdown in desktop sales was seen by many as a function of the weakening economy. But as it became increasingly apparent that the market softness was tied to more fundamental changes in the industry, the computer makers began to focus on reshaping their strategies. **********"There is no question that there has been a slowdown in the industry and we don't see any signs that it's really coming back soon," said James A. Cannavino, an I.B.M. vice president and general manager of the company's personal systems division. "We're ending one era and heading into another." **********One sign of that change is that archrivals I.B.M. and Apple have begun discussing a potential alliance. Last month, I.B.M.'s president, Jack D. Kuehler, visited Apple's headquarters in Cupertino, Calif. The companies discussed a variety of possible technology exchanges in personal computers. These included licensing by I.B.M. of its RS/6000 chip technology to Apple, and Apple licensing some of its software to I.B.M. **********Each of these is a strength the other needs. The RS/6000 is a microprocessor I.B.M. uses in its work station business that may have applications for future personal computers. **********For I.B.M., using Apple's software would allow it to try to differentiate its machines more from those of competitors. Until now, it has used software jointly developed with Microsoft, but has been unhappy that Microsoft has had so much control over the direction of personal computer software. **********The source of many of the industry's current problems can be tracked to limitations found in the microprocessor chip that was the heart of the first I.B.M. personal computer introduced in 1981. At that time, I.B.M. chose the 8088 chip produced by the Intel Corporation, even though many computer experts considered an alternative chip, the Motorola Corporation's 68000, to be technically superior. **********The 8088 chip could use only a limited amount of computer memory, and it seemed adequate at the time. Later, however, it became the Achilles' heel of the I.B.M. and compatible computer makers. **********Microsoft's MS-DOS operating system was designed around those limits. By contrast, early work stations were built around chips made by Motorola, without the memory limits. As a result, the work station world has been able to develop more advanced software. **********The conventional wisdom once was that the MS-DOS operating system, on which Microsoft and I.B.M. built the business marketplace, would last forever. But that has proved inaccurate. The traditional MS-DOS market has trailed off rapidly and the remaining upgrade business from 16- to 32-bit computers and from character-based to graphical systems based on programs like Microsoft's Windows has not covered the decline. Shift Was Predicted **********Many veteran industry executives said that the upheaval had been long overdue. **********"I've been predicting this for some time," said Gordon Bell, a leading industry computer designer. "The surprise is that it took so long before the brutality of it happened. The guys who have gotten less efficient, like Compaq, were obvious targets." **********While personal computer makers have continued to innovate, many have been slow to push beyond the original single-application uses like word processing and spreadsheets, which drove the industry in the early 1980's. **********"There is a shift inside the industry," said Andrew Grove, Intel's president. "The center of gravity is increasingly moving to group or community computing." **********No one seems to have been well insulated from the changes, although some of the companies hurt most say they see opportunities. For the moment, though, they are all scrambling to refashion their strategies -- restructuring, as well as looking for markets with high growth potential like mobile notebook and pentop computing.  Leaders Aren't Leaving **********The three industry leaders are not leaving the field. In fact all are trying to either create new markets or expand existing ones. Each is taking a somewhat different tack. **********I.B.M., the most broadly diversified of the PC manufacturers, is hoping that it will be able to use sophisticated software to differentiate it from the pack of clone makers. It is gambling that a new version of its OS/2 operating system, which has languished until now, will eventually be an industry hit and permit the company to tie personal computers more closely to its large commercial systems. It has also recently entered the notebook market and re-entered the home computer market. **********But Mr. Cannavino, the I.B.M. vice president, argues that his company should benefit if corporate customers shift their buying to systems that work together. "Computing in the future will require a systems and support structure that is more substantial," Mr. Cannavino said. "We have lots of experience doing this." **********If I.B.M. sees its future in moving upscale, Compaq has a different vision. The rapid shift in the industry appears to have caught the Houston-based company by surprise. **********Compaq originally made its name by cloning I.B.M.'s personal computer, but it has been slow to differentiate itself from the commodity part of the market. Now it is attempting to re-create the phenomenon of the clone companies with a new line of machines that will match the abilities of the work station makers. **********To do this, it has struck up an alliance with 20 other computer and software companies, including the Digital Equipment Corporation, the Microsoft Corporation, Silicon Graphics Inc. and the MIPS Computer Company, to define a new standard for advanced personal computers. The group, known as the Advanced Computing Environment, has defined a new standard aimed at creating a new generation of personal computers that will share information effectively and have powerful graphics features. **********Apple has yet another strategy. In October 1990, it embarked on a quest for growth in the low-cost consumer market, a strategy it has consciously avoided since its founding in 1977. **********To accommodate this strategy and still squeeze out the kind of profits it made when it had the freedom to price its computers above those of other PC makers, it has had to push down costs. It has already announced that it will cut employment 10 percent. And on Friday, the company confirmed that it is considering cutting executive pay by 10 percent. **********But it is exploring other new markets, too, from palm-top computers to mobile consumer appliances. It has invested in General Magic Inc., a Silicon Valley start-up led by former Macintosh developers. The company is trying to develop a portable software system that will have the same influence that the Macintosh has had on the desktop.  New Uses of Computers **********What will determine the success or failure of all of these efforts, industry executives say, is the degree to which these companies are able to offer significant technical innovations that permit new uses of computers. For example, with the introduction of its System 7 operating system earlier this month, Apple has a substantial advantage in developing new applications. **********I.B.M. will introduce a new version of its OS/2 operating system later this year. Microsoft's competing version of OS/2 will not be available until sometime next year. **********As these companies pursue their strategies, one thing seems certain: profit margins will continue to erode before new approaches bear fruit. **********In fact, declining profitability is likely to be a persistent problem in the personal computer industry for the foreseeable future. The Gartner Group forecasts that beginning this year, the volume in personal computer shipments will rise 16 percent annually, from the 10 percent annual growth seen over the last five years. But it expects revenues to grow by only 13 percent, down from 21 percent annually from 1985 to 1990.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/11/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; To Saddam Hussein, With Ill Wishes
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/11/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; To Saddam Hussein, With Ill Wishes
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/11/world.body_text: **********Defense Secretary Dick Cheney flashed a wicked smile, grabbed the big black marking pen and sent something less than his best wishes to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. **********"To Saddam," Mr. Cheney wrote on the 2,000-pound bomb destined for an Iraqi target. "With appreciation. Dick Cheney." **********At today's bomb-signing ceremony at a large Saudi air base, Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was next in line. "To Saddam," he wrote. "You didn't move it, and now you'll lose it. Colin Powell."  Stealth's the Word **********It had been a taxing, somber weekend for Mr. Cheney and General Powell, who had come to Saudi Arabia for briefings on the progress of operations in the Persian Gulf and for guidance on when American-led forces should launch a ground war against Iraq. **********In a pleasant diversion on their way home today, the two stopped for a pair of rousing meetings with airmen at the sprawling Saudi base used by a squadron of American F-117A Stealth fighters, the jet-black, stingray-shaped planes that are designed to deflect enemy radar. **********The Stealth project is still so sensitive that Defense Department officials insisted today that reporters not disclose any details about the location of the Saudi base. They could not even specify if the base was in the northern, southern, eastern or western part of the country. **********Airmen at the base are not allowed to call home to the United States for fear they might be overheard on open phone lines discussing the abilities and the exact mission of the Stealth, which is being used for bombing raids on Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait.  For the Children **********Bingo night held a special significance last week on the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt, now cruising in the gulf. All proceeds went to the families of three Navy pilots who failed to return to the carrier from raids on Iraq. **********Lieut. Cmdr. Tom Hammon of Baytown, Tex., organized the fund-raising drive, which is intended to educate the four children of the missing fliers. More than $8,000 has been collected so far. **********"It was something to see, a petty officer third class walking in with $20 bills still warm from the cash machine, giving two weeks' pay to kids of men he'd never met," said Commander Hammon, a maintenance officer in the carrier's fighter wing. **********"The guy just handed me the money and tried to walk away before I could shake his hand," he told an American pool reporter. "That's the kind of people we have here." **********Commander Hammon said the four children were an 11-year-old, a 3-year-old and twins a year and a half old. He would not identify the children by name or sex, out of concern that someone might harass their mothers. "We take care of our own," he said.  A Price on Their Head **********The price on the head of a pro-Iraqi terrorist in Saudi Arabia just went up. **********The Saudi Government has announced it will pay one million Saudi rials, or about $278,000, to anyone who provides "information on subversives or their accomplices." **********The price paid by the terrorist remains the same. Under the Sharia, the Muslim code that is law in Saudi Arabia, conviction on charges of murder or attempted murder can result in a public beheading or removal of limbs.  Small, Slow, Deadly **********More on the Stealth fighters: Few Americans have ever been given the opportunity to see one of these remarkable planes up close, and for American journalists who viewed the squadron today at a Saudi air base, a few myths about the plane were exploded. **********Despite photographs in newspapers and magazines that would tend to make it look like one of aviation's behemoths, the Stealth is actually quite small, about the same size as an F-15 jet fighter. The Stealth is 65 feet long and 12 feet high, with a wingspan of 43 feet. **********It is also, by standards of the American military jet fleet, quite slow. The Stealth flies at subsonic speeds. **********Sgt. Bobby Shelton, a spokesman for the 37th Tactical Fighter Wing, which flies the Stealth here and in the United States, said the beauty of the plane was, of course, its ability to evade radar and to hit targets with what he described as "pinpoint accuracy." **********The war in the gulf is its first big test in combat, "and we've performed flawlessly," he said. Secretary Cheney said today that the Stealth was one of the department's "great success stories of recent years." **********Air Forces officials acknowledge that the plane was not tested as it might have been. Iraq's air defense operations were largely knocked out in the first days of the war, negating much of the need for the Stealth's special abilities. **********At least one of the Stealth pilots who met with Mr. Cheney today complained that his fighter appeared to be cursed. The pilot, Maj. Lee Guston, said his fighter had been nicknamed Christine, for the killer car of Stephen King horror-novel fame. **********"It's just a jinxed jet sometimes," the major said. "We've had some electrical anomalies, but we keep her flying." **********Whatever the problems, it should be noted that along Christine's side were the stenciled shapes of 11 bombs, meaning that the plane had completed 11 successful bombing missions over Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait.  Today's Souvenir **********The world turns. The stories change. **********A German television journalist posted a sign in a hotel in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, this weekend offering a piece of the demolished Berlin Wall -- a souvenir of last year's big story -- for a piece of a American-made Patriot defense missile. **********The Patriots have become press darlings in recent weeks after knocking several Iraqi Scud missiles out of the sky over Israel and eastern Saudi Arabia.  THE F-117A STEALTH FIGHTER The first brief details and a photograph of the F-117A were provided by the Defense Department on Nov. 10, 1988, although the fighter had been under development for more than 10 years. Its swept back wings and angular, pyramid-shaped fuselage are designed to keep the plane from being detected by radar. In addition, the surface is covered with radar absorbing materials. The F-117A was first used in the U.S. operation to overthrow Panama's military government in December 1989. Six fighters flew from their base at the Tonopah Test Range in Nevada to Panama, refueling in air, and two of them each dropped a laser-guided bomb on two barracks at Rio Hato. First flight: June 1981. First use in combat: Dec. 21, 1989, Panama. Crew: Pilot only. Armament: Full range of Air Force weapons, including Maverick air-to-surface missiles and high-speed anti-radar missiles. Dimensions: Wing span, 43 feet 4 inches; length, 65 feet 11 inches; height, 12 feet 5 inches. Normal maximum speed: Near Mach 1. Range: 900 miles, without refueling in air. Primary contractor: Lockheed Aeronautical Systems Group, Burbank, Calif. Source: Jane's All the World's Aircraft; Periscope
