https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/world.body_text: **********Stunned and wary, the Soviet opposition movement was considering today whether it could conduct a civil disobedience campaign to protest the Government's tough new military plan for policing the nation. **********The Kremlin's plan, which goes into effect on Friday, gives sweeping investigative powers to the K.G.B. and authorizes the use of the army to begin policing major cities and regions of the nation in the name of combatting economic crime. **********The government of the Russian federated republic, the largest part of the Soviet Union, protested the military patrols today, calling them "a gross violation of human rights" and democratic sovereignty, and saying the patrols risked further destabilizing this tense and troubled nation. Opposition Has Been Growing **********Vocal opposition to the plan has been growing, and today the Government reported the first instance of popular protest, which halted railroad service for a few hours in Samtrediya, a city in Georgia. Some dissidents are proposing widespread nonviolent disobedience, but it is not yet clear that the fledgling opposition movement can manage such an effort. **********Critics say the actual motive of the Kremlin military patrols is to crimp political dissent, not economic crime. Sergei S. Stankevich, deputy chairman of the insurgent-led Moscow City Council, said that Moscow's streets were orderly and had no need of troop patrols. The measures, he said, are probably a prelude to additional hard-line economic and social changes being planned by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********As the deadline for the tougher policing measures approached, the Kremlin denied that the military patrols were intended for anything but "to prevent crime on the streets and insure citizens' safety." Moscow military officials said that while the use of tanks and armored personnel carriers was an option under the new plan, these would be kept in reserve on the grounds of city garrisons. **********"I don't care how they say it -- this is martial law," one Muscovite said in a conversation, summarizing the public's widespread skepticism about the Kremlin's use of troops as police, to be used wherever and whenever Government officials decide they are necessary. Gorbachev Responds to Critics **********That measure, plus a related one allowing the K.G.B.'s police investigators widespread authority to look into personal and business relations for evidence of crime, have been denounced as unconstitutional. Responding to criticism that the measures are dictatorial, Mr. Gorbachev today signed a presidential order reaffirming the military city patrols and asserting that they were legal under his recently broadened emergency powers. **********Tension over the heightening of central Kremlin power has been growing across the nation ever since a bloody crackdown on the Baltic independence movement began earlier this month with Mr. Gorbachev's blessing. He followed this up by authorizing stronger K.G.B. and military powers in the civilian sphere, proposing limits on the non-government press and suddenly banning 100-ruble and 50-ruble notes. **********This increased public alarm over the economy, particularly over price increases for "food and other luxury items," as one newspaper sardonically put it. President Gorbachev has backed off from promises to move rapidly toward the free market and again embraced economic Communism. **********In the capital's non-government farmers' markets, where many prices float, a chicken now costs 50 rubles. This is a breathtaking amount for most citizens, close to a fifth of the average monthly wage. Chickens in Government stores sell for a set price of 8 rubles, which is a recent increase, but they seem tiny, blue-hued and inedible. Rumors Denied, but Only in Part **********As the publics spread rumors that steeper, more sweeping price rises are in the works, a Government spokesman for the price committee complained about "frightening" misinformation. But then he said that "a price reform is necessary," although he did not say it might come as soon as Friday, as rumors insist. **********Critics speculate that the tougher policing measures have been prepared in conjunction with further drastic economic changes that will prove highly unpopular. **********Leaders of the insurgent movement, who have stepped up their warnings of a Gorbachev dictatorship and of de facto martial law, met last weekend in Kharkov to consider the feasibility of civil disobedience. **********Further strategy meetings are being held here this week, with the key figure once again being Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic. He has become the chief rallying point in the opposition to President Gorbachev's swift retreat from his own democratization campaign toward traditional hard-line control. **********Mr. Yeltsin, who has not publicly committed himself to a course of action, is preparing for a meeting on Thursday of his republic's Parliament to debate the Gorbachev program and consider countermeasures.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/world.main_headline: Iraq, Seeking to Regroup Forces, Orders an Amnesty for Deserters
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: IRAQ; Iraq, Seeking to Regroup Forces, Orders an Amnesty for Deserters
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/world.body_text: **********Seeking to regroup and marshal their war-scarred forces, the Iraqi authorities declared an extraordinary amnesty today for deserters and other soldiers absent from their units. **********Weeks of bombing of Iraqi positions and the lightning advance of allied ground forces have spread deep disarray in the Iraqi military, allied officials say. Iraqi Army units have been cut off from one another, tens of thousands of prisoners are in allied hands, and unknown numbers of deserters have shed their weapons and uniforms. **********A decree from Iraq's Revolutionary Command Council, broadcast on the Baghdad radio today, said, "Deserters and absentees shall be pardoned from the crime of desertion or absenteeism from military service, provided they join their divisions and army corps within seven days, effective from the announcement of this decree." **********The decree was unusual because desertion is routinely punishable by death and because Baghdad is generally very reluctant to acknowledge anything short of valor among its armed forces. Moreover, it seemed to acknowledge desertion on a large scale. **********In another highly unusual move in a society where security concerns are paramount, the Baghdad radio also listed the location of units to which deserters and absentee troops should return, and the deployment seemed to suggest that units had been depleted across the country, including Kurdish areas in the north. **********The radio listed five major units in Basra province to which deserters should report, including the Republican Guard, once viewed as the cutting edge of the Iraqi Army and the most loyal to President Saddam Hussein. It also urged troops to return to units in the Erbil region in the north and other units in the Maysan, Tamim and Karbala districts. **********The decree attributed the disarray to "the disruption of bridges and roads under the circumstances of the war, which was imposed by the infidels and unjust ones on Iraq" and to "administrative and transport difficulties." **********"Some have failed to respond to the call for compulsory service and reserve service," it said, but added that since some bridges and roads had now been repaired, soldiers should prove their "sincere patriotism" and return their units. The decree was signed by President Hussein as chairman of the Revolutionary Command Council, the Baghdad radio said. **********The decree did not allude to reported strife in southern Iraq or suggest that the reason for the regrouping was to move against insurgency. Rather, diplomats suggested, the intention may have been to restore some order to one of the Government's most important institutions in readiness for any further upheaval.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/23/busin.main_headline:
Global Investing - a special report: GERMANY;
Insider Trading Scandal Grows
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/23/busin.print_headline:
Global Investing - a special report: GERMANY;
Insider Trading Scandal Grows
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/23/busin.body_text: **********The last thing Germany needed was a scandal that would put a spotlight on the fact that insider trading is not illegal in Germany, and that its markets are dominated by its banks. **********Germany has been trying to raise Frankfurt's status as an international financial center and is vying to be the site of the proposed European central bank as part of Europe's economic integration. **********But an insider trading scandal erupted with the publication last month of an anonymous letter from a former Deutsche Bank employee who worked in its securities department. Using the details in the letter -- names, account numbers and records of money transfers -- federal and state prosecutors are investigating possible tax evasion linked to reported insider trading. **********Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest commercial bank and a behemoth in the nation's bank-dominated securities market, is pursuing its own internal investigation, a spokesman said. On July 5, the bank dismissed Manfred Mertens, its 30-year-old chief options trader, saying he violated unspecified "internal rules not related to trading and sales." The Frankfurt Stock Exchange is also investigating. **********Until now, Germans assured themselves that a gentleman's agreement was sufficient to prevent insider trading, which is deemed unethical but not criminal. In the rare case where someone was caught violating the unwritten code, the result has always been a slap on the wrist, a quick return to business as usual and a few disapproving articles in the national press calling for better regulation. A Clamor for Change **********Those calls have now become a clamor. "Everyone here wants laws making insider trading a criminal offense," said Rudiger von Rosen, chairman of the Federation of German Stock Exchanges and managing director of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange. "We are working on them, but it takes time. It must, and will, happen by the middle of 1992. That is the mandate we are working under from the European Community." **********But Mr. von Rosen minimized the current investigations. "There is no scandal here. There are only competing accusations in the media, nothing more," he said. **********Rather than closing ranks as it has in the past, the city's banking community is bitterly split over securities trading practices. Adding to the tension are rumors that the Frankfurt state prosecutor will soon expand his inquiry to include other banks as well as independent stock traders. **********Helmut Hartmann, chief spokesman for Deutsche Bank, said in a newspaper interview that he did not think insider trading was any more of a problem at Deutsche Bank than at any other bank. That drew irate responses from other bankers. **********"It irks me," said Ulrich Ramm, chief economist at Commerzbank A.G. in Frankfurt. "If Deutsche Bank is successful with something, they present it as a wonderful new discovery. But when they run into a problem, they say it is shared by the entire German banking sector, even though our bank and others have completely different internal controls than they do." Borrowing to Invest **********At Deutsche Bank, employees can borrow an amount equal to one year's salary to speculate in the securities markets, a spokesman said, and traders are not required to clear their trades immediately, but can wait in some cases until the following day. That allows major investors to conceal the size of their positions from the market and does not give the market the latest information about prices at which securites are actually changing hands. **********By contrast, Commerzbank employees must route their stock trades through the bank's personnel department, which has a special unit to monitor in-house securities trading, and traders, analysts and other potential insiders are barred from borrowing to conduct their personal trades. **********Deutsche Bank is said to be weighing a change in its house rules, but it is concerned that it will lose some of its best traders to other banks where personal trading is permitted. **********To eliminate such disparities in trading practices, Mr. von Rosen said, Germany needs new laws and "a central authority." But he said he did not believe insider trading could be completely eliminated. "Even with the best laws, you cannot completely protect people from being murdered in New York," Mr. von Rosen said. "We have to make it possible that the investor gets the fairest treatment possible. The markets here must be extremely transparent. But it is not possible to control everything."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/22/busin.main_headline: Bear, Stearns Sues Proxy Firm, Saying Deceit Was Used to Obtain Secrets
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/22/busin.print_headline: Bear, Stearns Sues Proxy Firm, Saying Deceit Was Used to Obtain Secrets
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/22/busin.body_text: **********Bear, Stearns & Company filed suit yesterday against one of Wall Street's largest proxy solicitors, charging that employees of D. F. King & Company illegally obtained confidential information about the securities transactions of some of the brokerage's wealthiest clients. **********The suit says King employees used the confidential information in the company's proxy business and sold it to some clients. The information was said to include the names of Bear, Stearns clients and the number of shares they held in specific stocks and other securities. Such information could be useful to companies that want to find out who is accumulating their stock or who owns securities that would need to be tendered in a corporate reorganization. **********John Gavin, president of D. F. King, indicated yesterday that evidence had been found supporting the claim, but he said the questionable activities involved only a single employee. "Based on counsel's preliminary review of the facts, the allegations, if true, appear to be limited to only one of King's employees," he said. "Pending completion of the investigation, that employee has been suspended."  Market-Intelligence Unit **********Like other proxy solicitors on Wall Street, King runs a market-intelligence division, which is hired by corporations and others to determine why unusual trading activity is taking place in clients' stock. It is this division that conducted the activities detailed in the suit. **********The lawsuit describes a scheme that Bear, Stearns unraveled after becoming suspicious three years ago. The firm said that people working for King telephoned employees who worked in sensitive areas at the brokerage. The King employees identified themselves as senior executives or traders at Bear, Stearns, the brokerage contends, and demanded that the clerks tell them which accounts had bought particular stocks or bonds, and in what quantities. **********Proxy solicitors emerged as important powers on Wall Street in the last decade. As takeover battles moved from the board room to shareholders, proxy solicitors made the appeals to individuals, drafted the advertisements stating a company's case, and counted the ballots. **********As their roles grew, the proxy firms established market-intelligence units, which built on the proxy business to keep a steady flow of revenue coming from companies that wanted to know why investors were buying or selling large amounts of their securities.  Battle for Dominance **********King, one of two giant proxy solicitors on Wall Street, has for years been locked in a head-to-head battle with its chief competitor, Georgeson & Company. A third proxy solicitor, the Carter Organization, was rocked in a 1989 scandal that resulted in a guilty plea by its founder, Donald C. Carter, to charges of stealing $1 million from clients. **********Bear, Stearns executives expressed anger yesterday about the scheme that they charge D. F. King with committing. "To say that we're upset about this is an understatement," Alan C. Greenberg, the chairman of Bear, Stearns, said in an interview. "What they have done, what we are aware of, is absolute lying and stealing." **********Mr. Greenberg said the New York City Police Department was alerted to the situation during the firm's internal investigation. A lawyer for Bear, Stearns said the firm had not yet consulted the Securities and Exchange Commission or the United States Attorney's office, but was examining that possibility.  First Suspected in 1988 **********If such a scheme did take place, the potential damage to market investors could be substantial. Mr. Greenberg said the firm first suspected leaks of confidential information in 1988, as some clients who had quietly accumulated large amounts of stock in a company were telephoned by executives of that company to find out their intentions. Also, holders of large amounts of bonds in confidential accounts were called during corporate restructurings by officials seeking their support. Mr. Greenberg refused to say if King was responsible for those leaks, citing a court-imposed seal on a related lawsuit. **********But Bear, Stearns is contending that it was damaged by the scheme it says occurred, as some clients stopped doing business with the firm after confidential information was leaked. "There is no question that people did leave," Mr. Greenberg said. "They were afraid there was leakage. It was horribly embarrassing." **********The firm investigated the leaks for years, believing that the information was stolen or that employees were bribed or tricked. After using lie detectors and other investigative efforts, Bear, Stearns executives concluded that employees were being tricked by someone outside the firm. **********Bear, Stearns said it obtained evidence of a link to King by tapping phones in sensitive areas and obtaining a court order for telephone company records. Those records showed that calls in which people claimed to be Bear, Stears executives were placed from King's offices. **********A related suit from Bear, Stearns was filed in the past against King, the complaint indicates. The allegations in that suit, however, were sealed. Bear, Stearns is now seeking to have the filings in that suit unsealed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/24/busin.body_text: **********Foote, Cone & Belding, Chicago, yesterday was awarded the advertising account for Moussy, a non-alcoholic brew imported from Switzerland by the Coors Brewing Company of Golden, Colo. Foote, Cone is also the agency for Coors beer brands, including Coors Light and Coors Extra Gold. **********Heidelberg & Associates, New York, had handled the account before Coors acquired Moussy's North American distribution rights in April as part of efforts to expand its product lines. Coors is also introducing its own non-alcoholic brew, Cutter, in a campaign created by Tatham/RSCG, Chicago. **********While Moussy's billings previously ran under $1 million, advertising executives expect Coors will substantially increase the budget to compete with other non-alcoholic brews.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/09/busin.body_text: **********An Atlanta financier and a group of pilots, mostly former employees of the bankrupt Eastern Airlines, said today that they planned to start a new airline in November using the Eastern name and some of its assets. **********The financier, John R. Mitchell, who is the group's chairman, said the airline would begin operating in November or early December under the name "the New Eastern." The group, currently called the Airline Acquisition Corporation, said it expected to close on a $550 million capital package on Oct. 15. **********Mr. Mitchell said the company had commitments, primarily from foreign investors, for $160 million in equity. The group would need $90 million more in equity and $300 million in various debt instruments. **********He would only name one of the potential foreign investors, Cousourio Cintemex of Mexico, but said additional equity was being sought from the Middle East. United States law, however, requires carriers to raise 51 percent of their equity from domestic sources. The group has hired Lehman Brothers as its financial adviser. **********Eastern ceased operations Jan. 19 after failing to recover from a March 1989 strike by unionized mechanics. The company had been in bankruptcy proceedings for nearly two years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/10/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********"It's Time to Stop Poking Along at 55" (Forum, Sept. 29) obviously generated considerable interest (Letters, Oct. 13) but two myths concerning the 55 miles-per-hour speed limit still need addressing. **********We have been told it saves lives because in 1973, when the law was enacted, the number of highway deaths declined. But because of fuel shortages, the number of vehicle miles driven that year declined 25 percent. The number of highway deaths per 100 million vehicle miles actually rose in 1973. In 1989, deaths per 100 million vehicle miles dropped to 2.3, the lowest since statistics were first recorded in 1926. In 1990, they dropped to a new low, 2.2. **********As an automotive engineer, I have kept a record of the fuel mileage for each vehicle I have driven for the past 30 years, matching it to various conditions. Since 1973, I have found that I get 8 to 10 percent more miles per gallon driving in the 65 to 70 m.p.h. range than at 50 to 55 m.p.h. Others who keep mileage records report similar results. The reason is obvious if you observe traffic flow. Driving 55 m.p.h. on a highway designed for 70 m.p.h. causes a reduction in the highway's vehicle capacity, producing congestion and backups that force braking, acceleration and accelerator-pumping. **********We should return to a strictly enforced 70 m.p.h. limit on the Interstates and other highways designed for that speed. We'll save lives and fuel. DONALD G. HARTER  Holmdel, N.J., Oct. 23

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/busin.main_headline: Boeing Sees End To Unit's Losses

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/busin.body_text: **********The Boeing Company's military division, which has lost money for several years, will become profitable late in 1991, a company vice president, Gary Bland, said. Boeing expects its overall earnings to rise to $4.50 or $5 a share this year, compared with $4.01 in 1990, Mr. Bland told industry analysts. **********Boeing is the world leader in commercial aviation, producing about 60 percent of the jets used by airline companies. But its military division has lost money for several years as United States military spending has leveled off. Despite the expected year-end turnaround, the division could still lose as much as $150 million in 1991, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; BellSouth Wins Bid For Australia Service
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/20/busin.body_text: **********The BellSouth Corporation, the regional Bell company based in Atlanta, said yesterday that it was part of a three-nation consortium that won the right to provide telecommunications services in Australia. **********BellSouth said the group, which includes Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain, bid the equivalent of $640 million. **********The venture, known as Optus Communications, will compete against the Government-owned entities, Telecom Australia, which provides local service, and OTC, which provides long-distance service. **********BellSouth and Cable each own 24.5 percent of the venture. BellSouth's share of the purchase price is about $157 million. BellSouth will offer expertise on cellular telephones and Cable and Wireless on international long distance. They will jointly operate domestic long-distance service. **********Optus's majority holders are Australians, as mandated by law. They are Mayne Nickless, a transportation and health services company; the Australian Mutual Provident Society and National Mutual, two life insurance companies, and AIDC Ltd. Telecommunications Fund, a mutual fund. **********Like other Bell companies, BellSouth has tried to cope with slow-growing domestic markets by searching for opportunities abroad. Though Australia is in a deep recession, BellSouth is betting that the economy will revive and prosper. Australia's gross domestic product per capita is about $18,000 a year, compared with about $22,000 in the United States. Australia's distance from other countries could also increase long-distance calling. **********Optus plans to spend $3.1 billion over the next five years to modernize Australia's telephone network with fiber-optic cables. BellSouth said it would contribute $300 million of its own money over the next four years and that the contribution will hurt earnings by 4 cents a share in 1992 and 7 cents a share in 1993. BellSouth earned $1.63 billion, or $3.38 a share, on revenues of $14.3 billion in 1990. **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, BellSouth shares lost 62.5 cents each, closing at $46.875.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/20/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: News Analysis; For Bush, Half a Loaf?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/20/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: News Analysis; For Bush, Half a Loaf?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/20/world.body_text: **********The Soviet peace initiative seems to present President Bush with a painful choice: pushing for an all-out military victory over Iraq or nurturing a diplomatic settlement that might get the Iraqis out of Kuwait but also allow President Saddam Hussein to save enough political face to preserve his Government. **********Mr. Bush has been keeping his own counsel as he wrestles with what aides say could be his most difficult challenge: how to appear open to a peaceful solution without letting Mr. Hussein gain politically on the virtual eve of what would likely be his military defeat. As one Administration official put it today: "If Saddam accepts this Soviet proposal we have a real problem." **********Administration officials say the problem is rooted in the fact that the Soviet proposal, which has not been disclosed publicly, does not, on the surface, appear unreasonable. Without being specific about its provisions, Administration officials hint that it involves Soviet commitments to Iraq -- commitments that would not bind the United States or its coalition partners -- in return for an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, which the United States is demanding. **********The main problem, officials say, is that President Bush has been committed to ending the Persian Gulf war with either a military defeat of Mr. Hussein or a political humiliation of him by forcing the Iraqi leader to withdraw from Kuwait without any "reward." Anything short of either of those options, officials argue, could leave Mr. Hussein as a dangerous power in the region. **********Mr. Bush's objective, in other words, is not simply to get Iraq out of Kuwait, but to do so in a way that will insure that Mr. Hussein has nothing to show to his people and the Arab world for his Kuwait adventure -- except the destruction of his army and his country. Aides say Mr. Bush seems to believe that the Soviet initiative, if accepted in its present form by Iraq, might prevent such a clear-cut outcome. 'He Got Off the Hook' **********This is because the Soviet initiative, according to the vague descriptions being offered here, seems to involve Kremlin promises to try to address the Arab-Israel dispute after the gulf war, to secure Iraq's territorial integrity, to work for a lifting of sanctions on Iraq, to saving Mr. Hussein's regime and to oppose any retribution against Mr. Hussein. Those are concessions that the Iraqi leader has sought and might be able to present at home and in the Arab world as some sort of reward for leaving Kuwait. **********"Even if it doesn't look like much today," an Administration official said, "what will it look like six months from now when he is still around? People will say we rewarded aggression. People will say he got off the hook. They will ask what was this all about. They will say that after all the lines we drew in the sand we blinked." **********Because President Bush and his advisers are convinced that they could crush the Iraqi Army in Kuwait at a relatively low cost in allied lives, they say they are frustrated to have to deal with any solution that would involve neither a clear-cut military defeat of Iraq nor a clear-cut political defeat of President Hussein. 'Disastrous to Pause' **********As Representative John Murtha, the Pennsylvania Democrat who is chairman of the House Appropriations defense subcommittee, told reporters after meeting today with President Bush: "It would be disastrous to pause right now and let Saddam Hussein rehabilitate himself. He's either going to start withdrawing now or he's going to be forced to withdraw with some bloody battles. We're going to get him out of Kuwait. And I think Saddam Hussein will go, either from inside, internally, or militarily." **********But this raises a second problem. Administration officials know that if Iraq accepts the Soviet initiative, and the United States still goes ahead with a ground war, many Americans and many American allies in Europe and the Arab world who are not part of the anti-Baghdad military force would ask: how could the President risk so many lives to liberate Kuwait by force when he could have had a peaceful Iraqi withdrawal at the small price of Soviet promises that might not even bind the United States? **********Indeed, the German Government has already expressed support for the Soviet initiative. U.S.-Soviet Ties at Risk **********Even more serious would be what might happen to Soviet cooperation with the United States in the gulf, which has been the keystone of the entire international coalition. If Moscow has made what it believes to be a good faith offer involving, in its view, only relatively minor Soviet concessions to Baghdad, and the Iraqis accept it and Washington rejects it, that could mark the end of Soviet-American cooperation in this crisis, and afterward. **********"We ought not to be dismissive of the Soviet effort," said Representative Lee H. Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who is chairman of the House subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East. "The Soviets are going to need our support after this war ends and we are going to need their acquiescence in the Middle East to do what we want. There is a lot at risk in United States-Soviet relations, in United States-Arab relations and in United States-Europe relations if we pass up a real opportunity to end this war." **********The third problem, from the Administration's point of view, is what happens if the Iraqis agree to most of the Soviet proposal but ask to simply negotiate a few points. **********"How can we then launch our ground war?" the Administration official asked. "If they are perceived to be working toward peace, how can we put our other foot down?" Exploiting a Delay **********Yet, said the official, any pause in the war would surely be exploited by the Iraqis to repair their runways or communications. **********What Mr. Bush did today when he said the Soviet proposal fell "well short" of American conditions was a pre-emptive strike, officials say. He hoped to both signal America's ongoing openness for diplomacy -- by not totally rejecting the Soviet initiative -- while signaling Moscow that if it wants its mediation effort to bear any fruit it is going to have to strip it of any components that would help Mr. Hussein survive politically. **********Mr. Bush's message has only highlighted the difference between the American and Soviet approaches to the gulf crisis. For the Kremlin the issue is Kuwait. For the United States the issue is Kuwait and the fate of the Iraqi Army and President Hussein. **********Those are also the issues for America's main allies in the region, particularly Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Israel. **********The Saudis believe that a Saddam Hussein who survives this war would bide his time before coming after them. Israelis have told Washington that they would rather live with President Hussein without his army than Iraq's Army without Mr. Hussein -- although they would prefer to be rid of both. The Israeli view is that capabilities create intentions, and therefore as long as Iraq has such a large army it will eventually be a threat, even if Mr. Hussein is removed and is replaced by some colonel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/world.main_headline: Assassination in India; On the Funeral Route, Quiet, Uneasy Crowds
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/world.print_headline: Assassination in India; On the Funeral Route, Quiet, Uneasy Crowds
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/world.body_text: **********A helicopter swooped low and showered rose petals over the gun-carriage carrying the body of Rajiv Gandhi. The crowd surged forward as the journey began in heavy heat through the capital. **********"A fair man, an honest man, not like the average Indian politician," murmured D. Rama Krishna Reddy, a 30-year-old lawyer, standing in the swarm near Teen Murti House, the historic mansion where Mr. Gandhi lay in state. "Rajiv was a viable leader. Who else is there?" **********Along the nearly six-mile route, there was more sadness than grief as thousands watched, mostly in silence, while the gun carriage moved quickly through the streets surrounded by hundreds of men in white shirts, members of Mr. Gandhi's Congress Party, and jeeps loaded with soldiers. **********But Mr. Gandhi's assassination has left the mourning crowds uneasy about the violence that blights India, about the political future of the world's most populous democracy, even about Mr. Gandhi's legacy.  'Nothing Changes' **********"People thought a new India would be born with Rajiv Gandhi," Rajesh Kumar, an engineer, said near India Gate, the high stone arch on the eastern end of Raj Path. "It wasn't. He had too many cronies, corrupt people around him. He disappointed us. There are still two Indias, high-tech and poor, with people hungry. Nothing changes. This election, we hoped, it would change. We hoped he had changed." **********Nearby, an army officer, a man in his late 40's with a British accent, recalled that he knew Mr. Gandhi at the exclusive Doon School, a preparatory academy in Dehra Dun, in the foothills of the Himalayas. The officer, who declined to give his name, was a year ahead of Mr. Gandhi. **********"He was well-behaved, very popular," the officer said. "His grandfather, Pandit Nehru, would come visit, and it was very glamourous. Maybe Rajiv was a little out of depth at first in politics. He tried and sometimes failed. Nobody's perfect. The tragedy is we all sensed he had the possibility of being a true leader. Now he's gone." **********The flower-bedecked gun carriage and procession took three and a half hours to move through New Delhi and reach Shakti Sthal, a site beside the bleak Jamuna River where Mr. Gandhi's grandfather, Jawaharlal Nehru, and mother, Indira Gandhi, both Prime Ministers, were cremated. **********The procession stirred some emotion, especially at the conclusion as Mr. Gandhi's son, Rahul, a sophomore at Harvard University, clad in white kurta pajamas, lit the sandlewood funeral pyre amid the chanting of Hindu hymns. His sister, Priyanka, placed her arm around her mother, Sonia. Mrs. Gandhi wept. The entire congregation, including foreign dignitaries, stood silently for two minutes.  City Is Closed Down **********Earlier, as the funeral convoy reached downtown, several women were seen wailing. The terraces of high-rise buildings were jammed. Helicopters circled overhead. The city itself was closed down. **********Crowds of almost entirely young men, marching beside the funeral convoy, raised their fists and shouted in Hindi, "The nation will remember the martyrdom of mother and son!" and "Long live Rajiv Gandhi!" **********But the response to the procession along most of the route seemed surprisingly muted. **********"We are left alone," Chinni Rao, a 42-year-old businessman, said as the procession moved toward India Gate, the massive war memorial. "The grandfather is dead, the mother is dead, and now Rajiv. The Nehru family has served our country in my lifetime. They are gone. Perhaps the wife or children will keep the tradition alive." **********Nearby, Sunil Broota, a businessman, mopped his brow with his handkerchief. He had waited more than an hour in the sun to catch a glimpse of the funeral procession. 'Who Else Is There?' **********"He was the only national leader we had," he said. "'Who else is there? No one." **********As a loudspeaker repeated Hindu funeral chants, Mr. Broota said: "This is not the end of the family. It's not the end of the dynasty. I don't believe that at all. It won't be. Someone will come from the family. Maybe not not this year. But sometime. Someone will come." **********The procession threaded past crowds that waited in a faintly carnival mood. Hawkers sold ices and chunks of coconut. Beggars sat on sidewalks. Water trucks pulled up, and crowds gathered to pass around a single glass and drink. There were families from villages in Rajasthan and elsewhere in northern India, but most of the throng seemed to be men from New Delhi who wanted to pay final tribute to the politician they called Rajiv. **********"There's no strong person out there now," said Subodh Kapoor, a 30-year-old government worker, seated on the grass. "The situation is so strange. Everything is uncertain. Stability seems in jeopardy. People are even a bit frightened."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/15/world.main_headline: 7 Soviet Republics Agree to Seek New Union
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/15/world.print_headline: 7 Soviet Republics Agree to Seek New Union
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/15/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the leaders of seven republics agreed today to work toward a new confederated "Union of Sovereign States," with the central authorities exercising powers delegated by sovereign republics. **********There was no immediate indication exactly what powers would be delegated to the center, and participants said the agreement was still subject to approval by the parliaments of all the republics. **********The absence of several republics -- most notably the Ukraine, which is abstaining from any such discussions until after the republic holds a referendum on Dec. 1 on its future -- raised further questions about the prospects of the agreement. **********But all participants at the meeting, including President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic, seemed heartened at least by the fact that agreement had been reached to pursue some form of political union. **********The very site of the meeting, a Government retreat in the suburb of Novo-Ogaryovo, was the one at which republic leaders first met in April to shape a new association. The agreement they reached then collapsed with the coup attempt in August, and officials said the new project was totally different from the federation envisioned then. **********The key difference is the wariness of most republic leaders of creating any central structures that could eventually reanimate the dictatorial center of the past. **********Speaking briefly to reporters after their eight-hour meeting, Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Yeltsin and leaders of Byelorussia, Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan, Kirghizia, Tadzhikistan and Turkmenistan indicated that more than half the discussion had been dedicated to the basic shape of the new association. **********Mr. Yeltsin said the participants finally had agreed that the future union should be a "Union of Sovereign States -- Confederated State, fulfilling functions delegated by states participating in the agreement." **********The formula seemed to accept both Mr. Gorbachev's call for a state that could be a genuine subject of international law, and insistence of the republicans on a confederation in which they would determine and limit the powers of the central Government. A confederation is a league of independent states joined by negotiated bonds. **********Mr. Yeltsin said after the meeting that it was still difficult to say how many republics would join the union, but added, "After today's discussions, I am firmly convinced there will be a union." **********Declining to take part in the meeting, besides the Ukraine, were Georgia and Moldavia. The Armenian leader is now in the United States and did not send a deputy, and the leader of Uzbekistan reportedly missed the session because of transportation problems. The three Baltic republics, their independence now internationally recognized, no longer take part in such discussions. 10 Signed Economic Pact **********The move toward a political association follows the signing of a draft economic pact by 10 republics to create a free-market zone in place of the former command economy. That agreement was intended to prevent the chaotic disintegration of complex economic ties among the republics, but a final agreement has not yet been reached. **********Leaders of the Ukraine at first balked, but finally also joined in the economic agreement. But the republic's Prime Minister, Vitold Fokin, today threatened to resign unless the Ukrainian Parliament lifted its resistance to ratifying the agreement. **********Nursultan Nazarbayev, the President of Kazakhstan, who has been among the strongest advocates of negotiating a new political union, said after today's meeting that the economic treaty "was constantly balking in the absence of a political union." **********The heads of the republics gathered as the State Council, the collective federal executive formed after the August coup. They also named Ivan Silayev as the new national Prime Minister. The appointment formalized a function that Mr. Silayev, formerly Prime Minister of the Russian republic, had been filling as head of the interim Inter-State Economic Committee.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/30/busin.main_headline: ABC Agrees To Broadcast Cable Show
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/30/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; ABC Agrees To Broadcast Cable Show
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/30/busin.body_text: **********ABC and the cable network Nick at Nite have agreed to run a new situation comedy on each network on separate nights. It is the first time that a program produced by a cable network will be carried by a broadcast network. **********ABC has bought the rights to the first six episodes of the series, a comedy called "Hi, Honey, I'm Home," and will begin running them in July. ABC is expected to announce a date for the series today. **********Each episode of the show will run on ABC once during the week and will be rerun on Nick at Nite later the same week. **********The process, which Nick at Nite is calling an "instant rerun," is a precursor of a new cooperation between broadcast and cable networks in an effort to share program costs and expand their audience reach, Geraldine B. Laybourne, the president of Nick at Nite, said yesterday. **********"This is a sign of the kind of alliances we are going to see in the 90's," Ms. Laybourne said. **********The deal rose from a previous agreement between ABC and Nick at Nite's sister network, MTV, to develop a weekly series for the network. ABC did not pick up the first series pilot produced by MTV, but the cooperation between the companies led Nick at Nite to offer the comedy series to ABC. **********As soon as ABC executives saw the pilot episode for "Hi, Honey, I'm Home," they wanted to put it on the broadcast network first, Ms. Laybourne said. **********Executives at ABC's programming department had the day off yesterday and could not be reached for comment. **********The series will have a special television angle as well. It deals with a television situation-comedy family from the 1950's whose series is put on hiatus by a network. It is a "Donna Reed"-type family, Ms. Laybourne said. **********While waiting to see if they can get back on the air, the television family members are "relocated" to a suburb next to a "real" family of the 90's, led by a single mother. The two families have a culture clash, which Ms. Laybourne said subtly and humorously pointed out the conflicts faced by women torn betwen careers and traditional concepts of motherhood. **********The show features a mostly new group of writers, producers and actors and will be taped at the Nick at Nite studios in Orlando, Fla.  'Vested Interest' **********Ms. Laybourne said Nick at Nite, which depends heavily on old network reruns for its regular programming fare, had a "vested interest" in the broadcast networks. "I guess you could say if network TV is not so strong as it might be, we're threatened too," she said. **********Nick at Nite and ABC have also agreed to cross-promote the series on the two networks. Ms. Laybourne said clips from the first episode would also run on Nick at Nite's sister cable networks -- MTV, VH-1 and Comedy Central -- just before the first episode is broadcast on ABC. The four cable networks are owned by Viacom Inc. **********Nick at Nite will produce at least 13 episodes of the series. "It's a great deal for ABC," Ms. Laybourne said. "They didn't have to pay for a pilot out of their development budget." She would not disclose the program's costs. **********The broadcast networks have been looking for ways to offer more original programs during the summer months, when millions of viewers abandon network television during its regular diet of reruns. But escalating program costs have become a problem for the broadcast networks, even during the regular television season. The networks have increasingly looked to special or unusual program deals to get different shows on during the summer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/02/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Tough Times for Movie Theaters
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/02/busin.body_text: **********For the first time that he can recall, Sumner M. Redstone, the owner of the National Amusements theater chain, has strong doubts about the movie theater business. **********Mr. Redstone has been a leader in building movie theaters across the country. But now he is retrenching. **********"The industry is no longer recession resistant," Mr. Redstone said. "All the dynamics make it worse." **********Mr. Redstone, who also owns Viacom Inc., a cable television and broadcasting company, pointed to the increasing competition from other forms of entertainment, including the growing number of pay-per-view movies on cable television. "You really will have 10 or 15 channels of pay-per-view," he said. "That business is growing at movie theaters' expense." **********In addition, Mr. Redstone said, "good movies like 'Frankie and Johnnie' that used to do good business don't last as long. That's bothersome. **********"This time, the recession counts."  Severe Problems **********While Mr. Redstone may be more outspoken in his concerns than other theater-chain executives, they also acknowledge that they have had a poor year. Whether they see the industry's problems as cyclical or part of a larger trend, they all agree that the problems are severe. **********Box-office receipts are down more than 4 percent so far this year. Receipts totaled $3.93 billion in late November, down from $4.12 billion at the comparable point last year, the trade paper Variety reported. **********While the Thanksgiving weekend has produced some hits -- including Paramount's "The Addams Family," Disney's "Beauty and the Beast" and Columbia Pictures' "My Girl" -- Mr. Redstone for one is still pessimistic. **********"Even though the individual pictures were extremely strong and therefore encouraging, I estimate the industry gross was off about 20 percent from the holiday period last year," he said Saturday. **********Moreover, two big movie theater companies, the Cineplex Odeon Corporation and AMC Entertainment Inc., have reported losses in one or more quarters this year. Both incurred debt from overexpansion, but their core business is weak as well. Counting on Christmas **********Carmike Cinemas Inc. and the theater divisions of the General Cinema Corporation and the United Artists Entertainment Company have been profitable. But Carmike's net income was basically flat for the first nine months of 1991, as were the earnings of the United Artists theater division. Moreover, United Artists' earnings a year earlier were depressed by a one-time write-down for a restructuring that included closing some theaters. And General Cinema's profits came only after an extensive restructuring, in which the company also closed some theaters. **********Theater operators are still counting heavily on Christmas films, particularly "Hook," a highly promoted film that will open on Dec. 11. A. Alan Frieberg, the president of Loews Theaters, a unit of Columbia Pictures, said the mix of films this season looked like one of the best in years. The successful recent openings of several films have increased hopes among theater owners that audiences will flock to "Hook," "The Last Boy Scout" and "Prince of Tides." **********Some theater chain owners are optimistic. At Carmike, for example, its chairman, Michael W. Patrick, remains bullish, although he acknowledges that he is anticipating a flat year at best for his company. **********For years, the film business was considered recession proof on the theory that any economic difficulties would be offset by moviegoers' need to escape them.  Discounting at Cineplex **********"But this time, the recession is taking a whack at us," said Allen Karp, president of Cineplex Odeon. His company has started discounting tickets to attract more moviegoers. **********Moreover, there are fewer films that last for weeks or even months. The longer a film plays, the better it is for theater operators, since they get a larger percentage of each box-office dollar. **********Mr. Redstone, for one, has become convinced that the theater business is no longer a growth business. Over the last decade Mr. Redstone's National Amusements Inc. built dozens of large theaters. It currently operates nearly 700 screens. But now, Mr. Redstone said, "barring a miracle location, we won't build." **********Not everyone is so negative. Richard Simon, a movie industry analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, noted that although theater attendance was down in the second and third quarters, it was up in the first quarter, despite the Persian Gulf war. "That tells you the business is product driven," he said, referring to the films that the theater chains show. Study of Carmike **********Still, after concluding a study of Carmike Cinemas, Mr. Simon did not recommend the stock. "Carmike, like everybody else, is exposed to the overall dynamics of the box office," he concluded. **********Few new theaters are opening these days, in part because there are already so many theaters that operators are having difficulties getting exclusive rights to show a film in a particular area. **********Of course, not all movie chains are retrenching completely. Mr. Patrick of Carmike gets high marks from competitors for expanding into smaller cities like Cedar Rapids, Iowa, and Bozeman, Mont. But in these cities, there is little competition from other theater chains. **********Loews, meanwhile, has added a handful of theaters, particularly in the New York market. Mr. Frieberg said its two new multiplex theaters in Manhattan were doing well. **********Other chains, however, are not so willing to bet on the future. AMC Entertainment, for instance, began selling some theaters last year after expanding aggressively in the 1980's. **********And AMC has been cutting ticket prices, particularly for its matinee and 5:30 P.M. shows. "Attendance over the summer and the fall has been very, very bad," said Jack Holland, vice president for marketing at AMC. "We don't believe it is the end of the world, but this is a particularly bad cycle." **********Some analysts are critical of the price cuts by AMC. Still, Mr. Holland argues that one way to stop the downward trend in moviegoing is, once again, to cut ticket costs. **********That, of course, does not bode well for earnings. And if the strategy smacks of fear, it is not surprising, given the malaise that is evident in the industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Grey Advertising Picked by Raytheon
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/11/busin.body_text: **********Moving to consolidate advertising for accounts that had been handled by a dozen agencies, the Raytheon Company, Lexington, Mass., yesterday named Grey Advertising, New York, as its agency of record. **********The announcement followed a three-month review that began with 20 agencies and ended with Grey facing one other finalist: Della Femina, McNamee Inc., New York. Many advertising executives had considered Della Femina the front-runner, because it had handled advertising for Raytheon's corporate and government groups. **********Last year, billings on the account totaled $10 million, but a 1992 budget has not been determined, a Raytheon spokesman said. Raytheon, a diversified manufacturing company, is perhaps best known for its Patriot missile, used in the Persian Gulf war. **********Besides the corporate and government groups, Grey will handle business-to-business and consumer advertising for Raytheon's energy and environmental group, Raytheon Marine, Raytheon's semiconductor division, Switchraft and D. C. Heath. **********Advertising for the company's Beech aircraft division remains at McCann-Erickson Southwest, while Raytheon's appliance group continues to be handled by agencies that include Foote, Cone & Belding.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Retailers' Sales Poor Last Month
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/11/busin.body_text: **********The nation's largest retailers said yesterday that their September sales were even weaker than expected, heightening concern that consumer spending would not pick up in time to prevent a third disappointing Christmas in a row. **********Merchandise sales at Sears slipped, while those at J. C. Penney were essentially flat. Even K Mart's discount stores, which generally turned in robust sales during the recession, showed a decline last month. **********But Wal-Mart and the Gap continued to stand out against the industry's lackluster results. Sales rose by 32 percent at Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, and by 41 percent at the Gap. Consumers Remain Cautious **********Mostly, however, the September sales results indicate that consumers are extremely wary, retailers and analysts said yesterday, as they are faced with gloomy employment figures and high consumer debt. **********"Despite what economists have said about the economy being in a slow recovery, nobody has told the consumer yet," said Jeffrey B. Edelman of C. J. Lawrence Inc. **********Until September, the white-collar nature of the recession had taken a greater toll on department stores and more expensive retailers. "This month, everybody had a disappointment," said Daniel Barry, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company.  Broad Sales Decline **********The weakness was widespread, cutting across all categories of retailing. The Merrill Lynch index of 22 leading retailers showed that September sales were up by only 1 percent over the period last year. The index compares sales of stores that have been open at least a year, or same-store sales, which analysts view as the best barometer of performance. **********Jeffrey Feiner, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company, called sales for the month "disappointing and below expectation." **********The weak results were particularly troubling because retailers' results were being compared with September of last year, which was one of the worst retailing months in 1990, because of the drop in consumer spending after the invasion of Kuwait last August. **********"It's clear that consumer spending has been a lot weaker than anyone expected," said Mr. Barry of Kidder, Peabody. "Virtually all the major retailers were below plan, and they were planning conservatively." **********At Sears, Roebuck & Company, the sales at its merchandise group fell by 1 percent for the month, to $3.07 billion. The Chicago-based retailer's same-store sales for the month were off by nine-tenths of a percent. Dollar figures for same-store sales were unavailable for any of the retailers. **********J. C. Penney & Company, which is based in Dallas, reported that its overall sales were up by four-tenths of a percent, to $1.31 billion, while those at its same stores were down, also by four-tenths of a percent. **********At the Gap Inc., its same-store sales were up strongly, by 20 percent, compared with an overall sales gain of 41 percent, to $255 million. The company, based in San Francisco, offers a frequently changing line of casual clothes in attractive stores. **********"Denim is the hottest thing out there in Retail-land," said Thomas Tashjian, an analyst at the First Manhattan Company.  Wal-Mart Keeps Ahead **********Wal-Mart Stores Inc., based in Bentonville, Ark., also continued to outpace its competitors. Its overall sales gain of 32 percent, to $3.26 billion, included the results of the McLane Company, a retailer acquired last year. Excluding McLane's results, Wal-Mart's September sales were up by 24 percent. **********Sales at Wal-Mart's same stores rose by 7 percent. **********There were signs, however, that the sluggish sales climate has begun to filter down to discounters, which have been one of retailing's bright spots this year. **********Sales at the K Mart Corporation's stores were down slightly last month. The company, based in Troy, Mich., does not publicly release separate sales information for its stores, but it confirmed that it had told analysts of the sales decline at its discount stores. The retailer attributed the drop to the prolonged warmer weather, which can hurt fall apparel sales, as well as the weak economy, which dampened spending on big-ticket items. **********While sales at K Mart's discount-store operation were down slightly for the month, the company said its September sales increased by 5.3 percent over all, to $2.97 billion. Those at its same stores rose by 1.4 percent.  One Bright Spot **********But despite yesterday's gloomy results, several large retailers told analysts that their sales for the first week of October were robust. **********Last month, retailers were forced to cut prices to lure consumers into stores. "Frankly, too much of our business is being done on promotion or some kind of value price situation," said Stephen E. Watson, the president of the Dayton Hudson Corporation in Minneapolis. **********But in contrast to markdowns taken last year to move surplus inventory, analysts said that this year retailers ordered more cautiously and they were using markdowns to draw in consumers and increase market share. **********"Retailers are acting in a much more prepared fashion," said Mr. Tashjian of First Manhattan. **********Still, Mr. Feiner of Merrill Lynch said that September's weak sales were likely to make retailers even more cautious about inventory levels for the rest of the year, especially as the holiday season approached. **********"We expect to see some cutbacks, in terms of merchandise commitments for Christmas," he said. Such a move by retailers could ripple through the economy, hurting clothing manufacturers, he said.  Dayton Hudson Up 9.1% **********At Dayton Hudson, its overall sales were up 9.1 percent last month, to $1.34 billion, with those at its same stores gaining 5.1 percent. Sales at its Target discount unit rose by 12 percent, with those at Target stores open for more than a year increasing by 7 percent. **********The May Department Stores Company, based in St. Louis, said its overall sales rose by 8.3 percent, to $973 million, while its same-store sales rose slightly, by four-tenths of a percent. **********The Limited Inc., with headquarters in Columbus, Ohio, said its September sales increased by 16 percent over all, to $532.5 million, while those at its same stores grew by 4 percent. **********The New York-based Woolworth Corporation said its total sales dropped by 1.9 percent, to $874 million, in September. But the retailer's stores in the United States experienced a 4.1 percent sales gain, to $496 million, while those at its same stores fell slightly. **********The Melville Corporation, based in Harrison, N.Y., whose stores sell footwear, apparel and other products, said its overall sales rose by 7.2 percent last month, to $892.8 million, while its same-store sales fell by five-tenths of a percent. **********The TJX Companies, a discount retailer of specialty clothing with headquarters in Framingham, Mass., reported an 11.6 percent rise in its sales over all, to $265.8 million. The retailer does not report its same-store sales.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/23/busin.body_text: **********In the market for a possible merger partner or an acquisition, Getty Petroleum said its board had retained Morgan Stanley & Company to review a range of strategic options for the company. A Getty spokesman said the company's "main objective" in hiring the investment bank was to establish a link with a refiner to stabilize Getty's supplies of oil products. The spokesman said the options that would be reviewed included a joint venture, a merger or the purchase of a refiner.
