https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/04/busin.body_text: **********The Government and a pharmaceutical trade group today urged Western drug concerns to resume deliveries of medicines to eastern Germany, where they can sell them only at a 55 percent discount. **********To protest the new discount regulation, some pharmaceutical companies in western Germany stopped deliveries on Wednesday, causing hundreds of drugstores in former East Germany to balk at opening on the first business day of the new year. **********The Labor Minister, Norbert Bluem, and the head of the German Society of Pharmaceutical Industries, Hubertus von Loeper, met today in Bonn and issued a joint appeal to the drug makers. **********They asked pharmaceutical companies to make full deliveries, and Mr. Bluem promised "to fight for a quick and acceptable legal rearrangement," the Labor Ministry said in a statement. **********There was no immediate reaction from the drug companies in western Germany. Details of the negotiations between Mr. Bluem and the industry union are scheduled to be released on Friday. **********The unusual drug discount was mandated by the unification treaty between East Germany and West Germany. It was seen as one way to help the low-paid eastern Germans cope with the shift from heavily subsidized medicines to high drug prices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.main_headline: Federal Insurance Role Spurs Congress Debate
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.print_headline: Federal Insurance Role Spurs Congress Debate
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.body_text: **********A debate over possible Federal regulation of the nation's troubled insurance companies heated up today with the release of a new study saying state officials cannot adequately police the industry. **********But lawmakers at a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee hearing remained divided on whether Congress needs to set minimum solvency standards for insurers, create a new Federal regulatory body or try to fix the state system. **********"Something needs to be done," said Representative Dan Schaefer, Republican of Colorado. His constituents, he said, are increasingly afraid that "when they need insurance the most, when disaster strikes, they will not be able to get what is due them." **********Congressional concern over the insurance industry, which is now regulated on a state-by-state basis, has increased in recent months because of the financial woes of several large companies that lost money through heavy investments in "junk bonds." And the failures of insurance units owned by the First Executive Corporation and by the First Capital Holdings Corporation have left thousands of policyholders wondering if they will collect any benefits. G.A.O. Seeks National Rules **********The National Association of Insurance Commissioners, a voluntary organization of state regulators, has tried to respond to industry troubles by developing a national system of solvency rules. **********But the new study, by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said the association's proposals would not work, and it called instead for enforceable national standards. **********"Do we want to try to correct some problems before the disaster occurs?" asked Richard Fogel, a G.A.O. assistant comptroller. "Or do you wait until the disaster? **********"The main road to effective regulation of the insurance industry does not pass through N.A.I.C." **********The G.A.O. said the National Association of Insurance Commissioners did not have the power to compel states to adopt or enforce standards. It also said some of the association's proposed rules were too vague to provide uniformity. Regulators Want More Time **********The president of the association, James Long, said Congress should give states a chance to improve the system. He said that this year, so far, 44 states have considered parts of the association's solvency standards and 20 states have passed new laws. **********The association did ask Congress to pass legislation making insurance fraud a Federal offense. It is also considering a plan in which the Government would authorize the association to review the solvency of non-United States insurers operating in this country. **********In a separate report, issued Tuesday, the G.A.O. said state insurance regulators were typically late in taking formal action against financially troubled insurance companies. **********The report said that in 71 percent of failed-insurer cases for which it had obtained data, regulators took no formal action until after the insurer became insolvent. In at least 36 cases, the insurer continued to write policies after regulators identified it as financially troubled, the report said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/06/busin.body_text: **********A bill to reform trading practices in the futures pits while giving Federal regulators more authority to discipline wrongdoers easily passed the House today 395 to 27. **********It was the second time in two years that the House has passed such legislation. The last bill was derailed by a jurisdictional battle between the agencies that regulate the futures and securities markets. **********The Commodity Futures Improvements Act of 1991 would curb the practice of dual trading, in which futures brokers trade for themselves as well as their customers. Critics have said dual trading and similar trading practices, at a minimum, create the appearance of a conflict of interest. **********At worst, the critics say, the practices can lead to the kind of fraud schemes uncovered in a sweeping Federal investigation of the Chicago futures pits two years ago. **********The 1991 bill also requires futures exchanges to set up audit trails that can allow an individual trade to be retraced within a minute of its completion. The provision is intended to deter unscrupulous traders who now record trades by hand from post-dating or otherwise doctoring records to cover wrongdoing. **********The measure also increases the enforcement authority of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which oversees the industry. **********The bill gives the commission the authority to seek fines against purported lawbreakers while it moves to obtain a restraining order in civil lawsuits. **********The bill also makes futures trading on inside information a felony punishable by up to three years and prison and a $500,000 fine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.main_headline: G.I.'s Leaving Iraq DMZ and Its Refugees Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; G.I.'s Leaving Iraq DMZ and Its Refugees Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.body_text: **********An empty cargo plane, its rear gate yawning in the heat, stood on the runway waiting for any last-minute refugees from Iraq. By 2 P.M., none had come down the road, so the black-and-green aircraft pirouetted slowly, rushed down the runway and was gone. **********At what for nearly two months was a refugee camp here for as many as 11,500 Iraqis, army bulldozers graded the expanse of sand that had once been a bidonville of tents, cardboard shacks and corrugated steel compounds. Gone were the food lines, the screaming hordes of children chasing white Frisbees flung by grinning American soldiers, the protest signs carried by black-draped women pleading not to be abandoned to Saddam Hussein's police. **********And in Safwan itself, American soldiers filled water jugs and barrels for the last time from a white water tanker. **********"It's the last day for water, for medical, the last day for the school food drop, the bulk food drop," said Lieut. Col. John F. Kalb, a commander of the final group of American troops here in Iraq. "It's kind of the last day for everything. Tomorrow, we pull back behind the DMZ."  U.N. Declares Control **********Today, the United Nations declared that it was in full control of the demilitarized zone between Kuwait and Iraq, a band extending six miles into Iraq and three into Kuwait. Now, under the terms of the cease-fire resolution approved by the United Nations Security Council, all armed forces, including the 2,400 American troops of the First Brigade here, will pull back to positions inside Kuwait. **********Although the zone is monitored by United Nations observers, its jurisdiction now reverts to Iraq and its police, and the tension surrounding their imminent return is evident. **********Blocks of graffiti -- "No for Saddam, Yes for Freedom" -- have been scrubbed out or painted over. In their place, new slogans have appeared, like "We Love Brave Saddam." On the Mayor's house, the graffiti say, "Saddam, Commander of the Arabs and the Baaths," a reference to the Iraqi President's Baath Party. **********Two days ago, Colonel Kalb said, three men shot and wounded a man reading a newspaper in a pickup truck, and then fired two shots into an army vehicle giving chase. "We think they were resistance-type guys," the colonel said. "We chased them, but the gunmen escaped." **********And in the school, a hand grenade was found on a desk. The note next to it read: "Stop studying. This is the first warning." 'Now, What Will I Do?' **********In the water line that forms every morning and seems undented by evening, women and children struggled with four-foot high water barrels, rolling them away from the water tanker toward home. One woman, affectionately called Battle Ax by the soldiers -- "she runs this place," a soldier said -- expressed alarm at the impending departure of the Americans. **********"I don't know what we'll do," she said. "I've been coming here ever since the water has been coming here. Now, what will I do? God knows." **********As for the Iraqi police who wait just up the road, she was apprehensive. "They'll kill us," she said, "because we take water from the Americans. We take food from the Americans." **********The woman, who gave her age as "40, 50, I don't know," lifted a water jug and placed it on her head. Surrounded by some of her 12 children, she headed home. **********As the women labored to carry tubs and barrels of water home, the men of Safwan lounged around the taxi stand, smoking cigarettes, laughing, resisting talk of the town's return to the Iraqi fold. A dark green United States military police vehicle crawled through the garbage-strewn streets, past crumbling buildings. The children waved and forked their fingers in "V" signs. The men did not smile. **********At the old Safwan camp, Spec. Duraid Antone surveyed the cleanup operations and talked of what he knew of Iraq. "I was born in Baghdad," the 22-year-old American soldier said. "I remember Baghdad a little. But I don't recognize these people. The Iraqis I know are not like the refugees. They aren't poor like this." **********A translator and interrogator, Specialist Antone acknowledged that he changed his Arabic accent when speaking to the people of Safwan. "I speak Lebanese," he said. "These people are very paranoid. They feel everyone is against them. Using the Iraqi dialect would make them very nervous." **********In full battle gear, Specialist Antone seemed distant from the Iraqis here, separated from the land of his birth. "It's a little weird," he said, "not in the sense I'm Iraqi, but in the sense I went back to Iraq to fight a war."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/15/busin.main_headline: Technology; Sensors That Tell Just How Good the Packaging Is
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/15/busin.print_headline: Technology; Sensors That Tell Just How Good the Packaging Is
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/15/busin.body_text: **********A package on its way from a warehouse to a store may encounter bumps that can cause profound damage to its contents. To measure such jarring events, the International Paper Company is using a new sensor that fits inside a package and records the level of shock, vibration, temperature and humidity the parcel encounters in transit. **********The company uses the data to help determine the effectiveness of the packaging materials it designs and to develop packages that provide protection at the least cost. **********Based on information provided by the sensor, International Paper has decided that some of its packaging offers more protection than is needed, and it has already redesigned some cartons to use less material, thereby saving money. **********The sensor is manufactured by Instrumented Sensor Technology Inc. of Lansing, Mich. The company began selling the sensor a year ago and now has about 100 customers, ranging from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to railroad companies, computer makers and packaging companies. **********The Instrumented Sensor device is housed in a metal box that is about four inches wide and two inches high and that weighs about two and a half pounds. **********While paper companies and shippers have previously used machines to assess the forces that buffet packages in transit, the earlier gadgets were used in laboratory-like settings. The new sensors are significantly smaller and quicker, and they can actually go inside a package or machine and provide data collected while goods were in transit. **********International Paper began using the new sensor last November to collect information for an important shipping customer. Four other shippers are also eager to use it, International Paper says. **********The company typically deploys a pair of the sensors when measuring the stress a package undergoes as it is being transported by truck. One sensor is placed inside a package and another is placed on the floor of the delivery truck. **********The sensor inside the container is mainly used to measure sudden shock and to determine drop heights, registering whether a package falls to the floor from where it is stacked and the distance of the drop. The sensor on the floor measures the vibration caused by the variations in acceleration of the truck. In addition, the sensors can measure humidity and temperature. **********"In the past, we have used package performance testing equipment in the laboratory to simulate what a package is exposed to in transit," said Stephen Beshore, program manager at International Paper's package innovation center. "But this device gives us a much more accurate reading of what a package goes through." **********He added, "By placing a sensor in the container being transported, we can tell when a truck hits potholes. We can tell when the truck comes to a cloverleaf on the highway and measure the sideways acceleration. It gives a precise reading of what goes on during the transportation of an item." **********The information is recorded and stored in a microprocessor-based digital data system inside the sensor for several weeks and later is transferred to computers for processing and analysis. The company then generates statistical summaries and graphic displays of the material. **********"The equipment allows us to measure what each box is required to do," Mr. Beshore said. "We test it and then design a package that tells us everything the package has to withstand: whether it will be dropped, whether it is crushed while being loaded, whether the moisture in the air affects the contents. And we're now designing packages that do what the customer needs." **********Typically, the company would collect data from a number of shipments in analyzing its packaging. Mr. Behore said International Paper discovered through the use of the sensors that "our packaging is overdesigned in that it is stronger than it needed to be." **********In response, International Paper has modified some of its designs. For example, the company made containers that were 12 one-thousandths of an inch thick to transport cigarettes. After testing with the sensor, the thickness of the boxes was reduced to 10 one-thousandths of an inch. "That's not insignificant when you're talking about the volume of containers we produce," Mr. Beshore said. **********Products that monitor the level of vibration and shock to shipments are not new. But most of the earlier technology was quite bulky, perhaps between 10 to 20 times the size and weight of the Instrumented Sensor device. **********The previous technology generally used an instrumentation device that recorded signals onto a tape. With that technology, everything was recorded, even if a truck was sitting on the side of the road, and thus much of the information recorded was superfluous. **********Using the technology pioneered by Instrumented Sensor, the recording device can be set up so that data are taken only if they exceed a predetermined level, much as a sound sets off a voice-activated cassette tape recorder. **********The Instrumented Sensor equipment is also notable for its compactness, which enables full analysis to be accomplished in a self-contained package. Once the data have been removed from the sensor, Mr. Beshore said, "Within a matter of several minutes to an hour, the computer will crunch the information and the customer will immediately have tables and charts." **********The newer equipment is cheaper as well. Customers say the older recorders and associated equipment were twice as expensive as the Instrumented Sensor equipment, which costs $7,000 to $8,000 a unit. **********While International Paper uses the sensors to design packaging to transport boxes of everything from food to cigarettes to antifreeze, there are uses for the sensors beyond the packaging industry. They are now being used to record data during the transportation of components -- particularly rocket boosters -- used on the space shuttle. **********"It's a useful monitoring device for extremely high value cargo," said Gregory D. Hoshal, president of Instrumented Sensor and creator of the monitoring units. "In the case of components for the space shuttle, it is important because it can provide detailed data on anything that goes wrong in the transportation process." **********Mr. Hoshal estimated that over all the market for acceleration-based measuring devices could reach $80 million to $100 million a year. **********He said companies that make industrial products were prime candidates to employ the sensors to measure the stresses the work environment places on their products. "It's useful for companies that design computers because the computer is exposed to such environmental hazards as shock and vibration," he said. **********Mr. Hoshal added that there were a number of customers using the sensor to design the next generation of products by assessing conditions the products must endure in their end use. **********"Some companies are using the sensor to determine the impact on their products of such things as the continuous slamming of drawers on a desk where a sensitive piece of computer equipment is used," Mr. Hoshal said. "That way, they know what they need in the next wave of that equipment."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.main_headline: World Markets; Caution in the Coup's Aftermath
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.print_headline: World Markets; Caution in the Coup's Aftermath
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.body_text: **********It is not quite the same as the Berlin Wall coming down. But the collapse of the hard-line coup in the Soviet Union last week is expected to send a new surge of confidence though Europe, giving some lift to the stock markets in the countries that will play a role in economic development of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. **********"It is the definitive death of Communism. The political risk of Communism has diminished, and that changes the whole outlook for Europe," said David Roche, international strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company in London. **********Mr. Roche, who interrupted his vacation because of the coup, is now heading for the Soviet Union. But before he left London, he added to his portfolio to reflect the week's events, buying stocks like Mannesmann in Germany. **********The return of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the political victory won by Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin and the humiliating defeat of the old-line Communists mean two things for the equity markets: The general risk factor added on for turmoil in the Soviet Union, especially in markets in Germany and Austria, is lower. Many stocks now will not look as expensive as they might have. And the outlook for capital gains from the development of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe is a little better again -- and a bit better balanced. **********Market analysts don't expect a headlong rush of often unthinking buying that the market experienced after the Berlin Wall cracked in October 1989. In the sober reassessment since then, investors have learned how long and how risky the wait for those gains might be. **********And analysts are quick to point out that the victory is a fragile one. The Soviet economy is in a shambles. If the economic reform does not bear some fruit quickly or if Mr. Gorbachev does not move fast enough, the mood and politics in the country could deteriorate rapidly. **********But in the post-coup Soviet Union, with Boris Yeltsin playing a larger, if not equal political role, Mr. Gorbachev will have to move toward real economic development rather than try some faulty hybrid as before. Because of this change, analysts say, investments in the Soviet Union and investments in the companies that invest in the Soviet Union will all look more attractive. **********Mr. Roche's bullishness isn't entirely new. In the case of Germany, he is talking his own book a little. He was increasing his investments in Germany earlier this year when many other brokers and fund managers were staying away and telling others to do so. **********Still, there's no denying the sudden new allure. "I am sufficiently confident, and this brings us to a more bullish stance," Mr. Roche said. **********A flow of capital toward Europe because of the dramatic events in the Soviet Union could also affect investment outlooks in the United States, some analysts believe. For one thing, it could take away some support from the stock markets. It could also weaken the dollar some in the near term. **********"How much more potential is there in the U.S. market now compared to Europe over the next couple of months?" asked Jeffrey Loper of A.G. Edwards. His answer: None. **********Other analysts also are noting that despite the euphoria following the failed coup, many of the same tired problems that financial markets faced before are still there. And these should not be forgotten. **********One is that some markets are still expensive, including the United States and Germany. On the day of the coup, following a burst of panic selling that sent markets sharply down, analysts said that many markets looked better priced as a result of the declines. With the run-up in prices after the Soviet troops withdrew from Moscow and the coup leaders fled, that price advantage has all but evaporated. **********By week's end, most of the major markets around the world had regained most or all of their lost ground. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 3,040.25, up 72.23 points since the coup. In London, the FT-SE 100 index closed at 2,640.7, a new record high and up 19.7 points since the coup. France's CAC-40 closed at 1,833.45, 13.14 points over the pre-coup level. Germany's DAX 30 index, which was hit the hardest, closed at 1,627.24, just 26.09 points below last Friday's level. Only in Japan, where the Nikkei 225 fell 450.43 Friday, did the index end far below (749 points) the pre-coup level. **********Second, despite the Soviet events, the risk of higher interest rates in Germany has not gone away. The Bundesbank rate rise on August 15 clearly left room for ratcheting German rates up another notch. **********Also, Japan is still in trouble. Granted, the Nikkei looks less expensive at its present levels, which are not too far above the lows hit during the Persian Gulf crisis. But the country's stock and bank scandals have undermined investor confidence. Tokyo analysts continue to speculate that the scandals could widen and that eventually Japan's Finance Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, might have to resign. **********Finally, the failed coup did nothing to alleviate the global shortage of capital. And if the West now begins to put more money into the Soviet Union, which appears to be a necessary element for success in the post-coup environment, it will only add to the strain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/02/world.main_headline: P.L.O. Refuses Order to Disarm in Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/02/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; P.L.O. Refuses Order to Disarm in Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/02/world.body_text: **********In defiance of a new Government ban on private armed groups in the country, the Palestine Liberation Organization said on Sunday that it would not lay down its weapons and vowed that thousands of its guerrillas would continue to fight Israel from southern Lebanon. **********The Government of President Elias Hrawi on Thursday ordered all Lebanese and non-Lebanese militias to hand their weapons over to the army by the end of April. **********The move is intended to end Lebanon's 16 years of civil war, in which the P.L.O. has played a major part. **********But Zaid Wehbeh, the organization's most senior leader in Lebanon, told a rally on Sunday in the southern port city of Tyre that the P.L.O.'s weapons were not meant for use in domestic Lebanese conflicts, "but for regional considerations required for the struggle" against Israel. **********Unless the Palestinians are disarmed, Government officials have said, Israel will refuse to give up the area it calls its security zone north of its border with Lebanon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/01/busin.body_text: **********The First Boston Corporation's index of high-yield "junk bonds" posted a 2.7 percent positive return in January, its best showing since July. **********The index of 240 issues reflected a number of positive developments, including the General Cinema Corporation's $1.4 billion agreement to acquire Harcourt Brace Jovanovich and RJR Nabisco's announcement that because of investor interest it was increasing the size of its debt exchange, analysts at First Boston said. The good news for those companies had a ripple effect through the market, the analysts said. **********RJR Nabisco, which has more outstanding high-yield securities than any other company, said it had increased the size of an exchange offer to up to 41 percent, or $1.17 billion, of oustanding subordinated debentures due in 2007. Previously, the maximum to be exchanged was $752.7 million, or about 26 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/world.main_headline: Addis Ababa Journal; Today, a Flower-Filled Prison. But Tomorrow?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/world.print_headline: Addis Ababa Journal; Today, a Flower-Filled Prison. But Tomorrow?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/world.body_text: **********Early every morning, finely dressed women gather at the front gate of the Yekatit 66 Institute for Political Education carrying fresh clothes and picnic baskets full of cake and cheese. **********As a disheveled group of guerrilla guards nod courteously, the women walk past a bust of Lenin to find their husbands sitting around a fountain full of goldfish in the shade of palm trees and purple flowers. The couples embrace tenuously, since this is not a society where emotion is shown freely in public. **********The detainees, as they are called, look like anything but prisoners, clothed in their imported sweatsuits and fine leather shoes. They are 300 former ministers, Politburo members and senior officials of the old Marxist Government who enjoyed unquestioned power until rebels from Tigre Province in northern Ethiopia captured Addis Ababa last week. **********As the vanguard of Ethiopia's ill-fated 17-year revolution, they had been the "new men" who set the example for the students who were obliged to study Marx, Engels and Lenin at the institute before joining the Government of President Mengistu Haile Mariam. They were an elite who received perquisites that the hungry Ethiopian masses could not even dream of: luxury cars, fine whisky and vacations to the cool mountains of East Germany and the steamy beaches of Cuba. **********But now, after this country has undergone three changes of government in three weeks, their futures are uncertain.  Fear of the Firing Squad **********"We're O.K. for now," said Shimelis Mazengia, 42 years old, who was one of 17 members of the governing Politburo. "But who knows what will happen tomorrow." One of his colleagues, who spoke on condition of anonymity, suggested it was only a matter of time before they would face a firing squad. **********Until noon today, the old political education school turned internment camp was a model by which the Tigrean interim Government tried to show its tolerance for human rights. Journalists and diplomats were permitted to interview the prisoners as a sign of their fair treatment. But this afternoon, the Tigrean authorities banned such encounters without giving an explanation. **********A Western diplomat suggested that the Tigreans were tightening their grip over the former officials in response to complaints by their loosely aligned ethnic Oromo and Eritrean guerrilla allies that they were being too soft on the prisoners. **********In their final interviews before access was restricted, the detainees expressed a wide variety of emotions, ranging from fear to resignation, from shameful remorse to obstinate pride in their revolutionary experiment. **********Maj. Gen. Girma Neway, who was the chief of police under the old Government, said he was biding his time by reading Ken Follett novels. General Girma is trying to survive by offering intelligence files to the Tigreans, and expressing his intense regret for his years of service to President Mengistu. **********"The whole revolution went wrong when Mengistu began meddling with individual freedom," he said as he scratched his rough whiskers in contemplation. "I'm finished with politics." **********Despite eight months of ideological and technical training in the Soviet Union, General Girma claims now he never believed in Communism and often voiced concerns about the repression, albeit cautiously. "I feared execution every day under Mengistu," he said. **********The inmates live in student dormitories on the small but well-groomed campus. There is a cafeteria where they sip cappuccino and sweet tea over games of checkers. There is also a sizable library, which was enlarged in the last two years to include non-Marxist books as the old Government tentatively moved away from its radical moorings. **********Several detainees said defiantly that they had nothing to be ashamed of, either because they remained committed to the revolution or because Mr. Mengistu was at the root of all excesses. Others warned that their brand of Marxism was not nearly as radical as the Albanian variety espoused by the Tigreans as recently as two years ago. **********"I knew about the Red Terror," said Abdulhafiz Yusuf, a former Central Committee member of the old ruling Ethiopian Workers Party, referring to the Government's slaying of thousands of dissidents without trial in the mid-1970's. "But I had nothing to do with it. I was in charge of cultural affairs." 'Re-education' Is Predicted **********Sipping syrupy coffee with Mr. Abdulhafiz in the cafeteria sat Girma Beshah, Mr. Mengistu's English-language interpreter. A refined man with a goatee, Mr. Girma attributed their current situation to the fact that Mr. Mengistu obstinately resisted the pleas of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union to follow perestroika and make peace with the northern separatist guerrillas. **********"He listened to Erich Honecker's speeches instead about how the Soviet experience wasn't relevant to the German Democratic Republic," Mr. Girma said. **********Across a flowery path from the cafeteria, Tigrean officials man the old administration building. In the director's office, amid the complete works of Lenin and Kim Il Sung of North Korea, Halefom Alemu, the 33-year-old Tigrean commander, voiced little sympathy for his prisoners. **********"There will have to be some re-education," he said, "but the final solution will come from the people. The people will say who is guilty and who is innocent."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; The Argument Over the Banks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; The Argument Over the Banks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/busin.body_text: **********THE battle has begun over the Administration's proposals for the most drastic overhaul of the nation's banking system since the Depression. President Bush's aim is to restore confidence in the banking system and make America's banks world leaders again. **********As the Treasury stresses, of the 30 biggest banks in the world, ranked by deposits, nine were American in 1969, with the top three the Bank of America, Chase and First National City, which became Citibank; in 1989, only one of the top 30 was American, with Citibank in 27th place. The Administration's aim is admirable, but there are risks. **********It says one of its main goals is to "make banks stronger and safer by strengthening the role of capital -- not by raising capital standards, but with a plan to attract capital to the banking industry." One element would be to permit industrial companies to buy banks. But critics say that would transform the economy and society into a far more concentrated structure, dominated by big corporations. **********Henry Kaufman, president of Henry Kaufman & Company, an investment advisory firm, regards this proposal as "very dangerous." In an interview, he said it would confer too much power on a corporate and financial elite, with close ties to the Government, transforming the United States from an economic democracy to a "corporate state." **********Other critics of the plan say the "too big to fail" doctrine, which would be retained, would increase the concentration of financial power by throwing the weight of Government behind big banks and would contradict the Administration's professed support of market-determined solutions. **********Robert Glauber, Treasury Under Secretary and former Harvard professor, who had most to do with the drafting of the plan, rejects charges that it would favor the big over the small. He said in an interview that there would not be a big push by industrial corporations into banking. Few, he said, are so flush with cash that they would want to put billions into bank investments and acquisitions. And relatively few banks would look attractive now, given the competition from other financial service companies and "non-bank banks," their low and often overstated profits, low stock values, large numbers of nonperforming loans, and the necessity of being subjected to Government regulation. One almost wonders why the Administration even wants to propose acquisition of banks by industrial companies. **********On both the adequacy of capital and "too big to fail" issues, Mr. Glauber said the Administration's aim was to reduce failures by big and small banks alike and to improve banks' profitability by widening their opportunities to compete in other lines of business and across state borders. **********But "despite the Administration's market orientation," he said, it would have to act to prevent failures of big banks that would threaten the economic system. Central banks in all countries act to prevent "systemic risk." The issue is always which banks to save, and here the Administration provides for joint decision-making between the Federal Reserve and the Treasury. "Secretary Brady doesn't believe bigger is better," Mr. Glauber said. "He believes in strong community and regional banks, and our plan will help regional banks to grow and expand across state borders." Yet many smaller banks fear that the plan would open their territory to big money-center banks, and they will fight it in Congress. **********Should the Glass-Steagall Act be repealed, as the Administration proposes, and commercial banks allowed to do investment banking and sell insurance? Albert Gailord Hart, professor emeritus of economics at Columbia University, a noted banking scholar, told his seminar this week: "The idea that banks can be put in good shape by letting them horn in on the overcrowded businesses of investment banking and insurance is crazy. Whenever banks go into a new line where experience as commercial bankers is not the key to success, they come a cropper." **********As evidence, he cited "the Florida real estate disaster when banks went into real estate investment trusts," the losses (including the failure at Continental Illinois) when banks engaged in syndication of loans based on oil and related real estate in the Southwest, the evaporation (which still plagues us) of "sovereign loans" in the third world. "The further mess created by the banks' involvement in corporate takeovers in the 1980's," he said, "is just beginning to become clear to outsiders, but will prove at least as expensive as those just mentioned." **********Like Professor Hart, Gail Fosler, chief economist of the Conference Board, fears that diversification by banks into other businesses will weaken their ability to perform their "remarkable function as instruments of monetary policy." She stressed the danger of banks being driven further into riskier credit markets, creating pressures on the Federal Reserve to "overliquefy -- and ultimately create more inflation." **********In Congress this year, the banking issue will be the most urgent after the war in the Persian Gulf, and it is an issue even more crucial to the nation's economic strength.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/27/busin.body_text: **********The Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, said yesterday that it would not, as had been expected, bid for the banks of the failed Bank of New England Corporation. It cited the weak state of the New England economy as the reason for its decision. **********"We had no sense of when the region would get better, or if it had already bottomed out," said William Boardman, a Banc One executive who has arranged dozens of acquisitions in the last decade. Over the next several years, "we think there are going to be other opportunities that are probably a better use of our resources," he added. **********Bids for the Bank of New England's failed subsidiaries in Massachusetts, Maine and Connecticut are due on Friday, with the winner to be announced in mid-April. In addition to the BankAmerica Corporation, which has said it will bid for all the banks, analysts have said the Bank of Boston Corporation, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company are interested in some of the banks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/04/world.main_headline: Latvia and Estonia Vote for Sovereignty
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/04/world.print_headline: Latvia and Estonia Vote for Sovereignty
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/04/world.body_text: **********Voters in Latvia and Estonia heightened their challenge to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Sunday, voting overwhelmingly for independence in the two republics. **********With most of the ballots in the advisory plebiscites counted, officials said independence was favored by 77 percent in Latvia and by a similar percentage in Estonia. **********The balloting, similar to a referendum last month in which Lithuanians voted overwhelmingly in favor of independence, drew large numbers of voters in both republics. Many of the voters described the plesbiscites as another fateful step in the Baltics' year-old struggle to reverse the Kremlin's forced annexation of Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania in 1940. **********"We are moved to tears this day," said Emily Grefcova, a gray-haired Latvian emerging from a voting booth. She related memories of the early days of Soviet occupation, when hundreds of thousands of Baltic citizens were deported on Stalin's order to misery and death in Siberia as Russians began moving into the three republics.  Instructing the Young **********"I always kept telling the young people what Latvia once was like," she said, talking of past independence and gesturing to her young grandson, Kaspar. The boy was one of countless children shepherded to the polls to see the elders express their views on ending fealty to Moscow. "I want him to live the life I once lived, in a free Latvia." **********For many, the sheer act of voting represented defiance of Mr. Gorbachev's demand that the Baltic republics hew to the law of union. Nationalist leaders say the voters' resolve grew after Soviet leaders endorsed an army tank raid on Jan. 13 that killed 16 Lithuanian demonstrators in Vilnius. **********Further challenges loom over Mr. Gorbachev's latest strategy for containing the 15 Soviet republics' campaign for self-rule: a national referendum on maintaining the current union, scheduled for March 17. **********The three Baltic republics, plus Armenia, Georgia and Moldavia, have said they will not participate, Other republics are adding their own sovereignty-oriented questions to the ballot to challenge the Kremlin's authority. Dilemma for Russian Minority **********Apart from the spirit of local nationalism that seemed to prevail in today's plebiscites, there was a mixed sense of resentment and conflict among the republics' sizable minorities of non-Latvians and non-Estonians. These mainly Russian-born voters and their offspring feel caught between the demands of the republics' rising nationalism and the patriotism invoked by the Gorbachev Government in its anxious defense of the shaky Soviet empire. **********"I have lived here 30 years, my best years," said Rudolf Chaika, a Russian who was first posted here from Moscow as a soldier in the Soviet Government's huge system for guarding the Baltics. He changed careers and chose to stay, raising a family that has come to think of Latvia as home. **********"But this campaign has made me feel like an alien, an occupier, half-man, half-citizen," he said, nearly trembling as he referred to local proposals for citizenship restrictions that would favor indigenous Latvians. **********The republic's new, democracy-minded Parliament is expected to approve a moderate measure offering Latvian citizenship as a free choice. But in the campaign for the plebiscite, the Communist Party has warned the Russian minority that it faces a future of second-class rights and legal bias. **********Mr. Chaika said the issue was posed too simplistically on the ballot query: "Are you for a democratic, independent state of Latvia?" A similar question was on the Estonian ballot. **********"Can I vote 'no' to democracy? If I say 'yes,' how can I know what sort of democracy will follow? I do not like what I see so far," he said. **********Ethnic Latvians account for 52 percent of this republic of 2.6 million people. Ethnic Estonians account for 60 percent of the neighboring republic's population of 1.5 million. **********"This is an important day for us as far as trust is involved," said Dagnia Freimane, a Latvian poll watcher. "The older Russian immigrants have come to trust us and are voting yes, but others think they have 'liberated' us and we should be grateful."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/04/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Meridian Bancorp in Mellon Accord
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/04/busin.body_text: **********Meridian Bancorp Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell the $197.7 million credit card portfolio of its Meridian Bank and Delaware Trust Company subsidiary to the Mellon Bank Corporation for undisclosed terms. It said the transaction would result in a pretax gain of about $35.2 million. **********It said it was selling the portfolio because of increased competition from large issuers that could squeeze profits. The company said the sale did not include its $85 million portfolio of American Automobile Association Visa cards, for which it is still reviewing bids. Meridian shares were unchanged at $16.625 in over-the-counter-trading today, while Mellon Bank shares lost 25 cents each to close at $29.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/07/busin.print_headline: Marketing Deal by Vitro And Corning
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/07/busin.body_text: **********In an indication of the quickening pace of economic integration between the United States and Mexico, Corning Inc. and Vitro S.A., Mexico's giant glass manufacturer, agreed yesterday to market their housewares together around the world. **********Pending final negotiations and approvals by the directors and the governments, the partnership would create jointly owned companies in each country with combined annual sales of more than $800 million. **********The transaction was valued at nearly $300 million, including a cash payment by Vitro to Corning of more than $130 million. **********Officials of the two companies insisted that the prospect of a North American Free Trade Agreement had been only one of several incentives. But it appeared to have been an important one. **********For Vitro -- which seized more than a quarter of the United States glass container market with its acquisition of the Anchor Glass Container Corporation in 1989 for about $900 million, including $460 million in debt -- the alliance is a powerful shield against the new competition that free trade is expected to unleash in Mexico's glass and housewares industries. **********The joint venture follows a familiar pattern at Corning, which has moved into areas like optical fibers and television glass through deals with conglomerates from Germany to Japan. But by its timing, analysts said Corning's accord with Vitro could hardly be more propitious. **********After years of failed efforts by the company to force products like its Corning Ware and Pyrex through protectionist barriers along the Rio Grande, Corning gets with this deal a strong foothold in Mexico when consumer buying power is on the rise and tariffs are on the wane. **********Perhaps most important, analysts say, the two companies will merge product lines that have been struggling to grow in recent years but appear quite complementary. To the Corning Ware and Visions cookware, Pyrex bakeware, Revere Ware and Corelle dinnerware of its American partner, Vitro will add its Crisa glassware and stemware, Termocrisa and Fortecrisa dinnerware and Cien and Kristaluxus crystal ware. **********"The consumer-products division has unquestionably been Corning's sore spot over the last couple of years," said Jonathan Goldfarb, who follows the conglomerate for Merrill Lynch Research. "There is a reasonable chance that with this combination, the new company is going to make strategic sense." **********Corning stock rose $1.50 yesterday, to $65.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Officials of the two companies said their distribution networks for housewares would probably be only the first thing they would share. **********Down the road, a Vitro official suggested, the two companies might get together to sell products like Corning's fiber optics technologies to Mexicans, who are abused by what they are certain is some of the worst telephone service in the world. A Corning official, on the other hand, said he thought the fiber-optics division would be able to market its products in Mexico without any help. **********Amid the increasing number of Mexican-American joint ventures that have taken place since Mexico began knocking down trade and investment barriers in 1988, the letter of agreement signed yesterday formalizes at least one of the largest. But more than its scale, the accord is distinguished by its balance. **********The deal differs from the one last month that joined the two countries' biggest retailers, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Cifra, S.A., in a plan to open warehouse-style stores in Mexico. **********"What distinguishes this joint venture from the others is that it goes both ways and encompasses true globalization," Julio Escamez, the president of Vitro-Crisa, the group's glassware division, said from the company headquarters in Monterrey, Mexico. "We both needed to broaden our product lines." **********Corning's chairman, James R. Houghton, said in a telephone interview that he expected the deal to be completed by the end of the year. He and Richard Dulude, Corning's vice chairman for consumer products, recalled that the company had sought a way into Mexico for years. Until two years ago, they were daunted by Mexican tariffs on housewares of 100 percent. But the continued drop of tariffs now at 20 percent is just part of the attraction, Mr. Dulude said. **********"Whether the Mexican market opens or not, the standard of living is going to increase and the consumer housewares business is going to increase as well," he said. "Someone is going to take advantage of that."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/22/world.body_text: **********Somewhere in the far west of China, nestled in the Himalayas, is a Shangri-La brimming with contentment and human rights -- or so say the Chinese newspapers these days. **********It is Tibet, although it does not entirely resemble the Tibet that Western visitors describe. The Chinese newspapers are full of reports about progress there, as China on Wednesday celebrates the 40th anniversary of what it calls "the peaceful liberation of Tibet." **********China is using the 40th anniversary celebrations to spread its own perspective on Tibet: that the "roof of the world" has always been part of China, that the life there has improved dramatically in 40 years of Communist rule, and that the overwhelming majority of Tibetans are delighted with socialism. **********"Only after Tibet conducted democratic reforms did the masses truly become the masters and life become better with each passing day," People's Daily declared today at the top of the front page. "With life this good, the masses are very angry at the few people stll festering for Tibetan independence." **********Li Tieying, a Politburo member, has arrived in the Tibetan capital of Lhasa to lead a delegation to attend the celebrations. Scores of Chinese journalists have also arrived in Lhasa, but no China-based foreign reporters have been allowed to visit Tibet for the festivities. **********Duan Jin, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, explained that the Tibetan authorities were limited in their capacity to host foreign journalists, and that in any case Western reporters were not always fair in their coverage. **********For the last few years, the Chinese Government has only rarely permitted foreign reporters to visit Tibet, apparently because the journalists invariably report that the population would prefer independence to the current regime. While diplomats and scholars are often skeptical of some of the assertions and criticisms made by the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of the Tibetan people, his photo is everywhere in Tibet and there is little doubt that he is still revered and supported by virtually all Tibetans. **********The nature of the celebrations on Wednesday has not been revealed, perhaps for security reasons. Separatist demonstrations, often led by Buddhist monks and nuns, have occurred regularly in Tibet for four years, and martial law was lifted in Lhasa only last May. Martial law was imposed in March 1989, after clashes that left at least 16 people dead. **********"They must be taking a lot of precautions" to insure that there will be no unrest, said an Asian diplomat in Beijing. He noted that there have been reports that the army and police presence in Lhasa has been bolstered substantially in recent months. **********A Tibetan court sentenced three Chinese, all members of the Han ethnic majority, to death last month for killing a Chinese soldier and stealing guns and ammunition. A Tibetan newspaper said the three planned to sell the weapons to "rioters and rebels in Lhasa." **********The three men, who presumably have been executed by now, had attacked a government armory in late March, killing the guard and stealing 19 pistols and 869 bullets. The incident was a reminder that while the opposition to Chinese rule has been largely peaceful so far -- partly because it is backed by Buddhist monks who profess pacifism -- it is not impossible that protesters will increasingly turn to violence. **********The celebrations on Thursday will mark the 40th anniversary of the signing of a 17-point agreement between the Communist Government and representatives of the Dalai Lama. Tibetan exiles say that the agreement, which concedes that Tibet is part of China, was achieved by threats and coercion. In any case, they say, Beijing has not abided by the promises in the agreement. **********The topics of a seminar in Beijing on the 40th anniversary suggest the way that the commemorative activities are unfolding. Themes included "Tibet being an inseparable part of China" and "the great achievements made in Tibet in the last four decades since the region was peacefully liberated."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/24/world.main_headline: 3 Latin Presidents Press Castro for Faster Change
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/24/world.print_headline: 3 Latin Presidents Press Castro for Faster Change
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/24/world.body_text: **********In a meeting that underscored their differences with the United States over how to promote democratic change in Cuba, three Latin American Presidents today urged President Fidel Castro to quicken the pace of reform in his country offered the prospect of closer relations in return. **********In public, Mr. Castro showed limited interest, insisting in tough, familiar language that Communism had not failed in Cuba. **********But Latin officials said he was more conciliatory in private, effectively pledging that the modest reforms announced at a Cuban Communist Party congress last week were part of a process that would continue. **********"He said, 'I know the magnitude of my problems and I know I have to carry out reforms,' " said a senior Mexican official who participated in Mr. Castro's sessions with the Presidents of Mexico, Venezuela and Colombia. However, the official said that Mr. Castro added: "Don't ask me to make them and I don't want to talk about them so as not to confuse my people." Reaction of 3 Leaders **********If Mr. Castro persuaded the three Presidents -- Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico, Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela and Cesar Gaviria Trujillo of Colombia -- it was not obvious. **********While they pledged to help end Cuba's isolation in Latin America and offered to mediate in its conflict with the United States, they said pointedly that economic subsidies to Cuba were out of the question. Mr. Salinas and Mr. Perez emphasized that they had no intention of helping Cuba replace the cut-rate oil that the Soviet Union has said it will stop supplying to the island. **********Even so, the encounter seemed likely to maintain the gap between the United States and three of its closest and most important hemispheric allies over how to loosen Mr. Castro's hold on power. Those differences have become clearer over the past two months as Cuba's deepening economic crisis and the withdrawal of Soviet support have raised expectations of change. **********Bush Administration officials, while sharing the goal of greater democracy, have insisted that Mr. Castro's hand will have to be forced. **********In Washington and abroad, United States officials have argued for continued if not heavier economic and diplomatic pressure on Cuba, opposing its readmission to the Organization of American States and suggesting efforts to patch the leaky American economic embargo of the island. They have also pressed the three Latin nations not to come to Mr. Castro's economic rescue. **********"We aren't saying that Castro has to be violently overthrown," one American official said last week. "But it seems to us that easing the economic situation isn't going to help get him out, either." **********The three Presidents' initiative on Cuba reflects a growing assertiveness in regional foreign policy at a time when their countries' economic and political affinity with the United States is stronger than it has been in years. **********Latin officials have noted that the three nations have similar motives to intervene. All three have at times used a conciliatory approach to Cuba to counter leftist criticism at home. But more importantly, Mexico and Venezuela especially are in the midst of a profound economic restructuring that hinges on foreign investment. And as Mr. Salinas noted today, "What happens in Cuba will have repercussions in all of the other countries." **********In contrast to the sharp tone that characterized their opposition to Reagan Administration policies in Central America, Mexico, Columbia and Venezuela have for the most part gone quietly about their efforts on Cuba. Mr. Perez, for instance, was reported to have invited Mr. Castro to Caracas for secret talks in July, and twice sent the Venezuelan Foreign Minister to meet with officials in Cuba. **********Today, Mr. Perez was particularly sharp in his criticism of the American blockade, painting it as archaic and counterproductive. "It has been there for 30 years," he said. "That says it all." **********In a joint communique, the three Presidents said they were determined to "contribute to the creation of a climate of understanding and cooperation in the region and offered the Government of Cuba and the countries with which it may have differences its good offices to initiate a rapproachment."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/world.main_headline: Nicaragua Devalues Money To Stem Economic Collapse
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/world.print_headline: Nicaragua Devalues Money To Stem Economic Collapse
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/world.body_text: **********Trying to satisfy Nicaragua's international creditors without setting off another round of violent strikes by Sandinista labor unions, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro began a new economic stabilization program today based on a major devaluation of the currency. **********"We have already exchanged war for peace," Mrs. Chamorro told the nation in a televised address on Sunday. "Now we are going to exchange economic disaster for the stability we all want." **********She presented the plan after several days of uncertainty that saw commerce come almost to a halt over price confusion and the nearly worthless cordoba drop from 7 million to the dollar to about 12 million in one day of street trading on Friday. **********The Government intends to replace the existing cordoba over the next two months with the so-called gold cordoba -- actually a bill, too -- that it created last year on a par with the dollar. The gold cordoba has so far served mainly as a way to guarantee bank deposits and loans. **********The new parities are five gold cordobas to the dollar and five million old cordobas to a gold cordoba. The old cordoba is to disappear by the end of April. **********The package also includes increases in state salaries and in the wholesale prices of basic foods and fuel, in public transportation and in utilities, but generally by three or four times the existing levels, not the five times the devaluation seemed to represent. **********Mrs. Chamorro also promised to push ahead with her commitment to liberalize the economy, still struggling under the weight of the heavy state structure created during nearly 11 years of rule by the Sandinistas, but offered few specifics. **********Although many in Mrs. Chamorro's Government think Nicaragua deserves more economic help with fewer strings attached than what it is now receiving from the United States and other leading nations, these steps were timed to impress donors and would-be donors with the Government's economic seriousness. **********Representatives of donor nations are scheduled to meet in Washington on March 25 and 26 to consider an aid package for Nicaragua that would pay off its $350 million in arrears to the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank. **********Trying to head off labor and other opposition that could destroy any hope of reviving Nicaragua's prostrate economy, Mrs. Chamorro's chief minister, Antonio Lacayo, spent the past week discussing elements of the plan with virtually every sector of Nicaraguan society. **********The key group, the Sandinista Front, along with the labor movement affiliated with it, the National Workers Front, has been critical but did not immediately mount public protests or strikes. **********The labor group met on Sunday night and announced that it was rejecting what it characterized as a "shock" treatment. The group declared that the plan violated what it said was Mr. Lacayo's promise to take gradual measures. **********Seeming to take a negotiating position, the labor group demanded, among other things, that salaries be raised by about twice what Mr. Lacayo announced. It called for workers to "mobilize" in defense of these demands but said the precise steps would be discussed in meetings of individual unions starting today. **********These measures are similar to stabilization attempts that President Daniel Ortega Saavedra and the Sandinista Front made in the last year of their Government, with the difference, Mr. Lacayo said, that this Government counts with international support to back up the currency and make the plan work.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/18/busin.main_headline: Media Buyers Are Quarry Of Discovery Channel Drive
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/18/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Media Buyers Are Quarry Of Discovery Channel Drive
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/18/busin.body_text: **********THE Discovery Channel, the cable television network that specializes in adventure programs, is embarking on an adventure of its own: its largest effort yet to stalk elusive advertising dollars. **********In a new campaign called "That's the Thrill of Discovery," the nation's fifth-largest basic cable network, which reaches more than 55 million households, is touting its virtures to media directors and other executives who decide where to place advertising. Print, transit and telephone kiosk ads are appearing in New York and Chicago; Detroit and Los Angeles will follow. **********Discovery, a subsidiary of Discovery Communications Inc. in Bethesda, Md., is the latest cable network to invest in this kind of concentrated campaign. Such ads to sell ads are becoming increasingly common among cable networks, as they strive to attract the growing amount of advertising revenue being diverted from the broadcast networks. **********Advertising revenue for cable networks rose to $1.8 billion last year, according to the Cable Television Advertising Bureau, up 24.4 percent from $1.45 billion in 1989. **********Discovery's advertising is "a basic campaign that concentrates on our basic selling points," Chris Moseley, Discovery's senior vice president of marketing and communications, said in a telephone interview yesterday. **********The focus on basics is necessary, Ms. Moseley said, because "while we have very loyal advertisers who work with us, there is a general lack of awareness on what are the real selling points of Discovery as a media opportunity." **********So Ahern & Heussner, the New York agency that was awarded Discovery's $3 million-plus account, has produced a "tactical campaign meant to position the network in the media community by informing and educating," George Heussner, executive vice president and creative director, said in a breakfast interview yesterday at the agency's Manhattan office. **********Before landing Discovery's account, the agency, which lists cable networks including Lifetime, the Monitor Channel and Showtime among its present and former clients, had been working for Discovery on smaller projects. **********One of the new ads is aimed at emphasizing that "everything on Discovery is real-life, nothing dramatized," said Paul Ahern, the agency's president, subtly criticizing the broadcast television trend of showing series that involve re-creations and dramatizations. **********The ad, featuring a photograph of a whale surprising a couple in a kayak, reads: "When people experience the excitement of real life, that's the thrill of Discovery. . . . Nothing's as vibrant, timely or thrilling as programming that's true to life." **********"If people believe what they see to be true, that can carry over into the advertising," said Marcia Norcia, Ahern & Heussner's vice president and account director, "and advertisers benefit." **********A second ad is meant to capitalize on an A. C. Nielsen survey that showed that Discovery drew the largest prime-time cable audience of male viewers 25 to 54 years old, a demographic segment many advertisers prize. **********Under a dramatic photograph of a man leaping across icy mountain peaks is this text: "When men would rather be here than any place else, that's the thrill of Discovery. What do men want? Real excitement. Pure entertainment." **********Three future ads will discuss other Discovery attributes, Ms. Moseley said, including the network's size, which research showed was significantly underestimated by those who decide where to place advertising, and Discovery's popularity among cable viewers as measured in a survey by cable system operators.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/17/busin.main_headline: Gains Shown by Microsoft Despite Slump for Industry
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Gains Shown by Microsoft Despite Slump for Industry
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/17/busin.body_text: **********Despite the slump suffered by many companies in the personal computer business, the Microsoft Corporation reported today that it had a 65 percent increase in profit on a 57 percent increase in revenue. **********For its third fiscal quarter, ended March 31, Microsoft had net income of $123.8 million, or 98 cents a share, up from $75.2 million, or 62 cents, for the comparable period a year earlier. Sales rose to $486.9 million, from $310.9 million. Per-share figures reflect a 4 percent increase in shares outstanding, to 126.3 million. **********Microsoft's continued growth reflects both the company's flow of new products and its dominance of parts of the software market -- for instance, the operating systems that personal computers require to run applications programs, like word processing or spreadsheets. Four Applications for Sale **********Microsoft benefits both from sales of Windows 3.0, a program that gives the MS-DOS operating system much of the ease of use of Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh, and from application programs to use with Windows. It has four Windows applications for sale when many competitors have yet to release any. Demand for the company's applications software, like the Excel spreadsheet, continued to grow, said Mike Hallman, Microsoft's president and chief operating officer. **********Microsoft announced its results today after the close of stock trading, but they were within the range of most analysts' estimates. Its shares fell $1.50 to close at $112.25 in Nasdaq trading after moving up $6.50 Monday in expectation of positive results. **********"Windows represents the first new generation of software for the I.B.M. PC since its introduction," said Rick Sherlund, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs. "There are 70 million PC users coming back into the market to buy replacement products." **********Microsoft also benefits from personal computer manufacturers selling Windows with their computers along with MS-DOS, said David Readerman, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers in San Francisco. **********A claim against Microsoft's Windows 3.0 program was added today by Apple Computer to its three-year-old copyright infringement lawsuit against Microsoft and the Hewlett-Packard Company. The original suit asserted that an earlier version of the program, Windows 2.03, and a Hewlett-Packard program called New Wave, violated Apple's copyrights on the screen display of the Macintosh. **********William H. Neukom, Microsoft's vice president for law and corporate affairs, said he was informed this morning by Edward B. Stead, Apple's vice president and general counsel, that the company intended to amend its complaint to include Windows 3.0. **********Mr. Neukom said Microsoft's response to the amended complaint would be the same as to the original. "We don't think that we've done anything wrong," he added. "We will fight any new allegations as vigorously as we have the old ones."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/world.main_headline: Sri Lankans Accuse Army of Massacre
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/world.print_headline: Sri Lankans Accuse Army of Massacre
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/world.body_text: **********Government troops angered by the death of three of their comrades "ran berserk" today and shot, hacked or beat to death more than 150 Tamil villagers, survivors said. **********Accounts from local residents and members of the clergy, which have been reliable in the past, indicated that the troops ransacked two villages southwest of Batticaloa in eastern Sri Lanka to avenge the deaths of three soldiers on Wednesday. **********A Defense Ministry official said he had been told that the civilians died when Tamil rebels used them as human shields in an attack on Government troops near Batticaloa. **********"I don't know how many, but we have received complaints of a massacre," said Walter Fernando, air chief marshal and deputy secretary of the ministry. "If this is true, the strongest action will be taken against the miscreants."  Tamil Lawmaker Is Angry **********But Pararajasegaram Joseph, a Tamil member of Parliament from Batticaloa, said: "Troops ran berserk and killed innocent Tamils. Somebody should put a stop to this carnage." **********Accusations of massacres have been traded by both sides in the civil war between the predominantly Sinhalese Sri Lankan Army and rebels of the Tamil ethnic minority. But the reported massacre appears to be the most serious attributed to Government soldiers since peace talks collapsed a year ago and the civil war resumed after a 13-month truce. **********Villagers said the killings were carried out in revenge for the deaths of three soldiers on Wednesday in a land-mine explosion at Kokkadicholai, a mile or two east of the villages. **********At least 120 people were killed in Makiladitivu and 35 in the nearby village of Munaikkadu, they said. The villages are about 120 miles northeast of Colombo and eight miles southwest of Batticaloa. Hundreds of villagers fled to Batticaloa, where they relayed their accounts by telephone to Colombo. Deaths, Looting and Fires **********"They killed everybody -- men, women and little children," one resident said. "Sixteen bodies were dumped in the crater created by the land mine. The soldiers looted and set fire to more than 400 homes in the villages." **********About 17,000 people have died in Sri Lanka's civil war since 1983. The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam are fighting for an independent homeland in eastern and northern Sri Lanka, where most Tamils live. **********Tamils, who are mostly Hindus, make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. The Sinhalese, who are predominantly Buddhist, make up 75 percent of the population.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/21/busin.body_text: **********Motorola Inc. will invest $20 million in the Echelon Corporation, a Silicon Valley company that is developing electronic systems to control machines and appliances. Motorola will own 19 percent of Echelon and Gary L. Tooker, Motorola's president and chief operating officer, will take a seat on Echelon's board. **********The agreement is "a financial investment and a vote of confidence," said M. Kenneth Oshman, president and chief executive of Echelon. **********Echelon, based in Palo Alto, Calif., is developing systems for the automatic control of electrical machinery in homes, factories and automobiles. The system is based on tiny chips, which Echelon calls Neurons, that attach to or are built into machinery and which respond to command signals transmitted over telephone or electric power lines. **********In a home, for instance, the front hallway light could be programmed to come on whenever the garage door is opened. Systems using Echelon's technology are expected to begin appearing next year. **********The company was started in 1988 by A. C. (Mike) Markkula Jr., the former president of Apple Computer Inc. Mr. Oshman, the chief executive, is the co-founder and former president of the Rolm Corporation. Financial backers, who invested $30 million before Motorola came along, include Apple and many prominent venture capitalists. **********Motorola had previously agreed to manufacture and sell the Neuron chips, as did Toshiba.
