Joachimsthal Journal;
Introducing Capitalism, Hard Work and Bananas
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/04/world.print_headline:
Joachimsthal Journal;
Introducing Capitalism, Hard Work and Bananas
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/04/world.body_text: **********Gregor Stephan does not want to hear the tale of his family's first visit to West Berlin in November 1989, just hours after the Berlin wall burst open. A precocious 6-year-old, he says he has total recall of that day's heady air, jubilant masses and bedlam. What he wants is a banana. Now. **********His mother chides him for interrupting her story, then laughs and hands over the fruit. **********"You were too young to remember, Gregor," said Annette Stephan, 33, sitting in her living room in Joachimsthal, a village 40 miles northeast of Berlin. **********"That day was special," she said, recalling the family's first stroll into the west, when they were met and accompanied by this reporter. "We were so happy just to be there. None of us had any idea what was ahead. Democracy, elections, getting the deutsche mark, unity, so much has changed since then." Bananas No Longer a Luxury **********Like all eastern Germans, the Stephan family is still coming to grips with the changes that culminated in German unification on Oct. 3, 1990. The differences are at once monumental and mundane. Capitalism has replaced Communism, and bananas are an everyday snack for Gregor, rather than a luxury item rarely found in East German food stores. **********The changes have also brought a pervasive sense of ambiguity to eastern Germany one year after unity, a mood shared by Mrs. Stephan, her husband and her parents. They are optimistic about the chances for economic recovery in the depressed region, but deeply concerned over the high level of unemployment and rising incidence of neo-Nazi violence toward foreigners that they see as an outgrowth of joblessness. **********While benefiting from extensive Government investment in their area's infrastructure, the Stephans and many other eastern Germans also tend to see their western countrymen as arrogant know-it-alls. And they are bewildered by the western German legal system, which has put on trial four former East German border guards accused of killing a young man who tried to flee in 1989. Police Partly Blamed **********"I don't undertand how they can try those boys, but let the political leaders and military commanders who gave the shoot-to-kill orders go free," said Hans Schmalfeld, Mrs. Stephan's father. With his wife Wally, 55, he owns and operates an ice cream parlor in Joachimsthal, a town of 3,000 at the northern tip of the Werbellinsee, a large, picturesque lake in the Schorfheide forest. They went into business in 1978, one of a handful of private enterprises tolerated by the Communist authorities. **********They spend their days expanding and improving their business. In the evenings, they watch television and worry about what they see. Mr. Schmalfeld said the eastern German police are partly to blame for the recent attacks on foreigners in Hoyerswerda, a coal mining town near the border with Czechoslovakia. **********"I saw those attacks on television and I thought, 'Oh dear God, not again,' " said Mr. Schmalfeld, 53. "This is how the Nazis gained power in the 1930's, and that is what started all our troubles here. I think we take these attacks more seriously than the western Germans because we've had lots of experience with dictatorship. It makes us afraid." **********Mr. Schmalfeld blamed the police for allowing the violence. "The fact is that they would rather look on and do nothing than make a mistake that might cost them their jobs," he said. "Most of the foreigners came here to do jobs that no one else wanted. Now that jobs are scarce, some people are looking for scapegoats." **********The Schmalfelds' jobs are relatively secure, since they have their own business. But Joachimsthal's industries, a woodworking and a garden-tool factory, have closed and unemployment has risen to between 60 and 70 percent, local officials said. **********Tourism was the other big source of income in the town. When East Germans could not travel to the West, 12,000 part-time residents and 30,000 tourists came each summer. But the number of tourists has dwindled. **********There are positive changes in Joachimsthal. A storm sewer system is being built, streets are being repaved, public buildings and private homes and businesses are being refurbished. In an effort to cash in on the construction boom, Annette Stephan and her husband, Joachim, 34, opened their own construction company on July 1. Mrs. Stephan runs the company and is the offical owner. **********"Since we started this construction company, we're working harder than ever before," said Joachim Stephan, a trained brickmason. "It's been six days a week from dawn to dark. But things are going good for us." **********The family financed their initial investment of $30,000 with a low-cost, Government-backed bank loan. For the first year, Mrs. Stephan hopes for turnover of $210,000. In the first three months of the company's existence, they have taken in $84,300. **********She pays her husband $1,084.34 a month. He had been making $783.13 a month working for a formerly state-owned construction company. Mrs. Stephan has not yet decided what she will pay herself. **********"It depends on whether we make a profit," she said. **********It is a measure of how rapidly things have changed, she said, that Communism, division, the Berlin wall opening and unity are only memories now. **********"From this vantage point," she said, "one can't comprehend how they could do all that to us, locking us up, stultifying our minds, wasting so many lives. It seems so pointless and so long ago."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/world.main_headline: Americans Aiding Kurds See A 'Major Change in Direction'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Americans Aiding Kurds See A 'Major Change in Direction'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/world.body_text: **********American military officers, diplomats and aid workers in this eastern Turkish city, a staging area for relief, were taken by surprise by President Bush's speech Tuesday night announcing plans to establish camps for the Kurds. **********"It was sort of like the start of the war -- somebody called up and said 'Turn on C.N.N.' " said a United States Embassy official working with the operation here, a base for helicopter relief about 100 miles from the point where the Turkish and Iraqi borders intersect. "We don't know anything at this end yet." **********Comdr. John Woodhouse of the Navy, spokesman for the United States European Command, said tonight, "This is taking a major change in direction, and the answers are not going to come quick." **********As sheep and cows grazed just off the airport runway here, carts pulled by bony horses plied the main street passing rows of Kurds, refugees from an influx in 1988. **********The handful of shabby hotels are filling up with relief workers and journalists, and at the military air base this afternoon, a big Soviet cargo plane stood near United States Air Force C-130's and Army Chinook helicopters in dull olive battle paint, having delivered a load of Soviet relief supplies. **********British and American soldiers were putting up a tent city near the runway to house their growing effort. Stacked along one edge of the tarmac were neat piles of cargo: powdered baby formula, cases of medicine, tents from the Italian Government, cots from the German Red Cross. **********Private relief groups bring their shipments here, and the military carries them on by helicopter. Save the Children, for example, dropped off 32 tons of goods the other day, including plastic sheeting for shelters **********Farther south, at Silopi on the Iraqi border, where the helicopters bring the relief supplies, about 2,000 American soldiers and marines are putting up their own camp to serve as a distribution point. **********Here, there was one sign of preparations for the new plan -- marines in full combat gear practicing leaping out of helicopters and forming a defensive perimeter. It is a role the marines could play as part of the mobile "rapid response force" deployed to protect the camps from any Iraqi attacks. **********The plan is believed to have been pressed by the Turkish President, Turgut Ozal, who was worried about the uneasy presence of about 600,000 more Kurds, an economic drain on this poor country and a potentially destabilizing element in a part of Turkey with its own simmering Kurdish nationalism. **********The American military's goal here had been to deliver emergency supplies, create a logistical system and at the end of 30 days, be able to hand over the entire operation to private aid agencies. **********A new timetable announced by the Pentagon at a briefing today -- having construction on the Iraqi camps begin in a few days and the bases operating within a couple of weeks -- seemed unrealistic to some of the experienced aid workers here. **********"We would do 20 days of intensive planning, including selecting the sites," a relief official said. "It would be 25 days before we turn the first spade of earth, and maybe in about a month after that, it would be ready for 10,000 people."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.main_headline: Two Ranking Aides To Arafat Are Slain By Gunman in Tunis
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: THE P.L.O.; Two Ranking Aides To Arafat Are Slain By Gunman in Tunis
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.body_text: **********A gunman in Tunis shot and killed two of the highest-ranking leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization late Monday night. The victims were among the closest and most influential aides to the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat. **********The two men, who were shot to death about 11 P.M., were Saleh Khalef, known as Abu Iyad and widely acknowledged as Mr. Arafat's heir in Fatah, the mainline P.L.O. group, and Hayel Abdel-Hamid, known as Abu al-Hol, the chief of security of the guerrilla organization. **********Mr. Khalef was a founder and leader of Black September, which carried out the massacre of 11 Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympics in Munich. **********The two Palestinians were shot by a renegade bodyguard in the home of Mr. Abdel-Hamid, where Mr. Khalef was spending the evening, Palestinian officials in Tunis said in telephone interviews early this morning. **********Their deaths dealt a heavy blow to the P.L.O., which already suffers from a serious lack of decision-makers at the top, save for Mr. Arafat and his hard-line spokesman on foreign affairs, Farouk Kaddoumi. **********They follow by less than three years the slaying, also in Tunis, of another senior P.L.O. leader, Khalil al-Wazir, or Abu Jihad, apparently by Israeli agents.  Today many, although not all, Palestinians who discussed the matter said they were confident that Israel was behind the Monday night killings. **********But another theory was that the killings were the work of a rival Palestinian group, the Abu Nidal Organization. **********Some Palestinians interviewed noted that Abu Nidal, a Palestinian renegade with a history of terrorist operations, was a bitter enemy of Mr. Khalef. **********But others pointed out that Abu Nidal now lives in Iraq -- where he moved from Syria -- and is under Iraqi control at a time when Baghdad has no interest in antagonizing the P.L.O. The P.L.O. has supported the Government of President Saddam Hussein throughout the Persian Gulf crisis. **********On Monday night, a P.L.O. observer at the United Nations, Nasser al-Kidwa, said he had "no doubt" that Israel is behind the killings.  Systematic Slayings **********A Palestinian official in Tunis said the gunman shot Mr. Khalef with 10 bullets from a Kalashnikov machine gun, killing him instantly, then shot Mr. Abdel-Hamid and a third man, an aide to Mr. Khalef, whose name was Mohammed al-Omari. Both died in the Tawfik Hospital, not far from the scene of the killings. **********The official, who asked not to be identified by name, said the gunman had been detained and that "an investigation is under way." **********[ The killer held two relatives of one of the victims hostage for six hours before he was captured, The Associated Press reported. ] **********[ P.L.O. guerrillas and Tunisian police officers stormed into Mr. Abdel-Hamid's house, where the shootings occurred, arrested the assailant and freed the two women hostages -- Mr. Abdel-Hamid's wife and a daughter -- unharmed, the police commander said. ] P.L.O. and Iraq **********The death of Mr. Khalef came when the P.L.O. is most vulnerable, as several important Arab countries like Egypt and Saudi Arabia are boycotting it because of its support of President Hussein. **********And, many experts said, it leaves a big void in the organization as Mr. Khalef was regarded as a man of his word who, unlike Mr. Arafat, shunned the limelight, and he contributed significantly to policy-making. **********[ Mr. Arafat was on his way from Amman, Jordan, to Paris for talks on the gulf crisis when the shooting occurred, but canceled his trip, according to Daniel Bernard, a French Foreign Ministry spokesman, as quoted by The A.P. ] **********"He was a crucial advocate of the P.L.O.'s policy of political compromise in recent years," said Prof. Rashid Khalidi, of Mr. Khalef. "This assassination is the hardest blow the P.L.O. has had in some time." Mr. Khalidi is a professor of political science in Chicago and the author of a book on the P.L.O.'s structure and philosophy. **********The killings are almost certain to inflame the feelings of Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip as the killing of Abu Jihad did three years ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/17/busin.body_text: **********GlenFed Inc., parent of the nation's fourth-largest savings and loan association, said today that it would add to loan-loss reserves, sell some assets, freeze management salaries and suspend its dividend. The company also said it would eliminate 600 jobs in the next quarter through attrition, but layoffs were not ruled out. **********GlenFed said the moves, which it called "necessary and prudent," would result in a $140.8 million loss for the quarter. **********On the New York Stock Exchange, GlenFed's shares dropped 87.5 cents each, to $4.625. The 15.9 percent decline was among the biggest of the day on the Big Board. In addition, the Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its credit rating to speculative grade on some debt of the Glendale Federal Bank, the company's banking subsidiary. New Capital Rules **********GlenFed, which has $24.4 billion in assets and operates 235 branches of Glendale Federal in California, Washington and Florida, said it wanted to protect itself better from the effects of continued recession, as well as to insure that it stays in compliance with strict new capital requirements intended to keep the industry solvent. **********"This positions the company on a pre-emptive basis to continue to meet the capital guidelines," said Keith P. Russell Jr., GlenFed's president. **********Analysts said they had expected Glenfed's moves, which follow similar changes at banks and several other large California savings and loans. **********In lowering the credit rating, Standard's & Poor's noted that the quarterly loss would cut into the bank's capital levels. S.& P. also said GlenFed's "moderately high exposure" in commercial real estate markets in Calfifornia could leave it vulnerable. But it added that today's moves might ultimately improve GlenFed's earnings power. Reserves Are Increased **********GlenFed said it would add $141.8 million to its loan-loss reserves and reduce the value of some loans and real estate assets by about $75 million. Money was also set aside to cover the sale of the North American Title Company subsidiary to management. **********GlenFed said it would carry out cost-cutting measures to save more than $160 million a year beginning within 18 months. The moves include cutting jobs and freezing management salaries for 18 months. **********The company's board voted not to declare a quarterly dividend and probably will not resume payments for at least one year. **********The quarterly loss compares with net earnings of $39.9 million, or $1.30 a share, in the period a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/world.main_headline: Calling Home, Ex-P.O.W.'s Tell How They Survived It All
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: FAMILIES; Calling Home, Ex-P.O.W.'s Tell How They Survived It All
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/world.body_text: **********One of the Americans just freed from captivity in Iraq told his mother that he was roughed up during an interrogation by the Iraqi secret police, his mother said yesterday, but another of the former prisoners said he owed his life to his captors. **********The first former captive, First Lieut. Robert J. Sweet of the Air Force, told his mother of a roller-coaster of abuse and then protection in captivity. **********He said Iraqi soldiers beat with rifle butts just after he ejected from his downed plane behind enemy lines, but that other Iraqi soldiers rescued him from the beating. Then he was sent to Baghdad, his mother said, where the interrogation and subsequent abuse by the secret police reportedly took place. **********In another of several conversations that the freed Americans had with relatives in the United States, Lieut. Robert Wetzel of the Navy, who was released in a first batch of six Americans freed on Monday, said he felt that his Iraqi captors had saved his life. **********And a third former captive, Chief Warrant Officer Guy L. Hunter of the Marines, who flew to freedom in Saudi Arabia yesterday, said he was kept in solitary confinement, with only a blanket to ward off the cold. **********For Lieutenant Sweet, shot down in his A-10 Thunderbolt over northwest Kuwait, captivity alternated between violence and being saved from violence by the Republican Guards. 'Sounded Really, Really Good' **********The 24-year old airman called home to Washington, W. Va., yesterday and he "sounded really, really good," said his mother, Mary Ann Sweet. **********"When he was parachuting down, there was a tank shooting at him, 'Oh Lord, this must be it,' " she quoted her son as saying. **********The tank crew first reached him and began beating him, she said, adding that Republican Guard officers "saved his life and stopped the men from inflicting any more damage on him." **********"He said he was okay for a few days with the Republican Guard and then they sent him to Baghdad," Mrs. Sweet said, adding that there, "the secret police got a hold of him." **********"He said that he is still very weak," she added. **********William Wetzel said that he had all but given up hope after his 30-year-old son was shot down in his A-6 bomber over southwestern Iraq. Then on Monday, after he was released, their son called from the hospital ship Mercy in the Persian Gulf to tell them of his 45 days in captivity. **********"He said that when he was ejected from the plane, he had two broken arms and a broken collarbone," Mr. Wetzel said. "The Iraqis took him to a hospital and ministered to him for two weeks. He said he owes them his life." **********"He was impressed with their competence and how kind they were in treating him," Mr. Wetzel said. **********In Oceanside, Calif., the call to Mary Hunter came from her husband in Saudi Arabia. Warrant Officer Hunter was the first American pilot taken prisoner when his reconnaissance plane was shot down over Kuwait on Jan. 18. **********At a news conference near Camp Pendleton, she said: "He was kept in solitary confinement for all but two days of his captivity. He said he wasn't beaten but also wasn't allowed to bathe or brush his teeth. He had only a blanket to ward off the cold." Explanation to His Wife **********Warrant Officer Hunter told his wife that he appeared on Iraqi television condemning the allies "because if you didn't, you'd be in big trouble." **********"I wanted to know if they hit and I didn't get a very positive answer to that," she said. "He kind of laughed when I asked him, but then he said it was O.K. but the laughter makes me kind of question that. I think he didn't want to talk about it." **********Mrs. Hunter said her husband told her that he was doing an impression of the actor Peter Sellers' accident-prone character Inspector Clouseau, of "The Pink Panther" film series, when his captors forced him to criticize the allied war effort. **********After hearing that her husband was safe, Mrs. Hunter said that she sent the couple's three children off to school. **********"Tell them your daddy's free and he's coming home." **********Warrant Officer Hunter was shot down along with Lieut. Col. Clifford M. Acree, 39. Colonel Acree's wife, Cindy, said in a statement yesterday that she was "thrilled by the news of Cliff's safe release and was elated to see him walk off the plane this morning." **********"I've always said that our wedding day was the happiest day of my life, but this may top even that," she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/busin.main_headline:
Real Estate;
New Offices At a Project In Bergen
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/busin.print_headline:
Real Estate;
New Offices At a Project In Bergen
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/busin.body_text: **********AFTER a decade of development, a 60-acre tract in the eastern corner of this Bergen County suburb is now midway through its transformation into a two-million-square-foot corporate park. But the work has proceeded more slowly than planned and with adjustments to a softer commercial real estate market. **********Two office buildings have just been completed and construction on a third is about to begin at the tract, which is called the Overpeck Centre. The three buildings will have a total of 658,000 square feet. The developer of the corporate park is Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus, N.J., the pet food company. **********Two other office buildings, with a total of 288,000 square feet, and a 10-screen movie theater had been completed earlier. Hartz began the project in 1981 after agreeing to lease the property from the village for 99 years and give it a share in the proceeds. The site, once mostly a public landfill, overlooks the 810-acre Overpeck County Park and is about six miles from Manhattan. **********Construction is also expected to begin this spring on the project's retail operations, which will have up to 20,000 square feet, said Martin P. Gold, Hartz's director of marketing and planning. Rents for the shops have not yet been set. Plans for a 200-room hotel are waiting for the market to improve, he said, adding that the pace of future construction would also be tied to the market. **********When completed, the total value of the project, the first large-scale development in the village in 50 years, is expected to be $150 million. Like other projects across the state, Overpeck has shifted from speculative to buid-to-suit development. Hartz has struck two such deals. **********One is the 300,000-square-foot structure that Hartz recently completed for the UJB/Financial Corporation, a financial services organization that is consolidating its back-office operations, now at five locations. The company expects to have more than 800 employees in the building by the end of the year. **********Under the second deal, Hartz is leasing 4.5 acres to Samsung America Inc., which will build its corporate headquarters there. The company will relocate from Fort Lee, N.J., to the 150,000-square-foot building when it is completed next spring. **********A third building, with 208,000 square feet, had been started on speculation. In January, Mellon Securities Transfer Services moved 355 employees into 98,000 square feet of the recently completed structure. It relocated from 75,000 square feet in Fort Lee. **********The rest of the space in the new building is vacant. Asking rents are $21 to $22 a square foot, on a par with rents in comparable buildings in the northern New Jersey office market, said Robert Rudin, executive director of Edward S. Gordon New Jersey, a commercial brokerage in Saddle Brook. **********Mr. Rudin said concessions, like six-months' free rent, were still common in New Jersey and would remain so until the surfeit of space built during the construction frenzy of the mid-80's was absorbed. There is an 18-month supply of class A space -- which consists of newer buildings in better locations -- and a five-year supply of class B space, he said. **********But in certain markets -- like central Bergen County, which includes Ridgefield Park -- there are not many large blocks of contiguous class A space available. **********Most of the leasing now going on is prompted by corporate relocations within the county, Mr. Rudin said, noting that tenants could move and make good deals and that many were abandoning old space for new buildings. As a result, he added, there had not been substantial absorption of older space, which has a 24 percent vacancy rate. The vacancy rate for the entire northern New Jersey market is 18.9 percent. **********"Speculative construction," Mr. Rudin said, "is a thing of the past." **********Mr. Gold of Hartz agreed with that assessment. He noted that Overpeck Corporate Centre's location and access to a large labor pool would enable it to compete for tenants. It is linked to Route 46, the New Jersey Turnpike and Interstates 80 and 95 by a $4 million road network that Hartz built when it undertook the project. **********For UJB/Financial, the proximity of major highways played a role in its decision to move to Overpeck. The development was selected after a three-year search and from among 30 other sites in northern New Jersey, said Alan N. Posencheg, an executive vice president of the company. He said the favorable terms of the 20-year lease his company had signed for the building was another factor. **********Ridgefield Park's Mayor, Fred J. Criscuolo, described the project as a gold mine for the 1.9-square-mile community. He said it had fulfilled its promise to help revitalize the area and to balance the tax base in the primarily residential village, where homeowners had shouldered the burden of high property taxes for years. **********Mayor Crisuolo said that last year Overpeck, the community's largest ratable property, saved each household $340 on its tax bill. The development is now producing revenues of $1.5 million a year. **********Mr. Gold said there was land available for up to four more office buildings and the hotel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.main_headline: How Can We Save New York City?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.print_headline: FORUM; How Can We Save New York City?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.body_text: **********Ron Silver Actor and president of the Creative Coalition. **********Reestablish faith in the city's ability to improve things. We are overwhelmed by cynicism and a feeling that we can't do anything. We are able to overcome. There's a lot we could do: Start by reforming the State Legislature. It's corrupt to the bone. Limit legislative terms. Get people reinvolved in city politics. Find a creative solution to the city's racial problems. Get the Federal Government to assume responsibility for Medicaid. Revitalize Midtown. The main thing is to reduce cynicism. A lot of people think New York is a failed enterprise. It isn't. Leonard Stern Chairman of the Hartz Group. The city has to send a signal to its two crucial industries -- tourism and people in commercial offices -- that New York is safe and attractive. The central business district is roughly the same as the central tourist district. That district has to be kept clean and safe. That's not expensive; it would probably cost less that $50 million a year. It would take a political will, because the outer boroughs would want a share of the budget, but the fact is, most businessmen and most tourists don't visit the outer boroughs.  Richard Ravitch President of the Citizen's Budget Commission. We must have a five-year fiscal plan involving the city and state that reflects trying honestly for credible, balanced budgets. They would have to include reductions in services and the allocation of the revenue burden, if necessary, to the largest tax base. The city and state have to work in a partnership. Lloyd A. Williams President of the Uptown Chamber of Commerce. All city employees, especially uniformed employees, must be residents of New York City. Law enforcement officers, in particular, are on call 24 hours a day, seven days a week, but they're only on duty in the city during the workweek. That means that upwards of 70 percent of their call time goes to their own community. There is an economic spinoff of having a police officer living on the block. People feel safer; they will spend more in their neighborhood. Lady Miss Kier and DJ Dmitry Members of the rock group Deee-lite.  Instead of warehousing vacant city property with the hope of selling it in a depressed market, encourage the expansion of the homesteading program for hardworking, serious New Yorkers. There are thousands of applicants who are willing to be involved in a 4- to 5-year homesteading program who are turned down because of city policies. It's a permanent solution to homelessness that will boost morale. Thomas B. Stoddard Executive director, Lambda Legal Defense Fund. If New York City really wishes to assure its future, it must face up to the issue of poverty. The city should concentrate its efforts on children. Remake the public school system. Sung Soo Kim President of the Korean-American Small Business Service Center of New York. New York's 195,000 small businesses are the backbone of the city: the prime source of neighborhood manpower, taxes -- and they are the first steps of livelihood for new immigrants. City government has made us a cash cow. We need risk-taking, creative leadership rather than a caretaker government.  Danny Wintrode Hairdresser. If there were more severe punishments, there would be less money spent on jails. The money could be put into more beneficial means of bringing the city back. Ronald K. Shelp Head of the New York City Partnership. We've got to stop living in the past. New York's future has to include restructuring city government, downsizing the work force, new kinds of productivity initiatives and privatization. **********Jerrold Nadler Democratic Assemblyman from Manhattan. We have to try to regain the city's blue-collar economy by recreating a major port in New York. We can do that by reconnecting the city to the rest of the United States by rail freight. Everything now is transported from New York by truck, and the cost of getting freight in and out of the city by truck is tremendous. It has probably cost us 800,000 to 900,000 jobs in the last 25 years. Despite our natural geographic advantages, the Port of New York lags behind Baltimore and Norfolk, Va. Stephen Berger President of Financial Guaranty Insurance Company. What the business community needs most is a sense of stability, predictability and security about the city's future.  Mattie Balaj Manhattan doorman. You could try legalized gambling, but that draws crime and drugs. We need to attract small businesses and factories to the outer boroughs. Then people can work and live in their neighborhoods. Philip Howard Lawyer and a vice president of the Municipal Art Society.  The loss of confidence in New York is the greatest danger to New York's economy. The villain is a city government that seems incapable of adapting or dealing with current problems. Our city government is also notoriously inefficient. The city makes the simplest venture cumbersome and costly. This is true for everyone: a homeless man recently told me he refused to go on welfare because he hated dealing with all the forms.  Carol Bellamy Managing director, Bear Sterns & Company. Multifaceted strategies are needed. Here are two: Streamline government. Improve our schools. Peter P. Smith President, Partnership for the Homeless. The city must find ways to translate far more of its vast wealth into a coordinated job training, education and skills development effort. We could start by requiring every service or production business to set aside a certain number of jobs for trainees whom they would train and subsidize until they are ready for full-time employment. Michael Musto Night-life columnist for the Village Voice. It would benefit our image and financial state to encourage a booming night life -- one that would pump glamour, excitement and revenue into the city that's always prided itself on having the most dazzling after-hours entertainment. Loosening cabaret laws and zoning regulations that make it difficult to open and run clubs would help maintain our reputation as the city that doesn't sleep. A tax cut would give us a reason to party. Stanley Aronowitz Sociology professor, CUNY Graduate Center.  New York is is a first-world city but it is also a third-world city. Because three-quarters of a million factory jobs have been lost in the last two decades, at least a third of the city's residents have no hope and no reason for hope in the future. We need a program to stimulate new small businesses, especially in production industries. City and state government should identify native skills and match them with industrial and market needs; persuade banks to make guaranteed low-interest loans, and impose commercial rent control to make cheap space available. Penn and Teller "Penn and Teller Rot in Hell" is at the John Houseman theater in New York. Penn Jillette: Solving New York City's problems is as easy as solving the nation's problems. Tax the churches and stop wasting money arresting people for victimless crimes. For New York specifically, charge admission to Times Square before it becomes a mall. Teller: As a commuter I don't think there are enough tolls, I know of two stretches of the Sawmill River Parkway where it is almost possible to accelerate to the speed limit before braking for the next quarter-toss. There's money to be had here! Sandra Feldman President, United Federation of Teachers. Invest in the schools and the children who will be in the work force of the 21st century. By cutting more than a half a billion dollars from the city's public schools, New York dealt a terrible blow to the competence of its future work force. Teachers can't turn out educated, adaptable young adults without a reasonable investment.  Dr. Ernest Drucker Professor of epidemiology and social medicine at Montefiore Medical Center. New York's immediate economic future is threatened by the related epidemics of AIDS and drug addiction. Both consume vast economic resources: over $1.3 billion for AIDS and over $2 billion for drug addiction. Our failure to offer adequate treatment or AIDS prevention services for the city's 200,000 injecting drug users virtually assures that they will continue to become infected themselves and, often, to infect their wives and children. Joe Dibona New York City cab driver. Stop pretending there are no classes in this country. The middle class has come down a lot. I was doing better 10 years ago. You have to make it on your own. Nobody gives a damn. Edwin Rubenstein Economist, adjunct fellow at the Manhattan Institute and National Review columnist. Albany holds the key. I don't mean increased state aid -- that's clearly impossible. The state can, however, ease up on the myriad of costly rules and regulations it imposes on local governments. The most burdensome state mandate is Medicaid. Not only is the state's program egregiously expensive ($4,500 per patient here versus $2,100 per patient in the rest of the nation), but New York is one of the few states that require city governments to contribute anything at all to Medicaid. Caroline R. Jones President of Caroline Jones Advertising in Manhattan. Education. Education. Education. Illiteracy fosters ignorance, breeds intolerance, self-pity, boredom, crime and a host of other ills. Education is important not just for skills, but for the culture of the school. It is a place where children can learn responsibility and self-esteem. Jay Mazur President, International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union. Maintain manufacturing as the key to a balanced economy that builds on the strengths of New York's diverse and creative work force. The city's apparel industry, for example, provides over 100,000 entry-level jobs, mostly to newer immigrants. Nathaniel Dunford Social worker at Project Life, an agency that serves developmentally disabled adults. More funding should be provided for preventive education programs -- parenting skills, treatment programs, job training programs -- for single mothers, drug addicts and youth, some of whom are the same people. Dealing with problems now is cheaper than dealing with them later. **********Joe Queenan Contributing editor, Spy magazine. Hire John Gutfreund to handle the sale of municipal bonds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/busin.main_headline: Industrial Output Falls 0.8% to Lowest Level in 2 1/2 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/busin.print_headline: Industrial Output Falls 0.8% to Lowest Level in 2 1/2 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/busin.body_text: **********Industrial production declined eight-tenths of a percent in February to the lowest level in two and a half years, the Government said today. It was the fifth consecutive monthly decline, and analysts saw it as another sign that the recession was continuing unabated. **********The February performance marked the longest string of declines in manufacturing output since a 10-month stretch between March and December 1982, during the most severe recession since the Depression in the 1930's. **********"It's further evidence that the economy, as of February, was still in a full-fledged recessionary decline," said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. **********"There is not yet any indication from this sector of the economy that a bottom has been reached," added Marilyn Schaja, an economist at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation of New York.  Factories Slowing **********The Federal Reserve report also showed the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities falling eight-tenths of a percentage point, to 79.1 percent of capacity. That was the lowest level since October 1986, when the rate was 79 percent. **********The central bank's report on prodution displayed a broad decline, led by a 5 percent drop in motor vehicle assemblies. But excluding automobiles, output was still down seven-tenths of a percent. **********Excluding vehicles, the consumer goods sector fell five-tenths of a percent, about the same rate of decline as in December and January, the report said. Production of appliances, carpeting, furniture and electricity for residential use was down. **********Analysts attributed the slide to slack demand resulting from uncertainties over the Persian Gulf crisis, growing unemployment that is eroding purchasing power, and, in some cases, tight lending requirements. **********Output has not risen since inching up a barely perceptible one-tenth of a percent in September. The declines included drops of six-tenths of a percent in October, 1.5 percent in November, 1.1 percent in December and a revised five-tenths of a percent in January, slightly worse than the decline of four-tenths initially reported last month. **********Output of durable goods -- products like automobiles and large appliances that are expected to last more than three years -- dropped 1.3 percent for the fifth consecutive decline.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/05/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices fell broadly yesterday for the third day in a row as growing concern over the economy outweighed sentiment that war was beginning to look less likely. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which sank close to 25 points by noon, rallied on news of the announcement by Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, that he would go to Switzerland to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on Wednesday. **********Within minutes the Dow recouped its loss and by 1 P.M. climbed 32 points from its low. It fell for the rest of the session, though, ending at 2,566.09, down 7.42 for the day and 63.12 for the week. **********Trading activity, still sluggish, slumped to 140.8 million shares, from 141.5 million on Thursday. In a mixed picture, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell at about the same rate as the Dow, but on the New York Stock Exchange, 790 stocks rose and only 698 fell. **********Traders said a cable break in New Jersey interrupting A.T.& T.'s long-distance service for New York had little effect on their ability to do business or get quotations.   Effect of Phone Problem **********The New York and American stock exchanges said service was largely unaffected because other phone lines were available to all of the top investment firms. The National Association of Securities Dealers, which runs the over-the-counter service, said that 450 of its 3,000 terminals were down most of the day but that 150 were restored for part of the day by backup equipment. It described activity as "about the same as the two previous days." **********One trader remarked that because commodity dealings were seriously hurt for most of the day, one of the biggest headaches was the inability to get up-to-date prices for crude oil until the final 30 minutes of trading. **********They maintained that with the situation in the Persian Gulf changing so rapidly, the price of crude oil is important to the entire situation and that traders are hampered in other markets by not knowing what the price of crude oil is at any given moment. **********In a reflection of how seriously investors feel about the deteriorating economy, Peter G. Grennan, head of stock index futures trading for Shearson, Lehman Brothers, said: "There's a growing feeling peace will break out and the market should have responded better than it has. It's telling you that the economy could be losing momentum much faster than expected." **********A weak economy, he argued, means weak profits, and "the market's very nervous about fourth-quarter earnings," which start coming out around the middle of January. **********"When earnings come out and are less than expected," he said, "there's no mercy; the stocks get sold."   Big Name Stocks **********In anticipation of some disappointments when earnings are announced, institutions have been unloading many of the big-name stocks all week. **********Yesterday alone, Schlumberger, the oil-service company, fell 1 7/8, to 53 5/8; Disney, the entertainment giant, fell 3/8, to 100 1/8; Procter & Gamble, the consumer products company, fell 7/8, to 83 3/4, and 3M, another big consumer producer, fell 1/4, to 83 1/4. **********Royal Dutch/Shell, the oil company, slid 1, to 76 1/8; Johnson & Johnson, the drug company, fell 1/2, to 68 3/4; Abbott Laboratories, another big drug company, fell 7/8, to 40 3/4; Pfizer fell 3/4, to 77, and American Home Products fell 1 3/8, to 49 3/8. **********Although traders attributed some of the drug selloff to caution in advance of earnings reports, contradictory recommendations from analysts also contributed to the decline. Merrill Lynch prompted a selloff Thursday after saying the group had had big gains and investors should now lighten up. Yesterday Cowan & Company joined Merrill Lynch but Dean Witter, concerned about the recession, urged investors to lean heavily on drug stocks, regarded as recession-proof. **********Merck fell 1 3/8, to 85 1/4; Bristol-Myers Squibb 3/4, to 63 5/8; Bausch & Lomb 2 5/8, to 65 5/8; American Cyanamid 1 1/8, to 49 7/8; Warner Lambert 1 1/4, to 63, and Forest Labs 1 5/8, to 46 3/4. **********Birinyi Associates, which monitors program trading, reported heavy buying and selling just before and after the noon announcement of the Baker meeting in Switzerland but said that the activity raised the Dow only six points.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/29/busin.main_headline: F.T.C. Acts On Inaccurate Credit Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/29/busin.print_headline: F.T.C. Acts On Inaccurate Credit Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/29/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it was moving to protect prospective employees from being turned down for jobs because of inaccurate credit reports. **********The agency said the Electronic Data Systems Corporation had agreed to settle charges that it had denied jobs to some people partly because of poor credit reports but had never told them that was the reason. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, a prospective employer must disclose that fact so an applicant can review the report and correct any errors. **********Randy Dove, a spokesman for E.D.S, which is based in Dallas, said that about 150 people had been turned down for jobs since 1989 in part because of unfavorable information in their credit report. In settling the case, E.D.S. agreed to notify those people about the decision and to provide them with the name of the credit-reporting agency so they could obtain a copy of the report. Broad Investigation Started **********The case is the first of its kind, but Barry Cutler, director of the F.T.C.'s Bureau of Consumer Protection, said the agency had begun a broad investigation into the issue. "Several companies, both large and small, have been notified that they are the subject of inquiries involving the same question," said Mr. Cutler, who declined to elaborate. **********The F.T.C. action reflects an increasing concern both in Government and among consumer groups about the widespread use of reports supplied by credit-reporting companies and their potential for inaccuracy. Errors on the reports may result in denial of loans and jobs. **********Jean Noonan, the F.T.C.'s associate director for credit practices, said an increasing number of companies were using credit reports either as part of the initial screening process for a prospective employee or as a final credit check when a job was offered. **********Ms. Noonan said she believed the use of such reports was growing because of Federal limitations on the use of polygraphs. "I think some employers use them as a general measure of integrity," she said of the credit reports. **********Based on the results of its investigation, Mr. Cutler said the F.T.C. was preparing a publication to notify employers of their responsibilites to disclose credit-reporting information to job applicants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.main_headline: Company News; Qantas to Cut 3,651 Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.print_headline: Company News; Qantas to Cut 3,651 Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.body_text: **********Australia's Qantas Airlines said today that it would cut its work force by almost a fifth and make other cost reductions in hopes of saving $185 million a year. **********The airline said $122 million of the savings would come from staff cuts, which would reduce the work force by 3,651, to 17,138. **********The reductions will affect 33 percent of the company's managers and 16 percent of other staff, Qantas said. **********Industry officials estimated that Qantas faces a $274 million loss in current fiscal year, which ends on June 30, the result of the slump in flying and of higher fuel bills because of the Persian Gulf war. Qantas posted a 93 percent drop in profits, to $9.2 million, in the 1990 fiscal year. **********John Ward, Qantas's chief executive, said Qantas must return to profitability if it is to achieve a successful transition to private ownership. Forty- nine percent of the airline is to be sold by the Australian Government at a value estimated at $760 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/05/busin.main_headline: U.S. Surgical Ad in Times Apparent Hoax
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/05/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; U.S. Surgical Ad in Times Apparent Hoax
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/05/busin.body_text: **********The New York Times said yesterday that an advertisement in Business Day on Tuesday concerning the U.S. Surgical Corporation was apparently a hoax by a person or group that has not yet been identified. **********The four-by-five-inch ad asked that shareholders of U.S. Surgical interested in joining a class-action suit against the company contact the law office of Siegel & Kaplan P.C. at 264 Pondfield Road in Bronxville. The ad asserted that "certain irregular trading patterns" in the company's stock had occurred between March and July 29. **********U.S. Surgical is a major developer and marketer of surgical stapling and of procedures to minimize the cutting in surgery, like a new technique for gall bladder surgery requiring a very small incision. The company has frequently been the target of protests from animal rights groups over its use of animals in research, but there is no known connection between the hoax and animal rights groups. **********Marianne Scipione, a spokeswoman for U.S. Surgical, said the hoax was discovered when the company tried to contact the law firm after the ad appeared, only to find there was no such firm and no such address. The company then notified The Times. **********William K. Adler, a spokesman for The Times, said that a person called the newspaper's legal classified advertisement department last week and discussed placing the ad on Tuesday and in today's issue. Soon after, The Times received via fax a confirmation of the order and detailed instructions for billing following publication. The faxed material appeared to be on authentic letterhead stationery from what appeared to be a law firm. **********Mr. Adler said that fraudulent ads were rare in The Times because the paper has safeguards, including random spot checks. But he said the usual warning signals were not present in this case because the hoaxers appeared to be highly professional. **********The Times canceled the ad that was to appear today and both The Times and U.S. Surgical were trying to identify the person who placed the ad. **********The motive behind the hoax remains unknown, but Ms. Scipione said the ad might have been intended to send the price of the company's stock down, creating an opportunity for profit by someone who had sold the stock short. A short seller borrows shares and then sells them, hoping for a decline in price so that the cost of replacing the borrowed stock is less than what was netted from selling it. Since the ad appeared Tuesday, the price of a share of U.S. Surgical has declined by $3.50, to $69.75. **********Ms. Scipione said that the ad's premise for a class-action suit was difficult to fathom because the company's stock increased by more than 50 percent during the period mentioned in the ad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/busin.main_headline: Ogilvy to Promote Tourism in Illinois
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Ogilvy to Promote Tourism in Illinois
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/busin.body_text: **********After a lengthy review, the Illinois Bureau of Tourism has awarded its $11 million advertising account to Ogilvy & Mather, Chicago. **********The two other finalists in the review, which began with 25 agencies, were also Chicago agencies: the incumbent, McConnaughy Stein Schmidt Brown, which had handled the account for two and a half years, and Foote, Cone & Belding. **********With the change in agencies, the bureau plans a substantial shift in its advertising. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/01/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; What Happens To Oil Prices?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/01/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; What Happens To Oil Prices?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/01/busin.body_text: **********AN effort to assess the economic consequences of the crushing of Iraq and the expulsion of Saddam Hussein's forces from Kuwait must start with the effect on oil prices and supplies. **********It was the Iraqi leader's aim, long before the invasion of Kuwait, to gain more oil resources, force up oil prices and achieve the wealth and arms he needed to dominate the Arab world. After being frustrated by Iran, he turned against Kuwait. **********Last summer, in the midst of an oil glut partly caused by Kuwait's frantic step-up of sales to the West, Iraq stepped up its pressure on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to cut production. Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, among others, acceded. On July 27 an OPEC agreement raised the target price to $21 a barrel. At the time, John H. Lichtblau, a leading oil analyst, said of the agreement: "It's a sea change. Higher prices were always within OPEC's grasp if they adhered to discipline. This time, discipline is guaranteed by a principal player which carries a loaded gun." **********In the new issue of Foreign Policy, Prof. M. A. Adelman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology writes: "As a beneficiary of this increase, Saudi Arabia conveniently ignored the Iraqi threat. But then the enforcer, like many before him, decided there was more profit as a hijacker." **********Now that the enforcer-hijacker's power has been broken, what happens to the oil price? Richard T. McCormack, Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, said in an interview yesterday, "That depends on whether Saudi Arabia decides to keep its oil production up." He credited the Saudis with "averting a bad problem" during the oil embargo and the war. **********Despite the run-up past $40 a barrel early in the Persian Gulf confrontation, the oil price has come down almost to where it was a couple of weeks before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last Aug. 2, but it is still well above the $13 price that Saudi light crude touched last June. Oil closed yesterday at $19.16. **********Mr. McCormack noted that OPEC's target price was still $21 a barrel, but said he favored "letting the market do its thing." He opposed "a misguided attempt" by the United States or other governments to try to set the price. **********But Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and other OPEC members can be expected to make a strong effort to stabilize the price at $21, the target set before the Iraqi invasion. They will argue that such a price will be crucial to pay for the reconstruction of Kuwait, including the cleanup of the oil-polluted gulf. They also argue that they need the money for plan to redistribute wealth to the poor Arab states, ostensibly to assuage the anger of poor Arab individuals and states against rich Arabs and their Western allies. **********Skeptics say such arguments are only rationalizations for the wealthy oil producers' desire to stabilize prices at a high level. **********But they may get some support in the West. Some American officials, who insisted on anonymity, said France would try to support the Arabs in this effort to stabilize oil prices, for two reasons: first, because President Francois Mitterrand is a Socialist and favors redistribution of income, and second and more important, because France wants to puts its arm around the shoulder of wealthy Arab countries and be in a position to get big contracts for building roads, air bases, factories, generating plants and weapons. **********But there could well be conflict within the United States Government on whether to seek a stabilized oil price at a high level; this is a position that might be supported both by contractors or oil producers looking for business in the Middle East and by domestic producers seeking wider profit maragins. Factors strengthening forces that want to see the Arab oil states earn more would be the huge United States budget deficit and the opposition to using taxpayer dollars to finance reconstruction in the gulf. **********Mr. McCormack contends, however, that it would be impossible to stabilize the oil price at a high level, even if the United States wanted to, because of the competition from natural gas, coal, nuclear and other energy sources. Further, he said, OPEC now controls less than half the world's oil. "All previous oil price run-ups," he said, "have resulted, without exception, from political acts, and it is a complete illusion that we could or would do that now -- nobody is prepared for it." Nevertheless, he expects OPEC, trying to counter the market, to "do its thing." **********The resolution of these forces, in his view, will be an oil price of about $18. Professor Adelman thinks that with wide oscillations that price may be about right in the year ahead. Some oil industry analysts put the average price somewhat lower -- at $15 a barrel. **********The elimination of Iraq as the enforcer or hijacker makes it likely that a lower price than OPEC's $21 target will prevail, and the lower price will help to support American and world economic recovery. So, too, will the ample flow of contracts to United States companies and the replenishment of military stockpiles in the near future. Such factors are not great enough, relative to gross national product, to provide the basis for expecting a boom, but they do support expectations of a gradual American recovery.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/busin.body_text: **********The American Express Company reported yesterday that its net income had dropped 46.4 percent in the fourth quarter and 84.6 percent for all of 1990, because of a loss of nearly $1 billion on the year at its troubled Wall Street brokerage house, Shearson Lehman Brothers. **********American Express said it had earned $137.9 million, or 28 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, compared with $257.2 million, or 61 cents a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenue declined less than 1 percent, to $6.3 billion, compared with $6.32 billion a year earlier. **********For the full year, the company reported earnings of $181.5 million, or 34 cents a share, compared with last year's $1.16 billion, or $2.70 a share. Full-year revenue declined nearly 3 percent, to $24.3 billion, from $25 billion a year earlier.  Problems at Shearson **********While its main business units, including Travel Related Services and IDS Financial Services, reported record profits, American Express saw its earnings dragged down by Shearson's poor performance. **********American Express disclosed the earnings shortly before 6 P.M., well past the close of the stock market. Its stock rose 25 cents yesterday, to $20, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Analysts expressed surprise at the magnitude of Shearson's losses. Many had been predicting fourth-quarter losses of $50 million to $75 million. Instead, Shearson reported a loss of $115 million for the quarter, compared with earnings of $4 million a year earlier. For the full year, Shearson reported a loss of $966 million, compared with 1989 profit of $110 million. **********"The area of continuing surprise has to be Shearson," said Alison A. Deans, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. "No one was expecting another round of severance charges of this magnitude." **********The 1990 figures include $787 million in charges for layoffs and office closings at Shearson, as well as $50 million in the fourth quarter for severances and more charges related to dismissals and closings. **********Fourth-quarter results at Shearson also reflected a reserve of $35 million that the company said was related to shares in the troubled Polly Peck International P.L.C., which were bought on behalf of Polly Peck's chairman, Asil Nadir. Polly Peck's stock collapsed late last year. American Express did not elaborate on the statement. **********Shearson's annual revenues totaled $10.2 billion in 1990, down more than 18 percent from $12.5 billion in 1989, primarily because of decreased interest and dividend revenues. **********American Express attributed Shearson's poor performance to "a continued and worsening industrywide slowdown in a difficult economic environment."  Commissions Are Down **********Brokerage commission revenues were down 18 percent, to $1.6 billion. Revenue from market-making and principal transactions were down 5.5 percent, to $1.2 billion. Investment banking revenues dropped 41.5 percent, to $563 million. And investment advisory revenues fell 7.5 percent, to $633 million. **********American Express said its management had met its targets for reducing expenses. Shearson's fixed expenses were cut 9 percent, or $266 million, from 1989 levels. What American Express described as "fourth-quarter, ongoing fixed expenses" were reduced by $86 million from fourth quarter 1989, or $344 million on an annualized basis. **********Ms. Dean noted that Shearson had made some progress in cutting staff costs, but she said it still had a long way to go. Last year, the number of stockbrokers declined 16 percent, to 8,711, and the overall Shearson work force fell 12 percent, to 31,300.  Gains at Charge-Card Unit **********Meanwhile, American Express's mainstay business, the charge-card and travel division known as Travel Related Services, reported an annual profit of $956 million, up 15 percent from $830 million a year earlier. Full-year revenue increased 16 percent, to $9.7 billion. **********In the fourth quarter, net income for Travel Related Services rose 13 percent, to $215 million. Charge volume during the quarter, which occurs during the Christmas buying season, rose 10 percent, to $30 billion. **********American Express also said its IDS Financial Services, which provides financial planning and other services, posted net income of $207 million during the year, up 18 percent from the 1989 level. Revenue rose 14 percent, to $2.2 billion, from $1.9 billion in 1989. In the fourth quarter, IDS's net income rose 16 percent, to $56 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/31/busin.main_headline: What the Market's Saying About Oil Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/31/busin.print_headline: What the Market's Saying About Oil Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/31/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********In "Gulf Problems That Can't Be Ignored" (March 10) Hossein Askari seems to imply that his oil price expectations are widely held by the oil market. For example: "Supply and demand    will    reduce prices to $12 to $15 per barrel in the next two years. . . ." and "Two years after the war . . .    the expectation is    for a substantial oil glut that could reduce prices to less than $10." **********It should be noted, however, that the New York Mercantile Exchange now lists oil futures contracts for delivery through December 1993, providing some visibility into    the market's    price expectations. As of Friday, March 8, the final day of trading before Mr. Askari's article appeared, crude oil futures prices had settled just below, or in one case just above, $19 per barrel for all contracts for delivery from June 1991 through December 1993, and prices have stayed at that level. Mr. Askari may ultimately prove to be correct.  However, those are only his views, and at the moment, his view is clearly in the minority. ROBERT BOSLEGO  Winchester, Mass., March 11    The author is president of the Boslego Corporation, oil consultants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/busin.main_headline: Strife Cripples Yugoslavia's Big Tourist Industry
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/busin.print_headline: Strife Cripples Yugoslavia's Big Tourist Industry
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/busin.body_text: **********The boutiques beneath the soaring arches of this city's Roman palace stood deserted on a brisk spring afternoon, their jewelery and folk art gathering dust. The hotels were all but empty. Those in the tourism business here concede that the 1991 season is the worst in their memory. **********"Last summer, there were many people here; now, there is nobody," said Jadranka Durdov, a 25-year-old saleswoman. "It's obvious the political situation has scared people, and I can understand why." **********Up and down the picturesque Adriatic coast, the story is much the same for what has been one of Yugoslavia's leading industries. Visitors from Europe and the United States are staying away, apparently frightened by this nation's ethnic violence. Local tourism agents estimate that this year they are seeing only 10 percent as many visitors as last year. Destination for Westerners **********With tourism booming in Eastern Europe since the fall of Communist governments, Yugoslavia had expected business to improve. For the last decade, Yugoslavia has carved out a singular niche among Eastern European nations. While Bulgaria, Romania and even Hungary catered largely to visitors from other Communist countries, Yugoslavia successfully marketed itself as a cheap, sunny destination for Westerners. **********The collapse of the nation's tourism, a $2.7 billion business last year, is one of the worst economic consequences of the conflicts that threaten to tear this country apart. Ljubica Milojevic, chief of the research department at the Tourism Association of Yugoslavia, said that bookings nationwide were off 60 to 80 percent from last year. **********Tourism has been one of Yugoslavia's leading sources of Western currencies, she said, employing 400,000 and accounting for about 3 percent of gross national product. More than 9 million foreigners visited Yugoslavia in 1990, about 40 percent from Germany. **********In better times, Split, a city of 280,000, was one of the nation's chief attractions. Its walled old city, built by the Roman Emperor Diocletian in the years 300 to 304, is one of the best-preserved Roman ruins in Europe. Local legend has it that the emperor settled here because of the waters, the beautiful women and the absence of earthquakes. Near Empty Restaurant **********But on a recent Saturday evening in Split, the Adrijana Restaurant, known for its seafood, served its first and only customers at 10 P.M. They were foreign journalists covering Yugoslavia's latest crisis. **********On the sidewalk out front, several people lurked in the shadows, approaching anyone who could possibly be a tourist with their forlorn, multi-lingual pleas: "Room? Zimmer? Camara? Sobe?" **********At the Bellevue Hotel nearby, Vjenceslav Perkov, a manager there, lamented the lack of traffic. "Yugoslavia is a beautiful country with the most beautiful sea in the world," he said. "This political situation has had a terrible influence on tourism. If events do not calm down, many hotels here will have to close down." **********Yugoslavia's tourism has long added to the disputes among the nation's six republics. More than 80 percent of tourist dollars and Deutsche marks are spent in Split, Dubrovnik and other coastal communities in the republic of Croatia. The republics have bickered for years over how much the federal Government should invest in projects like constructing new roads to the seashore, which some argue would mainly benefit Croatia. Serbians Block Road **********Recently, the tourist business has become a target for Croatia's restive Serbian minority. Last year, Serbs challenging the newly elected nationalist government in Croatia blocked the main road from Western Europe to the coast, causing a sharp decline in late-season bookings. About half of the coast's tourists come from Germany, and the main auto route crosses the republic's Serbian areas. **********This year, tourism prospects dimmed when Yugoslav Army tanks rolled through the streets of Belgrade in February to quell rioting. Croatian officials said that events this spring then destroyed their last hopes of salvaging the season. **********Rebel Serbs seized the Plitvice national park in Croatia, whose water falls and forests form the backdrop for many of the country's tourism posters. When paramilitary policemen stormed the park on Easter Sunday, a bus filled with Italian tourists was caught in the crossfire. Their quick-witted driver ordered passengers to crouch on the floor, averting any injuries. **********The violence has intensified. First, clashes between Serbs and Croatians left at least 18 dead. Then, an anti-Army protest in Split turned into a riot that led to the fatal shooting of a 19-year old conscript. Airlift on Standby **********Even before these troubles, travel agents in Split had received little more than cancellations and unusual requests. Some Belgian tourists said they would come to the region only with a guarantee that if ethnic strife broke out, they would immediately be airlifted out. A plane was reserved, but not needed. **********Ana Manzoni, director of the foreign travel division at Dalmacijaturist, a worker-owned agency with annual revenues of $150 million, said she foresaw layoffs if business did not pick up. **********"The damage has already been done," she said, after hearing Prime Minister Ante Markovic address reporters at the nation's annual tourism convention. "At best, we may end up with 40 percent of last year, which was not a good year. It is really a disaster."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/26/world.main_headline: Ireland to Tighten Law on Fugitives
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/26/world.print_headline: Ireland to Tighten Law on Fugitives
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/26/world.body_text: **********The Government has agreed to close loopholes in the law that have been used by fugitive Irish Republican Army guerrillas to avoid extradition to Britain. **********The problem of extradition, a sore point between London and Dublin, flared up here in recent weeks in two situations involving I.R.A. members who were convicted of murder or attempted murder in Northern Ireland but avoided extradition because of Irish law. **********The publicity given the two situations also underscored Irish ambivalence toward the outlawed I.R.A. **********While the Government of Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey has promised to push law revisions through Parliament, probably early next year, the existence of the loopholes was well known, and the question arose as to why the Government did not act until Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary, Peter Brooke, came to Dublin and complained forcefully. **********Since the signing in 1985 of the Anglo-Irish Agreement, which calls for cooperation in controlling terrorism, there have been several sensitive cases a year involving I.R.A. operatives accused of serious crimes. **********"At present someone cannot be extradited for possession of a machine gun with intent to endanger life or for storing weapons or explosives," said Sean Barrett, a spokesman for the opposition Fine Gael party. Michael McDowell, a lawyer and a leader of the Progressive Democrats, who are in Mr. Haughey's coalition Government, said that "a loophole exists which permits people to successfully plead their offenses are politically motivated." **********In one situation, the Supreme Court refused on Nov. 15 to extradite two men convicted in the North of involvement in the killing of a British Army captain in a shootout in 1980. The court did not rule on the guilt or innocence of the two men, who were accused of carrying machine guns, but not of actually firing them in the encounter . Doherty's Case and Another **********Under Irish law, such an offense may be considered a political act, not criminal. The I.R.A. routinely asserts that its members are soldiers in a war, not criminals, and that their actions are political. One of the men convicted of murder in the case was Joseph Doherty, who is in Federal prison in the United States, where he has become a hero to some Irish-Americans and has the announced support of Mayor David Dinkins of New York in his fight against extradition. **********In the second instance, Prime Minister Haughey was forced 10 days ago to withdraw his candidate for Defense Minister, James McDaid, after it was disclosed that Mr. McDaid had been photographed congratulating a man who had been freed by the Supreme Court, which had ruled that to return him to Northern Ireland might subject him to brutality by prison officers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/18/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: AROUND THE WORLD - WESTERN EUROPE; Allied Backing, But Protests Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/18/world.body_text: **********Western European governments gave their full backing today to the American-led offensive against Iraq and urged President Saddam Hussein to "see reason" by leaving Kuwait to avert "pointless suffering" by his own people. **********Underlining the apparent success of today's attacks, France's armed forces chief, Gen. Maurice Schmidt, said Iraq had lost around 50 percent of its air force and was no longer able to launch "serious chemical weapons" against Saudi Arabia or Israel. **********Fears of terrorist reprisals prompted tight security measures across Western Europe, with American, British and French embassies, military bases, airlines and schools given special protection. Many bomb threats and several small incidents were reported in Germany, France and Italy. **********With British and French forces in the gulf already taking part in the war, Italy announced that 10 of its Tornado combat aircraft would join the offensive against Iraq, while the Netherlands placed three naval warships under United States command. **********In Brussels, where NATO ambassadors were called into session today, the 16-nation alliance expressed hope that the anti-Iraqi coalition would quickly free Kuwait, but it boosted its naval presence in the eastern Mediterranean as a "precautionary measure." Peace Rallies in Several Cities **********Peace rallies were quickly organized in many German, French and Spanish cities. In Rome, Pope John Paul II expressed "deep sadness" over the outbreak of war, which he called a "grave defeat" for the world. **********Foreign and defense ministers of the Western European Union, a nine-national military organization, held an emergency meeting in Paris today to be briefed by British and French officials and to coordinate the activities of their naval forces in the area. **********Earlier, France's Defense Minister, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, said 12 French Jaguar fighter-bombers took part alongside American aircraft in the second wave of raids early today, but he said Paris had agreed with Washington that its forces would strike only at Kuwait and not inside Iraq. **********He also reported that Iraqi anti-aircraft guns had damaged four French fighters and wounded one pilot. **********But General Schmidt said Iraq's Air Force had been decimated. "There are very few Iraqi planes still flying, around 15 at nightfall and two were shot down," he said. **********He said Iraq now had little hope of launching chemical weapons because their missile sites had been "neutralized."  Opposition in Germany **********In Germany, Chancellor Helmut Kohl seemed to take note of strong domestic opposition to the use of force against Iraq when he told Parliament that he was "deeply disturbed" by the outbreak of war and reiterated that German soldiers would not be sent into action in the gulf. **********But speaking after being sworn in for a new term as Chancellor, Mr. Kohl also said: "We should not forget that our American, British and French allies are bearing the main burden of defending law and freedom in this conflict. They have a right to our solidarity, and we stand by them." **********As hopes of an early end to the war grew, however, European anxiety about terrorism increased. Belgium ordered seven of the nine Iraqi diplomats in Brussels to leave the country, while France stepped up surveillance of Iraqis and other Arabs living. Three firebombs were thrown at a synagogue in Lyons, and another exploded outside an army recruitment center near Paris. In Milan, firebombs were thrown overnight at an American bookstore and a British school. **********Some of the tightest security precautions were taken in Germany, where more than 100,000 antiwar protesters marched in different cities today for the sixth successive day. Vandals broke away from one march in Berlin and smashed windows at a United States cultural center.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/busin.main_headline: Chief Executive Post Shifted at Nestle Foods
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chief Executive Post Shifted at Nestle Foods
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/busin.body_text: **********Nestle operations in the United States, built up through big acquisitions over the last several decades to become a business with $7 billion in annual sales, have been in the throes of reorganization since the first of the year. **********The changes continued this week with the early retirement of C. Alan MacDonald, 57 years old, the chief executive and president of the Nestle Foods Corporation, based in Purchase, N.Y. **********Nestle Foods is one of the food units of Nestle U.S.A. Inc., the major domestic operation of the big Swiss company, Nestle S.A. Nestle U.S.A. is based in Los Angeles, with Timm F. Crull as president and chief executive. Mr. Crull came to Nestle through the Carnation Company, which Nestle acquired in 1985. **********Mr. MacDonald became a Nestle executive from Stouffer Restaurants, which Nestle bought in 1973. In all, Mr. MacDonald spent 36 years with Stouffer and Nestle, and was president of Stouffer Frozen Foods from 1972 to 1982. **********Nestle makes use of the executives it acquires when it purchases companies, and it does not to try to run operations with executives sent over from Swiss headquarters. **********Mr. MacDonald's duties are being taken over by a longtime Nestle American executive, Frank Cella, 50, senior vice president of Nestle U.S.A. The company said Mr. Cella would oversee the operation of Nestle Foods "for the immediate future" and during the continuing consolidation that began with the creation of Nestle U.S.A. on Jan. 1. The company he will run currently has under it businesses like Nestle Chocolate, Nestle Ice Cream, specialty products and Nestle Puerto Rico. **********"There could be more changes; it's all being studied by the steering committee," Dick Curd, a Nestle spokesman, said. **********The committee has been created "to oversee the entire process," he said, with nine task forces of various disciplines, like accounting, manufacturing and sales. It is recommending various new ways to organize such as putting all distribution or all the ice cream under one company. **********Mr. Cella joined Nestle in 1963 in sales. He held several posts in the United States and Canada and joined the Carnation unit in 1989 as senior vice president, becoming senior vice president at Nestle U.S.A. under Mr. Crull at the beginning of the year.
