https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/07/world.main_headline: As Yugoslavia Boils, Serbs Hail a Would-Be King
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/07/world.print_headline: As Yugoslavia Boils, Serbs Hail a Would-Be King
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/07/world.body_text: **********Heavy artillery shelling and air strikes were reported across Croatia today in continued defiance of a cease-fire while a new figure, Prince Aleksandar Karadjordjevic, heir to the long-vacant Yugoslav throne, offered himself here as a peacemaker. **********The Prince addressed a large rally in central Belgrade -- by some estimates exceeding 70,000 people -- and presented himself not only as a conciliator but as an alternative to the authoritarian government of President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia. The throng responded passionately, shouting, "We want a king!" **********The fighting, pitting forces of the breakaway republic of Croatia against Serbian militias backed by Yugoslav Army units, was reported near Zadar and around encircled Dubrovnik on the Adriatic coast, as well as in Vukovar, Vinkovci and Osijek in the eastern Slavonia region. The army said that Dubrovnik's airport had been captured from the Croatians.  Tentative Agreement **********The Yugoslav press agency reported that Serbian forces had reached the center of Vukovar, a city long held by Croatian forces. **********The death toll since Croatia's independence declaration in June is in the hundreds, with the national newspaper Borba placing the toll at 2,500. **********The cease-fire, brokered on Friday in the Netherlands by mediators from the European Community, envisioned the removal of blockades of about 40 Yugoslav Army garrisons in Croatia as well as political steps to defuse what is still an undeclared war. In The Hague, community foreign ministers agreed to impose a trade embargo on Yugoslavia Monday night if the fighting was not halted by then. **********The principal antagonists, Mr. Milosevic of Serbia and Franjo Tudjman, President of Croatia, and the Yugoslav Defense Minister, Veljko Kadijevic, appeared to accept the latest cease-fire on Friday and even expressed some optimism. But they had accepted previous European-negotiated truces that were never observed. **********From Friday night through Saturday afternoon, Mr. Tudjman and General Kadijevic exchanged four faxed messages between Zagreb and Belgrade, with the Croatian leader demanding a cease-fire first and the Defense Minister demanding the unblocking of his garrisons as a first step. **********In the same period, both sides ordered further mobilizations of their forces as fighting flared anew. **********Another ingredient was added to the nation's turbulent and complex politics with the arrival in Belgrade Saturday night of Prince Aleksandar, who has been accorded a triumphal welcome by the Serbs of his ancestral homeland after having spent all his life in exile. The monarchy was abolished by Tito in 1946 and moved to London.  'Service of the Homeland' **********The 46-year-old Prince Aleksandar, a London businessman and former British Army officer, appeared at what amounted to a series of monarchist rallies. **********"If you so desire, I am ready to put myself at the service of the homeland as an ambassador of peace, a fighter for civil liberties and human rights, and as a protector of Serbs," said the pretender to the throne that his late father, Peter II, vacated in April 1941 when Nazi forces invaded Yugoslavia. He also called for "genuine parliamentary democracy." **********He spoke in front of the new St. Sava Church and next to a statue of his great-great-grandfather, Karadjordje Petrovic, the peasant warrior who led the first Serbian rebellion against the Turks in 1804 and who founded the dynasty. **********The Karadjordjevics are a star-crossed dynasty. For instance, the Prince's grandfather, King Aleksandar I, was assassinated 57 years ago in Marseilles by killers working for Croatian nationalists. **********This morning, Prince Aleksandar laid a wreath at the grave of his grandfather in the heartland town of Oplenac, at a ceremony attended by thousands. Threat to Milosevic? **********Aleksandar I began his reign as the King of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes in 1918, but changed his title to King of Yugoslavia in 1929. The ambiguity between Yugoslavia and Serbia clings to the grandson today. The Prince avoided mention of "Yugoslavia," speaking instead of "my country," "fatherland" and "my dear Serbs." **********For President Milosevic, who seems bent on creating a new, smaller Yugoslavia dominated by Serbia, the Prince is a potential threat, a fact underlined by the crowds today who chanted not only "Stay!" to Aleksandar, but also "Slobo, go away!" **********The Serbian crowds also demonstrated that the Karadjordjevic dynasty can mobilize symbolic energy. This was evident in the guards surrounding Prince Aleksandar strutting in uniforms bearing patches proclaiming "Serbian Army." It was also manifest in the presence of Serbian Orthodox priests and nuns, of royal insignia and banners, and the singing of Serbian hymns and anthems. **********The Prince is to leave Monday after 36 hours here, but other princes and princesses are arriving to honor his grandfather at Oplenac Wednesday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/09/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; NBC News Lays Off 18 Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/09/busin.body_text: **********Eighteen NBC News employees were laid off on Friday, and an official of their union said a grievance would be filed this week accusing the network of violating the union contract. **********The union may also charge NBC with sex and age discrimination, said John Clark, the president of Local 11 of the National Association of Broadcast Engineers and Technicians. **********Mr. Clark said the union would charge that NBC violated an agreement not to lay off more than 4 percent of the union-represented employees of NBC News this year and that NBC put the layoffs into effect without first offering another round of buyouts. **********Peggy Hubble, the director of press relations for NBC News, said, "Laying people off is never easy, but this decision was made in complete accordance with the union contract." **********NBC has had longstanding problems with the union, which waged a strike against NBC for more than 100 days in 1987. Twice this year, NBC has offered buyouts to union employees. **********Of the sex and age discrimination issue, Mr. Clark said NBC had offered triple severance to the dismissed employees as long as they agreed not to sue on the basis of age or sex discrimination. **********Eleven of the 18 news writers to be laid off on Jan. 3 are women. Several of them complained yesterday that NBC followed a pattern of discriminating against women and cited the conditional severance offer as proof. **********A senior NBC executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the severance bonus and the conditions under which it would be granted were spelled out in the last union contract. The NBC executive said the employees should have been aware that the severance agreements precluded any sort of grievance appeal, not just on the basis of sex or age discrimination. **********Ms. Hubble said more than half the people affected by the layoffs would be hired back by NBC News in positions with slightly different job desciptions. "The decisions were based on the nature of the jobs and the skills of those involved," Ms. Hubble said. **********Two news writers said the new positions were outside the union jurisdiction.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/busin.main_headline: Stocks Climb Broadly as Dow Jumps 24.01
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/busin.print_headline: Stocks Climb Broadly as Dow Jumps 24.01
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/busin.body_text: **********With no unsettling news from the Middle East by closing time, stock prices advanced broadly yesterday in the heaviest trading in a week. **********Analysts attributed it to Wednesday's Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that the economy needs a lift -- a clue that he would make sure it happens. **********The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 24.01, or nearly 1 percent, to 2,643.07. Birinyi Associates said repeated waves of computerized program buying raised the blue-chip index close to 21 points. **********Activity soared to 223.2 million shares, up from 169.4 million the day before and the highest since last Friday. **********The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 1.4 percent, or the equivalent of 37 points on the Dow, while the Nasdaq composite index climbed nearly 2 percent, the equivalent of 56 Dow points. Gains Outpace Declines **********Advances outnumbered declines 3 to 1, with 1,231 stocks, or 61 percent of the Big Board total, ahead for the day while 398 fell. Seventy-two stocks reached new highs and 17 fell to new lows. **********Analysts were impressed by the rise in secondary stocks, the mainstay of the Nasdaq index. The lesser stocks were a big factor in leading the market out of its lows last October and are expected to do it again. **********From airlines, banks, chemical companies and paper to technology, drugs, insurance and retailing, the advance in the Dow extended across most leading industry groups. **********Airlines were especially strong, rising in the wake of weak crude oil prices and the news that foreigners would be allowed to invest more heavily in American air carriers. **********The rise pushed the Dow transportation index ahead 40.02 points, or 4 percent, with UAL up 5 1/4, to 128 3/4; Airborne Freight 2 1/8, to 20 1/2; AMR 1 1/2, to 52 5/8; Delta Air Lines 1 3/4, to 68 3/8, and Southwest Airlines 1 5/8, to 22 5/8. Conrail rose 4 3/8, to 44 1/2, after reporting better-than-expected profits.  March Crude Oil Contract **********The March crude oil contract, meanwhile, fell 33 cents, to $21.71 a barrel, close to its low for the day. **********"Many people were puzzled why the transportation index went up so much," said Hugh Johnson, chief strategist for the brokerage firm First Albany Corporation. "I think the main reason was that the Saudi oilfields appear to be safe," but he also cited the relaxation of limits on foreign investment in airlines. **********He attributed the rise in the Dow to "a carry-over of Greenspan's testimony on Wednesday implying that the Fed was prepared to lower short-term interest rates, particularly if bank lending and money growth remains sluggish." **********Shocked by the rise in the market -- after Wednesday's gain -- short-sellers who had hoped to make a killing if the market fell, were forced to buy to cover stock they had borrowed, driving the market ahead. **********The Dow picked up steam from the opening bell. By 10 A.M. it was ahead nearly 25 points. Bt 11:15 it was up 31. Prices fell a little but by 12:30 were ahead 33 points. **********Traders have become accustomed to shocks from the Middle East late in the day, which may explain why the Dow drifted a little toward the close. **********Despite the strong rise in the Dow industrials, individual price gains were mainly thin. A.T.& T. rose 5/8, to 29; Kodak 1/8, to 40 1/8, and Coca-Cola 3/4, to 48 7/8. But International Paper tacked on 2 1/4, to 57 7/8; Boeing 1 5/8, to 48 3/4; I.B.M. 1 3/4, to 121, and Sears 1, to 26 7/8. **********Blockbuster Entertainment, which has been strong since the fall, headed the Big Board active list, sliding 2 1/4, to 25 5/8, on 4.8 million shares even though fourth-quarter earnings met analyst estimates. **********Data General, a technology company, rose 4, to 8 1/4, after going into the black in the December quarter. Bankers Trust fell 4 1/8, to 41, after George Salem, banking analyst for Prudential-Bache, cut his earnings estimate for this year after a lower-than-expected 1990. **********News Corporation, headed by Rupert Murdoch, rose 7/8, to 7 7/8. He said he was prepared to dilute his family's 45 percent control by issuing more full voting stock, Dow Jones reported.  Tokyo Stocks Advance **********TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 25 (REUTERS) -- Japanese stocks rose today for the second straight gain. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 304.24 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 25,573.25. The Nikkei rose 218.91 points on Thursday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/world.main_headline: U.S. HOPES SESSIONS ON MIDEAST CREATE A NEW ATMOSPHERE
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/world.print_headline: THE MIDDLE EAST TALKS; U.S. HOPES SESSIONS ON MIDEAST CREATE A NEW ATMOSPHERE
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/world.body_text: **********Bush Administration policy makers say the core of their strategy for the Madrid peace talks is very simple: keep the Arabs and Israelis talking long enough to create a changed environment so breakthroughs that now seem impossible might become possible. **********There is no "Bush peace plan" that the President will suddenly pull out of a briefcase when he arrives in Madrid, replete with maps, compromises and novel ideas to settle all outstanding issues, say American officials who have been planning for the peace conference, which opens on Wednesday. **********But there is an American conviction that the very act of getting all the parties to sit down with one another for the first time will create a new dynamic between them and open the door for compromises down the road. The United States plans to nurture such compromises, first from the sidelines and later as a direct mediator with bridging proposals of its own if the parties alone cannot make any headway. The U.S. Balancing Act **********The trick, say American officials, will be to carry out such mediation without supplanting the direct, face-to-face encounter between the parties, which is essential for changing how they look at, and deal with, one another. **********The Administration's strategy, said one senior policy maker, is based on the assumption that over time "the very act of the parties' sitting down will begin to shatter mythologies on both sides." In particular, they hope to destroy the Israeli argument that there are no Arabs to talk to, and the Arab argument that all the Israelis want is Arab lands. **********But for those long-held views to be shed, and for concrete peace agreements to be produced, the senior official added, "it is critical that this process continue over time." Defining Areas of Substance **********He elaborated: "The longer these negotiations go on, the greater the likelihood that areas of substance will be defined to hook them into something that in fact is a real negotiation." **********Officials acknowledge that this strategy is untested, and has three potential weaknesses. First, they could discover that the problem between Arabs and Israelis is not that they fail to understand each other, but that they understand each other all too well, and therefore the more they talk directly, the more the fundamental disagreements will be highlighted instead of bridged. **********Second, a change of the atmosphere and dynamics between Arab nations and Israel ultimately requires change within the countries. Is a minority Government like Syria's -- dominated by members of the small Alawite sect of Islam in a country with a Sunni Muslim majority -- really ready to end its conflict with Israel and slash its army? Can Israel's governing Likud party, whose very raison d'etre is its commitment to keeping the West Bank, conclude agreements that would gut its ideological core? **********Third, the United States did not get the parties to agree to talk by gentle dialogue, but by using economic clout over Israel, by letting the leaders of Saudi Arabia know that they owed Washington for the Persian Gulf war, by using the Soviet Union and the Saudis to press the Syrians and by tacitly threatening the Palestinians with international isolation.  Washington's Hardball Tactics **********American officials say privately they know that these same hardball tactics, if not tougher ones, will be required to promote actual agreements. But the challenge will be to twist arms without contradicting the terms of the conference, which President Bush described innocently on Friday as not intended "to impose a settlement" but "to bring people together so they can achieve a settlement." **********For now, Washington is not discussing these issues publicly. To pursue its strategy -- which was worked out by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Administration's senior Middle East experts, Dennis B. Ross, Daniel C. Kurtzer, Aaron D. Miller, Richard N. Haass and William J. Burns -- Washington has evolved a game plan. **********It deals with each phase of the talks: from the three-day opening conference at the Royal Palace in Madrid starting on Wednesday, through the first bilateral negotiations that will follow that meeting and into the third phase of detailed negotiations. **********Phase one in the Administration's strategy involves getting the most mileage from the ceremonial opening in Madrid. Bush's Presentation **********President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union will address the opening session. Mr. Bush is planning to use the opportunity, officials say, to lay out a broad American vision of why peace is in everyone's interest, as well as what Washington regards as the basic ingredients of a settlement -- themes like trading land for real peace. **********Already, the two sides have publicly put forward their well-known positions. The Arabs have insisted that Israel give up all of the territory it gained in the 1967 war -- namely the Golan Heights, which once was controlled by Syria; the West Bank and East Jerusalem, which once were under Jordanian control, and the Gaza Strip, which was controlled by Egypt. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Government has repeated its position that it does not intend to give up any more land. **********While the Administration does not expect any party to drop or modify its basic positions at this opening session, it is nevertheless quietly coaching Israel, Lebanon, Syria, Jordan and the Palestinians to use their opening speeches to convey the message that there really are new possibilities. **********For instance, the Administration would like the Israelis at least to hint, even vaguely, that the Golan Heights might be negotiable -- or to say that while Israel wants to keep that territory forever, it is looking forward to hearing Syria's views on the subject because alternatives might be possible. **********Similarly, the Administration is urging the Syrians at least to hint that the payoff for Israel if it returns the Golan Heights, with its commanding view of northern Israel and of Damascus, could be more than just nonbelligerency, but real peace. **********Phase two of the talks starts after the opening, when Israel and Syria, Israel and Lebanon and Israel and the joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation are supposed to sit down for separate, face-to-face, two-way negotiations.  Confidence-Building Gestures **********The Administration wants these talks to evolve in two stages. Washington expects the parties to make conflicting demands. But it hopes to prevent these collisions from derailing the bilateral talks by encouraging the parties to consider first trading small, confidence-building gestures. **********For instance, Administration officials say they hope to encourage a deal in which Israel would agree to suspend building settlements in the occupied territories in return for suspension of the Arab economic boycott of Israel and suspension of the Palestinian uprising, against Israel. **********Prime Minister Shamir has rejected such a deal already. Washington is talking to the Israelis as well as to the Saudis and other Arabs about ways to "sweeten the pot" for all sides. **********Exactly how the United States will make its suggestions, though, raises what American officials say is the most sensitive aspect of the bilateral talks. How does the United States encourage the parties to keep talking long enough to produce psychological transformations without stepping in and becoming a mediator interfering with the give-and-take of direct talks? Standing Outside, Whispering **********According to the conference invitation, Washington is allowed to attend the bilateral talks only if both sides invite it. Initially at least, the Israelis are unlikely to do that, because they want to underscore the face-to-face aspect of talks and the implicit recognition this connotes. **********Therefore, said an American, Washington's representatives will stand "just outside the door," whispering to both sides. **********"We have told all parties that we expect these to be genuine and meaningful negotiations," said a senior American official. "Our role will be to go in at times to offer advice on how best to approach certain problems. We are not going to go in and say, 'You ought to do it this way or that way.' But we will say: 'Hey, if you are going to present something that way, you are bound to get the following response. So you need to think that if you are going to say X you have to couple it with Y.' " **********When President Carter mediated between Egypt and Israel in 1978 and when Henry Kissinger mediated between Syria and Israel after the 1973 war, both Americans had a very clear idea of what the bottom lines were for all parties. Arabs and Israelis sought American intervention to bridge their positions; this time Washington forced the parties together. **********The framework for negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians is already agreed on. The two sides, according to the conference invitation, will begin with "talks on interim self-government arrangements" for Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********But the Israeli-Syrian negotiations have no agreed framework. Washington's first challenge is to find some imaginative way to bridge Syria's desire for a return of total sovereignty over the Golan Heights with the Israelis' insistence on not giving up the strategic high ground. **********The second challenge posed by the Syrian-Israeli negotiations, say American officials, is that if they deadlock, the Syrians not be allowed to exercise a veto over the Israeli-Palestinian talks. **********But this is easier said than done. The Syrians have already announced that they are not going to take part in the multilateral talks between Israel, Jordan, the Palestinians, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, Qatar, Oman, Morocco and the United Arab Emirates, which are supposed to accompany the bilateral negotiations. These talks will deal with regional problems like water, arms control, refugees and economic development. **********Washington has managed to persuade the other Arabs to go despite the Syrian objection, but the Syrians struck a quiet deal in Damascus last Wednesday with the Saudis and other Gulf Arabs in which the Arabs promised Syria that while they would engage the Israelis in a dialogue in these multilateral talks, they would not "close" any agreements until Syria was satisfied that Israel would cede territory in the bilateral negotiations, Arab diplomats said. REPRESENTING THE UNITED STATES **********The American delegation to th eMiddle East peace conference in Madrid includes five foreigh policy specialists chosen for their expertise in issues related to both Israel and the Arab states. DENNIS B. ROSS Director of State Department's Policy Planning Staff, a research group that explores new ideas and policies ... senior foreign policy adviser to George Bush's presidential campaign ... from 1986-88, National Security Council director of Near East and South Asian Affairs ... in early 1980's, a member of the planning staff that he now leads, working on Middle East issues ... spent a decade working on Middle East peace proposals with his key aides, Daniel C. Kurtzer and Aaron D. Miller ... Baker's right hand in the recent Mideast peace shuttle ... Ph.D. from U.C.L.A. ... analytical, a conceptualizer of new strategies and policies. AAQRON D. MILLER State Department Policy Planning staff member ... Political officer at American Embassy in Amman in 1984 ... Middle East analyst at State Department from 1980 to 1984 ... Ph.D. in Middle East history ... author of two books on Palestinians and the P.L.O. ... expert on Palestinian question in inter-Arab politics .. pragmatic analyst who often takes centrist position on Middle East isues .. helped write the letters of assurance and invitations to Arab and Israeli leaders. DANIEL C. KURTZER Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, Policy Planning Staff ... First Secretary of Political Affairs at American Embassy in Cairo from 1979 to 1982 and in Tel Aviv from 1982 to 1986 ... United States delegate to talks on Palestinian autonomy in 1979 ... helped negotiate terms for arbitration between Israel and Egypt during Taba border dispute ... Ph.D. from Columbia University, B.A. from Yeshiva University, where was dean in the late 1970's ... an Orthodox Jew from New Jersey who, while working in Cairo, traveled to Israel to buy kosher food ... praised by Arab and Israeli diplomats for his knowledge of Middle East history ... argued for years that the U.S. must reach out to the Palestinians, including the P.L.O. ... helped draft the carefully worded letters of assurance and invitations that are bringing Arab and Israeli leaders to the negotiating table. WILLIAM J. BURNS Deputy Director of State Department Policy Planning Staff ... from 1986 to 1989, Director and Senior Director of Near East office at the National Security Council ... past assignments include State Department special assistant and staff assistane for Near East Affairs, political officer at American Embassy in Amman .. Ph.D from Oxford University ... author of a book on U.S.-Egyptian relations ... as Dennis Ross's deputy, runs Policy Planning staff ... sounding board for colleagues on planning staff ... seldom reveals personal opinions; usually aruges Americn policy position. RICHARD N. HAASS Special Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs and Senior Director for Near East And South Asian Affairs, National Security Council ... President Bush's adviser for Madrid conference ... State Department political and military policy analyst since 1982 ...Defense Department special assistant, 1979 to 1982 ... public policy lecturer at Harvard, 1985 to 1989 ... Rhodes Scholar with Ph.D. from Oxford ... author of two books on superpower arms control ... received Presidental medal for role in advising President Bush during Persian Gulf War ... unsentimental, tough on both Israelis and Arabs .. reflects and encourages President's position ... advocates philosophy of "ripening" - settling political conflicts when they are ripe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/29/world.main_headline: European Community Aides Back a U.N. Force for Kurds
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/29/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; European Community Aides Back a U.N. Force for Kurds
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/29/world.body_text: **********The European Community today endorsed a British proposal to send a United Nations police force to Iraq to show hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees that it is safe to return home. **********Britain made its proposal at a two-day meeting of community foreign ministers in this resort town on the French border with Luxembourg. **********The plan received "a unanimous welcome," said Foreign Minister Jacques Poos of Luxembourg, the chairman. **********The United Nations force would replace 9,000 American and allied troops who are setting up refugee camps in northern Iraq and asking the Kurds to leave mountain areas along the Iraqi and Turkish borders. Many Kurdish refugees say they will not budge unless they are certain they will be safe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/busin.main_headline: The Executive Computer; Networld: The Talk Is of Strategic Partnerships
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/busin.print_headline: The Executive Computer; Networld: The Talk Is of Strategic Partnerships
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/busin.body_text: **********When 20,000 managers of corporate computer systems gathered at the Networld 91 trade show here last week, they found vivid proof that the personal computer industry remains in a mating frenzy, with companies seeking strategic partners in virtually every market corner. **********The latest significant technological pairing, announced at the show, brought together Novell Inc., of Provo, Utah, the leading maker of operating system software for personal computer networks, and the International Business Machines Corporation. **********Responding to what it said were requests from customers, I.B.M. said it would begin selling and supporting Novell's Netware operating system, along with its own LAN Server software. Novell is to develop versions of Netware for I.B.M.'s high-end personal computers and mid-range systems, which will run on top of I.B.M.'s OS/2 and AIX-Unix operating systems. I.B.M., in turn, will develop the fittings necessary for Netware and LAN Server to work together seamlessly on large business networks. Officials at both companies say the alliance does not involve any financial dealings. **********For their customers, the plans are good news. Novell Netware, which works with almost all major brands of personal computers, has become the network operating software of choice at the departmental level for most businesses because it is relatively simple and inexpensive to install. I.B.M.'s networking efforts, on the other hand, have been strongest at the top, reaching down from the big, central computing systems for which I.B.M. is famous. **********By embracing Netware and integrating it with LAN Server, I.B.M. will in theory eventually be able to connect mainframes, minicomputers, engineering work stations, powerful network PC's called servers, desktop PC's, dumb terminals and even portable computers with a unified system of plumbing. Information would flow through the plumbing "transparently," meaning that an executive could log on to the networked system at any machine, using a standard set of commands, and have access to all information regardless of where it resides. **********But such a system may take years to evolve. "Rome was not built in a day," said James A. Cannavino, an I.B.M. vice president and general manager of its personal systems division. Nor was Rome built without intrigue and some bloodletting. In embracing Novell, I.B.M. appears to be turning its back on the Microsoft Corporation, which is developing a rival operating system for local area networks, called LAN Manager. **********Although I.B.M. and Novell have worked together for several years in developing networked systems for schools, I.B.M. has largely ignored Netware in the business market. Instead, I.B.M. has licensed Microsoft's LAN Manager technology and has incorporated aspects of it into its own LAN Server software. I.B.M. says it will continue to support LAN Server, but it will now compete directly with Microsoft's LAN Manager by selling Netware as well. **********I.B.M. and Microsoft, which is based in Redmond, Wash., and is the nation's largest personal computer software company, have had a very close relationship since the early days of the personal computer industry. But the two companies have clashed repeatedly on the direction that system software will take in the future. **********Playing to the large base of low-end PC's installed around the world, Microsoft emphasizes the DOS and Windows operating systems; I.B.M., whose interests lie in selling newer and more powerful PC's, emphasizes OS/2 and Presentation Manager. **********Mr. Cannavino sought to downplay the notion that the I.B.M.-Microsoft rift has become irreconcilable. "Our interests overlap in some areas, and they compete in some areas," he said. A Microsoft official at the show said only that the I.B.M.-Novell alliance "sounds like it will be good for OS/2," which Microsoft continues to develop. **********Rival computer makers said they were not particularly concerned by the I.B.M.-Novell alliance. "It's good for the industry," said a spokesman for the Compaq Computer Corporation of Houston, which itself has a strategic alliance with Novell. "If it widens the acceptance of Netware and network computing, it will help us sell more computers." **********The Digital Equipment Corporation, the second-largest computer maker after I.B.M., also announced its support for Novell's Netware at the show. **********Digital stopped short of selling Netware, however, and simply announced plans to have its own Pathworks network operating system, based on Microsoft's LAN Manager technology, coexist with Netware. Digital also announced a number of improvements to the Pathworks software. **********The I.B.M.-Novell alliance was not the only major news of the show.  Motorola introduced its wireless networking system and the Lotus Development Corporation, a Notes update. Both will be discussed next week. Compaq's Change of Heart **********One of the most significant announcements at the show had little to do with products. Compaq, which since its beginning in 1982 has referred all customer problems and complaints to its dealers, said that it would soon offer direct telephone support, through a toll-free line, that will providing answers to basic questions and product information. **********For complex computing problems that require expert answers, Compaq will offer, for $3,000, a contract for direct telephone technical support for business customers. **********Compaq's change of heart demonstrates the profound changes taking place in computer technology, the way personal computers are used in businesses and the way these computers are sold. Compaq also designated about 10 percent of its dealers as a special category that will specialize in issues relating to local area networking. **********"Frankly, these changes are necessary given how complex networking is getting," said Edward R. Anderson, president of the Computerland Corporation of Pleasanton, Calif., Compaq's largest dealer. **********Some personal computers, including Compaq's Systempro and its desktop machines based on Intel's i486 chip, are becoming more powerful and complex, rivaling minicomputers and even mainframes in power. Most dealers lack the expertise to support the systems they sell, and if such a system fails, the customer is often shunted from one company to another. Under the $3,000 contract, Compaq will now offer to fix as many as 10 major corporate computing problems, whenever they occur, even if the problem does not involve Compaq computers. **********"It's an important move," said Lee Levitt, an analyst with the International Data Corporation in Framingham, Mass. "Compaq is saying, 'Reach out and touch us.' "
