https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/25/world.main_headline: HONG KONG BUOYED BY AIRPORT ACCORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/25/world.print_headline: HONG KONG BUOYED BY AIRPORT ACCORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/25/world.body_text: **********After two bleak years in which it has lurched from one crisis to the next, exhaling confidence the way a punctured tire loses air, Hong Kong finally seems to be feeling good about itself again. **********A new agreement was reached at the beginning of this month between Britain and China about a new airport to be built here -- and more broadly about how the territory will be governed until the hand-over to China in 1997 -- and it has elicited an enormous sigh of relief. **********Spirits also rose today after the United States Senate vote Tuesday on trade benefits to China. Because Hong Kong depends a great deal on China for its economic livelihood, the vote, which makes likely the prospect of unconditional extension of the benefits, touched off even greater business optimism.  Stock Market at a High **********For two straight days now, the Hang Seng stock market index has hit a new high, closing today at 4,028.77, up nearly 19 points from Tuesday's record. Housing prices are also estimated to have risen at least 10 percent since the airport agreement was announced on July 4. And for the first time since the Army crackdown in Beijing two years ago, there seems to be a measure of hope in the air here. **********Hong Kong's confidence has been shaken not only by the political repression and ideological orthodoxy on the home turf of its future landlord, but also by the arrests of Hong Kong visitors on the mainland and a rising number of mainlanders sneaking into the territory and committing robberies. Emigrants continue to flee the territory at a pace of over 1,100 a week. **********Now, with major uncertainties removed, politicians, business executives and bureaucrats here are turning to the nuts and bolts of the airport and port project, which is expected to dominate the economy until 1997 and cost more than $16 billion.  Caution and Foreboding **********As with all bouts of optimism in Hong Kong in the last decade, however, this one is mixed with caution and a foreboding that China's verbal assaults may once again cloud the skies. **********The agreement provides that China will support the construction of the airport in Hong Kong and will honor Hong Kong's debts after 1997. In exchange, Britain agrees to consult Beijing on all matters relating to the airport that will have an impact after 1997. Academics and politicians say the document is a crucial annex to the original joint declaration in 1984, which provides the basis for the handover of power. Some say it could set a precedent for power-sharing on all matters straddling 1997. **********"China got what it wanted -- it got a formal acknowledgment of their role prior to 1997," said a diplomat in Hong Kong. The Chinese, he added, are believed to have suggested registering the memorandum as a treaty with the United Nations, as was the case with the 1984 Joint Declaration, but the British said no.  Risk of Imported Labor **********As companies enter the contract bidding in the next few months for certain parts of the airport project, the Government is suggesting that the construction activity will add more than a full percentage point to Hong Kong's economic growth estimates in the near future. Costs for the airport and rail and bridge links will be $12.7 billion and billions more for the port development. **********Although the political uncertainty may be removed for the moment, some economists and analysts say the endeavor will still stumble. For instance, a construction boom could be inflationary, unless the Government allows the import of labor. Another major risk that investors and bankers must consider is that all the connecting parts, such as the rail link, the suspension bridge and the airport, must be completed before any one can be used. **********For the moment, the general public is busy with Hong Kong's favorite pastime: making money. Last week, the first Government land sale since the memorandum brought a price that was more than double the one reached for a similar plot in the same area last November. And there are some indications that the small investor also wants to keep investing in Hong Kong.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/28/world.main_headline: Over Steep Turkish Passes, the Kurds Start Back to Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/28/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Over Steep Turkish Passes, the Kurds Start Back to Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/28/world.body_text: **********The movement of Kurdish refugees back to Iraq from their grisly camps in the mountains of southern Turkey appears to be starting in earnest. **********United States Army helicopters today flew 325 Kurdish men from Isikveren, one of Turkey's biggest and most desolate refugee centers, to help build the resettlement encampment of blue and white tents in the river valley outside Zakho, in northern Iraq. **********Special Forces officers running the airlift plan to bring in at least 250 more Kurds from other border encampments each day for the next three days, in an effort to build enthusiasm for the move among the refugees. **********There were about 6,000 volunteers for the pick-and-shovel jobs in the Zakho camp this morning, said Dayton Maxwell, the United States Agency for International Development's specialist in charge of disaster relief here.  Some Now Return Voluntarily **********Perhaps more significantly, in the nameless valleys and gorges scattered along the Iraqi side of the mountains, people were coming back on their own today, in groups of tens and twenties, building into the hundreds. They climbed over high passes and ridges from Turkey onto footpaths that turned into dirt tracks and finally, roads. **********The returning refugees had little to carry -- perhaps a blanket, a transistor radio, a few belongings bundled into a makeshift pack. Mostly they walked, but on some roads there were donkeys carrying bundles or refugees packed into a truck bumping down the road. **********The mass flight of Iraqi Kurds for the Turkish and Iranian frontiers began when Iraq's forces crushed a Kurdish rebellion last month in the aftermath of its defeat in the Persian Gulf war. The United Nations estimates there are 416,000 refugees at this border and farther within Turkey, while 200,000 to 400,000 are reported on the Iraqi side of the border. More than a million people have fled to Iran, the United Nations says; on Friday, it doubled its estimate of the daily death toll among the refugees, from 1,000 to 2,000. **********American military and aid officials hope that once movement of the Kurds and other refugees back to their homes in Iraq begins, it will become a mass flow, as their exodus was. **********About 200 families returned to their homes in Zakho last night, Mr. Maxwell said. That number would surely have swelled today. **********A major factor in the growing movement appeared to be the removal of several hundred armed Iraqis described as policemen, but widely believed to be soldiers or security agents. **********But on a number of roads, Kurdish guerrillas known as Pesh Merga (those who face death) kept some refugees back, saying the streets were still unsafe, in an apparent effort to assert their authority. A local commander said about 3,000 of the guerrillas have gathered on the outskirts of the zone protected by Western forces, where half a dozen refugee camps are planned. **********Mr. Maxwell, explaining the airlift of the Kurdish refugee workers, which has been worked out over the last week with traditional clan chiefs, said:  Momentum Needed **********"The important thing is to break the ice and get some momentum going. They are very anxious to come, and now that the flow has started, we will get supplies in place and start moving people through." **********At Zakho today, First Lieut. Joel Baker of the Marine Corps, whose combat engineering platoon hammered together the 1,000-tent camp at Zakho in a hurry, watched refugee families coming back to town along the main highway. They were packed into carts pulled by tractors. **********"The marines put up this place to give the Kurds their freedom," he said. "It makes you feel good to see how hard work can change people's lives." **********The roads on the Iraqi side showed the haste with which the refugees moved out, taking off in every vehicle that moved, including fire trucks, garbage trucks, buses, ambulances and taxicabs. **********High in a mountain valley, more than an hour's drive from the last visible population center at the village of Darkar, a group of 17 refugees paused to rest in the shade of a tree before passing two abandoned municipal fire trucks on their way back to Zakho. **********"I want to go home," said Hayam Haji, a 12-year-old girl. "Zakho is better to live in. I am not happy because Saddam is still in power. When Saddam is gone, I will be happy."  Taking Precautions **********A man going back to the town said: "I'm going back to Zakho to look at the house and see if everything is all right. If the Pesh Merga are in the town and everything is all right, I will go back." **********But the bright day, in which British marines and fresh paratroopers manned positions hard by the roadblocks of the Kurdish guerrillas, barely concealed the Mideast tribal blood feuds that could spell trouble for the coalition forces committed to keeping the peace here. **********"The situation is not stable now," said a guerrilla leader named Mohammed Shafik, at a roadblock only a few miles from the last roadblock set up this morning on the main highway by American and British marines. "Due to this instability, we will keep our weapons." **********"We have many reservations about Saddam Hussein," he said, referring to the agreement reportedly reached between the Iraqi President and some Kurdish leaders. "We have to be alert in our minds. We have had many bad experiences." **********At another roadblock, a guerrilla leader who gave his names as Abu Zira put the score-settling to come bluntly: "We don't want anybody who was appointed by Saddam Hussein. **********"I think the British, Americans and French will remain as long as it is in their interest," he said. "When it is not in their interest they will leave. And when the allied forces leave the place, the Pesh Merga will start fighting again."                    --------------------       EUROPEANS PRESS U.N. ROLE **********MONDORF-LES-BAINS, Luxembourg, April 27 (AP) -- Officials from France and Britain proposed today that the United Nations encourage hundreds of thousands of Iraqi Kurdish refugees to return home by assuring their safety. **********"The Kurds demand more security," France's Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, said after an informal meeting here of European Community foreign ministers. "The United Nations must be involved in returning the Kurds." **********Mr. Dumas proposed that the Security Council meet to examine conditions in Iraq. French officials said such a guarantee would force President Hussein to respect his accord in principle with Kurdish leaders. The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, suggested a United Nations police force to protect the Kurds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/22/world.main_headline: GENSCHER AT EYE OF POLICY DEBATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/22/world.print_headline: GENSCHER AT EYE OF POLICY DEBATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/22/world.body_text: **********In the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war, a far-reaching political debate has broken out here over how Germany should fulfill its global responsibilities in the years ahead. **********Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher is at the center of the debate. Polls show that Mr. Genscher is still held in high esteem by the German public, but he has been the target of stinging criticism from many political leaders, including some who supported him in the past. **********During the gulf crisis, Mr. Genscher was criticized for appearing reluctant to support the anti-Iraq coalition. More recently, he has been caught up in arguments over the possible use of German troops in future conflicts. **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl has publicly defended Mr. Genscher and reprimanded his critics. But the criticism has continued. Western Alignment Urged **********Hans Stercken, chairman of the parliamentary committee on foreign affairs and a senior member of Mr. Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, has been urging that Germany align its foreign policy more closely with other Western nations. **********"We can no longer go our own way in the world," Mr. Stercken said in a recent interview. **********Leaders of the Christian Democratic Union's Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union, have been even more outspoken. The party's general secretary, Erwin Huber, called last week for a "clear course correction" in German foreign policy. **********"Foreign Minister Genscher's prolonged speechlessness during the gulf crisis has seriously damaged our image in the world," Mr. Huber said. **********Hans Streibl, Premier of Bavaria and an important ally of Chancellor Kohl, has described Mr. Genscher as "minister of travel and television." Finance Minister Theo Waigel complained that in recent months Mr. Genscher "has not always been where he should have been." Accused of Quasi-Neutralism **********Mr. Genscher has been Foreign Minister since 1974, longer than any of his Western counterparts. At several points in his tenure, he has irritated officials in Washington and other allied capitals by appearing not to support Western initiatives fully. They accused him of a quasi-neutralism that came to be known as Genscherism. **********Fundamental to Genscherism was said to be the belief that Germany could play a role as a bridge between East and West without losing its status as a reliable NATO ally. Mr. Genscher is a strong advocate of negotiated settlements to international problems, and critics say he occasionally takes that credo too far. **********Last year, after the United Nations endorsed military action against Iraq, Mr. Genscher again provoked Western criticism by supporting several unsuccessful peace initiatives. **********In a speech last month in Switzerland, Mr. Genscher rejected charges that he had acted against the interests of the anti-Iraq alliance. He said he had always given the alliance "clear and unequivocal" support. **********"Germany is carrying more than its fair share of the burden for the establishment of a peaceful, peacefully evolving world," he said. Larger German Voice Urged **********Soon after delivering that speech, Mr. Genscher suggested that if foreign powers expect Germany to assume greater responsibility in the world, they should give it a chance to express its views "more strongly" in the United Nations Security Council. **********His comments were widely interpreted as a call for a German seat on the Security Council. Officials in France, which holds one of the five permanent Council seats, immediately rejected the idea. **********Germany did not send troops to join the anti-Iraq coalition because of a constitutional clause that severely limits the use of German military power abroad. In recent weeks, Mr. Kohl has been seeking to amend that clause, but he has had little success. **********The opposition Social Democrats voted on Monday to oppose the amendment proposed by Mr. Kohl, which would have allowed German troops to take part in multinational operations sanctioned by the United Nations. Mr. Genscher's party, the Free Democrats, took a similar stance. **********The positions taken by the Social Democrats and the Free Democrats mean that Mr. Kohl's proposed amendment is probably dead. Gulf Cost Issue Raised **********Washington's irritation with Germany may be rekindled by suggestions being made in Bonn that the Government renege on its pledge of $11 billion to help defray the costs of the gulf war. The Social Democrats have asserted that the United States is seeking contributions that far exceeded the actual cost of thewar. **********Finance Minister Waigel is to travel to Washington on Monday to discuss the matter with American officials. **********American officials have refrained from publicly criticizing Mr. Genscher or the Bonn Government. They still consider Germany a reliable ally, and according to public opinion polls in the United States, most Americans agree. **********"This generosity in the assessment of the Germans could be based on the fact that the war was won so quickly and with so few casualties," said a recent editorial in the Suddeutsche Zeitung. "If a single American unit had been wiped out in an Iraqi poison-gas attack, or if Saddam had fired a single poison-gas missile at Israel, the Germans would be in trouble in the United States for a long time. Kohl and Genscher are benefiting more from luck than from their own political skills."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/world.main_headline: Bush Is Leaning To Food Credits For the Soviets
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/world.print_headline: Bush Is Leaning To Food Credits For the Soviets
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/world.body_text: **********With the United States and the Soviet Union seeming to move toward another summit meeting, President Bush hailed the accomplishments of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today and indicated that he was inclined to find a way to satisfy the Soviet leader's request for emergency aid to buy American food. **********"When you look at the accomplishments of Mikhail Gorbachev, they are enormous," Mr. Bush said at a White House news conference, going out of his way to praise the Soviet leader. "And yes, the Soviet Union is fighting difficult economic times. But I am not about to forget history. And what he did in terms of Eastern Europe, what he's done in terms of perestroika and glasnost, has my respect." **********In Moscow, Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov said that if the West was truly interested in the success of economic reforms in the Soviet Union, it could not take a "wait and see" attitude toward providing aid.  [ Page A12. ] Ties Seems to Improve **********Developments in recent days suggest that Soviet-American relatons are improving again after a period of coolness that began when Eduard A. Shevardnadze resigned as Foreign Minister in December and Moscow cracked down violently against independence movements in the Baltic republics. **********An implicit deal seems to be in the making in which Mr. Gorbachev will satisfy American concerns about the conventional arms treaty, Mr. Bush will help him with more economic aid, and they will both agree to hold a summit meeting in June or July, when they will focus on the still uncompleted strategic arms reduction treaty. **********Mr. Bush, in a meeting today with Baltic leaders, was quoted by his visitors as speaking freely about his coming meeting with Mr. Gorbachev, although arrangements have not been completed. **********In addition, reports from Moscow indicate that Parliament this weekend may pass a law lifting legal barriers against travel abroad, something long demanded by the United States before remaining trade barriers can be removed. **********In discussing the Soviet request for additional credits to buy more American grain, Mr. Bush said, "I've always felt that when people are hungry or need support as it relates to food and nourishment that we ought to try to help." Still Undecided on Method **********But Mr. Bush quickly went on to say that he had still not decided how to respond to Mr. Gorbachev's appeal for the United States to guarantee up to $1.5 billion worth of commercial bank loans by the Soviets to purchase American grain -- largely because by law the Administration cannot extend more such guarantees unless the Soviets are deemed a credit-worthy borrower, which they no longer are by the international banking community. **********Administration officials said, however, that the President has asked his aides to look for alternative ways to extend food aid or technical assistance to the Soviets and that this was now being explored by a variety of departments. **********Mr. Bush's lavish praise for Mr. Gorbachev today, and his strong hint that he would provide some sort of economic help, were in marked contrast to his public position last week. He said then that "regrettably" the Soviets could not meet the requirements of credit-worthiness, and he left the impression that as a result no American help would be forthcoming. **********Since then, though, Mr. Shevardnadze met with Mr. Bush on Monday and appealed for help. And Mr. Gorbachev agreed Tuesday to send the Soviet Chief of Staff, Gen. Mikhail A. Moiseyev, to Washington next week to try to resolve the last disputes over the treaty limiting conventional forces in Europe. **********The Soviets have virtually used up all of the $1 billion in credit guarantees that Mr. Bush granted them through the Commodity Credit Corporation in December to buy grain to get them through the winter. With Washington guaranteeing the loans, the Soviets could not only get them from commercial banks, which would not normally lend them money, but also get a better interest rate. **********Mr. Gorbachev's reason for seeking more help and the Administration's inability to give it automatically have to do with several factors that have developed since December. **********First, the United States farm bill that went into effect in 1991 tightened up the conditions for agricultural credits by stipulating that the Secretary of Agriculture had to be able to affirm that a country receiving such benefits could service its debts. **********Second, with the Soviet foreign debt now $60 billion and rising, Moscow has become less able to repay many of its commercial lenders, and is now in arrears. **********Third, last fall, when the Soviet winter grain crop was being planted for harvesting this spring, its economy was experiencing widespread dislocations, with shortages of seed, fertilizer, tractors, fuel and workers prepared to do their jobs properly. Administration experts are predicting not only a poor Soviet harvest this spring, but also a poor spring planting, which will reduce the fall harvest needed to take the Soviets through next winter. **********The impulse to help Mr. Gorbachev is not simply motivated by his cooperative behavior in Eastern Europe and in the Persian Gulf, officials say, but also by the feeling in Washington that he is making a real push to complete the conventional and strategic arms control treaties, which the Administration is eager to lock in. **********Administration officials say they are also inclined to help Mr. Gorbachev because if they do not, there could be more serious upheavals in the Soviet Union this year, which could spill over into Eastern Europe. **********At the same time, extending new food credits to the Soviets is viewed by some in the Administration as the equivalent of giving drugs to an addict, since it is increasingly clear that the Soviet leader is either unable or unwilling to adopt the real free-market economic reforms that might one day make such credits unnecessary. **********Among the alternative approaches being considered would be for the President to extend bank loans or food aid under his discretion to meet humanitarian disasters, although this would require declaring a disaster in the Soviet Union, which would be complicated. **********Another option is to use the up to $300 million in credits that could be secured through the Export-Import Bank. A third option, already in the works, is to send a team from the Department of Agriculture this month to advise the Soviets on how to reorganize their farm distribution system. Another possibility is to make grain available on concessionary terms through Public Law 480. **********After his news conference, Mr. Bush met for 40 minutes in the Oval Office with President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania, Prime Minister Ivars Godmanis of Latvia and Prime Minister Edgar Savisaar of Estonia. This marked the sixth time he has met with Baltic leaders in the last year. **********Mr. Godmanis, speaking to reporters after the meeting with Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, said Mr. Baker had suggested that the Baltic republics try to establish their independence from Moscow in ways "which also save face for the Soviet Union."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/busin.main_headline: Launching by Soviets Succeeds, but Advertising Plan Fails
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Launching by Soviets Succeeds, but Advertising Plan Fails
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/busin.body_text: **********Britain and the Soviet Union are apparently better at outer space than at advertising space. **********A Soyuz TM-12 spacecraft launched on Friday from Soviet Central Asia carried into orbit two Soviet astronauts and Helen Sharman, a 27-year-old chemist and Britain's first astronaut. But the craft, which docked yesterday with the Soviet Union's Mir space station and is to return to earth next Sunday, did not carry the millions of dollars worth of Western advertisements that were originally planned to make the mission profitable for the Soviet Union. **********"Because of the economic and political situation in the Soviet Union, companies doubted the Russians could deliver," said Danny Rose, an account director at Saatchi & Saatchi Sports Events and Licensing, the British advertising agency that was retained to sell corporate sponsorships for the mission. "There was never any doubt that the Russians could put someone in space. But in terms of the commercial opportunities, that proved more difficult." **********When the space mission was announced in June 1989, Saatchi & Saatchi, the world's second-largest advertising company, after the WPP Group, was given responsibility for its marketing. **********Saatchi's experts on corporate identity gave the joint mission its name, Juno, after the Roman goddess of marriage. They designed a logotype of a flying goose. MSL International, a Saatchi subsidiary that specializes in recruitment advertising, took charge of finding the British astronaut, and placed newspaper ads headlined: "Astronaut wanted. No experience necessary." **********Another Saatchi subsidiary was sought to sell corporate sponsorships for the mission. The Moscow Narodny Bank, a Soviet-owned British bank that was organizing Juno, said it planned to sell $:16 million ($28 million) worth of sponsorships, in packages of $:1 million to $:2 million, that could include billboards at the launching site, ads on the side of the spaceship and patches on the British astronaut's uniform. **********But when Juno was launched on Friday, there were no ads at the Baikonur space center, on the Soyuz rocket or on Ms. Sharman's uniform. **********"The Soviet side had started off with an estimate they felt was achievable, but was not realistic," said Michael Parker, the chairman of Saatchi & Saatchi's worldwide business-to-business advertising network, who directed the Juno project for the agency. **********By December 1989, after getting in touch with more than 50 companies, the agency had managed to arrange only three sponsorships, including one from Memorex videotapes, at costs that started at $:500,000, a sum comparable to the price a company would pay to be the main sponsor of a world-class rugby or skiing event, Mr. Rose said. **********Late last year, when it had become clear that Juno would not come close to raising $:16 million, the Moscow Narodny Bank scuttled its plans for a commercially sponsored mission but said it would forge ahead without the ads, footing the bill itself. **********The sale of sponsorships was hindered by a dearth of information about the mission, Saatchi executives said. **********"It was very difficult working with the Russian authorities to really identify what would and wouldn't be possible," Mr. Rose said. "Would it be possible to take a pocket calculator on board? If I wanted to pitch a sponsorship to a communications company, would their equipment be compatible with the Mir's signals? I never had a 100 percent concrete book of benefits I could go to a sponsor with." Japanese Sponsorship **********The Soviet Union's only previous involvement with ads in space was last year, when the Tokyo Broadcasting System paid it an amount reported as $12 million to send a Japanese journalist into space. Several companies, including Sony and Minolta, bought sponsorships that included logotypes on the side of that rocket. **********Without Saatchi's help, Moscow Narodny Bank signed three sponsors for the Juno mission: Olympus cameras, the Poqet Computer Corporation and Interflora, a flower-delivery service. **********Joanna Dodd, a spokeswoman for the mission in London, said, "It has not been disclosed and never will be how much they paid." Nor did she know what the companies' contracts allowed them to do, although she said visible advertising was not included. **********But, she said, "Interflora is looking at having an order for flowers placed from space."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/world.main_headline: Salvadoran Assembly to Take Up Charter Changes
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/world.print_headline: Salvadoran Assembly to Take Up Charter Changes
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/world.body_text: **********Despite the delay in agreeing on a cease-fire in the decade-long civil war, the search for peace in El Salvador should advance slightly this week with the introduction into the Legislative Assembly of a package of proposed constitutional changes. **********Leaders of the main political parties are expected to return from Mexico City, where peace talks are being held, and introduce agreed-upon changes on Thursday affecting the role of the armed forces, the judicial system and expansion of the elections commission. A high-level Government official said that the Assembly would act on them before the session ends on Tuesday and that the Government and the guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front would probably resume negotiations next month over the cease-fire and the details of the armed forces' reorganization. **********Government officials and diplomats familiar with the United Nations-sponsored talks say that the two sides are much closer on substantive questions than it seems, but that the process was slowed when the Government rejected a guerrilla request to rewrite the rules by which the Constitution could be changed. In turn, the guerrillas took the cease-fire proposal off the table. **********On the touchiest point -- how to reform and reduce the size and power of the armed forces -- officials and politicians say there is agreement on almost every aspect except whether to allow the armed forces themselves to have a representative on the five-member commission to be created to purge undesirable officers. **********While the constitutional changes to be introduced include a general philosophical statement reducing the armed forces' vast overall influence, more specific military questions, including the makeup of the purge commission, will remain on the table for the continued Government-guerrilla talks. **********The guerrillas, in their regular radio broadcast this morning, accused President Alfredo Cristiani of having caved into pressures and threats from far-rightist elements in his own Arena party in rejecting the proposal of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front to revise the rules for amending the Constitution. **********But Ernesto Altschul, vice minister of the presidency, a post similar to deputy chief of staff for Mr. Cristiani, asserted that the guerrilla group had intended to take advantage of the proposed rule changes to open a "permanent political campaign" on any constitutional amendments it wanted to propose from the time it lays down arms until the next elections, in 1994. **********He explained that this would have been possible because the proposed revisions would have made it possible to change the Constitution with action in just one session of the Assembly, plus a referendum. Mr. Altschul said the guerrillas, who have no chance to win Assembly seats until 1994, had hoped to create a political platform for themselves in the meantime through the amendment mechanism. **********"The F.M.L.N. knows that if they can't find a way to campaign politically between 1991 and 1994 the votes they receive in 1994 will be minimal," he said. **********"So we resisted," he added. "We said we want a clear debate now over what should be changed in the Constitution." **********The present constitutional reform rules have no provisions for a referendum but require that the amendment be approved by two successive Legislative Assemblies. The next few days, however, represent an opportunity to get changes approved quickly because the current Assembly comes to an end on Tuesday and the new one, whose members were elected in March, will be seated the next day, May 1. **********This explains the hurry by political parties, including Arena and the opposition Christian Democrats, to introduce the changes on which they have agreed. It is not clear whether Democratic Convergence, the leftist coalition with ties to the guerrillas, will support the package. It had agreed in principle, but party leaders were subsequently angered when the Government rejected the proposal to rewrite the rules for constitutional changes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/15/busin.main_headline: Simon Concert to Test Time Warner Synergy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/15/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Simon Concert to Test Time Warner Synergy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/15/busin.body_text: **********Time Warner Inc., which is financing Paul Simon's concert in Central Park tonight, is betting that the event will pay off in numerous ways. **********In return for underwriting the concert the company, of course, will benefit from the publicity and public good will generated. But the concert is also an effort to use the widely touted "synergies" that the giant entertainment conglomerate described when Warner, the parent of Warner Records and Warner Brothers and cable television systems, merged in 1990 with Time Inc., which owned Home Box Office and cable systems in addition to its publishing empire. **********The biggest potential profit from the concert would be from a best-selling record album that might be released by Warner Records. Warner, though, can release a record only if Mr. Simon is satisfied with the concert's quality. **********There is a precedent for success, however. The album that Mr. Simon recorded with his former partner, Art Garfunkel, when they reunited for a Central Park concert nearly a decade ago, was a hit for Warner Records, selling more than four million copies.  Home Video a Possibility **********Time Warner's home-video company may also release a video of the concert, if Mr. Simon approves. And while home-video sales of such concerts are rarely best sellers, the fact that the Central Park event will already have appeared on HBO would be of intrinisic promotional value to sales of any resultant video or record. **********Beyond that, Warner International can also license replays of the concert overseas and already has an agreement to do so in Germany. **********After a Madison Square Garden concert on March 17, Mr. Simon came up with the idea of a free Central Park concert. He spoke to a public relations man, Dan Klores, who in turn called the city's Parks Commissioner, Betsy Gottbaum. Together with the concert producer, Ron Delsener, they went to see Mrs. Gottbaum, who detailed the city's requirements. **********To raise the necessary funds, Mr. Simon then spoke to Time Warner's chairman, Steven J. Ross. Mr. Ross put Mr. Simon's group together with other top company executives. It was after two executives went to a Simon concern and visited with Mr. Simon that discussions about Time Warner's role took shape. **********HBO gets the rights to carry the concert live. "The value that generates in terms of signing up new subscribers is incalculable," said one Time Warner executive. **********One record industry executive who declined to be named noted that for Time Warner the deal is a risk that depends on whether there is a record and how it sells. But he added that the investment, which he said appeared to be less than $3 million, was not large relative to the size of the company. Contribution to City Parks **********Time Warner's New York City Cable Group will make a contribution to the City Parks Foundation of $400,000, roughly half of which will cover the city's expenses related to the concert for security, sanitation and other costs. **********The cable group and HBO are financing the balance of the concert for about $750,000. That figure has risen by several hundred thousand in recent weeks as costs related to the concert have soared. **********HBO will be paying additional money for the right to carry the concert live and tape it for future replays. Although HBO did not disclose the amount, one executive involved in the overall deal said he believed it was about $1.2 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/05/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Centocor's Drug Is Ruled Safe
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/05/busin.body_text: **********An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration endorsed a drug produced by Centocor Inc. today to treat bacterial infections that kill tens of thousands of patients a year. **********The committee's finding that the drug is safe and effective appears to be a victory for Centocor in its battle with the Xoma Corporation. **********Centocor, based in Malvern, Pa., and Xoma, with headquarters in Berkeley, Calif., are trying to bring to market what could be the next big drug produced by biotechnology, with potential sales of hundreds of millions of dollars a year.  No Vote on Xoma Drug **********The committee discussed Xoma's drug but did not vote on it because the F.D.A.'s staff said it needed more time to analyze data on the drug's effectiveness, which it described today as inconclusive. **********"Centocor has won, and Xoma has lost," said Robert Kupor, a biotechnology analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company, who attended today's committee meeting in Rockville, Md. The panel's recommendation makes it very likely the F.D.A. will approve Centocor's drug, known as Centoxin, for sale within a few months, he said. **********But Dr. Patrick J. Scannon, Xoma's president, said the company was stunned by the panel's decision, adding that analysts were overreacting to its comment about the data on its drug. He said the F.D.A. merely needed more time to analyze test results. "I feel very strongly that once they see the complete analysis, things will move right along," Dr. Scannon said.  The Battle Turns Sour **********The immediate future of the small biotechnology companies rides on these drugs, and the fight has gotten nasty, involving lawsuits and scientific mudslinging. The stocks of both companies have fluctuated recently, as analysts have tried to guess which company would come out ahead. Centocor's stock surged $3 today, to $40.50, while Xoma's plunged $5, to $15.50. Both issues are traded over the counter, where Xoma was the second-most-active stock, with a volume of 6.6 million shares. **********Each company's drug aims to treat a sometimes fatal type of bacterial infection that occurs in hospital patients who undergo surgery or those who suffer from wounds or burns. The so-called gram negative bacteria release toxins into the blood that can cause septic shock, a condition in which the patient's temperature rises and body organs fail. **********The drugs are monoclonal antibodies, bioengineered versions of the proteins that the body uses to fight infections. The antibodies are designed to home in on the toxins in the blood and neutralize them. **********Physicians say that regardless of which company benefits from today's endorsement, the development of the drugs is a milestone. "It is of major potential significance," said Dr. Roger C. Bone, the chairman of the department of medicine at Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago. **********But the approval of the Centocor drug, which is expected to sell for more than $3,000 a treatment, is also likely to pose questions for doctors and for a health-care system struggling to control rising costs. **********That is because the studies to date show that Centoxin can reduce the death rate in a small segment of the patients treated, but it is hard to identify those patients in advance. **********"You have a problem in overuse of a potentially very expensive medication," said Dr. Bone. **********Indeed, the F.D.A. panel, the Vaccines and Related Biological Products Advisory Committee, made up of medical experts from universities and hospitals, seemed to think that Centoxin's label should include certain restrictions to be determined by the F.D.A. on its use, said Teena Lerner, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York. **********"I'd classify it as a kind of muted victory," Ms. Lerner said, adding that "it wasn't a ringing endorsement" of Centoxin.  A Critical Problem **********The primary problem, Dr. Bone said, is that there are 500,000 to 600,000 cases of sepsis, a condition of high fever and organ misfunction that could be caused by infection. But only about 200,000 of the cases are caused by gram negative bacteria, and not all of those cases involve bacteria in the blood, the condition for which Centocor's drug is useful, he said. **********Yet because the infections can be so dangerous, doctors may use the drug on any patient suspected of having such an infection. That would result in overuse, Dr. Bone said. But waiting one to three days for test results to see if the infection is caused by gram negative bacteria would be risky. **********Most analysts had favored Centocor's drug over Xoma's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/04/busin.body_text: **********Spending on new construction projects rose eight-tenths of a percent in April from March, the largest gain in 14 months, the Commerce Department said today. **********Analysts said the strong rise was a sign that some parts of the building industry might be climbing out of the economic doldrums. **********The spending rise -- to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $392.6 billion -- followed a revised 2.1 percent drop in March. April's rise was the strongest gain since March 1990, when spending went up by 2.2 percent. **********The improvement was concentrated, however, coming in nonresidential building like industrial plants, offices and commercial projects. Residential construction spending was down in the month, as were taxpayer-financed projects like road building. Mixed Signs **********"I don't know whether we can take this as a sign that we've turned the corner on nonresidential spending," said Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI/McGraw Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass., "but it's consistent with the view that things cannot get a whole lot worse in that sector." **********The building industry led the economy into recession last year and has slumped to severely depressed levels. For instance, while April's spending gain was a clear improvement over recent months, it still reflected a 12 percent decrease from a year earlier, when construction spending was at a $444.7 billion rate. **********But housing starts improved in April, as did sales of new and existing homes. Accordingly, a pickup in spending for single-family home projects is anticipated later this year. **********The April rise in housing starts was one of a series of recent indications that have bolstered hopes for a summer recovery from the recession. On Friday, the Government said its main forecasting gauge for the future of the economy rose in April for a third straight month, and the nation's purchasing managers today reported an improvement in orders during May. **********The construction spending report showed that outlays for single-family building rose to a yearly rate of $86.3 billion in April from $85.3 billion in March. But spending on apartments was down to $14.4 billion from $16.4 billion. **********Nonresidential spending was up by 4.4 percent, to a rate of $95.7 billion, the biggest gain in more than two years, since a 5.1 percent rise in December 1988, according to Commerce Department officials. **********Within that category, spending on industrial projects rose to a $21.3 billion annual rate, from $20.2 billion in March, while office construction spending rose slightly, to $22.8 billion in April from $22.4 billion. **********Dave Seiders, senior economist with the National Association of Home Builders, cautioned that high vacancy rates in office buildings built in the 1980's would prevent any major expansion soon in office building.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/05/busin.main_headline: Talking Deals; Reverse Buyouts Losing Appeal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/05/busin.print_headline: Talking Deals; Reverse Buyouts Losing Appeal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/05/busin.body_text: **********THE market for initial stock offerings by debt-laden private companies appears to have taken a downward turn, leaving some investors and bankers openly wondering whether the opportunity for wild success in those deals has passed. **********In such offerings, known as reverse leveraged buyouts, a company taken private returns to the public markets, allowing investors to buy a piece of the restructured company and its owners to profit handsomely. Reverse buyouts have been among the most profitable deals on Wall Street in the last year, with the total dollar volume of offerings rising to $4.6 billion so far this year, from $583.3 million last year, according to IDD Information Services. **********So the first signs of wariness for these deals is attracting a lot of attention. Wall Street's growing angst is focused largely on the troubles in the Nov. 22 initial public offering of Stop & Shop Holdings Inc., a company taken private in 1988 by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. **********Initial offerings earlier this year of companies owned by Kohlberg, Kravis, the New York buyout firm, have proved to be some of the year's best deals for investors and the companies, too. For example, Duracell International, which came to market in May, performed like many reverse leveraged buyouts brought to market this year: The new shares came to market, and soared in price in the first day of trading. That kind of performance persuaded numerous debt-laden companies that the time had come to go public, and they rushed to market. **********But the performance of Stop & Shop underscored a growing queasiness among investors. While the 17 million shares in the company had been expected to be priced at at least $14 according to the initial filings, they were actually priced at $12.50 a share. They closed at that price on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. **********The impact of the disappointment with Stop & Shop have been quick. Reverse leveraged buyouts "will probably keep getting done, but they aren't all going to be slam-dunks anymore," one investment banker said yesterday. Another market professional added, "The window is closing on the effusive buying attitude" for initial public offerings of highly leveraged companies. **********Already, Wall Street has begun adjusting its plans. Of the four planned reverse leveraged buyouts that had filed registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission, three -- Almac's Supermarkets, Multi Local Media Information and Unifax -- have postponed their offerings, according to IDD. The one going ahead is Owens-Illinois Inc., another company owned by Kohlberg, Kravis; it is scheduled to be offered this week in a deal underwritten by Morgan Stanley & Company. **********Several Wall Street executives said the troubles with the reverse leveraged buyout offerings were largely a result of the troubled conditions in the market. The 120-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average shocked investors, making new offerings less enticing and pushing money managers to the sidelines. "The economy, coupled with the pragmatism of year-end portfolio tidying-up, as well as a 120-point drop in the Dow, says, 'Hey, we are taking a breather for while,' " said Michael D. Madden, co-head of investment banking at Lehman Brothers. **********The track record of the reverse leveraged buyouts that have come to market in the last year indicates that investors were growing wary before the Dow plunged. On Nov. 14, the day before the drop, fully 37.5 percent of the companies that issued shares this year in reverse leveraged buyouts had seen the value of their stock drop -- sometimes as much as 50 percent. **********But since the market drop and the decline of consumer confidence, the number of companies doing reverse leveraged buyouts this year that saw their stocks drop increased only slightly, by 1.7 percent, to 39.2 percent of all reverse leveraged buyouts this year. **********And the companies that declined included some that had been considered sure investments. Ann Taylor Stores, which went public earlier this year with great success, only to be followed by turmoil at the company, dropped by more than 32 percent in value from the first day of trading until the day before the market plunge, falling from $26.875, to $18.25. That decline has grown only worse since then, with the stock closing at $13.25 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. **********The meaning? With shares in more than one-third of the reverse leveraged buyouts having suffered losses in their first months of trading, Wall Streeters say, a conservatism is creeping into the marketplace that makes a repeat of the huge successes of earlier this year unlikely. **********But, with corporations weighed down by the debt taken on in the 1980's, few expect a less-enthusiastic market to hold back reverse leveraged buyouts for long. **********"There is a strong desire out there among corporate decision makers to de-leverage," said Tom Davis, the head of equity transactions at Merrill Lynch & Company. "It's a secular trend that will be with us for the next few years."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/14/busin.main_headline: U.S. Nearer Farm Accord With Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/14/busin.print_headline: U.S. Nearer Farm Accord With Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/14/busin.body_text: **********American and European Community officials said today that they were approaching a compromise on reducing subsidies to farmers -- a major stumbling block in global trade talks -- but that some obstacles remained. **********Negotiations picked up steam after President Bush met with European Community leaders last weekend, the officials said, and both sides have adopted more conciliatory positions. A breakthrough might allow for a conclusion later this year of the 108-nation round of trade talks covering a broad range of issues. **********After meeting in Rome Tuesday with the United States Secretary of Agriculture, Edward R. Madigan, the community's Commissioner of Agriculture, Ray MacSharry of Ireland, said today, "We are hearing more realistic numbers than we've heard in a long time."  Still Difficult Positions **********In a telephone interview, Julius Katz, the deputy United States trade representative, said, "I think it could come to an agreement quickly, but there are some difficult positions that still have to be reconciled." **********European and American officials said Washington had initially proposed a cut of 35 percent over five years on export subsidies and 30 percent over five years on internal supports and barriers to market access. This was a far more conciliatory position than the 90 percent cut over 10 years that Washington had been calling for. **********Mr. Katz said the community countered by proposing a 35 percent cut in the three areas over six years -- and that became the focus for last weekend's negotiations. Previously, the community had said the most it would cut was 30 percent over 10 years. **********"Thirty-five percent over six years, that was definitely talked about," Mr. Katz said. **********He said that Washington also wanted to make sure there was a review and new negotiations to cut subsidies further after the five- or six-year period elapsed. **********Although the gap between the two sides on export subsidies sounds small, the negotiators said there were snags over two issues: the base period of the cuts and whether the reductions should be in budgetary terms or volume terms. **********The Europeans have long wanted to begin counting the cuts from 1986, so they would include subsidy cuts that the community undertook that year. The Americans want the base period to begin when the accord is reached. **********American officials assert that the reductions should be in volume terms, rather than in budgetary terms, to insure a reduction in the amount of heavily subsidized community exports flooding world markets. **********"You may say there was a breakthrough in that we finally started a negotiation after five years," Mr. Katz said. "But you can't do it all in one morning." **********European officials insist that agriculture is just one part of the negotiations, and they assert that they will reach an agreement on agriculture only as part of a global package. The trade talks, which began in Uruguay five years ago and are known as the Uruguay Round, also involve setting rules for trade in textiles, intellectual property and services like banking and insurance. The talks are being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that oversees trade.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/16/world.body_text: **********The Philippine Government ordered the evacuation of hundreds of thousands of people tonight after scientists warned that a volcano erupting north of here appeared close to a catastrophic explosion. **********Earthquakes associated with the eruption of Mount Pinatubo were felt in Manila, 55 miles away, and volcanic ash blanketed the capital, forcing its international and domestic airports to close because of limited visibility and concern that jet engines would be damaged by the ash. **********Rains from a tropical storm turned the ash to mud, and its weight collapsed the roofs of two bus terminals and several schools and houses. At least 10 people were reported killed. The mud slowed the evacuation, and some routes were reported blocked altogether when the tropical storm caused ash-choked streams to overflow.  Darkness Before Sunset **********In addition to the ash, the volcano hailed inch-thick rocks over hundreds of square miles. In Manila, darkness set in several hours before sunset. **********Volcano scientists urged the evacuation of people living within 25 miles of Mount Pinatubo after satellite photos released tonight showed that a 1.8-mile crack had developed between two craters along the volcano's southern side. The scientists warned that the buildup of pressure within the mountain could be enough to blow it apart, a phenomenon that happened most recently at Mount St. Helens in Washington state in 1980. **********The Mount St. Helens blast killed more than 50 people, but it was in a sparsely populated area. By contrast, more than half a million people live within 25 miles of Mount Pinatubo.  'Everything Would Be Destroyed' **********The Philippine Institute for Volcanology and Seismology said the fissure appeared to be a precursor of an "avalanche" of molten rock and ash. **********"The possibility of this avalanche is very, very high," said Glenda Besana, a geologist with the institute. "Everything would be destroyed in its path -- trees, houses, everything." **********The largest of the cities affected by the evacuation order was Angeles, a city of 300,000. Reports from the area spoke of a huge traffic jam as those not already frightened away by the volcano, 15 miles distant, packed their belongings and fled. **********The last 900 Americans guarding Clark Air Base, one of the largest American military installations outside the United States, were evacuated earlier in the day. The base is adjacent to Angeles and slightly closer to the volcano than the city. The Pentagon said earlier in the week that 3,300 tons of munitions were stored at the now-unguarded base, but that the eruption posed little danger to the weapons. Officials have refused to say whether nuclear weapons are stored at Clark. **********Also affected by the evacuation order were the cities of San Fernando and Olongapo, which are on the edge of the 25-mile zone. Olongapo, the larger of the two cities, has a population of 200,000. **********Officials at the United States Navy base at Subic Bay, next to Olongapo, announced no evacuation plans. Since the eruption began last Sunday, the naval base has been plagued by electricity and water shortages caused by volcanic ash that settled in the machinery of local utility systems. **********On Monday, nearly 14,000 of the 16,000 Americans living or working at Clark were evacuated south to Subic Bay, which is itself home to about 16,000 Americans. **********In a tacit admission that Clark would not be able to resume normal operations for months, if not years, the United States Embassy in Manila announced today that thousands of the evacuees would be sent home to the United States.  Dozens Reported Trapped **********"Continuing volcanic activity, uncertainty over how long the danger will last and severe overcrowding at Subic naval base combined to necessitate the removal, which will take place over the next few weeks," the embassy said in a statement. **********The biggest single loss of life from the eruption was reported from Angeles, where the roof of a bus terminal in the city collapsed under the weight of rain, ash and falling mud. An Angeles hospital reported that two people were killed, but radio reporters said that only 12 of about 100 people believed to have been in the terminal had been pulled from the rubble. The station appealed to disaster officials to send medical crews and acetylene torches to free trapped victims. **********About 85,000 Americans and Filipinos have fled their homes in the central Philippines since Mount Pinatubo returned to life last weekend, more than six centuries after its last major eruption. **********Most of the Americans evacuees have sought shelter in overcrowded housing compounds at the Subic Bay naval base. **********But military officials say that with Subic itself under siege from the volcano, the former residents of Clark will have to be moved out of the Philippines as quickly as possible. **********"Our resources are stretched to the limit," said an American official in Manila. "We've got to start moving these people out of the country and get them back home. We don't have room for them. God knows when we'll get back Clark in operation again.' **********The American lease on the Clark and Subic bases expires in September, and American officials have said that the volcano will clearly have an impact on the final rounds of negotiations with the Philippine Government over a renewal of the lease.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/10/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; 2 G.M. Divisions Expand Incentives
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/10/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation's Pontiac and Chevrolet divisions revised their incentive programs to add rebates on certain 1991 models. The Pontiac program includes rebates of $1,500 on the Bonneville, $1,000 on the Firebird and Grand Prix and $750 on the Trans Sport. **********The Chevrolet incentives range from $300 to $1,500 and affect the Geo, Cavalier, Camaro, Corsica, Beretta, Lumina and Caprice. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Sallie Mae Prices $650 Million Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.body_text: **********The Student Loan Marketing Association has priced $650 million in short-term floating-rate notes through various securities dealers. **********Sallie Mae, which generally prices these types of securities on a monthly basis, priced yesterday's issue at 100 to yield 27.5 basis points more than the bond-equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill auction rate. **********Interest on the notes is adjusted weekly the day after each Treasury bill auction and is payable monthly. **********The organization, a major financial intermediary serving the education credit market through the purchase of student loans from lenders, said the notes were being sold in denominations of $1,000 and $1,000 increments above that amount.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/25/busin.main_headline: The Energizer Bunny Is Jumping Into Print
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/25/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; The Energizer Bunny Is Jumping Into Print
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/25/busin.body_text: **********E.B., the Energizer battery bunny, is about to cross over into print, in a completely different form. **********For the last two years, the pink rabbit has been seen in award-winning commercials created by Chiat/Day/ Mojo Inc. that parody other commercials for products like soap and coffee. The device is meant to illustrate that the Eveready Battery Company's Energizer brand is so powerful, E.B. is "still going," escaping from Energizer's spots into other companies'. **********But the new print campaign, to run in magazines including Child, Newsweek and Parenting, does not parody print advertisements. Instead, E.B. is seen "still going" in photographs shot at famous sites like Utah's Monument Valley. **********The print campaign is also a parody, said Harriet Blickenstaff, a spokeswoman for the Ralston Purina Company in St. Louis, Eveready's parent, spoofing "the genre of travel postcards." The campaign, she added, is intended to reach the many battery buyers who are not heavy television viewers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/11/world.main_headline: Salvador Talks Fall Short of Goal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/11/world.print_headline: Salvador Talks Fall Short of Goal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/11/world.body_text: **********Salvadoran Government and rebel negotiators concluded their talks here tonight with considerably less progress than they had set out to make but with some hope of still achieving peace by the year's end. **********In a last attempt to push the two sides to a treaty before his tenure expires on Dec. 31, the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, called them to New York for a new round of meetings on Monday. **********The negotiators said their failure to resolve fundamental issues in Mexico had put the talks at a crossroads. **********"I give it 10 days either to work or to break down," said Col. Mauricio Ernesto Vargas, Salvador's chief military's representative at the talks. **********The two sides agreed weeks ago that they would move their discussions to New York when they reached the brink of an accord that would end the 12-year-old civil war. But instead, representatives of the rightist Government and the leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front will still have to resolve issues that go to the heart of their conflict. **********Under pressure from guerrilla combatants and field commanders, representatives of the rebel front, known by its Spanish initials as the F.M.L.N., are still seeking to insure that its members play an important role in a new civilian police force. Without such a role, they say, both a treaty and their own security will remain in jeopardy. **********The Government, and particularly its armed forces, say they will never accede to what they characterize as the rebels' demand for a quota of representation. And while rebel officials insist that they are not asking to join the police in specific numbers, some diplomats say, their positions echo old demands to give up their arms only if they are allowed to join the military in bearing others in a new El Salvador. **********In telephone interviews from San Miguel de Allende, the colonial town in central Mexico where they have been meeting for the past two weeks, the negotiators and diplomats close to the process said several other basic issues had also resisted solution. Among those are how much land will be distributed to peasants and supporters of the rebels, how the Government will cut the size of its armed forces and what freedom the rebels will have to organize politically after peace is achieved.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/21/busin.main_headline: Dow Up 20.12, to 2,934.48, in Busy Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/21/busin.print_headline: Dow Up 20.12, to 2,934.48, in Busy Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/21/busin.body_text: **********Stocks closed broadly higher yesterday in the heaviest trading in nearly a year, as investors took the Federal Reserve's rate cut as a signal that it was serious about jolting the economy to life. The Dow Jones industrial average advanced to 2,934.48, up 20.12 points for the day and the week. **********Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 318.4 million, barely eclipsed by the 318.9 million shares traded on Jan. 17, the day after the Persian Gulf war started. There were nearly twice as many advancing issues as losing ones on the Big Board: 1,138 to 618. **********Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president and head of stock index futures trading at Shearson Lehman Brothers, said yesterday's market was a little more than technical. It was not only influenced by the "triple witching" -- the expiration of options on individual stock, index and futures contracts during the last hour of trading, but also by the Fed's cut in the discount rate, he said, adding, "And it was difficult to figure which played the more important role." **********The New York composite was up 2.22, to 213.13, and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 4.52, to 387.04. On the American Stock Exchange, the composite rose 0.62, to 367.22. **********Trading on the Nasdaq was also active and moved the composite up 1.23, to 535.76, while the Russell 2,000, an indicator of smaller issues, slipped 0.13, to 176.07. **********Traders said buying was seen across most of the market, particularly in issues influenced by interest rates. **********Wall Street stocks surged at the opening on news that the Fed had lowered the discount rate by one percentage point, to 3 1/2 percent. **********Some analysts doubted that the rally could be sustained, citing the triple witching, which normally adds volatility to trading, and year-end selling by investors for tax purposes. In addition, they said the cut in the rate, the largest since 1981, would increase concern over the economy. **********With the discount rate now at its lowest level since 1964, stocks eased off session highs but remained firm through the day, as a strong bond market added support. **********The rate cut "clearly indicated that the Federal Reserve is deeply concerned about the failure of the economy to make a recovery," said Hugh A. Johnson, a senior vice president of the First Albany Corporation. **********Elsewhere in the market, Nicolet Instrument said it expected its stock price to recover after investors assess the company's statement that its fiscal 1992 year-end earnings will not reach the previously expected record levels. Trading was halted yesterday at 1:58 P.M. for about a half-hour on order imbalances, meaning that there was an excess of buy or sell orders that was almost impossible to match with its opposite. The stock closed down 4 3/8, at 11 7/8. **********Traders said Scimed Life Systems, which makes coronary angioplasty catheters, rose 5 3/8, to 73 1/2, after it reported better-than-expected results for the third quarter. Scimed said that excluding a $28 million charge from the settlement of patent litigation with Eli Lilly, the company's operating profits had more than doubled. **********A number of analysts raised their ratings and earnings estimates for the company yesterday. **********Lockheed fell 1 3/8, to 43 5/8, as Steven Binder, an analyst at Bear, Stearns, cut its rating to "avoid," from "hold," traders said. **********In other activity, Amgen and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation both gained, as they will both soon be added to the S.& P. 500 index.  Amgen rose 2 to close at 60 1/4, and Freddie Mac gained 4 1/8, to 108 3/8.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/06/busin.main_headline: Tartikoff's TV Valedictory: It's Tougher Now Than Ever
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/06/busin.print_headline: Tartikoff's TV Valedictory: It's Tougher Now Than Ever
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/06/busin.body_text: **********NBC was still the No. 1 network last week when the chief architect of its six years of prime-time leadership, Brandon Tartikoff, announced that he was leaving network television to run a movie studio. **********Eleven years earlier, when Mr. Tartikoff began running the NBC entertainment division, the network was in a shambles -- a distant, hopeless third in the ratings, the joke of the television industry. **********The punchline is that NBC's ratings in the 1979-80 television season were 40 percent higher than what the network scored when it won the ratings race this season. **********No television executive has ever enjoyed the reputation that Mr. Tartikoff fashioned for himself in pulling NBC out of the ratings cellar in the early 1980's -- and none is likely to have it ever again, several industry executives said after Mr. Tartikoff's appointment as the new chairman of Paramount Pictures. **********Although that lofty assessment of Mr. Tartikoff's abilities is widely held in Hollywood, NBC has seen its ratings plunge in the last two seasons even as Mr. Tartikoff was continuing to choose the programs. "Brandon is a brilliant guy," said one senior NBC executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, "but we've been going down the past two years with the same guy flying the plane." **********Still, the television business -- especially the power and position of the broadcast networks -- has so fundamentally changed that most executives believe no network programmer can ever again have as much long-term impact as Mr. Tartikoff had. Indeed, although Mr. Tartikoff said last week that "someone with vision could still have impact," he added that "they would have to have the resources and support I got." **********When Mr. Tartikoff took charge of NBC's programming in January 1980, the only limits on his prospects were his own creative abilities. **********Now, Mr. Tartikoff said, the job is defined by its limits. These include limited ratings expectations because of all the new channels competing for viewers; limited margin for error because of the diminished network reach; limited patience from new corporate managers with no broadcasting background, and limited profits, leading to limited budgets. No Longer a Shock **********"Think about this," Mr. Tartikoff said in a telephone interview from his NBC office in Burbank, Calif. "In my first year as president of entertainment, NBC had only $48 million in profits. That was considered shocking, that a network could be that close to breaking even. Now it is commonplace to think that two networks could get through a year and not make any money." **********Indeed, CBS lost money last year and expects to post a loss for the current television year. **********The changes have mainly to do with two factors, Mr. Tartikoff said: the "power shift" away from the networks and the overall economics of the business. **********The television landscape has been reconfigured in the last decade, he said. "In 1980, cable had not hit criticial mass; neither had VCR's. There was no Fox network." **********The last decade saw the emergence of cable stations like the ESPN sports channel and Turner Network Television as the percentage of households with cable television roughly tripled to about 60 percent. In addition, syndicated programs proliferated on independent broadcast stations.  'Last Colossus of Programming' **********Even in the less-crowded television arena of 1980, Mr. Tartikoff was not an overnight success. **********"Tartikoff was the last colossus of programming," a senior industry executive said. "That's gone forever. There's no patience left in the business. Brandon had two and a half rough years. Nobody could afford to be that patient with a program executive now." **********Indeed, NBC's slide in the ratings grew so steep between Mr. Tartikoff's first season and 1983 that managers for NBC's affiliated stations pressed for him to be discharged. But Grant Tinker, then NBC's chairman, had complete faith in Mr. Tartikoff's talent and complete patience with the difficult situation he was then facing. Mr. Tinker shrugged off the complaints of the affiliates. **********Mr. Tartikoff said, "I had Grant Tinker supporting me and Fred Silverman teaching me." Mr. Silverman had been the original giant of network programming, having pushed first CBS and then ABC to the top of the ratings before he became corporate president of NBC. **********But that quality of talent is not evident at the networks today. Instead, Mr. Tartikoff said, "The networks have all these numbers-crunchers considering how to save money by cutting back on the network service in prime time." He added, "That was unheard of 10 years ago." **********So was putting on programs purely because they are cheap to produce, as the networks do now with the spate of so-called reality shows moving into prime time. "Does the world really need 'True Detective' and 'American Detective' in the same season?" Mr. Tartikoff asked. **********With programs now costing so much more to produce, some formats are all but closed to programmers, he said. **********"Nobody makes 'The A-Team' anymore," Mr. Tartikoff said. "Nobody makes action-adventure anymore because it costs too much and it doesn't sell in syndication. Producers don't want to do an hour show for you anymore. The diversity is not what it used to be." Best Writers and Producers **********Mr. Tartikoff revived NBC's fortunes in the 1980's by recruiting the best writing and producing talent, and giving them good time periods and plenty of time to make a program work. **********"That strategy is commonplace now, too," Mr. Tartikoff said. And it has helped drive the costs up. The best writer-producers -- like Steven Bochco ("Hill Street Blues," "L.A. Law") and James Brooks ("The Simpsons") -- now make long-term expensive deals, which include commitments for shows to get on the air. **********"People get commitments for three or five series on the air," Mr. Tartikoff said. He noted that Linda Bloodworth, the writer of "Designing Women," received five commitments from CBS. **********"She's good, but that means she's crowding out somebody else," he said. "Maybe she's going to crowd out the next Steven Bochco from getting an opportunity on your schedule. ABC has made a lot of these commitments. They are almost in the position we found ourselves in at NBC when we had all this heavy-hitting talent lined up. You start locking yourself in, and then you start cutting loose other talented people." New Economic Realities **********Later this month, Mr. Tartikoff will give a speech that lays out his strategy for dealing with the new economic realities facing television programmers. "We can't keep doing business the way we did 10 years ago," he said. "Instead of letting the corporate bean-counters come up with ideas like cutting the budget for developing series by 20 percent, we have to start asking ourselves if we can do the same programming job with 10 people instead of 30." **********Mr. Tartikoff said he would have moved NBC in that direction if he had stayed. Last year, he said he hoped that before he left the network, he would have restored NBC to dominance in the 1990's as he had in the 1980's, retiring "undefeated." **********"I guess I'm not quite going out like Sandy Koufax," he said last week. "This is more like Koufax going out with a 15-14 season."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/16/busin.body_text: **********I.B.M. came out with some grim earnings numbers yesterday, but after the company indicated that the worst might finally be over, its stock price rose sharply, buoying the whole stock market. **********The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest computer maker, said its third-quarter earnings fell 84.5 percent, on a 5.6 percent revenue decline, but it also said it had made progress in reducing its work force and bringing several important product lines to market. **********Central to its positive outlook is success in cutting costs. I.B.M. has been struggling for years to reduce its costs significantly and yesterday's report showed that its sales, general and administrative costs declined for the first time in almost 20 years.  Cuts in the Payroll **********These expenses were down 1 percent after discounting for the effect of a special $100 million charge to cover the additional costs that arose when more employees than were expected took incentives to leave the company. The company told analysts that research and development expenses also declined by about 1 percent last quarter. **********The stock market liked the company's assessment. After an initial decline of $2.125, I.B.M.'s stock recovered strongly, ending with a $3 gain, to $104.25. It was the fourth-most-active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, with more than three million shares changing hands. The Dow Jones industrial average followed the leader, rising 21.92, to 3,041.37.  [ Page D10. ] **********"The year-to-year numbers were ugly, but under the surface it was a pretty good report," said Stephen Cohen, a computer industry analyst at the Soundview Financial Group. "Expenses were under excellent control." Trouble Is Industrywide **********Steven Milunovich, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, added, "Any technology company earnings report that is not a disaster is pretty much good news these days." **********I.B.M. has been trying to alter its business model in recent years to survive in a more competitive industry by slashing staff through a series of voluntary inducements. The company's work force has now declined by about 50,000 since it peaked at 406,000 in 1985. Yesterday the company said it expected to reduce the head count by about 20,000 this year, almost 3,000 more than it had previously stated. **********"Although business conditions remain unsettled, we expect improvement in the pace of our business as shipments of our new product line build," I.B.M.'s chairman, John F. Akers, said in a statement. **********For the quarter ended Sept. 30, the Armonk, N.Y., computer maker's revenue was $14.43 billion, down from $15.28 billion. Earnings were $172 million, or 30 cents a share, compared with $1.11 billion, or $1.95, in the 1990 period. **********A number of analysts said they still saw signs for concern based on continued pressures from price competition and the recession. **********Rick Martin of Prudential Securities said he was cutting his estimate for the fourth quarter based on an unexpected decline in gross margins on equipment. He said he estimated that gross margins were probably no better than 47 or 47.5 percent for the quarter compared with an expected 55 percent.
