He said he spoke to the company yesterday and was told that I.B.M. expects margins to only partly return at the end of the year. 'A Nasty Situation' **********"It's really a nasty situation," he said. "I think that Wall Street earnings estimates are going to trail off during the quarter." **********He said he attributed the margin decline to pricing pressures, underuse of capacity during the recession and the effect of product introductions, which slow initial sales. **********The company appears to be making a strong transition to its new line of mainframes, several analysts said. I.B.M. began shipping its new family of top-of-the-line processors last month, and its strength in the fourth quarter is largely dependent on the success of the new machines. But a number of questions remain on price issues analysts said. If the company is forced to offer deep discounts to sell its new machines, which are for the largest corporations, it will subtract significantly from fourth-quarter earnings. **********"The big question is price," Mr. Milunovich said. Aggressive Offerings **********Separately, I.B.M. told analysts in a telephone conference call that it believed its market share in the personal computer market would hold for the year, after a decline in the first half. Several analysts said that the company would show a number of aggressive desktop offerings shortly and that it expected its new machines to make up ground that it had lost recently to clone companies like Dell Computer and Zeos. **********During the morning conference call the company said United States sales continued to decline during the quarter, but that the decline was slower than the previous quarter. As a result the company said that the economy might have bottomed out and that it expected an improving economy in the fourth quarter. **********I.B.M. also said sales of mainframes, computer storage devices and low-end personal computers had declined so far this year on a year-to-year basis, while its AS-400 minicomputer and RS/6000 work station lines had shown increases. **********The company also said its European business declined compared with the second quarter of 1991.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/world.main_headline: JORDANIANS AGREE TO JOIN IN TALKS ON MIDEAST PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/world.print_headline: JORDANIANS AGREE TO JOIN IN TALKS ON MIDEAST PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/world.body_text: **********Jordan joined Syria, Lebanon, Egypt and Saudi Arabia today in agreeing to attend a regional peace conference proposed by the United States. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, however, told the visiting American Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, that he wanted more time to consider the matter. **********King Hussein said, "We are ready to attend a peace conference, and we are very happy indeed it is going to be a comprehensive one." The Jordanian ruler spoke at a news conference with Mr. Baker after their talks in Amman, Jordan's capital. **********Until now, Jordan has wavered on accepting the American proposal, waiting to see if Syria would.  5 Acceptances in His Pocket **********Mr. Baker, armed with commitments from the five Arab countries to take part in a conference that would open the way for direct negotiations with Israel, flew here from Amman to try to persuade Mr. Shamir to drop his opposition to the proposed peace talks. **********The Israeli Government, though, seemed shocked -- confronted by Mr. Baker after he obtained, over three days, commitments from the Arabs to take part in the conference and in subsequent direct talks. **********Jordan also joined Saudi Arabia and Egypt in offering to suspend the Arab economic boycott of Israel if it will suspend the building of settlements in the occupied lands. And President Bush, on a visit to Turkey, again suggested that Israel halt settlement building on the West Bank. **********The Israeli public appears skeptical about the latest round of American diplomacy, tempering hope with caution.  [ Page A6. ] Deadline or No Deadline **********Mr. Baker denied that he had set a deadline for an Israeli response on peace talks, but American officials say it is possible that when President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet in Moscow on July 30 and 31, they will issue invitations to the conference -- as its joint sponsors -- whether the Israelis have responded positively or not. Such a move would put Israel under even greater pressure to attend. **********"We have always indicated that that would be something we might pursue," said Mr. Baker, when asked whether invitations would soon be sent. "Of course, it would be much better, if there is going to be a conference, if everybody could sign on before invitations are issued." **********Senior Israeli officials said they had no idea what Mr. Shamir was going to do, and the Israeli Prime Minister was saying nothing. **********Mr. Shamir's dilemma, though, is clear. If he says yes to Mr. Baker, his fragile coalition Government is likely to collapse and he will be challenged by members of his own rightist Likud bloc. If he says no, he risks alienating Israel from the United States, and from much of the rest of the world. **********Mr. Baker met with Mr. Shamir alone for 90 minutes. The meeting was taken up almost entirely with a review of the essence of the letter that President Hafez al-Assad of Syria sent to Mr. Bush a week ago. In that letter, the Syrian leader is said to have committed his Government to take part in the peace conference and subsequent direct talks. **********The Israelis have been deeply suspicious that Washington and Damascus struck some sort of deal. American officials said that Mr. Baker, without actually showing Mr. Shamir the Assad letter, had briefed him both on its contents and on the side assurances that the United States had provided the Syrians. What U.S. Would Do for Syria **********Those side assurances mostly involve restatements of American policy: that the United States does not recognize the Israeli annexation of the Golan Heights; that it believes that United Nations Security Council Resolution 242, calling on Israel to exchange land for peace, applies to the Golan Heights as well as to the West Bank, and that the United States is committed to pushing any peace negotiations actively, so as not to allow delays. **********Mr. Shamir asked Mr. Baker for more time to consider the matter, and the two men will be meeting again on Monday. "We are not under any pressure to give an answer soon," the Prime Minister's spokesman, Avi Pazner, said. "The problem is content, not deadlines." **********Before Mr. Baker met with Mr. Shamir, he held talks with three West Bank Palestinian leaders, led by Faisal al-Husseini, and made it clear to them that they, too, had to make some hard decisions. American officials said it was a tough, and at times emotional, encounter in which the Palestinians were essentially told that as the weakest party in the equation, they would have to accept previously unpalatable political realities. **********One of those is that the Palestine Liberation Organization, led by Yasir Arafat, can have no direct involvement with their delegation to the peace conference, since that would prompt the Israelis to walk out immediately. **********The other is that no Palestinians from East Jerusalem can take part in the first stage of the negotiations. The Israelis have ruled this out, arguing that such a role would imply that East Jerusalem, which Israel has annexed, was negotiable. **********But it is possible that the second restriction might be finessed if there is a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation and Palestinians born in Jerusalem take part with Jordanian passports. **********Despite those restrictions, the Palestinian leaders were told that they would soon have to come up with a list of acceptable representatives, American officials said. **********An intriguing thing about the endorsements that Mr. Baker has won from the Arab countries is that the Arab leaders all say in public that they are ready to accept Mr. Bush's proposal to attend "a peace conference" to reach a "comprehensive solution" based on Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338. But none of them ever mentions that this conference is intended as a ceremonial opening event for direct Arab-Israeli talks. **********American officials insist that the Arab leaders have privately assured them that they understand this, but do not now want to say it publicly for fear of alienating their own hard-liners. Each one, instead, allows Mr. Baker to say it for him. **********Thus, when reporters asked King Hussein today if he would say in public that he was committed to direct talks with Israel, he was not pleased. **********Looking a bit flummoxed, the King replied, "This is about the most ridiculous question I have ever heard." **********If it is so simple, the reporters persisted, why not give just a simple answer? **********"What do you attend a conference to do?" the King retorted. "To mime? To make faces at each other, or to discuss and try to resolve the problem? I have been calling for this for years and years. I assure you that this is really the intention, and it is very, very clear." **********As the journalists continued to press the King to say the words "direct bilateral talks with Israel," he declared the news conference over and walked out with Mr. Baker.                    --------------------       BUSH REITERATES VIEW **********ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 21 (Special to The New York Times) -- President Bush, on a visit to Turkey, suggested once again today that Israel should be flexible for the sake of peace in the Middle East and halt settlement building on the West Bank. **********"The question of settlements has been important," Mr. Bush said, in response to a reporter's question at a meeting here today with Turkish opposition leaders. "I haven't encountered anybody in this part of the world that thinks increasing settlements is a helpful thing. And the United States policy has been opposed to it for years." **********The President also said he did not want to use a "volatile" word like pressure in talking about his stance with the Israelis. He preferred to call it "reasoning and taking this -- what I keep calling a new credibility for the United States in the Middle East -- and using that to encourage what is a very reasonable and important step to peace."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/07/world.body_text: **********As Michel Aoun, the exiled Christian general who battled the Lebanese Government for two years, stepped up his calls for rebellion in Beirut, France warned him today to tone down his language to prevent French-Lebanese relations from worsening. **********In an unusual statement, the French Foreign Ministry publicly warned General Aoun that his inflammatory remarks risked breaching an agreement in which the Lebanese Government allowed him to seek asylum in France on condition that he refrain from political activity. **********The Government's warning came just hours after a French magazine published an interview in which General Aoun said that within the next year the Lebanese people would rebel and oust Syrian forces from their country. **********The general, who was spirited out of Lebanon a week ago to a heavily guarded villa in Marseilles, said that his stay in France was just temporary and that he would someday return to liberate his country.  'I Remain a Symbol' **********"I remain a symbol," said the 56-year-old general, who headed an anti-Syrian interim Government for two years. "It's not false modesty to say I am, and I will be the liberator of my country." **********In an interview published today in Paris-Match, a weekly magazine, he added, "Within 12 months, the Lebanese people will rise up and throw out Syrian and other foreign forces, before organizing free elections." **********General Aoun's remarks have angered the Lebanese Government and risk fraying relations between Lebanon and France. The Beirut Government has protested to France about the remarks and demanded that French officials stop the general from making what the Government of President Elias Hrawi views as calls to rebellion. **********At a news briefing today, a French Foreign Ministry spokesman, Maurice Gourdault-Montagne, said: "He undertook certain commitments in accepting asylum in France. We are upholding our commitments. General Aoun has to uphold his commitments."  Spent 10 Months in Embassy **********Before arriving in France, the general spent 10 months in refuge at the French Embassy in Beirut after Mr. Hrawi asked Syrian forces to flush him out of his bunker at the presidential palace in Baabda, a suburb of Beirut. **********After intense negotiations between France and Lebanon, the Beirut Government granted General Aoun amnesty and allowed him to leave so long as he not return for five years or engage in political activity. Beirut had accused him of embezzling millions of dollars, but in today's interview the general said such charges were baseless. **********Speaking about his 10 months in the French Embassy, he said, "In my gilded cage in the French Embassy, I felt freer than President Hrawi, who has to go to Syria every week to report in." **********"I do not consider myself in exile -- I am simply on a trip," he added. "I have only two suitcases, which I have not even unpacked." **********Paris-Match also quoted him as saying, "If I am in exile, then the Lebanese people are in exile in their own land since the country is occupied by foreign forces, and liberty and democracy do not exist."  French Envoy Is Summoned **********On Tuesday, An Nahar, a Beirut newspaper, published remarks by General Aoun urging a rebellion against President Hrawi and his Syrian allies. In response, the Lebanese Foreign Ministry summoned the French Ambassador, Daniel Husson, on Thursday to demand that France stop him from breaching the amnesty greement. **********Quoting diplomats, the Beirut press reported Thursday that France had instructed the general to exercise political restraint in public so as not to damage to French-Lebanese relations. **********General Aoun said the statements quoted Tuesday came from remarks he made to visitors to Marseilles who later relayed them to the newspaper. He has also told supporters that he does not consider himself bound by the amnesty accord because he does not recognize Lebanon's Government as legitimate. **********In March 1989, General Aoun began a six-month battle to push Syrian forces out of Lebanon. He later spurned a peace plan brokered by the Arab League, and he continued fighting not only the Syrians but also a rival Christian militia that supported the accord. That agreement, approved by the Lebanese Parliament, gave Muslims a greater role in the Government and legitimized Syria's troop presence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/28/busin.main_headline: Canada Beer and Asia Tools Target of U.S. Import Curbs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/28/busin.print_headline: Canada Beer and Asia Tools Target of U.S. Import Curbs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/28/busin.body_text: **********The Bush Administration said today that it planned to impose duties on Canadian beer to retaliate for Canada's restrictions on American beer. And it said it would extend some restrictions on imports of tools from Taiwan and Japan used to make machinery, including military equipment. **********The move against Canadian beer could result in a doubling of the price of imported brands like Molson, Labatt and Moosehead next April, when the duties are scheduled to go into effect, although continuing negotiations could lead to smaller duties or no duties at all. **********The tool restrictions would retain five-year-old caps on imports from Taiwan and Japan that were initially imposed because of the Reagan Administration's reluctance to have the United States become dependent on foreign equipment for the American military buildup. **********Coming three days before President Bush's trip to Asia, on which he will press Japan to pull down its trade barriers, the two announcements this afternoon appeared to represent a shift in Administration policy, trade experts said. **********"Taking machine tools and Canadian beer on the same day adds up to a get-tough stand on trade policy," said Gary C. Hufbauer, a fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. **********The two decisions are likely to mean that the Administration will extend similar import restrictions on steel and impose permanent duties on imports of Canadian softwoods next spring, he added. **********But the White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, who announced the machine-tool decision today, avoided presenting that action as a move toward protectionism. **********"The main responsibility for achieving international competitiveness rests with the industry itself," he said. **********The announcement today to prepare sanctions on Canadian beer imports, which was made by the deputy United States trade representative, Julius L. Katz, reflected American frustration with six years of efforts to open up Canada's beer market. Quebec province, for example, has 11,000 grocery stores licensed to sell domestically brewed beer but only 300 stores are licensed to sell American beer. **********The Geneva-based General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which sets rules for international trade, issued rulings disapproving of the Canadian beer restrictions in 1988 and again this year, but has not required removal of the limits, which are set and maintained by each province. The GATT ruling this year only requires Canada to file reports next March and July on any changes in its policies. **********The Canadian Embassy here objected to the American announcement, adding that it planned to comply with the GATT ruling. **********"Canada has told the U.S. that retaliation is premature and inappropriate," said Pam K. Chappell, an embassy official. Suit by U.S. Companies **********Two American brewers, The G. Heileman Brewing Company and the Stroh Brewery Company, filed a legal case against their Canadian rivals in 1990 that forced the Office of the United States Trade Representative to announce by Sunday whether it was prepared to impose duties. **********The exact amount of the duties on the $150 million a year of Canadian beer imported into the United States will depend on a planned Government study to determine the value of sales now lost unfairly by American brewers. **********If the Government study finds that American losses exceed $150 million, the Administration will seek to eliminate Canadian beers from the American market by charging a prohibitive tariff that could exceed 100 percent of the wholesale price, said an American trade official who insisted on anonymity. People would presumably stop buying Canadian beer if it rose to $10 or more a six-pack. Partial Duty Possible **********If the study found that losses were less than $150 million, the Administration could either impose prohibitive duties for part of each year or a moderate duty all year, the trade official added. The United States currently charges a duty of 1.2 cents a liter, or about 2 1/2 cents a six-pack, for Canadian beer, and this is scheduled to fall by 25 percent next year because of the free trade agreement with Canada. **********Today's decision on machine tools was particularly hard fought within the Administration because it involves both trade and national security issues at a time when American officials are groping toward new policies after the collapse of the Soviet Union. **********The Office of the Trade Representative and some White House officials had argued that continued restrictions could not be justified on purely economic grounds because of the industry's success in competing against some imports. The Defense Department, however, successfully argued that national security required President Bush to extend some of the restrictions, which are actually imposed by the exporting countries under American pressure as so-called voluntary restraint agreements.  From Cars to Submarines **********Machine tools are used to cut and grind the metal parts for everything from cars to bombs and nuclear submarines. Some members of Congress had joined the Defense Department in warning that the United States could not afford to depend on imported tools lest the supply be cut off. **********Free-traders in the White House and elsewhere in the Administration had contended that the war in the Persian Gulf and the Soviet Union's collapse had made it unlikely that the United States would again fight a war long enough to require the mobilization of the American economy. **********President Bush ordered today that import restrictions on machining centers and computer-controlled machines that punch, shear, round and mill metal be extended for two years, although the caps are to be gradually lifted during that time. But import restrictions on similar machines without computer controls will be allowed to expire next Tuesday. **********The Coordination Council for North American Affairs, which represents Taiwan in the United States, said the American decision unfairly penalized Taiwan. The decision keeps imports at 1986 levels, when Taiwan's industry was still small.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/15/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; N.A.B. Names New President
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/15/busin.body_text: **********Leonard Forman has been named president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, the sales and marketing organization of the newspaper industry. **********Mr. Forman had served as acting president of the bureau since last summer, when Craig Standen left the position. **********"I'm really excited about the opportunity to work within the business to effect change," Mr. Forman said yesterday. "When business is difficult, there's a willingness to be innovative." **********Mr. Forman, who served as director of strategic planning at The New York Times Company for 13 years, said newspapers needed to work together to simplify the advertising process. He said he hoped, for example, that advertisers might use the bureau as an intermediary to reach a number of newspapers simultaneously. **********"We need to do a better job as a collective industry," he said. "We need to look at changes in the way we serve our advertisers."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/10/busin.main_headline: Fujitsu Names Chiefs In a U.S. Revamping
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/10/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Fujitsu Names Chiefs In a U.S. Revamping
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/10/busin.body_text: **********Fujitsu America Inc. yesterday reorganized its business operations to create two subsidiaries, Fujitsu Computer Products of America Inc. and Fujitsu Network Transmission Systems Inc. Fujitsu America will now act as a holding company for Fujitsu Ltd.'s businesses in the United States. **********Fujitsu named Norman B. Petersen, 60 years old, chairman, and Lewis Frauenfelder, 51, president and chief executive of Fujitsu Computer Products, the larger of the new entities. To be based in San Jose, Calif., the computer company will combine the marketing operation of Fujitsu America with its engineering research unit, Intellistor, of Longmont, Colo., and manufacturing operations in Hillsboro, Ore. **********"Fujitsu has made the decision to combine these entities into one full- service company," Mr. Frauenfelder said in a telephone interview. "My job is to bring these together into a strong local force that understands the requirements of American customers and can satisfy them with locally produced products." The company will sell Fujitsu's Japanese data storage and printer products as well as American-made equipment, he said. **********Mr. Frauenfelder has been president of Intellistor, a data storage systems design company, which he founded in 1983 and sold to Fujitsu in 1987. Intellistor conducted development engineering for Fujitsu for two years before the acquisition. **********Mr. Petersen has been chairman of Intellistor and president of Fujitsu America's computer products group, which forms the marketing arm of the new entity. **********Before forming Intellistor, Mr. Frauenfelder served as vice president of engineering at the Storage Technology Corporation and spent 10 years with the International Business Machines Corporation. Mr. Petersen joined Fujitsu America in 1983 after holding management positions at Memorex, Storage Technology, Control Data and I.B.M. **********Fujitsu also promoted Jinjiro Dodo from group president of its transmission division to chairman and chief executive of Fujitsu Network Transmission Systems, based in Dallas. Koji Inoue, deputy group president, was named president and chief operating officer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.main_headline: The Executive Life; Separating the Fugitives From the Stress Fighters
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.print_headline: The Executive Life; Separating the Fugitives From the Stress Fighters
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.body_text: **********When it comes to vacations, T. Boone Pickens is a power player. Win Smith, senior vice president at Merrill Lynch, is a stress fighter. Barbara Feigin, director of strategic services at Grey Advertising, is a fun worshiper. **********"Vacations are like behavioral Rorschach tests," said Dr. Howard Glazer, a psychologist at New York Hospital. **********Ever alert for an opportunity to draw back the curtain of ignorance, the Hyatt Hotels Corporation decided to ask executives how they spend their vacations. Then it hired Dr. Glazer to fit executives seeking relaxation into a series of pigeonholes. **********Voila! The signs over the slots read: power players, stress fighters, schedulers, fun worshipers and fugitives. By exercising the columnist's prerogative, a sixth category can be added: cheaters. **********The survey was done by Research & Forecasts Inc., a New York polling firm. It involved telephone interviews with 500 executives from around the country, who stay at least half the time in non-Hyatt hotels. The survey found that executives take an average of four vacations annually, most lasting less than a week. Once rid of office stress, 91 percent of executives said they become friendlier, 72 percent more athletic and 65 percent sexually freer. It takes 42 percent of executives two to four days to unwind and find their particular pigeonhole. **********Dr. Glazer calls the categories "archetypes" and bases them on demographic data, including age, income level, gender and industry. "It shocked us that there were such distinct types of people who conformed to such different vacation patterns," said Darryl Hartley-Leonard, Hyatt's president. **********Well, maybe. The first group, the power players, is largely composed of C.E.O.'s, presidents and company owners. These people supposedly make the smoothest transition from work to vacation and back again.  "Doing business helps them to relax," said Nicholas Tortorello, chairman of Research & Forecasts. "They don't see it as agony or pain in any way." He cites Mr. Pickens, a former client, as a perfect example. "I've been with him on vacation, when he'll sit by the pool talking on a portable phone to his office. He's always cool, calm and collected, no matter where he is." **********Likewise, Mr. Hartley-Leonard, a C.E.O. to the core, prides himself on being a power player. "For years my wife has told me it's ridiculous to spend an hour working each morning when I'm on vacation," he said.  "But I need my fix in order to feel comfortable." **********The stress fighters spend their vacations frantically exercising and dieting. "These are the people you see up at 6 A.M. in jogging clothes, the ones who are always carrying a bottle of mineral water," said Mr. Tortorello.  "They're on a mission, not a vacation." Stress fighters rarely enjoy traveling to foreign cities; they usually opt for state-of-the-art spas or rigorous nature treks. **********Five years ago, Mr. Smith of Merrill Lynch, a veteran marathon runner, joined Arthur Levitt, former head of the American Stock Exchange, on an Outward Bound trip; since then, he's ventured into the wilderness annually. This summer, he went rafting down the San Juan River and mountain biking in Moab, Utah. "I can't stand lying around on the beach," he said. **********The schedulers like to structure vacations as heavily as work. "These are the ones who end up on a tour bus," said Mr. Tortorello.  "They're a bit manic about scheduling every moment. They're deathly afraid of getting somewhere and having nothing to do." He notes that schedulers are unlikely to be in frequent contact with their offices: "They want to be constantly stimulated so they don't have to think about what they left behind." **********The fun worshipers enjoy exercise, but aren't ascetics like the stress fighters. They plan in advance, but they aren't control freaks like the schedulers. They're similar to the power players, with one notable difference: they avoid the office entirely. **********Ms. Feigin of Grey Advertising took her 21-year-old twin sons to a beach resort in Los Angeles this summer. "I wanted to be in a pretty place, with good things to eat and plenty of sun," she said. "I didn't want anything frenetic." While Ms. Feigin refrained from taking work with her, she did ask that her mail be sent on the last day of vacation so she could read it on the plane coming home. **********The fugitives use vacation as an escape. On the lam from stressful jobs, they abandon their inhibitions and party all night. Ever been to Club Med? The fugitives are the ones drinking pina coladas for breakfast. "Despite their relative success, they're plagued with insecurity," Dr. Glazer said. "They're usually in industries like investment banking where you can make big bucks at a young age and end up over your head. They're typical baby boomers, who can't stop worrying about their careers and their money." **********But the Hyatt study left out one possible group, the cheaters. These are executives who think they're taking vacations but aren't. Harold Geneen bragged about all the time he took off while running the ITT Corporation. In fact, most of his "vacations" involved inviting business associates to ITT's fishing camp in Florida or the company's hunting lodge in Georgia. **********"A lot of people think they're taking vacations when they're going to seminars or conferences," said Earl Goldman, who runs his own insurance agency in Concord, Calif.  "It's not a real vacation if you're with your colleagues or your customers." **********Mr. Goldman is not a cheater or a power player. Each year, he takes at least six weeks off and refuses to bring any work, to read any business periodicals or to contact his office.  "I give them my itinerary, and tell them to call me only if somebody dies," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/02/world.main_headline: Bush Gives Praise to Kuwait After Meeting With the Emir
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/02/world.print_headline: Bush Gives Praise to Kuwait After Meeting With the Emir
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/02/world.body_text: **********After meeting with the Emir of Kuwait, President Bush today praised "Kuwait's great progress in reconstruction, physical and political," despite charges by human rights groups that abuses are rampant, including torture and arbitrary detention. **********After their third meeting since the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq on Aug. 2, 1990, Mr. Bush and the Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, issued a demand that Iraq unconditionally release all Kuwaiti citizens who have been held by the Baghdad Government since the war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.main_headline: Other Phone Failures Hurt Air Control
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.print_headline: Other Phone Failures Hurt Air Control
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.body_text: **********Major telephone failures that significantly degrade air traffic control services are far more common than is generally recognized, according to data released today by a Congressional subcommittee. **********Although few of them were noticed by the public, there were 114 episodes of "major" telephone failures that disrupted air traffic control in the year beginning in August 1990, the data showed. **********Ten of the failures affected air traffic controllers in the New York area, and 15 of them in the Washington area, the data showed. **********The information, compiled by the Federal Aviation Administration, indicated that the outages lasted an average of about six hours. **********It is rare for a telephone failure to have as severe an effect on air traffic as the one on Tuesday night, when a power failure at an A.T.& T. center in Manhattan caused all air service in and out of the New York metropolitan area to be halted for several hours, stranding tens of thousands of passengers. **********But the F.A.A. has long identified such failures as one of its most pressing problems, and has been seeking to overhaul its nationwide telecommunications network and to make improvements on a spot basis throughout the system. **********The compilation defined major phone failures as "those having significant operational impact, including air traffic delays, increased air traffic workload and safety concerns." **********The F.A.A. data were provided this week to the House Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance of the Energy and Commerce Committee, which requested the material after this week's failure. The committee released a copy of the data. **********Like the failure earlier this week, the disruptions of telecommunications listed in the data affected the normal handling of aircraft by air traffic controllers, including radio communications between controllers and pilots, the availability of radar information to controllers and automated transfer from one controller to another of the responsibility for guiding a plane. **********The report, which listed each incident, did not include any information about the possible safety concerns they raised. **********The F.A.A. has said that it designs its air-traffic-control system in a way that allows planes to fly safely even after severe failures. The planes make contact with airport towers or regional control centers whose services are not disrupted, and they are rerouted to new destinations or held on the ground to prevent overloading the region where phone lines are down. **********But controllers, airline officials and independent safety experts have said that the phone failures do diminish the safety margins built into the system.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/busin.body_text: **********Most globe-trotting executives will be staying home for a while. With war raging in the Persian Gulf, many large corporations have banned travel to the Middle East and greatly curtailed other international travel, officials of several dozen top companies said. **********At many companies, permission for international trips deemed essential for business must come from senior-level executives. Domestic travel has apparently not been affected. **********Many companies "have either limited travel, banned travel to Europe or banned travel outright," said John Riepe of the National Business Travel Association, an association of corporate travel managers based in Arlington, Va. Bans at G.M. and 3M **********"Prior to the outbreak of conflict, we had implemented a ban on international travel," said Thomas Pyden, a spokesman for the General Motors Corporation in Detroit. "That has remained in effect." **********The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, in St. Paul, eliminated European travel in early January, and broadened the ban after war broke out on Jan. 17. "All international travel has effectively been curtailed," said Mark Fenner of 3M. **********Companies said they had restricted travel because they were concerned about the safety of employees. President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has encouraged his followers to commit acts of terrorism against the interests of the United States and its allies. **********Some large companies, however, have simply urged employees to be careful. "We have advised employees to use extreme caution and common sense, but we don't have any travel bans," said Jack Batty, a spokesman for the General Electric Company in Fairfield, Conn. **********A survey conducted last week by the Carlson Travel Group, one of the nation's largest travel agencies, found international travel bans at 25 percent of the companies surveyed. "Travel today is much more the exception than the rule," said Dexter Koehl, a spokesman for the Minneapolis-based agency. He said the other companies had restricted international travel, allowing trips only with approval from the highest corporate level. **********Carlson Travel surveyed travel managers at 20 corporations. It also interviewed the managers of 20 of its own travel agencies. **********The curtailing of travel goes beyond safety concerns, Mr. Koehl said. Senior executives "are very concerned about liability" if an employee is injured or killed traveling on business, he said. **********At the Chrysler Corporation, for example, which has scaled back international travel sharply, responsibility for approving trips abroad has been kicked upstairs to the company's senior management, said Thomas Houston, a company spokesman.  Reduced Demand for Flights **********The shutdown of corporate travel has dealt another blow to the troubled airline industry. Trans World Airlines, for example, plans to cancel up to half of its overseas flights because of the drop in traffic. **********At United Air Lines, "we have seen a softening in demand for international seats," said Sara Dornacker, a spokeswoman in Chicago. "We attribute this to a temporary suspension of travel by business travelers to international destinations." United has not cut flights because of the reduced demand, she said. **********Traffic to Europe is also down for American Airlines. In a typical January, American's flights to Europe are nearly 60 percent full. Since the war broke out, the trans-Atlantic flights are only about 40 percent full, said Lise Olson, a spokeswoman for American. **********"We have received reports from companies that have canceled business meetings in Europe," she said.  Scrutinizing Travel Costs **********While employee safety is the paramount concern, the travel bans come at an opportune time for corporations already scrutinizing travel costs in light of the weakening economy. **********Several companies surveyed by Carlson Travel spend more than $100 million a year on travel. **********Mr. Riepe of the National Business Travel Association said American companies spent more than $30 billion a year on travel. **********The price of jet fuel doubled after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, and airlines raised the price of tickets three times. As a result, even before the war and the threat of terrorism, the sharp increase in travel costs in a soft economy had caused a number of companies to curtail travel. **********"This just makes the decision to stay put a little easier," said Mr. Houston of Chyrsler.  Alternatives to Travel **********For safety reasons, the International Business Machines Corporation is trying to avoid all travel to sensitive areas and is suggesting that employees use teleconferences or video conferences to avoid trips, said Rita Black, a spokeswoman. She said I.B.M. had been seeking alternatives to travel for some time to control costs. **********The companies with travel bans said the bans were in place for an indefinite amount of time. **********A number of companies, including the Xerox Corporation in Stamford, Conn., Tenneco Inc. in Houston, and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, do not have bans. A.T.& T. has only put out a memorandum about the dangers of air travel. **********Barry Lane, a spokesman for the Unocal Corporation in Los Angeles, said, "We haven't restricted travel, but the company has strongly recommended against it at this time, particularly foreign travel." He said he knew of one executive, due to be transferred to London, who put off the move because of security concerns. **********A few companies continue to send workers to the Middle East. The Lockheed Corporation has employees in Saudi Arabia supporting the operation of its transport aircraft and other Lockheed products.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/06/busin.main_headline: Mayors Press Congress For Control Over Cable
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/06/busin.print_headline: Mayors Press Congress For Control Over Cable
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/06/busin.body_text: **********More than 600 mayors and local officials asked Congress today for legislation that they said would increase competitiveness among operators of local cable television franchises. **********"Our constituents have come to us with countless complaints concerning, among other things, poor signal quality, the failure of cable operators to respond to service requests within a reasonable time period and, of course, dramatic rate increases," the 616 local officials said in a letter sent to every member of the Congress. **********The officials were led by Mayors Maynard Jackson of Atlanta, Raymond L. Flynn of Boston and Sharpe James of Newark. Mr. James will represent both the United States Conference of Mayors and the National League of Cities at a hearing scheduled next week by the Senate Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Communications.  Cite Lack of Control **********More than 55 million households are served by 9,600 cable systems in 28,000 communities, according to the National Cable Television Association, which represents the cable operators. This accounts for nearly 60 percent of the 93 million households with television sets. **********The officials complained that although their constituents looked to them to insure efficent cable operations at reassonable costs to consumers, "under the current statutory framework, we lack the authority to address many of these complaints." The officials lost this authority under the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984. **********The local officials requested an end to current procedures, which they said favored the cable operators' ability to renew franchises. The localofficials want a totally competitive renewal process that allows municipalities to grant franchises to whomever they wish. Most franchises are renewable in 10 to 20 years. **********The officials also seek to restrict the cable operators' ability to sue municipalities. **********James P. Mooney, president of the National Cable Television Association, said the officials were seeking to enhance their power at the expense of consumers. "They want to be able periodically to hold an auction for the franchise and get each contestant, including the incumbent, to engage in a contest of promises," Mr. Mooney said. "That would have the effect of increasing the company's costs, which have to be passed on to the subscribers." **********Mr. Mooney said the officials actually wanted to restrict competition, a charge the mayors' groups rejected. Mr. Mooney said the local officials "want to be immune from damages from First Amendment lawsuits brought by people who want to compete with the franchise holders." **********Some cable industry experts have contended that cable franchises have become a form of political patronage and that to receive their franchises many cable operators had to give local politicians an equity share in their companies.  F.C.C. Ruling **********But Norman M. Sinel, a lawyer for the mayors' groups, said such cases were usually initiated by the cable operators. Still, in a July 31 ruling, the Federal Communications Commission noted what it regarded as abuses of municipal authority in franchising the cable operators. **********In a ruling on competition in the cable industry, the F.C.C. said, "We recommend that Congress amend the Cable Act to forbid local franchise authorities from unreasonably denying a franchise to applicants that are ready and able to provide service." **********It added, "Congress should also make it clear that local authorities may not pass rules whose intent or effect is to create unreasonable barriers to the entry of potential competing" cable operators. **********"Franchise requirements should be limited to appropriate governmental interests," the F.C.C. said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/01/world.body_text: **********Prince Norodom Sihanouk's guerrilla army said its field commanders had been ordered to respect a temporary cease-fire in Cambodia starting on Wednesday. **********All combatants have now said they will honor the truce. These are the Sihanouk forces and the guerrilla groups allied with it -- the Khmer Rouge and the Khmer People's National Liberation Front -- and their enemy, the Vietnamese-installed Government in Phnom Penh. **********The truce was jointly proposed on Monday by France, Indonesia and Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations -- the main mediators in the current Cambodian peace negotiations. **********They said fighting should be halted from Wednesday to at least the end of peace talks expected to be held in May in Jakarta, Indonesia. **********It would be the first truce in 12 years of war. But there is no means of monitoring the cease-fire, and both sides have expressed pessimism that it would hold. **********The truce is intended to improve the atmosphere for the Jakarta talks, which are to focus on disagreements over a peace plan proposed by the United Nations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/05/busin.main_headline: Salomon Agrees to Pay Freddie Mac Fine
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/05/busin.print_headline: Salomon Agrees to Pay Freddie Mac Fine
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/05/busin.body_text: **********Salomon Brothers Inc. said today that it would pay a penalty imposed by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation for falsifying bids in the sale of Government-sponsored bonds. But 17 other Wall Street firms have sought more time to decide whether to pay the fines. **********The agency, known as Freddie Mac, has given the others until 9 A.M. Monday to pay penalties resulting from the discovery of inflated orders and faked sales confirmations -- or be barred from future sales of Freddie Mac securities. While the total penalty imposed on the group is only $1 million, the Wall Street firms fear the precedent set by the Freddie Mac action and want more time to review their options. **********Leland C. Brendsel, the agency's chairman and chief executive, praised Salomon and expressed hope that the remaining firms would quickly follow suit. **********Salomon's action "cleans the slate with Freddie Mac and goes a long way to insuring the integrity of the marketplace," Mr. Brendsel said in a statement. "I hope Salomon's decision is quickly followed by the other dealers." **********The action today comes at a critical time both for Wall Street firms that are accused of widespread bid-rigging in a number of different markets and for government-sponsored entities, like Freddie Mac, that have been accused of being lax and are trying to fend off attempts in Congress to be more closely supervised. As a result, Freddie Mac's handling of this scandal is being watched by a Congress increasingly skeptical of the agency's ability to monitor its own affairs. **********An investigation conducted over the last several weeks by Freddie Mac found that the 18 dealers had lied to the agency to gain a larger share of the agency's debt underwritings. The fine, imposed late Thursday night, was made equal to 20 percent of the commissions paid to the group in the sale of some $3 billion in securiites in the last two years. A total of 25 banks and Wall Street firms sell the agency's debt, which is used to finance home mortgages. **********A similar investigation is taking place at the Federal National Mortgage Association, called Fannie Mae, where many of the 55 dealers that sell Fannie Mae securities, which are also used to finance housing, admitted to inflated orders. David Jeffers, a spokesman for Fannie Mae, said the agency would not "hesitate to admit sanctions up to expulsion" when its investigation is finished. Mr. Jeffers would not say when that might be. **********In a statement, the Public Securities Association, which represents the dealers, said the 24-hour deadline for the payment of the fine was "not a reasonable amount of time." The association said almost all of the members of the selling group had met in New York to discuss a course of action. **********Joseph Sims, an association spokesman, said he had no idea how many firms might ultimately pay the fine and added that the group felt the 24-hour deadline was a dangerous precedent that did allow enough time to analyze the situation. **********Cheryl Regan, a spokeswoman for Freddie Mac, said the agency agreed to an extension since "we're trying to work things out with our dealers and it was a practicality." Firms, however, that do not "indicate an intent to comply" by Monday morning would be expelled from sales beginning that day. **********Freddie Mac would not identify the 17 firms, nor indicate the size of the penalty Salomon agreed to pay. In a statement, Salomon, which has admitted to submitting false bids in Treasury auctions, said it was paying the fine to maintain continued participation in the sales. **********There was speculation on Wall Street today that the 17 dealers might refuse to pay in a show of strength that would force Freddie Mac to sell its securities through only a handful of dealers. Proponents of this view pointed out that the fines were extremely small and that the issue was one of principle. Mr. Sims of the dealer's association said the dealers wanted to "weigh the pros and cons of paying the fine or losing this business relationship."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/busin.main_headline: Hotel Executive to Run New Burger King Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Hotel Executive to Run New Burger King Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/busin.body_text: **********Completing a management alignment undertaken by its British owners, the Burger King Corporation has named a hotel executive, Barry L. Conrad, to direct the franchise side of the business. **********Mr. Conrad, who will head Burger King's newly created USA Franchise division, will be responsible for the profitability, growth and development of the chain's more than 4,500 franchised restaurants in the United States, which represent 85 percent of Burger King's business. **********The 800 restaurants owned by the company are under Robert J. Stetson, president of company stores. **********Burger King's chief executive, Barry J. Gibbons, has been running the franchise side of the business along with his other duties, a Burger King spokeswoman said yesterday from the company's headquarters in Miami. **********Mr. Gibbons was appointed in January 1989 to revive the hamburger chain after its parent, the Pillsbury Company, was purchased by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British congomerate. Mr. Gibbons previous experience was operating 2,000 restaurants and pubs in Britain and elsewhere in Europe for Grand Met. **********Troubled relations with franchise owners was close to the top of Burger King's list of problems when Grand Met took over, and Grand Met has been working on the problem. **********"Grand Met has done an awful lot to improve the company," Mr. Conrad said yesterday. "In two years it has made giant strides, so some of that preliminary work has been done, and I will take it from here" as far as the franchise business goes. **********Mr. Conrad has had experience working for a British parent company. He is president and chief executive of Trusthouse Forte Hotels Inc., with responsibility for 500 hotels in North and South America. Trusthouse Forte is a London-based hotel company with worldwide operations. **********Mr. Conrad had managed the Sonesta hotel chain and was chief executive of Quality Inns before joining Trusthouse in 1986. While working for Trusthouse, Mr. Conrad was based in El Cajon, Calif. He prepared for his career at the University of Maryland and the hotel and restaurant school of Cornell University. **********This will be his first post away from the hotel industry. "The hospitality business is both food and beverages and hotels, so I think this is not an unusual transition," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/06/busin.main_headline: In Defense of Lotus in Japan . . .
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/06/busin.print_headline: In Defense of Lotus in Japan . . .
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/06/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********The Forum article "Japan's Mythical Trade Surplus" (Dec. 9), an interview with Bill Totten, author of "Don't Blame Japan" and president and founder of Ashisuto, a company that sells software in Japan, contains the assertion that large American software companies "tend to be arrogant or tend not to make their products fit the needs of the Japanese." Based on other comments made by Mr. Totten, I assume the Lotus Development Corporation was one of the companies to which he was referring. **********Let me set the record straight. After almost three years of painstaking development work to insure the product met specific requirements of Japanese users, Lotus introduced 1-2-3/J in 1986. Within a month, it was the best-selling software package in Japan. According to Nikkei Sangyo Shimbun, a daily business newspaper in Japan, 1-2-3/J has been the best-selling spreadsheet in Japan since its introduction. The product has won numerous awards, including being the first non-Japanese product to win the prestigious Nikkei Award for creative excellence. **********Lotus has 120 employees in Japan, all but one of whom is Japanese, and it's likely Japan will be the company's second-largest market in 1991, trailing only the United States. **********For someone who claims to have adopted the Japanese culture, Mr. Totten's inaccurate and specious comments are uncharacteristic of Japanese business etiquette. RICHARD ECKEL  Cambridge, Mass., Dec. 14    The writer is senior manager, corporate press relations, of the Lotus Development Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/22/busin.main_headline: The Prince a Corporate Raider? No, Just Joking
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/22/busin.print_headline: The Prince a Corporate Raider? No, Just Joking
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/22/busin.body_text: **********Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, the 35-year-old Saudi who is investing $590 million in Citicorp, once declared in an effusive moment that he would "love to be a corporate raider." **********Prince Waleed was said to be unavailable in Saudi Arabia yesterday, but his advisers were assuring Citicorp that the remark in 1988 to a reporter for Forbes magazine was made in jest. **********The source of his money for the Citicorp move is not completely clear. Most of what is known about the Prince comes from his advisers and his own account, rendered during the few times he has spoken with the press.  Started With a $15,000 Loan **********By their version, he started in business in Riyadh in 1979 after receiving a degree in business administration from Menlo College in Atherton, Calif. His start-up capital was $15,000 he borrowed from his father, Prince Talal bin Abdul Aziz. He quickly exhausted that money and, when his father refused to bankroll him further, went to the local branch of Citibank. **********At first, Citibank was also reluctant, but agreed to a loan when the young Prince put up his home as collateral. His fledgling enterprise, Kingdom Establishment for Trading and Contracting, grew and expanded remarkably in a variety of fields including real estate, construction, travel and finance. In 1988, Forbes magazine estimated that Prince Waleed, at 33, had a net worth of "at least $1 billion," making him perhaps one of the dozen richest members of the royal family. Yet in its 1990 tabulation of the world's billionaires, Forbes did not mention Prince Waleed. **********But some Saudi experts expressed doubts yesterday about the notion that Prince Waleed was a self-made billionaire whose money for the Citicorp move came entirely from his own coffers. One adviser to the Saudi royal family -- an extended tribe with roughly 20,000 members and 4,000 princes and princesses -- said it seemed unlikely Prince Waleed could have made so much money during the 1980's, when oil prices were depressed for several years, which slowed the Saudi economy. **********Instead, the adviser and an Arab banker, both of whom asked not to be identified, said the American-educated Prince probably had some help from his father, Prince Talal, a Saudi businessman of established wealth. **********Prince Talal was a Saudi Government official who, like some of his countrymen, became enamored of the Egyptian leader Gamal Abdel Nasser's message of pan-Arab nationalism in the late 1950's -- an ideology opposed by the monarchy of Saudi Arabia. Prince Talal moved to Egypt in the early 1960's but later became disenchanted with Mr. Nasser. By the late 1960's, he had moved back to his homeland, but the Saudi rulers would not allow him to rejoin the Government. So he went into business. Favorable Terms for the Saudis **********Middle Eastern finance experts said the big Saudi investment in Citicorp was probably not directly related to the gulf war or championed by the Riyadh Government. The fall in the price of the shares of big American banks since the war and the recession began, however, made it possible for the Saudis to make a large investment on more favorable terms. **********Prince Waleed's investment, they said, mirrored the optimism of most Middle East investors about the long-range prospects for the United States economy. "He undoubtedly views this an an investment in a premier bank in a country that still has tremendous potential -- that's got to be the principal motivation," said Sharif Ghalib, a Middle East expert at the Institute of International Finance in Washington. "And there's no question that that is how gulf investors view the United States."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/15/busin.main_headline: Axa Backtracks on Equitable Life Stake
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/15/busin.print_headline: Axa Backtracks on Equitable Life Stake
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/15/busin.body_text: **********Groupe Axa, one of France's largest insurance companies, announced today that it had reached an agreement with the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States to obtain a major stake in the troubled New York-based insurer. **********But later in the day the company backed off from the remarks saying that a definitive agreement had not been worked out. **********In a meeting with French stock analysts this morning, Claude Bebear, Axa's chairman, announced that there was an agreement but declined to say what size of a stake Axa would obtain in Equitable. He said the Paris-based company would be "the uncontestable lead shareholder" in what is the third-largest insurance company in the United States, after the Prudential Insurance Company of America and the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. Equitable manages $140 billion in funds **********Mr. Bebear (pronounced bay-bay-are) stressed however that his company's agreement with Equitable required approval from the New York State Insurance Department. **********"We have agreed with the Equitable people on a plan, but it must be approved by the department," Mr. Bebear said. "We're in talks at the moment." He declined to predict the outcome of those discussions. **********Later in the day Axa retreated from the remarks that Mr. Bebear had made, with a company spokesman saying that there was no definitive agreement between the companies. "Friendly conversations are being pursued between Axa and Equitable," the spokesman said. "We cannot yet speak about an agreement." **********Analysts suggested that Axa was backing off because the insurance department might be concerned that the agreement was announced before it had been approved. In addition, analysts say, the department might ask for changes in the agreement that one of the parties might find unacceptable. **********A spokeswoman for Equitable declined to comment on the state of the talks, although Equitable officials have confirmed that Axa was one of the potential investors in the discussions. "We are highly optimistic about our current discussions," the spokeswoman said. **********In recent weeks, Equitable officials have said that they are seeking investors to put up $1 billion to shore up the company's capital base, which has been greatly weakened by soured investments in "junk bonds" and real estate. Equitable officials said that in return for the $1 billion, the investors would receive a 40 percent stake. **********This morning, Mr. Bebear said Axa would be part of a group of investors that would pump about $1 billion into Equitable, and he added that Japanese and American investors might take part. "There are also some Japanese companies that are very interested, and we're also talking to some United States investors," he said.   Japanese Talks Acknowledged **********Equitable officials had acknowledged that they were talking to two large Japanese insurance companies, Meiji Mutual Life and Nippon Life, but Mr. Bebear declined to say whether those companies would join the investor group. **********Equitable is seeking outside investors as part of an effort to transform itself from a mutual company owned by policyholders into a shareholder-owned company whose stock is traded publicly. **********Axa, which is Europe's eight-largest insurance company, had $9.4 billion in premiums last year and $306 million in profits from its insurance operations.   Management Called 'Imprudent' **********Mr. Bebear said today that an "imprudent" management team had gotten Equitable into trouble, but he added that they had been replaced by capable people. In an interview last month, Mr. Bebear said that in Axa's past foreign acquistions, it had retained most of the top managers because they knew the local market. He indicated that he would likely do the same at Equitable. **********Analysts say Mr. Bebear may have had to promise to retain Equitable's management as a condition for Equitable's choosing Axa as a major investor. "I don't think Axa is going to put in any new management over there," said Simon Rudolph, an insurance industry analyst with Morgan Stanley in London. "I would have thought it only natural that Axa would want to have considerable day-to-day information and control of what's going on. If they don't have, that would certainly surprise me."  Previous Effort Failed **********Two years ago, Axa failed in its efforts to acquire Farmers Group Inc., a large California-based insurer, when a foreign raider's attempt to take over Farmers' parent failed. Farmers is owned by B.A.T. Industries, a London-based conglomerate that repelled a takeover effort by a group led by Sir James Goldsmith, the British-French industrialist. **********Speaking about Equitable, Mr. Bebear said, "We're convinced that we can perform an operation that will be very pleasing to our investors." **********Mr. Rudolph, the analyst, said that in view of Equitable's serious financial problems, Mr. Bebear was pursuing a high-risk strategy. **********"Perhaps he knows something we don't know," Mr. Rudolph added. "He must have gone into Equitable's books."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/23/world.body_text: **********President Alfredo F. Cristiani and commanders of his country's guerrilla insurgency held intensive talks Sunday and early today on the main issue blocking an end to El Salvador's 11-year-old civil war. **********When talks broke up at 1:45 A.M. today, diplomats at the United Nations appeared to be moving toward resolution of the issue, the demand by the guerrillas -- steadfastly rejected by the Government -- that some of them be incorporated into the armed forces as a means of assuring their personal safety after the cease-fire. **********Diplomats close to the talks said the guerrilla leaders were seriously considering a proposal by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar that would, instead, provide for a substantial participation by former guerrilla combatants in the civilian-run police force to be created to replace the present military-led police. **********Mr. Cristiani and the five rebel commanders spoke in vague, but optimistic terms as they went in and out of the United Nations headquarters Sunday and early today for separate meetings with Mr. Perez de Cuellar.  Rebels Plan a Cease-Fire **********Schafik Handal, head of the Salvadoran Communist Party and spokesman for the rebels, repeated their commitment to declare a unilateral cease-fire if a major breakthrough occurred in these talks, even if a formal accord was not ready for signing. **********Negotiations have been under way for nearly 18 months between the Government and the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, the guerrilla umbrella organization. A number of accords already have been reached on the issues of human rights and political and military reform in El Salvador. **********But what a United Nations mediator, Alvaro de Soto, called the "crunch issue" -- the concern of the guerrillas for their personal security after the fighting stops -- became the roadblock to a complete settlement. **********At the urging of the United States and the Soviet Union, Mr. Perez de Cuellar invited both sides to New York a week ago and has been holding daily sessions with them. Mr. Cristiani and the rebels have not met face to face, but some rebels and members of the President's Cabinet have met as a working commission. **********Diplomats said a major effort was being made to persuade the guerrilla leaders to accept the police role instead of a military function. 'Friends' Join Negotiations **********They said this diplomatic effort was being accompanied by a commitment to the guerrillas that a broad-based "political mechanism" would be created to help carry out the peace agreements, particularly those involving reform of the armed forces and the security of the former guerrillas. **********Such a group would have representation from the Government, army, guerrillas, church and political parties and would be closely linked to the United Nations peace verification mission that recently set up operations in El Salvador. **********Mr. Perez de Cuellar discussed this plan with the guerrilla leaders at a session Saturday night at which the United Nations Ambassadors from Spain, Mexico, Colombia and Venezuela arrived to help argue the case. **********Those four countries united in June as the "group of friends" of the Salvadoran peace effort and have since been in regular contact with all those involved and with the State Department. American officials have praised their work. **********At the time they formed the group, the leaders of the four countries issued a declaration asking the two sides in the Salvadoran negotiations not to introduce elements not previously on the agenda. The Government claimed that was what the guerrillas were doing when they brought up putting some of their people in the army. Cristiani Under Pressure **********For a number of years the guerrilla leaders have claimed that the only way to end the war in El Salvador is to merge what they call the "two armies" -- their forces and the Government's. But the Government contends the rebels did not make that a negotiating point until a few months ago, when they began to speak of their need for "participation" in the army, which the guerrillas said amounted to less than their earlier merger proposal. **********Without using figures, the guerrillas said they wanted to move some of their people into the army at all levels, including officers, and to take part in the selection and training of future cadets. Government officials said this plan still amounted to a merger, by another name, and said the only way former guerrillas could get into the army would be by applying to become cadets. **********Mr. Cristiani is believed to have been under intense pressure from his army not to give any ground on this point, and diplomats working on the negotiations said that left little room to maneuver in trying to draft a plan acceptable to the guerrillas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/busin.main_headline: Bush Is Confident Economy Will Rebound
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/busin.print_headline: Bush Is Confident Economy Will Rebound
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/busin.body_text: **********President Bush, elected on a platform of peace and prosperity only to find himself plunged into war and recession, promised the business community last night that the economy would overcome "temporary disturbances and short-term setbacks." **********"While our economy may be beset by difficulty, it should not be beset by doubt," Mr. Bush told business executives at a dinner of the Economic Club at the New York Hilton in midtown Manhattan. **********In a speech upbeat in tone but short on specifics, Mr. Bush tried to reassure the business community with predictions that "our best days are before us." **********No President wants to take the blame for a recession and Mr. Bush is no exception. He asserted that a slowing American economy had been pushed over the edge into recession by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. Shock of Invasion **********"When Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990, it was a shock to the world's conscience," and business and consumer confidence fell, the President said. **********But in response to questions after his speech Mr. Bush forecast that the recession would be shallow and that "in a couple of quarters, we'll come out of this and we'll have a robust economy." In support of that forecast, he pointed to the recent strong rally in the stock market and said it indicated pessimism was on the decline. **********Mr. Bush's trip to New York was his first visit outside Washington unrelated to the military since the United State-led force attacked Iraq three weeks ago. **********The President arrived at the hotel in a 40-car motorcade from Newark International Airport amid tightened security precautions that included 1,500 plainclothes and uniformed officers guarding his route and sharpshooters positioned on rooftops, the police said. About 3,500 antiwar protesters staged a noisy demonstration outside the hotel and 10 were arrested, but mostly for blocking traffic, the police said. **********In his speech, Mr. Bush acknowledged that the war, the savings and loan crisis and the recession "haven't helped a bit" in controlling the deficit that has burdened the nation.  But he promised that with the bipartisan budget agreement in place, the deficit would be "virtually eliminated" by 1995. **********Mr. Bush said the Administration would also try to spur economic growth by scaling back on "counter-productive" Government regulations, providing incentives to promote private savings and "job-creating investments" and putting Federal money into education, public works and space technology. **********Asked about whether the so-called peace dividend that had been hoped for as the Cold War with the Soviet Union ended could still materialize, the President said defense spending was reduced in the budget he submitted to Congress this week. But he joked that he had been brought up to believe that dividends were paid out of profits, and he noted: "We're operating at a three-hundred-and-some-jillion-dollar deficit, so we're not in exactly a dividend-paying mode." **********The President voiced optimism that the stalled Uruguay round of trade talks would be concluded successfully but he added that both Japan and Germany "have got to give us access to markets." He said he hoped that a victory in the gulf would add to the United States' credibility in those talks and perhaps make Japan and Germany more willing to compromise.  Must Avoid Extreme Measures **********In his speech the President also somewhat defensively continued to reject suggestions, heightened since the war, that he propose conservation measures and strategies to make the country less dependent on foreign oil. **********"Some will argue that reducing our energy vulnerability is not enough, and that we should embark upon more drastic measures designed to achieve total energy independence," he said. "The reality is that we are a long way from total energy independence. We must avoid unwise and extreme measures that would seriously hurt American consumers, American jobs and American industries."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/02/world.main_headline: U.N. Nuclear Agency Submits a Plan for Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/02/world.print_headline: U.N. Nuclear Agency Submits a Plan for Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/02/world.body_text: **********A tough, all-encompassing plan for long-range monitoring of Iraq's nuclear technologu has been submitted to the Security Council by the International Atomic Energy Agency, an arm of the United Nations. **********The plan, a copy of which was obtained today by The New York Times, would give the agency virtually complete control of Iraq's future nuclear development as well as unlimited right of movement within Iraq and across its borders. Diplomats here said the plan called for the most stringent inspection requirements in the United Nations' history. **********Under the long-range plan, Iran would have to supply the agency with inventories of all nuclear materials and installations and notify the agency of any changes in the inventories a month before they are made. **********It would also require complete design information for any planned nuclear installation 180 days before construction begins, as well as all information on changes in Iraq's overall nuclear program one year in advance. It would be required to produce any other information or data the agency says it needs to monitor Iraq's complinace with Security Council Resolution 678, which set terms for a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war. **********The agency would have the right to "full and free" access at any time to "all locations, all persons and all information" it decides is necessary for its verification program. It would have the right to hold unannounced inspections on short notice and would have the right restrict or stop movement of any suspected material and equipment. **********It would have freedom of entry and exit to Iraq "without delay" or the need for visas for people travelling on United Nations documents. It would have the right to install equipment and construct inspection installations; to have its own means of transport and communication and unrestriced use of Iraqi communications systems, and to make fixed-wing and helicopter overflights as needed. **********If approved by the Security Council, the long-range plan would go into effect once the present phase of inspections, verifications and destruction of weapons-quality nuclear materials has ended. The current phase, begun almost immediately after the gulf war ended, is expected to end sometime this fall. **********The duration of the long-range program would be determined by the Security Council, the agency document said. **********The long-range plan is subject to modification, the agency proposal made clear.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/08/world.body_text: **********Eduard A. Shevardnadze, a former Soviet Foreign Minister, said today that he blamed himself partly for the rapid crumbling of the union, saying the republics should have been offered autonomy earlier. **********"Perhaps I, above all, should have understood since I should have known what the nationalism problems might lead to," Mr. Shevardnadze said in a BBC radio interview. **********"Of course I realized we should be resolving certain things more quickly, more decisively," he said. "That perhaps was my mistake. You know, if we'd offered our republics a deal like the new union -- even less than that -- three years ago, they'd have all signed it straight away." **********Mr. Shevardnadze resigned last year saying he feared that a dictatorship was coming and has now joined a reformist movement in Moscow.
