https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/busin.main_headline: Making a Difference; DiMaggio's New Team
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/busin.print_headline: Making a Difference; DiMaggio's New Team
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/busin.body_text: **********Paul Goldin may be an old New York Giants fan -- "It killed me when they moved," he said recently -- but he didn't let sentiment stand in his way 10 days ago when he signed Joe DiMaggio to an exclusive autograph agreement with Score Board Inc., Mr. Goldin's sports and entertainment paraphernalia company. **********The 77-year-old former Yankee joins a roster at Score Board that already includes such legends as Willie Mays, Mickey Mantle, Reggie Jackson, Joe Montana and Wayne Gretzky. For $5 to $25 an item, the athletes sign their names to photographs, baseballs, bats or footballs, which Score Board then sells through catalogues, hobby stores, magazine ads, department stores and television shopping networks. **********Mr. Goldin, a 59-year-old former statistics professor at Drexel University, got started in the business when he and his son, Ken, began to sell baseball cards as a hobby years ago. **********Score Board is riding high on the nearly insatiable American lust for sports. "Anything to do with sports will probably be around for quite a while," said Ronald B. Morrow, a managing director at Smith Barney who tracks baseball card companies. "It's not just a fad that's going to go away." Mr. Morrow said Score Board, as a marketer and distributor, isn't going head-to-head with well-established card manufacturers like Topps and Fleer. **********The four-year-old Score Board, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., had earnings of $2.8 million last year on sales of $33.4 million. It appears regularly on lists of fast-track companies and has watched its stock soar in the last year to $40, from $5. Mr. Goldin expects the two-year agreement with Mr. DiMaggio, struck in the 50th anniversary year of his 56-game hitting streak, to generate about $1 million in profits for Score Board. **********Mr. Goldin is still in business with his son, now 26 and a vice president. Score Board is into some of the lesser -- but very profitable -- sports like wrestling and monster truck racing. And it is tapping into another insatiable American lust: for celebrities. It already has "Star Trek" and Elvis Presley products and is planning to sign up country and western singers and movie stars.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/10/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; The Other Enemies: Fine, Pervasive Sand and Cutting Rocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/10/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; The Other Enemies: Fine, Pervasive Sand and Cutting Rocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/10/world.body_text: **********The sand of the northern Arabian desert, as fine as talcum powder, is becoming a new enemy to allied troops, already plagued by grit-clogged equipment, as they move into their most forward positions in preparation for a ground war. The northern desert is very rocky, too, taking its toll on self-propelled weapons and vehicles. **********The pervasive powder finds its way into weapons, engines and the computers that direct modern warfare, making soldiers and technicians increase maintenance and bringing worries that performance could deteriorate the longer the equipment needs to be used in the desert. **********"It's a nuisance we can do without," Sgt. 1st Class Surender Kotnakota, who is in charge of maintenance for a forward battalion, told pool reporters. "It requires a lot of extra effort to keep things clean. Long term, it could be a serious problem." **********Air filters on trucks must be changed every other day, rather than every 30,000 miles, he said. M-16 rifles, the infantry standard issue, must be stripped and cleaned daily. The ammunition magazines of M-16's have jammed from clogging by sand. **********Against regulations, soldiers are wrapping undershirts around their rifles to protect moving parts. A budding desert fashion of wrapping a scarf around one's head, knotted in the back, is also being discouraged by officers as "Rambo-like." The fine sand has clogged the Army's vehicle transmissions and fuel filters, and rocks have punctured tires. **********Earlier, when troops were first sent to Saudi Arabia, sand began eroding the leading edges of helicopter rotor blades, but the problem was solved by taping the edges with epoxy. **********In the north, where the sand is finer and rises more easily, the epoxy tape must be changed after several hours of flying time. The powdery sand is sucked into helicopter engines. **********"For now, they are performing well," said Lieut. Col. Bill Tucker, the commander of an Army battalion of Apache helicopters used to hunt tanks, adding: **********"It's going to have an effect. You can't put a time or date on it. It wears out moving parts of the engines. The sand collects inside the engine, causes it to get hotter and therefore doesn't produce as much power."  Seder Amid Islam **********The religious practices of the American and other Western troops is a very sensitive subject in Saudi Arabia, where the royal family's political legitimacy rests on its claim to protect Muslim orthodoxy and King Fahd calls himself the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, the most sacred Islamic shrines, in Mecca and Medina. Although the Baathist Government of the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, is officially secular, his propaganda has played on the theme of an aggrieved Islam, threatened by the West and the Jewish state of Israel. **********Nevertheless, kits with materials for the Jewish festival of Passover quietly arrived here this week and are to be distributed in time for the celebration late next month, an Army Protestant chaplain, the Rev. Marc Coker, told pool reporters. **********The kits contain material for the tradtional seder meal, including matzoh, or unleavened bread, and copies of the Haggadah, the book of seder prayers and readings.  Golf in the Gulf **********Just outside the gate of the largest United States air base in Saudi Arabia lies the new pride and joy of Lieut. Col. Mike Townsend, an F-16 fighter-bomber pilot: the nine-hole Desert Fox National golf course he laid out between missons over Iraq and occupied Kuwait. **********Golf in the gulf, of course, has its own hazards. **********Players pick up a doormat-sized piece of Astroturf from Colonel Townsend's tent on the way to the course. After teeing up on it, they carry it around to serve as a patch of fairway for the rest of their approach shots. The whole course is sand. **********"It's a par three, so if you're a good golfer, you can hit the green with one drive from the Astroturf," said Chief Master Sgt. Jim Chumley of the South Carolina Air National Guard. "If not, then you're in the sand trap. Wherever you hit the ball, you're in the sand trap." **********Since the entire course is sand, the actual traps are outlined with sandbags. But here, they are referred to as "SAM traps," for surface-to-air missiles. The two toughest holes are called Mount Suribachi and Pork Chop Hill, named for the sites of grueling victories in World War II and Korea, on small hillocks covered with volcanic rock. The most common complaint is the need to clear the rocks off these holes. The course rules warn players to "use caution for natural inhabitants," presumably referring to Bedouins and camels, but perhaps also to scorpions. **********Not surprisingly, the best score so far belongs to the base doctor.  A Grunt's Glossary **********Further notes from a grunt's glossary, the language of the soldiers in the field: **********L.P.C.'s, or leather personnel carriers: boots. **********Big Red: the desert sun. **********Bolo Badge: the Purple Heart medal given for wounds, especially if they were foolishly acquired. **********B.C.D.'s or Birth Control Devices: the extremely ugly military-issue spectacles. **********Ninja women: black-wrapped Saudi women. **********Echelons beyond reality: command decisions.   Dreading the Triage **********An Army surgeon, Dr. Glenn Trip, worries about the moment he will have to look at a mortally wounded American soldier taken to his base hospital, hope and fear in his eyes, and mark the letter "E" on his forehead with a grease pencil. **********Dr. Trip, a pediatrician in civilian life, was called up with the Reserves and assigned as the triage officer at a medical station that could see thousands of wounded brought in if a ground war grinds on. **********His job is to sort the wounded into three catagories: I for immediate, those with a good chance to live if they are rushed first to surgery; D for delayed, the more lightly wounded who can be bandaged and stabilized and can wait for later treatment, and E for expectant, the most gravely wounded and likely to die, who are set aside until the flow of "immediates" has been cleared up. Any hope of saving the E's could go unfulfilled if hospitals are jammed with casualties. **********Asked what he would say if a patient he has just marked with an E asks him if he is going to make it, Dr. Tripp blinked and took a breath. **********"I don't know what I will say," he replied finally. "I don't know."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/23/world.print_headline: Turner's Wife Taking Gift: The Child He's Never Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/23/world.body_text: **********Four years and nine months after she first tied a yellow ribbon around an apricot tree in the front yard of her modest home here, Estelle Ronneburg, the mother of Jesse Turner, sat in the darkness before dawn today watching images of her only child flickering on the television screen. **********"Oh, it looks wonderful to see him," she said of her son, who was freed by his Lebanese captors on Monday. "It makes it believable to me." **********Her joy and relief at the end of Mr. Turner's 1,731 days of captivity had remained bottled up all Monday by doubts that his release had in fact occurred. **********After the announcement from the United Nations that he was free, Mrs. Ronneburg and her son's wife, Badr Turner, allowed themselves enough belief to begin packing their bags to fly to meet him in Germany today. Joanne, Mr. Turner's 4-year-old daughter, who was born five months after he was seized on Jan. 24, 1987, will meet her father for the first time.Pictures of Her Father **********Mrs. Ronneburg said that her daughter-in-law had shown Joanne pictures of her 44-year-old father and that she was sure the young girl would recognize him, even without the beard he has worn almost all of his adult life until now. **********"I hope she will not be too shy when she meets her daddy," she said. **********For her part, Joanne, who is suffering from a cold, spent much of Monday night drinking hot chocolate and asking reporters when they were finally going to leave her house. **********Mrs. Turner had planned to fly to Lebanon on Wednesday after being invited last week to visit her husband in captivity. The invitation had led Mr. Turner's family to assume that he would not be released.City Plans a Party **********Instead, she spent Monday preparing her small two-bedroom duplex around the corner from her in-laws' home for her husband's return. She straightened the sign next to her husband's picture that reads, "We have not forgotten you, Jesse!" and embraced friends bringing a bottle of champagne she said she would open the night the family returns home. **********"People here are very supportive and kind and caring, and they know how to show their love," Mrs. Turner said of the town that became her home in January. **********Allowing herself a cautious smile, she said: "Of course, I would be happy for any family. But we have been waiting so long and our time is finally coming." **********The city that had held prayer services, celebrated Jesse Turner Day, sent Valentines to his wife and tied yellow ribbons on downtown trees has begun planning what one resident called "a no holds barred" party for Mr. Turner's return. Mayor Dirk Kempthorpe announced that his office would coordinate the celebration. **********Mr. Turner's stepfather, Eugene Ronneburg, a long-haul truck driver, had left home Sunday on a run to Seattle, and flew back to Boise on Monday night in time to have a hot bath and pack for the trip to Germany. **********At the airport this morning, carrying huge bouquets of flowers wrapped in yellow ribbons, the family left on a flight to Chicago as other passengers waved and called out good wishes. From Chicago, they went on to Frankfurt and Weisbaden. Phone Call From Husband **********Late Monday night, reassured by the announcement from the United Nations that he was free and en route to Damascus, the family received a phone call from Tom Cicippio, whose brother Joseph Cicippio remains a hostage. **********"Oh, Tom, we've been wishing so hard that your brother would get released," Mr. Ronneburg told him. "We're hoping they all get released pretty quick." **********Just after 2 A.M. this morning, Mrs. Turner received a brief telephone call from her husband during which she said they exchanged messages of love. **********Asked what she will do when they are finally reunited in Germany, she said, "I will look at his face to see how he is doing and I will look to see how he moves toward his daughter for the first time."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/18/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Traders Defy Forecasts Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/18/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Traders Defy Forecasts Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/18/busin.body_text: **********MANY expected a war to bring panic. Instead, the reaction verged on euphoria. **********Whether that reaction can last is likely to depend largely on the course of war news from Iraq. Yesterday, the markets treated Saddam Hussein as a proven loser, unable even to cause significant damage to Saudi oilfields. **********Such an evaluation is premature, as both President Bush and Prime Minister John Major of Britain emphasized, and as last night's explosions in Israel may have proved. But by the nature of financial markets, those who wait for sober reflection and more facts are left out of the game. **********That may be truer now than ever, with satellite communications making it easy to get much faster battle information. In 1815, Nathan Rothschild reaped enormous profits with advance word, via carrier pigeons, of the British victory at Waterloo; yesterday, everyone from Japanese currency traders to President Bush was getting information from the same television broadcasts. **********Some portion of yesterday's move in markets around the world -- no one can say how much -- came from buying by those who thought they had been playing it safe in advance of a war. Some institutional investors, having husbanded cash because they feared a collapse of prices, felt it necessary to jump into the markets to avoid being left behind. **********But those were not the only buyers. Fidelity reported that its discount brokerage business was double that of a normal day, and that buyers outnumbered sellers two to one. And there was panic buying by speculators who had bet on a price decline in the event of a war, and had to buy quickly to cut their losses. **********The market action provided a classic illustration of the ability of markets to confound forecasts, and of the danger of relying on consensus predictions of market movement. **********For months, as prices deteriorated in world stock markets after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, the common expectation was that the start of shooting involving the United States would drive the prices of stocks and bonds down, while giving an immediate lift to quotes for the dollar, gold and oil. **********There was, in fact, a whiff of panic selling yesterday. Oil prices shot up in after-hours trading just after the first word of war, and in Japan, where stock trading began shortly after the attack, prices plunged quickly, and the Nikkei 225 index was soon down 1.5 percent for the day. **********But as word spread of the apparently overwhelming success of the bombing attacks, the market perceptions turned. Suddenly, the biggest risk to oil traders was of being caught with excess inventories as an oil glut -- brought on by the return of Iraqi and Kuwaiti production -- sent oil prices plunging. And that was good news for bonds, where prices soared, and bad news for the dollar and gold, both of which had attracted buyers as havens in times of crisis. **********As measured by stock prices, the wave of enthusiasm seemed to peak in New York in the morning, after propelling prices steadily up during the trading days in Japan and Europe. The Nikkei 225 ended Thursday with a gain of 4.5 percent -- a 6 percent swing in prices from the daily low. European markets opened higher, slipped a bit, then rose to new highs near their closing times. **********In New York, the initial wave of buying sent prices soaring in the opening minutes, but without much in the way of follow-through until late in the afternoon. **********The easiest way to bet for or against a big rise in stock prices is to play stock index futures, and it was there that the most intense speculation -- and short-covering -- took place yesterday morning. The March futures contracts on the Standard & Poor's 500 were delayed in opening by a circuit breaker meant to limit big moves. But when they did open they went wild, soaring 5.3 percent from the close the day before. **********That rise, pushing the contract from Wednesday's 318.50 to 335.00, came while the actual stock market was struggling to open many stocks amid cascades of buy orders. Because actual market indexes treat stocks that have not opened as still being at the prior day's prices, the reported figures for the actual indexes did not rise to such levels. **********But in fact, that was the high for the day. The futures contract fell to below 327 by late morning, then moved up gradually until spurting in late afternoon to close at 332. Such stocks as Eastman Kodak, Alcoa and AMR, the parent of American Airlines, all hit their highs for the day when they opened. **********That late afternoon rally, which propelled the Dow Jones industrial average to a gain of 114.60 points, or 4.6 percent, to 2,623.52, reflected in part the plunges in gold, down $30 an ounce, and oil, down more than $10 a barrel, which continued through the day. It also reflected the new belief that it is a bigger risk to be left out of the stock market when good news arrives than to be in it when bad news comes. **********That sentiment was also shown by the fact that the futures contract closed well above the actual S.& P. 500, which ended the day at 327.97. **********"People are deadly afraid to be left out of the market," said a trader for one major Wall Street firm as the day ended. With evidence that Iraq still has some firepower left, that may change.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/world.main_headline: Aligarh Journal; Campus Under Fire: Not Just a Crisis of Identity
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/world.print_headline: Aligarh Journal; Campus Under Fire: Not Just a Crisis of Identity
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/world.body_text: **********At Aligarh Muslim University, an island of uneasy calm in a storm of Hindu-Muslim violence that killed scores of people in this city in December, a concerned faculty is challenging religious bigotry and political opportunism where they believe it must be fought: in Government offices and the courts. **********Professors and administrators use strong language to describe the situation they face, asserting that "fascism" has entered Indian politics in the name of religion. **********Since Hindu militants began trying on Oct. 30 to build a temple on the site of a mosque in Ayodhya, at the other end of Uttar Pradesh, a state with a large Islamic minority, Muslims here have developed an "identity crisis," a political scientist said. **********Aligarh Muslim University, one of India's oldest educational insitutions, narrowly escaped disaster when false newspaper reports sought to drag its teaching hospital into confrontation with Hindu militants by charging that 78 Hindu patients and attendants had been killed there. Riots broke out in half a dozen cities as the reports spread around the state. Local Government Decision **********At the same time, local government officials decided to close the university and send home its 18,000 students, 60 to 70 percent of whom are Muslims. **********At that point, Naseem Farooqi, an electronics engineer who recently became the university's vice chancellor, drew the line. **********"This university has very high secular traditions," he said in an interview. **********"There was no trouble in the university at all," he said. "All around us, people were being pulled off trains and killed, pulled off buses and killed. My concern was, where do I send all these students? The local government does not have the power to close a university. That power rests with the vice chancellor and the central Government." **********On this procedural challenge, local officials backed down. But not before India's Government-run television network had broadcast an announcement that the university had been shut. Panicky parents called from all over India and abroad. Preparing a Suit **********Mr. Farooqi, the equivalent of a college president, who spent 40 of his first 70 days in office working under curfew, lodged a complaint with the Press Council of India against a local Hindi-language newspaper, and is ready to sue it and others for publishing false reports about the medical center, the Jawaharlal Nehru Medical College Hospital. **********The vice chancellor added that the reports were circulated to deflect attention from the deaths of Muslims at the hands of Hindu mobs. **********"On the 8th of December, the Gomti Express train was stopped near Aligarh and a number of people were killed," he said. "To cover up that story, a local newspaper, in typically fascist style, said that 74 people had died in our hospital. The assumption was that they were Hindus. This was a totally false story. We checked out every patient." Problems at Hospital **********At the hospital, Dr. S. Badrul Hasan, the medical superintendant, said problems are continuing. He quotes Indian Supreme Court decisions to support his appeal to the city administration to lift restrictions on his ambulances. In Aligarh, emergency services and hospital care have become segregated, and the wounded suffer. **********Dr. Hasan said he cannot respond to emergency calls -- many from Muslims, who are still the victims of random stabbings and shootings -- without local government permission. Hindus are going to the district government hospital. Dr. Hasan called in a limping ambulance driver who, he said, had been beaten by state police as he tried to pick up victims. **********'You just cannot assault an ambulance driver," Dr. Hasan said. "You can stop him. You can check him. You can arrest him. But you don't assault him." Documenting in 3 Languages **********In her garden, Abida Sami Uddin, a political science professor, discussed her methodical translations of all reporting on the recent violence, which has now abated. She plans to document, in three languages -- Hindi, Urdu and English -- the role played by the local press in fanning violence. **********Her husband, Sami Uddin, the university dean, is spending 20 hours a day, from 6 A.M. until 2 A.M. the next morning, patrolling the campus, now guarded by paramilitaries from the Central Reserve Police Force. **********The Central Reserve Police, criticized in Kashmir and Punjab, are welcomed here by Muslims, who save their most serious charges for the state's Provincial Armed Constabulary, which many accuse of being Hindu militants in police clothes. **********At his office, under a portrait of Mohandas K. Gandhi, an advocate of nonviolence and religious harmony, a new Senior Superintendent of Police, D. N. Samal, unambiguously supported the Muslim view that politicians using religion to build "vote banks" were more often than not at the root of violence here. 2 Journalists Arrested **********Mr. Samal has arrested two journalists for inciting tensions, and he acknowledges that here and everywhere in India, more Muslims than Hindus have died. He says he has singled out the troublemakers -- "outsiders" -- and will take action "in a planned manner." **********"People here are not criminal," he said. "But that instinct often comes out in a mob situation. People who would not normally want to touch a knife or gun, will pelt stones and throw bombs when the mass psychology takes over." **********"People in Aligarh have lived together, Hindu and Muslim, for many years," Mr. Samal said. "They will live together again."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/14/world.main_headline: Flying Eye Hospital Uses Tact to Reach Cuba
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/14/world.print_headline: Flying Eye Hospital Uses Tact to Reach Cuba
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/14/world.body_text: **********Stepping briskly from his sleek white DC-8 aircraft, Oliver Foot, director of Project Orbis, the flying eye hospital, immediately sought to put a receiving line of Cuban doctors and Government officials at ease. **********Bringing relieved smiles to the faces of his hosts, Mr. Foot told them, "We are coming to Cuba to share knowledge and to learn from each other so that what we learn can be disseminated around the world." **********Although in their travels Orbis doctors often emphasize that they learn even as they teach, for an increasingly isolated Cuba the remarks were seen as a vital statement of mutual respect without which the rare humanitarian mission would have risked a sputtering start. **********Cuba's universal health care system, whose quality in many ways rivals that of more highly industrialized countries, remains one of the proudest hallmarks of a Communist system that is locked in an economic decline. **********For Orbis, negotiating such Cuban sensitivities was merely one of a host of challenges in a three-week mission beginning in mid-June that broke modest new ground in bilateral ties while serving as a reminder of the frosty diplomatic and political void that has kept Cuba at least at arm's length from the United States. **********"We were in China just after Tiananmen Square, and the Soviet Union well before glasnost, but this was arguably the hardest trip of all for us to pull off," said Mr. Foot, who has helped organize visits to some 60 countries since joining the eye foundation in 1982. **********Because of the United States' 30-year economic embargo of Cuba, and an equally long tradition of mutual ideological hostility, exchanges between the two countries have long been largely limited to family visits and occasional study trips by academics.Because it is a nonprofit medical charity that is broadly international in its membership and fund raising, Orbis had hoped it would have little trouble breeching the gulf between the two countries. **********But as the tentatively scheduled date for the visit approached, frosty Cuban-American realities quickly began to encroach on the foundation's plans. Although Cuban eye specialists had long agreed on the desirability of a visit by the flying hospital, a Government invitation failed to materialize, perhaps another reflection of Havana's reluctance to be seen as wanting in health. **********To expedite things, Mr. Foot enlisted the help of the former Canadian Prime Minister, Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who personally reached President Fidel Castro to promote the visit. **********With the Cuban invitation in hand, Mr. Foot said he called the State Department a month before the departure date to make a routine inquiry into travel security in Cuba and was told "security is fine, but Treasury regulations won't allow you to go." Positive Aspects Highlighted **********The next month was spent wrangling with the Treasury Department, which, citing the potential monetary value of medical techniques, declined to give it a special exemption from the ban on economic exchanges with Havana. **********Finally, with quiet support from the State Department and a pledge to spend only monies raised by the foundation's offices in London and Hong Kong, the trip was approved. **********Once on the ground, Orbis doctors, perhaps sensing the delicacy of the situation, repeatedly highlighted the positive aspects of Cuban care, even as they privately noted some of its deficiencies. **********"The cases presented to me would have been difficult ones in any clinic in the world," said Dr. Forrest Ellis, a pediatric ophthalmologist from the University of Indiana, after surgically correcting an eye muscle in a 6-year-old girl that his Cuban counterparts thought was congenitally absent. **********Cuban health-care professionals, who worked side by side with their American counterparts, seemed delighted by the exchange. **********"Who cares who is the most sophisticated or the most advanced," said Anna Remon, a 40-year-old ophthalmological nurse who assisted in Dr. Ellis's operation. "Our cooperation seems to have helped this little girl, and that is what matters."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister John Major of Britain met with Chancellor Helmut Kohl here today, and afterward both leaders stressed their friendship and common policy goals. **********It was Mr. Major's first visit to Bonn since he took office in November, and comes at a time of strain in British-German relations. Some British politicians and commentators have accused Germany of not contributing fully or enthusiastically enough to the anti-Iraq coalition. **********Mr. Major thanked Germany for its "very generous" $690 million contribution to the British war effort. **********Mr. Kohl refused to commit himself to further contributions, but promised to consider any future requests. **********"We Germans, and the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany, stand fully and completely at the side of our friends in the gulf," the Chancellor said. He described relations between Bonn and London as "close and friendly." **********In the weeks since war broke out, Britons have accused Germany of failing to supply aircraft parts expeditiously, restricting low-altitude training flights by allied pilots, and other failings. Mr. Major did not refer to any of those disputes. **********"There is no difference in our assessment and objective as far as the gulf is concerned," he told reporters after his two-hour session with Mr. Kohl.

Each A.D.R. will represent one-eighth of a class B share.
