https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/22/busin.body_text: **********The Meredith Corporation, a publisher and broadcaster, reported sharply lower earnings today for its first fiscal quarter compared with results a year ago that included a big gain on the sale of assets. **********Earnings from continuing operations were also down sharply because of the effect of the nationwide slump in advertising spending. **********Meredith said it had earned $2.8 million, or 17 cents a share, in the three months that ended on Sept. 30, down 95.4 percent from $60.9 million, or $3.62 a share, in the comparable period last year. **********The 1990 results included $52 million in income and a gain on the sale of its printing operations. Last year's results also included a pretax gain of $5.9 million on the sale of Sail magazine. **********Income from continuing operations of $2.8 million was down 68.5 percent from $8.9 million. **********Meredith's revenues slipped 5.2 percent, to $170 million from $179.4 million. **********Meredith publishes Better Homes and Gardens and The Ladies' Home Journal magazines and has a custom publishing arm. It owns seven television stations and has a residential real estate marketing and franchising operation. **********The company's stock fell 25 cents on the New York Stock Exchange today, to $26.75.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/28/busin.main_headline: War Reports May Provide A Springboard for Profits
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/28/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: TELEVISION; War Reports May Provide A Springboard for Profits
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/28/busin.body_text: **********EVEN with the costs of covering the Persian Gulf war piling up alarmingly for the network news divisions, there may be a light at the end of the tunnel. The light reads: "On the Air." **********The gulf war is proving to be exceptionally good television programming. Despite the ongoing decline in network audiences, people are watching this war. If they continue to watch news programs after it ends, the war may turn out to be a springboard for some long-term profits for the network news divisions. **********"Nightline" on ABC is the prototype of a network newscast that grew from crisis coverage into an established program. Born as a nightly recap of events after American hostages were seized in Iran in 1979 (and originally labled "America Held Hostage") "Nightline" quickly became an institution, generating both profits and enormous prestige for ABC News over the last decade. **********The "Nightline" precedent is clearly on the minds of some network news executives as they add programming to cover the gulf war. **********The war is costing each of the broadcast networks an average of about $1.5 million a week. Some days the price has run much higher, depending on how much satellite time the networks have to pay for. **********And the tab is still running. The prospect of a long war has sent shock waves through the network financial offices. The year has already been a dismal one as the networks struggle through a slump in advertising sales and a prime-time season without a new hit series. **********But the three networks -- as well as CNN -- have all realized substantial ratings gains for programs covering the war during its first 10 days. More significantly, some news programs that have been able to take advantage of the high interest in the war could eventually survive its end and thrive as ongoing profit centers. **********For CNN, the chance to capitalize on the war interest may come right away. The prime-time national ratings for CNN in the first week has ranged from 5 to 11.7. That is an enormous improvement over the average CNN prime-time rating of 0.7 (Each rating point represents 931,000 homes.) **********But each of the broadcast network news divisions has reason to hope to gain something as well from the intense interest in the gulf war. **********ABC hopes to continue the increasing superiority it exhibited in all of its news programs during the first week of the war. CBS hopes to capitalize on the improved recognition for its morning news program and the reprieve for its late-night news program, which was to be canceled. **********And NBC has the most to gain. If the network can successfully transfer the audience watching its news programs during the war into regular viewers after the war has ended, NBC could achieve a long-elusive goal: making its news division profitable. **********Both ABC News and CBS News were making money before the war, largely because of the amount of weekly programming those news divisions produce. NBC News has never been able to establish a successful prime-time series. **********But its latest effort, a half-hour Sunday night program called "Expose," has gotten off to an auspicious start. Last week, the program had a 10.8 rating in a time period where NBC had trouble getting a 7 rating earlier this season. Part of the reason: "Expose" offered fresh reporting on the gulf war. **********This week, NBC News will begin a new daytime series, "A Closer Look." Though the intention of the series is to run reports of interest to women, this week it will concentrate on war-related topics. If that helps the series establish itself, NBC News will have found another profitable outlet. **********Certainly, the main growth that NBC would like to see from the war coverage is a permanent extension of its evening newscast from half an hour to an hour. Even before the war began, NBC announced that it would expand its newscast to cover war-related stories. The network's executives openly hoped to find a way to make the expansion permanent. **********Local stations have long opposed any network news expansion because it would eat into their programming time. So realistically, NBC executives admit that a permanent hourlong newscast remains a long shot. But the longer newscast will be broadcast indefinitely as the war goes on. **********CBS has a more exact parallel to the "Nightline" precedent at work. The late-night CBS News program, "America Tonight," was originally scheduled as a stopgap program to fill the 11:30 P.M. time period until the entertainment division had some action shows to put there. "America Tonight" was officially canceled just before the war started. **********But the network rescinded the cancellation to allow the news division more air time to cover the war. Now, "America Tonight" is thriving on its war coverage. Last week, in the overnight ratings for the country's 25 largest markets, the program was up a full ratings point, to 4.7, from the week before the war started. **********"That sort of improvement augurs extremely well for this show," said Howard Stringer, the president of the CBS Broadcast Group. He said the low cost of "America Tonight" would make it a "major profit center with ratings like that." **********CBS is also encouraged by the higher ratings last week for "CBS This Morning," which has long been the weakest of the network morning programs. **********ABC, however, has taken the most advantage of interest in war reports. The ABC evening newscast had its highest rating ever in the war's first week. And the ratings of "Nightline," now an hourlong program, grew more than two ratings points. The ABC magazine program "Prime Time Live" was also up substantially in the ratings. **********If ABC holds on to a percentage of the additional viewers, it may be able to translate them into higher revenues -- as long as advertisers come out of the war more enthusisatic than when they entered it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/05/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; TURKEY IS KEEPING FRONTIERS CLOSED
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/05/world.body_text: **********Despite growing international and domestic pressure to let in a flood of Kurdish refugees from northern Iraq, Turkey insisted today that it did not have the resources to deal with a mass migration and would keep its borders closed. **********While Turkish officials report that several hundred thousand Iraqi Kurds are trying to escape the Iraqi Army by fleeing into Turkey, fewer than 10,000 people were said to have managed to find sanctuary in a string of Turkish border towns about 200 miles east of this regional capital. **********The semi-official Anatolian News Agency reported that as many as 80,000 other Kurds were technically inside Turkish territory, but were right at the border and were being held there by security forces. **********"We are taking measures to make mass entries more difficult," said Murat Sungar, chief spokesman for the Foreign Ministry in Ankara. Aid Sent to Refugees **********Nevertheless, the Turks tried to maintain a flow of food, medicine and blankets for the refugees, in some instances by hauling material on mules because the roads could not support cars or trucks. Some aid was donated by Britain, France and the German Red Cross. **********In Hakkari, a border town about 300 miles east of Diyarbakir, at least 35 Kurds were reported to have undergone emergency surgery, including more than half a dozen who needed leg amputations after having stepped on land mines on their trek into Turkey as they fled revenge-minded troops of President Saddam Hussein who have recaptured northern zones from Kurdish rebels. **********"This is a kind of genocide," President Turgut Ozal told the British network, ITN. Turkish officials have said that more than 200,000 Iraqi Kurds are gathered across the border and are "in mortal danger." Mr. Ozal predicted that the number could climb to as much as 600,000 in the next 10 days. **********In addition to calls from abroad for Turkey to ease its no-entry stand, Turkish opposition figures, including some members of Parliament who are Kurds themselves, made similar pleas. Former Prime Minister Suleyman Demirel, leader of the opposition True Path Party, warned, "Turkey cannot stay idle before Saddam's massacre."  Balancing on Fine Line **********Turkey is trying to keep its balance as it draws a fine line in its refusal to permit a wholesale influx of the Iraqi Kurds. **********On the one hand, Turkish officials acknowledge that the Kurds' situation is grave, and they recognize that they would be vulnerable to widespread condemnation if refugees were slaughtered by Iraqi troops while knocking vainly on Turkey's door. **********On the other hand, the Turks insist that they have neither the money nor the means to absorb so many displaced people all of a sudden, and they have asked the United Nations for help. Foreign Minister Ahmed Kurtcebe Alptemocin warned that a sudden migration of this magnitude would "threaten our social and economic security." **********Mr. Ozal went even further in the British television interview, challenging Europe to take in refugees, too, instead of asking Turkey to shoulder the entire burden. **********"I ask the European countries: You should take half, and I will get the other half," he said. "Will you accept that?"  1988 Experience Recalled **********Turkish officials are still bitter about their last experience with a large migration of Iraqi Kurds, in 1988, when more than 60,000 people poured into Turkey claiming that their villages had been attacked by Iraqi soldiers using chemical weapons. The Turks complained that Western Europe did little to help then, and instead rebuked Turkey repeatedly for supposedly not giving the refugees adequate shelter. Even Turkish human-rights campaigners, who normally are quick to protest the mistreatment of Turkish Kurds, criticized Europe for having been longer on talk than action in this matter. **********In the meantime, Turkey continues to shelter 27,000 of the 1988 refugees, who are housed at camps outside Diyarbakir and Kiziltepe, near the border with Syria. **********Bulent Akarcali, a member of Parliament from the governing Motherland Party, typified the Turkish resentment when he predicted that the next few months would go like this: **********"Ankara will open its doors to the refugees. These refugees will say how much they love Turkey during their first week here. The West will also praise Turkey. Then the Council of Europe and many countries will start talking about poor conditions, and international organizations will ignore the issue and not help Turkey." **********In conversations with Turkish reporters, Foreign Ministry officials and military commanders accused Iraq of a campaign to push an unwanted ethnic group outside its borders. Some suggested that Iraqi leaders were also deliberately trying to put a strain on Turkey as revenge for Ankara's role in the anti-Iraq coalition during the Persian Gulf crisis. **********A respected daily newspaper, Milliyet, quoted an unidentified Cabinet minister as saying Turkey reserved the right to intervene militarily if the Iraqis continue to drive the Kurds to the border. Mr. Alptemocin said in Parliament on Wednesday that "our southeastern frontier is under threat." **********"There is mortar fire on those people coming from Iraq," he said. Some 20 shells dropped in our territory." **********Speaking with Turkish reporters, the Iraqi Ambassador in Ankara denied that his country had any intention of harming Turkey. But the Ambassador, Rafi Micvel el-Tikriti, said Iraqi forces were fully justified in pressing their campaign against the Kurds. "Nobody should expect that we would offer a flower to our enemies," he said. **********Iran says that up to a million and a half Iraqi Kurds are headed its way. But that figure, like those offered by the Turks, is difficult to confirm. **********In the 1988 migration, initial estimates of refugees proved to be highly inflated, although the real numbers -- 60,000 in Turkey's case -- were large enough.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/22/busin.main_headline: Regulators Are Faulted in Problems of Big Insurer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/22/busin.print_headline: Regulators Are Faulted in Problems of Big Insurer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/22/busin.body_text: **********As California and New York officials try to assess the possible financial losses facing customers of the Executive Life Insurance Company, many government officials, analysts and consumer groups blame weak regulation for not preventing the insurer's financial problems. **********The insurance industry has historically been regulated by the states. Critics of the system say state regulators and legislators did little to rein in Executive Life as it amassed a huge portfolio of "junk bonds." **********The critics say the Executive Life situation also exposes weaknesses in the system. They contend regulators and politicians in too many states are susceptible to lobbying by the industry. They also say the system facilitates the wishes of insurers more than it protects consumers and that regulators have been too willing to handle problems in private. New York Is Praised **********The criticism extends to most states, though New York is often cited as the state that did the most to crack down on Executive Life. California, the home of both Executive Life and its parent, the First Executive Corporation, is often singled out as the state that did the least. **********In a speech here last week, John Garamendi, who took office in January as California's first elected Insurance Commissioner, said that during the 1980's, California's Insurance Department "just turned its back" on First Executive. Mr. Garamendi has long been critical of Roxani Gillespie, who was California's appointed insurance commissioner through the latter half of the last decade. **********Harvey Rosenfield, chairman of Voter Revolt, a self-styled consumer advocacy group in Los Angeles, compared the performance of insurance regulators to that of savings and loan regulators in the years leading up to the crisis in that industry. **********"And just as in the S.& L. debacle, the insurance regulators who were supposed to protect the public from this kind of disaster failed to do so," Mr. Rosenfield said. **********Current and past state regulators, including Ms. Gillespie, defended their approach, saying they had been taking steps to monitor First Executive closely for more than a year and that even today Executive Life has not technically been found insolvent. **********Regulators in California seized control of Executive Life this month because of the weakening condition of its junk bonds and a deluge of customers seeking to cash in policies, a process similar to a run on a bank. Last week, regulators in New York seized a smaller subsidiary, the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, for the same reasons. **********It remains unclear whether Executive Life's customers face losses. The New York subsidiary is considered to be in stronger condition, and New York regulators said they believed that none of the New York company's customers will have losses. Congressional Action **********Industry executives and analysts say they expect new Congressional hearings on the regulation of the insurance industry and that Federal oversight is a possibility. Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, is drafting legislation that would give added power to Washington. **********Executive Life's demise is likely to hasten changes at the state level as well. **********Some states are likely to follow New York in developing tougher regulations. Starting in 1985, New York enacted a series of rules, including one limiting junk bond holdings, that allowed it to keep Executive Life of New York on a tight leash. **********Legislation was introduced in the California Assembly last year that would have limited an insurer's junk bond holdings to 20 percent of its assets -- the same as in New York. The measure failed after heavy lobbying by First Executive, despite the well-publicized troubles with the insurer's portfolio. Legislators say the prospects for tighter regulatory restrictions on junk bonds and other issues have improved. Trenton Tries Strong Steps **********State regulators have increasingly split over the best way to handle troubled insurers. Last fall, the New Jersey Insurance Department became concerned about Executive Life. Breaking with other state insurance departments, which had been urging low-key, coordinated action, New Jersey in December demanded that Executive Life put up a $500 million deposit to guarantee that it could pay all obligations to customers in the state. **********In an action that was widely criticized by consumer groups, The National Association of Insurance Commissioners promptly passed a resolution condemning New Jersey's action, stating that Executive Life and Executive Life of New York "are in no imminent financial danger." **********New Jersey subsequently dropped its demand for the deposit in return for Executive Life's agreeing not to sell more policies in the state. **********Larry Gorski, an Illinois Insurance Department official who helped to draft the association's position on Executive Life, said the group's assessment was based on extensive studies of the insurer's finances and its ability to meet its obligations. **********But Joseph M. Belth, professor of insurance at Indiana University and editor of the Insurance Forum newsletter, said the regulators' association might have erred in failing to consider the sequence of events that eventually led to the seizure of Executive Life: that the possibility of the parent company's bankruptcy would lead to a surge in policy surrenders and withdrawals by customers of its operating subsidiaries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/busin.main_headline: Role of Taxes Debated in Adding to Income Gap
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/busin.print_headline: Role of Taxes Debated in Adding to Income Gap
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/busin.body_text: **********Federal tax policy contributed to the widening gap between the wealth of rich and poor Americans in the 1980's, a group of experts told the Senate Budget Committee today, but they disagreed on how great a role other economic factors played in the inequity. **********There was near unanimity that, as the committee chairman, Jim Sasser of Tennessee, put it, the 80's were "the decade when the rich got richer and the poor got poorer." **********Robert McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a coalition of labor, public interest and community groups, said "huge tax breaks" for wealthy Americans had stimulated "gross overconsumption" by that sector of society. At the same time, he said, lower-income families were facing increased tax burdens because Social Security taxes were raised and because states had to raise sales taxes and other taxes to make up for reduced Federal aid.  A Conservative Viewpoint **********A contrary view was expressed by Marvin H. Kosters, an economist with the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research and policy group here. Mr. Kosters said tax policy might have had some effect on the distribution of income, but it was a relatively minor element. The chief factor for the change, he said, was the widening gap between the wages paid to skilled, educated workers and their unskilled, uneducated counterparts. **********An important way to close the gap, he said, would be to improve the education and training of unskilled workers. Tax policies that aim at redistributing income, he said, "are more likely to impair human-capital investment and income growth." **********Gary Burtless, a senior fellow of the Brookings Institution, said economic and demographic developments, including the declining demand for unskilled labor and the growing number of single-parent families, "were far more important than direct Government policy in explaining the swelling incomes of the affluent and the shrinking wages of the less skilled."   The Role of Government **********But he added, "Even if the role of Government was smaller than sometimes suggested in the press or Congress, I regard it as scandalous that Government policy should have played any role at all in making the matter worse." **********Mr. Burtless, too, urged that unskilled workers get more and better training and that schools provide more help to students who are not bound for college. **********He also said he thought the issue of income distribution should be directly addressed by reducing Government transfers of income to the wealthy, like Social Security and Medicare payments. He proposed taxing such benefits once they exceeded the payroll contributions made by the recipient.  Data on Average Family **********Senator Sasser said the net worth of the average American family, adjusted for inflation, declined by 3.4 percent between 1984 and 1988, while the richest 20 percent of households saw a 14 percent increase in wealth during the period. **********He also cited data showing that the real hourly earnings of the average worker had declined 4 percent since 1982. He added, "That's 4 percent below the low point of the 1982 recession -- the deepest postwar recession we've seen." **********Mr. Sasser said the income disparity was reflected in tax trends during the decade. The wealthiest 1 percent of Americans, he said, pay a tax rate that is 9 percent below the rate paid 10 years ago because of "the supply-side tax cuts of the 1980's." **********"By contrast," he said, "tax rates for 60 percent of Americans have increased." **********Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, expressed skepticism about the disparity of wealth in the United States, saying that the 1980's had been a time of general prosperity for the nation. **********"If you torture numbers long enough they will tell you anything," he said, challenging the statistics.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/17/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasuries Down in Slow Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/17/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities moved lower at the end of a slow session yesterday, as dealers continued what has become a lengthy process of distributing notes and bonds purchased at last week's refunding auctions and digested reports that provided little new economic insight. **********A report showing that housing starts rose by 6.2 percent in April was counterbalanced by Labor Department data showing that initial unemployment claims rose slightly in the week that ended on May 4. **********"The market got the kind of numbers it expected," said Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. **********"We have had a lot of numbers this week, and they haven't changed many minds," Mr. Johnson added. "They say that, yes, there is a recovery coming, but it isn't going to be very snappy."  Looking to Next Auctions **********With little additional economic news expected for at least a week, dealers said the focus had turned to auctions next week of short- to intermediate-term notes. **********"The big story right now is how the short end of the curve will do in the face of overwhelming supply," a government bond trader said. "The market seems to imply that it can handle it, but it remains to be seen." **********With the target for the overnight Federal funds rate likely to stay at 5 3/4 percent, analysts said, there seems to be little reason to expect short-term interest rates to rise much. **********In the secondary market for Treasury notes and bills, the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at a price of 100 9/32 late yesterday, down by 2/32, to yield 6.84 percent. And the 7 5/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 13/32, down by 3/32, to yield 7.77 percent.  Short-Term Rates Mixed **********Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed. **********By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.39 percent, down by 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged, at a late-offered rate of 5.57 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by 2 basis points, to a late-offered rate of 5.75 percent. **********Among longer-term maturities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 97 23/32 in late trading, down by 3/32, to yield 8.33 percent, a yield that was unchanged from late Wednesday. **********Meanwhile, the 8 percent 10-year Treasury notes were offered at 99 5/ 32, down by 2/32, to yield 8.12 percent. **********A number of new issues were priced in the investment-grade corporate bond market, including $500 million in 30-year subordinated notes issued by the Barclays Bank N.A. Capital Corporation. **********The 9 3/4 percent notes, which are noncallable for 10 years, were priced at $99.70, to yield 9.781 percent, or 1.45 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing. **********Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated AA-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.  Light Secondary Activity **********In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said prices of most issues were unchanged in very slow trading. **********Activity was also sluggish in the secondary market for municipal bonds, participants said. **********The prices of most widely quoted tax-exempt issues were unchanged on the day. **********In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose strongly in the week that ended on May 6. **********The growth was much stronger than analysts had been projecting, and all but erased the sizable declines that had been reported for the last two weeks. **********Despite the strong rebound, the money report had little effect on prices in the credit markets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.main_headline: Investment Firm Head Widens Insurance Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Investment Firm Head Widens Insurance Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.body_text: **********Donald H. Rundlett has always liked the insurance industry. And with the decision of the firm he heads, Private Capital Partners Inc., to rescue the healthy life insurance subsidiary of the troubled Monarch Capital Corporation, he has thrust himself into the industry's spotlight. **********Mr. Rundlett, who has worked as a broker, a commercial banker and an investment banker, is the chairman and chief executive of Private Capital, in Purchase, N.Y.. The private investment banking group said late Monday that it was forming the Old Bay State Life Insurance Company to acquire the stock of the Monarch Life Insurance Company of Springlfield, Mass. **********Mr. Rundlett, 55 years old, works with five other partners who all have connections throughout Wall Street from their previous jobs. The firm has been developing an extensive business in the insurance industry since it was formed in 1985, having underwritten a number of insurance companies and reinsurance companies. "It's an industry we know and like," Mr. Rundlett said yesterday. **********The decision to purchase Monarch in some ways came backwards. The firm began to look for a insurance company last spring when David Whitt, the former chief executive of Beneficial Standard Life of California, came to Private Partners after the insurance company he had turned around had been sold. **********Mr. Whitt "came to us and talked to us about finding a company for him to head," Mr. Rundlett said. Because of Mr. Whitt's success in the business, Private Capital began searching last spring for a company for the executive to take control of. **********With the default of Monarch Capital on a $235 million loan, the firm found its company in Monarch's insurance subsidiary. The subsidiary was seized last week after the default because of fears among Massachusetts insurance regulators that banks could force Monarch Capital into bankruptcy. **********Mr. Whitt, 55, will serve as the head of the newly formed company. **********"We think Monarch Life Insurance offers us a superb opportunity," Mr. Rundlett said. It is one of the best brands in the industry. We think this company can be a very, very attractive investment opportunity in the years ahead." **********Mr. Rundlett has a long history of looking for financial opportunities. He came to Wall Street in 1962 as a broker with Merrill Lynch & Company, and in the intervening years joined White, Weld & Company and Citibank in senior positions. In 1981, he rejoined Merrill as chairman and president of a private bank at the firm.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Texscan Trail Leads to Firm
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Texscan Trail Leads to Firm
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/busin.body_text: **********THE extraordinary rise in the price of the Texscan Corporation's stock last week, which led the Securities and Exchange Commission to halt trading in the shares on Monday, appears to have been prompted by a strong recommendation of the stock by a Florida public relations firm. **********The recommendation came from the Payne Financial Group of Fort Lauderdale, run by Thomas Payne. "He distributed public reports to a number of brokers," said Allen Lerner, Mr. Payne's lawyer, referring to the company's annual and quarterly reports to shareholders. "Evidently they agreed and went along with the recommendations." **********In an interview, Mr. Payne said he had not been retained by Texscan. He did not identify any clients who were interested in the company. **********The share price of Texscan, a supplier to the cable television industry, leaped $2.875, to $8, in the final four days of trading last week, as more than a quarter of the shares in public hands were traded on the American Stock Exchange. **********On Monday, the S.E.C. halted trading for two weeks, saying it suspected the stock's rise might have been "the result of manipulative conduct or other illegal activity." **********Although S.E.C. officials would not discuss the agency's action, stock traders said yesterday that it appeared the S.E.C. had acted because of repors that inside information might have been circulating among investors. **********That information concerned a report by First Boston, prepared for the Texscan board earlier this year when the company's management was considering whether to attempt a buyout. One person interviewed by the S.E.C. said commission officials had brought up that report. **********In the interview, Mr. Payne said he had not seen the First Boston report, which was never made public, but had heard rumors about it. His lawyer, Mr. Lerner, said he had heard rumors that the report concluded that the stock was worth $12 a share, in part because of large tax-loss carryforwards the company had after emerging from bankruptcy in 1987. **********William H. Lambert, the company's chairman, said the First Boston report had not been made public, but he said the report concluded that the stock was worth "significantly below" $12 a share. **********He said the report had been distributed only to the board members of the company, its lawyer and its chief financial officer. **********Under S.E.C. rules, such documents can normally be kept confidential, but it would be illegal for an insider to trade a company's stock while in possession of material non-public information. **********Mr. Lambert said that no member of the board had bought stock since the report was presented, but that one director, whom he declined to name, had sold 10,000 shares last week while the price was rising. **********Mr. Payne said he had personally bought some shares of Texscan, but had not sold any. He said that he had clients who paid him for information but that he also provided information to brokers who did not pay him. Utilities and Interest Rates **********Are the utility stocks sounding a warning on interest rates? **********Since peaking a week ago yesterday at 220.89, the Dow Jones utility average has fallen 5.2 percent, to 209.51, arousing some concerns because its performance has been much worse than those of most other stock indexes. The Dow industrials have slipped 1.9 percent over the week, and the Standard & Poor's 500 is down 1.5 percent. **********Over time, the Dow utilities have gained a reputation as a forecaster of trends in interest rates. Utilities are vulnerable to those trends in two ways, because they borrow large sums of money and because their shares generally pay high dividends and are often bought by investors who might otherwise buy bonds. **********Over the same period, bond prices have dipped, but not by nearly as much. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds has risen to 8.26 percent, from 8.11 percent, amid fears that the Federal Reserve may not continue to ease credit aggressively. That move in rates cut the price of a long Treasury bond by about 1.6 percent, far less than the decline in utility stock prices. **********Among the 15 stocks in the Dow utilities average are several electric utilities whose prices have slipped about 5 percent each. Electric utility stocks are especially sensitive to interest rates. **********But for those still hoping for lower rates there may be pleasure in the fact that the biggest damage to the Dow utility average was done by natural gas stocks, whose profits were damaged by weak prices and a warm winter and whose performance has less relationship to interest-rate expectations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/13/busin.main_headline: NCR Stockholder List Is Given to A.T.&T.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; NCR Stockholder List Is Given to A.T.&T.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/13/busin.body_text: **********The NCR Corporation turned over a list of the names of most of its shareholders to A.T.& T. yesterday, compelled to do so by the ruling of a Federal appeals court in Manhattan in the telephone company's takeover battle for the computer maker. **********The list gives the American Telephone and Telegraph Company a way to reach individual NCR shareholders directly to try garner support for its $90-a-share cash offer. **********Mark Feighery, an NCR spokesman, said the company turned over the shareholder list after the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit lifted a stay of a lower court order requiring NCR to furnish its stockholder list to A.T.& T. NCR had requested the stay after a Federal District Court ordered it to relinquish the list. **********NCR said the list represented the names of owners of more than 80 percent of its 64.4 million common shares. **********About 70 percent of NCR's stockholders voted last month to accept A.T.& T.'s bid. But "getting the list," said Donald Geogerian, the head of research for Dreyfus Management Inc., "gives A.T.& T. an edge to try to up that percentage." **********The telephone company's tender offer is now set to expire on Friday, but the company is expected to extend it. A.T.& T. is expected to report the results of its tender on Monday. **********A.T.& T. began its hostile $6.12 billion cash takeover bid in December, after the computer maker's board rejected an $85-a-share stock offer. NCR, based in Dayton, Ohio, has continued to rebuff the offer and has said it will not consider a merger for less than $125 a share. **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, A.T.& T. closed at $33.875 a share, off 12.5 cents. NCR closed at $92 a share, up 25 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/busin.main_headline: Few Sponsors for TV War News
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/busin.print_headline: Few Sponsors for TV War News
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/busin.body_text: **********National advertisers have been extremely reluctant to buy commercial time on the special network news programs about the war in the Persian Gulf, and the absence of advertising may reduce war-related coverage for at least one network, CBS. **********Executives at all three major networks said in interviews that many advertisers' skittishness about war coverage was costing them millions of dollars. Each of the networks has been spending more than $1.5 million a week just to cover the war. They have lost many more millions of dollars in advertising revenue from the entertainment shows that have been pre-empted by special war coverage. **********Howard Stringer, the president of the CBS Broadcast Group, called the advertiser resistance "disturbing." **********"If we do a thoughtful news broadcast, it ought to be an opportunity for advertisers to share in that responsibility," he said. **********Mr. Stringer and Peter Lund, the executive vice president of the CBS Broadcast Group, said the news division might be forced to scale back plans for prime-time war specials. **********They said that even though the specials had all received high ratings, they had sold only about 20 percent of their commercial time, making them economically unfeasible for the network. Three CBS war specials attracted more viewers than competing entertainment shows. **********Many advertising executives acknowledged that several of the companies they represented had decided to avoid war programming. They said the sponsors cited fears that their commercials might be juxtaposed with such images as dead or maimed soldiers. There is also a reluctance, they said, to place upbeat commercials for items like soups, sodas and cereals on programs about the war. **********Executives for NBC and ABC, who refused to be quoted by name, agreed that the lack of advertising on news programs was a serious financial problem. But they said it had not yet affected any programming decisions. **********The CBS executives said they had even offered advertisers assurances that the war specials could be tailored to provide better lead-ins to commercials. One way would be to insert the commercials after segments that were specially produced with upbeat images or messages about the war, like patriotic views from the home front. But, Mr. Lund said, "we had no success." Fewer Prime-Time Specials **********As a result, "you are absolutely going to see fewer of the prime-time news specials on CBS," he said. "In fairness to our shareholders, we can't lose $1 million every time we do one of them, and we are losing an easy million between what we lose in ad revenue and the production costs." **********Mr. Lund said the reluctance of advertisers had even extended to regularly scheduled news programs like "60 Minutes" and "48 Hours" when they dealt heavily with war issues. **********Advertising executives said the tone of most commercials was vastly different from that of the war news. "Commercials are full of music and happiness," said William Croasdale, a senior vice president of the Backer Spielvogel Bates ad agency. "They have a lot of comedy in them. Everything is upbeat. Sponsors don't want to shift from a general discussing K.I.A.'s -- soldiers killed in action -- to 'Double your pleasure/double your fun.' It's jarring." **********Though network coverage of the American-led war against Iraq has decreased in the last week, network news executives predicted that the start of a ground war would re-intensify the coverage.  'It's Been Frustrating' **********An ABC news executive, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said, "The advertisers are very skittish and it's been frustrating." Though news programs have not been altered, the executive said, "We were stunned that we couldn't attract more advertising for the Peter Jennings children's show." **********Mr. Jennings anchored a well-reviewed and well-rated special Saturday morning program on Jan. 26 in which children were encouraged to call in with questions about the war. "But almost no advertisers were interested," the ABC executive said. **********An NBC News executive, who did not want to be identified, said that his network had also been affected, but that the advertising problem seemed to be easing a bit this week. "The 'Today' show got back to more normal programming," the executive said, "and the advertisers were happy with that. A lot of them said they wanted us to get back to Gene Shalit's movie reviews and the other lighter stuff." **********Richard Dale, an executive at Deutsch Advertising, said some sponsors were reasonably concerned about juxtaposing the war and commercials. "After a segment about a chemical attack that includes a shot of a disfigured face, it might not be the best time to talk about Oil of Olay skin care." he said. **********But Mr. Dale said that even for sponsors unconcerned about juxtaposed images, advertising in war news might be a mistake. "I just think it's wasted money," he said. "Commercials need to be seen in the right environment. A war is just not an upbeat environment." **********He also suggested that the weak advertising market was affecting the number of commercials on news programs. "All these advertisers have been cutting back budgets," he said. **********Responding to the advertiser reluctance, CBS conducted a polls on reaction to the commercials on "60 Minutes" last Sunday. CBS asked viewers whether they recalled the ads and whether they thought the advertisers were being exploitative. **********David F. Poltrack, the senior vice president of CBS research, said the study showed that viewers were watching news programs even more intently than normal programming and that the commercials in the programs were recalled far better than most. "A large majority found the commercials in no way exploitative," Mr. Poltrack said. He added that some viewers even believed sponsors who supported programs on the war were "doing a public service." Campbell Soup's Reaction **********Still, many sponsors remain nervous. The Campbell Soup Company, for example, has decided to "minimize" its commercials in news programs while the war continues, said Paul N. Mulcahy, Campbell's vice president of advertising. He said the decision was part of a trend among advertisers to "stay away from programs involving heavy controversy." **********Mr. Croasdale of Backer Spielvogel Bates added: "We applaud what the networks are doing, but this is sort of the same situation as we've seen with some controversial television movies. After that sort of broadcast, letters get written -- some very thoughtful letters -- and they don't go to the advertising division. They go to the C.E.O. Then they come to the advertising division with a sticky note at the top from the C.E.O., saying, 'I don't want to see any more letters like this.' "

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/15/busin.main_headline: Ask Computer Picks 3 To Head New Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/15/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Ask Computer Picks 3 To Head New Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/15/busin.body_text: **********Ask Computer Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would split into three parts in an effort to decentralize and promoted three vice presidents to be presidents of the new units. Ask, which produces software to automate manufacturing, also gave Les Wright, its executive vice president and chief financial officer, the additional title of chief administrative officer. **********Eric Carlson, 47 years old, was named president of Ask's applications business unit; he has been executive vice president and general manager of the applications products division. Dennis McGinn, 46, was named president of the Ingres business unit, the data base software company that Ask acquired last year; he has been executive vice president for field operations. David Sohm, 42, was elevated to president of Data 3 Systems; he has been vice president and general manager of Data 3 since its acquisition by Ask in 1989. **********"Ingres is running as a successful business, indicating that its merger with Ask is now complete," Sandra L. Kurtzig, Ask's chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement. "Going forward, Ask needs a decentralized structure that gives the business unit presidents a flexibility in running their organizations, and enables each business to maintain its identity and visibility," she said. **********Ms. Kurtzig, 45, said the decentralization would also free corporate staff to focus on long-term planning and policy making. Mr. Wright, who is 37, will be the focal point for the different business units and oversee the corporate functions of treasury, legal, human resources and investor relations. Mr. Wright, Mr. Carlson and Mr. McGinn will all remain executive vice presidents of the corporation and, with Ms. Kurtzig, will form an executive operating committee. **********Mr. Carlson joined Ask, based in Mountain View, Calif., in 1990 from the Unisys Corporation, where he was vice president and general manager of the Unix Systems Group. Mr. McGinn was previously general manager of the Hewlett-Packard Company's industry marketing group. Mr. Sohm joined Ask in 1984 as vice president for marketing after 12 years at Hewlett-Packard, most recently as marketing manager for the manufacturing productivity division. Mr. Wright joined Ask in 1984 as controller; he was previously manager of accounting for Trilogy Ltd.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/19/world.main_headline: In Canadian Comic Book, AIDS Is the Villain
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/19/world.print_headline: In Canadian Comic Book, AIDS Is the Villain
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/19/world.body_text: **********A glossy, brightly colored, sexually explicit comic book brought out with federal funding by Montreal General Hospital is stirring sharp reactions both inside and outside the city. **********Its aim is to promote safe sex among thousands of "wildcat" teen dropouts, or "chats sauvage," of the inner city. **********"In the AIDS era, we're forced to find ways to reach these street kids with what they will understand and relate to," said Deborah Bonney, of the hospital's department of community health. "Remember, these kids are in revolt against authority, and they don't read a lot." **********The 28-page Tete a Queue (head of the tail -- a street reference to the male sex organ) is a teaching aid for social workers who contact the teenagers in arcades, in convenience stores and on street corners. **********Geared primarily to heterosexuals, it was produced by a team largely drawn from Croc, the Quebec humor magazine, with a $41,000 grant from the Department of Health and Welfare in Ottawa. The book is written in "joual," or Montreal street French. **********The book is forthright about depicting sexual activity, all of it with the protection of condoms. **********"Like that," one boy says to his girlfriend, "we can make love to the max." The characters are also shown saying "non" to needles and drugs. **********The controlled experiment involving selective distribution of 10,000 copies has taken on larger dimensions as a result of reports in the local media. **********The mass-circulation La Presse published explicit excerpts to accompany a news story about the project. **********"The reaction was one of surprise, not about what we did but that there was such a magazine put out by a hospital," said the managing editor, Marcel Desjardins. **********"In the last five years, our city has become quite open about AIDS," he explained, "and since we cater directly to all these people and the purpose is laudable, we decided it would be a public service." **********Some of the sharpest criticism came from Jean-V. Dufresne, columnist for the competing mass-circulation paper, Le Journal de Montreal, who complained that it depicted Quebec's young people as "the lewdest, most unkempt, most animal-like, most foul-mouthed adolescents of the planet." **********Defenders argued that the most effective vehicle for the safe-sex message is a visual one rooted in the culture of the street adolescent. **********"Sexuality is very culture-bound," said Dr. Catherine A. Hankins, an epidemiologist on the McGill University medical faculty who is active in AIDS studies, "and one of the postitive things about the AIDS epidemic is that we basically have to explore the cultural aspects of the target audience if we are going to succeed in fighting the disease." **********Although Canada has a lower incidence of AIDS than the United States, mainly a reflection of less intravenous drug use, the problem is becoming increasingly severe in cities. Montreal has counted 1,335 cases since surveillance began in 1979. This is one-quarter of the 5,349 cases in all of Canada, but well below the 34,090 cumulative total in New York. **********The Montreal experiment is being followed elsewhere in North America, where many organizations use visual material to explain safe sex. **********"I'm delighted to hear this kind of project is being given the support and credibility of the Canadian government," said Franklin D. Carson, acting director of the department of education of the Gay Men's Health Crisis of New York City, an AIDS education organization. "That's the kind of national leadership in AIDS prevention that is desperately needed in this country." **********In the United States, public funding for such materials remains controversial, but, although there is generally a greater reserve about sexual issues in Canada than the United States, the federal Government here runs into few problems funding explicit campaigns. **********Academics point to the different social and political dynamics of the two countries. In the United States, powerful right-wing religious forces opposed to explicit talk of sexuality have more influence on the health agenda than in Canada.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/23/busin.body_text: **********Trade talks between China and the United States were set back today when Chinese officials retreated on points they had agreed to in earlier negotiations on protecting intellectual property. **********"Negotiations go in ebbs and flows, and this is an ebb," an assistant United States trade representative, Joseph A. Massey, said today. Mr. Massey spoke after 10 hours of talks with Chinese officials in Beijing this weekend to try to resolve disagreements in Chinese-American trade issues. **********He said Chinese negotiators had submitted a proposed text of an agreement that showed they had pulled back on some points already agreed to by the sides. But he would not specify what those areas were. **********China is filled with pirated copies of Michael Jackson and Madonna music tapes, American videocassettes and an autobiography of President Bush. Some industry groups estimate that the amount of copyright piracy, including computer software, reaches $430 million a year. **********The sides have been negotiating for seven months to draw up a bilateral agreement on protecting United States copyrights and patents in China, but little substantial progress has occurred recently. **********Last month, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said that if the sides did not reach agreement on intellectual property issues by Jan. 16, the United States would impose "prohibitive tariffs" on certain imports from China. **********The sides plan to hold more talks after Jan. 8.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/08/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Anacomp Chief Settles Charges
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/08/busin.body_text: **********The chairman of Anacomp Inc., an Indianapolis computer services company, has settled civil charges of engaging in what was reported to be an insider trading scheme, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today. **********In a civil lawsuit filed in Federal court in Indianapolis, the S.E.C. charged Louis Ferrero, Anacomp's chairman, with illegally tipping off a friend to Anacomp's pending acquisition of another company, the Xidex Corporation, in 1988 before the deal was made public. There was no allegation that Mr. Ferrero engaged in inside trading himself. **********Without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Mr. Ferrero, who is 47 years old, settled with the S.E.C. and agreed to pay penalties totaling $277,750. **********Insider trading charges are still pending against the friend, Michael Maio, chairman of Landmark Savings and Loan in Indianapolis, and two other people who also did not settle with the S.E.C. **********The S.E.C. complaint contends that Mr. Maio illegally traded on the stocks of Xidex and Anacomp and passed on the confidential information to two other people who, in turn, traded on the inside information.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/world.main_headline: Violence Imperils Democracy, Indian Leader Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/world.print_headline: Violence Imperils Democracy, Indian Leader Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/world.body_text: **********As Indians prepared to resume voting this Wednesday in a national election interrupted by the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi, the nation's President warned political parties tonight that violence and intimidation at the polls were threatening the democratic system that has sustained India since independence in 1947. **********"A country ceases to be a democracy where the will of the people is not reflected in the elections and where the sacred right to vote is deprived either by a dictator or by musclemen employed by inscrupulous politicians," the President, Ramaswami Venkataraman, said. **********"Parties that gain power through malpractices will not get the cooperation of the people," he said. "That a government which does not reflect the will of the people does not last long is one of the lessons of history." **********Mr. Venkataraman has been reported to be considering canceling the voting and even changing India's parliamentary system. It was unclear whether his remarks were intended as a threat to make such drastic changes.  More Voting Wednesday **********Since March, India has been under a caretaker government led by Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar, whose Socialist Janata Party commanded barely a tenth of the seats in the lower house of the Indian Parliament. Other parties have accused Mr. Shekhar's party and the Congress Party, which supported his administration for four months, of manipulating the election machinery. **********Fifteen states, parts of states, or territories are expected to vote on Wednesday in 115 parliamentary constituencies. On Saturday, eight more areas in 186 constituencies go to the polls. But even as new booths open, the chief election commissioner is daily declaring balloting null and void in polling stations where voting took place in 204 constituencies on May 20, the day before the assassination . Punjab state was expected to vote on June 22, but today the election commissioner suggested that he might call off the voting there. **********In Punjab on Friday, India's Home Minister, Subodh Kant Sahay, escaped an assassin's bomb. Two other candidates were shot to death elsewhere in the state.
