https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/busin.main_headline: Clifford Resigning as Chairman Of Bank That Had Secret Links
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/busin.print_headline: Clifford Resigning as Chairman Of Bank That Had Secret Links
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/busin.body_text: **********Clark M. Clifford, a towering figure at the intersection of law and politics in the capital for nearly half a century, resigned today as the chairman of Washington's largest bank holding company, apparently under pressure from Federal regulators and the board of the bank he led for nine years. **********Federal regulators and investigators have said that First American Bankshares Inc. was secretly controlled by the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, a loosely regulated international banking concern that was seized last month after auditors reported that the bank had a complex past that included bribery, money laundering and bank fraud. **********Mr. Clifford's law partner and protege, Robert A. Altman, who was president of the First American Corporation, also resigned today. The corporation was one of several holding companies that form the First American group's intricate structure. Temporary Chairman Named **********For now, First American said Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, a former United States Attorney General and former general counsel of the International Business Machines Corporation, would serve as First American's chairman. **********Banking officials said the Federal Reserve Board and Charles McC. Mathias, the former Republican Senator from Maryland who is on First American's board, helped force the resignations that commenced the latest chapter in the B.C.C.I. saga and precipitated the dizzying decline of Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman from their highly lucrative bank posts. **********Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman have consistently insisted that they were unaware that B.C.C.I. held any controlling interest in First American. **********The resignations also crystallize how much Mr. Clifford's long relationship with First American and B.C.C.I. had tarnished his once-illustrious reputation in the twilight of his career as a lawyer, lobbyist, adviser to Democratic Presidents and an unchallenged symbol of rectitude in Washington. **********Mr. Clifford, who is 84 years old, represented the Arab-owned, Pakistani-run B.C.C.I. when it first tried to acquire American banks in the late 1970's. **********The crux of Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman's problems is that law enforce- ors with B.C.C.I. money. If they were aware that B.C.C.I. controlled First American, and lied to regulators about it, they could be charged with fraud. **********Neither man has been formally accused of any wrongdoing. **********Last month, the Federal Reserve moved to fine B.C.C.I. a record $200 million for "secret arrangements" that allowed the foreign bank to acquire First American but were in violation of agreements with the Fed that barred B.C.C.I. from having any ownership interest in First American. Those commitments were made by Mr. Clifford. **********Mr. Mathias, who had taken a leading role in managing the bank earlier this year when the B.C.C.I. connection was first discovered by the Fed, took the leading role in demanding the ouster of Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman, banking officials said.  'The Fed Wanted Them Out' **********"The Fed wanted them out," one official said, "and Senator Mathias played the leading role." **********Mr. Mathias declined through a spokesman to discuss the specifics of how the resignations came about. **********Frank Mankiewicz, the bank's public relations counsel, disputed the assertion that the resignations of Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman had been forced. Rather, he said, they had chosen on their own to resign for the good of the company. **********Mr. Katzenbach, the new chairman, is expected to attempt to extricate First American from B.C.C.I. and eventually to sell the bank to new owners. But those tasks will be complicated by the fact that B.C.C.I.'s shares in First American have been seized by foreign bank regulators and are tied up in court proceedings in London and New York. **********Mr. Katzenbach said in a statement that the Fed had tentatively endorsed a plan for a trust to be established holding First American shares. **********"Constructive ownership of the bank will be in the trust," Mr. Mathias said. He added that the legal issues might take a long time to resolve and that the trust would allow the bank to continue operations until that occurred. **********An order freezing B.C.C.I.'s assets in the United States, including the First American holding, was extended last Friday by Federal Bankruptcy Judge James Garrity in New York. It would prevent the movement of any First American shares. But Harvey Miller, a bankruptcy lawyer representing a claim against B.C.C.I., said that if the Fed asked Judge Garrity to revise his order to permit such a transaction, it would likely be granted.  Three Inquiries Under Way **********The Fed, the District Attorney in Manhattan and a Federal grand jury here are investigating whether Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman knowingly misled regulators with their repeated assurances over the years that B.C.C.I. would not be involved with First American. **********Robert M. Morgenthau Jr., the District Attorney in Manhattan, is investigating because First American has a branch in New York. Law enforcement officials have said that one of his objects is to see whether B.C.C.I. used First American to launder money. **********In a statement issued late today, Michael Cherkasky, chief of the investigation division for District Attorney Morgenthau, said, "We have been informed of the resignations, and they will not impact on our ongoing investigation." **********The officials said that Mr. Clifford had been interviewed extensively by New York City investigators, though he has not appeared before the New York grand jury. They said Mr. Altman had not yet been interviewed in New York.  Indictments in Manhattan **********So far, Mr. Morgenthau's investigation has yielded indictments against B.C.C.I. and two of its top executives for bribery, money laundering and fraud. The bank pleaded guilty in 1990 to money laundering charges in Tampa, Fla., and was fined $15 million. **********First American officials said that neither Mr. Clifford nor Mr. Altman had received any special compensation for their resignations. **********Over the years, Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman profited handsomely from their B.C.C.I. dealings. At one point, both men borrowed 100 percent of the purchase price of First American stock on highly favorable terms from B.C.C.I. **********But the action that raised the issue most profoundly of whether Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman knew of the B.C.C.I. role in First American was a series of stock transactions in 1988 in which the two made a profit of $10 million in less than two years. A secretive subsidiary of B.C.C.I. in the Cayman Islands subsidized a buyer who officials have said was a small-time money-lender who purchased most of the stock at three times the price paid by Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman. **********And B.C.C.I. is said to have made a $2.2 million commission on the deal.  Audit Earlier This Year **********An audit earlier this year showed that some First American shareholders used money from B.C.C.I. to buy their shares in First American in 1982 and never repaid the loans, making B.C.C.I. the secret owner. **********Throughout the year, Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman said they were unaware that B.C.C.I. held a controlling interest in First American. In June 1981, Mr. Clifford, relying on his reputation, assured Federal regulators that B.C.C.I. would have no role in First American, an assertion he repeated several times in the ensuing years. **********Mr. Clifford now contends that he was gulled by the founder and former head of B.C.C.I., Aga Hassan Abedi, a Pakistani who is at the center of the unfolding B.C.C.I. story. **********But investigators and Federal regulators have said there is much evidence that makes the claim that they were unaware of B.C.C.I.'s involvement less plausible. Dual Role as Lawyers **********Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman, as lawyers, represented both B.C.C.I. and First American. The group of original stockholders in First American who were represented by the two lawyers were assembled by Mr. Abedi. **********In his statement of resignation today, Mr. Clifford said that First American "has been operated honestly and without control from B.C.C.I." He added that he and Mr. Altman had resigned because the publicity about B.C.C.I. and First American could have an adverse impact on the bank. **********"Mr. Altman and I must insure that this public attention does not adversely affect the company," Mr. Clifford said in a statement. **********He also said he was gratified that First American customers had remained loyal throughout the affair. **********But despite statements that the bank remains in strong condition, a confidential report from the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates nationally chartered banks, gave the bank a rating of "4" on a scale of 1 to 5, 5 meaning that a bank is about to fail. The bank has struggled recently with bad real estate loans reflecting the recession in the Washington area. **********The Comptroller's office said an institution with a "4" rating was one in which "a high potential for failure is present but is not yet imminent or pronounced." **********Jack W. Beddow, chief executive of the bank's holding company, said that there had been some impact on the bank as a result of the growing difficulties surrounding its association with B.C.C.I., but that it was "mild" and depositors were overwhelmingly remaining confident in the bank. "There have been phone calls, inquiries and some confusion, but that is all," he said. **********Mr. Katzenbach, who now practices law in Morristown, N.J., said he was "honored to have the opportunity to help guide First American into a new chapter in its distinguished history."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/17/world.main_headline: Pope Asks Pardon of Brazil's Indians
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/17/world.print_headline: Pope Asks Pardon of Brazil's Indians
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/17/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II offered symbolic atonement to Brazil's dwindling Indian population today for the "weakness and defects" of some missionaries during centuries of evangelism. But he defended the "shining and eternal example" of the Roman Catholic orders that brought Christianity to Latin America. **********With his comments to 160 Indian leaders in this city deep in Brazil's interior, the Pope seemed to enter a gathering debate before the Columbus quincentenary next year over whether the European arrival in the Americas brought development and justice or destruction and cultural loss. **********Earlier this year, Indians from Peru, Ecuador, Brazil, Bolivia and Colombia demanded that the 500th anniversary of Columbus's voyage should not be celebrated because it marked the beginning of what they called the world's greatest genocide. **********The leaders who met the Pope today repeated the argument, saying in an open letter to him, "The indigenous people of Brazil are against the festive commemorations because all through those centuries we suffered a process of extermination." **********Moreover, while Indian leaders here say they are far more troubled by the aggressive proselytization by fundamentalist Protestant missionaries and have few current problems with the Catholic Church, some argue that forced conversions in the 491 years since Catholic missionaries arrived in Brazil have damaged the Indians' cultural heritage.  Criticism Is Challenged **********Midway through a 10-day visit to Brazil, and on the 13th anniversary of his accession to the papacy, the Pope took issue with such criticism. **********"I cannot deny the great pain that I feel when I learned that some, including those who should have seen in this a correct model, have tried to denigrate the history of evangelization in Brazil through a distorted vision that is more ideological and political than religious," he said. **********In a far more conciliatory gesture, however, he recalled that on his first visit to Brazil 11 years ago, he had paid homage to Catholic evangelists by declaring: "I kneel before each of these missionary figures, men like us, with weaknesses and defects. Today, the Pope wishes to repeat the same words and the same gesture in a spiritual sense as a sign of love and reparation." **********The encounter took place under trees at a Catholic institute here, where the Pope sat on a kind of canopied red throne facing Indian leaders who were bare chested, barefoot and painted. **********Here, close to the southern rim of the Amazon basin, the Pope confronted some of the violence-laden tensions that threaten Brazil's 220,000 Indians as internal migration of poor Brazilians and the depredations of ranchers, loggers and gold prospectors threaten Indian lands. **********"The Pope has not come, like the bandits of the past and the prospectors of today, to search for gold," the Pope said at a Mass in 105-degree heat. **********He said migrants moving around Brazil to escape poverty entered a "vicious circle," bereft of both resources and land. **********The Pope reserved his most emotive words, however, for Indians, sayingthe church "has been and will continue to be at your side, to defend your dignity as humans."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/06/world.main_headline: As Ireland Battles AIDS, the Church Is Called a Roadblock
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/06/world.print_headline: As Ireland Battles AIDS, the Church Is Called a Roadblock
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/06/world.body_text: **********This nation is playing out the tragic drama of AIDS, and tradition, Roman Catholic orthodoxy and ignorance are among the grim protagonists, advocates in the fight against the disease say. **********Ireland does not appear to have as serious a problem as many other countries; it has proportionally far fewer cases than the United States and even fewer than other European countries, official statistics indicate. But advocates say the situation is troubling because conservative attitudes arising from Roman Catholicism both predispose this country to the spread of AIDS and hamper its prevention. **********Catholicism dominates Irish society, with 90 to 95 percent of the population of 3.5 million people professing affiliation with the church. Efforts to promote the use of condoms have been opposed because they clash with the church's teachings. The distribution of clean needles to drug addicts has run into similar church-led opposition on the ground that it promotes drug abuse.  'Attitudes Have to Change' **********In line with church teachings, abortion is illegal here, making it more likely that mothers with AIDS will pass on the disease to babies. Homosexuality is outlawed as well, leading some campaigners against AIDS to conclude that many gay men are disguising their sexual orientation by marrying and having children, and perhaps further helping the disease's spread. **********Some political observers say that the election in December of Mary Robinson, a political outsider, as the first woman to be Ireland's President may signal a liberalizing of attitudes, although the presidency is a largely ceremonial post. A member of the small, leftist Labor Party, Mrs. Robinson campaigned hard for the liberalization of laws on divorce, contraception and homosexuality. **********"Attitudes have to change in Ireland," said Brian Murray, chairman of a voluntary organization, Cairde, that helps AIDS victims. "Otherwise, there will not be tolerance of the use of condoms or clean needles. Attitudes arising from Catholicism have produced a very conservative moral ethos that decries the use of condoms in any context. Governments try to fall in behind public opinion and public opinion is led by the church on these issues." **********The Government says it is working hard to stem the disease's spread and points to its compulsory AIDS education program in secondary schools and its financing of a drug-treatment center in Dublin that offers condoms, clean needles and counseling. **********The church, too, offers materials to help teachers educate students about the dangers of AIDS. It emphasizes monogamy and abstinence. Church and Morality **********"The Catholic Church, as is widely known, promotes the view that sexual morality, if observed, would prove to be a great antidote to the spread of AIDS," said Des Cryan, a spokesman in the Catholic Press and Information Office. "And the general attitude in Ireland, not just among Catholics, but the general attitude is that they basically oppose free, clean-needle schemes because they think it would contribute to drug abuse." **********Government statistics put the number of people here diagnosed as having AIDS at 172 as of October. Nearly 1,000 more were said to be infected with the HIV virus, which causes the disease, but doctors and advocates say that there could actually be three times as many cases. **********World Health Organization figures show that for 1989 there were 1.3 diagnosed cases of AIDS reported here for every 100,000 people while the United States had 13.3 per 100,000. **********Here, about 60 percent of people with the virus and nearly half of those with AIDS are intravenous drug users, representing the sad legacy of cheap heroin dumped into the poor housing projects of Dublin and other European cities in the early 1980's. **********The spread of the disease among homosexual men is viewed by officials as a lesser problem and statistics show only 135 infected with the virus. **********Those active in fighting AIDS say the country's conservative, church-influenced attitudes have led to the failure both by church and Government to develop practical and comprehensive programs against the disease. **********The state-financed program for drug users, which includes outreach workers, is faulted for its location in a fashionable section of Dublin, which critics say leaves it inaccessible to people in deprived areas where drug abuse flourishes.  Sexual Orientation Disguised **********The Government has not directed an AIDS education campaign at homosexual men. James Walsh, the state AIDS coordinator, said the rate of homosexual infection slowed in Ireland as it did in other countries after gays started employing safer sexual practices in the mid-1980's. **********But some advocates say the actual number of cases of AIDS infection among gay men is not 135 but closer to 2,000. Because homosexuality is illegal, they say, many homosexuals disguise their sexual orientation, marry and have children. **********Official statistics are also viewed as misleading in another way. Anti-AIDS campaigners say that because of largescale emigration, especially among people between the ages of 18 and 35, many Irish citizens infected with the virus could be in other countries. **********The Irish characterize their country as a large village of sorts -- family-oriented, relatively slow to change but edging toward greater secularism. **********Many young people who ignore the church's moral arguments against risky sexual and drug activities still share traditional values like the importance of having a family. **********At St. James's Hospital, which treats most of Dublin's AIDS cases, the state's only AIDS consultant said that half of the 120 women there infected with the virus wanted to get pregnant, despite counseling about the disease. The consultant, Dr. Fiona Mulcahy, said the other half insisted that they did not want to get pregnant, but less than a third used contraception.  Amniocentesis Unlikely **********Scientists think that about 40 percent of babies of infected mothers will themselves be born with the AIDS virus and die, and that the rest will lose their mothers. Official statistics show that Ireland has 69 babies infected with the AIDS virus. **********Family planning experts say it is still nearly impossible to obtain amniocentesis -- the medical procedure that can trace fetal abnormalities -- because detection of defects could lead to a woman seeking an abortion. **********Similarly, until 1979 it was illegal to provide contraceptive services and information; condoms can now be legally sold only at pharmacies, doctors' offices, clinics that treat sexually transmitted diseases, state health boards and family planning centers. **********The Roman Catholic Church offers what it calls a "resource pack" as a guide to help teachers discuss AIDS with secondary school students. **********The material says that condoms, if used correctly, reduce the risk of infection but provide nothing like complete protection. It says that "sexual intercourse expresses the total, unconditional self-giving of husband and wife, with openness to the procreation of new life," and that the "use of contraceptives contradicts this truth and is, therefore, morally wrong." **********The Government began its AIDS education program this school year over the objection of Catholic bishops who viewed it as morally aimless. Mr. Walsh said that the program seeks to promote mutual fidelity in sexual relationships. Students are advised that if they do take risks, condoms provide highly effective prevention. A Challenge to the People **********Mr. Walsh says that some people have criticized this approach from the opposite extreme of the bishops, as slanted too heavily toward trying to instill sexual morality. **********Campaigners against AIDS say that to prevent the disease from taking a grim toll, the Irish must challenge the church and other symbols of authority. **********David Esson, who runs a self-help group for AIDS victims called Irish Frontliners, said, "Irish people are conditioned in such a way that no matter how big the biggest wrong, they do not speak out against authority, be it the church, a Government minister, a policeman or a teacher." **********"They accept what is happening," he said. "This means that we have lost quite a lot of people so far to AIDS and we are going to lose quite a lot more."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/14/busin.main_headline: Britain Cuts Interest Rate Half a Point
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/14/busin.print_headline: Britain Cuts Interest Rate Half a Point
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/14/busin.body_text: **********In response to mounting political pressure and growing signs that Britain's recession is becoming severe, the Conservative Government today cut interest rates by half a percentage point. Banks followed suit, reducing their main rates to 13.5 percent. **********Several economists, including some prominent Thatcherites and opposition leaders, described the cut as too little and too late to offer much help to the economy. "The forces have already been set in motion for a quite nasty recession in the United Kingdom," said Paul Turnbull, an economist at Smith New Court Securities P.L.C., a London brokerage. **********But Government officials stressed that fighting inflation remained the top priority and said they would be cautious about making additional rate cuts. Inflation declined to 9.3 percent in December from a peak of 10.9 percent in the fall, but is still the highest in the European Community. **********The interest-rate cut was the first since a one-point reduction in October, when Britain joined the European Monetary System, linking the value of the pound to other European currencies. **********The debate about whether to join the system was one issue that had split the Conservative Party and led to the downfall of Margaret Thatcher, who resigned as Prime Minister in November.  Thatcher's Fears **********Mrs. Thatcher had resisted joining the system, fearing that it would undermine British sovereignty by reducing Government control over interest rates and thus the British economy. Her fears seem to have been borne out. **********The 10 countries now in the system are obligated to keep their currencies within a certain band relative to the others, and interest rates are a principal means of doing that. **********Those in favor of joining the system, including John Major, who was Chancellor of the Exchequer before succeeding Mrs. Thatcher as Prime Minister, argued that membership would help give Britain the discipline to check inflation. The system is dominated by the German mark, which means that the Bundesbank, Germany's inflation-fighting central bank, has significant influence over the interest-rate policies of other countries. **********Indeed, the Bundesbank seemed to reduce Britain's room to cut rates when it raised some rates by a half a point on Jan. 31. **********David R. Walton, an economist at Goldman Sachs International Ltd., pointed out that the pound was in the bottom half of its band against the nine other currencies in the monetary system. But the main constraint on the British Government cutting rates has been that the pound has been near its lower limit against the Spanish peseta.  Realignment Resisted **********A cut today in Spanish money market rates, to 14.5 percent from 14.7 percent, gave the British room to cut rates. **********Prime Minister Major and the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Norman Lamont, have repeatedly resisted heeding the calls within Britain for a realignment of the relative European currency values. **********"There can be no letting up on that goal" of lowering inflation, Mr. Lamont told the House of Commons today. He warned that a devaluation of the pound could cause a rebound in inflation. **********John Smith, a senior official of the opposition Labor Party, said, "Interest rates should have been lowered months ago," adding that today's cut would "do little to stop the slide." An extended recession would greatly increase the Labor Party's chance of beating the Conservatives in the next general election, which must be held by mid-1992. **********With the departure of Mrs. Thatcher and with Britons strongly supporting their country's relatively big role in the Persian Gulf war, the Government's approval rating is extraordinarily high: 89 percent, according to an opinion poll published this week in The Sunday Times of London.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/21/busin.snippet: The Supreme Court's sharp right turn has brought exultation to many of the nation's corporate boardrooms. While the Court has shown its ideological turn mainly in civil rights and social policy, the implications are clear for economic affairs as w...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/21/busin.main_headline:
FORUM;
A Premature Corporate Sigh of Relief
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/21/busin.print_headline:
FORUM;
A Premature Corporate Sigh of Relief
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/21/busin.body_text: **********The Supreme Court's sharp right turn has brought exultation to many of the nation's corporate boardrooms. While the Court has shown its ideological turn mainly in civil rights and social policy, the implications are clear for economic affairs as well: The liberal activist court that intervened actively and eagerly in areas from clean air to employment policy is no more. **********But the satisfaction of business leaders with this turn of events is premature. A conservative court may mean that intervention in corporate business affairs will no longer come from the judicial arena. But it is likely to put intervention back, with increased vigor, in 51 separate arenas -- the state legislatures and Congress. The upshot will be 51 headaches for business. **********The central judicial theme of the Rehnquist Court is deference to the legislature, and that is not likely to change if Clarence Thomas joins the Court. In this last term, for example, in Pacific Mutual Life Insurance v. Haslip, the Court upheld a huge punitive damage to an Alabama woman who had been defrauded of $4,000. The Justices made clear that they were not applauding juries going overboard in awarding damages. Rather, they were deferring to states to set standards for jury awards. Two years ago, when the Court sharply curtailed discrimination cases by changing the burden of proof to the employee, it was not saying that affirmative action is wrong, overdone or unconstitutional. Instead, it put responsibility on Congress to set whatever rules it wanted. **********This is a sharp turnaround. For decades, Congress and the state legislatures used an activist Court to avoid responsibility in controversial and difficult policy decisions -- from abortion to crime to the environment. They simply passed the buck to the Court. They believed that the justices, by and large, would reflect their basic viewpoints and that the justices were ready -- and eager -- to take on the responsibility and power. No more. **********The Rehnquist Court, unlike the Warren and Burger Courts, no longer reflects the Democratic and largely liberal political majority present in Congress and most state legislatures. The bulk of the key decisions in the last court docket were decided in a conservative direction by 5-4 or, increasingly, 6-3 margins. Seven of the nine justices now on the Court were appointed by Republican Presidents; with Thurgood Marshall's retirement, it will be eight. **********As the Court shows it is not willing to let the legislatures off the hook, state lawmakers are increasingly becoming aware that to defer politically difficult and controversial decisions to the Court may be disastrous for them. That could result either in the wrong political result or in having the issues flipped right back to the state level. Newly energized and active legislatures have cropped up as a result. **********Companies are beginning to feel the pain of 50 separate sets of state regulations and requirements for packaging, labeling, content, environmental controls, product liability and insurance. They have only seen the tip of the iceberg. The Court has sent a clear signal to the states, empowering the legislatures and their members, spurring new activism. More state legislatures have expanded their regulatory agendas, becoming increasingly involved in consumer and environmental matters, in ways that generally please consumer advocates and environmentalists. That activism, in turn, has spurred wider use of initiatives and referendums at the polls, requiring tremendous effort on the part of business to hold its own. **********As for Congress, its recent lethargy shows signs of ending. It feels embattled by a popular Republican President and an ideologically hostile Supreme Court. The Court's turn to the right will most likely be the catalyst to get the Congress moving again -- and not in directions that will please business. Consider some items at the top of the Congressional agenda now: the 1991 Civil Rights bill, striker replacement legislation, mandated and employer-provided health benefits. None are issues that small -- or big -- business wants to see favored with aggressive Congressional action. **********For business, an active conservative Court will mean not relaxation, but challenge -- the daunting challenge of making its voice heard in 51 separate arenas across the country.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.main_headline: ABC Makes an Effort To Reassure Children
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.print_headline: ABC Makes an Effort To Reassure Children
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.body_text: **********Prompted by concerns that live scenes from the war front might frighten children more accustomed to seeing the skirmishes of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, ABC News took time yesterday morning to explain the war to youngsters during a special report on the Persian Gulf conflict. **********After apologizing to young viewers for pre-empting the cartoons they usually watch on Saturday, Peter Jennings, the ABC anchor, said, "Kids should also remember that this is all happening far away and that there is no danger to them at home." **********In the weeks leading up to the war in the Persian Gulf, ABC News executives discussed how they would deal with images that might be disturbing to children. **********Patrick M. Roddy of ABC, executive producer of "World News This Morning" and the news portions of "Good Morning America," said the slaying of Chinese protesters in Beijing in June 1989 had made ABC more sensitive to the effect of violent breaking news on children. The Chinese crackdown was seen at American breakfast tables. **********"I wanted to make sure that our coverage of this war was not only up to the minute and accurate and aggressive, but that it be all those things and still not add to the nightmares of children," he said. **********Twelve-year-old Kelly Greenwood, daughter of Bill Greenwood, an ABC News correspondent, helped her father edit a news segment for children that explained troop strengths and the importance of the Middle East region in the world economy while assuring children that it was normal to be upset about the war there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/busin.main_headline: Louisiana-Pacific Plans to End Clear-Cutting in California
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/busin.print_headline: Louisiana-Pacific Plans to End Clear-Cutting in California
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/busin.body_text: **********The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation said today that it would phase out clearcutting of trees on its California timberlands by 1994. Lumber industry officials and environmental groups said it appeared to be the first time a major timber company in California, and perhaps the nation, had given up the practice, which has been strongly criticized by environmentalists. **********Clear-cutting is cutting down all the trees in an area at once. While timber companies have said the practice is sound, environmentalists have said it creates eyesores, increases erosion and eliminates wildlife habitat. **********Lousiana-Pacific, based in Portland, Ore., said it was responding to public sentiment expressed last November in a statewide initiative that would have virtually eliminated clear-cutting and placed other strict controls on forestry in California. While the initiative, known as Proposition 130, was narrowly defeated, the election was "close enough to tell us there's genuine interest and concern in California" about clear-cutting, Harry A. Merlo, the company's president, said in a statement. **********An official of the Sierra Club applauded the decision. "I think that eliminating clear-cutting is a very laudable move," said Gail Lucas, forest issues representative for the organization in California. "It reflects an awareness of the public's concern and distaste for that kind of activity."  Other Reasons Suggested **********Ms. Lucas said, however, that there were other issues about which environmentalists are concerned, like making sure that trees are harvested only as fast as they can be replenished and allowing trees to grow to full maturity before they are cut down. **********Officials of some other environmental and industry groups said that Mr. Merlo could have several reasons for promising to phase out clear-cutting. For one thing, the company's harvesting of timber in California is likely to be severely restricted anyway to protect the northern spotted owl, which has been designated a threatened species. So the company might have little extra to lose and a lot of good will to gain by stopping clear-cutting. **********In addition, it was suggested that Louisiana-Pacific appears to be hoping that giving up clear-cutting will stave off stricter regulations on such aspects as how many trees it can cut down or how old trees must be before they can be cut.  Agreement Seen Near **********It was not clear whether other companies would follow Louisiana-Pacific's lead. David Kaney, general manager of the Simpson Timber Company in Arcata, another major California company, said Simpson planned to continue clear-cutting because "to give up clear-cutting would reduce the productivity of the land by 40 percent." **********Still, environmentalists said that other concessions by timber companies could be on the way. **********In California, seven large environmental groups, including the Sierra Club, the Wilderness Society and the Audubon Society, were said to be nearing an agreement with lumber companies over proposed state legislation that would greatly change the way forestry is conducted in the state. **********The proposed legislation would accomplish part of what Proposition 130 tried to do in terms of reducing clearcutting, regulating the rate at which trees can be cut and so on. But it would not be quite as stringent, so it could win acceptance by the lumber companies, officials familiar with the negotiations said. A Major Landowner **********Several small lumber companies in California and elsewhere never practiced clear-cutting, preferring to harvest selected trees in a forest. In the state of Washington, the Plum Creek Timber Company, after coming under fierce attack from environmentalists, promised to leave more trees standing to help harvested areas regenerate. **********Louisiana-Pacific is a major landowner in California, with nearly 500,000 acres, mostly redwood and Douglas fir. A spokesman, Barry Lacter, said clear-cutting was used for 15 to 20 percent of the company's harvest from those lands. **********The company does not clear-cut on the 1.5 million acres it owns outside California because the practice is not appropriate for the trees in those areas, he said. Mr. Lacter said the company would continue to take timber from clear-cuts on national forest land, where the harvesting method is determined by the Forest Service. **********Mr. Merlo of Louisiana-Pacific has a reputation as an industry maverick. While he has not agreed with or been popular with environmentalists, he has long realized that environmental restrictions would reduce the supply of trees available to forest products companies. He has been shifting his company toward making boards out of wood chips that can be cut from small, plentiful trees such as aspen.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/09/world.main_headline: Vietnamese Foreign Minister Asks for Ties Now With U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/09/world.print_headline: Vietnamese Foreign Minister Asks for Ties Now With U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/09/world.body_text: **********The new Foreign Minister of Vietnam called today for the immediate restoration of diplomatic ties between Vietnam and the United States and described the Bush Administration's refusal to end a 16-year trade embargo against this impoverished nation as "not right." **********At a news conference with foreign journalists, Foreign Minister Nguyen Manh Cam said the United States had increased its demands for restoring relations with Vietnam. "If the conditions continue, it will be difficult to reach a settlement," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/02/busin.body_text: **********Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said today that he might sell as many as 315,000 shares of Chrysler's common stock, or more than three-quarters of his personal holdings. **********In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which requires corporate insiders to disclose large changes in their holdings, Mr. Iacocca disclosed that he now controlled 408,840 Chrysler shares and held options to buy an additional 2.5 million shares. **********Mr. Iacocca, who is 66 years old and was married for the third time on Saturday, said he might sell or give away shares from time to time, not specifying any time period. **********Chrysler shares closed today off 1/4, at 14 1/4. At that price, Mr. Iacocca's holdings would be worth almost $5.83 million, and the 315,000 shares earmarked for possible sale would be worth almost $4.49 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/23/world.print_headline: THE END OF THE SOVIET UNION; Yeltsin Roots: Firmly in Soil
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/23/world.body_text: **********President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic was reassuringly prosaic this weekend as he succeeded to the leadership mantle of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the President of a Soviet Union that has melted out from under him. **********While the watching Western world at first may miss Mr.  Gorbachev's flourishes about historic new beginnings replete with fresh catchwords to match "glasnost" and "perestroika," there is something to be said for Mr. Yeltsin's bluff push forward sans rhetoric with the new Commonwealth of Independent States. **********Far from bang or whimper, the union went out with a laborious sigh as Mr. Yeltsin signed up the old Soviet republics to scramble with him back from the edge and try a fresh course toward a future he says will be harsh but ultimately redeeming.  [ Texts of the agreements signed in Alma-Ata are on page A10. ] **********In this hope, the Alma-Ata meeting in the Kazakh capital near the Chinese border was merciful for its dearth of grand promises. The Soviet empire lies fallen and drenched in highblown promises and political bombast, and in the endless resort to apocalyptic warnings. Routine references to the likelihood of food riots are this season's replacement for last year's "famine" talk in the de rigueur doomsday musings of Russian politics. **********Mr. Yeltsin displayed this weekend how he plays at neither dire warnings -- "No pessimism," he told the public last week -- nor at the bounding internationalist's role that Mr. Gorbachev perfected for the foreign audience. **********Boris Yeltsin is a politician for the domestic landscape, a strategist rooted in the provincial earth. He looks for reassurances from his sense of the ordinary crowd, and not from an outside world breathless at the drama it imagines here in the fallen empire's struggle to get up and go forward. The Art of Compromise **********Mr. Yeltsin is showing some skill at a necessary political art that has been largely absent across the years of Mr. Gorbachev's retreat from totalitarian military and domestic policies. This is the art of compromise. It is an art for which Mr. Gorbachev had no domestic inkling or appetite as he brandished the age-old Kremlin ways of imperious soliloquy and sweeping decree even in trying to apportion democracy and economic change. **********Mr. Yeltsin has already cut some deals, and the most obvious is the new commonwealth, a confused, far-from-perfect arrangement whose only early virtue is in demonstrating the common resolve to find a pragmatic way forward from the disaster of Communism. **********In compromising, Mr. Yeltsin has taken to dispatching political aides to rivals and colleagues to make private deals the way Mr. Gorbachev never did. They helped clear the way both for the enlarged commonwealth and for some of its early compromises, like the agreement that Russia would succeed to the Soviet seat on the United Nations Security Council. **********The latter is a key requirement of the Bush Administration's strategy to see nuclear weapons scaled down and controlled on a single territory, Russia. **********In seeking the Security Council seat, Mr. Yeltsin thus had some extra weight in pointing to the United States, which is strategically withholding recognition of the republics until important military matters are settled. **********In the opening display of the commonwealth's gathering of the 11 republic's leaders, there were surreal and disheartening echoes as of a party Politburo meeting that has gone public and go-go in the search to survive. With the exception of a committed insurgent like President Levon Ter-Petrosyan of Armenia, the gathering was a grouping of veteran party infighters. When Rakhman N. Nabiyev, the white-haired President of Tadzhikistan, suddenly roused himself from a passive stare to launch a gruff paean to harnessing hydroelectric power, there was the faint aroma of Stalin's pipe smoke in the room. **********In this disquieting aura, President Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine was the most successful example of the mass conversion of convenience that the more fleet-footed party politicians have undergone. He beamed next to his nationalist flag while back home his former Communist majority in the Parliament worked on fresh nationalist nostrums and impassioned demurrals from commonwealth commitment. **********But at the heart of this motley, post-Communist Canterbury pilgrimage here in the moribund empire's snowbound outback sat President Yeltsin, happy for the individuals' having trekked at all, regardless of their separate histories and intrigues. Even more than the dominance of geography and resources presented by his Russia, Mr. Yeltsin is the leader of the new commonwealth by dint of his personal risks in anticipating the end of Communism. Without Mr. Yeltsin in its midst, the gathering would truly resemble reconstructed Communism. **********Boris N. Yeltsin was the politician who stood alone four years ago, when others temporized, to be purged from Mr. Gorbachev's party hierarchy for insisting that change had to come far faster than Mr. Gorbachev's vision allowed. On the outs, he was free to believe in Mr. Gorbachev's electoral reform even more than Mr. Gorbachev, and so Mr. Yeltsin submitted to popular election and won Russia. **********From this vantage, he gained the strength to stand again last August while others like Mr. Kravchuk temporized and to insist that the coup by the Kremlin hard-liners was hollow and unfrightening. Whether the frail, history-stained commonwealth born of the failed coup will progress at all beyond its opening muted ceremony was unanswerable in Alma-Ata. But without Mr. Yeltsin's presence, this would barely be a serious question.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/15/busin.main_headline: Time Warner to Begin Rights Offering Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/15/busin.print_headline: Time Warner to Begin Rights Offering Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/15/busin.body_text: **********Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it would begin its rights offering today to raise $2.8 billion through the sale of 34.5 million new shares of stock at $80 a share. **********Ten investment banks will underwrite the offering, which gives shareholder six-tenths of a right, for each share they own, to buy a share of stock at $80. It is the largest underwritten rights offering in United States history. **********The underwriting will be signed, and the amended registration statement will be filed and declared today, when the rights will begin trading. Investors will be able to convert their rights to shares starting next Monday, and the offer will be open until Aug. 5.  Problems With the Old Deal **********In early June, Time Warner had said it hoped to sell 34.5 million new shares at prices ranging from $63 to $105 a share. But the deal angered shareholders and raised concerns at the Securities and Exchange Commission that forced Time Warner to scrap that deal and come up with a new one. In the first deal, shareholders generally felt that they were being coerced into buying stock at a price that they could not determine before the deal actually closed. **********Investment bankers are committed to the new rights offering, although they have a limited number of exit clauses. The deal is off if the Dow Jones industrial average or the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 20 percent or more during the offering period. **********The three lead investment firms, both domestically and overseas, are Salomon Brothers, Merrill Lynch and Goldman, Sachs, which together will put up a total of $650 million. The balance is being spread among seven other investment firms. The leading underwriters overseas are Credit Suisse, Nomura Securities and S. G. Warburg. Other European firms are also involved. **********The three lead firms will split a fee of $27.6 million, and all the firms standing by will split a fee of $55 million. In addition, the investment firms will get a 3 percent discount on all shares they purchase. No Change in Stock Options **********In the revised offering, Time Warner's top three executives -- the chairman and co-chief executive, Steven J. Ross; the president and co-chief executive, N. J. Nicholas Jr., and the vice chairman, Gerald M. Levin -- will not have their options adjusted to reflect the stock's dilution. That is an apparent response to shareholders' concerns that the executives were being protected while other shareholders were being asked to put more money into the deal. **********Investment bankers and analysts differed yesterday on how they expected the stock and the rights to perform. **********Several investment bankers involved in the deal anticipated a dip in the stock price. "My guess is that it is a big financing and a lot to absorb, so it will go down slightly," said a media analyst who has followed the deal but declined to be identified. **********In any case, the new deal is expected to be more appealing to arbitragers than the previous offering, because of the fixed price. **********For example, an arbitrager might sell the stock short at $90, and then buy rights for $9.75, giving him the opportunity to make 25 cents on the transaction. The right would allow him to buy a share at $80, putting his total cost at $89.75. **********On the New York Stock Exchange on Friday, Time Warner's share price closed at $89.75, down $3.875, as news of the new deal leaked out. **********What could stem a further drop in the stock is the investor enthusiasm that the deal might prompt. The new offering appears to be a more straightforward deal than its predecessor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/27/busin.main_headline: Midway Enters Bankruptcy And Obtains a Line of Credit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/27/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Midway Enters Bankruptcy And Obtains a Line of Credit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/27/busin.body_text: **********Midway Airlines, the first large carrier to start flying after deregulation in 1979, filed yesterday for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. **********The airline said, however, that it would continue to operate and that it had arranged a $40 million line of credit, while it seeks to bring down its costs and debt. **********David R. Hinson, Midway's chairman and chief executive, said, "We're committed to the maintenance of our published schedules and to honor all passenger reservations and tickets." **********He added that Midway had to file for bankruptcy protection before Continental Bank would extend credit. The step makes the bank the first claim on the airline's assets in repaying money owed. Similarly, Pan American World Airways filed for Chapter 11 protection to get a $150 million loan from Bankers Trust. **********In a news conference, Mr. Hinson said that the airline would break even in March and that current bookings were at a high. **********"Our wish is to emerge from this financial reorganization as quickly as possible," he said. "We got into a situation where circumstances overwhelmed us." **********The bankruptcy filing, made Monday night, will enable the carrier to shrink its operations and restructure its finances, Mr. Hinson said. **********Several analysts said that the carrier, whose main hub is at Midway Airport in Chicago, had a chance to reorganize and come out bankruptcy, but that much would depend on the economy. **********"Unless there is a traffic recovery by June, then the likelihood of a successful reorganization is dim," said Julius Maldutis of Salomon Brothers Inc. **********Midway's shares fell $1.25 each yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $2.625. The percentage drop, of 32.3 percent, was the Big Board's largest. **********What put Midway into its precarious position was an attempt to seize the opportunity from the troubles at Eastern Airlines to build a second hub in Philadelphia. Eastern had to keep selling assets to cover its losses, while it tried to revive under the protection of Chapter 11, and Midway was able to buy landing slots, gates, international routes and planes from Eastern for more than $200 million. **********The move made strategic sense, but Midway ran into fierce competition from USAir, which did not want another carrier on its turf. USAir, which had also sought Eastern's assets, built up its service at the hub. **********In addition, Eastern, which is now being liquidated, cut fares to $79 one way between the Northeast and Florida in a desperate move to win back traffic. That put competitive pressure on Midway. Final Blow: Fuel Prices **********The final blow to Midway came with the crisis in the Persian Gulf, which sent jet fuel prices soaring while traffic began to fall -- "both things they had no control over," Mr. Maldutis said. **********In October, the carrier agreed to sell its Philadelphia assets to USAir for $67.5 million, taking a loss of more than $30 million on the sale. Midway, which kept the planes it bought from Eastern, began withdrawing from Philadelphia on Jan. 8. **********Midway, which employs 5,700 workers, suspended payments on leases for aircraft and loan payments in December and began talks with its lessors and lenders to reduce costs. **********"Over the past eight months, Midway and its investment bankers have explored virtually every option available in order to attract additional capital," Mr. Hinson said. The efforts failed, he said, because of the hostile environment facing the industry. **********One thing in Midway's favor is that travelers have become accustomed to Chapter 11 filings by airlines. There may be a small loss of bookings in the first few days after a filing, but in other cases bookings have gone back to normal once travel agents and the public realized that the carrier was operating its flights. **********Continental Airlines, for example, filed for Chapter 11 protection last December and experienced only a small decline in bookings. Since then, it has been operating normally. **********Midway began as a no frills discount carrier in 1979 and grew rapidly, becoming profitable two years later. The established carriers, however, began to respond to its low fares and Midway changed strategy, becoming a high-cost carrier catering to the business traveler.  Changing Strategies **********It offered first-class service for the price of coach, which worked at first, but again the carrier was at a disadvantage. It was unable to offer the extensive frequent-flier programs of the majors and did not have the marketing influence that comes from owning extensive reservation systems. It could not offer frequent flights to many cities. **********Again in the late 1980's the carrier changed strategy, becoming a niche carrier, which emphasized Midway Airport's advantages -- being close to downtown Chicago and less crowded than O'Hare International Airport.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/busin.main_headline: Sterling Car a Test for Grace & Rothschild
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Sterling Car a Test for Grace & Rothschild
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/busin.body_text: **********FOR the last four years, Grace & Rothschild Advertising, a small New York agency, has managed to persuade people to buy the Range Rover, a British off-road vehicle that does what a Jeep can do -- but that costs as much as a Mercedes. **********With aplomb, Grace & Rothschild depicted Range Rovers plowing through rivers and climbing harrowing slopes. One ad showed a Range Rover coolly cruising on the side of a hill. **********"The British," the caption reads, "have always driven on the wrong side of the road." **********Now Grace & Rothschild has taken on an even tougher job: selling another expensive British vehicle that $100 million in advertising and three other agencies have failed to move. **********In an interim campaign that began last week, Grace & Rothschild is trying to increase the sales of the $28,500 Sterling motor car that has gone nowhere but down, even before the recession that is crushing most automobile makers. **********So far, response to the new campaign is promising. Although one of its first television ads was pre-empted last Wednesday because of the onset of the Persian Gulf war, subsequent ones, especially those on the Cable News Network, seemed to be drawing consumer interest. Before the effort, inquiries ran about one to three calls daily on an informational "800" number, but climbed to 350 a day on Monday. **********The Sterling could use the attention. Its total sales last year were about 4,000, down by more than 70 percent from the 14,000 sold in 1987, its introductory year. By contrast, another luxury-car competitor, the Acura Legend, sells 12 times as many cars. **********Yet both cars are mechanically similar, since Honda, maker of the Acura Legend, owns 20 percent of Britain's Rover Group, which also makes the Range Rover, and provides the engines, transmission and other parts for the Sterling. "It's not really a bad product," said Cynthia M. Certo, director of forecasting at Integrated Automotive Resources, an automotive consulting firm in Wayne, Pa. "But it entered a crowded market and had weak advertising that didn't distinguish it from the pack." **********Grace & Rothschild's first task was to come up with what the agency's president, Diane Rothschild, calls "intravenous advertising" to keep Sterling Motor Cars alive. The agency had just won the account in November, but quickly fashioned a temporary campaign for the first quarter of this year. **********In the print advertisements, Sterling lists about 40 features, including map-reading lights and burl walnut trim, that come standard with the vehicle. The headline reads, "Find another $28,500 car with all of this and we'll buy it for you." **********Sterling says that before it will make good on its promises to buy a customer a rival luxury car, if it meets the features on the Sterling 827SL, the customer has to visit a Sterling showroom to make his case. **********Sterling spent $20 million last year on print and television ads but has not decided how much it will spend this year until Grace & Rothschild can devise the longer-term effort. **********With about $75 million in billings, Grace & Rothschild was founded in 1986 by Ms. Rothschild and Roy Grace, two expatriates from the large firm of Doyle Dane Bernbach. While at their old employer, Mr. Grace had been creative director on an Alka-Seltzer ad -- "That's a Spicy Meatball," says a heartburned actor flubbing his lines -- and an American Tourister luggage ad -- a gorilla manhandles a suitcase -- now honored by the Museum of Modern Art as classic TV commercials. His collague, Ms. Rothschild, worked on campaigns for Volkswagen and Chivas Regal. Ms. Rothschild wrote the copy for the Range Rover ads. **********Michael B. Jackling, vice president of marketing for Sterling Motor Cars, the Miami-based importer of the vehicles, hired the firm because he had admired the Range Rover ads. "Their tone," he said, "is absolutely perfect." Being the ad agency for a sister company did not hurt, either. **********Grace & Rothschild believes advertising grows out of the product, not market research. Such research is only valuable for indicating what consumers might think about a product, the agency's founders say. "Market research tells you to make an Edsel or New Coke," Mr. Grace said. **********With J & B Scotch, another Grace & Rothschild client, market research had shown that people thought the brand was a drink for older consumers. "But we didn't say, 'This is not your father's J & B,' " Ms. Rothschild said. "We did a campaign that made people come to that conclusion on their own." **********In ads written by Ms. Rothschild, the initials J & B were depicted in situations with a hip fillip. One Christmas ad, for example, showed the large and puzzling letters, " ingle ells, ingle ells." The caption: "The holidays aren't the same without J & B."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/25/world.main_headline: U.N. Leader Seeks A $1 Billion Fund For Peace Missions
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/25/world.print_headline: U.N. Leader Seeks A $1 Billion Fund For Peace Missions
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/25/world.body_text: **********In an effort to resolve the latest financial crisis to grip the United Nations, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar will ask governments, private corporations and wealthy individuals on Monday to set up a $1 billion Peace Endowment Fund to help pay for future United Nations peacekeeping operations. **********In addition, Mr. Perez de Cuellar will ask the General Assembly to authorize him to start charging governments interest on unpaid contributions they owe. He also plans to more than double the United Nations reserve fund and allow him and his successors to take out loans from commercial banks to plug budget gaps. **********The Secretary General will also ask members for advance payment of their 1992 dues so he can pay December staff salaries. The United Nations now has enough cash on hand to pay its 5,000 or so employees through the end of this month. But the organization's Deputy Controller, Susan R. Mills, said last week that unless it could quickly find $100 million more, it would be unable to meet its December payroll. **********Mr. Perez de Cuellar, in a report he will send to the Assembly on Monday, says, "It is a source of profound concern to me that the same membership which sees it appropriate to entrust the United Nations Secretariat with unprecedented new responsibilities has not taken the necessary action to insure that the minimum financial resources required to carry out those responsibilities are provided on a reliable and predictable basis." **********The reason the United Nations is once again on the brink of insolvency is that members, principally the United States, continue not to pay their dues fully and promptly at a time when the organization faces soaring new bills for peacekeeping operations. **********To improve the organization's financial health and meet the cost of new peacekeeping operations, the Secretary General will ask for $500 million in new contributions from the membership before the 1991 General Assembly session ends next month. **********Under his plan, $300 million would go to the proposed new $1 billion Peace Endowment Fund, with the United Nations asking corporations, foundations and wealthy individuals to put up the rest. Income from this fund would be used for peacekeeping.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.main_headline: World Markets; Sweden Gets a Case of the Jitters
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.print_headline: World Markets; Sweden Gets a Case of the Jitters
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.body_text: **********Sweden is stumbling. **********After a surprisingly robust performance this year, the stock market has gotten a case of the jitters, the result of a pessimistic economic outlook and the uncertainty surrounding the upcoming elections this fall. **********Since Aug. 1, the Swedish market's Affarsvalden index has declined 2.4 percent, closing Friday at 1,096.20. It has fallen 4.7 percent from its 1991 high of 1,149.80, which was set on July 11. **********James Capel Inc. in London is telling its clients to take profits now and wait until the fourth quarter before deciding on whether they should return to Stockholm. UBS Phillips Drew of London is cutting its forecast for the Affarsvalden index to 1,050 by year's end, down from 1,100. **********Because many of the country's blue chip companies, like Astra and Ericsson, depend on exports, the outlook for the economies of Europe and the United States are just as critical to investors as that for Sweden. And the news is not rosy. The recovery in America may not be vigorous. In England, the recession is dragging on. And in Germany, a major Swedish trading partner, the economy is slowing and interest rates could rise another notch. **********The change in sentiment toward the Swedish market is also a result of a worry over the latest round of six-month earnings reports, which began to come out last week. SKR, the ball-bearing manufacturer, announced a 95 percent drop in pre-tax profits. The company said it expected earnings to improve in the second half of the year, an announcement that gave the stock market a little lift at the end of the week. **********Sweden's own economic outlook is also darker than many local investors had thought. The recession is expected to continue through this year, the experts say, with forecasts showing a weak recovery, at best, developing next year. **********Although analysts at UBS expect corporate earnings to increase 20 percent to 25 percent in 1992, part of the rebound will be a result of one-time restructuring charges many companies are taking this year year to cut costs. Some companies, like Volvo, also had major costs for development of new models, which will not be repeated. **********The September election, in which the current Government of Social Democrats, led by Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson, will be fighting for its political life, is also adding uncertainity. **********The possibility of a coalition government of several conservative and non-Socialist parties could add impetus to the move that is seeking to tilt what was once a major Western welfare state toward an open market orientation. But the coalition, analysts argue, could break apart over other issues, like nuclear power and membership in the European Community. And in recent polls, the Social Democrats, although still trailing, have gained some ground. **********Much of the impetus for the market rally came from signs of a change in the Social Democrats' attitude and economic management. Less inclined toward innovation, the Government, analysts say, is now more likely to use inflation than the unemployment rate as the key guide to policy. **********The Government's decision to apply for membership in the European Community also encouraged many foreign investors to buy stocks before the country's stock market is forced by E.C. rules to open its door fully to foreigners. According to James Capel, foreigners were net purchasers of 3.7 billion kronor worth of stock by the end of May, compared with 1.2 billion kronor for all of last year. **********The decision to tie the krona to a basket of European currencies, as represented in the European Currency Unit, gave the Swedish currency a new stability. It opened the way for cuts in interest rates at home and raised confidence that the government would not use krona devaluations just to make Swedish exports cheaper abroad. **********In addition, two major deals, both involving the Wallenberg family, which has major stakes in many Swedish companies, poured billions of kronor into the market, helping to spur domestic buying. One was the friendly $2.8 billion takeover of Alfa-Laval, a manufacturer of dairy machinery, by Switzerland's Tetra Pak. The second was the purchase by the Wallenbergs of the remaining shares in Saab-Scania that they did not own. **********The market also rebounded from a very low level, having fallen 37.6 percent after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Even after this year's rally, the market is 18 percent below its pre-invasion level, according to the Financial Times index of world stock markets. During the war rally in January and February, the market was the top performer in the Financial Times index, rising 27 percent. **********"There is no room for any disappointments coming through," said Roddy Bridge of UBS in London. "If this earnings period disappoints, the cash that had been supporting the market can turn around and the market can fall. This is what I am hoping for so that we can take a look to see if we should go positive on the market again."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/busin.main_headline: Lloyd's Seeking to Oust Seized Bank's Lawyers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/busin.print_headline: Lloyd's Seeking to Oust Seized Bank's Lawyers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/busin.body_text: **********The seizure of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, the worldwide private bank based in Luxembourg, has raised a question about whether the bank can continue to be represented by Patton, Boggs & Blow, the prominent Washington law firm that also represents the Abu Dhabi Government. **********Before it was seized by the Bank of England this month, the bank was controlled by the ruler of Abu Dhabi, Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nayan. Once the Bank of England closed the bank, it appointed a receiver, Touche Ross, the accounting firm, to administer the reorganization of the institution. **********In a motion filed here today in a lawsuit involving the bank, Lloyd's of London, the insurance organization, asked a Federal court to disqualify Patton, Boggs from continuing to represent the bank because of what the international insurance giant contended was a conflict of interest arising from what it said was dual representation. **********In its motion, Lloyd's argued that representing the interests of Abu Dhabi and the interests of the bank means that "serious conflict between the receiver and the ruler is inevitable." The motion said, "Given the commitments made by the ruler and the role that the ruler and the private department of the Government played in the operation of the bank, it is likely that the receiver will seek a financial contribution from both of them." **********Timothy May, the managing partner of Patton, Boggs, did not return a telephone call today seeking comment. **********People involved in the case said today that Touche Ross had given Patton, Boggs temporary approval to continue representing the bank's interests in the United States. **********In the case, Lloyd's accused the bank of taking part in a multimillion-dollar conspiracy to smuggle coffee to the United States from Central America. Lloyd's said it insured shipments of coffee that had been expected to be delivered to Jordan but were smuggled into the United States.                    --------------------       Hong Kong Turmoil **********HONG KONG, July 17 (Reuters) -- The Hong Kong Government moved today to liquidate the local subsidiary of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International as the parent company's shutdown caused a demonstration and roiled the colony's banking industry and stock market. **********Depositors were withdrawing money from another Hong Kong bank, the International Bank of Asia Ltd., which, like the Bank of Credit and Commerce is controlled by Arab investors. The International Bank denied having any financial problems. **********But the Government pumped about $7.7 million into the banking system, and a nervous stock market fell sharply only a day after hitting an all-time high.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/04/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; When Children Have Children
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/04/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; When Children Have Children
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/04/busin.body_text: **********EVERYONE knows that teen-age pregnancy is the curse of the underclass -- that children who have children doom themselves to a life of poverty and dependence. But everyone, it seems, could be wrong. **********A National Bureau of Economic Research working paper published this summer by Arline Geronimus, a researcher at the University of Michigan, and Sanders Korenman, a Princeton economist, offers striking evidence that early motherhood does not much affect women's future earnings or increase the probability they will end up on welfare. **********No reasonable interpretation of the results, however, will provide comfort to the more-the-merrier, birth-control-is-genocide crowd. The fact that poor women lose little by giving birth as teen-agers, Mr. Korenman argues, says only that poor women have little to lose. **********Study after study has shown that girls who have babies end up poorer and less educated than other women. And the experience of the women in the broad sample used by Ms. Geronimus and Mr. Korenman is no different. Among women followed for two decades by the Center for Human Resource Research at Ohio State University, those who became mothers as teen-agers were four times as likely to end up on welfare and three times as likely to become dropouts as those who waited to have babies. **********But correlation is not causation: The fact that people with heart disease average more sleep than healthy adults does not mean that sleep damages the heart. And as one might expect, studies that have been controlled for family background -- parents' income, race, education and occupational status -- suggest that early pregnancy is just one of several factors determining the economic future of young women. **********Ms. Geronimus and Mr. Korenman suspected, however, that these standard background variables did not capture all the relevant differences between families. So they limited their own statistical analysis to a sub-sample of 51 families in which at least one sister had a baby before age 20 and at least one did not. **********They discovered that teen-age motherhood lost most of its dismal predictive value: Early parenthood in itself apparently did not make it more likely that the women would end their schooling before high school graduation or become dependent on welfare. **********What is one to make of this remarkable finding? The casual interpretation is that teen-age pregnancy is no big deal -- and thus that denying teen-agers easy access to birth control information and abortion would have no great social or economic consequence. **********And apparently inadvertently, Ms. Geronimus has given her critics reason to believe this is her own reading of the evidence. In earlier scholarly articles she argued that contrary to the conventional wisdom poor women were more apt to deliver healthy babies when they were teen-agers -- before their capacity for successful reproduction was damaged by drugs and hard living. She has also speculated that poor teen-age mothers, in contrast to older impoverished mothers, are better able to draw on extended families for support of the young. **********But a simpler and more defensible interpretation of this study's result is that 1990's-style poverty is apt to ruin the lives of young women, whether or not they give birth as teen-agers. The fact that so many poor girls choose to have the babies may follow from their sense that they have nothing better to look forward to. Or as Ms. Geronomus put it, "Teen-age fertility among the poor may well be an adaptive response to social reality." **********This does not imply that teen-age motherhood is any less of a catastrophe: Something is deeply wrong, it is safe to assume, when 15-year-old girls would rather change diapers than get on with the adventure of growing up. Nor does it get politicians and school administrators off the hook on abortion and contraception. Girls who are motivated to break out of poverty may still lack the means to make it without help in remaining childless. **********What the findings may do, however, is make it less respectable to dismiss poverty as the consequence of sin. The very idea of an underclass is an embarrassment to a nation that takes great pride in social mobility. Thus for many Americans, the only plausible explanation for chronic poverty in a land of opportunity is moral deficiency. **********Few of the liberal social scientists who have been sounding the alarm about teen-age parenthood in the last decade would classify themselves as moralists. But the idea that poverty is a consequence of casual, early sex does mesh neatly with the view that bad things mostly happen to bad people. And while the Geronimus-Korenman research is not likely to cause a sea change in attitudes, it might slow the gradual but unmistakable erosion of public sympathy for the victims of poverty.
