https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/07/world.main_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL: TV Critic's Notebook; Soviet Odd Couple Makes U.S. Debut
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/07/world.print_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL: TV Critic's Notebook; Soviet Odd Couple Makes U.S. Debut
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/07/world.body_text: **********As coups go, it was a lot more successful than the last one that involved Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin. ABC scored by getting the two Presidents together, more or less, with people in America's biggest cities plus Brighton Beach, for what was billed as "A National Town Meeting." **********Wearing blue suits and red neckties, the allied rivals sat, freshly shaved cheek by newly powdered jowl, under glittering chandeliers in St. George's Hall in the Kremlin -- some town hall -- and answered questions from just folks and Peter Jennings, television protocol requiring that heads of state be received by anchors if at all possible. **********What were they doing there besides boosting a network's ratings? If television was using them, they were using it, the usual symbiosis. **********Could they resist talking directly to an audience whose representatives are even now considering how much and what sort of aid to give to what used to be the Soviet Union? At least as enticing, the event was being carried live and would be repeated in prime time across their own country as well as in Eastern Europe. **********How better to shore up politically problematic positions and certify international stature these days than to demonstrate that one is a hot commodity in the land of super-hot commodities? If you can make it there, you can make it anywhere. Screened for Sanity **********Despite a late beginning that strained Mr. Jennings's talent for improvisation but accommodated a score of commercial spots, it was a well-produced stunt. The questioners had evidently been screened for sanity and diversity and their questions were the ones that Americans have been asking. **********They touched on Cuba, Chernobyl and the K.G.B. A defector asked about political prisoners, a businessman about guarantees to foreign investors that their property would not be confiscated, a farm representative about grain distribution. **********The answers were for the most part one answer: No, things have not been good, but they will be better. Through their joint presence and cooperative mien, the leaders of the new Soviet or non-Soviet state or states were there to reassure Americans that they were on a steady democratic course. The Glass of Democracy **********And what could be a more appropriate conduit than the tube, that glass of democracy when it is allowed to be? Viewers of CNN had just seen the men together at the podium of the lately concluded Soviet Congress, and the two leaders had also been interviewed separately here and there. But this was a first, and it was treated that way by the ABC engineers. The monitors beneath the huge American flag on the network set confirmed that people all over the United States were in on it. **********Most of the stars' lines were straight out of stock, but this show was not about the script; it was about the players. Their testy relationship was no secret to anybody who watched the evening news. How would they behave when yoked together by the requirements of politics at home and by public relations on a global stage? **********Several times Mr. Gorbachev started a reply by remarking that he agreed with what Boris Nikolayevich had just said, and Mr. Yeltsin referred courteously to Mikhail Sergeyevich, but a contrary spirit kept peeping naughtily through the good manners. **********Mr. Gorbachev fitted more comfortably into the elegant surroundings. Mr. Yeltsin, with a face that bore the marks of a rough-and-tumble career, occupied his period chair like a slugger at a dinner party, now and then knocking over a piece of china, maybe by accident, maybe not. **********After Mr. Gorbachev spoke of "cooperation" in response to Mr. Jennings's very first question about how the two were getting along, Mr. Yeltsin moved in with the reminder that not long ago his comrade had considered him a political corpse. **********He made it plain that if relations were now improved between them, it was because the Soviet President had come round to the Yeltsin position on radical reform. Mr. Gorbachev, who consistently took a mollifying tone, responded like a therapist: "Let each remain his own person." **********On farm problems Mr. Gorbachev spun out some bureaucratese about the creation of "a normally functioning market." But Mr. Yeltsin declared challengingly that Russia would deal directly with the world's grain exchanges without any intermediaries, meaning the central Government. When Mr. Jennings pressed him on whether Russia intended to take care of itself, he snapped back, "You have understood me correctly." A Grin on His Face? **********And was it just imagination that discerned a grin playing about the Yeltsin lips when a New Yorker asked Mr. Gorbachev how he had allowed the coup plotters to serve in his Government? It was a lesson, Mr. Gorbachev said. Mr. Yeltsin didn't have to say anything. **********What message was getting across, in the United States or in their disunited homeland? Viewers may have wondered how permanent such an alliance could be if these two could not manage to paper over differences even in a television studio. **********Yet overall it was a reassuring occasion. Their exchanges, though a bit oblique, were less programmed than those in American Presidential debates, and their personalities were opened up to the world. **********Most resoundingly, their very presence was an acknowledgement of their need for, and deference to, public acceptance. Whatever they do now, the program was saying, it cannot be hidden behind the closed doors of the Kremlin, into which the cameras have now intruded in a big way.

Premier's "operating results for the first three quarters of this year reflect a strengthening of the bank's capital and reserve accounts," the Fed said in its order.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/10/busin.main_headline: Managing; Farewell to the Training Seminar?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/10/busin.print_headline: Managing; Farewell to the Training Seminar?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/10/busin.body_text: **********John L. Hanson, vice president of human resources at the Parker Hannifin Corporation, recently gave copies of "Keeping the Best," Martin Yate's book on motivating employees, to about 40 of the industrial component manufacturer's managers. "The book says that the first step in satisfying customers is having satisfied employees, and I want to drive that point home," he said. **********Ricardo C. Calvillo, president of the New York advertising agency Calet, Hirsch and Spector, gave a dozen of his top people copies of Peter M. Senge's "The Fifth Discipline: The Art and Practice of the Learning Organization" because he thought it offered well-reasoned views on operating in a tough business environment. **********"I'm tired of '10 quick solutions' magazine articles, or seminars based on bromides," said Mr. Calvillo. Indeed, he is currently looking for other books to distribute. "Today's times cry out for the kind of profound ideas that need an entire volume to explore," he said. **********Educators who bemoan the declining popularity of books, accompanied by the rise of sound bites and short printed takes, can take heart. There is at least one arena where the bound volume is having a renaissance: the work place. **********"Five, seven years ago we sold virtually nothing to corporations," said Bob Adams, who owns Bob Adams Inc., a publisher of business books -- including "Keeping the Best" -- in Holbrook, Mass. "Last year we sold $110,000 worth to companies -- and I'll bet a lot of our bookstore sales were to companies, too," he said. **********Don't bet against him. No one has hard numbers -- bookstores do not track who buys books, or for what use -- but publishers say informal feedback from stores and from regional offices indicates that multiple-copy sales to companies are making up an increasing percentage of the sales of business books. **********"There's no question, more of our sales are to corporations, for their employees," said James Picard, an account manager for Great Performance Inc., a Portland, Ore., publisher of books on stress management. "More and more of our books are being bought in bulk." **********There are many reasons for the current flurry of corporate book-giving. American companies, desperate for better ways to compete globally, are seeking the proper balance between entrepreneurial spirit and team playing, between motivating and coddling, between hard work and workaholism, between centralized planning and decentralized decision-making. **********In the old and fatter days, they might have sent people en masse to weeklong seminars on any of those subjects. But few managers in the modern pared-down corporation can afford the time or money. **********"Companies are wising up to the fact that books provide very important training for the lowest possible cost per employee," said Jeremy P. Tarcher, editor in chief of Jeremy P. Tarcher Inc., a Los Angeles publisher that is enjoying brisk corporate sales of "Working from Home," a book by Paul and Sarah Edwards on telecommuting. **********There are less mercenary reasons, too, of course. Some companies give books -- particularly ones on fitness, stress management and other ways of improving employees' lives -- as morale boosters and signs that management cares. Furthermore, the how-to gift book fits nicely into the pan-societal trend toward self-service and self-help in an era demanding more of each worker. **********And, publishers are simply making business books more available. **********In August, the Professional Book Group at McGraw-Hill Inc. appointed three people whose sole duty is to sell books to corporations. The company's title list, which is heavily weighted toward reference and training books, is including more books that "help individuals do their job," said Elizabeth L. Crawford, director of special sales. One example: "How to Present Like a Pro," a book on communications by Lani Arrendondo that McGraw-Hill is marketing to human resources people. **********As a marketing strategy, Bob Adams sent copies of "Keeping the Best" to the chief executives of Fortune 500 companies. "When a chief executive passes a book along to the human resources department, they are a lot more likely to order it in bulk," he said. About 1,000 of the 30,000 copies the book has sold since it came out in November were multiple-copy sales to corporations. **********For some companies, book buying comes in waves. When the MCI Communications Corporation began seriously to erode the monopoly held by American Telephone and Telegraph on long-distance service in the mid-1970's, and again, when A.T.&T. was broken up several years later, numerous books circulated through the company, recalled Burke Stinson, an A.T.&T. public relations manager. "Anxiety levels were so high that managers bought everything from how-to marketing books to 'Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance,' " he said. **********A.T.&.T. recently bought 20,000 copies of "Working from Home" as gifts for people who provided the company with work-at-home tips which it then printed in its customer newsletter. But, a growing number of A.T.&T. people are starting to work from home, too. "I suspect we'll send copies to our own people soon," Mr. Stinson said. READING INTO THE READING LIST **********It might seem that giving books to employees is all upside potential, no downside risk. Not true. **********Some employees resent having philosophies shoved down their throats. Burke Stinson of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had "mind control freaks who want everyone on their teams to think like they do" give him "gifts" of books that he then felt forced to read. **********"In my mind, a smart, enlightened manager is one who would tell me about a book and then leave me the option of whether to get it," he said. **********Distributing books to selected employees can make those who did not receive them feel slighted. "When the boss gave a copy of 'In Search of Excellence' to one of my colleagues and not to me, I started looking for a job," said one New York executive, who insisted on remaining anonymous. **********Conversely, buying enough books for everyone can be tantamount to a product endorsement. That's one reason why executives at the International Business Machines Corporation rarely buy books for their employees. **********"The culture here makes people skittish about even appearing to endorse anything," said Mac Jeffery, an I.B.M. spokesman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/world.main_headline: Iraq Atom Effort Ruined, Inspectors Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/world.print_headline: Iraq Atom Effort Ruined, Inspectors Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/world.body_text: **********Contradicting reports that Iraq had produced enough nuclear material to build at least one atomic bomb, United Nations inspectors have concluded that bombing raids during the Persian Gulf war probably destroyed Iraq's uranium enrichment installations before they produced any weapons-grade material. **********The inspectors, part of the team sent here by the Security Council to check on Iraq's nuclear potential, say Iraqi officials have deluged them with information about the enrichment program since Monday. On that day, the International Atomic Energy Agency's Director General, Hans Blix, told the Security Council that Iraq's disclosures about its nuclear installations were still inadequate, even though Iraq had acknowledged that it had a secret enrichment program. **********The inspection team's conclusion appeared to support Iraq's claim that it is not hiding nuclear installations. A report in May by an Iraqi defector said Iraq had produced 90 pounds of enriched uranium, enough for two bombs. After this report, Mr. Bush said President Saddam Hussein was lying and indicated that the United States might resume attacks on Iraq if it kept trying to produce nuclear weapons. **********[ State Department and other officials familiar with intellgience reports on Iraq's nuclear ability said they remained skeptical of the new report. "That doesn't ring right," an official said. "We know they produced some highly enriched material and that material was taken out of some of those facilities." ] U.N. Council to Get Report **********As a result of the inpsectors' conclusion that the enrichment installations were probably knocked out in the allied raids, the United Nations officials say the team is likely to send the Security Council a new and more positive report on the Iraqi disclosures. **********Mr. Hussein, in a 45-minute televised address marking the anniversary of his Baath Party's seizure of power in 1968, made no reference to his clandestine nuclear weapons program, to the renewed threat of American bombing. **********A positive report by the United Nations inspectors to the Security Council on Iraqi nuclear disclosures could lead some diplomats and officials to argue that the United States should not be quick to fulfill its threat to resume attacks on Iraq if it continues to refuse to disclose the location of its nuclear installations, as required by a Security Council resolution. **********But the United Nations team has also asked Iraq for a categorical assurance that it is not concealing other nuclear installations. **********Asked tonight whether the United Nations is giving Iraq a last chance to come clean about any other secret nuclear installations, Demitri Perricos, the chief United Nations inspector, said, "Yes, you could say that is what we are doing."  U.N. Aides Satisfied **********The United Nations officials now say they know all they need to about these plants and are reasonably sure that they have not produced any weapons-grade enriched uranium by the time the allies destroyed them. Tonight, Mr. Perricos said he did not believe the press reports that Iraq had enriched nearly 90 pounds of uranium up to weapons-grade level. **********The United Nations inspectors discovered that one of the installations bombed by the allies -- at Tarmia about 30 miles from Baghdad -- was an enrichment plant using electromagnetic technology and was about six months from becoming operational. **********It was equipped with some 30 calutron machines used for enriching uranium. The machines, all of which were damaged by the raid, were spotted by the inspectors being removed from the plant on trucks and were subsequently buried at sites around the country. **********Iraq has now dug up the remnants and showed them to the inspectors. "They were trying to hide the evidence," an official said. **********Iraqi nuclear officials have told the inspectors that Baghdad has tried to keep its enrichment program secret because it was afraid that Israel would bomb the plants otherwise. In 1981 Israeli warplanes destroyed an Iraqi nuclear reactor that the Israelis said was being used to develop an atomic bomb.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/world.main_headline: After Inroads by Inkatha Rivals, a South African Township Fears to Sleep
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/world.print_headline: After Inroads by Inkatha Rivals, a South African Township Fears to Sleep
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/world.body_text: **********As the Malinga brothers told it later, their night of terror began when the raiders arrived in a police armored car shortly before midnight on July 26. They threw firebombs into the Malinga home, smashed windows and kicked in the door. **********Belesia Malinga, their mother, hid under her bed. She was dragged out and shot to death. Sibusiso Malinga, who is 21 years old, scrambled atop a rickety wardrobe but was stabbed with a spear. **********His younger brother Zachariah, 16, was hit with a spear and a machete but managed to run outside. Sibusiso staggered after him, only to be stabbed and struck again. He played dead. **********"I heard one of the white policemen ask another whether I was in fact dead," Sibusiso Malinga said later in an affadavit. "Upon receiving an affirmative answer, they left me and walked away."  Collusion Is Charged **********Sibusiso, Zachariah and their older brother, Philemon, 29, said the attack was carried out by local members of the Inkatha Freedom Party and the South African police. The Malinga brothers' version of events is widely believed among the 2,000 residents of this poor, tin-roofed township surrounded by the flat cornfields of eastern Transvaal province. **********The African National Congress charges that what happened in Kwadela is part of a pattern of collusion between the police and the Zulu-based Inkatha movement in rural black communities where the congress is expanding its membership. **********Inkatha is a bitter rival of the African National Congress, the leading black political movement challenging white-minority rule in South Africa. Allegations that Inkatha colludes with the police arise often enough in the Transvaal and Natal but are seldom conclusively proven. **********In Kwadela, at least nine victims have come forward to name their assailants, sometimes the same ones. They explained in detail how they were attacked, though often they were not sure why.  'The Only Reason' **********"The only reason I can give you is that they were members of the A.N.C.," said Jeremiah Mashinini, a 59-year-old schoolteacher who is chairman of the congress's branch in Kwadela. **********"There's a lot of that in the eastern Transvaal -- attacks by unknown elements in the awkward hours of the night," said Jackson Mthembu, the congress's spokesman in the eastern Transvaal. **********The attacks in Kwadela point to another factor in the politically motivated violence inhibiting change in South Africa. The congress and allied local civic associations regard members of black township councils as collaborators with apartheid and demand that they resign. They want the township councils replaced by unified administrations under which affluent white towns would share tax revenue with their impoverished black neighbors. **********Mr. Mashinini said the trouble started with a rent boycott by township residents last year to force Kwadela's Mayor, Napoleon Mkhonza, and five other council members to step down. Three of the council members obliged; the others refused to quit. **********"The A.N.C. doesn't want any other party to be present," Mr. Mkhonza said. "They want it to be an A.N.C. area. That's the long and short of it." **********Like other councilmen seeking political protection, Mr. Mkhonza joined the Inkatha movement, which is recruiting beyond its traditional Zulu base in Natal. Now, he said, "I am the leader of Inkatha in this area." **********The Mayor spoke of attempts to torch or vandalize the homes of council members. But Mr. Mthembu, the congress's spokesman in the region, said he saw Mr. Mkhonza shoot a woman in Kwadela last year.  'Just Another Name' **********Mayor Mkhonza has brought in a dozen young men from the nearby town of Ermelo to protect him. Mr. Mashinini and other residents said the armed youths came from a gang called the Black Cats, which had terrorized the region earlier. **********"It is just another name -- Black Cats," he said. "They are Inkatha members from Ermelo." **********Mr. Mthembu disagreed. "Inkatha had no presence in the eastern Transvaal until the notorious gang called the Black Cats decided to call themselves Inkatha members," he said. **********While Mr. Mashinini was attending the congress's conference in Durban early in July, the house of his son Humphrey and daughter-in-law Julia was firebombed. The couple tried to run out the front door, but shots drove them back into the flames. Julia Mashinini, who was seven months' pregnant, died of burns 17 days later. Humphrey Mashinini remains in the hospital. **********"They just went for them," said Mrs. Mashinini's brother, Victor Nkosi. "I think one of the causes is that they were A.N.C."  Attacks and Retaliation **********Elias Nkosi, an unemployed laborer, said his house was also burned down, as was that of John Blose. Both are active in the congress's Kwadela branch. **********"Most of the people here are A.N.C.," Mr. Nkosi said. "That's why they had to go to fetch people from outside to attack the A.N.C. here." **********On July 26, the night before Mrs. Mashinini's funeral, the Malingas' house was attacked. Congress supporters retaliated by burning down at least three shacks occupied by Inkatha members. **********Philemon Malinga, who hid in the bathroom during the attack on his house, said in his affidavit that "I heard someone say, 'Let us go, we are finished.' " He said he saw five men, including a white policeman, climb into an armored car and leave. He identified each one by name. **********Responding to a request for comment, the South African police rejected what it called "allegations and insinuations" that officers participated in attacks on houses in Kwadela. A police statement said Mrs. Malinga had been stabbed and that the autopsy found no gunshot wounds. It also said one policeman had rescued a retarded youth from the burning Malinga home.  Police Role Debated **********The Mayor, who lives two doors from the Malinga home, said the police were there to clear a path for the ambulance. But some other residents contend that the police, who are based a block away, assisted the attack. **********Mayor Mkhonza said the African National Congress had rebuffed his efforts to negotiate a truce. **********Mr. Mashinini, who has taught in Kwadela for 24 years, said school attendance had dropped as parents sent their children to stay with relatives elsewhere. People are now afraid to join the African National Congress, he said, and some leave their dwellings at night to sleep in the surrounding fields. **********"My children don't sleep here because they fear they will be attacked by Inkatha," he said. "I'm the only one who sleeps here because I can't leave my property alone."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/busin.main_headline: Oil Prices Fluctuate Wildly, Then Settle Just 9¦ Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/busin.print_headline: MARKETS' DAY OF WIDE SWINGS; Oil Prices Fluctuate Wildly, Then Settle Just 9¦ Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/busin.body_text: **********Oil prices took a wild ride yesterday but came to rest just about where they started. When Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced his disappointing news in Geneva just before 2 P.M., the price jumped nearly 30 percent in five minutes, rushing from $24 a barrel to $31. **********It was the widest price swing within one day's trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange since trading in crude oil began in March 1983. **********Worldwide, the price bounced throughout the day. Early in the morning, before futures trading opened in New York at 9:45, prices in this country and in London were slightly higher because of fears that war was likely. But then the meeting between Mr. Baker and Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi Foreign Minister, lasted longer than the market had expected, with reports of progress. Suddenly traders were afraid of holding oil or contracts for oil that would lose value because of peace. **********Then came word, which proved incorrect, that the two men would hold a joint news conference, and the market went lower, expecting an agreement. But when Mr. Baker said the talks had been inconclusive, "the market exploded," said Richard D. Donovan, senior vice president at Lehman Brothers. Traders became convinced that the oil or contracts they had sold in the morning would be worth much more later on because of war, and they all turned to buy. **********"It's staggering," said Mr. Donovan, who pointed out that oil is the world's biggest commodity. Describing what a move that size would mean on other markets, he said, "Can you imagine the Dow Jones going up 750 points in five minutes? Or gold going up $100?" **********Theodore R. Eck, chief economist at Amoco, called the jump "phenomenal." **********"It just tells us there's extreme uncertainty and the folly of trying to forecast prices," he said. **********Despite the size of the trading range, $7.65, the day ended with crude for February delivery up only 9 cents, at $27.26 a barrel. The surge had been preceded by a huge selloff, and the market, which frequently overshoots its mark, fell back after reaching its peak. **********The record change in closing price from one day's session to the next is $5.41, set last Oct. 22. Trading was heavy yesterday, at 126,000 contracts, but short of the record of 185,000 set last Aug. 7.  Petroleum Products Advance **********Heating oil for delivery next month closed at 77.09 a gallon, up 2.79 cents, and unleaded gasoline closed at 73.31 cents, up 3.13 cents. **********For some traders, however, the volatility yesterday was evidence that in a war, the market could test the price-movement limit recently set in place by the exchange -- a move of $15 a barrel in one day. **********"If the market can move $7 in five minutes on a just a press conference, you can well imagine that it could do more in a war," said Nauman Barakat, a vice president at Merrill Lynch. "It's certainly possible that the $15 limit could be reached." **********Another analyst, Peter C. Beutel, said, "The thing that has made this market so volatile is the black-and-white nature of the negotiations." Mr. Beutel, who is with the Pegasus Econometric Group, said, "There was no place to be in a middle ground." **********But other market-watchers said there was meaning to be gleaned from the fact that the swing was not even larger. At the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington-based consulting group, J. Robinson West, the president, said, "Although we may be closer to war, timewise and in terms of options, the price was $10 lower than the peak reached earlier." **********The reason, he said, was that the trading yesterday "was not an international economic panic, just a traders' panic." When prices peaked above $40 a barrel in October, he said, "all eyes realized that there was a quantum change in trading oil, the fundamental commodity of international trade." This time, he said, it was "traders watching short-term spikes." **********Vahan Zanoyan, an analyst at the same company, said that if peace actually prevailed, prices would decline below yesterday's $24, and if war came, they would rise above $31. **********This is not the first instance of a huge increase in the price of oil, but the market yesterday was substantially different from the last two crises -- during the Arab oil embargo of 1973-74 and following the fall of the Shah of Iran in 1979. This price revolution is televised, on thousands of monitor screens around the world, making the volatility far more obvious and inviting participants -- oil producers, oil users and speculators -- to join in, perhaps driving the changes even further. **********But the market is working well, said Nachama Jacobovitz, a spokeswoman for the exchange. No matter what the price at any moment, she said, "people were able to lock in the prices they wanted to."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/busin.main_headline: NEC May Acquire Stake In Ailing Bull of France
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; NEC May Acquire Stake In Ailing Bull of France
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/busin.body_text: **********The NEC Corporation, one of Japan's largest computer makers, said today that it was negotiating with Compagnie des Machines Bull about buying shares in the faltering French computer giant. **********NEC offered few details, but a spokesman said that if an agreement was reached NEC would acquire no more than 10 percent of Bull. It would be the second Japanese investment in a major European computer company in less than a year. Bull is mostly owned by the French Government. **********In Paris, a spokesman for Bull said the Tokyo talks were aimed at "accommodating" the stake that NEC already has in a Bull subsidiary based in the United States after recent shifts in Bull's corporate structure. He refused to say whether fresh money would also be involved. **********Bull, France's largest computer maker, is among the hardest-hit of Europe's computer and electronics makers. A selloff of part of the company has been considered all but inevitable. **********Bull lost $1.2 billion in 1990, and has grown increasingly dependent on NEC for its most critical mainframe computer technology. For months, French officials have been urging Bull's management to seek help from abroad, chiefly from NEC. **********NEC said that it had "not yet decided" how to respond to Bull's request for an equity investment. But there seems little doubt that NEC -- in its effort to assure that Fujitsu, Japan's largest computer maker, does not gain too large a lead in the European market -- will take a stake. **********Bull's economic condition is so severe that France recently pledged more than $1 billion to shore up the company and pay for its research. But computer industry experts say that money will barely scratch the surface. To try to broaden its product line in the 1980's, the company bought the computer businesses of Honeywell Inc. and the personal computer business of Zenith Electronics. **********NEC and Bull have long had technical agreements, and in the United States they operate a venture to sell NEC supercomputers. NEC owns about 15 percent of Bull HN, which controls Bull's overseas operations. The Italian and British operations, previously attached to this American subsidiary, have been transferred to Bull's European division. As a result, the Bull spokesman in Paris said, it was necessary to "accommodate" NEC's stake in Bull HN in the company's new structure.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/busin.main_headline: Ammirati Drops Next Inc., Fearing Conflict With Nikon
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Ammirati Drops Next Inc., Fearing Conflict With Nikon
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/busin.body_text: **********AMMIRATI & PURIS has resigned the estimated $4 million account for Next Inc., the Redwood City, Calif., computer company, because of the possibility that Next and Ammirati's newest client, the Nikon Photo Group will produce competing products. **********"We felt compelled to resign because of a conflict that may exist between Nikon and Next," Martin Puris, president and chief executive of Ammirati & Puris, said yesterday. In a statement, Mr. Puris said Nikon's current involvement in electronic imaging and its future plans in that area could create an "uncomfortable situation" if the agency continued to represent Next. **********Ammirati, which creates ads for BMW and the United Parcel Service, received the $15 million Nikon account in December. **********Some computer industry consultants said it was possible that Nikon Photo, part of Japan's Nikon Corporation, was exploring technology that would put it in direct competition with Next. Nikon now produces digital scanners, which "read" photographs and convert pictures into electronic impulses that can be used by computers. This electronic imaging is most commonly used in publishing. Some consultants said Nikon might be considering a move into the computer end of the process. **********Some consultants said Nikon might have been concerned because Next introduced a new computer work station in September that is capable of producing the complicated color electronic imaging that is used in animation and publishing. **********Stephen Gardner, an executive vice president at Ammirati, said the agency would not elaborate on what specific new products from either Nikon or Next would be competitive. **********Richard Lo Pinto, the marketing division manager at Nikon, would not comment about Nikon's product plans or any possible conflict with Next. **********For its part, Next seemed somewhat baffled by Ammirati's move. Karen Sipprell, director of marketing communications at Next, said the company had no knowledge of any competitive situation with Nikon. **********Some agency executives said Nikon might have also been concerned because one of its rivals in photographic equipment, Canon, was an investor in Next. But Ms. Sipprell said that as far as she knew Canon's investment was not a problem. **********Advertising and computer executives said they were not surprised that Ammirati was willing to give up the Next account. For one thing, the Next account had a high profile when Steve P. Jobs, the company's founder, introduced his new computer in the fall of 1988. In addition to the widespread publicity, ads appeared in leading newspapers and business magazines like Forbes, Fortune and Business Week. But lately, ads for Next have only appeared in specialized computer magazines like PC Week. **********In addition, Mr. Jobs is widely considered in the advertisiing industry to be a difficult client. Several executives who have worked with him say he often insists on changing finished advertising against an agency's advice. Some of these executives said that although Mr. Jobs always challenged agencies to do innovative work, he often demanded so much control over the creative process that it hampered his agencies. **********In response, Ms. Sipprell said agencies that have worked with Mr. Jobs have "appreciated the challenge of being part of a marketing partnership" and have not seen his involvement as an "adversarial relationship."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/world.main_headline: Gains Seen in de Klerk-Mandela Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/world.print_headline: Gains Seen in de Klerk-Mandela Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/world.body_text: **********On the eve of a deadline set by the African National Congress for the curtailing of township violence, President F. W. de Klerk and the congress leader, Nelson Mandela, appeared to have made progress today in their search for a solution to the crisis. **********Mr. de Klerk said that more matters remained to be discussed but that he and Mr. Mandela had made "good progress" in more than three hours of talks at a secret location in Pretoria. **********"We are able and willing to assure you that we won't be immobilized by a deadlock situation," Mr. de Klerk said at the Pretoria Press Club this evening. He did not go into details. **********He indicated that a statement might be issued tomorrow, once the two leaders consult with their constituencies. Mr. de Klerk is scheduled to meet with his Cabinet in Cape Town and Mr. Mandela is expected to report to his congress's National Executive Committee.  Obstacle to Talks **********The President called violence the most serious single obstacle to negotiations that he has proposed on a new constitution that would give political rights to the black majority. **********A congress official reported that Mr. Mandela took a tough line today in conveying his organization's views to President de Klerk. **********On April 5, the African National Congress delivered an ultimatum that it would boycott discussions on a conference of political parties and subsequent negotiations on a new constitution unless the Government met its terms for ending the violence by May 9. **********Tonight, the Government moved to address the congress's broader complaint that security forces have ignored political violence in the townships, which has killed well over 600 people this year, including more than 120 this month. **********The Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok announced that more police officers and soldiers would be deployed in townships hit by unrest as part of a crackdown called Operation Stabilize. **********A statement released by his office spoke of eight townships around Johannesburg that are already designated as unrest areas, and said they would be subjected to stricter curfews and more roadblocks, cordons and searches. **********The townships affected are Soweto and two satellite municipalities, Meadowlands and Diepkloof; and Alexandra, Tembisa, Thokoza, Katlehong and Vosloorus, all of which were hit by factional violence in recent weeks.  Ban on Gatherings **********Outdoor gatherings would be prohibited for two weeks, Mr. Vlok's statement said, with exceptions for church and sports events and funerals. Recent political rallies held by the Inkatha Freedom Party have become catalysts for bloodshed. **********Mr. Vlok's statement said nothing about banning weapons, including traditional spears, clubs and other arms brandished by Inkatha supporters. The issue of eliminating such weapons figured prominently in talks that President de Klerk held yesterday with the Inkatha leader, Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi. **********The Government mounted a similar crackdown last September after violence became intense, but the effort only temporarily stopped the killing. **********Today, hundreds of members of the women's and youth leagues of the congress mounted demonstrations and sit-ins to call attention to the issue. At least 155 people were reported arrested. **********In its April 5 ultimatum, the African National Congress set these conditions: that Mr. Vlok and Defense Minister Magnus Malan be dismissed; that weapons be banned at public rallies and marches; that counterinsurgency units be dismantled; that police officers involved in two fatal confrontations be suspended; that police officers assigned to crowd control not be issued live ammunition; that single-sex migrant workers' hostels, which have been flashpoints for violence, be phased out; and that an independent commission of inquiry be established to investigate complaints of misconduct by the security forces. **********While the congress is said to be willing to relax its demand for the dismissals of Mr. Vlok and Mr. Malan, whom Mr. de Klerk has defended, it needs to show supporters concrete steps to restore order in the townships.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/27/busin.main_headline: Former Fed Governor Named Visa President
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/27/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Former Fed Governor Named Visa President
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/27/busin.body_text: **********How is the Visa credit-card system like the Federal Reserve? H. Robert Heller, who knows both institutions, says they have a lot in common. **********Yesterday, Mr. Heller, 51, was named president of Visa U.S.A. Inc., one of five regional units of Visa International. Since 1989, he has been executive vice president of Visa International and before that was a Fed governor in Washington. **********Mr. Heller takes a post that is being relinquished by Charles T. Russell, 61, who will continue as chief executive of Visa U.S.A. Mr. Russell is also president and chief executive of Visa International, the parent organization. **********"In a way, there are a lot of similarities between Visa and the Fed," Mr. Heller said yesterday. "Both are headquarters of a large associaton of banks and financial institutions. Visa in the U.S. alone has 19,500 institutions, while the Fed has 6,000 or 7,000 banks that it supervises directly." **********Another similarity, he said, is that the Fed and Visa run large-scale payment systems, Visa with credit payments from consumers and the Fed with its interbank payment system and its check-clearing operations. **********"We're competitive with the Fed, also," Mr. Heller noted. "Our purpose it to try to replace the check with plastic." **********Mr. Heller joined the Fed in 1986 and left in 1989 with six years to go on his term, indicating at the time that he needed a doubling or tripling of his $82,500 Fed salary. Mr. Heller said he had not regretted the decision. **********The Persian Gulf war, he said, has had little effect on Visa business. "When the war broke out," he said, "there was a sharp drop in the growth rate, and it went down for the next four or five days. But then people got tired of sitting at home and went out to catch up. So it looked like a big valley at first and then sort of a mountain." **********Before joining the Fed, Mr. Heller spent eight years at the Bank of America, where he was director of international economics. The bank, incidentally, once owned Visa, which is now owned by its member banks in proportion to the business they generate. **********Mr. Heller was born in Cologne, Germany. He is a graduate of the University of Minnesota and holds a doctorate from the University of California at Berkeley. He taught at several institutions, including the University of California at Los Angeles and the University of Hawaii before joining the International Monetary Fund, where he worked from 1974 to 1978, moving on to the Bank of America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/27/world.main_headline: In Addis Ababa, a War Comes Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/27/world.print_headline: In Addis Ababa, a War Comes Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/27/world.body_text: **********With rebels at the outskirts of this Ethiopian capital, residents here today demonstrated all the emotions associated with a crisis. **********Some people showed great tenderness, some the deepest sorrow, some anger, while others refused to give up hope that Ethiopia could still be saved from disintegration. **********A mother's wails echoed through the rotunda of St. George's Cathedral. **********"God, please don't let my son be dead," Zenbetch Haile, 60 years old, cried as she bowed before a mural of St. George slaying the dragon. **********Alarmed by the woman's hysteria, a man helped her up and wrapped his arms around her until she stopped shaking. He asked her what had happened.  Her Son Is a Soldier **********She said her 19-year-old son was a soldier based in Asmara, the northern provincial capital captured by Eritrean separatists Friday after weeks of heavy shelling, trench fighting and finally block-to-block combat. **********"I can't live without him," she sobbed as she wiped her tears away with her white shawl. **********Outside the graceful old church, where cows grazed and legless beggars wheeled themselves around on planks of wood riding on ball bearings, a Coptic Christian monk in a yellow robe gathered a flock of 40 worshipers. **********"All these plagues -- the famines and the war -- have come down on us because we gave up religion for the idols of Communism," said the monk. "Now that we have torn down that Lenin statue we can be saved." **********Still, the bad news from the battlefront continued today at the same numbing pace as it had for the last 10 days. Tigrean rebels, often disparaged by the capital's Amhara ethnic majority, captured the air force's principal base, 15 miles southeast of the capital. **********The three loosely aligned rebel groups are scheduled to open American-sponsored peace talks with the Government in London this week, giving many here a straw of hope. The guerrillas, however, hold all the bargaining chips, and until recent months they consistently espoused Marxist doctrine not very different from the Government's.  'The Americans Must Help Us' **********"The Americans must help us," Girma Debela, a 32-year-old electrician, pleaded to an American visitor at St. George's Cathedral. "The Americans have the solution for Kuwait. Maybe they have the solution for us, too." **********At nearby Abuna Petros Square, which is dedicated to one of the nation's war heroes against the Italian occupation in the 1930's, a group of 250 university students gathered today for a peace demonstration. **********Not long ago, many of these students espoused the Government's hard-line brand of socialism, but today they made no mention of any ideology. Waving Ethiopian flags, they chanted "We don't need war!" and "One country, one people!" **********Those were words that displayed more hope than realism. The aspirations for unity are shared by the tottering Government and the Bush Administration, but the Eritrean People's Liberation Army, one of the two major rebel groups that will be represented at the talks, now controls all of that Red Sea province and pledges to fight on until it wins a provincial referendum on independence. **********This highland capital of three million people has not yet descended into the chaos that much of the rest of the country has, but there are troubling signs. Foreign residents and Ethiopians who can afford to have been flying out by the hundreds. **********Some shopowners of Tigrean descent have boarded up their stores in fear that the defeated troops will take their frustrations out on them. Although it does not seem that the troops are responsible for any widespread abuses, many residents say soldiers are firing off their weapons for one reason or another.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/26/world.main_headline: Israel Held Likely to Agree To U.S. Site for Peace Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/26/world.print_headline: Israel Held Likely to Agree To U.S. Site for Peace Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/26/world.body_text: **********Israeli officials said today that they were all but certain to agree to resuming peace talks in Washington next week, but added that they want the meetings to be brief, confined to procedural matters and then moved to a new location in or near the Middle East. **********As expected, Israel let the day pass without formally answering a United States request for a yes or no to its invitation to get direct negotiations going again with neighboring Arab states and the Palestinians, this time in Washington on Dec. 4. **********Officials said they did not view today as a do-or-die deadline. **********Besides, some allowed that the irritation level remains high here over the shabby way in which many Israelis feel the Bush Administration had treated their Prime Minister last week. So Israel will act in its own time, they said -- certainly not until Wednesday and perhaps not even until Sunday, when the full Cabinet is scheduled to meet next. **********That would not leave much time before negotiators are supposed to be in Washington to pick up where they left off in Madrid three weeks ago in their direct talks with delegations from Syria and Lebanon and a joint team of Jordanians and Palestinians. **********For all that, there seemed little question that Israel will eventually say yes, as Jordan and Lebanon already have. And if Lebanon goes to Washington, it is presumably only because its chief patron, Syria, plans to attend as well. Palestinian leaders in Israeli-held territories say they are also disposed to go but first want to clear up questions about American visas for their representatives. **********While the Israelis in their hesitation have focused almost exclusively on issues of form -- the where, when and how of negotiations -- they insist that these matters bear substantive implications. **********Above all, a senior official said, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is "very, very determined" to have the talks moved quickly to the Middle East, or at least to a nearby site like Cyprus. Therefore, he said, the goal is to have at most a session or two in Washington, and at that the discussions should be focused not on pivotal matters of land and peace but rather on more mundane questions about how to proceed next. **********The newspaper Haaretz reported today that the Israeli Government also wants to make sure that its Washington meetings with various Arab delegations do not take place at the same time or in the same place, to avoid even the appearance that a regional peace conference is under way, with Israel sitting alone among the Arabs. **********But the desire to dwell for now on procedure instead of substance could run afoul of the Bush Administration, which hopes to give a kick-start to discussions on the real issues dividing Israel and its neighbors. **********According to the Israeli press, the letters of invitation sent by the United States last week to the parties included proposals on central matters like the Golan Heights, the self-declared Israeli security zone in southern Lebanon and Palestinian autonomy in Israeli-occupied territories. **********For instance, the Americans reportedly recommended that Israel determine that it would withdraw from the Golan Heights in exchange for a peace treaty with Syria. They also were said to have proposed that the Israelis and Palestinians each suggest a model for Palestinian self-rule but that they delay discussions of issues that could become stumbling blocks, such as who will control land and water resources.  Intervention by Bush **********To the Israelis, form is intertwined with substance because they fret that what the Arabs really want is to deadlock the talks and have the Americans impose a settlement. According to their argument, designating Washington as a permanent site for negotiations would make it relatively easy for President Bush at some point to intervene, personally and dramatically. **********Such a solution, it is further argued, is not likely to favor Israel. **********American impartiality in the Middle East has been openly questioned by Mr. Shamir and many of his Cabinet ministers ever since the peace process moved into high gear last summer. A series of clashes in recent months have soured relations with Washington. **********And although Israeli concerns have hardly been ignored, there is a restiveness within the Government here that the United States has a foot in the Arab camp, or at least a couple of toes.  Israeli Feelings Bruised **********Those bruised feelings deepened after the State Department sent out its invitations to come to Washington only hours before Mr. Shamir called on Mr. Bush at the White House. This was seen by many Israelis as humiliating treatment of their national leader, and a senior aide to Mr. Shamir said that he found the anti-Washington resentments to be running surprisingly high. **********Criticism of recent American behavior has come from all political corners, including people who strongly disapprove of Mr. Shamir. But there are also many Israelis who say that the United States had to take decisive, perhaps even rude, action to get the talks going again; otherwise, they argue, Mr. Shamir would pile one delay atop another. **********"On the record?" an opposition member of Parliament said. "It's horrible what the Americans did. Off the record? I love it. As Woody Allen said, if the end doesn't justify the means, what does?"

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/15/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Icahn Stake In Southland
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/15/busin.body_text: **********A group of investment companies headed by Carl C. Icahn disclosed today that it had acquired a 5.1 percent stake in the Southland Corporation, operators of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain. **********Mr. Icahn, a takeover strategist who is also chairman of Trans World Airlines, said that as of Wednesday he controlled 20.9 million shares of Southland stock as a result of the Dallas-based company's reorganization. **********A Federal bankruptcy judge approved Southland's reorganization plan last month, clearing the way for a $430 million takeover by two Japanese companies. **********Under the reorganization plan, the Ito-Yokado Company and the Seven-Eleven Japan Company will pay $430 million for 70 percent of Southland. **********Southland stockholders, primarily the founding Thompson family, will retain a 5 percent stake. **********The other 25 percent will belong to holders of bonds issued in 1987 to finance Southland's $4.9 billion leveraged buyout. The face value of the notes, whose holders include Mr. Icahn, will be cut by more than half.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/13/world.main_headline: Cambodians See the Return of Prince Sihanouk as the Best Hope for Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/13/world.print_headline: Cambodians See the Return of Prince Sihanouk as the Best Hope for Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/13/world.body_text: **********The young dancers knelt at the feet of Chea Samy and presented her with small bundles of incense, their tribute to a woman who is considered a master of the art of ancient Khmer dance -- and one of the few master teachers who managed somehow to survive the terrors of the Khmer Rouge. **********Miss Chea Samy, now 73 years old, says she is overwhelmed by the scheduled return to Phnom Penh this week by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the long-exiled former King of Cambodia, who is seen by many here as Cambodia's best hope for peace after what has been nearly a full generation of war. **********"Maybe there can be peace now after so much pain," Miss Chea Samy said, sitting barefoot on the tile floor and watching intently as the dancers of Cambodia's national troupe went through the delicate, stylized motions of classical Khmer dance, rehearsing for this weekend's gala performance for the prince. "The Khmer Rouge killed much of my family, and they tried to kill my art. We believe Prince Sihanouk is a man of peace." Looking to Peace **********The Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh, an ancient city of gentle, faded beauty that has known little in recent years but brutal oppression or civil war, is finally allowing itself to consider the possibility that peace has arrived, and that it could last. **********On Thursday, Prince Sihanouk, who ruled this country before his overthrow in 1970, and has been in exile for all but a few years since, is to return to Phnom Penh. The event will mark the formation of a national reconciliation council led by Prince Sihanouk that will help run the country in consultation with the United Nations until free elections are held in 1993 under a peace accord signed in Paris last month. **********This week, for the first time since Phnom Penh was overrun -- and emptied -- by the Communist Khmer Rouge 16 years ago, the Cambodian capital is bustling with diplomats and journalists who have come here not to track the battles, but to assess the peace. **********The guerrilla fighters are on their way home, as well. Leaders of the American-backed Khmer People's National Liberation Front, one of four factions that will share power in the new government, landed at the city's international airport today to join in the celebrations. 'Happy to Be Home' **********"We are very happy to be home," said the rebel group's chief of cabinet, Pen Thol, who had not been in the capital, his home, in 16 years. **********The biggest crowds in Phnom Penh this week have been in front of a modern whitewashed villa a few blocks from the languorous Tonle Sap River, where about 40 Australian soldiers working as United Nations peacekeeping troops have set up heir headquarters. **********"It makes me feel relief," said Pan Tao, a cook who had come with her seven-year-old son to watch the high-spirited Australians in their green jungle fatigues unload trucks of communications gear they will use to monitor the cease-fire. "We now have soldiers of peace, and that is better." **********The preparations to welcome Prince Sihanouk home are in evidence everywhere in the city, from the last dabs of ochre paint applied to the newly renovated royal palace to the two-story-high portraits of the Prince that are being readied for the airport and the main thoroughfare into the city. **********The five Sihanouk billboards have drawn much comment because they are based on a quite flattering photograph that is at least 15 years old. 'Welcome the Prince Home' **********"I know that the Prince now has gray hair, not black hair, but this is the photograph that the Ministry of Culture wants us to use," said Le Ly, a 45-year-old billboard painter who stood atop wooden scaffolding along the roadway to paint the left eyebrow on the mercurial Prince. **********"It does not matter," he said, pushing back his wide-brimmed straw hat and grinning. "We will welcome the Prince home no matter what color his hair is. The Prince must come back so there will be peace." **********While Prince Sihanouk has long been in exile -- from 1970 to 1975, and again since 1979, when he was allowed to flee to China ahead of advancing Vietnamese troops -- the Prince still evokes strong and to a large degree affectionate memories among the residents of Phnom Penh. **********There is some bitterness about Prince Sihanouk's willingness to make peace with the Khmer Rouge, and lingering resentment of his association with the fanatical group in the early 1970's; he served briefly as a figurehead under the Khmer Rouge when it came to power in 1975, before quickly falling out of favor and being placed under house arrest for several years. **********But the so-called changeling Prince, now 69 years old, is seen as the one Cambodian who might be able to unify the nation and to bring about a stable peace. Khmer Rouge Also Returning **********"I am proud to do this painting of a man of peace," said Keo Ty, another of the billboard painters. "It is a happy time for all Cambodians." **********Even as the people of Phnom Penh ready themselves for the return of the prince, their exhilaration is tempered by the knowledge that the dreaded Khmer Rouge will soon return to the capital as well. **********Under the United Nations peace accord, the Khmer Rouge, the most powerful guerrilla faction in the long Cambodian civil war, is part of the coalition government and will be permitted to put forward candidates in the national election. **********During its four-year reign, which ended with a Vietnamese invasion in 1978, the Khmer Rouge pursued a radical, peasant-driven collectivist revolution and in the process presided over the deaths of more than one million Cambodians by execution, starvation or disease. **********Many residents of Phnom Penh think the Khmer Rouge and its paramount leader, Pol Pot, are capable of doing it all over again. Western diplomats reported over the weekend that the Khmer Rouge, in violation of the peace accord, is hiding troops and huge cache of weapons in the mountains for a possible return to armed conflict. Enraged by Khmer Rouge **********"When the Pol Potists come back to Phnom Penh, I do not know what I will do," said Ros Sophal, a 34-year-old dancer in the classical dance troupe that will be performing for the Prince on Sunday. "If I could get near them, I would hit them. I would hurt them." **********Mrs. Ros Sophal has reason to be enraged. Her husband, a young soldier in the American-backed Government of Premier Lon Nol, was executed by the Khmer Rouge, as were several other relatives. **********When Phnom Penh was emptied by the Khmer Rouge days after they took the city in 1975, she was forced into the countryside, where, like millions of other Cambodians, Mrs. Ros Sophal was required to work in the fields day and night for the sake of the Khmer Rouge revolution. "We would begin at 4 o'clock in he morning and we would work until midnight," she said. "Every day. For years." **********There was also the fear, she said, that the Khmer Rouge would learn that she had been trained as a classical dancer -- often a capital offense under a government that saw Khmer dance as a vestige of the old decadence. **********Toni Shapiro, a 34-year-old Cornell University doctoral student in anthropology who has been in Cambodia for more than a year studying Khmer dance, said that 90 percent of all of Cambodia's classical dancers and other professional artists are believed to have been killed during the Khmer Rouge era. **********"Not a day goes by here when somebody doesn't mention something about the Khmer Rouge and about their relatives who were killed by the Khmer Rouge," she said as she watched the national troupe rehearse for its Sunday performance for the Prince. "I see the tears everyday."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/24/busin.main_headline: Wall Street; Off the Beaten Bankruptcy Path
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/24/busin.print_headline: Wall Street; Off the Beaten Bankruptcy Path
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/24/busin.body_text: **********John C. Boland, a former newspaperman, labors over his computer keyboard in a brick garret whose walls are lined with vintage paperback mystery novels, while tea cools in a lumpy pottery mug and four cats (one named Mouse) grumble in the cozy kitchen two floors below. **********The result of all this homespun activity is Bankruptcy Values, one of the quirkiest institutional newsletters in the burgeoning field of bankruptcy investing. **********Let others on Wall Street huff and puff over the prospect of investing in well-worn bankruptcies like Continental Holdings or Revco. As editor and publisher of Bankruptcy Values, Mr. Boland travels off the beaten path, seeking old-fashioned bargains among the most obscure veterans of Chapter 11. "I take a rigid value approach," he said, after hushing the cats and fielding the phone. "In fact, the popularity of a situation is a sure sign to me that it's getting dangerous." **********And those signs are proliferating sharply these days, Mr. Boland warns, as more Wall Street players flock to the distressed securities game. "The business is attracting a lot of people whose very presence is lowering the returns. This business is a seesaw -- and we are in a terrible swing downward right now." **********Some of the companies Mr. Boland follows, while hardly household names, have had spectacular recoveries after leaving Chapter 11. He was an early investor in the various securities of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, which filed for bankruptcy protection in August 1987 and emerged on Jan. 22 in reorganized form. As the company cleared the courthouse door, Mr. Boland continued to recommend its stock, which was trading around $4 a share. But the shares have traded as high as $5.875 in recent weeks, and Mr. Boland said last week that he now thinks they are a trifle expensive. "I wouldn't be an aggressive buyer here, unless I knew something was up," he said. "And I don't." **********There have been duds in Mr. Boland's portfolio, too -- companies that went from obscurity to oblivion. "This is a business where there is so much risk in everything you do that you have to be prepared to look like a fool for a long time before something works," he said. "And sometimes, you just stop and try something else." **********In some ways, that is how Mr. Boland came to be producing Bankruptcy Values. An editor at the Baltimore Sun and then a senior editor at Barron's, he struck off on his own in 1983. First came a book on Wall Street personalities, and then his first newsletter, Value Investing in Special Situations. Through it all, he managed to work primarily from his attic office in the narrow brick townhouse he bought nearly 20 years ago in Baltimore's Fells Point section. **********After the 1987 crash, Mr. Boland scrapped his first newsletter and focused on Bankruptcy Values. But his latest picks have already left bankruptcy behind. That's where the values are, he said. **********Unfortunately, many of his favorites are low-priced and volatile stocks that trade infrequently and are largely ignored by analysts. Acknowledging those risks, Mr. Boland insists on an extremely diverse portfolio and does a lot of first-hand, albeit reluctant, research. He shuddered as he described a trip through the Nevada sandscape to check out the Mego Corporation, a recent pick. **********But the trip confirmed that Mego, the successor to a bankrupt toy manufacturer, is "a real company, with real assets and real earnings." And real glitter, too: Mego's chairman and one of its large shareholders is Robert Nederlander of the Nederlander Group, whose investments include a big chunk of the Great White Way and the New York Yankees. Another big investor and board member is Wilbur L. Ross of Rothschild Inc., one of the best-known creditor negotiators in the bankruptcy game. With the company's share price roughly equal to its earnings, and considerably lower than book value, Mr. Boland has been buying the stock and advising clients to do likewise. **********Mr. Boland is also recommending a casino company, the Elsinore Corporation, whose tattered past includes ownership of the failed Atlantis casino in Atlantic City. The company's chief asset now is the dowdy Four Queens casino in Las Vegas, but Mr. Boland thinks aggressive management could spruce up the share price considerably. **********That happy prospect seemed likely last year when Elsinore caught the eye of Harold Goldsmith, the co-founder of Merry-Go-Round Enterprises, the retail clothing chain. After acquiring nearly 20 percent of Elsinore, Mr. Goldsmith announced in January that he planned to seek control. But on Feb. 13, he was killed in the crash of a chartered jet approaching the Aspen, Colo., airport. **********That tragedy raises a host of uncertainties for Elsinore, Mr. Boland said. "The main question now is where his Elsinore shares will go." He added: "In aggressive hands, it could be positive. And the stock is very cheap on a cash-flow basis, so I'll stay with it and wait for a spark. But there aren't many Harold Goldsmiths around." **********The management factor also figures in Mr. Boland's view of the Texscan Corporation of El Paso, a cable television equipment manufacturer. Mr. Boland recommended the stock last summer but grew cautious last month when William H. Lambert, the company's chairman, proposed a management buyout. No price has been disclosed, he noted, although the company's shares have climbed to nearly $8, from around $6. "It's an arbitrager's business from $8 on," he said. "I've been a seller at these prices." **********Mr. Boland doesn't spend all his time poring through corporate casualty lists. He travels with his wife, Miga -- to his astonishment, he loved Paris, he says. He fusses with the lawyer next door over the backyard landscaping. And somehow, between bankruptcies, he finds time to write mystery novels. His latest, due out soon from St. Martin's Press, is set on Wall Street but is obviously    not    autobiographical: it is called "Easy Money."
