https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Government recorded a small budget surplus of $1.76 billion in January, despite sharply lower tax receipts from corporations, the Treasury Department said today. **********The surplus in January, the fourth month of the 1991 fiscal year, compared with a deficit of $7.3 billion in December. In January a year ago, there was a surplus of $8.28 billion. **********With the country in recession, money from corporate income taxes fell to $3.83 billion last month from $22.52 billion in December. Most corporations make payments once a quarter based on their estimated earnings for the period. **********Tax payments by individuals increased to $50.88 billion, from $46.47 billion in December. **********Military spending on fell last month to $20.87 billion from$25.17 billion in December despite the beginning of the Persian Gulf war in mid-January. **********Total Government income in January was $101.80 billion, down from $102.27 billion in December. Spending fell last month to $100.04 billion from $109.58 billion in December.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/09/busin.body_text: **********The Mobil Corporation may be responsible for cleaning up wastes at 47 sites under the Federal Superfund program, a fact not disclosed in the company's annual report. **********A subsidiary of the Amoco Corporation tried to install hazardous-waste incinerators on Indian lands, ostensibly to avoid state and Federal emissions regulations. **********The American Cyanamid Company releases four times as much toxic waste into the environment per $1,000 of sales as the average chemical company. **********These nuggets of information -- not denied by the companies involved -- are in a series of environmental profiles being published by the Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit group in New York that monitors social policies of large corporations. The reports are intended to appeal to socially conscious investors and to encourage companies to minimize pollution. **********The council's reports are part of a growing effort by public interest and environmental groups to examine and publish analyses of the vast amounts of environmental data that the Government has required companies to file in recent years. Early next year, the Investor Responsibility Research Center, a Washington-based organization that conducts investment research for university endowments and pension funds, will publish statistical summaries of the environmental performance of all 500 companies in the Standard & Poor's index. **********Both organizations sell their research, but are operated on a nonprofit basis. **********While not refuting many of the specific statements in the council reports, the companies contend that the documents distort their environmental performance by dwelling largely on past problems. **********Other groups are digging into environmental data as well. Friends of the Earth, for instance, issued a critical 112-page study of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's environmental performance in August in response to television advertisements the company has run that depict animals applauding Du Pont's decision to use double-hull oil tankers. The group said the Du Pont study was the first of a series of reports on what it calls "corporate environmentalism." **********The new reports come in addition to the annual compilations of toxic emissions issued by Citizens Fund, another public advocacy group. **********Industrial companies are required by the Government to report their emission levels for several hundred chemicals believed to be toxic, even if the emissions are within permitted limits. Citizen Fund aggregates the plant-by-plant data submitted by the companies and characterizes the chemical as acutely toxic, cancer causing or linked to birth defects. Since the data were first published three years ago, many major corporations, including Du Pont, Mobil and the Monsanto Company, have announced programs to cut their emissions sharply. **********Some officials of environmental groups have said that publication of the toxic emission data has had a more powerful effect on reducing pollution than 20 years of regulation by the Environmental Protection Agency. William Reilly, the administrator of E.P.A., described the data as "one of the most important tools we have to reduce toxic emissions."  Range of Environmental Criteria **********The new reports go beyond toxic emissions to look into data concerning E.P.A. enforcement actions and fines paid, Superfund liabilities reported in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and published accounts of environmentally related incidents. Alice Tepper Marlin, the director of the Council on Economic Priorities, said the reports came in response to requests by users of the group's other research services. **********"The environment has emerged as the No. 1 concern with much of our audience," she said. The group also publishes "Shopping for a Better World" and "The Better World Investment Guide," both of which rank companies on a variety of social criteria, including advancement of women and minorities, animal testing and charitable giving. **********Margaret Carroll, executive director of the Investor Responsibility Research Center, said investors were beginning to realize that sloppy environmental policies could hamper the financial performance of companies. "This is not so much a moral or ethical issue as one that potentially affects the bottom line," she said. "There may be indications in the data of future liabilities." **********One example, said Scott Fenn, another official of Investor Responsibility, is Superfund liabilities. Legally, each company involved in a site is liable for the complete cost of cleanup, although in practice the cost is usually spread among several companies. **********Knowing that one company has dozens of Superfund liabilities and has paid large fines for environmental violations could help an investment manager evaluate it against another that has little liability and few fines. **********Ms. Tepper Marlin said the 35 companies covered in the first set of reports were given an opportunity to review the findings and supply additional material.  Mobil's Protest **********A sampling of the companies involved indicates they are uncomfortable with the council's analysis, even when some of their responses are included in final drafts. In a letter to Jonathan Schorsch, the council's project director, Mobil described its profile as "incomplete and unwarranted." **********In particular, the company objected to the council's use of published accounts of environmental incidents without any effort to check the underlying facts. "Conclusions reached in the profile appear to be based, at least in part, upon a combination of limited factual information and unproven newspaper allegations, media perceptions and incomplete reports," the company said in a six-page letter to the council. **********At Amoco, Walter R. Quanstrom, the vice president for environmental affairs and safety, "commended" the group for including many of the company's comments, but questioned what he called a misplaced emphasis on a small subsidiary. **********Mr. Quanstrom said it was true that the company's Waste-Tech Services unit opened negotiations with some Indian groups about building incinerators on their land, but said the company backed away from the proposal and none was actually built. **********"Waste Tech represents less than one one-hundredth of Amoco's revenues, but they have a whole page on it," Mr. Quanstrom said. "I think that is a wee bit overplayed." **********Mr. Quanstrom of Amoco said he had observed a trend toward measuring the environmental performance of companies much the way financial performance has long been analyzed. "I think what we're going to do is develop some rules," he said, "so that apples are measured against apples." **********Charlotte Cuff, public affairs director for American Cynamid, said that the council had not used most of the material her company provided in support of its position and that the council added allegations after the company reviewed an early draft. The report, she said, "should have little credibility as a source of information." **********The Council on Economic Priorities plans to profile an aditional 100 companies next year and plans to be monitoring 500 by 1996. The individual reports are available on a sliding- fee scale ranging from $20 for individuals and small nonprofit institutions to $100 for corporations. **********The Investor Responsibility Research Center, in contrast to the 20- to 50-page reports issued by the council, confines its statistical summaries to two pages.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/03/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; For Shakespeare, Just Log On
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/03/busin.body_text: **********The development of a nationwide data network will allow personal computer users to tap sources as large as the Library of Congress or receive their own personalized electronic newspapers. **********Several innovations, taken together, have already demonstrated that searching vast computer data bases can be easier than consulting a card catalogue, and not nearly as difficult or expensive as computer searches are today. Computer users might read some Dickens more readily than they could check out David Copperfield from the local library. **********Those in the industry say that users with little computer skills will soon be able to search through several terabytes of information, or several trillion characters of text, in seconds. The Library of Congress, with 80 million items, contains an estimated 25 terabytes of information. **********Already, an experimental computer library has linked 150 universities to 40 sources of information, ranging from National Institutes of Health data to corporate documents and Shakespeare's plays. New software allows users to browse or zero in on particular information. **********As methods of retrieving information are standardized and perfected, industry executives and computer scientists say, thousands of new services, ranging from electronic newspapers to the computer equivalent of free public libraries, will blossom. "Everyone is realizing how important it is to get into the mass market for information," said Thomas Koulopoulos, president of Delphi Consulting Group, a Boston market research firm. **********Such ready access to huge amounts of computerized information has been the dream of many in the industry. But a lack of computing power, effective software and high-speed digital networks has stalled progess until recently. **********If many of the technical problems are being solved, major business and political disputes remain. The researchers acknowledge that they must resolve several questions of privacy and pricing before they can put the new methods to commercial use. **********Many sources of information, like government documents, might be available free, but other services, including electronic newspapers, will be available only to those who pay. The industry has yet to settle on ways to protect and charge for intellectual property in a computer network where information can be copied instantly. But to encourage progress, the Thinking Machines Corporation, a Cambridge, Mass., supercomputer manufacturer, has made its software available at no charge. **********Some industry enthusiasts say the new technology will transform the way computerized information is sold. Mitchell Kapor, the founder of the Lotus Development Corporation, predicts the growth of a new industry as significant as the personal computer business. Some companies, like the Dow Jones Corporation, that already provide computerized information over telephone lines have taken part in developing the new computer library.  The Search Is Simplified **********In 1989, Thinking Machines enlisted the support of Dow Jones, Apple Computer Inc. and the KPMG Peat Marwick accounting and consulting firm to design the computer library, called Wide Area Information Servers, or WAIS (pronounced ways). The system permits computer users to quickly search through a huge volume of information even if it is stored at several distant locations. **********The system lets users conduct searches by typing common English phrases instead of more complicated computer commands. While current systems like Dialog and Nexis require users to specify precisely the information they want, the new system can respond to a user's inferences. It initially presents a sample list of documents. The user chooses one or several, and then a "relevance feedback" program presents other documents most like the ones selected. **********"This solves the problem of how to get to the information you need, getting not too much and not too little," said Esther Dyson, editor of Release 1.0, a computer industry newsletter. **********This is a sharp contrast to the way services operate today, Ms. Dyson said. A computer user may need to call seven or eight separate data bases depending on the kind of information needed. **********The WAIS system lets users of Apple personal computers harness a network of Thinking Machines supercomputers and smaller "server" computers to search data bases stored by Dow Jones, KPMG and several corporations and universities. Users can also read electronic mail, enter their corporate electronic libraries and summon up a wide variety of documents, newspapers and magazines. A 'Corporate Memory' **********At Thinking Machines, the WAIS system serves as a "corporate memory," allowing employees to retrieve memos, documents and other internal information. Employees who may not be working together can share expertise. **********"If someone did something in Los Angeles and I'm sitting in San Francisco, I may not know about the work," said Robin Palmer, a senior manager at Peat Marwick. **********WAIS delivers information over the Internet, a collection of 2,600 high-speed public and private computer networks. This Government-sponsored system of data highways is rapidly being improved and turned to commercial uses. **********The market for software that allows the rapid retrieval of computerized text is small but growing, according to industry analysts. In 1989, the United States had fewer than 60,000 users; by the next year, total sales were about $120 million. The Delphi Consulting Group expects the market to grow to 160,000 users and $235 million by 1992. **********"Information retrieval technology is starting to spread from supercomputers all the way down to personal computers," said Brewster Kahle, a Thinking Machines scientist who has led the WAIS experiment. **********The WAIS system is built on a procedure for retrieving information developed by librarians who initially set out to computerize their card catalogues. The procedure -- known in the field as Z39.50 -- now has the support of the Library of Congress, Apple, Sun Microsytems Inc., Next Inc., Dow Jones and Mead Data Central. **********In the future, a special directory or "white pages" will keep an up-to-date list of all the separate sources on the network. **********Apple has its own electronic library project, borrowing its name, Rosebud, from the movie "Citizen Kane." The three-year-old project is based on the WAIS system, but adds features including the ability for a user to develop a personalized electronic newspaper. **********Rosebud uses special programs -- called "reporters" -- that let customers specify the kinds of information and news they want to retrieve from the WAIS system every day. Researchers at Apple's Advanced Technology Group said that in the future the necessary retrieval software might be a standard part of a computer's operating system. **********They expect improvements in the Internet computer network to greatly lower the cost of information searches, promoting the introduction of many new services. The Government proposes to expand and improve Internet by financing a National Research and Education Network, or NREN, that could extend a high-speed computer links into schools and communities across the country. **********"With things like NREN, everthing could change overnight," said Tim Oren, an Apple researcher.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/10/world.body_text: **********Washington has suspended new aid to the non-Communist Cambodian factions, Administration, Congressional and non-Communist Cambodian officials say. **********The officials also say that the non-Communist factions, which Washington has long supported, are running short of money because aid left over from the previous fiscal year, which ended last Sept. 30, is now running out. **********At least $7 million in American aid to the non-Communists, authorized and appropriated by Congress for this fiscal year, has not yet been spent, the officials here and in Washington say, because of disputes with Congress over allegations that some past American aid might have benefitted the Communist Khmer Rouge. **********The Bush Administration will try to reach a better understanding of its Cambodian policy with Congress during hearings on Wednesday and Thursday. **********The Khmer Rouge, under whose rule from 1975-79 more than one million Cambodians died, is the strongest partner in a shaky alliance with the two non-Communist factions, one led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk and the other by Son Sann, a former Sihanouk prime minister. **********The non-Communists say they have received no new American money since Feb. 1, and that thousands of hungry refugees who are fleeing to areas under their control thus cannot be fed. But Western diplomats, while not denying that bad harvests have created serious hunger in many areas, say that the non-Communists are using the hunger issue to regain the aid. **********"This American aid was never intended to feed refugees," a senior Western diplomat said. "If people are starving, there will be other resources." **********Concern that the non-Communists might be cooperating on the battlefield with the Khmer Rouge led Congress last year to alter this year's funding. The Administration has said no aid went directly to the Khmer Rouge, but said there were incidents of low-level battlefield coordination. It cut out a covert aid program overseen and administered by American intelligence agencies and required some money to be spent on aid inside Cambodia, in areas controlled by the Government, installed by Vietnam after it drove out the Khmer Rouge. **********Congress had already banned the executive branch from providing any aid to the Khmer Rouge or any "lethal aid" to the non-Communists. The old American program totaled about $24 million a year in both overt and covert aid. This year, however, Congress stipulated that after $7 million in the old overt spending category was disbursed, the Administration would have to report back to Congress and seek approval for up to another $13 million in appropriated spending. The administration must report on whether there has been cooperation between the non-Communists and the Khmer Rouge. **********In addition, Congress ordered that another $5 million be spent inside Cambodia on assistance to needy children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/06/world.main_headline: Iraq Christian Minority Begins to Look for Door
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/06/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Iraq Christian Minority Begins to Look for Door
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/06/world.body_text: **********In the northern Iraqi town of Dohuk the other day, three middle-aged women, enveloped from head to toe in long black veils, did something that is very unusual in this part of the world. **********They walked straight up to a Western male correspondent, and one of them, pulling back her veil, said in English, "We are Christians, and we want to go to America." **********"America, America," her two companions chanted. Then all three crossed themselves fervently several times before scuttling back into the crowd, where they were soon indistinguishable from all the other veiled Muslim women, moving like black cones along the street. **********With the end of the Persian Gulf war and an announcement that Iraqis will be allowed to travel abroad again next month after a nearly nine-year ban, a wave of restlessness is sweeping through this country's roughly 800,000-member Christian minority, with many saying they want to leave for good. Invitation to Leave **********This restlessness attracted at least semi-official attention last week when a magazine called Babil -- the Arabic for Babylon -- that is owned by President Saddam Hussein's son, Udai, published an article suggesting that those disloyal enough to want to leave should do so now. Good riddance to them was the implication. **********The article never mentioned Iraq's Christians by name. But Christians have been quick to see themselves as the target of a rebuke. **********To judge by external signs, Christians here seem as ostentatiously loyal to the present Government in public as everyone else in this country. **********At the Virgin Mary Church, the Rev. Afran Rassam of the Chaldean Catholic Church, an Eastern Rite of Roman Catholicism, keeps a large color picture of President Hussein on his office wall, alongside an even gaudier lithograph depicting the Sacred Heart of Jesus. **********On the living room wall of his house at St. Joseph's Church, the Rev. Louis Shabi, another Chaldean priest, has hung a painted plate carrying a picture of the President in Arab headdress, staring out at the ivory crucifix on the wall opposite. Many Have No Complaints **********Many Christians say they have no complaints about the way the Government has treated them, although they add that they have suffered persecution under earlier regimes. **********Iraq's ruling Baath Party has always been a secular political movement, interested in material goals and with no time for Islamic fundamentalism. **********"This Government has been good to us," Father Shabi says. "We do not complain." **********But he acknowledged that there are "ignorant people" who sometimes accuse the Christians of being Europeans, not Iraqis, although the Chaldeans claim descent from the disciples of the Apostle Thomas, who came here from Jerusalem in the first century, long before the rise of Islam. **********In fact, it is the gulf war more than anything else that has unsettled Christians here. During the conflict, many say, they were identified with the American-led coalition forces attacking the country and were discriminated against. **********A Christian translator recounts how his wife was thrown out of the local shop when she went to collect the family's monthly ration of low-priced food. "They told her, 'If you want food, go and ask Bush for it,' " he said. **********Many other Christians tell of being called Crusaders or "members of the coalition" because of their religion. **********While Iraq's 600,000 Chaldean Catholics are by far the largest Christian group in this predominantly Muslim country of more than 18 million people, there are also smaller numbers of Syrian and Armenian Catholics as well as members of the Orthodox Greek and Armenian faiths and some Protestants. **********For many Christians, the urge to leave stems not only from a sense of oppression resulting from the gulf war but also from a complex mixture of economic and social factors. **********Prospects in general do not seem bright in a country that will probably be shackled with reparation repayments to Kuwait for years. And some Christians fear discrimination against minorities if conditions worsen. Hurt by Economic Slowdown **********Some Christians say the postwar economic slowdown is already hitting them hard. Often better educated than Muslims and fluent in English or French, many had taken jobs with foreign concerns that have now departed or at embassies that are closed. **********Past waves of immigration also mean that Iraqi Christians often have relatives in countries like the United States, Australia and Canada who can help them start a new life abroad. Sometimes foreign branches of their churches help them to emigrate. **********"The young see this as their chance to go," said an Armenian Christian woman who was visiting the Virgin Mary Church today and whose son lives in San Francisco. **********However much they support the Government in public, Iraqi Christians sometimes give the impression that they regard themselves as a beleaguered group by the very piety with which they practice their religion. **********At evening High Mass at the Virgin Mary Church last Sunday, there was barely standing room inside. Rituals Carefully Observed **********A packed congregation sang hymns in Chaldean and Arabic to Arab rhythms thumped out on an electric organ with the gusto of Bible Belt gospelers. **********The finest points of ritual were meticulously observed, with everyone genuflecting and crossing themselves on entering and leaving. **********During the service a steady stream of congregants briefly left their places to kiss the feet of a statue of St. Francis. The entire congregation appeared to take communion. **********Asked to explain such fervor later, Father Shabi smiled gently and recited an ancient Chaldean proverb that says those who have been bitten by a snake always fear the sight of its skin. **********"It means we remember that we have known difficult times," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/28/busin.print_headline: Keep Big Brother Out of Pathmark
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/28/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********I was surprised and dismayed that the Big Brother surveillance aspect of computerized grocery carts was not mentioned in "Push M for Mayo, Sales Pitch Included" (July 7). Invisible infrared triggers on the grocery store ceiling record exactly where customers take their videocarts in each aisle. Data-hungry marketeers will know exactly what goods Jane Doe of 20 Main Street purchased, and when, on a regular basis. **********Why should this bother us? So much of our lives is revealed to strangers through proliferating data banks. I do not want Pathmark to be able to find out how much macaroni I bought this year, and to sell that information. That is part of my private life. Can you imagine if libraries regularly released a list of the books you read each year? Do you want everyone to have access to these details? **********What next? Will I have to punch in my Social Security number to use my grocery cart? Will it monitor what foods I purchase and transmit that information to my doctor, who will reprimand me for high sugar intake; or to my insurance agency, which will deny me benefits because as a diabetic I should not buy so many sugar-rich items? It frightens me to read that customers see these videocarts as helpful. Videocarts are a portentous violation of privacy. TARA M. PHETHEAN  Larchmont, N.Y., July 12

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/13/busin.main_headline: Deal Set on OPEC Cut, But Not All Are Happy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/13/busin.print_headline: Deal Set on OPEC Cut, But Not All Are Happy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/13/busin.body_text: **********OPEC decided today to cut oil production by 5 percent, or about a million barrels a day, which several officials of the group said should push prices higher. **********But underscoring the tension in two days of talks here, Algeria and Iran expressed reservations about the plan in the final communique, and officials from those countries complained that the output cuts were too small to lift oil prices to OPEC's target of $21 a barrel. OPEC oil has fallen to $17.74 a barrel on average, in part because of the allies' quick success in the war against Iraq. **********OPEC's Secretary General, Subroto, announced the group's decision at 7 P.M. here, and afterward crude oil for delivery in April rose 69 cents a barrel to settle at $19.68 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. When OPEC oil is trading at $21 a barrel, higher-quality West Texas oil costs $23.  [ Page D17 ] .  More Power for Saudis **********OPEC officials and oil analysts here said today's decision reflected the Saudis' increased power within the group after the defeat of Iraq by Riyadh and its allies. How the agreement will affect oil prices was unclear, with oil experts and even OPEC ministers disagreeing among themselves about whether the cuts were large enough to raise prices. **********After today's meeting, production of the 13-member group, currently estimated at 23.4 million barrels a day, would fall to 22.3 million barrels if members adhered to the agreement. **********Saudi Arabia, by far the largest producer in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, stubbornly resisted some other members' pleas for the group to cut production by 2 million barrels a day, with the Saudis absorbing 1.3 million barrels in cuts. Those members contended that the larger cuts were needed to bring prices back to $21 for a "basket" of seven OPEC crudes. **********Under today's agreement, Saudi Arabia is expected to produce 8 million barrels a day, down from the 8.45 million barrels that Riyadh says it has produced in recent days, but far more than the 5.4 million barrels it produced under the old OPEC quota, before Iraq invaded Kuwait in August. **********Oil experts said the reservations that Iran and Algeria expressed about the plan reflected their belief that OPEC, including Saudi Arabia, should accept far greater production cuts. It also reflected their unhappiness with the way the Saudis were exercising their muscle.   'A Price-Increasing Effect' **********"All ministers agree that one million barrels per day less than present production will have a price-increasing effect," Dr. Subroto said at a news conference. He said he did not know whether the price would increase "directly to $21," but said, "I'm sure it will go in that direction." **********One Iranian official, speaking privately, expressed skepticism that the 5 percent cut in production would firm up oil prices. "It's not a serious number like the market is expecting," he said. **********This morning, before the agreement was announced, Iran's oil minister, Gholam Rezah Aghazadeh, predicted that cutting production to a range of 21 million to 21.5 million barrels a day would raise prices to a range of $18 to $21 a barrel. But he said reducing output to 22 million barrels a day would keep prices between $15 and $18. **********Dr. Subroto said today's agreement called for OPEC members to make "voluntary" proportional production cuts of 5 percent. But Algeria's oil minister, Sadek Boussena, who is also OPEC's president, said Algeria would ignore the agreement and would not cut production. **********Some oil experts said the soft nature of today's agreement might lead to overproduction, because OPEC members might not adhere to the 5 percent cuts.  'Prices Will Drop' **********"I think in the coming weeks prices will drop because people will start to see a glut in the market," said Pierre Terzian, editor of Petrostrategies, a Paris-based oil journal. **********OPEC officials said they could not specify the exact levels of new production because of the voluntary nature of the agreement and because OPEC had asked members to report within seven days their exact production levels. Oil experts estimated that under the new agreement Saudi Arabia would pump 8 million barrels a day, followed by Iran with 3.2 million barrels, the United Arab Emirates, with 2.3 million, and Venezuela with 2.2 million. **********Oil analysts said one reason it was not hard to persuade members to agree to 5 percent cuts was that even with the reductions many members would be producing well above the quotas set last July. Those quotas were suspended after Iraq invaded Kuwait and the United Nations ordered an embargo on oil from those two countries, which had been producing 4 million barrels a day. OPEC members were encouraged to produce as much as they could to make up for that loss. **********Today's agreement excludes Iraq and Kuwait because OPEC officials expect neither nation to export oil in the second quarter. OPEC will meet again in June to set production levels for the third quarter. **********When the current meeting began on Monday, OPEC's secretariat said demand for OPEC oil would be 21.4 million barrels a day in the second quarter, some 2 million barrels below current production levels. But Saudi officials forecast that demand for OPEC oil would be 22.4 million barrels a day in the second quarter. They said increases in oil companies' stocks, a decline in Soviet oil exports and a rebound in the American economy would raise demand for OPEC oil. Saudi Demand Is Met **********Oil officials here said one index of Saudi Arabia's new power was the closeness of the new production level to the estimate for demand by the Saudi oil minister, Hisham M. Nazer.. Showing new assertiveness, Saudi officials said they would refuse to produce fewer than 8 million barrels a day, and they persuaded other ministers to agree to that. **********The Saudis also got their way in insisting that this week's gathering, a meeting of OPEC's market monitoring committee, not be turned into an emergency full-scale ministers meeting. Saudi officials worried that such a meeting might erupt into a political fight in which a heated debate would develop over future quotas for Iraq and Kuwait. There was also concern that OPEC members would attack one another over their stands in the gulf war. **********One factor that helped Saudi Arabia dominate the meeting was the humbling of Iraq and the absence of Iraqi officials, who had been the intimidating price hawks at previous meetings. **********Saudi officials rejected criticism that they were doing Washington's bidding by pushing for higher production levels and thus lower prices than some members wanted. Saudi officials noted that they had long opposed steep price increases because of their desire for steady growth in worldwide oil demand.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/01/world.main_headline: THE MIDDLE EAST TALKS: In Israel and Arab Nations: Hostility and Skepticism, Fascination and Hope; For Both Israelis and Palestinians, Memory's Burden
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/01/world.print_headline: THE MIDDLE EAST TALKS: In Israel and Arab Nations: Hostility and Skepticism, Fascination and Hope; For Both Israelis and Palestinians, Memory's Burden
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/01/world.body_text: **********It just isn't the same, Shlomo Bar-Eli decided today. **********With a clarity as rich as the blue sky sheltering Jerusalem, he recalled the still-astonishing day in 1977 when President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt came calling on Israelis, saying the time had come to study war no more. **********"When I saw Sadat's plane land, I was shivering," said Mr. Bar-Eli, a Jerusalem lawyer. "But then, Sadat came to say something to us." **********"Now," he said, "everyone is crawling to this conference only because America is sitting on them." **********But don't get him wrong, Mr. Bar-Eli quickly added with a slight shrug: It cannot be bad for enduring enemies to sit for the first time at the same table, even if they do spend their time talking at, and not with, each other.  Hope and Skepticism **********His was a widely shared opinion here today as Israelis followed the Middle East peace talks with hope but also with skepticism and a cold-eyed conviction that an event is not necessarily impressive just because it is historic. **********It was different for many Palestinians in Israeli-occupied territories, which were in effect shut down for a second straight day by a general strike ordered by radical opponents to the Madrid conference and by scattered curfews imposed by the Israeli Army. Unlike previous days this week, though, this one passed with only a smattering of reported violence and casualties from clashes between soldiers and Arabs and between rival Palestinian factions. **********Palestinians have felt shunted to the wings of the world stage for so long that the very fact that they had a representative speaking for them in Madrid sent hundreds of people marching happily through the streets of Ramallah, six miles north of Jerusalem in the West Bank. Some climbed onto army jeeps, and lay olive branches on them. **********They were delighted, they said, with the speech given by the chief Palestinian delegate, Dr. Haidar Abdel-Shafi. "He expressed our opinions and spoke of our rights for the first time in more than 40 years," Rasmi Matariyeh, a pharmacist, told a Reuters reporter. **********On the western side of the so-called Green Line separating the West Bank from Israel proper, Israelis seemed similarly pleased with their own chief delegate, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, for presenting their case forcefully. **********Even on the political left, where Mr. Shamir's hard-line views are hardly pleasing and where many were disappointed that the Prime Minister offered no conciliatory gestures to the Arabs, there was relief that he at least did not give a lectern-thumping diatribe against territorial concessions or a freeze on Jewish settlement in the occupied territories. Peace Now, a prominent group of anti-settlement campaigners, called his Madrid speech important because "it left all doors open." **********Nevertheless, in this city where the main commodity is memory, serving as both blessing and curse, many Israelis were unpersuaded that much would truly materialize from all the speeches and the reactions and the spin-doctored news conferences of this momentous day. **********"It's all a show," Shira Shelkowitz said from behind the counter of the health-food shop where she works. "You feel good about it. It's nice to see everybody sitting down together. But it's not the real thing." **********The real thing here is not just peace but also territory, and on that score Israelis are as divided as the land itself. **********Not an inch should go back to the Arabs, Ben-Zion Borochoff insisted as he clipped a customer's beard in his barber shop. "America can't tell us where we settle or not settle," he said. "We don't tell them what to do." **********Well, others said, maybe a few inches could go back, maybe the Gaza Strip, which most Israelis feel is not worth owning in the first place. Maybe parts of the West Bank as well, still others suggested. Jacob Stein, for one, said he was certain that a secret deal was already in the works to return parts of the West Bank and the Golan Heights. **********He could live with that, said Mr. Stein, a glassblower. "But it must be for real peace," he insisted. "To give anything back, we need not just a piece of paper."  The Right to Exist **********More than a few people agreed with Mr. Shamir when he said at the Madrid conference that the underlying issue is not territory but the question of a Jewish state's right to exist in an unfriendly neighborhood. **********But the world can change, some said, and that includes hard-nosed attitudes that may seem inflexible. **********Feri Mechabel, a florist who came here from Iran soon after the 1967 Middle East war, remembers that he was little impressed when Mr. Sadat journeyed to Jerusalem 14 years ago, preaching good will and ultimately forging a peace treaty with Prime Minister Menachem Begin in return for getting the Sinai Peninsula back. **********"I was in the army back then, and I was not ready to give up an inch," Mr. Mechabel said, arranging a floral bouquet. Now, he wishes that 1977 could be duplicated, for he is prepared to yield some land, even if he draws the line at East Jerusalem, captured and annexed by Israel in 1967. **********"There's been a lot of blood since then," he said. "But you can't wash away blood with blood. You have to get an agreement and be done with all this."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Security; With No Signs of Terrorism, F.B.I. Still Adds Precautions
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Security; With No Signs of Terrorism, F.B.I. Still Adds Precautions
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.body_text: **********Federal law-enforcement officials say they have no hard evidence that the Persian Gulf war will lead to terrorist acts in the United States, but they say extra security precautions are justified. **********On that premise, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun an aggressive program intended to heighten vigilance in the United States and to serve as a warning to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that plotting terror is futile. **********Mr. Hussein has said in several speeches that he will use any means possible to widen the conflict, which American officials have interpreted as a threat to use terrorism. Today Abu Abbas, head of the Palestine Liberation Front, called on Palestinians to strike at the interests of the United States and its allies. **********"Hurry and strike at and destroy the interests of U.S. imperialists and their allies," he said in a broadcast over Iraqi radio. **********It was because of such threats, that the F.B.I. rapidly expanded its program in recent weeks. Officials said that the program relies on measures like electronic eavesdropping and other information collected here and abroad on suspected terrorists. **********"We are doing everything we possibly can to make the environment as hostile as we can," a senior Justice Department official said. **********The program also involves seeking out Iraqi nationals who have overstayed their visas and conducting criminal investigations. **********But the F.B.I.'s tactics, including interviews with Arab-American leaders, have inflamed fears that the Justice Department has responded to the crisis by reverting to the style of J. Edgar Hoover, whose agents tracked imagined subversives and spied indiscriminately on political dissidents. **********"We want the F.B.I. to be vigilant, and we support the F.B.I.'s anti-terrorism efforts," said Representative Don Edwards, a Democrat of California, who is chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee on civil rights. "But we must avoid infringements of our civil liberties." **********Bureau officials said that since 1982, when counter-terrorism was made a priority within the agency, agents have largely succeeded in preventing terrorist attacks in the United States. They said the number of such attacks declined to 5 in 1990, from 25 in 1986. Senior Justice Department officials concede that the threat of terrorism stemming from the conflict with Iraq remains at a "low level." **********But those senior officials said the precautionary measures are necessary. They point to a variety of chilling factors, like Mr. Hussein's statements, the existence of a training camp of the Abu Nidal terrorist organization in Iraq and the recent movements of some members of the Palestine Liberation Organization from their bases in Lebanon and elsewhere to undisclosed locations. **********Terrorism experts said fears are further heightened because support groups of the Abu Nidal group and the P.L.O. are known to exist in the United States. **********Throughout the week, the F.B.I. increased security at its own offices and operated on a "terrorist advisory," which warns of a general possibility that such acts could occur, although there have been no specific threats. **********The bureau also increased security on Capitol Hill. The leadership of Congress and at least six members of the House and Senate have been provided armed guards and other protection after a marked increase in threats of violence against lawmakers, two Congressional officials said today. **********The officials, a member of Congress and an aide, said that F.B.I. agents and the Capitol police force are accompanying the members, most of whom were not identified. **********For the last week, armed guards have been posted at the homes of the congressional leadership, said one official. Shotgun-toting police have been visible in force on the Capitol grounds, and new barricades have been erected at one key entrance to congressional office buildings.   1 KILLED BY TERRORIST BOMB **********MANILA, Jan. 19 (REUTERS) -- An Iraqi man was killed and another man was wounded today when a bomb they were apparently trying to plant at United States offices in Manila, exploded prematurely, the Philippine police said. The attempted attack was believed to be the result of Mr. Hussein's call to carry the gulf war to other parts of the world. **********The Philippine police said the bomb contained 200 pounds of explosives and was probably aimed at a building housing the Thomas Jefferson Library and other American offices. It exploded less than 100 yards from the building.  GREECE EXPELLS IRAQIS **********ATHENS, Jan. 19 (Special to The New York Times) -- Greece expelled four Iraqis to Libya today and arrested five others on suspicion that they were planning terrorist activity, a police spokesman said. The move came with the expulsion of most of the Iraqi diplomats here. **********The spokesman said two of the five Iraqis who were seized were later released, and that the remaining three were to be expelled on Sunday. Also flown out to Libya today were 23 of Iraq's 30 diplomats, who were ordered out of the country by the Government. **********All Western embassies and missions, Greek airports and many foreign businesses are being guarded by armored vehicles and heavily armed police officers, while diplomats and foreign nationals in general have been advised to stay indoors. The British and American schools here have been temporarily closed.  Diplomats Flee Lebanon **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 19 (REUTERS) --American diplomats in Lebanon have left the country, fearing a backlash because of the war in the Persian Gulf, security officials said. **********They said Ambassador Ryan Crocker and his staff flew to Cyprus by helicopter after Palestinian and Arab extremist groups threatened to attack United States interests to avenge air strikes by the American-led coalition on Iraq. Mr. Crocker assumed his post in Lebanon in November, 14 months after the embassy was closed because of threats by Christian hardliners.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/busin.main_headline: Dozens of Agencies Pursue Three Japanese Car Makers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Dozens of Agencies Pursue Three Japanese Car Makers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/busin.body_text: **********ALTHOUGH car and truck sales in the United States remain mired in a slump severe enough to sadden any glad-handing dealer, the appeal of creating vehicle advertising remains strong enough to entice more than two dozen agencies into eagerly pursuing three Japanese auto makers. **********Subaru of America is expected to name a short list of finalists sometime this week in the monthlong review of its $60 million account, now handled by Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver. American Isuzu Motors is seeking an agency for its car and truck account, valued at $74 million to $100 million, to replace Della Femina, McNamee, which it dismissed Thursday after an 11-year relationship. **********And in the realm of possibility, agency executives say Mazda Motor of America is continuing to plan a luxury car line code-named Pegasus. If that car, which has involved preliminary discussions with agencies, is introduced, it could mean initial annual ad spending of $60 million to $75 million. **********Combined total billings of the three accounts exceed $200 million -- as much as an agency that would rank around 43d among all shops in the United States would have. **********Of course, no one agency could serve all three, given the insurmountable competitive conflicts that would ensue. Yet even singly, the billings at issue are magnetic, especially during a recession that has touched off a feeding frenzy among income-starved agencies for whatever sizable pieces of new business become available. **********Apart from the financial implications, an added draw makes an automotive account attractive to just about every agency without one. Call it the lure of the open road. **********"A car is one of those things that's bigger than life," said Mark Goldstein, president of Earle Palmer Brown Advertising, the Bethesda, Md., agency that is among those identified as being on the long list of Subaru contenders. "It adds a tremendous cachet to your business. You can park a car in front of your building. You can't park a box of Tide in front of your building." **********So overwhelming is the desire for auto business that even allied fields bask in a halo effect. When Avis Car Leasing announced the selection yesterday of six finalists on its $30 million-plus account, now being handled by Backer Spielvogel Bates, Robert Cardillo, vice president of sales and marketing, noted that the car-rental company began its review with a list of 120 agencies. **********Besides Backer, the finalists, all based in New York, are DDB Needham Worldwide, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, FCB/Leber Katz Partners, McCann-Erickson and TBWA Advertising. A decision is expected in mid-June. **********Servicing a car account is "almost synonymous" with an agency's being regarded by potential clients and its peers as substantial and significant, said Richard Costello, president of TBWA, which is also considered to be among the ranks of Subaru candidates. **********"What crystallized it for me was what happened last fall or winter, when we pitched the Nikon account," he continued. "I looked around the room, and there were five of the best agencies: Ammirati & Puris, which has BMW; Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, which has Infiniti; Della Femina (Isuzu); Levine, Huntley (Subaru), and TBWA, nothing. I thought, 'Man, we're the best agency in America that doesn't have a car account.' " And the winner was a car agency, Ammirati. Mr. Costello added, "With all the nice things that have happened to us over the last few years, the one thing we feel we're missing is the car accunt." **********And while the current vehicle sales picture is bleak, automotive accounts remain desirable, Mr. Goldstein said, because, like other marketers, including airlines, restaurant chains, telecommunications outfits and computer makers, "advertising and promotion are critical to them to market their products, whether we're having boom times or we're in a recession."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/world.main_headline: Tourists Stay Home, Blighting the Caribbean
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/world.print_headline: Tourists Stay Home, Blighting the Caribbean
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/world.body_text: **********As a glance down any of the nearly empty beaches here attests, these are difficult times for the islands of the Caribbean. **********The region's all-important tourism industry has been left reeling by a dramatic decrease in travel by Americans from causes as diverse as the Persian Gulf war, a global recession and a relatively mild winter in the northeastern United States. **********Workers in travel-related businesses have been laid off or placed on rotating shifts and airlines have slashed faresand concocted other incentives to generate business. Hotel operators, all but writing off the peak winter season, are pinning their hopes on a healthier spring and summer. **********"The past couple of weeks we've been at around 60 percent occupancy, and I suspect the major factor is the war," said Kent Lawrence, a reception desk clerk at the 480-room Wyndham Rose Hall hotel in Montego Bay, Jamaica's largest tourism town. "Normally this time of year we have a lot of groups passing through and we're at 90 percent occupancy or more. It's usually hard to get a room." **********The story is much the same throughout the region, with the number of hotel guests tumbling from levels that ranged from near-normal to full through early January to disturbingly low occupancy rates with the approach of war. Last week, in a sweeping cost-cutting measure, the 411-room Nassau Beach Resort Club in the Bahamas announced the dismissal of 122 employees. **********"We were full from Dec. 24 through Jan. 4," said Lee Issa, owner of the 130-room Swept Away resort in Negril, Jamaica. "We didn't have a room available for that period, then away went our momentum." **********The Caribbean Tourism Organization in Barbados, a regional travel industry group, said that preliminary estimates based on vacation bookings in North America suggested that this year's peak season, which runs through late March, would see an overall decline of 15 percent or more in the region's tourism trade compared with last year, when visitor records were broken in several islands. **********"We've already had a ho-hum January and a slow February, and the lack of forward bookings suggests that March will be much worse than February," said Arley Sobers, the organization's director of research. **********He said that major tourism markets like Jamaica and the Bahamas, while they are suffering serious declines, may have been spared the worst of the slump because of their proximity to the United States, by far the region's mostimportant market. **********Trade experts say that more distant destinations in the Leeward and Windward chains, places like Barbados, Antigua and St. Lucia, would most likely be even harder hit. **********Airlines that fly to the region, while declining to give passenger data for competitive reasons, also say they are suffering a serious slump. "The Caribbean and Europe are the two areas where we have been hit pretty hard," said Lise Olson, a spokeswoman for American Airlines, the region's largest carrier. **********The slump has prompted many airlines, including American, to offer steep discounts and other travel incentives. **********A spokeswoman for Pan Am, Elizabeth Hlinko, said that in some markets, particularly the United States VirginIslands, the reduced fares had led to a sizable increase in bookings for March. **********Many Americans who went through with their vacation plans despite the war said that they wrestled with guilt about relaxing on the beach while United States soldiers fought in the desert more than concerns for their own security in deciding whether or not to leave home. **********"We thought if it was going to be a terribly bloody war, then just from an ethical point of view we wouldn't feel right being on vacation," said George Adams, a 32-year-old Chicagoan who arrived here with his wife, Faye, on Sunday. Mr. Adams said the two made their decision to go ahead with their plans after following early reports of successes in the ground campaign.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/29/busin.body_text: **********Japan's two major airlines said today that soaring aviation fuel prices and a sudden drop in international passengers because of the Persian Gulf war hurt profits in their last fiscal years. **********Japan Airlines, Japan's international flag carrier, and All Nippon Airways, the domestic flag carrier, announced results for the year ended March 31. **********Japan Airlines said its earnings fell 17.3 percent from the previous year to $99.3 million. Its international passenger traffic fell 3.5 percent, to 7.9 million passengers, its first drop in almost 20 years. **********The airline's domestic passenger traffic grew by 6.6 percent, to 14.41 million, pushing total passenger growth up 2.8 percent, to 22.32 million. **********All Nippon Airways said profits slumped 28.8 percent from the year before, to $77.4 million. Its international passenger traffic expanded 17 percent, to 1.21 million, and its domestic traffic rose 9 percent, to 32.2 million. International passengers grew because the airline initiated new overseas flights this year, including Tokyo-Paris, Tokyo-New York, Tokyo-Brussels, and Nagoya-Kuala Lumpur.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/18/busin.main_headline: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS TO REVIVE CREDITS FOR ARMS EXPORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/18/busin.print_headline: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS TO REVIVE CREDITS FOR ARMS EXPORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/18/busin.body_text: **********The Bush Administration is asking Congress to authorize a Government agency to underwrite sales of military goods for the first time since the 1970's. **********After a long and divisive internal debate, the White House came down on the side of American military contractors, whose business has been lagging because of American plans to reduce the size of the armed forces. **********The proposal comes at a time when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and other members of the Administration have been trying to limit the rearmament of the Middle East in the wake of the Persian Gulf war. **********Administration officials insist the two efforts are not at counterpurposes.  Could Include Third World **********The legislation would establish a pilot program that would guarantee up to $1 billion in commercial bank loans to overseas buyers of military products. The sales are expected to be made largely to members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and to Japan, Israel and Australia. Should the President determine it is in the national interest, the program would also be available for "any other country," which would include the third world. **********Backers say the proposal, which the Administration sent to Capitol Hill last week, would merely level the playing field with America's main industrial competitors, most of which have export credit agencies that finance military sales. **********A State Department official, who insisted on anonymity, said the proposal is "a strictly commercial operation and is to be used only to counter subsidized credit packages from competing countries, like France." **********But opponents of the proposal say that by diverting resources that should be concentrated on nonmilitary exports, the program will hurt American competitiveness and encourage poorer countries to spend more money on arms. America's competitiveness will suffer, they say, because there is less of a ripple effect through the economy from arms sales than from, say, advances in consumer electronics.  'Very Wrongheaded' **********Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, Export Financing and Related Matters, called the proposal "very wrongheaded." Arms sales, he said, are "by their very nature noncommercial and political." **********In 1989, the last year for which statistics are available, the United States sold about $10.8 billion worth of major conventional weapons systems abroad. The bulk of these sales went to American allies in NATO. **********The Administration's request that the Export-Import Bank, a Government agency, underwrite the arms sales promises to be hotly debated in Congress. A Pentagon-administered military credit guarantee program was suspended in the late 1970's after too many customers went into arrears. **********With the President's backing, the proposal is expected to pass the Senate. But it will run into stiffer opposition in the House, and at this stage, its fate there cannot be determined. **********Even within the Administration, the proposal produced a debate before the White House decided to proceed. The State Department and the Pentagon supported the change. The principal objections came from some executives of the Export-Import Bank. **********The bank was founded 56 years ago to stimulate trade by providing financing to overseas buyers of American goods at below-market rates. Since 1974, it has had policy of financing only nonmilitary exports.  Would Rescind Ban **********The Administration's proposal would rescind Section 32 of the Arms Export Control Act of 1968, which was enacted after widespread use of the agency as an instrument of "backdoor financing" of military sales to Southeast Asian nations during the Vietnam buildup. Section 32 bans the use of Export-Import Bank financing of military sales to developing countries. The White House has proposed that the Export-Import Bank guarantee up to $1 billion of commercial bank loans to the overseas customers of American military contractors. **********Such a sweeping expansion in the scope of Government credit activities for military exports has been vigorously promoted by large military contractors like the United Technologies Corporation, the Raytheon Company and the Martin Marietta Corporation, and the White House has now decided to go along. **********After that decision was made, John D. Macomber, president of the export agency and a friend of President Bush, offered this explanation: "The central point is that we're going through very difficult times in this country for defense industries. The basic motivation behind this is that the Government recognizes there are some real economic adjustment problems for these companies to go through, and this would be a way for the Government to be of some help." He was referring to the budget cutbacks of the last two years. **********Representative Jim Moody, another Wisconsin Democrat, is seeking legislators' signatures on a letter to Secretary Baker, warning that the initiative is "likely to cost the taxpayer dearly" and is a "rather transparent attempt to circumvent the budgetary limitations" of the Pentagon's Foreign Military Sales program. **********This program is the main military assistance effort under which the Pentagon in the next fiscal year plans to spend nearly $5 billion in grants and low-interest loans to American allies. Although 50 countries are on the list of recipients, half goes to two, Israel and Egypt.  Opposition From Industry **********The Administration has also been seeking to limit strategic arms in talks with the Soviet Union, and it has proposed restrictions on the sale of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons technology to the third world. The Administration proposal has divided the export community. Most companies whose earnings are primarily from military sales back the proposal. Others, like the Boeing Company and the General Electric Company, which have some military business but far larger nonmilitary operations, have reservations. **********They worry about the crowding out of scarce credit resources, the possibility that separate divisions within companies may have to compete for Export-Import Bank money and an undercutting of political support for the bank if it becomes too strongly identified with military programs. **********"Boeing recognizes financing support is required for the export of defense products," said John F. Hayden, the company's corporate vice president. "But we question the appropriateness of involving Ex-Im Bank as the mechanism." **********He noted that since "defense products exports are not simply commercial transactions, but involve foreign policy and national security, Boeing feels the Department of State may be the appropriate agency to administer a defense-products export-financing program." **********Willard M. Berry, vice president for Congressional affairs at the National Foreign Trade Council, said that before Congress takes up the proposal, "it is in the interest of all concerned to insure that all alternatives are explored and the pros and cons of each are fully debated." **********William F. Paul, senior vice president of United Technologies, said that because the United States could not provide competitive credit terms, his company lost a big Brazilian military helicopter contract to France's Aerospatiale in 1988. **********"We need a mechanism for financing this kind of defense trade when it's necessary," Mr. Paul said. "Our competitors have access to this sort of facility, and we desperately need it ourselves." **********Largely through the efforts of Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, United Technologies, based in Hartford, won legislation last year specifically authorizing the export credit agency, on a one-time basis, to provide loan guarantees for a bid to produce 200 military helicopters jointly with Turkey. United Technologies is competing with French and Italian companies.  Some Risks Involved **********But opponents of the proposal say the Export-Import Bank should not be used to assume the risks of financing military exports and taking the risk of political backlash. **********Albert H. Hamilton, a former government affairs manager for the bank and now senior associate of First Washington Associates, an Arlington, Va., consulting firm, said export credit agencies of other countries have gotten into serious polticial and financial difficulties by supporting exports of military equipment. **********One example is the British agency's backing of military sales to the Kwame Nkrumah Government in Ghana. When that Goverment changed in 1966, its successor sought to repudiate the arms-related debt. **********The new legislative proposal may explain why President Bush during his visit to Ottawa on Wednesday was cool to Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's proposals to curb arms sales. **********The President said at a new conference that the destruction of Iraq's military threat gave him hope that there would not be increasing arms sales in the Middle East. But he added: "That doesn't mean we're going to refuse to sell anything to everybody. We're not going to cut off all weapons sales."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/28/busin.body_text: **********Helmut Schlesinger, the Bundesbank's vice president and the chief ideologist of its rigid anti-inflation policy, is expected to be named this week to succeed Karl Otto Pohl as president of Germany's powerful central bank. **********Government officials said they expected Mr. Schlesinger, a 66-year-old native of Bavaria, to be appointed to a two-year term and Hans Tietmeyer, 59, a member of the bank's seven-member board and an adviser to Chancellor Helmut Kohl, to be named vice president and eventual successor to Mr. Schlesinger as president. **********Elevating Mr. Schlesinger, a lean, bespectacled intellectual, to the top post at Europe's most powerful central bank would be a forceful signal to Germany's trading partners and the world's financial markets that the resignation of Mr. Pohl does not presage any change in the Bundesbank's policy of tight money and relatively high interest rates.Assurance of Stability **********Mr. Pohl, 61, announced on May 16 that he was stepping down for personal reasons after 11 years in office. **********"Selecting Mr. Schlesinger would send a clear message that the Bundesbank's monetary policy remains stability-oriented," said Peter Pietsch, an economist with Commerzbank A.G. in Frankfurt. "He has been the monetary theorist at the Bundesbank, while Mr. Pohl played a more public role in presenting the policy. Appointing Mr. Schlesinger and Mr. Tietmeyer would be both a tribute to Mr. Schlesinger's role and many years of service, and a strong statement that the Bonn Government and the Bundesbank are in agreement on policy." **********The Bundesbank president will be chosen by Mr. Kohl's center-right coalition Government and officially appointed by President Richard von Weizsacker. Mr. Schlesinger's appointment is said to be strongly supported by Finance Minister Theo Waigel, a fellow Bavarian who shares many of Mr. Schlesinger's views on financial matters. **********Mr. Schlesinger has been with the Bundesbank since 1952. He became head of the economics and statistical departments in 1964 and moved up to the board as chief economist in 1972. When Mr. Pohl became president in 1979, Mr. Schlesinger was appointed vice president. In 11 years in that post, Mr. Schlesinger has sometimes been attacked by critics as obsessive and narrow-minded for his belief that squelching inflation must be the primary goal of monetary policy. **********Over the last year, for example, the United States and several Western European nations have been urging Germany to lower its interest rates to stimulate global economic growth. But the Bundesbank has steadfastly refused to lower its two leading interest rates, the discount rate and the Lombard rate, from their current levels of 6.5 percent and 9 percent, respectively. **********Mr. Schlesinger responded to recent cuts in American interest rates by saying they take some pressure off the Bundesbank to raise its key interest rates further. But the lower American rates, he said, do not make it possible for Germany to lower rates, which were increased on Jan. 31 by one-half percentage point each.Personality Contrasts to Pohl's **********While Mr. Pohl is a pragmatist known for his warmth, wit and amiability, Mr. Schlesinger is widely viewed as a somewhat humorless technocrat. An avid mountain climber and skier, he is an economist by training and "Professor Doktor" by title. Colleagues say he possesses an encyclopedic knowledge of monetary policy and near-total recall of facts, figures and mathematical formulas. **********Those qualities and Mr. Schlesinger's penchant for giving central bankers from other countries impromptu lectures about the danger of inflation have contributed to the occasional friction between Germany and other leading industrial nations over monetary policy. **********The United States Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, became exasperated in late 1987 when he was Treasury Secretary and the Bundesbank refused to cut interest rates. Mr. Baker publicly accused Mr. Schlesinger of heading a clique of "rigid monetarists" who "find inflation under every rock." Mr. Baker also blamed the Bundesbank and Mr. Schlesinger for the stock market collapse of 1987, which came after several rounds of Bundesbank rate increases.Sees Himself as Open and Flexible **********Mr. Schlesinger vehemently denies being the personification of German inflation angst and describes himself as an open and flexible central banker. To answer his critics he merely points to Germany's record of steady, if sometimes unspectacular, economic growth and minimal inflation over the last decade. **********The expected appointment of Mr. Tietmeyer to the post of vice president is also seen as a vote for continuing the Bundesbank's policies. As the Finance Ministry's state secretary for international finance from 1982 to late 1989, he developed a reputation as a tough negotiator and tireless worker. **********In January 1990, Mr. Tietmeyer joined the Bundesbank's board. Chancellor Kohl called him back to Bonn two months later on special assignment as his personal adviser on monetary union with East Germany. **********Despite Mr. Tietmeyer's close links to the Chancellor, he is seen as loyal first and foremost to the Bundesbank and the policies forged by Mr. Schlesinger.
