https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/busin.main_headline: A.T.&T. Buying Computer Maker In Stock Deal Worth $7.4 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/busin.print_headline: A.T.&T. Buying Computer Maker In Stock Deal Worth $7.4 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/busin.body_text: **********After more than five months of stubborn resistance, NCR agreed yesterday to be acquired by A.T.& T. for $7.4 billion worth of A.T.& T. stock. **********The acquisition signals the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's determination to expand beyond telecommunications to compete in computers with giants like NEC and Fujitsu of Japan, Siemens of Germany and I.B.M. **********In starting its quest to buy the NCR Corporation, A.T.& T. was seeking a permanent solution to the problem of its money-losing computer business and hoping to find a way to expand into new markets, ones that increasingly rely on linking computers and communications. Analysts say A.T.& T.'s computer business has lost more than $2 billion in six years. **********NCR, based in Dayton, Ohio, grew from the National Cash Register Company (it still makes some cash registers) to become the fifth-largest computer maker in the country. **********When A.T.& T. began its pursuit of NCR in December, many industry observers were surprised that kindly Ma Bell had put on the grim visage of a corporate raider. The hostile bid was another milestone in the transformation of the heavily regulated bureaucratic monopoly that existed before the 1984 court-ordered breakup of the Bell System. **********In recent years, as a more aggressive corporation, A.T.& T. has cut costs and more closely tied executive pay to profit levels. **********Robert E. Allen, the chairman of A.T.& T., said yesterday that with NCR the company would work toward providing "global computer networks as easy to use and accessible as the telephone network is today." **********Jack B. Grubman, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc., said: "A.T.& T. would like to be a $100 billion company by the end of the decade. They would love to be able to go to the chief executive officer of Nestle and say, 'We will provide you soup to nuts, your entire information network.' " **********Given that assumption, Mr. Grubman and others say more large deals are likely to follow. "Over the next decade they will do several more deals of this size or bigger," Mr. Grubman said. **********Under the definitive merger agreement, A.T.& T. will exchange $110 worth of its own stock for each NCR share, but on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, NCR's shares closed at just $104, up 50 cents. The difference reflects the fact that investors are expected to have to wait four months for the deal to close. But that price is still more than double the $48 that NCR was trading for a month before A.T T. made its first offer in December. A.T.& T.'s shares slipped 37.5 cents yesterday, to $36.75. **********A.T.& T. dwarfs NCR in size, with 1990 revenues of $37.3 billion, compared with $6.2 billion for NCR. Still, the computer maker will provide A.T.& T. important entries into financial and retail industries. NCR is in the process of introducing a line of "open system" computers that are capable of being linked with computers and software made by different manufacturers. **********The merger agreement signed yesterday is subject to the approval of NCR shareholders. The First Bid **********It all started in December, when A.T.& T. offered $90 a share, or $6.1 billion, for NCR. By keeping A.T.& T. at bay during the winter, Charles E. Exley Jr., NCR's chairman, was able to cajole A.T.& T. into paying an additional $1.3 billion. **********"He has done a lot for shareholders," said Don Geogerian, head of research of Dreyfus Management Inc., an institutional stockholder of NCR. **********Martin D. Sass of M. D. Sass Investors Services said, "Mr. Exley played his cards pretty strongly to get A.T.& T. up to $110." **********In the end, the booming stock market made a hero out of Mr. Exley. **********A.T.& T.'s stock was trading around $30 in December. At the time, A.T.& T. said it was willing to pay for NCR with stock or cash. A stock offer at that time would have involved three A.T.& T. shares for each NCR share. **********But in April, with the shares of A.T.& T. above $37, A.T.& T. could agree to meet NCR's asking price of $110, at minimal additional cost. **********A.T.& T. plans to issue new stock to acquire NCR. Analysts estimated that the new stock would dilute A.T.& T.'s per-share earnings by 10 to 15 cents a year. Staying in Dayton **********A.T.& T. said NCR would retain its headquarters in Dayton, and its corporate name. Mr. Allen, the A.T.& T. chairman, said NCR would continue to support civic and philanthropic organizations in Dayton. **********The companies have been on the verge of an agreement for three weeks. Part of the final haggling was over how much protection NCR shareholders would have if A.T.& T.'s stock price fell while the acquisition was being completed. **********In a compromise, A.T.& T. agreed to insure that NCR shareholders would receive $110 worth of stock as long as A.T.& T. shares traded between $34.125 and $40.625. **********The exact number of A.T.& T. shares to be exchanged for each NCR share will be determined by A.T.& T.'s average closing price during the 20 trading days before NCR shareholders meet to vote on the merger. A date for the meeting has not been set, but it is expected to take place in four to five months. **********The maximum number of A.T.& T. shares exchanged for each NCR share would be 3.223, if A.T.& T. stock fell to $34.125 or below. The minimum number would be 2.708, if A.T.& T. stock was $40.625 or above. **********Analysts said it was unlikely that A.T.& T. stock would fall below $34.125 without a significant overall market drop. Several analysts have predicted that A.T.& T.'s stock would rise to about $50 in the next 12 months. **********As an all-stock deal, the merger would be tax-free to NCR stockholders. Some Special Accouting **********The all-stock deal also makes it possible for A.T.& T. to use an accounting treatment known as a pooling of interests, which would be favorable to its reported earnings. **********A.T.& T. and NCR plan to talk to the Securities and Exchange Commission to determine if the pooling method can be used. If not, A.T.& T. plans to offer 40 percent cash and 60 percent stock. **********Mr. Exley led the resistance to A.T.& T.'s offer, initially saying NCR was worth at least $125 a share. Before NCR's March 28 annual meeting, he said he would accept $110. **********Mr. Exley, who has more than 30 years of experience in the computer business, played an unusually active role in fending off A.T.& T., as he and his management team kept the company's Wall Street advisers on a tight leash. **********"Let's just say that they are very actively involved in deciding their own approach to things," said a person working with NCR. **********During the takeover fight, NCR contended that A.T.& T. was taking advantage of a temporary drop in NCR's stock price. But beyond stalling for time, Mr. Exley had few options after A.T.& T. made its initial bid. **********And as time went on, his options were reduced. Ruling by a Judge **********In March, a Federal judge in Dayton threw out NCR's main line of defense, an employee stock ownership plan, saying that it had been adopted simply to protect the incumbent management and that it made a mockery of shareholder rights. At NCR's annual meeting in March, NCR shareholders voted Mr. Exley off the board, as A.T.& T. won four seats. **********The deal will add considerably to the wealth of Mr. Exley and other NCR executives. Through stock options and direct holdings, Mr. Exley owns more than 306,359 shares of NCR, worth nearly $34 million under terms of the deal. Gilbert P. Williamson, NCR's new chief executive, has stock options and holdings worth about $11 million at the purchase price. **********Mr. Exley plans to retire after the merger is complete. **********A.T.& T.'s unsuccessful ventures in computers began in 1983, with the company's investment in Ing. C. Olivetti & Company of Italy. Olivetti made a line of personal computers for A.T.& T. that proved to be unpopular, and A.T.& T. swapped its stake in the Italian company in 1989. **********Now the fate of A.T.& T.'s own computer business is uncertain. By publicly stating that it will turn its computer operation over to NCR's management, A.T.& T. has hurt morale among the 9,000 employees in its computer division. **********In preparation for the acquisition, the company has trimmed 1,000 jobs in the division since fall. **********Mr. Allen would not speculate on the fate of A.T.& T.'s computer employees yesterday. **********Several months ago, A.T.& T. said it would pay bonuses to workers who remained at their jobs for six months to discourage worried workers from looking for jobs outside the company. **********Mr. Grubman, the analyst, said many of A.T.& T.'s computer employees would be dismissed. "I don't think that NCR needs more people," he said. He added that the deal made immediate financial sense for A.T.& T. because it would allow the company to replace its unprofitable computer operation with a profitable one. **********A.T.& T. said yesterday that the acquisition would result in "one-time material charges to A.T.& T.'s earnings." **********fter more than five months of stubborn resistance, NCR agreed yesterday to be acquired by A.T.& T. for $7.4 billion worth of A.T.& T. stock. **********The acquisition signals the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's determination to expand beyond telecommunications to compete in computers with giants like NEC and Fujitsu of Japan, Siemens of Germany and I.B.M. **********In starting its quest to buy the NCR Corporation, A.T.& T. was seeking a permanent solution to the problem of its money-losing computer business and hoping to find a way to expand into new markets, ones that increasingly rely on linking computers and communications. Before NCR's March 28 annual meeting, he said he would accept $110. **********Mr. Exley, who has more than 30 years of experience in the computer business, played an unusually active role in fending off A.T.& T., as he and his management team kept the company's Wall Street advisers on a tight leash. **********"Let's just say that they are very actively involved in deciding their own approach to things," said a person working with NCR. **********During the takeover fight, NCR contended that A.T.& T. was taking advantage of a temporary drop in NCR's stock price. But beyond stalling for time, Mr. Exley had few options after A.T.& T. made its initial bid. **********And as time went on, his options were reduced. Ruling by a Judge **********In March, a Federal judge in Dayton threw out NCR's main line of defense, an employee stock ownership plan, saying that it had been adopted simply to protect the incumbent management and that it made a mockery of shareholder rights. At NCR's annual meeting in March, NCR shareholders voted Mr. Exley off the board, as A.T.& T. won four seats. **********The deal will add considerably to the wealth of Mr. Exley and other NCR executives. Through stock options and direct holdings, Mr. Exley owns more than 306,359 shares of NCR, worth nearly $34 million under terms of the deal. Gilbert P. Williamson, NCR's new chief executive, has stock options and holdings worth about $11 million at the purchase price. **********Mr. Exley plans to retire after the merger is complete. **********A.T.& T.'s unsuccessful ventures in computers began in 1983, with the company's investment in Ing. C. Olivetti & Company of Italy. Olivetti made a line of personal computers for A.T.& T. that proved to be unpopular, and A.T.& T. swapped its stake in the Italian company in 1989. **********Now the fate of A.T.& T.'s own computer business is uncertain. By publicly stating that it will turn its computer operation over to NCR's management, A.T.& T. has hurt morale among the 9,000 employees in its computer division. **********In preparation for the acquisition, the company has trimmed 1,000 jobs in the division since fall. **********Mr. Allen would not speculate on the fate of A.T.& T.'s computer employees yesterday. **********Several months ago, A.T.& T. said it would pay bonuses to workers who remained at their jobs for six months to discourage worried workers from looking for jobs outside the company. **********Mr. Grubman, the analyst, said many of A.T.& T.'s computer employees would be dismissed. "I don't think that NCR needs more people," he said. He added that the deal made immediate financial sense for A.T.& T. because it would allow the company to replace its unprofitable computer operation with a profitable one. **********A.T.& T. said yesterday that the acquisition would result in "one-time material charges to A.T.& T.'s earnings."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/08/busin.main_headline: Daimler and Mitsubishi to Rethink Cooperation Pact : An Alliance on the Rocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/08/busin.print_headline: Daimler and Mitsubishi to Rethink Cooperation Pact : An Alliance on the Rocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/08/busin.body_text: **********Top executives from Daimler-Benz AG and Mitsubishi Corp., having achieved few tangible results in the grand alliance they announced 20 months ago, will do some soul-searching during two days of talks that begin Tuesday near Baden-Baden, Germany, executives and industry analysts said Monday. **********"Some blunt language" is planned, said a spokesman for Mitsubishi Corp., the giant trading house at the center of the Japanese group. He said Mitsubishi executives would talk "about the need to re-evaluate how this alliance ought to be." **********Industry analysts have begun to ask whether the two groups, which have managed only one significant agreement - to distribute Mercedes-Benz cars in Japan - are drifting apart. **********"The fact that they've been talking for 20 months and nothing has come out suggests the scope for fundamental cooperation is somewhat more limited than the optimists were predicting," said Stephen Reitman, auto analyst with UBS/Phillips & Drew in London. **********Announced in March of 1990, the alliance promised to give Mitsubishi a gateway to Europe and Daimler enhanced access to the Far East. **********Powerful synergies in automotive, electronics and aerospace technologies threatened to alter the global competitive landscape. The Mitsubishi group includes, among other companies, Mitsubishi Motors Corp., Mitsubishi Electric Corp. and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd., Japan's biggest aerospace and defense contractor. **********But doubts about the alliance arose in March when a meeting of the two groups' leaders was canceled, a decision blamed on security concerns during the Gulf war. Suspicions deepened when Mitsubishi Motors Corp. signed an accord in May to produce cars jointly with Volvo AB in a Dutch plant. Analysts said wide differences between the groups - in size, style and substance - had thrown up obstacles that were leading the companies to pursue ad hoc alliances. **********The Mitsubishi Corp. spokesman said that the Gulf war and the collapse of communism had drastically altered the political and economic landscape, complicating the already exceedingly complex task of marrying two industrial combines that stand at the center of Asia's and Europe's biggest economies. **********The task now, he said, was to discuss the rapid changes in Southeast Asia and Europe and sort out growth prospects and relative competitiveness. "We don't need to reach concrete agreements for this meeting to be successful," he said. **********But some analysts said time may be running out for the two companies to cooperate, especially in the automobile sector in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, a promising area where Mitsubishi Motor's know-how in light trucks and minicars meshes with consumer needs and complements Daimler's contacts and understanding of local markets. **********Two Japanese rivals of Mitsubishi, Toyota Motor Corp. and Nissan Motor Co., are setting up distribution channels there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/25/busin.print_headline: EC Plans to Tighten Bank Monitoring
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/25/busin.body_text: **********The European Community's top banking official said Wednesday he would introduce new deposit-insurance legislation in the wake of the closure of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. **********The measure will "provide additional incentives" for member states to closely monitor banks licensed in their countries, because "their fund will pay" to compensate depositors in cases of bank failure, said Sir Leon Brittan, the EC commissioner who oversees competition issues and financial services. **********BCCI, which was closed by regulators on July 5, was based in Luxembourg even though its operations were centered in London. **********In addition to the deposit-insurance legislation, Sir Leon said it might be helpful to hold international discussions on "whether certain types of corporate structures for banks are safe or in any way need to be reviewed." **********He declined to be more specific when asked whether he had BCCI's structure in mind. **********Sir Leon said an EC banking law, approved in December 1989 and taking effect in 1993, would help prevent future incidents like the BCCI affair. **********The law grants banks licensed in one EC country a "passport" to operate Community-wide. **********"There will be an obligation for banking regulators to cooperate," Sir Leon said, because regulators in a bank's "home" country will be informed about irregular branch activity by regulators in the various "host" countries. **********Host-country regulators can intervene under the law "to prevent or punish irregularities committed in their territories," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/05/busin.print_headline: G-7 Leaders Set Specific Projects To Help Soviets
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/05/busin.body_text: **********The seven leading industrial nations are preparing a package of specific projects aimed at helping the Soviet Union reverse declining energy production and overcome food-distribution bottlenecks, Western officials said Thursday. **********But, as leaders of the Group of Seven industrial democracies have made increasingly clear in recent weeks, they have no plans to provide financial assistance to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev when they meet him in London on July 17 at the end of their annual economic summit. **********In London, British officials preparing for the unprecedented meeting between the Soviet leader and the G-7 heads said they did not even expect Mr. Gorbachev to ask for large-scale aid. **********"It is understood generally, and I believe it is understood in Moscow, that the summit is not an occasion for financial-assistance decisions," a senior British official said. **********As a result of the talks, the G-7 leaders are also expected to agree to grant the Soviet Union associate status in the International Monetary Fund. **********Other officials involved in preparations for the meeting said G-7 officials are debating whether to encourage individual countries to provide further export credits to the Soviets. **********"The extent to which we will make trade credits available has yet to be determined," said an official who will be traveling to London for the summit. "It will depend to a large degree on Gorbachev's own commitments to reform." **********Germany and Italy are the strongest advocates of a large Soviet aid package. Mr. Gorbachev will meet with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany in Kiev on Friday to outline what he plans to discuss at the London session. **********Japan and the United States, on the other hand, are the most reluctant to move forward until Soviet leaders agree on major changes toward adopting a market economy. **********Providing technical assistance for the antiquated Soviet energy industry and the inefficient farm sector is one way for Western leaders to bridge their own differences over Soviet aid. **********But the speed with which such projects could actually get off the ground will depend to a large degree on how soon the Soviet Union prepares the legal framework for private investment and sorts out the differences between the central government and the republics over who owns the nation's vast natural resources. **********Top aides from the seven industrial powers, known as sherpas, are scheduled to meet in London this weekend to map out more detailed plans for the summit. **********While ruling out a major aid package, most G-7 leaders do not want to send Mr. Gorbachev away from the meeting empty-handed. **********"We don't want to have him going home seeming to have been disappointed," a Paris-based official said. "That's why it is important to ensure that no one builds up excessive expectations. This is a problem that is not going to be solved overnight." **********The United States, Japan, Germany, France, Canada, Italy and Britain are members of the G-7. The prime minister of the Netherlands, Ruud Lubbers, who is currently head of the European Community Council of Ministers, and Jacques Delors, EC Commission president, will also attend. **********British officials said a top priority would be to see whether the summit can "give a push" to the stalled global trade talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. **********One said they would seek to "reaffirm their support for an early, successful and comprehensive outcome" to GATT. **********The summit participants will also discuss the world economy, Eastern Europe, developing-country debt, the environment, arms transfers and the fight against the international drug trade. **********These discussion are expected to result in three communiqués. A general political statement will "encapsulate" the themes of global partnership and strengthening the international order, including a possible proposal to enhance the role of the United Nations in disaster relief. **********A second political declaration may be issued on the subject of arms transfers and nuclear proliferation. "The Gulf war did illustrate the danger for the world as a whole of unrestricted arms sales," the official said. The third communiqué will deal with international economic issues. **********Though summit organizers "will be working very hard" to ensure that these topics receive sufficient attention, the senior British official acknowledged that Mr. Gorbachev's visit was likely to dominate headlines. **********The British official said the G-7 summit itself would prepare for the discussions with the Soviet leader, but would make no decisions and probably no announcement. "It is not the intention of the heads of government to have their meeting and present Mr. Gorbachev with a fait accompli," he said. **********What the seven are likely to do is issue a statement on Eastern and Central Europe "assuring those who are implementing courageous political and economic reform" that they have "not been forgotten," the official said. **********Leigh Bruce in London contributed to this article.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/world.snippet: Moving to stifle the worst uprising he has faced, Saddam Hussein put internal security in the hands of a trusted cousin.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/world.main_headline: Hussein, Battling Uprising, Names Cousin as Internal Security Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/world.print_headline: Hussein, Battling Uprising, Names Cousin as Internal Security Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/world.body_text: **********AMMAN, Jordan, March 6 -- Moving to stifle the worst uprising he has faced, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today put internal security in the hands of a trusted cousin who oversaw Kuwait's occupation and reportedly used chemical weapons against restive Kurds in 1988. **********Arab diplomats here say Mr. Hussein, who also ordered road blocks around the capital and gave cash bonuses to loyalist troops, might be expanding an internal crackdown by remaining units of the Republican Guards routed in the Persian Gulf war. **********That sense of concern was reinforced today when Iraqi officials said most Western journalists would be expelled from the country by Friday, and that no others would be allowed to enter for at least a week. **********In the week since the Iraqi Army was smashed and its soldiers were sent into haphazard retreat, dissent and rebellion has seethed in southern and northern Iraq. Shiite Muslims, who form 55 percent of Iraq's population of 18 million, have risen in the south and Kurds have claimed their own revolt in the north. President Hussein's 12-year-old Government is rooted in the Sunni Muslim Arab minority. **********Reuters reported today that the Republican Guards were in the streets of the capital and had put up roadblocks on its approaches, suggesting an effort to tighten security to prevent rebellion from spilling into the capital. **********The replacement of Interior Minister Sameer Mohamed Abdul-Wahab with President Hussein's cousin, Ali Hassan al-Majid, was announced on the Baghdad radio as allied officials in Saudi Arabia said Republican Guard forces had apparently turned the tide of a revolt in Shiite-dominated portions of southern Iraq. **********The Kurdish rebels, however, claimed today to have occupied towns in the Kurdish-speaking north. **********Majid belongs to a clan that has intermarried with President Hussein's family in the Tikrit region north of Baghdad. He was the second family member to be brought closer into the ruling elite since the occupation of Kuwait last Aug. 2. **********According to specialists, he has risen through the ranks of Iraq's intelligence and internal security services to become one of President Hussein's closest aides. His brother, Hussein Kamal al-Majid, was appointed Oil Minister after the invasion of Kuwait. **********While some of President Hussein's exiled adversaries interpreted the change of ministers as a sign of the Iraqi leader's increasing dependence on loyalists bound by family ties, other analysts saw it as a show of strength. Wants to Demonstrate Control **********"He wants to demonstrate to his enemies that he and his clan are absolutely in command," said Charles Tripp, a London-based scholar with close knowledge of Iraqi politics. The man Ali Hassan al-Majid replaced, Mr. Abdul-Wahab, had also been viewed as close associate of President Hussein. **********Both the Shiites and the Kurds are backed by Iraq's neighbors, Iran and Syria, which have a long record of animosity toward Baghdad. In the war, Iran professed neutrality and Syria sided with the United States and its allies. An Iranian official, Deputy Foreign Minister Mahmoud Vaezi, sought today to distance Teheran from the revolt in southern Iraq, saying that "no country must interfere in the internal affairs of Iraq." **********However, Arab diplomats here said, Teheran seemed to have offered at least tacit support to the revolt by highlighting news of it through its official news organizations. **********President Hussein sought today to buttress the loyalty of his troops after their defeat by ordering monthly bonuses, particularly to the Republican Guards, which numbered 150,000 men at the beginning of the crisis but which allied commanders said were largely destroyed as a fighting force. Largest Bonus to Guard Units **********The bonuses, the Baghdad radio said, were 100 dinars -- 300 dollars at the official exchange rate -- for the Republican Guard, representing a one-third increase of salaries of 300 dinars. Army and police volunteers were given bonuses equivalent to $150, and regular soldiers were given increases of $50 a month. **********Despite Western assessments of the Republican Guards' disarray, Western officials in Saudi Arabia said loyalist troops had apparently put down an Islamic revolt in Basra, Iraq's second-largest city, where rebellious Shiites claimed to have control over the weekend. **********While the Shiites form a minority of the world's Muslims, they represent a majority in Iran and southern Iraq. **********But the officials said the southern city of Karbala, which houses one of the most sacred Shiite shrines, was in turmoil, and further strife had been reported from Najaf, where a gold-domed mosque marks the tomb of Shiism's founder, the Imam Ali. A Republican Guard unit was reported heading for Karbala. [ Although the allies continue to contol a broad swath of southern Iraq, a State Department official in Washington said on Wednesday that outside powers should not intervene in Iraq's affairs during the period of instability. But President Bush and others have said several times that they would like to see President Hussein overthrown. ] **********As allied accounts described a gradual reassertion of Government control in the south, Kurdish dissidents said from their exiled headquarters in Paris and Damascus that their insurgents, known as the Pesh Merga -- "those who face death" -- were confronting loyalist forces and had taken control of five cities, including Erbil, the provincial capital. Significant Battle Reported **********Jalal Talabani, leader of the Marxist Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, told reporters in Damascus that "tens of thousands of guerrillas" were fighting 60,000 Government troops in the north. **********He said Erbil and the towns of Salahad-Din, Khabata, Daratow and Aski Kalak were under insurgent control. The claim has not been verified. **********Also today, Iraq's Government-controlled Baath newspaper carried an article it said was signed by Mr. Hussein's son, Udai, in which he denied reports that he had been killed in Basra. **********News that President Hussein had elevated Mr. Majid to the main internal security portfolio, however, produced fearful responses among many Kurds, who remember the days in March 1988 when attacks with what they describe as chemical weapons killed an estimated 5,000 Iraqi Kurds at the town of Halabja on the Iran-Iraq border. **********In August 1988 Iraq agreed to a cease-fire with Iran after an eight-year war. The Republican Guard then turned against the Kurds, who had sympathized with the Iranians. **********Kurds are a fractured group, mainly Sunni Muslims, whose disparate clans total an estimated 20 million people spread over Iraq, Turkey, the Soviet Union, Syria and Iran. They have fought for many years for Kurdish states, without success. Iraq has offered its Kurdish minority a form of autonomy, but has never succeeded in eradicating revolt. **********Mr. Majid, said one Kurdish exile in Paris, "will try to destroy the people. He is known by everyone in Kurdistan and Iraq as a terrorist and very dangerous." **********Mr. Tripp, the London-based expert on Iraqi politics, said that in the mid-1980's Mr. Majid assumed responsibility for coordinating the country's five intelligence services and became a member of the Special Bureau, an inner caucus of loyalists, many of them linked to the Iraqi leader by blood ties. **********Before the August 1988 cease-fire with Iran, he was assigned as commander of northern Iraq -- meaning the Kurdish areas -- and given the job of obliterating Kurdish dissent. Tens of Thousands Fled **********Tens of thousands of Kurds fled into Turkey and Iran as the campaign unfolded. Western specialists with close knowledge of Iraqi affairs said that while Iraq's military had balked at a scorched earth policy against the Kurds, the 48-year-old Mr. Majid did not. Under his control, Iraqi authorities enforced population transfers, evacuating Kurdish villages in border areas and moving their residents to southern Iraq. **********During the first few months of Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, when exiled Kuwaitis reported many atrocities, he was effectively the military governor of Kuwait. **********Since the end of the gulf war less than a week ago, President Hussein has acquiesced with uncharacteristic speed in allied demands for a cease-fire, reversing his annexation of Kuwait, offering to return Kuwaiti assets and releasing allied prisoners. **********His intention, analysts and diplomatas believe, is to remove any source of friction with the Western allies and pursue his crackdown on internal dissent. He has reportedly calculated that a fractured Iraq, or a Shiite fundamentalist regime in Baghdad, would offer the United States and its allies more problems that his own continued tenure.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/26/busin.body_text: **********Bankers are expecting a heavy flow of new Eurobond issues in coming weeks as issuers and investors return from their summer holidays. European sovereign and supranational borrowers are likely to dominate the market, and the nondollar currencies probably will be the favored vehicles. **********The reason for this, bankers explain, is that institutional investors' portfolios are already overweight in dollar-denominated paper, and at this point they are beginning to view the yen and the European currencies as offering higher potential capital gains. **********The dollar has lost some of its glamour because of the way it **********traded last week. The fear ignited by Monday's coup in the Soviet Union did send the dollar up sharply - but the fact that the rush into the perceived safe haven of the dollar failed to drive the currency to a new high for the year cast a long shadow over forecasts that the dollar would be trading at 2 Deutsche marks by year-end. **********Anticipation of continued big currency gains has been a major element in whetting international demand for dollar-denominated bonds. At the current rate of 1.75 DM, the dollar is up 21 percent from its record low set in February. But there are increasing doubts whether in the near term it will be able to climb much over 1.80 DM. **********Meanwhile, with the economies of Japan and Germany expected to start slowing sharply in coming months, interest rates in Japan and Europe are expected to begin falling and push up bond prices. **********Japan Development Bank met a tremendous response last week when it sold 120 billion yen of 10-year government-guaranteed bonds priced to yield 4 basis points more than comparably dated domestic government bonds. By the end of the week, the paper was trading 4 basis points below domestic government yields. **********For international investors the development bank's bonds were more attractive than domestic paper, which is subject to a withholding tax on interest payments as well as a transaction tax. Managers said less than 5 percent of the issue was sold to Japanese investors and estimated that two-thirds was taken by institutional investors in Europe. **********The large size of the issue was also welcome because it assures an active and liquid secondary market - a feature that remains uncommon in the Euroyen sector. **********IN CONTRAST to the institutional investors' strategy of pursuing capital gains from expected interest rate cuts, retail clients were in evidence last week stretching for high yield. Double-digit returns were offered by Latin American issuers who tapped the Eurodollar sector. A substantial portion of this paper, bankers report, is being sold to Latin Americans - effectively repatriating offshore flight capital. **********In addition, there is demand from the growing number of emerging markets funds as well as from U.S. insurance and pension funds that remain hungry for the high yields on junk bonds. About half of the $200 million issue from Petrobras, Brazil's oil company, was distributed as a private placement to U.S. investors. **********While the credit ratings for Brazil and Venezuela remain below investment grade, the fact remains that in the nine years since the debt crisis erupted no issuer has defaulted on servicing bonds while bank debt has been continuously rescheduled and in part forgiven. **********Although a growing portion of Latin debt is now in the form of bonds as a result of the officially sponsored debt-reduction plan suggested by Nicholas Brady, the U.S. Treasury secretary, the short-term nature of the Eurobond offers comfort to investors. **********The Petrobras paper was issued for five years with an annual yield of 12.25 percent paid semiannually. The company has the right to call the paper after two years - in which case holders will earn a semiannual yield of 12.75 percent - and holders have the right to request early repayment after three years, earning 12.375 percent. **********Brazil has yet to agree on a Brady Plan restructuring of its bank debt, and the bonds were priced to yield 5 percentage points more than comparably dated U.S. government bonds. **********Venezuela, which has restructured its debt and ranks about equal with Mexico as the most creditworthy of the big Latin American debtors, offered $150 million of five-year bonds with no opportunity for early repayment to yield 9.59 percent - a spread of 2.35 percentage points over U.S. government paper. **********The terms were considered comparatively stingy. Last March, Mexico paid a spread of 2.4 percentage points for three-year money. But in all cases, these issues are largely placed before they are announced so there is not much loose paper waiting to be sold. **********Venezuela's major private cement company, Vencemos, also tapped the market, seeking $35 million for two years and $40 million for five years with the yields. The two-year paper offered a 3.2 percentage point spread over comparable U.S. Treasuries, while the five-year securities were priced at a 3.9 point spread. **********Argentina, which also lags in solving its overhang of bank debt, is expected to come to market this week for up to $200 million and one of the nation's largest private companies will be seeking $100 million. **********When not seeking high yields, European retail investors were out in force to buy $250 million of four-year notes issued by Deutsche Bank and $200 million of five-year paper offered by Swiss Bank Corp. Both issues were priced to yield a scant 30 basis points over U.S. Treasury paper - the level at which the World Bank giant global bonds trade.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/19/busin.snippet: Leading officials of the European Commission are seeking to squelch what they portray as a campaign to wrongly suggest that an agreement limiting car imports from Japan also restricts production at Japanese "transplant" factories in the EC.. &qu
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/19/busin.body_text: **********Leading officials of the European Commission are seeking to squelch what they portray as a campaign to wrongly suggest that an agreement limiting car imports from Japan also restricts production at Japanese "transplant" factories in the EC. **********"I can't understand what the confusion is all about," the EC internal market commissioner, Martin Bangemann, said Wednesday. **********"It's absolutely clear that the agreement places no limits on Japanese transplants." **********The EC competition commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, strongly criticized what he described as attempts by dissatisfied parties within the EC to blur details of the agreement to restrict Japanese car imports during a seven-year transition period beginning in 1993. **********"Articles have questioned what the agreement says because some people don't like what it does say," he said Tuesday in an interview. "It's as simple as that. **********He added "So if you don't like it, you can't go home and say that you can try to fur it up at the edges, and that's what's been going on." **********Officials said the Commission's irritation was directed at France, and particularly at the outspoken chairman of Peugeot SA, Jacques Calvet, who urged revision of the EC-Japanese pact almost as soon as it was agreed to on July 31. **********The chairman of the French state-owned automaker Renault, Raymond Levy, has also been critical of the agreement, warning of huge job losses in the EC auto industry. **********"We're tired of people trying to unstitch the agreement," said one official. "People have been saying after this pact has been negotiated that it is now open to negotiations, and that's just not true." **********In a sense, the emotional European Community debate over Japanese cars has now come full-circle: months of bitter debate among EC countries over how many vehicles to allow was followed by a period of hard bargaining with Japan, and now the intra-Community sniping has resumed. **********The EC-Japan agreement restricts direct imports from Japan to 1.23 million per year by 1999, and a totally free market takes effect in 2000. **********There is an EC assumption, however, that transplant production within the Community, which totaled 260,000 last year, will not exceed 1.2 million by 1999. **********"That assumption is made, nobody is in disagreement over it, but it is not a control," said Sir Leon. "It is absolutely clear that cars made in Europe by Japanese-owned companies are in the same position as cars made in Europe by U.S.-owned companies, that is, that you are free to make as many as you like." **********Top Commission officials are concerned that continuing confusion over the agreement will only be counterproductive, by distracting Community automakers from the difficult task of adapting the industry to make it competitive in a true open market after the turn of the century.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.snippet: After two days of talks with Japanese leaders, the European Community on Tuesday came away empty-handed but "satisfied," a sign that despite its soaring trade deficit, the Community was eager to promote broader ties with Tokyo to help establish
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.main_headline: EC-Japan Talks: No Gain, No Pain
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.print_headline: EC-Japan Talks: No Gain, No Pain
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.body_text: **********After two days of talks with Japanese leaders, the European Community on Tuesday came away empty-handed but "satisfied," a sign that despite its soaring trade deficit, the Community was eager to promote broader ties with Tokyo to help establish its own political identity. **********Although the Community and Japan remained far apart on a range of trade and investment disputes, Brussels appeared willing to put these concerns to one side. **********"Serious trade problems remain which should not be underestimated," said Frans Andriessen, the EC Commission's vice president for external affairs in a speech Tuesday in Osaka. "The need to strengthen relations between both parties derives in the first place from political considerations." **********Mr. Andriessen's visit marked the first ministerial-level meeting since the landmark declaration last July in The Hague that committed both sides to "equitable" market access and coordination on international security issues, from arms control to drug trafficking. **********Both sides find themselves in similar stages of political development. "Tokyo and Brussels represent major economic players whose political capacity is lacking maturity," Mr. Andriessen noted. **********But more than political ties, however, the issue that dominated Mr. Andriessen's talks with Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and members of Japan's newly installed cabinet was trade. Japan conceded nothing, an outcome Brussels appeared resigned to accept. **********An EC official said: "The U.S. has sticks. The EC doesn't." He was referring to the Community's commitment to seek multilateral resolutions to trade disputes, unlike Washington, which in the past used the threat of its trade law to retaliate unilaterally. **********On the political front, there was plenty of hope but no concrete results. Officials were pleased that Brussels and Tokyo had begun to seek cooperation on regional issues. **********"With the U.S., we've had a dialogue, and plenty of squabbles," said Kaoru Ishikawa, a Foreign Ministry official in charge of EC affairs. "This hadn't existed before with Europe as a whole." **********Tokyo expressed an interest - but made no commitment - in giving more assistance to Eastern and Central Europe, although it shot down a request to give more aid to the Soviet Union. **********"We're more and more interested in Eastern Europe," Mr. Ishikawa said. "But it remains very far away, both psychologically and geographically." **********Brussels, for its part, shares a common interest in the Cambodian peace process. But it balked at a Japanese request to cofinance a reforestation project in the Malaysian state of Sarawak. **********While continuing to seek areas of political cooperation, the Community also stressed that improved trade was the most efficient means of achieving political aims. **********Brussels also sought to fight what it saw as Tokyo's tendency to cave in to U.S. pressure to buy American-made goods. **********That is one reason why, in talks with Trade Minister Kozo Watanabe, EC officials focused on aircraft, telecommunications and other high-technology items it feels are competitive, yet have little market penetration in Japan. **********Another is that stepped-up purchases of these big-ticket items would go a long way toward trimming the Community's trade deficit with Japan, which is set to soar to a record $30 billion in 1991, after $18.5 billion a year ago, according to EC estimates. **********But to Japanese officials, Mr. Andriessen's appeals on trade sounded disingenuous. The chief cause of the imbalance, they said, was rising consumer demand in Germany following unification and a slowdown in Japanese demand for European paintings and luxury goods. The onus was on European companies to work harder to penetrate the Japanese market, they added. **********Mr. Ishikawa said: "Unless we try to vacuum in what they're trying to sell there won't be a balance in trade. It's a pity." **********Yet in a compromise that resembles the two-way criticism of Tokyo's Structural Impediments Initiative talks with Washington, the Community and Japan have agreed to exchange lists of specific demands on bilateral trade and investment concerns by next spring's round of senior-level meetings. **********Brussels, however, apparently backed down from an earlier threat to impose a deadline for Tokyo to respond to its specific requests. **********Mr. Watanabe also assured Mr. Andriessen that Japanese automakers' recently announced plans to expand procurement of foreign auto parts would not focus exclusively on the United States. **********Mr. Andriessen also pushed Japan to open its rice market and accept a proposal to convert nontariff barriers into tariffs to help reach a major agreement on freer trade in the Uruguay Round of world trade talks. **********Although Japanese officials failed to accept his demand, they appeared to be slowly preparing the groundwork to make an 11th-hour concession that would open the market from 3 percent to 5 percent but continue to protect Japanese farmers.

The family is faced with a litany of woes, ranging from soaring estimates of their public companies' debts to the announcement Wednesday that th...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/05/busin.body_text: **********It now appears unlikely that the companies controlled by the Maxwell family will avoid receivership. **********The family is faced with a litany of woes, ranging from soaring estimates of their public companies' debts to the announcement Wednesday that the Serious Fraud Office has begun an investigation into alleged improprieties in the management of Mirror Group Newspapers pension funds. And many analysts said the end seemed near. **********"I would give the private Maxwell companies an 85 percent chance of going into receivership," a London-based banking analyst said Wednesday. "As for the public companies, I'd say their chances of avoiding it are less than 50-50." **********The Maxwells' bankers were still reeling over the revelation Tuesday that there were £300 million ($530 million) in secret loans from the family's public companies to its private enterprises and an additional £300 million borrowed from the public companies' pension funds. At a stroke, that boosted the family's known private-company debt by two-thirds. **********"Of course, the banks cocked it up," said Rodney Marion Green, a banking analyst with James Capel & Co. **********For National Westminster Bank, the head of the steering committee representing banks with loans to the Maxwells' private companies, Wednesday marked a new humiliation. **********NatWest's shares closed at 266 pence, down 9 pence for the day. **********"For the first time in history, National Westminster now has a smaller market capitalization than Lloyds Bank," a banking analyst said. He said the exposure to Maxwell interests - the largest of any bank - was "a factor" contributing to NatWest's slide to the third-largest British bank in terms of market capitalization, after Lloyds and Barclays. **********With the Maxwell interests unraveling, a number of analysts were scrambling for precedents that might offer some clue as to the next steps. **********"Some people are drawing parallels to Asil Nadir and Polly Peck," a media analyst said. Others cited the case of Alan Bond of Australia. In both cases, banks have faired poorly in recovering on their loans. **********Then, too, there were unusually vehement cries that banks should have known better. Although most analysts said it was difficult for banks to protect themselves from fraud, others pointed out that the Maxwell case was an exception. **********In July 1971, an official investigation of Robert Maxwell by the British Department of Trade culminated in a report that accused him of making statements he must have known to be false and concluded in part, "He is not in our opinion a person who can be relied on to exercise proper stewardship of a publicly quoted company." **********As for Robert Maxwell's public reputation, the Independent on Sunday, of which Mr. Maxwell owned 6 percent, said in an editorial after his death that he was, among other things, "a liar, a cheat and a bully." **********Although conceding that British banks were "in this up to their bloody armpits," one banking analyst said the bulk of the debts of the Maxwell companies are held by foreign banks such as Crédit Lyonnais, Paribas and Sumitomo Trust & Banking Co. **********"This was not a game played by London rules," the analyst said. **********At this juncture, the betting is that creditors to the Maxwell public companies will be, as one banking analyst said, "badly burned." Prospects for recovering a healthy slice of loans to MCC looked brighter, and most analysts continued to regard the Mirror Group as a good prospect.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/world.main_headline: Israel Expels 4 More From the Gaza Strip
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/world.print_headline: Israel Expels 4 More From the Gaza Strip
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/world.body_text: **********Israel expelled four Palestinians from the Gaza Strip to Lebanon early this morning. All four were accused of fomenting and carrying out violent acts on behalf of the Palestine Liberation Organization . **********"The expulsions were carried out following a Supreme Court denial of their appeals against the orders," the army said. The four -- Jamal Yassin Abu-Habel, Muin Mohammed Maslan, Hisham Mohammed Ali Dahalan and Jamal Abed Abu-Jadyan -- were taken by helicopter to southern Lebanon and dropped off to search for a taxi to Beirut. **********The four bring to 69 the number of Palestinians deported since their uprising began in the occupied territories more than 41 months ago. **********The expulsion order against the four was issued on March 24 and the court held the final hearing on their appeal on Tuesday. Under normal circumstances, they would have been expelled the next morning. **********But on Wednesday, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was here, meeting with Government leaders as part of his effort to arrange a regional peace conference. The United States has been one of the most outspoken critics of Israel's policy of expelling people accused of crimes. And so the army apparently decided not to carry out the order until after he had left.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/08/busin.main_headline: Making a Difference; Extracting Siberian Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/08/busin.print_headline: Making a Difference; Extracting Siberian Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/08/busin.body_text: **********Big oil companies remain wary about pledging billions to ventures in the vast oilfields of the Soviet republics. But a deal joining Phibro Energy Inc. of Greenwich, Conn.; a Houston-based independent, Anglo-Suisse Inc., and a Russian oil association nearly a year ago is already providing the Russians with foreign currency from crude exports. **********Several other independent oil companies in the West had signed deals before the coup attempt last month, but few have moved as rapidly as the Phibro-Anglo-Suisse group, called White Nights. A Russian oil cooperative has 50 percent ownership. **********"Our history of dealing with the Russians was that it might take months to hammer out a contract, but once it was done, the Soviets honored their commitments," said Ronald H. Benson, a Phibro executive who is president of White Nights. The group has nearly 1,000 workers, including more than 900 Soviet workers hardened to life in western Siberia. **********Those harsh conditions and the collapsing Soviet economy have taken a toll on some Texans and Oklahomans. Gilles Labbe, president of Anglo-Suisse, said that this summer he fired two American administrators who were frustrated by the bureaucracy. **********Yet production is rising. Output in three fields operated by White Nights has grown to 22,000 barrels a day and will reach 400,000 by 1996, Mr. Labbe said. Another deal signed in July among the same partners, called Golden Mammoth, will pump 600,000 barrels a day in five years, from 25,000 today, he said. **********White Nights expects to invest $1 billion over 20 years and to drill more than 500 wells in three fields that hold 800 million barrels. Another $2 billion is expected to be spent in Golden Mammoth, which has two billion barrels of reserves, Mr. Labbe said. **********Oil experts gauge the Soviet Union's total oil reserves at about 60 billion barrels. But some geologists say the region could surpass Saudi Arabia, with its proven reserves of 250 billion barrels. **********Big Oil seems certain to join the hunt soon. Matthew Sagers, an analyst at PlanEcon, a consulting firm in Washington, said deals with Western companies could increase Soviet oil output by four million barrels a day in 1994, from about 10 million barrels today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.main_headline: BTR Bids $2.55 Billion for Hawker Siddeley
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.print_headline: BTR Bids $2.55 Billion for Hawker Siddeley
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.body_text: **********In the third major takeover bid in Britain in five days, BTR P.L.C, an industrial conglomerate, offered about $2.55 billion today for the Hawker Siddeley Group P.L.C., a diversified industrial manufacturer. **********Hawker Siddeley's board said it would fight the bid. The businesses of the company, whose sales totaled $4.2 billion last year, include electric motors and power equipment, instruments and controls, batteries, rail and industrial goods, and servicing aircraft engines. **********Analysts said the unsolicited bid confirmed their view that the takeover market in Britain, which had been moribund since the end of 1989, was coming back to life. "We will not necessarily go back to the boom of 1989, but we will see a slow upsurge in large bids," said Philip Healey, the editor and publisher of Acquisitions Monthly, a British magazine. **********The analysts cited several reasons that the takeover boomlet was occurring now -- falling interest rates and a rising stock market, which make it easier to finance acquisitions; the economic recovery in the United States, a large market for many British companies, and the widening belief that the British recession has bottomed out. **********"The takeovers tell you that corporate U.K. is fairly confident about the prospects for a recovery," said Michael Armitage, an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company. **********The BTR bid follows two others by industrial conglomerates: Williams Holdings' $1.2 billion hostile bid for Racal Electronics, an electronics and security company that is expected to be only marginally profitable in its current fiscal year, and Hanson P.L.C.'s $606 million friendly bid for Beazer P.L.C., the troubled construction and building materials company. **********Hanson, Williams and BTR all have reputations as shrewd buyers of industrial companies. They typically have not overpaid and have succeeded in improving the profitability of the parts of the acquisitions they have kept by exercising tight management. **********In the last three weeks, 11 bids have been made for publicly held British companies, with a total value of more than $:3.1 billion, or about $5.35 billion, Mr. Healey said. That compares with a total in the first eight months of the year of $:2.8 billion. The 11 include BTR's friendly $34 million bid for Rockware Glass Ltd., a British glass and packaging manufacturer, and American Brands' hostile $494 million bid for Invergordon, a whisky distiller. **********Analysts also see as potential takeover targets: Allied-Lyons P.L.C., Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., the big food and drinks companies that might interest other food giants; the Asda Group P.L.C., a British supermarket concern with dismal profit margins; Pilkington Glass Ltd., the glass manufacturer, and Amec, a construction company, which would both profit from an economic upturn. **********"Many people are looking around for cyclical companies that would benefit from an upturn and whose profit margins are not so great and could be improved," said Philip J. Wolstencroft, an equities strategist at Smith New Court Securities Ltd.  Reasons for Bidding **********In bidding for Hawker Siddeley, BTR's chairman, Sir Owen Green, said he thought his target, whose profits have been falling in recent years, could do better under BTR. "Hawker Siddeley shareholders have endured their company's underperformance for a decade," he said. **********But Hawker Siddeley said its management was in the middle of a program to improve profitability by cutting costs and fine-tuning its businss mix. The analysts said both assertions had some validity. **********In trading on the London International Stock Exchange today, Hawker Siddeley's shares rose by $:1.18, or about $2.04, to $:7.58, or $13.08. That inidcates investors think a higher bid will come from BTR or someone else: BTR offered Hawker Siddeley shareholders a package of cash and BTR shares that it valued at $:7.41, but which was worth $:7.27 based on BTR's closing price today, or $:7 in cash. **********In London, BTR's shares closed at $:4.10, or $7.07, off 13 pence, or 22 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/24/busin.main_headline: Wall Street; Selling More Shares -- Without Penalty
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/24/busin.print_headline: Wall Street; Selling More Shares -- Without Penalty
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/24/busin.body_text: **********The more, the merrier? That's what Steven G. Einhorn, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company, predicts for the stock market. "We believe that a significant amount of new equity supply will develop in the next several years," Mr. Einhorn said. "It's already starting." And despite the fact that new shares dilute the value of a company's old shares, Mr. Einhorn thinks investors will cheer this trend. **********In fact, companies that have sold additional shares recently have not been penalized by the market, as they were during the 80's. "That's the best evidence that investors recognize corporations need more equity on their balance sheets," he added. **********Mr. Einhorn believes the shrinking supply of stock in the 80's, caused by leveraged buyouts and mergers, was one factor in the decade's long bull market. Will a boom in supply depress stock prices? "Not necessarily," he said. "There have been times when there was an increasing equity supply and a rising market. We think this will be one of them."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Issues Narrowly Mixed
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed again yesterday, as dealers placed bids at an auction of $12.5 billion worth of new two-year notes. **********Memories of last month's two-year note auction, when a small handful of firms made an aggressive, enormous bid for the securities, hung heavy over yesterday's sale, traders said. **********As a consequence, market participants intent on picking up at least some notes placed very conservative bids, thereby forcing up interest costs to the Treasury. **********Bids at the auction produced an average yield of 7.06 percent, up from 6.81 percent at the two-year note sale in May. **********The rate was also much higher than it was late Monday, when the two-year notes were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 6.99 percent.  'Ridiculously Cheap' **********"The whole world owns this one," one government securities trader said. "And they are ridiculously cheap compared to the outstanding two-year note." **********Late yesterday the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes sold in May were offered at a price of 99 23/32, down 1/32, to yield 6.90 percent. **********"There was a concerted effort to avoid the perception that there was an attempt to corner this new two-year issue," said William V. Sullivan, Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. **********Reaction was muted to several economic reports that provided further evidence of a turnaround in May. **********Nevertheless, bond prices, which tend to deteriorate on signs of economic strength, were modestly higher by midafternoon. **********Among the reports was a 3.8 percent increase in orders for durable goods in May. The gain was the biggest monthly rise since March 1990. But analysts said that since much of the gain was in military and transportation orders, the overall increase overstated what really went on last month. Moreover, order backlogs remain weak. **********"Excluding defense and transportation, orders were up 1.4 percent," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "Orders have clearly bounced off the bottom, but order backlogs haven't really increased. To build a base for future production and employment, you need backlogs to rise." **********Similarly, analysts said a rise in the Conference Board's consumer confidence index during May, while welcome, masked continued problems in attitudes. **********A brighter sense of the future was the main reason consumer attitudes improved last month. But consumers' sentiment about their current situations deteriorated for the 10th straight month in May. **********"Consumers are still nervous and uncertain," Mr. Fine said. **********In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 95 29/32, up 2/32, to yield 8.50 percent, the same level as late Monday. **********Among outstanding note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 97 27/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.32 percent. And the 7 percent three-year notes were offered at 99, down 1/32, to yield 7.38 percent. **********In advance of today's auction of $9.25 billion worth of new five-year Treasury notes, the securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.96 percent. **********Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged. **********Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.56 percent late yesterday and six-month bill rates stood at 5.74 percent, unchanged from late Monday. **********In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Private Export Funding Corporation offered $100 million worth of 10-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by J. P. Morgan Securities. **********The 8 3/4 percent notes, which mature on June 3, 2003, were priced at $100, or par, 41 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.  Municipal Activity Was Light **********With the exception of some outstanding securities issued by Suffolk County, L.I., activity in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds was very light. **********After Monday's ratings downgrade by Standard & Poor's, which cut its rating on $271 million worth of outstanding Suffolk County general obligation bonds to BB from BBB-plus, traders said that yields on some securities rose yesterday. **********For example, an insured 7 percent Suffolk County issue maturing in 2010 that had been priced to yield 7.10 percent before the downgrading was announced was offered at a price to yield 7.25 percent late yesterday. **********Aside from the activity in selected Suffolk County issues, market participants said prices of most widely-quoted municipal issues were unchanged to 1/8 of a point lower. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction of new two-year Treasury notes: (000 omitted in dollar figures) Average Price . . . 99.890 Average Yield . . . 7.06% Low Price . . . 99,890 High Yield . . . 7.06% High Price . . . 99.945 Low Yield . . . 7.03 Accepted at low price . . . 64% Total applied for . . . $37,198,515 Accepted . . . $12,528,945 N.Y. applied for . . . $34,298,110 N.Y. accepted . . . $11,444,710 Noncompetitive . . . $1,080,000 Interest set at . . . 7%

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/09/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press Notes; Dow Jones Plans to Tighten Foreign Policy for Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/09/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press Notes; Dow Jones Plans to Tighten Foreign Policy for Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/09/busin.body_text: **********WHILE working as a foreign correspondent at The Wall Street Journal may be a glamorous job, it is about to become a significantly less rewarding one financially. **********Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Journal, has notified foreign correspondents and other expatriate employees that on Jan. 1 1992, the company will cease paying allowances for housing, goods and services under its old formula. The new rules will apply to those posted abroad after Jan. 1, but will not apply to expatriates now in place until June 30, 1993. **********"It represents a substantial pay cut," said Ken Martin, vice president of the Independent Association of Publishers' Employees, the union for Dow Jones employees in the United States. Employees abroad are not covered by the union contract, but Mr. Martin said the union was receiving calls from expatriates. **********Donald L. Miller, vice president of employee relations for Dow Jones, said the "very substantial subsidy" now in place for housing would be replaced by a formula that gives subsidies only to the extent that housing costs in a foreign city exceed those in the New York City area. **********Those working abroad for Dow Jones will be expected to take care of their own housing, just as they would if they were working in New York. **********The company is also changing the way it calculates the net pay in dollars of employees abroad. The company guarantees that expatriates will be paid enough to maintain this net pay, regardless of currency fluctuations. But the lower the net pay, the lower the basis for compensation. **********Currently, only Federal taxes are deducted from gross pay in calculating net pay. Under the new system, New York state and city nonresident taxes will also be deducted. The added taxes represent 8 to 9 percent of gross wages. **********Other benefits, like home leave and relocation reimbursement, will remain unchanged. **********No details were given on how much the average expatriate's compensation would be reduced. **********Mr. Miller declined to predict how much money the company would save. A letter to expatriates said the company was now spending $4 million on overseas allowances, which account for more than half of their total compensation. **********He said the change reflected Dow Jones's evolution from an American company with a few expatriate workers to a global company. **********About 1,800 employees work abroad for various editions of The Journal, the Telerate financial-data subsidiary and other Dow Jones operations. Of these, only 120 are expatriates; the rest are foreign nationals who do not receive a housing allowance. **********Anders F. Halden, regional manager in New York for the Corporate Resources Group, a Geneva-based concern that helped set up the new Dow Jones compensation system, said he was unaware of any other news organizations that were setting up similar systems. **********"We hope to be able to catch more, using Dow Jones as a reference point" Mr. Halden said. **********Nancy Nielsen, a spokeswoman for The New York Times Company, said the company gave its expatriate employees a cost-of-living allowance, which included a subsidy for housing and currency fluctuations. She said the Times Company re-evaluated the method for setting that allowance annually, but that there were no current plans to change that method. Rumors in Little Rock **********Little Rock, Ark., was aflame with rumors last week that the struggling Arkansas Gazette was about to be sold by the Gannett Company to its archrival, The Arkansas Democrat. **********Some local television stations quoted unidentified sources as saying that a sale was probably imminent. **********But neither Gannett nor Walter E. Hussman Jr., owner of The Democrat, has been willing to explain what is going on. Thus far, there is voluminous smoke, but no apparent fire. **********Douglas H. McCorkindale, Gannett's vice chairman, said, "Nothing is going to happen soon." But he added that Gannett was "in a total no-comment posture on Little Rock." **********A secretary for Mr. Hussman said he was unavailable for comment. **********The sale scenario makes sense in that Gannett is widely believed to be losing heavily in Little Rock. Two persons close to the company's affairs said The Gazette was expected to lose more than $30 million this year. **********Gannett acquired The Gazette in 1986 for $51 million and the assumption of $9 million of existing debt. **********The Democrat is also unprofitable. But Mr. Hussman's Wehco Media group has other profitable ventures that offset the losses, and the paper has gained in circulation and advertising market share since 1986. **********Gannett is widely believed to be trying to either sell The Gazette, close it or persuade Mr. Hussman to agree to a joint operating arrangement in which production, distribution and advertising would be merged, while both papers would continue. **********But Mr. Hussman has said he does not want to be in a joint operating arrangement with Gannett. **********Lee Dirks, president of Lee Dirks & Associates, a newspaper brokerage in Birmingham, Mich., said the Justice Department would probably not allow Gannett to sell The Gazette to a direct rival like Mr. Hussman unless there were no other buyers. As owner of The Gazette, Mr. Hussman would be free to close it. **********Mr. Dirks added that should such a sale be in the works, Gannett would probably have to declare the paper was for sale and seek an alternate buyer. That might explain why nothing will happen soon. Twists in an Ad Format **********For four years, newspaper publishers have been talking about adopting a standard invoice format for national advertisers, in hopes that more national advertising will follow. **********Finally, it looks like they may actually get it done. **********A dizzying array of invoices made buying newspaper advertising difficult. So in 1988, a standard invoice format was introduced. **********While most papers claimed to have adopted it, "each paper put a little twist to the format," said Uldis Grava, director of marketing planning for the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. He estimated that only 15 percent of the nation's newspapers actually used the format correctly. **********The current advertising drought has spurred action. In mid-September, the bureau's board will meet to complete a new simplified format. **********This time, chairmen of many of the largest newspaper groups have personally guaranteed strict compliance. Mr. Grava said the new standardized invoice should be widely adopted by the end of the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/07/busin.body_text: **********One of the great bogus concepts wafting through management suites is something called "consensus:" solving knotty problems through unanimity. **********As a concept it's a failure -- and in the end, that's what it produces, too: failure and mediocrity in performance, accountability, options, even commitment to the project. Something that is everyone's task is nobody's task. **********But another management strategy is fast becoming the mark of corporations that excel -- Motorola, Corning, Intel, 3M, among others -- and it involves teamwork without consensus. This strategy spins on the ability of a company to manage diversity. **********This is how it works. Consider a team to be a well-identified unit of five to nine peers who share time and space and report to a boss or team leader. Imagine assembling a team of people who are well educated, talented and well trained. They care about their business and each other. They've done their homework and in meetings, they act as advocates of particular ideas. **********It would be downright silly to think these people might arrive at a single point of view. More to the point, we shouldn't want them to. Who needs resolutions so watered down that no one cares what gets decided? What companies should strive for is a climate that encourages competing options. That's what produces results. **********How can companies achieve this? To manage diversity, someone must sit at the head of the table to make the final decision, to choose from competing options that have been brought up by team members. Those "facilitators," the hottest executives in America today, are: *********** Astute selectors, carefully determining who will be on their team. They may be new to the job, and even inherit a team, but they must be able to assess who's with them and who's not, who should be hired and fired, and who can be given more time to grow because potential is there. *********** Invisible initiators, encouraging team members to act on their diverse strengths. They believe in their people more than those associates believe in themselves. They make sure employees stretch themselves and take risks. And they make sure the employees -- not the facilitators -- get credit for accomplishments. *********** Willing workers, who don't sit behind a desk, barking orders. Nor do they overdelegate. Rather, they give their strengths to the organization, doing their share of the work that is generated through collaborations with team members. *********** Learners, prepared to have their minds changed by subordinates who may know more about the subject. This, of all their roles, is most important for facilitators. **********When all of these pieces are in place, they produce not only strong management but future strength: Subordinates learn from facilitators so that they, too, can manage diversity. When this new teamwork is in place, it can produce a company that is energized, fiercely competitive -- and a lot more fun to work at.
