https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/busin.print_headline: Suzuki Starts Joint Venture In Hungary
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/busin.body_text: **********The Suzuki Motor Corporation began the first major Japanese investment in Eastern Europe today, signing a joint venture project that will start producing hatchback passenger cars at a former Soviet military base in northern Hungary next year. **********The $235 million Magyar Suzuki plant, near the Danube River in the city of Esztergom, represents the largest single foreign investment in Hungary. **********Planning for the project began when Hungary was still under Communist rule, but at the signing ceremonies today, it was hailed as a milestone on Hungary's way to a market economy and a telling mark of approval by Japan's cautious capitalists. **********"This sends a very strong signal that the investment climate here is such that it can attract capital, that other businesses should look very carefully at the opportunities that Hungary can offer," said Judhvir Parmar, vice president of the International Finance Corporation, an affiliate of the World Bank, which holds a 9 percent share in the project. 6 Years of Negotiations **********The International Finance Corporation, which specializes in financing projects in developing countries, is providing an $85 million credit to the Suzuki project. The corporation announced today that it had also agreed with the Budapest Bank to provide $68 million in credits for small-scale ventures in Hungary. **********Osamu Suzuki, president of the Japanese auto manufacturer, said it had taken six years of negotiations and four personal visits to Hungary before the deal was finally signed. He added that he expected the project to become "an initiator for new investments from Japan." **********The Hungarian partner in the Suzuki project is Autokonszern Inc., a group of local companies that joined forces last year to match Suzuki's 40 percent share in the venture. Initial capital investment in the project is $74 million. After lengthy negotiations with the Hungarian Government, the new company was able to win a 10-year tax-break package and special consideration on import duties. In return, it promised to try to use Hungarian-made components for about 50 percent of the final product. **********Peter A. Bod, Hungary's Minister of Industry and Trade, said the target figure for local content would be a useful test for Hungarian manufacturers as they try to bring their products up to Western standards. "If we can meet the 50 percent test, then Hungarian manufacturing industry will have reached the highest class," he said. **********The model to be produced here will be Suzuki's five-door Swift, and when it is driven off the assembly line late next year, it will be the first car manufactured in Hungary in 50 years. During the Communist era, Hungary imported cars from other Comecon countries; in the last two years, the number of Western-made cars here has increased dramatically, despite a hefty import tax. **********The Suzuki project has attracted considerable attention in Hungary because it will be a brand-new business; because of the Japanese reputation for quality, and because it will make cars. "Cars have always meant more to people than just another consumer item," Mr. Bod said. **********The Suzuki plant, which will employ 1,100 people, is expected to reach peak production of 60,000 cars a year. At a news conference today, Istvan Lepsenyi, the president of Magyar Suzuki, said 60 percent of the cars produced would be sold in Hungary and 30 percent through the Suzuki sales network in Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A.L. Labs President Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.body_text: **********A.L. Laboratories, a generic drug maker, said yesterday that its president of six months, Richard P. Storm, resigned by mutual agreement with the board. Though Mr. Storm, 53 years old, has 30 years experience in the pharmaceutical industry, he had no previous experience with a smaller, more specialized company like A.L. Laboratories, said I. Roy Cohen, the vice chairman, whom Mr. Storm succeeded as president in January.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/06/world.main_headline: Robert Maxwell Found Dead Off Canary Islands
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/06/world.print_headline: Robert Maxwell Found Dead Off Canary Islands
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/06/world.body_text: **********Robert Maxwell, the flamboyant and combative British publisher whose global empire includes The Daily News in New York, vanished suddenly from his yacht today while cruising off the Canary Islands. His body was discovered hours later, floating in the sea. **********The sole passenger on his vast, 180-foot, white-carpeted yacht, the 68-year-old Mr. Maxwell had last been seen alive by members of the 13-member crew in the dim pre-dawn light, pacing the decks alone. **********Crew members reported him missing about six hours later, when the yacht dropped anchor at 11 A.M. off the coast of Tenerife and they discovered his stateroom was empty.  Body Recovered From Sea **********Spanish maritime authorities said Mr. Maxwell's body was recovered late this afternoon from calm seas about 20 miles southwest of Grand Canary Island, following an extensive air and sea search. **********The body, which Spanish officials said was unclothed, showed no signs of violence. It was taken immediately to a forensic institute in Las Palmas, on Grand Canary Island, for an autopsy to ascertain the cause of death. **********Details of the bizarre death continued to unfold through the evening, with reports surfacing that Mr. Maxwell's mansion outside Oxford was under guard tonight. Meanwhile, colleagues who knew of telephone conversations Mr. Maxwell had from the yacht with family members and business associates in the hours before he died expressed bafflement, saying there was nothing in his manner to suggest he was distressed or acting oddly.  Built Publishing Empire **********Mr. Maxwell fled the collapse of Czechoslovakia in 1939 to become one of the most powerful publishers in Britain and the world, presiding over a multibillion-dollar empire that he assembled with brass and bravura over 40 years.  [ Obituary, page D23. ] **********Mr. Maxwell's abrupt and unexpected end raised questions about what will happen to his business holdings, including The Daily News, which he purchased earlier this year as it teetered near collapse after a long strike. **********Analysts of the newspaper industry said that the death had cast the fate of the New York newspaper into serious doubt, with one expert noting that the Maxwell committment to the paper was "more personal than corporate; more an ego trip than an investment." His tangled empire also includes Macmillan Inc., the publishing company, The Daily Mirror in London, and The European, a weekly newspaper designed to cover and circulate in an integrating Europe.  Sons to Head Empire **********Ian and Kevin Maxwell, two of Mr. Maxwell's sons, were named acting chairmen today of, respectively, the Mirror Newspaper Group and Maxwell Communications Corporation. **********The mysterious circumstances of Mr. Maxwell's death write a dramatic final scene for a man who himself seemed larger than life. Once a penniless refugee from Nazi persecution, he came to command a global business empire, and count among his acquaintances many world leaders. **********Politicians and colleagues in Britain rushed to pay him tribute today, describing him as "the Citizen Kane of his time," reflecting the penchant for controversy that had characterized his life until the last.  Charge of Israeli Link **********Two weeks ago, he was described in a book as being closely linked with the Mossad, the Israeli secret service, an allegation that sparked an intense flurry of controversey here when it was aired in Parliament. **********Mr. Maxwell described the allegation as "ludicrous, a total invention," and filed a libel action against the author, Seymour Hersh, a former reporter for The New York Times who is working on a special project for The Times's Washington bureau. **********The book, "The Samson Option," which describes the development of Israel's nuclear weapons program, also accused Nicholas Davies, the foreign editor of The Daily Mirror, Mr. Maxwell's flagship paper, of working closely with a Mossad agent, and dealing in arms. **********Mr. Davies denied the charges and filed a libel suit of his own, but was later dismissed by Mr. Maxwell after questions were raised about a trip he allegedly made to Ohio to visit an arms merchant. **********There has also been mounting speculation about the condition of Mr. Maxwell's financial empire. **********A spokesman in London for the Mirror Newspaper Group said Mr.Maxwell had been on a solitary sailing holiday off the coast of North Africa since last Thursday, and was due to return to London late today or Wednesday. **********He was reported to be the only passenger aboard the gleaming yacht, the Lady Ghislaine, a 430-ton luxury vessel which is named after one of Mr. Maxwell's daughters. The yacht cost an estimated $25 million when it was commissioned in 1986 by a brother of Adnan Khashoggi, the Saudi Arabian arms dealer. **********The news that Mr. Maxwell was missing first broke in London in mid-afternoon, when his two publically owned companies, Mirror Newspaper Group and Maxwell Communications Corporation, announced they were voluntarily suspending trading on the London stock exchange.  Announcement in Britain **********Shortly afterwards, the Mirror Group released a brief, eight-sentence statement, saying that Mr. Maxwell "is missing at sea, feared lost overboard." **********The statement reported that a search was under way, and that weather conditions were good. The company also said that Mr. Maxwell's wife, Betty, and his eldest son, Philip, had left for Tenerife. **********According to a chronology pieced together from various company and official statements, Mr. Maxwell had boarded the yacht alone in Gibraltar last Thursday, after flying to the British colony from London. **********The yacht sailed to Madeira, off the coast of Morocco, and then on to the Canaries over the weekend. On Monday, Mr. Maxwell had telephone conversations from aboard the yacht with an executive of Mirror Group Newspapers, a lawyer in Paris and members of his family.  'Perfectly Good Mood' **********A company offical later described Mr. Maxwell as being in a "perfectly good mood." **********Later, crew members reported seeing Mr. Maxwell walking on the deck of the yacht at about 4:25 A.M. Charles Wilson, executive editor of Mirror Group newspapers, said in an interview that it was not unusual for Mr. Maxwell to keep such late hours. **********"He was a light sleeper, often up and about throughout the night," he said. **********Then about 20 minutes later, the crew reported he called the bridge from his stateroom, asking that the air conditioning in his quarters be turned down. **********That was the last time the crew reported any contact with Mr. Maxwell. About six hours later, at 11 A.M., the crew attempted to put a telephone call from New York through to Mr. Maxwell's stateroom, and there was no answer. When they went to investigate, they discovered him missing. **********After a thorough search of the yacht, the crew asked for help from Spanish maritime authorities in mounting a search. **********The body was discovered in the sea just before 6 P.M., by helicopters from Spanish Air Sea Rescue. Mrs. Maxwell and her son later positively identified the body.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/22/busin.main_headline: Selling Bikes After the Wild Ones Have Settled Down
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/22/busin.print_headline: ALL ABOUT: MOTORCYCLES; Selling Bikes After the Wild Ones Have Settled Down
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/22/busin.body_text: **********IT'S fun to think of motorcycle history in terms of celebrity cachet. James Dean and Marlon Brando made motorcycles sexy and sinister. Malcolm Forbes associated them with well-heeled capitalists. Ronald Reagan visited a Harley-Davidson plant and presto, motorcycles symbolized America's renewed manufacturing competitiveness. **********But behind the scenes, the motorcycle business is a lot less glitzy than the parade of flashy names might indicate. In fact, it is downright depressed. The recession, creeping couch potatoism and an explosion of consumer electronics products vying for the dwindling discretionary dollar have created a shrinking market for motorcycles. **********According to the Motorcycle Industry Council, a trade group in Irvine, Calif., there are 7.3 million bikes on the road, down from 7.7 million in 1985. Don J. Brown, a motorcycle industry consultant also in Irvine, said sales of new street, dirt and sport bikes will reach $1.33 billion for 266,000 units this year, almost identical to last year, but a drop from the $1.9 billion in revenues and 680,000 bikes in the industry's peak year of 1984. **********Dealers report that their only vibrant sellers are accessories -- like mugs with motorcycle logos, helmets and helmet decals. **********Honda and the other Japanese companies have had the worst time of it, because the yen has made their products prohibitively expensive. But even America's Harley, which says it sells every bike it makes, is not sanguine. "A shrinking market is difficult for everyone," said Michael E. Keefe, Harley's director of marketing communications. **********The council describes the typical rider as a 32.5-year-old man with household income of $39,200; a decade ago, he was about 27 and had household earnings of $17,800. "Far from being a rebel, the typical cyclist is the guy next-door," said Gary A. Christopher, the American Honda Motor Company's manager of motorcycle product evaluation. **********The manufacturers are actively wooing that guy. Through the council, they have formed Discover Today's Motorcycling, a publicity campaign that positions motorcycling as safe, fun and something an educated, well-mannered person would do. American Honda's own $75 million campaign, "Come Ride With Us," has the same goal. Competing With Japan Harley's Problem Is Too Few Bikes **********For a while, it looked as though Harley-Davidson would get an easy ride. **********Through much of the 1980's Honda, Kawasaki, Yamaha and Suzuki, the four Japanese manufacturers that dominated the American motorcycle market, focused primarily on high-performance sport bikes -- bikes that could go 175 miles an hour, that let their riders crouch forward in racer stance as they took corners at hairpin angles. **********The problem, motorcycle experts say now, is that the Japanese were so busy innovating they forgot to hark to their market. "Every year would bring a different looking, faster bike," said Paul Dean, editorial director of Cycle World Magazine in Newport Beach, Calif. "That meant a steep depreciation rate, incredibly high costs for replacement parts and huge insurance premiums." **********By the late 1980's the Japanese were erring at the other extreme. Recognizing that they were cannibalizing each other's sales as the market shrunk, they set out to woo new riders. They advertised in magazines like Life instead of biker books, they spurned new high-tech products in favor of non-racy bikes like Honda's Pacific Coast, a midsize touring bike that even has a luggage trunk. **********"We were trying so hard to get the yuppies that our core group of cycle enthusiasts felt abandoned," said Honda's Mr. Christopher. **********Against that backdrop, Harley cleaned up. It made big, clunky cruisers with lots of macho image but little glitz, whose basic design hadn't changed in years. A weak dollar helped it compete on price. **********Mr. Brown said Harley had nearly 31 percent of the street-bike market in 1991; second-seller Honda had 26 percent. R. L. Polk & Company, a Detroit company known for its auto industry statistics, said that in 1985, Honda had nearly 47 percent of the street-bike market, with Harley at a paltry 9.4 percent. **********But Harley's sales have been constrained by capacity. The company has a new paint facility and two new assembly lines about to open, but for now it cannot make more than about 70,000 bikes a year. And it exports about 40 percent of them. **********The result is that Harley dealers remain on allocation. "I have six customers for every motorcycle I get," said Michael J. Lombardi, a Harley dealer in Staten Island. **********The Japanese, meanwhile, are back in stride. They are offering new sport bikes to win back enthusiasts, and small off-road bikes that offer an unintimidating introduction to biking. **********While they are unlikely to woo away the Schwarzenegger wannabes -- he rides a Harley -- industry experts think they have a good shot at riders who want a bike that is smaller than a Harley.  As Machines Age Used Bikes Are Selling -- For Now **********Bikers aren't the only ones getting older. So are their machines. **********According to the motorcycle council, the average motorcycle in 1985 was less than five years old; last year it was about 9.5. Dealers got more than 14 percent of their revenues from selling used bikes last year. **********In Harley's case, one reason why the used market is thriving is that demand for new bikes outstrips supply. For the Japanese bikes, which are more plentiful, the reasons are rooted in the steeply rising prices. "People are saying, 'Let someone else take the depreciation,' and looking for good used bikes," said Mr. Dean of Cycle World.. **********The vibrant secondary market is unlikely to last much longer, though. As fewer new bikes are sold, the number of bikes coming into the used market must perforce dwindle. That means that the most popular used bikes will become harder to find, and concomittantly more expensive. **********Mr. Brown, the consultant, predicts that sales of used motorcycle will drop as much as 25 percent in the next four years. "That means new bikes will soon sell well again," he said. The Requisite Helmet Sales Are Insured As States Pass Laws **********Bike manufacturers may be wimpering, but helmet makers are all smiles. The reason: Unlike bike sales, helmet sales have seen nary a blip. Though the council does not break out sales of helmets, sales of peripheral equipment reached $1.66 billion last year.  There are eight million helmets in use. **********"Our business has grown 20 percent a year, and there's no reason to think that will stop," said Patrick Donnelly, director of sales for the Shoei Safety Helmet Corporation, the Los Angeles company that is the largest helmet maker. **********Helmet sales are bound to increase even further, as more states pass laws requiring riders to wear helmets. California, a major holdout, just passed such a law, effective Jan. 1. Most experts say a Federal law is inevitable. **********New helmet technology also is spurring sales. Stores already are selling Italian helmets with a thermal control system that makes them cool in summer and warm in winter. And David A. Bottell, a California entrepreneur, is looking for a manufacturer to make the Protector, a new helmet designed by Lawrence A. Bernstein, the California inventor, that uses special side panels to enhance peripheral vision and hearing. "Those are the things riders complain about most," said Mr. Bottell. **********Mr. Bottell is getting high-profile vocal support from Gary Busey, the 47-year-old actor who almost died in a cycle accident three years ago. **********Scarcely two months after his accident, Mr. Busey was railing against mandatory helmet laws. His argument: Helmets took away too much hearing and peripheral vision. Now, he claims that motorcycle industry representatives took advantage of his post-accident emotional vulnerability to get him to castigate helmet laws. With almost religious zeal, he is holding press conferences, lobbying in Washington, and otherwise trying to insure that helmets are made mandatory throughout the country. **********"There's a reason God let me come back alive," Mr. Busey said. "And that's to make sure that we don't see more kids with the life smashed out of their bodies because they aren't wearing helmets."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/busin.main_headline: Dividend Linked To Pet Inc. Spinoff
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Dividend Linked To Pet Inc. Spinoff
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/busin.body_text: **********The Whitman Corporation declared a dividend of one share of Pet Inc. common stock for each share of Whitman common stock to accomplish a previously announced spinoff of the food operation. Payment of the dividend is conditional on receipt of a ruling from the Internal Revenue Service by March 28 that the distribution is tax-free to shareholders and the company. If a favorable ruling is received by March 28, the dividend will be paid on April 1. **********Whitman said the dividend would establish Pet Inc. as an independent company. After the spinoff, Whitman will consist of three operating companies: Pepsi-Cola General Bottlers, the Midas International Automotive Company and Hussman refrigeration operations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/busin.main_headline: Bell Atlantic To Use Retail Sales Outlets
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Bell Atlantic To Use Retail Sales Outlets
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/busin.body_text: **********Looking for a more alluring way to sell telephone services like caller I.D. and call forwarding, the Bell Atlantic Corporation is about to try marketing them through department stores, to be sold in the same manner as cosmetics, clothing or cookware. **********The market trial, the first effort by a phone company to sell such services through a department store, will begin on Friday through Hecht's, a 27-store chain around Baltimore, Washington and Richmond. **********If the trial proves successful, company officials say they plan to branch out to other retail chains around the Middle Atlantic region in which Bell Atlantic operates. The services will be sold through the stores' consumer electronics departments, which already sell telephones and answering machines along with televisions and stereos.  More Aggressive Marketing **********The new effort comes as all the nation's telephone companies are beginning to market a host of new service options made possible by new network technologies. In addition to caller I.D., which identifies the telephone number of incoming calls, these include three-way conference calling, home intercom services and selective call forwarding. **********Because customers do not view such services as essential, telephone company officials have begun to realize they need to sell them much more aggressively than ordinary telephone service. Thus far, Bell Atlantic and the six other regional Bell companies have followed generally passive strategies, waiting for customers to place orders for new service and advertising primarily by stuffing promotional messages into monthly bills. **********"We're fairly dependent on customers' contacting us," said Mary Matthews, who directs sales-channel strategies forBell Atlantic. She added that the company had only recently started developing telemarketing programs to bolster sales of new services. **********Ms. Matthews said that the decision to move into department stores also reflected an effort to prepare for marketing consumer information services, such as sports scores and stock quotes provided over telephone lines. On July 26, a Federal judge moved to lift a restriction that had barred the Bell companies from owning such services, although the restriction remains in effect until the issue has been heard by an appeals court. **********"Today, we're offering nearly 20 services," Ms. Matthews said. "Tomorrow, it may be hundreds." **********Daniel P. Reingold, an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, said Bell Atlantic had been one of the most aggressive of the seven Bell companies in trying to market new services and transform itself from a traditional utility. **********"It's not a major sea change in marketing capabilities," he said, "but it seems to indicate a willingness to experiment with new channels of distribution." **********It remains to be seen, however, whether customers respond. Mr. Reingold noted that in the 15 years since the introduction of call waiting, call forwarding and three-way conference calling, only about a third of telephone customers have signed up for any of them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/28/busin.main_headline: At Age 75, a Lawyer Is Given Chief's Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/28/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; At Age 75, a Lawyer Is Given Chief's Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/28/busin.body_text: **********At an age when many people are 10 years into retirement, Julian O. von Kalinowski refuses to slow down. Two weeks ago, the 75-year-old Los Angeles lawyer became chief executive of Litigation Sciences Inc., a 12-year-old firm at the forefront of the booming trial-consulting industry. **********"When you reach retirement age, you begin to miss certain things," Mr. von Kalinowski said in a telephone interview. "I'm not the kind of person who can play golf all day or sit around and read books." **********So Mr. von Kalinowski plans to search actively for ways to improve on the considerable success of Litigation Sciences, since 1987 a subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi Worldwide P.L.C. The company pioneered the practice of jury research, in which defense lawyers try out strategies on mock juries arranged by consultants. **********Mr. von Kalinowski, an antitrust specialist who had been an advisory director for Litigation Sciences for three years, said jury research was not only justifiable but even crucial in today's legal environment. **********"As the current state of things is, you're almost guilty of malpractice if you don't use jury consultants in a complex case," he said. "If you're not using it, your opponent is going to be using it." **********Despite the company's foundation on jury research, Mr. von Kalinowski said he was more excited about building on other areas. "We've gone far afield from just jury preparation," he said, noting such services as courtroom graphics, video depositions and assistance with communications skills. Mr. von Kalinowski thinks Litigation Sciences can go still further. **********"What I'd like to see is to expand into other areas," he said. "I'd like to see us get involved earlier in the trial process," helping to shape strategy even before the jury stage. **********Gregory J. Mazares, the company's president and chief operating officer, said Mr. von Kalinowski's experience and renown made him a major draw for the company. In discussions with potential clients, Mr. Mazares said: "I don't have to say a word. His name speaks for itself."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/19/busin.main_headline: Chief of Claris Is Selected For a High Post at Go Corp.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/19/busin.print_headline: Chief of Claris Is Selected For a High Post at Go Corp.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/19/busin.body_text: **********The Go Corporation, which will display its pen-based computer operating system software next week, yesterday named William V. Campbell president and chief executive. Since 1987, Mr. Campbell has been president and chief executive of the Claris Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Apple Computer Inc. devoted to software. **********Mr. Campbell, who is 50 years old, succeeds S. Jerrold Kaplan, a co-founder of Go, who was named chairman. That post was previously held by L. John Doerr, a general partner in Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers, a venture capital firm. He remains a director of Go, a privately held company based in Foster City, Calif. **********While Go is only a little more than three years old, and is about to introduce its first product, Mr. Kaplan said it was time to bring on someone with Mr. Campbell's management experience. "This is a very complex business," he said. "There are so many outside constituencies we're dealing with that it makes sense to do this earlier" than is usual for such a young company. Mr. Kaplan will continue to set the company's technology direction. **********Mr. Campbell said it was the opportunity to create something entirely new in computing, like Apple's Macintosh in 1984, that attracted him to Go. "I came to Go only because of looking at the technology," he said. "They've been evangelizing us to do software for them at Claris, so I got a chance to look at the product." **********Before the creation of Claris, which had previously been the applications-software division of Apple, Mr. Campbell was Apple's executive vice president and group executive for sales and marketing from 1984 to 1987. Before joining Apple, he was director of marketing for the film division of the Eastman Kodak Company and a vice president of J. Walter Thompson, the advertising agency.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/02/busin.main_headline: Trump Deal Is Seen With Bondholders
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/02/busin.print_headline: Trump Deal Is Seen With Bondholders
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/02/busin.body_text: **********A settlement is imminent in claims made by some bondholders of Resorts International Inc. against Donald J. Trump, several people involved in the negotiations said yesterday. **********The bondholders assert that the New York financier fraudulently took millions of dollars out of Resorts International when he sold the gambling and resorts company to Merv Griffin in 1988 and left the company with a debt load that drove it into bankruptcy. **********In the settlement, Mr. Trump and one of his insurance companies will reportedly pay some Resorts bondholders $12 million to drop all claims of "fraudulent conveyance" against him and the Trump Organization. Resorts, which underwent a bankruptcy reorganization in United States District Court in New Jersey, is expected to contribute an additional $5 million to the settlement. The $5 million had originally been given over to a litigation trustee appointed by the court to pay the legal expenses of bondholders who had claims against Mr. Trump. **********The settlement negotiation now hinges on whether Resorts will contribute any additional cash to the $17 million that bondholders are expected to get. Several people familiar with the negotiations said executives at Resorts were balking at the request for an additional cash contribution for the bondholders. The bondholders represented in the negotiations have not yet filed a lawsuit against Mr. Trump but have threatened to do so if a settlement of the claims they presented during the Resorts bankruptcy reorganization is not reached soon.   Deal With Griffin **********Mr. Griffin bought Resorts from Mr. Trump in a leveraged buyout in 1988. Mr. Trump kept the company's then-unfinished Taj Mahal casino for $273 million and also received, through a lucrative management contract, about $64 million from Resorts. **********The bondholders who will receive this settlement held about $300 million of Resorts bonds that were issued before Mr. Trump took control of the company. They now hold several series of Resorts bonds issued as part of the reorganization and much of the company's stock. **********As litigation trustee, Mr. Feinberg also controls a Resorts account worth about $3.8 million. That account was created to pay the bondholders, who also got certain trust certificates during the Resorts reorganization, if they could not settle their claims against Mr. Trump by Sept. 1, 1991. If the claims are settled before that date, the $3.8 million must be returned to Resorts. Mr. Feinberg has asked Resorts to contribute about half of the $3.8 million to the settlement money because if no settlement is reached by September, Resorts will lose the entire sum. **********If Resorts agrees to the demand, the bondholders could eventually receive about $19.5 million in cash. **********Corporate Officers and Directors Assurance Holding Ltd., a Bermuda insurer that provided liability insurance to the officers and directors of the Taj Mahal, will put up the bulk of the $12 million in cash that Mr. Trump's interests will contribute. It was unclear how much cash Mr. Trump would contribute.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/05/busin.main_headline: Dow Edges Down 9.17 to Close at 3,008.50
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/05/busin.print_headline: Dow Edges Down 9.17 to Close at 3,008.50
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/05/busin.body_text: **********Stocks closed lower yesterday after the Dow Jones industrial average dipped to the psychological barrier of 3,000 and then rebounded slightly to close at 3,008.50, a loss of 9.17 points. **********Anxiety over the employment statistics to be released by the Government tomorrow caused many traders to remain on the sidelines while a batch of program trades in the late afternoon caused the market to fall by nearly 18 points before beginning a slow recovery. **********Volume totaled 157.5 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange, slightly higher than in the previous session; declining issues on the Big Board outnumbered advancing stocks by a ratio of 9 to 5. **********"It's a waiting game," said Gene Jay Seagle, director of technical research at Gruntal & Company. "The market fell on a lack of buying rather than from terribly heavy selling." **********The mood of the market is one of caution as investors wait to see whether a worsening employment picture will encourage the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy. Cuts in interest rates have generally proved to be a powerful long-term stimulus to the stock market. **********A small example of the effect of falling interest rates came yesterday when the Bank of England announced before the United States markets opened that it was lowering a key rate to 10.5 percent, from 11 percent. That caused a slight morning rally on the Big Board before stocks began to head down. **********Trading patterns were similar in other markets. The American Stock Exchange's composite index closed down 1.53 points, at 369.99, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 2.99, to 517.92. **********Ricky Harrington, director of investment policy at Marion Bass Securities in Charlotte, N.C., said that if volume remained steady, the market could experience a "technical rebound" in the next day or two. **********"I think you can make a case that there's technical support at 3,000," Mr. Harrington said. "But if you begin to get diminishing volume, then look for a move back behind 3,000 next week." **********Market analysts discounted the effect the appearance of Salomon Brothers officials before a House committee yesterday may have had on trading. They said that any market pressure had already been absorbed in stock prices and noted that shares of Salomon Brothers traded down only 3/8 yesterday to close at 25. **********There was a split decision on two leading drug stocks. Centocor was the most active over-the-counter stock, rising 3, to 40 1/2. That came on news that the Food and Drug Administration had approved a Centocor drug to fight bacterial infections. But the agency did not approve a rival drug from Xoma, and that company's shares tumbled 5, to 15 1/2. The two stocks were the most actively traded yesterday. **********The stocks of waste management companies also fell after the announcement on Tuesday that the earnings of Browning Ferris were still being hurt by the recession. Browning Ferris fell 1 1/4, to 20 1/2, and was the third-most-active stock. **********Goodyear was one of the few bright spots among blue chips. The stock rose 2 3/8, to 40 7/8, after announcing tire price increases that were welcomed by analysts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/08/busin.snippet:
A co-op near Gracie Mansion that recently took over 139 apartments from a sponsor and investors who had defaulted on maintenance payments is putting 109 of the apartments up for auction in an effort to get out from under high carrying costs.

The ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/08/busin.main_headline:
When Owners Default on Maintenance;
Co-op Board Will Auction Apartments
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/08/busin.print_headline:
When Owners Default on Maintenance;
Co-op Board Will Auction Apartments
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/08/busin.body_text: **********A co-op near Gracie Mansion that recently took over 139 apartments from a sponsor and investors who had defaulted on maintenance payments is putting 109 of the apartments up for auction in an effort to get out from under high carrying costs. **********The 50-year-old complex, called Gracie Gardens, comprises four former rental buildings at 515-525 East 89th and 520-530 East 90th Streets, just west of East End Avenue. The six-story structures, which are connected by a central garden, contain 272 apartments ranging in size from studios to three bedrooms. The complex was converted into a co-op in 1981. **********Twenty of the seized units have already been sold, but by hiring a professional auctioneer and marketing the remaining 109 units the way a developer might, the co-op board hopes to sell them all at a Nov. 24 auction. The sale will be at the St. Moritz Hotel at 50 Central Park South at 1 P.M. **********Potential buyers can view the eight vacant units, all of which are one-bedroom apartments. Floor plans of the 101 occupied apartments, which must be purchased subject to the tenancy of rent-controlled and rent-stabilized tenants, can be examined at a sales office at the co-op that has been furnished as a model apartment. The auction company, Carlton Property Auctions Inc. of Great Neck, L.I., is holding seminars at the model on Thursday evenings and weekends to acquaint buyers with how the auction will work. **********The apartments will be auctioned in pools, with each pool containing about 25 units. Each winning bidder selects the apartment of his or her choice left in that pool. All apartments except three vacant units will be sold to the highest bidder. Those three units, vacated by tenants under an offer that they move out in return for a 50 percent share of the proceeds, have minimum bids of $45,000, $65,000 and $90,000. **********Jayby Associates of Manhattan, which did the conversion, sold many of the occupied units to investor groups. Although maintenance payments on those units began to fall into arrears as long ago as 1988, most of the proprietary leases of the investors were not canceled until last spring. **********Gracie Gardens is one among many co-ops affected by sponsor defaults that are struggling to find ways of disposing of siezed apartments that often cost much more in monthly maintenance charges than they return in rental income. The 101 rental units at Gracie Gardens, for example, pay a total of $50,230 in rent, but the maintenance charges on the units add up to $110,829, a difference of $60,599 each month. **********The number of such defaults has grown steadily over the last two years, with an estimated 500 buildings affected, according to the State Attorney General's office. **********"What is so interesting about Gracie Gardens is that literally at the Mayor's doorstep is a case study of the kind of things that can go wrong with co-ops," said Leonard Lombard, a Manhattan broker and owner of Penthouse Properties who has handled many apartment resales in the complex. "Here in a microcosm, you have a sponsor who can't make his payments, shareholders that literally have been bled to death, repairs required by city law that perhaps are too expensive, and a co-op that perhaps wanted to be more than it should be." **********Maintenance costs at Gracie Gardens have almost tripled since 1981, up from $12.38 to $32.54 a share annually. A one-bedroom unit paying $4,209.20 a year maintenance 10 years ago now pays $11,064. **********"Maintenance costs may be high compared to other buildings, but that comparison is very deceptive," said Lawrence M. Kaye, president of the co-op board. "We have done our capital improvements and we have a fairly good mortgage situation, so unless you know the status of other buildings, to compare is not fair." Improvements, financed by a mortgage, have included new roofs, new windows, asbestos removal, and refurbished boilers and lobbies. **********Insider prices in 1981 ranged from $39,000 to $116,000. In a pre-auction campaign that ended Oct. 28, occupied rental units were offered to tenants and to co-op shareholders for $13,000 to $19,000, resulting in 18 sales and two pending contracts, said Steven W. Birbach, president of Carlton Property Auctions. Prices that may go even lower at the Nov. 24 auction will provide opportunities for investors willing to wait for a tenant to move, he said. In a recent resale, a two-bedroom unit at 510 East 90th Street sold for only $155,000, but three years ago, a one-bedroom at 520 East 90th Street fetched $225,000. **********Auction incentives include a 25 percent monthly rebate on maintenance costs that is being offered to buyers of occupied units for the first two years. Buyers of vacant units can get 50 percent of the purchase price financed by the co-op but occupied units must be paid for in cash.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.main_headline: Chairman of Time Warner Treated for Prostate Cancer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Chairman of Time Warner Treated for Prostate Cancer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.body_text: **********Steven J. Ross, the chairman and co-chief executive of Time Warner Inc., is being treated for prostate cancer but plans to continue with his normal work schedule, the media company said yesterday in a statement. **********A spokeswoman, Jeanette Lerman, said that the tests revealing the cancer came back yesterday from the laboratory and that Mr. Ross, who is 64 years old, was at home on vacation. She added that he would undertake whatever therapy was required, in a hospital if necessary, but that he intended to "go on working at the typical Steve Ross pace." **********Mr. Ross, who suffered a heart attack in 1980 and then gave up his habit of five packs of cigarettes a day, said in a statement, "My physicians are optimistic, and I am maintaining my normal work schedule." Said to Have Been Caught Early **********Officials close to Mr. Ross said the cancer had been caught early and appeared to be treatable. Prostate cancer is diagnosed in about 96,000 American men a year, and more die of it than any other cancer except lung cancer and colon cancer. **********In an interview last Thursday, the last he granted before the cancer was revealed, Mr. Ross appeared extremely uncomfortable and was in obvious pain from severe backache. **********One doctor, Peter Wayne, said that the back was the first place to which prostate cancer spreads. But the Time Warner officials said that the back pain was unrelated and that there was no evidence of a spread of the cancer. **********Mr. Ross's schedule has been relentless since last year, when his Warner Communications Inc. was acquired by Time Inc. in a deal that created the world's largest media company. **********Mr. Ross, who shares the chief executive's post with Nicholas J. Nicholas and is scheduled to hand over control of the company to him in 1994, said in the interview that he was currently spending most of his time seeking other strategic partners to invest in Time Warner's businesses. **********At a time when the company's future is still being mapped out, analysts expressed concern at his illness. **********"If something happens to him, that is very bad for the conceptual development of the corporation," said Emanuel Gerard, a partner at Gerard, Klauer, Mattison & Company and former Warner executive. **********Despite the recent alleviation of its debt, Time Warner's stock price -- which rose $2.25 yesterday, to close at $84.125, before the announcement -- has remained depressed at levels far below the $200 a share that Paramount Communications offered to pay for Time before the company chose instead to acquire Warner. **********This low price has angered some Time Warner employees and shareholders. So, too, has Mr. Ross's compensation, which totaled $78.1 million last year, largely as a result of payments stemming from Time's acquisition of Warner.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/31/world.main_headline: Support by U.N. Powers Buoys Cambodian Hopes
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/31/world.print_headline: Support by U.N. Powers Buoys Cambodian Hopes
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/31/world.body_text: **********The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council offered qualified support today to efforts by the Cambodian Government and three rebel factions to end the Southeast Asian country's long civil war, but called on the Cambodians to resolve troublesome disputes over election procedures and disarmament. **********A joint statement of support issued by the five United Nations powers -- the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France -- came as something of a relief to Cambodian negotiators, who said that with the approval of the Security Council, a final peace agreement could be signed by the end of the year. **********Earlier, the Cambodians had expressed worry that compromises reached in negotiations this week among the warring factions might be scuttled by the United States because the provisions deviated from a peace plan crafted by the five Security Council members. **********The joint statement, issued by the five after their representatives met with Cambodian Government and rebel leaders in Pattaya, a Thai resort south of Bangkok, hailed "very positive progress" in the weeklong talks that ended today.  Words of Sihanouk **********Prince Norodom Sihanouk, a former Cambodian head of state and a major mediator in the negotiations, told reporters that with the assistance of the Security Council, "I am now confident there will be a peace agreement signed by the end of this year." **********In November, Prince Sihanouk is scheduled to return to Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital, for the first time since the city fell to invading Vietnamese forces early in January, 1979. **********Talks are expected to continue next month at the United Nations between the Vietnamese-installed Cambodian Government and the three major rebel groups -- the followers of Prince Sihanouk, the rightist Khmer People's National Liberation Front, and the Communist Khmer Rouge, who killed more than a million people and brought about a total upheaval in Cambodian society during their rule of the country from April 1975 through the end of 1978. **********Western diplomats, while conceding that hopes for peace in Cambodia have been dashed before, say the negotiations this week do seem to have abreviated the timetable for final settlement of the civil war that followed the Vietnamese military victory over the Khmer Rouge. That civil conflict has raged since 1979, when Vietnamese forces installed a satellite Government now led by Prime Minister Hun Sen, a former Khmer Rouge commander who left the Khmer Rouge ahead of the advancing Vietnamese. **********"You see it in the faces of the Cambodians," said a senior Western diplomat who was monitoring the talks in Pattaya. "They are sick of the war and they see no chance for a military solution." **********An Asian diplomat said he remained concerned about the motives of the Khmer Rouge in participating in a negotiated settlement. **********"I wonder and worry about what the Khmer Rouge will do once it returns home with the legitimacy that a settlement offers," he said. "We should all worry." **********The permanent members of the Security Council retain what amounts to a veto over any compromises worked out among the Cambodians, since the United Nations is being called on to provide manpower and hundreds of millions of dollars in other aid to monitor the truce in Cambodia and administer the country until elections are held. **********The Council members' statement today called on the Phnom Penh Government and the rebels to resolve procedures for free elections and to "reflect further on the question of total demobilization, preferably prior to the elections."  How to Apportion Votes? **********The election procedure is perhaps the central unresolved issue in the negotiations. Mr. Hun Sen's Government is seeking a constituency system, under which voters would cast ballots for local candidates to represent them in a national assembly. **********Some of the rebels are instead demanding a proportional system, in which each party would receive an allotment of seats in the assembly on the basis of the proportion of the votes it got in nationwide balloting. **********On Tuesday, the Cambodian factions reached agreement to reduce their military forces by 70 percent. **********Prince Sihanouk, among others, had warned that the United States might veto the compromise because it did not provide for a total disarmament of the factions, as members of the Security Council had sought. But the United States did not take such an action.  Status of M.I.A. Talks **********As the Government seemed ready to make peace with the rebel groups, there was also evidence today of a warming in relations with its longtime adversary in Washington. **********A statement released by the United States Embassy in Bangkok said a Defense Department delegation conducted "cordial and productive" meetings last week in Phnom Penh and Hanoi, the Vietnamese capital, over the fate of Americans missing since the Vietnam War. **********During the delegation's visit to Phnom Penh, Cambodian officials turned over the remains of what they said was an American apparently missing since the war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/busin.main_headline: Dow Up 40.70 as Late Rally Erases Losses
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/busin.print_headline: Dow Up 40.70 as Late Rally Erases Losses
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/busin.body_text: **********The stock market closed sharply higher yesterday, bouncing back briskly late in the day after a steep decline earlier. The Dow Jones industrial average, which at mid-morning was down nearly 30 points from Friday's close, finished 40.70 higher at 2,935.38. **********Various forces converged to drag prices down in the morning: weakness in the Japanese and London markets, a lower-than-expected November index from the nation's purchasing managers that the market took as further evidence of a weak economy, and poor showings by I.B.M. and Digital. **********Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 188.3 million shares, yesterday, up from 76.8 million on Friday, as gainers outpaced losers, 927 to 781. Bush Move a Factor **********Anthony Ludovici, the senior vice president and senior investment analyst at Tucker, Anthony, said the market's comeback was timed to a White House announcement around noon that Predsident Bush would discuss the economy in a speech tomorrow at an American Enterprise Institute conference. **********The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said it would be an important speech on the economy, but did not suggest the President would introduce any new proposals. **********Mr. Ludovici said the market had interpreted the news as meaning that the President would be looking at the economy sooner rather than later. **********"At the time of the announcement, there was a spread between the futures market and the cash market," he said. "Almost immediately, futures-related program trading kicked in and established the trend for the balance of the day, and reinforcing confidence for the moment."  Tangible Evidence Needed **********Edwin Walczak, the first vice president of Vontobel U.S.A., said yesterday's market still "needs tangible evidence that either the economy is doing something good, or that Washington will do something smart." **********He added, "And until either happens, I can't see why the market should do terribly well." **********Stocks in Tokyo took a beating before the opening in New York, with the Nikkei index losing 695.06 points, or more than 3 percent, to 21,992.29. The Nikkei regained some ground in early trading today, rising 265.82, to 22,258.11, by midday. **********The Big Board's composite index rose 2.90 points, to 210.65, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 6.18 points, to 381.40. **********Trading on the American Stock Exchange was active, as the index closed 1.21 points higher at 371.89. **********On the Nasdaq, the composite index rose 7.01 points, to 530.91, as the Russell 2,000, a barometer of small companies, rose 0.28 point, to 176.65. **********I.B.M., which is still reeling from its announcement last week of its fourth-quarter charge and additional layoffs, weighed heavy on the Dow in early trading, as the stock touched a nine-year low of 90 5/8, before closing down 1/4, to 92 1/4. **********Traders said the stock might have reacted to an announcement planned by McCaw Cellular Communications on the details of a deal with Oracle Systems to create a data broadcasting system, which analysts said could compete with a satellite-data network developed by Motorola and I.B.M. **********McCaw's stock rose 1 1/2, to 27 3/4, while Oracle's gained 7/8, to 14 3/8, and Motorola's rose 3/4, to 60 3/8.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/20/busin.main_headline: Division on Exports to Iraq Continues to Grow Deeper
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/20/busin.print_headline: Division on Exports to Iraq Continues to Grow Deeper
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/20/busin.body_text: **********Divisions within the Administration over past American exports to Iraq widened today when the top investigator of the United States Customs Service said his agency would defy the Commerce Department and investigate some companies that applied for export licenses. **********The Commerce Department had reluctantly given the Customs Service a list of companies that applied for export licenses to Iraq from 1985 through Aug. 2, 1990, along with the department's complete files on those companies, on condition that theCustoms Service not get in touch with them. **********This condition was added because "Commerce has already been in contact with those parties regarding compliance with the restrictions on exports and further contact would be unnecessary and could confuse industry," Dennis Kloske, Under Secretary of Commerce for Export Administration, told a Congressional committee last month.   Investigatory Needs **********The Customs Service, a branch of the Treasury Department, contends that it is charged with enforcement of export control laws, and needs a free hand in conducting investigations. **********The dispute underscores the conflicts within the Administration on the politically sensitive question of the sale to Iraq of advanced technology with military applications. The White House has denied reports that it ordered the dismissal of Mr. Kloske for telling Congress that the Administration ignored his recommendations last year to limit the export of American technology. **********Commerce Department officials reflect the business community's fears that these export applications include proprietary information and that dissemination of the documents could severely harm a company. "If a company's competitor got hold of this information, it would know the company's whole marketing strategy for a whole part of the world," said Willard Workman, director of policy and programs at the United States Chamber of Commerce. "Some companies' survival could even be threatened."  Promise to Protect Data **********John C. Kelley, director of the Custom Service's Strategic Investigations Division, said in an interview that his agency would protect the information carefully, Mr. Kelley said: "We're pursuing our normal course of investigative activity. We will take appropriate action where and when it's necessary." **********He noted that the Customs Service had broader investigative authority than the Commerce Department, which is charged with enforcement of the Export Administration Act. The Customs Service also administers that act, the Arms Export Control Act and nuclear regulatory laws. **********The Commerce Department last month made public a list of $500 million in advanced American manufactured goods that it said were sold with its blessing to Iraqi Government agencies from 1985 until Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August. **********Mr. Kloske was on vacation and unavailable for comment. Quincy Krosby, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Export Administration, said the number of applicants for export licenses to Iraq was confidential.  Concern in Congress **********Representative Cardiss Collins, Illinois Democrat and chairman of the Commerce, Consumer Protection and Competitiveness Subcommittee, expressed her concern over the Commerce Department's position in a letter on Monday to Robert A. Mosbacher, Secretary of Commerce. **********Noting the conditions under which the Commerce Department had given the Customs Service the list of export license applicants, she wrote, "I can only hope that what appears to be nothing more than 'bickering' between two government agencies will not become the biggest obstacle in our country's efforts to identify and block transactions between the U.S. and Iraq." **********No Commerce Department officials would discuss the interagency dispute on the record. Mr. Mosbacher was in Mexico City, with his spokeswoman, Marcy Robinson. Neither could be reached for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.main_headline: Where Car Makers Fear to Cut
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.print_headline: Where Car Makers Fear to Cut
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.body_text: **********Auto executives traditionally do not discuss future car and truck models for fear buyers might put off a purchase until the new ones arrive. But the Chrysler Corporation took that risk by recently allowing dealers, journalists and others onto its test track to give them a glimpse of the 1993 mid-size models on which Chrysler is pinning its hopes for a recovery. **********The slump in car sales and the national recession, which coincide with yet another big push by the Japanese for American market share, is squeezing Detroit and causing a torrent of cash to flow out the door. All of the auto makers are cutting costs and conserving resources. What they are struggling to avoid, though, are any deep cuts that would delay or eliminate new products. A Matter of Perceptions **********Chrysler, like the others in the Big Three, does not want investors, suppliers or lenders to get the idea that it is paring spending for new models, a perception that would only worsen its problems on the showroom floor. **********The pressure to spend, even when money is scarce, is a matter of market share for the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, and a matter of survival for Chrysler. All three are striving to avoid having their need to save money force them into canceling or delaying important vehicle projects. G.M. on Monday announced plans to float an issue of preference stock to raise $600 million, partly to pay for future vehicle models, among them eight new-car and thee new-truck models in the next year. **********"Spending for new products must go on in good times and bad," said James B. Fitzpatrick, a G.M. vice president for communications and marketing. "It is our lifeblood." Cash generated internally at G.M. has shrunk from $10.08 billion in 1987 to an estimated $5.27 billion this year, according to estimates by Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. **********Japanese auto makers can develop a new vehicle in far less time than Detroit can, and they are invading market niches in the United States where they have never been before. Today, for example, Nissan showed journalists its first mini-van, named the Quest. It was designed in California and will be built at a Ford plant near Cleveland starting next April. Last year, Nissan withdrew from the market its Axxess station wagon that was meant to attract mini-van buyers but was a flop. **********American auto makers know they cannot compete unless they compress their normal five-year product-gestation period to three years, like the Japanese, and bring out more new cars more frequently. Indeed, the most scathing criticism that could be leveled at the American auto industry would be to say that it was mortgaging the future by scrimping on new-product development. **********But new products take money. Depending on the extent of the redesign, the cost of bringing a new car to dealer lots ranges from $500 million to $1 billion. **********While G.M. has been able to keep most models on schedule, it has acknowledged a few delays. Rumors among parts suppliers say G.M. has delayed its redesigned S-10 Blazer utility vehicle to 1995, from 1994.  Taking on More Debt **********As for Ford, it borrowed $800 million in the first quarter of the year, raising its debt to $8.2 billion; a year ago, debt stood at $4.4 billion. Ford's debt-to-equity ratio on March 31 was 38 percent, compared with 16 percent a year ago. Ford is trying to keep most future models on schedule, but analysts and suppliers say it has delayed the redesign of the Taurus and the Sable models for one year, to 1995. **********After Ford announced a first-quarter loss of $884 million, David N. McCammon, vice president-finance, said projects "are basically intact, but we always are making timing adjustments" to cut costs and looking for ways "to get a dollar's worth of new products for every 80 cents we spend." **********Chrysler, which has suffered critical losses and has little financial cushion, has the least borrowing power among the Big Three, the lowest relative stock price, and the least ability to put money into new products. But Chris Cedergren, an automotive analyst for J. D. Power & Associates, an automotive consulting firm in Agoura Hills, Calif., said Chrysler more than any other American auto maker might be trying to pull spending forward. **********Perhaps because of its well-publicized financial weakness, the No. 3 auto maker must go to the greatest lengths to prove that its $3 billion in cost-cutting is not hampering development of new models. The company renegotiated a $1.5 billion line of credit after the lowering of its debt ratings made borrowing from the public too expensive. **********"The fear is that Chrysler is cutting into muscle and bone," said Ronald Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco. "But I hope not, because I love the way the L/H looks." He was referring to the code name for Chrysler's 1993 mid-size sedan, which will be sold by the Eagle, Dodge and Chrysler divisions; it will be built, starting next year, at a factory in Bramalea, Ontario. **********Other Chrysler vehicles badly need replacement, too. The full-size pickup truck -- referred to by some Chrysler engineers as "Festus," the grizzled codger in the "Gunsmoke" television western -- has not been redesigned for more than 15 years. Chrysler is planning to replace it in 1993.  No Profits, No Cash **********In economically healthy times auto makers pay part of their new-product costs with cash from current sales. But with no profits, auto makers must increase borrowings or sell equity. In the last six months, the Big Three have been forced to trim dividends and drastically cut costs to strengthen balance sheets enough to finance new-product spending. **********One-time expenses have also been a drain on cash. G.M., for example, was obligated on March 1 to buy $600 million worth of its class H stock from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute as part of the renegotiated terms of the sale of Hughes Aircraft to G.M. in 1985. **********The three-year labor contract negotiated in the fall with the United Automobile Workers union has become a huge financial burden as well. Under its terms, the Big Three must pay most workers even if they are laid off, a situation that makes labor costs akin to a fixed expense. In previous recessions, labor expenses went down as sales and production dropped, allowing auto makers to keep losses in check. **********In 1982, under an earlier labor agreement, the industry was operating at only 62 percent of capacity, yet auto makers were breaking even. But last year, utilization was at 78 percent and still the industry lost about $5 billion in North America, according to an analysis by Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.  The Cost of Competition **********Of course, foreign imports and transplants -- Japanese cars made in America -- were not as much of a factor during the last recession. Vicious competition is hurting the Big Three's ability to maintain prices. Even with much lower production, the auto makers have been forced to continue offering large rebates on most car and truck models -- another drain on cash. **********Shorter development cycles for cars like Chrysler's L/H model should help to cut costs, analysts say. Chrysler will have brought the L/H out in 42 months, a 30 percent reduction in the typical development time, helping produce a 25 percent cut in development costs, according to an estimate by Sanford C. Bernstein. **********Chrysler believes the length of the cycle will be about 39 months, said Glen Gardner, who heads the project; that compares with the Japanese average of about 36 months. "The trick is going to be to get the rest of our projects on this schedule," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/30/busin.body_text: **********The excise tax on luxury items passed by Congress last year has hurt the middle class by depressing sales in the automobile, jewelry, boat and aircraft industries, business executives told Republican lawmakers today. **********Automobile dealers told the House Republican Study Committee that the 10 percent luxury tax on cars costing more than $30,000 had kept customers away and forced the dealers to lay off sales people and other workers. **********"Clearly, the luxury tax has failed miserably in achieving its apparently intended goal of soaking the rich," said Joseph Herson, who owns a Porsche, Jaguar and Audi dealership in Rockville, Md. "All it has done is hurt small businesses and working men and women and their families across the country." **********Mr. Herson, who spoke on behalf of the Federation Against Inequitable and Regressive Taxation, a group representing dealers of luxury imported cars, said a study done for the organization found that the tax had caused a 20 percent drop in demand for vehicles costing $30,000 or more. This represents $1.3 billion in lost sales so far this year, he said. **********The 10 percent tax also applies to furs and jewelry priced at more than $30,000, to boats costing more than $100,000 and planes over $250,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/27/world.main_headline: Soviet Aide in China to Help Improve Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/27/world.print_headline: Soviet Aide in China to Help Improve Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/27/world.body_text: **********A Soviet official arrived in Beijing today for a four-day visit, part of a broad effort by China to improve its relations with the Soviet Union and European countries. **********The visit by the official, Vladimir Ivashko, Deputy General Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, will help prepare for a trip that the Chinese Communist Party leader, Jiang Zemin, is expected to make to the Soviet Union this spring or summer. Mr. Jiang would be the first Chinese party chief to visit Moscow since the Chinese-Soviet split of 1960. **********Beijing and Moscow normalized their relations in May 1989, when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived for a summit meeting. But Mr. Gorbachev's arrival gave a lift to the Tiananmen democracy movement then under way, and the Chinese leadership -- while pleased by Mr. Gorbachev's recent assertion of a harder line -- remains wary of him and of his political restructuring in the Soviet Union. **********In another sign of improving relations, the Soviet Defense Minister, Dmitri T. Yazov, is expected to arrive early next month for a long-delayed meeting on military issues and weapons sales. China has been trying to arrange some major weapons purchases from the Soviet Union.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/24/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; New Portrait: Python in Red
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/24/busin.body_text: **********The pantheon of celebrities who have posed for the American Express Company's "Portraits" campaign now includes a 6 feet 5 inch man wearing a short red dress, matching high heels and pearls. **********The British humorist John Cleese, of "Monty Python" fame, is the latest subject of Annie Leibovitz's portraits series. The ad, by Ogilvy & Mather, London, is appearing in magazines in Britain and the United States, where it has been placed in The New York Times Magazine, New York magazine and L.A. Style. **********Gail Wasserman, an American Express spokeswoman, said the ad would appear in publications with a "somewhat younger and more urban audience," who would be familiar with Mr. Cleese's work and not misinterpret the ad. But, she added, the ad is consistent with others in the campaign. "In different ways," she said, "all of them show an unexpected aspect of a character being photographed." **********Other ads have featured Thomas P. O'Neill, the former House Speaker, and the singer Ella Fitzgerald, among others. **********Mr. Cleese insisted that the ad be "as silly as possible," according to the British magazine Expression. He first suggested dressing as Genghis Khan surrounded by "dismembered carcasses," before settling on the tight red number.
