Executive at Go-Video Promoted to President
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/busin.body_text: **********Go-Video Inc., the videocassette recorder company that lost an important antitrust lawsuit earlier this year, said yesterday that it had promoted Bob Palko to the positions of president and chief operating officer. **********Mr. Palko, formerly executive vice president of marketing and sales, replaces Eric J. Schedeler, who resigned as president earlier this year. **********Go-Video manufactures a dual-deck VCR that can record one program while playing a second tape. In June, the Scottsdale, Ariz., company lost a trial in which a jury rejected claims that three Japanese electronics companies had conspired to prevent introduction of the company's VCR-2. **********Go-Video said it would appeal the verdict, but that process could take two years or more. **********Since the trial's end, Go-Video has turned its focus away from litigation and back to the issue of carving out a niche for the VCR-2 in the hotly competitive consumer electronics field. **********"We're focusing on sales and marketing and trying to accompish an overall profitability," said R. Terren Dunlap, Go-Video's chairman. **********"We now have in place a new distribution organization established by Bob Palko that already has resulted in replenishment orders from national accounts, new sales to established retailers and continual increases in sales to catalogue and credit card mailer accounts," he said. "We recognize that the next several fiscal quarters will be very important to the company." **********In the fiscal year ended July 31, Go-Video reported yesterday that it lost $1.4 million on revenues of $17.2 million. The revenue figure includes $12.4 million in VCR-2 sales and $4.8 million in litigation settlements from a number of Japanese electronics companies. The loss included "substantial" legal fees, Go-Video said. **********Mr. Palko, who is 45, has spent 25 years in the consumer electronics industry. He had previously been president and chief executive of Home America, a Phoenix consumer electronics chain, and a vice president at Silo, a large Philadelphia-based electronics chain. Mr. Palko, who is married and has two children, lives in Phoenix.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/05/world.main_headline: Today at Babi Yar the Spirits Will Rest
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/05/world.print_headline: Today at Babi Yar the Spirits Will Rest
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/05/world.body_text: **********Over the years, Aleksandr Shlayen has made hundreds of pilgrimages to the deep ravine on the northern edge of Kiev, where he stands quietly among the birch trees and listens for the voices of the dead. He says he does not strain very hard to hear them. **********"Here, they were machine-gunned, and there, their bodies fell and were buried by the thousands," Mr. Shlayen said today, hunched against a cold wind as he gestured toward the steep hillside, where scores of his family members and their neighbors, all of them Jews, died 50 years ago. "At Babi Yar, each tree grows up from the dead." **********Until a week ago, the ravine was unmarked, excepts for the lonely visits of Mr. Shlayen and a few others, part of a park where people come to walk their dogs and jog on footpaths laid out across the killing ground, above the skeletons. **********Now, in ceremonies on Saturday marking the 50th anniversary of the Babi Yar massacre, the forested gully and the surrounding area will be commemorated, officially recognized by the Ukrainian government as the place where an estimated 100,000 people, most of them Jews, were killed and buried in mass graves by the Nazis from 1941 through 1943. **********A few days ago a large bronze menorah was put up here, on the spot where the Nazis killed 33,000 Jews during a 36-hour period beginning on Sept. 29, 1941. The victims were marched from the city to the ravine, stripped and then killed with grisly efficiency. **********For years, what happened at Babi Yar was ignored by Soviet officials, and Jews who tried to pray at the site were often arrested. Many did not even know of the place until 1961, when the poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko published his anguished work "Babi Yar." **********It reads in part: **********No gravestone stands on Babi Yar **********Only coarse earth heaped roughly on the gash **********Such dread comes over me. **********Moscow Preferred Generalities **********In 1974, the Soviet Government finally did put up a memorial to Babi Yar, but it made no reference to the Jews selected to die. Rather, it depicts what it calls the "victims of Fascism" at Babi Yar, with the central figure being a Communist resistance fighter. **********Moreover, the monument is nearly a mile from the ravine where the killings took place. Instead, it marks the spot where the Nazis later tried to conceal evidence of the massacre by burning many of the corpses in a huge pyre. **********The ceremonies on Saturday are to bring together delegations from Israel, Europe and the United States, as well as the top officials of the Ukraine, who seem to have eagerly seized on the Babi Yar anniversary as an opportunity, in part, to score political points with Western governments. **********The Ukraine, which recently declared its independence from Moscow, is now looking for support from the West in its quest to become a sovereign nation.    Gestures of Democratization **********Sergei Komissarenko, a Ukrainian Deputy Prime Minister who organized the events this week, put it directly: "With the independence declaration," he said, "it is important that we show we are democrats and that we support ethnic and religious minorities." **********Mr. Komissarenko and other top officials have recently traveled to Israel, and joined members of Ukrainian opposition parties in emphasizing ethnic cooperation and tolerance. This contrasts sharply with the situation in other Soviet republics, where there has been violence between ethnic groups. **********As part of this week's activities, exhibits and photographic displays have been set up on the streets of Kiev, describing in detail what happened at Babi Yar. Streamers are stretched across streets that read, in Hebrew and Ukrainian, "Never Again." **********And across the front of the Tchaikovsky concert hall, a giant painting depicts the terrified faces of men and women standing beside a gully of stacked bodies. **********"When I look at these now, I get an unpleasant feeling in my soul," said Lyudmila Kayurova, a 52-year-old Russian woman from Kiev, who was among the crowd viewing the displays near Independence Square in the center of town. "It was a tragedy for all of us, and only now can we talk about it." **********No one knows for certain how many died at Babi Yar during the two years of German occupation. Soviet reports after the war estimated the number at 100,000 -- a toll that also included gypsies, Communists, Christians and Soviet prisoners of war. **********The Ukrainian government has now embarked on a program to improve the situation of Jews in the republic, a place where intolerance -- particularly anti-Semitism -- were powerful forces for centuries before the Nazis came. **********It has said it will reopen two synagogues seized by the authorities years ago and turned into theaters. On Thursday, the government also invited reporters to visit the opening of State School 229, the first Jewish school in Kiev in 50 years. **********According to official estimates, about 150,000 Jews still live in Kiev. While conditions have improved, many say they would still rather emigrate to Israel or the United States than remain in the Ukraine. **********The ravine where the killings took place 50 years ago was adjacent to a 19th-century Jewish cemetery, and some of the old tombstones, vandalized long ago, can still be seen in the weeds and undergrowth beside park paths. **********Mr. Shlayen, a film maker who has made two documentaries about Babi Yar, walks with pride around the area where the menorah stands -- at the end of a long brick road that follows the final mile of the Jewish victims. **********He picks up litter and stones lying on the pavement, and at one point he stopped to shoo off two women walking their dogs along the edge of the ravine.  But even Mr. Shlayen is thinking about leaving the Ukraine for a life in the West, now that the government has agreed at last to commemorate the place to which he has devoted so much of his life and energy. **********"Now people will know what happened here," said Mr. Shlayen, who was 10 when he was evacuated from Kiev in 1941, as the Germans advanced on the city. He returned three years later to find that many of his friends and relatives had been killed, and vowed never to forget what others refused to remember. **********"People don't have the right to forget," he said. "They simply don't have that right."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/01/world.main_headline: Bad Frankenhausen Journal; A Hero and a Picture From History's Attic
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/01/world.print_headline: Bad Frankenhausen Journal; A Hero and a Picture From History's Attic
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/01/world.body_text: **********Here amid the low hills where 5,000 of his followers were killed one afternoon in 1525, Thomas Muntzer still casts a bizarre shadow. **********In life a religious mystic and political revolutionary, Muntzer became in death a symbol of defiance and, oddly, of the glories of Communism. The authorities in the former East Germany idealized him as a visionary peasant leader, and in his honor they put up one of Europe's strangest monuments outside this village 100 miles southwest of Berlin. **********On a ridge overlooking rich farmlands that have been tilled continuously for nearly a millennium, the East German Government built a futuristic circular building that looks like a craft from outer space. Inside is the largest painting in the world, a vast panorama honoring Muntzer and his contemporaries. **********The painting is nearly 50 feet high and more than 350 feet long. Among the 3,000 characters depicted are not only Muntzer and his mentor Martin Luther, but also titans like Copernicus, Durer, Erasmus, Gutenberg and Columbus. A Name That's All Over **********In eastern Germany, every schoolchild knows Thomas Muntzer. Scores of streets, plazas and agricultural cooperatives are named after him. Even the People's Army, which is now dissolved, had a Thomas Muntzer Battalion. But in western Germany, people know almost nothing about him and historians consider him irrelevant to the modern age. **********Many westerners were therefore puzzled when a Government office in Berlin was firebombed on March 29 and the attackers left a note saying they were members of Thomas Muntzer's Wild Bunch. The group had never been heard of before. **********The target of the fireboming was a field office of the Treuhand, the agency assigned to close or sell thousands of formerly state-owned companies in eastern Germany. The Treuhand has aroused much anger in the east, and its director, Detlev Karsten Rohwedder, was killed by the Red Army Faction three days after the Berlin bombing. **********Depending on which theory one prefers, Thomas Muntzer's Wild Bunch is a gang of disgruntled youths from eastern Germany, or a splinter group of the Red Army Faction, or even a handful of former East German police agents bent on destabilizing Germany. **********Almost as uncertain is the identity of Thomas Muntzer himself. Pioneer socialist or misguided fanatic bent on martyrdom, he is a figure for the unified nation to reckon with as it seeks to come to grips with its history. **********Muntzer was born in 1489, entered the clergy as a young man, and soon joined Luther in his conflict with the established church. But the two quarreled and Muntzer, who claimed to have received a series of divine visions, came to believe that he had been anointed as an apocalpytic messenger of God. **********"Like Christ, I have been sent by the Father!" he told ecstatic congregations throughout Brandenburg, Saxony and Thuringia. "I come to bring not peace, but the sword!" Barons Raise an Army **********Early in 1525 Muntzer established a model of his ideal theocracy at the town of Muhlhausen. He issued several decrees on behalf of the poor, distributing free seeds and livestock and confiscating a monastery to house the homeless. **********Then in April 1525 he and several thousand followers set out on a redemptive crusade against the established order. In a single week, Muntzer's peasants, armed only with axes and pitchforks, overran 18 monasteries, 5 castles and the residences of 21 aristocratic families. **********Feudal barons led by the Prince of Saxony quickly sent an army against Muntzer. It surrounded his band on May 14, and demanded his surrender. He refused, rallying his followers with promises that God would protect them. At that moment a brilliant rainbow appeared in the sky. "Look, God has sent us a sign!" Muntzer proclaimed. "Now we know he will help us to punish the murderous Prince." **********But there was no divine intervention that day, and Muntzer's crusade came to a violent end. Soldiers fired rifles and artillery until no one was left standing. Five thousand died, and two weeks later Muntzer was beheaded. **********For centuries after his death, Muntzer was remembered, if at all, as a religious fanatic who led his people to disaster. But after East Germany was established in 1949, its leaders began a search for historical icons, and they found Muntzer. **********In the mid-1970's, to mark the 500th anniversary of his birth, the East German authorities chose to build the circular museum that now stands here, overlooking the ravine where his movement met its violent fate. A Portrayal of an Age **********To paint the gigantic panorama inside, the Government commissioned one of its favored artists, Werner Tubke. He and several of his students worked on it for four years. It was finally opened on Sept. 19, 1989, less than two months before the Berlin wall was breached and the Communist Government began to collapse. **********"The painting is not just a portrayal of Muntzer, but of the age he lived in," said Gunter Sickert, a director of the museum. "It deals with the great human problems of love and hate, war and peace, joy and suffering, victory and defeat." **********Some viewers find echoes of Breughel or Bosch in Mr. Tubke's overwhelming work. Many stare intently at sections of it, seeking to decipher biblical or historical allusions. All notice the vivid rainbow that arches over the central battle scene. **********In recent months, however, people from western Germany have been coming to visit the panorama, and not all are so impressed. Some leave muttering that what Mr. Tubke has created is not art at all, but a kind of kitschy monumentalism. **********The Bonn Government has promised that the museum will remain open. Whether the giant painting will remain on display, however, is still undecided. **********"I would advise that it be left as it is," said Leo Seivers, a historian from Hamburg who has written extensively on Muntzer. "The painting is violent and exaggerated, but it could be preserved as a curiosity or a tourist attraction." **********"Muntzer was portrayed falsely in East Germany," Mr. Sievers asserted. "He was certainly the most radical German theologian of his time, but he is very much a 16th-century figure. The Communists tried to make him into a prototype of the socialist revolutionary. That didn't have to do with history, it had to do with the regime's need for heroes."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Ashton-Tate Names Chairman and President
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/busin.body_text: **********The Ashton-Tate Corporation yesterday elected William Lyons, the company's current chief executive, to the added post of chairman. David R. Proctor succeeds Mr. Lyons as president and will also be chief operating officer. **********Mr. Proctor, who has been executive vice president for product development, will continue to manage product development, which will include all research and development facilities in the United States, Britain and Singapore. He joined Ashton-Tate in May 1990 as vice president and general manger of the database division, which is by far the largest unit of the company. **********The elevation of Mr. Lyons is "in recognition of the substantial progress the company has made under his leadership," said Carmen Santoro, an outside director who has been serving as non-executive chairman. He will become vice chairman and chairman of the executive committee. **********Ashton-Tate, based in Torrance, Calif., has returned to profitability under Mr. Lyons's leadership, but it still faces significant challenges. While its dBase software is still the leading database management program for personal computers, competitors like Borland International Inc., with its Paradox program, have been whittling away at Ashton-Tate's market share. In addition, both Borland and the Microsoft Corporation will soon show database programs designed to work with Microsoft's Windows program, which makes programs easier to use. **********Mr. Lyons said Mr. Proctor was elected president in recognition of his accomplishments in successfully managing the development of dBase and other products. "With Dave's management skills and technical expertise, Ashton-Tate will be able to continue delivering industry-leading products and improved customer service," he said. **********Mr. Proctor, who is 51 years old, was named executive vice president for product development in October 1990. Before joining Ashton-Tate, he spent more than 23 years at the International Business Machines Corporation, most recently serving as Asia Pacific director in Tokyo. Before that, he worked for Rocketdyne, a division of Rockwell International. Mr. Proctor has an M.S. degree in mathematics from Stanford University and a B.S. degree from the University of Oklahoma. He and his wife, Judy, have three children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/busin.main_headline: Mutual Funds; Catching Up With Peter Lynch
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/busin.print_headline: Mutual Funds; Catching Up With Peter Lynch
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/busin.body_text: **********About this time last year, Peter Lynch, the legendary stock picker who led Fidelity's Magellan Fund, retired at the age of 46 as head of the nation's largest and most successful stock fund. **********These days, Mr. Lynch still keeps an office at Fidelity, and he works there anywhere from two to five days a week. He leaves home at 8 A.M. instead of 6:45, after making breakfast and lunch for his daughters. He leaves the office at 5 P.M., not 7, and does not work weekends. But he still eats lunch at his desk, he says, and "I go like crazy" during the work day. **********Mr. Lynch resigned as a director of Fidelity when he left Magellan because "it was too time consuming," he said, and he wanted "a new challenge." Instead, he was elected by other trustees as one of 12 trustees for the Fidelity Funds. **********In this role, he acts as "scorekeeper, judge and cheerleader," he said. "My job is to make sure that Fidelity shareholders are treated fairly." **********Each month, Mr. Lynch and the rest of the equity committee listen to presentations by two stock-fund managers. While they look at whether a fund's investments are in line with its objectives, the big question, Mr. Lynch says, is: Can you tell me the 25 biggest positions in the fund, and why you own them? **********In fact, the trustees met last week to review Magellan's performance under his successor, Morris Smith. How is Mr. Smith doing? "Great," Mr. Lynch said. **********Besides his responsibilities for Fidelity, Mr. Lynch continues as a director of the Morrison Knudsen Corporation and of W. R. Grace & Company, which he joined in the 80's because he was friendly with William J. Agee and J. Peter Grace, the companies' chief executives. When he retired, he was besieged with requests to join other boards, all of which he declined. **********Overall, Mr. Lynch estimates, the Fidelity work takes only one or two working days each month; the corporate board work takes another day or two. The rest of his working time is spent with charities. **********The biggest beneficiary is the Archdiocese of Boston. Mr. Lynch says his best accomplishment this past year is a scholarship program for inner-city students sponsored by the archdiocese. For last February's black-tie fund-raising dinner, Mr. Lynch persuaded companies to buy tables "to get Boston business to hear the story of the inner-city schools," he said. Next year he will serve as chairman of the affair. **********He is also chairman of the investment committee for the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, and he spent a small amount of time teaching at Boston College. **********Most of his activities require Mr. Lynch to keep up with the financial markets. As for his current thinking on the United States, Mr. Lynch said the economy began to run out of steam a little more than a year ago. The 1990 slowdown would have been a small one, he said, except for the added pressures created by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last summer. Now, "it looks definitely like a good-size recession," he said. **********Is a recovery imminent? Mr. Lynch notes that housing is more affordable that it has been in 15 years and consumer confidence is much improved from its low levels of last fall. He concluded: "All the ingredients are there for a recovery, but there are no signs of it yet. Things will probably look a lot better in 12 months." **********As for stocks to buy, Mr. Lynch demurred. "I'm out of the business of predicting stocks for public consumption," he said. **********When he was picking stocks out in the open, Mr. Lynch was on the top of the heap. As he took over Magellan on June 1, 1977, the fund had $22 million in assets. By the time he left, assets totaled $14 billion. **********In that time, Magellan earned an average annual return of 29.3 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks mutual funds. That is nearly double the 15.2 percent return for the Lipper Growth Fund Index. And while the stock market suffered several setbacks of 10 percent or more during Mr. Lynch's tenure, Magellan never lost money for a full year. **********What does he have to say to fund investors who are looking for guidance? **********First, he recommends long-term horizons. Do not invest money that might be needed in the next year or two, because market behavior for such short periods can be random, he said, adding that "people who try to get into the market for a quick 10 percent usually end up losing 10 percent." It is only over 5 or 10 years that the stock market becomes fairly predictable, he says. **********Investors should also gauge their "tolerance for pain," Mr. Lynch said, because the stock market has dropped at least 10 percent 40 times in the last 70 years, or roughly every two years. Ask yourself, "what will I do when the market drops?" he suggests. If the likely response is to sell, do not invest. **********For long-term investors, he is a strong proponent of "dollar cost averaging." Investing small amounts regularly reduces the average cost of fund shares because more shares are purchased when prices are lower. **********Finally, do not overpay for mutual funds. While many financial advisers generate huge commissions by selling funds that carry hefty sales charges, Mr. Lynch said, "In most cases, there's no correlation between what you pay and what you get."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/25/world.main_headline: Shamir Is Unyielding on Makeup Of Palestinian Peace Delegation
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/25/world.print_headline: Shamir Is Unyielding on Makeup Of Palestinian Peace Delegation
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/25/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir stressed today that Israel should seize the opportunity to attend the American-designed peace conference, but only if no Palestinians from East Jerusalem or with any connection to the Palestine Liberation Organization will be there. **********The Prime Minister said that if it turns out that no Palestinians are prepared to come to a conference on such terms, Israel would be willing to negotiate directly with any Arab country. But he cautioned both Syria and Jordan that they must not expect to get any land for peace -- only peace for peace. **********The thrust of Mr. Shamir's remarks, as well as those made by Palestinians today, suggested that the Bush Administration's initial optimism that a peace conference could be announced when the President meets with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow next week may be premature.  Dispute Over Representation **********It appears that neither Israelis nor Palestinians are prepared to compromise on the longstanding issue of who will represent the Palestinians. And until that is resolved, it is difficult to imagine the convening of a peace conference. **********Equally important, Mr. Shamir held out no hope to the Syrians and Jordanians that if they engaged in direct talks about "real and true peace," they had a chance to regain any of the Golan Heights or West Bank occupied by Israel since the 1967 war. **********The Prime Minister, questioned in a television interview, said: **********"I do not believe in territorial compromise. Our country is very small. Where would you find among the nations of the world a people who would be ready to give up the territory of their homeland?  'It All Goes Together' **********"I believe with all my heart and soul that we are eternally tied to this homeland. Peace and security go together. Security, and a territory, a homeland -- it all goes together. That is our belief, that is the belief of the party I belong to and in my opinion, that is the feeling of a large majority of the Jewish nation." **********The conditions that Mr. Shamir laid down were not new, but his remarks tonight were important for several reasons. First, they marked his first public comments in Hebrew in reaction to the news brought Sunday by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d that Syria, Jordan and Lebanon had all agreed to take part in a peace conference with Israel. **********Up to now, Mr. Shamir has been quoted by aides as saying optimistic things in private or to various visiting American groups. **********But when it came to addressing his own constituency in Hebrew, it was clear that the news that Syria was ready to attend a peace conference that would open the way for the first direct talks with Israel was not something so enticing to Mr. Shamir that he is prepared to drop his conditions on Palestinian representation, or to suggest even the remotest hope of a territorial compromise.  Separate Deal With Syria? **********Second, his comments were important because they suggested that Mr. Shamir already realizes that it may be impossible to bridge the gap between Israel and the Palestinians over how the Palestinians should be represented, and he is already trying to offer Syria the sort of separate deal that Israel struck with Egypt in 1978 at Camp David, Md. -- but without offering the Syrians a chance to recover their occupied land, as the Egyptians recovered Sinai. **********There is no indication at this stage that the Syrians would accept such a separate negotiation. They have said the opposite in public. Thus, if Mr. Baker does not find a way to resolve the question of Palestinian representation, it is hard to see how a conference can begin. **********The Israelis say they will not formally agree to attend until they get a list of Palestinians from the United States. American officials say they are waiting for the Jordanians and Palestinians to agree on a joint delegation. **********Mr. Baker, when he spoke with three Palestinian representatives in Jerusalem on Sunday, told them that while he sympathized with their plight, the realities of power in the Mideast now were such that if they wanted to take part in negotiations, they would have to essentially accept the Israeli conditions.  Baker Proposal Rejected **********He tried to make it easier for them by asking Israel to agree that no East Jerusalem Palestinians would be in the opening round of talks, which will be limited to the question of autonomy for the Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. But they can be in discussions later, when the final status of the territories will be decided. The Israelis rejected this idea, as did the Palestinians. **********"We told Mr. Baker that the United States does not recognize the Israeli annexation of East Jerusalem, so how does he expect us to?" said Hanan Ashrawi, one of the West Bank Palestinians who has been meeting with Mr. Baker. **********"There is no Palestinian -- credible or incredible -- who will be prepared to take part in a peace conference in which no Palestinians from East Jerusalem are allowed," he said. "It is a matter of substance. It means accepting the Israeli annexation." **********In a parallel diplomatic move, the French Foreign Ministry announced today that Faisal al-Husseini, the other leading West Bank Palestinian involved in talks with Mr. Baker, was coming to Paris tonight for talks with the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, on the Palestinian representation issue. French Help Sought **********Palestinians say Mr. Husseini will try to enlist French help to soften the American and Israeli positions, something that will not be greeted warmly by Mr. Baker, who has had a monopoly up to now on the diplomacy. **********Mr. Shamir made it quite clear that for him this issue was non-negotiable. He will only talk to Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza Strip, or to Palestinian refugees living in Jordan and carrying Jordanian passports. **********To talk to Palestinians from East Jerusalem or Palestinian refugees from abroad, he argues, would be to admit that East Jerusalem is negotiable and that Palestinian refugees have a right to return to their homes in Israel as the country existed before the 1967 war. **********In Mr. Shamir's view there are only two solutions for the Palestinians. One is for those living in the West Bank and Gaza to accept an autonomy arrangement that recognizes Israeli rule and the other is for those living in Jordan to remain there as Jordanian citizens and for Israel and Jordan to reach a peace agreement between them. 'This Is Our Right' **********"We must know who are the people who will compose the Palestinian delegation within the Palestinian-Jordanian delegation," the Prime Minister said. "This is our right. Under no circumstances can they be from East Jerusalem. Jerusalem, united in its completeness, is the capital of Israel." **********The Palestinians reject such conditions, asking: In what negotiation in history can one side demand to choose the other's delegation? **********"They don't agree with us and for now, because of this, there is no Palestinian-Jordanian delegation," Mr. Shamir said. "We know this process will not begin until all the parties agree to take part in it. But you know something: I am prepared to negotiate only with Syria, with all the Arab states. I don't need them all." **********Asked if that meant he was was ready to go to a conference that did not have Palestinians there, Mr. Shamir replied: "As far as I am concerned, yes."  A Package Deal **********The problem the United States now faces, though, is that it has presented the peace conference, and sold it in the Arab world and Israel, as a package. Politically, the Arab countries need the Palestinians there to cover their own direct talks with Israel. **********It would be very difficult now for the United States and the Soviet Union, the co-sponsors of the conference, to simply issue invitations, as Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev were hoping to do at their summit meeting in Moscow that begins Tuesday. **********First, they have no one to send the Palestinian invitation to at this point, and second, Mr. Shamir warned them not to try to paint him into a corner by demanding that he agree to the conference and leave the detail of Palestinian representation to be worked out before the talks open in October. **********Mr. Shamir said Mr. Baker explained to him that the Syrians had decided to accept the conference out of recognition that they had to put themselves in the good graces of the United States now that the Soviet Union was in decline and America was the world's only real superpower. **********President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was also driven to break from the Arab consensus and offer peace with Israel in the late 1970's out of a desire to gain American favor and aid, Mr. Shamir indicated, but he said there was one important difference. **********"Sadat," the Prime Minister said, "started his move with an appeal to Israel, not to the United States." **********"He came to Jerusalem, to the Knesset, and said to the Jewish nation: 'I want peace with you, I understand your security problems,' " Mr. Shamir said. "Assad has not said that up to today. He turned first of all to the Americans, and only the Americans. Up to now he has not spoken at all about peace. He talks about 'resolving the dispute.' It is not the same thing."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Goods Seized by Microsoft
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/30/busin.body_text: **********The Microsoft Corporation said today that it, in conjunction with United States marshals, had made a large seizure of counterfeit software. Six individuals and 10 businesses said to have participated in a Los Angeles-based counterfeiting scheme may have been distributing illegal software throughout the United States for more than a year, Microsoft said. **********The company has filed a civil suit against them in the Federal Court for the Central District of California. **********Nearly 20,000 illegal packages of Microsoft's products, with a street value of more than $1 million, were uncovered and seized in raids and investigations over the last four months, the company said. The seized software included three versions of the Microsoft MS-DOS operating system, including the latest, version 5, and the Microsoft Windows software environment, version 3.0. **********Customers and dealers could identify authentic packages by their holograms, Microsoft said, although some legal software made by licensees might not have these three-dimensional labels. The seized packages used shiny silver stickers that do not have a three-dimensional effect. The holograms include a circular MS-DOS sign on the side of the box and a rectangular Microsoft logo on the spine of the manual. **********The defendants in the case, all in the Los Angeles area, are: Xymox, Falcon, Micro Griffin International, Micro Aid Distributing and Micro Aid International, owned by the brothers Soheyl and Abbas Moshtael; Williams Lithograph and Meap Communications and Graphics, owned by Amnon Peery; Ross Bindery; L.A. Perfect Binder; GIM Graphics, owned by George Chacon, and two individuals, Payam Golestani and Farhad Zanich.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/04/world.main_headline: Peres Urges Halt to West Bank Settlements
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/04/world.print_headline: Peres Urges Halt to West Bank Settlements
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/04/world.body_text: **********Shimon Peres, head of the opposition Labor Party, called today for a halt to Israeli settlements in the occupied territories and said there could be no Middle East peace unless this country gives up some of the Arab land it has held since the 1967 war. **********Mr. Peres proposed the creation of a demilitarized West Bank, with Israel retaining certain, unspecified areas for security purposes but yielding the rest to a new "Jordanian-Palestinian confederation" that would include the present Kingdom of Jordan. The crowded Gaza Strip would also be a part of this confederation, he said. **********"Peace cannot be achieved without territorial compromise," Mr. Peres, a former Prime Minister, said in an interview at his party's headquarters in which he reiterated his party's position on several issues. He said that one of the best ways to expedite the Middle East peace process being promoted by the United States was to freeze settlement activity in the territories. **********On both counts -- land concessions and a halt to settlements -- the Labor Party leader is diametrically at odds with the no-compromise stand taken by the Government and the Likud party of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. **********"When somebody says Gaza belongs to us, we are not convinced," Mr. Peres said. "We think that we belong to Gaza more than Gaza belongs to us. We are more in a way the policemen of Gaza than its proprietor. **********"We would not like to dominate another people against their will," he continued. "It's a moral issue. It's a political issue. Throughout our history as a Jewish people we have never dominated other people, and whoever dominated us disappeared from history. We don't want to copy that." **********Some opinion polls here suggest that a majority of Israelis share his views on a settlement freeze, and that their ranks include a significant share of Likud voters. But the surveys also suggest that agreement on this issue does not necessarily translate into broad popular support for Mr. Peres's party, which had belonged to a Shamir-led government until the coalition broke apart 19 months ago. Political commentators say Labor is now at a low ebb as it prepares for elections scheduled to be held within a year. **********Rejecting this view, Mr. Peres said there will be many new voters in the next election, including a large number of Soviet immigrants. "None of us knows how they'll vote," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/06/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking to ease the process by which smaller companies can tap capital markets, the S.E.C. chairman, Richard C. Breeden, said today. **********"The commission should be willing to revisit our own rules under the securities act and the investment company act to streamline the process by which smaller companies can tap the market without abandoning protections against fraud," he said at the annual session of the Securities Industry Associations. **********He said simplified offerings and filings under the exchange act and broader use of the business development companies' provisions of the investment company act could help lower costs and improve capital access. **********Mr. Breeden described the 1990's as the decade of greater globalization of markets. In the last two years, gross purchases and sales of foreign securities by United States investors have risen by one-third, Mr. Breeden said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/22/busin.body_text: **********FOR a while, it looked like Triumph motorcycles, once king of the rebel's road, would live on only in celluloid.  From the late 70's through the early 80's, the Triumph Company seemed a terminal case, kept barely alive by a workers' cooperative that was determined to keep making bikes even though Japanese companies had pretty well won their customers. By 1983 even the workers gave up, and John Bloor, a British millionaire, bought Triumph from its liquidators. **********Now the Triumph is coming back. Mr. Bloor, who apparently saw more value in the Triumph name than in the design, spent seven years engineering a secretive recovery for the company. He built automated facilities, re-staffed and commissioned new motorcycle designs. Last December he unveiled the result at the Motor Cycle Show in Birmingham, England: four new motorcycles, ranging in size from 750 cc to 1200 cc, made in an ultra-automated plant with capacity to produce about 15,000 bikes a year. **********For now, the bikes are available only in Europe, and no one has figures on how well they are selling. But they seem unlikely to make a splash with the Triumph-riding rebel of yore, so immortalized by Marlon Brando in "The Wild One." **********One motorcycle industry insider, who demanded that his name be withheld, said the new Triumphs look more like five-year-old Japanese bikes than vintage Bonnevilles. "They're probably selling to collectors now, but it's hard to tell who they will appeal to later," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/30/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Radio Deal Would Link Drive-Time Rivals
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/30/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Radio Deal Would Link Drive-Time Rivals
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/30/busin.body_text: **********TOGETHER, for the first time, Howard Stern and Don Imus. **********Each weekday morning, these two radio stars battle for a share of the morning "drive time" market, along the way sometimes heaping abuse on each other. Mr. Stern ranked second in the market, with a 7.0 rating on WXRK-FM, in last summer's Arbitron ratings for morning drive time, the latest figures available. Mr. Imus ranked seventh, with a 4.0 rating, on WFAN-AM. Overall, WXRK tied for 10th in the New York market, at 3.8; WFAN ranked 15th, with a 3.3 rating. **********Now the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation, which owns WXRK-FM, is planning to buy WFAN-AM, the home of Mr. Imus, for about $70 million from the Emmis Broadcasting Company of Indianapolis. The deal appears set to go through, assuming the investing public is willing to finance the acquisition by purchasing stock in Infinity, which wants to go public only three years after a leveraged buyout took the company private and left it saddled with debt. **********Infinity officials declined to be interviewed last week, but the deal has generated some excitement in the radio industry. **********"There is a tremendous synergy on the morning shows," said J. T. Atherton, managing editor of Radio Business Report, an industry publication. "You put them together and that will be one hot item to sell" to advertisers. Besides putting the two morning stars into one advertising package, there is speculation that Infinity intends to export Mr. Imus's program to some of its other stations, as it already does with Mr. Stern's. **********Infinity owns 17 radio stations in 12 markets, including stations in Philadelphia and Washington that carry Mr. Stern's show, and it has done better than many broadcasters in the current recession, with revenues rising at a slow rate, and losses diminishing. Investors in Infinity will no doubt be hoping that under the company's ownership, the two New York stations -- WXRK with Mr. Stern and WFAN with Mr. Imus -- will show improved results, for the price being asked in the offering is not a cheap one. **********The company plans to go public by selling six million shares at a price of $16 to $18 a share. **********In this deal, the company's name seems appropriate, because any price is an infinite multiple of its nonexistent profits. The company reported a loss of $39.6 million in 1990, and $24.1 million in the first nine months of this year, not including an extraordinary gain it recorded from buying back bonds at a discount. **********In the world of broadcasting, of course, profits under generally accepted accounting principles are often not deemed to be an achievable goal, and managements urge investors to ignore the depreciation of intangible assets. What counts, they say, is cash flow. **********The proposed public offering values the company at 11.7 to 12.3 times its 1990 cash flow, incorporating WFAN's results. That multiple evidently will be somewhat lower for 1991, because Infinity's results improved slightly in the first nine months of this year, while WFAN's moved up significantly. **********Infinity obviously thinks there is plenty of room for improvement in operations at WFAN, which carries Mr. Imus weekdays from 5:30 to 10 A.M., and all-sports programming the rest of the time: the games of the New York Mets, Knicks and Rangers, and a host of sports talk shows. **********The figures included in the prospectus for the offering indicate that WFAN had cash flow -- before interest expenses and before management overhead -- of $4.6 million on revenues of $21.4 million in 1990. At $70 million, Infinity is paying 15 times that cash flow. **********In fact, WFAN's results are improving. For the first nine months of 1991 it reported cash flow of $6.4 million on revenues of $20.7 million. Because the prospectus does not give comparable results, and because the fourth quarter is not an especially strong one for WFAN -- with baseball over and the two local professional football teams on other stations -- it is not possible to estimate the multiple being paid based on 1991 cash flow. **********By the standards of a few years ago, when deals relied on rapidly advancing ad revenues or soaring prices of radio stations, this deal is conservative. But its success still seems to be dependent on capital markets remaining friendly. **********The pro forma financial results indicate that had this deal been done at the beginning of 1991, and the bonds repurchased then, Infinity would have had operating cash flow of $9.8 million, for the first nine months, even after paying its interest expenses. If the fourth quarter is that good, that would leave $13 million of cash flow available for the year, compared with a margin of only about $3 million in all of 1990. All figures ignore capital spending, which is running at better than $1 million a year. **********Unfortunately, $13 million will not be good enough in 1992, because the company is scheduled to repay $16.9 million of long-term debt that year, a figure that rises gradually each year to $21.5 million in 1994, and then zooms to $252.9 million in 1995, when Infinity will have to refinance its operations. **********One aid to 1992 cash flow may be the proceeds from the sale of Infinity's current AM station in New York, WZRC. After converting from a Spanish-language format in 1990, that station now plays rock music, but it does not have enough listeners to be included in the Arbitron ratings. Under Federal Communications Commission rules, Infinity will have to sell WZRC after it completes the acquisition of WFAN. Infinity has asked for a one-year waiver in order to avoid an abrupt sale. **********It may be encouraging to prospective buyers of Infinity shares that insiders at the company are not taking out cash from the offering. In fact, they put cash into the company at the end of September, enabling the company to repurchase bonds at a discount. **********But those insiders, who include management and Lehman Brothers, which is underwriting the new offering, did not pay retail. Their price was about $12 a share, or a discount of 25 to 33 percent from the price being asked of the public investors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/07/world.main_headline: Rome Journal; Retiring a Token Makes Big Issue of Small Change
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/07/world.print_headline: Rome Journal; Retiring a Token Makes Big Issue of Small Change
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/07/world.body_text: **********Obscured by oddments like the Persian Gulf crisis and Western Europe's latest gyrations toward unity was a recent notice that a small piece of Italian tradition is about to fade away. **********The small piece is known as the gettone, a ridged copper token that has been used for more than five decades to make calls from pay telephones. It is a simple device that makes it unnecessary to rejigger the phone's internal mechanism whenever the rates change. **********But the phone company considers the gettone to be outmoded, and says that by the end of next year it should be phased out almost entirely, giving way to machines that accept only coins or prepaid, magnetically coded cards, which have been steadily gaining popularity here. **********France had similar tokens, jetons, and there was reportedly little mourning when they started to disappear a few years ago in favor of the magnetic cards. But some Italians expect the reaction here to be a bit different. In Italy, the gettone is an integral part of the daily routine, not just for making phone calls but also for clearing life's many unexpected hurdles. Accepted as Currency **********While technically it is not legal to use a gettone as currency, everyone accepts it as a full equivalent to a 200-lire coin, or about 18 cents. That is no paltry matter in a country where the search for a shopkeeper with small change sometimes makes Ahab's pursuit of the white whale seem like a fish-shoot in a barrel. **********The problem was acute a decade ago. Small coins all but disappeared, forcing stores to make change with pieces of candy and baubles. Since then, the situation has markedly improved. Still, many storeowners despair of the long lines that await them at local banks, and so they try to avoid going there even if the result is a coinless cash register. **********Under such circumstances, the telephone token looms large as a coin of last resort, so much so that one restaurant owner in Rome says he will resist to the end before giving up his gettone-only pay phone. **********Many of his regular customers are prominent politicians and assorted hangers-on, some of whom belong to the fast-shrinking tribe of Rome residents who do not walk about with cellular phones attached to their ears. These people need a public phone that works, the restaurant owner says, and his gettone machine has withstood the test of time. To him, the new telephone cards are a form of electronic alchemy, inspiring no confidence. **********He is not alone in doubting phone company innovations. Some Phones Don't Work **********The company's surveys show, for example, that one pay phone of every 12 on Italy's streets does not work. But many people suspect that the ratio is appreciably higher, given the lamentable state of public services that, most Italians admit, are the bane of this, the world's sixth largest economy west of Minsk or east of Vladivostok. **********Actually, until the other day Italy thought it was the fifth largest. **********The country had puffed out its chest five years ago when it seemed to have moved up a notch, thanks to a statistical recalibration that took account of the sizable underground -- look out, here comes the tax collector! -- economy. There it was, "il sorpasso," the overtaking of Britain that put Italy behind only the United States, Japan, Germany and France. **********But a European Community report this week told Italians that, sorry, the figures had been rechecked, and it seems they are really No. 6 and they have been No. 6 throughout the last five years, once factors like real purchasing power are taken into account. A Downbeat Mood **********Whatever its proper place, Italy has entered palindromic 1991 in a decidedly downbeat mood. Opinion polls show that Italians foresee a worsening economy and a high probability of yet another Government collapse, not to mention that they worry like everyone else about a gulf war. **********But there are bright spots, and one is that a sixth-place economic force cannot be expected to have the same level of public services as a fifth-place power. That is some consolation, however scant, for the millions of Italians who have had it with late-running trains, strike-bound planes, phones that fail, health services that further afflict the afflicted and mails that go through now and again. **********According to Corriere della Sera, a respected national daily, only 52 percent of all telephone calls here reach their intended destination -- odds that are slightly better than one can find at a casino blackjack table. Many calls that do get through are suddenly cut off, or, more commonly, the connection sounds as though the person on the other end is crinkling an empty potato-chips bag against the mouthpiece. Improvement in Mail **********As for the mails, the latest Government figures show rapid improvement. Two years ago, it took the average letter 8.5 days to go from one point to another in Italy. Now, the post office says, the delivery time has been trimmed, on average, to 4 days and 15 hours. One could also note, however, that a person with one foot in a bucket of scalding water and the other in a pail of ice water is, on average, comfortable. The post office average includes fairly common deviations like a letter from New York that was postmarked June 27, 1989, and arrived in Rome the following April 19. **********A report last month by Censis, the country's principal gatherer of statistics, concluded that Italians were fed up with the poor quality of their public services. There is a "new culture of saying no," Censis said, adding that more and more people are crying out, "Basta" -- "Enough." **********At the phone company, executives agree, and say that is why they are pouring billions of dollars into a modernization program that should, within a few years, raise Italian telephone services to the ranks of the best. Getting rid of the gettone in favor of zippy electronic cards is merely one part of the process, they say. **********"The gettone," said Carlo Dellepiane, a senior company official, "is antiquated." **********So, Italians say with a heavenward roll of the eyes, are stable phone rates. In mid-January they go up again.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/07/world.main_headline: Saudi King Says He Expects Iraq to Yield
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/07/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF; Saudi King Says He Expects Iraq to Yield
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/07/world.body_text: **********King Fahd of Saudi Arabia said today that he shared President Bush's impression that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq would withdraw his forces from Kuwait in compliance with the United Nations Security Council deadline of Jan. 15. **********In a rare public appearance, the King reviewed the international forces arrayed here against Iraq and offered advice to Mr. Hussein, calling him his former friend. The King urged Mr. Hussein to "spare everyone bloodshed and catastrophe" by withdrawing from Kuwait. **********He also said a negotiated solution to the conflict between Iraq and Kuwait was still possible -- after Iraq withdraws its forces.  Readiness for War **********In response to a reporter's question, King Fahd implicitly warned President Hussein that if he did not withdraw, Saudi Arabia would be prepared to use force, with its allies, to insure Iraq's departure from Kuwait and the restoration of stability in the region. "We are sure, God willing, that peace will be realized -- either way," he said. **********Asked if he would go along with a possible agreement between Iraq and Kuwait that would give Baghdad the use of Kuwait's two islands in the Persian Gulf or some disputed territory, King Fahd said that first Iraq had to withdraw. "Then, if there is any demand, the two countries should sit together and discuss the matter between themselves," he said. "Whatever they agree on, we will support." **********His position mirrored that of the Bush Administration. Earlier in the crisis Prince Sultan, the Defense Minister and a brother of the King made remarks that were widely interpreted as a suggestion to Kuwait that it cede some territory to Iraq. This idea was quickly repudiated by senior American and Saudi officials, eager to dispel any impression that anything short of total and unconditional Iraqi withdrawal was unacceptable. The King's insistence today on withdrawal as a precondition to any negotiations over territory underscored that point.  Visit to Military Base **********King Fahd gave this assessment during a visit to King Khalid Military City, a vast military complex about 60 miles southwest of the Kuwaiti border. Asked whether he shared President Bush's feeling that Iraq would withdraw its forces at the last minute before the United Nations deadline, King Fahd replied: "I do share with President Bush his instinct and his hope. And I hope Saddam Hussein will take the important step and withdraw from Kuwait and spare everybody the bloodshed and catastrophe of war." Mr. Bush said in an interview in last week's issue of Time magazine that "my gut says he will get out of there," **********In the strongest defense to date of his decision to invite largely non-Muslim foreign forces to come to this center of Islam, King Fahd rejected assertions that the large international presence here risked destabilizing his highly conservative kingdom. "We have taken the right step," he declared. "We still know it's the right step. We don't have any instability. The people who objected are those who supported Saddam Hussein from the beginning." **********King Fahd said that Saudi Arabia had "an understanding" with all countries that had sent forces here that "once the crisis is over, all the troops will go back to their homes." But, asked how he would protect his country in the future, he did not rule out a future foreign presence. "There is always a way to negotiate and discuss and make agreements in the future so things like what happened now will not be repeated."  On Throne Since 1982 **********The 69-year-old Saudi ruler, a cautious and normally retiring leader, has ruled the country, containing about 40 percent of the world's oil reserves, since 1982. **********In his visit to the international force, King Fahd first reviewed 1,000 American and 500 Saudi soldiers with Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the United States ground forces here, and then, in a separate ceremony, some 5,000 troops from Britain, France and several Islamic countries that have also sent forces. **********The review was his first since the crisis began more than five months ago. It was also the first time in the crisis that he has met with and answered questions from Western reporters. These rare gestures came nine days before the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations Security Council in a resolution authorizing the use of force if Iraq does not withdraw from Kuwait. It also seemed intended to blunt growing criticism from Congress and Middle East analysts of the size of Saudi Arabia's financial contribution to the effort to defend the kingdom and force Iraq to leave Kuwait. Congress is scheduled to debate the use of force against Iraq and related issues later this week.  'A Wonderful Gesture' **********General Schwarzkopf, speaking to reporters shortly before the troop review, said King Fahd's visit was "a demonstration that we are all in this together." Asked whether he thought the King should have come sooner, the general replied: "Who am I to tell kings what to do? They're really busy people. It's a wonderful gesture he's coming out here to see them now." **********The review of the troops was organized quickly on less than 48 hours' notice, officials here said. American forces were summoned to this base at Hafr al-Baten only yesterday to begin rehearsals. While some American officers said they were delighted that Saudi Arabia did not seem to share the embarrassment of other gulf states about the presence of so many American soldiers in this region, others seemed slightly irritated by the short notice, the changes in review procedures just before the King's visit, and the interruption of their military preparations and exercises. Anthems Are Played **********The King's visit began with the review of Saudi and American soldiers, who stood across from each other on the giant tarmac of the Hafr al-Baten air base. After the Saudi and American national anthems were played, King Fahd and General Schwarzkopf rode in the back of an open jeep on this cold, crystal-clear day past soldiers of the 22d Support Command, the band and color guard of the Army's First Cavalry Division, army engineers, a hospital company, quartermasters, the 766th Transportation Company of the Indiana National Guard, and a signal battalion. A smiling King Fahd, wearing a light brown, gold-embroidered cloak and traditional Saudi headdress, waved once to the troops, but did not address them. **********He then drove in a 50-car motorcade at breathtaking speed some 40 miles across the barren desert, where his party, which included more than 100 members of the royal family, ministers and friends, reviewed some 5,000 soldiers standing at attention in formation behind their national flags and signposts indicating their countries in English and Arabic. There were no American soldiers at this gathering, although a signpost for the Americans had been prepared and was lying alongside the formation. **********One officer said that the Americans had not come to hear the speech at this review because they had been paid a special tribute by their own review earlier in the day. **********The King delivered his speech in Arabic -- a 45-minute long account of his role in the crisis -- from a Bedouin-style tent pitched over luxurious Arabic carpets less than 500 yards in front of the soldiers. The King and General Schwarzkopf and other commanders of the foreign forces sat on high-backed chairs with thick, embroidered cushions, in front of which was a coffee table adorned with fresh roses and boxes of tissues. Incense scented the air. As the reporters selected by the Saudis for this rare visit with King Fahd crowded around the tent, the King uttered a few words of welcome in English, and answered eight questions in Arabic. **********He also invited those reporters present to return to the kingdom as his guests after the crisis was over, "to see the development we have achieved in this great country." **********In his account of the crisis, King Fahd suggested that he had been personally betrayed by President Hussein, who he said had repeatedly assured the Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, in Baghdad before the crisis that he meant Kuwait no harm. **********The King said that since he and Mr. Hussein had met in 1975, the Iraqi President had "called me every other day," to say that because of his help to Iraq, "they considered me a hero." Suddenly after Aug. 3, the King said, "I became in his eyes a terrible man. I just cannot believe this."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/10/busin.body_text: **********The Illinois Central Corporation plans to refinance $150 million of its high-interest series K mortgage bonds, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********Illinois Central, based in Chicago, said that to pay for the refinancing it was negotiating the sale of $100 million in notes to institutional investors through a private placement. The company is also negotiating with its bankers for an additional $50 million in financing. **********The series K bonds, which mature in 1994, were issued in 1984 to replace other debt and have a 15.5 percent coupon. They are callable on June 1 at par. Illinois Central, the parent company for the Illinois Central Railroad Company, has also registered to sell about $54.8 million in stock, with the proceeds of the sale to be used to repay part of a term loan and possibly buy back debentures. The company said that if the private placement failed, it would use the proceeds from the stock sale to redeem the series K bonds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/11/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Bond Rally's Continuation Is Questioned
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/11/busin.body_text: **********With long-term interest rates at their lowest levels in more than a year, some credit market analysts are beginning to wonder whether the bond market rally that began in mid-January has run its course. **********Bond yields have fallen by more than half a percentage point in scarcely a month's time, and since much of the $11 billion worth of new 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds sold at last week's Treasury refunding auctions remain in Wall Street's hands, dealers are watching to see whether retail investors will step up and buy the securities. **********"The Street has a very real interest in keeping the rally going," said William N. Griggs, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm. "But at the moment there does not seem to be any clear sign of overwhelming retail demand. Do investors believe that this is about the end of the decline, and that rates could turn around?" Lower Yields Expected **********Despite the seeming lack of enthusiasm by investors, Mr. Griggs and other analysts said the recession and an anticipated sharp slowdown in inflation this year would probably push bond yields lower. **********"The bullish posture of the dealer community is absolutely appropriate," said James M. Benham, chairman of Benham Capital Management Group, a Mountain View, Calif., firm with a fixed-income portfolio of $7.5 billion, most of it in Government securities. "The bond market rally is real. The weakness in the economy is clearly evident, and talk about a turnaround this spring looks like a hope to me, not reality. I think bond yields are destined to fall to 7.75 percent at least and possibly as low as 7 percent by year-end, depending on what the economy does and how the Fed responds." **********Because the drop in short-term rates has been so much more pronounced than in bond yields, Mr. Benham said more and more investors in his funds were lengthening the maturity of their holdings to capture additional yield.  Salomon Assessment **********"The most compelling argument in favor of lower yields stems from the forces that are undercutting inflation," Robert DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers, noted in the firm's weekly newsletter Comments on Credit. **********Because of the recession, wage pressures are easing, Mr. DiClemente said. And a slowdown in other industrial economies, many of them crucial American export markets, will impede a quick recovery in the United States. **********Still, there are signs that investors, who grew increasingly conscious of credit quality as 1990 progressed, are now willing to take on more risk in exchange for yields that are much higher than those offered on AAA-rated Treasury securities. **********Despite the recession, prices of a wide variety of corporate bonds have been rising for much of the last month, from high-yield "junk bonds," to medium- to high-quality corporate issues. Corporate Yields at a Low **********Corporate bond indexes compiled by Merrill Lynch show that yields on high-quality corporate bonds with maturities of 10 years or more are now at 52-week lows, at just over 9 percent. So, too, are yields on riskier investment-grade corporate debt, securities rated A to Baa. At the end of last week, Merrill Lynch's index showed those issues were yielding about 9.80 percent. **********The improvement in the corporate market has much to do with the overall decline in interest rates. But analysts said the declines in many corporate issues in the fourth quarter turned them into bargains. **********"In the fourth quarter the whole corporate market got cheap, too cheap relative to the economic fundamentals," said Thomas J. Sowanick, senior fixed-income strategist at Merrill Lynch. **********"With the general level of bond yields down, and the fact that long Treasuries are now yielding under 8 percent, investors have been given a reason to take on incremental yield."  Views on Corporate Market **********Given the economic outlook, participants in the corporate market said prices would probably improve further. **********"For the first time probably since 1982, people think they should buy corporates because the Fed is lowering rates and, while credit quality looks bad now, it will improve in six or seven months," said one corporate bond trader. "Prices in this market are not the equivalent of being 6 percent or so from their all-time peak, as they are in the stock market." **********Analysts said that upcoming economic reports this week should be favorable to prices in almost all fixed-income markets. **********"We are looking for a whole string of weak numbers, from industrial production to retail sales to producer prices," said Steven Slifer, a senior vice president and financial market economist at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. "If we get that string, the market might begin building an expectation that the Fed will ease again before the end of February." Possible Stumbling Block **********The producer price report that Mr. Slifer referred to might prove a stumbling block. **********Most analysts, including Mr. Slifer, anticipate that the Producer Price Index for January, which is expected to be released on Friday, will show that prices fell last month, in large part because of a decline in energy prices. **********Some analysts noted, however, that much of that decline occurred after the onset of fighting in the Middle East. In early January, the period when data for the report were collected, wholesale gasoline prices actually rose, they said. **********As a consequence, Brian Jones, an economist at Salomon Brothers, is estimating that producer prices probably rose by two-tenths of a percentage point last month, after a decline of six-tenths of a point in December. **********Excluding food and energy, however, the core inflation rate probably increased by a mere one-tenth of a percentage point, Mr. Jones said, compared with an increase of three-tenths of a point in December.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/31/busin.main_headline: An Issue of Consumer Privacy . . . And Corporate Retreat
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/31/busin.print_headline: FORUM; An Issue of Consumer Privacy . . . And Corporate Retreat
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/31/busin.body_text: **********Economic factors were important in the decision by Lotus and Equifax to cancel Lotus MarketPlace: Households, but privacy concerns were given the greatest weight. **********A principle of consumer privacy is that personal information collected for one purpose should not be used for another without the individual's consent, and we provided several consent mechanisms in MarketPlace, including the ability to have your name removed from a database. **********But this principle should not be applied in a wooden, absolute fashion; that would simply return us to the days of less efficient mass marketing. Rather, it should depend on two things: what the impact of that information use would be on the consumer, and the sensitivity of the information. **********In MarketPlace, the information was not very sensitive; direct marketing databases are just names and addresses, selected by computer-modeled demographic analysis. And the information they generate is used to provide consumers with offers of products and services. **********Consumers seem to want those benefits. A 1990 survey commissioned by Equifax and conducted by Louis Harris & Associates and Alan F. Westin, a privacy expert, found that when the direct marketing process is explained to consumers, a 2-to-1 majority of respondents considered it acceptable for companies to use information about them in order to conduct direct mail marketing. **********Although concerned about threats to privacy, respondents said they were willing to make trade-offs in the use of personal information. For example, 67 percent of respondents found it acceptable for companies to buy data -- names and addresses of people in certain age groups, estimated income groups and residential areas -- so as to mail offers of products and services to people they think will be interested. When they were told that names of people not wanting to receive offers by mail could be deleted from mailing lists, acceptability jumped to 88 percent. **********Direct marketing is used by businesses and consumers because of convenience, low cost and diverse merchandise. As businesses improve their ability to find out who their audience is, costs can be cut and more value delivered. **********MarketPlace could have helped small businesses become more competitive. We believed it also achieved a proper privacy balance and would have been well accepted by consumers. A strong set of privacy protections against improper users and uses was built in. The decision to cancel MarketPlace was difficult. But it shows that a business can be motivated not only by the bottom line but also by social responsibility.

Japanese commercial broadcasters and newspapers have most to los...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/30/busin.main_headline: Western Programs Stand to Gain in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/30/busin.print_headline: Western Programs Stand to Gain in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/30/busin.body_text: **********Western suppliers of movies, TV programs and recorded music, and Japanese consumer electronics companies will be the biggest winners with Japan's expansion of satellite broadcasting. Japanese commercial broadcasters and newspapers have most to lose, analysts said. **********Cable News Network is already in negotiations to expand its distribution via satellite in Japan. Other U.S. broadcast and cable networks also should find new outlets here, as will Western film studios and record companies. **********Japanese electronics companies will enjoy growing sales of equipment to receive satellite broadcasts, although already the majority of sales are for gear incorporated into televisions or videocassette recorders, rather than separate units. This tends to trim profit margins. Half the Japanese population is expected to have access to satellite programming by 2000, either with home receivers or via cable hook-ups, the National Association of Commercial Broadcasters in Japan estimated. **********Sony Corp. and Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. look like the biggest winners, cashing in twice: by selling equipment and by syndicating programming from the American movie and record companies they bought in recent years. Sony acquired CBS Records and Columbia Pictures (now Sony Music Entertainment Inc. and Sony Pictures Entertainment Inc.) and Matsushita took over MCA Inc., owner of MCA Records and Universal Studios. **********Japanese commercial broadcasters will be hardest hit. Government policies that seek to prevent concentration of media ownership will make it difficult for commercial broadcasters and other big media groups to set up their own satellite stations; they may have to settle for equity participation. Newspapers and other existing media will also face greater competition for advertising revenues.

But does the subjective intention of the investor really affect the - supposedly objective - moral qual...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/30/your-.main_headline: Good, Bad? Or Is Money Just Ugly?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/30/your-.print_headline: Good, Bad? Or Is Money Just Ugly?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/30/your-.body_text: **********AN there really be such a thing as a morally 'good' or 'bad' investment? There are, undoubtedly, different kinds of intentions among investors. But does the subjective intention of the investor really affect the - supposedly objective - moral quality of the act? **********What if, for example, a massive hole were suddenly to appear in the ozone layer? Undoubtedly, there would be some investors whose first response would be to reach for a pair of Ray Bans, and then invest in skin cancer clinics. While that action could hardly be considered noble, is it really immoral? It may be downright cynical, but is it wrong? **********The obverse side of the coin would be the investor who tried to put money into a "worthy" company. Perhaps an investment in a corporation dedicated to environmental concerns? But should the stock rise because of the extra work, the worthy investor would be profiting from the changed environmental conditions just as much as the cynic. **********And of course the great danger for the second investor would be the adoption of a holier-than-thou attitude. Both investors make money, but the second investor might just choose to feel comfortable about it. **********It could be argued that money, and markets, are completely outside morality. After all, a market can only react by going up, down or remaining unchanged. **********When socialist premiers - and Democratic presidents - are assassinated, stockmarkets have traditionally risen. Is that immoral? No - because money is outside morality. It is amoral. Trying to ascribe moral value to a stock price is like trying to work out the best floor - ethically speaking - on which an elevator should be.
