https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/07/busin.body_text: **********Money Managers Like European Bond Yields **********Opinions vary widely about when the dollar will recover and how high it will climb, but the consensus is that it will be headed up. This optimism about the currency, however, does not translate into an eagerness to buy dollar assets. Portfolio managers say prices of U.S. stocks fully reflect the expected recovery, while bond prices are not expected to match the gains foreseen in European markets. **********About the most optimistic estimate for the dollar, which ended last week at 1.6765 Deutsche marks and 129.80 yen, is Citibank's forecast of 1.90 DM and 139.50 yen by year-end. National Westminster sees the dollar at 1.70 DM and 131 yen at the end of the year and then rising steadily throughout 1992 to reach 1.90 DM and 139 yen. Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank's DKB International sees dollar weakness immediately ahead against the mark with a year-end forecast of 1.62 DM but a recovery against the yen to 140 and then steadily higher dollar rates throughout next year. **********Michael Cowan, an asset allocation manager at Morgan Stanley Asset Management in London has no quarrel with the view that the dollar is headed up. "The dollar is cheap on its long-term purchasing power parity basis. We think that will be corrected, and the dollar rally will reassert itself," he said. **********At the same time, he considers the U.S. bond market "one of the least attractive of all the major markets." **********Yields on 10-year U.S. government notes ended the week at 7.38 percent. Using Morgan Stanley's estimate that inflation is not likely to fall much below 4.5 percent, the real yield would thus be below 3 percent. **********That may be the typical real yield looked at over a 30-year perspective, but it is unattractivem compared with what is available in other markets, Mr. Cowan said. Indeed, inflation-adjusted yields outside the United States are now so high that Morgan Stanley's normal asset mix of portfolios - half in stocks and half in bonds - has been tilted to 55 percent in bonds and only 45 percent in equities. **********"Equity markets are expensive relative to long-term trends," Mr. Cowan said. "Over the last 15 years, world equities typically traded at 1.6 times book value and 6.2 times cash flow but at the moment those ratios are 2 times book value and 8.2 times cash flow." Book value is basically the net value of a company's assets minus its liabilities, and cash flow is a measure of income available after certain deductions such as interest payments. **********With the current ratios, equities are expensive, Mr. Cowan explained, particularly compared with the high real yields of around 5 percent now prevailing in bond markets. "The fact that you can get higher real yield from bonds than one has typically achieved over the last 30 years indicates the bond market is a good place to park money at the moment," he said. **********The markets he likes most are Germany, Britain, France, Finland and Japan. **********"We're most keen on German bonds," he added, with "very attractive yields currently at 8.5 percent and inflation estimated at 3 percent over the next five years. That indicates real yields of 5.5 percent." **********Mr. Cowan estimated that 25 percent of his bond portfolio is invested in Deutsche mark bonds, considerably more than the 7.5 percent share that German bonds account for in Salomon Brothers' World Bond Index. On the other hand, U.S. bonds, which account for 51 percent of the Salomon index, make up only 38 percent of Mr. Cowan's portfolio. **********But given the outlook on the currency, the dollar exposure in the bond portfolio is closer to 62 percent, since a quarter of the nondollar holdings have been hedged into the U.S. currency. **********"We have money in Italian, Finnish and Danish bonds, which are not represented in the index at all but make up 10 percent of our bond holdings, so we consider we are taking some big bets," Mr. Cowan said. **********As far as maturity, he said the bond portfolio overall has a life of 4.8 years, relatively long measured against the three-year span he considers to be the "neutral" position. Holdings in U.S. and Japanese bonds average 3.5 years, British bonds five years and German and French bonds seven years. **********"At some point next year we believe German rates will fall.and we want to be locked in with long maturities," he said. **********The bulk of the equity investments are in U.S. stocks, which account for 45 percent of the total. But again investments in European stock markets are larger than their weightings in the Morgan Stanley index. German stocks account for 7 percent, compared with an index weighting of 4 percent; Swiss stocks 6 percent, compared with a 2 percent weight in the index; and Finnish stocks take 3 percent, compared with a 0.2 percent weighting. **********The equity holdings are not hedged on a currency basis, but Mr. Cowan notes the companies chosen all have substantial dollar revenue. **********Alan Saunders, head of investment strategy for Union Bank of Switzerland's private banking clients in London, has 60 percent invested in bonds for income-oriented dollar accounts and 40 percent for portfolios geared to aggressive capital growth. **********About 60 percent of the bond portfolio is in European markets, with Italian, Spanish, French and European currency unit bonds accounting for the bulk. Mr. Saunders has omitted German bonds, seeing better value in the higher yields of neighboring countries. He also has up to 10 percent in cash and invested short-term to benefit from the inverted yield curves in many European countries that have pushed short-term returns above those available in long-term investments. **********"At the moment we're happy to run European exposure for dollar accounts. At some stage we'll need to hedge into dollars, but for the moment we feel pretty relaxed about it," he said. **********For European investors, three-quarters of the bond investments are in European markets with the remainder about equally split between U.S. and Japanese bonds. **********At Banque Julius Baer in Zurich, Helmut Sauer said bonds make up 70 percent of conservative portfolios, 55 percent for riskier accounts. "We have a strong conviction that most bond markets will do well over the next six months," he said. **********For Baer's European clients, Ecu, French franc and sterling bonds account for a third of total bond holdings. French and British equities also account for a large part of the stock investments. **********"Declining inflation will buoy the bond markets, and the decline in interest rates will help the equity markets," he said.

A flat corporate earnings outlook over the next fe...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/16/busin.main_headline: High Rates and Ratings Cool Singapore Bourse
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/16/busin.print_headline: High Rates and Ratings Cool Singapore Bourse
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/16/busin.body_text: **********After surging in the first few months of 1991, the Singapore stock market is being dragged down by rising interest rates and a perception that it is over-valued relative to other regional markets. A flat corporate earnings outlook over the next few months combined with a spate of new issues also are depressing sentiment, analysts said. **********The DBS Index of 50 leading stocks closed Monday at 419.07, down 1.27 points from Friday and well below its 1991 high of 446 on June 3. **********Since then, the four major Singapore banks have raised their prime rates by half a percentage point to 7.5 percent.Economists expect a further increase following a rapid rise in three-month interbank rates to 6.25 percent currently from 4.5 percent in April. **********"Demand for credit is strong because of new issues in the pipeline, buoyant economic growth and a tight labor market," said Bibiana Yow, head of research at Smith New Court Securities Pte. **********Two companies will close their listing offers later this month while several more will seek listings on the Singapore exchange in the next few weeks. **********In the past, a number of local and foreign banks have offered 100 percent financing for applicants bidding for new shares. But banks are more wary now because the market is in decline and the Monetary Authority of Singapore has advised banks it was unhappy with the speculative fever their lending helped arouse. **********The Singapore government is forecasting economic growth of between 6 and 8 percent in 1991, after adjustment for inflation. Earnings of most Singapore companies, however, "will reflect subdued economic conditions" in the United States, Europe, Japan and other major markets, said Ang Chor Chen, an analyst with DBS Bank Ltd. **********Nevertheless, Mr. Ang said prospects looked brighter for 1992, and any correction in the Singapore market should be seen as an opportunity to buy. **********IN THE FIRST HALF of the year, the performance of Singapore stocks was among the most impressive in the region. The DBS 50 index increased by 24.1 percent, outpaced only by the Manila Stock Exchange with a gain of 62.6 percent and the Stock Exchange of Thailand, which rose 24.9 percent. **********In the same period, the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange composite index went up by 22.3 percent, the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong by 21.3 percent and the Jakarta Stock Exchange by 17.1 percent. Japan's Nikkei index slipped by 2.3 percent. **********The Singapore market's rise has left it looking "quite expensive in regional terms" to foreign investors and fund managers, said Manu Bhaskaran, economic research director at Crosby Securities Pte. In recent weeks, foreign investors have taken profits and have been net sellers of Singapore stocks, said Low Siew Kheng, research dirctor at Baring Securities (Singapore) Pte. **********At the end of June, based on Crosby Securities' forecasts of 1991 earnings for listed companies, Singapore stocks on average were trading at 16.4 times earnings, compared with a ratio of 14.2 in Indonesia, 14.1 in Thailand, 10.8 in the Philippines and 10.6 in Hong Kong. **********Only Malaysian stocks had a higher rating, with a price-earnings ratio of 19.1. But Mr. Bhaskaran said that if Singapore Airlines was removed from the list of Singapore stocks, the market's average P/E ratio would be around 20. **********SIA, which has a low P/E multiple, accounts for about 12 percent of Singapore market capitalization of 74.8 billion Singapore dollars ($42.5 billion). **********Rajeev Bhaman, an analyst at BZW-Pacific Union Pte., said the prospective 1991 P/E ratio for Singapore stocks "is hardly cheap in the context of either forecast earnings growth of 11 percent in 1991 or 15 percent in 1992." **********In an attempt to tighten financial discipline of listed companies, the exchange rejected rights issues by United Industrial Corp. - a heavily indebted property and manufacturing group - and two other property developers, Hotel Properties Ltd. and Eu Yan Sang Holdings. **********The three firms sought to raise a total of 403 million Singapore dollars. In rejecting UIC's plan for a cash call of 266 million Singapore dollars, the exchange criticized the practice of several unspecified companies, which it said had "diverted funds raised for specific purposes stated in shareholders circulars to other uses."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.snippet: The German cartel office is opening an investigation to see if the move by Allianz AG to boost its stake in Dresdner Bank will hamper competition in the German insurance or banking industries, according to Hubertus Schön, spokesman for the cartel ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.body_text: **********The German cartel office is opening an investigation to see if the move by Allianz AG to boost its stake in Dresdner Bank will hamper competition in the German insurance or banking industries, according to Hubertus Schön, spokesman for the cartel office. **********But the investigation will go further, assessing for the first time the position of Allianz AG in the insurance market of a united Germany in the wake of its controversial acquisition last year of a controlling stake in East Germany's former state-run insurance monopoly. **********Allianz, Europe's largest insurer, has long been the premier insurer by a wide margin in the rich West German market and has been on a buying spree that included the $3.3 billion purchase last year of Fireman's Fund Insurance Co. in the United States. **********"As part of the investigation, we will look at the situation of Allianz in Eastern Germany and this will make it the first time that we look at the competitive situation of the insurance industry in all of Germany," said Mr. Schön. **********While politicians and the public have long been suspicious of the power of the largest banks, many analysts have felt that there has been too little concern about power concentration in the insurance business. **********"German politicians are always speaking out against the power of the banks but they should look into Allianz and the insurance industry if they are serious about competition," said Thomas Albrecht, banking analyst with UBS/Phillips & Drew in London. **********The cartel office was never able to rule on the takeover by Allianz of the East German insurance network because the purchase took place before reunification, and was thus up to East German antitrust authorities. The cartel office decided against the purchase, but was overruled by the East German government in favor of Allianz. **********Mr. Schön said that the cartel office had needed a concrete new development to look closer at competition in the insurance industry of a united Germany, and this was provided by the news that Allianz had boosted its stake in Dresdner Bank, Germany's second largest. **********The Allianz chairman, Wolfgang Schieren, speaking at a press conference in Munich on Tuesday, confirmed earlier reports that his company had lifted its stake in Dresdner Bank to approximately 23 percent. The stake had previously been estimated to be anywhere between 10 percent and 20 percent. **********Normally the cartel office can only rule against a purchase if it involves a stake of more than 25 percent. Now, an amendment passed last year allows the cartel office to block a purchase if it decides that a stake of even less than 25 percent may give the purchaser effective market dominance. **********In the case of Dresdner Bank, for example, the cartel office would consider not only the 23 percent stake of Allianz but an additional stake held in the bank by Munich Reinsurance. **********Since Allianz and Munich Reinsurance have mutual cross-holdings amounting to 25 percent of each other's stock, the cartel office is expected to consider whether the two may effectively work in tandem to exert a powerful voice in Dresdner Bank's affairs. **********The cartel office will focus its investigation primarily on the insurance industry even though Allianz and Dresdner Bank have also been cooperating on financial services. Two years ago Allianz and Dresdner Bank agreed to jointly market various banking and insurance products, joining the movement where customers are able both to bank and to buy insurance at the same address. **********Allianz also announced on Tuesday that its premium income rose by about 20 percent to 38.3 billion Deutsche marks ($21.9 billion) in 1990 and predicted that it should rise a further 25 percent to 48 billion DM in 1991. Due to heavy payouts required by spring storms last year, however, profits dipped slightly to 1.006 billion DM in 1990 from 1.157 billion DM the year before. **********An exact forecast for profit growth was hard to make, Mr. Schieren said,because of uncertainties in Eastern Germany.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/10/busin.snippet: Executives of the world's major stock exchanges formally endorsed the virtue of self-regulation Wednesday at a time when their Hong Kong hosts are in the midst of a bitter standoff with local regulators.. Wrapping up their three-day annual confere...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/10/busin.body_text: **********Executives of the world's major stock exchanges formally endorsed the virtue of self-regulation Wednesday at a time when their Hong Kong hosts are in the midst of a bitter standoff with local regulators. **********Wrapping up their three-day annual conference here, the International Federation of Stock Exchanges adopted a declaration in which members committed themselves to self-regulation while pledging to cooperate with the government regulators. **********John J. Phelan, president of the Paris-based federation, said the organization was moving in the direction of making the declaration a prerequisite for membership. **********The meeting comes as the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission is insisting that the colony's exchange make its governing council more representative of high-volume traders and other market users. **********But the group of small brokers that has dominated the exchange for years has stubbornly resisted change. In August, these brokers effectively vetoed a voluntary reform package painstakingly negotiated by regulators and exchange executives, setting the stage for the imposition of a much harsher government plan. **********Last week, in a last-ditch attempt to stave off the government, the exchange proposed a new voluntary plan that will be put to a vote at the end of the month, one day before the government plan is scheduled to be imposed. **********Mr. Phelan, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, refused to comment on the situation, but he said that all of the federation's member exchanges have had internal and external squabbles over the years. **********In addition to the pledge on regulation, Mr. Phelan said that the federation was working toward meeting the recommendation of a task force of the group of 30 industrialized nations, which called on the world's markets to settle all trades within three days by 1992. **********Mr. Phelan said federation members had agreed to settle all trades within five days by 1994 and would probably reach the three-day target 18 months later. **********The federation, which consists of 31 full members and seven associates, seeks to foster cooperation among the world's securities exchanges.It has no regulatory powers and none of its decisions are legally binding. **********It is planning a workshop for emerging stock markets in London in December.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/31/your-.snippet: WHILE the world's stockmarkets have shown their international outlook with their reaction to global political issues, the U.S. market has concentrated more on domestic concerns. And one of the biggest has been the fat of the American banking indus...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/31/your-.main_headline: U.S. Banking Industry Finds Salvation in Merger Binge
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/31/your-.print_headline: U.S. Banking Industry Finds Salvation in Merger Binge
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/31/your-.body_text: **********WHILE the world's stockmarkets have shown their international outlook with their reaction to global political issues, the U.S. market has concentrated more on domestic concerns. And one of the biggest has been the fat of the American banking industry. Creaking under the strain of collapses, such as that of the Bank of New England around the turn of the year, the U.S. banks had to shake themselves up or die. **********Over the year 1990 an index of bank stocks compiled by the Wall Street firm Keefe, Bruyette and Woods plummeted 33 percent, compared to a 7 percent fall in the Standard & Poor's 500 index. Now the roles are reveresed, thanks to a merger wave that has been sweeping over the American banking system - one that is already looking very different from last year's model. **********The mergers have helped to make bank stocks among the hottest investment plays in U.S. stock market this year: An index of 50 bank stocks compiled by Salomon Brothers, the New York investment house, has surged by nearly 50 percent since the beginning of the year, compared with only a 17.5 percent rise by the Standard and Poor's 500 stock index. **********What's more, the merger binge, which so far has involved five of the 10 largest American banks, is believed to have only just begun. Before it is finished analysts say that the 12,300 U.S. banks that currently exist could be reduced to 6,000 or less. **********Analysts say the consolidation forces that are currently reshaping the U.S. banking system are not only more powerful than anything that has hit the industry before but they have also turned the traditional merger-related investment strategy on its head. **********Traditionally, profiting from mergers within a particular industry has meant focusing on targets. **********The hope was to find a company too weak to protect itself from a powerful predator who could pay several times the target company's book value to win control. In such circumstances, the target company's shareholders would reap a windfall while the stock price of the predator would slump. **********But in the current merger spree "the focus has shifted to the acquirers," said Richard Stillinger, an analyst at the Keefe Bruyette and Woods. **********"The market is saying that those banks likely to benefit most from the merger trend are those that are already performing strongly within their market," Stillinger said. **********A perfect example was the recent BankAmerica takeover of Los Angeles-based Security Pacific Corp. **********BankAmerica, one of the strongest and the most profitable U.S. banks, acquired the troubled Security Pacific for essentially its book value - or the value of its assets minus it liabilities. In the mid-80's, banks would routinely pay merger premiums of two or even three times book value to acquire a target. **********In addition to being able to buy a rival at a bargain-basement price, acquirers such as BankAmerica benefit by being able to cut hundreds of millions of dollars in costs from the combined bank consolidating overlapping operations. Such cost savings, according to analysts, will sooner or later translate into higher earnings. **********Thus in each of the major U.S. banking mergers to date - BankAmerica's takeover of Security Pacific, Chemical Bank's acquisition of Manufacturer's Hanover, and NCNB Corp.'s purchase of C and S/Sovran Corp.-the predator's stock price has surged. **********The alternative strategy of focusing on weak banks as merger candidates is extremely dangerous, analysts said. **********"Some weak banks are totally dependent on a turnaround in the real estate market over the next 12 months in order to survive," said Antony Polini at A.G. Edwards and Sons, a St. Louis-based securities firm. "Those are not the kind of dice I like to roll," he said. **********Analysts said strong banks that are potential acquires in the current merger wave are Fleet/Norstar Financial Group and Key Corp. in the Northeast; NCNB Corp. and First Union Corp. in the Southeast; Bank One, NBD Bancorp and Northwest Corp. in the Midwest; and BankAmerica and Wells Fargo and Co. on the West Coast. **********In the initial stage of the merger spree, the focus is on "in-market" mergers - this is, mergers between banks in the same market. **********Such Mergers like ManufacturersHanover and Chemical Bank deal in New York, present the greatest opportunity for immediate cost savings because the overlap in branch networks and other operations is substantial. **********Other such in-market deals reported or rumored to be pending include a merger between the bank of Boston and Shawmut National Corp. in New England, National City Corp. and Ameritrust Corp. in the Midwest and Wells Fargo and First Interstate Bancorp in California. **********But the ultimate result of the merger wave is expected to be a system similar to that in Britain or Japan where unlimited nationwide branching allows banks to become much larger. **********In that way the merge spree, by eliminating excess capacity and making banks less economically dependent on any one region, is expected to make the beleaguered U.S. banking system much healthier. **********Mr. Polini of A.G. Edwards said a second wave of mergers will focus on banks seeking to extend their market reach, to an adjoining state or to another area of the country. He said investors can play this stage of the game by either betting on acquirers or targets. **********Likely targets, he said, are those banks that are "strong players in local markets but not in their region and could therefore fit well into a larger company." **********Specifically, he said banks that are either first or second in market share in their state or region but still relatively small - meaning $10 billion or so in assets - will be natural takeover targets. **********Specific companies fitting that bill, he said, include Signet Banking Corp. in Virginia, which has $12 billion in assets, UJB Financial Corp. in New Jersey with $13 billion in assets and Michigan National Corp. in Michigan with $11 billion in assets. **********The key point in shopping for U.S. bank stocks, analysts say, is to buy quality at a reasonable price. Stocks with big takeover premiums already built into their price should be avoided. **********"Banks that are good performers in desirable markets are good merger bets," said Mr. Stillinger of Keefe Bruyette & Woods. "But they are also good investments if a merger does not occur," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/15/busin.main_headline: EC May Punish Deficits With Refundable Fines
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/15/busin.print_headline: EC May Punish Deficits With Refundable Fines
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/15/busin.body_text: **********The European Community, searching for a way to discipline member countries that run up big budget deficits in the future, is leaning toward a system of refundable fines as a sanction. **********Under the "carrot-and-stick" approach, which is backed by the EC Commission, member states with deficit problems would deposit money into an escrow account. The funds would be repaid later when budget criteria were met. **********The proposal was received favorably by EC finance ministers in Luxembourg last week. Several Community officials said it may emerge as a compromise solution to the sensitive issue of sanctions under EC plans for economic and monetary union, more attractive than other possible alternatives such as nonrefundable fines or a cutoff of EC program funds. **********"The escrow system seemed to get the most interest," an EC diplomat said of the Luxembourg meeting. "It adds a carrot to the stick, and this would help governments present the package to their publics in a much more attractive way, by saying, 'We'll get the money back later as long as we behave well.' " **********Enforcement of fiscal discipline is among the few outstanding issues in the Community's conference on monetary union, which is due to end before a Dec. 9-10 summit of EC leaders in the Netherlands. **********There is general agreement that member states should hold outstanding government debt below 60 percent of their gross national product. **********Germany insists that under monetary union, there must be strong sanctions on states with excessive deficits or else free-spending countries will drive up interest rates by borrowing too much. Britain opposes mandatory sanctions on sovereignty grounds and Greece resists any sort of economic sanctions, but most other countries accept the need for some type of discipline.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/07/busin.snippet: Japan's semi-public broadcaster NHK has abandoned one of its most cherished dreams, the creation of a worldwide news network that would have challenged the growing hegemony of Western broadcasters such as Cable News Network and the British Broadca...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/07/busin.body_text: **********Japan's semi-public broadcaster NHK has abandoned one of its most cherished dreams, the creation of a worldwide news network that would have challenged the growing hegemony of Western broadcasters such as Cable News Network and the British Broadcasting Corp. **********"We will keep the concept or spirit of the Global News Network, but as a business it's not feasible," NHK's chairman, Mikio Kawaguchi, said Friday at a press luncheon. **********GNN was the brainchild of NHK's previous chairman, Keiji Shima, a feisty former newsman who wanted the world to get an Asian perspective on the news to balance what he saw as the biased and increasingly dominant reporting of Western news organizations. **********"I don't want to badmouth Mr. Turner," Mr. Shima said a year ago of the creator of CNN, Ted Turner. "But CNN is trying to force U.S. news on the rest of the world." **********From a Japanese perspective, Mr. Shima's fears turned to ironic reality shortly afterward during the Gulf war, which was widely opposed in Japan. Then, the superior reporting resources of U.S. networks forced Japanese networks to rely on CNN and other U.S. broadcasters. The American networks gained effective control of Japanese airwaves as rapidly as U.S. fighters took control of Iraqi airspace. **********Mr. Shima envisaged GNN as a 24-hour English-language news service based in New York that would gather news footage from Asia, Europe and the United States. Each center would be responsible for eight-hour daily segments focusing on its own region. **********GNN was more than a challenge to the rapidly expanding market share of CNN and the BBC. By surrendering editorial responsibility to different regions, it was also a plea for a more pluralistic approach to broadcast journalism. **********Mr. Shima believed that while Asia should accept news filtered by Western reporters and editors, Asians should cover issues about Asia. Japan, if only out of necessity, would take the lead role. **********But the quest for a broader Japanese role in the global information order sparked fears, both at home and abroad, of a potential backlash in Asia, a region still bitter over Japanese atrocities earlier this century. NHK's satellite broadcasts, which spill over into parts of South Korea and other neighboring nations, have elicited official complaints from Seoul, which maintains an official ban on Japanese culture. NHK was forced to narrow the footprint of its broadcasts to prevent their reception abroad, but succeeded only partially because of the long and narrow shape of the Japanese archipelago. **********The proposal of Mr. Shima, who resigned earlier this year amid charges he lied to parliament to cover up a sexual liaison, also met suspicion among Western broadcasters critical of mainstream Japanese journalistic reporting, which tends to be scant on criticism or analysis and often numbingly long on detail. **********For these and other reasons, NHK had a hard time finding partners and found itself unable to foot annual costs estimated at more than 100 billion yen ($778 million.) "It seemed feasible until the summer," Mr. Kawaguchi said, "but now setting up GNN is totally out of the question." **********Instead, NHK plans to pursue a scaled-down version of GNN, a type of Asian news pool that would aim to boost the quality and exposure of Asian newscasts. "My ambition is to upgrade cooperation with Asian broadcasters to put Asian broadcasting in the top ranks," Mr. Kawaguchi said, adding that NHK also would seek to use more Asian-produced programs on daily life, culture and art. **********The attempt to carve out a greater Asian role for NHK comes as CNN and BBC are plugging into new satellite technology to expand their reach in the region. CNN says it serves more than 150,000 private homes and about 70,000 hotel rooms in Asia. Its coverage is set to broaden with the addition of broadcasts from Indonesian and Japanese satellites. **********The BBC also stepped into the competition in October with its 24-hour World Service Television. Its signal is beamed from Asiasat, a satellite whose mammoth signal reaches a potential 3 billion viewers from Turkey to Japan. Although the BBC's broadcasts come in only faintly in Japan, they were seen by many here as an infringement of Japanese sovereignty. **********Neither CNN nor the BBC expect to reach more than a tiny fraction of the massive Asian audience. Not only do most Asians not understand English well enough to enjoy watching newscasts in English, but it is also illegal for individuals to own satellite receiving dishes in China, Malaysia, South Korea and Singapore. **********But the transnational broadcasts could challenge the monopoly on news held by the region's mostly state-run broadcasters and provide competition that would sharpen NHK's skills. "We welcome the BBC venture," Mr. Kawaguchi said. "But we think we will reciprocate later," he added, hinting that NHK would eventually move onto the international broadcast scene in some form.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/03/your-.body_text: **********LIKE doctors disputing the meaning of a set of X-rays, two investment advisers who publish global-market newsletters have peered at their charts and tables and made opposite prognoses for the Hong Kong stock market. One thinks the patient will barely survive. **********The key Hang Seng index does present a fuzzy picture. It's up about one-third since the start of the year, rising from just above 3,000 to close off the week near its all-time high. But it took its time making its all-time high, exceeding the 1987 pre-crash level long after other major indices. **********Paul Melton, editor of The Outside Analyst, an advisory letter published in Amsterdam, has been selling his subscribers on the virtues of the Hong Kong market, where he finds prices downright cheap using traditional measures of valuation. **********Hong Kong stocks were trading at nine times their estimated 1992 earnings, Mr. Melton said in a recent edition. That's less than the 11.7 price-to-earnings they carried in the bear market year of 1981 and far less than the average ratio of 14.6 in the 15 years that ended in 1988. **********If shares rally until they hit that average price-to-earnings ratio, the Hang Seng will rise to 6,500. That's one big if, of course. Another is that earnings will meet their forecast of 30 percent growth from 1990 to 1992. **********Based on another valuation measure - book value, or the intrinsic worth of companies' assets - Hong Kong stocks are the cheapest of eight major markets that Mr. Melton studied. The market's price of 1.17 times book value is well below its five-year average of 1.60, meaning the Hang Seng could reach 5,500, were it to trade at that average ratio. **********"Once again, among the major markets, only Hong Kong looks attractive," he wrote. **********The market that Mr. Melton sees as undervalued is in danger of an imminent crash, if you ask Robert Prechter Jr., editor of Prechter's Global Market Perspective, published in Georgia. Mr. Prechter's specialty is Elliott wave theory, which holds that markets move in predictable five-wave patterns that reflect society's emotional extremes. **********The Hong Kong market, he wrote before the new high was reached, was completing a fifth wave of a "supercycle" that had propelled it through a decades-long bull run. During the last few years, the wave took the shape of the dread "diagonal triangle." **********"The drop following a diagonal triangle is usually dramatic and powerful," he wrote. "A few more points are all that is required to finish the pattern, so the potential for severe decline over the next few years is very high." **********Mr. Prechter seemed pleased that shares fell about 10 percent in the course of a week. Looking further out, he wrote: "When the Hang Seng index has crashed to below 1,000, people will be blaming it on the scheduled assumption of power by mainland China. It will be too late to act then, however." **********The index has recovered from its recent fall, and then some, and is closer to 6,500 than 1,000. There's no sure way to predict where it will go from here, but over time the Hong Kong market is likely to leave one of the two analysts feeling a little ill.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/03/busin.body_text: **********An Indonesian-controlled bank in Hong Kong has a tentative agreement to buy the subsidiary here of the scandal-torn Bank of Credit & Commerce International, the subsidiary's liquidator said Monday. **********Noel Gleeson, who was appointed by the colonial government in July to wind up BCCI's Hong Kong unit, said he had court approval of the sale agreement. **********It gives Hongkong Chinese Bank, controlled by the Lippo group of companies based in Indonesia, exclusive rights to buy BCCI's Hong Kong unit for eight weeks. If a firm deal cannot be reached by then, the bank will be put into liquidation. **********Mr. Gleeson stressed that a number of conditions would have to be satisfied before the sale could go through. These, he said, included Hongkong Chinese Bank's obtaining a guarantee against any hidden liabilities, and an agreement from depositors not to remove their funds from the new bank for a designated period after the sale. **********Under the agreement, the assets of Bank of Credit & Commerce Hong Kong, as the subsidiary is formally known, and a related deposit-taking company called Bank of Credit & Commerce Finance International are to be acquired by a new company controlled by Hongkong Chinese Bank. **********Mr. Gleeson's statement said Hongkong Chinese Bank would have at least a 51 percent interest in the new bank. **********The closing of BCCI's Hong Kong unit has been an embarrassment to the colony's government. As regulators elsewhere moved against BCCI branches in early July, the government first assured depositors that the bank was sound, then shut its doors three days later and refused to offer a guarantee to prospective buyers. **********Last month, however, the Abu Dhabi government, the majority shareholder of the parent BCCI, agreed in principle to issue a guarantee against unrecorded liabilities in the Hong Kong unit. **********According to analysts, the sale will likely hinge on what investigators from Hongkong Chinese Bank find during their detailed examination of Bank of Credit & Commerce Hong Kong's books. **********Hongkong Chinese Bank specializes in trade finance. Its parent, Lippo, is a collection of companies in Asia and the United States active in finance, real estate, insurance, manufacturing and information technology. Group sales are about $6 billion a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/09/busin.print_headline: In Hong Kong, Nothing Is as Certain as Volatility
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/09/busin.body_text: **********The word most often used to describe the Hong Kong stock market is "volatile," and it has certainly been living up to that reputation of late.Only a few weeks ago, brokers were predicting a long, difficult summer in which the market would be overshadowed by high local interest rates, the U.S. debate on renewing China's most-favored-nation trade status and uncertainty over the city's vast $16.2 billion airport development project. **********Then suddenly the sky cleared.The government reversed itself and engineered a lowering of the prime rate. China looks like it will retain its MFN status, albeit with some conditions. Andannounced an accord that puts the airport project back on track. **********All this good news translated into a stellar performance for the market last week. The Hang Seng index shot up 221 points, or more than a 6 percent gain, on near record volume. Flushed with euphoria, many analysts and brokers predicted the index was headed into uncharted territory. **********But the Hang Seng closed down 11.98 points Monday in reaction to the day's precipitous 720-point drop in Japan's Nikkei average. "This is a manic-depressive market," remarked Robert Broadfoot, managing director of Political & Economic Risk Consultancy Ltd. **********Monday's decline notwithstanding, a large number of brokers and fund managers believe the market is headed for a historic revaluation that will send prices far above the Hang Seng index's previous record of 3,950, set before the 1987 stock market collapse. **********"We feel the market is poised for the re-rating that it has long deserved, barring sharp falls in other markets," said Ravi Narain, research director at Peregrine Brokerage Ltd. **********Mr. Narain points out that companies on the Hong Kong exchange currently trade at an average price-earnings ratio of about 11, significantly below regional markets such as the Philippines, with an average P/E of 13.2, Thailand at 12 and Malaysia at 21. Yet only Hong Kong is expected to see corporate earnings increase this year. **********WITH THE AIRPORT AGREEMENT and thus a new modus vivendi between Britain, Hong Kong and China, Mr. Narain predicts that the Hong Kong market's P/E ratio should rise as high as 14, led by foreign institutional investors who have stayed on the sidelines for the most part during the airport imbroglio. **********Even a rise to the relatively conservative ratio of 12 would bring the Hang Seng index to a record 4,100 by the end of the year and to 4,900 by the end of 1992, if the 19 percent earnings growth predicted by Mr. Narain and other brokers for next year is accurate. **********But other brokers point out that the Hong Kong exchange, even though it may trade at a discount, still has been one of the world's top-performing markets since the beginning of the year. **********"One doesn't really like the market to storm up so quickly," said Clive Weedon, research manager at ChinTung Securities Ltd, one of the colony's top brokers. "That is not healthy. One should always keep an eye on overseas markets. No market as cheap as this can go it alone forever." **********Mr. Weedon believes the airport deal will mostly benefit companies outside Hong Kong and may strain the finances of the Hong Kong government, which has promised to leave at least $3.2 billion in its Treasury when the Chinese take over in mid-1997. Already, he said, the government has cut back its spending on infrastructure projects to save for the airport, leaving local construction companies in the lurch. **********He recommends local property companies such as Cheung Kong Holdings and Henderson Land because they specialize in residences that are being snapped up by Hong Kong Chinese who want to secure housing before 1997.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/busin.print_headline: Murky Statistics Cloud East German Picture
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/busin.body_text: **********New industrial production figures show a confusing pattern in Eastern Germany's struggling economy, making even the government skeptical about any trend as yet. **********The government announced Tuesday that industrial production in Eastern Germany had risen 5.4 percent in May over April, but had fallen by 11.3 percent in April from March. **********Since this key indicator has been seesawing ever since it began to be computed last December, analysts see Eastern Germany as a statistical no man's land in which figures inherited from the old regime appear more discredited than ever and calculations remain difficult. **********The murkiness of the Eastern German situation also complicates planning for the Bundesbank as the central bank council prepares to meet on Thursday to decide whether to raise key interest rates. **********With many economists warning that too aggressive a rate hike might jar the already weakening economy, it makes it all the more difficult for the Bundesbank to steer policy when Eastern Germany - home to nearly a fifth of the population - remains largely a blind spot. **********[In Bonn, Economics Minister Jürgen Möllemann launched a rare attack on the Bundesbank, warning that a rise in interest rates could "seriously injure the delicate first shoots of recovery in Eastern Germany," Reuters reported. **********[Higher rates could dampen willingness to make investments needed in the East. However, Mr. Möllemann's comments caught many observers by surprise because Bonn usually leaves the Bundesbank free to set monetary policy.] **********Economists generally doubt that the economy in Eastern Germany will turn around until early next spring. After that, growth is expected to be halting and fragile. **********Such impressions may have to remain without a solid statistical foundation for some time, however, because current figures cannot be seasonally adjusted or compared in the usual way to figures from the previous year, federal statisticians said. **********They noted that it also takes longer to make calculations about Eastern Germany. Industrial production figures for June, for example, may not be ready for another month. **********Mr. Möllemann, often adept at finding rays of hope even in the Eastern German economy, said in a press release that the new figures do not yet unmistakably show whether the drop in industrial production has bottomed out. **********The new figures show that industrial production in May was 39 percent lower than its level in the third quarter of last year, the best comparable period. **********One of the few discernible patterns appears to be a steady revival in the category of stone and gravel processing, a reliable barometer of the construction industry, which in turn is often an early signal of general recovery.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/04/world.body_text: **********After a long and angry debate, the Israeli Cabinet today voted to accept as a new member of the Government a small right-wing party that advocates expelling all the Palestinians from the occupied territories. **********Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir pushed through the appointment of the Moledet Party -- the Hebrew name means homeland -- over the opposition of senior members of his Government to expand his coalition to 66 seats in the 120-seat Parliament. That is considered a safe governing majority. No longer will any but the very largest of the minor parties have the power to bring the Government down. **********Mr. Shamir has said that like other Cabinet ministers and like members of the opposition, he disagrees with Moledet's platform and will not allow the idea of "transfer," as mass expulsion is euphemistically known here, to be discussed in his Government. Still, the appointment adds a sharp right edge to a Government that is already the most right-wing in Israel's history. **********Several of the most senior members of the Government -- the Ministers of Justice, Health, Finance, Defense and Foreign Affairs -- voted against the new coalition agreement or abstained, participants at the meeting said. Vote totals from the closed meeting were not disclosed.  Charges of Racism **********In several cases, dissenting ministers said they considered the Moledet Party to be racist. And they openly worried that the move would jeopardize Israel's new-found international standing as a result of its military restraint in the face of Iraqi missile attacks. **********"The view represented by Moledet is one that we reject out of hand," said Health Minister Ehud Olmert, a close adviser to Prime Minister Shamir. "It is a moral distortion and is likely to bring a moral stain onto the Government." **********Opposition politicians said they were appalled. **********"This will cause terrible damage to the state, especially since we are now protesting against the racism of Saddam Hussein and the racism of Germany," said Ran Cohen of the leftist Citizens' Rights Party. **********A recent national survey by the Hanoch Smith research concern, taken in December, found that 49 percent of the nation's Jews favor expelling the Palestinian residents of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip if no peaceful solution to the Israeli-Arab conflict is found. Forty percent disagreed with that idea. **********The Moledet Party's leader, retired Gen. Rehavim Zeevi, will be a minister without portfolio and, more important, a member of the ministerial committee on defense and security. Just after the vote, Mr. Zeevi said he would set up a committee to advise Mr. Shamir on security matters, as Mr. Shamir had requested.  Arabs to Get Gas Masks **********As the Cabinet was voting on the Government's new members, the army announced that it had decided to begin large-scale distribution of gas masks to Palestinians in the West Bank. **********The last four Iraqi Scud missiles fired at Israel, including two Saturday night and this morning, have fallen near Palestinian communities in the West Bank, although no one has been injured in any of those attacks. **********Just before the war began Jan. 17, the Israeli Supreme Court ordered the army to distribute gas masks to all 1.75 million Palestinians in the occupied territories. The army objected, saying the masks would not be needed since Iraq seemed unlikely to target Palestinians. **********But when the court learned that all of the roughly 100,000 Jewish settlers in the occupied territories had already been given gas masks, it ordered that they be distributed to the Arabs, too. **********Only then did the army reveal that it had only about 175,000 masks for the Palestinians, 10 percent of the number needed. In any case, on Jan. 15 all of the Arab residents of the territories were put under house arrest, meaning they have not been allowed to leave their homes for any reason without permission. So the distribution of even the few masks on hand has been held up; about 50,000 of those had been distributed before today. **********Today, Brig. Gen. Freddy Zach, deputy administrator of the military government in the occupied territories, said masks would be given first to those Palestinians living in areas where the recent missiles have fallen, near Tel Aviv.  Support for Hussein Cited **********Explaining the 20-day, open-ended curfew, which Arabs say is having devastating effects on their economy, General Zach noted that the Palestinians still support President Hussein. **********"They still believe that eventually he will win," the general said. "They still believe that he has the secret weapon, that he can destroy half of Israel as he had promised several months ago." **********At the same time, a Jerusalem court today ordered that the jail sentence for Sari Nusseibeh, a leading Palestinian political figure jailed on a charge of spying for Iraq, be cut in half -- from six months to three. **********Last week, the army accused Mr. Nusseibeh of passing data to Baghdad through the Palestine Liberation Organization detailing where Scud missiles had landed, so the Iraqis could improve their targeting. Mr. Nusseibeh vigorously denied the charge, and after viewing the state's secret evidence today, the court decided that the sentence was excessive. **********A judge ruled that the army had no reason to hold Mr. Nusseibeh any longer than the Persian Gulf war lasted, which the judge decided would be no more than three months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.body_text: **********Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister, appealed to the Bush Administration today to extend new food credits to the Soviet Union, asserting that the fate of democratic change in Moscow may be at stake. **********As Mr. Shevardnadze made his remarks in his first appearance in the United States since resigning his post in December, President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania offered the opposite advice only a few blocks away during the first day of his own visit to Washington. **********The presence of the two Soviet political figures and their conflicting views underscored a difficult choice the Administration is facing. **********The Administration is nearing a decision whether to guarantee $1.5 billion in additional commercial bank loans for Soviet purchases of American grain. Mr. Bush said last week he was not inclined to authorize the guarantees, but officials said Mr. Shevardnadze might have helped sway Mr. Bush during their talks at the White House today. **********The new loans would supplement $1 billion in credits guaranteed by the Commodity Credit Corporation last December when the Administration waived the restrictions prohibiting preferential trade treatment with nations that restrict emigration. Moscow has already spent nearly all of the original credits. **********Mr. Shevardnadze linked the future of Soviet politics to the uncertain economic situation and the possibilities for increased cooperation with the West. He echoed a request that the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, made in a recent letter to the Agriculture Department for $1.5 billion in new credit guarantees. **********"This is a very acute issue with us now," Mr. Shevardnadze said, "and I want to say quite straightforwardly that a decision which will be taken in Washington will to a large extent determine the fate of reform and democracy in the Soviet Union. I want to stress this, that we have very little time." **********Mr. Shevardnadze, in an interview after his meeting at the White House with Mr. Bush, said he had consulted with Mr. Gorbachev before visiting Washington, but he insisted that he was not carrying a message from the Soviet leader. Mr. Shevardnadze said Mr. Bush listened attentively to his appeal but did not commit himself one way or the other. **********"But I had the impression he understands how acute this question is with us," he added. **********But Mr. Landsbergis said he would counsel Mr. Bush against extending new loan guarantees until Moscow liberalizes its policies. "It shouldn't be given to the Soviet Union to prevent it from adopting a path of dictatorship," he said in an interview. "It should only be given after it demonstrates that it is going down the road of democratization." U.S. Recognition Urged **********Mr. Landsbergis said he would tell Mr. Bush when they meet on Wednesday that Lithuania needs Washington's formal diplomatic recognition to prevent another Soviet military crackdown against his breakaway republic. The Soviet Union annexed Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia in 1940 as a result of a secret pact with Nazi Germany. **********Prime Ministers Edgar Savisaar of Estonia and Ivars Godmanis of Latvia are also scheduled to meet with Mr. Bush this week, even as American officials began analyzing the meaning of a meeting that Mr. Gorbachev had with Rupert Murdoch, the Australian media executive, in which he upbraided the Administration for pursuing policies that seemed to undercut his authority. Mr. Gorbachev's comments were carried by the Soviet press agency Tass. **********A State Department official said: "There is a sensitive, delicate political balance here between supporting Baltic aspirations for independence and keeping our lines open to the Soviet leadership. That's not always easy to do." **********Administration officials have said they are undecided on the latest plea for grain credits, expressing concerns that it would be unwise to extend them to Moscow at a time when its creditworthiness is questionable. "We are not helping them by creating another Poland financially," the State Department official said. But he acknowledged that Mr. Shevardnadze's advice could strengthen Mr. Gorbachev's case.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/world.main_headline: PACT IS REACHED TO REDUCE NUCLEAR ARMS; BUSH AND GORBACHEV TO MEET THIS MONTH; 7 POWERS GIVE SOVIETS NEW ECONOMIC ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/world.print_headline: SUMMIT IN LONDON; PACT IS REACHED TO REDUCE NUCLEAR ARMS; BUSH AND GORBACHEV TO MEET THIS MONTH; 7 POWERS GIVE SOVIETS NEW ECONOMIC ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/world.body_text: **********After nine years of negotiation, the Soviet Union and the United States reached agreement today on a strategic arms treaty, the first to mandate reductions by the superpowers, and President Bush immediately agreed to meet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow late this month. **********Then Mr. Gorbachev, the proud leader of the nation where Communism first flowered, sat down with the heads of the seven most powerful capitalist nations and asked them for help in reforming an economic system that has all but collapsed. Almost 75 years after the Bolshevik Revolution, the Soviet President's pleas represented an admission of economic failure. **********Mr. Gorbachev laid his plans before the Western leaders in what another participant described as "an eloquent performance." Officials taking part in the closed meeting reported that Mr. Gorbachev insisted that Soviet progress toward a market economy and private ownership of property was irreversible, but that he made no new proposals. Gorbachev's Courage Hailed PHE> **********Nevertheless, Mr. Gorbachev won praise from the leaders of the seven countries -- the Group of Seven. Mr. Bush said the Soviet leader had shown "enormous courage" in pushing ahead with reforms. **********"It's not going to be quick or easy to implement change in the Soviet Union," Mr. Bush said after the meeting, "but we believe President Gorbachev has made an irrevocable commitment." **********Britain's Prime Minister, John Major, who played host to the group's 17th annual economic summit meeting, said: "This has been a day I believe that history may well see as a landmark. It will be seen as a first step toward helping the Soviet Union become a full member of the world economic community."  [ Excerpts from the Bush-Gorbachev and Gorbachev-Major news conferences, and from the summit's economic declaration, are on pages A10 and A12. ] **********The Moscow meeting was tentatively scheduled for July 30-31. **********Under the provisions of the arms treaty to be signed there, the overall number of nuclear weapons in each side's arsenal will be cut by 25 to 35 percent. The American arsenal will be reduced from about 12,000 warheads and bombs to about 9,000, while Moscow's stockpile is to be reduced from roughly 11,000 to roughly 7,000. **********While Mr. Gorbachev made no specific requests for immediate financial assistance, officials of several nations said, and left little time for questions, he asked the group to "take a step forward" in developing greater cooperation with his country. **********"The ice has started moving; the icebreaker is on its way toward renewal," the Soviet leader told reporters later. But he quickly added, "There is need for movement from the other side," meaning the West. **********Mr. Gorbachev came away with the prospect of a bit more Western aid than had seemed likely a few days ago, including pledges of a "special association" with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, extensive programs of technical assistance and an early visit to Moscow by the group's finance ministers to discuss further measures. But he won no promise of major infusions of cash. **********In addition, German officials promised that they would invite the Soviet leader to attend next year's economic summit conference in Munich, and President Francois Mitterrand of France said that he favored ultimately asking the Soviet Union to join the club, making it a Group of Eight. **********At the news conference tonight, Mr. Major said the meeting had established "a partnership with the Soviet Union on a new and better footing," as a first step toward Moscow's integration into the world economic system. **********Mr. Gorbachev called the three-hour session "one of the most important meetings of our time." **********"Today has meant a lot," the seemingly weary Soviet leader said. **********"It's been a good day for the United States," Mr. Bush replied. A Qualified Success **********Merely by winning admission to the forum of capitalist leaders this week, Mr. Gorbachev can claim a victory. But some things that most of the participants would have liked to give him, including full membership now or soon in the International Monetary Fund and greater drawing rights at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, were blocked by the United States and Japan. **********Mr. Gorbachev had to overcome American opposition and that of hard-liners in his own country to gain an invitation to London. Still, some members of the Gorbachev delegation expressed open disappointment today with what he had achieved. One said that "the Soviet Union doesn't understand Western economics, and the Western nations don't understand Soviet politics." **********Still, the arms accord is likely to help Mr. Gorbachev with his increasingly restive people, as it will free scarce resources for domestic concerns. **********By the time that the strategic arms reduction treaty is carried out, probably in 1999, the number of American warheads on weapons that can reach the Soviet Union will drop by about 25 percent, and the comparable Soviet total will fall by about 35 percent. The treaty puts sub-limits on various weapons systems and is particularly tough on the Soviet SS-18 missile, the most powerful in either arsenal. **********For two days, the prospect of Mr. Gorbachev's arrival here had hung over those attending the conference -- the leaders of Britain, the United States, France, Canada, Italy, Germany and Japan. Today, as his motorcade of Zil limousines flashed across central London from one meeting to another, he utterly dominated the scene, eclipsing and in some cases eliminating debate on other issues. **********The summit conference never really came to grips with the environment, referring discussion of global warming and the rain forests to a United Nations conference next year on the subject and thus avoiding an all-out clash between the United States and the Europeans, especially Britain. Tariff Issue Deferred **********On another difficult matter, described by everyone as crucial, the group merely pledged to complete by the end of the year the current round of talks designed to bring up to date the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. This is precisely what was promised in Houston a year ago and not delivered. **********Mr. Major, who presided over this week's sessions in a bright and breezy way that contrasted sharply with the stern, hectoring manner of his predecessor, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, said it had been "a friendly and very frank summit." He added, "People did speak their minds clearly and comprehensively and on occasions in an unforgettable way." **********Much of the groundwork was laid before today. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, the Soviet Foreign Minister, had resolved all outstanding questions on the all-important arms treaty, except one technical issue, at a series of meetings in Washington that ended Sunday. That related to the definition of a new missile, in terms of its throw-weight, or destructive capacity, for treaty purposes. **********White House aides said Mr. Bessmertnykh asked this morning for a meeting with Mr. Baker just before Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev were to meet for lunch at the United States Ambassador's residence. A senior American official said the Foreign Minister brought new proposals, and after a flurry of conferences, the President and his advisers agreed that the final obstacle had been overcome. 'Our Hospitality' **********Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev spent most of their lunch discussing economic and other matters, then slipped into an adjoining room to ratify what had been agreed to on arms. **********Beaming, the two men met briefly with reporters, Mr. Gorbachev saying that his country was "ready to give our hospitality to the President of the United States and Mrs. Bush." He had sought the Moscow meeting for the last year. **********"Before you change your mind, we accept with pleasure," replied Mr. Bush, who had held out for the treaty as a condition for making the trip. **********Neither side was willing to specify what the final arrangement was, because neither wanted to appear to have made the final concession, lest it be seen as soft by the legislative hard-liners in Washington and Moscow whose backing will be needed if the treaty is to be ratified. **********British and American experts said the difficulties in reaching agreement were more political than military. The Soviet Union is believed to be developing a more advanced, more powerful version of one of its missiles. **********The Administration wanted to head that off, remembering the deployment of the SS-19 after the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty. Critics of the 1972 agreement charged that its negotiators had failed to get tight enough language. Gorbachev Explains His Country **********At his meeting with the Group of Seven, Mr. Gorbachev made no specific requests for monetary aid. **********"He really was trying to explain more what was going on inside the Soviet Union, what the pressures were, what he was up against in terms of history, if you will," Mr. Bush reported. "He really stopped short of what some predicted might be on his agenda." **********Mr. Major reportedly opened the meeting by telling the Soviet leader: "You are among well-wishers. The challenges you face are formidable, but the opportunities are limitless." **********He said candidly, however, that the West expected reform in property rights, market prices, the breakup of state monopolies and the establishment of a Western-style legal system. **********Mr. Gorbachev, in turn, spoke of the need to dismantle barriers to the Soviet economy, including trade restrictions and lack of access to loans. **********Daniel Bernard, the French spokesman, described the Russian's presentation as a "particularly rich" 30-minute speech that dealt with the relationship of the Soviet republics to the central Government in Moscow and with his own reform intentions. **********A British official said Mr. Gorbachev's explanation of his economic policies today was not significantly different from the plan detailed in a 23-page letter he sent to the seven leaders last week. **********According to one official, Mr. Gorbachev's one-hour opening statement this afternoon and his remarks at the news conference tonight were not "very specific on details." **********He left unclear, this official said, the answers to such questions as exactly how the Soviets intended to privatize state-owned enterprises and liberalize controlled prices. **********"There was movement in the right direction," an official said, adding that Mr. Major would try to get clarification during his talks with Mr. Gorbachev here Thursday. **********In a briefing tonight, Mr. Gorbachev's chief spokesman, Vitaly Ignatenko, disclosed few details of the private discussions today. He did say that Mr. Gorbachev had discussed the need to create a stabilization fund to bolster the ruble, as a way to more quickly complete the conversion of the ruble on international currency markets. However, he did not seek Western aid for such a fund. "Today was not the occasion" for that, Mr. Major explained. Status of Soviet Republics **********Mr. Ignatenko said Mr. Gorbachev spoke at length about the relationship between the central Government and the republics, and assured Western leaders that he had a mandate to speak for all the Soviet Union in his attempts to press forward with an agenda of economic reform. **********A six-point program of assistance was ultimately agreed on, but some of the points struck economists as imprecise and redundant, an attempt to make a small package look bigger. The Western summit partners committed themselves to these goals: ***********Setting up the special relationship with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, leaving it up to the institutions and the Soviet Union to negotiate the terms. ***********Urging other international organizations to make their knowledge and skills available to Moscow. ***********Offering technical assistance to help the Soviets exploit energy resources, improve food distribution, increase nuclear safety, make their transportation system more efficient and convert military industries to civilian ones. ***********Helping expand trade with the West and with Eastern European nations. ***********Sending Mr. Major to Moscow before the end of the year to check on the progress of reform and, if appropriate, to recommend further Western aid. ***********Sending the finance ministers' group to Moscow very soon. **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, which has supplied most of the Western aid to the Soviet Union in the last year, had hoped for bolder action. But he spoke of "a good start." **********Mr. Mitterrand said "we must, really must, reach out," and his aides said that he, too, would have liked to do much more to help the beleaguered Mr. Gorbachev than was agreed to in London.
