https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/03/busin.main_headline: Shearson Is Paying $750,000 To Settle With Big Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/03/busin.print_headline: Shearson Is Paying $750,000 To Settle With Big Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/03/busin.body_text: **********Shearson Lehman Brothers has agreed to pay $750,000 to the New York Stock Exchange to settle accusations of wide-ranging violations of the exchange's rules at one of the brokerage firm's most profitable branches. **********In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Shearson said it had agreed to settle a variety of charges about improper practices at a Manhattan office, known as the Water Street branch, without admitting or denying guilt. The charges concern activities that occurred in 1986, when the market was booming. **********In the filing, Shearson said that as part of the settlement it would accept a censure from the Big Board and provide the exchange with a written report detailing the findings of an audit of the procedures and controls in Shearson's margin loan department.  'In Compliance' **********A spokesman for the firm said yesterday that Shearson had tried to correct any problems at the branch. "The matters in question occurred virtually five years ago," the spokesman said. "The firm has long since taken the steps to insure that the branch is in compliance with all relevant regulations." **********The settlement was a strong blow to the salesmen at the Water Street branch, which some employees said acted virtually as a separate entity from the rest of the firm. The branch "had a fairly lax atmosphere," one Shearson executive said yesterday, speaking on condition that his name not be used. **********Employees at Shearson and other Wall Street executives said that the charges included accusations that purchases were made for customer accounts without the knowledge or permission of the clients. If clients objected to the purchases, the securities were often "parked" in a series of inactive accounts, Wall Street executives said. The securities were said to have been improperly held in those accounts until they were subsequently sold to another customer or into the marketplace. **********Those activities were only part of a larger series of rule violations. Wall Street executives said that, because securities were being purchased without permission and sold into inactive accounts, the branch failed to keep proper books and records and also failed to characterize the trades correctly in its records. Those violations are listed in the S.E.C. filing. **********In addition, people briefed on the settlement said the the Big Board charged that a number of salesmen had churned customer accounts. In churning, a broker will buy and sell securities excessively, thus increasing commission income for the broker. **********The Big Board accusations also focused on claims that the Water Street branch improperly extended margin loans to clients seeking to buy securities. The Water Street branch was said to have allowed customers facing heavy losses more time than they would have been allowed under the rules of the exchange to put up additional cash to avoid having securities sold. **********Some changes have occurred at the Water Street branch since the investigation by the New York Stock Exchange began last year. Seymour Passman, who had been the branch manager, left his position in January and now works at Shearson as a broker. Also, Wall Street executives said, a number of the brokers at the Water Street branch have been dismissed as a result of the information obtained in the inquiry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/21/world.main_headline: Church Council Calls for Truce in Gulf War
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/21/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF; Church Council Calls for Truce in Gulf War
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/21/world.body_text: **********The World Council of Churches, ending its seventh assembly, called today for an immediate and unconditional cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war, followed by an unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait and then regional negotiations aimed at a comprehensive peace. **********But the process of debate was passionate and disorganized, with some amendments approved by large majorities and later overturned, including one that would have committed the council to a more explicitly pacifist position. **********The confusion and ambivalence, delegates said, reflected both the urgency of the debate on the possible eve of ground combat and the churches' own long ambivalence about the theory of a "just war." **********"There is an increasing judgment in the churches that the technical sophistication and destruction capacity of modern weapons makes the idea of 'just war' not only obsolete but immoral," said Dr. Janice Love, co-moderator of the Public Issues Committee, which drafted the statement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/07/world.main_headline: YUGOSLAVIA TENSE AS ITS PEACE TALKS REACH STALEMATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/07/world.print_headline: CONFLICT IN YUGOSLAVIA; YUGOSLAVIA TENSE AS ITS PEACE TALKS REACH STALEMATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/07/world.body_text: **********Talks aimed at averting confrontation between the Yugoslav national Government and the republic of Slovenia broke down today after the independence-minded Slovenes rebuffed an ultimatum to relinquish international border posts by Sunday. **********Brinkmanship, bellicose language and diplomatic impasse raised tensions elsewhere in the country as the talks were interrupted in Ljubjlana, the Slovenian capital. But a cease-fire between the national army and Slovenia's militia generally held. **********Senior officials of the Croatian and Serbian republics said their forces were girding for a possible war with each other after two days of fighting between police officers and ethnic Serbs in Croatia.  An Ambiguous Warning **********In Belgrade, the national capital, Gen. Veljko Kadijevic, Yugoslavia's Defense Minister, said that army units were being harassed by Slovenian forces and that the military would soon propose "appropriate decisions" to Yugoslavia's collective presidency. **********But in an ambiguous statement, he strongly hinted that the army would not oppose Slovenia's secession. He said his troops' most important task was to disarm rapidly growing local militias. **********On Slovenian television, Vasil Tupurkovski, a member of Yugoslavia's collective presidency, warned: "Tensions are very high both in Slovenia and the rest of the country. Everything could collapse with a small incident, because the passions and emotions are enormous. **********"I hope that reason wins out with everyone: with those in Slovenia, those in the Yugoslav presidency and at the top of the Yugoslav national army. There is no other solution except a political and peaceful one. I am convinced that war is in no one's interest." **********Bluffing and bluster are part of politics in the Balkans, and tough talk is frequently followed by last-minute accord. It was not clear whether today's round of contradictory statements was a prelude to compromise or conflict. **********The most immediate potential flash point was noon Sunday deadline set by the collective presidency for Slovenia to relinquish international border posts. **********The Slovenes took control of customs stations along the country's northern border after voting to secede from Yugoslavia on June 25, and held them in the face of an attack by Yugoslav Army forces. The border posts are viewed in Slovenia as a symbol of sovereignty.  Fighting Leaves 60 Dead **********In the fighting, which reached its fiercest point on Tuesday, 60 people have been killed, including civilians, militiamen and soldiers, and 288 wounded. **********After a brief cease-fire, Yugoslavia's collective presidency agreed to return the army to its barracks but demanded that Slovenia release captured soldiers, dismantle roadblocks and give up the border posts. The presidency set a series of deadlines for compliance with its demands, but did not say what would happen if Slovenia defied the order. **********So far, the Slovenes have refused to accept a compromise proposed by the national Government under which the Slovenes could keep the border posts but would give the customs revenue to the Government. **********Many Slovenes believe that the army is poised to impose the presidency's deadline with a crushing show of force. **********Still, it appeared today that the Slovenes' intransigence might be part of a negotiating strategy under which they would present their fallback positions on Sunday in a meeting with European Community observers who are now in Yugoslavia.  Consequences Not Specified **********Stipe Mesic, the Croat who heads the presidency, insisted today that the army has no authority to move against the Slovenes, and would not do so without civilian approval. The presidency's ultimatum does not specify the consequences if Slovenia refuses to accept its conditions. **********General Kadijevic, the Defense Minister, said in his nationally televised address that the army would seek the presidency's approval for any steps, suggesting that Mr. Mesic had indeed succeeded in restoring some measure of civilian control. **********Military intentions remain a subject of intense speculation, which was only deepened by the general's remarks today. Some say the army is simply trying to play a role as mediator, but many in Croatia and Serbia see it as predominantly the tool of the Serbs. About 70 percent of its officer corps is of Serbian origin; its foot soldiers are conscripts from all the republics.  Placatory Words From General **********General Kadijevic acknowledged that the operation against Slovenia had been a mistake and asked: **********"Why would soldiers of other nationalities die in Slovenia if, for the Slovenes, they are foreigners and occupiers? It is not our goal to kill Slovenes if it is not their desire to live in Yugoslavia." **********In Croatia and Serbia, however, the talk today was of war. **********Croatia's Information Minister, Hrvoje Hitrec, said in an interview that fighting between the two republics could break out within days and if it did, it would make the initial fighting between Slovenia and the national army look like "Disneyland." He said that Croatia has canceled all leaves for doctors and drawn up plans to mobilize 100,000 reservists within hours. **********Mr. Mesic said that fighting between Serbia and Croatia could result in thousands of casaulties.  Restive Serbian Minority **********Croatia, the second largest of the Yugoslav republics with 4.7 million people, has a Serbian minority of about 600,000 within its borders. The Serbs have stepped up their challenge to the Croatian government since Tuesday's declaration of independence. **********Croatian police officials charged today that many of the armed men attacking local police officers and militiamen live in Serbia. The officials said they would soon begin a major operation to arrest the Serbs who control local police stations in a number of towns.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/26/busin.main_headline: MURDOCH SELLING 9 U.S. PUBLICATIONS FOR $600 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/26/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; MURDOCH SELLING 9 U.S. PUBLICATIONS FOR $600 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/26/busin.body_text: **********Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born publisher whose wide holdings in the United States include New York magazine, 20th Century Fox and several television stations, agreed yesterday to sell most of his magazines in this country for more than $600 million, people involved in the talks said. **********The buyer is a partnership controlled by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts, the New York buyout firm that was also involved in the recent purchase of the Bank of New England. **********As head of the News Corporation, Mr. Murdoch, now a United States citizen, went on an acquisition binge in the 1980's, but the debt he took on along the way has proved a huge burden. In February he had reached agreement with bankers to change the terms on much of his $8.2 billion in debt.  TV Guide Is Not in Deal **********Although the agreement with the banks did not specify asset sales, analysts had always assumed that $800 million or more would have to be raised for him to be able to meet his obligations. **********The partnership, called K-III Holdings, is buying nine publications, the most profitable of which is The Racing Form, a daily newspaper that has covered thoroughbred racing nationwide with no serious competition. **********The other publications are Soap Opera Digest, Soap Opera Weekly, New York, Seventeen, Premiere, European Travel & Life, Automobile and New Woman. Mirabella, the fashion magazine, and TV Guide were not part of the sale, the people said. Heavy Debt Incurred **********The price was fairly low compared with what the magazines might have fetched in the 1980's, but Peter Diamandis, former head of Diamandis Communications, said that given how treacherous the magazine market has been lately, Mr. Murdoch got a decent price. **********But if the price was low, Mr. Murdoch had little choice. Like the heads of many other media companies, both domestic and foreign, Mr. Murdoch determined to expand his company internationally in the 1980's, presumably on the theory that only big global companies would prosper. Media executives justified that expansion on the theory that their properties generated so much cash that they could comfortably pay off part of the debt they had incurred, or, if neccessary, sell some properties at ever-rising prices to meet those obligations. **********In the United States alone, Mr. Murdoch bought the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation, Metromedia's televison stations, TV Guide, a variety of magazines and book publishers. **********But by this year Mr. Murdoch's cash flow was insufficient to meet debt payments and he was forced to sign the agreement with the banks to renegotiate his loans. **********To some degree, the theory has proved true that diversification within media would pay off. Fox's movies "Home Alone" and "Edward Scissorhands" were both surprise hits. Because they were relatively low-budget films and were highly profitable, they took some of the pressure off the News Corporation. But not enough to avoid a substantial sale of assets. **********And so last month, after much speculation, the magazines were put on the market. Mr. Murdoch, perhaps because he was so aware that in the current economy it would be hard to sell the unsuccessful properties, was determined to sell all the publications as a group.  Interest From Other Buyers **********A number of buyers were apparently interested, including Reed International, the British concern that has been expanding its American publishing business and whose properties include Variety, the entertainment trade paper. **********But the sale was not easy because a number of Mr. Murdoch's magazines do not make money, according to proprietary data. **********Of those that do, The Racing Form is by far the most profitable, having had cash flow last year of $25 million, according to industry estimates. **********Soap Opera Digest is also considered a desirable property. Last year it had $15 million in cash flow on sales of $37 million.  Magazine Business Struggles **********Mr. Murdoch sold his publications for about 10 times their last year's cash flow, or the cash the magazines generated. That is a relatively low multiple compared with what the publications might have fetched in the 1980's. Mr. Diamandis said the going rate was about seven times cash flow. "In the late 1980's, the multiples were as high as 15 times cash flow," he said. **********Soap Opera Weekly is a relatively new publication that is barely making money. **********The data on New York magazine reflect not only how difficult the magazine business has become, but particularly how tough the New York market is. Last year the weekly publication had cash flow of $7 million on revenues of $47 million. Its cash flow was down from $9.7 million a year earlier, and its revenues were relatively flat. **********On the other hand, some magazines, like Seventeen, have prospered despite new competition from publications like Sassy. The monthly magazine aimed at teen-age girls had cash flow of $9.6 million last year on net revenues of $47 million. That profit was up from $8.4 million a year earlier.  Losses for New Publications **********The data also indicate how difficult it is to start a new publication and how long it takes before that publication makes a profit. For example, Premiere, a magazine that covers the movie industry, lost $1.6 million last year on revenues of $14.5 million. Although it continues to lose money, the losses have declined. The previous year it had lost $5 million on sales of $11 million. **********European Travel & Life also continues to lose money, having a negative cash flow last year of $984,000. Still, that figure is down sharply from the previous year's loss of $2.4 million, giving some indication that eventually it may become profitable. **********Mr. Murdoch did not sell TV Guide, which many industry experts say was Mr. Murdoch's biggest acquisition error. The News Corporation paid $3 billion for a publication considered to have been worth $2 billion or less. **********K-III Holdings was formed in February 1989 by Kohlberg, Kravis and several former executives at Macmillan Inc., the publishing and information services company. Since then it has been involved in various acquisitions or proposed acquisitions in publishing. In May 1990 it bought Ward's Communications, which puts out a highly regarded auto industry newsletter, and in December it bought the assets of Field Publications and Funk & Wagnalls.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/27/busin.main_headline: BANK DEPOSIT FUND NEARLY INSOLVENT, U.S. AUDITOR SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/27/busin.print_headline: BANK DEPOSIT FUND NEARLY INSOLVENT, U.S. AUDITOR SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/27/busin.body_text: **********The nation's top auditor said today that many more banks were effectively bankrupt than regulators had recognized, and that therefore the program that insures depositors was "nearly insolvent." **********The official, Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, suggested that a quick way to fix the fund, which is financed through premiums paid by banks, would be to raise $15 billion through additional contributions from the banking industry. **********"The bank insurance fund is nearly insolvent, and I cannot overemphasize how important it is to restore it as quickly as possible," Mr. Bowsher told the Senate Banking Committee. "If you don't get on top of this soon enough, then the taxpayers will eventually lose."  40 Cents for Every $100 **********To raise $15 billion quickly, Mr. Bowsher urged Congress to consider an immediate special assessment on banks of 40 cents for every $100 in deposits. He said that if the lawmakers found this would unduly restrict lending by the banks, Congress might consider levying an assessment of 20 cents in 1991 and again in 1992. **********In either event, he strongly urged the Senators not to put a cap on existing annual premiums at 30 cents for every $100, as the Bush Administration has proposed. **********The $15 billion increase could be used by the fund both to bail out insolvent banks and to borrow against, thus further strengthening the insurance program. Existing law permits the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which operates the fund, to borrow up to nine times its net worth. The law also gives the agency a credit line of $5 billion with the Treasury. Audit Used Regulators' Files **********Economists for the White House and for Congress have relied upon economic models to determine the net worth of the bank insurance fund, and their findings have predicted that the program may run out of money within a year or two. But the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress that Mr. Bowsher heads, conducted an audit that was based on information from the regulators' own files. The results of the audit, presented at the hearing today, showed that the fund and the banking industry were in far weaker condition than previously calculated. **********Mr. Bowsher's testimony was the most dire of any Government official in a long series of hearings over the last year. In the hearings, a progressively worse picture of the plight of the insurance fund has emerged. **********Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the chairman of the Banking Committee, said the G.A.O. had found that "the bank insurance fund is essentially out of money." **********"We're in a position of some real vulnerability," said Mr. Riegle, Democrat of Michigan. **********But the proposal made by Mr. Bowsher today provoked only criticism in Congress and from the industry and appears to have little chance of approval. The Administration and bank regulators have proposed a different way to recapitalize the fund. **********They have recommended repairing the fund by increasing its authority to borrow by $70 billion. On Thursday, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, introduced a measure to increase the fund's borrowing authority by just $25 billion, but Treasury officials have criticized that measure because it does not include most of the proposals they have put forward to overhaul the entire banking system.  On Top of Current Premiums **********Mr. Bowsher's suggestion that the fund be buttressed by an immediate special assessment was immediately challenged by banking groups, who said a bite of 40 cents for every $100 in deposits would be too much for the industry to bear. The assessment would be on top of existing premiums, which are scheduled to increase this summer to 23 cents for each $100, from 19.5 cents. **********The $15 billion sought by Mr. Bowsher to bolster the fund is slightly less than the entire industry's earnings last year. It also represents less than one-tenth of American banks' existing capital -- the owners' stake in the banks that is crucial as a cushion to absorb large losses. **********Mr. Bowsher said preliminary results of the audit of the bank fund put its net worth at the end of last year at $2 billion to $5 billion. The actual amount depends upon how dozens of large banks that are effectively insolvent, but have not yet been seized by the Government, are classified. **********Unaudited results put the fund's net worth at $8.4 billion as of Dec. 31. L. William Seidman, the chairman of the F.D.I.C., disclosed on Tuesday that his agency was disputing the G.A.O.'s audit, but the accounting office declined to comment before presenting its conclusions to lawmakers today. **********Mr. Seidman has said the fund is weak and needs additional borrowing authority. But he has said it would not be insolvent if, as many economists and Government officials have predicted, the economy began to turn around by summer. **********Both Mr. Seidman and Mr. Bowsher acknowledge that a large part of their dispute centers on timing -- whether to recognize losses in 1990 or 1991 for a fund that virtually all officials now concede is headed toward insolvency if Congress and the Administration are unable to agree on a solution. **********The findings of the audit have a far-reaching effect, though, because the F.D.I.C.'s authority to borrow from the Government is largely tied to its net worth. This week, officials said they had begun to draw on their borrowing authority to help finance the failure of the Bank of New England and two affiliated banks, whose cost had already been subtracted by the F.D.I.C. in its calculation of the bank fund's net worth of $8.4 billion. That collapse requires an initial outlay of at least $5 billion. It is estimated that the failure will cost as much as $2.5 billion ultimately, after the banks' bad assets are sold. **********Mr. Bowsher and Mr. Seidman have said they hope to work out their differences soon. But if they are unable to reconcile the different financial figures, Mr. Bowsher said the accounting office would have to give a qualified, or adverse, auditor's opinion that the F.D.I.C. balance sheets are not based on generally accepted accounting principles. Those principles require that all contingent liabilities be included in the audit. **********Bank deposits of up to $100,000 are protected by the F.D.I.C., and depositors holding up to that amount would continue to be protected even if the fund became insolvent. If that occurred, the fund, which was created in 1934 after many banks collapsed in the Great Depression, would have to be bailed out by taxpayer funds, since it is backed by the full faith and credit of the United States. **********Mr. Bowsher told reporters after the hearing that the existing difficulties could put the bank fund in the same position as the now-depleted fund that protected depositors at savings associations. **********"It's somewhat similar to the savings and loan situation of 1988," Mr. Bowsher said. "You don't have money to resolve problems now, so you start parking your problems and then it costs even more."  Examination of 368 Banks **********Mr. Bowsher said the G.A.O. figures reflected an examination of the financial condition of 368 banks. Those banks were on the regulators' list of troubled institutions. Many had assets of more than $100 million. **********He said that 71 of those institutions were "already insolvent, or nearly so" and would cost the fund $7 billion to $11 billion. Of those banks, he said the problems of at least 40 were so grave that they had to be calculated in the net worth of the fund at the end of last year. **********"The remaining 31 banks, more likely than not, will fail without recapitalization, but do not meet the criteria of insolvency and therefore present accounting rules do not require the fund to reserve for these banks," he said.  Banks See 'Alarming Proposal' **********Banking groups and some Senators on the banking committee criticized Mr. Bowsher's idea of a special premium, saying it could further tighten credit at a time when there were already complaints that banks had refused loans to credit-worthy customers. **********"It is an alarming proposal that would strike extremely hard at many institutions," said Charlotte LeGates of the National Council of Savings Institutions, a Washington-based trade group of banks and savings associations. "To lead the American public to the idea that bankers can go into the vault, spin the dial and pull out vast hoards of cash is something that is simply not true." **********Richard A. Kirk, the president of the American Bankers Association, said the G.A.O.'s proposal "clearly would be economically and financially counterproductive." **********"If you really want to see a credit crunch, this is the way to get one," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/world.body_text: **********When the politicians of the Congress Party moved yesterday to ask Sonia Gandhi to succeed her slain husband as party leader, it was hardly the first time that they were seeking to exploit family connections to link today's party to the one that led India to independence and then shaped the country's institutions and agenda. **********This time, the move seemed desperate, since the widow of Rajiv Gandhi is an Italian-born woman who has stayed away from politics and who was not even an Indian citizen until eight years ago. **********Still, the attempt by the party leadership to evoke an image of continuity with a glorious past, through ties of blood and marriage, is understandable. The original Congress Party was one of the great political organizations of the world, a disciplined force that reached into the most remote villages to determine the nation's destiny and set its priorities. **********But there are many in India and abroad, both scholars and politicians, who dispute the present party's claims of direct descent from that old Congress. They say that the party led by Jawaharlal Nehru was very different from the Congress Party led by his daughter, Indira Gandhi, and the one directed by her son Rajiv.  Will She Accept Offer? **********Moreover, they say that whether or not Sonia Gandhi accepts the party leadership, they cannot envision the Congress Party ever regaining the dominance it had when it was the major vehicle, first for independence and then for nation-building. **********"That old Congress Party essentially came to an end in the late 1960's, when Indira Gandhi put an end to it," said Atul Kohli, a Princeton University professor, whose book, "Democracy and Discontent: India's Growing Crisis of Governability," was published last month. **********Mr. Kohli said that the old party had been forged by a single nationalistic agenda. Its leaders rose through the ranks, often going to prison in the colonial period, and developing discipline and cohesion in the process. But in the second decade after the independence of 1947, that single national agenda was no longer quite so compelling. **********Philip Oldenberg, an India scholar at Columbia University, dates the change in the party to 1969, when Mrs. Gandhi removed the old party bosses known as "The Syndicate."  Rearrangement of Power **********"She changed the party from a bottom-up party to a top-down organization," he said. Under the old system, Congress Party bosses spent years developing political power in their regions. Fortified by the votes they could amass and the patronage they could dispense in their regions, they would stake their claims and bargain with the party's national leaders. **********Mr. Kohli said that when Mrs. Gandhi purged the old regional leaders, she was aware that as the country matured, there were likely to be more and more challenges from below. "She realized that if the party was to survive, it had to go through a metamorphosis, and what she came up with was something akin to a mass movement." **********Rather than commanding a network of bosses, each with his own base, she sought to amass power from contact with the people and dispensed positions solely for personal loyalty. **********"The power of the new Congress types flowed from the closeness to the top," said Mr. Kohli, who noted that this form of leadership continued when Rajiv Gandhi took over the party in 1984 after his mother was killed. Different Style of Leadership **********One sign of the party's growing rigidity has been the failure of its recent leaders to permit full and open elections for leadership positions. These had been conducted regularly since the party was first formed under British rule, but no such ballot has been held since 1972.. **********Even as the Congress Party changed its style of leadership, it clung to the slogans of secularism, tolerance and nonalignment in foreign affairs that had been established in the Nehru years. This, however, did not distinguish it from many other parties that had adopted these values as their own. **********David Lelyveld, a dean at Columbia who has studied and written about India, noted that the range of Indian politics is populated by people who have fled from the Congress Party and now lead other groups. "On most points of ideology, I cannot tell the difference," he said. "All of them are for an independent foreign policy; all of them are for secularism." **********Mr. Lelyveld said he thought it would be wonderful if there were to be a laerge-scale return of those who had jumped or been pushed from the Congress Party during the time it was led by Mrs. Gandhi or her son. This might lead to a revitalization of a centrist political force that could counter growing divisiveness in religion and caste. But he added, "I really can't see this happening because of personal ambitions and the resentments that have developed over the years." 'Organizational Vacuum' **********Mr. Kohli said that over the long run, the decline of the Congress Party is likely to continue, though the party might do well in the second and third rounds of elections next month with the help of a strong sympathy vote. **********"The organizational vacuum will continue," he said. **********Mr Kohli, who argues in his book that all of India's parties are weak and weakening, said he believes that the Congress Party will never regain its once-dominant position. It no longer establishes the political agenda, he said, and is "caught in the middle" between those parties seeking constituencies on the basis of religion and those appealing to voters on the basis of caste coalitions. **********"It may benefit through its centrist appeal," he said, "but it is also likely to be found wanting with no great ideas to offer."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/12/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Pennzoil Move On Exploration
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/12/busin.body_text: **********The Pennzoil Company said it would shift the focus of its oil and gas exploration to outside the United States. After a board meeting on Tuesday, the company said it would spend up to $100 million a year for three years on foreign exploration, along with its 1992 domestic exploration budget of about $100 million. James L. Pate, the president and chief executive, said the increasing number of foreign areas that have become available represented "a major business opportunity." **********Pennzoil also announced a new management team to pursue exploration. Thomas M. Hamilton, 48 years old, will become the head of oil and gas operations, replacing William H. Schell, 65, who is retiring. Dr. Hamilton, a geologist, had been the chief executive of the British Petroleum Company's Frontier and International Operating Company. Pennzoil said it was hiring two senior vice presidents, David R. Henderson, 41, and Richard S. Langdon, also 41.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/busin.body_text: **********Stung by declining sales across almost its entire hardware product line, I.B.M. said yesterday that its operating earnings plunged 48.7 percent in the first quarter of 1991 and revenue fell 4.5 percent. **********The computer maker, which is based in Armonk, N.Y., sent its stock into a tailspin last month after warning Wall Street analysts that first-quarter results would fall 50 percent short of its quarterly results a year ago. Most I.B.M. watchers were predicting that first-quarter earnings would be flat. **********The stock, which had risen to $127.875 before the company's warning on earnings, tumbled $12.75 that day. Yesterday, it fell $2.125 a share to close at $108.50 on the New York Stock Exchange, where it was second on the most active list.  In Line With Prediction **********The earnings results announced yesterday were generally in line with what the International Business Machines Corporation had predicted last month. But the company's poor performance raised questions for a number of financial analysts who suggested that the giant computer maker had erred in minimizing the difficulty surrounding its current shift to a new generation of mainframe computers. **********For the first quarter of 1991, revenue amounted to $13.5 billion, down 4.5 percent from the previous year's $14.2 billion. Net earnings from operations for the three months amounted to $532 million in 1991, compared with $1.04 billion in 1990, or 93 cents a share, compared with $1.81 in 1990. **********I.B.M. actually reported a net loss of $1.73 billion for the quarter, but that largely reflected a one-time accounting adjustment of $2.26 billion, or $3.96 a share, to take account of what the company expects it will eventually pay out in health benefits for retirees.  Part of Personnel Costs **********The theory is that the eventual retirement health benefits of today's employees are part of a company's personnel costs and they should be charged against current profits even though the actual outlays are many years down the road. I.B.M. is one of the first of the nation's leading corporations to comply with the new accounting rule. **********The company said it had double-digit revenue declines in a number of its product lines, including both mainframe and personal computers. The company's rapidly growing RS/6000 work station line, introduced last April, was the one positive factor in the hardware sales. But an I.B.M. spokesman said sales of those models had also been disappointing during the first quarter. **********"It looks like it could get worse before it gets better," said Steven Smith, a financial analyst at Paine Webber. **********Sales of computer hardware declined 17.2 percent worldwide in the quarter over the corresponding three months last year. In Europe, sales of computers were still slightly positive for the quarter, analysts said. But after subtracting for the effect of the dollar, sales also declined there. **********"There was one aspect that was truly stunning," said Marc G. Schulman, an analyst at UBS Securities. "I.B.M. indicated that its PC revenues declined as much as its overall equipment revenues. I have to conclude that there is a slowing of the PC market worldwide." **********Both software sales and support services, however, increased substantially in the quarter. Revenue from services grew 18.9 percent, while software sales rose 13.9 percent. Confidence Shaken **********The unusual weakness of I.B.M.'s first quarter seemed to shake the confidence of a number of analysts who said they were considering further rollbacks in their annual earnings estimates, lowering their forecasts significantly below last year's $10.51 a share. **********The company gave no indication that it expected any significant financial improvement until the international economy improved. In a statement, I.B.M.'s chairman, John F. Akers, said, "The worldwide economic slowdown has created an uncertain and difficult business environment." He added that he believed the strength of I.B.M.'s product line would permit the company to revive quickly once the economy improved. **********I.B.M. said in March that it planned to reduce worldwide employment by 14,000, or 3.8 percent, this year, but the company said yesterday that the employee cuts would not have a financial effect on the first quarter or the rest of the year. No Layoffs Planned **********I.B.M. shed 4,000 employees after the sale of the company's office equipment division last month. An additional 10,000 employees will be reduced through attrition. No layoffs are planned but I.B.M. will try to persuade employees to leave by offering early retirement and voluntary resignation incentives. **********Several analysts said they believed that while the company has been attributing its earnings decline exclusively to the world economic climate, its product offerings may be causing it more difficulty than it is willing to acknowledge. **********"They continue to blame the entire shortfall on the worldwide economy and I think that's hurting their position," said John B. Jones, Jr., an analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. "The survey data we have show that mainframe sales have fallen off dramatically." Earnings from mainframes make up more than half of I.B.M.'s total profits. **********Mr. Jones suggested that a significant revenue decline was attributable to the delay in introduction of the most powerful members of I.B.M.'s new System/390 mainframe family. While it is now shipping air-cooled versions of the new computers, the most powerful high-speed water-cooled machines will not be available for sale until the third quarter, pushing significant revenues toward the end of the year. **********An I.B.M. official disputed the suggestion that the company might be suffering the effects of a product introduction delay. He restated that the company believed its revenues were being depressed by a worldwide economic recession. **********"I.B.M.'s plan for the first half of the year says flat to down," said Rick Martin, an analyst at Prudential Securities. "That sounds like transition to me." **********In the market for personal computers, which is a small but growing part of I.B.M.'s business, representing less than a fifth of its sales, Mr. Martin said that the industry had been seeing rather weak growth for the last three or four quarters and that that trend had now been compounded because the average selling price peaked last year and had now started to decline. **********I.B.M. is particularly vulnerable to large-scale trends because it is the only personal computer maker that has products at every level, from cheap home personal computers to some of the largest and fastest machines that act as storage systems in office networks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/06/world.main_headline: Shells Still Fall on Croatian Towns Despite Truce
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/06/world.print_headline: Shells Still Fall on Croatian Towns Despite Truce
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/06/world.body_text: **********The thunder of exploding Yugoslav Army shells and and air-launched rockets continued to roar around the Croatian port city of Dubrovnik and dozens of other Adriatic coastal towns today, hours after the presidents of the warring Yugoslav republics of Croatia and Serbia agreed to a cease-fire. **********Pro-Serbian Yugoslav Army units also carried out many artillery and air attacks today against inland regions of Croatia and staged a new offensive against the town of Karlovac, threatening to block the last main highway linking the breakway republic's capital, Zagreb, with the coast. **********Fires, whipped up by fierce sea winds, are burning out of control across acres of brushland near Dubrovnik, the renowned resort that has been cut off for five days. The Yugoslav military suspended its naval blockade of Dubrovnik's port briefly today to allow a ship with three European Community cease-fire monitors to dock. **********"We feel like a dot in the heart of hell," said Dubrovnik's Mayor, Zeljko Sikic, as quoted by Reuters. "The army's aim is to exhaust the population." **********Despite the cease-fire, which was announced in the Netherlands under the auspices of the European Community, there was no evident lessening of conflict in this region today. **********In a televised statement tonight, Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman, called for a general mobilization. **********"All those who are called into the ranks of the Croatian Army must report immediately," he said. "I especially call on everyone who possesses weapons to volunteer for the ranks of the defense forces." **********The Yugoslav Army has been mobilizing reservists in Serbia and other republics for weeks. **********Dubrovnik's historic Old Town -- a masterpiece of Renaissance and Baroque architecture that was for centuries the hub of a wealthy, independent city-state -- remains untouched by the fighting. Local news reports, however, said shells fired from the mountains above the city had exploded within yards of its walls. **********The Croatian radio reported tonight that equally prized palaces, churches and museums in Zadar, the old Byzantine capital of Dalmatia, had been severely damaged in attacks. **********Air and artillery attacks called in by the Serb- and Communist-controlled Yugoslav Army's command knocked out all of Dubrovnik's electricity, telephone service and commercial radio and television communications. Artillery attacks continued from the mountains north and east of the city, and army forces today reportedly captured several villages to the east of it. **********Firemen can do little about the blazes in the city's suburbs because the waterworks have been disabled. **********"The Serbs shot at our fire brigades when they tried to approach the fires," said Anton Matic, a member of the local crisis center in Ston, a small walled town 25 miles from Dubrovnik. **********Information coming from Dubrovnik through a police radio hookup said several thousand refugees from surrounding villages had poured into Dubrovnik's luxury hotels and the Old Town. **********Yugoslav Army forces closed the ring around Dubrovnik on Friday at Slano, a coastal village about 25 miles west of the city. **********"Now the army is bringing in fresh troops to Slano with helicopters and along the road over the mountains," said the commander of the Croatian territorial-defense forces in Ston, who refused to give his name. "If they move eastward toward the city, we have forces in place to stop them." **********"We have almost no weaponry to use against tanks," said Klemo Manenica, Ston's police chief. "There just aren't enough weapons." **********As in other theaters of the war, the fighting in Dalmatia is mostly done from afar, with mortars, canon and high-powered rifles. The property damage and psychological trauma are far more striking than the death tallies. **********Before the announcement Friday of the acceptance of what would be the sixth cease-fire, the army's commanders had said they would continue the siege of Dubrovnik until Croatia's military either surrenders or withdraws from the city.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/17/busin.body_text: **********The flamboyant former chairman of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, Ronald Li, has pleaded guilty to two more counts of corruption, according to the Independent Commission Against Corruption. Mr. Li, who was given a four-year prison sentence in October on two counts of corruption, told the High Court last week that he illegally accepted shares or commissions from two companies in exchange for supporting or not opposing their listing on the exchange in August 1987. Mr. Li, 62 years old, will not be sentenced until the cases of seven other former senior exchange executives, who have been jointly charged with him, are resolved, the court said. The others have pleaded not guilty to corruption charges.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/22/world.main_headline: Envoy Denounces Soviet TV for Scapegoating U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/22/world.print_headline: Envoy Denounces Soviet TV for Scapegoating U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/22/world.body_text: **********The United States Ambassador to Moscow today assailed the main Soviet evening television news program for reviving the old practice of blaming foreign interference and connivance for Soviet problems. **********The Ambassador, Jack F. Matlock Jr., took the program Vremya (Time) to task at a briefing for Soviet reporters, which was reported by the Interfax news agency. The sharpness and openness of the criticism was a departure from the Ambassador's usual background briefings for the press, and appeared to signal his readiness to challenge the revival of anti-American reporting on the evening news show. **********Mr. Matlock's specific target was a report on Vremya last Saturday in which the newsreader, Dmitri Biryukov, accused the A.F.L.-C.I.O. of interfering in internal Soviet affairs by declaring solidarity with striking Soviet coal miners, giving them financial assistance and inviting them to the United States. **********Mr. Matlock opened the briefing by playing a tape of the program. According the Interfax account, which was confirmed by the Embassy spokesman, the Ambassador said he was "staggered" by the presentation. **********He asked, "Is there not the slogan, 'Workers of the World, Unite' on Pravda's front page? Or does this slogan not imply help? Or perhaps Vremya commentators simply do not read Pravda?" **********Mr. Matlock said that American miners and trade unions did have contacts with their Soviet colleagues, and that representatives of independent Soviet miners' unions had been invited to the United States under the International Visitor Program, along with Soviet writers, actors, medical workers and staffers of the state television and radio company. **********Mr. Biryukov also alleged that American diplomats were attending rallies of striking miners with unfriendly intentions. The Ambassador declared that there was nothing untoward in these actions: "We seek to understand what is taking place in the country and what processes are under way. We do everything openly." New Television Director **********The Ambassador charged that over the past two months Vremya had resumed a xenophobic stance. He said that under Leonid P. Kravchenko, the new director of state television appointed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last November, Vremya had passed beyind editorial commentary to expressing the opinions of specific state structures. **********The transformation of state television under Mr. Kravchenko, and especially the undisguised use of Vremya as a vehicle for the Kremlin, have been one of the most visible aspects of Mr. Gorbachev's new politics, and a major target of the liberal opposition. **********Before Mr. Gorbachev introduced his "new thinking" in foreign policy five years ago, it was a mainstay of Soviet propaganda to imply that foreign plotters and secret services were always seeking to do harm to the Soviet Union. The insinuations served both to perpetuate a suspicion of foreigners in the population, and to create scapegoats for Moscow's own problems. **********Mr. Gorbachev's shift from liberal advisers to an alliance with conservative forces in recent months has included a revival of the practice. The President himself on a recent visit to Byelorussia insinuated that there was something suspicious in the fact that "democrats" were frequently invited to travel abroad, although he frequently travels in foreign countries himself. **********According to the report, the Ambassador also said that American economists doubted that the economic changes such as price increases now being put in practice by the Kremlin could have positive results. "We would like to maintain mutually beneficial economic relations with the Soviet Union, but we just do not know of any way to maintain them with the command and administrative system," Mr. Matlock was quoted as saying. **********But the Ambassador was also quoted as saying that American-Soviet relations were developing in the right direction, and that there could be no return to the cold war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/busin.body_text: **********Exceeding the most optimistic Wall Street projections, the Exxon Corporation said today that net income in the first quarter rose 75 percent, to $2.24 billion, its highest profits for any quarter since John D. Rockefeller organized the company in 1882. **********Like other international oil giants, most of Exxon's gains came in foreign refining and marketing, where profits were almost five times higher and provided half of the company's total earnings, at $1.1 billion, from $219 million in the first quarter last year. Combination of Factors **********The increase included a one-time gain of $160 million from sales of an Australian refinery to the Mobil Corporation and of a large tanker to a Greek shipping concern. **********The combination of huge demand for jet fuel, kerosene and other refined products by the allied forces in Saudi Arabia, cold weather in Europe and rising government-controlled prices for gasoline and natural gas in Europe and Asia created a rare bonanza for refiners. **********When crude oil costs plummeted after allied air attacks began on Jan. 17, profit margins on refined products like jet fuel and diesel soared to an average of more than $7 a barrel in the quarter in Europe and Singapore, from a more typical level of about $2.50. **********Profitability has since retreated to about $3.80 a barrel in Europe, and 98 cents in Singapore markets, but Exxon still appears likely to register the most profitable year in its history, said Frederick P. Leuffer, senior oil analyst at C. J. Lawrence Inc. in New York. He said Exxon should earn $6 billion this year, more than the $5.53 billion it earned in 1984, its most profitable year to date.  Net Off at Sun **********"The higher earnings for the year will simply be a function of the first quarter and nothing beyond that," said Frank P. Kneuttel, an oil analyst at Prudential Securities. The factors creating the huge profit were "unique and unlikely to be replicated," he added. **********In a separate report, the Sun Company, the nation's largest independent refiner, said its net income fell 42 percent. Excluding a one-time gain caused by an accounting change last year, operating income was unchanged. **********Following are the details of the companies' results: Exxon **********Earnings were equal to $1.78 a share in the quarter, compared with $1.28 billion, or $1.01 a share, in the first quarter of 1990. Sales for the Dallas-based company rose nearly 15 percent, to $30.69 billion, from $26.71 billion. **********While not referring directly to the Persian Gulf war, Exxon's chairman, Lawrence G. Rawl, said "unusually favorable market conditions" in the foreign refining business generated much of the company's profit in the quarter. **********Refining profits were also strong in the United States, rebounding to $256 million, from a $28 million loss in the quarter a year ago, when repairs limited production at some refineries. **********Profits from foreign oil and gas production fell slightly, to $721 million from $730 million, but plunged in the United States, to $150 million from $355 million, partly because of a $75 million write-down for oil reserves Exxon plans to sell. **********Another factor was a drop in the average price paid for its Alaskan crude oil, which was $14.67 a barrel in the quarter, compared with $16.61 in the quarter last year. Natural gas prices were also lower in the United States, falling to an average of $1.87 per 1,000 cubic feet in the quarter, from an average of $2.05 a year ago. **********Higher demand and prices for basic petrochemicals, like polyethylene, and falling prices for crude oil and other raw materials helped profits in chemical manufacturing rise to $223 million, from $181 million. **********The company allocated $2.5 billion in 1989 for costs to clean shorelines, restore wildlife habitats and reclaim other areas fouled in the Exxon Valdez oil spill of March 1989. No provisions related to the Alaskan cleanup were included in the first-quarter results. **********However, Judge H. Russel Holland, a Federal district judge in Alaska today rejected Exxon's plea-bargaining settlement with the Government in which the company agreed to pay $100 million to settle criminal violations concerning the oil spill. **********Exxon's shares were unchanged today, at $60.875, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Sun **********Net income was $41 million, or 39 cents a share, compared with $71 million, or 66 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year. Sales fell 1.9 percent, to $3.05 billion from $3.11 billion. **********Earnings from operations over all were unchanged, said Robert McClements Jr., chairman of the company, based in Radnor, Pa. The 1990 results included a $30 million gain from an accounting change. **********Profits in refining and marketing in the United States rose to $38 million, from $25 million, mainly because of higher profit margins. Refinery operating levels fell to 78 percent, from 97 percent, because of shutdowns for repairs and improvements. **********Sun's shares fell $1.25 today, to $33.25, on the Big Board.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/09/busin.main_headline: Filling Plate Takes Priority Over Curbing the Appetite
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/09/busin.print_headline: Filling Plate Takes Priority Over Curbing the Appetite
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/09/busin.body_text: **********The problem with a nation whose oil production satisfies barely half its oil appetite is not its appetite, the Bush administration has apparently concluded, but its production. **********With most eyes now focused on the war in the oilfields of the Middle East, many elected officials and private analysts are calling for cutting imports. That was a goal, Secretary of State James Baker 3d said in a speech earlier this week. **********But the oil segment of the draft of the National Energy Strategy is aimed mainly at supplying the American appetite, rather than curbing it. This is in sharp contrast to the energy policies generated by the oil crises of 1973-74 and 1979. Those earlier policies assumed that the cause of the imbalance lay at least in part on the consumption side. Other Sources of Energy **********Imported oil amounts to nearly half the oil used in this country but only 10 percent of total energy consumption, which includes natural gas, nuclear power, coal and hydroelectric power. The United States also imports natural gas and other fuels but exports coal. The net result is that the nation produces about 82 percent of all the energy it uses. **********Opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to drilling is the oil companies' biggest hope for expanding reserves, and thus production. But in the view of industry and others, this is not salvation. The Department of Energy said last fall that the median estimate of its size was 3.2 billion barrels, which is huge by the standards of what is found in the United States these days, but small relative to consumption. And there is always the possibility that it will come up dry. **********"This will not prevent an increase in the level and share of imports," said John H. Lichtblau, the president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, a nonprofit group in New York. "Increase is inevitable," he said. "The rate might be slightly slower than if the Government had not come up with anything."  Competitive Problems **********Brooks B. Yeager, a lobbyist for the National Audubon Society, contends that policies aimed at production cannot make much difference in the level of imports. A bigger factor in production, he said, is prices. "Our ability to pump oil out and market oil is always dependent on whether it is competitive with Middle East oil," he said. Because of geology, it simply is not, he said. But measures that would make domestic drilling competitive, like import fees, have generally been ruled out by the Bush Administration, which says they would interfere with a free market. **********Other facets of the policy statement will not cut oil consumption significantly either. **********Nuclear power, for example, the other main focus of the energy package, does not usually substitute for oil; it mostly replaces coal and natural gas. **********And efforts to encourage greater production of other energy sources -- mostly through a return to market principles -- will also have a relatively minor impact on oil consumption and imports.  Fewer Approvals to Get **********Builders of oil and gas pipelines would be relieved of having to obtain an entire category of cumbersome approvals. Nuclear power plant builders would no longer have potentially contentious and delaying hearings at the end of construction. And nearly anybody and his brother could enter the wholesale electricity market as producers. **********The treatment of consumption by the energy policy plan stands in sharp contrast. Gone is all mention of gasoline taxes, taxes on all fuels based on energy content or on carbon production, or new taxes on cars based on their fuel economy. **********Taxing cars based on fuel economy is one idea that is certain to be revived in Congress this year. Cars are widely veiwed as the biggest single target for greater efficiency, and the Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards, imposed after the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo, include one of the two major elements of energy policy surviving from that era. The other is the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which is barely mentioned in the draft, with a call for stockpiling oil products, as well as crude oil.   Not Much Spending Required **********The Department of Energy had considered a variety of methods for stimulating oil production, mostly centering on tax breaks. Some of those would have cost the Treasury $16 or more for every barrel produced. Very few of the proposals that survived to the draft plan stage would require Washington to spend money. **********Mr. Bush's approach also differs from his predecessors' in largely avoiding reliance on new technology, although it would encourage some fleet vehicles to run on alternative fuels, which have not been demonstrated on a large scale, with some reduction in gasoline demand. It would also provide some money for research.  Ideas Around for Years **********Those ideas have been around for years. But it was clear early in the process of developing the strategy that in a political sense, the options were limited. Energy is so basic to so much of the economy that any change represents the swing of an elbow that hits someone in the eye. **********The oil exploration industry got what it wanted most; the refining industry did not get a huge new requirement for alternative fuels, although it may have a new market to meet if fleets turn to other fuels. The auto industry avoided the mileage standards it did not want. The electric utility industry got a change that will please most of its members. **********And the strategy seems mindful of the war in one particular way. By not moving to curb consumption or imports, the Saudis, the Venezuelans and other oil exporters with whom this country has cultivated a good relationship were spared the shrinkage of a big market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/world.body_text: **********While Israel has promised not to settle any of its new Ethiopian immigrants in the occupied territories, nearly 200 Ethiopians from the last airlift, in 1984, say they have been trapped against their will for seven years here in the West Bank's most militant Jewish settlement. **********As soon as the 14,100 new immigrants stepped off the planes late last month, Simcha Dinitz, the nation's most senior immigration official, said all of them "are going to be housed in our 100 absorption centers, and none of them are in the territories." **********Mr. Dinitz's promise seemed to satisfy the United States and other governments that had expressed concern. But here in the West Bank's oldest settlement, in the heart of Hebron, Erez Mekerit, a 22-year-old soldier, and his friends are asking: What about us? **********Mr. Mekerit was a part of Operation Moses, the secret airlift in 1984 that brought 10,000 Ethiopian Jews to Israel. A few months after they arrived, before any of them had got their bearings, "they brought us out here," said Avraham Kasu, 20, another soldier. 'Won't Let Us' Leave **********"And for seven years we've been requesting to leave," Mr. Mekerit said. "But they won't let us. We don't have any options." **********His friend Rutti Kasa, 18, a high school student, nodded at that and said: "Everybody here wants to leave. Lots of people are afraid. There's no place to work out here. Our relatives are afraid to visit us. We've been crying and complaining the whole time we've been here. But they won't let us go." **********With hardly an exception, nearly all of their Ethiopian neighbors agree. **********It is not that these people are prisoners of the West Bank. In theory every one of them could pack up and leave Qiryat Arba tomorrow. Some of them have. **********But the Ethiopians cannot move without significant Government assistance, and that has not been forthcoming. Spreading Them Across Country **********In 1984, as now, the Ethiopian immigrants arrived in Israel with few possessions, no money, little education and not much idea of how or where they should live in Israel. For the first year, the Government made almost all of their decisions for them -- fed them, clothed them, found them jobs and assigned them places to live. **********Late in 1984, after the immigrants had been in the country for about six months, the Government moved them out of absorption centers and into permanent homes they had been assigned. The policy then, as now, was to spread them all over the country. As Gad Ben Ari, spokesman for the Jewish Agency, puts it now, "there was much less sensitivity about these things then." **********So about 60 families, more than 300 people, were assigned homes in Qiryat Arba. **********The mayors of some small towns in Israel were complaining that they had too few apartments for their own residents' children. But Qiryat Arba welcomed the Ethiopians with open arms; like all settlements, it was always eager to expand, **********"Other places don't want them," the settlement's leader, Elyakim Haetzni, said at the time. "We'll take all they can send." U.S. Protested in 1985 **********When the United States learned of that early in 1985, the Reagan Administration delivered an official protest to Israel. But Yaacov Tzur, the Absorption Minister then, assured Washington that Qiryat Arba would not be the immigrants' final home. Soon the matter was forgotten. And now, six years later, the Ethiopians say they have been forgotten, too. **********Most of these people are not ideological; few of them seem to care much about the debate over the West Bank. They want only to be near places of employment, close to their families. One after another of them complained that their parents, brothers, sisters and others would not even visit them here. **********"They think it's like Lebanon out here," Mr. Kasu said. **********Time and time again they have put in requests to move. But many are unemployed, for there is little work in the West Bank. And for most of those who do have jobs, the work is menial. **********"I don't have any work; I can't find any work out here," said Eli Noga, who is 34. "It's pretty here; the people are nice. But like everyone else, I've asked to leave. I want to live with other Ethiopians." Needs Government Subsidy **********But Mr. Noga, like the others, lives in a Government-subsidized apartments. He would need another wherever he lived. **********"I remember that many of them didn't want to be there even in 1984," Mr. Ben Ari said. But then, he added, the division of the Jewish agency involved in settling immigrants was controlled by a Likud Party official, a strong advocate of West Bank settlement. There was also a Likud Government of the time. **********With Mr. Dinitz at the head, the Jewish Agency is under Labor Party control today. But now, with all the new Soviet immigrants, there is a drastic housing shortage nationwide. **********The Jewish Agency is a quasi-governmental organization. But the Government would have the largest role in trying to resettle Qiryat Arba's Ethiopians. Still, the right-wing administration of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, struggling to catch up with the drastic housing shortages while also eager to see the West Bank's population grow, has shown no inclination to help them. Priority to the Homeless **********"We know they are unhappy," Mr. Ben Ari said. "But they already live in their housing solutions. For new homes, we need to give priority to those people who are still in absorption centers and don't have any permanent homes at all." **********So the Ethiopians say they are trapped. **********"Maybe they aren't trying to keep us against our will," Miss Kasa said. "But nobody's giving us any place to go. And you definitely see that they want new immigrants out here." **********With that, she gestured behind her to a large shipping crate that had held the belongings of new neighbors, a family that had just arrived in Israel. The stenciled letters on the side of the box were in Russian. Others like it are scattered among several buildings. **********In the last two years, some of the Ethiopian families with independent means have managed to move out of Qiryat Arba on their own. And in almost every case that an apartment is vacated, Miss Kasa says now, "Russian immigrants are moving in."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/23/busin.main_headline: Intel Adds Cheaper Chip At Top of Line
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Intel Adds Cheaper Chip At Top of Line
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/23/busin.body_text: **********The Intel Corporation today showed the first of a series of chips that it hopes will help it maintain its supremacy in microprocessors, the central control chips inside personal computers. **********The new 486SX is a scaled-down version of Intel's most powerful microprocessor, the 486. At $258, it is less than half the price of the full 486 and roughly equal to the price of the earlier-generation 386. **********Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., had prospered as the only vendor of the 386, which is used in personal computers that conform to the standard initially established by the International Business Machines Corporation. But recently, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., began selling a clone of the 386. Strategic Offering **********By offering a lower-priced 486, however, Intel hopes to get the personal computer industry to migrate toward the more powerful 486, for which Intel remains the only vendor. **********The 486SX is slower than the full 486, which has been renamed the 486DX. It also lacks the part of the 486 known as the floating-point unit, which is designed to do high-speed arithmetic. But Intel said the new chip was still 10 percent to 40 percent faster than its fastest 386. **********Several companies, including I.B.M., AST Research and Dell Computer, are expected to announce personal computers based on the 486SX this week, though they are expected to continue selling 386-based machines. Indeed, migration to the 486 is likely to be gradual. Dave House, senior vice president of Intel, said the company expected that by the end of the year there would be two million computers in the world that use the 486 or 486SX, compared with 30 million using 386 chips.  Chip for High-Speed Arithmetic **********Intel also plans to introduce chips that attach to the 486SX and improve its performance. The first of them, announced today, is the 487SX, which provides high-speed arithmetic. **********Intel also intends to increase the speed and power of its chips continually. This summer, the company is expected to introduce a version of the 486 that runs at 50 million cycles a second, or 50 megahertz, a big jump from the fastest existing 486, which runs at 33 megahertz. **********Intel also said today that in 1992 it would begin selling the successor to the 486, expected to be called the 586. Mr. House said the new chip would be two to four times as fast as the 486DX and would contain more than four million transistors, compared with 1.2 million for the 486 and 275,000 for the 386.
