https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/19/world.body_text: **********The Pentagon has called on commercial air cargo companies to supply additional long-range aircraft to the military operation in the Persian Gulf, increasing the military's ability to deliver ammunition, spare parts and weapons to the forces there. **********Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney declared "an airlift emergency" on Wednesday night, taking the formal step needed to commandeer the airplanes, mostly from companies like United Parcel Service and Federal Express, the Military Airlift Command announced today. **********The activation of additional aircraft suggested that the Pentagon is prepared to continue military operations for a prolonged period. **********Officials said the move could provide as many as 17 more cargo planes, on top of the 23 cargo planes already provided under an earlier activation of the civilian air fleet.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/03/world.body_text: **********China's propaganda laboratories, after searching for years for a way to flavor "political study" to make it palatable, may finally have hit upon a success. **********The Chinese leadership is vigorously promoting a new film about Jiao Yulu, a Communist Party hero from Maoist days, and the surprise is that some people actually enjoy the film, though perhaps for the wrong reasons. **********"At first we didn't really want to see another political propaganda film," said an editor who attended an early screening. "But in fact it's a pretty good movie, and a lot of fun to watch." **********A Chinese official involved in propaganda, who attended the official premiere a few days ago in the Great Hall of the People, said proudly: "We're now trying to educate people through entertainment. The movie is very touching in places, and it's made so that people will enjoy it." **********Jiao Yulu (whose name is pronounced jow oo loo), was a Communist Party secretary in a poor county in Henan Province for 15 months in the early 1960's. By all accounts he was well-liked and energetic, but he was virtually unknown when he died of liver cancer in 1964. Not until two years later was he proclaimed a national hero and celebrated throughout the country. **********Such heroes were largely forgotten in the 1980's, but returned to prominence after the rise of the hard-liners two years ago. Over the last 18 months, the Government has periodically called on the country -- and especially party officials -- to learn from Mr. Jiao and his selfless enthusiasm for serving the people. **********The film glorifies Mr. Jiao in his period as county party secretary, and fits squarely in the current passion for sentimentality in the arts. The first scene is of people crying, and the tears keep coming throughout the movie.The movie has already sold 520 copies around the country, an all-time record in China, although this may be because local film distributors feel it would be a political mistake not to buy it. Chinese "work units" are expected to organize their employees to see special screenings of the film as an alternative to more traditional kinds of "political study" sessions, such as reading speeches of national leaders. **********Yet while the movie will probably leave viewers with a highly favorable impression of Mr. Jiao, who is constantly shown spurning privilege and mingling with ordinary citizens, this may not do much to bolster the legitimacy of the present leadership. **********"The message from the leaders in this type of propaganda is that the people should be more like these role models," a Western diplomat said . "But the message the people may get is: Why can't our leaders today be more like the heroes of the past?" **********The movie has just opened, so it is too soon to know how the general public will react. But diplomats and Chinese alike say it is possible that viewers may go home wondering: Why was Mr. Jiao so popular, while Prime Minister Li Peng is so unpopular? Why can't we find somebody like Mr. Jiao to be prime minister? **********The Minister of Radio, Film and Television, Ai Zhisheng, seemed inadvertently to underscore the dissatisfaction with today's leaders when he was quoted on the front page of People's Daily a few days ago as saying, "The people and the times, they require Jiao Yulu." **********Perhaps unintentionally, the film has also portrayed Mr. Jiao as something of a rebel against the party establishment. At one point after he violates a regulation, a "work team" is sent out to investigate his conduct, just as "work teams" were sent to many offices after the 1989 crackdown. Fearful that Mr. Jiao will be dismissed, the local citizens even threaten to march on Beijing, in a scene that tends to legitimize the 1989 demonstrations more than the Government that crushed them. **********Other propaganda films have backfired in the last couple of years. Shortly after the crackdown, for instance, a movie gained renown because of a line in which a pre-Communist government decides not to fire on protesters. The contrast with the killings in 1989 was stark, and invariably audiences broke into applause.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/06/busin.body_text: **********In a stunning break with its past management, Salomon Brothers Inc. announced yesterday that it would pay no compensation, severance or future legal expenses stemming from the Treasury markets scandal to the four senior executives who have resigned, including John H. Gutfreund, the former chairman who built Salomon into a bond-trading giant. **********The decision, reached at an early morning meeting yesterday by the firm's board, would also end compensation and payment of legal expenses to Thomas W. Strauss, the former president; John W. Meriwether, a former vice chairman, and Donald M. Feuerstein, the former general counsel. The men, or lawyers for them, all declined to comment. **********The firm said it would continue to meet any legal obligations to the men that could arise under their employment contracts or other agreements. The firm's new legal counsel will determine over the next few weeks what those obligations are. **********The decision could be a significant tactical move to portray the actions of the senior executives as outside the scope of their employment, said a lawyer who has discussed the case with executives involved in it. **********"They directors have made the decision that they will argue that these executives were not acting on behalf of the company," said the lawyer. "It means that the directors have decided that the interests of the executives are not congruent with those of the firm." **********Salomon's decision, in effect, now isolates the firm's former top managers, as investigations continue into the unfolding illegal bidding scandal in the Treasury markets. **********The board's action is perhaps the most surprising for Mr. Gutfreund, who until last month was one of Wall Street's most powerful executives. Mr. Gutfreund resigned his post days after Salomon disclosed that he and the other three executives had known of illegal bidding by the firm since April, but had failed to inform the Government for four months. **********The decision is likely to prevent the executives from receiving a portion of a three-year, $100 million deferred payment pool that is scheduled to be distributed to the firm's top executives early next year. Mr. Gutfreund is the only executive who is not a member of that pool. **********Robert Baker, a spokesman for the firm, said the conditions on the decision were there only because of legal limitations. "The board went as far today as they can legally go," he said. **********The salaries of at least three of the executives were in the multimillion-dollar range. Last year, according to Government filings by the firm, Mr. Gutfreund was paid $2.264 million, and Mr. Strauss was paid $2.014 million. In 1990, Financial World magazine identified Mr. Meriwether as one of Wall Street's highest paid executives, with an estimated annual compensation of $8 million. Mr. Feuerstein's salary has not been disclosed. **********The board also decided that the men would no longer provided offices or paid for expenses. The executives have continued to work in Salomon's old headquarters building, and the decision indicates that if they do not move, they will have to pay Salomon for their space. **********During testimony before a Congressional subcommittee on Wednesday, Warren E. Buffett, the new chairman of the firm, was told that Salomon should have no further financial dealing with the former executives, a suggestion that appears to have been quickly accepted. **********"There should not be a dime spent by the firm to defend the wrongdoers" Representative Jim Slattery, Democrat of Kansas, told Mr. Buffett. "These men should be in striped suits, sweeping up Wall Street." **********Last night, Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, who conducted the Congressional hearing on Wednesday, applauded the board's decision. "This kind of misconduct requires strong medicine," he said. "By today's action, Salomon continues to show it is taking its problems -- and the need for strong remedies -- seriously."  Buffett's Philosophy **********Thomas A. Russo, a partner at Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, a Wall Street law firm, said, "This fits with Warren Buffett's general philosophy of taking anyone who has anything to do with the scandal and divorcing them from the new Salomon Brothers." **********A partner at the law firm Howard, Darby & Levin, which represents both Mr. Gutfreund and Mr. Strauss, said he had no comment on Salomon's announcement. Mr. Feuerstein said, "I don't think it's appropriate to comment." A spokesman for Mr. Meriwether said his client was unavailable for comment. **********With the interests of the firm and the former management now completely broken, the possibility of Salomon's uncovering more information about the executives' knowledge of the illegal bidding and other actions seems more remote. In a report submitted to Congress on Wednesday, the firm said that it had asked to re-interview Mr. Gutfreund and Mr. Strauss about the case, but that the request had not yet been granted. The report said the two men had indicated that they would continue to cooperate with the firm's investigation. **********Before the firm announced its final break with the former management yesterday, Standard & Poor's lowered Salomon's credit ratings a notch because of the scandal. The ratings went to A from A+ on billions of dollars of senior long-term debt, to A- from A on subordinated debt and to BBB+ from A- on preferred stock. Moody's Investor Service Inc. lowered its rating on some Salomon debt a week ago. Salomon's stock closed yesterday at $24, down $1 on the New York Stock Exchange. **********In a statement, Salomon said the move by S.& P. "will have no significant impact on the firm's overall liquidity, which remains strong." But the rating change will increase the cost of borrowings for Salomon when its finances are already under stress.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/world.main_headline: In a Kurdish City, the Streets Are Still, the Shops Barred
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; In a Kurdish City, the Streets Are Still, the Shops Barred
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/world.body_text: **********Nearly a month after the Iraqi Army drove Kurdish insurgents from this provincial capital, ending a 17-day rebel occupation, only a trickle of people who fled the fighting are returning home, despite a Government offer of amnesty. **********This became clear today when the Iraqi Government took a party of foreign journalists on a visit here, apparently in the hope of convincing them that conditions are returning to normal in Kurdistan. The region was virtually depopulated last month, when more than a million and half of Iraq's 3.5 million Kurds fled as troops loyal to President Saddam Hussein bore down. **********But the visiting reporters could not find a single shop open in this dusty town of 150,000 nestling under a barren mountain range some 30 miles from the Turkish border. Everywhere rusting shop shutters were pulled tight and garbage-strewn streets were virtually deserted, with few cars moving. **********Older people stood in clusters near the town center and a handful of vendors offered a few potatoes, spring onions, tomatoes, dates and a little meat but no eggs or staples of any kind.  Some Refugees Turn Back **********At the girls' school, Falheela Hussein, the headmistress, said that only about 200 of her 500 students were showing up for classes and that these were mostly members of Iraq's Chaldean Christian minority, which is traditionally loyal. Most of the missing girls are Kurds, she said. **********Several students said they and their families fled toward Turkey and Iran when Kurdish rebels first attacked the city, then returned because of the severe conditions they encountered. **********Leila Zaid, a 15-year-old Kurdish girl, said her family fled to Zakho, the city on the Turkish border where United States forces have set up a haven for Kurdish refugees, but they found the cold and shortages of food and shelter unbearable. A Kurdish vegetable store owner, Haj Abu Mohammed, said he had fled and then returned after he heard that the Government was offering a general amnesty. **********The Governor of Dohuk Province, Mohammed Perous Rustam, himself a Kurd, insisted that conditions were returning to normal in the town, although he admitted that 70 percent of the population had left in the last few weeks. He accused the Kurdish rebels of preventing people from returning with threats of violence and demands for money. **********The Governor said several thousand Kurdish guerrillas attacked the town and captured it on March 14, holding it for 17 days until Government forces "swept them out." He reported that about 100 people were killed in the fighting and that the rebels executed some 20 city officials while in control. **********People in the town spoke of harsh living conditions, saying there was little food available and only intermittent supplies of water and electricity. **********If conditions in Dohuk are typical of the rest of Kurdistan, it appears unlikely that the recent exodus of Kurds is going to be quickly reversed. **********Dohuk is the capital of one of three provinces that make up the autonomous region of Kurdistan. Although an integral part of Iraq, the Kurds preserve their own language and customs and enjoy a degree of self-government. The two other Kurdish provinces are Irbil and Sulaimaniya.  Signs of Fierce Fighting **********The drive from the northern city of Mosul to Dohuk, across a high rolling plateau fringed by harsh mountains, disclosed a powerful Iraqi military force in the area and evidence of fierce fighting during the revolt. Clusters of tanks and army encampments were spread along the roadside as well as artillery guns, their barrels pointing up into the mountains. **********In Dohuk itself and its surroundings, the huge portraits of President Hussein that adorn major road junctions and important buildings have all been smashed and defaced by the rebels. **********Many buildings are pitted with bullet holes and the army controls all entry points to the town. There were also signs of fighting in the outskirts of Mosul, Iraq's third-largest city, 30 miles away. Gunfire had damaged buildings and walls and several electricity pylons had been knocked over. **********Nevertheless, with this latest Kurdish uprising now crushed, the Iraqi Government appears anxious to reach a permanent settlement with its Kurdish population. **********The Kurds are a Sunni Muslim, non-Turkic and non-Arab people who speak a language related to Persian. There are about 20 million of them, half in eastern Turkey, the rest in northern Iraq, western Iran and parts of Syria and the Soviet Union. The were denied the autonomy that they were promised in a post-World War I treaty and have waged intermittent guerrilla war for their own nation-state in Iraq, Iran and Turkey since then. **********Last week talks opened in Baghdad between the Government and representatives of Kurdish opposition groups in exile. Arab officials say that the talks are continuing but that neither side has given a progress report. **********Kurdish opposition leaders in London insist that they are not seeking an independent Kurdish state but only greater autonomy within Iraq and the right to return to villages from which the Government removed them some years ago as a security precaution.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/08/busin.main_headline: Dun & Bradstreet Unit Looks for New Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/08/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Dun & Bradstreet Unit Looks for New Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/08/busin.body_text: **********A spokeswoman for Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver, New York, said yesterday that the agency had resigned the advertising account for Dun & Bradstreet Software, Framingham, Mass., because of creative differences. **********But Anne Lynn Galloway, the software company's advertising manager, said that it had begun a review of the account and that the agency was not invited to participate. She added that no decision on finalists was expected until Thursday. **********An executive familiar with the account, who insisted on anonymity, said that four finalists had been selected: Grey Advertising, New York, which is Levine, Huntley's parent; Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston; Mullen Advertising, Wenham, Mass., and Wells Rich Greene BDDP, New York. The account had no billings last year, several executives said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/busin.body_text: **********Hachette S.A., the French publisher, said today that the head of its book division had stepped down over "policy differences." Jean-Claude Lattes will be replaced by Jean-Louis Lisimachio, the company said. Hachette did not give details of the departure of Mr. Lattes, who headed the book division for 12 years, but people close to the publishing group said difficulties with Hachette's Grolier unit might have been responsible for his departure.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/19/busin.body_text: **********Cray Research Inc. has signed a licensing agreement with Beta Phase Inc., a maker of high-performance electronic connectors based in Menlo Park, Calif. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/03/busin.main_headline: Columbia Pictures Shift Expected
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/03/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Columbia Pictures Shift Expected
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/03/busin.body_text: **********Sony Pictures Entertainment plans to announce on Thursday that Mark Canton, a former Warner Brothers executive, will replace Frank Price as head of Columbia Pictures. **********The planned announcement comes after a turbulent and confused day at Columbia, a Sony Pictures subsidiary, in which Mr. Price's office sent newspapers copies of his biography and his planned projects, while executives at Sony Pictures said they were not announcing any changes today. **********Mr. Price, who was put in charge of Columbia a little more than 18 months ago, and Sony executives declined to comment. Mr. Canton, a longtime tennis-playing friend of Peter Guber, the head of Sony Pictures, played an important part in releasing such Warner successes as "Lethal Weapon" and "Batman." But he was also involved in several critical and financial disasters, including "Bonfire of the Vanities." Said to Be Guber's Doing **********Officials at the studio said that the change-over was Mr. Guber's doing. Film executives here said Mr. Canton owed his accession to one of the most powerful jobs in Hollywood largely to the fact that Mr. Guber feels very comfortable with him. "The comfort level is very strong," said one executive, who refused to be identified. "He was never too comfortable with Frank, who has a different style and is of a different generation." **********Studio officials said Mr. Price, 61 years old, would be paid $15 million to $20 million in a buyout deal and would remain with Columbia Pictures to produce films that do not necessarily have to be made at Columbia. Executives said the buyout amount represented the value of the rest of Mr. Price's five-year contract -- he took over Columbia in March 1990 -- and the value of his profit-sharing arrangement with Sony. **********Executives said the figure also included the estimated worth of scripts, many of them considered to have a potentially high commercial value, owned by Mr. Price's production company. **********As a movie executive at Columbia and elsewhere, Mr. Price, a former television writer, has been responsible for hits like "Tootsie," "Out of Africa," "Ghostbusters," "Gandhi," "Kramer vs. Kramer" and "Back to the Future." **********This term at the helm of Columbia has been Mr. Price's second. He headed the studio from 1978 to 1983 and then ran Universal Pictures studios for three years. He returned to Columbia last year to replace Dawn Steel. His big recent success was the critically acclaimed film "Boyz N the Hood." Another film on his watch, "Return to the Blue Lagoon," took a financial and critical drubbing. **********Film executives said the size of Mr. Price's buyout and the confusion over his departure in recent weeks were a considerable embarrassment to the Sony Corporation, which has already spent vast sums in Hollywood. **********The Japanese giant bought Columbia for $3.4 billion in 1989. Sony also paid hundreds of millions of dollars to hire away the producers Peter Guber and Jon Peters but later bought Mr. Peters out of his $2.75-million-a-year contract. The company also made a costly multimillion-dollar buyout of Walter Yetnikoff, who had been the head of CBS Records. **********While Sony will not say, it is widely believed that Mr. Peters was paid $15 million to $25 million and that Mr. Yetnikoff walked away with a $20 million severance after receiving about $40 million in the few years Sony had owned CBS Records. **********"It's absolutely extraordinary the money Sony is tossing around -- and for what?" said one prominent studio executive. "You don't get rid of someone like Frank Price, a guy with a track record like his, after 18 months. Frank is a guy who may be slow, but he's smart, he's methodical and he succeeds." Sony Chief's View of Studio **********Movie studio chiefs assert Sony is plainly unhappy with the current team's performance at Columbia. But in a recent impromptu conversation with a reporter in Tokyo, Akio Morita, the president of Sony, denied that he was very concerned about the financial drain and a lack of big movie hits. **********"It's no problem!" Mr. Morita said. "You have to remember the lessons we always learned in R.&D., which is that you make an investment and it takes 10 years to get a return on it. So wait 10 years and you will see that we made the right decision." **********Asked about the negative newspaper and magazine articles about Sony Entertainment, Mr. Morita replied: "Look, it wasn't our decision to change the name to Sony Entertainment. That was their decision in Los Angeles. We had nothing to do with it." **********And when asked about the executive turnover at Sony Pictures, he said: "That's always going on in Hollywood. It's no problem." **********As head of his own company, Price Entertainment, Mr. Price has 30 to 40 projects and will work out of the Sony Pictures studios in Culver City in Los Angeles, associates said. **********His decision today to send out facsimilies of his biography and plans for the future stunned Sony officials. **********Mr. Price's move was apparently prompted by a report in The Hollywood Reporter today that expressed uncertainty about the number of films he will make with Columbia. Aides said Mr. Price was especially touchy to the commonly expressed criticism that he makes decisions too slowly. **********Aides also said Mr. Price believed that Sony was planning to announce the change-over today, not Thursday, and was planning, essentially, to publicly disclose his own plans and not leave it entirely in the hands of Sony executives. **********Mr. Price is both annoyed and frustrated at the way his ouster has been handled, aides said. Mr. Guber and Mr. Canton have declined to comment on the executive shuffle, which has been the talk of studio executives for the last two weeks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/04/busin.body_text: **********The Allied Stores Corporation and Federated Department Stores Inc. today reported losses for April. Federated said it lost $7.05 million, on sales of $335.9 million, in the four weeks that ended on May 4. That compares with a loss of $9.33 million, on sales of $401.5 million, in the five weeks that ended on April 6. Allied said it lost $11.4 million, on sales of $189.5 million, in the latest period, compared with a loss of $9.86 million, on sales of $217.1 million, in the previous five weeks. Both companies, affiliates of Federated Stores Inc., are required to report their results each month to the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Cincinnati. They filed for bankruptcy protection in January 1990.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/world.main_headline: U.S. Agrees to Protect Minerals in Antarctic
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/world.print_headline: U.S. Agrees to Protect Minerals in Antarctic
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/world.body_text: **********The United States will end its isolated opposition to an international treaty imposing a 50-year ban on mineral exploitation of Antarctica, President Bush has announced. **********Environmental advocates praised the Administration's decision to sign a protocol protecting the Antarctic environment, which had been approved by 38 other nations. The action appears to have ended an increasingly heated confrontation between the White House, on the one hand, and Congressional leaders, pro-environment groups and foreign governments, on the other. **********In a statement made on Wednesday at Rapid City, S.D., Mr. Bush explicitly supported limits on tourism, waste disposal and marine pollution in Antarctica, as well as "restrictions on mineral activity." **********The environmental advocacy group Greenpeace issued a statement saying, "We are pleased that President Bush has acknowledged the importance of protecting Antarctica." The statement added: "That recognition carries with it a responsibility to lead the way for permanent protection of our last continental wilderness." **********The United States has long insisted that mineral exploitation of Antarctica be subject to international regulation in the interest of protecting the fragile habitats along the continent's fringe. But Washington had flatly opposed outright permanent bans on mining, oil extraction and other forms of commercial exploitation. **********After long negotiations, however, the State Department tentatively agreed to a protocol to the 1959 Antarctic Treaty that would prohibit mining for the next 50 years, but which would allow any nation signing the treaty to withdraw from the agreement. Representatives of the 39 nations party to the agreement met in Madrid last month with the expectation of signing it on June 23, the treaty's 30th anniversary. **********The accord demilitarized Antarctica, suspended all territorial claims on the continent, and limited activities to scientific research. The treaty was subject to review at the end of 30 years. Bush Wanted More Leeway **********But on the eve of the signing of the new protocol, the American delegation said it needed more time, since President Bush intended to introduce wording that would allow signing nations to withdraw from the agreement fairly easily, even before the expiration of the 50-year mining ban. **********Among American critics of the proposed change was Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, who said that "the State Department is poised to fly in the face of a carefully crafted and hard-fought agreement." He added, "Why they feel they have to upset the apple cart at this critical point is beyond me." **********Senator Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, commented: "The Administration's rejection of a treaty to protect Antarctica -- supported by every nation considering it -- reverses legislation passed by Congress and signed into law by President Bush, leaving the United States once again as the lone stumbling block preventing international action to protect the environment." **********In his statement, Mr. Bush did not say when the United States would sign the protocol.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/06/world.main_headline: Refugees Fear Future in Iraq Without U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/06/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Refugees Fear Future in Iraq Without U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/06/world.body_text: **********For many Iraqis who are flocking to this region, the Americans who are handing out food and medicine are regarded as benefactors. For others here, these same Americans are seen as the major threat to a cherished way of life. **********Many Iraqis who have lived in this sleepy community for years say they want to see the United States Army go, even though they appreciate the goods that the Army has been distributing. **********"We wish the Americans would leave tomorrow," Abdullah Mohammed, the Mayor of Safwan, said as he offered a guest a cup of sweetened tea.  Americans Are Strangers **********"It is our home, and the Americans are a stranger people," he said through an Iraqi interpreter. **********But just about a mile down the road at the Temporary Refugee Center, thousands of desperate Iraqis who have fled the fighting north of here are distraught that the Americans are intent on leaving Iraq and are begging the Americans to take them along. **********"What will happen when the Americans leave?" asked an educated refugee who opposes President Saddam Hussein and would identify himself only as Ahmed. "Are we going to be killed by Saddam's troops?" **********Safwan falls inside the nine-mile-wide demilitarized zone that is to be set up along Iraq's border with Kuwait under the United Nations Security Council's cease-fire resolution. **********The United Nations peacekeeping force that is to patrol the zone will presumably be able to protect the 11,000 refugees here from the Iraqi Army. But the fate of the 5,000 refugees in camps in Salman and Busaya, towns that fall outside the corridor, and other small groups scattered throughout the occupied zone remains uncertain.  Uneasy Peace in the Town **********To most of the world, Safwan is the place where Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the American commander in the Persian Gulf, and Iraqi generals worked out a temporary cease-fire. **********But Safwan does not look like an important place. Street vendors sit on the cracked pavement and sell home-grown tomatoes. Blood from a newly reopened butcher shop trickles out the door and across the sidewalk. **********There is an uneasy peace between the Iraqis in the town, who are reluctant to talk politics, and the refugees at the camp just outside, many of whom are bitter foes of President Hussein. **********The American Army is caught in the middle. Many Iraqis in the town view the refugees from the fighting in the north as trouble. They say the newcomers are bringing crime to their neighborhoods. And the local residents appear to be afraid that the influx of refugees will mark their town as a center of resistance to the Iraqi authorities. **********An Iraqi professional said that while the clinic run by the American Army had helped Iraqis here, he was looking forward to the day the Army would leave. "How would you feel if your country were bombed by Iraq?" he said. "We are not a primitive people. We do not like to live in darkness and see houses fall down and people killed." **********But many of the refugees, who count themselves as ardent opponents of Mr. Hussein, view Safwan with suspicion and say the big mistake of the United States was to end the war too soon. **********"Bush says he does not want to intervene in a civil war," said an Iraqi who has traveled to the United States and who also identified himself only as Ahmed. "But you helped the resistance in Afghanistan and Nicaragua. This is an uprising, not a civil war. It is between good and evil." **********The refugees -- who number between 7,000 and 10,000, according to estimates here -- generally stay within the wire mesh fence that surrounds this sandy compound, the grounds of an abandoned Indian construction company. Many of the refugees sleep in the open air, under the skies gray with smoke from the nearby oil fires. Women can be seen washing clothes in dank pools of water outside the gates. **********Some of the refugees say they are afraid to venture much outside the gates for fear that they will be kidnapped by Mr. Hussein's agents. **********While Army officials with the Third Armored Division here have not reported any kidnappings, Army officials say that Iraqi Government agents have been picked up here and at Checkpoint Bravo, a post about 35 miles west of Basra, manned by the Army's First Armored Division. The Iraqi agents were suspected of preparing lists of Mr. Hussein's opponents for retribution once the Americans left. **********Juggling these two communities is a delicate task for the Third Armored Division. On the one hand, the Army is trying to help the Iraqi authorities assume responsibility for managing Safwan. On the other hand, they are providing food and care at the refugee camp to some of Mr. Hussein's most fervent opponents. **********Army medical teams, who set up a clinic in Safwan several weeks ago in an abandoned Government hospital, were heartened to receive a letter the other day from Iraqi officials in Basra. The letter said the staff of the hospital planned to return to work side by side with the Americans until the United States Army left. **********Other Army efforts to manage the situation here have been less successful. Two weeks ago, word spread throughout Safwan that the refugees at the camp planned to hold a demonstration against Mr. Hussein. When the United States Army heard the reports, it withdrew its military police to the outskirts of town so they would not get caught up in any possible fighting and could be deployed more easily if a disruption broke out. **********No demonstration was held, and military police patrols of Safwan have resumed. The refugees say they appreciate the food and medical care that they receive from the Army. **********But one thing the Army cannot give them is an answer about their fate. One refugee said that every morning he approached Army officials and asked them if the United States would help the foes of Mr. Hussein to escape from Iraq when the Army left. **********"The answer is always the same," he said. "They say that this is a matter for the politicians."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/23/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Capital Cities Net Declines Nearly 45%
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/23/busin.body_text: **********Capital Cities/ABC Inc. said yesterday that its quarterly income fell nearly 45 percent from the period a year earlier. The company said the recession and the Persian Gulf conflict hurt most of its broadcasting and publishing businesses. **********As with the other two leading networks, ABC was affected by weak advertising demand and the pre-emption of scheduled commercial time because of news coverge of the gulf war. Capital Cities/ABC said those problems were partly offset by revenues from the broadcast of the Super Bowl and two National Football League playoff games.  'A Difficult Quarter' **********John S. Reidy, a media analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said: "We knew it was going to be a difficult quarter. It was in line with our expectations and the current trends for networks. The big unknown is how the networks' up-front business will shape up for the coming season. There is no one willing to stand out on the limb and make any predictions. There is absolutely no clue as to how it will go. " **********The company reported net profits of $58.5 million, or $3.50 a share, for the first quarter, compared with $106.3 million, or $6.08 a share, for the 1990 quarter. Its revenues were down slightly, to $1.25 billion, from $1.26 billion a year earlier. **********The number of the company's shares outstanding dropped to 16.7 million from 17.4 million. Publishing Revenues Down **********Capital Cities/ABC's 8 television stations and 21 radio stations reported small declines in revenues because of soft ad demand. The publishing operations reported a 7 percent drop in revenues in large part because of weak markets. **********Capital Cities/ABC alluded to continuing problems yesterday, saying that since the war ended, some recovery toward more normal business patterns was being experienced by many of its businesses, but that the "current level of advertising demand may not be sufficient to preclude an earnings decline in the second quarter of 1991." **********In recent weeks, the General Electric Company has said that the first-quarter earnings of its NBC operation were "sharply lower," though it did not break out its earnings separately. CBS Inc. has reported a loss for the quarter, which it attributed to the high cost of sports programming and costs associated with covering the war. CBS said it expected to have a loss for the year, which would be the second annual loss for the network in 40 years.  Broadcast Income Off 40% **********At Capital Cities/ABC, the company said that its operating income from broadcasting fell 40 percent, to $120.2 million from $200.5 million, and that its publishing operating income fell 24 percent, to $18.4 million from $24.3 million. The company publishes daily and weekly newspapers, shopping guides, various specialty and business periodicals and books. **********Capital Cities/ABC also owns 80 percent of ESPN, which accounts for about 90 percent of the company's video-entertainment operation. Its operating income was down marginally but no figures were given. **********It also owns approximately a third of the Arts and Entertainment Network and a third of Lifetime, another cable-television service. The company did not provide income figures for the businesses. **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Capital Cities/ABC's stock fell $7.75, to $461.25.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/16/busin.body_text: **********COMPANIES **********Citicorp, reeling from bad loans, said it lost $885 million in the quarter and would rebuild its strength by eliminating its dividend and cutting expenses further.  [ Page A1. ]  Security Pacific also reported a stunning loss and suspended its dividend, but Chemical and Manufacturers did better.  [ D8. ] **********I.B.M. came out with some grim earnings numbers, but after it indicated that the worst might finally be over, its stock price rose sharply. It said it had made progress in trimming its work force and bringing several important product lines to market.  [ D1. ] **********Merrill Lynch and Paine Webber reported strong earnings. The shares of both firms climbed sharply.  [ D1. ] **********General Electric reported a modest 2 percent profit increase but said earnings of its finance unit jumped 19 percent.  [ D1. ] **********Wachtell, Lipton's slick image has been dented by, among other things, a whiff of scandal in the Salomon debacle.  [ D1. ] **********Continental Air's fate has narrowed largely to two choices, its chief executive said.  [ D3. ] **********Defeating an appeal by drug companies, the Supreme Court refused to order regulators to adhere to deadlines set by Congress aimed at speeding approval or rejection of generic drugs.  [ D3. ] **********Five chip makers infringed on a Texas Instruments patent, the I.T.C. ruled. But another ruling nearly nullified that one. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/24/world.print_headline: AFTER THE COUP; Radicals' Proud Moment
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/24/world.body_text: **********Boris N. Yeltsin and his minions were riding high on their victory today, grilling a humbled Mikhail S. Gorbachev, shaping the composition of the next Government, shutting down hostile newspapers and suspending the Russian Communist Party. **********But even as they savored the spoils of a decisive victory over a system that had resisted them so long, it was far from clear that their ascendance would translate into the radical transformation of Soviet society that has been their goal. **********The lesson of anti-Communist revolutions past was that the sweet taste of victory was inevitably followed by the bitter reassertion of hard realities. The fall of the Berlin wall was followed by the bankruptcy of eastern Germany. Czechoslovakia faced dismemberment, Romania remained chaotic. New Dangers **********And this country, whether under the restored Russian tricolor or the hammer and sickle, was still a beggared land with only a marginal experience of democracy, a widely divided populace and an economy in tatters. **********There were new dangers, too: Mr. Gorbachev was still capable of applying brakes to radical reform. A newly ascendant Russian leadership stood to touch off a wave of seperatism. The window of opportunity opened by the failed coup could rapidly close when the hangover sets in. **********Mr. Yeltsin himself was setting questionable precedents by decreeing the closing of newspapers and suspending the Russian Communist Party, and the anti-Communist fervor underscored the weakness of the fledgling democratic institutions. Mr. Yeltsin's following had been united largely in opposition to the Communists, and it could yet splinter under the pressure of hard decisions. **********For now, in the immediate aftermah of the ignominious collapse of the old commissars' coup, there seemed no limit to the possibilities before the victorious collection of reformers, nationalists, intellectuals and democrats ranged behind the burly back of Mr. Yeltsin. Gorbachev Isolated **********The K.G.B. was under siege, the military was docile, the police were under a Yeltsinite, the Communist Party no longer had the wherewithal to resist the long-gathering fury of the nation and President Gorbachev was isolated. **********But even as the victors celebrated, the challenges were evident. **********There was Mr. Gorbachev. Brought before the Russian Parliament in what was meant as a show of gratitude and solidarity for his deliverance by the Russian leaders, he soon came to appear less a president than a co-conspirator in the dock at a political tribunal. **********Though he repeatedly said "we reformers" and spoke of the need to maintain unity "in the ranks of democrats," he made clear he was not prepared to cast his lot unequivocally with the radical reformers. **********He talked of continuing with his Government's weak economic program, he maneuvered to keep his own people in Government, he defended the "peasants, workers and intelligentsia" of the Communist Party, and he sought to depict the coup as aimed against him personally and not as an onslaught by the system with which he had been allied and organized by those he had appointed. **********Soon heckling spread through the hall, and Mr. Yeltsin, openly asserting his power over an old rival, repeatedly prompted and corrected Mr. Gorbachev, even ordering him in prosecutorial tones to read out notes from a closed meeting of the Council of Ministers at which minister after minister was revealed to have embraced the state of emergency or condoned it. **********The sparring suggested that even if the balance of forces had dramatically tilted toward Mr. Yeltsin, a new relationship had yet to take shape between the old rivals and Mr. Gorbachev was not yet ready to assume a ceremonial role. **********And for all of Mr. Yeltsin's new authority, Mr. Gorbachev still commanded considerable powers as federal President, capable at least of impeding the passage of that with which he disagreed. **********That possibility alarmed advocates of radical reform who believed that the moment had to be seized immediately if it was not to be lost. 'Ready Now to Accept Sacrifice' **********"People who stood three nights in the rain to protect Yeltsin are ready now to accept sacrifice," argued Sergei A. Zverev, a member of the economic research center led by the radical economist Grigory A. Yavlinsky, with whom Mr. Yeltsin had held vigil in the threatened Russian Parliament during the coup. "But the window will not be open forever." **********The heckling of Mr. Gorbachev and the shouts of "resign, resign" as he drove away from the parliament testified to the mood of disappointed expectations. **********It began on Wednesday night, when on his return from the Crimea Mr. Gorbachev did not come directly to the Russian Parliament where the resistance to the coup was centered. And it turned more sour over the full day that passed before he came. **********"If he had come that night, we would have carried him on our shoulders," Mr. Zverev said. "Instead he started saying that he is still a Communist. He missed a great opportunity."  'He Is Lucky He Survived' **********Mr. Gorbachev's performance was also seen as a failure to appreciate the real significance of the coup. **********"What Mikhail Sergeyevich failed to understand is that all his power and the power of the bureaucracy is supported by four whales -- the military industrial complex, the K.G.B., the army and the bureaucracy," said Dr. Vyacheslav Fyodorov, a prominent eye surgeon and a Russian deputy. **********"Until he destroys them, not without our help, his power is ephemeral. Any moment, as soon as he stops serving them, they will wipe him out. He is lucky that he survived. But instead of eliminating the chance of a repetition, he is dreaming of some strange reformation." **********Yet if Mr. Gorbachev disappointed the Yeltsinites by affirming old socialist loyalty and clinging to old programs, the newly ascendant forces had yet to shape their own clear agenda. Mr. Yeltsin had adopted for Russia a version of the radical "500-day" economic program that Mr. Gorbachev had earlier rejected. But until the new union treaty became binding, he still lacked the levers or powers to put it in effect.  Dangers in the Streets **********The other potential dangers rose from the streets. Though a wave of anti-Communist fervor was inevitable in the heat of the moment, it was only Mr. Gorbachev who cautioned that the passions undermined the political tolerance that the reformers had so ardently demanded. **********Mr. Yeltsin, instead of urging caution, seemed to fan the flames by closing down hostile Communist newspapers and demonstratively signing a decree to suspend the Russian Communist Party while Mr. Gorbachev was still at the podium. **********Beyond that was the repeated claim of victory for the Russian republic. One of the disclosures at the parliament session was that Mr. Gorbachev had agreed that the federal Prime Minister would always be a Russian citizen, and that news, combined with the vast new influence of the Russian Government on the Kremlin, seemed likely to fan secessionist sentiments in the other republics. **********And yet, arrayed against all these challenges was the sense that the people had finally overcome what had been the major obstacles to real freedom and real change. **********For all the dangers and threats inherent in a time of revolutionary change, a nation that was despairing of its ability to finally shake off its 70-year yoke had finally done it, and that at a moment when it desperately required a morale boost. **********"If we could do this," argued an engineer outside the Russian Parliament, "I think we can do the rest."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/busin.main_headline: Regional Danger in the Free Trade Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/busin.print_headline: Regional Danger in the Free Trade Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Your articles on the decision to negotiate a free trade agreement in North America -- "We Will Regret a Rush to Free Trade" (Forum, Oct. 6) and "Make the Free-Trade Vision a Reality" (Forum, June 30) -- fail to look beyond the Western Hemisphere to how to make the global free-and-fair-trade compact attainable and viable. This is the logical next stage of the liberal-trade policy we have been trying to perfect for half a century. **********With few exceptions, even self-styled free traders have easily accepted, even touted, the current initiative, in some cases proposing refinements, but not questioning its regional limitations. **********Widely neglected is the real possibility that the free-trade bloc projected for our hemisphere -- and those that exist or are being created elsewhere -- could engender a new fashion in trade protectionism: regional, not nationalist, but objectionable nonetheless. DAVID J. STEINBERG  Alexandria, Va., Oct. 7

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/26/world.main_headline: EUROPE EMBRACING BALTIC INDEPENDENCE; PURGE OF MILITARY
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/26/world.print_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL: SOVIETS' RUSH TOWARD DISUNION SPREADS; EUROPE EMBRACING BALTIC INDEPENDENCE; PURGE OF MILITARY
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/26/world.body_text: **********Following quickly on the rout of the Communist Party, the unraveling of the Soviet Union itself gained speed today, with one republic after another joining the rush to independence or laying claim to powers of the central government. **********One day after the vital Ukraine declared its independence, Byelorussia unexpectedly followed suit, Moldavia announced it would vote on a similar declaration Monday, and Western governments began recognizing the secession of the three Baltic republics. **********President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic, who has emerged in the aftermath of the failed coup by hard-liners as the predominant political figure in the country, said in a television interview that he hoped the mainstay repulics would sign a treaty next month reorganizing the country into a looser federation. **********But with 8 of the 15 republics now asserting or contemplating claims of full independence, there were growing doubts that even Mr. Yeltsin could find a formula to halt the dismembering of this nuclear superpower.  Repercussions of Coup Attempt **********Aftershocks from the abortive coup against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the Soviet leader's subsequent abandonment of the Communist Party rolled across the country today. **********A presidential spokesman announced that Mr. Gorbachev's military adviser, Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, had killed himself on Saturday night. No evidence has surfaced implicating Marshal Akhromeyev, the former chief of staff of the armed forces, in the attempted coup, but he was instrumental in promoting the military commanders who participated, and he had publicly belittled the danger of a putsch.  [ Obituary, page A13. ] **********The new Soviet Defense Minister announced plans for a wholesale purge that he said would replace "about 80 percent" of the top command structure with younger officers. **********"The people must be younger than we have had, more loyal, and not capable of unconstitutional gambits," said the minister, Gen. Yevgeny Shaposhnikov, who as commander of the air force defied the conspirators and supported Mr. Yeltsin. **********Shake-ups were also anticipated in the K.G.B. and Interior Ministry, following the collaboration of top national security officials in the three-day coup. **********[ The Speaker of the Soviet Parliament, Anatoly I. Lukyanov, who has been accused of complicity in the coup, resigned his post, according to Vitaly S. Ignatenko, a spokesman for Mr. Gorbachev who was quoted on a Cable News Network broadcast. ] **********Local governments across the country seized Communist Party buildings following Mr. Gorbachev's decree on Saturday effectively nationalizing the party's wealth. Citizens toppled monuments to Bolshevik heroes, prompting Mr. Yeltsin and other officials to plead for calm. **********"There should be no euphoria of revenge," Mr. Yeltsin told a television interviewer tonight. "Otherwise we will lose our self-respect as democrats." **********Mr. Gorbachev, who appears to have become essentially a junior partner in a coalition government with Mr. Yeltsin, was reported to be at work on a speech for an emergency session of the Soviet Parliament on Monday, which will seek to clarify the murky issue of just who is running the country.  Gains for Yeltsin **********Although the Soviet leader remains Commander in Chief of the armed forces, and is still formally in charge of the central Government, since his return from captivity he has ceded to the Russian president remarkable sway in dictating the shape of a future government. **********On Saturday Mr. Gorbachev named Mr. Yeltsin's prime minister, Ivan S. Silayev, to head a committee charged with drastically reshaping the federal Government and decentralizing economic powers to the republics. **********The four-member committee is dominated by Yeltsin loyalists, who favor slashing central ministries, privatizing state-owned industry and moving rapidly to a free market. **********Mr. Yeltsin said he remains committed to a union treaty that would cede vast powers to the republics.  A Role for Gorbachev? **********The Yeltsin team, which once called for Mr. Gorbachev's resignation, now plans to retain Mr. Gorbachev in a scaled-back role, presiding over military and foreign policy and such centralized economic structures as the electric power grid. **********"Mikhail Sergeyevich has not yet exhausted his potential," said Ruslan Khasbulatov, chairman of the Russian parliament, in an interview with the independent news agency Interfax. "I don't think that he needs to resign. We, the Russian government, will help him a great deal." **********Mr. Yeltsin said today that he believed the republics should be represented in the National Security Council as a check on the Soviet president's handling of defense policy, and Mr. Khasbulatov suggested that in the new federation, the president would be chosen by the republics rather than in a general election.  A Different Viewpoint **********But aides involved in negotiations between the two leaders say that Mr. Gorbachev has not yet entirely resigned himself to the role of a figurehead. **********In the appointment of a new chief of the security agencies, Mr. Gorbachev successfully insisted on putting his own man in charge of the K.G.B., for example. The parliamentary session gives Mr. Gorbachev a chance -- perhaps his last chance -- to describe how he sees his future role. **********But the redistribution of powers is complicated by the eruption of secessionist sentiment, which is worrisome to both leaders. **********In the Ukraine, the independence declaration calls for the republic to assume control of Soviet military assets on its territory and create its own army. The declaration, which requires popular ratification in a referendum in December, leaves unanswered the question of the nuclear weapons deployed there. **********Mr. Yeltsin faces the additional predicament that the disintegration of the union could spread to his own domain. The Russian federation includes dozens of ethnic homelands, many of them itching for greater sovereignty. Concern Over Ukraine **********A Yeltsin aide said today the Russian president would support the wishes of the Ukrainian people, but expressed concern about the loss of such a key republic. In addition to the question of the military and the Ukraine's importance as a farming and industrial stronghold, the aide said, the loss of its 52 million Slavs would tilt the ethnic balance of the remaining union toward the Muslims of Central Asia. **********That concern grew today with news that the parliament in Byelorussia, the third Slavic republic, had approved an independence declaration. Byelorussia, with a population of 10 million the fifth largest republic, has long been regarded as the most conservative of the republics on the European portion of the Soviet Union, and has seemed relatively immune from the secessionist passions of its Baltic and Ukrainian neighbors. **********The declaration was apparently designed by Byelorussian Communists, who still hold a majority in the parliament, as a way of insulating themselves from Mr. Gorbachev's decree ordering confiscation of party property. A smaller nationalist faction in the parliament also supported the move. Byelorussian Leader Quits **********In another move to protect the party from the wave of anti-Communist sentiment, the hard-line Communist president of the republic, Nikolai Dementei, resigned under pressure. **********The republic of Moldavia announced today that its parliament would vote on secession on Tuesday, a measure that is expected to pass. **********"Moldavia will no longer be part of an empire which is falling to pieces," the speaker of its parliament, Alexandru Mosanu, told Reuters in Kishinev, the capital. "We shall become independent, and this is part of a chain reaction which no force in the world could stop now."  Recognition of Baltic Republics **********The Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, whose claim to independence has been endorsed by Mr. Yeltsin but not Mr. Gorbachev, today began to win international recognition. Denmark and Norway announced that they would establish diplomatic relations with the breakaway republics, which were forcibly annexed in 1940. **********Latvia and Estonia voted their independence this week, while Lithuania declared its freedom last year. **********The German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, called on the European Community today to recognize Baltic independence, and there was mounting pressure in the United States for President Bush to do the same. **********Mr. Gorbachev has insisted in the past that secession be carried out according to Soviet law, which requires a referendum and a waiting period of up to five years. He now finds himself under strong pressure from Mr. Yeltsin to acquiesce. Military Commander Ousted **********The Soviet Government today showed signs of relaxing its stance on the Baltics. The commander of military forces in the region, a bitter foe of pro-independence governments, was dismissed for acquiescing in the coup. **********The Latvian president, Anatoly Gorbunovs, met in Moscow today with leaders of the Soviet military, K.G.B. and Interior Ministry and announced afterward that they had agreed to suspend their activies in his republic and open negotiations on "disarmament." **********In the aftermath of Mr. Gorbachev's resignation on Saturday as general secretary of the Communist Party, the party leadership today followed his urging and called for an emergency meeting to disband. **********The party's administrative secretariat issued an appeal to Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin to permit a special session of the governing Central Committee where "the only possible decision" would be dissolution. **********In announcing his resignation on Saturday, Mr. Gorbachev noted that the party leadership had taken no position condemning the coup, that the main conspirators against him had been members of the Central Committee, and that party newspapers had supported the putsch. **********Their behavior, he said, had exposed millions of rank-and-file Communists to the threat of anti-Communist hysteria. **********The secretariat insisted that the coup plans were kept in secrecy and that party leaders "tried to do everything to prevent blood from being spilled." **********Some republics have suspended or outlawed the party, and party buildings have been sealed pending investigation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/world.main_headline: 100 Killed in Blast at Ethiopian Depot
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/world.print_headline: 100 Killed in Blast at Ethiopian Depot
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/world.body_text: **********A huge explosion at a major munitions depot leveled a shantytown here today, leaving scores dead. Government officials blamed a grenade attack launched by stragglers from the dissolved Ethiopian Army. **********Officials of the interim Government and some diplomats said the blast, which could be heard across this city of three million people, killed more than 100 people living in a highly congested neighborhood adjoining the arms storage center. **********The explosion, which began just before 4 o'clock this morning, set off fires that contnued to blaze and smoulder for more than 11 hours. As daylight spread, the quarter, which housed some 10,000 residents, was reduced to a smoking ruin of mangled tin and splintered wood. **********Rescuers from the Red Cross said it would take days to dig through the rubble and to account for all victims. They recovered three bodies this morning and removed 80 wounded people. **********But one Ethiopian journalist said he counted 15 dead bodies as he walked through part of the area. **********The rescuers said the many corrugated iron huts in the quarter had kept the numbers of dead and wounded lower than might have been expected if the housing was more substantial. They said the iron sheeting was just strong enough to withstand the showers of shrapnel but not so heavy as to crush or bury residents as the houses collapsed. **********Gebre Tsadkan, the Tigrean military administrator in Addis Ababa, said his men had captured several suspects, including a former high-ranking Ethiopian army officer. He said the officer was caught trying to shoot a grenade into a truck full of fuel. He said other attackers tried but failed to set fire to a nearby grain depot. **********Doctors said the victims were mostly hurt by flying glass, shrapnel and bullets set off by the heat of a fire storm.  Shock Waves and Flames **********At the Dejazmach Balcha Memorial Hospital, run by Soviet medical personnel, several victims looked traumatized from the fiery explosions as they waited for treatment. **********"Even houses built of stone were consumed by fire," said Addis Metafari, a 26-year-old housewife whose right leg was heavily bandaged, in between her moans for water. She described waking up startled by bright red flames and helping her mother-in-law escape down a hill when "I felt my leg not moving." **********The blasts that ravaged the southside Nefafilka neighborhood sent explosive projectiles and tracer bullets flying for miles, setting off minor fires in the western outskirts. Shock waves broke windows across much of the capital. Looting was reported in a number of markets. **********The attack, the most serious violence to occur here since rebels from the north of Ethiopia overthrew a 17-year old Marxist regime of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam and installed themselves as an interim government, took place as the city appeared to be returning to normal after a week of street battles and demonstrations.  Vulnerability to Attacks **********"This proves the Tigreans are not yet in control of the city," said a senior Middle Eastern diplomat, speaking of the now ruling rebel forces whose home base in Tigre Province lies several hundred of miles from here. "They are not prepared to stop terrorism." **********The Tigreans have not been fully accepted or enthusiastically welcomed by the Amhara ethnic group that dominates Addis Ababa. They are particularly unpopular among nationalists who resent their loose alliance with separatist rebels who seek to form an independent country in the Red Sea province of Eritrea.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/06/world.body_text: **********The shriveling central Soviet Government holds firm control over its 27,000 nuclear weapons, Pentagon officials said this week, but the former republics are pressing for a greater say in the fate of the weapons on their soil. **********The Soviet authorities are said to be in early discussions with Ukraine to give the newly independent republic greater control over the 4,000 nuclear weapons on its territory. Ukraine, which has pledged to create a nuclear-free state, has called for the republics with strategic nuclear weapons to form a collective military command to control and eventually destroy them. **********The Bush Administration's decision to send Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to Kiev this month to discuss Washington's concerns reflects the priority that the United States places on keeping tight control over the Soviet nuclear arsenal as more republics break free. **********The Soviet Union has about 12,000 long-range nuclear weapons in missile silos and submarines and aboard planes as well as 15,000 shorter-range tactical weapons, including artillery shells, gravity bombs and ship-based weapons.  Security of Weapons **********Paramount to American interests, senior Administration officials say, is averting economic and social turmoil that could lead terrorists, thieves or warring armies to seize the weapons now under heavy security. On his trip to Ukraine, Mr. Baker and another American envoy, Assistant Secretary of State Thomas M. T. Niles, will also seek assurances that Kiev intends to honor international arms control agreements signed by Moscow. **********"The most important thing is for the republics to achieve a peaceful separation," a senior Defense Department official said. "If the situation degenerates into the kind of civil war you have in Yugoslavia, no amount of good will will withstand that kind of battering." **********Administration officials said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was a leading advocate of the Administration's decision to move toward recognition of Ukraine's independence, which was opposed by the Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********Since the failed coup in August, Mr. Cheney and senior American military officers have expressed confidence in Soviet control over long-range, or strategic, missiles, and the more mobile tactical, or battlefield, nuclear arms. Confidence in Safeguards **********Elite Russian-dominated military forces guard nuclear weapon depots. Warheads are typically stored miles from their launchers or aircraft and are secured by coded locks. Senior Pentagon officials said this week that American intelligence had detected no significant weakening in these safeguards. **********There are strategic nuclear weapons in Ukraine, Russia, Byelorussia and Kazakhstan and tactical nuclear weapons in all 12 republics, most of which have declared independence in some form. Ukraine has about 15 percent of the Soviet nuclear weapons, including 46 SS-24 long-range missiles that each carry 10 warheads and 130 older SS-19 missiles that have six warheads each, according to Bruce G. Blair, a specialist in Soviet nuclear control procedures at the Brookings Institution. **********Other American experts estimate that Ukraine has 2,500 to 3,000 tactical nuclear weapons, including artillery shells, gravity bombs and ship-based weapons. **********The Administration has taken several steps since the failed coup to encourage a rapid reduction in Soviet nuclear forces. President Bush announced a unilateral initiative in September to dismantle all American tactical nuclear weapons on land and at sea, a decision that prompted a similar order from Mr. Gorbachev for Soviet tactical weapons. **********Soviet and republic leaders have met with senior State Department and Defense Department officials in recent days to discuss the American and Soviet arms proposals and ways to build on them. **********Last week, Congress approved a measure to spend up to $400 million to assist the Soviet Union and the republics in dismantling and destroying their nuclear weapons. The Ukrainian Foreign Minister, Anatoly Zlenko, told a news conference in Kiev this week that his fledging country was interested in taking up the American offer. **********Senator Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican who is the main sponsor of the Soviet aid proposal, along with Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, said, "Right now, there's an eagerness to move to destroy these tactical nuclear weapons in the former republics, but the concern is that eagerness might not last forever." Transferring Arms **********Ukrainian leaders have expressed a willingness to transfer tactical and possibly even older-model strategic weapons to the Russia republic, which has the capability to dispose them, American arms control experts said. But Kiev has taken an increasingly firm stance on retaining some control over the more modern SS-24 missiles, prompting some independent analysts to speculate that Ukraine wants to use the weapons as bargaining chips with Moscow and the West. **********"The United States wants above all to see safe, secure and reliable control over nuclear weapons," the Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, said this week. "It is for the republics and the central authority to work out the arrangements and exactly how that will be accomplished. We certainly don't want to see a proliferation of centers of control over nuclear weapons." **********In Brussels this week, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization urged Ukraine to renounce nuclear weapons, abide by all the Soviet Union's international commitments and define its relations with Moscow and other republics peacefully.  Sharing Control **********Mr. Blair of the Brookings Institution said reports from Kiev indicated that Ukrainian leaders had been meeting quietly with Soviet officials on sharing control over strategic nuclear weapons on Ukrainian territory. He said these talks would continue through next year on guaranteeing that Moscow would consult Kiev before firing strategic nuclear weapons. In a second phase of the agreement, to be carried out from 1993 to 1995, Moscow would need approval from Ukrainian leaders to launch a missile. **********Scientists at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Havard University have suggested that tactical nuclear weapons stored at 15 depots be moved to four central sites, where the weapons would be tagged, identified and eventually dismantled with American assistance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/world.body_text: **********The Government and the guerrillas have threatened to resume the Salvadoran civil war at full force after the latest round of peace talks recessed without agreements and each side asserted that the other was toughening its stand. **********"If they want war, they'll get war," President Alfredo Cristiani said on Wednesday in response to intelligence reports that the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front was preparing for a new offensive. This morning, the guerrillas' Radio Venceremos responded with almost the same phrase. **********Military action is already unusually intense for the rainy season, with the guerrillas relentlessly attacking the electric power system and the army mounting operations to reduce areas of guerrilla control in expectation of a cease-fire in place. **********The latest talks, dealing with a cease-fire and changes in the army, concluded last weekend in Caracas, Venezuela, and a Government official said negotiations would probably resume late in June or the beginning of July in Mexico.  Both Sides Report Progress **********Even while accusing each other of blocking peace, both sides said some progress had been made in the discussions, without specifying what it was. Neither showed any sign of abandoning the year-old negotiations. **********Ernesto Altschul, deputy chief of staff to President Cristiani, said he felt that a breakthrough was near but that the situation on the battlefield was likely to get worse before the cease-fire actually came. **********The army has closed off most of the combat areas to foreign journalists by denying them safe-conduct passes to travel on the roads, but the daily bulletins of the army and the announcements on guerrilla radio confirm frequent combat in the departments of Usulutan, Chalatenango, Morazan and around Guazapa Volcano north of the capital. The deaths and injuries in individual actions have been mostly in single digits, suggesting that the battles have not been large. **********There had been widespread hope that the latest talks would produce a cease-fire, coming as they did on the heels of a successful round in Mexico in March in which a package of constitutional changes was agreed to. The changes were viewed as necessary to entice the leftist guerrillas and their supporters into taking part in peaceful political life once the war has ended.                    --------------------       Democrats Drag Feet on Aid **********WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- House Democrats moved today to delay action on aid to El Salvador at least until September, to keep up pressure on the Government and leftist rebels to reach a peace agreement this summer. **********The Rules Committee chairman, Representrative Joe Moakley, Democrat of Massachusetts, arranged the procedure as his panel gave the go-ahead for action next week on a bill authorizing foreign aid programs for the year that begins Oct. 1.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/12/busin.body_text: **********Japan said today that it would limit car exports to the United States to 2.3 million annually, prompting an outcry from some quarters of the United States auto industry, which has been losing ground steadily to Japanese auto makers. **********The United Automobile Workers union and the Chrysler Corporation called for the Japanese Ministry for International Trade and Industry to include cars built in the United States by Japanese companies in the export ceiling. **********The Ford Motor Company said it was "discouraged that Japan appears to be insensitive to the chronic U.S. trade deficit." In a statement, the General Motors Corporation, the industry leader, said it was concerned with the trade imbalance with Japan but does not think voluntary restraints are effective or necessary. **********There has been little political support outside the automobile industry to limit the United States production of Toyota, Honda, Nissan and other Japanese auto makers, which stands at about 1.5 million cars annually, in addition to the 1.5 million annually imported from Japan. **********Japan first agreed to annual voluntary export curbs in 1981 under strong pressure from the United States Government and American auto makers, then seeking to retrench and restructure. **********When the United States decided not to ask for continued restraints in 1985, Japan set the ceiling at 2.3 million a year and has maintained that figure since. **********In announcing the extension, the Ministry of International Trade Industry said that exports of cars to the United States have declined in recent years. But while exports have dropped, the number of Japanese cars produced in the United States has grown, increasing the share of Japanese brands in the American market to 28.1 percent last year.
