https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/25/busin.body_text: **********The Circle K Corporation, a convenience-store chain that filed for bankruptcy protection in May 1990, said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Robert A. Dearth Jr., had resigned. **********In a statement released by the Phoenix-based company, Mr. Dearth cited personal and family circumstances. He said that since Circle K was unable to file a proposed reorganization plan now, he would step aside so the company could find a successor who could remain throughout the reorganization. **********The company said Mr. Dearth would pursue other career opportunities. **********Bart A. Brown Jr., Circle K's chairman and chief executive, has assumed Mr. Dearth's responsibilities until a successor can be found. **********Before joining Circle K, Mr. Dearth worked for the American Financial Corporation, Circle K's largest shareholder. He tried to restructure Circle K without seeking bankruptcy protection, but was forced to do so when the company's banks failed to agree on a reorganization plan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/03/world.main_headline: Batticaloa Journal; Atrocity by Atrocity, a Priest Chronicles a War
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/03/world.print_headline: Batticaloa Journal; Atrocity by Atrocity, a Priest Chronicles a War
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/03/world.body_text: **********The other day, the Rev. Harry Miller walked into the parched scrubland outside this war-weary town. He walked until a couple of young men with automatic rifles materialized from the landscape to escort him to their camp. **********It was the local headquarters of the guerrilla army of ethnic Tamils -- the so-called Tamil Tigers -- who are fighting to establish a separate state on this island. **********"They had kidnapped this guy," Father Miller said, his native Louisiana lilt skewed by a South Asian cadence nurtured over the last 43 years here. "They wanted him to provide them with 75,000 rupees," about $1,875. "He's a pensioner working on our Peace Committee. I told them, 'You're not going to get any money from him even if you kill him.' Finally, I gave them 10,000 rupees and he's back." **********For Father Miller, it was a routine day, perhaps a bit better than routine because for the first time in a while he had saved a life. More often in the last year, though, it has been chronicling the deaths and disappearances of thousands of local people that has consumed the New Orleans Jesuit.  The Grim Statistics **********In a corner turret of the high school he once ran, Father Miller records each death, each disappearance, each buried body, each pile of ashes, all the final product, he says, of arrests and roundups of Tamils by the Sri Lankan army and police. He tells the tale of what happened to Kockkadicholai village in July. **********"There was this army tractor going along hauling some things and the Tigers blew it up and killed the soldiers," he said. "The army came back and massacred the people of this village, 123 dead and 40 in the hospital. They burned 350 kadjan houses, coconut leaf houses. They just shot the people. Fifty-six of the bodies were burned, 67 were buried. It was the army. No doubt about it. **********"They feel free to burn bodies at the roadside because nobody will testify against them. They feel free to throw boys in wells because nobody will testify against them. They feel free to kick boys in the head because nobody will testify against them. They feel free to dispose of 2,700 citizens of Batticaloa." **********Behind his battered wooden desk, Father Miller flips through page after page listing the names of people who are no longer found in Batticaloa, names a small group called the Peace Committee have compiled and sent to the local army and police commanders seeking information. The committee, a group of local people put together by Father Miller, badger the army and police for explanations. Rarely do they get any; more often than not it is subtle threats of violence that filter their way. **********"Already, two presidents of the Peace Committee have resigned," Father Miller said. "They were afraid for their families."  Rebels Rule by Night **********For nearly a decade now, the Tamil Tigers and the Sri Lankan armed forces have battled for control of this eastern part of this island. The Tigers say they fight for the rights of the Tamil ethnic minority, for years discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese; the Sri Lankan forces battle to preserve national unity. **********In daylight hours, the army controls the single 50-mile stretch of road between government-controlled areas to the west and Batticaloa. But when the sun settles into the mountains, the countryside, and the road, return to the Tigers. **********The Tigers tax the local population in gold, as they do elsewhere in the territory they control, And while the practice of requiring families to give up one of their sons to the movement has not become widespread here, there is a mixture of resentment and ambivalence toward the guerrillas among the people of this shrinking town. "They presume to talk for us," Father Miller said, "but nobody asked us. We didn't chose them. But they have the guns." **********When he came here in 1948 as a fresh-faced missionary, Sri Lanka was a drowsy place of farmers and fishermen. "It was like 1890's America, like the Louisiana my grandfather grew up in." recalled Father Miller, who is 65 years old. "It's changed a bit and changed for the worse. In those days, there was never any violence, except on the football field." **********Last year, a fellow Jesuit from Louisiana, Eugene J. Herbert, disappeared while riding his scooter back to Batticaloa from an outlying convent. "I went to the army and the police," said Father Miller, "and no investigation was ever done." **********It was last year, he said, that the killing here reached a crescendo and the work of the Peace Committee began in earnest. "Last July we started to keep a record of the people taken into custody by the army. As of this month, we have 2,700 disappeared people. Some came back. Most of those who didn't come back are probably dead. In the early days last year, we saw piles of burning bodies. People continue to disappear, up until this week." **********So gruesome has the situation become that the local police chief talks of his police camp as Belsen, a reference to the Nazi death camp. **********"That's where they take young boys to question them," Father Miller said. "They tie them up, drop them in a well. 'Are you a Tiger?' 'No.' Drop them again. 'Are you a Tiger?' 'No.' Eventually they get a confession." **********Father Miller shook his head. "There's no resolution. Neither side has lost. Neither side can win." But still, he insisted, he will remain here to document the brutality that has overcome his once peaceful town. **********"If I find I have no work, I'll go back to Louisiana," he said. "If peace comes, maybe my work will be finished."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/02/busin.main_headline: Chief Leaves Square D As Schneider Moves In
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/02/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chief Leaves Square D As Schneider Moves In
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/02/busin.body_text: **********No one was surprised when Jerre L. Stead stepped down yesterday from his job as chairman, president and chief executive of the Square D Company, the $1.65 billion electrical distribution equipment giant. Once Square D was acquired by Groupe Schneider S.A., the French electrical equipment maker, in May, analysts said it would be only a matter of time until Mr. Stead moved on. **********"He was not entirely in favor of the takeover, so I'm not surprised he is leaving," said Russell Leavitt, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. **********Employees in the company's Palatine, Ill., headquarters will be told today that Didier Pineau-Valencienne, Groupe Schneider's chairman and chief executive, will take on those titles at Square D and that Charles W. Denny 3d, who has been with Square D for 31 years, will become chief operating officer. Mr. Denny, 55, will oversee day-to-day operations of Square D and report to Mr. Pineau-Valencienne. Both appointments are on an interim basis but are expected to become permanent in October, Mr. Stead said. **********Square D was acquired for $2.23 billion in a hostile takeover by Schneider after a 10-week fight. The deal made Schneider the world's largest maker of electrical distribution equipment including circuit breakers, switches and infrared measurement devices. **********Mr. Stead, 48, said he planned to announce his new job on Tuesday. He refused to give any details. He has been with Square D for four and a half years, joining the company in 1987 as president and chief operating officer and becoming chairman in 1989. Before joining Square D, he was an executive at Honeywell Inc. **********Mr. Stead said the merger would be completed within 30 days and it was time to "move on to other challenges." He acknowledged that there was concern on the part of employees about his plans, but he insisted that employees had remained neutral throughout the merger process. **********Despite his initial rejection of the takeover attempt, Mr. Stead says he has had an excellent relationship throughout with Mr. Pineau-Valencienne and is pleased with the transition. He said Mr. Pineau-Valencienne had asked him to stay on for five years when the merger first happened, but that he said at the time he would only remain through the transition period. **********Mr. Stead said he announced his departure about a month early to settle the question for employees as to whether he would stay or leave. "The global business market is far too demanding for the energy to be wasted on me staying or leaving," he said. **********Mr. Stead said he had actively pushed for Mr. Denny to be named chief operating officer. Mr. Denny has been executive vice president in charge of Square D's $1.2 billion worldwide electrical distribution business since 1989. **********A native of Middletown, Ohio, Mr. Denny holds a bachelor's degree in economics from Wesleyan University and an M.B.A. from Northwestern University. He joined the Barkelew Electric Manufacturing Company in 1960 and stayed on after Barkelew was acquired by Square D in 1967.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/01/busin.main_headline: Nuclear Cuts Pose Threat For Other Arms Programs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/01/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Nuclear Cuts Pose Threat For Other Arms Programs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/01/busin.body_text: **********By reopening the debate in Congress on the appropriate level of military spending, President Bush's move to reduce the nation's nuclear forces raises the possibility that Pentagon contractors will face deeper and faster cuts in weapons programs than they previously envisioned, analysts said today. **********In acknowledging in his speech on Friday that the threat from the Soviet Union is considerably diminished, President Bush made it easier for Democrats in Congress to oppose a wide range of weapons programs, analysts and industry executives said. Support for the Northrop Corporation's B-2 Stealth bomber, already waning, eroded further over the weekend, with even staunch supporters like Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, the chairman of the Armed Services Committee, saying the program should be scaled back. **********Some analysts said Democrats and Republicans alike would find it increasingly difficult to vote for expensive nuclear and nonnuclear weapons systems in the face of pressure on domestic spending programs for education, health care and other issues that the Democrats are likely to raise in next year's Presidential election. The result could well be the cancellation of current programs like the General Dynamics Corporation's Seawolf submarine and the scaling back or slowing down of programs including the Star Wars antimissile shield and the Lockheed Corporation's next-generation Air Force fighter, the F-22. **********"We're going to start denominating social programs and calculating how many B-2's they represent, and that can't be good for the defense industry," said Robert Paulson of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company in Los Angeles. "The pressure will be felt across the industry." **********The most immediate losers in the industry are those companies working on nuclear-weapons programs killed by the President in his speech on Friday. They include the Boeing Company, which was working on a short-range attack missile, and the Rockwell International Corporation, which along with a number of other contractors was working on a rail-based version of the MX Peacekeeper missile. **********But those programs are relatively small by industry standards. The real worry for the industry is that Congress will start slashing Pentagon spending for other, bigger programs it feels are no longer justified given the state of the Soviet Union. **********"There's going to be a lot of rhetoric that doesn't talk to the real issues of force structure, and there are going to be a lot of big-ticket programs with extensive vulnerability" to Congressional budget cutting, said Bernard Schwartz, chairman of the Loral Corporation, a New York-based supplier of military electronics. **********Gordon Adams, the director of the Defense Budget Project, a nonpartisan research group in Washington, said the President's speech had already increased the chances that the $850 million-a-copy B-2, which accounts for half of Northrop's revenues, will be canceled in negotiations going on now in Congress to reconcile budget bills passed by the House and the Senate. **********Northrop has delivered three of the bat-winged bombers to the Air Force and has 12 more in various stages of production. The Air Force so far has stuck to its request for 75 of the planes, including funds for 4 more next year. But analysts said Northrop would never build the B-2 at the rate of 36 a year that was envisioned under the Air Force's original plan to acquire 132 of the bombers. They said that even if the program is not canceled this year it faced years of limping along with low profits. **********Mr. Adams said he thinks the budget negotiators will also give more consideration to cutting back on the Star Wars program. The antimissile program is spread among dozens of companies, with TRW Inc., Lockheed, Rockwell and others among the largest. **********But the deepest cuts, Mr. Adams and others said, could come if Congress casts aside the budget agreement it made last year with the Administration, under which cuts made in the military, at least through next year's budget cycle, could not be used to finance domestic programs. **********"We already saw the Democrats after the failed coup in the Soviet Union trying to establish guns versus butter as an issue, and now the budget deal that everyone saw as fixed for 1993 is coming unglued," Mr. Adams said. Under those conditions, he said, a number of other big programs could be endangered. **********Analysts said there are a handful of programs that will be particularly vulnerable in any budget debate next year. At the top of the list is the Seawolf submarine, which is being built by General Dynamics at its Electric Boat division in Groton, Conn. The Seawolf is designed to attack Soviet nuclear submarines and has been plagued by cracks in its welds and other technical problems. **********Among the other vulnerable programs are the Air Force's C-17 cargo plane, which is made by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and has just entered its initial flight testing, and the Army's LH combat helicopter, which is being developed by Boeing and the United Technologies Corporation.  Boon for Electronics **********In the long run, budget pressures could make it harder to keep financing programs that the Pentagon has been trying to kill but that Congress has kept alive to maintain jobs in home districts, including the Grumman Corporation's F-14 fighter. **********The one element of the business that continues to have a reasonably bright outlook is military electronics. The armed services are increasingly seeking to upgrade the capability of current weapons systems by cramming sophisticated new electronic components into them. The Pentagon is pushing for more "smart" weapons, like missiles that can identify and home in on their targets with little or no direct human aid. And demand within the military is growing for more surveillance satellites and command and control systems. **********"We think we're still opportunity-rich in terms of the programs we see coming on," said Mr. Schwartz of Loral.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/16/busin.main_headline: How Nissan Smooths Out the Bumps
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/16/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; How Nissan Smooths Out the Bumps
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/16/busin.body_text: **********The Nissan Motor Corporation has introduced on its Infiniti Q-45 luxury model the first computerized suspension system in the United States that adjusts each shock absorber independently for stiffness and extension. **********Sensors mounted near the four wheels constantly "read" the car frame's height off the road, while six sensors positioned around the car monitor bounce and side-to-side motion. That information is converted to electric signals and fed into a microcomputer control unit. The controller adjusts the extension of each shock absorber by rapidly pumping hydraulic fluid into or out of the four shock absorbers. **********In fact, Nissan engineers say they can program the system to "lean into" turns like a motorcycle and compensate entirely for the centrifugal forces that act on a car as it rounds corners. But tests of the system showed that drivers were disoriented when the body roll was eliminated altogether, so Nissan engineers programmed some body roll to help drivers maintain a feel for the road. **********Nissan expects about 15 percent of Infiniti buyers to pay for this so-called active suspension, an option that adds $5,000 to the Q-45's $40,000 price. Other car makers will probably offer their own versions -- analysts and automotive engineers think that about 6 percent of all vehicles sold worldwide will have the systems by the year 2000, a survey by the University of Michigan has found. **********The active suspension system adds 132 pounds to the car and reduces mileage by about two miles a gallon. But Nissan executives say they do not expect prospective buyers to be put off by that.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/21/world.main_headline: Castro Gets Attention, but Not Money, From Latin Leaders
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/21/world.print_headline: Castro Gets Attention, but Not Money, From Latin Leaders
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/21/world.body_text: **********Received with courtesy and little else by his fellow Latin American leaders, President Fidel Castro prepared to return to Cuba today after gaining only token gestures of friendship for his beleaguered Government. **********During a two-day conference of leaders from all 21 of the world's Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking nations, Mr. Castro pressed his requests for financial aid and other support to help Cuba pull out of its deep economic slide. He also delivered familiar denunciations of the United States and its policies toward the third world. **********But while many leaders welcomed Mr. Castro's presence as a symbol of the conference's political diversity, they made little effort to play down the Cuban leader's deep estrangement from most of the region's governments, which are democratically elected and economically conservative. **********"Let us permit the parliaments and the people to write their history in a sovereign fashion," declared Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain, as Mr. Castro shifted uncomfortably in his chair, "and relegate guerrilla adventures to the tales of the imaginative novelists that this continent has in such great supply." **********Before the formal opening of the conference on Thursday, Mr. Castro scored some achievements, winning re-establishment of consular relations with two former political adversaries, Colombia and Chile. **********The conference's host, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico, went out of his way to emphasize his commitment to giving Mr. Castro a respectful hearing, using the Cuban leader's presence as a political counterbalance to the pro-American economic policies his own Government is pursuing. **********But suggestions that the conference would serve as a forum for negotiating democratic changes in Cuba's Communist system were quickly set aside in the initial hours of the conference, when Mr. Castro took the offensive, attacking the United States and other economic powers for creating Latin America's problems. **********"The policies of the great economic powers and the international financial institutions under their control have not produced development, but have brought poverty to more than 250 million people," Mr. Castro declared in his speech at the inaugural session. "The world is heading in a still worse direction, toward world political hegemony by a superpower that has often made excessive use of force." **********Despite the characteristic power of his oratory, several regional leaders did not even bother to applaud Mr. Castro's remarks, and many used their own speeches to hammer away on the themes of self-sufficiency and democracy, two subjects of particular sensitivity for the Cuban leader. **********Diplomats who sat in on Mr. Castro's private meetings with other leaders said no commitments of financial help had so far been made to him. **********As reporters surrounded him after the opening session, Mr. Castro began to relax and enjoy himself. But when a correspondent asked whether he planned to permit free elections in Cuba, he angrily waved away further questions, denouncing what he described as an "interminable campaign of defamation" against him. **********In a concrete step toward the conference's goal of regional economic integration, Venezuela, Colombia and Mexico announced agreement to eliminate trade barriers and create a three-way free trade zone. **********On another regional matter, 30 of the most prominent literary figures from the Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking world made a joint plea that the leaders take action to save the rain forests. **********The statement, presented by the Colombian Nobel laureate Gabriel Garcia Marquez and a Mexican poet, Homero Aridjis, was signed by writers across a wide political range -- from the conservative Mexican poet and Nobel laureate Octavio Paz to the leftist Uruguayan writer Mario Benedetti.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/23/busin.body_text: **********The Union Carbide Corporation said today that its first-quarter earnings dropped 11.7 percent, primarily because of costs from an explosion at one of its Texas plants. **********The earnings were consistent with the company's announcement in March that its profits would be reduced by $18 million for the quarter. **********The lost profits were related to the interruption of operations at Union Carbide's Seadrift plant near Port Lavaca, Tex. An explosion and fire on March 12 killed a worker. **********For the quarter that ended on March 31, its net income totaled $83 million, or 54 cents a share, on sales of $1.85 billion. That was less than $94 million, or 66 cents a share, on sales of $1.92 billion, for the comparable 1990 period. **********Robert D. Kennedy, the chairman, said results were stronger than anticipated because of declining raw material costs and strong exports of some chemicals, including ethylene glycol. Sales were up 3 percent in the company's chemicals and plastic businesses, but earnings fell 12 percent to $9 million because of the Seadrift explosion. **********On the New York Stock Exchange today, Union Carbide's shares rose 37.5 cents, to $18.125.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/05/busin.main_headline: Forbes Will End Publication of Egg Magazine in March
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/05/busin.print_headline: Forbes Will End Publication of Egg Magazine in March
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/05/busin.body_text: **********Egg, the magazine started by Malcolm Forbes just before his death last year, announced yesterday that it would cease publication with its March issue. **********"It was a victim of the overall environment, and it was just not possible to see how the growth that we had to have was going to happen," said Timothy C. Forbes, president of Egg, a division of Forbes Inc. **********The oversized magazine, which covered the downtown scene, was aimed at a young, urban, hip audience in New York and Los Angeles. Its first issue was published in March, just about the time that magazine advertising and newsstand sales began their precipitous decline. Among those cutting back were national advertisers like liquor and tobacco and local advertisers like restaurants and clubs, all of which were the backbone of Egg's advertising.  Decline in Pages **********The March 1990 issue, for instance, had 150 pages; the March 1991 issue will have 82 pages, Mr. Forbes said. Last month Fame magazine closed for the same reasons. **********Speculation in magazine circles that Egg would not survive centered not only on the harsh economic climate but also on the belief that the downtown nightlife scene, a phenomenon of the 1980's, was past. "I think Egg was a poorly positioned concept," said Martin Walker, president of Periodicals Studies Service, a magazine consultant. "It was a downtown magazine for uptown people." **********But Suzan Nanfeldt, senior vice president at Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss, an advertising agency, said that the magazine had a good editorial mission and a strong sense of what it wanted to be. "It was trying to be an insider's guide to the downtown cultural life of New York," she said. "I would never say that downtown has died. I would say that it is probably changing directions, which it does every month anyway."  'Never Found Its Way' **********Claude Fromm, executive vice president of the TBWA advertising agency, said that advertisers now tended to place ads month by month instead of making longer-term commitments, making it especially difficult for new magazines to get off the ground. "Egg unfortunately never found its way," he added. "It never became hot." **********Mr. Forbes declined to say how much had been invested in Egg. Forbes, a privately held company, does not release financial information. **********Egg's circulation was 80,000, Mr. Forbes said, with the bulk in New York and Los Angeles. About 35,000 copies were sold on newsstands, 20,000 went to subscribers, and the remainder was unpaid circulation. **********The magazine was the idea of Malcolm Forbes, but his son said yesterday that Mr. Forbes's death had not lessened the commitment to go ahead with the magazine. "I wouldn't say we suffered for lack of enthusiasm," he said. "The death of the magazine wasn't a function of cost, losses or desire. It was the function of a harsh economic environment."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/29/busin.main_headline: American Airlines' Tie To Rodeos Is Protested
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/29/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; American Airlines' Tie To Rodeos Is Protested
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/29/busin.body_text: **********The International Society for Animal Rights has given a "Lemon Award" to American Airlines for its advertising at rodeos. The organization contends that the company is using animals to promote products in a tasteless and insensitive way. **********"American Airlines sponsors rodeos out of their advertising budget, and rodeos are very cruel," said Amie Hamlin, issues specialist for the organization, based in Clarks Summit, Pa., which has given its "awards" for two years. **********"American Airlines does serve as the official carrier for a number of rodeos in the United States," said Marty Heires, a spokesman for the airline. "This is a sales contract and not a sponsorship, and we are not committing one way or another on whether it's a good or bad event." The airline has no plans to change its arrangements with rodeos as a result of the criticism, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/14/busin.body_text: **********Just a trade show or two ago, executives in the electronics industry were steadfastly adhering to their blood oath not to pay royalties to the music industry. But in a remarkable sea change last week, the industry agreed to compensate rock stars, songwriters and music publishers for profits lost to home recordings made using the latest digital technology. **********The recession and the need to spark life into the consumer electronics business are getting some of the credit for the landmark agreement. So is John V. Roach, the 52-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Fort Worth-based Tandy Corporation. **********No one had a larger role to play in getting the process under way than John Roach," said Jason Berman, president of the Recording Industry Association of America. **********Mr. Roach's interest goes beyond aspirations to become the Henry Kissinger of the audio industry. Tandy, as part of an attempt to improve sales at its Radio Shack stores, is planning to introduce a sophisticated digital compact cassette player (DCC) next year, using technology licensed from Philips N.V. Mr. Roach plans on "using DCC as a springboard for making Tandy a presence in the United States audio business," said Paul Gluckman, managing editor of Audio Week, a newsletter. **********To do that, Mr. Roach needs Michael Jackson and other stars on digital cassette, and without the royalty agreement, the music industry was refusing to let their recordings be played at the digital party. **********"Tandy wants to market DCC next year without the encumbrance of a political hassle," said Mr. Gluckman. **********Mr. Roach is also clearing the way for Tandy's long-promised recordable compact disk, which has been delayed for several years because of technical problems. **********Said Mr. Berman, of the Recording Industry Association, "He introduced a businessman's perspective."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/21/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; With Caution, Geer, DuBois Manages a Shift at the Top
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/21/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; With Caution, Geer, DuBois Manages a Shift at the Top
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/21/busin.body_text: **********A GROWING number of mid- sized agencies built in Madison Avenue's heyday in the 1960's and early 1970's now face the difficult challenge of finding new top executives to replace retiring founders. **********Geer, DuBois is one example. The New York agency, whose clients include Sony and Brown & Williamson Tobacco, has begun to tackle the tricky problem of installing new management without alienating clients with close ties to those who had been in charge. **********Nearly nine months ago, Peter Geer, the chairman, brought in John Hayes from Ammirati & Puris to take over management. Mr. Hayes, now president, runs Geer, DuBois in partnership with Rodney Underwood, who joined 18 months ago, also from Ammariti & Puris. Mr. Underwood is vice chairman and executive creative director. **********It is too early to tell if the new managers will succeed, but they got a vote of confidence recently from a couple of clients. On Monday, the Paddington Corporation, a beverage importer, awarded Geer, DuBois about $15 million in new business: the accounts for Baileys Original Irish Cream, Sambuca Romana and Cinzano liqueurs. **********Earlier, Brown & Williamson had given the agency an additional assignment: its Raleigh Extra cigarette account, which is expected to have billings of about $10 million. **********"Any time there is a change in top management it can be a source of concern," said Roger Slone, the senior vice president for marketing at Paddington. "But this has been managed very well." **********Mr. Geer said he had sought new managers because the agency needed an infusion of energy. "I'd lost the drive to give the agency the cutting edge it needed," Mr. Geer said. "We needed people who would be willing to take chances." **********Mr. Geer, who is 61 years old and plans to remain chairman for several more years, joined Geer, DuBois in 1958. The agency was started by his parents (his mother's maiden name was DuBois) largely as a public relations concern. It was Mr. Geer who reshaped the company to specialize in advertising. **********He said he knew the transition to new management would be tricky because clients would likely be nervous about the smallest change. He said the fact that both Mr. Hayes and Mr. Underwood had been brought in from outside the agency was a particular concern. **********The timing of the change was critical. With about $145 million in billings, a healthy infusion of new business would push the agency over the $200 million mark, making it large enough to compete for bigger national accounts. **********At first, the new managers moved cautiously in taking the reins. Most important, clients had to be reassured that while it would not be business as usual at the agency, they had nothing to worry about. "I've spent a lot of my time talking to clients and gaining their trust," Mr. Hayes said. **********"The work is now very exciting," Mr. Geer said. To try to give the agency's ads a fresh look, Mr. Underwood has hired young commercial directors who are more likely to put an unconventional spin on a marketing strategy. **********The team also brought in a new research executive, Martyn Straw, from Ogilvy & Mather. Mr. Straw changed the agency's approach to consumer research, bringing in researchers to work with the creative department from the start of an assignment. More often, a smaller agency's research is used to test the effectiveness of a finished idea. **********The staff seems to be accepting the change. No top executives have left, which Mr. Underwood sees as an encouraging sign. To keep the staff updated on changes and, more important, to get to know them, Mr. Hayes and Mr. Underwood take four employees to breakfast each week. "It gives them an informal forum to talk to us about problems, concerns or new ideas," Mr. Hayes said. **********Joy Sliwa, an executive vice president and director of media services, said she welcomed the changes. "Before John and Rodney came, I never felt a concerted effort at the agency to grow," said Ms. Sliwa, who has worked at Geer, DuBois for 25 years. "The new leadership is strong and there is more direction now."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/28/world.main_headline: Paris on No Dollars a Day? East Europeans Find a Way?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/28/world.print_headline: Paris on No Dollars a Day? East Europeans Find a Way?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/28/world.body_text: **********They stand out immediately because their squat, centrally planned buses look positively intimidated by the air-conditioned, toilet-equipped giants that carry Danes, Germans, Italians and the like around the obligatory tourist sights of Paris. **********But for tens of thousands of Eastern Europeans visiting for the first time, what really counts is that they are no longer so different. Since the fall of Communism, they too can visit the Louvre, take pictures of the Arc de Triomphe and pray at Notre-Dame. **********"It is a dream," said Vlasta Valentova, a radio reporter from Prague who was part of a group popping bottles of sparkling Czechoslovak wine near the Eiffel Tower. "My dream was to be able to travel, to get to know places. Just to see Paris, to know that I can come back, is already enough." **********In reality, "seeing Paris" is about all that an estimated half-million Eastern Europeans -- Poles, Czechoslovaks and Hungarians in the main -- can afford to do here this summer. Even a cup of coffee at a sidewalk cafe seems pricey, given their carefully calculated vacation budgets. **********No one seems to mind. "We're here to visit, not to shop," said Yolanda Grabowska, the interpreter for a group of Polish Catholics who had visited the shrine at Lourdes, in southern France. "Anyway, we have the same things in Poland and they're cheaper."  Versailles, Then Tents **********The trip is possible because most Eastern Europeans come on prepaid bus tours. Many stay in schools, hostels and church halls, and some set up tents or rent mobile homes at a campsite in the Bois de Boulogne, the large and lovely wooded parkland on the city's western edge. Almost all the visitors bring food and drink with them. **********One late afternoon at the Bois de Boulogne campsite, where about a third of the 2,500 campers were from Eastern Europe, Miss Grabowska's group was preparing supper over gas fires. Noodles boiled in one pot, a meat stew from a can cooked in another, and sausages waited on every plate. "We buy milk and bread locally," she said. **********Nearby, a dozen tents set up by a Hungarian tour group were closed and silent. "They're visiting Versailles today," one of the camp organizers said. "They took packed lunches with them, but they'll be back to cook dinner. They have quite a nice bus. Some of the Hungarians even come by car." **********In one mobile home, Michal Matejovic, the driver of a group from Benesov, Czechoslovakia, chewed on a sandwich as he studied a map to prepare the evening tour of Montmartre. "Before the revolution, some tourists would always stay behind," he said. "But not now. They don't mind going home." French Ambivalence **********Nonetheless, the influx of Poles, Czechoslovaks and Hungarians this year has stirred ambivalence in France, where for months newspapers have been carrying reports that millions of people are awaiting the chance to migrate west from Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. **********"The Hungarian tourists who come to France are already employed," said Tibor Varkony, a spokesman at the Hungarian Embassy in Paris. "They are real tourists who have no intention of staying. They have a tight budget, but they come to see the monuments." **********France's Ministry of Tourism hopes that while the half-million East Europeans visiting Paris this summer will spend relatively little, they will return with more money in future years. Yet many French tradespeople look at them with disapproval and distrust. **********"There's discrimination against Poles," said Anita Antoniszyn, a 19-year-old student from Poznan. "We stopped at a town yesterday and I visited a shop. As I was leaving, a saleswoman stopped me and looked through my bag. I was upset and I was angry." Poles Look for Work **********Since visa requirements for Poles, Czechoslovaks and Hungarians were lifted, French officials concede that they have become alarmed by the number of Polish tourists who stay on to look for work. Some Poles even apply for political refugee status, though they are routinely turned down. **********"We are tourist-immigrants," a young Pole announced laughingly as he sat with friends, surrounded by rucksacks, on the steps of a Polish-language church here. "We stay if we can. If not, we go home. But there's no work in Poland." He flexed his right arm. "Look, we're strong. We can work." **********Beside the official campsite in the Bois de Boulogne is an improvised camp that has been home to about 80 Poles for the last nine months. "When we run out of money, we work picking fruit," said a young man who sat with others around a table playing cards. **********There were also authentic tourists at this campsite. Three blond young men slept beside a Soviet-made Lada with a DDR sticker announcing that they came from the former East Germany. **********Nearby, there were Swedish and Dutch backpackers who preferred not to pay to put up their tent.  Impressed by the Service **********Michal Vrba, Tomaz Proset and Michal Ohera, three 18-year-old students from Czechoslovakia, said they could spend two weeks in France and the Netherlands for the equivalent of $180 each -- as long as they slept in tents and ate their own food. They allowed themselves a bottle of wine a day. **********"What has most impressed me is the service here -- you get served so quickly and politely," Mr. Proset said. **********"Politely?" a surprised resident of Paris asked. "You must go to Czechoslovakia and you will see the difference," Mr. Proset insisted, in fluent English. **********Certainly, many East European tourists here seem too happy to even think of complaining. "I want to see how young French people live," said Magdalena Janowska, a 22-year-old Polish medical student, waving away the fatigue of the 14-hour bus ride from Jelenia Gora. "Museums are history. People are life. They can teach me more." **********But a Polish priest traveling with a Catholic group from Kalisz had made up his mind. "There are too many ads everywhere, there are too many big buildings, there is too much noise," he said. "It stops people from talking." **********He offered his final verdict on France: "The men spend too much on drink, the women spend too much on clothes."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/02/busin.body_text: **********The Work Wear Corporation has decided to defer today's interest payment on the company's 13 percent senior subordinated notes that are due Jan. 1, 1997. **********The board of the Cleveland maker of industrial work clothing will decide whether the company will make the $6.5 million interest payment before the end of the 30-day grace period, according to a filing today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********The deferral is the result of uncertainties surrounding the company's efforts to reach an understanding with a noteholders' committee concerning the company's long-term objectives, the filing said. The company has to reach an understanding before the end of the grace period. **********On May 31 the company's cash reserves were in excess of $16 million, according to the S.E.C. filing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/busin.body_text: **********The financial crisis that has plagued many of the nation's savings institutions has hit home. The credit union used by Government employees and former officials who regulate the nation's savings and loans has been insolvent since 1989, its president said today. **********"It is an embarrassment," said James Deemer, president of the credit union and comptroller of the Office of Thrift Supervision, which supervises the nation's 2,300 savings associations. "We had hoped nobody would find out about it." **********The condition of the credit union was publicly disclosed in an article in the latest issue of National Mortgage News, a weekly trade publication. **********"We made too many bad loans, basically car loans and personal loans," Mr. Deemer said. "At the same time, we had extra cash that was not being lent out." **********Mr. Deemer said that the credit union reported its difficulties in 1989 to the National Credit Union Administration, the Federal agency that regulates credit unions and insures their deposits. At the time, the credit union was facing a deficit of $118,000. **********He said a two-year plan to reduce the deficit had cut the figure to $19,800. The plan eliminated certain benefits and substantially cut costs. **********The credit union has 2,000 members and has reported $4.1 million in assets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/28/busin.main_headline: Continental Agrees to Sell Its Micronesia Air Routes
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/28/busin.print_headline: Continental Agrees to Sell Its Micronesia Air Routes
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/28/busin.body_text: **********Continental Airlines said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell its Micronesia routes to a Hong Kong investment group for $270 million in cash. **********The sale would strengthen Continental's cash position and improve the carrier's chances of successfully reorganizing and emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The deal would require the approval of Judge Cornelius Blackshear, who is overseeing Continental's reorganization in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York. **********The routes, which are operated by Continental/Air Micronesia, represent a small portion of Continental's flights, about 60 departures a day among Continental's daily total of more than 2,000 departures. The sale would involve all the routes operated by Continental/Air Micronesia, except flights between Honolulu and Tokyo and Honolulu and the South Pacific. **********Art Kent, a spokesman for Continental, said the Hong Kong group, called Arral, would offer employment to all of the 1,017 workers in the division, which would be renamed Pacific Air Micronesia Inc. The group would also have the option of leasing the 15 planes currently used on the routes. **********Mr. Kent said that the transaction, if approved by the bankruptcy court, would be completed in the next two months. In addition to the Micronesia routes, Arral would also get $20 million of a new issue of preferred stock in the reorganized Continental. **********In recent months, Continental has been in intensive talks with Northwest Airlines, which is considering taking over the carrier. But a decision by Northwest is not thought to be imminent. One difficulty in a Continental-Northwest deal would be integrating Continental's primarily nonunion work force with the largely unionized employees of Northwest. **********If a Northwest takeover does not occur, the cash from the sale of the Micronesia routes would be important to carrying Continental through the winter, when passenger volume is traditionally weak.
