https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/28/busin.main_headline: Equitable Backs Plan To Go Public
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/28/busin.print_headline: Equitable Backs Plan To Go Public
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/28/busin.body_text: **********Directors of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, moving to shore up the capital base of the nation's third-largest insurer, yesterday approved a plan for the company to become publicly owned. **********The plan, proposed last year, would make Equitable the largest policyholder-owned company to convert to public ownership. Access to the capital markets will allow the company to raise money to offset large losses on its junk-bond and real estate investments. 'Win-Win Situation' **********The conversion is the largest element of a revitalization plan for Equitable that was begun by Richard H. Jenrette, the chief executive. **********"The conversion plan could be described as a 'win-win' situation for policyholders," Mr. Jenrette said yesterday. "Their insurance benefits will remain unchanged, but their contracts will be backed by an institution that is financially much stronger as a result of the new capital that is raised." **********But the plan must clear other hurdles. Equitable must receive the approval of the New York State Insurance Superintendent, as well as from two-thirds of its policyholders. Policyholders who can vote must have held an insurance policy or annuity contract that was in force as of yesterday. **********Policyholders can receive compensation -- in stock or, in some cases, cash and policy credits -- if they are eligible to vote and their policies are still in effect when the company's new shares are issued. **********If the plan is approved, Equitable expects to begin its stock offering next year, with shares trading on the New York Stock Exchange. French Insurer to Benefit **********One big beneficiary of the plan will be Groupe Axa S.A., the French insurer that agreed in July to inject $1 billion into Equitable. Axa received surplus and secured notes in the transaction, which will become common stock when the company converts. That would make Axa the single largest shareholder in the new public company, with 40 percent to 49 percent. **********Under the terms of the plan approved yesterday, a new holding company, the Equitable Companies, will be chartered in Delaware. The holding company will be the publicly traded entity, while the insurer will become a subsidiary. **********Equitable officals also said yesterday that the company planned to relocate some support staff to its operations in Atlanta. They will be offered transfers from operations in San Francisco and Secaucus, N.J.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/24/busin.main_headline: Machine Tools Orders Fell 19.6% in May
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/24/busin.print_headline: Machine Tools Orders Fell 19.6% in May
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/24/busin.body_text: **********Orders for American-made machine tools fell in May for a third straight month, dropping 19.6 percent from the April level, an industry trade group said in a monthly report being released today. **********The drop comes in spite of predictions by makers of machine tools and the industry trade group, the Association for Manufacturing Technology, that industry orders would generally improve as American businesses began spending to upgrade their manufacturing plants. **********Analysts interpreted the May figures as evidence that capital spending continues to show little sign of rebounding and that the nation's economy remains in a recession despite recent signs of recovery.  Lowest Since 1987 **********In its report, the association said new orders for machine tools fell to $155.8 million in May from $193.7 million in April. It was the lowest monthly new-order total since August 1987, when it was $142 million. New orders in May were also 24.5 percent below the level of May 1990. For the first five months of this year, machine tool orders are down 13.6 percent from a year earlier. **********Machine tools are used to cut or shape metal parts used in durable products like appliances, automobiles, aircraft and building components. The level of orders and shipments of machine tools is considered an important indicator of the health of American industry. **********"There seems to be a reluctance on the part of manufacturers to upgrade their facilities," said Richard O. Priebe, a spokesman with Cross & Trecker Inc., a large machine tool maker that earlier this month agreed to be acquired by a competitor, Giddings & Lewis Inc. "Manufacturers seemed to be sitting tight right now," Mr. Priebe said. "It reflects a general weakness in the economy, and that caused manufacturers to delay their purchases." **********Larry W. Hollis, an analyst with Robert W. Baird & Company, a brokerage in Milwaukee, said the May figures reflected weakness in the economy. "In recessions, orders are generally slow," Mr. Hollis said. He added that the May report indicated that foreign machine tool makers, particularly those in Japan, "continue to make significant inroads in American market share." He added that foreign machine tool producers "now have about half of the domestic market."  Link to Factory Use **********Despite the weakness of new orders in recent months, Albert W. Moore, president of the Association for Manufacturing Technology, said he remained encouraged by recent data from the Federal Reserve showing two consecutive months of higher factory utilization. "Conventional wisdom in our industry is that machine tool orders escalate when capacity utilization crosses the 80 percent level," Mr. Moore said. **********"Manufacturers also have tigher control over their inventories now than in most downturns," he added. "With lean inventories, production will respond quickly to higher demand, in turn creating demand for the machine tool which will be needed to meet new production levels." **********Machine tool orders have been hurt by the economic woes of automobile makers, which typically account for more than a third of the industry's new orders. And some analysts suggest that a pickup of new orders from car makers, who are expected to retool soon for new models, will help stimulate new orders for machine tools. Strong Foreign Demand **********The May report also showed that orders from foreign customers dropped a sharp 54 percent from the previous month. Industry executives said that they could not account for that decline, but analysts suggested that it probably resulted from a large level of foreign orders in April. **********Orders from foreign customers, which reached a record last year, were up 10.7 percent for the first five months of the year, while orders from domestic customers fell 18.9 percent in the same period. Orders from domestic customers were down 8.7 percent in May from the April rate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/world.body_text: **********Yugoslavia's conflict grew more extensive today as communities far from the scene of battle tried to keep federal army forces from crossing into Croatia, where the fighting has been confined for the last three months. **********Here in the capital of secessionist Croatia, officials said they expected an all-out attack by federal troops and said a 12-mile-long column of Yugoslav federal Government tanks, troops and artillery that moved out of Belgrade had split and crossed into their republic to launch a three-pronged offensive on settlements including the towns of Osijek and Vukovar. **********In Belgrade, an authoritative newspaper, Borba, reported that Yugoslavia's federal Government, supposed to reflect the interests of all six constituent republics, was in danger of total collapse after Prime Minister Ante Markovic, a Croat, demanded the resignation of Defense Minister Velko Kadijevic, a Serb. The tattered federal Government is virtually the only remaining emblem of Yugoslavia's frayed national unity. A Western diplomat called the development "the end of normal, civil government." **********In Bosnia, the republic south of here that has not previously been embroiled in the conflict, officials said members of Muslim and Croatian communities, who represent nearly two thirds of the 4.1 million population, blocked deployments by federal army troops apparently seeking to cross Bosnian territory to reinforce units in Croatia.  Drawing Bosnia Into Strife **********Tonight, Bosnian leaders said they ordered a mobilization of reserve units throughout the territory. Officials in Bosnia reported standoffs in two places -- Chaplina and Visegrad -- between local militias and federal army units who reportedly advanced firing automatic rifles into the air. **********In three months of fighting between Serbs and Croats, Bosnia has remained aloof despite widely voiced fears that the republic might be drawn into the conflict if its Croats or Muslims tried to prevent federal forces stationed there or groups of Bosnian Serbs from heading for the fighting in Croatia. **********Reports tonight from Bosnia indicated that the federal authorities were seeking to open a new front to relieve federal barracks blockaded by Croatian militias in Croatia and to force Bosnia to take sides. Apart from its territorial importance, Bosnia also hosts one of Yugoslavia's main airforce bases, from which jetfighters can reach Zagreb in less than 15 minutes. **********[ President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia signaled that his republic was on the defensive late Friday when he sent a letter to Mr. Kadijevic offering to lift the blockade of federal army barracks if the army ended its offensive, the Associated Press reported. ] A Military Agenda **********The developments in Bosnia suggested anew that Yugoslavia's predominantly Serbian generals were pursuing an agenda that coincided with the interests of Belgrade's former Communist rulers in extending their writ over areas beyond Serbia where Serbs form significant minorities. **********But military leaders also have a separate interest in securing their own survival in a post-Communist world where eastern Europe's security forces have frequently been discredited. The supposition among some diplomats is that the federal army is pursuing its own aims, beyond the ultimate control of the politicians. **********News of the reported new offensive into Croatia by a Belgrade government openly backing insurgents from Croatia's large Serbian minority of 600,000 brought further woes to this breakaway capital, where air-raid sirens howled three times today -- more out of nervousness over federal air force movements at a big base in neighboring Bosnia than at the prospect of attacks. **********Overnight, two explosions in Zagreb, one at a restaurant, elicited further complaints by Croats that what is termed a Serbian "fifth column" is at work in the city to spread instability -- an assertion that has been made about nighttime sniper fire. **********The sirens sent some Zagreb residents scurrying for impromptu bomb shelters in cellars and basement apartments whose sidewalk-level windows were jammed with sandbags.  Army Troops Press Ahead **********But such is the frequency of the alarms that, at the Parliament building, officials abandoned offices on upper floors only to take unscheduled coffee breaks in a ground-floor cafeteria that did a brisk business in espressos, cappuccinos and the slivovitz liquor favored in the Balkans. **********Since Croatia, like Slovenia to the north, declared independence from the Yugoslav federation on June 25, local militias here have fought Serbian insurgents drawn from Croatia's Serbian minority and increasingly supported by the Serb-dominated federal forces. **********Croatian Radio said "fierce fighting" was in progress in the eastern border area with Serbia, Yugoslavia's most populous component and the seat of the internationally-recognized federal Government in Belgrade.  U.S. FAULTS YUGOSLAV BUILDUP **********WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The State Department said today that the buildup by the Yugoslav military in Croatia represented a grave violation of the letter and spirit of the cease-fire agreement signed earlier this week. **********A spokesman for the department, Richard A. Boucher, said all parties to the conflict should halt all actions that contradict the agreement. **********He said the United States was not playing a direct role in efforts to achieve a peaceful settlement, supporting European Community efforts toward that end. FRANCE URGES U.N. TALKS **********UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 20 (Special to The New York Times) -- France is pressing for the United Nations Security Council to meet at the Foreign Minister level here next week on the Yugoslavia civil war, after the apparent failure of the European Community's recent peace efforts. **********Diplomats said there was now a good chance that the Council would hold such a ministerial meeting at the end of next week, when the foreign ministers of most of the 15 member countries are expected to be here for the United Nations General Assembly session.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/world.main_headline: Breaking the Beirut Hostage Impasse: New Mideast Alignments Clear Way
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/world.print_headline: Breaking the Beirut Hostage Impasse: New Mideast Alignments Clear Way
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/world.body_text: **********A powerful confluence of national interests has contributed to the surprisingly abrupt progress toward freeing the Western hostages held in Lebanon, according to specialists inside and outside the Bush Administration. **********In the long regional struggle that has brought hostage-taking to the fore as a widely condemned tactic, each of the major parties has either taken part in or witnessed military, political or economic turmoil that has changed national equations. **********Years of bleak stalemate in efforts to release the hostages may have given way to a recognition by the disparate powers with influence and bargaining leverage that it is time to resolve the issue finally, thereby removing what has become a signficant barrier to economic progress and political development in the region, the specialists said. **********As was demonstrated briefly last week with the abduction of the Frenchman Jerome Leyraud, hostage-taking is not likely to soon disappear from the region. But for Iran, Syria, Israel, Lebanon, the United States and some Western European nations, the time may have arrived for successfully closing out an ugly chapter of confrontation that has obsessed and dominated the region's conscience and haunted American politics.  A Self-Propelled Iran **********Trying to answer the question "why now?" Richard Murphy, the former Assistant Secretary of State who supervised United States policy in the Middle East for most of the 1980's, said that while Syria has been maneuvering for several years to win the release of the Western hostages, Iran's post-revolutionary leadership has not been able to make a clear-cut decision to press the pro-Iranian militants in Lebanon to release their captives. **********"The Syrians have never wanted to push Iran," Mr. Murphy said, "and Iran wasn't interested for a long time. But now the Syrians don't have to push them, because the Iranians are self-propelled -- not that there still aren't divided councils in Teheran." **********"Local politics" in Lebanon among the kidnapping groups is also a factor, an Administration official asserted. "They've held those people for six years and haven't gotten anything for the Islamic revolution," he said. "And hostages are only valuable if they are traded." **********The precise change in Iran that helped set off the release of two hostages in the last week remains a mystery, but Mr. Murphy argues that in the multifactioned ruling environment of Teheran, events today probably represent the culmination of forces that have been building for years. And those forces are well known.  Culmination of Forces **********After its eight-year war with Iraq ended in 1988, Iran was devastated economically. Its agricultural base has declined as its population has soared. Even before the death in 1989 of the uncompromising revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Teheran was looking to marshal massive resources to rebuild a shattered economy. That could happen only with Western investment and technology. **********"I think we are finally seeing it work out," said Mr. Murphy. **********Did the final factors include United States relief flights to Iran last spring, when hundreds of thousands ofIraqi Kurds overwhelmed Iranian refugee centers? Mr. Murphy said that might have added to the momentum. **********Another factor is that the United States, after a period of mixed signals that included the covert arms-for-hostages trading in the Iran-contra scandal, might have convinced Teheran's leaders that future trade, transfers of technology and financing cannot flow while Terry A. Anderson and his fellow hostages remain chained to radiators in Beirut's basement dungeons. **********For Syria, the end of the cold war and the American-led struggle against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq provided an obvious pretext for President Hafez al-Assad to reposition himself as an ally of the West. But what began as a tactical and perhaps transitory realignment by Mr. Assad might be turning into a strategic transformation for the man who came to prominence in the Middle East as the chief rejectionist. Fulfilling Assad's Interests **********"Ever since he came to power, Assad's interests have not been fulfilled by going the peaceful route," said Graham Fuller, a Rand Corporation analyst who served as a senior Middle East specialist in the Reagan Administration. "What Syria got out of being the leader of the hell-no crowd -- oil money, leadership of the Palestinian cause and Soviet arms -- made him a dominant force for 15 years. **********"Now for the first time," Mr. Fuller continued, "Syria is benefiting more from peace than from controlled confrontation and to me that is the real revolution in Syrian thinking." **********Thus, Syria's interests in Lebanon's hostage problem are far more subtle and vital to Mr. Assad's survival as a regional power. **********Since Lebanon was destabilized with the outbreak of civil war in the mid-1970's, Mr. Assad has been engaged in a struggle with Israel for effective control of his western flank, Lebanon. After two major Syrian military incursions into Lebanon and the humiliation of the Israeli invasion in 1982, Syria has forcefully backed a new Government in Beirut and emerged the demonstrable victor; Lebanon's new leadership is and is likely to remain pointedly pro-Syrian.  Removing Threats to Israel **********To keep Israel from reasserting a major role in Lebanon through partial occupation and military incursions against guerrilla bases, Mr. Assad must remove the security threats that face his sworn enemy, some analysts argue. **********One way to do that would be to win the freedom not only of the Western hostages, but of Israel's captive servicemen held by either pro-Iranian militiamen or Palestinian guerrillas. Once that is done, a Syrian-backed effort to demilitarize southern Lebanon and disarm the still independent militias there would, over time, remove Israel's pretext for continued occupation. **********How Syria brings peace to Lebanon also has a direct effect on the Middle East peace process, which has reached the sensitive stage of convening an international peace conference for direct talks between Israel and its Arab enemies.  Fine Line for Israelis **********Mr. Assad's performance in bringing security to southern Lebanon will bear directly on any argument he makes that Israel should return to Damascus control over the Golan Heights, seized in 1967. **********According to Willaim Quandt, Middle East specialist at the Brookings Institution who served in the Carter White House, Israel will have to walk a fine line in responding to the "good will" and momentum of the hostage releases last week while not giving away its leverage over the kidnappers. **********Among its hundreds of Arab prisoners whose freedom is sought by the kidnappers, Israel's main leverage is Sheik Abdel Karim Obeid, who Israel accuses of being a spiritual leader of the Party of God in South Lebanon. Israel abducted Sheik Obeid in 1989. **********"If they go ahead and release Sheik Obeid and this leads to the release of American hostages, they are going to get some credit in the United States," Mr. Quandt said. "If it doesn't cost them too much, they will seek to get it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/14/busin.main_headline: Strong Earnings Are Posted by Three G.M. Subsidiaries
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/14/busin.print_headline: Strong Earnings Are Posted by Three G.M. Subsidiaries
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/14/busin.body_text: **********The three non-automotive subsidiaries of the General Motors Corporation posted strong fourth-quarter earnings today, helping to alleviate the large decline in automotive profits that G.M. is expected to announce Thursday. **********Some financial analysts predict G.M. will announce losses of $1.4 billion for the quarter. **********But the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, G.M.'s finance arm; the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, and the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation, which includes the Hughes Aircraft Company and Delco Electronics, reported increased profits.  3.1% Gain at GMAC **********GMAC, one of the nation's largest financial institutions, said its net income totaled $259 million in the quarter, up 3.1 percent from $251 million in the comparable quarter a year ago. For the year, its net income was $1.19 billion, up 7.2 percent from $1.11 billion last year. GMAC said it earned $217 million from financing activities and $42 million from insurance operations in the fourth quarter. **********John R. Edman, GMAC's chairman, said the higher income from financing operations reflected lower interest rates during the year and higher income from international operations. **********GM Hughes posted income of $195.6 million in the quarter, up 6.8 percent from $183 million a year ago. Its revenues rose 1.7 percent, to $2.94 billion from $2.89 billion. **********General Motors' class H stock, which reflects GM Hughes operations, earned 49 cents a share, compared with 46 cents in the fourth quarter of last year. For the year, the unit's profits were $726 million, or $1.82 a share, down 7 percent from $781.2 million, or $1.94 a share. Its revenues rose 2.6 percent, to $11.7 billion, from $11.4 billion in 1989.  Reasons for Decline **********Robert J. Schultz, the chairman of GM Hughes, said the drop in profits was caused by a higher tax rate, lower military spending and lower automobile sales, which were partly offset by cost-cutting measures. **********The unit said the commercial business of Hughes Aircraft had risen to 25 percent of its total business in 1990, from 20 percent a year ago. The company's goal is an equal mix of commercial and military business by the end of the decade. **********Electronic Data Systems, based in Dallas, said its fourth-quarter net income rose 11.6 percent, to $133.4 million, from $119.5 million a year earlier. Its revenues totaled $1.7 billion, up 18 percent from $1.43 billion in 1989. Earnings attributable to G.M.'s class E shares were 56 cents a share, compared with 50 cents a year ago. **********For the year, earnings rose 14.2 percent, to $496.9 million, or $2.08 a share, from $435 million, or $1.81 a share, in 1989. The unit's revenues rose 11.7 percent, to $6.1 billion, from $5.46 billion in 1989.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/04/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Nabisco Biscuit Hires Marketer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/04/busin.body_text: **********The Nabisco Biscuit Company, leader of the country's $5.6 billion cookies and crackers market, yesterday appointed Barbara S. Thomas, a former Procter & Gamble executive, to be its senior vice president of marketing. **********Ms. Thomas will be responsible for Nabisco Biscuit's marketing, new business development and strategic planning. She replaces Bruce Wood, who became president of Nabisco Brands' Planters Life Savers. **********During the last four years, Nabisco Biscuit, based in East Hanover, N.J., has aggressively pursued a strategy of introducing miniature versions of its well-known brands. The company started the industry trend toward miniaturization with Ritz Bits in 1987. **********Since then Nabisco has introduced several other pint-sized versions of its cookies and crackers, but the only major new brands to be introduced during the last two years have been Teddy Grahams cookies and Mr. Phipps pretzel chips. The company, a unit of RJR Nabisco Inc., markets more than 100 kinds of cookies and crackers and last year had domestic sales of $2.7 billion. **********At Procter & Gamble Ms. Thomas, who is 41 years old, was general manager of cleaning and personal care products since 1989. She joined P.& G. in 1973 after graduation from the University of Michigan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/23/world.print_headline: NEW RIOTS IN ZAIRE; 300 ARE EVACUATED
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/23/world.body_text: **********Belgian troops evacuated hundreds of foreigners from copper-producing areas of southeastern Zaire amid further looting today, and the opposition challenged President Mobutu Sese Seko by reconfirming as Prime Minister, his political adversary, Etienne Tshisekedi. **********Western diplomatic officials said disgruntled Zairian soldiers in the city of Lubumbashi went on a rampage late Monday, ransacking homes and offices. Civilians joined in when they saw that no action was being taken against the troops. **********"They looted everything -- all night," a witness said. "They've stripped the face of the town. They've even taken corrugated metal from the houses." **********The looting continued today, and the diplomats said less serious pillaging, directed mainly at state property, also took place in a central city, Mbuji-Mayi.  Riots in Kisangani **********The state television reported riots in another central city, Kisangani, and in the mining towns of Kolwezi and Likasi. **********There were no reports of deaths or serious injuries. But the Belgian Air Force began evacuating about 300 foreigners from Lubumbashi, principal city in Shaba province, the area once called Katanga. **********A C-130 plane carrying 80 people flew to Brazzaville, Congo, and two more were scheduled to go there. About 130 people flew to Johannesburg in a civilian plane, a spokeswoman said. **********Half of Lubumbashi's 1,400 European residents took refuge in a school ready for evacuation and others waited in their houses. Many worked for a mining company, Gecamines, which produces most of Zaire's vital copper and cobalt exports. **********Riots and peaceful political protests in September riots forced General Mobutu to share power with his political foes for the first time in his 26-year-rule, appointing Mr. Tshisekedi as Prime Minister of a crisis Cabinet. **********The Central African country was plunged into fresh political turmoil this week when General Mobutu dismissed Mr. Tshisekedi after he struck out clauses in his oath of office swearing allegiance to the President. **********The main opposition coalition, known as the Sacred Union, reaffirmed its full support for Mr. Tshisekedi today. **********The decision switched the political onus back to the Zairian President. He can accept Mr. Tshisekedi's nomination, having failed to split the Sacred Union, or reject it and risk confrontation on the streets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/20/busin.main_headline: New York State's Bonds Plunge
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/20/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; New York State's Bonds Plunge
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/20/busin.body_text: **********A sharp upward revision in the size of New York State's budget deficit for the current and coming fiscal years sent prices of the state's outstanding bond issues sharply lower yesterday. **********The effect of the new figures helped to create a logjam in what had been expected to be a record week of new offerings in the tax-exempt municipal bond market. **********Given woeful economic conditions, the fact that state officials raised the projected revenue shortfalls was not altogether surprising, analysts said. But the timing of the announcement, as well as the size of the new projections, came as a shock.  2 Issues Priced Last Week **********The state released its new deficit estimates a day before two debt issues priced last week, one for the Metropolitan Transit Authority, the other for New York State, were scheduled to be released to investors. **********The new estimates show that the revenue shortfall could be twice the $1.8 billion projection made in July for the 1992-93 fiscal year. **********The huge increase represented a material change in the outlook that had been presented to investors when the M.T.A. and New York State issues were priced last week, and created doubt about whether the securities would be released as scheduled. **********"For anyone who follows the state's finances, this is not an entirely unexpected event," one municipal bond trader said. "But the problem is that the state is not as organized as it should be, and when something of this nature comes out between the sale of a new issue and when it is scheduled to close, it is an event."  Status of Offerings **********Telephone calls to Goldman, Sachs & Company seeking comment on the status of the M.T.A. deal were not returned. Goldman served as lead underwriter on the offering. An official at the New York State Comproller's office, who asked not to be identified, said the New York State issue would close as scheduled. **********The revised numbers created a turmoil in the market for outstanding New York State bonds. Traders said prices of some bonds fell by as much as a point after the figures were released. **********The news also had an effect on New York City, which was poised to price $1.2 billion in refunding bonds yesterday. Because of the uncertainty created by the revised budget projections, underwriters of the city issue decided to delay the pricing for at least 24 hours. **********In all likelihood, the city's decision to postpone its offering will cause the New Jersey Turnpike Authority to put off pricing $1.6 billion in securities. The issue had been scheduled to be sold today.  Other Reverberations **********Besides the New York City offering, the University of California Board of Regents chose not to price more than $353 million worth of refunding bonds yesterday. California pulled the issue because it did not like the preliminary pricing on the securities. **********"This is clearly one of the more confusing new-issue days I have ever seen," said Stephen C. Leslie, a senior vice president at M. R. Beal & Company. "It was a tough day." **********Some $8 billion to $8.5 billion in tax-exempt bonds had been scheduled to be sold this week, but analysts said yesterday's developments created a logjam that might take several weeks to sort out. **********It is unlikely that such a large volume of new securities would be offered during the rest of the week. And because of Thanksgiving, new issues that might otherwise have been priced next week will probably be delayed, the analysts said.  The Dow's Influence **********Stock prices, not New York State, was the primary influence on developments in the secondary market for Treasury securities yesterday. **********Once again, the steep selloff in the equity market persuaded investors to buy short-term Treasury bills and notes. Bond prices fell however, and long-term interest rates moved higher. **********"People are willing to sell bonds no matter what the news," one government securities trader said. "It seems like the money that went into bonds at the refunding auctions has come back out again." **********By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 101, down by 7/8 point, to yield 7.91 percent. **********Among note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 31/ 32 in late trading, down by 7/32, to yield 7.36 percent. And the 6 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 29/32, up by 2/32, to yield 5.50 percent.  Short-Term Rates Down **********Short-term Treasury bill rates moved lower. **********In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.52 percent, down by 4 basis points, or four one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 5 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.55 percent. And one-year bills were offered in late trading at 4.58 percent, down by 4 basis points. **********Activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by a three-part, $450 million competitive offering of securities by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company. **********Yields on the securities range from 7.185 percent on notes maturing on Nov. 1, 1997, to 8.79 percent on bonds that mature on Nov. 1, 2021. **********The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/18/world.main_headline: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Washington; BALTIC CRACKDOWN ANGERS CONGRESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/18/world.print_headline: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Washington; BALTIC CRACKDOWN ANGERS CONGRESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/18/world.body_text: **********Voicing anger at repressive measures taken by the Soviet authorities against pro-independence forces in the Baltic republics, members of Congress called on the Bush Administration today to impose sanctions on Moscow and take other retaliatory steps. **********The legislators, speaking at a session of the United States Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, pointed repeatedly to what they perceived as a link between the moves of Soviet military units in Lithuania and Latvia at the very time the United States had mounted air strikes against Iraq. **********Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, said he believed that the Soviet authorities were using the gulf fighting as a pretext for "continuing to heighten" their pressure on the democratically elected governments in the Baltic republics. **********Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, asserted that Moscow was also "flouting the embargo" by continuing to send military supplies to Iraq. "Gorbachev has shown he is no longer to be trusted," he said. Representative Don Ritter, Republican of Pennsylvania, proposed "a strategy to hold Mr. Gorbachev's feet to the fire," with a goal of stripping him of his Nobel Peace Prize. Delay in Summit Meeting **********The legislators' recommendations included postponing a Bush-Gorbachev summit meeting scheduled for next month and taking up diplomatic relations with the three Baltic governments. The United States refused to acknowledge the Soviet Union's annexation of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in 1940 and continues to maintain ties with the vestigial diplomatic missions of those countries in Washington. But it has not accorded full recognition to the newly elected governments of the Baltic republics. **********Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, declared: "Only by granting diplomatic recognition to the embattled Baltic republics can we send the message that must be sent." **********Both Democratic and Republican legislators said they felt the Administration was treading too lightly on the Baltics issue. "I think the Administration and the State Department will have to do better," said Representative Frank R. Wolf, Republican of Virginia. Representative Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico, said, "I would have wished a stronger response from the State Department." Measures 'Under Review' **********Addressing the Congressional members of the panel, which also includes representatives from the executive branch, Assistant Secretary of State Raymond G. H. Seitz said the Administration had a number of punitive measures "more or less under review." **********Mr. Seitz, who is responsible for European and Canadian affairs at the department, said the Administration was considering a proposal to elevate the Baltic states to the status of observers at sessions of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. That conference is the permanent forum that grew out of the 35-government Helsinki agreement of 1975. **********Asked whether the United States might send a special high-level delegation to the Baltics to show solidarity with the independence movements, Mr. Seitz said that, too, was under consideration. **********Representative Steny H. Hoyer, the Maryland Democrat who as co-chairman convened today's session of the commission on one day's notice, said such a delegation to the Baltics should be headed by former Presidents Carter and Reagan. **********In a statement, Mr. Seitz said that the Administration, viewing the military actions in the Baltics 'with abhorrence," had repeatedly sent protests to Moscow. "We ask the Soviet authorities to undo what has been done," he said. **********He also noted that Dainis Ivans, deputy prime minister of Latvia, and Bronius Kuzmickas, one of the vice presidents of Lithuania, were arriving in Washington this evening and would "be received here at a high level." Several of the commission members urged that President Bush receive the Baltic leaders as a means of sending the proper signal to Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/27/busin.main_headline: Nintendo and Minnesota Set A Living-Room Lottery Test
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/27/busin.print_headline: Nintendo and Minnesota Set A Living-Room Lottery Test
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/27/busin.body_text: **********In Minnesota, all you will need is a dollar, a dream and a Nintendo set. **********The state plans to test a system that will allow people to use Nintendo equipment to play the state lottery in the comfort of their living rooms. **********With the growth of lotteries tapering off, industry executives and officials in other states are eager to see whether this approach can draw more people to the games by letting them play without standing in line to buy tickets.  Combating a Slowdown **********"The lottery industry is looking for ways to expand its horizons," said Connie Scovin, an executive with the Control Data Corporation, the Minneapolis-based company that developed the idea and is designing the test system. **********Nearly a third of the nation's homes have Nintendo sets, and if the Minnesota test is successful, Control Data plans to make the system available to other states. **********The test will involve 10,000 homes next year. For the test, the state will provide the video game sets and the modem devices that allow them to communicate with a central computer. Participants, who will pay a service charge of $10 a month, will get software that lets them play all of Minnesota's games, including the biggest jackpots. **********After players set up accounts with the lottery, they will be able to select their lottery numbers on their television sets at home. The numbers will be stored electronically in the central lottery computer and in a file in the player's Nintendo set. **********Small prizes will be credited to the player's account. To collect a large jackpot, winners will have to go to a state lottery office and identify themselves as the holder of the winning account. **********It is illegal in Minnesota for minors to play lottery games, and the Nintendo plan has been criticized by the State Attorney General and others who say it will make it easy for children to gamble. The system will have passwords and other safeguards intended to thwart unauthorized playing. **********"Kids are gambling now; this will allow them to gamble more," said Tony Bouza, the former Gaming Commissioner in Minnesota. Young people today are well acquainted with technology, and they will inevitably devise ways to bypass the security measures, he predicted. He also said that gambling at home by adults sets a bad example for children. "You can't create safe sins," he said. **********But others say the new system could serve a broader purpose, providing the catalyst that will encourage more people to use computers and phone lines to tap into a growing pool of information and services. **********Nintendo's use as a gambling device may help put spark into the market for such on-line services, said Gary Arlen of Arlen Communications Inc., a research firm in Bethesda, Md. "I've been looking for the killer service," he said. "This is the kind of thing that makes sense." **********For more than a decade, large corporations like Sears, Roebuck and I.B.M. have invested hundreds of millions of dollars in networks that allow people to shop, read the news, and make travel reservations using home computers linked to telephone lines. Such systems, including a Sears-I.B.M. joint venture, Prodigy Services Company, have been somewhat cumbersome to use and have been viewed more as a novelty than a necessary adjunct to daily life. Only about 3 percent of the households in the United States use an on-line service like Prodigy, Mr. Arlen said. **********But as giant corporations have stumbled, Nintendo has been lurking in the background, the envy of the industry, with 30 million units already in use. Nintendo has had its eye on far more than the video-game market since it sold its first machine in the United States in 1986. **********In Japan, Nintendo customers use their machines for banking and for buying and selling stocks. In a prescient bit of engineering, Nintendo included a plug to snap in a modem on the bottom of every machine sold in the United States. **********With the lottery game, Nintendo will introduce its modem to the United States. As a contractor to Control Data, Nintendo will supply the modem and a specially designed software cartridge that provides lottery graphics. Control Data officials said Nintendo was providing the 10,000 machines and the other equipment for the test at no cost. The machines retail for about $80. **********People who already have Nintendo machines would have to retrofit them with a modem to take advantage of on-line services. Computer modems are currently available for less than $100, and Mr. Arlen said Nintendo engineers could probably come up with a modem that would cost $50 to $75. Still, he questioned how many consumers would be willing to nearly double their investment in the machines. **********Nintendo has also explored setting up a game network in which players could challenge other players, and has considered a stock trading service with Fidelity Services of Boston. Both projects are on hold. Nintendo said in a statement, "We are constantly approached by third parties who have ideas that are outside the traditional video-game arena." **********Some in the industry say Nintendo may harm its image by its association with a lottery. They note that the company is already under fire from some parents and educators who say its games lack educational content. **********"It's Jimmy the Greek comes home to your kid's bedroom," said Bob Heitman, general manager of the Sierra Network, a computerized game network that charges players to use its service. The network is a unit of Sierra On-Line Inc., a maker of computer games. **********"I have a bad feeling for lotteries," he said. "As a family game company, I would not do it or advocate that our company do it."  New Uses for Older Machines **********For Nintendo, the lottery business could help prolong the life of its older model, which has been outmoded by a more powerful Nintendo machine introduced in the United States last month. Also, the introduction of gambling could help combat the general decline in interest in video games. **********In a statement, Nintendo said, "This test could provide us with some insights into the potential for further network applications; however, our main focus is to find the kind of entertainment software that will truly take advantage of that potential." **********Nintendo says that its machines are more than just toys and that 35 percent of Nintendo players are over the age of 18. Minnesota lottery officials and Control Data executives say their system's safeguards should be adequate to keep children from playing the lottery at home. Otho Brown, a vice president of Control Data, likened the situation to banking through automatic teller machines -- parents who keep the password a secret should have no concern about a child's misusing a cash card. **********The lottery system has a number of built-in safeguards, including a feature that disables the unit if an incorrect password is entered. Becoming eligible to play the lottery at home is an involved process that requires mailing in a copy of a driver's license or other photo identification. And, all play is prepaid through deposits the account holders make with the lottery, so no one can run up a big unpaid bill. A $50 daily limit will be put on each player. Control Data's Hopes **********If the home system is successful, it could provide an important business advantage for Control Data. The Minnesota-based company lags behind the Gtech Corporation of West Greenwich, R.I., the leader in supplying computer equipment and services to lotteries. **********"We entered the test with the idea that lotteries would use it nationwide," said Mr. Brown of Control Data. He said lottery growth has slowed because the games have already attracted all the people interested in playing. **********Nationwide, more than $20 billion was spent on lottery tickets last year, an increase of 2.8 percent from a year earlier, according to the North American Association of State and Provincial Lotteries in Washington. There are lotteries in 33 states and the District of Columbia. **********As a result of the slowdown in the rate of growth, Mr. Brown said the lottery industry has been exploring ways to increase the appeal of the games and attract new types of customers. A group of state lotteries is considering sponsoring a nationally televised lottery show. **********Mr. Brown said Nintendo owners are better educated and more affluent than the typical lottery players. He said that if home lottery play caught on, it could increase volume by 10 percent to 15 percent a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/19/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Ameritech Plans to Cut 2,300 Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/19/busin.body_text: **********Following the lead of other regional Bell operating companies seeking to cut costs, Ameritech said yesterday that it planned to use attrition and layoffs to trim its work force by nearly 2,300, or 3 percent, over several years. **********Ameritech is taking a quarterly charge of $140 million, or 53 cents a share. This includes costs for severance pay, as well as separate charges for the write-down of certain assets in unregulated businesses like audiotext, and the early retirement of high-interest debt. **********All the Bell telephone companies, as well as the GTE Corporation, must compete against a growing number of smaller, often more efficient telecommunications companies. These concerns can woo away the giant phone companies' most lucrative business customers while saddling the local carriers with more tightly regulated, and often less profitable, phone service for residential customers. The residential market in many areas has also been growing far more slowly than the market for business customers. Plans to Cut Work Force **********Other "Baby Bells" have either taken or are considering similar charges for layoffs. Nynex, in New York and New England, said last month that it planned to reduce its work force by 9,900 and take a $550 million charge, most of it for severance pay and other costs. U S West took a similar $590 million charge. **********Ameritech, based in Chicago, has about 75,700 workers and provides local service for Illinois, Michigan, Ohio, Wisconsin and Indiana. It posted 199o revenue of $10.66 billion. **********On the New York Stock Exchange, Ameritech's shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday to $63.125. **********Ameritech also said it would increase its quarterly dividend, but at about half the usual annual rate of 7.3 percent. It increased the dividend 3 cents, to 88 cents a share, or $3.52 annually. William L. Weiss, Ameritech's chairman, said in a statement, "We recognize the importance of dividends to our shareowners," but added that the level of increase was in line with the company's lower operating performance. **********The $140 million charge, taken this month, will lower fourth-quarter earnings by more than half of the $1.05 a share that analysts had expected. **********Full-year profit is likely to be about $4.17 a share, down nearly 12 percent from the $4.73 a year earlier, which included 28 cents of one-time gains from the sale of assets. **********Marion M. Boucher, a telecommunications analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said the Ameritech action was "a fairly routine charge that should have a positive impact on earnings." She raised her estimate of 1992 earnings to $4.82 a share from $4.76. **********About $52 million of the $140 million charge results from work force reductions, mainly because of the planned job consolidation and layoffs over the next three to five years. Voluntary Retirement Program **********Less than 20 percent of the $52 million is also associated with a voluntary retirement program, announced earlier this year, intended to reduce the number of managers by 2,000 by the end of this month. Ameritech was not more specific. **********Another $67 million is for the writedown, or the reduction in value, of assets in less successful businesses. These businesses are in the unregulated portion of Ameritech's business that go beyond what the industry calls Plain Old Telephone Service, or POTS. They include Ameritech's venture into audiotext, an information service available over the telephone through "800" and "900" numbers. **********The balance of $21 million is for a variety of charges including costs associated with the advance payment of $175 million in debentures due in 2001. The notes carried an interest rate of 9.6 percent, at a time when borrowing costs have fallen sharply.

The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/15/world.main_headline: Rebel Kurds Claim Control of Iraq Area
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/15/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: IRAQ; Rebel Kurds Claim Control of Iraq Area
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/15/world.body_text: **********Kurdish rebels battling troops loyal to Saddam Hussein today claimed control of wide areas of the Kurdish region in the rugged northern part of Iraq, as opposition forces in several parts of the country reported new military gains. **********Radio reports in Turkey and Iran said there was heavy fighting in Kurdish districts along their borders with Iraq, and a Kurdish radio station monitored by the British Broadcasting Corporation tonight appealed for discipline among people living in areas it said were now in rebel hands. **********In the south of the country, near Basra, Shiite opposition forces said 16 high-ranking officers of the Republican Guard had joined the rebels, and there were also unconfirmed reports that the key provincial city of Hilla, 60 miles south of Baghdad, had fallen to Government foes, who also reportedly executed several local officials loyal to President Hussein. **********Although the battlefield reports of rebel advances, gleaned from radio broadcasts and news reports emanating from the opposition in Iran, Lebanon and Europe, could not be independently verified, diplomats here said there appeared to be growing pressure within Iraq on President Hussein's beleaguered Government.  Prisoners to Be Freed **********Earlier in the day, in a decree from the ruling Revolution Command Council, and broadcast on Baghadad radio, the Government announced it would open prison doors and release Iraqi inmates, except those imprisoned for the most serious offenses. **********The general pardon includes all except those prisoners convicted of spying, currency violations, rape, counterfeiting, premeditated murder and several other charges, among them crimes that are punishable by the death penalty. **********Government radio broadcasts from Baghdad made no mention today of the rebel battlefield claims, but an official of the Iraqi Ministry of Information released a statement early in the day, strongly denying reports Wednesday on Iranian radio that there had been street battles inside the capital between anti-Government demonstrators and soldiers. **********The Government radio broadcast described the reports as "fabricated, baseless and completely unfounded," and attributed them to an "aggressive campaign being waged by the hostile quarters against Iraq and its steadfast people."  Reports of Rebel Successes **********The reports of fresh rebel successes came a day after representatives from several Iraqi opposition groups, including Kurds, socialists, Shiite and Sunni Muslims and former Army officers, concluded a three-day conference in Beirut, vowing to put aside their differences and work to defeat President Hussein. **********According to broadcasts from the Party of God radio in Lebanon, monitored by the BBC, rebel factions from Iraq's Shiite Muslim community claim to have captured the key provincial town of Hilla, 60 miles south of Baghdad, near that portion of the rich Euphrates River Valley where the ancient city of Babylon once stood. **********Quoting a communique from the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution, the radio station said rebels had also taken control of seven surrounding towns, and executed the provincial governor, the chief of police, the head of security and the leader of the local Baath party. **********In the south, near Basra, according to the official Iranian News Agency, IRNA, rebels say they seized several Government tanks in fighting, and claim that 16 Republican Guard officers switched sides and joined opposition forces.  Iraqi Control Seen as Lessening **********The Iranian agency, quoting the Radio Voice of Revoluntionary Iraq, which broadcasts from Basra, said a former general in the Revolutionary Guard now says that 70 percent of Basra Province "is out of Iraqi Government control." **********In an attempt to rally the faithful, Shiite opposition forces also asserted today that Iraqi artillery had damaged holy Islamic shrines in the city of Karbala. **********In the Kurdish districts in northern Iraq, the Kurdish radio station, Voice of the People of Kurdistan, tonight invited foreign journalists to come and visit what it called "liberated Kurdistan." **********All through the day, there were various radio reports monitored by the BBC, describing heavy fighting in several cities in the Kurdish region. In the Dohuk area, near Turkey, rebel forces said they captured 10 towns in fighting today, and controlled 90 percent of the province.  Gunfire on Turkish Border **********Along the Turkish border, Turkish villagers reported seeing Iraqi customs officers fleeing, and reported the sound of gunfire. **********In Raniya, near the Iranian border, Kurdish forces said they stormed Government offices and now controlled key roads in the area. Further south, near Kirkuk, Iraqi troops set fire to oil wells in battles with Kurdish rebels, Iranian radio broadcasts said. **********The Kurds, who make up about 21 percent of Iraq's 17 million people, have long been engaged in a battle for their own national identity, in the mountainous regions that cut across Iran, Iraq, Syria and Turkey.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/world.main_headline: Nemuro Journal; Kaese! Japanese Refugees Fight to Reclaim Islands
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/world.print_headline: Nemuro Journal; Kaese! Japanese Refugees Fight to Reclaim Islands
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/world.body_text: **********Mitsuo Yanami still remembers well the day in early September 1945, hours after Japan's unconditional surrender aboard the battleship Missouri, when Soviet soldiers overran the tiny island where he lived, just north of here in the frigid northern Pacific. **********"We were shocked," recalled Mr. Yanami, who was 17 years old at the time. "At first we thought they were Americans. After all, the Americans had just won the war, and we didn't even know the Soviet Union was one of the Allies. But then we overheard them talking about Stalin." **********The Soviets took the last of the islands a day after Japan's formal surrender, expelling Mr. Yanami and 17,384 other residents -- the Japanese are nothing if not precise, and they have accounted for everyone -- and leaving behind a legacy of bitterness that the Government maintains is shared by all of Japan. **********On Tuesday, building on a four-decade-long public relations campaign, the aging refugees of the islands off Japan's northern coast see one great chance to win their Northern Territories back: the arrival of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the first Soviet leader ever to visit Japan.  Soviets Seek Japan's Help **********The 46-year-old occupation of the islands -- Etorofu (which the Soviets call Iturup), Kunashiri (Kunashir), Shikotan and the Habomai group -- has turned into something of a national obsession in Japan, an obsession fed by influential right-wing groups, powerful fishing organizations and the former islanders themselves. For years this fast-declining fishing town has been dotted with signboards with the rallying cry "Kaese!" -- "Give them back!" -- and the Government has made it clear that a give-back will be the price next week if Mr. Gorbachev wants billions of dollars of Japanese consumer goods, technology for Soviet factories and Japanese-financed oil exploration in Siberia. **********It is a price that many Japanese officials suspect Mr. Gorbachev will be unable or unwilling to pay. Yet here in Nemuro, the former islanders who live within sight of their old homeland -- the closest island is only two miles away -- are spending their days spreading and dashing rumors of a secret deal in the works. **********For several weeks hopes have risen on reports that Japan may be prepared to pay upwards of $28 billion, masked as economic aid, to regain sovereignty over the islands. That comes to roughly $22,680 an acre for one of the world's most remote, ice-blocked and inhospitable corners. Then the other day a Japanese newspaper quoted the Soviet Defense Minister, Dmitri T. Yazov, as saying there would be absolutely no deal. **********Mr. Gorbachev's staff also tried to reduce expectations as they arrived in Tokyo this week. "This is a problem that has gone on for a hundred years," said Vitaly N. Ignatenko, Mr. Gorbachev's spokesman. "It will not be solved overnight." Nasty Battles Brewing **********Even though it is hard to find anyone here under the age of 70 who says he is actually willing to move back to the islands, nasty battles are already brewing as Japanese families jostle for long-lost property rights. **********Mr. Gorbachev may well offer to acknowledge Japanese sovereignty over two of the islands closest to Japanese shores and promise to talk about the other two, a deal that the Soviets briefly put forward and Japan rejected a quarter-century ago. Taking an uncharacteristically hard-line stance, Japan's Foreign Ministry has left little room for such compromises, saying that for the visit to be a success Mr. Gorbachev must now recognize Japan's claim to all four -- even if the actual turnover takes years. **********No one can quite explain why the issue has such an emotional appeal for Japan, save for the fact that the Japanese are inculcated from childhood that they live in a small country with no land to spare. When foreigners suggest that the loss of the islands was a relatively small price for Japan to pay for its colonial forays into Korea, Manchuria and vast stretches of Southeast Asia, islanders here respond with cold stares. U.S. Is Blamed Too **********"Certainly Japan was responsible for starting the war," Mitsuo Takaiwa, a prosperous-looking former fisherman. But, he said, the Soviets are more to blame for exploiting Japan's helplessness in the last days of the war, in violation of a nonaggression pact between the two nations. "The U.S. is responsible, too," he said, "for allowing the Soviet Union to do that." **********More than 9,000 fishermen have been detained by the Soviets for poaching in the island waters, and fishing seems to be one major reason Japan wants the territory back. The area around Nemuro was harvested to the point of depletion, and major fisheries stand to gain millions of dollars if the islands come back. **********But the people of Nemuro say they do not want to kick out the 20,000 to 30,000 Soviet citizens now living on the disputed territory, a figure that includes a large number of military personnel. "I think it may be possible to live together," says Hirotoshi Kawata, a 56-year-old city official who remembers befriending a soldier named Aleksei who was part of the invading party. **********But for the 11,000 surviving islanders, the war will not really be over until the islands are repatriated. **********"The islands were rich when I was there, and I have always dreamed of returning," Shoji Ashizaki, who once lived on the Habomais. "We Japanese know we can make them rich again."
