https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/30/busin.main_headline: Germany Rolls Out Its Fast Train
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/30/busin.print_headline: Germany Rolls Out Its Fast Train
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/30/busin.body_text: **********Germany's state-owned railroad system formally introduced its new high-speed train service today, as slick, computer-controlled trains capable of speeds of 250 miles an hour carried 4,000 guests to a coming-out party in Kassel, a crossroads city lying almost precisely at the country's geographic center. **********President Richard von Weizsacker officially started the Deutsche Bundesbahn's new Inter-City Express service at noon by pressing a button on a computer control panel. **********"I am confident that the high-speed trains will encourage a renaissance in rail travel," said Mr. von Weizsacker, who had arrived 15 minutes late because, a Bundesbahn spokesman explained, someone accidentally activated the emergency brakes on the President's high-speed train during the trip from Bonn, about 80 miles away. **********More than two dozen Inter-City Express trains will begin regular service Sunday morning on a newly built line linking Hamburg, Frankfurt, Stuttgart and Munich and cities in between. The network will be expanded in the future to include Berlin and other destinations, and it will eventually be part of a planned Western European high-speed train system. **********Development of the German high-speed rail network began in 1973. The entire system -- which included creating special rails, boring miles of tunnels and building the roadbed -- cost $12 billion, Bundesbahn officials said. **********Unfortunately, Mr. von Weizsacker's trip typified the delays many patrons have come to expect from the state-owned Bundesbahn, which is losing billions of dollars each year with no prospect of a turnaround in sight. **********Whether the consortium that developed Germany's high-speed rail system will be able to catch up with its French and Japanese competitors, which have been building and operating such trains for years, is also an open question. **********The Inter-City Express trains and track were developed and built for the Bundesbahn by a consortium consisting of AEG A.G., the electronics subsidiary of Daimler-Benz A.G.; Thyssen Henschel, a subsidiary of the vast Thyssen A.G. industrial conglomerate, and Siemens A.G., Germany's largest electronics concern. **********The Germans contend that their high-speed train is more technologically advanced and more comfortable than its French and Japanese counterparts. But it also costs more. **********Industry experts said experience and more flexible pricing made France's TGV trains and the Japanese "bullet" trains the front-runners in the bidding to build high-speed lines in other Western European countries and in the United States. Canada, South Korea and Taiwan are also accepting bids on high-speed train systems, while Australia, Brazil and the Soviet Union are considering such projects. **********Price was apparently a factor on Tuesday when the Texas High Speed Rail Authority chose a $5.7 billion bid by a consortium that included GEC Alsthom of France and the Morrison Knudsen Corporation of the United States to build a high-speed line linking Dallas, Houston and San Antonio. Texas rejected the German consortium's $6.7 billion bid. **********The new German trains are gleaming white with a single red stripe down each side and can carry up to 750 passengers at an average speed of 150 miles an hour. **********They will cut travel time from Hamburg to Frankfurt by one hour to three and a half hours and will shave two hours off the trip from Hamburg in the country's north to Munich in the south, making it about seven hours. A one-way ticket between those two cities will cost $176 in first class and $117 in second, or 14 percent more than regular express-train fares. **********Each train, which costs $30 million and is a single unit with engines at both ends, is sealed and pressurized like an airliner. Passengers can listen to a variety of music channels or radio on headphones. Small television sets are imbedded in the backs of some seats, allowing passengers to watch videos. **********The new high-speed train service is one of the few bright spots the Bundesbahn has had in recent years. Despite annual Government subsidies of about $8 billion, the Bundesbahn lost $2.9 billion in 1990, after losing $2.26 billion the year before. It has debts of $27.68 billion. **********Heinz Durr, the Bundesbahn president, said he expected the Bundesbahn's losses to deepen in 1991, even though ridership was up about 6 percent in the first quarter of this year from a year earlier, and freight volume had risen around 8 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/21/busin.body_text: **********The New York State Environmental Facilities Corporation yesterday priced a $48 million water-pollution-control revenue bond through competitive bidding won by Kidder, Peabody & Company. **********The bond offering, involving a Westchester County project, was bought and reoffered to the public at a price to yield from 4.4 percent for a bond due in 1992 to 5.35 percent in 1996, 5.95 percent in 2001, 6.4 percent in 2006 and 6.5 percent for bonds due in 2008 through 2011. **********Underwriters said the issue was rated triple-A by Moody's, S.&. P, and Fitch Investors Service, without the aid of insurance as a credit enhancement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/28/busin.main_headline: Venture Set With Du Pont On Pesticides
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/28/busin.print_headline: Venture Set With Du Pont On Pesticides
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/28/busin.body_text: **********Crop Genetics International, a small agricultural biotechnology company, and E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, one of the world's largest agricultural chemical producers, said yesterday that they had formed an alliance to develop naturally occurring insect viruses into pesticides. **********Du Pont, based in Wilmington, Del., will provide Crop Genetics with up to $3.7 million over two years to develop virus products and mass-produce them at low cost with a proprietary process. Du Pont is expected to help formulate the products so they can be applied inexpensively to crops, to help them gain regulatory approval and to help sell them. Profit sharing will be negotiated case by case as products are ready for market, the companies said. **********In over-the-counter trading yesterday, Crop Genetics' stock shot up 72.2 percent, gaining $3.25, to $7.75. It was that market's biggest gainer in percentage terms. **********The first targets will be caterpillars that attack fruits and vegetables. Crop Genetics, based in Hanover, Md., submitted three such viruses to the Environmental Protection Agency for registration as a new pesticide last summer. The process normally takes up to a year for products that do not involve genetic engineering. **********Like other naturally occurring insect killers, or biopesticides, the viruses have potentially important environmental benefits compared with synthetic chemical products produced by Du Pont and other chemical giants. The viruses are deadly only to the insects in which they are found, and even then only when present in larger concentrations than are commonly found. **********The viruses also tend to break down relatively quickly into environmentally harmless remains when they are outside their host insect. Thus, farmers could spray large concentrations on crops without harming helpful insects, other animals, farmworkers or consumers. A Major Drawback **********The biggest roadblock to using viruses as pesticides is that they may take several days to kill an insect. That has not stopped the Agriculture Department from developing Gypcheck, a virus used against the gypsy moth by the Forestry Service. But the private sector has remained primarily committed to synthetic chemicals, and most new biopesticides are based on toxic proteins found in naturally occurring bacteria that quickly kill specific insects. **********A virus manufactured in the 1970's by Sandoz Ltd. of Switzerland for use against the boll weevil failed commercially. **********"Growers want to see bugs dying right away," said Fred Betz, a microbial pesticides expert at the E.P.A. **********Joseph Kelly, the chairman and chief executive of Crop Genetics, said farmers were increasingly willing to be patient in using a product that was more environmentally sound. But he stressed that the viruses would most likely be used with other biological and chemical pesticides. **********For example, a virus might be applied when a vegetable was first emerging from the ground, but a chemical would be used if the plant was nearly mature to kill insects as quickly as possible and preserve its appearance. Various Methods Urged **********Frank R. Owen, the global product manager for Du Pont's $1.7 billion agricultural chemicals group, noted that rotating among different types of pesticides would make it harder for insects to develop resistance to any one product. **********Du Pont's only other venture into biopesticides so far has been a two-year-old agreement to handle the marketing in the United States of Biobit, an anti-caterpillar toxin isolated from a common bacteria by Novo-Nordisk A.S. of Denmark. **********The worldwide market for pesticides affecting leading crops, including insecticides, fungicides and herbicides, is thought to be about $20 billion. Analysts figure that biopesticides account for about $100 million of it, at most, but the segment is growing rapidly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/01/busin.main_headline: Mitsui Venture In Real Estate
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/01/busin.print_headline: Mitsui Venture In Real Estate
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/01/busin.body_text: **********The Mitsui Real Estate Sales New York Company and the Edward S. Gordon Company said yesterday that they had formed a venture to serve the commercial real estate needs of Japanese companies and nationals in the New York region. The venture will be called Mitsui/ESG and will be run by executives from both companies. **********Mitsui, the dominant commercial property broker in Japan, and Gordon, a leading real estate services company in New York, intend to serve Japanese corporations that have invested in New York properties, as well as Japanese tenants looking for space. **********Masahiko Kawakami, an executive vice president of Mitsui Real Estate Sales, said of Japanese investors who have bought New York properties: "It was easy to just pay and get the properties. Now we must learn to get the return from the real estate." **********Many Japanese investors have spent more than $11 billion on New York real estate since 1985, Mitsui/ESG said. **********The venture, to be in the Pan Am Building at 200 Park Avenue in Manhattan, will be run by Mr. Kawakami, as well as David Levinson and Randy Kohana of Edward S. Gordon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.main_headline: San Francisco Agency for The New Yorker
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; San Francisco Agency for The New Yorker
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.body_text: **********THE New Yorker magazine awarded its $1 million advertising account yesterday to Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein of San Francisco, but the significance of the assignment goes far beyond its billings. **********More than anything else, the 66-year-old magazine, which is owned by Advance Publications Inc., is considered a plum assignment because of the prestige and audience it brings. The magazine asked only five advertising agencies to participate in its review, but Steve Florio, the president and chief executive of the New Yorker Magazine Inc., estimated that he had fielded an additional 35 serious inquiries. **********What stood out immediately about Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein, one of the most talked-about agencies in the country, was that all its top executives read the magazine closely, Mr. Florio said. **********"It's part of their lives," Mr. Florio said. "It wasn't just another business assignment. They really were passionate. This may sound silly, but they really wanted it." **********The magazine put its account under review several months ago when it became clear that its longtime agency, Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners, would lose several top executives when it merged into the new firm Lord, Dentsu & Partners. **********The agencies that participated in the review, in addition to Goodby and Lord, Dentsu, were Deutsch Inc. and Omon Advertising. Edward McCabe, the copywriting star who recently started his own agency, McCabe & Company, also made a pitch, Mr. Florio said. **********Martin H. Landey, chairman of Cox Landey & Partners Inc. in New York, said that advertising agencies generally coveted national magazine accounts because they were usually aimed at national advertisers. The New Yorker, Mr. Landey said, is particularly valuable. **********"It's probably more visible because it's a New York magazine and because the creme de la creme of advertisers are in the magazine," he said. **********Mr. Florio said he was adamant that the winner of the review have a New York office, and he stipulated that Goodby must establish a physical presence in New York. While Andy Berlin, a principal in the $100 million San Francisco agency, was unwilling to say directly whether the agency would indeed open a New York office, he said he and his partners were seriously discussing it. **********Mr. Florio said the agency would not be asked to make any "radical changes" in the magazine's advertising strategy, particularly because -- unlike most publications -- the magazine's ad pages went up in 1990 and circulation reached a high of 623,000. The agency's initial assignments will include the preparation of trade advertising, as well as some circulation and promotional materials. **********"An awful lot of what's happening in magazines has to do with the general image people have of you," Mr. Florio said. "They'll have a lot to do with that." **********In the last six months, Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein, which Jeffrey Goodby, Mr. Berlin and Richard Silverstein formed in 1983, has landed multimillion-dollar assignments from several big advertisers, including Nippon Steel, the National Basketball Association and Heublein Inc. **********Advertising Age, a trade publication, named Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein the United States Agency of the Year in 1989. **********Mr. Berlin said yesterday that acquiring The New Yorker account brought back personal memories. **********"When I was a freshman at Duke University, I sent my poems and my essays to The New Yorker," Mr. Berlin said. "I papered my wall with all the rejection letters, but I posted them with pride."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/31/world.main_headline: The Saudis Are Fearful, Too, As Islam's Militant Tide Rises
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/31/world.print_headline: The Saudis Are Fearful, Too, As Islam's Militant Tide Rises
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/31/world.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia's religious and political leaders are concerned about militant religious fundamentalists who are using mosques and religious universities to stir up opposition. **********The senior religious leader, Sheik Abdelaziz ibn Baz, who in the past was generally assumed to be at least tacitly opposed to the modernization policies of the Government, made a speech over the weekend attacking the militant fundamentalists. **********Sheik Ibn Baz's attack was publicized by the Saudi press agency and in Saudi newspapers received here today. It echoed an earlier, unpublished warning by Prince Turki al-Faisal, the Saudi chief of intelligence, who made his comments in a rare public speech at a mosque in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, Saudi officials said by telephone from Saudi Arabia. **********These developments, whose details are just coming out of Saudi Arabia, are unfolding at a time when militant fundamentalists have grown in number in Saudi Arabia and elsewhere in the region. Fundamentalists have already taken over in the Sudan, which has aligned itself with Iran. **********In Saudi Arabia the number of fundamentalists has grown considerably since the Persian Gulf crisis began in the summer of 1990. They are now estimated to include tens of thousands of younger radical religious leaders, Islamic university teachers and students. **********Islamic fundamentalists are challenging several governments in the Middle East that are secular in their orientation, like those in Algeria, Tunisia, Egypt and Jordan. But their challenge to the Saudi Government, which is fundamentalist, suggests in the view of experts that they are using religion to change the established order. **********Saudi Arabia strictly observes Islamic precepts and edicts in everyday life, banning alcohol, demanding that women wear veils, making prayer obligatory five times a day and requiring religion as a part of education. **********In the view of most Saudi affairs experts, the militants do not constitute a mortal danger to the Saudi Government. But ever since a group of them took over the Grand Mosque of Mecca in 1979 -- they were routed in a bloody battle with Saudi forces after a two-week siege -- they have become a growing disruptive force, and the Government has decided to challenge them. **********As the movement spread, it seemed to feed off the frustrations of hundreds of thousands of university graduates unable to find jobs or suitable employment. It has been self-sustaining, with no evidence of foreign financial support. **********Over the last few months, the militant elements, which discreetly coordinate their activities through religious societies and mosques, have adopted a strategy of attacking Government policies in public speeches in the mosques and in university lectures. **********More important, they have been recording and distributing their assaults on Government policies and personalities, including several officials, columnists and senior religious leaders, in hundreds of thousands of audio cassettes widely available in every city of the country in what the Saudi Government now regards as a menacing, subversive campaign. Sweeping Attacks **********The fundamentalists' assaults on the Saudi Government have been aimed at virtually every aspect of domestic and foreign policy. **********They have criticized the arrival of American troops during the gulf crisis. They have attacked Saudi Arabia's support of the Middle East peace negotiations sponsored by the United States and have opposed any talk of peace with Israel. **********The fundamentalists have also described the Saudi Government's banking and financial policies, particularly Saudi Arabia's growing role as a major power in international finance. **********The criticism by the religious militants has in the last few weeks also stretched to Saudi Arabia's educational system and the participation of women in higher education, even though education of men and women is strictly segregated. They have gone so far as to call leading female educators in the country "prostitutes." **********Sheik Ibn Baz, a blind man who commands enormous reverence among the Saudi public and within the vast traditionalist religious establishment, singled out those who he said "whisper secretly in their meetings and record their poison over cassettes distributed to the people, or those who make these allegations in public lectures at universities." **********"This behavior," Sheik Ibn Baz warned, "is against the will of God." 'Lies and Conspiracies' **********The sheik is President of the Administration of Scientific Research, Religious Scholarship and Guidance. His post is roughly the equivalent of several ministerial positions overseeing all religious affairs and supervising the country's mosques, religious universities and educational authorities and the religious affairs police. While considered an ally of the Saudi ruling family, Sheik Ibn Baz is somewhat independent in his views and thus enjoys an authority that is separate from the will of the ruling family. **********He went on in his statement, which was published in detail in the Saudi daily Asharq Al Awsat on Saturday, to condemn the militants' assertions as "lies," and "conspiracies against Islam and Muslims." **********"Many of those who pretend to have knowledge and a religious calling," he said, "have, in this day and age, surfaced to contest and injure established religious leaders, doing so secretly in their gatherings, or proclaiming their views openly in sermons in the mosques, or recording these views on cassettes that are distributed among the people. **********"I counsel those who have misguided youths and filled them with hatred and conspiracies and erroneous gossip about such and such person, to repent and to desist for these activities." **********Among other things, some of the public speeches and cassettes of the Saudi religious militants over the last few weeks publicly attacked the Saudi Women's Renaissance Association, with which several of the royal family's princesses and prominent Saudi women are associated. The militants described the women as "prostitutes" and demanded that the association be disbanded. **********The move prompted a rare response by Prince Turki, the son of the late King Faisal, in a speech made a mosque. According to several Saudis familiar with the situation, Prince Turki accused the militants of slandering some of his acquaintances. **********"The thrust of his message was, 'You have gone too far,' " said a Saudi businessman who has firsthand knowledge of the Prince's comments. "It's more than a warning. It's the beginning of a confrontation by a senior and powerful member of the Saudi royal family." **********Taken together, the retorts by an eminent member of the ruling family and the traditional religious establishment are unusual in their severity, indicating that a new threshold of confrontation between the ruling establishment and radical militants has been reached. **********The Saudi ruling establishment's reaction, not coincidentally, parallels major recent policy initiatives by King Fahd, who announced a few weeks ago his intention to institute a "consultative council" and publish a body of written civil laws regulating business activities and civic litigation. **********These steps were widely viewed as necessary to support Saudi Arabia's fast-changing status as a major economic force, and essential to permit the growth and evolution of the Saudi private sector, which works in association with foreign, mostly Western, banks, companies and financial institutions. **********These trends are fiercely resisted by the xenophobic militant elements in Saudi Arabia because they threaten to seriously dilute their control over the ordinary lives of Saudi citizens and give the establishment a strong base to push for more modernization.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.main_headline: AID TO BANGLADESH IS STILL HAMPERED
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.print_headline: AID TO BANGLADESH IS STILL HAMPERED
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.body_text: **********Survivors of last week's cyclone in Bangladesh are suffering from a lack of food and clean water, and many could die of disease, the League of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies said today. **********The official Cyclone Preparedness Center said the death toll as of this evening was 125,672, up only slightly from the previous day. **********"An estimated four million people are now at serious risk from lack of fresh drinking water and food," a statement issued by the league said. "Many more deaths could follow from lack of water, food and disease." **********Red Crescent officials said the toll could climb to 200,000 when rescue and relief teams reached isolated areas. But Bernard Kouchner, French Minister of State for Humanitarian Action, said the toll might go down as more accurate casualty reports are tallied. **********"It has been my experience, weeks and months later, the number of deaths decrease," he said. "But I could be wrong." **********Mr. Kouchner toured the disaster area by helicopter on Sunday with Prime Minister Khaleda Zia of Bangladesh, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan and Mother Teresa. **********He said the devastation was colossal and the United Nations should convene a meeting to raise money for reconstruction. **********Up to 10 million people living along the low-lying coast and offshore islands were affected by the storm, and damages so far exceed $1.42 billion, officials said. **********The cyclone flooded farmland just before harvest time, when reserves of food were already low. **********The Red Cross and Red Crescent societies noted that the cyclone had struck during a full moon and high tide, which "combined to maximize its destructive onslaught." **********Pilots braved squalls over the ravaged areas today to drop desperately needed supplies to marooned islanders. **********Journalists aboard one flight said riding the small plane buffeted by the wind was "like being on a yo-yo." **********Bangladeshi airmen pushed food and medicine from the twin-engine propeller plane over Kutubdia, one of the dozens of islands swamped by a 20-foot tidal wave that was whipped up by 145 mile-per-hour winds a week ago. Offer From Mother Teresa **********Mother Teresa, whose order of nuns operates homes for the destitute and dying in several third world countries, offered to provide temporary shelter for children and old people made homeless by the storm, the state-run television said. She said she was shocked by the scale of the destruction. **********More than 2,000 trawlers and thousands of fishermen have been missing in the Bay of Bengal since the cyclone pounded the coast for nine hours on the night of April 29, the Deep Sea Fishing Boat Owners' Association said today. **********Journalists aboard the relief plane saw trawlers tossed far inland by the tidal surge and perched incongruously in rice paddies on Kutubdia. Officials said today that the death toll in Kutubdia, which had a population of 90,000, was over 15,000 and rising. **********The relief plane with journalists aboard was unable to land, so the crew dropped supplies without parachutes 150 feet to waiting crowds. **********Sometimes the boxes disappeared under water in flooded fields. Others shattered on impact. **********Nizam Ahmed, a local journalist who visited Kutubdia by boat, said hundreds of human and animal corpses still littered inundated fields and "ghost villages." **********"It looked like the area had been carpet-bombed," Mr. Ahmed said, "with damaged houses and craters created by the tidal surge. People were either half-naked or wearing torn and dirty clothes and appeared to be in shock." **********Bad weather, communications disruptions and a shortage of boats and aircraft are slowing relief efforts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/26/world.main_headline: 9 Croatians Are Killed In Fighting With Army
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/26/world.print_headline: 9 Croatians Are Killed In Fighting With Army
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/26/world.body_text: **********Fierce fighting in the Yugoslav republic of Croatia continued today. At least nine of the republic's militiamen were reported killed and 17 wounded, a ministry of information official said. **********It was the second time this week that Croatian forces had come under fire by army troops, whose announced mission in the region is to keep the peace. **********The clash raised new fears that the army, which is led by a predominantly Serbian officer corps, was beginning to side openly with rebel Serbs in Croatia. 'This Was a Massacre' **********"We are in a war with the army, we cannot escape it," said Mario Nobilo, the spokesman for the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman. "This was a massacre." **********The army said today that it responded to shooting from the Croatian side; officials in Zagreb, the capital of Croatia, insisted that the soldiers fired their tank cannon without provocation. **********This has been the worst week of fighting in Yugoslavia since the end of World War II. On Monday, at least 20 people died in battles between Serbs and Croats, the two largest ethnic groups in the country. **********Although they speak the same language, the two are divided by history and religion, and they share bitter memories of World War II. Serbs, who are primarily Eastern Orthodox, were killed in concentration camps set up by the Nazi-installed wartime government of Croatia. Croats, who are mostly Roman Catholic, in turn suffered at the hands of Serbian guerrillas. In all, a million Yugoslavs died in the war, and estimates say as many as half were killed by each other. **********The election of nationalist governments last year in Serbia and Croatia set the stage for this year's cycle of violence. Battle Began at 3 A.M. **********Officials in Croatia said 21 civilians and 63 of its police and national guardsmen have been killed in fighting since last August, when the Serbs began actively resisting the republic's newly elected government. In contrast, the republic of Slovenia reported only five killed in its fighting earlier this month against the Yugoslav Army. **********But that was a different sort of warfare. The Slovenes set up barricades and used their mountainous terrain to trap the army tanks and kill them. **********Today's fighting took place in the broad, agricultural plains of eastern Croatia. The region, called Slavonia, is peopled by a mixture of Serbs and Croats, and its expanses of cornfields are ideal maneuvering territory for tanks. It is an area where many of the villages are controlled by Serb militants who stand at barricades denying Croatian police the right to traverse the roads. **********According to the Croatian account, today's battle began at 3 A.M. near Erdut, a town in eastern Croatia that sits on the west bank of the Danube. The river marks the border between the republics of Serbia and Croatia, and Yugoslav Army tanks have been deployed on both sides for several weeks. About 11 percent of the population in Croatia is Serbian. Three Towns Shelled **********The Croats said tank fire came from armored units stationed in both Serbian and Croatian territory. They said shells landed in three towns: Erdut, Dalj, and Aljmas. **********Croatia also charged that the army refused to open a path through Serbian villages for ambulances, delaying by hours treatment of the wounded. The army could not be reached for comment tonight on this accusation. **********Some Croatians speculate that the Yugoslav Army tanks are marking what may become the expanded borders of the republic of Serbia. The officials have charged that some of the Serbs in the army are providing weapons to fellow Serbs in the ethnically mixed areas of Croatia. More than 70,000 army troops are garrisoned in Croatia, and more may well be stationed in the republic after the army completes its withdrawal of troops from the neighboring republic of Slovenia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/16/busin.main_headline: Law Firm Spared in '$92 Million Boo-Boo'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Law Firm Spared in '$92 Million Boo-Boo'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/16/busin.body_text: **********For more than five years, it was widely known on Wall Street as the "$92 million boo-boo" -- the one that those who deal in high finance hope they will never make. **********In this case, it involved a $92,885,000 mortgage by the Prudential Insurance Company on eight container ships owned by the United States Lines, in which the final three zeros were inadvertently dropped when the mortgage was filed in 1986. The mistake meant Prudential's lien on the ships was listed as only $92,885. **********Three years later, Prudential filed a $31 million lawsuit against three law firms in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan, contending that the $92 million mistake was the firms' fault and that it cost the insurance company millions of dollars in losses when the ship company filed for bankruptcy and Prudential went to foreclose on the ships. **********The law firms were Dewey, Ballantine, Busby, Palmer & Wood, which represented Prudential; Haight, Gardner, Poor & Havens, which represented the GE Credit Corporation, Prudential's partner in the mortgage, and Gilmartin, Poster & Shafto, which represented the ship company. **********The cases against Dewey, Ballantine and Haight, Gardner were settled out of court several weeks ago, Prudential said yesterday. **********But Gilmartin, the third law firm, did not settle. **********Based on a ruling yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, Gilmartin made the right decision. The appellate court unanimously upheld a lower court order in December that in effect dismissed Prudential's case against it. **********At the same time, the appellate ruling confirmed the wisdom of Dewey, Ballantine and Haight, Gardner in settling because it upheld the trial court's refusal to dismiss Prudential's legal action against them. **********Lawyers from both firms and a Prudential spokesman refused to disclose the terms of settlement. **********According to the appellate ruling, Haight, Gardner acknowledged "that the $92 million error occurred in its office, when it was preparing its share of the documents" involved in the mortgage. **********As a result, Dewey, Ballantine contended that any mistake was Haight, Gardner's fault.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/10/busin.main_headline: Exxon Plans Additive for Cleaner Fuel
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/10/busin.print_headline: Exxon Plans Additive for Cleaner Fuel
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/10/busin.body_text: **********The Exxon Corporation today became the latest refiner to announce plans to invest millions of dollars in new plants to produce an essential component of cleaner-burning fuel. **********Analysts say the component, methyl tertiary butyl ether, could be in short supply for the next few years as tougher laws take effect to limit smog-related pollution, raising demand for cleaner fuels. **********Exxon U.S.A., a Houston-based subsidiary of the big oil company, said it expected to spend more than $100 million to build plants to make the compound, known as M.T.B.E., at its three largest American refineries.  Plans for This Year **********Construction on the first plant is to begin this year at Exxon's refinery in Baton Rouge, La., with work on another planned for 1993 in Baytown, Tex. Plans for a third plant, at Exxon's refinery in Benicia, Calif., north of San Francisco, are under study. **********The Clean Air Act, passed by Congress in 1990, requires cleaner-burning gasoline to be sold beginning in the fall and winter next year in 41 metropolitan areas, including most of the nation's largest cities. The anti-pollution standards for gasoline will be toughened again in 1995 and further in 2000. **********Several large gasoline marketers, including ARCO, Shell and Exxon, began testing sales of cleaner-burning premium gasoline blends using M.T.B.E. more than a year ago. The oil companies are depending on these reformulated blends to blunt campaigns by some environmentalists to restrict gasoline sales sharply in the years ahead. **********"The Exxons of the world are trying to protect themselves from a shortage situation," said Urvan Sternfels, president of the National Petroleum Refiners Association, a trade group based in Washington. "There is a really serious question as to whether there is going to be enough oxygenates available to meet all of the new demand that we anticipate." **********William I. Ludlow, vice president of DeWitt & Company, a consulting firm in Houston, said current supplies of M.T.B.E. appeared adequate to meet demand in the next few years, but could become tight when regulations are stiffened in 1995. **********M.T.B.E. includes an oxygen molecule that permits more thorough combustion of fuel by engines and reduces carbon monoxide and other exhaust emissions. The chemical compound had been used since the mid-1980's to raise octane levels in premium gasoline blends, but refiners have promoted it in the last few years as a way to reduce pollutants. **********The Clean Air Act mandates higher oxygen levels in gasoline next year in areas where carbon dioxide pollution produces a brown haze during the winter months, especially in high-altitude areas like Denver.  Practical Components **********M.T.B.E. and ethanol are considered the two most practical components available to refiners to raise oxygen levels to at least 2.7 percent of the gasoline mixture. Aromatics like benzene and toluene, once used to raise octane levels, have been restricted because of concerns that they help to create smog and may contribute to cancer. **********Mr. Sternfels of the refiners association said many refiners favored M.T.B.E. because ethanol was more costly and could not be blended into gasoline transported through pipelines. Also, the building blocks of M.T.B.E., the common chemical feedstocks isobutylene and methanol, can be easily supplied. **********Total consumption of M.T.B.E. increased to 96,000 barrels a day last year, from 30,000 barrels a day in 1985, and will probably triple again to more than 300,000 barrels a day by 1995, said Joe Leonard, a petrochemical industry analyst at Chem Systems Inc., a consulting firm in Tarrytown, N.Y. **********"As more and more gasolines are reformulated for more cleaner-burning characteristics, M.T.B.E. will go into all gasolines, not just premium blends," he said. **********As recently as a year ago, few refiners produced their own M.T.B.E.; ARCO Chemical, which is 83 percent owned by ARCO Inc., accounted for 40 percent of the world's supply. Since then, Chevron, Conoco, Shell, Unocal, Amerada Hess and Mobil have announced plans to build plants within existing refineries.  Big Plants Planned **********Most of these plants will produce fewer than 5,000 barrels of M.T.B.E. a day for use within the same gasoline refineries. But Tenneco Inc. and Phillips Petroleum are building plants to produce more than 10,000 barrels a day and plan to sell much of the output to other gasoline refiners. **********With M.T.B.E. becoming a more important cost factor in gasoline output and future supplies uncertain, refiners want captive supplies, Mr. Sternfels said. **********Exxon U.S.A. currently buys M.T.B.E. from a sister company, Exxon Chemical, and from other suppliers. A spokesman for Exxon U.S.A., Henry Beathard, said the company decided to build its new plants because "we can produce it more cheaply than we can purchase it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/21/busin.main_headline: Symantec Is Set To Acquire DMA
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Symantec Is Set To Acquire DMA
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/21/busin.body_text: **********The Symantec Corporation said today it will acquire Dynamic Microprocessor Associates Inc., known as DMA, in a stock swap valued at about $22 million. Based in Huntington, L.I., Dynamic produces pc Anywhere, the leading remote control communications software product for linking remote PC's with networks. Symantec is based in Cupertino, Calif. **********"It's really synergistic with our utilities business," Gordon E. Eubanks Jr., Symantec's president and chief executive, said. Symantec will market pc Anywhere under the Norton name, Mr. Eubanks said. Symantec shares closed today at $53.25 in over-the-counter trading. DMA is closely held.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/09/busin.main_headline: Patents; Unaddressed Question in Amgen Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/09/busin.print_headline: Patents; Unaddressed Question in Amgen Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/09/busin.body_text: **********In handing Amgen Inc. a stunning victory in its four-year patent feud over a top-selling anti-anemia drug, the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit this week all but ended one of the most closely watched legal battles in biotechnology. **********Nevertheless, the most interesting issue posed by the case remains unaddressed: Should a patent based on isolating a natural protein cover the manufacture of the protein through genetic engineering? **********Here was a case in which one company, Amgen, was indisputably the first to produce the drug, erythropoietin, or EPO, through genetic engineering. Despite that, until this week the company that was clearly second in achieving this goal, Genetics Institute Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., was able to exert patent claims at least as strong as Amgen's. **********The court had long ago established that Dr. Fu-Kuen Lin of Amgen was the first person to isolate the human gene for EPO in 1984. It was also Dr. Lin who first produced the protein by inserting the gene into cells from a Chinese hamster. Patent Obtained on Molecule **********Until this week, however, Genetics Institute had the upper hand on patents for EPO. In 1987, it obtained a patent on the EPO molecule itself, which it had isolated and purified from human urine. Amgen never made use of this development. **********Strictly speaking, the Genetics Institute development had nothing to do with genetic engineering and had almost no commercial usefulness. Natural EPO is so rare that it is impossible to obtain in commercial volumes from natural sources. Thus, both companies were racing to achieve the same ultimate goal: finding the EPO gene, so the protein could be harvested in large quantities from genetically transformed animal cells. **********But the Genetics Institute patent on the molecule was of great value as a legal tool. Following accepted doctrine in patent law, the Federal District Court in Boston decided that Genetics Institute's patent covered EPO regardless of how it is produced. As a result, it ruled last year that Amgen's recombinant version of EPO infringed its rival's patent and it ordered Amgen to enter a cross-licensing agreement.  Ruling Reversed **********The appeals court decision this week reversed that order, though not on the ground of fundamental principle. The decision, written by Judge Alan D. Lourie, concludes that Genetics Institute never clearly demonstrated that it had purified a molecule with the biological characteristics it had claimed in its patent. As a result, the court declared the patent's key claims invalid. **********For many experts, however, the big question is whether patents like those of Genetics Institute are simply being applied too broadly even when they are valid. "It was already known that EPO existed, as well as what it did and where you could get it," said Harold C. Wegner, a patent attorney in Washington. "What was so novel and non-obvious about purifying it from urine?" Indeed, EPO was so well known to researchers that numerous biotech companies, including Genentech Inc., joined the race to find the EPO gene until Amgen announced Dr. Lin's findings. **********This issue may well arise with other drugs, because the allure of biotechnology is largely in its potential for producing large volumes of proteins that are known but are rare in nature. Indeed, the issue was at the heart of a legal dispute over patent rights to Factor VIII, a blood-clotting drug used to combat hemophelia. In that case, involving the Scripps Clinic and Research Foundation and Genentech, a Federal district court ruled that Scripps's patent on the molecule was invalid for a host of technical and procedural reasons. **********But even critics like Mr. Wegner have trouble defining the scope of claims for patents on purified natural proteins. Traditionally, patent law has held that patents for novel compounds should cover those materials no matter how they are produced. The reason is that lab bench processes for making them will always be different from mass production processes, and the initial challenge is to develop the material itself. **********But in biotechnology, the production process is central. Without genetic engineering, there is simply no real commercial product. As a result, some experts say the courts should view a protein produced by gene splicing as, in effect, a new protein. **********"The theory here is that the second inventor has contributed something much more valuable than the original molecule," argued Robert P. Merges, associate professor of law at Boston University. Indeed, Dr. Merges said, there is already some precedent for this principle in patent law, but the courts have thus far not applied it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/world.main_headline: Bush Links End Of Trading Ban To Hussein Exit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Bush Links End Of Trading Ban To Hussein Exit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/world.body_text: **********President Bush said today that the United States would oppose the lifting of the worldwide ban against trading with Iraq until President Saddam Hussein is forced out of power in Baghdad. **********His statement, along with earlier remarks by the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, indicated strongly that the United States has decided to try to drive Mr. Hussein from power through a postwar policy of economic strangulation. **********Implicit in the statements by Mr. Bush and his spokesman was a threat to use the veto authority that the United States holds in the United Nations Security Council as one of its five permanent members to oppose lifting the sanctions against Iraq. **********In his first comments on the trials of Kuwaitis accused of collaboration with Iraqi occupation forces, Mr. Bush today said Kuwait should extend fair-trial protections to the accused.  [ Page A10. ] Security Council Acts **********A mechanism for a controlled lifting of the trade ban, approved today by the Security Council, would permit Mr. Hussein's Government to begin selling its crude oil to pay for reparations to Kuwait. Also, Iraq has asked for permission to finance urgent cargos of food, medicine and basic raw materials by selling its oil. **********But the Council has not taken the decisive action to allow the sale of oil to begin. The statements by Washington and earlier comments by the British Government indicate that such a move may be a long time in coming as long as Mr. Hussein remains in power. **********Mr. Bush, speaking at the White House with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, said the United States "will abide by the United Nations resolutions, of course," and he added, "There are certain areas where Iraq, in order to comply with United Nations sanctions, must sell abroad." **********But the President added that, "at this juncture, my view is we don't want to lift these sanctions as long as Saddam Hussein is in power." **********Mr. Bush's statement came on a day when the Security Council passed a resolution formally setting up a procedure, yet to be activated, for processing damage claims against Iraq and docking future oil earnings to pay for them. Kuwait is asking that half of Iraq's future oil earnings be diverted under United Nations authority to pay for $60 billion or more in damages. **********The Security Council will have to vote on the sanctions question after it is satisfied Baghdad is cooperating with plans for destroying its nuclear, chemical and biological research installations and its ballistic missile plants. **********Today's resolution established a 15-nation body, the Governing Council of the United Nations Compensation Commission, with members drawn from the Security Council nations. **********The commission is to process claims and provide compensation from Iraqi oil revenue once shipments are flowing again, something Mr. Bush now indicates the United States will oppose while Mr. Hussein remains in power. **********Mr. Bush's statement echoed a similiar statement by the British Prime Minister, John Major, to his Conservative Party on May 11. Mr. Major said Britain might veto any move in the Security Council to lift sanctions as long as Mr. Hussein is in power. **********Earlier in the day at the White House, Mr. Fitzwater referred reporters to a May 7 speech by the deputy national security adviser, Robert M. Gates. Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Gates's strong formulation on the sanctions question represented American policy. **********In the speech to the American Newspaper Publishers Association, Mr. Gates, who has been nominated to be Director of Central Intelligence, said of Mr. Hussein, "Iraqis will pay the price while he is in power." **********"All possible sanctions will be maintained until he is gone," Mr. Gates continued. **********He said Iraq "will be nothing but a pariah state" as long as Mr. Hussein rules and that "Iraqis will not participate in post-crisis political, economic and security arrangements until there is a change in regime." **********Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Gates's remarks at the publishers' meeting in Vancouver, British Columbia, were "extremely underreported" but reflected a determination by the United States that, "because of the invasion and occupation of Kuwait and the brutal repression of his own people, Saddam is discredited and cannot be redeemed." **********In recent weeks, Mr. Bush has repeatedly stated that the United States would not have normal relations with Iraq while Mr. Hussein was in power, but he has demurred on saying how he would treat requests by Iraq to sell oil for various urgent requirements. **********Kuwait's United Nations representative, Mohammed A. Abulhasan, said today that he had told the Security Council that his Government wanted Baghdad to pay up to 50 percent of its future revenue to settle compensation claims once the embargo is lifted. **********This would mean that as much as $10 billion of the $20 billion Iraq is expected to earn annually from selling oil at current prices would be available to meet damage claims, which Mr. Abulhasan estimated at around $60 billion. **********"We favor a high level of payments because we want all claims paid within 10 years," he said, adding that Kuwait's claims are growing by $120 million a day to cover losses from the wells Iraqi troops set aflame. While Washington, like Kuwait, has spoken of fixing payments as high as 50 percent of Iraq's oil revenue, Britain, France and the Soviet Union -- all Council members with a veto -- expect a ceiling of 25 to 30 percent, with an actual first-year payment of about 25 percent. **********This means that Iraq would be required to hand over about $5 billion of its annual oil income, approximately what it was spending on foreign arms before the Persian Gulf war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/04/world.main_headline: British Tories Lose Many Local Posts
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/04/world.print_headline: British Tories Lose Many Local Posts
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/04/world.body_text: **********Results of local government elections across England and Wales on Thursday showed today that Prime Minister John Major's Conservative Party had taken a drubbing, despite his recent decision to abandon an unpopular per-capita community charge. **********The jubilant leaders of the opposition Labor Party and the Liberal Democratic Party, Neil Kinnock and Paddy Ashdown, predicted that Mr. Major would go down to defeat when he called the national election that must be held by the middle of 1992. **********But some Tories said today that because of their poor showing in the local council elections, the earliest possible date for a nationwide ballot now looked like this October. There were even a few predictions that Mr. Major might wait until the very last moment, July 11, 1992, before his first attempt at leading his party to national victory, after three straight successes under his predecessor, Margaret Thatcher. **********He took over from her after a party leadership battle last November, when the Conservatives' fortunes were at a low point and it was trailing Labor by double-digit figures in the polls. **********The Conservative Party chairman, Chris Patten, said of the local elections today that "it was not our night." With about 12,000 local council seats up for grabs, Conservatives, who had held 5,200 of them since 1987, lost well over 850, while Labor gained more than 450 and the Liberal Democrats, more than 500. Small parties also lost seats to Labor or the Liberal Democrats. **********The popular vote put support for the Conservatives at 36 percent, Labor at 37 percent and the Liberal Democrats at 21 percent, a result Mr. Ashdown called "a stunning achievement" for his party. **********The way winners in a Parliament election are determined, figures like these would produce a rough tie in the House of Commons between Conservatives and Labor, with Mr. Ashdown's party winning a small number of seats that might hold the balance of power in a "hung Parliament." **********If that happened, he said, the Liberal Democrats would demand a form of proportional representation in future elections, giving them a chance of winning far more seats. **********'Quite Bearable,' Major Says **********Mr. Major, who had hoped for a better showing, stayed up until 1 A.M. watching the results on television. He said today that they were "a little disappointing but quite bearable." The slight consolation, as he saw it, was that Labor was still not strong enough to oust the Conservatives. **********"The Government should be very worried indeed," Prof. Anthony King of the University of Essex said on BBC television this morning. "It should be thinking very hard now about the kind of economic recovery that can put them back on course for victory in a general election." **********Besides the uproar over the per-capita charge, a mounting recession was thought to be the main reason for the decline in Conservative fortunes. This downturn has mainly been the result of tight-money policies. **********Unemployment rose above 2 million in March, and manufacturing output declined by 4.6 percent from a year ago. Interest rates still start at 12 percent, going up to 30 percent a year on some credit cards, and the Government acknowledges that economic recovery will not begin for a few months. **********Adding to these worries was the disclosure last week that Government attempts to impose more efficient management on the popular National Health Service had led to the loss of 900 jobs at two London hospitals. Labor politicians warned that the initiative would lead to cuts in the quality and availability of care at those hospitals and 54 others that had been allowed to opt out of the National Health Service. **********Today, Mr. Kinnock demanded an immediate general election, which he said he was sure Labor would win. His party took control of councils the Conservatives had dominated in southern districts like Plymouth, Kingswood and Luton; the Liberal Democrats won the Tory strongholds of Lewes, Poole and North Wiltshire.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/18/busin.main_headline: Biggest Increase For Price Index In Eight Months
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/18/busin.print_headline: Biggest Increase For Price Index In Eight Months
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/18/busin.body_text: **********In an inflation report that many investors and analysts found disturbing, the Consumer Price Index climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in September, the biggest increase since January. **********Prices for food and energy, which have been restraining the inflation rate for much of 1991, were two of the main factors pushing it up last month. **********The broadly based increase was higher than generally expected and contributed to a big selloff in the bond market, raising interest rates. The rationale was that the Federal Reserve would be less inclined in the face of fresh evidence of inflationary pressure to take further steps to ease interest rates as a stimulus to the economy.  3.7% Rise in Benefits **********The report on the Consumer Price Index also means that nearly 50 million recipients of Social Security and other Federal benefits tied to inflation will get increases of 3.7 percent in January. This is the smallest adjustment in five years. It is the amount by which prices in the third quarter exceeded those a year earlier.  [ Page A10. ] **********But while the inflation figures captured much of the attention, a sizable proportion of economists found other indicators published today, particularly industrial output, of equal if not greater importance. Industrial production rose a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the Federal Reserve reported, and what was initially reported as a three-tenths of 1 percent advance for August was revised to zero. Although industrial production covers only about one-third of the economy, it is an important indicator because it reflects the part of the economy most sensitive to the business cycle. **********"The recovery to date has been modest, and now it looks even more modest than we thought," said Lyle E. Gramley, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association. "We have very little momentum going into the fourth quarter." **********Mr. Gramley, a former research chief and board member at the Fed, said that while there was no danger the economy would slip back into recession, the usual forces to sustain recovery were missing. He also said the data would seem to increase, not reduce, the chances for additional Fed rate-cutting. **********"I'm a little puzzled about what it is they're waiting for," he said. **********At a briefing for reporters, Michael J. Boskin, the President's chief economic adviser, said that the Fed "may well have to consider further action" if neither the economy nor the nation's money supply perk up. **********Figures on international trade published today for August showed the American deficit rising for the second straight month, to $6.8 billion, with exports down 3 percent. Exports, which have been relatively robust of late, are counted upon to help sustain the recovery, which most economists believe began during late spring or early summer. **********In still another report, the Labor Department said that initial claims for state unemployment insurance fell 13,000 in the first week of October, to 423,000, but continued to rise a bit on the four-week moving average that many analysts use to smooth out gyrations. That average rose to a seasonally adjusted 432,500 from 427,000. **********Michael W. Keran, chief economist at the Prudential Insurance Company, joined Mr. Gramley in minimizing the significance of the inflation figures and contending that the Federal Reserve will pay more attention to the weak production results.  No Change in Outlook **********"We don't think this represents a major change in our outlook about inflation," he said. In any event, Mr. Keran added, the Fed's long-run strategy may be to bring down inflation, "but its short-run strategy is to not have recession." **********On the other hand, Paul W. Boltz and Norman Robertson, chief economists for T. Rowe Price Associates and the Mellon Bank, respectively, found the inflation data worrisome. **********"This is an alert," Mr. Boltz said, that modest inflation is unlikely to continue into the new year. Noting the turnaround in food and energy prices, he said, "They stopped helping -- and there it was." He also argued today that the recovery "is on increasingly firm footing." **********Mr. Robertson said he was disturbed by both the inflation and output data, which reflect what he called a weak and hesitant economy and inflation so stubborn that it flares up in a protracted period of recession and sub-par growth. **********The report on consumer inflation came as such a surprise today in part because it followed a favorable reading last week on producer prices, which rose only one-tenth of a percent in September.  Rise Without Food and Energy **********Even without food and energy, the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the fourth straight advance of this size. A leading contributor was a five-tenths of 1 percent jump in housing, which makes up 41 percent of the index and showed no price change in August. **********Both renters' costs and homeowners' costs rose five-tenths of 1 percent, more than offsetting a three-tenths of 1 percent decline for maintenance and repairs. The price of household fuels and utilities turned up, rising six-tenths of 1 percent over all, with fuel oil up 1.7 percent, natural gas up 1.4 percent electricity up seven-tenths of 1 percent. Household furnishings and operations rose two-tenths of 1 percent following a small decline in August. **********Food prices rose just one-tenth of 1 percent, but this followed two months of larger declines. Fresh fruits jumped 3.1 percent, dairy products advanced six-tenths of 1 percent and pork and fish prices also moved up. Prices for beef, poultry and eggs, however, fell. Surge in Motor Fuels **********In transportation, a two-tenths of 1 percent advance was mainly attributable to a nine-tenths of 1 percent surge in motor fuels. A drop in automobile finance charges held the costs of new cars to three-tenths of 1 percent and used-car prices fell. Public transportation dropped seven-tenths of 1 percent, reflecting a 1.4 percent cut in airline fares. **********Clothing fell four-tenths of 1 percent following two large increases, the result of earlier-than-usual introductions of fall and winter wear. **********The cost of medical care continued to bound ahead, rising seven-tenths of 1 percent to a level 8.4 percent above that of September 1990. **********In the entertainment and other goods and services categories, prices of sporting goods, fees for participant sports, tuitions and other school fees and tobacco products all moved up by more than 1 percent last month. **********Viewed another way, services in the C.P.I. rose five-tenths of 1 percent, compared with three-tenths of 1 percent in August, while commodities rose two-tenths of 1 percent for the third straight month. **********For the third quarter, prices rose at an annual rate of 3.3 percent, up from 3 percent in the second quarter and 2.4 percent in the first, a combined rate less than half the 6.6 percent pace during the first nine months of 1990. **********The the index covering all urban consumers now stands at 137.2. This means that a basket of goods and services that cost $10 in 1982-84 now costs $13.72.
