https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/10/world.main_headline: Fear Rises as Another Palestinian Dies in Kuwait
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/10/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Fear Rises as Another Palestinian Dies in Kuwait
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/10/world.body_text: **********A prominent Palestinian has been shot to death here in circumstances that have raised concern among American officials that Kuwaitis, including some army and Government officials, are still abusing Palestinians. **********Dr. Salim Mukhtar, a 56-year-old dentist and writer, a widely respected figure among Kuwait's Palestinians, was slain last Thursday night, according to police records. The incident occurred near an army roadblock by the Sura district next to the main Palestinian quarter, Hawali. It is the only area of the city still regularly blocked off by army checkpoints. **********Dr. Mukhtar was shot twice in the back of the head, once in the neck and once in the chest, Kuwaiti police reports compiled that night at a nearby hospital said. His body bore a grazing wound from a bullet across the stomach that also struck his companion, a woman, in the leg. **********The woman and other witnesses said Dr. Mukhtar's car was pulled over by another car, possibly a white Mercedes with a blinking blue light, and three men got out and one opened fire with a pistol, according to investigators looking into the incident.  A Telltale Question **********"Do you recognize me?" the gunman reportedly asked before shooting, some accounts of the incident said. **********If true, the odd question is striking. The same question was said to have been posed to a prominent Kuwaiti leader of the opposition to Iraq's occupation, Hamad al-Jauan, seconds before a gunman shot him in the chest after knocking at his door in the first days after the Iraqi forces were ousted. Mr. Jauan was evacuated by American diplomats and military officials and is now reportedly being treated in a military hospital in the United States. **********At the time, many opposition members attributed the shooting to private militias loyal to some younger members of the ruling Sabah family who were described as intent on preserving the status quo. **********Palestinians here, numbering perhaps 400,000 and long established, had furnished many of the engineers, teachers, other professionals, bureaucrats and shopkeepers who built Kuwait's roads, schools, hospitals and other basic installations.  Palestinians Suffer for P.L.O. **********After the Iraqi occupation, some Kuwaitis took out their anger and frustration on the local Palestinians, whom they blamed for the Palestine Liberation Organization's support for Iraq and accused of collaborating with the occupation. **********Underground leaders have said that while some Palestinians worked with the Iraqis, many others helped them, providing food and other necessities. And Palestinians here were split over the official P.L.O. stand. **********American officials say they put considerable backstage pressure on leaders of the Kuwaiti Government, including the Crown Prince, Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, after initial reports of Palestinians being beaten at roadblocks and bodies turning up in hospital morgues, vacant lots and garbage dumps. **********The Kuwaitis were warned, the Americans said, that they should not be seen as acting like the Iraqi occupiers did. A human rights group, Middle East Watch, says that at least 30 people were killed, a report that Western diplomats say they find credible. **********United States Army officers working with the Kuwaitis say that despite their efforts, there are still cases of Kuwaiti soldiers or policemen pulling people from their homes and beating them; they say they are not sure how many Palestinians and others may be held captive, and they worry that trials for the 600 or so prisoners being charged with crimes during the occupation could turn into kangaroo courts. **********Kuwaiti officials have finally given American officers a list of 546 prisoners who are being held in what the Red Cross described as extremely overcrowded conditions in a military prison and who are to be transferred to civil authorities. **********But the Americans say they do not know how many people might be in other prisons, including Jiwan, which is run by the Kuwaiti National Guard, a force that guards the royal palaces and other major installations. Unlike the army and the police force, which were made up largely of Bedouins, the National Guard is composed of Kuwaiti citizens.  Responses, but No Solution **********"The Kuwaiti Government is well aware that we're constantly pushing them on human rights," an American officer said today. "We're consistently getting the right answers, but then this stuff keeps going on. You don't know whether it's incompetence and inefficiency, or that they're just telling us what we want to hear and waiting for us to go away, or some of both." **********Asked if he was worried that human rights abuses might occur once American forces left, the officer replied: **********"Of course. I think the potential is clearly there. The only reassuring thing is that Kuwaitis mostly just talk."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/08/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Hasbro's Takeover Of Tonka Advances
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/08/busin.body_text: **********Hasbro Inc. said it had virtually completed its acquisition of the Tonka Corporation, which owns the Monopoly board game and Play-Doh modeling compound. Hasbro said it had acquired 13 million Tonka shares, or approximately 87 percent of Tonka's stock, at $5 a share. It also said that 90 percent of Tonka's outstanding bonds had been tendered. **********The deal, valued at $486 million, is expected to close next month. Barry J. Alperin, Hasbro's vice chairman, said the acquisition would put Hasbro's total sales at more than $2 billion a year, well ahead of the company's closest rival, Mattel Inc. Hasbro's stock was unchanged on the Big Board today, closing at $26.50.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.main_headline: Big Loan Is Proposed For F.D.I.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.print_headline: Big Loan Is Proposed For F.D.I.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.body_text: **********L. William Seidman, the nation's senior banking regulator, said today that he had recommended that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation borrow $10 billion to avert the possible insolvency of the program that protects bank deposits and that the interest on the loan be paid by raising the annual contributions of banks by 18 percent. **********Mr. Seidman, chairman of the F.D.I.C., said that by borrowing the money rather than relying solely on bank contributions, the agency would be able to raise substantially more money. Neither he nor the Administration has said whether the money should be lent by the Government or the banks. **********The increase in the premium to be paid by the banks could take effect by June 30, he said. The increase would put the premium at 23 cents for every $100 in deposits, up from 19.5 cents.  Taking the First Step **********The board of the F.D.I.C. is expected to take the first step toward carrying out the premium increase on Thursday by seeking comment on a proposed rate increase, a move that in the past has invariably led to increases. **********The bank insurance fund, which protects deposits up to $100,000 per account, is having serious problems. The White House and the Congressional Budget Office have forecast that a growing number of failures of large banks could make the fund insolvent within two years. **********An insolvent bank insurance fund would raise the possibility of another costly taxpayer bailout to protect the insured deposits at the failed banks. The bailout of the savings and loan industry, approved in August 1989, is expected to cost taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars.  A Steady Decline **********Payouts last year to depositors and to banks that agreed to buy failed institutions left the bank fund with $8.5 billion at the end of the year, down from $13.2 billion at the end of 1989. This year the fund is expected to post its fourth consecutive annual drop and its largest decrease since its creation in 1934. **********"No one knows how much will ultimately be enough" to insure the soundness of the fund, Mr. Seidman said in an impromptu meeting with reporters this afternoon after delivering a speech here to the annual conference of the Institute of International Bankers. "What we believe is $10 billion ought to get us through this year even under the most adverse conditions." **********Although the refinancing of the bank insurance fund is widely considered to be the most pressing domestic financial issue confronting the Bush Administration, the Treasury Department has left it largely in the hands of the F.D.I.C.  Some Vague Guidelines **********Three weeks ago Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady presented a wide-ranging proposal to overhaul the banking laws, but it was vague on the topic of replenishing the fund, noting only that any solutions should be long term, should rely on industry money and should not injure the health of the banking system. **********The Treasury Department declined to comment on Mr. Seidman's proposal today, although Mr. Brady's views on the F.D.I.C. plan are expected to become known on Tuesday and Wednesday, when he appears before the Senate and House Banking Committees. **********An increase in premiums to 23 cents would be the second increase in six months and a 92 percent jump from the 12 cents that banks paid last year. The added cost will affect both customers and shareholders of the nation's 12,300 insured banks. For the first nine months of last year, the industry reported earnings of about 60 cents for every $100 in deposits. **********"It's a tough increase and it will hurt, but the banking community has seen this coming for a long time," said Edward L. Yingling, chief lobbyist for the American Bankers Association. Deciding Where to Borrow **********Mr. Seidman said he had still not decided whether the $10 billion should be borrowed from banks, as a banking industry coalition has recommended, or from the Treasury Department, the Federal Reserve, or the Federal Financing Bank, which was established in 1973 to assist agencies whose obligations are guaranteed by the Government. The F.D.I.C. has the authority to raise premiums; certain new kinds of borrowing would require legislative approval. **********The industry group also recommended that premiums be capped at the current rate of 19.5 cents. Each increase of a cent for $100 in deposits raises about $250 million. The proposed increase of 3.5 cents would raise the banks' premiums to the 23-cent level already set for savings and loan associations. **********In an interview today, Mr. Seidman said he recommended the 15-year borrowing plan in a report sent on Friday evening to the Treasury Department as part of the first step in a two-part plan to raise cash. He declined to elaborate on the second part of the plan, but people who have been briefed on the proposal said it recommended that the F.D.I.C.'s authority to borrow from the Treasury be increased, a move that would require legislation.  Lines of Credit **********Under existing law, the F.D.I.C. has a credit line with the Treasury Department of $5 billion. It may also borrow money from the Federal Financing Bank or other sources based on a formula that relies on the net worth of the fund. Under the formula, and based on the present condition of the fund, the F.D.I.C. can now borrow $65 billion, but that would be reduced as the fund's net worth declines. **********Mr. Seidman said a statistical analysis by the F.D.I.C. had concluded that an increase in premiums would not produce "a significant amount" of additional bank failures. **********Mr. Seidman conceded that the increase in bank premiums would "obviously have some effect on the credit crunch," making less money available for lending in certain markets where credit is already tight. "The greatest worry is that we don't do anything to substantially increase the credit crunch," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/world.main_headline: Hueys and Scuds: Vietnam And Gulf Are Wars Apart
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK; Hueys and Scuds: Vietnam And Gulf Are Wars Apart
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/world.body_text: **********High technology is one thing the biggest thing, perhaps -- that sets this war apart from Vietnam. **********Technology in aerial combat between attack and defensive missiles, guiding Patriots to their deadly rendezvous with Scuds. Technology for pilots, enabling them to skim the ground, juke to avoid ack-ack and perform other jazzy maneuvers, all at night or in the clouds. Technology that guides cruise missiles so precisely that one fired from a battleship in the Persian Gulf clipped a communications tower in Baghdad neatly in two, according to witnesses in the Iraqi capital. **********Technology that makes this a real-time war, with a speech by Saddam Hussein or a briefing at the Pentagon or even a Scud vs. Patriot duel over Saudi Arabia visible in Baghdad and Washington and London at the same time. Technology that links reporters in Dhahran instantly with editors in New York or Los Angeles, commanders and staff officers in Riyadh continuously with the Pentagon and the White House. The Upper Hand in the Dark **********Pilots in Vietnam could do little more than find their way from one airstrip to another after sunset, worrying all the while about running into a mountain. For the most part, the enemy owned the night. **********This time, if the new-fangled scopes and gadgets work as they're supposed to work -- and that's still a large "if," though early evidence is highly encouraging -- allied infantrymen and tank crews will have the upper hand in the dark, as the allied pilots already do. **********Comparing the endearing little UH-1 Huey helicopter, which saved so many lives and seemed like such a piece of technical wizardry, to the fearsome Apache attack helicopters here is like comparing a Model T to a Lamborghini. Sunspots to Glitches **********Only 25 years ago, well within the working lifetimes of many of the combatants and some of the correspondents in the war in the Persian Gulf, reporters sent their dispatches from Vietnam by radio telegraph, which was sometimes interrupted by sunspots, and television cameramen had to ship combat footage to Hong Kong or Tokyo, and then on to the United States, by plane. **********A newspaper reporter who spent almost three years in Saigon talked more times to his editors on his first day in Saudi Arabia than he did in the entire time he was in Vietnam. Stories are written on computers now, of course, and not on typewriters, and they are transmitted by satellite. **********There are problems with all of this, of course. Greater and greater complexity means more and more glitches and more and more repairs. Modems and lasers are a lot more temperamental than notebooks and hand grenades. **********Then there is the tendency to believe, after a time, that the machines are somehow magical and final, when of course they are not. **********A runway cratered or a bridge dropped or a transmitter damaged by a sophisticated missile is no more and no less replaceable or reparable than a similar target damaged by an old iron bomb. **********Finally, the effect of the communications revolution is to speed things up so much that time for decision-making is minimized and time for reflection is often eliminated. In With the New **********But the lasers and the heat seekers, the computers and the satellites, are here to stay, along with a new whole lexicon of slang and acronyms. **********For example, Lantirn, which stands for Low Altitude Navigation and Targeting for Infrared Night, is an advanced guidance system, carried in pods slung under the wings of some F-16 fighters, that enables pilots to deliver bombs with great precision. Then there is the SLAM, or Stand-off Land Attack Missile, launched from a carrier-based attack plane. **********A few Vietnam-era favorites are back -- infantrymen and Marines still call themselves "grunts" -- but instead of "boondocks," privates and sergeants tramp hereabouts across "beaches" (deserts) and wadis (dry river beds). Pilots talk about "fur balls," or particularly tangled dogfights, and about "the golden BB," which is the antiaircraft doctrine, supposedly Soviet in origin, holding that if enough metal of some kind is thrown up -- missiles, shells, bullets -- planes will come down. **********To some sentimental old soldiers and camp followers, one big loss is the World War II-era United States Army helmet, a fine, deep sort of thing, as useful for shaving and cooking as for deflecting bullets. It has been discarded for a flatter model that looks as if Rommel ought to be wearing it. Also sorely missed is the Jeep, replaced by something the grunts call the Humvee, which carries more. It's less fun to drive and looks like a panel truck that something fell on. **********The M-16 rifle is back, no great favorite two decades ago, so a new generation will discover whether it works better in the sand of Arabia than it did in the paddies of Vietnam. **********A hundred stories and a thousand pictures have testified already to the presence of women in the ranks in unprecedented numbers, but there has been less comment about another major change: the much larger numbers of black officers involved here, starting at the top with Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and spreading down through the ranks. **********Col. Daniel James, an air ace in Vietnam, was one of relatively few black pilots then. Black naval officers were even more unusual. That has all changed, a result, like the presence of so many women so close to the front, of the social revolution that followed and was partly caused by the Vietnam War. Evolution of Shopping **********For all the veterans of Vietnam brought here by Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait, another stunning surprise is the local stores. **********Except for those with access to an American commissary or post exchange, Americans in wartime Saigon had to do without things like milk, celery, tape recordings, and a hundred other items. A pint of strawberries, lovingly hand-carried from Da Lat or another town in the highlands on an Air America flight, was a gift as exotic as frankincense or myrrh. **********Shopping in Dhahran is not all that different from shopping in Larchmont, N.Y., or Phoenix. Radio Shack is here (though the troops have pretty well cleared out its stock for the moment), as is Baskin-Robbins. **********You can pick up a shirt or a skirt at Benetton, rent a Chevrolet from Avis, buy a new Volvo or Fiat. Commerce has slowed since war began, but it hasn't stalled. **********At the Jamir Bookstore today, three airborne troopers of the new breed were buying reams of computer paper. Around the corner, a selection of compact-disk players was for sale. And the Safeway in nearby Al Khobar -- yes, that Safeway, the one with the big red "S" -- was featuring, in addition to eight brands of mayonnaise, 12 brands of hairspray, Weber barbecue grills and 30-minute film processing, Roquefort and Brie and Gruyere from France, Gulf of Mexico shrimp, Holland veal, Irish lamb and Australian beef. **********But no wine, of course, no beer, no gin and no whiskey, and no nuoc mam, the pungent Vietnamese fish sauce that so many Americans grew to love in their Southeast Asian years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/busin.main_headline: No More Aid for M.B.A.'s in China
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/busin.print_headline: No More Aid for M.B.A.'s in China
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/busin.body_text: **********In a modest structure on the leafy campus of the Dalian University of Technology, just across from a huge statue of Chairman Mao leading his Communist flock, capitalism is the burning issue. **********The Chinese at the school, who are not trying to outflank Communism's nemesis but to absorb more of it, are losing some ground. Despite Chinese protests, the Commerce Department has refused to renew an annual $400,000 contribution to a business school program here that has turned scores of young Chinese managers into freshly minted M.B.A.'s for service in their homeland. **********The 11-year-old program was unique: a Government-to-Government arrangement, financed partly by each country, that offered management courses to officials from many of China's top enterprises. **********It provided regular American M.B.A. degrees, under a program run by the State University of New York at Buffalo, which provided the curriculum and professors. The program at this campus in Dalian, a port city in China's industrial northeast, the region once known as Manchuria, also took senior Chinese officials and offered them midcareer training in American management techniques. **********And the professors did not train the Chinese to work just in foreign ventures, as the management courses of some other countries in China do. The majority of the Dalian program's graduates returned to their state-owned enterprises, introducing American methods directly into the heart of Communist China. **********But the Commerce Department's decision to stop supporting this program is a sign of the times inside China and in Sino-American relations. **********The United States' decision to pull the plug on the M.B.A. program reflects the political realities as the American love affair with China continues the cooling-off that started with the killings of pro-democracy demonstrators two years ago in Tiananmen Square. **********President Bush is currently struggling to renew China's favored access to American markets. An antagonistic Congress that has lost patience with what it considers China's poor human rights record voted Tuesday to impose restrictions on trade between the countries but the narrow majority is not likely to withstand a veto. **********The shift in Washington is occurring as the Chinese have expanded foreign trade and encouraged foreign companies to invest in private businesses. The M.B.A. students here speak English as their second language, and use it to debate finance, marketing and labor management strategies, not class warfare. **********Even with the setbacks that Western-style reform has suffered for three years, China remains eager to learn what it must to advance its hobbling economy and integrate it more closely with the industrialized democracies. **********Ultimately, though, the decision to halt the program here raises the question of which measures taken by an angry United States against China really punish the country or soften its behavior, and which merely undermine the United States' goal of achieving political and economic reform. **********"We admit we have a lot of problems trying to reform our system," said Zhu Shunqing, an economist who is the dean of the university's school of management. "The graduates of this school have new ideas, and they understand the thinking of foreigners. What we have to have is useful knowledge to help with the reform process, even from capitalists." **********Like the dean of a Harvard or a Stanford, Mr. Zhu proudly ticked off the important government offices and corporations in which the graduates of the American program have landed, from the State Planning Commission and top provincial offices to some of China's largest state enterprises. President Ronald Reagan praised the program during a visit to China in 1984 and Henry Kissinger spoke at one of its graduations. **********That record of success has only increased the dismay over the Commerce Department's decision to kill the program. The department has decided that it can spend the $400,000 a year it contributes to better effect elsewhere, perhaps in Eastern Europe. **********"This is painful for me because I started the program 11 years ago," said Richard W. H. Lee, the Commerce Department's director of science and technology programs in East Asia. "Everyone considers it a great success, but it is a matter of priorities. The department's priorities have changed."   'The Wrong Information' **********Mr. Zhu, too, acknowledged the apparent shift in priorities. "The Department of Commerce said they wanted to change their emphasis from China to Eastern Europe," he said. "They said they didn't think we would reform our economy. I say they have the wrong information." **********Many who have been involved in the program concede it had shortcomings; some of the young M.B.A.s found there was little use for their new skills in hidebound state-owned enterprises, for instance. **********Mr. Zhu said some graduates were frustrated when they returned to a Chinese environment. Some were relegated to jobs as translators without real influence. But he said those problems were declining because the students were being chosen with more care. **********But almost all felt that the positive aspects outweighed those flaws, and that the good will it generated for the United States was important.  Better Business Relations **********"It's a tragedy," said Joseph A. Alutto, the dean of Buffalo's business school until earlier this year, when he moved to Ohio State University. "You could not find a more cost-effective way of developing better business relations. And the need for this expertise and these relationships has never been greater." **********Added David B. Matthews, the resident administrator of the program for the State University of New York: "We really do have an impact on the senior level of managers in the Chinese economy. If you close it down you lose that." **********Although Commerce Department officials prefer to say the annual grant is just being suspended, the program's administrators say the likelihood of reviving it is slim because of the long lead time to attract students and professors. **********The American Government has encouraged American corporations to consider picking up the program's decidedly modest cost. There is already an advisory counsel made up of some of America's biggest companies, including I.B.M., Xerox, Citicorp, General Electric and Coca-Cola. The companies have provided internships for the Chinese students and other forms of backing.  Where Government Has Clout **********But most agree the corporations could never replace the Government as chief sponsor. The fact that the course was Government-to-Government gave it clout in a country where the Government so tightly controls the economy. If it were a corporate program it would lose that important status, and possibly the backing of the Chinese Government, Mr. Zhu said. **********"Part of the whole reason this has been so successful is the kind of students it draws, and that's because it's Government to Government," Mr. Lee said. **********Mr. Zhu said: "China has really opened to these ideas. It is not a good choice for you to close that door."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/25/busin.main_headline: Money Market Accounts And C.D.'s Drop in Yield
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/25/busin.print_headline: Money Market Accounts And C.D.'s Drop in Yield
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/25/busin.body_text: **********Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts showed further declines in the week that ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a publication in North Palm Beach, Fla., that focuses on interest rates. **********Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, said there had been considerable impact from recent cuts by leading banks in the prime lending rate to 8 percent from 8 1/2 percent. **********"New York institutions continue to cut rates at a rapid pace," he said. "While the recent drop in the prime rate did little to affect loan rates, it is having a big impact not just on certificates of deposit but also on money market accounts as well." **********At the Treasury's weekly bill auction on Monday, three-month bills were auctioned at an average discount rate of 5.18 percent, only slightly lower than the 5.19 percent the previous week, while six-month bills averaged 5.23 percent, compared with 5.22 percent. **********But the rates that bank offered customers showed larger declines. According to The Monitor, the largest change among New York area banks was made by the Chemical Bank, which lowered its money market rate by 26 basis points, to 4.60 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********Another substantial cut was made by Chase Manhattan, which lowered its money market rate by 21 points, to 4.60 percent. Marine Midland lowered its rate on three-month certificates of deposit by 16 points, to 4.86, the largest cut in that category. **********As for six-month certificates, four major banks -- European American, Connecticut National, Bank of New York and National Westminster -- cut their rates by 11 basis points. **********Among commercial banks in New York , the average yield was cut to 4.78 percent, a decline of 5 basis points, for money market accounts, and three-month certificates are down 5 basis points, to 5.02 percent. **********For depositors at savings institutions in the New York area, yields were cut an average of a basis point, to 5.34 percent, for money market accounts and 3 points, to 5.44, for three-month certificates. **********Nationwide, according to The Monitor, the average money maket account yields of 20 major banks outside of the New York area were cut by 5 basis points, to 5.03, and the six-month certificate rate was cut a point, to 5.28.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Neglected Economist Honored by President
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/19/busin.body_text: **********For years, Friederich von Hayek was a prophet little honored in this land. In a 1944 best seller, "The Road to Serfdom," the Austrian-born economist warned the West that socialism -- whether German Nazism, Soviet Communism or the "gentler and kinder" British brand -- would inevitably lead to poverty and loss of liberty. **********An ardent opponent of most government intervention in the economy, Mr. von Hayek, though respected for early contributions to monetary theory, was all but ignored by other economists for 30 years after World War II as Keynesian thought became a dominant intellectual force, the European social democracies boomed and the Soviet Union and other centrally planned economies scored impressive feats of industrialization. Even after he won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1974, Mr. von Hayek's following in the United States consisted mostly of a small band of monetary economists and libertarians. **********With the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, all that has changed. Mr. von Hayek's views on the economic inadequacies and political ills of central planning are now those of the mainstream. Yesterday, President Bush awarded the 92-year old Mr. von Hayek, a British citizen, the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian honor. **********"More than almost anyone else in the 20th century, this guy was vindicated by the events in Eastern Europe," said Austin Furse, director of policy planning at the White House. Mr. von Hayek has a wide following among Eastern European economic reformers, he noted, including Vaclav Klaus, the Finance Minister of Czechoslovakia. **********Once described as "articulate, austere and infinitely urbane," Mr. von Hayek was born in 1899 into a Viennese family of academics and civil servants. He eventually left for the London School of Economics, where he lectured throughout the 1930's and 40's. When Keynesian thought triumphed and his own reputation as an economist went into eclipse, Mr. von Hayek turned to philosophy and psychology, which he first taught at the University of Chicago, then in Salzburg, Austria, and finally in Freiburg, Germany. **********Conservatives have been urging President Bush, who picks the Medal of Freedom winners himself, to honor Mr. von Hayek. The Nobel laureate's son, a British physician, was on hand at the ceremony yesteray to accept the medal on behalf of his father, who lives in Freiburg and has been ill for several years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/busin.main_headline:
All About/Comic Books;
Reaching Beyond The Ghouls and Gore For Major Payoffs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/busin.print_headline:
All About/Comic Books;
Reaching Beyond The Ghouls and Gore For Major Payoffs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/busin.body_text: **********For years, Spider-Man, Superman and other comic book stars were entertainment industry weaklings. Movie, television and video-game characters drew more attention. But now the superheroes are back in all their glory. Comic book sales are up and publishers are churning out new titles to feed a growing market. **********In the clearest sign of the comic book's return to prominence, media giants like Disney, MCA and Time Warner all are investing more. While most comic books only fetch $1 to $2 an issue, the media companies hope for big payoffs from finding memorable characters to feature in theme parks and films, and to decorate T-shirts and lunch boxes. **********Two sorts of superheroes have led the industry's revival. Batman starred in an immensely successful film, and the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, pizza-eating swashbucklers, rose from the pages of an obscure comic book to appear in a movie, a television series and a stage show. Comic book publishing executives say that such successes have attracted fans to newer books like Lobo -- DC Comics Inc.'s "scourge of the cosmos" -- and the Punisher, Marvel Entertainment Group Inc.'s well-armed vigilante. **********As the industry has grown, marketing has become more expensive and sophisticated.  DC Comics is testing television advertising, which most publishers have shunned. Marvel is bringing out new titles -- Barbie, to attract girls. and N.F.L. Superpro, about a superhuman athlete -- to take the market beyond the young males craving ghouls and gore. **********Comic book retailers are also entering a new era, opening clean, brightly lit stores in shopping malls and on main streets. Bill Liebowitz, who owns the three Golden Apple comics shops in Los Angeles, said that the industry merits much greater respect. "The general public's perception of comics has been that they are read by little kids and cretins, and that the stores are located in bad parts of town and run by guys who can't get a date," he said. "That's just not true. Comics are increasing in quality and complexity. We're an entertainment alternative." Changing MarketsThe Yen for What The 40's Had **********The comic book industry has doubled its sales at specialty stores in five years, to $350 million, according to Melchior T. Thompson, a consultant in Burlingame, Calif. He estimates that the nation's 4,000 specialty shops account for 65 percent to 85 percent of comic book sales. Newsstands and other stores have the rest. **********Comic book industry executives say that sales are growing 10 percent to 20 percent annually. But they still envy the multibillion-dollar annual sales of the movies and video games that use similar adventure themes. **********When executives talk about the potential of comic books, they point to other countries. The Walt Disney comic book Topolino, with varying Disney characters each week, is thethird-largest Italian magazine, with weekly sales of about 650,000 copies. In Japan, adults read comics ranging from the violent to the romantic. **********"We see room for a quintupling of our current market size," said Milton Griepp, president of Capital City Distribution Inc., the nation's second-largest distributor of comic books (after Diamond Comic Distributors) to specialty shops. **********If he is right, comic books will regain the popularity they had in the 1930's and 1940's, before parents and politicians attacked many comic books for corrupting children with their violent tales. By the 1970's, the books had disappeared from many newsstands. **********About 15 years ago, publishers decided to concentrate on their most loyal buyers, who patronized a small group of specialty shops. Distributors offered much deeper discounts to the shops than to the newsstands. In return, the shops forfeited the right to return unsold comics to the publishers, a privilege that the newsstands retained. **********The new sales method, known as direct distribution, rescued the industry. Costly returns were reduced. And many small, independent publishers could afford to enter the market. New publishers could pitch comic book ideas to retailers through distributors. Distributors could size up the likely orders before publishers had invested in production. **********As a result, new comics have proliferated. Where comic stores once carried 70 or 80 titles, they now offer as many as 500. Niche marketing is common. "With 500 titles, you not only have the standard superhero books but also books about female spies and cowboys," said Mr. Liebowitz. The Big MoneyPerelman, MCA And Time Warner **********Among the nation's nearly 200 comic book publishers, the biggest are backed by the biggest money. Marvel, owned by the financier Ronald O. Perelman since January 1989, had 46.1 percent of the comic book store business handled by Capital City Distributors. DC Comics, a subsidiary of the Time Warner Company, had 28.6 percent. No reliable figures for the entire market are available, but Capital City's numbers are considered representative. **********Other major entertainment companies are buying in. Last year, MCA Inc. spent a reported $7 million to $10 million to buy almost 20 percent of Harvey Comics Entertainment Inc., the 50-year-old publisher of Casper the Friendly Ghost and Richie Rich. MCA, which has agreed to be acquired by Matsushita of Japan.  MCA plans to keep its comic book characters working hard. The Harvey's investment included agreements for them to appear at MCA theme parks, perhaps in stage shows or rides, and in films and television programs. Harvey also plans to launch a comic book based on MCA's "Back to the Future" films. **********Entertainment industry executives add that MCA's Universal Pictures, or another studio, might make a film featuring Harvey's Richie Rich. A possible star, they say, is Macaulay Culkin, the child star of the movie "Home Alone." Jeffrey Montgomery, Harvey's chairman, said his company will continue developing new characters that then might star in films. "Comic books are a great breeding ground," Mr. Montgomery said. "To launch a comic book costs less than $50,000. If it hits, it's worth billions." **********In late 1989, the Walt Disney Company reacquired from a licensee the rights to publish its own characters -- Mickey, Minnie and the rest -- in comic books. Disney is ready to produce a new line of comics under the Hollywood imprint, targeting the core comic book audience of teen-age and young adult males. **********Disney will test its ability to cross-pollinate between films and comics this summer with the release of a big-budget film and tie-in comic book called the Rocketeer, about a stunt pilot who flies with a rocket pack. The Packaging From Archie To Spidey to Anne **********The Flash may have his own television show and Batman his own movie. But the current best seller among comic books concerns an uptight photojournalist named Peter Parker and his heroic alter identity: Spider-Man.  Marvel Comics now sells five different Spider-Man books a month with titles like the Amazing Spider-Man and the Web of Spider-Man. In an age when a famous comic book artist can achieve almost as much reknown as an actor, it is Todd McFarlane, who was asked to create a new Spidey book last summer, who has the best seller.  Mr. McFarlane's Spider-Man sells 800,000 to 1 million a month, according to Marvel, in an industry where 400,000 is huge. The premiere issue sold almost 3 million, many to speculators. **********Comic book aficionados link Spider-Man's appeal to his everyman qualities. True, he stands apart by virtue of the radioactive spider bite that gave him the strength and agility of a giant arachnid. Otherwise, Peter Parker is a doting new husband who struggles like everyone else to make ends meet. **********Archie Comic Publications Inc., meanwhile, is among those planning to keep its best-known character as clean cut and uncommitted as ever. Archie, 50 years old this year, is perpetually involved in what Michael I. Silberkleit, the company chairman, calls "the basic love triangle: He's in love with two beautiful girls. People read to see which girl he'll marry. Of course he won't marry either one." **********Other small companies pursue constant new faces, some, like Barbie, aimed at preteens, but most still the brutally tough crime fighters and appalling villains. **********There are more elaborate comics based on familiar themes. First Publishing's Classics Illustrated tales include versions of "Robin Hood" and "Great Expectations." Other publishers mine action and horror films for ideas. Last summer, the publisher Dark Horse hit it big by combining characters from two recent movies in one issue, Aliens Vs. Predators. **********For more sophisticated tastes, there are "graphic novels" -- longer stories with more complex characters and glossy, durable covers -- that can cost $15 to $25.  DC's Why I Hate Saturn, out last year, tells the story of Anne, a trendy intellectual writer in New York, who drinks too much and has trouble with men. Betty or Veronica she is not. **********WHO WANTS BACK ISSUES? **********Own a pristine copy of the first issue of Action Comics? It could more than cover the downpayment on your next house. **********The 1938 comic book, in which Superman first appears, is one of several estimated to be worth $80,000 to $100,000. Pre-World War II comics gain not only for the venerable characters they include but also because so many issues were destroyed during the war's scrap paper drives.  But even recent issues, like the first issue of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, published in 1982, are worth several hundred dollars. The collectible market is substantial, supporting scores of annual comic book shows. **********Collecting fever begins at the comic book shops, where children, the most devoted fans, congregate. Shop owners often raise prices for selected back issues they keep on hand. **********Not all back issues become more valuable; stockpiling comics is a speculative business. Gary Colabuono, who operates six Moondog's Comicland shops in the Chicago area, said that since last summer, with the onset of recession and war, prices for the more expensive comics have leveled off. **********Don Thompson, co-editor of the weekly Comics Buyer's Guide, said that collecting -- as opposed to speculating -- is routine among comic fans. The books are serialized; one issue almost never tells a whole story. So old fans want entire collections, and new fans often want old issues to learn more about the origins of a particular character or story line. **********Collecting can be expensive. To buy every comic published in one month would cost $1,200 to $1,500. Fanatics routinely invest $100 to $400 a month in their hobby. "There are people who live in sparse apartments, living on baloney sandwiches, who spend every spare penny they can on collecting," Mr. Thompson said. "Where they store them I don't know."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/06/world.main_headline: SOVIET CONGRESS YIELDS RULE TO REPUBLICS TO AVOID POLITICAL AND ECONOMIC COLLAPSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/06/world.print_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL; SOVIET CONGRESS YIELDS RULE TO REPUBLICS TO AVOID POLITICAL AND ECONOMIC COLLAPSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/06/world.body_text: **********Bowing to the reality of a collapsing union and an ultimatum from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the all-Soviet Congress voted today to surrender power to a new government largely controlled by the republics. **********The action served largely to confirm the collapse of central authority over the 15 constituent republics in the 16 days since the aborted right-wing coup and the increasingly urgent need to restore at least a modicum of order before the centrifugal forces turned uncontrollable. **********The major effect of the new central structures approved by the Congress of People's Deputies was to grant sweeping emergency powers for an undefined transitional period to a State Council composed of Mr. Gorbachev and leaders of the participating republics, backed by a largely subordinate legislature and a central Interrepublican Economic Committee to manage the economy.  [ Text of resolutions and excerpts from Mr. Gorbachev's remarks, page A12. ] Gorbachev the Manager **********In so doing, the Congress effectively dissolved itself as the highest legislative authority in the Soviet Union and laid the foundation for a far looser union in which the republics would seem to predominate in deciding the policies and powers of a subordinate and reduced center. A major question remains the extent of Mr. Gorbachev's remaining power and influence. Although his powers seem sharply diminished, it is possible that he might emerge with important powers in the new State Council, particularly if the republican leaders pay more attention to their problems at home. **********Under a rough timetable worked out today, the new two-house legislature will convene no later than Oct. 2, and will probably set up a commission to draft a new constitution. It is expected that the new constitution will provide for new elections to the presidency at some future date, at which time Mr. Gorbachev's political future would be decided.  'Rose to the Occasion' **********Mr. Gorbachev, who survived the coup only to stand on the brink of losing any viable levers of control, emerged in the interim order with considerably clipped powers and subordinate to the republics, less an executive president than a coordinating manager. **********Yet the very fact of his survival, his experience in domestic and foreign affairs and the familiar determination he displayed at the Congress suggested that he could emerge with a significant role in the new council. Most republic leaders had problems enough at home, and Mr. Gorbachev was likely to be the major conduit for foreign aid. **********Whatever the reason, his obvious good humor at the Congress testified to his satisfaction at what he described as a historic moment. **********"By determining the principles and mechanisms for the transitional period, the Congress lays the groundwork for a future union of sovereign states," he said before closing the session. "The Congress rose to the occasion at this crucial and, without any exaggeration, historic moment in the development of our state." **********For the moment, the arrangement was less a power-sharing agreement than a desperate attempt to create an emergency control center that could combat the incipient chaos and ethnic strife loosed by the coup, prevent the collapse of the economy and the fragmentation of the military.  Principles for the Future **********The law made no attempt to define the scope, functions or procedures of the new State Council, leaving that to the republican leaders and Mr. Gorbachev to sort out. It was unclear how the republican leaders would be represented in the council and how often the council would meet, whether Mr. Gorbachev, more attuned to Moscow, might rule between meetings with the Russian leader, Boris N. Yeltsin, or would have to check his every action with republican representatives. **********The Congress did, however, pass a nonbinding resolution outlining broad principles for the future, pledging to honor existing Soviet agreements with other states and charging the State Council with "insuring the legal continuity of power and management, guaranteeing a peaceful and orderly transition to a democratic civil society." **********The State Council was to hold its first meeting Friday, when it was likely to appoint the Economic Committee -- in effect an acting cabinet -- and consider emergency economic programs. There were reports that Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the prime advocate of radical economic reform, was readying a preliminary economic plan. **********The council was also expected to recognize the independence of the three Baltic states, an issue the Congress avoided taking up for fear of prompting demands by other republics for similar recognition. The Baltics are the only states whose independence has received broad recognition abroad, and while most other republics have also proclaimed independence, all except Moldavia might yet form some new form of association. **********The new Government was declared a transitional authority until those republics that wanted to could agree on a new relationship, still undefined. The law set no time limits, and deputies talked vaguely of a transitional period of two months to two years. **********Besides Mr. Gorbachev, it was also a satisfying moment for those who had struggled for years against a monolithic and repressive system that had held their nation in thrall for seven decades, and who viewed the vote as its final burial. **********The eulogy was proposed by Anatoly A. Sobchak, the liberal mayor of Leningrad: "I propose a fitting conclusion to our work by fulfilling the last will of Vladimir Ilyich Lenin and burying him according to the religious and national traditions of our people at Volkovo Cemetery with all appropriate honors."  Gorbachev Turns Tough **********Lenin had in fact asked to be buried next to his mother and sister in the Leningrad cemetery, but the proposal was quashed by Mr. Gorbachev. **********The end did not come easily. For two days the debate at the Congress ranged from bitter resistance against the surrender of power to somber acknowledgment that the old order was out. **********At today's session, however, Mr. Gorbachev turned tough. Flanked by Mr. Yeltsin and the leaders of nine other republics, the man who six years earlier first loosed the democratic processes that created this Congress now sternly demanded that it fulfill its purpose by clearing the way for the new era. **********Turning away all speakers, demanding silence and obedience in the vast Palace of Congresses, Mr. Gorbachev martialed vote after vote until the deputies balked on a critical paragraph. Twice they denied it a two-thirds majority needed for a constitutional change, when Mr. Gorbachev declared an ultimatum: "We've been talking for three days and we must move foward. Either take this decision and continue on the path, or we will seek new answers." **********He did not elaborate, but the glare of the republic leaders made clear that they were the new law in the land with or without the endorsement of Congress. This time, by a margin of scores of votes, it passed -- 1,606 for, 116 against, 83 abstaining and 37 not voting. **********Critical to the passage was the decision by Estonia and Latvia, despite their independence, to have their deputies take part in the vote. Lithuania withdrew its deputies from the outset. **********The rest went easily, and by the time the Congress was called on to vote on a Declaration of Human Rights, no one even asked to speak. The declaration, which includes guarantees of free movement, is nonbinding. **********The central action taken by the congress, the law on transferring power, was in part a compromise. The original proposal from the republican leaders had called for a largely nominal legislature appointed by the republics. 2-Chamber Parliament **********The final version created a two-chamber Parliament with a Council of the Republics and a Council of the Union. **********The Council of the Republics would have 20 deputies from each republic except Russia, which would have additional deputies from ethnic subrepublics for a total of 52. The catch, however, was that each republicwould have only one vote in the Council of the Republics. **********In the Council of the Union, seats would be apportioned by quota. Its action would be subject to approval by the Council of the Republics. **********The law also lifted a requirement for the Congress to formally dissolve itself. Deputies were allowed to retain their credentials until the end of their term in two and a half years, along with their privileges and immunity, but regular assemblies were canceled. **********Substantive powers were granted to the State Council, which was authorized to organize its own work and whose decisions were declared binding. The law said nothing about the relationship between the council and the Parliament, empowering the council in effect to rule by decree. **********The law called for an Interrepublican Economic Committee to be named by the republics. All national military, security and foreign-affairs institutions were placed under the control of the council. **********The resolution passed by the Congress gave a broad, though nonbinding outline of thenew Government's goals. **********It charged the new leaders with "insuring the legal continuity of power and management, guaranteeing a peaceful and orderly transition to a democratic civil society," and it called for accelerated efforts to negotiate a new Union Treaty "in which each state can independently define the form of its participation in the Union." **********The resolution called on republics to reach agreements among themselves on a variety of economic, fiscal, military and other issues. It pledged to honor all Soviet international agreements, and called for negotiated agreements with republics that wanted to leave the union. **********While the Congress met, events across the land underscored the urgency of restoring order. Railroad lines in Moldavia remained blocked by women demanding the release of leaders of the "Dnestr Republic," an enclave largely populated by Russians and Ukrainians that opposes Moldavian independence. **********A new wave of violence was reported in South Ossetia, a region that demands independence of Georgia, and in Georgia tensions were high after the police fired on demonstrators opposed to the authoritarian President, Zviad Gamsakhurdia. Armenia and Azerbaijan squared off for new confrontations over the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh and rumblings were reported in several ethnic regions of the Russian Federation. **********Yet the documents adopted today marked a turning point in the tumult that swept over the Soviet Union with the collapse of the coup and the subsequent eruption of nationalist and republican claims. The same republican leaders who had rushed to declare independence now sat alongside Mr. Gorbachev and argued the need for maintaining a center, and the deputies who had defended or attacked the old order now mustered the dignity to surrender their own hard-won authority in the name of a new order. **********At the center stood Mr. Gorbachev, still self-confident and assertive, a man who had come within a hair's-breadth of being swept away by the same processes he had set loose six years earlier, but who had clambered back to center stage by dint of his fundamental faith in the union's potential for renewal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/21/busin.body_text: **********The Commerce Department today began investigating charges by American auto makers that Japanese companies were "dumping" mini-vans in the United States at prices below cost to increase their market share. **********The inquiry was sought three weeks ago by General Motors, Ford and Chrysler through the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association. **********The International Trade Commission is expected to take testimony on Friday from officials of the Big Three and the Japanese auto makers. **********The American auto makers contend that the Japanese auto makers -- Toyota and Mazda in particular -- are selling mini-vans at prices below their production costs. **********Toyota has called the Big Three's accusations absurd. **********Through the first five months of the year, the Big Three held 86.1 percent of the mini-van market, with Japanese makers holding 13.2 percent. **********The complaint said Toyota was selling its Previa mini-van to dealers at 5.4 percent to 30.5 percent below fair value. It said Mazda was selling its MPV model at 14.8 percent to 27 percent below fair value.
