https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/16/busin.main_headline: CBS Considers Its Options After a Death in the Family
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/16/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; CBS Considers Its Options After a Death in the Family
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/16/busin.body_text: **********The death of Redd Foxx, who starred in "The Royal Family" on CBS, has left the network, advertisers and agencies facing delicate choices, from whether the series will stay on the air to what will become of the commercials running on the show. **********While no decisions have been made yet, CBS would like to avoid canceling the series, because that would free advertisers from millions of dollars in commercial commitments. **********Mr. Foxx, who died on Friday, had filmed seven episodes of the situation comedy, three of which have not yet been run. In the series, created by Eddie Murphy Productions for Paramount Television, Mr. Foxx and Della Reese play parents who find their imminent retirement interrupted when their daughter and grandchildren move in. **********Since it is unusual for a leading actor to die during a series, there are no formal procedures to deal with Mr. Foxx's death. **********"It's a terribly unfortunate situation," said Paul Schulman, president of the Paul Schulman Company in New York. He purchases $175 million worth of commercial time annually and had bought spots during "The Royal Family" for a client, the Ralston Purina Company. **********Before the 1991-92 television season started, advertising executives had expected that "The Royal Family" would be a successful new series at 8 P.M., Eastern time, on Wednesdays. This summer, during the advance, or up-front, market, they bet on its potential drawing power by committing clients to purchases that, according to Advertising Age, averaged $80,000 for each 30-second spot. **********Those spots were part of guaranteed packages the executives bought from the networks. For example, while CBS does not guarantee Mr. Schulman that a spot during "The Royal Family" would attract a certain number of viewers, the network would guarantee him that figure for a package of 100 spots during its Wednesday lineup. **********"It becomes a question of whether Redd Foxx's absence causes the show to perform less well than the guarantee," said Joseph Ostrow, corporate executive vice president and worldwide media director for FCB/ Leber Katz Partners in New York. If it does, he added, "then you get compensatory spots," or make-goods, for the rest of the season. **********CBS thought "The Royal Family" had "breakthrough potential," -- the chance to become a huge hit, thereby improving the network's previously anemic Wednesday ratings. **********The series had yet to achieve hit status, according to David Marans, senior vice president for media research at J. Walter Thompson in New York. Yet ratings for its four appearances before Mr. Foxx's death -- it was 51st among 99 series measured in the A. C. Nielsen ratings -- were higher than for any recent CBS Wednesday lead-off series. **********At CBS, "The consensus is we'd like the show to continue," said George F. Schweitzer, senior vice president of marketing and communications, adding that meetings are being held to discuss "where it goes from here." **********The next step for advertisers is to wait as CBS "tap-dances for a while," said Aaron Cohen, senior vice president and director of network broadcasting at Ayer Inc. in New York, "and to encourage them to do the best they can." **********The executives' position is bolstered "by the fact we can take our money back" if CBS cancels "The Royal Family," said Jon Mandel, senior vice president and director of national broadcast at Grey Advertising Inc. in New York, who had purchased spots during the series for clients including Domino's Pizza and Mitsubishi. **********CBS is studying the possibilities. Mr. Schulman suggested "replacing Red Foxx with a major name," like the actor Sherman Hemsley, star of the comedies "Amen" and "The Jeffersons." **********"We hope that will work," Mr. Schulman said. "If it doesn't, we won't be terribly depressed. Our biggest sponsorship on NBC is on 'Unsolved Mysteries' -- which runs opposite "The Royal Family." **********In the meantime, Mr. Schweitzer said, CBS will pre-empt "The Royal Family" twice before it returns on Oct. 30. Tonight, it will be replaced by "Teech," a comedy that normally follows "The Royal Family" at 8:30, and a week from tonight, by a World Series pre-game show. **********Viewers with long memories offered CBS solace by citing television history. In 1960, when the actor Ward Bond died, his NBC series, "Wagon Train," was second in the ratings. After he was replaced, by the actor John McIntire, it rose to No. 1 during the 1961-62 season.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/13/busin.main_headline: Keeping Up With the Joneses' PC
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/13/busin.print_headline: Keeping Up With the Joneses' PC
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/13/busin.body_text: **********In a move that speaks volumes about the changing computer industry, I.B.M. recently began letting consumers trade in their old personal computers for a discount on a new one. **********Thus is the personal computer business becoming akin to selling automobiles. Like the car, the personal computer is turning into a replacement product, because many businesses and homes that are most likely to use computers already have them. After a decade of rapid growth from selling computers to new users, companies big and small are increasingly reliant on selling replacement machines or improved versions of software. **********"In the 90's, every buyer of a computer has a computer," said Alex Randall, president of the Boston Computer Exchange, a broker for used computers. "You can't sell a better computer to a person that has an adequate one without displacing the adequate one." **********The shift is having a profound effect on many aspects of the business. **********Advertising is no longer full of such devices as the Charlie Chaplin figure used by the International Business Machines Corporation to make computers friendlier to novices. Now ads from established companies like Compaq and smaller upstarts like Dell Computer emphasize megabytes, megahertz -- and price. **********Hardware companies like the Tandon Corporation and AST Research Inc., are making their computers easy to upgrade as a way to capture more business. **********Software companies, too, are finding that sales opportunities increasingly lie not among new users but in raiding their competitors' clientele while offering upgrades to their own customers. The redesigns make the programs more powerful, easier to use or just better looking, with pretty typefaces and more colorful graphics. **********"Style and new technology will cause you to get a new car every few years, and the same is true for software," said Spencer Leyton, senior vice president of business development for Borland International Inc., a leading software company. **********While selling upgrades and replacements can be a lucrative business, it means that the fast growth of the last decade might never be duplicated. Software companies like Borland, Lotus and Wordperfect know that selling a $100 upgrade package to the owner of a spreadsheet or word processor program is not as profitable as selling a new $500 program to the person who is just starting out. **********"Saturation has to be increasingly viewed as an issue, and that's not going to go away," said Peter Rogers, personal computer analyst with Robertson Stephens & Company in San Francisco. In a recent survey conducted by the investment banking company, personal computer managers at large corporations said that on average 71 percent of their employees who might be able to make use of a personal computer already had one. **********Some computer industry executives take issue with such estimates and say there are still many untapped markets. "We haven't at all seen the demise of the first-time user," said Winnie Briney, personal systems marketing director for I.B.M. **********A survey by Computer Intelligence, a market research firm in San Diego, indicates that 24 percent of companies, mainly small ones, still have no personal computers and 48 percent have fewer than five. Industry executives also say they see growth propelled by the increasingly popular laptop and notebook versions and new types of computers, like the pocket-sized models that use pens in place of keyboards. **********The industry also sees hope in new applications beyond accounting spreadsheets and word processing, like networks and software that allow a company's workers to collaborate on projects. Enhancements Rival First Sales **********Still, Inteco, a market research firm in Norwalk, Conn., estimates that replacement machines will account for 40 percent of personal computers sold in the United States this year, up from 23 percent in 1988. In terms of dollar value, sales of enhancements to existing machines will account for 39 percent of the United States market this year. That is only slightly less than the 40 percent of the market accounted for by new machines. Replacement machines will account for the other 21 percent of the dollars spent. **********For companies able to tap into the upgrade and replacement markets, business can be brisk. The stupendous growth in the last year by the Microsoft Corporation, the leading publisher of personal-computer software, has been fueled by sales of Windows 3.0, a software package that uses command menus and small pictures to make it much easier to operate a computer. **********Windows adds new features to Microsoft's venerable MS-DOS operating system and has been sold largely to people who already have computers running MS-DOS. Most recently, Microsoft has cashed in by selling nearly a million packages of MS-DOS 5, the latest version of the program, to customers who already owned earlier versions. **********Yet, even William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, is worried about market saturation. In a memo to employees in May, Mr. Gates said one of his long-term concerns was "that companies will eventually equip all the employees that need software with a full complement of packages, and our only revenue opportunity will be upgrades or ephemeral information."  Mining the Installed Base **********Many other hardware and software companies are trying to mine the market that comprises their existing customers. **********"The installed base is the most important asset the company has outside of its software," said Mr. Leyton of Borland International Inc., which makes a spreadsheet called Quattro Pro, among other products. Just how important was shown recently when Borland agreed to pay $440 million to buy its rival, the Ashton-Tate Company, best known for its popular database software called dBase. Analysts considered that a very high price, but noted Borland was not so much interested in Ashton-Tate's dBase as in its huge customer base. **********The Lotus Development Corporation created a special marketing group earlier this year that sells other software, accessories and even T-shirts by direct mail to the legions of registered users of its 1-2-3 spreadsheet. Lotus also now gets about 10 percent of its revenues from upgrades of 1-2-3, officials said. For the Wordperfect Corporation, producer of a popular word-processing program, the upgrade figure has been as high as 15 percent of quarterly revenues. **********And if selling to your own customers is good, why not sell to your competitors' customers? Why not indeed, say the software companies, which are busily raiding one another's installed bases. **********Borland has offered its Quattro Pro spreadsheet for only $130, well below the list price of $495, to people who already own Lotus 1-2-3. Analysts estimate that about 70 percent of the Quattro Pro sales have gone to owners of other types of spreadsheet. Now, Lotus, Microsoft, Wordperfect and other software companies are offering similar bargains to their competitors' customers. **********Such discounts would seem to cut into a software company's profits. But executives argue that such sales do not take the place of full-price sales because people who already own one spreadsheet or word-processing program would probably not switch to another if they had to pay full price. **********Moreover, once the customer is converted to a new product, there is the opportunity to sell upgrades later. Therefore, executives say, it pays to offer discounts to attract a new customer, just as magazines offer discounts to hook new subscribers.  I.B.M. Trade-Ins **********I.B.M. is trying a similar tactic with its new trade-in program. It will offer discounts toward new I.B.M. computers to customers who trade in not only old I.B.M. PC's, but also old Compaqs and Apples. **********Such trade-ins have been tried before by I.B.M. without much success. But this time the program is being met with more "jubilation," said Ms. Briney of I.B.M. **********Industry analysts call the new enthusiasm the result of a higher number of old computers, which need someplace to go if new ones are to be purchased. **********I.B.M. refurbishes the trade-ins and sells them as used computers or uses the machines for parts. **********So far the Apple Computer Corporation and Compaq have not started trade-in programs. Lori Strong, vice president of product marketing at the Compaq Computer Corporation, said the company -- whose machines are used more often in offices than in homes -- did not yet see much demand for trade-in incentives. When an experienced user buys a new, more powerful machine, Ms. Strong said, the old computer typically goes to someone else in the same company in a sort of trickle-down effect.  Easier Upgrades **********Realizing that upgrading will become more important, many computer hardware companies are designing machines accordingly, so that users can, say, install a more powerful microprocessor without having to buy a whole new machine. The Tandon Corporation recently introduced a computer in which users can snap in new microprocessors or a new disk drive as easily as a consumer slips a tape into a video cassette recorder. **********It remains an open question how successful the computer industry will be in shifting toward replacement machines and programs. Software, and even computer hardware, do not wear out like cars do. **********Users who once snapped up any new programs are beginning to decide they may not need every new bell and whistle offered in the latest version of their spreadsheet or word-processing program. Others are not convinced that the additional increment in speed offered by a new microprocessor will really make their life easier. **********It is such doubts that nag at executives like Pete Peterson, executive vice president of Wordperfect. "We are going to run into a situation," he said, "where we have mature products that do a good job, so that people don't need to move up."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/29/world.main_headline: U.N. Sees Kuwaiti Recovery From Sacking
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/29/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; U.N. Sees Kuwaiti Recovery From Sacking
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/29/world.body_text: **********Kuwait is making a good recovery from its Iraqi occupiers' widespread destruction, and most basic services should be restored within six months, the United Nations said in a report issued today. **********But while Kuwait requires relatively little outside humanitarian assistance at the moment, it remains in urgent need of help in restoring hospital services, extinguishing the 500 to 800 oil wells set ablaze by the Iraqi Army and clearing thousands of tons of unexploded munitions scattered across the country, the report says. **********The report was prepared by Under Secretary General Martti Ahtisaari of Finland, who was sent by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to assess humanitarian needs in Iraq and Kuwait after the suspension of fighting in the Persian Gulf war. Mr. Ahtisaari arrived in Kuwait on Monday and left on Wednesday.  Effort to 'Extinguish Kuwait' **********Last week Mr. Ahtisaari presented a far gloomier report on conditions in Iraq, which he said the allies had bombed back into a "pre-industrial" age and appealed to the Security Council to lift its embargo on deliveries of food and essential humanitarian goods. **********Today's report accuses Iraq of making "a deliberate attempt to extinguish Kuwait." It speaks of "prolific evidence of arson, looting, malicious destruction of homes, businesses, markets, museums, libraries and all that a nation cherishes." **********It also reports that power and telecommunications should be fully restored to Kuwait City by mid-April. It said that most services should be functioning throughout the country in six months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/20/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Fox Slows, but Stays Restless
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/20/busin.body_text: **********The Fox Broadcasting Company turned momentum into money last year. Now the young and restless network has lost ground in the ratings even as it expanded its program base. **********Advertising industry executives predict that Fox will take in less advertising money for its fall programs this year than it did last year. **********But Barry Diller, the chairman of Fox, is promising an announcement tomorrow on a change in program direction, just before the company officially introduces its fall lineup of prime-time programs. The announcement appears to be an attempt to counter the impression that the once-hot network has cooled down. Buzzword of the Business **********The move is consistent with Mr. Diller's and Fox's talent for seizing the attention of the television industry. Last spring, Fox was the buzzword of the business, principally for its daring decision to move its sudden and spectacular hit, "The Simpsons," from a safe haven on Sunday night to a Thursday face-off with the most popular show of the previous half decade, "The Cosby Show" on NBC. **********At the same time, Fox had two other series with growing ratings and reputations, "Married With Children" and "In Living Color." **********Fox was adding more viewers every week, especially the young adult viewers most sought by advertisers. Even executives at the other networks were acknowledging that they needed to find Fox-like shows for their own schedules. **********A year later, the attention -- and the noise level -- surrounding Fox are considerably more muted. **********In the television season that ended in April, Fox's overall rating slipped from a 6.5 to a 6.4. (Each rating point represents 931,000 homes.) Fox added no new hit series; no Fox series, not even its big three from a year ago, increased its ratings from the previous season. Furthermore, Fox so overestimated the ratings its programs would receive that it was forced to offer free commercial time to advertisers for most of the second half of the season. **********Gene DeWitt, the president of DeWitt Media, an advertising-buying service, predicts that "Fox will get whacked real hard" by advertisers this year. He said Fox, which took in about $500 million in advance commercial billings last spring, could fall as much as $200 million short of that amount during this year's "up-front" advertising buying season. **********"I think the up-front could pass Fox right by," Mr. DeWitt said, adding that one big advantage Fox enjoyed last spring was gone. At the time, ABC, CBS and NBC were trying to institute a new system for guaranteeing ratings for advertisers, using complicated formulas based on discrepancies in the Nielsen ratings. **********"Fox became close to a must-buy," Mr. DeWitt said. "Now, after a year of weak advertising sales, you have three networks saying, 'Yessir, Mr. Advertiser.' And Fox is no longer a must-buy." **********Howard Stringer, the president of the CBS Broadcast Group, who had once been outspoken in calling for more Fox-style shows, now dismisses any idea of imitating Fox programming. "That particular enthusiasm has run its course," he said. **********And the producers of "The Simpsons," disappointed that television's most-talked-about show did not grow in its second year as most hit shows do, lobbied hard in the last week to be shifted back to Sunday night. **********But none of this apparent bad news has diminished the enthusiasm, or the cockiness, of the Fox executives. They offer nothing but positive assessments about the television season that just ended, about their expansion in September from three nights of programming to four, plus an occasional Monday night movie, and about the season to come. 'In Very Good Shape' **********"We have the hard work accomplished," said Peter Chernin, the president of the Fox Entertainment Group. "We feel we are in very good shape." **********That optimism may lead Fox to an altered plan for the network. One senior industry executive, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said Mr. Diller's announcement tomorrow might involve a shift of one entire night of programming, from Friday night, when ABC's children-oriented shows dominate the younger audience that Fox wants, to either Tuesday or Wednesday night, when more young viewers would be available. **********Sam Simon, the executive producer of "The Simpsons," said the show's producers "lobbied intensively" for Fox to make an equally dramatic announcement about "The Simpsons" this spring. "We want them to put us back on Sunday," he said, though he added, "I think it's unlikely." **********No matter what announcement Mr. Diller makes tomorrow, it will almost certainly not include any concession that this year's ambitious expansion was not a success. Mr. Chernin said Fox had made remarkable strides this year toward its long-term goal of a full seven-night prime-time schedule. "We are now a force," he said. **********Fox overcame its chief potential impediment in March when the Federal Communications Commission redefined what a television network is in terms that will allow Fox to expand to 15 hours of prime-time programs without undermining its television syndication business. Although the three older networks are still not allowed to sell programs under the new regulations, Fox will still be able to earn profits from syndicated shows like "A Current Affair." **********Mr. Chernin said Fox had succeeded in growing to a viable four-night network, with the possibility that the Monday-night movie would become a regular part of the Fox lineup. **********"We have strong anchors we can build on," he said. He pointed to one new series, "Beverly Hills 90210," as a growing phenomenon, especially among teen-age girls. **********Some advertising executives said Fox could be aiming its programs at too young an audience. Fox's ratings fell significantly this year among both men and women aged 18 to 49. But Fox demonstrated sharp growth among both teen-agers and children. The average age of the Fox audience fell to 28 from 29. **********"You can skew too young for some advertisers," said Betsy Frank, senior vice president of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising. She said Fox would always be strong with advertisers like soft-drink and sneaker makers, but may have trouble selling to package-goods advertisers who want to reach a more adult audience. **********Mr. Chernin emphasized that Fox succeeded so far because it had a vision for the new network and stuck to it. "We chose to take the ambitious, risky route," he said. "We do shows that are distinctly Fox shows, shows that have a certain edge." Complaints About 'Slob-coms' **********Some critics have charged that the distinctive Fox edge is a low-brow mentality that often veers into outright vulgarity. One recent comedy, "Top of the Heap," has been harshly criticized for heavy doses of sexual innuendo. Ms. Frank said the term increasingly being applied to Fox's kind of comedies was "slob-coms." **********But Mr. Chernin said the criticism was unjust, pointing to the acclaimed work on "The Simpsons" and "In Living Color." **********Mr. DeWitt believes Fox's problems are temporary. "I think they will break out over time," he said. "They've done a remarkable job so far. They've gotten to a decent plateau. They have to consolidate their gains while on this plateau and then they'll be ready for another jump."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/busin.main_headline: Microsoft Widens Its Split With I.B.M. Over Software
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/busin.print_headline: Microsoft Widens Its Split With I.B.M. Over Software
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/busin.body_text: **********The Microsoft Corporation is moving its software strategy farther away from that of the International Business Machines Corporation, its one-time partner, company executives said. **********Microsoft supplies the MS-DOS operating system used on I.B.M. and compatible personal computers. And the company worked with I.B.M. on OS/2, which was supposed to be a successor to DOS. But recently Microsoft and I.B.M. have had a bitter divorce, with I.B.M. continuing to support OS/2 while Microsoft supports its own program known as Windows. **********At a meeting for securities analysts at Microsoft headquarters here late Thursday afternoon, company officials clarified their strategy for providing operating systems, the software that controls the basic functions of computers. **********The company's shares soared $5 today, to end the day at $71, because analysts were impressed both with the clear statement of the company's direction and with the strong financial results Microsoft reported earlier this week. In addition, the company's outlook for the future was positive. **********Reflecting their widening split with I.B.M., Microsoft executives said they would no longer call a new operating system they are working on OS/2 3.0. Rather, the new operating system will be named Windows NT, standing for New Technology. And Windows NT will not be able to run programs written for OS/2, as had previously been planned. **********Microsoft said its strategy was to sell two different versions of Windows tailored for different types of computers but able to run the same programs. A low-end version of Windows will run on top of MS-DOS in computers using Intel Corporation microprocessors. Windows NT, which will be released next year, will be geared for more powerful computers and workstations using microprocessors from Intel as well as from MIPS Computer Systems. Windows NT will also be able to run programs like Lotus 1-2-3 written for MS/DOS. **********"We do not see a technical discontinuity over the next four to five years," said Steven Ballmer, Microsoft senior vice president of systems software. "We think we can evolve Windows." Microsoft officials seemed clearly stung by I.B.M.'s recent attempts to form alliances with Microsoft rivals, like Apple Computer Inc. and Novell. Mr. Ballmer said all these alliances were confusing and presented no clear picture of I.B.M.'s strategy.  OS/2 Called 'Dead End' **********"I can't tell you what I.B.M.'s strategy is," Mr. Ballmer said. "But I do know it's not working together with us. It's to our benefit because their customers can't understand it either." **********Mr. Ballmer said I.B.M.'s agreement to work on a new operating system with Apple Computer seemed to suggest that OS/2 was "a dead end." **********Microsoft executives pulled few punches in describing the company's dispute with I.B.M. To refute I.B.M.'s contention that OS/2 is more stable than Windows, Mr. Ballmer demonstrated several ways he could "crash" or stall a computer running OS/2. **********I.B.M. maintains that it is fully behind OS/2, which will be its strategic personal computer operating system. It has said that any operating system it will develop with Apple will not be out for several years and that the operating system will run programs written for OS/2, so customers who commit to OS/2 now will be protected.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/world.main_headline: Burmese Troops Reinforced as Civil Unrest Grows
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/world.print_headline: Burmese Troops Reinforced as Civil Unrest Grows
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/world.body_text: **********The military Government of Myanmar, alarmed by rebel attacks within 50 miles of the capital and large anti-Government demonstrations by students in two cities, is reinforcing troops in several regions to counter widening civil unrest, according to Administration officials and independent experts on the country, formerly Burma. **********Neighboring Bangladesh put its frontier forces on high alert today after Burmese troops attacked a Bangladesh Army base, killing at least one soldier, the Bangladesh Government reported. **********The movement of Burmese troops comes amid reports that Gen. Saw Maung, the leader of the ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council, may be ill and under pressure from within the junta or from Gen. Ne Win, who ran the country for more than a quarter of a century and is still a power behind the scenes. Foreigners returning from Yangon, formerly Rangoon, have reported that General Saw Maung has suffered some form of breakdown. **********Foreign Minister Raul Manglapus of the Philippines said that when he went to Myanmar in early December on behalf of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, he was told that he could not meet General Saw Maung because the junta leader was undergoing surgery. At Religious Festival **********On Saturday, General Saw Maung appeared on Burmese television attending a religious festival in the company of the head of military intelligence, Maj. Gen. Khin Nyunt, whom many consider to be the closest to General Ne Win and the real power in the junta. But General Saw Maung did not speak, and several who saw the program said that it was difficult to make a judgment about his health. Burmese exiles said that the film might have been an old one. **********Mr. Manglapus told reporters in Bangkok after his visit that Burmese generals seemed obsessed by fears of "Nuremberg-type trials" for their suppression of a democracy movement in 1988. In 1990, after national elections were won by the National League for Democracy, the military refused to hand over power. Mr. Manglapus said that the generals told him that a civilian government might bring them to court. **********There have been reports that General Saw Maung has been troubled by the repeated crackdowns, the isolation to which Mynamar has been subjected internationally and warnings from the few remaining nations giving aid that the junta must improve its record on civil rights. **********The most recent such warning came last week from Japan. South Korea is reported to be withholding about $22 million in development projects.The United States has cut all aid links to the Burmese Government. Attacks by Karen Guerrillas **********Josef Silverstein, a Rutgers University historian and expert on Myanmar's ethnic minorities, most of whom have been in rebellion for four decades, said that attacks led by ethnic Karen guerrillas in late November and early December in the Irrawaddy Delta between Yangon and Moulmein were "a major shock" to the military Government, which reported killing more than 570 rebels, indicating large confrontations. The rebels said they killed 500 troops. **********"The attacks were organized by Karens, but what came as a surprise was that that Burmans and Arakanese and Mons also joined in against the army," Professor Silverstein said, referring to other ethnic groups in Myanmar. "It took the army by surprise. The military has been particularly vicious since then." **********Mr. Silverstein said that the Karens and armed student groups claimed to be moving small units around the country. Students were also active in mounting demonstrations in Yangon and in Mandalay on Dec. 10, the day on which the National League for Democracy's leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, would have received her Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo. She has been under house arrest since July 1989. **********Administration officials believe that the recent movement of Burmese troops to the Arakan area near Bangladesh is precautionary. David I. Steinberg, a Georgetown University specialist on Burma, said that the Bangladesh-Burmese border has always been a sensitive one for Burmese governments because the Arakan region has a large Muslim population that has always been thought of as being outside the national mainstream. Many Cross Borders **********Many Bengalis crossed into Burma over the last half century and Arakanese have from time to time fled into East Bengal, now Bangladesh. **********The Burmese Army is thus facing Karens in the east and south, Arakanese in the west and Kachin rebels in the northeast along the border with China.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/26/world.main_headline: European Soldiers Restore Calm In Zaire Capital as Foreigners Flee
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/26/world.print_headline: European Soldiers Restore Calm In Zaire Capital as Foreigners Flee
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/26/world.body_text: **********French and Belgian troops helped restore calm to the Zairian capital today after two days of looting, but thousands of foreign residents prepared to flee the central African nation amid reports of continuing unrest in provincial cities. **********According to a Reuters report from the capital, Kinshasa, French troops took over operations of the ferry service and shuttled some 3,000 people, among them French, Belgian, Portuguese and Lebanese citizens, across the Congo River to Brazzaville, the calm capital of Congo. **********Hundreds more foreigners have flown from southern Zaire to Zimbabwe and South Africa or have escaped overland. Many carried with them terrifying stories of their homes' being looted by soldiers who mutinied early Monday over pay arrears. **********"Soldiers armed with machine guns broke into my house while we were there," a French refugee told Reuters in Brazzaville. "They stole everything." **********Downtown Kinshasa also displayed the scars of the violence after many food shops, pharmacies, electronics stores, car dealerships and restaurants were ransacked by soldiers and civilian bands that joined them in their rampage. So far, some 30 deaths have been reported.  4,000 Flee to Hotel **********Some 4,000 foreigners took refuge in the Kinshasa Inter-Continental Hotel on Monday, with as many as 700 forced to camp out in the building's lobby. The hotel is a few blocks from the river, which offered the shortest route of escape by ferry or pirogues, the small dugout canoes that move up and down the fast moving and broad river. **********France now has 700 paratroopers in Zaire, while Belgium has so far deployed 500 soldiers and is planning to send more. **********France's Defense Minister, Pierre Joxe, said the presence of French troops in Kinshasa since early Tuesday "restored order very rapidly" in the capital. But he said he had no detailed information about the situation elsewhere in the country. **********Although it is still unclear whether the troubles have shaken President Mobutu Sese Seko's grip on power, continued looting in the copper belt town of Kolwezi prompted France and Belgium to send two companies of soldiers there today. Sporadic looting was also reported in Likasi and Kamina in the south and Kisangani in the north.  Mobutu Announces Curfew **********In a televised address announcing an overnight curfew early today, Mr. Mobutu, who has ruled the nation of 38 million people since 1966, said the unrest was the worst seen in the capital since Zaire won its independence from Belgium 30 years ago. He said it took on the character of "a real insurrection" as the soldiers' wage protests turned into vandalism. "What is even worse is that these actions have destroyed the economic, industrial and commercial infrastructures of Kinshasa for a long time," he said. **********Zairian opposition groups in Kinshasa and abroad have attributed the outburst to a severe economic crisis that has brought four-digit inflation and to Mr. Mobutu's seeming reluctance to carry out his pledge to install a multiparty democracy in Zaire.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/08/busin.body_text: **********INTERNATIONAL The Unraveling of Robert Maxwell's Posthumous Empire **********A month after his body was found at sea, Robert Maxwell's media empire is in ruins. Last week, Mr. Maxwell's sons, Ian and Kevin, filed for bankruptcy protection in the British courts for the family's private businesses. The New York Daily News, one of the family's companies, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law, and Kevin Maxwell vowed to keep the newspaper alive. Britain's Serious Fraud Office began investigating charges last week that Robert Maxwell illegally drained up to $765 million in Mirror Group P.L.C. pension funds to prop up his ailing businesses. It was also discovered that his private companies borrowed $538 million -- perhaps more -- from the public ones. The tattered empire with its hundreds of subsidiaries is now expected to be sold off. But according to John Talbot, an administrator appointed by the British courts, the assets may be significantly less than the liabilities. The Intractable Trade Problem  Economists often suffer from a disease called hardening of the categories. No matter what reality says, their paradigms stay the same. Trade is one of those categories. Despite seven years of a cut-rate dollar that was supposed to make American products more attractive, America's trade deficit with Japan has barely budged, though there has been remarkable progress elsewhere. And years of trade talks have not put many American goods on Japanese retail shelves. But while economists urge patience, business people are not optimistic. "The Japanese have built a structure that is completely different from ours," said Arnold Brenner, an executive vice president in charge of the Japanese operations of Motorola Inc. "For an American company, it is always going to be especially tough to break in."  G.E.'s Alliance With South Korea  The General Electric Company has been doing its part lately to bring down the trade balance by exporting jet engines, locomotives and power generators. Last week, it made a deal to sell a $400 million communications satellite to South Korea. The Lucky-Goldstar Business Group has agreed to be a partner in the project. G.E. beat British Aerospace P.L.C. for the contract. But it was not just G.E.'s experience that clinched the deal. It also agreed to transfer technology to its South Korean partners -- a promise that some fear might harm G.E. later. The Biggest L.B.O.   The collapsing Soviet Union got its own version of a leveraged buyout. Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of Russia, said last week he had reached an agreement with the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, for Russia -- the largest and richest republic -- to assume the central Government's debt and payroll. The power of the purse -- not to mention the fact that most of the republics have broken with Moscow -- elevates Mr. Yeltsin and downgrades Mr. Gorbachev. By taking over the budget, Mr. Yeltsin also gets control of the ruble. That gives him a lever to use to stabilize prices. The downside risk, as with all L.B.O.'s, is whether Mr. Yeltsin can afford to take on so much debt. Even Japan May Suffer  They are not exactly jumping out of windows, but Tokyo's investors are not a happy lot. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell more than 1 percent on a single day last week and since March has lost 17.3 percent of its value. Companies are also having trouble raising capital -- unusual in Japan. And some investors fear the English-speaking recession (it's hit America, Britain, Canada and Australia) will soon reach Japan. "They are going into a contractionary period," said Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics. Japan's rate of growth "will decelerate from 3 to 6 percent to 0 to 3 percent and cause fiscal problems for the Government," he said. That's slow, but not a recession. "What's happening in Japan is what happened here, but from a higher base," Mr. Weinberg said. Salomon Wins Back Confidence  Last week, after a three-month suspension, Salomon Brothers Inc. said it had won back the World Bank's business. The Bank, as it is called, is the second-largest borrower in the world's financial markets. Its decision was an indication that Warren E. Buffett, the Omaha investor who is Salomon's interim chairman, was succeeding in making the go-go Wall-Street firm more, well, Midwestern. The California Public Employee Retirement System -- the nation's largest -- is considering rescinding its suspension too. If that happens, Solly's rehabilitation may soon be complete. Sweden's Monetary Medicine  Most of the world considers it a bold move when the Federal Reserve raises or lowers the discount rate a quarter of a percentage point. Not in Sweden. Last week, Sweden's central bank increased the rate it charges banks to borrow to 17.5 percent from 11.5 percent -- a six percentage-point jump. COMPANIES **********Wanna Buy a Route? In Cash?   Last week, after its financing deal with Delta Air Lines unraveled, Pan American World Airlines shut down. The airline had been on the verge of extinction for almost a decade, selling off pieces of itself including its New York terminal and signature headquarters building until all that remained was a small domestic operation and some valuable Latin American and Caribbean routes. The routes will go on sale today. But there is one inhibiting factor. Judge Cornelius Blackshear of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District in Manhattan insists that all bids for Pan Am's routes be in cash. That's the one commodity in today's airline business that remains in short supply. Digital Quietly Tends to Business  While the International Business Machines Corporation anguishes in public about its future, the Digital Equipment Corporation, the nation's No. 2 computer maker, continues to plod along. Last week, it unveiled four aggressively priced workstations built on a new, superfast RISC chip -- for reduced instruction set technology. And while I.B.M. and the Microsoft Corporation continue to feud, Digital and Microsoft are doing just fine, thank you. Digital's new boxes will run Microsoft's Windows NT, its newest operating system.  The Days of 3.25% Interest  For those who love 1950's nostalgia, consider this: Citibank, the nation's No. 1, bank, said last week it will lower the interest rate paid on passbook savings accounts to 3.15 percent from 4.34 percent at its Citibank FSB savings and loan in Chicago. That rate has not been around since Cadillacs had fins and blouses had Peter Pan collars.  ECONOMY **********Making Room for New Ideas  Though John Sununu liked to call himself the Administration's "pit bull," many thought of the White House chief of staff, who resigned last week, as more of the monkey on the President's back. A conservative Republican, he helped fashion President Bush's economic strategy. But even conservatives grew to dislike his ideas. "When faced with economic policy failures, he was incapable of admitting mistakes," said Edwin S. Rubenstein, an economist at the conservative National Review magazine. "Holding to the budget agreement the way he did was a mistake -- hubris." Of the new chief of staff, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, Mr. Rubenstein said: "He's tough, not so ideological, but a 'yes' man."  A Sickly G.D.P.  The economy is still struggling to rouse itself from its slump. The Commerce Department said last week that gross domestic product expanded by a slim 1.7 percent in the third quarter. G.D.P. measures the total output of goods and services within America's borders. For an economy emerging from recession, growth is typically in the 6 percent range. "Will there be a double-dip recession?" asked Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities Inc. "No. We'll have slow growth. But a persuasive case can be made for the other side of the argument."  Payrolls Drop; So Do Rates  The unemployment rate held steady in November at 6.8 percent, as expected. But payrolls tumbled by nearly 241,000, the second-largest drop of the year. Payroll statistics are considered more accurate. The drop in payrolls raised the Federal Reserve's level of concern about a possible "double-dip" recession; last week it dropped the Federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other, to 4.5 percent from 4.75.  A Few More Construction Dollars  No, it wasn't an aberration. Construction spending rose 1.0 percent in October, the fourth straight monthly gain and part of the longest string of advances in five years, the Commerce Department said. Despite the gain, spending on construction is still below last year's level. The industry "needs an economic stimulus package, and we need it now," said Mark Tipton, president of the National Association of Home Builders. Manufacturing Peters Out  For months, the manufacturing sector was the lone horse pulling the nation's economic wagon. Domestic and export sales of manufactured goods grew as the rest of the economy languished. But manufacturing lost its snap in November. The National Association of Purchasing Management, which surveys 300 corporate executives on the size of their order books, said its index fell last month to 50.1, from 53.5 in October. A reading of 55 shows expansion, 50 indicates stagnation and below 44 signals recession. "The economy grew perceptively weaker in November," said Robert Bretz, chairman of the association's survey committee. Detroit Is Quick to Rejoice  Ten days of improved sales is not enough to signal an industrywide turnaround. Even so, the numbers sure looked good to Detroit. Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks climbed 20.9 percent in late November, the auto makers said last week. Sales to rental fleets pushed the sales figures higher. Though sales for the entire month were down, Detroit did win back some business from the Japanese. Detroit had 62.3 percent of the market last month, compared with 60.1 percent a year earlier. But before Detroit uncorks the champagne, it should recall that in the 1970's, the General Motors Corporation had 60 percent of the market all to itself.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/06/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; 3-Year Note Yield Lowest Since 1987
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/06/busin.body_text: **********Good demand for a $12.5 billion offering of new three-year notes yesterday in the first part of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions produced the lowest yield on such a security since early 1987. **********At the auction, where demand was as strong as expected, the three-year notes were sold at an average yield of 6.98 percent, down from 7.78 percent at the last three-year note auction on Nov. 6 and the lowest since the sale on Feb. 3, 1987. **********Credit market participants reported that demand from domestic as well as foreign buyers was solid. **********Overseas interest in the securities did not include the Japanese, however. Dealers familiar with the bidding activities of Japanese firms said that while bids of around $3 billion were placed for the new notes, the firms subsequently turned around after the auction and unloaded their positions. 'We Are in the Business' **********"The bids were made to show that we are in the business, and nothing else," a trader at one Japanese firm said yesterday. "This was not an economic decision." **********For the last year or so, high domestic interest rates, smaller current account surpluses and problems in Japanese financial markets have sharply reduced the amount of new funds that Japanese investors are willing to commit to American financial assets like Treasury securities. **********In the secondary market for Treasury securities, prices were narrowly mixed. Note prices dipped slightly after the auction results were announced, but bond prices rose somewhat, and long-term interest rates flirted briefly with 8 percent. **********Despite the success of the three-year note sale, credit market participants said the results showed nothing about how investors would react to offerings today and tomorrow of 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. Indeed, most traders said interest rates on the securities would probably have to move a bit higher from their current levels to insure strong demand. **********"At this point, the Street is asking itself if the market is going to improve further over the next few weeks," a government bond trader said. "Right now, it looks like there will be no news for a while that could help the market. That means yields on the 10's and 30's might need to back up a bit." **********Peter Bass, a managing director at S. G. Warburg & Company, said: "The market will have to get a little bit cheaper, but not a lot, to sell the debt. I think there is decent domestic interest in securities, and that a yield of 7.85 percent for the 10-year and 8.05 for the bonds would attract interest." **********Late yesterday, the new 10-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.82 percent. The 30-year bonds were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 8 percent. No Reaction to Car Figures **********The sense that for the time being traders have already discounted more bad news on the economy was reinforced yesterday when the bond market essentially yawned after the nation's leading car manufacturers reported that sales in the last 10 days of January were a mere 5.4 million units at an annual rate. **********For all of January, car sales were only 5.9 million units, seasonally adjusted. Analysts said it was the first time the monthly total had fallen below six million since January 1987. **********The auto sales figures "suggest a decline in January retail sales of some 1.2 percent," analysts at MMS International, an economic information and service company, said in their daily market commentary. The level is "consistent with a recessionary pullback in consumer spending, they added. **********Auto sales numbers often elicit a reaction in the credit markets, but not so yesterday. **********In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered late yesterday at a price of 108 6/32, up by 7/ 32, to yield 8.02 percent, compared with 8.04 percent late on Monday. Earlier in the session, the bond was offered at a price to yield 8 percent. **********Among note issues, the 7 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered in late trading at 100 13/32, down by 1/32, to yield 7.40 percent. And the price of the 7 percent two-year notes fell by 1/32, to 100 3/8, to yield 6.79 percent. **********Rates on short-term Treasury bills dipped slightly. **********Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.93 percent late yesterday, down by 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a basis point, to a late offered rate of 5.91 percent. **********In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, the Federal Reserve's moves late last week to lower its discount rate and the overnight Federal funds rate generated a strong rally in bank bonds. **********Dealers said yields on outstanding issues of money-center banks like Chemical Bank and Citicorp fell by 50 basis points to a full percentage point. **********The rally in bank bonds was far stronger than what was experienced in the rest of the investment-grade market. Nevertheless, market participants said prices of most corporate bonds rose by a quarter of a point to three-eighths of a point in active trading. **********In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, traders said that a $138 million issue of bonds sold by the Municipal Assistance Corporation for New York City was well received. **********Elsewhere in the municipal bond market, the Massachusetts Health an Education Department sold $150 million in securities for Harvard University in a negotiated deal. **********The issue consists of serial bonds with maturities of 1992 to 2005, and three term bonds. **********Yields on the serial bonds range from 4.85 percent on securities maturing in 1992 to 6.50 percent on those maturing in 2005. **********Term bonds maturing in 2011 and 2015 carried the maximum yield of 6.62 percent. **********B T Securities Inc. acted as lead underwriter for the offering, which is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********In the secondary market for municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely-quoted issues were unchanged to up an eighth of a point. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-year Treasury notes: (000 omitted in dollar figures) Average Price . . . 99.720 Average Yield . . . 6.98% Low Price . . . 99.720 High Yield . . . 6.98% High Price . . . 99.747 Low Yield . . . 6.97% Accepted at low price . . . 61% Total applied for . . . $41,483,080 Accepted . . . $12,647,510 N.Y. applied for . . . $39,145,230 N.Y. accepted . . . $12,040,150 Noncompetitive . . . $769,000 Interest set at . . . 6 7/8% The three-year notes mature Feb. 15, 1994.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/09/busin.body_text: **********The hard times in the airline industry claimed another victim today when Air Europe, a large British carrier, and its parent, the International Leisure Group Ltd., sought bankruptcy protection from creditors and grounded the airline's fleet, stranding 25,000 people. **********And in another sign that airlines expect no quick recovery from the severe downturn gripping the industry, British Airways, Britain's largest airline, said it was withdrawing from five unprofitable routes. It is ending service between Gatwick Airport near London and Stockholm; Barcelona; Karachi, Pakistan; Banjul, Gambia, and Freetown, Sierra Leone. **********British Airways had previously announced that it would withdraw from other routes, make big cuts in its work force and delay the delivery of ordered planes. "Since then, the situation has not improved and we have had to look closely at further uneconomic parts of the route network," Liam Strong, director of marketing and operations at British Airways, said today.   'A Bad Omen' **********Although dwarfed by British Airways, Air Europe expanded quickly and became Britain's second-largest scheduled international carrier. It has a fleet of 37 planes, 2,000 employees and offered scheduled service to 19 destinations in Europe, mostly from Gatwick Airport but also from Manchester. It also offered charter service in Europe and to Orlando, Fla.; North Africa, and East Asia. **********Analysts said Air Europe was in the vanguard of the new airlines trying to exploit the opportunities created by the continuing deregulation of the European airline industry. The market is dominated by a handful of large carriers, most of which are at least partly owned by governments. **********"The financial collapse of Air Europe is a bad omen because what it in effect says is the cost of entering the market is prohibitive," said Richard Whitaker, editor of Airline Business, a trade magazine. "Air Europe offered real competition because it flew head to head with major carriers on major routes like Paris and Brussels and offered cheaper fares." **********Peter Bergius, an analyst at Kleinwort Benson Securities Ltd., commented, "There will be other small airlines that go under or are forced to link with others." A small German carrier, German Wings, went out of business last year and a small British carrier, Dan-Air, is struggling. **********Air Europe was founded in the late 1970's by Harry Goodman, a British entrepreneur who first focused on providing packaged holidays for Britons and then expanded into scheduled service. He hoped that by building a fleet of fuel-efficient planes, Air Europe would be able to capture business from the high-cost European giant airlines that dominate the market. **********He seemed to be well on his way to succeeding. In the year that ended Oct. 31, Air Europe carried 3.7 million scheduled and chartered passengers. **********Mr. Whitaker of Airline Business said Air Europe's scheduled service was similar in quality to that of the big airlines while the fares were about 15 percent less for business-class seats and about 10 percent less in the economy class. **********The packaged holiday companies owned by International Leisure, which include Intasun, Select, Global and Lancaster, are collectively No. 2 in the business in Britain. But the company was pushed into a crisis by the combination of large debt, a sharp decline in the packaged holiday market that began in 1989, and the rise in fuel costs and the plunge in travelers because of the Persian Gulf conflict and the recession in Britain. 'Ran Out of Cash' **********"It turned out to be too much, and they ran out of cash," said Timothy Hayward, head of corporate recovery at KPMG Peat Marwick McLintock, the accounting firm. Mr. Hayward, one of the court-appointed administrators for International Leisure, was pessimistic that the group would survive. He said it was more likely that its parts would be sold and said several airlines, which he declined to identify, had expressed interest. **********Citibank disclosed today that a syndicate of 14 banks that it led had asked the court to appoint an administrative receiver to take control of 12 leased aircraft to cover the group's exposure to International Leisure. Others said the exposure was $315 million, which a banker confirmed. **********Citibank said in a statement that the banks took action only after "we were advised by International Leisure Group that they had not been successful in raising the additional finance required for continuation of its operations." **********Mr. Hayward also said the action by the banks "was not the cause of the company's collapse." **********International Leisure is privately owned and does not regularly release financial figures. It said in its court filing that it had lost $:50 million ($98.3 million) from November through January. Mr. Hayward said the group had total liabilities of $:480 million, of which $:200 million was related to leased planes. Its liabilities exceed its assets by $:15.4 million, he said.  A Long Struggle **********The company was known to have been struggling for a long time and had acknowledged that it was talking with Lloyds Bank and several large shareholders about financial relief. It recently withdrew its applications to offer service to New York, Los Angeles, the Caribbean, Toronto and Vancouver, British Columbia. **********Mr. Goodman seemed to get a reprieve in January, when Lloyds agreed to a plan that would have converted an overdraft of $:50 million into equity. While the conversion has not yet been put into effect, Brian Butler, a Lloyds spokesman, said today's decision to seek bankruptcy protection was not the result of a change of mind by Lloyds. **********"We certainly haven't withdrawn our support in any way at all," Mr. Butler said. "We're disappointed that the company has had to cease operations. We tried to find a way forward and will continue to do so."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/04/world.body_text: **********The European Community decided today to convene a Yugoslav peace conference here beginning on Saturday to try to find a solution to the many conflicts dividing that country. **********The conference, with Lord Carrington of Britain as chairman, would try to begin a two-month arbitration process to give binding decisions on the ethnic and nationality divisions inflaming Yugoslavia. Hans van den Broek, the Dutch Foreign Minister, who now holds the community's presidency, said after today's meeting of the 12 Foreign Ministers, that the leaders of Yugoslavia's six republics, as well as the federal government, had been invited to Saturday's gathering. **********Mr. van den Broek, who has spent much of his time since Slovenia and Croatia declared independence on June 25 in trying to mediate Yugoslavia's conflicts, said he expected all the invited officials to attend on Saturday, but acknowledged that there had been no formal acceptances yet. **********At the same time, Mr. van den Broek said that the European Community, joined by Sweden, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Canada, would begin sending a force of unarmed cease-fire monitors to Croatia Wednesday or Thursday. The monitors, eventually to number 200, would remain in quarters in Zagreb until the cease-fire the community negotiated Monday with the warring parties is actually observed. **********The Dutch Foreign Minister said the monitors' mission would be to investigate reports of cease-fire violations, not to enforce the cease-fire. He said the monitors, operating in civilian clothes under the European Community flag, would only be deployed if the shooting stops. **********Lord Carrington would operate as chairman acting in behalf of the community. He is a former British Foreign Secretary who negotiated the end of white rule in Rhodesia in 1979, leading to the creation of Zimbabwe. He was Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Brussels from 1985 to 1989 and is chairman of Christie's, the auction house. **********The peace conference would create a panel of five judges, three from the community and two from Yugoslavia, to decide on questions submitted by the contending parties. The principles to be followed, the community's statement said, were "No unilateral change of borders by force, protection for the rights of all in Yugoslavia and full account to be taken of all legitimate concerns and legitimate aspirations." **********The community said its nominations to the arbitration panel would be Robert Badinter of France, Aldo Corrasaniti of Italy and Roman Herzog of Germany. At Peace Palace in the Hague **********The conference is to take place at the Peace Palace in the Hague, constructed by Andrew Carnegie in 1913. The Hague was the site of several unsuccessful peace conferences before World War I broke out in 1914. The Peace Palace is now the seat of the International Court of Justice, an arm of the United Nations. **********The community Foreign Ministers are to meet again in Brussels on Friday to examine the situation in Yugoslavia. As levers to influence events in that country the community has a $1.1 billion aid program, currently suspended, promises of further aid if there is peace and the threat of economic sanctions if the fighting continues.                    --------------------       New Battles in Croatia **********ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept. 3 (Special to The New York Times) -- As the European Community announced its plans for a peace conference, new battles erupted today in towns and villages of Croatia. **********In Osijek, a long-besieged village within the heavily Serb region of Croatia, national air force jets screamed overhead and mortar shells fell in the center where Croatian defenders were positioned. The Army's chief of intelligence, Gen. Marko Negovanovic, said in a news conference in Belgrade that four civilians had been killed. In all, officials here claimed that at least 11 lives had been lost in fighting since the cease-fire was signed on Monday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/19/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; 2 U.S. Ships Badly Damaged By Iraqi Mines in Persian Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/19/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; 2 U.S. Ships Badly Damaged By Iraqi Mines in Persian Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/19/world.body_text: **********Two American ships, operating off Kuwait in preparation for an allied ground offensive, struck Iraqi mines today. At the same time, allied land forces stepped up artillery barrages and cut lanes for armored vehicles through the twin sand-and-rock berms that mark the Saudi border with Kuwait. **********The two vessels, the helicopter carrier Tripoli and the guided-missile cruiser Princeton, were engaged in the largest minesweeping effort since the Korean War. Both suffered substantial structural damage, but officials said they remained ready for warfare, and casualties were light. **********Heavy artillery fire and vigorous reconnaissance patrols, reported by allied military spokesmen tonight, precede infantry or armor attacks. Minesweeping operations, which a Saudi official said began along the Kuwaiti coast today, precede ampibious assaults. **********But officials here and in Washington continued to insist that no date has been chosen for a ground offensive to drive Iraqi forces from Kuwait, which they have occupied since Aug. 2. **********As Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi Foreign Minister, headed from Moscow back to Baghdad with a Soviet peace proposal to be presented to President Saddam Hussein on Tuesday, newspapers close to the Saudi royal family warned the allies against what one of them called "unacceptable dillydallying" by the Iraqis. Prince Sultan, the Defense Minister, said the Aziz-Gorbachev meeting would "have no effect on the military situation unless the Iraqi regime follows the correct path" and unconditionally withdraws from Kuwait. **********Brig. Gen. Richard I. Neal, spokesman for the United States command here, tried to discourage speculation that an offensive was imminent. He said that the longer the allies waited, the better shape their assault troops would be in. But other headquarters officers disputed that and said it would be difficult to maintain combat readiness more than a week. **********"The politicians have to realize that you cannot keep soldiers at a fever pitch indefinitely," said the commander of a British armored brigade. "We've finished our practice. The guns are loaded. The troops are on a knife-edge of anticipation. It is time for a quick, positive decision." **********"This week is ideal," an American colonel said. "There's no moon, the tides are right, we're sharp. I expect that we'll get the word from Washington shortly and then hit Saddam with everything that we've got." **********There was every indication that if the allies attack, they plan to penetrate Iraqi territory as well as ousting the Iraqis from Kuwait. Maj. Chris Batchelder of Syracuse, a specialist in military government with the 3d Armored Division, told pool correspondents that such administrations would be set up in all captured areas. **********Allied intelligence believes that the Iraqis' fighting strength has been sapped by a month of ceaseless bombing, which continued today despite unfavorable weather. Brig. Gen. Daniel Gazeau, deputy commander of French ground forces, said the enemy is "very close to the point where it's impossible for him to conduct offensive actions." **********Some bombing missions were canceled and others were diverted to secondary targets because of thick cloud cover, but pilots still managed 2,400 sorties, raising the total reported for the war to 80,000. Included were 870 over Kuwait, 100 against positions of the Republican Guard along the Kuwait-Iraq frontier, and 130 in search of launchers for Scud missiles. **********Sirens sounded in Baghdad during the hours before dawn, and in the suburbs, brilliant fireballs were seen, Western journalists in Iraq said. More heavy raids were carried out on the Iraqi capital during the day, and then tonight, Tomahawk cruise missiles shrieked in from the south, some of them landing near the hotel where foreign journalists are staying.  Flamboyant Rescue Mission **********An American F-16 was shot down over Kuwait, the 21st United States aircraft lost to enemy fire. But a search-and-rescue team composed of helicopters and fighters raced 40 miles behind enemy lines -- into "Indian country," in General Neal's phrase -- and rescued the pilot. **********Even after all the allied air strikes, General Neal conceded, anti-aircraft fire from artillery guns remains very heavy in places. And Group Capt. Niall Irving, the British military spokesman, said that Royal Air Force pilots were spotting a large number of mobile surface-to-air missile sites in Kuwait. **********The Tripoli, an 18,500-ton amphibious assault ship carrying 2,000 marines, is part of a 31-vessel task force operating in the northern end of the Persian Gulf in anticipation of a possible Marine landing. The flagship of a mine countermeasures group, she carries a crew of 680. Four were hurt when a floating mine blew a hole 16 feet by 20 feet in her hull below the waterline. **********General Neal said all four of those hurt had been treated by medics on board. Watertight doors were slammed shut to control flooding. **********"We've encountered a number of mines," Capt. Bruce McEwen told his crew on the Tripoli's closed-circuit television system after the blast at 4:36 A.M., which jarred those on the vessel awake in an instant. **********"The ship is stable," he said. "The ship is at no risk." **********While British and American helicopters circled above, pool reports said, marking other mines with smoke for destruction, the Tripoli sat dead in the water for several hours. Power was later restored, but Captain McEwen said he was not sure that the hull could be repaired in the gulf. **********"We've got two compartments that are completely full, and they're 60 by 50 feet, so we took a lot of water," said Adonis Oldenburg, 19 years old, from Las Vegas, Nev., a damage-control worker and fireman's apprentice. **********An hour after the Tripoli was hit, and about 10 nautical miles away, the two-year-old Princeton was helping to screen the minesweepers. It set off an influence mine, which is detonated by the proximity of a ship. No hole resulted, but one of two propellers was damaged, forcing the vessel to operate at half-power, and a large crack was opened, running from the main deck through two upper decks. **********Two sailors suffered minor injuries and a third incurred a head wound. **********The 9,600-ton Princeton, with a crew of 360, is a Ticonderoga-class cruiser costing more than $1 billion. It is equipped with an Aegis computer-linked radar and missile system for air defense. That system was reported fully operational. **********Not since April 1988 when the American missile frigate Samuel B. Roberts was nearly blown in half by an Iranian mine during the Iran-Iraq war has a United States ship hit a mine in the gulf. More than 80 mines, believed to have been dumped into the gulf by the Iraqis, have been found and destroyed in the last few months, but until today, no allied warship had hit one. **********On the Saudi-Kuwaiti frontier, British artillery opened up on Iraqi targets for the first time. Asked whether that meant an attack was near, Brigadier Rob McAfee of the British Army replied, "I'd rather the Iraqis made their own deductions about that." **********He said that 18 targets had been fired on, with three Iraqi tanks, three guns and three gun positions destroyed. One purpose of the barrage was to "unmask enemy guns," the brigadier said, meaning persuade them to fire and give away their locations. **********British and American tanks appeared to be rolling into position for a concerted attack involving more than three divisions. Bulldozers cut through the berms, and armored reconnaissance vehicles took up positions beside the pathways they created. Markers with arrows and brigade symbols, a British pool report said, have been set up to guide armor.
