https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/24/busin.main_headline: On a Roll, Pepsi Changes Its Face
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; On a Roll, Pepsi Changes Its Face
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/24/busin.body_text: **********Pepsi-Cola unveiled its new face yesterday, a logo that the company hopes will make it seem peppier and younger than its age-old rival. **********The new logo, with streamlined blue letters suspended over what looks like a rolling tri-colored beach ball, comes as Pepsi attempts to press home a series of public relations victories over Coca-Cola intended to capture the attention of the nation's youngest consumers. **********In the world of colas, competition means an ever-changing array of packages and imagery, while the drinks themselves remain very much the same. **********"If you are Pepsi, you want to show that you are up to date, that you are current," said Tom Pirko, the president of Bevmark, a Los Angeles management consulting company that specializes in the beverage industry. "They want Coke to appear to be the cola appealing to older people." **********Many analysts agreed that a logo change for Pepsi, the first since 1973, was probably a good strategic move in appealing to youth. But several others were not so sure that Pepsi's final choice had been a good one. **********Mr. Pirko, for one, said that for all the attention Pepsi was directing at the new logo, it looked much like many corporate designs churned out for other corporations over the years. **********"It looks like United Airlines to me, or I.B.M.," Mr. Pirko said. "The guy sitting next to me on the airplane said that it looks like the Korean flag." **********Part of the thinking behind the new design, Pepsi-Cola officials said, was to link the Pepsi and Diet Pepsi brands more closely on the shelf. **********"For some time, the consumer feedback on Pepsi and Diet Pepsi has been that one is the stepchild of the other," said Hellen Berry, a vice president of marketing with the Beverage Marketing Corporation in New York. "The new layout really links the two together." **********Analysts said that whether consumers were pleased with the new logo was less important than the fact that the logo was new. Younger buyers are attracted to packaging that seems to be on the cutting edge of style, even if the product itself is older than their grandparents. **********The new design, the eighth in the company's 97-year history, comes after Pepsi scored a number of victories with its commercials and marketing campaigns in recent years, at least in the eyes of people in the advertising industry. **********Pepsi's successes include a commercial that features Ray Charles saying "You've got the right one baby, uh-huh," which was lauded by advertising executives as one of the most effective campaigns of recent years. This past summer, Pepsi's "cool cans," incorporating bold designs of surfers, sunglasses and confetti, also proved highly popular. **********Coke, meanwhile, had some notable public relations failures. It had to pull its "magic cans" off the market last year when the cans, which were supposed to offer surprises inside, including money, malfunctioned and caused consumers to complain that the soda tasted bad. Coke also pulled humorous Diet Coke commercials from the Super Bowl, out of fear that they contrasted poorly with the nation's somber mood at the time, with hundreds of thousands of troops in the Persian Gulf. **********More often than not, the Pepsi-Coke battle is won or lost not in the marketplace -- where Pepsi's and Coke's standings have remained relatively unchanged -- but in the rather insular community of advertising executives. But many analysts say the key to growth in coming years will be capturing the loyalty of younger consumers, something Pepsi hopes to do with its new red, white and blue logo. **********"Our assignment was to take Pepsi into the 1990's," said Ronald Peterson, a managing partner at Blyth Associates, the marketing firm that designed the logo. "The fact that the logo is by itself, with an italized face, gives it motion and action. It gives it a much more dynamic look." **********Pepsi sells more soda in supermarkets than Coca-Cola, but Coke has an advantage in overall sales. Coke's share of the market has hovered at about 40 percent over the years, and Pepsi's share has remained about 30 percent. Over the last year, soft drink sales barely grew. **********"The overall soft drink market has been in the doghouse," said Wiliam Leach, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "Pepsi has described itself as 'the choice of a new generation' for a long time. That generation, they are afraid, is like me, approaching 40. They need a new, new generation."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Airbourne Troopers; From Officers to Grunts, Anticipation of Combat
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Airbourne Troopers; From Officers to Grunts, Anticipation of Combat
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/world.body_text: **********"One day, yeah. The next day, no," said Staff Sgt. Wayne O'Neil of the 101st Airborne Division, pondering whether he wanted to end the current relentless bombing of Iraq and begin a ground war. **********"It's time, I'm ready to go home," he said, surveying his universe of a tent, his eight-man unit handling TOW antitank missiles mounted on trucks, and endless wind-blown, rock-strewn sand. **********"Because of the frustration and anger, you'd like to begin the attack," he said. "But that would be stupid on our part. Especially with all the married personnel, we want to go home as safe as possible. Then some days, you say, why not? We're ready, let's take the chance." **********Along the miles of northern Saudi border where the 101st Airborne Division is strung out -- military security regulations preclude giving exact locations or plans -- there is a sense of heightened anticipation and preparation. The mission of the 101st will be to land by helicopter far behind enemy lines, attacking Iraqi troops holding Kuwait from the north. **********Throughout the darkness on Thursday night, the division's helicopters droned overhead. In the first morning light, a long, gray smudge from the night's bombing hung low over the northern horizon. **********But there is little sense of urgency among the soldiers who have already been here for six months, only a quiet, businesslike concentration on specific jobs, with ears continually cocked toward small transistor radios carrying news on Armed Forces Radio and the BBC.  Softening Up the Enemy **********The senior officers say they are happy to have the bombing go on, reducing potential American casualties while cutting down Iraqi military power. **********"Every artillery piece they take out by air is one less I have to worry about," said Lieut. Col. Harlan Lawson, commander of an artillery battalion whose 105-millimeter howitzers will go to battle slung under helicopters. **********Roughly 60 percent of the soldiers in the 101st are married; young privates and corporals with nascent mustaches clip pictures of their children to the sun visors of their boxy-looking vehicles. **********The word here is that at the division's home base, in Fort Campbell, Ky., the traditional rough, male barracks-room life is almost a thing of the past. Instead, top sergeants drop by their younger troops' houses before payday, peeking in the refrigerator to see how the family is managing on Army pay. The division has family support sessions now at Fort Campbell, showing videotapes of the soldiers to their wives. **********Many soldiers here, from low-ranking enlisted men to majors and colonels, have spouses also serving in Saudi Arabia, some careerists, others from reserve units. That nearness is in many ways an additional worry and burden on the troops, especially since, several said, mail from a few hundred miles away is taking many days to arrive. **********About 9 percent of the soldiers in this paratroop division are women, trudging across the sand under Kevlar helmets and armored vests with rifles slung over their shoulders. While some are perimeter security guards, others are helicopter pilots almost certain to see fire in an assault. 'The Square War' **********The prohibition on alcohol and drugs in this strict Islamic kingdom has cut disciplinary problems, said First Sgt. Victor Edwards, "not 90 percent, but 99.9 percent." **********Perhaps as a result, there is a wholesomeness among the soldiers here that has led some to dub this "the square war." The other night, two majors standing in front of a top-secret operations map compared notes on the Boy Scout troops they lead at home. **********This is an army that delights in its new high-tech equipment, particularly the night-vision goggles that turn darkness into an eerie but discernable green light. Lethal weapons are referred to as "systems." Amid a cluster of tents and antennas on a barren rise, Sgt. Donald Stallings of the Signal Corps tends a state-of-the-art, 20-foot satellite communications dish with a range of 25,000 miles. **********In the back of a truck a little way off, Sgt. Maria Marin operated a switchboard with 90 lines that could patch a telephone call into a foxhole. She knew her telephone extensions from memory. **********"You work with it so long," she said. "You don't even have to look at the board anymore." **********Farther along the line, the combat engineers had dug earthworks around their positions and acquired much-envied showers. Like the rest of these complex, self-contained units, the engineers, who will be in the first wave of the invasion, were focused on their specific jobs. **********"Minefields, yes, that's definitely one of the most important of our jobs," Sgt. Lloyd Stanley said. "We'll blow them. But it's when we build the defense line after the assault that our job really gets hard."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/27/busin.main_headline: 2 Southern Banks Discuss Merger To Form the 2d Biggest in the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/27/busin.print_headline: 2 Southern Banks Discuss Merger To Form the 2d Biggest in the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/27/busin.body_text: **********The NCNB Corporation, a fast-growing banking powerhouse from the Southeast, is negotiating to acquire another large Southeastern banking company in what would be the largest merger in American banking history, setting the stage for a decade of consolidation in the troubled industry. **********Directors of the C&S/Sovran Financial Corporation, which itself is the product of a merger last year, could decide as soon as today to accept NCNB's offer to combine and become the nation's second-largest banking organization. Its operations would stretch from the coastal cities of Baltimore and Miami to the oilfields of West Texas, and it would have assets of $116 billion.  Bigger Than BankAmerica **********It would surpass the BankAmerica Corporation, which had $111.9 billion in assets as of March 31. Only Citicorp, with assets of $216.9 billion, would be larger in the United States. **********If NCNB can bring off the deal, it would open a new realm for super-regional banks, which began in the early 1980's as some states opened their borders to interstate acquisitions. **********NCNB, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., has grown rapidly into Florida, and five other states including Texas -- where it wrangled billions of dollars in Federal assistance in 1988 to take over the failed First Republicbank, the state's largest. **********In a decade, Hugh L. McColl Jr., NCNB's fiercely competitive chairman and chief executive, has taken his little-known bank with big ambitions and created a banking behemoth by acquiring a hodgepodge of community banks, failed banks and savings and loans as well as regional institutions. **********NCNB has grown into one of the nation's 10 largest banking companies, has $66 billion in assets, from the North Carolina National Bank with $7.7 billion in assets in 1981. **********In addition to NCNB, other strong regional banking companies include Banc One, of Columbus, Ohio; Fleet/ Norstar, of Providence, R.I.; NBD, of Detroit; Norwest, of Minneapolis and Suntrust, of Atlanta. **********The prospect of an NCNB-C&S/Sovran merger "is potentially a catalytic event for the banking industry," said James J. McDermott, Jr., president of Keefe, Bruyette, Woods Inc., a bank research firm in New York. **********William M. Isaac, the former head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said, "It is enlarging and redefining the emerging super-regional banks." He added that the strong earnings power of regional banking organizations like NCNB allows them to make acquisitions of weaker institutions. **********Many industry experts believe 10 to 15 super-regional banking organizations will emerge before the decade is out, ranging from $100 billion to $200 billion in assets. "We are going to see the banking industry continue to consolidate," Mr. Isaac predicted. **********Banking experts have long anticipated that some hard-charging regional banks would come to rival some of the nation's biggest banks in money centers like New York, Chicago and San Francisco. Word of a possible merger moved C&S/Sovran's stock on the New York Stock Exchange to close as $22.75, up $3.375. NCNB's shares on the Big Board closed at $38.25, up 12.5 cents. **********A person close to NCNB said the deal would be worth almost $4 billion in stock for shareholders of C&S/Sovran. **********A spokesman for C&S/Sovran, which has headquarters in Atlanta and Norfolk, Va., Scott Scredon, said yesterday that the company's chairman and chief executive, Bennett A. Brown, had been authorized to meet with NCNB's Mr. McColl, "to discuss the North Carolina bank's proposal to merge." It said that Mr. Brown would discuss NCNB's offer with the C&S/ Sovran board today. **********In a statement, NCNB confirmed "preliminary and exploratory" discussions between the companies and added it looked forward to continuing the talks. **********Mr. McDermott, the banking analyst, said investors were unconvinced by Wednesday's announcements that NCNB would eventually succeed in adding C&S/Sovran to its growing network. "We are in the early stages," he cautioned. In the past, big bank mergers have hit snags and Mr. McColl's blunt, outspoken style has a reputation for rubbing some people the wrong way. Earlier Takeover Proposal **********C&S/Sovran was forged last year from two regional companies, the Citizens & Southern Corporation, based in Atlanta, and the Sovran Financial Corporation, of Norfolk, Va., after Mr. Brown of Citizens & Southern rejected a hostile takeover offer from NCNB in 1989. **********For NCNB, C&S with or without Sovran had some attractive strategic advantages. Since, 1985, when NCNB bitterly lost out in a bid to acquire a big Atlanta bank, Mr. McColl has been minor player in Georgia and Atlanta where C&S dominates the market and the economy grew robustly in the mid-1980's. **********Now with Sovran, NCNB would get a large franchise in the suburban Washington market. That area is mired in a real estate recession, but Mr. McColl has perceived the region as a lucrative consumer banking market with long-term growth potential. **********Besides Georgia and Washington's suburbs in Maryland and Virginia, a C&S/Sovran deal would include banks in the deal Tennessee, South Carolina, Kentucky, Maryland and Florida.  Problems From Earlier Merger **********For C&S/Sovran, a combination with NCNB may be the best solution for a merger that had its problems. Many C&S/Sovran shareholders have been disappointed with the results. Wall Street analysts faulted company executives earlier this year for moving too slowly to trim payrolls and exploit other cost-cutting opportunities that usually provide the economic appeal for regional banking mergers. **********The company reported a 72 percent drop in earnings in the first quarter along with a jump in nonperforming assets to $1.1 billion, or more than 3 percent of loans outstanding -- an unhealthy level. The recession was a factor, but the main problems included bad loans on several commercial real estate projects in the Washington area. **********The company continues to pay a dividend and has adequate capital, but its stock value has plunged. Mr. Brown, who is 62 years old, postponed his retirement planned for the end of this year and agreed to stay for at least another year.  Change of Attitude Possible **********But some individuals believe that Mr. Brown, who refused in 1989 to meet with NCNB's Mr. McColl, to discuss the earlier takeover offer, is more willing to bargain now because a takeover by NCNB would bring a more rapid payoff for C&S/Sovran shareholders than would be required if the company remained independent. **********John S. Poelker, a financial consultant in Atlanta who worked with Mr. Brown for eight years as president of Citizens & Southern between 1978 and 1986, said the big question facing directors on Thursday will be how fast the company's earnings and stock value can rebound on their own compared with the bid NCNB puts on the table. **********"Clearly, the combination of C&S/ Sovran with NCNB creates a very powerful entity with a lot of resources," Mr. Poelker said. He said C&S/Sovran would require as many as three years before the stock could recover from the recent setbacks. **********A person close to NCNB said Mr. McColl's offer was to exchange each common share of C&S/Sovran for three-quarter share of NCNB stock. C&S/Sovran has 133.4 million common shares outstanding. **********Figured at the closing price Wednesday for NCNB's shares, at $38.25, the deal would be worth $28.69 a share for C&S/Sovran shareholders, a 26 percent premium over C&S/Sovran's closing stock price of $22.75 yesterday on the Big Board. **********In a separate announcement, NCNB said its earnings for the second quarter would fall slightly, to $1.20 to $1.25 a share, compared with $1.26 a share in the corresponding period last year. Profits will be flat or slightly higher than the $1.20 a share earned in the first quarter this year, the company said, with nonperforming loans rising $20 million to $50 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/25/world.main_headline: Baker Asks Asians to Move Warily on New Pacts
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/25/world.print_headline: Baker Asks Asians to Move Warily on New Pacts
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/25/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d urged major Southeast Asian countries today to move cautiously on proposals to create new trade and security alliances that would replace "tried and tested frameworks" involving the United States. **********Speaking at the annual meeting of foreign ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, Mr. Baker appeared to react warily to proposals made at the meeting to create an East Asian trading bloc that did not include the United States, and to begin regular regional meetings on military issues. **********He was also apprehensive about a suggestion that Soviet and Chinese representatives be included in future meetings of Asean, which is made up of Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore and Brunei. **********"We have had a remarkable degree of stability in this region," said Mr. Baker, referring specifically to security cooperation in Southeast Asia. **********"We ought to be careful about changing those arrangements and discarding them for something else unless we're absolutely certain that the something else is better and will work," he said at a news conference.While Mr. Baker received a warm reception this week from the Asean foreign ministers, a central theme of the Kuala Lumpur meeting was that the non-Communist nations of Southeast Asia must integrate their economic and security planning, even if that means asserting more independence from their old ally in Washington. **********Asian diplomats said there was general agreement on the need for closer economic ties within Asean in response to trading blocs being created in Western Europe and in North America, and on the need for new cooperation on military issues in light of the reduced American presence in the region. Not one of the proposals that had most worried American officials was adopted by the Asean foreign ministers at the meeting this week, although all remain under consideration. **********Among them is a Japanese plan for formal regional meetings on defense issues. American officials say they are wary of the proposal because it might weaken a string of bilateral military agreements between the United States and nations in Asia and the Pacific. **********Like the United States, Japan is invited as a "dialogue partner." **********The most serious disagreement between the United States and its Southeast Asian allies at the gathering appeared to center on Myanmar, formerly Burma, and whether economic sanctions should be imposed on that nation to end human rights abuses. **********American and other Western nations have for some time been urging Asean members to use their influence to persuade the Burmese to hand over power to civilians leaders elected last year. **********"We would like to see Asean use whatever influence they have, individually or collectively, in order to move the Burmese Government toward greater respect for human rights, greater respect for political process, freedom for political prisoners," Mr. Baker said. **********Southeast Asian nations have been wary of Western attempts to impose human rights standards on Myanmar, if only because many of their own governments are also subject to criticism about human rights abuses. **********Asean officials said today that the Philippine Foreign Secretary, Raul Manglapus, would soon travel to Myanmar on behalf of the association to discuss human rights. But Asian diplomats at the Kuala Lumpur meeting insisted that Mr. Manglapus's trip was not a response to Western pressure. **********"This will be a cordial meeting between Manglapus and the Burmese," said one diplomat. "We believe that friendly, constructive persuasion -- not bullying -- will be most effective in bringing about change in Burma." **********Several Asean officials drew comparisons this week between the association's policy on Burma and the Bush Administration's policy on China -- continued contact despite concern over human rights violations. **********At the news conference, Mr. Baker said the United States continued to hope for better relations with Vietnam, but that normal relations were not possible until Hanoi helped bring about a settlement in the Cambodian civil war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/01/world.main_headline: China Vows to Stay on the Communist Road
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/01/world.print_headline: China Vows to Stay on the Communist Road
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/01/world.body_text: **********The People's Republic of China began celebrating its 42d anniversary tonight with an acknowledgment that the road to socialism is tortuous, but it pledged to keep going anyway. **********"The glorious history of the People's Republic of China of the past 42 years has proved and will continue to prove that no difficulty can crush or cow the Chinese people," Prime Minister Li Peng declared, in a possible allusion to the collapse of Soviet Communism. **********"No tempest will shake their determination to move along the path of building socialism under the leadership of the Communist Party of China." **********Mr. Li spoke at a National Day reception in the Great Hall of the People. Outside, tens of thousands of Beijing citizens gathered around Tiananmen Square, gazing at festive decorations that included an enormous floral arrangement reading "Socialism Is Good." **********National Day formally falls on Oct. 1 -- the day in 1949 when Mao Zedong declared from the Tiananmen rostrum that the People's Republic had been formed and that "the Chinese people have stood up!" -- but festivities customarily begin the previous evening. **********The authorities have arranged for flags and banners to be put up throughout the capital, but the mood remains relatively somber among the public. Even in the Great Hall, the celebratory banquet was smaller than usual, with officials' saying that this was because of the disastrous flooding that hit eastern China this year. Apparently the leaders thought it inappropriate to overdo the banquet at a time when many people were still homeless from the floods. **********For the first time in recent years, the authorities did not allow foreign journalists to mix with the banquet guests, possibly because correspondents in the past sometimes asked officials questions. The Government has been sharply critical of Western journalists recently and is following a growing number of them. **********Mr. Li, in his speech tonight, pledged that China would "open our door even wider" to the outside world and "accelerate our pace of reform." He also promised to "continue to carry out political restructuring." **********But he did not provide any specifics, and he also said that China would "strengthen the function of dictatorship," presumably over those who oppose Communist Party rule. Apparently in an allusion to the party's disintegration in the Soviet Union, he said, "The road is tortuous, but the future is bright."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/02/busin.main_headline: Cutbacks by Network News Ground Bush's Press Plane
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/02/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Cutbacks by Network News Ground Bush's Press Plane
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/02/busin.body_text: **********In a symbol of the financial retrenchment taking place throughout the network news business, the press plane covering the President of the United States was canceled by the White House for a trip last weekend after the networks significantly reduced their staffing on the Presidential fishing vacation. **********Joe Peyronnin, the vice president of CBS News, called it "a sign of the times in network television." **********The cancellation of the press flight was the latest example of changes and reductions in news coverage at the networks, much of which are coming in reaction to enormous budget deficits rolled up by the news divisions during the war in the Persian Gulf, from both the cost of the coverage and the loss of advertising revenue during special broadcasts. **********Each of the network news divisions has undergone a thorough review of staffing and capital expenditures in the wake of the losses, NBC alone estimated its losses at $55 million. Layoffs of correspondents and other news employees are expected to be announced in the next several weeks, especially at CBS, which is facing companywide budget cuts that one senior network executive said would total $150 million. **********Next week, the networks will begin a monthlong cost-cutting experiment with CNN in pooling camera crews covering the President's daily activities. That pooling will extend to at least some of the President's travel schedule. Although CNN is planning to expand its worldwide coverage, it too is looking for ways to hold down spending. **********The television news organizations decided independently last week that the President's weekend fishing trip to Isla Morada, Fla., could be covered by a greatly reduced staff using a pool crew. That decision indirectly led to the cancellation Friday of the charter flight of reporters that traditionally accompanies the President when he travels out of Washington. A representative of the White House travel office said it was the first time the press plane had been canceled in the 30 years he had helped schedule those flights. **********The three broadcast networks have already cut the size of their news staffs by several hundred people each in the last five years and have reduced the number of their domestic and foreign bureaus. NBC News, for example, which had 1,362 staff members in 1986, is now down to 1,033, despite having more news programs on the air. And ABC, the leading network news division, has closed domestic bureaus in Boston, Chicago and Dallas and foreign bureaus in Frankfurt, Prague and Budapest -- consolidating them into one bureau in Berlin. **********"It's all part of the same picture," Mr. Peyronnin said. "It is all a matter of economically prudent management trying to spend its dollars in a cost-effective way." **********But Steve Friedman, the executive producer of the "NBC Nightly News," said. "We're doing this to save money, yes, but our role is changing, too. We're not in the overall killer-coverage business anymore. We're in the program business." 'One Picture of Bush' **********Mr. Friedman said the networks would increasingly cover stories based on the needs of specific news programs and less as a means of insuring that every event had a separate network presence. "We all had the one picture of Bush fishing in Florida if anybody wanted to use it," Mr. Friedman said. **********Another senior network news executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the trip was not expected to make news. "This was a dog trip anyway," he said. "Nobody wanted to go on it." The executive said the decision to pull back from covering the President's trip was not setting a precedent. **********But Jack Nelson, the Washington bureau chief of The Los Angeles Times, said reporters from print publications who had intended to take the press charter could not do so because, without full network participation, the trip became prohibitively expensive. News organizations pay for the seats on the press plane for their reporter or reporters, but unlike on a commercial airliner, the price per seat depends on the number of passengers. The fewer the passengers, the higher the cost per person.  More Than First Class **********The cost of the press flights has generally averaged out to about 50 percent more than it would cost to fly a commercial flight in first class, Mr. Peyronnin said. He added that the extra cost was used by the White House to set up telephones, copy speeches and perform other general services for the press. **********Sean Walsh, an assistant White House press secretary, said that 70 to 80 journalists typically flew on the press plane that follows the President. Network news employees usually make up close to half that total. **********This past weekend, Mr. Walsh said, the networks had signed up for only eight seats on the plane. Mr. Nelson of The Los Angeles Times said the White House first said the trip cost for each reporter would increase to about $2,000. But as print organizations declined to ride because of the cost, the amount continued to go up, he said, eventally reaching $16,000. At that price all organizations dropped out.  Flew on Commercial Flights **********News organizations then arranged to fly reporters to Florida on commercial flights. The network news organizations also sent additional crews to Florida, some from New York, some from the network's local television stations in Miami. **********Mr. Peyronnin said the networks "are reviewing the costs of everything" in the wake of the war and what he called "changes in the television economy." The networks have all suffered from a soft marketpace for advertising. **********Part of that review of costs, Mr. Peyronnin said, was the fact that the networks have been "all but underwriting the costs of the press planes because we have always assigned so many people to cover the President." **********Mr. Friedman said the shrinking staffs and declining number of bureaus made it "much harder to do the job than it used to be in the old days when we had a complete menu to choose from." He said the new strategy was to fly correspondents to stories.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/busin.main_headline: Mutual Funds; Management Is Asking for a Raise
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/busin.print_headline: Mutual Funds; Management Is Asking for a Raise
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/busin.body_text: **********For many mutual fund investors, 1990 was a losing year. But the fund industry over all pulled through in fine shape, reaching $1 trillion in assets. Now funds want bigger profits for themselves. **********A hot trend among funds is to seek larger management fees. Such fees are collected annually by all funds, even "no load" funds that impose no sales charges, and they come on top of exit fees, redemption fees and other one-time charges. In the last few months, half a dozen fund groups have asked shareholders to approve increases in management and advisory fees. And there is little doubt that other fund groups will follow suit. **********"As more and more groups raise their fees, so will the rest of the industry," said W. Sam Chandoha, a senior vice president with the Shareholder Communications Corporation, a New York proxy solicitation firm. **********In February, shareholders voted down proposed fee increases in three Fidelity funds. But all other recent proposed fee increases passed. T. Rowe Price received increases on five funds in April. Scudder and Seligman also won raises. **********The high approval rate is "unusual, because it's a direct cost to the shareholder," Mr. Chandoha said. Others say the fact that the stock market is near all-time highs makes it easier for funds to push through fee increases. Most funds asking for such increases have argued that their fees were lower than their competitors'. **********John C. Bogle, chairman of the Vanguard Group, thinks the fund industry is already making enough money. He calls the recent round of proposed rises in fees astonishing. Nonetheless, he said: "It's up to the shareholders. If they don't have the gumption to vote against them, it's their problem." Government regulation prevents funds from raising fees unilaterally. **********Industry observers cite a variety of factors propelling fees upward. For one, courts have shown no inclination to limit the fees funds can collect. In a closely watched case, an investor in the Franklin U.S. Government Securities Fund sued, saying the fees to manage the fund were too high. The judge found Franklin was earning an after-tax profit of 35 percent but concluded that was a fair return.  In late March, a Federal appeals court affirmed the decision. **********The push to increase recurring management fees comes as one-time charges are under siege. Last fall, the National Association of Securities Dealers proposed a rule that would cap the crazy mix of up-front sales loads, exit fees and 12b-1 plans, which pay certain marketing expenses, at 7.25 percent, or 6.25 percent for funds that also charge an annual "shareholder servicing fee" of a quarter of 1 percent, the maximum allowed. Last month, the Securities and Exchange Commission, which must approve the proposal, asked for public comment. **********At the same time, several funds are reducing up-front sales charges. The Oppenheimer group just replaced its 8.5 percent sales load with 5.75 percent fees. In the last year or so, Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, American and Putnam all reduced many up-front charges. **********To some industry observers, it is a clear case of giving with one hand and taking back with the other. Because most investors focus on sales charges, funds are inclined to raise fees "in an area where no one is paying attention," said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc., a Chicago-based mutual fund consulting firm. **********Others suggest that increases in management fees are aimed at compensating the funds for the loss of revenue that will result when the N.A.S.D. fee caps are imposed. In some cases, the 12b-1 fees pay the salespeople who pitch the funds while management fees are used to pay the fund's adviser. But in many cases, one company owns both the fund's distributor and its adviser, so money from both sources ends up in one pocket. **********Oddly, as the N.A.S.D. and the S.E.C. review proposals to force funds to lower fees, the handful of states that had set caps on total expenses that can be charged on funds have dropped them amid industry lobbying. **********That clears the way for higher management fees, "a strategy that fund advisors can take to boost shrinking margins," said Carl Frischling, a New York lawyer who specializes in mutual funds. **********There is no doubt that margins are being squeezed. Before the 1987 market crash, pretax margins on publicly traded fund companies ranged from 40 to 45 percent, said Dean P. Eberling, an industry analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers. That has dropped to roughly 30 percent. **********Others insist that fee increases are just a question of catching up for older funds. Many of the 3,000-plus funds are relatively new, and were set up with high management fees. **********Meanwhile, competitive pressures in the industry are intensifying. Investors are demanding better service. The technology and support needed are increasingly costly. **********So despite the push to increase margins, some of the new money is likely to flow back into the funds. A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services, said, "I think that -- whether the funds know it or not -- they won't be able to take cash out of the business at the same rate as before, if they want to maintain their market share."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/06/busin.main_headline: McDonnell Has Loss and Cuts Payout
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY EARNINGS; McDonnell Has Loss and Cuts Payout
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/06/busin.body_text: **********The McDonnell Douglas Corporation lost $1 million in the fourth quarter and slashed its stock dividend for the first time in recent memory, company officials said today. **********The loss was expected, but the halving of the dividend to be paid to stockholders in April, to 35 cents from 70.5 cents, surprised some Wall Street analysts. **********The cut will save the struggling aerospace giant $13.6 million over the first three months of the year. **********"It's a painful action for the company and shareholders, but hopefully it will convince everyone that there's a commitment to change," said Howard Rubel, an analyst with C. J. Lawrence in New York. **********Andrew Wilson, a spokesman for McDonnell, which is based here, said the company's quarterly dividend had not been cut for at least two decades "and maybe never." He did not have records that would indicate whether it had been cut before the 1970's. Stock Declines **********McDonnell Douglas stock closed down 62.5 cents, to $40.125, on the New York Stock Exchange today. **********The loss in the final quarter, which ended on Dec. 31, resulted from a $350 million write-off because of last month's cancellation of the A-12 Avenger program by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. He stopped the development of the plane, a carrier-based jet for the Navy, because of cost overruns and delays. **********The cancellation led to 5,600 layoffs at McDonnell Douglas, which had already laid off 15,000 employees in 1990 as part of a cost-cutting program. **********The Pentagon wants to recover $1.9 billion from McDonnell Douglas and the General Dynamics Corporation, its partner in the A-12 program, because of the cancellation. Both companies are opposing that effort. **********The company said today in a prepared statement that if "the courts ultimately determine that the contract was properly terminated for default, McDonnell Douglas would have a substantial additional loss beyond the provision announced today." **********McDonnell Douglas makes the F-15 Eagle for the Air Force, the FA-18 jet for the Navy and the AV8B-Harrier for the Marines. It also makes Tomahawk cruise missiles for the Navy. All of these are being used in the Persian Gulf war. **********The company is also the world's second-biggest maker of commercial aircraft, after the Boeing Company. **********The loss in the last quarter was in contrast to a profit of $60 million, or $1.56 a share, a year earlier. Sales of $4.13 billion in the quarter were down a bit from $4.3 billion a year ago. Last Loss in '89 **********The last time McDonnell had a quarterly loss was in the second quarter of 1989, when the company lost $48 million, Mr. Wilson said. **********For the year, McDonnell reported a profit of $306 million, or $7.99 a share, up 39.7 percent from $219 million, or $5.72 a share, in 1989. **********The 1990 figure was swollen by a one-time net gain of $99 million after adding in a $376 million after-tax gain for some changes in the McDonnell pension fund and subtracting a $277 million after-tax write-off for the A-12 and the C-17 programs. Without that gain, profits for the year would have fallen 5 percent. **********Sales for the year came to $16.26 billion, up 11.4 percent from $14.59 billion a year earlier. **********Analysts said they thought some of the problems that have plagued McDonnell Douglas for the last two years were being solved. **********"As we look to 1991, there appears to be daylight on some of the nagging issues," said Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst for UBS Securities in New York. "There are uncertainties to be sure, but things are not as bleak as they could be."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/05/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Chip Estimate Cut By NEC Officials
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/05/busin.body_text: **********The NEC Corporation, one of Japan's top makers of computers and semiconductors, lowered its estimate for production of its most sophisticated computer chips because of weak demand. NEC officials said the company had expected production of four-megabit dynamic random access memory chips to reach about four million a month by this summer. But they said output was now expected to hover around three million a month. **********Company executives explained that an economic slowdown in the United States and Europe had chilled the demand for computers and other advanced electronic products using four-megabit chips, the most sophisticated now available on the market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/04/busin.main_headline: Are Insurers Overly Risky? New Rules Aim to Find Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/04/busin.print_headline: Are Insurers Overly Risky? New Rules Aim to Find Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/04/busin.body_text: **********Amid deepening public concern over the health of insurers, a new regulation now taking effect may help separate the financially strong from the shaky. **********The rule will require nearly all insurance companies for the first time to have their financial condition reviewed annually by an actuary -- a highly trained industry statistician -- to determine whether the insurer has enough money to pay claims and meet other financial obligations. If a company seemed weak, policyholders could get refunds of their unused premiums, and regulators could take remedial action before the insurer became insolvent. **********Life insurers already face this requirement, and state regulators are extending the rule to property and casualty insurers, which had been free to set thier financial reserves at whatever level they felt appropriate. **********The new rule is the latest attempt by insurance regulators to shore up an industry that has been buffeted by slumping commercial real estate values, plummeting prices for "junk bonds" and rapidly rising jury awards. Hard-hit insurers have been failing at an increasing rate, leaving many policyholders without coverage when they made a claim. **********Still, critics note that the new rule does not require an insurer to have an independent actuary certify whether its reserves are adequate. In fact, the actuary could be an employee. **********While the certification requirement should give consumers extra protection, it may well come at an extra cost. Right now, only midsized and giant insurers like Aetna, State Farm and Metropolitan Life, employ actuaries full time. Thousands of small companies, many of them family operated, will have to hire outside actuaries. That means their policyholders will probably end up paying that extra cost through higher premiums. **********The regulation, which was adopted by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners and cleared by state legislatures where necessary. covers property and casualty companies, which insure against a wide range of loss, including theft, fire and vandalism. Millions of the cars, homes and other property of millions of Americans are insured by these companies. Such companies also provide payments to injured employees through workers' compensation policies and cover industrial plants and equipment against loss. 'Early Warning System' **********"You are not going to eliminate fraud or mismanagement," said James J. Murphy, executive vice president of the American Academy of Actuaries, the actuarial profession's trade group. "But better monitoring by a responsible professional, such as an actuary, should give us a better early warning system." **********For property and casualty companies, the rule takes effect with their 1990 annual statements, which they are currently filing with state insurance commissioners. **********Advocates of the rules hope that policyholders will read an actuary's opinion in the insurer's annual report to see if an insurer has the financial wherewithal to pay probable claims. Based on this picture, policyholders could decide if they wanted to stay with that company or take their business elsewhere. Industry experts hope that at a minimum, the provision will limit policyholder losses if a company does become bankrupt. **********It is also hoped that the rule will slow the growth of many insurers because the amount of coverage an insurer may write in a year is tied to its reserves and capital base. The aim is to guard against runaway growth, which some experts fear could lead to a breakdown in financial controls. **********Finally, the new rule could lead many insurers to set premiums at a higher, healthier level as a means of bolstering their capital. **********Because individual states are responsible for regulating insurance, though they often coordinate their rules, the new rule actually takes the form of 50 individual state laws. The fact that property and casualty insurers were not subject to the same tougher financial oversight that applies to life insurers had left the public vulnerable and regulators with a big gap in their supervision. **********"You could buy a property policy, you could pay the premium at the beginning of the year, and six months later that insurer could be gone," said Stephen P. Lowe, a specialist in insurance company reserves at Tillinghast, an actuarial consulting firm. **********Given the freedom to set their own level of reserves, many insurers greatly underestimated their obligations. Tillinghast studied 53 large insurers recently. It found that the $13.2 billion in reserves the companies had set aside by Dec. 31, 1984, were 20 percent too low by the end of 1987, based on the payouts the insurers had made. Over the 10 years ended 1986, Tillinghast said, the reserves of the same 53 insurers were too low each year by between 10 and 25 percent. **********"If you don't stop an imprudent insurer fast enough, it can dig itself into a deeper hole," said Michael Walter, former president of the Casualty Actuarial Society, an organization for property and casualty actuaries. **********The new rule is already causing changes. Mr. Lowe said Tillinghast had told several clients to bolster their reserves after the actuaries conducted reviews. In the case of one midsized insurer, which he declined to identify, the company's net worth was cut in half before the actuary agreed to issue a favorable opinion. That insurer, which thought it would report a large profit for 1990, will report break-even results. Other actuarial consultants report similar experiences. **********While supporters of the new law view it as a boon to consumers, some experts point out problems. **********For example, unlike the certified public accountants who render opinions on the financial statements of public companies, the actuaries giving opinions on insurance company reserves will not have to be independent. The actuaries can even be on the payrolls of the insurance companies they are studying. That means an actuary working inside an insurance company could be pressured to render a favorable opinion. **********Actuarial profession officials argue that any actuary found to have compromised an opinion would be expelled from the field, but others acknowledge that the risk remains. Laws now being considered in several states would require that an independent actuary be appointed by the insurer's board of directors and that any insurer that changed actuaries report the change to its state insurance commissioner. **********The cost to some insurance companies could be substantial. **********"If you are only making $500,000 a year in profit, I am not sure you can afford another $5,000 in consulting fees," said Armand DePalo, chief actuary of the Guardian Mutual Life Insurance Company.  Reserve Weakness **********As the number of insurance company insolvencies rose in recent years, industry experts have increasingly blamed inadequate reserves. A report last year by the House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations titled "Failed Promises" chronicled how five large property and casualty insurers became insolvent in the 1980's, leaving policyholders with substantial losses. The subcommittee identified insufficient reserves as a reason for the failures. **********"I have seen company managements that are extemely capable in running their businesses fall down in this area," said Mr. Lowe of Tillinghast. "Reserve-setting has been an Achilles' heel of insurers, particularly smaller ones." **********The old approach to setting reserves was inconsistent and made it hard for consumers to compare the financial strength of insurance companies. Management could make a company seem healthier by understating reserves. Understating reserves also helped bolster profits, since every dollar increase in an insurer's reserve cuts net income by an equal amount. **********But even actuaries warn against expecting too much from the new rules, given other pressures faced by insurers, like court orders to pay for pollution or asbestos cleanups. **********"There are simply too many unknowns and there is too much risk involved for even a skilled actuary to say with great certainty what an insurer's final payments will be," said Mavis Walters, president of the American Academy of Actuaries. "This is all a step in the right direction. But whether it will reduce insolvencies is anybody's guess."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/busin.body_text: **********National Health Laboratories Inc., a unit of Revlon Inc., said yesterday that it planned to sell 40 million shares to the public, which would raise $700 million at yesterday's market price. **********The sale will give Revlon even more money to reduce its debt. On Wednesday it announced the sale of Max Factor and other cosmetics lines to the Procter & Gamble Company for $1.14 billion. **********Revlon's stake in National Health will fall to 42 percent, from 82 percent, when the sale is completed and Revlon will have about 42 million of the 100 million shares outstanding. **********Paul W. Shaum, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. who follows Revlon, said the Max Factor sale gave Revlon nearly enough money to pay off its bank debt due through 1994. **********"In a very real sense, this National Health sale was unnecessary," Mr. Shaum said. "Revlon is now way ahead in its amortization schedule" for paying back debt. He speculated that Revlon's chairman, Ronald O. Perelman, was "just taking advantage of current market conditions," meaning a recent demand for new issues. **********In over-the-counter trading yesterday, National Health closed at 17 1/2, up 1 1/8. Revlon is privately held. **********National Health, a provider of clinical diagnostic laboratory services, reported first-quarter earnings of $24.5 million, or 25 cents a share, up 23.1 percent from $19.9 million, or 20 cents, a year earlier. Quarterly sales rose 16.2 percent, to $141.9 million, from $122.1 million a year before.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/19/busin.body_text: **********The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment insurance rose slightly in the latest week, the Government said today, but economists said the overall employment picture continued to brighten. **********The Labor Department reported that first-time applications for state unemployment benefits rose to 395,000 for the week that ended July 6, from 388,000 the previous week, when the number of claims was at a nine-month low. **********The increase was the first since the week that ended June 8, when new claims rose by 47,000. But economists linked the latest increase to special factors tied to the start of the third quarter and said the figures did not change their outlook for a gradual improvement in the labor market and economy. **********While the jobless claims figures jump from week to week, the four-week moving average, which tends to smooth out special factors, has continued to fall. In the latest report, the average fell to 409,250, from 422,500 in the prior four-week period. **********"This is the ninth consecutive week the moving average has declined," said Douglas Schindewolf, economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. He also noted the average had fallen in 14 of the last 15 weeks. **********The unemployment rate was at 7 percent in June, compared with 5.3 percent a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.main_headline: British Feel Pinch as Dollars Stay Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: LONDON; British Feel Pinch as Dollars Stay Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.body_text: **********With Americans and other business travelers staying home in large numbers because of the war with Iraq, some London hotels and shops say that they are having a terrible time. **********"The 15th of January was two deadlines -- one for Saddam Hussein and one for us," said Olivier Louis, executive assistant manager of Le Meridien Hotel in London. "The second week of January was better for us than last year. It was a rush to beat the deadline. Now occupancies in all of the West End five-star hotels are down 15 to 20 percent."  Travelers 'Just Aren't Coming' **********Paul E. Cuss, chief cutter at the Turnbull & Asser shirtmakers on Jermyn Street, looked around his deserted store and said: "Business has dropped right off in the past 10 days. The business travelers just aren't coming over." American business customers for his custom-made shirts, which start at the equivalent of about $150 apiece, normally account for a considerable part of his trade, Mr. Cuss said. **********A spokeswoman for the Savoy Hotel said occupancy was down about 15 percent because American travel was off, and British Airways said passenger traffic had fallen by 8 percent in the first week of the war. **********Americans seem to be the travelers most spooked by the threat of terrorist retaliation for the American-led war in the gulf. **********"There are a lot of members who are just not flying, and companies that were scheduled to have meetings with British contacts this month have just decided not to fly," said Mara Papatheodorou, a spokeswoman for the American Chamber of Commerce in England. "It's either being done by phone or fax, or postponed."  Americans Decline to Travel **********Other British observers are less than impressed. **********"There's something about the Americans that differs wildly from me and thee," Vicki Woods wrote in this week's issue of The Spectator. "My neighbor the headhunter was due to hold his annual board meeting in Frankfurt. He had to cancel it when the American contingent squealed about traveling to Europe." **********"Americans are scared of living and scared of dying," Ms. Woods philosophized. "How does a nation like this ever raise an army?" **********But Americans are not the only ones who are frightened, apparently. Heathrow Airport's main terminal for British Airways flights from other European countries was virtually deserted on Monday evening. **********Mr. Louis said American business travelers, who normally make up 40 percent of his hotel's clientele this time of year, now only make up 25 to 30 percent.

"Wholesale prices to retailers have been dropping," said Trilby Lundberg, an industry analyst, "and this has allowed retailers to cut prices to consumers in order to chase sales."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/busin.body_text: **********The South Korean Government plans to provide $2.1 billion in grants and loans in the next five years to help finance industries' development of manufacturing technology, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today. **********The plan was outlined n a report submitted to President Roh Tae Woo. **********Officials said 919 technology-development projects would be assigned to Korean manufacturing companies, yet to be selected, under the plan, which begins this year. **********They said the Government had decided to give priority to revitalizing manufacturing industries through development of technology so that the nation's sagging exports could regain lost competitiveness. **********South Korea lags behind industrialized nations in high technology for electronics, new materials, bio-engineering and aerospace. **********Officials said about 20 percent of the money would come in official grants, with the remainder in loans with interest rates of 8 percent to 9 percent a year. Bank loans here now carry an annual interest rate of about 12 percent. **********They said South Korea would seek 7 joint research projects with Japan and would cooperate with the Soviet Union on 350 projects, mostly for technology transfer to Korea. They did not say what areas would be involved.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/04/world.main_headline: Liberian Says Vote Will Put End to Civil War
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/04/world.print_headline: Liberian Says Vote Will Put End to Civil War
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/04/world.body_text: **********Amos Sawyer, President of the interim Government of Liberia, announced today that Liberians had agreed on a strategy to settle the two-year-old civil war through "free and fair elections under international supervision." **********He expressed the hope that elections could be held in six to nine months. **********In an emotional declaration to the General Assembly, Dr. Sawyer apologized that his country had become West Africa's "problem child" and emphasized that "our nation would have perished" without the support of the Economic Community of the West African States. Noting, however, that regional assistance was limited, he appealed to the United Nations and its agencies for technical and financial help. **********A number of delegates from widely different regions spoke hopefully about the favorable atmosphere for resolving long-term crises and the new opportunities for the United Nations in this process. Ministers from Ivory Coast, Morocco, Guinea, Mozambique, Bulgaria and Mongolia all spoke of an improvement in international relations with the end of the cold war and the need to develop the role of the United Nations. Universal Aid Is Urged **********A grim note was sounded by the Moroccan Foreign Minister, Abdellatif Filali, who said that the greatly improved East-West relations had not generated any improvement in the "deplorable conditions" in which the overwhelming majority of people lived. He stressed that the international organization must help shape a new world order, providing for the social and economic development of all countries. **********Foreign Minister Viktor Vulkov of Bulgaria called "particularly encouraging" the growing role of the United Nations in keeping international peace and security and cited the Security Council's resolutions on the restoration of Kuwait's sovereignty. He also spoke of favorable prospects for early and peaceful solutions, under United Nations auspices, to other international issues like Cyprus, Cambodia, Afghanistan and Western Sahara. **********Also highlighting the current "dynamic of detente," Amara Essy, the Foreign Minister of Ivory Coast, noted the favorable prospects for a resolution of the 16-year-old conflict in Angola and the conflicts that have long plagued the Middle East. **********The delegate from Ivory Coast, which heads the five-nation West African mediating committee on Liberia, outlined recent regional efforts that led to the agreement last month for disarming the warring Liberian forces.  He noted that his country alone had received about 320,000 Liberian refugees and, with the help of the United Nations High Commission for Refugees, is trying to assist them **********Guinea, another neighbor of Liberia, has taken in 500,000 Liberian refugees, according to Zainoul Abidine Sanoussi, Guinea's permanent representative. He delivered an urgent appeal to the international community for medium and long term assistance for the Liberian refugees and the countries providing them a safe haven.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; King Broadcasting's TV Asset Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/02/busin.body_text: **********The King Broadcasting Company agreed today to sell its six television stations and 13 cable systems to the Providence Journal Company and its joint-venture partner, Kelso & Company. **********No price was disclosed for the television and cable operations, which represent about 85 percent of King Broadcasting. **********Steven A. Clifford, King's chief executive, said the rest of King's assets, -- six radio stations and a mobile telephone company, would be sold to other buyers. **********Last August, Priscilla Bullitt Collins, King's chairwoman, and her sister, Harriet Stimson Bullitt, announced the company was for sale and suggested it might be worth an estimated $650 million. The women, the company's controlling shareholders, also said about $100 million of the proceeds would be used to finance environmental causes. **********"During the time the company has been for sale, the economy has not been helpful." Mrs. Collins said. **********The company was founded in 1946 by Dorothy Bullitt, the women's mother, who died in 1989 at the age of 97. She was active in company mangement until her death and left most of her estate to the Bullitt Foundation. **********The company's six television stations are in Seattle and Spokane, Wash.; Portland, Ore.; Boise and Twin Falls, Idaho, and Honolulu. The cable division has more than 200,000 subscribers in Washington, Idaho, Minnesota and California. **********Stephen Hamblett, Providence Journal's chairman and publisher of The Providence Journal newspaper, said, "If we are successful in acquiring King Broadcasting, we will operate King in a manner consistent with the philosophy with which it has been operated by the Bullitts." **********Bishop Cheen, a senior analyst at Paul Kagan Associates of Carmel, Calif., said the deal was a good fit because Providence Journal "knows how to run a medium-size market broadcasting operation." He added that Providence Journal was flush with cash and had avoided a large amount of debt. **********Providence Journal, a diversified communications company based in Providence, R.I., was founded in 1829. **********The company's four television stations are in Tucson, Ariz.; Albuquerque, N.M.; Louisville, Ky., and Charlotte, N.C. It also owns a cable television company, Colony Communications, with more than 500,000 subscribers in New York, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Florida and California.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/10/world.body_text: **********Israel and its Arab neighbors prepared to reopen direct peace talks on Tuesday with the Palestinian delegation under growing pressure either to win quick concessions from Israel or to place conditions on future negotiations that the Israelis would certainly reject. **********Parties on all sides engaged in a final public-relations blitz today, with the joint Jordan-Palestinian delegation insisting that it would send two teams to the State Department on Tuesday -- one to negotiate with Israel on Jordanian matters, and a second to deal exclusively with Palestinian issues. **********Although the Palestinian negotiators are officialy part of Jordan's delegation, they have sought from the start of the talks to establish a separate identity that would force Israel to confront their desire for independence head on. **********Israeli officials said today that the Israel-Jordan part of the talks could not be conducted by subcommittees without the agreement of both sides, but appeared to leave open the prospect that such an accord could be reached on Tuesday.  Demand by U.S.-Arab Group **********In a news conference here today, one Palestinian-American group demanded that the Palestinian delegation boycott negotiations until Israel halts its settlements in the occupied territories and guarantees that the talks will lead to the establishment of an independent Palestinian state. **********The group, Palestinian Americans for Peace and Justice, presented the Palestinian delegation with petitions asking it "to stand firm in the face of Israeli abuses and pressure from the U.S. Administration" to accede to Israel's conditions for peace. **********That group is but a tiny bystander in the sprawling and complex negotiations now under way, but its sentiments mirror those of thousands of Palestinians in Israel and nearby Arab states who are intensely watching the moves that the delegation makes in the talks. **********Many of them feel excluded from a role in the negotiations. At Israel's insistence, the 14-member Palestinian delegation includes only those who live in the occupied territories of the West Bank or Gaza, although a "shadow delegation" includes some Palestinians from Jerusalem. Issue of P.L.O. Role **********The head of the Palestinian delegation, a Gaza doctor named Haidar Abdel-Shafi, said today that the delegates would give serious thought to the Palestinian-American group's demands, as well as to a third request that the delegation declare itself to represent the Palestine Liberation Organization formally. **********"If we find our cause needs to be corrected, I shall do my utmost," said Dr. Abel-Shafie, who was a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization's first executive committee in the mid-1970's. **********But despite that show of concern, the moderate Palestinian delegates -- pragmatists whose immediate hope is to win self-rule for Palestinians in the occupied territories -- realize that to make such demands would torpedo the already stormy talks, outside experts said. **********Israel has rejected outright any proposal to convert the occupied lands into a separate Palestinian state, and it conditioned its own participation in the talks on the absence of any P.L.O. members in the Arab delegations. **********Rather, the Palestinian negotiators are under growing pressure to come away from the talks soon with a prize to show supporters, proof that it can negotiate seriously and productively with the Israelis. **********"The delegates know that if they accept any of those sorts of conditions, the talks are over," said Robert Satloff, deputy director of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, a research institute that is closely following the negotiations. "They have a higher goal, and their goal is an agreement on self-government." Hard-Liners Object **********The delegation's negotiating position is that Israel should grant Palestinians in the occupied lands some form of self-government as a step toward the creation of an independent state. But even that goal is not acceptable, at least publicly, to the harder-line Palestinians who are not represented in the talks and who are demanding the quick establishment of a Palestinian state. **********With the support of P.L.O. leaders, including the organization's chairman, Yasir Arafat, they are beginning to attack the moderates for making too many concessions to Israel to get to the negotiating table, and getting nothing in return. **********Anan Ameri, a member of the Palestine National Council who appeared at the news conference today, said that "in four, five, six years of self-rule" in the occupied territories that the negotiators are proposing, "nothing will be left" for Palestinians because of continued Israeli settlements. **********Mr. Arafat staked out the same position in an interview on Nov. 15 with the Egyptian magazine Al Musawwar. "I have never agreed to self-rule, not even transitionally," he said. That and related proposals to make a transition to independence for Palestinians, he said "are Israeli ideas that we will not accept even if the Americans do."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.main_headline: Prudential Names Head Of Retail Securities Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Prudential Names Head Of Retail Securities Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.body_text: **********George A. Murray gave Hardwick Simmons his first job as a management trainee at Hayden, Stone Inc. 25 years ago, not long after Wick Simmons was graduated from the Harvard Business School. **********Mr. Simmons, the recently appointed chief executive of the Prudential Securities Group, returned the favor yesterday, announcing that he had chosen Mr. Murray to head Prudential's retail brokerage operations. **********Mr. Murray, 60 years old, a senior executive vice president in charge of strategic planning for Shearson Lehman Brothers' retail operations, is joining Prudential as it is placing major emphasis on its network of 6,000 brokers. Prudential, based in Wilmington, Del., reported a $100 million profit for the first half of 1991, after a $259 million loss in last year's Wall Street slump. **********In a memorandum to employees announcing the appointment yesterday, Mr. Simmons, 51 years old, took note of Mr. Murray's 35 years in the securities business where, he said, "George has held almost every key retail management position." **********After graduating from Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Me., Mr. Murray became a trainee at Merrill Lynch in 1955. He joined Hayden, Stone in 1959, rising on the retail side as branch manager, sales and marketing director and divisional officer. He was named an executive vice president in 1968 and was president briefly in 1970, leaving the firm after Hayden, Stone merged with Cogan Berlind Weill and Leavitt later that year. After a further series of mergers, the firm became Shearson Hayden, Stone in 1974. **********Mr. Simmons also made his mark in retailing with Hayden, Stone and with Shearson, where he headed the retailing group from 1983 until his resignation last year. Mr. Simmons joined Prudential as chief executive three months ago, succeeding George L. Ball. **********After Mr. Murray left Hayden, Stone, he was a vice president with Dillon, Read & Company, the investment banking firm, and then became chief operating officer of Dominick & Dominick, a brokerage firm, in 1973. He rejoined Shearson Hayden, Stone in 1975 in a series of executive jobs in retailing and strategic planning. He took early retirement from Shearson Lehman Brothers in August 1988 but returned in April 1990 as a senior executive vice president. Mr. Murray and his wife, the former Trudy Rollins, have seven adult children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/16/world.main_headline: Paris Journal; If the Old Party's Dying, There's Life in the Fair
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/16/world.print_headline: Paris Journal; If the Old Party's Dying, There's Life in the Fair
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/16/world.body_text: **********By the time word arrived from Moscow that the party was over, the dates had been fixed, the invitations printed and the musicians hired. So French Communists went ahead with their annual festival here this weekend as if they still had something to celebrate. **********There were bumper cars and other rides for the young, and scores of stands serving sausages, pates, wine and beer for others. Music blared from four stages and there were even a few tents given over to intense debates about everything from unemployment to immigration. **********There was also a speech from the perennial French Communist leader, Georges Marchais, who expressed sadness that the Soviet Union was borrowing the recipes of "the most savage capitalism," but insisted, "We carry the name 'Communist' with pride and see no reason to renounce it." **********And as in previous years, the crowds -- perhaps as many as a half-million people in two days -- flocked to La Courneuve Park outside Paris for what is known as the Fete de L'Humanite, so named because it is organized by the party's official newspaper, L'Humanite.  On the Slide for 15 Years **********Yet even the turnout could not shake the gloom of many Communists. "People said this could be the last Fete de L'Humanite, that the end of Communism has come," Guy Poussy, a member of the party's Central Committee, said, "so a lot of people may have come to look at an endangered species." **********The collapse of the Soviet Communist Party, however, is only the latest setback. Once one of the strongest in Western Europe, the French Communist Party has been on the slide for the last 15 years, as much a victim of France's prosperity as of its own failure to shake off its Stalinist past. **********From 1945 until the mid-1970's, the party routinely won 20 to 25 percent of the vote. By 1981 it was down to 16 percent, in 1988 it won only 11 percent and today polls give it 7 percent. No less dismaying, many former Communist supporters have switched their sympathy to the far-right National Front. **********"We have to rebuild people's faith in themselves," Mr. Poussy went on. "We have to involve the country's youth because there's a lot of despair. We have four million youths with terrible education and no hope of finding a job. There must be an alternative." **********Yet at the weekend fair, most young people barely glanced at stands decorated with the hammer and sickle as they headed for the fairground attractions or the daylong rock concerts. "I'm not interested in politics," said a 20-year-old called Paul. "I've just come to see my friends."  'Our Ideas Remain Valid' **********As the crowds swirled by, party loyalists with clipboards and membership forms tried to get passers-by to sign up, but only a handful even stopped to chat. "One young man said he could never join the Soviet party but would give it a try here," one recruiter, Dominique Rethore, said. **********Many older people, in contrast, showed up because, they said, it was more important than ever to show their colors. "The fascists have taken over in Moscow, but they won't last," Vicent Nickrass, a 61-year-old retiree from Somme, proclaimed confidently. "The Communists remain Communists and they know what to do." **********Jean-Louis Fernandez, a gray-haired worker from a Paris suburb, said he would continue to vote Communist but admitted he was "a bit disappointed" by what had happened in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. "But our ideas remain valid," his wife, Laure, chipped in. **********It was an argument that Mr. Marchais also used today. Yes, he conceded with a touch of mea culpa, "crimes and errors" had been committed in the name of Communism, but in a highly developed capitalist nation like France, "the humanist values of Communism are still alive and relevant." **********Certainly, no one expects the French Communist Party to dissolve itself or change its name. In theory, growing unemployment and dissatisfaction with the Socialist Government of President Francois Mitterrand could even help the Communists. Yet, under Mr. Marchais, the party still seems trapped in the past. **********As change reached the Soviet Union in the late 1980's, for example, the 71-year-old leader could not hide his distaste for the changes introduced by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, perestroika and glasnost. He even sounded relieved when Mr. Gorbachev was ousted on Aug. 19, although he hurriedly welcomed the coup's failure three days later. **********Not surprisingly, dissidence is growing. One group of reformers urged the Politburo to resign after its ambivalent response to the Soviet putsch. Charles Fiterman, a prominent liberal, has long campaigned against "democratic centralism." Yet because he has not democratized the party, Mr. Marchais seems unlikely to be toppled. **********At the Fete de L'Humanite, party stalwarts could at least take refuge from the triumphant cries of French conservatives in recent weeks. And while many sat around trying to explain why Communism had imploded in the Soviet Union and why the French party continues to shrink, others seemed determined to have fun. **********In search of a theme for the fair, the editor of L'Humanite, Roland Leroy, chose solidarity with Cuba as perhaps the least likely to be controversial. Throughout the park, stands sold pins, posters and rum drinks to help finance a plan to send a boatload of food to Cuba. **********Indeed, the mood was cheerful enough for Mr. Marchais to announce confidently that another -- the 57th -- Fete de L'Humanite would be held next year. His speech, though, was repeatedly interrupted by chants of "Johnny! Johnny!" Many youths could not wait for him to end because the aging rock star, Johnny Hallyday, was next on stage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/11/busin.main_headline: Agencies Caution Clients On Using Patriotic Themes
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Agencies Caution Clients On Using Patriotic Themes
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/11/busin.body_text: **********The temptation to wave the flag in ads seems nearly irresistible now -- companies like the General Motors Corporation and Delta Air Lines Inc. are already using patriotic themes -- but many agency executives said in recent interviews that trying to capitalize on the victory in the Persian Gulf war was a mistake. **********"It is inappropriate to use the war as a selling tool," said Stephen Novick, an executive vice president and co-creative director at Grey Advertising. "Most consumers are going to see right through the gimmick, and they are bound to view it as pseudo-patriotic." **********Donny Deutsch, the creative director of the Deutsch agency, said he had considered using a shot of a high school band playing the national anthem in a commercial for one client. "We worried that it would seem exploitive," he said. "So we cut it out." **********Since the end of the war, a handful of advertisers have run ads that refer to the conflict. Delta has a print ad that offers to cut fares by 70 percent for people who served in the gulf and their families for travel in the United States until Sept. 30. A recent print ad for Moet & Chandon champagne urged people to tear the ad up and throw the pieces in the air to celebrate the end of the war. **********Perhaps the most ambitious effort so far is a 30-second commercial jointly sponsored by General Motors and the United Automobile Workers union.
