The spot shows auto workers on the job and soldiers in the gulf region while one G.M. worker sings "America the Beautiful." **********Howard Erickson, a spokesman for the U.A.W.-G.M. Human Resources Center, said the company and the union decided to run the ad to honor the hundreds of G.M. and union workers who served in the Middle East in the reserves. "We considered that some people might perceive this as commercialism," Mr. Erickson said. "But we don't think so, because the tone is just right and it focuses on people." **********Clint Rodenberg, senior vice president of marketing at Schieffelin & Somerset, which markets Moet champagne, said the Moet ad was celebrating peace, not victory. Mr. Rodenberg also said the ad had brought a positive public response. **********Executives at Delta did not return telephone calls seeking comment. **********Many executives said even ads that celebrated the end of the war would ultimately do more harm than good. For one thing, they said, there were millions of Americans who opposed the war. In addition, although it was a victory, more than 100 Americans died in the conflict and many were wounded. **********"This was a war, and no matter what the outcome, any war is tragic," said Allan Beaver, the vice chairman and director of creative services at Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver. "It is bound to turn off enough consumers to make it bad for business." **********Mr. Beaver said that one of his agency's clients, whom he would not identify, considered running an ad tied to the war, but that the agency convinced the company that it would be bad strategy. **********Some agency executives said that the only foolproof way for an advertiser to address the war in an ad would be to leave its name off as the sponsor. But if the company gets no credit, it serves no marketing point and most would reject the idea, agency executives said. **********While overtly patriotic themes may not work, some executives said advertisers could probably benefit from ads that talked about a renewed spirit in the country without referring to the war. "There would be nothing wrong with running ads showing Americans feeling good about themselves and their country," said Patrick Cunningham, the chief creative officer at the Ayer agency. **********Some executives predicted that advertising might return somewhat to the kind of "naive attitude" that was prevalent in the 1950's. Mr. Deutsch said he expected to see a lot of ads with a "Gee whiz, everything is going great" theme. **********"This is the first time in several decades we've had a reason to feel good about ourselves," he said. "Now, 'Made in America' will mean something again."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/08/world.main_headline: TATARS SEEK SPLIT WITH THE RUSSIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/08/world.print_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL; TATARS SEEK SPLIT WITH THE RUSSIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/08/world.body_text: **********From an office decked with the green banners of Islamic solidarity, Rafael F. Mukhametdinov today surveyed the ruins of the Soviet Union with satisfaction: One empire down, he mused. One to go. **********With Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Soviet Union in shards, Mr. Mukhametdinov, a Tatar separatist leader, has set his sights on the dismantling of Boris N. Yeltsin's Russian republic, itself a mosaic of ethnic homelands where the calls for independence have grown bolder with the weakening of Moscow's grip. **********Here in the Tatar Autonomous Republic, the most restive of the ethnic subdivisions that cover most of Russia's land mass, the cries for independence -- independence, that is, from Mr. Yeltsin -- have sent a shudder of anxiety through the large Russian population and marred the Russian President's moment of triumph.  Opposition to a Split **********"The big empire has collapsed," said Mr. Mukhametdinov. "The Russian federation will be more difficult, but I think it is inescapable that this empire will also collapse." **********So far, the clamor for secession here has been confined to nonviolent street rallies and the speeches of a few separatist political leaders. **********An outright split is strongly opposed by a pro-Yeltsin parliamentary faction grouped around the tiny Democratic Party of Russia and by the best-selling local newspaper, Vecherny Kazan. **********The Communist majority in the local Parliament has demanded greater self-rule, including the right to ignore laws and tax levies of the Russian republic, but stopped short of declaring full independence. **********"The idea is not the collapse of the Russian federation, but a reformation," said Vasily N. Likhachev, Vice President of the Tatar Autonomous Republic. Annexed by Ivan the Terrible **********Mr. Yeltsin has promised to give the autonomous regions greater self-rule, including a bigger share of what they produce, but has insisted that the Russian federated republic remain "one and indivisible." **********Like the Soviet Union, the Russian federation is a domain acquired by conquest and merger, and gerrymandered into ethnic autonomous entities -- 16 "autonomous republics" like this one and about a score of enclaves with lower status. **********Tatarstan, known in ancient times as the Khanate of Kazan, was annexed by Ivan the Terrible in the 16th century as he pushed Russia's frontiers eastward. **********The autonomous entities contain much of the republic's natural wealth and industrial strength. Yakutia, in the far east, is rich in diamonds and gold. Komi, to the north, has coal. Bashkiria is a major source of natural gas. The Tatar Autonomous Republic has oil reserves and major industries like the Kamaz truck factory and the Ilyushin aircraft plant.  'A Big-Power Chauvinist' **********In most of those territories, the call for sovereignty has been muted by demographics. The local populations are often outnumbered by transplanted Russians. Tatarstan's population of 3.5 million includes about 48 percent ethnic Tatars, 43 percent Russians and a mix of other groups. **********But the crash of the Soviet center has shaken the equilibrium in Mr. Yeltsin's domain. **********For one thing, the ascendancy of Mr. Yeltsin has stirred longstanding resentments among non-Russians, not only in neighboring Soviet republics like the Ukraine and Kazakhstan, but in the minority enclaves within Russia. **********"Yeltsin, to put it bluntly, is a demagogue and a big-power chauvinist," said Marat A. Mulukov, a history professor who is chairman of the Tatar Civic Center, the largest establishment of the nationalist groups.  Communists Court Nationalists **********Mr. Mulukov contends that Mr. Yeltsin and his followers have seized on the disarray in Moscow to suppress the yearnings of minorities and reimpose "the Russian boot." **********Their indignation flared anew this week at the interim power-sharing arrangement negotiated by Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Yeltsin and other republics' leaders, a deal that gives only token representation to the autonomous entities. **********"Tatarstan has more heavy industry than any of the three Baltic republics, more than Moldavia and Tadzhikistan," Mr. Mulukov said. "The only reason we are not given equal status is Russian chauvinism." **********A second result of the failed coup is that the crumbling of the old Communist Party network has left local Communist leaders searching for new partners among the nationalists.  Awkward Spot During Coup **********Mintimer S. Shaimiyev, the Communist President of Tatarstan, found himself in an especially awkward spot. During the three days of the Moscow coup, he professed neutrality. The police in Kazan broke up a student demonstration supporting Mr. Yeltsin, and the director of the Communist-run printing plant censored newspapers that tried to publish Mr. Yeltsin's views. **********Before the failed coup, Tatar nationalists regarded Mr. Shaimiyev as a dubious ally, too cautious in his courtship of Moscow. But now that pro-Yeltsin forces are demanding his removal as a traitor, the nationalists have mobilized to defend him as a symbol of their sovereignty. **********"Overnight they went from crying 'Down with Shaimayev!' to 'Hands off our President!' " said Yelena N. Chernobrovkina, a reporter for Evening Kazan, who views the alliance as a maneuver by the Communist old guard to hold on to power. **********But Tatar leaders said they feared that the pro-Yeltsin forces would use Mr. Shaimiyev's wavering as a pretext to suppress their drive for self-rule.  Bolder Nationalist Movement **********"They accuse us of uniting behind the conservative forces," Mr. Mukhametdinov said. "It is true that Shaimiyev has not conducted himself like the ideal leader of a sovereign state. But at the moment that is where the power resides in the republic. We are uniting against a greater threat." **********Even before the upheavals in Moscow, the Tatar nationalist movement had been growing bolder and more influential. **********A year ago the Tatar Civic Center won a first victory when the Tatar Parliament declared its "sovereignty," establishing the Tatar language along with Russian as equal "official languages" of the republic and asserting the supremacy of local laws over others. But the practical effects were minimal, as Tatarstan continued to abide by Soviet and Russian laws. **********More radical nationalist movements have sprung up to challenge the cautious Tatar Civic Center. **********Mr. Mukhametdinov, 44, is deputy chairman of Ittifaq, the National Independence Party, whose program calls for creation of a territorial army, the automatic right of resettlement here for the five million Tatars estimated to live elsewhere in the Soviet Union, and a vigorous educational campaign to discourage Tatar youngsters from marrying outside their race. Nearly a third of the marriages here are said to be mixed.  Ties to Turkic Republics **********"What is the sense of struggling for equal rights if every third Tatar marries a Russian?" said Mr. Mukhametdinov. "In three generations we will die out as a nation, victims of biological assimilation." **********Mr. Mukhametdinov also is chairman of the Assembly of Turkic Peoples, an umbrella group of organizations across the Soviet Union sharing Turkic linguistic and cultural roots. **********While Mr. Yeltsin looks to the West for economic and political models, many Tatars argue that their natural allegiance is with Turkey and the Turkic-speaking Soviet republics like Azerbaijan and Uzbekistan. **********"If Russia is ruled as a federation of states without regard to nationality, like America, there can only be one result: the little nations will die out," said Mr. Mukhametdinov.  Cordial Ties to Russia **********As in other Eastern-oriented republics of the Soviet Union, nationalists here stress that this is a resurgence of Turkic nationalism, not Islamic fundamentalism. They advocate secular government, with no political role for Islam. **********The coup appears to have narrowed the distance between the radicals and more cautious Tatar groups. **********"When we started out in 1988, our goal was to raise ourselves to the status of a full Soviet republic," said Mr. Mulukov of the Tatar Civic Center. "Now we see that the union is finished, and the policies of Yeltsin give us no hope of receiving full independence within Russia. As part of Russia, we are doomed to be a second-class nation." **********The republic's government, while vowing to maintain cordial relations with Russia, has also become more insistent about escaping Russian control. One recent decree declared that all property on the territory of the republic, including the oilfields and factories run by Soviet and Russian ministries, now belong to the Tatars.  'A Boxcar Free of Goods' **********An economist who chairs the Tatar Parliament, Farit R. Gazizullin, said that in short order the republic plans to stop paying taxes to Mr. Yeltsin's Government. **********"We pay Russia half a billion rubles a year in taxes," he said. "We cannot accept that any longer." **********Regardless of its political status, he said, Tatarstan remains dependent on Russia for metal and other raw materials -- a point driven home the other day when an empty freight train pulled into Kazan Station painted with a sarcastic message from Russian steelworkers in the Ural Mountains: "To free Tatarstan, a boxcar free of goods." **********The pro-Yeltsin forces argue that remaining within the Russian federation is essential to protect the rights of non-Tatars and to insure that the Communist old guard does not smother reforms aimed at greater democracy and free markets.  Anti-Russian Hostility **********"If Tatarstan stays on the road of confrontation with Yeltsin, it can't be excluded that we will simply become a little island of national Communism in the sea of Russia," said Khasbulat K. Shamsutdinov, deputy editor of Vecherny Kazan. **********Rashid Akhmetov, a Tatar who heads the local branch of the Democratic Party of Russia, said: "The revival of national identity is beautiful. But the idea of a national state is frightening." **********Most people of Russian heritage interviewed here said that they had seen no sign of Russian hostility against Russians and that they consider the potential for civic strife remote. But Russians said they live with growing uncertainty about their future. **********A few Russians have reportedly moved away to predominantly Russian regions, and others say they would consider leaving if the country's acute housing shortage did not make relocation so difficult. **********"A lot of people would leave if they had relatives to put them up," said Rashit Sakhibdayev, 34, a city judge. "But in this country it's not that easy to pick up and go."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/world.main_headline: Arriving in Tokyo, Baker Starts 3-Nation Asia Tour
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/world.print_headline: Arriving in Tokyo, Baker Starts 3-Nation Asia Tour
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrived in Tokyo today at the start of a politically risky Asian tour likely to determine whether relations between China and the United States remain strained or can begin to recover in the aftermath of Beijing's violent crackdown on democracy advocates in 1989. **********After stops in Japan and South Korea, Mr. Baker is to travel on Friday to Beijing in the highest-level visit by a Bush Administration official since the Tiananmen Square killings of June 1989. Although Mr. Baker's trip is going ahead as planned, President Bush last week responded to domestic political concerns by canceling a planned Asian tour beginning late this month. **********Administration officials say that secret contacts between Washington and Beijing have assured Mr. Baker that he will not leave China empty-handed or embarrassed. But it is far from certain that members of Congress will be satisfied with what he extracts from the Chinese in the key areas of arms control, human rights and trade.  Solarz 'Uneasy' **********"I am uneasy with this trip," said Representative Stephen J. Solarz, the Brooklyn Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asia, and a leader of efforts to punish China for the crackdown. "If Baker comes back and demonstrates that the trip was justified in the areas of our concern, fine. If he comes back as empty-handed as some others in the Administration before him, the trip will be rightly judged as not only a failure, but a mistake." **********Mr. Solarz argued that if Mr. Baker "gives the present Chinese leadership gratuitous legitimacy" without getting anything substantial in return, the debate over the Administration's China policy will likely be rekindled. An unimpressive result might also give new impetus to efforts to strip China of "most-favored-nation" trading benefits, which the Administration renewed in June.  Movement Is Seen **********An Administration expert involved in planning the trip said, "The Chinese have been doing some things -- not in the human rights area -- in a direction which we see as more positive than negative and we would like to encourage them to continue that movement. **********"Look, everyone has mixed feelings about this trip," the official added. "I supported it because you cannot talk credibly about Asia, about Japan becoming a regional power, about the future security architecture in Asia and leave China unattended. It is too important. You avoid China at your peril." **********Chinese leaders, the official said, "will want the maximum to give themselves face out of this visit. They will limit their cooperation in the absence of such meetings in order to get that. You go into it aware of that, and it is just a question of how you deal with it." **********Bush Administration officials cite several areas where they contend the Chinese are moving in the right direction. The first is their agreement in principle to sign the treaty against the spread of nuclear weapons. Others include Beijing's limited cooperation on Middle East arms control -- which primarily involves not yet delivering missiles contracted for by Syria -- and its commitment in principle to join the Missile Technology Control Regime. Finally, on Sept. 23, the Chinese agreed to begin talks on assuring Washington that it will not export to the United States goods produced by prison labor.  Cooperation With Iran **********And then there are the areas where Washington will try to prevent further deterioration, like China's increasing nuclear cooperation of with Iran. **********What Mr. Baker will apparently try to win from the Chinese is some sort of ironclad commitments not to sell nuclear technology to countries like Iran, Syria or Pakistan, nor any ballistic missiles. Even if the Chinese sign the treaty controlling missile technology, the question is how closely they will abide by it. The treaty against the spread of nuclear weapons is before the Chinese legislature and the Chinese authorities are saying it must be passed there first, although the regime could push it through any time. **********"The Chinese are very good at appearing to make concessions and then not doing it," said a Congressional staff expert on China. "That is why the assurances have to be ironclad." **********Because so many other issues have captured the headlines in recent years, American trade problems with China have been largely lost from view, but they are extremely serious. To control inflation in recent years the Chinese have clamped down tightly on imports, devalued their currency and erected import-license trade barriers to support their state-owned enterprises -- including those that depend on prison labor. This has led to diminished American exports to China and a trade defict in 1990 of about $10.5 billion.  Talks on Market Access **********The United States is already engaged in negotiations with the Chinese over market access. Another yardstick for the success or failure of Mr. Baker's trip will be the extent to which it can speed up these negotiations. **********The area where Congress will be most closely watching Mr. Baker's trip, however, will be in the field of human rights. Legislation that would strip China of its preferential trading status is now on hold in Congressional committees; whether the legislation is revived will depend in part on how many political prisoners the Chinese release amonng those arrested since the 1989 crackdown. **********Amnesty International estimates that there are roughly 800 such political prisoners, and Congressional experts hope that half will be freed, including some prominent dissidents. **********Before Mr. Baker visits Beijing, he will be making his inaugural stopover in Seoul, the South Korean capital. **********The most pressing issue now on the Korean-American agenda, say American officials, is what can be done about quickening pace of North Korea's nuclear arms program. Some experts believe North Korea is only 6 to 12 months away from producing a bomb.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/busin.main_headline: Pogo Producing Picks A Successor to Liedtke
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Pogo Producing Picks A Successor to Liedtke
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/busin.body_text: **********The Pogo Producing Company, an oil and gas exploration and production concern founded by the oilman William C. Liedtke Jr., has named Paul G. Van Wagenen to take the place of Mr. Liedtke, who died of cancer on Friday at the age of 66. **********Mr. Van Wagenen, 45 years old, has been at Pogo for 12 years and was named president of the Houston-based company in October. He will continue to hold that job as well as those of chairman and chief executive. **********"Paul Van Wagenen was Bill Liedtke's hand-picked successor and the unanimous selection of the board," said William E. Gipson, a board member who is a former Pogo president. **********"We don't see any dramatic changes in store," Mr. Van Wagenen said yesterday. "I had the good fortune of being able to work shoulder to shoulder with Bill Liedtke, a true giant in the industry. We faced the challenges together over the last few years." **********Mr. Liedtke, a friend and former business associate of President Bush, was a co-founder of the Pennzoil Company and from 1977 headed Pogo, which was spun off that year from Pennzoil to look for natural gas in the Gulf of Mexico. Pogo took its name from Pennzoil Offshore Gas Operators. **********The oil and gas industry "is on the rebound," Mr. Van Wagenen said. Pogo showed a profit of $18.2 million last year, compared with a $5.6 million loss in 1989. "At the same time we've halved our debt of $515 million and kept our overhead low," he said. "During the boom days in the oil patch, we, like many others, had a much larger staff." **********The staff has been reduced to 101 from 240, Mr. Van Wagenen said, and will probably stay at that level. "We seem to function best as a lean, mean group of oil finders," he said. **********Mr. Van Wagenen made his reputation as a Pogo lawyer, fighting the company's battles in court to make gas purchasers pay up. In the 1980's, as natural gas prices rose, gas purchasers sought to get out of long-term contracts, called take-or-pay deals. Pogo had a good record of getting these disputes resolved in its favor, the company said. **********Mr. Van Wagenen is a magna cum laude graduate of Brigham Young University with a law degree from the University of Washington. He worked for Exxon for 12 years and in the Dallas law firm of Johnson & Gibbs before joining Pogo in 1979 as its first in-house legal counsel. **********For relaxation, Mr. Van Wagenen does some managing -- of Little League baseball. "You'll find that about an hour, an hour and a half in the evening with 6- and 7-year-old kids improves your attitude," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/02/busin.main_headline: Todd Board Vote Is Set for Borman
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Todd Board Vote Is Set for Borman
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/02/busin.body_text: **********The Todd Shipyards Corporation of Jersey City has agreed to allow a Los Angeles investor to run for election to its board, and he is expected to become chairman of the company. **********As part of a settlement reached on Tuesday, the investor, Burton Borman, and five associates, including retired Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., will be nominated for election to the Todd board at a special shareholders meeting on Sept. 16. In return, Mr. Borman agreed to drop a lawsuit he filed on July 26 against Todd and its directors for canceling a special shareholders' meeting scheduled for Aug. 15.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/busin.body_text: **********INTERNATIONAL Gorbachev's Latest Plan Leaves Economists Unimpressed **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he badly needs credits from the West for his latest reform plan to work. But that request comes at a time when the West is hard pressed for the cash. No matter. To get the money, Mr. Gorbachev wants to take his flip charts to the July economic summit meeting of industrialized countries in London. But the bets are that if he goes, he won't come back with much. Western economists looking at the latest plan are not impressed. "It's anarchic," said Marshall Goldman of Harvard University. "There is no provision for a convertible ruble. And Gorbachev, as late as November, did not support private property." The plan allows state-owned enterprises to sell 10 percent of their goods on the open market. Not good enough. "Since November 1989, I counted eight reform plans," said Mr. Goldman. Most were abandoned. "Too bad the Soviet Union can't produce products the way it produces plans," he said. A Tower of Power for Sony?  Few buildings convey corporate power as convincingly as A.T.& T.'s granite-clad headquarters in Manhattan. It was completed in 1983, weeks before the telephone monopoly was broken up by the government. Trouble is, while the breakup made the American Telegraph and Telephone Company smaller -- it shed the eight "baby bells" -- the size of the building remained the same. Now, A.T.& T. is planning to lease its tower to the Sony Corporation. And Sony will get an option to buy it. While the building may be too expensive for A.T.& T., Sony is flush with cash. Sales were up 25 percent for the year, and profits climbed 13.7 percent, it reported last week.  A Trade Pact on the Fast Track  It was a big victory for the Administration. The House and Senate approved a renewal of the fast-track legislation Mr. Bush so anxiously sought. The legislation gives the Administration the power to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico and present it to Congress for approval with a simple yea or nay vote. Congress cannot haggle over the fine points. The deal could be completed within a year. "I couldn't be more pleased," Mr. Bush said.  Buying Jet Parts from Japan . . .  In times past, Boeing's main suppliers were American. That is changing. The Boeing Commercial Airplane Company signed an agreement last week with Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries to help it build major parts of the 777, its newest twinjet. Boeing's new partners will make 20 percent of the plane and shoulder some of the investment risk. But eyebrows are being raised. With commercial aviation targeted for growth by Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Investment, is Boeing about to create its newest rivals? No, says Boeing. It will only show its partners plans for the parts they actually build. But what will the partners show each other? . . . and Selling G.M. There  Toyota and the General Motors Corporation teamed up once before.  Now, if the rumors are true, they will do it again. Toyota is thinking about selling G.M.'s cars in Japan through its dealer outlets. G.M. needs the help, too. Last year, it sold just 8,513 cars in Japan -- not many more than its sells on a good day at home. Trading Criticisms on Trade  Japan and the United States have been arguing about trade for decades. Last week, they gave each other report cards, and both received failing grades. Japan's negotiators complained that American companies pay their chief executives too much and that the Federal budget deficit is still too high. Japan begrudgingly gave credit to the United States for getting serious about education. America's negotiators were also upset. Japan is still a closed market, they said, with companies bound to each other through ties of ownership and seats on each other's boards of directors. But the Americans admitted that Japan has changed some of its distribution system. Both opinions have merit. But it is hard to figure out what some of these issues have to do with trade. A Joint Venture by Rivals  Last week, when Johnson & Johnson and Merck & Company bought a German drug company, Woelm Pharma G.m.b.H., a subsidiary of Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, for $90 million, it showed that rivals at home can be strategic partners abroad. They bought Woelm in a 50-50 joint venture they call the Johnson & Johnson-Merck Consumer Pharmaceuticals Company. (How will they fit that on the bottle?) The new acquisition will give the two companies access to Europe's $5 billion over-the-counter market. And they will get European manufacturing capacity, too. Woelm also has a distribution network that could help the companies push their way into Europe. But perhaps most important, by acquiring Woelm they now have expertise in getting new drugs past Europe's regulators, a definite advantage. Both companies are planning to sell over-the-counter versions of their prescription drugs there. More European acquisitions by the joint venture may be on the horizon. A spokesman said they are "studying additional opportunities." COMPANIES **********A Fallen Insurer Is on the Block How much is a failed insurance company worth? That is what the regulators in California want to know. Last week, they put the assets of Executive Life Insurance Company on the block. The regulators, who seized the company last month after it defaulted on its portfolio of high-yield "junk bonds," are proposing to divide Executive Life into two units, each to be sold separately. One unit would include the policies along with some of the bonds. The other would get the leftover assets, which the buyer could sell. Altus Finance, the investment arm of Credit Lyonnais, the French bank, has stepped forward to examine the books. One problem the regulators still have not solved: Executive Life owes $643 million in back taxes. Basic Research at Microsoft  William H. Gates, chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, the nation's largest publisher of personal computer software, thinks his company could get by without doing any research at all. Just buy what it needs from innovative software companies and university research labs. Still, it can't take chances. Microsoft announced it will open a basic research center at its headquarters in Redmond, Wash., to develop software to manipulate images, understand human speech and -- yes -- help scientists design new software. Where will Microsoft get its scientists? From rivals like I.B.M. The lab is not intended to become huge. Microsoft will spend just $10 million a year. Stocks Around the Clock  The Big Board's volume is up, but it has been losing market share to regional and even foreign stock exchanges, some of which trade 24 hours a day. So the Big Board petitioned the Securities and Exchange Commission to let it stay open later. Last week the S.E.C. agreed. In a phase-in program, the Big Board will take a slow stroll to a 24-hour trading day. Starting June 13, the 9:30 A.M. to 4:00 P.M. trading day will be extended to 5 P.M. for individual stocks and 5:15 P.M. for large baskets of stocks. Within a decade, the Big Board will be open around the clock. The impact of the new rules "will be felt around the world," said Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the S.E.C. More Paring at Apple For Apple Computer Inc., the future is clear. The company must increase its market share and pare its costs. Apple already cut the prices of the Macintosh. Sales jumped. Now comes the hard part: trimming its work force by 10 percent.  THE ECONOMY **********Good News and a Dash of Salt  At first glance, more good news. The sale of durable goods -- those big ticket items that are supposed to outlast their warranties -- grew by 2.9 percent in April, according to the Commerce Department. It was the first increase of the year. But sales were down in one crucial category -- nondefense capital goods. Sales of trucks, trains and machine tools fell by 10.3 percent, a signal that the nation's factories are not investing. "That's a bad sign," said Lawrence Chimerine, senior adviser to DRI Inc., an economic consulting firm. "You can't take these numbers as evidence that we've turned the corner." Prepaid Tickets for Speeders? The Texas State Legislature began a debate last week on a novel way to raise revenue. Sell speeding tickets in advance, the proposed bill says. The plan calls for books of five speeding tickets to be sold by the state motor vehicle department for $25. If you get stopped by the police for doing between 55 miles per hour and 70 m.p.h., just give the officer a pre-paid ticket. Nothing goes on your record. But if you get stopped for doing more than 70 m.p.h., the officer gives you the ticket -- the old-fashioned kind. That one goes on your record. The Legislature figures it will raise $100 million a year selling penalties in advance. It could even broaden which penalties are for sale. The Deficit Swells as Taxes Rise  Back in 1986, when the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced budget law took effect, the deficit was $221 billion. Much too high. What followed were five years of wrangling and political debate. Then, last fall, Congress and the Administration raised taxes and vowed to cut the deficit. Last week the fruits of their labors were unveiled: a $1.45 trillion budget for 1992 with a 1 percent drop for the military.But the estimated deficit increased to $278.8 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/27/world.main_headline: Debate in Parliament: Gorbachev Takes 'an Enormous Share' of the Blame; Legislators Speak Out: 'We Have the Spirit of Reaction in this Assembly'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/27/world.print_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL; Debate in Parliament: Gorbachev Takes 'an Enormous Share' of the Blame; Legislators Speak Out: 'We Have the Spirit of Reaction in this Assembly'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/27/world.body_text: **********Following are key sections of the session of the Supreme Soviet yesterday, including a speech by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and speeches by other Supreme Soviet members. The speech by Nursultan A. Nazarbayev was transcribed and translated by The New York Times and the BBC monitoring service; all others were translated by CNN and transcribed by Reuters.  GORBACHEV'S SPEECH **********Distinguished members of the Supreme Soviet: first of all, I would like to support the decision adopted by the Supreme Soviet to convene an emergency session of the Congress of People's Deputies, because the problem itself and everything we have gone through over the last days and the decisions that are necessary are all the prerogatives of the Congress. And this is the first thing I wanted to say. **********And then I would like to suggest the following thing: that is to invite members of the Russian Parliament and members of other parliaments to attend the session of the Congress. **********In the period remaining, I would request that the people's deputies working in commissions and committees in different chambers and groups of deputies to discuss and analyze everything that has happened and the reason for that and to draw appropriate conclusions. What is needed is not just philosophizing but specific and concrete decisions and actions, which must be based on accurate and uncompromising analysis of everything we have gone through. **********Naturally enough, in the buildup to the Congress, we will not remain idle. In fact, we have begun our work and we have raised the matter of nonconfidence in respect of the Cabinet of Ministers. The Cabinet of Ministers did not live up to the challenge and actually participated in the coup. The decree on the departicization of troops and the K.G.B. has been adopted. **********People have been removed from the key positions in the army -- I mean those who sided with the plotters. New people have been put in key positions. The office of the Procurator General of the U.S.S.R. and the Russian Federation is currently conducting a criminal investigation into the coup. **********You are familiar with the declaration I made earlier. I resigned from the post of the General Secretary of the Communist Party and I suggested that the Central Committee of the Communist Party should disband itself. Similar measures and these specific measures are necessary to defuse tensions in the country and we will unswervingly pursue this policy in the future. Signs of Impending Coup **********In this statement that I am making -- this is not a report, this is just a statement because a report would need much more preparation and we need to consult with each other before I make a report. But for the time being, I would like to dwell on the most important issues. **********Distinguished deputies, the coup was not entirely unexpected. It was not a bolt from the blue. It was prepared by the provocative statements of certain generals and people in key positions and certain statements made in the Supreme Soviet, and there were attempts to undermine the decisions. And the coup was impending and appropriate steps were necessary to protect the constitutional order in the country. However, that had not been done, although we did draw appropriate conclusions and we rebuffed those attempts in the Supreme Soviet, in the press and elsewhere. **********However, instead of decisive actions, there was lack of determination, and I am also responsible for that lack of determination. But this is one conclusion that must be drawn from that situation. There is another cause for the attempt to push the country toward totalitarianism and that is lack of decision in the implementation of democratic reforms, particularly in those structures that spearheaded the coup. And this is not only my responsibility but the responsibility of the Supreme Soviet, the party and the Government. **********Our good intentions and plans were not implemented because the old mechanism and the old structure of power had not been changed. And I mean primarily the state apparatus, which was totally in agreement with the policy of the party and there were people in key positions who remained loyal to the Stalinist doctrine. We vacillated for a long time and even at this moment, we have not embarked on the road of decisive transformation. **********This has affected the sociopolitical situation in the country. In fact, the plotters wanted to take advantage of the difficulties in the country and it is true that the people of the country are facing a very difficult situation. There's a slump in living standards. The criminality is on the rise. And the overall situation is deteriorating. **********There's another reason for the coup and that is there was lack of coordination between the forces of perestroika, between different groups of democratic forces. We were divided. And both in the session of the Congress and at plenary meetings, I used to say again and again that if we are committed to democracy and democratic movement, it would be a major mistake if we get involved in a political struggle. **********However, there was a lack of political vision and a lack of responsibility for our common cause. I mean the democrats first and foremost. Without appropriate constitutional supervision, the army was in a very difficult situation. However, the plotters failed to plunge the army into the struggle against its own people, and those were the major miscalculations on the part of the plotters. Troops Refuse to Attack **********They believed, and I apologize for the languages I'm using, but they believed that they could manipulate the people. However, the country had changed, and that was a major mistake on their part. The country had changed. The people had changed and the army had changed, because the army is a part of the people. And even those forces in the army that had been trained for emergency situations and contingency situations, for anti-terrorist activities, refused to take actions against the people. **********Although they were threatened with court-martial, they refused to participate in the coup. Airborne troops refused to participate. And you know the actual capability of airborne troops. Just three planeloads would have been enough to remove the Government from power. **********And those people who took the troops into the streets of Moscow refused to participate in the coup, and this is another major cause for the failure of the coup. However, troops were out in large numbers in the streets of Moscow. There were tanks in the streets. And those actions were taken without an appropriate approval on the part of the legislature. That means that the mechanism of power is not functioning properly. **********The K.G.B. had not been reorganized. It is true that the K.G.B. protects the interests of the state, using its intelligence agencies, but the K.G.B. remained an instrument of political struggle, despite the changes that have been made. **********The Supreme Soviet failed to move and members of the Cabinet of Ministers panicked and failed to take action  [ change of interpreter ]  face of the committee. All of this helped. But I, as President, bear an enormous share of the responsibility for this. I say this because during these days, a lot has become clear to me. I have drawn a lot of different conclusions from what has happened to us. **********They seem to say that I've come to a different country. I could even add another country in the sense -- the way that I look at various problems, such as human rights, and I look at the future also with other eyes. **********In any case, no oscillations and no delays will be accepted in carrying out these reforms as long as I am President. No more compromises with those who -- your applause I accept to mean that you are not willing to accept any compromises. Although my main desire was that everything we do should lead to democracy, and this supported my position -- and this is perhaps what helped me avoid doing anything that would have led our country to a catastrophe. **********One other reason that made the process of reform so painful and -- the party bureaucratic structures have -- I recall how in the Central Committee meeting there was some struggle against those who were trying to block the democratic transformations. The old system was already undermined, disorganized, but it continued to hang on and it tried to prevent the transformations from being carried out. Soviet Society's Changes **********Its -- we -- indeed, initially I thought it was possible to separate the millions of party members from the leadership. Indeed, the belief of many members of the party inspired me with hope that we would be able to have a genuine transformation and reorganize the party along contemporary lines. But this coup d'etat made it no longer possible for me to think this way. And I thought it was my duty as Secretary General and urged the Central Committee to dissolve itself for that reason. **********Even so, despite all of these reasons that made the plot possible, it was nonetheless condemned from the very beginning to failure. The last six years have shown that we did not live them in vain. We can no longer recognize how the country has changed. New democratic forces have emerged. These coup leaders didn't understand this, and maybe we also don't understand each other all the time, but nonetheless we have become able to deal them a crushing blow. **********This conclusion is directly linked to why the plotters hastened so rapidly to carry out their plans. I can state with full conviction that they understood that any delay was fatally dangerous to them because such processes were emerging, such as the nine-plus-one process we're engaged in. And not only in the party Central Committee, but even in the Supreme Soviet, we will understand that -- we have fully understood that process. And these days, we have to say everything sincerely and openly, because we are all here together and the country is behind us. **********That's -- in signing the union treaty and undertaking the transition to a market, the meeting of the E.E.C. is going to make it possible to be integrated into the world economy unless this coup failed and it was crushed. I would like once again to express my unlimited gratitude to the hundreds of thousands of Muscovites who came out into the streets, fearlessly confronting machine guns and tanks to defend legality. **********An enormous role here was played by Boris Nikolayevich Yeltsin and the Russian Parliament, the inhabitants of Leningrad and their leaders, and also the peoples of the other republics. **********The country did not accept -- however they tried to package their appeal to the people, the country would not accept what they had to say. And in these very difficult circumstances, people took -- were willing to accept decisive measures but not any kind of measure. At the same time, the very fact that the coup was possible is evidence that we are still only halfway there, and we have to take other urgent measures to create guarantees of constitutional legality. **********What shall we do next now? First of all, I feel it very important to immediately renew the process of signing the union treaty. The plotters were able to undermine this process. This was one of the main aims, unfortunately.  The Union Treaty **********A number of the decrees of this so-called Emergency Committee included decrees by the President of the Supreme Soviet Lukyanov, as we found out later immediately handed over to the information media, in which he tried to show that the union treaty should not be signed. **********The draft treaty is a balance of the interests of all participants. Of course, it could be improved here and there, but the main thing is, and here I agree with those proposals that have been made these recent days and the statement by the leadership of the Russian Federation and certain meetings, certain proposals made in Leningrad and other republics that we have to sign the treaty and not delay its signing any longer. **********The fact that it can be improved, this can be done by addenda and by protocols and thereby we will be acting on the basis of the people's will as expressed in a referendum. **********In meetings with the leaders of the nine republics on Aug. 23, after my return, I understood that the union treaty has got to be signed as quickly as possible. In the meantime, certain steps have been taken, but we are not talking only about the final step in the transformation of our society but only the first step. **********Second point: we have to take the attitude with respect to those republics who don't want to sign the treaty. They have to be given the right to make their own choice. After signing the treaty we have to start business discussions with those who want to leave the union. **********The preparatory work can be done here and now. The agreement with them has got to contain all guarantees of the observation of human rights, regardless of their ethnicity. We have to solve the question of compensating those citizens who don't want to remain outside the union but want to join it, the question of the military infrastructure, where it has to be retained for a certain period of time on the territory of those republics which have separated from the union. **********At the same time, considering the vital interests of all 15 republics in maintaining economic ties, we have to start to work on concluding economic agreements, and this has to be done here and now, immediately. **********In the third place, we have immediately to solve certain questions of how the country is going to be governed until the new constitution is accepted. This has to be done right now. We have to have elections to solve some major questions such as the election of the new U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet, a new vice president. We must consult with each other very assiduously on this. **********At the meeting with the leaders of the republics on the 23d of August, a proposal was made to have an authoritative body that can adopt coordinated decisions on all major questions relating to the whole Soviet Union. I'm talking about administration or government now.  New Soviet Laws **********It was proposed that we use the constitutional body known as the Security Council, which doesn't yet exist. And we have to enhance the significance of this body in its makeup and its competence. This can be done if the leaders of the republics enter it, those republics that have decided to sign the union treaty -- Comrades Bakatin, Primakov, Popov, Revenko,  [ GRIGORY I., a member of the presidential council ]  and others. **********We have to form on the basis of agreement with the other republics a cabinet of minsters of the U.S.S.R., although a decision has already been taken to form such a group with Comrade Silayev. **********In the fourth place, the plotters would not have been able to carry out their plans if on their path there had been a firm Supreme Soviet with its president. Therefore, we have to convoke the Supreme Soviet immediately. This was done immediately in Russia. This played an enormous role in blocking the coup d'etat. But at this moment the republics in the Supreme Soviet were not able to carry out their rights and responsibilities. **********Now why this did not happen, why they did not come to the capital immediately, this is something we have to think about. We can draw all sorts of lessons from this, not only moral and political ones but we have got to be able to insure that this will not occur again. **********What kind of formulation do we need in the Constitution or in the law? We'll have to think this one over also. I propose that those delegates here give some thought -- who is going to be the president of the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. **********I'm ready for consultations on this, am always, but in particular today. None of us should leave anything unresolved. We've got to act together and with the leaders of the republics so that there'll be total confidence and total understanding and total awareness that the job will be done as it must be done. In the fifth place, necessary to evaluate the situation and establish social control over the activity of the armed forces. **********Here major transformations are necessary. First of all, we have to do everything to make sure that today, during the work on the constitution there'll be military reform as well. And then this will become a major part of the new law on military reform. **********We've got to increase the professional makeup of the army. We have to reorganize the Committee of State Security. My decree of naming Comrade Bakatin as president of the committee has a second paragraph urging him to reorganize the whole system of state security. **********We have to erect a barrier against any possibility of abuse of the security organs against the constitution. **********I will sign a decree on the troops out of the Ministry of Defense. It's also necessary to suspend the activity of the law on the K.G.B., to work out a new conception of state security, and reform it accordingly. And  [ inaudible ]  economic measures. In view of the cardinal changes in the country, we have to revise existing laws. At the forthcoming session of the Supreme Soviet, let us discuss this and work out measures on our future economic policy, considering everything that we -- considering the fact that we are now in new circumstances after these events. Economics and Republics **********We have to do everything possible, and on my part, I will -- we should not be too hasty, but we have to proceed deliberately. At the same time I take on myself the responsibility of saying something about this. First of all, measures must include elimination of all blocks created by the old structures and the old people on the path to a market economy. We have to eliminate all obstacles to this. And we have to accelerate the creation of the necessary market institutions. **********We have to move the center of gravity of the economic decisions to the republican level, maintaining the, on the union government insuring a unified economic area.  [ Inaudible ]  cardinal change in our financial and creditary policy is necessary. Measures have to be taken to combat the budgetary deficit and to assure the money supply. All obstacles have got to be eliminated that prevent land from being granted to those who want to cultivate it. **********We have plenty of land. We have several million such farmers, but that is not the end of it. We have to insure that there be a genuine land reform, so that this land reform shall get the necessary oxygen, and for this it needs our support. **********Of course we have to collect the harvest, but there's -- there will be plenty to think about afterward, in the autumn. We have to organize a whole foreign trade, our trade with hard-currency countries. We're going to need to increase the economic assistance we get from Western countries. I've had negotiations with the main Western countries, and they have confirmed that due to the fact that the last events of recent days have convinced them that the Soviet Union has now set about reforms which are irreversible, and they understand the necessity of cooperating, and increasing this cooperation. **********Social policy should go, be conducted with less demagogy in carrying out our program. We've got to get away from economic fatalism. We've got to concentrate attention on the major questions of social defense of the workers, supporting their living standard, and in particular of the, those who are less well-provided for. And an acute issue, in particular, is the food and fuel question. **********Proposals to remedy this have been prepared in the republics, and we have to think about that, too. We cannot permit a breakdown in the supply of food and fuel to the population. **********Even from this rostrum, I want to take this opportunity to appeal to our peasants and to all inhabitants of our countryside, all of our miners, all of those working in the power industry, to stick to their jobs until we have succeeded in solving all of these main issues. **********The Committee on the Economy has been set up by me, and it has to concentrate its efforts primarily on these problems, because all these problems are interlinked. **********In the seventh place, after signing the union treaty we have to start an electoral campaign for elections to the Supreme Soviet, including the President. These are measures that in my view we have -- this is what we have learned from the events of the last days, and this campaign has to be worked up very closely. Committees of the Supreme Soviet have to deal with this in a business-like way and furthermore, they have to give thought to control mechanisms to insure that the election is carried out legally, and they have got to have all of our support. **********This is all I felt it necessary to tell you in this statement of mine, which I have prepared in the wake of these recent events. **********Everybody is expecting decisions and business from us, and I think that the Supreme Soviet, and all of us have to do everything possible to insure that legality and order should continue. That means that all of those who are participating in -- participated in the coup d'etat have got to be dealt with as the law provides. But on the other hand, at this moment, we and the democratic forces of the country, and the whole people are opposed to any arbitrary actions that would simply compromise and endanger everything we are doing now.  LEVON TER-PETROSYAN Armenian President **********Distinguished deputies, dear guests, I came up to this rostrum to make a short statement. It seems to me that I regret that we are being led away from the most crucial problem of this moment. And the most crucial problem of the current moment is not the assessment of what has happened and not the consequences, but the most crucial problem at the moment is what will happen to the center, what will happen to the union parties in power. **********It seems to me that the central authorities after this coup have been outdated. The center is dead. The center has committed suicide. And to reanimate this cadaver now would mean to get back to the danger of the catastrophe that we had. **********As I have been listening to the debate at the Supreme Soviet, it seems to me that the Supreme Soviet is not yet ready to seriously discuss this problem. That is why I think it's too early for me to speak. I'll speak before you at the Congress. . . .  YURI N. SHCHERBAK  Ukrainian Journalist **********Dear Comrades: please, I'd like to draw your attention to the draft resolution. We don't have the editorial group yet, but we'll elect it. There are several questions here and we put those in the work now. **********Five years after the atomic catastrophe, we have to live through a political Chernobyl. The resolutions and decrees of the Emergency Committee smelled of threats. And these decrees showed like an X-ray machine who is who, and we now know what could have happened if the plotters could have gotten access to the nuclear trigger. **********So in the Chernobyl catastrophe it was Block No. 4 that fell down, was ruined, and in 1991, it was not Chernobyl, but the Stalinist empire that collapsed. . . . **********The Ukrainian Parliament has ruled that the Ukraine will be an independent because on Aug. 19, 1991, it was threatened by the state coup of losing its independence. As the state now has the right to self-determination and this has been written down in U.N. and other international documents. **********So the Ukrainian Supreme Soviet or Parliament has declared the emergence of an independent state, the Ukraine. The Ukraine will have only its own laws and its own constitution and on December the 1st there will be a general referendum in the Ukraine, and we'll see what the people will decide. **********I'd like to tell you that 15 deputies, a group from the Ukrainian Parliament, and I hope that others will join in, as the citizens of the Ukraine have spoken in favor of an independent Ukraine. Then we are planning to set up our own National Guard and we envisage some other measures for political and economic sovereignty. **********We have been assessing the coup and the consequences it may have for Russia and the Ukraine. The people's deputies from the Ukraine have stated that the events of Aug. 19-21 have shown that the central Government is inconsistent, and Gorbachev included, and the present government bodies have no power to protect the security of peoples, and there are such uncontrollable structures as the C.P.S.U., the Communist Party, and the Ukrainian branch. **********By the way today they told me that in one of the headquarters of the Ukrainian head party they had found a note, an official document in favor, in support of this coup. I'm talking about the Ministry of Defense. . . . And there were a number of Soviet officials who backed the coup. For example, the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union heard more than one threat to carry out a coup. **********In May 1991, I wrote an article, a requiem for the Parliament, and I said that Gorbachev and Lukyanov are like Mozart and Salieri. But today I would compare them to Christ and Judas. . . . And I think we should remember that there were deputies here threatening the President all the time and let's get back to the protocols and read them. . . . Remember, Colonel  [ inaudible ] , Petroshenka and many others. . . . **********And now it is becoming clear that we should take another stand in respect to the union treaty. There can be three kinds of ties between the sovereign republics. First, they can be bound in one state. Second, the sovereign republics sign a union treaty with the state. And third, they just sign economic, military, ecological and other agreements between each other, being sovereign. **********From this point of view there can be no one state but the point is now to avoid bloodshed and to avoid the changing of borders and take into consideration the  [ unintelligible ]  and his experience instead of using the centrist structures here. I think that we should create a Eurasian community or something like the NATO and so on. Only these kinds of unions will give us peace, stability and security  [ unintelligible ]  the world. Thank you.  KONSTANTIN M. OBOROK  Moldavia Council Chairman **********People have been arguing that the tricolor of Russia should be retained as the national flag of the country. We have a particular problem in that we are committing an immoral act. The K.G.B. was instrumental in implementing the coup. However, I'm not going to speak about Lukyanov, but I called one of the deputies on Monday and I asked what was going on, and I was told that everything was under control, that the constitutional bodies were in place, everything was quiet. . . . **********In conclusion, let me say that we have the spirit of reaction in this assembly, and many members of this Parliament are reluctant to implement the reforms. **********I would like to say a prayer for Boris Yeltsin and Russian Parliament. VLADIMIR P. SHCHERBAKOV  Chairman, Moscow Trade Union Council **********We indulged in wishful thinking when we thought that our Constitution could protect the constitutional order and democracy. The Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. is called on to give answers to the following questions. **********What were the deep-rooted causes of the coup and what needs to be done now? **********One of the causes was the political, social, and economic crisis. **********Our people are suffering, there's a lack of power at every level, both executive, legislative, and judicial. **********Mikhail Sergeyevich, let me tell you that the replacement of Ryzhkov, and your special powers, did not help to change the situation in the country. **********Another root cause of the crisis is lack of democracy and lack of political culture in the country. As a result of that, a small group of apparatchiks believed that they could stage a coup, they thought that they were saving this country. This is easy to condemn, the plotters, and say to the people that the old system would be dismantled. **********On the 23d of August, the presidium analyzed the situation and therefore, today, we speak from the position formulated by the presidium. **********First of all, it is necessary to deal with the question of power in this country. This session should deal with the following issues: The formation of a new union government that would take this country through the period of transition. We believe Boris Yeltsin has suggested a very good idea of setting out a government of national reconciliation. **********Next, it is necessary to identify the deadlines for the election of the parliament and the president of the country. . . . **********In order to defend our democracy and to hold a genuinely democratic general election, we need to set up a united democratic front. **********As a first step, we need to organize a round table, and the Supreme Soviet must initiate the formation of such a round-table discussion. **********Mikhail Gorbachev promised to discuss the urgent measures such as food, energy, et cetera, and this is our top priority. **********People have got to know how he's going to be fed and how he's going to be heated. **********Finally, during the last three days there has been a greater change in people's consciousness than over the previous six years. The people have changed. We should not -- should we not make a use of this change in order to implement our economic reforms? The new consciousness needs a new economy. The people should become the bosses of their own factories and of their own country. **********Thank you.  ANATOLY A. SOBCHAK  Mayor of Leningrad **********Dear colleagues, I would like when I ask for the floor to speak from this rostrum about all the mistakes that we made and the reasons that with our connivance led to a coup d'etat, but today I have decided to talk about something else. **********I want to tell our distinguished colleague that all of the discussion here today leaves a very burdensome impression on me. We're talking about who is trying to distort his real position and make himself look better than he was. But let me talk about something else. **********Today we have before us perhaps the most favorable situation, the most favorable conditions for rapidly progressing forward in our political and economic reforms. **********For six years we have, our whole reform has been hindered by the Communist structures. For six years, every attempt that we had to move away from that center was blocked by the fact that the whole system of the Communist Party of the U.S.S.R. as a part of the state structure delayed and put the brakes on any reforms we tried to attempt. **********Today finally we have an opportunity to remove those shackles and we have the opportunity now to move forward, and what do we hear? I'm most concerned, more than anything else, at the tendency I hear to try to deprive the country of its governing bodies. People are saying we don't need any kind of unified all-union authority. We're hearing that everything has to be liquidated, that all independents exist at the republican level, et cetera, et cetera. **********There are two sources of danger here. First of all, Nursultan Nazarbayev, a man whom I greatly love and respect, a man who I worked with in Tbilisi in the old days -- and even then I had great respect for him and for his position of principle and honor -- but today when I heard his statement I thought that somehow it had been dictated by some kind of emotional factors connected with a lot of other equally emotional statements by some Russian deputies and some members of the Russian leadership. **********Now, I'm not talking about Yeltsin. But there were some statements to the effect that we have to convey all union functions to the Russian Parliament or the Russian leadership, all union prerogatives to the President of Russia. I understand that this evokes a kind of a negative reaction. I understand it perfectly well. But I cannot understand something else. **********Today there's a serious danger, a much greater danger they will take hasty decisions. Today we are deciding the future of the country and to some degree the future of humanity. Therefore it's very important that we not do things hastily, superficially, carried along by this wave of emotion in talking about national independence and the rest. **********Let me just give you one example. I was very concerned by the fact that the statements of the representatives of our republics, who talked about the necessity of full state independence, never said a word about how they were liquidating the Communist structures and what they're going to do with the party property. There's a very severe danger. All this talk of independence is designed to cover the desire to retain these party structures but in a new form, retain these party bureaucrats but simply call them national bureaucrats or national leaders. **********Until we have liberated our country from all the remnants of the Communist structures, we have to be quite straightforward to everybody. First of all, let us liquidate those elements or that system that has been suffocating us all these years. **********Let us first of all create the necessary legal basis, and then everybody has the right or every people, every state formation has the right to independence, to solving its own national problems. But in the beginning, it is necessary to guarantee the rights of every citizen so that we not condemn our citizens in various of these republics to a new totalitarian existence. And I think this is one of the most important problems before us. Mistake: Party Reforms **********Furthermore, I would like us to take a look at our ability to criticize ourselves. I think that the statement of our President was the most self-critical, although it could have even been more self-critical. We're talking about the mistakes of the union leadership and personally about Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev. **********His main mistake was that all the economic and political changes in the country were presented as the desire to reform a Communist society. So all reforms were acceptable or not acceptable to the degree they were acceptable to the Communist Party. **********And so these six years of attempts to reform the unreformable was our main mistake, and this is something we should have recognized a long time ago. We should have recognized that this system could not be reformed, was not capable of being reformed, and it should have been dissolved from the beginning. This is something we just waited to do today. It took a coup d'etat to do it. And let us look at ourselves critically, more critically than we have done in the past and all of this. **********Let us recall how we sat by and witnessed the continuing manipulations in this very hall, in particular, the last six months, when we agreed that we wouldn't come, didn't have to come here every single day. I was never here one time to deal with an item on the agenda decided upon ahead of time, that that particular item was in fact examined on that day. **********Every day Anatoly Lukyanov, was manipulating the agenda, manipulating the apparat, manipulating our votes in order to get the decisions he wanted. We should ask ourselves why we went along with this. Why did we deputies and members of the Supreme Soviet responsible for the work of this body, did we accept the dicta of this one individual who always got what he wanted? **********When he saw that the hall was against him, he postponed the decision and two or three days later, when there was a different atmosphere in the hall, when some of the deputies were not here, then he submitted an item for a vote. That is something which we should take note of. **********O.K., the judiciary will deal with Lukyanov and we'll find out what he really did and what role he played in this plot. But let us take a look at the position of our own legislative bodies. It's said that Lukyanov did not  [ unintelligible ] , but how about the committees, how about the factions? We have dozens of groups of deputies. Why did not one of those factions convoke on Aug. 19 and announce its own attitude? You are people's deputies after all. The decisions depend on you. This is called the Supreme Soviet. Nobody is higher than us. **********Why did not one single committee come and save the honor of the Supreme Soviet and condemn the activities of the emergency committee? Why did we permit ourselves to be led by the nose and did not speak with our own voice? We showed the decisions of the President to the generals. Where were our committees, where was our committee on security, which today, on the 24th, is publishing its conclusions? Where were the other committees? Return of Conspiracy **********Any committee could have met. How many people there were here, and could have taken its own decisions. Why did not any of them do this? Everyone of us here should look at his own conscience and ask why this was not done -- but they didn't do it. So let us think of the kind of system we want to have in the future so that this does not happen again. **********I am very concerned that today's discussions will be a very favorable soil for conspirators to come back in the future. Imagine if we had spoken this way on the eve of the coup. Think what kind of encouragement this would have given to the emergency committee. This is something, comrades, that you have all got without trying to conceal or gloss over your own role -- have got to take into consideration. **********But we cannot dissolve any governing bodies -- this is something we absolutely cannot do. We cannot remove the President, we cannot dissolve the Supreme Soviet. Who is going to run the country if we do that? **********We do not have a government. Therefore we need right now to insure that there is some authority, there is somebody to hand the authority over to. This session has got to solve a number of major issues. **********And on the last day of our previous session, when we decide some issues, I think that is the time to talk about dissolving ourselves in order to make way for a new election. We can have different types of elections. It will be a function of the new union of sovereign republics. **********But what shall we do today or tomorrow? We have time. This is in our control. We've got to abolish our own law giving the President supplementary laws, this very emergency rule of which was at the basis for many of the decrees of the emergency committee, but which the President did not use. **********What is the danger of such legislation, that if one person does not make use of this sort of law, then somebody else will? In this case Gorbachev never used any of those supplementary powers that were given to him, but the conspirators did make use of them in order to carry out a coup d'etat. **********Therefore I hereby propose at this session that that particular law be abolished. **********There is appeal from some delegates from the northwest and from the three Baltic republics, and I think it will be given to you -- and here we give our positions on a number of questions, in particular the question of the necessity of abolishing a number of laws relating to decrees of the Supreme Soviet with respect to the information media in particular. **********We at the Supreme Soviet have to examine the legality of some other decisions taken, such as the one to close up some of the newspapers and informational media. And bear in mind that we have a law on how these measures can be carried out, and the Supreme Soviet should examine that decree as well so as not to, on a wave of euphoria, make the kind of mistakes that will be a source of shame to us in the future. We've got to manifest self-restraint and create so that in the future we will not say that we missed the opportunity to bring our country out on the path of freedom and democracy. NURSULTAN A. NAZARBAYEV  President of Kazakhstan **********Esteemed peoples' deputies: Last week was not just a period of time. It was an epoch that divided us from all our past. It was a time of victory for the reactionary forces. But the people of Moscow stood face to face with tanks that were trying to restore authoritarianism. . . . **********Concern for the future of our country demands that we cope with the problems facing us. As we can see, these problems are far from being resolved. **********All of us today have a different awareness, and this obliges us to take a new view of the country's future and of the union treaty. **********It is clear to me that a renewed union cannot be a federation. We have spent too long chasing after the past. The Ukraine's declaration of independence, and a similar decision by Byelorussia, witness a new historical reality that we cannot escape or ignore. **********The situation has changed radically. You know that I was in favor of signing the union treaty, but recent events have shown how explosive the old plan was. We heard Andrei Sakharov call for the union's transformation into a community, a federation, a commonwealth, but his call fell on deaf ears. **********In a future union what we have in mind is more economic relations with the center. . . . Each republic should have its own army. This decision has already been made in many republics. Each republican army will send detachments under orders of the Defense Ministry, and if there is a common threat the Defense Ministry will mobilize all of the forces. . . . **********This is true also for inter-republican ties. The problem of disarmament should also be dealt with in a coordinated way. Each republic should set up its own Foreign Ministry for conducting external, economic activities and for concluding treaties with other countries. Each republic should have its own consulates to protect or defend its citizens wherever they may be located in the world. **********We are used to the term U.S.S.R. We propose leaving it, and expanding it into the Free Union of Sovereign republics. By this I mean all republics including the autonomous republics that have declared or intend to declare their independence.  Human and Language Rights **********We should give representatives of every nationality the right to speak in their own language at republic and union meetings, and each republic should have the right to hear their deputy in their mother tongue. Thus, we are in favor of a confederative treaty, and we are convinced that only in that way will we achieve equal rights among republics. Only in this way will we achieve a genuine federation. **********I would also like to mention that the existing union treaty is practically a confederative one. Let us recognize this and dot our 'i's. Only if we conclude an economic agreement also can we have a stable situation in which every republic will have full respect for its rights. **********We must grant human rights to every individual regardless of culture, race, religion or background. For this, Kazakhstan is ready to invite an international commission to work and be in a multinational republic. We urge that all violations of human rights cease immediately. We are also ready to invite a commission of experts to inspect hospitals in our republic. We also propose that all we also feel this to be a guarantee of the rule of law in our republic. I urge that all question of granting sovereignty to the Baltics, Georgia, and Moldavia to be given at once. **********It's true that this may cost some money but human lives are more valuable. **********In the new union there should be no union cabinet of ministers or union parliament, except groups or delegations from different republics. **********This is a moment of truth. I cannot see any other basis on which Kazakhstan will be willing to join the union. This is our strategy, and in the near future we have to form not a cabinet of ministers but a transitional goverment in which all of the republics will participate as part of an economic commonwealth. This interim economic council can include all of those including those who have decided to leave the union but are determined to continue their economic cooperation later. **********I don't want anybody to have the illusion that Kazakhstan will be anybody's younger brother. We will join a union only with equal rights and opportunities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/busin.body_text: **********The Government this week will no longer emphasize figures for the gross national product, favoring instead numbers on gross domestic product. **********What's the difference? **********The gross national product measures all the goods and services produced by workers and capital supplied by United States residents or corporations, regardless of location. The gross domestic product measures all the goods and services produced by workers and capital in the United States. **********Profits that a United States company receives from its overseas operations are included in the G.N.P. while profits foreign-owned businesses made in the United States are excluded. **********The profits on the overseas operations of United States companies are excluded from the G.D.P. while the earnings of foreign companies in the United States are included. **********Private economists support the change, saying it will make America's most important economic yardstick compatible with how most other countries measure their own economies. **********"No one measure is perfect," said Michael Evans, head of a Washington forecasting firm.
