"but a far better measure of how the U.S. economy is doing is what is produced inside our borders rather than what is produced all around the world." **********The Commerce Department will still publish the G.N.P. figure, but the first look at G.N.P. will come a month after the comparable G.D.P. report.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/05/world.body_text: **********The United Nations envoy, Cyrus R. Vance, said today that a cease-fire had so far failed to take hold in Yugoslavia, hindering the dispatch of a peacekeeping force to end five months of civil war. **********"Clearly, obstacles remain," Mr. Vance told journalists after meeting the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman. "The cease-fire hasn't taken hold and it must. The cease-fire is a very fundamental part of the problems we have to face." **********Mr. Vance, on the fourth day of a mission to Yugoslavia to assess chances for bringing in United Nations troops, arrived in Zagreb after a fresh round of talks in Belgrade with the Yugoslav Defense Minister, Veljko Kadijevic, on Wednesday morning. **********Clearly shocked by the destruction he saw on a visit to the Croatian town of Osijek on Tuesday, Mr. Vance called the meeting with Mr. Kadijevic to press him on what he said were army violations of Yugoslavia's latest cease-fire. **********Mr. Vance has repeatedly said that a solid cease-fire must be established between the Serbs, Croats and the federal army before United Nations troops can be dispatched. **********Despite his somber tone, the former United States Secretary of State did not rule out that peacekeeping forces could be sent. **********"I'm going to be here for several more days," he said. **********"In that time I will have to come up with a recommendation for the Secretary General. I don't want to prejudge what that will be." **********Mr. Vance said several other problems also remained, including the unblocking of Yugoslav army bases by Croatia and the withdrawal of federal troops from the republic.  By Car to Zagreb **********His trip to Croatia, which took him by plane to Graz in Austria then by car to Zagreb, came as sporadic fighting continued in the republic, including new shelling of Osijek in which one person was killed, according to Croatian radio. **********The Belgrade-based news agency Tanjug quoted the federal army as reporting intensive artillery exchanges near Novska on the closed Belgrade-Zagreb highway. **********Fighting was also reported around the Adriatic port of Dubrovnik. Croatian radio said a woman was killed and three houses were destroyed by artillery fire in one outlying village.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/15/busin.body_text: **********FIVE years ago, when W. Thomas Stephens became the Manville Corporation's chief executive, he toured several company plants. He expected to see somber workers. Manville, after all, was in bankruptcy -- asbestos, its original raison d'etre, had been found to cause a deadly form of lung cancer and the company was fighting a withering array of lawsuits; and, its attempts to remake itself into a fiberglass and paper packaging concern were causing chaos in the evolving corporate culture. **********Still, he did not expect the outright hostility he got. "Wherever I went, I'd get this, 'Why should I trust you?' attitude," Mr. Stephens recalls. "I realized then that management's reaction to the horrors of the last decade had been to shut the windows, close the doors, hide behind a cloak of secrecy, not only externally but internally as well." **********In fact, Mr. Stephens was suffering from what he calls "C.E.O. disease," a communications disorder in which the chief executive has a distorted view of what the troops think because he or she gets all information from top management. His cure of choice: A President's Council, comprised of 15 or so Manville employees, representing different levels and business units. The council members, who serve indefinite terms, are charged with alerting him to communications glitches at any level of the hierarchy. **********"Our job is to make sure that no information gets filtered out, on the way up or on the way down," said Georgianna Peterson, an employee relations manager on the council. **********Mr. Stephens offers a more colorful description: "Their job is to get me hot and bothered enough about communications problems so that I'm motivated to fix them." **********Apparently they do that job well. Since the council's inception three years ago, Manville has developed a set of governing principles, as well as a mechanism to encourage supervisors to hash out those principles with their staffs. Mr. Stephens has ended his habit of formal plant tours that are orchestrated by plant managers in favor of informal drop-ins during which he visits with workers. **********He now periodically sends letters describing the company's strategic goals to employees at their homes, where middle managers cannot inadvertently forget to distribute them and where families can review them. The letters, which include stamped envelopes addressed to Mr. Stephens, invite employees' suggestions or criticisms on any aspect of Manville's operations. More than 500 letters have come in, all of which Mr. Stephens says he answered personally. **********Council members use voice mail, corridor conversation or any other data gathering method they like to query their colleagues on what issues they want taken up with Mr. Stephens. They then convene to set priorities on issues. Finally, they confront Mr. Stephens with those issues. **********The issues can be as concrete as the cost factors involved in Manville's new flexible benefits plan, or as abstract as expressions of vague uneasiness about the way assets are allocated among divisions. **********"Tom never sidesteps questions or sugarcoats answers, and we make sure we convey everything he says when we go back home," said Arthur E. Flach, a technical support specialist on the council. **********Actually, the ground rules for reporting back are that only Mr. Stephens is quoted by name; anything that any council member says is repeated anonymously. **********One reason is that "We don't want a cult of personalities," said Sharon Stensaas, until recently a manager of employee communications, who helped set up the council. Another is so that lower-level council members need not worry about repercussions from their comments when they return home. "No one's afraid to speak out," said Janis Dolan, a maintenance worker on the council. **********Mr. Stephens continues to look for new ways to convey information directly. In the works: A system for sending monthly voice mail messages to employees, and for them to respond. He is also looking into whether to teleconference council meetings, so that they wreak less havoc with everyone's schedules. **********He stresses that none of these methods will replace face-to-face rap sessions, though. He tells a recent story to illustrate why: **********Last month, Mr. Stephens says, he wandered from floor to floor at the Denver headquarters, buttonholing people and asking them what was on their minds. **********"I figured they were all worried that we had lost money in the last quarter," Mr. Stephens said. "Turns out, they had full confidence in the company. They were a lot more worried about our plan to move offices. It just shows that you can't guess what's bothering folks; you have to ask." GETTING THE BOARD INVOLVED **********Manville's board, intrigued with the President's Council concept, has dined with the group twice. Directors say it was eye-opening for both sides. **********"Council members seemed surprised that we saw them as people, not numbers," said Robert E. Fowler, a Manville director who heads the Silvestri Corporation, a Chicago distributor of decorative accessories. **********Board members, meanwhile, were surprised at the nonadversarial stance taken by the council's union workers. Archie R. Dykes, chief executive of the Nashville-based Education Corporation of America and a Manville director, said he felt better about giving a green light to a multimillion-dollar expansion at Manville's West Monroe, La., plant after talking to an hourly worker on the council. **********"He clearly understood that he had as much at stake in Manville's success as did shareholders," Mr. Dykes said. **********The directors are expanding their dialogue with workers beyond the council. Plant visits are now part of all board meeting agendas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/world.main_headline: Albanians Expose High Living by Ex-Rulers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/world.print_headline: Albanians Expose High Living by Ex-Rulers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/world.body_text: **********They sent their daughters to Vienna "for treatment of migraine" at a cost of $3,400 or more. They secretly billed the Government for imported clothes, cosmetics, appliances, vacation homes and items as banal as camera film and soccer magazine subscriptions -- at a cost of $2 million a year. They enjoyed the best of food and drink. **********They are members of the 26 families of the Communist elite that for more than four decades ruled Albania, the poorest country of Europe. **********Now an item-by-item accounting of the indulgences of the former Communist leaders has been made public by a special investigating commission. **********While considerable information has emerged over the last 20 months about the lavish living of senior party officials in Romania, Bulgaria and the former East Germany, the Albanian report appears to be the most detailed and comprehensive portrayal of the practices of a Communist elite. **********Its completeness derives from the fact that the Albanian Communist leaders concentrated the bulk of their avarice in a single operation called the Directorate of Receptions, which recorded every transaction in detail. **********The directorate was created in 1956 by Enver Hoxha, the Stalinist dictator who ruled for 41 years until his death in 1985. Its authorization was secretly decreed by the party Politburo. **********Until early this year, when the Communist Party lost its monopoly on power, the directorate maintained a staff of 646 employees. **********The 26 families, including those of Mr. Hoxha and his successor, Ramiz Alia, were virtually all headed by members of the Politburo that ran the ruling Communist Party, including some who had retired. **********As described by Genc Ruli, the Finance Minister of the coalition Government elected in June, the inquiry into the last three years of the directorate's work led to the conclusion "that the former party leadership created for itself every opportunity to acquire privileges and enrich itself while the people were deceived by bogus and cynical propaganda about a struggle against privileges, luxury and inequality." **********For public purposes, Mr. Ruli noted, the Communist leaders said their salaries were the equivalent of $1,600 a year -- little more than twice the average factory wages in Albania. **********In fact, the inquiry showed that in addition to many other benefits, the leaders and their relatives were given subsidies that kept their rent, fuel and electricity bills to a total of $25 a month per family. **********Last year, when food was rationed for almost all of the 3.5 million Albanians, the priviliged party families received huge quantities of food free. The investigators estimated that the meat -- 136 pounds a day for the 26 families -- would have filled the quotas of 450 ordinary Albanian families. **********The Hoxha family alone -- including his widow and three children -- was supplied last year with 2 tons of meat, 310 pounds of butter, 62 gallons of beer and over 80 gallons of brandy and wine. **********The party families received other benefits ranging from the minor to the munificent. These included an annual vacation allowance of $19.20, entertainment subsidies of as much as $22,300 and up to $18,900 worth of private telephone calls abroad. **********The elite lived in spacious houses set in a protected compound in Tirana. When its occupants were moved out to apartments last spring, they looted furnishings and appliances valued at hundreds of thousands of dollars, according to Mr. Ruli's report to Parliament. **********Among the biggest spenders -- accounting for hundreds of thousands of dollars -- was Nexhmije Hoxha, the 70-year-old widow of the former dictator. **********In addition to free medical treatment at a special clinic, the ruling families often traveled abroad for medical attention. Former Deputy Prime Minister Manush Myftiu's daughter-in-law was sent to Vienna at a cost $3,800 for treatment of migraine headaches, as was the daughter of Besnik Bekteshi, a Politburo member, at a cost of $3,400. **********Mr. Ruli said legal proceedings had been instituted against members of the 26 families and that Albanian courts would determine their "legal accountability" and the "level of compensation these persons will have to pay."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/19/busin.main_headline: Greenspan Asserts the Recession May Be at an End, or Nearly So
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/19/busin.print_headline: Greenspan Asserts the Recession May Be at an End, or Nearly So
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/19/busin.body_text: **********Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the recession might already have ended but that no measurable expansion of the nation's economy had yet begun. **********"Clearly we have data which are subject to revision and are likely to be revised one way or the other," Mr. Greenspan told the House Ways and Means Committee. "But it's very difficult to get around the data of the last several weeks, which are strongly suggestive that the bottom is somewhere in the second quarter." **********The financial markets interpreted Mr. Greenspan's statement as an indication that the Federal Reserve is unlikely to reduce interest rates even though inflation seems well under control, and stock and bond prices fell slightly today. **********Mr. Greenspan's remarks were the first in which the nation's principal economic policy maker has said publicly that the recession might be over. A similar consensus has emerged among private economists in the last two weeks. **********In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan made these other comments about the economy: ***********Banks continue to be reluctant to lend, and credit is still tight. ***********The commercial real estate market remains in a slump and is not likely to recover as quickly as the rest of the economy does. ***********Foreign trade barriers do not significantly depress American exports, while United States trade barriers cost American consumers tens of billions of dollars a year. Optimism About Inflation **********In response to a question from Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Long Island, Mr. Greenspan said he was "confident that we can come out of this with a recovery without concurrently reigniting inflationary forces, which inevitably, within a reasonably short period, create the next recession." **********But he added that "we don't yet see any measurable upward thrust" in the nation's output of goods and services. And in response to further questions, Mr. Greenspan refused to say how long a recovery might last or how strong it might be. **********In testimony two weeks ago, however, Mr. Greenspan said the recovery might be stronger than expected. **********At a separate hearing by the Senate Finance Committee on the nomination of David W. Mullins Jr. to become vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, Mr. Mullins said the economy had touched bottom in the last month or so, or was about to do so. Edward Kelley, a Federal Reserve governor, told the Senate Banking Committee last week that the economy appeared to have bottomed out. **********Congressional pressure for lower rates notwithstanding, Mr. Mullins said, "it's not apparent that there is room" for the central bank to ease monetary policy soon without raising fears of inflation that could drive up rates on longer-term bonds. An increase in interest rates on long-term bonds might defeat the purpose of stimulating the economy by easing monetary policy, Mr. Mullins said. **********By pumping more money into the nation's banking system, the Federal Reserve can drive down short-term rates, making it cheaper for stores to hold large inventories and for consumers to take out home equity loans. **********But such a move tends to drive up long-term rates, as lenders become concerned that inflation will seriously devalue the money they are to be repaid. Long-term rates tend to affect purchases of homes and other large investments. **********Mr. Mullins said any gain to the economy from driving down short-term rates now would probably be offset by the loss from higher long-term rates. **********Mr. Greenspan said banks continue to be cautious in their lending practices, as they try to build up capital in case many of their nonperforming loans must be written off entirely. As a result, he said, "We are still in the grips of a credit crunch." **********Many of the banking industry's problem loans have financed commercial real estate. Mr. Greenspan said this sector of the economy would "lag quite considerably" in its recovery from the recession. **********"It shows very few signs that I can see that it is in the process of stabilizing; there's some, but not a great deal," he said. "But surely there is no evidence at this point which suggests that it is improving or about to." **********But an upturn in the number of Americans employed is likely a few months after a rebound in the nation's total output of goods and services, Mr. Greenspan said. **********Few questions to Mr. Greenspan from members of the House Ways and Means Committee dealt with the original subject of the hearing, the competitiveness of the United States in international markets. **********In his opening remarks, Mr. Greenspan strongly endorsed the Administration's position of eliminating trade barriers and holding down Government intervention in the market. There have been plausible estimates that "the unilateral removal of quantitative restrictions on imports of textiles, apparel and various agricultural products would result in net gains to U.S. consumers amounting to tens of billions of dollars," he said. **********"Moreover," he added, "the complete removal of existing foreign restrictions on U.S. exports probably would reduce our trade deficit by only modest amounts." **********Mr. Greenspan said the Federal Government should not provide subsidies to specific industries even if they appear especially likely to succeed. If the industries have genuinely good prospects, then the private sector will finance them, he said. **********But the chairman of the Federal Reserve has no legal authority over these issues, and many in Congress already have firm views about them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/22/busin.main_headline: Chase Has Profit as Turnaround Continues
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/22/busin.print_headline: Chase Has Profit as Turnaround Continues
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/22/busin.body_text: **********Chase Manhattan, although still working its way out of staggering loan losses, reported a $136 million net profit yesterday for the third quarter. The banking company attributed its turnabout partly to falling interest rates and to drastic cost-cutting over the last year. **********The profit, equal to 79 cents for each outstanding share of common stock, contrasted to a loss in last year's third quarter of $623 million. Chase has been profitable in each quarter this year, and net income for the first nine months totaled $385 million, or $2.31 a share, in contrast to a loss of $527 million in the comparable period on 1990. **********"Chase is turning itself around," said Thomas Hanley, a bank analyst at Salomon Brothers. "The various operating variables are going in the right direction." **********In a statement, Thomas G. Labrecque, the chairman and chief executive of the Chase Manhattan Corporation as well as the Chase Manhattan Bank, noted that the company's capital as a percentage of assets -- mostly loans outstanding -- had risen in the quarter and that staff cutbacks had "exceeded our target reduction of 5,000 employees." He did not say by how much. **********"We continue to be encouraged by Chase's progress," Mr. Lebreque said. He said in early October that third-quarter income would be about 80 cents a share. **********Chase's shares rose 50 cents yesterday, closing at $19 on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Net interest revenue -- mostly the spread between what Chase earns from interest on the loans it makes and what it pays to borrow the money that is lent out -- rose to $863 million from $795 million in last year's third quarter. Interest rates paid by Chase's borrowers fell more slowly than the rates the bank paid on deposits and to borrow funds in the market place. **********Chase also reported a $45 million contribution to income, representing interest payments from Brazil, which had not made such payments on its Chase loans in last year's third quarter. **********"If you look at the profitability ratio, Chase now has a return on average shareholder equity of 10.5 percent, which I would consider about average for Chase going back over time," Mr. Hanley said. In last year's third quarter, the return on shareholder equity was a negative 58.9 percent. **********Chase also reported an increase in the bank's capital, which serves as a cushion against loan losses. The most important capital measure, tier-one equity capital as a percent of risk-based assets, rose to 5.2 percent, well above the 4 percent minimum that will be required by the end of next year under newly adopted international banking standards. In addition, Chase's nonperforming loans, on which payments are not being made, fell to a total of $4.4 billion from $4.6 billion in the second quarter and $4.6 billion in last year's third quarter.  Loan Losses Decline **********Net loan losses fell in the third quarter, to $656 million from $682 million in the second quarter. But the charge-offs were far above the $380 million lost in last year's third quarter. The figures included $236 million in domestic loan charge-offs in the third quarter, down $22 million from the second quarter but $21 million above the comparable period last year. **********Consumer loans accounted for the biggest loss, $123 million, the same as in the second quarter. Commercial real estate losses were $86 million, compared with $117 million in the second quarter and $61 million in last year's third quarter. **********Chase put aside $265 million in the third quarter for possible loan losses in the future, the same amount as in the second quarter and down sharply from the $650 million in last year's third quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/06/world.main_headline: Text of the Radio Address by the President
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/06/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF; Text of the Radio Address by the President
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/06/world.body_text: **********Following is the text of the radio address by President Bush today, as issued by the White House: **********As the new year begins, new challenges unfold -- challenges to America and the future of our world. Simply put: 1990 saw Iraq invade and occupy Kuwait. 1991 will see Iraq withdraw, preferably by choice; by force, if need be. It is my most sincere hope 1991 is a year of peace. I've seen the hideous face of war and counted the costs of conflict in friends lost. I remember this all too well, and have no greater concern than the well-being of our men and women stationed in the Persian Gulf. True, their morale is sky-high. True, if they are called upon to fight the aggressors, they will do their job courageously, professionally and, in the end, decisively. There will be no more Vietnams. **********But we should go the extra mile before asking our servicemen and women to stand in harm's way. We should, and we have. The United Nations, with the full support of the United States, has already tried to peacefully pressure Iraq out of Kuwait, implementing economic sanctions, and securing the condemnation of the world in the form of no less than 12 resolutions of the U.N. Security Council. **********This week, we've taken one more step. I have offered to have Secretary of State James Baker meet with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Switzerland. yesterday, we received word that Iraq has accepted our offer to meet in Geneva.  Baker's Message **********This will not be secret diplomacy at work. Secretary Baker will restate, in person, a message for Saddam Hussein: Withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally and immediately, or face the terrible consequences. **********Eleven days from today, Saddam Hussein will either have met the United Nations deadline for a full and unconditional withdrawal, or he will have once again defied the civilized world. This is a deadline for Saddam Hussein to comply with the United Nations resolution, not a deadline for our own Armed Forces. Still, time is running out. It's running out because each day that passes brings real costs. **********Saddam already poses a strategic threat to the capital cities of Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Israel and Syria, as well as our own men and women in the gulf region. In fact, Saddam has used chemical weapons of mass destruction against innocent villagers, his own people. Each day that passes brings Saddam Hussein further on the path to developing biological and nuclear weapons and the missiles to deliver them. If Saddam corners the world energy market, he can then finance further aggression, terror and blackmail. Each day that passes increases Saddam's worldwide threat to democracy.  Economic Effects **********The struggling newborn democracies of Eastern Europe and Latin America already face a staggering challenge in making the transition to a free market. But the added weight of higher oil prices is a crushing burden they cannot afford. And our own economy is suffering, suffering the effects of higher oil prices and lower growth stemming from Saddam's aggression. **********Each day that passes, Saddam's forces also fortify and dig in deeper into Kuwait. We risk paying a higher price in the most precious currency of all -- human life -- if we give Saddam more time to prepare for war. And each day that passes is another day of fear, suffering and terror for the people of Kuwait, many who risked their lives to shelter and hide Americans from Iraqi soldiers. As the Emir of Kuwait said to our Vice President just last week, those who advocate waiting longer for sanctions to work do not have to live under such brutal occupation. **********As I have discussed with members of Congress, just two days ago and in our many other consultations, economic sanctions are taking a toll, but they are still not forcing Saddam out of Kuwait. Nor do we know when or even if they will be successful. As a result, America and her partners in this unprecedented coalition are sharing the burden of this important mission; and we are ready to use force to defend a new order emerging among the nations of the world, a world of sovereign nations living in peace.  Forces at the Front **********We have seen too often in this century how quickly any threat to one becomes a threat to all. At this critical moment in history, at a time the cold war is fading into the past, we cannot fail. At stake is not simply some distant country called Kuwait. At stake is the kind of world we will inhabit. **********Last Thanksgiving, I broke bread with some of our men and women on the front lines. They understand why we are in Saudi Arabia, and what we may have to do. I witnessed courage unfazed by the closeness of danger and determination undiminished by the harsh desert sun. These men and women are America's finest. We owe each of them our gratitude and full support. That is why we must all stand together, not as Republicans or Democrats, conservatives or liberals, but as Americans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/busin.body_text: **********The Compaq Computer Corporation told some retailers its newest laptop computer might not be available until March. Houston computer dealers said they had received back orders for the LTE 386s20, the seven-and-a-half-pound Compaq machine introduced in October. **********Until Compaq can catch up with demand, it has placed dealers on "allocation," a Compaq spokesman, Bob Beach, said. Dealers with the strongest record of selling laptops in volume will receive preference. Mr. Beach would only confirm that the company was short of several components, including disk drives.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/world.print_headline: Ugandan Says Muslim Group Plotted to Assassinate Him
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/world.body_text: **********Uganda's President, Yoweri Museveni, says he has uncovered a plot by a radical Muslim group to assassinate him, a Government-owned newspaper reported today. **********The paper, New Vision, said Mr. Museveni made the allegation in an address to a Muslim gathering in Kampala on Friday. He did not name the group but said it had objected to his being invited into a local mosque because he is non-Muslim. Muslims who spoke on condition of anonymity said the reported threat was linked to internal conflicts in the Ugandan Muslim community.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/09/busin.main_headline: Debt Payments Offset Profits For Maxwell's U.S. Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/09/busin.print_headline: Debt Payments Offset Profits For Maxwell's U.S. Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/09/busin.body_text: **********The Maxwell Communication Corporation's American operations have performed solidly since 1988, when most of them were acquired for about $3.3 billion in a splurge of buying. **********But the debt incurred to acquire them at what many analysts now see as highly inflated prices has undermined the company. **********The American properties -- principally Macmillan Publishing, the Standard Rate and Data Service, Official Airline Guides Inc. and a 50 percent stake in Macmillan/McGraw-Hill School Publishing -- accounted for about 90 percent of Maxwell Communication's operating profits in the fiscal year ended March 31, said Susan Aldridge, the company's chief financial officer. The company's annual operating profits totaled $:200.2 million, or roughly $347 million. **********In that fiscal year, however, Maxwell Communication's interest payments on its debt totaled $:196 million, or roughly $340 million, almost completely offsetting these profits. **********"The business have performed more strongly than Maxwell really had any right to expect," said William Reilly, chairman of the magazine publisher K-III Holdings Inc. and former president of Maxwell Communication. "In fact, the financial results have been excellent. **********"But he overpaid in a major way at a time when prices for media properties were sky high, and the debt is taking a toll," Mr. Reilly added, referring to Robert Maxwell, the company's founder, who died Tuesday. **********The obligations on Maxwell Communication's debt, now estimated at $2.5 billion, are pressuring the company to sell American properties whose strong performance might otherwise incline it to keep them. A loan repayment of $750 million is due next October. **********Since September, the company has sold four American businesses -- Maxwell Macmillan Professional and Business Reference Publishing, the medical book division, the Macmillan directory division (which publishes "Who's Who") and, most recently, its stake in Berlitz International Inc. -- for a total of $479 million. **********These were all solid businesses for Maxwell Communication. Berlitz, for example, increased its sales by 35.5 percent in the last fiscal year to $:152.9 million, or roughly $265 million. An executive formerly involved in the business said Berlitz's profit margin was probably at least 17 percent.  'We Are Not Rushing Around' **********"The disposal program is directed toward the repayment of debt, and that program continues," said David Shaffer, the company's new chief operating officer. "But we are not rushing around engaging in any new conversations. We are continuing the discussions with various interested parties that we have been having for the past four to six months." **********He declined to say what other pieces of the corporation's American operations might be for sale. But some analysts suggested one possibility was the Standard Rate and Data Service, which provides information on media rates to advertisers and is believed to have a profit margin in excess of 20 percent. **********"The Maxwell businesses here are all very good businesses and they are doing well," said Robert S. Pirie, the president and chief executive of Rothschild Inc. and one of the Maxwell family's investment bankers. **********The corporation's Macmillan Publishing Company has done particularly well in a generally difficult climate. Its adult-trade, or general-interest, publishing unit has earned a reputation for tight management at a time when many other publishers have consistently overpaid for books. Results in Other Sectors **********Meanwhile, the less volatile college, reference and juvenile sectors have also produced excellent results, said a former officer of Macmillan, who added that profit margins at Macmillan Publishing exceeded 20 percent on sales of about $350 million. **********Moreover, the 50-50 joint venture with McGraw-Hill Inc. in school publishing, set up in 1989, has also been highly successful. Last year, for example, it reached a record 36 percent share of the school market in Texas. **********The least successful part of Maxwell Communication's 1988 buying spree -- during which Macmillan was acquired for $2.6 billion, or about 20 times its earnings -- has been Official Airline Guides, a largely stagnant business bought for $750 million. **********If Maxwell Communication chooses to sell Official Airline Guides, analysts believe it will have to settle for a much lower price than it paid. 'So Many Sudden Changes' **********The problems for Maxwell Communication have been compounded by the fact that Robert Maxwell's death followed the departure of Harry A. McQuillen, the president of Macmillan Publishing. His successor has not yet been named. **********"It obviously unnerves some people to have so many sudden changes at the top," said Barry Lippman, who heads the adult-trade division at Macmillan. But he added that Mr. Shaffer had quickly put people in the publishing company at ease. **********This week, for example, Mr. Lippman was making a large bid for a book and sought Mr. Shaffer's approval while he was in London to talk with the Maxwell family. A faxed response came back immediately. "He must carry his fax machine on his hip," Mr. Lippman said. **********In general, two former officials of Maxwell Communication said, Robert Maxwell tended to be less involved with the American book and information-service businesses than he was with his newspapers. The adjustment to his death, they sugested, should therefore be less traumatic. Abandoning a Spinoff Plan **********Still, financial pressures remain severe. Some analysts suggested this was the reason the company said this week that it was moving away from an earlier plan to spin off some American businesses into a separate public company. **********Mr. Shaffer declined to explain the switch. He would say only that one aim of the "de-merger plan" had been to bring all the businesses of Maxwell Communication under American management, and that this had already been achieved by his appointment as the company's chief operating officer. He was previously president of Macmillan Inc., the corporation's American holding company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/03/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; New Zealand Pay-TV Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/03/busin.body_text: **********The two largest American cable television companies and two regional Bell telephone companies announced today that they had bought 51 percent of Sky Entertainment Television, a fledgling pay-television service in New Zealand. **********The buyers are Bell Atlantic of Philadelphia and Ameritech of Chicago, which together bought New Zealand's state-owned telephone company last year for $2.3 billion; Tele-Communications of Denver, and Time Warner of New York. **********Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Sky Entertainment, which has been in business for a year, broadcasts three channels of programming over UHF channels to customers who pay for decoders that unscramble the television signals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/busin.main_headline: All About/Snack Foods; Keeping the Gobblers, Chasing the Nibblers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/busin.print_headline: All About/Snack Foods; Keeping the Gobblers, Chasing the Nibblers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/busin.body_text: **********As aging baby boomers thicken around the middle, they nibble instead of gobble. Blithe college students shovel corn chips straight from the bag into their mouths, but paunchy young professionals count their Ritz crackers as they reach for the bean dip. **********The snack-food industry, which built its fortune on the voracious, must now come up with products that appeal to a variety of appetites, as well as answer consumers' growing worries about health and nutrition. To increase sales, it must win the nibblers and keep the gobblers. **********So, for the first time in more than 20 years, the industry is developing truly new products. It is making healthier, or at least healthier seeming, snacks made from grains and prepared with little or no oil with saturated fats. Sales of Frito-Lay's Sunchips and Mesa Food's Chi-Chi's white corn tortilla chips are thriving. Old standbys, like pretzels and popcorn, both of which can be made without oil, are enjoying a revival. **********The modern American snack-food business has become a nearly $12 billion industry, a point reached in 1989, dominated by a small shelf full of companies led by Pepsico Inc.'s Frito-Lay division, and other giants like Borden and Anheuser-Busch Inc. **********The typical snack-food consumer is someone from 15 to 20 years old and inured to the criticism that snack food is empty calories, high in sodium and saturated fats -- which have been linked to heart disease. **********As the baby boom generation ages, more of the population is hitting the far side of 45 years old. Having experienced intimations of mortality, this growing group is increasingly concerned about its health. About 80 percent of all snack foods are eaten by just 20 percent of snack-food consumers, typically those under 20 years old. **********"When people ask me what I do," said George J. Waydo, president of the snack- foods division of Borden Inc., "I tell them I'm in one of mankind's oldest and most important pursuits -- oral gratification." **********Who Sells the Most? Frito-Lay Is Leading a $12 Billion Market **********In 1989, the latest year for which data are available, Americans spent nearly $130 per household per year on snack foods, according to the Snack Food Association, a trade group. **********That amount is up nearly 10 percent from the year before and is growing substantially faster than other food categories, like soup or cereal. Since a person can only eat so much, increased snacking displaces other foods, but which ones is unclear. It is likely that salty snacks are taking a little bit away from cookies, crackers, ice cream and candy bars. **********Salty snacks is a catch-all category, as shown by what the average household eats: about 49 pounds per year of potato chips, tortilla chips, corn chips, pretzels, popcorn; "extruded" snacks like cheese puffs, which are forced and shaped through a dye; assorted nuts and onion rings, as well as foods that may call for an acquired taste, like pork rinds, the fried coating found on bacon. And what's the biggest item? Sixteen pounds of potato chips. **********The industry is not at all fragmented: Frito-Lay is the General Motors, Ford and Toyota of the snack-food business. Depending on which foods are included, Frito-Lay has nearly 50 percent of the market. **********Frito-Lay is strong in most of the major categories of the snack-food business, except nuts, with its dominant brands like Lay's potato chips, Doritos tortilla chips, Frito corn chips and Cheetos cheese-flavored snacks. **********Analysts say it is among the best-performing of the big food companies. In 1990, Frito-Lay had $5 billion in snack-food sales (some of it from foreign sales) and nearly $1 billion in profit in 1990. It is the smallest of Pepsico's three divisions in sales, but largest in profits. **********William Leach, a food industry analyst at Donaldson Lufkin Jenrette Securities, said Frito-Lay's 19 percent profit margin approaches that of Kellogg's. "And Kellogg buys corn for 4 cents a pound and sells it for $2 a box," said Mr. Leach. **********With this background in mind, it was small wonder that last month when Pepsico announced its first-quarter results, its stock price fell temporarily, by $1.75. While first-quarter worldwide sales rose 16 percent to $1.2 billion, operating profit dropped 4 percent to $175 million, mostly because of weak margins in the domestic market, the result of furious price cutting in the industry. **********The retail price of snacks, typically $1.49 a bag, is discounted on any given day from a third to a half -- roughly from 79 cents to 99 cents. **********Borden, with a snack-food portfolio similar to Frito-Lay's, is up and coming, though still a distant No. 2. Built aggressively during the 1980's by the acquisition of small regional companies, Borden has, for example, 12 brands of potato chips. **********Anheuser-Busch, the beer company, has its Eagle snacks subsidiary; RJR Nabisco Inc., the tobacco and food company, has its Planters nuts unit. They are also major presences in the market, but their snack-food divisions are minor parts of their total revenues. **********How Laggers Catch Up Efficient Production and Distribution **********The food industry's consolidation continues as big companies swallow up smaller ones. In the all-important supermarket portion of the industry, five companies made up 59 percent of sales last year, up from 58 percent the year before. **********Smaller companies, including Borden, find it difficult to compete with Frito-Lay because a high sales volume allows a company to spend more money on advertising, enhance its manufacturing efficiency and cut prices. **********"It's rough making money in this business," said Mr. Waydo, Borden's snack-foods executive. "Frito-Lay has the critical mass, so it would be murder trying to duplicate their distribution." Borden's solution: buy small regional companies, consolidate their distribution and pour national brands like Krunchers potato chips and new products like Wise Choice popcorn into the expanded distribution network. **********Borden is also using new machinery to eliminate expensive human labor. For example, optical scanners spot defective potato chips. As a result, Borden cut its manufacturing cost from up to 60 cents on the sales dollar during 1983 to 1985, to about 40 cents today. **********More profit can come from squeezing more savings from efficient distribution. Like Frito-Lay, Borden's distribution is direct to the store. That means a truck delivers to supermarkets daily -- about 4,000 trucks making half a million visits a week. **********"Having little trucks go door to door is the most inefficient thing you can do, unless you've got the volume," said Mr. Waydo. **********To pull more selling time out of its sales staff, Borden reorganized its distribution system. It went from using large warehouses to a system with 10 times as many small warehouses called "bin locations." These bin locations have smaller inventories of snack foods. Instead of having salespeople drive long distances to large warehouses, they now go to smaller centers. **********What's Healthy?  A Durum Wheat Snack: Suprimos **********But squeezing savings out of manufacturing and distribution goes only so far, as even efficient Frito-Lay knows. The market leader has long worried that snack-food consumption drops off sharply after consumers reach their 20's. **********To remedy this, in 1989, Frito-Lay bought Smartfoods, a small Boston entrepreneurial company that makes popcorn, to appeal to a wider and older audience. Young women, in particular, regard popcorn as lower in calories than other snack foods, even though it's coated, as Smartfoods' is, with Cheddar cheese, adding calories. **********"We needed to build a category in which people could snack throughout their 20's, and we felt that a product made from multigrains would be appealing," said David J. Guston, senior vice president marketing for Frito-Lay. **********That was the strategy behind Sunchips, introduced in a test market in February 1991. Ten years in development, Sunchips is made from wheat, corn, rice and oats and fried in canola oil, which is low in saturated fats. Achieving the right taste was the main hurdle: 10,000 consumer taste tests went into the development. **********What is Frito-Lay testing? Suprimos, durum wheat (as in pasta) snacks, coated in a cheese flavoring. "People do not need snack foods," Mr. Guston said. "Our job as marketers is to entertain and bring happiness to people." CHI-CHI'S CHIPS ARE EXTRA HOT **********The hottest product in snack foods illustrates how a slightly different product can appeal to a vastly wider audience. **********Sales of Chi-Chi's tortilla chips in grocery stores are growing at an annual rate of 50 percent, competitors say, and are now approaching 7 percent of a $2 billion tortilla-chip market. That is an impressive performance for chips that are available only in about a fifth of the country. **********Chi-Chi's chips are simply the ones that are handed out by the bowl at Chi-Chi's restaurants, a chain of 225 Anglo-Mexican restaurants in sections of the country where Mexican food is rare, like the Middle West. **********As with many snack foods, the great dividing line is between products in a bag, which appeal mainly to voracious young people under 20, and those in a box, which appeal mainly to nibblers over 40. **********Tortilla chips usually appeal to the very hungry, but Chi-Chi's chips, which are sold in a bag, are made from white corn, instead of yellow corn. **********"People think they are tasting a lighter product, less like corn," said Glenn D. Drasher, senior vice president of marketing at Chi-Chi's Inc., Louisville, Ky., a unit of Foodmaker Inc. in San Diego, which operates fast-food restaurants. **********Daniel R. Miller, executive vice president of Mesa Food Products Inc., which produces the chips under license from Chi-Chi's, said, white corn has "a more delicate, sweeter taste and it has a different mouth-feel altogether." **********Because Chi-Chi's product was first introduced in the company's restaurants, the chips are also popular for making nachos. "The beauty of this chip is that it gets the college crowd and the aging yuppies," said Mr. Miller.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/19/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Microsoft Stake In Publisher
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/19/busin.body_text: **********The Microsoft Corporation said today that it had purchased a 26 percent stake in Dorling Kindersley Ltd., a London-based book publisher. **********Dorling Kindersley specializes in highly illustrated, practical reference books for adults and children, including "The Way Things Work," by David Macaulay. **********Terms of the deal were not disclosed. As part of the agreement, the Microsoft Multimedia Publishing Group gains rights to license content from Dorling Kindersley for use in future software. **********Dorling Kindersley, which has a staff of more than 300 people, forecasts revenues of $70 million for the year that ends on June 30. **********"This relationship represents a fundamental shift in software products," William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. "To date, most software has provided tools for customers to use, such as spreadsheets, word processors and data bases. With multimedia titles, however, the shift is toward providing content to customers."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.main_headline: Making a Difference/The Soviet Coup; Shaken Up by a Hurricane From Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.print_headline: Making a Difference/The Soviet Coup; Shaken Up by a Hurricane From Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.body_text: **********James H. Giffen was sound asleep Monday morning when the manager of the Montauk hotel where he was vacationing woke him to say he had 30 minutes to evacuate because Hurricane Bob was coming through. Mr. Giffen switched on the television, to learn of a hurricane of quite a different sort: Mikhail S. Gorbachev was being ousted. "I drove right through that storm to Manhattan and started calling Moscow," Mr. Giffen recalled. **********Small wonder he reacted so: three years of hard work was threatening to go down the drain. **********Mr. Giffen, a lawyer who has written a widely used textbook on trade with the Soviet Union, is president of the American Trade Consortium, a coalition formed in 1988 by RJR Nabisco, Chevron, Eastman Kodak, Johnson & Johnson, Archer-Daniels-Midland, Ford Motor (which has since dropped out) and the Mercator Corporation -- the merchant bank that Mr. Giffen heads. Mr. Giffen, 50, was the group's wheel-greaser in chief, someone whose wide net of contacts and knowledge of the Soviet Union was supposed to help those companies form joint ventures there. **********Last week's failed coup was not the first obstacle Mr. Giffen has faced. "We got caught between the centralized Government and the republics, then between the economic reformers and the hardliners, then in the drama of the Yeltsin election," he said. Result: The dozen joint ventures he had hoped to put together by the end of 1990 did not get negotiated until March 1991. **********Mr. Giffen says he expects those ventures -- including a Chevron deal to drill for oil that is the largest joint venture under consideration in the Soviet Union -- to proceed on schedule, despite last week's turmoil. **********In fact, Mr. Giffen says the coup will turn out to be a marvelous thing. "The coup was tried by a bunch of hardliners who were trying to protect their jobs," he said. "Now the restored Government has a chance to replace the dunces with reasonable, experienced people." **********The future is not without questions, though. For one thing, will continued economic hardship pave the way for another coup? **********Mr. Giffen plays down that possibility. But what would he do if that happened? Says Mr. Giffen with but half a laugh: "Take another, more favorable look at trade with China."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/busin.main_headline: S.E.C. Widens Inquiry In Treasuries Scandal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/busin.print_headline: S.E.C. Widens Inquiry In Treasuries Scandal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/busin.body_text: **********The Treasuries market scandal that has rocked Salomon Brothers Inc. widened yesterday as the Securities and Exchange Commission began requesting documents from dozens of other firms, people who have been briefed on the growing inquiry said. The commission is seeking evidence of possible widespread collusion, fraud and other illegal practices in the $2.2 trillion Treasuries market. **********The far-reaching requests began to go out over the weekend, providing the first indication that Government investigators suspect that illegal bidding practices of the sort disclosed at Salomon Brothers may have been more widespread than previously thought. All primary dealers, which are the institutions authorized to trade directly with the Federal Reserve, are being asked to provide documents in the inquiry, said the people who were briefed on the investigation. They spoke yesterday on condition that they not be identified. **********The requests were issued after a formal order of investigation was approved by the S.E.C.'s commissioners. People involved in the case said that the Government's official name of the investigation did not even mention Salomon Brothers; it is called "In the Matter of Certain Treasury Notes." **********Naming the securities and not Salomon would seem to indicate that the commission believes the illegal activities might not be limited to those disclosed by the firm earlier this month. **********The S.E.C. has not yet subpoenaed other firms. Rather, it is asking for voluntary cooperation. "They expect voluntary compliance," one person involved in the case said. "If they don't get it, they will send subpoenas right away." **********The broadening of the investigation came as Salomon Brothers continued to move to restore order after the upheaval created by its admissions of illegal bidding in the Treasury market. Warren E. Buffett, the Omaha investor who was named chairman and chief executive of the firm on Sunday, flew to Washington yesterday to meet with a series of regulators who are currently investigating the firm. **********Mr. Buffett, whose company, Berkshire Hathaway Inc., put $700 million into Salomon in 1987 as the firm was fighting off a hostile takeover, replaced John H. Gutfreund, whose resignation as chairman and chief executive was accepted at a board meeting on Sunday. **********Salomon is currently under investigation by the S.E.C., the Treasury, the Federal Reserve and the Justice Department for its illegal bidding during several Treasury auctions. **********Salomon has admitted illegally purchasing more Treasury securities than the 35 percent maximum allowed any one firm, as well as other violations. Wall Street executives said such actions could create the perception that a leading force in the Treasuries market was dishonest and could damage market credibility worldwide. Dismissed Executives Replaced **********The firm also moved rapidly yesterday to replace two senior Salomon executives who were dismissed on Sunday for their role in the unfolding scandal. **********Salomon told its employees that Eric R. Rosenfeld, a 38-year-old managing director and co-head of fixed-income arbitrage, would be interim head of the Government trading desk. Hans Ulrich Hufschmid, 35, a vice president and manager of the foreign exchange desk in London, was named head of foreign exchange in New York. **********The two men replace Paul Mozer and Thomas Murphy, the two former top traders on the government desk who were dismissed for their roles in submitting illegal bids during several Treasury auctions since last December. **********As Mr. Buffett worked in Washington yesterday to contain the damage at Salomon, Deryck C. Maughan, the former co-head of investment banking, who was named chief operating officer on Sunday, took the firm's reins, seeking to calm executives at the New York office. **********In a series of morning meetings, Mr. Maughan repeatedly told the firm's executives and employees that he believed that Salomon should now turn back to its business. **********The statements were given at 8 A.M. at a meeting of the sales and trading departments and were repeated at a meeting of the investment banking division at about 8:35 A.M. **********"He said that we have hit bottom and we are going to go up from here," one executive who heard Mr. Maughan's statements said. "He said that there were going to be some of them who worried about these extraordinary events, and that the rest of us should get back to business." **********Mr. Maughan's statements were greeted with applause by Salomon employees, people who attended the meetings said.  Effect of Soviet Coup **********Salomon was also helped yesterday by outside factors. With traders re-energized by the tumult created in the financial world by the coup that deposed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, morale at the firm picked up. **********"I don't mean this the wrong way, but the coup couldn't have happened at a better time," one executive with the firm said. "In this, the marketplace needs Salomon Brothers, and people here can't help but focus on the marketplace." **********But many changes at the firm were evident. During yesterday's Treasury auction, Salomon participated, but employees were under the watchful eyes of lawyers and compliance officers to insure that all bids were properly done. As mandated by the Government on Sunday, the firm was prevented from placing bids for clients at the auctions. **********The government trading desk was also operating under a series of new rules that the lawyers and officers made sure were met. **********The changes at Salomon have not yet solved the firm's problems with its customers. Indeed, the California Public Employees' Retirement System, the nation's largest state pension fund, met yesterday to decide what actions it should take because of the scandal. **********"The question of whether or not to impose any sanctions on Salomon is currently under discussion," said Gray Davis, the California State Comptroller. "Clearly we have a fiduciary obligation to our benficiaries in this." **********The efforts to control the damage at Salomon Brothers came as primary dealers throughout Wall Street began to receive notification that the S.E.C. wanted voluminous documentation from them as part of its investigation of the scandal. **********A six-page letter dated Aug. 16 from William McLucas, the head of the S.E.C.'s enforcement division, began to be sent over the weekend to the 40 primary dealers, which are the largest buyers at government auctions. **********Mr. McLucas declined yesterday to comment on the S.E.C. investigation.  The S.E.C. Request **********In the letter, he said that the "staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission is requesting that primary dealers provide" documents that might detail a number of illegal schemes being examined by the commission. The requests apply to documents held by both the firms and their employees. **********The S.E.C. inquiry is examining possible illegal activities that have taken place at Treasury auctions since July 12, 1990 -- far earlier than the first violation that was admitted this month by Salomon. That violation took place at the December auction last year. **********Many of the requests for information deal with any collaborative arrangements that would indicate an effort to purchase secretly more than the legal maximum for a firm -- 35 percent of any single auction.  A Line of Inquiry: 'Parking' **********The request for documents indicates that the S.E.C. suspects the Salomon scandal could involve "parking," the same violation that was at the heart of the scandal that brought down Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in the 1980's. Parking is a practice in which the true owner of a security is hidden through an arrangement with another party, allowing the owner to avoid reporting and other legal requirements. **********In its letter, the S.E.C. asked for documents that relate to "the submission of false bids at any auction for U.S. Treasury securities or any parking or similar arrangements." **********That line of inquiry is focusing on whether firms may have submitted bids in customers' names with an agreement that the firm, not the customer, would be the true owner of any securities purchased. Such an arrangement could allow a firm to buy more than 35 percent of the securities. Deadline of Aug. 29 **********Salomon has admitted submitting bids in the names of customers who had not authorized or approved the orders. **********The S.E.C. is also seeking any information that would indicate that any customers of the primary dealers had submitted bids for any single Treasury auction at a single yield level that would exceed the 35 percent maximum. **********In addition, the inquiry is examining whether any firms have maintained "overstated, excessive or inaccurate information" in their records. **********The S.E.C. appears to be trying to gather the information quickly in its inquiry. Despite the breadth of its request, the commission has set an Aug. 29 deadline for voluntary compliance with the requests for information.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/03/world.main_headline: U.S. Officials Believe Iraq Will Take Years to Rebuild
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/03/world.print_headline: U.S. Officials Believe Iraq Will Take Years to Rebuild
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/03/world.body_text: **********Three months after the Persian Gulf war devastated Iraq's military and many of its civilian industries, the country remains seriously incapacitated, facing a potentially catastrophic health crisis this summer and many years of rebuilding its civilian economy, Bush Administration analysts say. **********A comprehensive assessment of the damage from the intense 43-day allied bombardment remains classified within the Administration, which has been reluctant to divulge details. But an overview of the damage to key sectors of Iraq's economy emerged in recent days from a series of interviews with Administration analysts, who agreed to discuss it if they were not identified. **********The assessment indicates that Iraq's electrical power industry may have been damaged well beyond the intentions of allied war planners, who developed a still-secret weapon that dropped thousands of metallic filaments onto the electrical network at key points to create huge short-circuits and blackouts on the night of January 17th, when the war began. This was followed by precision strikes on power plants. Most Power Still Out **********Even now, 80 percent of the the nation's power grid is out of service, and electrical shortages are aggravating the crisis in health care. **********In addition, allied warplanes wrecked Iraq's civilian telecommunications system, described as a total loss by one estimate; and the bombing campaign seriously damaged the national network of roads and bridges, crippling commerce in a nation that straddles two major river valleys, those of the Tigris and the Euphrates. Generally, the war damage seems less visible in Baghdad than in many areas of the countryside. **********The critical sector of oil production, the dynamo that drives Iraq's economy, requires a major infusion of cash, about $1.5 billion, to get its export pipelines going at prewar levels; and Iraq may not be able to maintain its gasoline production without Western technology, spare parts and expertise in the near term. Because of the international trade sanctions imposed after the invasion of Kuwait, however, Iraq has been unable to import urgently needed equipment and has not sold a cargo of oil, its principal source of income, since last August. **********One of the major mysteries remains how many Iraqi soldiers and civilians died. United States intelligence agencies assert that they have not addressed this question and the Bush Administration has not indicated any official interest. **********Intelligence officers connected with the United States Central Command conducted what they described as a purely mathematical exercise at the end of the war to estimate Iraqi war dead by subtracting prisoners of war and an assumed percentage of deserters and then assigning a mortality rate to those Iraqis who remained on the battlefield. **********By this method, the command derived an unofficial death toll of about 100,000 Iraqi soldiers, and Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the allied commander, was said to have provided this unofficial tally in private briefings to members of Congress. **********Some analysts have questioned this unofficial number, arguing that the United States estimate of 540,000 Iraqi troops in the war zone overstated the size of Iraqi forces and that desertion rates were underestimated. They also argued that such a large number of battle deaths would have been accompanied by at least as many wounded, and that no evidence of this has been detected by foreign relief agencies working with Iraq's medical system. **********The Iraqi Government has not come forward with any authoritative estimate of war dead. Other unofficial estimates of Iraqi war dead have put the figure at 25,000 to 50,000.  Civilian Death Toll **********Allied war planners sought to minimize civilian deaths in Iraq, though there were notable mistakes, including the attack on an air raid shelter in Baghdad that apparently killed more than 300 civilians. **********A report issued this month by the environmental group Greenpeace estimated the number of Iraqi civilians killed during the war at 5,000 to 15,000, based on a review of statements by allied officials and other unofficial sources. **********Overall, the American analysts say, the Iraqis are struggling precariously under a patchwork of short-term fixes and remedies that will probably deteriorate in the months ahead if the Bush Administration maintains trade sanctions in an effort to force President Saddam Hussein from power.  Similarity to U.N. Report **********The Bush Administration's internal findings parallel those reported by a special United Nations mission to Iraq in March, which concluded that because of the damage inflicted on it, "Iraq has, for some time to come, been relegated to a pre-industrial age, but with all the disabilities of post-industrial dependency on an intensive use of energy and technology." **********Some Administration officials had criticized the United Nations report, prepared under the supervision of Under Secretary General Martti Ahtissari, for describing the damage to Iraq with terms like "near apocalyptic." But in their detailed review of each sector of Iraq's economy, the United Nations and United States assessments are not dissimiliar. **********The Central Intelligence Agency estimates a national repair bill in Iraq of up to $30 billion, about half of which would have to come from hard currency earnings on resumed shipments of oil to world markets. Add to this the $8 billion Iraq owes this year on its $80 billion in national debt, none of which has been paid, and a yet-to-be-determined bill for war reparations to Kuwait, and the outline of Iraq's post-war economic crisis takes an ominous shape, with or without Mr. Hussein.  Risks of U.S. Policy **********Some analysts within the Administration suggested that its policy of maintaining sanctions was a risky course, both because of its impact on the Iraqi people and because it may backfire or fail. **********One senior analyst said that as the Bush Administration discovered last fall when sanctions did not dislodge Iraq from Kuwait, there is no direct linkage between economic pain and political change in a police state like Iraq. This makes a sanctions-based strategy "inherently unpredictable," he said. **********"To the extent Iraqis are convinced that life will be abnormal and harsh as long as Saddam is around, that is clearly an incentive for change," the senior analyst said. "But in a regime based on fear, the primordial interests of survival suggest that people would rather go hungry than take the risk of being dead." **********United States analysts say they do not know how much Mr. Hussein has in the way of hard currency to buy food and medicine in the short term, which he has been permitted to do since the United Nations began allowing humanitarian shipments on March 22. While $4 billion of Iraqi cash is frozen in foreign banks, they say Iraq is close to exhausting its cash reserves. **********At the outset of the war, the Bush Administration said its objectives included the elimination of Iraq's offensive war making ability and weapons of mass destruction. But in carrying out a strategy to achieve these goals, the Pentagon appears to have miscalculated the multiplying effects on public health of its large-scale destruction of Iraq's electricial power system, which fed civilian as well as military industries. **********The system powered water purification and sewage treatment plants, the loss of which led to a sharp increase in disease during and after the war. **********A report issued by a Harvard University study team this month said that "the collapse of electrical generating capacity has been a crucial factor in this public health catastrophe." The team predicted tens of thousands of additional war-related deaths by the end of the year, a finding the Administration has not disputed. **********"Without electricity, hospitals cannot function, perishable medicines spoil, water cannot be purified and raw sewage cannot be processed," the study team's report said. Short-Circuiting Power System **********Many of Iraq's electrical power plants were struck on the first night of the allied air war. Iraqi engineers and technicians later told Western visitors that allied warplanes dropped thousands of metallic filaments onto electrical transformers and power lines, causing a spectacular short-circuiting process. **********"It was really metallic threads, like a person's hair, very fine," said Julia Devin, a member of the Harvard team that toured Iraq in late April and early May and who returned with samples of the filaments collected from Iraqi plant technicians. **********An Air Force official this week confirmed the description of the attack. **********Tomahawk cruise missiles and guided bombs dropped from warplanes thereafter destroyed individual generating units, and these repeated attacks knocked out half of the country's generating capacity and damaged a large part of the other half, according to one Administration analysis. **********An Iraqi official last week said engineers had restored 1,580 megawatts of generating capacity out of what Western officials say was a prewar level of about 9,000 megawatts. **********The Iraqi Government announced this week that eight-hour daily blackouts will be a continuing feature even where electricity has been restored in major cities. Many smaller towns and villages still are without electricity. **********The longer term prospects for repairing the system may deteriorate due to the country's lack of access to Western technology, spare parts and expertise. Communications Badly Hit **********Of equally high priority on the allied target list was Iraq's telecommunications sector. Bombers struck telephone exchanges, microwave relay stations and cable networks, along with dedicated military links. **********The multibillion-dollar telecommunications system that Iraq had built with state-of-the-art Western technology is the most severely damaged segment of Iraq's civilian economy, United States analysts say. **********"The Iraqis are going to have to completely rebuild the system and they cannot do it without foreign equipment and expertise," said one analyst. **********While some telephone and telex circuits to the outside world and among major Iraqi ministries and military complexes have been restored, most Iraqis are likely to be without telephone service for the foreseeable future.  Oil Production Resumed **********Iraq resumed oil production in April and, according to a Central Intelligence Agency estimate, could be exporting one million barrels per day -- about a third of its prewar production level -- by summer's end if sanctions are lifted. With a $1.5 billion investment in new pumps for its export pipelines through Turkey and Saudi Arabia, Iraq could be exporting 2.7 million barrels per day by the end of 1992, according to the C.I.A. estimate. **********Refining oil for domestic gasoline consumption has been more problematical. Most major refineries suffered serious damage and Iraqi engineers will need foreign assistance and parts to repair them. **********Repairs at two large refineries enabled Iraq to lift gasoline rationing this month, but United States analysts say they are not sure the country can maintain gasoline output without access to spare parts and chemical additives produced outside the country. Damage to Transportation **********Iraq's highway and rail system is pocked by bomb craters and downed bridges. About 40 major bridges across the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers will have to be replaced, which can probably be done without foreign assistance, analysts say. Another 10 bridges are seriously damaged. **********Perhaps as important as this damage, Iraq's only tire factory, whose output served the whole country until it shutdown last fall, remains idled by lack of access to imported raw materials. **********Though Iraqi military engineers have worked around much of the damage with temporary bridges, transportation disruptions and bottlenecks, especially in southern Iraq around Basra, will have a significant impact on traffic and distribution for many months if not years.  Public Health Endangered **********The threat to public health in Iraq is of great concern to international relief agencies and health experts. Daily power blackouts are causing re-contamination of some drinking water supplies and threaten the country's ability to operate sanitary hospital wards and operating rooms, where refrigeration of drugs, vaccines and blood is of critical importance. **********Some back-up generators have failed for lack of fuel and parts. **********United States analysts said the compounding effect of continued poor sanitation in many parts of the country, the onset of summer heat and shortages of doctors and nurses could speed the growth of cholera, typhoid and gastroenteritis that may already have claimed tens of thousands of lives. Many foreign health workers left Iraq before and during the war and have not returned. **********Inflation has priced baby formula above the income level of many poor families, and transportation problems along with the closing of many regional health clinics have seriously retarded the level of health care services.Increasing child mortality is the most serious concern, public health experts and relief officials say.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Boise Cascade May Cut Dividend
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/13/busin.body_text: **********Boise Cascade, the world's eighth-largest paper producer, plans to sell more assets, and could lower its dividend to reduce debt. Boise Cascade has not cut its dividend in more than 20 years. The board of directors will meet today in San Francisco. "The company's bias is to hold onto the dividend," said Vince Hannity, a company spokesman. "But that depends on business conditions, and they're getting more difficult." **********The company, based in Boise, Idaho, is losing money this year because of problems at paper mills in International Falls, Minn., Rumford, Me., and Kenora, Ontario. Boise Cascade has also been hurt by declining paper prices that have accompanied the recession. The company has raised about $250 million from asset sales this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/27/world.main_headline: Parties Favoring Dutch Ties Do Well in Suriname Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/27/world.print_headline: Parties Favoring Dutch Ties Do Well in Suriname Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/27/world.body_text: **********Two political groupings that favor stronger ties with the Netherlands and clear subordination of the military to civilian authority emerged from national elections today with more than the two-thirds legislative majority needed to undertake constitutional changes. **********But some political analysts said that a stronger than expected performance by the New Democratic Party, a group with close ties to the military, could slow the push by the other parties to end the army's involvement in politics and forge a commonwealth-type relationship with the Netherlands.  New Group Wins 9 Seats **********According to preliminary results from the voting on Saturday, the New Front for Democracy, an alliance of traditional, ethnic-based parties that have long dominated civilian politics in Suriname, won 29 of 51 legislative seats in an orderly election. **********The New Democratic Party won 13 seats, a dramatic improvement from its performance in 1987, shortly after its formation, when it won only 3 seats. The party was created by the political wing of the military after international and domestic pressure forced Comdr. Desi Bouterse to relinquish power he seized in a 1980 coup. **********The New Democractic Party was installed in government after another coup by Commander Bouterse's soldiers last December. With its eye toward elections, the party recently undertook a number of populist measures, from raising salaries and promising interest-free loans to handing out food and drink at rallies, that appeared to have garnered stronger support among working-class Surinamese. **********Another group, the Democratic Alternative 91, a new party led by young professionals and technocrats whose campaign was based on the idea of granting significant oversight of the affairs of this country to its former colonial master, the Netherlands, won 9 legislative seats. **********"This represents a complete change with the past," a European diplomat said of the emergence of two significant parliamentary counterweights to the New Front. "But if the Front and Democratic Alternative get together, that would mean strong support for the commonwealth idea and constitutional change." **********Leaders of both the Democratic Alternative and the New Front said they would most likely work together to form a government in coming days, although they said that talks between them had not yet begun. **********Diplomatic and international observers said that Saturday's election, like others since the country's independence in 1975, was largely free and fair, although some observers raised questions about isolated incidents of potential intimidation of village dwellers in remote areas of the interior.  Army Interference Feared **********Surinamese politicians and foreign diplomats say that maintaining civilian authority and the army's respect for the outcome of elections have traditionally been more of a problem than organizing fair elections. **********The quesion in the minds of many here is whether Commander Bouterse, a 45-year-old former sergeant, will use force to block a close political association with the Netherlands, an idea he and his supporters have often ruled against. **********In the final days of the campaign, even as members of the military-linked New Democratic Party began telling voters that they too supported warmer ties with The Hague, politicians from rival parties who had urged constitutional changes aimed at constraining the military said they had received direct threats from Commander Bouterse's envoys. Several said they were strongly warned against trying to involve the Netherlands in efforts to restructure the army or oust Commander Bouterse. **********Amid speculation that the Netherlands, the United States and some neighboring countries might collaborate in a plan to remove Commander Bouterse, the politicians said they were warned that they could easily be found and killed before any such intevention could take place.
