https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; William Morris Shifts Follow 5 Resignations
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/busin.body_text: **********In an important realignment of its executive ranks after the resignations of five top agents, Hollywood's largest and best-known talent agency, the William Morris Agency, yesterday named Norman Brokaw as chairman and Jerry Katzman as president. **********Mr. Brokaw, who is 63 years old, has spent 48 years at William Morris, beginning in the mailroom. He later worked as an agent in both motion pictures and television -- his clients included Marilyn Monroe, Clint Eastwood and Bill Cosby -- before being appointed president and chief executive of the agency in 1989. **********Mr. Katzman, a 53-year-old lawyer, has most recently been head of the agency's television department, where he helped package "The Cosby Show" and "Murphy Brown" and represented Burt Reynolds, Angela Lansbury and Peter Jennings. He is the son of the motion picture producer Sam Katzman and has produced seven movies himself, including two starring Elvis Presley. **********Mr. Brokaw succeeds Lou Weiss, who was named chairman emeritus and will continue to run the agency's New York office. No successor to Mr. Katzman, who was head of the agency's television division, has been named. **********Four William Morris agents moved to International Creative Management last month, and a fifth, John Ptak, resigned earlier this week to join the Creative Artists Agency, which has become the most influential in Hollywood in recent years under the leadership of Michael Ovitz. **********It is not clear whether those agents who moved will be joined by their clients, but William Morris is expected to suffer some defections from its talent roster. The five agents' clients included Julia Roberts, Anjelica Huston and Joanne Woodward, as well as the directors Peter Weir, Stephen Frears and Costa Gavras. **********A William Morris spokesman said the executive realignment had been in the works since the fall and was not the result of the recent wave of defections. He said the announcement of the changes had been moved up several days.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/world.main_headline: Saudis to Accept Refugees From Camps in South of Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Saudis to Accept Refugees From Camps in South of Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/25/world.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia has decided to accept and shelter all Iraqi refugees now under American and Saudi control in the south of Iraq and is building a camp to accommodate as many as 50,000 people, a senior Saudi official said today. **********The official, Lieut. Gen. Khalid ibn Sultan, a prince who commanded the Arab forces in the coalition that ousted Iraq from Kuwait, also reaffirmed the kingdom's commitment to abide by international law and "Islamic humanitarian tradition" in handling nearly 14,000 Iraqi prisoners of war who do not wish to return to Iraq. **********In accord with the Geneva Convention for prisoners of war, he said, the prisoners will be permitted to remain in camps in Saudi Arabia until other countries accept them or until they want to return home. French Forces Leave **********"I am prepared to do whatever it takes to take proper care of all of these people," Prince Khalid said. "We cannot force them to return as long as Saddam is there. The Iraqi people are still our brothers and it is time to start healing the wounds, to forgive and forget." **********Prince Khalid, who is 41 years old, discussed the kingdom's policy on Iraqi refugees and prisoners of war in an interview after a ceremony of farewell in this Red Sea port city for the last remaining French combat forces in the kingdom. **********The commander said Saudi forces, helped by American troops, today completed a temporary refugee camp that could accommodate 30,000 people near the Saudi town of Rafha, just south of the Iraqi border in Saudi territory. The kingdom is planning to spend $30 million in the next four weeks to expand the camp's capacity to 50,000 and to build wells, food storage sites and air-conditioned accommodations for refugees to use this summer. **********In the next two days, Saudi troops are to begin moving people among the 20,000 Iraqi refugees at the Sadah camp, a few miles north of the Iraqi border, to the new site. The Sadah camp is under the control of Saudi forces. On Sunday, transfers will begin for the 7,000 refugees at Safwan camp, under control of American troops, just north of the Kuwaiti border. **********The fate of Iraqi refugees who fled their homes to safety in territory temporarily under Saudi and American control has weighed heavily on the coalition members and on the United Nations refugee agency. Many coalition and United Nations officials, as well as human rights groups, feared that President Saddam Hussein's forces would kill Iraqis who rebelled or fled once American and Saudi forces abandoned the areas, as they are required to do eventually under the cease-fire agreement. U.S. Is Reported Relieved **********"We will not withdraw our forces until those refugees who do not wish to return home are safely transferred to the camp in Saudi territory," the Prince declared. **********He indicated that the Iraqis would be welcome in the camp as long as they feared to go home. He did not say whether they would be permitted to work in the kingdom, and given Saudi Arabia's traditional reluctance to grant foreigners citizenship, it is unlikely that these refugees will become Saudi nationals. **********Prince Khalid said that he informed the United Nations and the United States military today of Saudi Arabia's decision to accept all Iraqi refugees unwilling to return to their homes. He said they seemed to greet the decision "with great relief." **********He said the Saudi Government was discussing the fate of refugees of other nationalities, mainly from Afghanistan and Pakistan, with the United Nations refugee agency. The kingdom is willing to help pay for the return of those refugees to their countries if that is necessary, he said. **********Prince Khalid also disclosed that a week ago he had stopped the return of about 1,000 Iraqi prisoners of war who wanted to return to Iraq pending the resolution of a longstanding dispute with Iraq over seven Saudi citizens for whom Iraq has not accounted.  'We Don't Believe Them' **********He said Saudi Arabia had previously permitted 1,096 of the 4,000 Iraqi officers and some 50,000 Iraqi soldiers to return to Iraq even though Baghdad said it could not locate the seven Saudis -- a pilot, two officers and four civilians. **********"But we don't believe them," he said. "We have reported our concern over the seven to the Red Cross. And Iraq must now search until they find our nationals, or discover what happened to them before more Iraqi officers return." **********He said that only three of the six prisoner of war camps were still operating. **********Prince Khalid, who is the son of Prince Sultan ibn Abdel-Aziz, Saudi Arabia's Defense Minister, stressed that in building the new refugee camp Saudi Arabia was not seeking to encourage Iraqis to leave their country. **********He said the kingdom was prepared to supply Iraqi villages currently controlled by Saudi or American forces with water and food and "whatever they need" to discourage Iraqis from abandoning their homes. **********"But most of the people now in camps do not want to go back," he said. "They fear that as long as Saddam Hussein is in power they will be killed. And we have an obligation to protect them."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.main_headline: Israel Says It Must Strike at Iraqis But Indicates Willingness to Wait
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF; Israel Says It Must Strike at Iraqis But Indicates Willingness to Wait
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.body_text: **********Israeli officials insisted today that the second Iraqi missile strike in two days had left them no choice but to retaliate, but they indicated that they were willing to wait in deference to American requests and because of new missile defenses provided and manned by the United States, which are already in place. **********The second attack provoked a new round of tough talk here. But behind the promise to strike back hard when the time is right lay the clear suggestion that Israel would do nothing for now in deference to the United States' concern that an Israeli response could shatter the anti-Iraq military coalition in the Persian Gulf war. **********The Israelis said they would withhold retaliation for now in part because the United States had rushed several batteries of Patriot antimissile missiles to Israel today, and that one of them was already in operation.  Operated by American Crews **********The Pentagon said a Patriot shot down an Iraqi missile in flight as it headed for an airfield in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, on Friday morning, the same morning that eight Iraqi missiles hit in the Tel Aviv-Haifa area. **********Four more Iraqi missiles slammed into heavily populated areas along Israel's coastal heartland early this morning. But once again, the 500-pound conventional warheads were reported to have killed no one, and they slightly injured about 15 civilians. Israeli officials put that down to remarkable luck, which they do not expect to hold should Iraq strike again. **********The Patriot batteries in Israel are manned by American crews, the first time that Americans have been deployed in Israel in its defense. Israeli crews have been in the United States for weeks, training in the operation of the Patriots in a program that began late last year. But they are not ready to use them. **********President Bush called Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir twice to express concern about the second Iraqi attack and to reiterate his hope that Israel would rely on the United States to retaliate.  [ Page 16 ] **********The Americans "understand the distress we are in," David Ivri, director general of the Defense Ministry, said this evening, "and they try to make it possible for us not to respond." **********Israel retains the right to respond, he and others stressed today. "But together with that," Mr. Ivri said, "everyone knows that our response can change the whole procedure of the war in the Middle East." **********Speaking of the deployment of the Patriot missiles, a spokesman for the Israeli Army said: "The aim of this swift supply is for immediate operation of these batteries in Israel. They are already put into place." **********In Washington, the Pentagon held a news conference to draw attention to the new aid program, and to the fact that Israel is now sharing information with the United States on Iraqi missile activity. **********Israelis were roused three times during the early-morning hours and ordered into their safe rooms, where they strapped on gas masks. The three early alerts proved to be false alarms. But a fourth alert, at dawn, foretold an actual strike. Two minutes after the sirens' warbling wail, three Iraqi Scud-B missiles fell in Tel Aviv while a fourth fell farther south along the coast, the army said. **********There were reports that another fell near Jerusalem at the same time, but they were never confirmed. One of those that hit Tel Aviv crashed through a three-story building in a city business district but did not explode.  Fired From Western Iraq **********The army said the Iraqi missiles that fell here this morning had been fired from western Iraq, where American and allied warplanes have been conducting extensive search-and-destroy operations to remove the mobile launchers from operation. **********"It's clear," a senior military official said this afternoon, "that the Americans will not be able to get them all, even within a matter of days." Military officials reported that at least 30 fixed and 20 mobile missile launchers remained intact and hidden in Iraq, despite the extensive allied effort to destroy them. **********As a result, military officials warned Israelis -- a people already dragging from three days under siege -- that they should expect more missiles over the next several nights and possibly Iraqi fighter-bomber raids as well. As of 10 P.M. tonight, there had been two more false alarms. **********Schools will be closed for the fourth day Sunday, and Israelis will once again be advised to stay at home, essentially shutting down the nation. **********Brig. Gen. Nachman Shai, the chief army spokesman and the military's voice to the Israeli people throughout this crisis, warned: "I would say that, even though all the missiles launched so far have used conventional warheads, we should expect them to use chemical weapons as well. The fact that they haven't used them doesn't mean they don't have them." **********The few Israelis who have dared leave their homes against the army's advice these last three days carry their gas masks as routinely as they might hold purses or briefcases in normal times. **********Senior members of the Government today reiterated their threat that Israel would respond, and harshly.   Problems With Retaliation **********But it became clear today that Israel's air force would not simply send fighter planes off in a quick retaliatory strike. With so many warplanes already in operation over Iraq, Israel's fighters might be lost among all the others in the sky, officials suggested, or worse, get into unintended combat with allied warplanes. **********So Israeli officials said they would wait, watch, study and choose their target carefully, then act only when they see they can make a spectacular impact. **********"We're not saying what we will do, when we will do it, where or how we will do it," Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said during a news briefing this afternoon. **********And Eliahu Ben-Elissar, chairman of the Parliament's Defense and Foreign Affairs Committee, added: "We won't appear for a meeting with Saddam Hussein where Saddam Hussein wants to meet us. But one thing should be clear: When we choose our target, it will be very, very painful." **********Today's strike, as Friday's, proved once again that Iraq's modified Scud-B missiles are more instruments of terror than weapons that can seriously threaten the security of the state. **********Officials have released no details about the missile that fell south of Tel Aviv, except to say that it injured no one. And one of the three missiles hitting Tel Aviv landed in a city park and did little more than scatter dirt across an adjacent road. **********Another missile blew open an underground concrete bomb shelter in a poor, working-class neighborhood of Tel Aviv, close to where one of the missiles fell during the first strike on Friday morning. But the shelter was empty. **********The last missile fell three stories through an empty apartment building before crashing to the floor in a ground-level jewelry store. It did not explode, and through the morning residents of the surrounding area were confined to their homes while army sappers defused the device. **********With the task completed just after noon, soldiers in a loudspeaker truck cruised the neighborhood broadcasting the message: "To all residents -- it is all right to go back to normal life. Good afternoon." Their voices had a sarcastic tone. **********At the site, soldiers then began dragging the six-foot warhead out of the store as boisterous crowds laughed and jeered, pushing to get close enough so they could actually touch the dull gray cone, battered but largely intact despite its long journey. **********"Look, look at Saddam's missile," several people chanted as the shell swung on its tether while a crane hoisted it onto an flatbed army truck. **********The crowd laughed as the truck hauled the missile away.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/busin.body_text: **********Consumers Union, publisher of Consumer Reports, said yesterday that it had suspended its chief financial officer, saying he had been involved in a kickback scheme. **********The organization said the officer, David Granston, was suspended after an investigation into an arrangement Mr. Granston had with a broker to share commissions for the purchase by Consumers Union of Government mortgage-backed securities, known as Ginnie Maes. **********"We have reason to believe that a crime or crimes may have been committed," Consumers Union said in a statement. **********Mr. Granston could not be reached for comment. **********Consumers Union said it made inflated commission payments between 1986 and 1991 and that the amount involved was several hundred thousand dollars. **********"Our organization is so based on ethics and integrity," said David C. Berliner, assistant director of Consumers Union, a nonprofit organization that tests products and reports its findings in its magazine, "we expect it of those we report on, and we demand it of ourselves. It's a thing we won't tolerate by anyone in our organization." **********"What we have discovered here is an employee who went to benefit himself," he said. "When we discovered it, we took swift action. We want everyone to know this is something we won't tolerate."  Dealings With Broker **********Mr. Granston is accused of entering into an arrangement with a stockbroker, Stanley Feminella, who had worked at three firms: David Lerner Associates in Syosset, L.I.; Paine Webber and Shearson Lehman. **********Because of that arrangement, Consumers Union said, it was charged commissions as high as 6 percent, which were split by the men. **********Mr. Granston had worked at Consumers Union since 1983. Before that, he was controller of The New York Times syndication sales service. **********Consumers Union said it had suspected some sort of wrongdoing, going back to 1987, but an internal audit by Coopers & Lybrand did not uncover any problems. A later investigation conducted by the law firm of Gallop, Dawson, Clayman & Rosenberg reported on the arrangement. That investigation is continuing, Consumers Union said. It also said it was turning over the information to the United States Attorney's office and would "institute appropriate civil actions for financial redress." **********Consumers Union invests its funds in Government securities, but not in corporate stocks or bonds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/08/busin.main_headline: Wall Street; A.D.R.'s Multiply in the Rush to Diversify Abroad
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/08/busin.print_headline: Wall Street; A.D.R.'s Multiply in the Rush to Diversify Abroad
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/08/busin.body_text: **********The barometer is rising for A.D.R.'s, the vehicle by which American investors can own foreign stocks. **********According to the Bank of New York, the largest single issuer of A.D.R.'s, or American depository receipts, trading volume on United States exchanges rose to a record half-year high of 2.6 billion A.D.R.'s valued at $42.8 billion. It was a 37 percent increase over the first six months of 1990. **********The number of A.D.R.'s traded on American exchanges is projected to reach 900 by the end of the year, up 7.7 percent from last year and 31.8 percent from 1985. **********An A.D.R. is a certificate representing one or more shares of a foreign stock issued by a depository bank. It is priced in dollars and traded like American stocks. **********Two reasons account for the rise in volume and in the number of foreign companies using A.D.R.'s. American investors, especially institutions, are more interested in the benefits of diversification to other markets. And more foreign companies want to tap the American market for capital.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/03/busin.main_headline: On Main Street, The Bulls Are Stampeding
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/03/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH; On Main Street, The Bulls Are Stampeding
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/03/busin.body_text: **********The public is back in the market, and the speculative stocks are soaring. The money managers, suddenly bullish, are searching for laggards, afraid to stay on the sidelines. All told, it is certainly enough to make a contrarian investor nervous. **********It is individual investors who are pushing up prices now. "A lot of buyers came into the market," exulted Larry Armstrong, executive vice president of Fidelity Investment's discount brokerage operations, after peace hopes brought a buying panic on Monday, with volume soaring and more than two buy orders for every sell. Even on Jan. 17, when prices leaped after the air war began, that ratio was just three to two. **********Those buyers want action, not safety. The Russell 2,000 index of small stocks rose 2.4 percent last week. The Dow Jones industrial average added only 20.54 points, or 0.7 percent, to 2,909.90. **********Investors are also pouring money into all kinds of mutual funds, especially those that buy junk bonds. Merrill Lynch's junk index leaped 8.7 percent last month. Marty Fridson, who runs junk research at Merrill, says second-tier bonds led the rally, as buyers passed up the highest-quality junk, which was already trading close to face value. **********It isn't only the retail investors who are eager. In early February, the so-called professionals were about as bullish as they were in September 1987, just before the crash, reports Dick Hoey, the chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd. Last September, when prices were far lower, they were more bearish than at any time since Mr. Hoey began his surveys of investment decision-makers in 1983. **********Anyone looking for evidence of speculation need only check out LTV, the long-bankrupt steel and aerospace company. After leaping 150 percent last week, its common shares are at $2.50 each, or about $300 million for the whole company. The cause for the glee is that LTV may be on the verge of settling its pension problems, on undisclosed terms that have not been completely worked out. **********When it finishes that deal, LTV will have to come up with a way to satisfy creditors who are owed $2.5 billion. Chances are that they will be offered packages of securities including gobs of common shares, badly diluting the stake of current holders. **********LTV's junk bonds are rising, but not as rapidly as the shares. The best secured of the bonds still trade for 60 cents or less on the dollar, while the worst fetch a dime. Even those bonds have priority over the common holders, so it is puzzling what the stock buyers think they see. Or maybe it just proves that, when the speculative juices are flowing, a lot of people buy first and ask questions later. **********Since Jan. 17, the Dow is up 16 percent, and the Russell 2,000 has soared 29 percent. Meanwhile, interest rates have stopped falling and started to edge up, on suspicions that the Federal Reserve will delay further easing while waiting to see if the recession is going to end soon. **********Few wars have been as joyful for investors. Now they are betting that with peace will come prosperity, and a lot of it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/07/world.main_headline: Israel Not Budging on Settlement Expansion
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/07/world.print_headline: Israel Not Budging on Settlement Expansion
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/07/world.body_text: **********The Israeli Government is convinced it faces a tough choice between continuing its expansion of West Bank settlements or getting aid from the United States for the absorption of Soviet Jews. And it has made a clear decision: settlements will continue. **********Israel greeted President Bush's latest criticism of its West Bank settlement expansion program, last Monday, with a low-key response that masked a deep and growing concern that the state may be forced to pay a heavy price for its settlement drive.Even though Mr. Bush softened his criticism by saying he did not believe there should be any quid pro quo between settlements and additional aid, officials here are convinced that Washington may refuse Jerusalem's request for $10 billion in loan guarantees for immigrant housing -- if Israel does not stop building new West Bank settlements or does not show more flexibility in the peace process. **********Every day, ministers and members of Parliament publicly debate what Israel should do. Economists offer draconian predictions of what will happen if the money does not come. **********And Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai has made it clear that Israelis should be ready for a contingency plan of huge tax increases and deep cuts in social services if the American aid is not granted. **********All this comes two months before Israel even intends to present its formal request for loan guarantees -- and before anyone in the Bush Administration has publicly made any connection between settlements and the peace process or the request for aid. **********Still, said a senior aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir: "We've learned not to take anything for granted here. If they're unhappy with us, we could have problems even if there is no direct linkage made." **********Asked to analyze the situation on Tuesday, Oded Ben Ami, Israeli radio's correspondent in Washington, said, "One must be blind to think there will not be a linkage; there will be one." **********But the settlement activity continues nonetheless. In fact, Housing Minister Ariel Sharon dedicated a new neighborhood in a northern West Bank settlement the very day President Bush's latest remarks were reported here, saying: "The settlements are not an obstacle to peace. The settlements are the best obstacle to war." **********At the same time, his office has hired architects to create master plans for new Jewish cities in the West Bank that could accommodate 500,000 people or more, although formal Government approval and funding would be needed to carry out those plans. **********The request for the $10 billion was first made during the Persian Gulf war, but at Washington's request the formal submission was put off until September. When Mr. Modai first raised the question, Israel was still being praised for its restraint during the gulf war. **********But last Monday Mr. Modai complained that the expected recompense for that restraint had not come. **********"I have a very uneasy feeling about the expectations that we had because, up to this very moment, I do not see that the position taken by the state of Israel, which was the key at the time, is being rewarded in any way," he said. **********But Mr. Modai, like others in Government, said Israel would not change its policies or budge an inch, even if the price was a rejection of the aid request. **********"We're a stiff-necked people," Mr. Modai said. "Whoever doesn't remember that should read the Bible." Mr. Shamir and other officials have said essentially the same thing. **********But Michael Bruno, governor of Israel's Central Bank, warned that "there's no way to absorb the massive immigration without help from the United States." **********And as he announced his contingency plan, to be carried out if the aid is not approved, Mr. Modai said: "If we have to implement the plan, a very heavy burden will fall on the shoulders of the Israeli citizen, both present and the future. If, God forbid, we have to implement it, it will be very tough." **********Mr. Shamir said: "I hope the pressures and conditions will stop. I hope the U.S. aid for immigrant absorption will come, just as it has in the past."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY EARNINGS; Philip Morris Climbed 20.6% in 3d Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/17/busin.body_text: **********The Philip Morris Companies announced a 20.6 percent rise in third-quarter earnings yesterday, based on the strong growth of its cigarette sales abroad and the sound performance of its food products. **********The results were marred only by a decline in its Miller Brewing Company. The company spent heavily on marketing a number of its beer brands, including Miller Genuine Draft, Sharp's and Milwaukee's Best. **********Earnings at the world's largest cigarette company rose in the latest quarter to $1.13 billion, or $1.22 a share, from $937 million, or $1.01 a share, in the third quarter last year. The gains came as Philip Morris increased its presence in the fast-growing world cigarette market and increased its share of the domestic cigarette market, with brands like Marlboro, Benson and Hedges and Virginia Slims and Bucks, a lower-priced brand. The growth came even as the domestic cigarette market is shrinking. **********Most analysts described Philip Morris's report as uplifting news for the company, which is attempting to expand its food and tobacco business to new and growing markets overseas. **********The earnings came on operating revenues for the third quarter of $13.77 billion, an increase of 7.4 percent over the $12.82 billion reported in the corresponding quarter in 1990. For the first nine months of 1991 operating revenues were $42.76 billion, up 15.7 percent, from $36.95 billion in the period last year. **********"Despite a recessionary trend in the U.S. and a general weakening of the economy in certain foreign countries," said Michael A. Miles, Philip Morris's chairman and chief executive, "the company's results for the quarter and year to date reflect the strength and depth of our domestic and international consumer brands." **********In the tobacco arena, revenues for Philip Morris USA rose 12 percent, to $2.8 billion from $2.5 billion. With more than 47 percent of Philip Morris's income coming from the domestic tobacco business, analysts looked favorably on an overall increase in its domestic unit sales of eight-tenths of 1 percent. Industrywide, unit sales declined 1.8 percent during the quarter. **********Philip Morris USA recently introduced Marlboro Medium cigarettes, as well as lower-priced brands to continue its growth of market share. **********"Their ability to grow in a declining category is impressive," said John McMillin, an analyst with Prudential. " They are increasing their presence in value-added brands and they are shifting their emphasis overseas, where there is plenty of room for growth." **********Philip Morris's cigarette revenues outside the United States and Canada increased 10.4 percent, to slightly more than $3 billion in the quarter, from $2.7 billion in the third quarter of 1990. Profits abroad rose 20.4 percent, to $501 million, from $416 million the year before. Volume of unit sales increased 11.6 percent in the third quarter. **********Analysts also noted a strong performance for the company's Kraft General Foods International, with products like Toblerone chocolate, Kraft mayonnaise and Tang. Revenues rose 12.6 percent, to more than $1.7 billion from $1.5 billion. **********Domestically, however, operating revenues were flat, compared with an income increase of 8.4 percent over last year. Analysts attributed slack food sales in North America to consumers' concerns about the economy and their shift to less expensive cheese and meat products and to store brands. **********The Miller Brewing Company reported a decline in income of 4.8 percent in the third quarter, to $99 million from $104 million, although revenues increased by 17.7 percent, to $1.1 billion, from less than $964 million in the third quarter of 1990. **********Despite the generally good earnings report, the company's stock slipped 50 cents, to $73.50 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. One analyst called the decline "a mystery."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/world.main_headline: U.S. NOW EXPECTS THE MIDEAST TALKS TO TAKE TIME OUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/world.print_headline: THE MIDDLE EAST TALKS; U.S. NOW EXPECTS THE MIDEAST TALKS TO TAKE TIME OUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/world.body_text: **********American officials said today that there would have to be a pause before reconvening the next round of direct Middle East peace talks to allow the negotiators time to consider their positions and enable the United States to find a new meeting place. **********And, because of the failure of Syria and Israel to make any headway in their direct talks, which ended about 3 a.m. today, officials who were part of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's contingent said they would probably have to come up with ideas of their own to break the impasse. **********Unlike the talks between Israel and the Jordanian-Palestinian delegation, which agreed to discuss Palestinian self-rule, there was no such accord between the representatives of Syria and Israel. The Optimistic Reading **********The only mildly encouraging development was a departure statement by the Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, who said he believed that the Israeli people wanted peace but that their Government was blocking the way. **********"I think the Israelis as a people desire peace," he said. "They are looking for peace. Israel is a special case, where the Government is more hawkish than the people. In the Arab world, it is just the opposite. We are more flexible than the Arab people." **********The Syrian official spoke to reporters after five hours of direct talks with Israeli representatives. Both sides said that these first contacts had made no progress but also said they were committed to continuing direct talks when and if they could agree on a site.  Taking Time to Consider **********American aides said they would take time out from the discussions to let the Mideast adversaries digest the implications of what has happened so far, and try to hammer out a compromise on where the next round of direct talks should take place. **********The Israelis want discussions to alternate between towns in their country and in Arab lands. The Syrians, Palestinians, Jordanians and Lebanese want them held in Madrid, under the umbrella of this conference, or in some other neutral site outside the Mideast. It is expected that Mr. Baker will invite the negotiating parties to Washington sometime in the next month. **********Although Mr. Sharaa's departure remarks today were considered highly polemical, Arab journalists present said they could not recall such an overture to the Israeli people from the hard-line Syrians. **********Mr. Sharaa, however, does not seem to have been suddenly transformed by the contact with Israel here. His comments appear to have been prompted, at least in part, by the negative publicity he received in the Western press for his behavior and remarks in Madrid. **********The Syrian had held up an old "wanted" photograph of the Israeli Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, during Mr. Shamir's underground days, and also engaged in vitriolic exchanges with the Israelis. Today, throughout his news conference, Mr. Sharaa took pains to say that his comments had been misunderstood by the Western news media. **********Of all the delegations in Madrid, the Syrians were the least experienced in dealing with the public and the press.  They tried to avoid calling on Israeli reporters during news conferences and often issued handwritten statements, while the Israelis, Palestinians, Jordanians and Lebanese were running off copies in several languages. **********Some Syrian journalists said privately that they were embarrassed, and predicted that their closed society would have to open a bit if Syria intended to compete in the game of public diplomacy with Israel and the Palestinians. **********On the substance of Sunday night's face-to-face contacts, Syrians and Israelis were in full agreement: Each heard nothing from the other that suggested a compromise was possible. **********The Syrian team was headed by an experienced former diplomat, Muwaffaq al-Allaf, while the Israelis were led by the Egyptian-born Yossi Ben Aharon, director general of Prime Minister Shamir's office, a man known for hard-line views. **********The Syrians said their negotiating strategy had been to keep repeating that they were not ready to discuss the substance of peace unless Israel first committed itself to withdrawing from the territories captured in the 1967 war, and particularly the Golan Heights. **********The Israelis said they were trying to persuade the Syrians to open direct communication outside the talks, and to discuss small, confidence-building gestures each side might take, before trying to deal with the territorial issue.  Dialogue at Cross-Purposes **********"It was in every respect futile," Mr. Ben Aharon said afterward, "because what they kept telling us constantly was 'When will you withdraw from the territories?' **********"We invited them them to Israel," he recounted. "They said no. **********"We asked them to establish a link between us. They said no. **********"We asked them to sign a peace treaty. They said no. **********Mr. Ben Aharon continued: "We asked if they accepted the legitimacy of Israel, even in Tel Aviv, and they said it is not a relevant issue now. They refused any other venue for the talks other than Madrid and would not go anywhere in the Middle East. **********"We said, 'Why don't we host you? Wouldn't you want us in Syria so your people will change their minds about us?' He kept saying that 'Once you withdraw, everything will be resolved.' " **********Members of the Israeli delegation described the Syrian negotiators as professional, armed with briefing papers, well versed in all the relevant United Nations documents, but extremely standoffish. There were no handshakes, and the two sides took their coffee breaks in separate rooms. **********Mr. Sharaa, who did not personally take part in the talks, said after briefings by his negotiators that "the Israeli delegates rejected all the requirements for peace; the Israeli head of delegation talked about everything other than the land that has been occupied for 24 years." **********He added: "The equation in our region is very clear. The Syrian delegate spoke about both land and peace. The Israeli delegate dropped the land, kept it under the feet of their soldiers, and spoke only empty rhetoric about peace." **********Nevertheless, said Mr. Sharaa, "our delegates will continue to resume the bilateral talks, and, of course, we are waiting for the co-sponsors to come up with a proposal for the next venue. We don't think our presence in the peace conference or ensuing negotiations is a waste of time." **********American officials say the Syrian-Israeli discussion, if it is to make progress, will require the greatest amount of mediation and other intervention, since neither side has any pressing need to compromise. **********Secretary Baker, who left Madrid on Sunday night and flew with President Bush today to California, said: "We're encouraged that the talks took place at all. They were businesslike and carried off in a constructive atmosphere. No one walked out in the conference or the bilateral. There is a sense of engagement now that bodes well for the future."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/busin.main_headline: Time Warner's Stock Stabilizes After Three-Day Plunge
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Time Warner's Stock Stabilizes After Three-Day Plunge
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/busin.body_text: **********After plummeting nearly 20 percent in just three days, Time Warner Inc.'s stock stabilized yesterday, losing 50 cents, at $94.125. The decline came in continued response to the company's proposed $3.5 billion rights offering for 34.5 million new shares of stock that would help reduce Time Warner's $11 billion debt burden. **********The company is now aggressively selling the deal to investors. But many were still trying to figure out yesterday whether it would be accomplished. One portfolio manager, who declined to be identified, said he felt it was likely that the deal would be completed. "I am as sure as you can be about anything in this complicated deal," he said. **********The fact that the stock is trading around $94 indicated to some investment bankers and analysts yesterday that the deal could close at about that price and that investors expected about 90 percent of the rights to be tendered. **********Time Warner has structured a deal in which every shareholder gets the right to buy six-tenths of a share of Time Warner stock at $105 a share. But as fewer shareholders exercise their rights, those who do would benefit. They could get their stock for as little as $63 a share and get additional shares. **********If the stock were trading for more than $105, more shareholders would clearly exercise their rights because they would be getting the stock at a discount. **********If the stock were trading at $94.50, for instance, and 90 percent of the rights are exercised, then investors would get their stock at $94.50. **********If a smaller percentage tendered at that price, they would get new stock for less than $94.50. But as one banker explained it, the belief is that if rights holders think others will get a better price, then they are likely to tender, too. **********Time Warner could call off the deal if the market drops 20 percent or more, or if fewer than 60 percent of the rights are validly exercised. **********The question now is not only whether Time Warner can complete the deal, but also whether it can subsequently arrange a foreign joint venture that would bring it additional financing. **********Several Wall Street analysts said yesterday that they saw the offer as a somewhat desperate act since the company had failed to complete a foreign joint venture.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/busin.main_headline:
Your Own Account;
Saving on Age-Weighted Retirement
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/busin.print_headline:
Your Own Account;
Saving on Age-Weighted Retirement
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/busin.body_text: **********One of the hottest topics in employee benefits right now is the age-weighted retirement plan, regulations for which were issued by the Internal Revenue Service last month. The new rules allow companies to make retirement plan contributions based on an employee's age, permitting a much larger share of contributions for those closest to retirement. Some experts say the rules are the most important change since 401(k) plans were introduced 10 years ago. **********Most of the attention is focused on small businesses, where the new rules allow an eye-popping disparity in retirement plan contributions for younger, lower-paid workers and older, highly compensated workers. For example, a 25-year-old might get a $200 contribution while the owner gets $30,000. **********The changes apply to defined-contribution plans, so named because the amount being contributed to the plan is defined while the ultimate benefit is not. **********The dollar limit on contributions to these plans is $30,000 a year, under both the new and the old rules. Small-business owners typically want to contribute the $30,000 maximum for themselves. **********Under the old rules, if that represented 15 percent of the owner's salary, the owner typically had to contribute 15 percent of each employee's salary as well. But the new rules might allow the owner to contribute as little as 1 percent for younger employees while making the full contribution for the owner's own account -- provided there is enough age difference to make the formula work. This allows the business owner to substantially reduce the total amount of money being contributed to the retirement plan. **********For example, Andrew M. Wray 3d, a financial planner in Memphis, has a client with a six-person company who was contributing $72,000 to the retirement plan in order to get his own $30,000 contribution. Under the new rules, he can contribute a total of just $37,000 while still getting his own $30,000 contribution. **********"It can decrease the total contribution the employer is making by 40 to 60 percent without decreasing his own contribution," Mr. Wray said. **********What's more, age-weighted plans that are also profit-sharing plans do not require a contribution every year, as do other major retirement plans. Employers who have this type of age-weighted plan can skip a year or two of contributions -- an option that is particularly appealing to employers in the current sour economy. **********This type of plan "is so exciting because it fills the need on the part of the business owner to reward more senior, longer-service employees and it offers the flexibility of making a lower contribution or none at all in bad times," said David I. Gensler, an actuary at Madison Pension Services Inc. in White Plains. "Part of the beauty is that the employer is not committed to putting the money in." **********The age-weighted plans cost less to administer, too, and require no employer contribution to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. That is the Government agency that insures the defined-benefit plans, which, in contrast to defined-contribution plans, promise to deliver a set payout on retirement. **********Nor does the age-weighted plan require the employer to make quarterly contributions as defined-benefit plans do. Instead, contributions are made just once a year. **********Not everyone is happy with the new rules, of course. Some experts have pointed out that younger, lower-paid employees are getting the short end of the stick. **********"You can put away $30,000 for yourself and peanuts for everybody else," said Richard R. Joss, actuary at the Wyatt Company, benefits consultants in Washington. **********Supporters of the plans argue that in many cases younger employees would prefer to receive their dollars as salary, rather than having the money tucked away out of their control for 40 years. Whether the dollars saved from the pension contributions actually get turned into higher pay remains a question, of course. **********But, the supporters say, if a retirement plan turns out to be too expensive for small-business owners, many will just abandon it and tuck money away just for themselves, "leaving employees out altogether," Mr. Wray said. **********Planners say that small-business owners should consider the age-weighted plans if there is a significant difference between the age of the owner and those of other key employees and staff members. "The higher the compensation, the older the employee, the more benefit" to the owner for using the plans, Mr. Wray said. **********Larger employers are interested in age-weighted plans, too, said Allen T. Steinberg, a partner at Hewitt Associates, benefits consultants in Lincolnshire, Ill. **********For example, an employer who is cutting back on retiree medical benefits might use such a plan to give those employees closest to retirement some extra money to help make up for what is being taken away. **********"There are a number of reasons you might want to target money to older employees," Mr. Steinberg said. "For large companies, it will be more of a niche tool."JUST HOW THE RULES APPLY **********Congress bans employers from giving relatively more in benefits to higher-paid workers than to lower-paid ones and the Internal Revenue Service issues regulations that tell employers how they must test benefits plans to show compliance. **********It is the latest regulations on nondiscrimination testing, out last month, that set up the rules for age-weighted retirement plans. Key to the plan is the concept of cross testing, which allows employers to test a defined-contribution plan, like the age-weighted plan, based on the eventual benefits to be paid rather than on current contributions. **********Consider this example, provided by Andrew Wray, a Memphis planner. One employee is 50 years old and earns $150,000. Her employer contributes $30,000 to the retirement plan this year on her behalf. Here's how the test works: If the money earns 8 1/2 percent until she reaches 65, she will have $102,000 from this year's contribution. With that money, she can buy an annuity at age 65 that will pay her $12,800 a year for life. This benefit amounts to 8 1/2 percent of her compensation at age 50. **********Another employee is 35. He earns $40,000 and has 30 years to retirement. The contribution made to the retirement plan for him is $2,400. If the money earns the same 8 1/2 percent, this employee will have a balance of $27,000 at retirement from this year's contribution. He can then buy an annuity with annual payments of $3,400. This is 8 1/2 percent of his compensation at age 35. **********"The I.R.S. is saying, as long as the benefit is the same in proportion to your salary, it's O.K.," Mr. Wray said.

They cite, as one example, arbitragers who sell short to benefit from a special situation like a takeover attempt they think will not succeed. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/28/busin.main_headline: Big Change Is Expected For Sears
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/28/busin.print_headline: Big Change Is Expected For Sears
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/28/busin.body_text: **********Sweeping changes at Sears, Roebuck & Company, including the possible sale or closing of the Sears catalogue, will be on the table next month when the company's board meets, retail executives and others watching the company say. **********Other possible moves include shifting top management and cutting $700 million to $800 million in operating costs, these people say. **********The nation's biggest retailer has been grappling with high expenses compounded by lower sales and stiff competition from Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and other rivals. Sears is expected to report sharply reduced earnings on Feb. 11 for the fourth quarter and last year. That is the same day its board gathers in Chicago for a two-day meeting.  Problems With Profits **********Founded in 1887, the Sears catalogue has the largest revenues of any mail-order business, but retail specialists say it has not been profitable for two years. Once a staple in millions of American homes the Sears catalogue presaged the opening of Sears stores. **********But it lost ground in recent years to specialty catalogues, which offer a narrower selection of merchandise, and to discount retail stores, which are able to change prices quickly. Sears catalogue prices must be set months in advance in order to meet printing and mailing schedules. **********In 1988, Montgomery Ward & Company closed its catalogue operation, which was the oldest in the country, and benefited by being able to divert the operation's expenses to supporting and expanding its stores. The J. C. Penney Company would have the largest catalogue business in the country if Sears closed down its catalogue, and some of Penney's people have been saying that its catalogue was doing better than Sears's and would soon be the largest.  Sears Declines to Comment **********Sears officials declined to comment on the industry reports that significant new changes were likely. "We do not respond to speculation," said a corporate spokesman at headquarters in Chicago. **********Declining profits from the catalogue have hurt the Merchandising Group's bottom line, and retail analysts have maintained for the last several months that Sears was negotiating to sell the operation, possibly to a Japanese buyer. **********Selling the catalogue would bring Sears a cash infusion and remove a money-losing operation. But if Sears cannot sell the catalogue, analysts say, it might decide to close the operation altogether. **********"The Sears catalogue business must be restructured because it is losing money and giving up market share to specialty catalogues, like those of Spiegel, Land's End and L. L. Bean," said Janet Mangano, research director for Jesup, Josephthal & Company in New York. "Previous actions on the catalogue haven't worked. It could be sold as a whole." Job Cuts and Refurbishing **********Early this month, the company said it would eliminate 21,000 jobs in its stores, primarily nonselling positions. It also said it was trying to cut other costs in its 800 large stores and refurbish them to make them more inviting to customers. **********One big problem, analysts say, is Sears's high cost of operations. About 30 percent of each $1 in sales goes to cover overhead, against 15 percent for Wal-Mart, which recently passed the K Mart Corporation to become the nation's second-largest retailer. **********Sears's board will consider a plan to cut costs by an additional $700 million to $800 million a year, said Walter F. Loeb, a New York financial analyst. The idea is to combine merchandising functions "so that there are only two or three general merchandise managers instead of six, take some strong action on the catalogue and in general do a more comprehensive restructuring," he said.  Estimates of Sears Earnings **********Analysts predicted that Sears would report 1990 earnings well below those of 1989. They predicted net income of $2.60 a share, against $4.12 a share in 1989. They said they expected fourth-quarter earnings of $1.07 to $1.10 a share, against $1.76 a share in the 1989 quarter. **********Those estimates embrace the entire company, which includes the Merchandising Group, Allstate Insurance, Dean Witter Financial Services and Coldwell Banker Real Estate. **********The core Merchandising Group, which is the company's biggest sales-and-profit contributor as well as its biggest drag on earnings, is expected to report net income of about $30 million, or 10 cents a share, for the full year, against 1989 net income of $292 million, or 77 cents a share, Mr. Loeb, the analyst, said. Severe Reversal Expected **********Such a result would be a severe reversal from 1989, when the Merchandising Group earned $28 million in the first three quarters. By contrast it lost $119 million in 1990's first nine months. For the crucial fourth quarter, which included the Christmas shopping season, Mr. Loeb estimated that the group earned $120 million to $125 million, against $264 million last year. In 1989, the Merchandising Group accounted for 59 percent of sales and 51 percent of income. The company's 1990 annual report has not yet been issued. **********With the Merchandising Group's poor results and the company's failure so far to improve its fortunes much, heavy pressure has fallen on Edward A. Brennan, Sears's chairman and chief executive. In August, Mr. Brennan resumed his former role as chairman and chief executive of the Merchandising Group and has since been wearing two hats -- in corporate and merchandising. **********But retailing executives and analysts are divided on whether Mr. Brennan has enough support to be left in place for further attempts to turn Sears around. None who speculated that his tenure might be in jeopardy were willing to be quoted by name. Talk of Ouster Discounted **********Others discounted such talk. **********"Ed Brennan is secure for now because he still has the directors behind him," said William N. Smith, retail analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York. **********N. Richard Nelson, analyst for Duff & Phelps in Chicago, agreed that Mr. Brennan's job was safe and said it would take more time for him to prove his value to the company. "I think he has not been in the retail job that long," he said, "and the retailing environment has not been good." **********If Sears is unable to find a new strategy for its merchandising operation and is unable to sell its catalogue, it is possible it will resume merger talks with Montgomery Ward. **********Last August, Sears was approached by Ward to consider a possible merger of the Merchandising Group with Ward, but Sears's directors turned down the proposed consolidation. Ward, whose chairman, Bernard F. Brennan, is Edward Brennan's brother, expects soon to report record earnings for 1990. This week, Bernard Brennan said there was still a "50-50 chance" that talks could be renewed. **********Bernard Sosnick, an analyst at the Deutsche Bank Group in New York, is convinced that "a restructuring of Sears's retail business is a dire necessity and must be done sooner rather than later because its competitors are becoming stronger each year." . **********"Wal-Mart's sales topped $32 billion in 1990 and will more than double by 1995," he continued. "Category killers, like Circuit City, Home Depot and Toys 'R' Us, which have dominant merchandise assortments and low operating costs, will continue to expand."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/26/busin.body_text: **********A month and a half after the United States imposed a 63 percent tariff on the most advanced screens for laptop and notebook computers, the Japanese have begun to retaliate. **********Some companies have said they will stop sending the screens to the United States, and the Toshiba Corporation, one of the largest Japanese companies to make computers in the United States, has said it is moving its operations abroad to obtain the screens without paying the tariffs. **********Thus, the retaliation will hurt the many American computer makers that rely on the Japanese screens and could lead to a loss of American jobs. The tariff was intended to protect a nascent sector of the American computer industry. **********Toshiba set clear terms for resuming the manufacture of its most sophisticated machines on American soil. "Our policy is manufacturing as close to our customers as possible," said Akira Ohashi, a spokesman at the company's headquarters here. "If the tariff is removed, we will produce again in the United States."  Trade Politics, Divided Loyalties **********The debate over protecting the American flat-panel screen industry has been rife with trade politics, and the loyalties of many companies affected are deeply divided. **********Several of America's most influential computer makers -- including I.B.M., Apple Computer and Compaq -- fought the duties because they are so heavily dependent on their Japanese suppliers. **********These companies argued that it was useless to place duties on imported screens because the American flat-panel screen industry does not have the financial strength or manufacturing capacity to supply them. Because they have no other choice than to buy their screens from Japan, the companies said, they must either raise prices for consumers or manufacture their machines outside the United States. (The tariff does not apply when the screen is imported to the United States as part of a larger computer system.) **********Paul C. Rosenthal, a Washington lawyer representing the American flat-panel display manufacturers that brought the dumping case, said it was unfair to blame the flat-panel display tariffs for moves toward manufacturing offshore. **********Mr. Rosenthal also noted that a study by the General Accounting Office released on Tuesday showed that American companies that rely on Japan for crucial components like flat-panel displays are often at a disadvantage because they cannot obtain the latest technology. **********Cydney L. Louth, a spokeswoman for the Commerce Department, said American law limits flexibility in clear cases of dumping. **********The leading American manufacturers of the "active matrix" screens that are at the heart of the dispute are OIS Optical Imaging Systems of Troy, Mich., and Standish Industries of Lake Mills, Wis. **********The advanced flat-panel displays are a small part of the market but are widely considered the wave of the future in portable computing. The tariff applies only to the most advanced screens, the active matrix screens, which provide remarkably sharp images, often in brilliant colors, that can change quickly. **********Toshiba said on Tuesday that its American subsidiary would immediately cease producing its most advanced active-matrix computers at its plant in Irvine, Calif., and move its assembly operations back to Japan. Other Japanese manufacturers, including the NEC Corporation, Japan's largest personal computer maker, will probably follow. **********Earlier this year, Toshiba reduced its work force in the United States by about 200 employees, from about 2,000. But the company said today that because only one laptop model was directly affected by the move back to Japan, no additional layoffs were expected. **********The largest maker of the screens affected by the tariff, the Hosiden Corporation of Osaka, said recently that it had stopped shipping its screens to American computer manufacturers. Apple Computer Inc., based in Cupertino, Calif., is one of Hosiden's largest customers. **********"Our customers do not want to pay the price of manufacturing their computers in the United States." said Hiroshi Yoshimura, director of Hosiden's planning division. **********Mr. Yoshimura declined to name Hosiden's customers. Apple, however, has repeatedly said it will move the manufacturing of its Macintosh portable computer from California to its plants in Singapore or Cork, Ireland. An Apple spokeswoman said today that no decision had been made. **********The Compaq Computer Corporation, based in Houston, said it was also thinking of moving production overseas, perhaps to Singapore. **********The 63 percent tariff on the flat-panel screens was approved by the Commerce Department and the International Trade Commission after an investigation that determined the Japanese makers were dumping screens -- selling them at unfairly low prices -- to seize most of the commercial market in the United States. **********One of the companies that may be hurt the most by the tariff is America's biggest computer maker: the International Business Machines Corporation. Earlier this year, I.B.M. began making active matrix screens in Japan in a joint venture with Toshiba. **********When the tariff decision was handed down, an I.B.M. spokesman called it "an eviction notice from the U.S. Government to the fastest-growing part of the U.S. computer industry." In fact, well before the tariff decision, I.B.M. turned over the development and production of its newest laptops to IBM Japan. **********Several Japanese manufacturers moved the final assembly of their laptop machines to the United States in recent years, primarily as a trade gesture. However, none have moved the most sophisticated part of the manufacturing process -- making the screens -- to American operations. Moving final assembly of the computers to the United States was also hastened by a 100 percent duty on Japanese-made laptops imposed by the Reagan Administration in retaliation for Japan's slowness in opening its semiconductor market. **********When a new semiconductor accord was signed several months ago, the 100 percent duty on finished computers was revoked. That made it as cheap to export laptops from Japan as it is to build them in America. Now that the United States has imposed the tariff on screens, it is now significantly cheaper to produce the machines in Japan.                    --------------------       Tandy-Matsushita Venture **********FORT WORTH, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Tandy Corporation and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan said today that they had formed a joint venture to make laptop and notebook computers. **********Production is scheduled to start by February at an existing Tandy site in Fort Worth that will initially employ about 100 people. The joint venture, to be called PTCC Inc., will make products to be sold under Tandy's name and Grid label, as well as by Matsushita under its Panasonic and Victor brand names.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/03/busin.main_headline: Rise Seen In Hiring in 3d Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/03/busin.print_headline: Rise Seen In Hiring in 3d Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/03/busin.body_text: **********Recent graduates and other job seekers may soon find that jobs are not so scarce. **********A survey of business hiring plans by Manpower Inc., the nation's largest temporary-employment agency, forecasts a notable upturn in the third quarter, which begins on July 1. Such a development is eagerly awaited by economists since a recovery cannot take hold as long as people are losing jobs and incomes. **********"This is the first sign of a positive trend we've seen since the third quarter of 1989, when hiring projections began to slide," said Mitchell S. Fromstein, president of Manpower, based in Milwaukee, which conducted the survey.  Expansion by 22 Percent **********The quarterly survey, published over the weekend, found that 22 percent of 15,000 businesses intended to expand their work forces during the summer while 10 percent planned to cut employment during the quarter, producing what Manpower called a net hiring strength factor of plus 12. **********This is considerably ahead of the first two quarters of 1990, when the strength factors were the lowest since 1982, and exceeded the normal jump for this time of year. **********When adjusted for seasonal variation, the latest figure of plus seven compares with plus one in the second quarter and represented what Manpower called the first trend reversal after nine straight quarters in which the strength factor either declined or remained unchanged. A Predictive Indicator **********Although employment itself is considered a coincident indicator of business conditions, shifting about the same time as the economy at large, the Manpower survey is regarded as a leading, or predictive, indicator since it deals with intentions. Mr. Fromstein said in an interview that these were usually carried out. "What was projected usually happens," he emphasized. **********Another predictive labor market indicator, published each Thursday by the Labor Department, is the number of people who have filed initial claims for unemployment insurance. This series seems to have peaked in March, when claims soared above 500,000, well above the 450,000 level of recent weeks. **********The Government's monthly report on the labor market, covering May, is to be published on Friday. Analysts expect further modest payroll job losses, along with a probable uptick in the unemployment rate, which eased two-tenths of a point in April, to 6.6 percent. **********Manpower's hiring-strength figures do appear to have anticipated both the brief 1980 recession and the extended 1981-82 recession, though by far the weakest figures were in 1982. **********The survey, based on telephone interviews with public and private employers in 476 cities, has been conducted quarterly since 1976. **********The latest data showed improvement in all four geographic regions, including the sharply depressed Northeast, where responses remained at 1982 recession levels. **********Seasonally adjusted, the Northeast moved from a strength factor of minus seven to zero for the third quarter, with the Midwest improving from four to ten, the South from three to eight and the West from three to seven, according to supplementary Manpower data. Some Exceptions in Gains **********By types of business, all sectors except transportation, public utilities, education and public administration show strong recovery from the second-quarter lows, Manpower said. **********The most notable increases are expected to be in construction, the manufacture of nondurable goods and in wholesale and retail trades and services. **********Mr. Fromstein remained cautious, however, about the projected upturn in hiring. "It is difficult at this early stage to predict a sustained recovery," he said. "But the first step toward that result is clearly in evidence."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/04/world.main_headline: Shamir's 'Yes' Buoys Israelis, If Only Because It's a Change
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/04/world.print_headline: Shamir's 'Yes' Buoys Israelis, If Only Because It's a Change
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/04/world.body_text: **********Smadar Sananes, 25 years old and blessed with a smile that could cut through clouds, said she saw peace headed her way, even at the waterfront restaurant where she and a friend were eating sandwiches and enjoying the sultry Mediterranean breeze. **********Her country's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, had announced that Israel would take part in a Middle East peace conference this fall, and although his was a conditional yes -- hinging on the thorny question of who would represent the Palestinians -- it was enough for Ms. Sananes to decide that all was well with the world. **********"It's very good," she said. "Finally, we are going to have peace. It's near. We can see it now much more than months ago."  Not Exactly Around the Corner **********Other Israelis are not so sure. In fact, many of them, perhaps most, would say that Ms. Sananes is naive, and that peace in this region is no more around the corner than a blizzard. **********Still, hawk and dove alike, they were delighted that Mr. Shamir had said on Thursday that Israel would attend the peace conference in October if the Government was satisfied with the makeup of the Palestinian delegation. **********An opinion poll published last week in the largest daily newspaper, Yediot Aharonot, suggested that three-fourths of the Israelis wanted their Government to accept the American peace initiative. Hard-liners opposed even to discussion of peace are few within the governing coalition, so it seems all but certain that Mr. Shamir will get the support he must have from his Cabinet when it meets on Sunday. Sharon Is Unhappy **********The only unhappy Cabinet minister from Mr. Shamir's Likud party is Housing Minister Ariel Sharon, the retired general and architect of the invasion of Lebanon, who has warned that the proposed conference would bring war with surrounding Arab countries instead of peace. **********"When they bring us a proposal that is not to our liking and we refuse to accept it, they will accuse us of sabotaging the very conference that we have just accepted," he told the Israel radio. "So what sort of negotiations are those?" **********Historic negotiations, replied Abba Eban, the former Foreign Minister and elder statesmen. For President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to agree to sit at the same table with Israel is "a historic turning point," Mr. Eban wrote in the newspaper Maariv, and "an opportunity that will not recur." 'A Zionist Victory' **********"Zionism has conquered the last of its opponents' fortresses," he said. "When a regime like that of Assad reaches the conclusion, for self-centered reasons, that it must agree to Israel's demand for direct negotiations, that's a Zionist victory." **********Yet on the streets of Tel Aviv, where Iraqi missiles fell only a few months ago, even people who were pleased by the Shamir announcement, like Carmel Barazani, predicted that "nothing will come of it." **********Mr. Barazani wears a pistol on his hip when he drives his taxi, insisting that it is a necessary precaution against possible terrorist attacks. Like many Israelis, he is convinced that the Arabs are not serious about negotiating and that they will make impossible demands. "Nothing will happen," he said. "No peace." **********If that turns out to be the case, at least a few people are already prepared to blame Mr. Shamir, who they say agreed to a peace conference only because he had no choice. The Americans were leaning on him hard, they argue, and it would have been difficult for him to say no when a month from now he will ask Washington for $10 billion in loan guarantees to help settle new Soviet immigrants. **********"In the end, it's all business," said Omri Achai, a restaurant owner in downtown Tel Aviv. "It's money. He needs help with so many Russians coming."  Confidence in Shamir **********"But his position has been known for years," Mr. Achai said of Mr. Shamir, "and he can't change overnight. He won't be the guy to give anything. It will be someone else after him." **********Round and round, in cafes and on Tel Aviv's beaches, the arguments swirl over how much territory, if any, Israel should give back to the Arabs. **********Miri Fabian, an actress who came to Israel from Czechoslovakia in 1949, would return it all -- East Jerusalem, the West Bank, the Golan Heights, the Gaza Strip, everything. **********"It's a chance worth taking," she said. "We've been a position of war for 40 years. Let's try it another way." **********But she acknowledges that she is in the minority. Far more people say that it is one thing to sit down at a negotiating table but quite another to yield territory. Not the Golan **********Even Ms. Sananes, who works for an automotive magazine, backed off after initially expressing a willingness to swap land for peace. Asked if that included the Golan Heights, from which Syrians used to fire onto Israeli settlements, she said no; national security would be compromised. **********Yitzhak Manshi, a 22-year-old soldier from Jaffa enjoying a day off at the beach, had no doubts on that point. **********"I support Shamir -- it's good to talk," he said, shuffling cards on a deck chair. "If they want peace, O.K. But peace for peace, not peace for land. We can give them Gaza and we can give them a mountain here or a mountain there somewhere else. But it is our territory." **********Nearby, David Birkhahn, a dentist from Jerusalem, said he did not understand why foreigners often consider Israelis intransigent when they hold such opinions. **********"Other countries say that Israel stands in the way of peace, when it is the Arabs who do," said Dr. Birkhahn, who moved here from Ireland in 1959. "Why should we give up territories for which we have spilled blood over 43 years of wars that were forced on us?" **********Then why agree to talk at all? **********"Because even though Arabs live in a realm of fantasy," he said, "I still hope that they come back to earth and realize that peace in the Middle East is good for both sides."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/15/busin.body_text: **********Hundreds of thousands of insurance policy holders and investors across the country are worried about the seizure of the Executive Life Insurance Company last week by California regulators, but few are as fearful and angry as those whose retirement benefits depend on the insurer's financial health. **********Dozens of companies have refinanced their pension plans in recent years by purchasing annuities from Executive Life, the primary subsidiary of the First Executive Corporation of Los Angeles. Annuities are contracts to pay cash over a period of time, usually in return for a single payment up front. **********Now, with Executive Life's financial condition deteriorating, largely because of losses in its huge portfolio of "junk bonds," employees and retirees are worried that the insurer will not be able to meet its financial obligations and that their pensions will be slashed or even lost. **********"I am angry about it," said Eli I. Schefer, a 71-year-old retired packaging engineer for Revlon Group Inc., which refinanced its pension plan with Executive Life annuities after it was acquired in 1985 by Ronald O. Perelman, the New York financier. **********"A lot of us worked 35 or 40 years for a company, and when they did this their fiduciary responsibility went to the winds," said Mr. Schefer, who relies on his Revlon pension for 60 percent of his income. **********Mr. Schefer, who lives in Sands Point, L.I., said he went to Revlon's headquarters in Manhattan on Friday to speak with executives about the safety of the annuities. He added that he was assured that Revlon would stand behind all its pension obligations and that for now he had little choice but to trust Revlon. Calls to Revlon today went unanswered.  Junk Bonds From Drexel **********The issue has been particularly contentious at companies that stripped excess money from their pension funds after being acquired in hostile takeovers financed by junk bonds sold through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the defunct Wall Street firm. **********First Executive was one of the largest buyers of Drexel's junk bonds. In several cases, it bought junk bonds issued by Drexel in takeovers. When the companies' new owners refinanced the companies' pension plans to strip out excess funds, First Executive sold the companies annuities that effectively replaced their pension obligations by making monthly payments to retirees. **********One example is the Pacific Lumber Company, which was acquired by the Maxxam Corporation in a hostile takeover in 1986. First Executive bought $343 million in junk bonds issued by Drexel to finance the deal. Maxxam then bought annuities from Executive Life to refinance Pacific Lumber's pension plan, despite questions raised by Pacific Lumber executives about First Executive's financial strength. **********"As you know, our employees are vitally interested in the quality of the company selected for the annuity contracts," Vincent C. Garner, a Pacific Lumber executive, wrote in a memorandum to Maxxam executives in 1986, just before the annuity business was awarded to Executive Life. "If Executive Life is selected, I believe its investment philosophy and heavy concentration in junk bonds and its role in financing Drexel Burnham's deals, including the Pacific Lumber Company's purchase, will be major sources of concern to our employees." **********The memorandum, which is cited in a lawsuit filed a year and a half ago against First Executive and Maxxam by Pacific Lumber employees, stated that Executive Life submitted the lowest bid. The suit contends that Executive Life was awarded the pension annuity business in return for First Executive's role in financing the takeover by Maxxam. **********The fears of Pacific Lumber employees were crystalized last week when California regulators took over the management of Executive Life, citing a rapid drop in the value of the insurer's junk bond portfolio. "It has everybody pretty well wound up and frightened," said John Maurer, a former Pacific Lumber employee who lives in Fortuna, Calif. "This is our worst fears come home." **********Mr. Maurer said he and other current and former Pacific Lumber employees have been trying to reach elected officials in California seeking assurances that the interests of pension holders will be given a high priority should Executive Life not be able to meet all its obligations. **********Regulators and analysts said it was still too soon to know what losses, if any, pension holders might be exposed to, or whether their interests would be given priority over holders of life insurance policies, individual annuities or other investments sold by Executive Life.
