https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/30/busin.body_text: **********Sears, Roebuck & Company's top 12 officers, including the chairman, will not get bonuses for 1990 because of poor performance by the retail division, company records indicate. **********Without the bonus, the salary of the Sears chairman, Edward A. Brennan, fell by $614,357, making him only the second- highest paid executive in the corporation. **********Mr. Brennan earned $978,854 for the year, according to the company's annual proxy materials, released Thursday. Philip Purcell, chairman of the Sears subsidiary Dean Witter Financial Services Group, was paid a 1990 bonus, making him the highest-paid officer at $1.365 million. **********Dean Witter's profits rose 40 percent, to $232.9 million, in 1990 while profits in the Sears Merchandise Group plunged 60 percent, to $257.4 million, the proxy materials stated. **********About 20,000 Sears employees had their pay frozen in December. **********Officers heading the other Sears financial services subsidiaries, the Allstate Insurance Group and Coldwell Banker Real Estate Group, were paid bonuses for 1990, but most officers of the Sears Merchandise Group, as well as top corporate officers, were not, a company spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/busin.body_text: **********Despite an increase recently in the number of women who own businesses, most small businesses formed in the 1980's were owned by middle-aged men, a survey released today said. **********The nationwide telephone survey, conducted in mid- March for I.B.M., polled 400 companies, each with fewer than 50 employees. **********In addition to finding that 81 percent of the businesses were owned by men, the survey found that the owners' average age was 43. It also said 72 percent of the owners had started their business instead of purchasing an existing company and that 38 percent of the owners had been dismissed or laid off from their previous jobs. **********Thirty-eight percent had college degrees, and nearly 70 percent started or bought their businesses alone. **********The survey found that 44 percent were Republicans, 20 percent independents and 20 percent Democrats.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/05/world.main_headline: Karachi Journal; A Hindu Romeo, a Muslim Juliet and Woe Aplenty
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/05/world.print_headline: Karachi Journal; A Hindu Romeo, a Muslim Juliet and Woe Aplenty
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/05/world.body_text: **********Zeba Bakhtiar, the angel-faced Pakistani star of the hit summer film "Henna," received her first set of reviews even before filming began. They were death threats. **********"I got some letters and phone calls, people saying they would kill me if I made the movie," the 24-year-old actress said. "They said Muslim girls should not be appearing in films with Hindu actors. Lots of people warned me not to appear in the film, not to take the risk." **********Released a few weeks ago and in most ways typical of the syrupy romance films that fill the movie houses of Pakistan and India, "Henna" is already being described as a landmark in the history of motion pictures on the subcontinent. **********It is as much a joint production on a major motion picture as the Indian and Pakistani film industries have ever seen, a Romeo and Juliet story with Romeo portrayed as an Indian Hindu -- and played Rishi Kapoor, who is one -- and Juliet a Pakistani Muslim by the name of Henna. It is also an enormous success on both sides of the border.  Of Land and Borders **********The movie was conceived by one of India's legendary film makers, the late Raj Kapoor, and directed by his son Randhir. Much of the dialogue was written by a respected Pakistani screenwriter, Haseena Moin. **********"Henna" is being promoted with the slogan: "God made land. Man made borders." And the border portrayed in the film could not be more troublesome. **********The setting of "Henna" is Kashmir, the divided northern territory that has been the focus of two of the three wars fought between India and Pakistan since their partition by Britain in 1947. **********The Indian-Pakistani relationship is considered so incendiary a topic in the motion picture industry that only a handful of films that touch on it have ever been made in either country. **********That includes the subject of the 1947 partition, in which hundreds of thousands of people, Hindus and Muslims alike, were killed in weeks of religious rioting, and millions of others were forced to desert their homes and their livelihoods. Out of the partition was born the largely Hindu nation of India and the Muslim nation of Pakistan. **********Ms. Moin, who traveled to India from her home in Karachi to work on "Henna," had her name removed from the credits before the film went into distribution, in part because of concern that "Henna" might be perceived as somehow pro-India. **********"Relations between India and Pakistan are not as friendly as they should be," said Ms. Moin, who is Pakistan's best-known television writer. "Kashmir is very controversial." **********"In the film, a wealthy Indian businessman is struck on the subject of India and Pakistan," said Jameel Akhtar Khan, professor of language and literature at Karachi University. "There are strong feelings on both sides. Film makers have not taken these risks."  Censors Ban a Play **********Novelists and book-writing historians have no reluctance to address the Indian-Pakistani relationship. But since more than half of the population in both India and Pakistan is illiterate -- an estimated 60 percent of the adults in India cannot read, 75 percent in Pakistan -- books often lack the audience to sway popular tastes. **********The fear among film makers, as well as theatrical and television producers, is largely a result of politics. **********Censor boards in both India and Pakistan monitor the political content of films and television programs. Earlier this year, censors in Karachi banned a well-reviewed play about the partition. **********There is the related concern over public taste and commercial appeal. Satish Anand, a Karachi film maker who is managing director of Eveready Pictures, said his competitors in Pakistan were just as concerned with the bottom line as their counterparts in Hollywood. **********"I think people in the industry have thought in the past that the relationship between Pakistan and India was a risky subject, commercially risky," he said. The financial success of "Henna," he said, may help change some of that thinking.  On Pirated Videotapes **********The antagonism between India and Pakistan extends to film distribution. Since the two nations went to war in 1965 over Kashmir, Indian films have not been shown in Pakistani theaters, nor Pakistan films in Indian cinemas. **********"Henna," like most popular Indian films, is seen in Pakistan on pirated videotapes, which are available in every video shop in Karachi. **********"Henna" follows a formula typical for an Indian or Pakistani film, which, simply put, is to appeal to every possible audience. "Henna" is part love story, part action-adventure and part musical. The drama is interrupted frequently for bouts of singing and dancing. **********The film is unusual in that the dialogue is in two languages: Hindi, the dominant language in northern India, for the Indian characters, and Urdu, a major Pakistani language, for the scenes in Pakistan. The two languages are closely related and can be understood on either side of the border.  'Not a Political Movie' **********While some viewers are reading a political message into "Henna," the director, Mr. Kapoor, insists he was only trying to make a film about the larger theme of tolerance. **********"This is absolutely not a political movie," he said in a telephone interview from Bombay, the film-making capital of India. "This film is about humanism and the need for people to overcome human barriers and borders." **********But Mr. Kapoor makes no money from the pirated videotapes sold in Pakistan, and he acknowledges that "Henna" may offer the chance to break down more than a quarter-century of film-distribution barriers between the two nations. **********He has requested a meeting with Pakistan's Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, to seek permission to show "Henna" in Pakistani theaters. **********"The film has been immensely popular in India and Pakistan," he said. "But in Pakistan, people have only seen it on video. I am proud of this film. I will tell the Prime Minister that 'Henna' was meant to be seen on the big screen."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/04/busin.main_headline: In U.S. Technology, a Gap Between Arms and VCR's
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/04/busin.print_headline: In U.S. Technology, a Gap Between Arms and VCR's
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/04/busin.body_text: **********From the opening salvos of Tomahawk cruise missiles to the final desert tank battles, the performance of high-technology weapons in the Persian Gulf war led to rejoicing over Yankee ingenuity and the quality of American technology. **********So some people are asking why a nation that can produce such sophisticated weapons cannot make a compact disk player and is falling behind Japan in everything from cars to computer chips. As the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, asked in the Democrats' response to President Bush's State of the Union Message, "If we can make the best smart bomb, can't we make the best VCR?"  A Mixed Answer **********Many people, including Senator Mitchell, say the answer should be yes. In addition to weaponry, the United States remains supreme in such technologies as supercomputers, software and biotechnology. If the nation were to devote as much effort to making cars and televisions as it does to producing missiles, this camp says, it might be possible to be more competitive in those areas where it is lagging behind. **********But many technology experts say the answer is not so simple. To begin with, they say, the weapons are not necessarily that sophisticated. Nor does the effort involved in making them translate automatically into success in commercial technology. **********Indeed, the nation's efforts to make weapons may hurt its competitiveness in other areas. Some executives say that because of the Pentagon mentality of striving for sophisticated technology at any cost, military technology has become irrelevant to economic competitiveness. In selling computers, television sets or automobiles, low cost and the ability to get to market quickly are as important as whiz-bang features. **********The Raytheon Corporation, for example, which built the Patriot anti-missile system that destroyed the Iraqi Scuds, has had a tough time in the consumer marketplace with its Caloric stoves and Speed Queen washing machines and dryers.  Future Debates **********The performance of the weapons in the Persian Gulf is likely to play a role in future debates about national priorities and how to restore competitiveness. In a number of interviews, technology executives, analysts and military systems experts agreed on these points: ***********Most weapons used in the war, including the Patriot and the Tomahawk, were developed more than 10 years ago, using technology far less sophisticated than that found in today's garden-variety personal computers. In that sense, the triumph of American weaponry in the war is not so much a sign of the nation's present prowess as it is a reminder of past ability. ***********While the Defense Department once pioneered in developing technology that later found commercial uses, the latest technology is now generally developed for nonmilitary applications; only later might it find its way into weapons. ***********Because of its loss of competitiveness in commercial technology, the United States cannot make some of its own weapons without help from other nations. A small but growing number of components and technologies in American weapons come from foreign suppliers, in some cases because there are no longer any American producers. **********Before the Persian Gulf war, a movement seemed to be building in the technology business and in Congress to redirect some Federal research and development spending away from purely military technology like the "Star Wars" anti-missile system and toward technologies with more civilian applications, like flat-panel monitors for use in television sets and computers. Whether the war will derail that movement is uncertain. **********For all the excitement over American weaponry, it is still too early to assess precisely how well the high technology performed. For every video clip of a smart bomb gliding into an airshaft, it is not known how many bombs went astray. And military analysts point out that Iraq was not the most technologically sophisticated opponent.  Good, but Expensive **********Still, even if the technology functioned as well as its ardent supporters say, consider the cost and time involved in building those weapons. Some $9.5 billion, for instance, has been spent on the Tomahawk cruise missile since 1972. Given such costs and time, some say, the weapons should work well. **********"We're all proud of the Patriot's performance, but it costs a million dollars every time you push the button," said Jacques S. Gansler, a former Pentagon procurement official and author of "Affording Defense." **********The military business, with its own goals and complex procedures, has evolved into a culture distinct from commercial business. Companies that excel in one arena often cannot excel in the other. **********Some executives and analysts go further, arguing that weapons development has actually hurt the nation's competitiveness by siphoning off research dollars and engineers that could have been developing commercial products. Where Americans developed spy satellites, Japan made video cameras and is reaping the revenues.  Research Called Unbalanced **********Just last month, for instance, executives from 11 large computer companies issued a report saying that too much Federal research and development money had been spent on the military and not enough on computers. **********The report said that nearly 70 percent of Federal research and development money goes to the military, up from 50 percent a decade ago. Although the Federal Government spends more over all on research and development than most of the other industrial powers, its nonmilitary research and development spending is less than in the other nations, as measured by percentage of gross national product. **********Military spending was once believed to contribute to the nation's overall technological ability. The fledgling American semiconductor industry got its start developing chips for the Minuteman missile in the 1960's and only later began selling to computer companies. **********That is less likely to be the case now, in part, some people say, because military technology has increasingly emphasized exotic technology with few apparent commercial spinoffs, like semiconductor chips that can resist nuclear radiation.  Shift in Electronics **********In the case of electronics, on which "smart weapons" rely, the growing computer and consumer electronics industries have simply spurted ahead of the military as users of chips and as technology leaders. In the 60's, about 70 percent of chips went into military equipment; now only about 8 percent do. So chip companies aim their development efforts at satisfying computer companies, not the Pentagon. **********Similarly, some composite materials used in weapons are "not nearly as advanced as what you could buy in a sporting goods store," said Michael Sekora, a former director of technology planning in the Pentagon. **********Robert B. Costello, chief of Pentagon procurement in the Reagan Administration, said: "Defense is not a leader. In many cases it's not even a user of the latest technology." **********Indeed, an increasing problem for the Pentagon is keeping its obsolete technology in operation. Because it takes 8 to 15 years to develop a weapon, the technology is often outdated by the time the weapon is ready. **********One company, Lansdale Semiconductor of Tempe, Ariz., does nothing but manufacture computer chips for the Pentagon that have long since been discontinued by the original manufacturer. Some of these chips are in the Tomahawk and Patriot systems and in sensors on helicopters used in the gulf war, said Lansdale's president, Dale Lillard.  Advantages of Commercialism **********Unencumbered by the burdensome military procurement regulations, and spurred by competition, makers of commercial products often rush ahead. An example of this is devices that calculate latitude and longitude by receiving signals from the Pentagon's Navstar Global Positioning System satellites. **********The Rockwell International Corporation, under a Pentagon contract, developed a portable receiver that weighs 17 pounds and can be carried in a backpack. But companies fiercely competing to sell receivers for use in pleasure boats offer units that weigh as little as three pounds and can be carried in one hand. **********These units are not quite as rugged as the military versions and lack some features, like protection against jamming. But when the Defense Department found itself needing thousands of receivers in the Saudi desert, it had to turn to a commercial supplier to provide them quickly and cheaply. **********Indeed, the Pentagon is buying more commercial products to save time and money. In a sense, therefore, the spinoffs are now going the other way: A healthy commercial industry is considered necessary for the military.  Foreign Technology Used **********One consequence of this is that the United States, lacking a consumer electronics business and behind in production of certain types of semiconductors, is becoming dependent on Japan and other nations for technology used in weapons. **********Virtually all the optical glass used in reconnaissance satellites comes from Germany. Many gallium arsenide chips, used in radars and satellite receivers, come from Japan. A report released two weeks ago by the General Accounting Office said that five parts of the Abrams tank are made by foreign companies, including the optics in the gunner's sight and an ingredient in a seal. **********The extent of foreign dependency is not known. Several reports suggest that current weapons contain a small percentage of foreign parts but that the next generation will have a larger percentage. Some people say there is no problem in relying on allies for military technology; others believe the best course is to be self-sufficient. Research and Development **********Still, some Pentagon and industry officials have been arguing that the Pentagon should direct some research and development money to help American technology companies compete in commercial markets. Only if American companies are successful in commercial markets will they be able to produce supplies for the military, these people say. **********If there is a lesson from the gulf war, some executives said, it is that the United States can accomplish what it sets its mind and money to do. If the nation determined that economic security was as important as military security, "we could catch up in the commercial arena as well," said William J. Spencer, chief executive of Sematech, a technology consortium in Austin, Tex., that is backed by the Pentagon and industry. **********"Why can't we make a VCR when we can make a Patriot missile?" asked Clyde Prestowitz, president of the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington. His answer: "We really care about making Patriot missiles."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/27/world.body_text: **********Units of the Yugoslav Army failed on Wednesday to dislodge Slovenian militias that were occupying key border posts to back up the republic's assertion that it was now independent of the Yugoslav federation. **********At the same time, tension rose in the neighboring republic of Croatia, which also declared independence on Tuesday from Yugoslavia, after ethnic Serbs stormed a Croatian police station in the town of Glina, about 50 miles south of Zagreb. A Croatian policeman and two civilians were reportedly killed Wednesday and six people wounded in the gun battle. **********But in general, the national forces and those of the northern republics challenging federal authority circled and maneuvered around each other without actually clashing. **********Reuters reported that the Yugoslav news agency Tanyug said tanks were moving toward Ljubljana, the Slovene capital. Tanyug said a soldier was slightly wounded in a clash with a Slovenian defense unit near Novo Mesto, close to the Slovenian border with Croatia, as a column of army vehicles broke through a barricade of buses and continued toward the airport. **********The Associated Press reported that defiant citizens set up roadblocks but apparently did not try to fight the advance. The significance of the army movement and the degree of resistence that it was met with were not clear, **********"It's a battle of nerves at this moment, it's not a real war," the Slovene Foreign Minister, Dimitrij Rupel, said earlier. **********Shortly after he spoke in Ljubljana, the Slovene capital was buzzed by Yugoslav MIG fighter planes making low-level sweeps that at times drowned out church bells tolling as part of an official celebration of the decision announced on Tuesday to pull away from the rest of Yugoslavia. **********But the federal Government succeeded in shutting down air traffic into and out of Ljubljana at noon on Wednesday by refusing to give aircraft access to air routes. The airport remains closed. **********On Wednesday afternoon, Yugoslav Army tanks and trucks heading up major roads toward border posts seized by the Slovenians were bottled up by Slovenes who stalled heavy trucks and constrution equipment in the path of the military convoy. **********"When they tell me to let them go, I'll let them go," said an officer of a Slovenian police unit blocking a main mountain pass on a road leading to the border crossing to Italy near the town of Nova Gorica. **********A few hundred yards back, a frustrated Army officer said his unit would get through the traffic jam. **********"We'll wait here as long as we have to," he said before adding "We'll fight our way through if we have to. It's all the same to me." Presidency to Meet **********Minutes later, the unit turned around and retreated. **********Despite a sense that the standoff was stiffening, the prospect of a negotiated settlement of the crisis became slightly greater as the Government announced that Yugoslavia's recently inert and immobilized federal executive, which includes representatives of all six republics, would meet early today to discuss the crisis. The announcement of the meeting, carried by Yugoslav radio and television, said the representatives of Croatia and Slovenia would attend, though that could not be confirmed. **********But early today Belgrade television quoted the Slovenian representative to the Presidency, Janez Drnovsek, as saying that neither he not the Croatian representative would attend the meeting, which he called illegal. **********Such meetings have been called before in the last two months only to be canceled at the last minute. **********One report circulating here held that the meeting was being convened by the Council for the Protection of Constitutional Order, a sort of national security group that includes the republican representatives along with the federal Minister of Defense, Gen. Veljko Kadijevic. Securing the Northern Borders **********Within hours of Tuesday's declarations by Slovenia and Croatia, Ante Markovic, the federal Prime Minister, announced that the Cabinet had ordered the army to take control of international borders in the two northernmost republics. **********The military's mandate is apparently to secure Yugoslavia's northern borders with Italy, Austria and Hungary, and to displace regional border guards and customs officials who were put in place as part of Slovenia's declaration of sovereignty. **********But on Wednesday night, state television here in Serbia showed images of Slovene border guards along the Austrian frontier hoisting the republic's white, red and blue banner under newly erected signs that read "Republic of Slovenia." **********Much of the army's movements on Wednesday were focused on regions of Croatia where that republic's declaration of independence from the federal state set off violent clashes between members of the 600,000-member Serbian minority there and the Croatian police forces.  Casualties of Serb-Croat Strife **********Conflicting reports of the numbers of dead and wounded circulated throughout the day, but according to the Croatian Interior Ministry in the capital, Zagreb, at least four people were killed, three of them when ethnic Serbs attacked the Croatian police station in the town of Glina. **********Conflicts between the Serbs, who have vowed to resist Croatian independence, and the Croatian police were reported throughout the day on Wednesday, focusing mainly on Glina and the city of Dvor on the Una River, about 60 miles south of Zagreb. In both places, Yugoslav army units accompanied by tanks held a fragile peace. **********An off-duty federal police officer was reported killed in a shooting incident in the Croatian town of Brsadin. The clashes on Wednesday raised the death total in Serb-Croat violence this year to about 25. **********The Croatian authorities, who on Tuesday announced that they would leave the Yugoslav Union, asserted that the National Army was slow to assist their republican police units in ending Wednesday's siege in Glina. Serbian Threat of Action **********"We did not win the cooperation of Yugoslav Army units until after a long series of discussions," said Milan Brezak, Croatia's Deputy Internal-Affairs Minister, in a news conference Wednesday. **********The clashes were reminiscent of earlier eruptions of violence between Serbs and Croats, the two largest ethnic groups in Yugoslavia. **********In Belgrade, which is the capital of the Serbian republic as well as that of the whole country, the Serbian Parliament debated the events of the last 24 hours in a special session, and the Serb Prime Minister, Dragutin Zelenovic, suggested that Serbia was prepared to take action that he did not fully specify. **********"Serbia has already taken steps to assure Serbian interests," Mr. Zelenovic told the packed assembly. "And they are going to be implemented when the Government of Serbia decides it is the right moment to do so." **********Mr. Zelenovic did not elaborate, but Yugoslavs and Western diplomats said they thought it was likley that Serbia might counter the steps taken by Croatia and Slovenia by declaring the annexation of the heavily Serbian regions in Croatia. **********Under the Yugoslav Constitution of 1974, which is still nominally in force though it has been shredded by all sides in the recent ethnic conflicts, the Defense Minister, though a member of the federal Cabinet, is responsible to the Presidency as commander in chief. But with the Presidency effectively inoperative, Yugoslavs and diplomats said command of the army appeared to have devolved, under an ad hoc arrangement, to Prime Minister Markovic, working in close concert with General Kadijevic.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/02/world.main_headline: Iraqis' Food Rations Are Reduced As Trade Embargo Cuts Supplies
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/02/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF; Iraqis' Food Rations Are Reduced As Trade Embargo Cuts Supplies
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/02/world.body_text: **********After four months of total trade embargo, the shortages in the Government food rationing program that has helped Iraq sustain its defiance of the United Nations demand that it end its occupation of Kuwait. **********Since September, Iraqi families have suffered declines of 25 percent to 50 percent in the amount of basic food items they are able to get in government stores by redeeming the rationing coupons issued to each family, Iraqi residents and foreign diplomats monitoring the program say. **********A food coupon that allotted 17.6 pounds of wheat flour a month for each person last September, can be redeemed today for only 11 pounds of flour. The sugar ration of 3.3 pounds a month for each person has been effectively cut to 1.15 pounds a month. Redemptions of tea coupons have slipped from about 4.5 ounces for each person to about 1.8 ounces. **********With Government food supplies severely reduced, more and more Iraqi families are being forced into the open food market, where prices of basic food items are seven times higher than they were at the outset of the crisis, but where shortages of rice, sugar and milk have become more apparent. 'Sanctions Are Working' **********"Sanctions are working, no matter what anybody says," one Asian ambassador said in an interview, noting that basics like eggs and fresh milk have either disappeared or have been priced beyond the reach of most Iraqi families. "The country has had no income in the last five months, so there has got to be a limit to their endurance," he added. **********The strongest indication of a looming food crisis was a Government announcement 10 days ago that all excess supplies of sugar and flour on the open market were to be confiscated by Iraqi authorities administering the rationing program. **********And last week, Government agents actually swept through food stores in Baghdad confiscating the scarce staple foods that were in private hands and for sale at wildly inflated free market prices, according to a number of Iraqi witnesses. **********Of basic food groups, meat has suffered the least price inflation, but still prices have almost doubled. Foreign diplomats said meat prices have been moderated somewhat by an increase in the slaughter in Iraq's sheep herds last fall, but with the end of the slaughter season, prices are expected to move up more rapidly in coming weeks as supplies tighten. Steak Supplies Dwindling **********One luxury hotel in downtown Baghdad is still serving T-bone steaks taken from Kuwait, but these supplies are dwindling rapidly. **********The price of Iraqi Sumer cigarettes, previously produced with local tobacco blended with some American tobacco, has leapt from half an Iraqi dinar to 3.5 dinars, a sevenfold increase. **********The Government mobilization of the agricultural sector to blunt the impact of the embargo has engendered mixed results and has resulted in an overall poor performance, with no improvement in grain production in sight because of the lack of rain in November, the planting month, diplomats said. Iraq imported 90 percent of its basic grain needs before the crisis. **********But a major expansion of vegetable crop planting on irrigated lands has helped supplement declining food supplies, a number of people said, though the manpower pool for the agricultural sector was reduced last month when the Government rescinded farmers' exemption from military service. **********Hundreds of thousands of Egyptian farm laborers also have fled Iraq and are no longer contributing to agricultural production here. Psychological Effect **********"In many ways they have felt the effect of this embargo," one senior envoy said of the Iraqis. "Psychologically speaking it has worked. Under the rations they are getting less food and they are critical about the rocketing price situation." **********The envoy pointed out that the standard of living has been seriously hurt in such important regional cities such as Karbala and Najaf, both important religious centers for the Shiite Muslim sect that is the largest population group in Iraq. **********Even during the early months of the embargo, an Indian philanthropic group set up a food distribution center in those cities and "they had such long queues they were very surprised," the envoy said. **********But for now, this envoy said he could not predict that the embargo would compel Mr. Hussein to pull his forces out of Kuwait by any certain date in the near future. **********If the minimum quality of life "can be secured by the Government, they can endure," the envoy said, adding that this remained an open question. Reserves Being Used **********A Middle Eastern envoy said the growing food problems had forced Iraq to tap strategic food reserves the Government might have been trying to preserve for the long run. Sweet shops and pastry shops, big users of sugar, were allowed to reopen during the Christmas holidays. **********The food crisis has also brought a notable increase in cross-border smuggling from Iraq's neighbors, particularly Iran and Jordan. One diplomat said that in October a check of the highway between Baghdad and the Jordanian border found the artery virtually free of traffic from Jordan. But a check 10 days ago of the same highway found "tens" of covered freight carrying trucks with Jordanian license plates streaming toward the Iraqi capital. **********"This is a new phenomenon," a senior Asian envoy said. **********Western embassies said they had received fresh reports of significant truck traffic entering Iraq from Iran at a number of points along the 700-mile frontier between the two nations, which fought a bitter eight-year war. Pressure on Hussein **********Foreign embassies monitoring the embargo's effects say it is too early to tell whether the volume of Government food distribution will continue to deteriorate at the current rate, but most analysts here agree that the food crisis will only add to the political pressure on Mr. Hussein to seek some political resolution to the Kuwait adventure. **********Outside the food sector, lines have developed in the last 10 days at government distribution points for bottled natural gas, which is used widely in Iraqi homes to fuel cooking stoves, hot-water heaters and space heaters. **********The price of the 100-pound metal cannisters of gas has remained stable, but neighborhood distribution trucks have disappeared in many parts of the city, forcing most families to drive to distribution centers, where lines have formed for the first time. **********Western officials said they have heard two explanations for the shortage, which is not yet deemed serious. One explanation is that with the sudden decline of crude oil production, the production of natural gas as a by-product has declined proportionately. **********Second, government plants that process the natural gas and fill the 100-pound metal cylinders for the retail market used sophisticated French-made machinery that may be suffering for lack of spare parts and proper maintenance with the departure of French and other foreign technicians. **********A still uncertain shortage that looms this month is for chlorine compounds used the the national water purification plants. Foreign technicians who departed last month reported that supplies of the chlorine compounds were critically short and would not last beyond Jan. 5 or Jan. 6. **********But some European embassies believe that the Iraqi authorities can make up for the shortfall by smuggling adequate quantities from Jordan or Iran.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/busin.main_headline:
Your Own Account;
Eliminating Chaos From Investing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/busin.print_headline:
Your Own Account;
Eliminating Chaos From Investing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/busin.body_text: **********In times of great political and economic uncertainty like these, investors worry that they simply can't digest all the conflicting reports and make the right decisions about their investments. Should they move to stocks? To cash? **********The truth is, you would probably be much better off if you ignored upheavals -- even war -- and forgot about the investment of the month. Instead, you should set up a portfolio that is broadly diversified over several different asset classes -- such as domestic and international bonds, stocks and cash -- and then resist the urge to tinker with it at every announcement of world, or domestic, events. **********Asset allocation is certainly not a new technique. But like most basics, it often gets lost amid the marketing gimmicks. Consider the asset allocation funds that appeared soon after the 1987 stock market crash, when mutual fund companies tried to shift the focus of investors away from the tattered equity market. **********One of the most pretentious of the lot drew money managers from different parts of the world; they met quarterly in a townhouse on Manhattan's Upper East Side with someone called "The Allocator," a money manager who made the final decision. Not only did this mumbo jumbo result in high expenses, but all that asset shifting made the fund a market timer -- trying to outsmart what is essentially a nonrational phenomenon. Then called the National Strategic Allocation Fund, it is now named the National Global Allocation Fund. **********Many investors are also confused about asset allocation and market timing. The theory behind asset allocation is that individual investors do not have enough information to time the market and they are better off hedging their bets. Although most small investors would agree in principle, they simply can't resist the urge to look for an investment that will double their money. **********"The desire to find a way to beat the system is so strong that it continually comes back cloaked in other language," says Roger C. Gibson, president of Gibson Capital Management Ltd., a money management firm in Pittsburgh. "Unless you completely extinguish the idea that market timing is not possible, it will just keep creeping out." **********Investors who resist the idea of market timing but then make a last-minute emotional decision to pull out of the market because they are worried, say, about war in the Middle East, make an obvious mistake: "They buy high and sell low, no question about it," said Harold Evensky, a financial planner at Evensky & Brown, Miami. **********So forget about hot tips. Think instead about spreading your assets across a variety of asset classes that will perform differently. This will cushion your portfolio against swings in any one sector. The more sectors you cover, the better your cushion. **********Mr. Evensky urges clients to divide assets into two basic categories: income investments, such as bonds, money market funds and Treasury bills, and growth investments, including stocks and even your home, which provide the opportunity for your principal to grow over time. Mr. Evensky breaks down growth investments into sectors that perform well in different environments: *********** Commercial. This includes investments that move with the business cycle like stocks, an investment in your own business, or equipment leasing. *********** Real estate. This moves in a slightly different cycle and does well in inflationary times. Mr. Evensky acknowledges that this is a particularly difficult category, given the current problems in the real estate market. But, he said, "In theory, it still makes sense." *********** Natural resources. This includes oil, gas and timber, which are used by business even if the economy is in the dumps. *********** Precious metals and collectibles. These are a hedge against inflation. **********Assuming you believe that you should diversify and sit tight rather than attempting to time the market, how should you deploy your assets over the various sectors? Mr. Evensky tailors a program for clients based on their risk tolerance, whether their financial needs are longer or shorter term, and a certain "feel" he has about what is appropriate for them. Even if you can't afford a financial planner, you can still proceed with the same basic approach. **********Finally, you should readjust your portfolio at regular intervals, say once a year. This is not to be confused with market timing. You stick to your initial allocation, trading only to keep the original balance. "Whatever has most recently done the best must be sold to get back to target and whatever has done poorly is now underrepresented," Mr. Gibson said.FIRST OF ALL, KNOW THYSELF **********William G. Droms, a professor of finance at Georgetown University, devised a shorthand method for deciding how to allocate investment assets. Value the seven statements on a scale of 1 to 5, with 1 being "strongly disagree" and 5 being "strongly agree." Then add up your points. *********** Earning a high long-term total return that will allow my capital to grow faster than the inflation rate is one of my most important investment objectives. *********** I would like an investment that provides me with an opportunity to defer taxation of capital gains and/or interest to future years. *********** I do not require a high level of current income from my investments. *********** My major investment goals are relatively long term. *********** I am willing to tolerate sharp up-and-down swings in the return on my investments in order to seek a higher return than would be expected from more stable investments. *********** I am willing to risk a short-term loss in return for a potentially higher rate of return in the long run. *********** I am financially able to accept a low level of liquidity in my investment portfolio. **********Here, depending on how you scored yourself, are Mr. Droms's recommendations on what percentage of assets to put into what sort of investment: **********Total ScoreMoneyFixedEquitiesMarketIncome **********30 to 35101080 **********22 to 2202060 **********14 to 21 **********303040 **********7 to 13404020 **********Equities would include real estate, venture capital, international stocks, gold, domestic stocks. Fixed income investments include American and international bonds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Britain; BOMBING EXPECTED TO LAST FOR WEEKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/world.body_text: **********The allied air campaign against Iraq will continue for two to three more weeks before ground forces go into action, senior British officials said today. **********One Government official in daily contact with the White House said there was no expectation that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq would capitulate and pull his forces out of Kuwait before the allies moved in on the ground. **********"Our air campaign will continue until we are satisfied his forces have been so cut back that a successful land campaign is assured," Air Vice Marshal Sir David Craig, Chief of the British Defense Staff, said here today. **********An aide to Prime Minister John Major said reaching that point would take two to three weeks more of intense bombing of missile sites, airfields and strategic installations inside Iraq, as well as Iraqi troop concentrations in and just north of Kuwait.  'He's Lying Low Now' **********One member of Mr. Major's Cabinet said the allies expected Mr. Hussein to try to use chemical and biological weapons if he finds his army being beaten by American, British and other allied ground forces. **********"He's lying low now, keeping his air force mostly underground and trying to present as elusive a target as possible," an adviser to the Prime Minister said. "But once we've started the ground campaign, he'll try to inflict great numbers of casualties on us and hope we lose stomach for the fight." **********British officials also believe that Mr. Hussein might use chemical or biological weapons against Israel and Saudi Arabia if his troops faced defeat on the battlefield. So far, Mr. Hussein has only used conventional warheads mounted on modified Soviet-built Scud missiles against Israel and Saudi Arabia. **********Mr. Major, like American officials recently, has warned that the war may last a long time, but he has the support of all but the left-wing fringes of the British political spectrum. **********The Labor Party leader, Neil Kinnock, has backed the military operations, even though he expects to run against Mr. Major in the general election that has to be called by July 1992.  Political and Public Support **********"We're fighting two wars at once," said John Gilbert, a Labor Party Member of Parliament who was a defense official in the last Labor Government. "There's the war to get Iraq out of Kuwait, and the war to eliminate Saddam Hussein as a threat to the regional stability and security of the Persian Gulf region. We should come right out and say so." **********Sir David welcomed "the strong political and public support, which has been so reassuring to us." Public opinion polls published last weekend showed solid majorities of the Conservative and Labor Parties backing the allies' use of force after President Hussein refused to comply with the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for withdrawing his troops from Kuwait. **********Britain has sent 35,000 soldiers, sailors, pilots and aircrews to the gulf. **********British public support for the war has not yet been weakened by the relatively losses suffered by its Tornado aircraft in the conflict. Five Tornados have been lost to Iraqi anti-aircraft fire and one went down in an accident. **********Sir David said today that contrary to news reports, only one Tornado had been lost while dropping JP-233 runway-cratering devices to keep Iraqi fighters from attacking Americans during raids on nuclear power plants, chemical weapons centers and other strategic sites inside Iraq. **********He said that the Tornados were now flying fewer low-level missions but that was because the allies had established air superiority over the Iraqis.  WEAPONS POTENTIAL DAMAGED **********PARIS, Jan. 25 (Special to The New York Times) -- France's armed forces Chief of Staff, Gen. Maurice Schmitt, said today that one week of bombing had virtually destroyed Iraq's nuclear weapons potential and had reduced its chemical arms capacity by three-quarters. **********He said there was no evidence that Iraq could install chemical weapons on Scud missiles, but added that they could still be delivered by aircraft or artillery. In a ground war, he noted, "we have predicted that we will fight in a chemical environment and we are ready."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Southland in Exit From Bankruptcy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/06/busin.body_text: **********The Southland Corporation, parent of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain, emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy after two Japanese companies pumped in $430 million of cash by buying 70 percent of its stock. The stock purchase by the Ito-Yokado Group and the Seven-Eleven Japan Company marked the final step in Southland's coming out from bankruptcy five months after it filed a "prepackaged" restructuring plan. **********Under the deal, Southland security holders are to receive 25 percent of the company's common stock and the right to buy another 2.5 percent. The founding Thompson family of Dallas will retain a 5 percent equity share in the company they took private in 1987 in a leveraged buyout. The debt from that deal forced the Dallas-based company to file for bankruptcy.
