https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/31/world.main_headline: A Royal Visit To Shore Up Canada Unity
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/31/world.print_headline: A Royal Visit To Shore Up Canada Unity
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/31/world.body_text: **********The Prince and the Princess of Wales -- with their interest in causes, he in the environment and Canadian unity, she in AIDS, drug treatment and battered women -- are trying to rejuvenate the constitutional monarchy in the largest country of the Commonwealth. **********The royal couple have drawn good reviews in a weeklong visit, culminating in the most pointed political intervention made by a member of the British royal family in Canada in recent memory. They returned home from Ottawa on Tuesday night. **********Against a backdrop of Quebec separatism, the heir to the British throne endorsed the status of the French-speaking province as a "distinct" society within the Canadian Constitution and made a strong plea for national unity. "The world, in brief, needs Canada," he declared. **********Speaking at Queen's University in Kingston, Ontario, on Monday, the Prince, who will turn 43 on Nov. 14, acknowledged that it was a "risky business" for a future king to be venturing into Canada's constitutional business, but observed wryly he had a "hereditary defect -- living dangerously." An Ancestor's Adventure **********He cited his great-great-grandfather, an earlier Prince of Wales, who in 1860 volunteered to ride a tightrope walker's wheelbarrow across Niagara Falls, but was finally talked out of the adventure by Canadian authorities. He became Edward VII in 1901. **********No Canadian authorities sought to talk Prince Charles out of his latest adventure, which could not have been better designed to bolster the position of the Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. Its latest constitutional proposals also recognize Quebec's distinctiveness as part of arrangements to keep the federation together. Few thought the words, however unusual, would stir any controversy. **********The royal couple were accompanied by their two children, William, 9, and Henry, 7 -- the first time the boys have traveled with their parents on an official tour overseas. Projecting a Homey Picture **********In the face of recurrent rumors of fractures in the marital alliance, the visit was intended to project a homey picture of family values. **********It also provided some on-the-job training in royal do's and dont's for the two boys. Prince William earned a publicly visible reprimand from his parents when, from the bow of the 413-foot royal yacht Britannia, family quarters for the week, he appeared to enjoy the limelight too much. **********About 1,000 people had gathered at the dock in the Toronto harbor on Lake Ontario, as the boy, dressed up in blue blazer and necktie shirt, waved to his future subjects longer than decorum allowed. His mother yanked his arm down in mid-salutation and pulled him away. His father then appeared to give him a dressing down. **********Crowds were generally restrained, and those who did come out seemed more curious than captivated about the royal doings. Newspapers reported numbers of onlookers far smaller than those drawn by the Duke and Duchess of York in 1987. Caring About the Issues **********The visit showed a rather engaging couple who were trying to show, despite the gulf between them and ordinary people, that they really care about today's issues. **********"Within the rigid restrictions of life in the royal lane, the Princess of Wales is trying to make a difference," wrote Rosie DiManno, a columnist for The Toronto Star. "The incredible part is that she seems to be succeeding." **********The press and television took gleeful note of one incident in which as Prince Charles was entering the Art Gallery of Ontario, his escort, Culture Minister Karen Haslam of Ontario, lost her footing and her left shoe. The Prince gallantly retrieved it and slipped it back on her foot. **********Recounting the experience later, Ms. Haslam said: "My gracious, my Prince is handing me my shoe," and the Prince of Wales, evidently thinking of Cinderella, replied: "Thank goodness it fits."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR:; Third World Seeks Advanced Arms
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/world.body_text: **********The deadly pounding that the West's military forces gave the Iraqis this year has whetted the appetite of third-world nations for advanced weapons, military analysts say. One result,, they say, could be a rapid advance in accuracy and technological sophistication of the developing world's military arsenals. **********Having watched as "smart" bombs and cruise missiles dispatched an armed force that Iraq spent $50 billion to amass, third-world nations are already scouting for similar weapons, Bush Administration officials and private experts said in interviews. **********The trend is worrisome, they said, because it suggests some erosion in the military edge that enabled Western nations to win so decisively, without heavy casualties to their own forces, in the Persian Gulf war. Wars Could Be More Destructive **********More important, it raises the prospect that future armed conflicts in the third world could be vastly more destructive as precision weapons that cannot easily be repelled wreak the sort of damage that Iraq's inaccurate Scuds never managed to inflict. **********Major powers like the Soviet Union and China are seeking the same weapons technologies, and some worry that they may supply them to other nations. But the arming of lesser regional powers is most troubling because, as Iraq showed, developing regions are easily destabilized by weapons buildups and are far more likely to erupt into war. **********Though the Bush Administration has stated its opposition to an arms race and is discussing with France and other Western powers an agreement to curb some weapons sales to prevent one, the United States has emerged from the war as the gulf region's premier arms seller. The White House told Congress in a classified report this month that it wanted to allow five Middle East allies to buy an $18 billion package of top-drawer weapons like F-16 jet fighters, Patriot antimissile defenses, multiple-rocket launchers and M-1 tanks. **********Some Persian Gulf nations are already rearming, though several factors work against an immediate and greatly intensified arms race, the analysts said. In the Middle East, war expenses and stagnant oil revenues will force the postponement of some major arms purchases until the mid-1990's, they said. Many experts also believe that Iraq's military devastation will itself dampen any future weapons buildup by eliminating the region's major aggressive power.  Arms Sales to Mideast Nations **********Germany has agreed to sell Israel two top-of-the-line diesel submarines capable of launching both torpedoes and cruise missiles. Strapped for hard currency, the Soviet Union is selling many of its best weapons, like MiG-29 jet fighters, to such nations as Iran and Syria. **********Other buyers outside the gulf, goaded by national pride and suspicion of their neighbors, are equally eager to buy. **********Pakistan's Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, drove home the point in a speech on March 16 in which he said that Iraq's crushing defeat only underscored the need to make his own nation "an impregnable fortress" to aggressors. **********"The military aspect of the gulf war has made the fact clear that to undermine the science, technology, research and modern advances in defense is disastrous," he said. "The challenge of the technology is a permanent phenomenon." **********China is believed to be considering the sale of its new M-9 and M-11 medium-range ballistic missiles, which are said to be more accurate and reliable than the Soviet-made Scuds used by Iraq, and already has sold M-series missile technology to other nations, the Pentagon said this month. China is just one of several developing nations with active ballistic missile programs. Soviet Arms' Reputation Is Hurt **********Just as ominous to some is a growing demand for adaptations of the state-of-the-art technologies used in such military hardware as cruise missiles, reconnaissance satellites and radar-invisible Stealth fighters. **********In a report this month, the director of naval intelligence, Adm. Thomas A. Brooks, said that at least 40 countries were seeking "low observable" weapons technologies like materials that absorb radar waves, and that France, Sweden and other Western nations were incorporating them in their own arms. By 2000, the report forecast, nine nations will join the six that now deploy reconnaissance satellites, a technology that gave the West a decisive advantage in the Iraq conflict. **********The report predicted a trend among developing nations toward "increasingly sophisticated military hardware, especially in naval and air forces," regardless of the cost. **********While most of these additions were contemplated well before the gulf war, experts say the war has lent a new gleam to Western weapons and wounded the reputation of hardware made by Iraq's supplier, the Soviet Union. More than that, the lopsided allied victory demonstrated that even an overwhelming force of the relatively capable tanks, jets and air-defense weapons common to the third world are ineffective against advanced weapons and computerized communications and intelligence systems. **********"Look at what our Apache helicopters did to their tanks with Hellfire missiles," said Richard Grimmett, an expert on third-world arms with the Congressional Research Service. "It's the old argument that the Israelis have always used: a qualitative advantage compensates for a quantitative disadvantage." Beyond Their Pocketbooks **********Government officials and private experts say that many advanced Western technologies, like the electronics and exotic materials used in the F-117 Stealth fighter, probably will not be offered on the world weapons market for decades and are beyond the pocketbooks of most developing powers anyway. On the other hand, they say, less advanced versions of those weapons, as well as simpler technologies that developing nations are beginning to master, still can play havoc not only with an enemy's military but also with a superpower's forces as well. **********In the ocean, nautical mines and submarines are a growing concern to Pentagon officials, who said that Persian Gulf naval forces were preoccupied this winter by the military potential of Iran's single, difficult-to-locate mini-submarine. Mini-subs are sold worldwide by an Italian company recently acquired by a Chilean arms merchant, Carlos Cardoen. **********Some experts believe that third-world arms makers will be able to produce rudimentary cruise missiles, somewhat bigger than those that rocked Baghdad, but far cheaper and nearly as accurate. The ground-hugging missiles themselves are reasonably simple to build, but an accurate guidance system that directs them to their targets is only now within their expertise, said W. Seth Carus, an arms expert at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy. **********"A whole range of cruise missiles clearly are within the competence of large numbers of countries," Mr. Carus said in an interview. "Places like India, Israel, China and even the Iraqis were starting to get into that business."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/busin.main_headline: Latvia Moves to Open an Air-Route Window on the West
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/busin.print_headline: Latvia Moves to Open an Air-Route Window on the West
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/busin.body_text: **********In the two months since Latvia gained independence from the Soviet Union, Western airlines and investors have become keenly interested in the rights to fly to this Baltic capital at the center of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. **********The Latvians also have ambitious plans to form their own national airline as a joint venture with a foreign investor. But Latvia's concerns about how much control foreign investors might have and problems with a small, crumbling main passenger terminal threaten to stall plans to turn Riga into an air hub for the Baltics and the Soviet Union. **********So far, Lufthansa, Swiss Air, El Al, Austrian Airlines, Hamburg Airlines, and even Malev Air, the Hungarian national airline, have all expressed interest in joining Scandinavian Airline System and the new United States-based Baltia Airlines in obtaining landing rights in Riga, according to the Transport Ministry. **********"We are looking forward to the opening of these airlines and are very interested in cooperation with the West," said Janis Janovskis, Latvia's Minister of Transport. **********The nucleus of the Latvia's new national airline would be the planes, staff and routes that make up the Latvian division of Aeroflot, soon to be turned over to Latvia by the Soviet Government. But the venture would also need Western investors' money, about $25 million of it. **********A group of Houston-based investors say they have nearly completed negotions begun with the Latvian Government last spring to form the new national airline, to be known as Baltic International Airlines, though interviews here make it seem less than certain that the Texans will succeed. **********According to Homi Davier, the head of the Houston group, and Girts Lejins, his lawyer in Riga, Baltic International would use Riga as its hub, to serve mainly European passengers bound for various parts of the Soviet Union. For a $25 million investment over five years, the Americans would receive a 45 percent interest in the new airline and Mr. Davier would become its president. **********The new airline would receive from the Latvian division of Aeroflot up to 30 medium-size Soviet passenger jets, 400 pilots and the rights to fly to 76 cities in the Soviet Union. Thirty percent of ticket sales would be made in rubles or in the new Latvian currency, once it is introduced, so tickets would remain affordable for Latvians. **********There are also plans for a joint venture between Riga's airport and the Americans to refurbish and expand the airport. **********But several Latvian officials expressed reservations about signing the final agreement with the Houston investors. Ojars Blumbergs, chairman of the Latvian Parliament's Committee on Energy, Transport and Communications, said a foreign partner for the new airline should be chosen by bid. **********Austris Zobens, the newly appointed Latvian director of the national airline, emphasized in an interview that a final agreement had not been signed with the American investors. He said that Latvia has a pressing need for financial and technical assistance, but expressed a hope that it would come in part from Western governments. **********"The decision is up to the Latvian Government. I believe we have many opportunities and we must choose the best partner," Mr. Zobens said. "Only one thing can be said firmly. It will be difficult for us to have a good company without Western help." **********Mr. Zobens also said, and other Latvian officials confirmed, that other investors have expressed an interest in forming a joint venture with the national airline. **********Several Latvian Aeroflot employees wondered whether Latvians were being slighted in the proposed joint venture. One employee, who declined to give her name, said of the Americans, "They're just trying to get the best deal. Why should the president of the Latvian national airline be American? Is it fair?" **********Even with an investor in place, the airline will have to overcome significant obstacles. Mr. Blumbergs acknowledged that most of the airport facilities the airline would use and the Aeroflot jets themselves are largely outmoded. **********And Mr. Zobens, who would be a vice president in the airline and its senior Latvian executive, said that he lacks experience running an airline. He spent 15 years as an Aeroflot pilot and two years as the head of a small civilian airport on the outskirts of Riga before assuming his current post. **********Still, the Latvians sense they are sitting atop a potentially lucrative capitalistic enterprise. Mr. Blumbergs said that the airline's routes to 76 cities in the Soviet Union would increase in value as more Westerners travel and do business in the Soviet Union. **********"There will be a lot of confusion in the Russian economy in the next few years," he predicted. "It's important that Latvian Aeroflot take advantage of these routes and exploit the opportunity that the poor quality of Aeroflot's other divisions presents us with." **********But exploiting such opportunities will also require a modern, competitive airport in Riga. While the city is ideally situated, a tour of what will soon become Riga International Airport revealed the enormous task the Latvians and a Western partner face. **********The airport now handles a million passengers a year and has 20 daily domestic flights and 5 international flights each week. SAS, the only foreign airline, has two flights a week to Copenhagen. **********"The airport was built in 1974 as a domestic airport and little maintenance has been done on it since then, except for the addition of the control tower," said Vilnas Azas, the airport's new director. **********His most immediate problem is the terminal's leaky roof. "In most international airports you have leaks, but not in all parts of the roof all day. It must be completely replaced," he said. **********The main terminal has few gates, which seem destined to invite long, Soviet-style lines. Serving possibly eight foreign airlines with a single international gate would require tricky scheduling. With only two baggage claim areas, two working fuel trucks, no hangars for passenger jets, and one customs area for passengers entering and leaving Latvia, drastic changes would have to be made to accommodate more Western airlines, Mr. Azas said. **********Riga International will also have to cope with the attitudes of 300 airport employees. "Our employees must learn to smile and keep smiling all day," Mr. Azas said. "I see a big problem in changing our staff's mentality and pushing them up to a Western service level." **********Mr. Azas, a 37-year-old former Aeroflot navigator, said he had seen only three Western airports: JFK in New York, Montreal and Stockholm. **********"I am not afraid of my lack of knowledge of this kind of business," he said. "I realize that there is a huge task in front of me, but I want to complete it. I want to make this airport good enough to be one of the best in Europe," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/busin.main_headline: New Impetus in Honda Car-Building Effort
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/busin.print_headline: New Impetus in Honda Car-Building Effort
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/busin.body_text: **********The Honda Motor Company, responding to "a number of socio-economic changes" that have complicated business, including the new Clean Air Act in the United States, announced today that it was intensifying efforts to develop vehicles that will set new environmental, energy and safety standards. **********Honda provided few details, except to say it was working on a highly energy-efficient compact model that would be introduced "in the near future." The auto maker will also begin public testing of what it says is the world's first electric motorcycle this year in Japan. **********Honda also announced it would create in Southeast Asia a fourth area for "self-reliant" automotive marketing and production, in addition to its centers in Japan, Europe and the United States. **********What a spokesman characterized as Honda's "new direction" was outlined in a New Year's address and policy statement, delivered in Tokyo by Nobuhiko Kawamoto, who took over in June as Honda's president and chief executive. **********Although Honda is one of Japan's smaller auto makers, it has produced some of the industry's most important engine technology, and therefore is closely watched by competitors. In the mid-1970's, Honda's CVCC engine, introduced in the Civic model, surprised the industry by meeting United States emission requirements without a catalytic converter or peripheral engine hardware. More recently, Honda engines have dominated Grand Prix racing.  Worldwide Strategy Pursued **********Rather than rely solely on imports, Honda has pursued a worldwide strategy of building separate companies for separate parts of the world that do their own consumer research and build and market their own vehicles. The company operates several plants and laboratories in North America. **********Honda sold nearly one million Honda and Acura brand cars in the United States in 1990, surpassing the Chrysler Corporation as the No. 3 seller of cars. Mr. Kawamoto said the company's target for 1991 is one million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/22/busin.main_headline: Made in the U.S.A., but by Sharp
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/22/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Made in the U.S.A., but by Sharp
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/22/busin.body_text: **********Japan's largest maker of flat-panel display screens, the Sharp Corporation, said today that it would begin producing some of them in the United States. The announcement appears to be a largely political gesture intended to defuse a new and increasingly contentious high-technology trade dispute. **********Sharp is the leading producer of the ultra-thin video screens, which are used in laptop and notebook computers. Its decision -- which is likely to be followed by other Japanese screen manufacturers -- comes less than a week after the Commerce Department accused those manufacturers of selling their products below fair market value.   Following Car Makers' Lead **********With its decision, Sharp appears to be following a strategy that has worked brilliantly for Japan's auto makers: to produce a good portion of their product in the United States, with American workers, making it far more difficult for Congress to take punitive or protective measures. Sharp said that in 1993 it plans to produce a half-million screens a year at the United States plant, or roughly a third of its projected market for this country. **********The announcement marks the first time that any Japanese maker has moved production of the screens to the United States. There is a smattering of American flat-panel producers, but they are widely considered to be well behind their Japanese competitors and far too small to make the kind of investments needed to produce the screens in volume. **********In the coming decade, virtually all computers -- and many types of television sets as well -- are expected to display their information on the sleek, thin panels, experts say, making it increasingly important for the United States that some production technology reside there. **********At a news conference here today, Sharp officials said that at least for the first few years, the $30 million, 250-employee plant they are building in Camas, Wash., near Portland, Ore., would perform "final assembly" operations. That means that the most difficult technology involved in manufacturing flat-panel displays -- producing the 10-inch computer screens from silicon, without a single flaw -- would remain in Japan. In the United States, the company will add peripheral electronics and the frame used to mount the screens in various types of computers. **********Sharp will produce only its simplest screens in the United States. The most expensive, sophisticated screens, involving color displays that use a new technology called "active matrix," will remain in Japan. **********Sharp officials denied that they were moving only a minimum amount of production and technology to the United States in hopes of preventing Congressional action against the Japanese producers. No Economic Reason Seen **********"If you include U.S.-made parts, half the value added of these screens will be in the United States," said Toshio Toda, the deputy general manager of Sharp's liquid crystal display group. **********But industry officials said there was no economic advantage for Sharp in producing the screens outside Japan. Because the screens are small and light, and require little direct labor, shipping them around the globe is relatively easy. **********"It is a familiar pattern," said John Stern, who heads a trade group office for American electronics makers in Tokyo. "After there are allegations of dumping, production begins to move to America." The term "dumping" refers to the practice of selling screens below the cost of producing and marketing them. **********Whether the Japanese are dumping has turned into a divisive issue for American industry. The small American companies working on flat-panel technology, which filed the initial complaints in Washington against Japanese competitors, said that unless the United States took action the domestic industry would slowly die. **********But the biggest computer makers in the United States, including the International Business Machines Corporation and Apple Computer Inc., pointed out that domestic screen makers do not make the kinds of screens needed for the next generation of portable computers. It would be ridiculous, they said, to force the Japanese to raise prices, and thus increase costs to American computer makers.  The Japanese 'Are Ahead' **********"The Japanese are clearly ahead in flat-panel displays," John Sculley, the chief executive of Apple, said here last week. "What is happening in America is really small-scale stuff compared to what is happening in Japan, and I don't see that changing anytime soon." **********Mr. Sculley and his fellow producers seemed to score a modest victory when the Commerce Department issued its preliminary ruling last week. The department concluded that the price differences, or "dumping margins," on which any import tariffs are calculated were relatively small. **********Nonetheless, the ruling seemed to galvanize the Japanese makers. Toshiba, Hitachi, Fujitsu, Sony and others are all investing heavily in flat-panel technology, concluding that it is a critical link in the food chain of high-technology parts that are common to a huge range of electronic goods. But tariffs and a growing American unease that the technology, which originated in the United States, was being hoarded in Japan could create a morass of political problems. **********Last year a Sharp executive said that his company would move production to the United States "when it becomes a necessity politically." But that moment has apparently not arrived for other companies. The Toshiba Corporation, which has a joint venture in the technology with I.B.M., is building new operations in Japan. I.B.M. has announced no plans to fabricate the screen in the United States, though it is widely assumed that eventually it will also move some production there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/22/busin.main_headline: A New Superintendent Of New York Banking
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/22/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A New Superintendent Of New York Banking
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/22/busin.body_text: **********While Congress is debating substantial changes in banking regulations, some of which could curb the powers of state regulators, Derrick D. Cephas was confirmed by the State Senate late last week as New York's Superintendent of Banks. He will replace Jill M. Considine, who resigned earlier this year to take a job at the American Express Company. **********Mr. Cephas, 39, a partner who specializes in banking law at Breed, Abbott & Morgan, was general counsel at the Banking Department for two years in the mid-1980's. **********As an appointee of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mr. Cephas is understandably mindful of the banking industry's importance to New York's economy and is wary of ceding the State Banking Department's powers to Federal regulators. "I understand the impetus for more centralized regulation, but there is validity to arguments that we should recognize the strongly local interest in banking," he said. **********"A lot of innovations have come out of the states," he added, including NOW accounts, one of the earliest forms of interest-bearing checking accounts, and rules specifying the maximum length of time a bank may withhold availability of money deposited by check. **********The New York Banking Department is pre-eminent among state regulators. It is responsible for supervising many of the New York-based subsidiaries and branches of the world's largest foreign banks, as well as large state-chartered American banks like Morgan Guaranty Trust, Bankers Trust, Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover Trust. At the more purely local level, it also regulates smaller banks, savings institutions and credit unions that have state charters, as well as mortgage lenders and check-cashing businesses. **********Mr. Cephas said he favored large banks entering new businesses, opening branches and combining with other banks across state lines. He opposes a Treasury Department proposal that foreign banks be required to operate their branches as separately capitalized banks, because it would become too difficult for them to do business in the United States, resulting in job losses for New York and inviting retaliation against large American banks in foreign markets. **********As for allowing commercial companies to own banks, another goal of some large New York City banks, Mr. Cephas said that he was reserving judgment pending more thought about the issue. **********Mr. Cephas and his wife, Donna, live in Manhattan and have a house in the northeastern part of Long Island, where he maintains a flower garden. "I'm not serious enough about it to make a new career, but I like to jazz up my yard, and add a few new perennials each year," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/24/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: U.N. Resolutions; Iraq's Shift in Position: Not Enough for the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/24/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: U.N. Resolutions; Iraq's Shift in Position: Not Enough for the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/24/world.body_text: **********Since Feb. 16, Iraq has shifted from a repudiation of all Security Council resolutions calling for its withdrawal from Kuwait to acceptance of Resolution 660, demanding its unconditional withdrawal. **********But the Iraqis have consistently demanded that all other United Nations resolutions, including those dealing with sanctions and other penalties, be voided as a condition of its withdrawal. The United States views this condition as a major sticking point for an accord. **********On Feb. 16, an Iraqi statement spoke for the first time of Baghdad's "readiness to deal with Security Council Resolution No. 660 of 1990, with the aim of reaching an honorable and acceptable political solution, including withdrawal." **********But the statement did not mention Kuwait, and it carried a long list of conditions, including demands that the allies halt the war and withdraw all forces from the region; that Israel withdraw from the occupied territories; that the Security Council repeal all sanctions; that the future Government of Kuwait be based on the "people's will," and that Iraq receive war reparations and be forgiven its debts.  A Moscow-Baghdad Shuttle **********In the next few days, Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq shuttled between Baghdad and Moscow, and on Thursday, the Soviets announced that the Iraqis had agreed to a seven-point plan that included accepting the terms of Resolution 660 unconditionally. **********Under that Soviet proposal, Iraq asked for an end to United Nations economic sanctions after it had withdrawn two-thirds of its forces from Kuwait. Iraq further asked that all United Nations resolutions, including Resolution 674, which demands war reparations, and Resolution 661, calling for the restoration of the Kuwaiti Government, be rescinded after the pullout. It was the first Iraqi offer that omitted mention of the Arab-Israeli conflict. **********The next day, the Soviets announced a plan under which Iraq shifted slightly in its call for an end to sanctions, saying they should cease after Iraq's full withdrawal from Kuwait. **********As the noon deadline for an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait passed today, President Saddam Hussein and the Soviet Union have shifted their views on how the crisis should be resolved, but not enough to satisfy the United States and its allies. The Main Sticking Points **********In the allied view, there are two main difficulties with the Soviet Union's latest plan, the six-point blueprint for an Iraqi pullout that Mr. Aziz accepted in Moscow on Friday. **********The first is that it provides 21 days for Iraq to complete its pullout. When President Bush set the deadline of noon today for the pullout to begin, he gave Iraq one week to complete it. **********The second difficulty was the call for the lapsing of the resolutions. **********"The Soviet proposals fall short of what we need because of the time deadline and the conditionality, which includes nullification of all Security Council resolutions," the American representative at the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, said today. **********More important, the Soviet plan effectively proposed that all international punishment of Iraq cease after the withdrawal. That would prevent the allies from pursuing their aim of maintaining the United nations military embargo against Iraq to wear down its army and perhaps eventually force it to accept some form of regional security pact that would place permanent limits on its armaments.  Trying to Destroy an Army **********Although the allies' primary goal is the restoration of Kuwait's Government, the Security Council has adopted a broader and vaguer aim defined as "the restoration of international peace and security in the region." The allies cite that goal to justify destroying Iraq's army. **********Lifting all Security Council resolutions would also prevent the allies from holding Iraq responsible for the damage its invasion caused. **********Finally, Iraq would not have explicitly agreed to recognize the Kuwaiti monarchy as a legitimate Government, allowing it to maintain its claim to Kuwait as its 19th province. Diplomats fear this might allow Iraq to give up southern Kuwait while holding onto a northern section including the disputed Rumaila oilfields, now administered as part of Basra province, as well as Warba and Bubiyan islands.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/19/world.main_headline: U.S. Says 4 Soviet Republics Vow To Carry Out Nuclear-Arms Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/19/world.print_headline: SOVIET DISARRAY; U.S. Says 4 Soviet Republics Vow To Carry Out Nuclear-Arms Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/19/world.body_text: **********The leaders of all four of the crumbling Soviet Union's republics that have long-range nuclear missiles have promised to carry out all cuts in nuclear weapons required of them under agreements made between President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush, American officials said today. The republics will also accept American advisers to help them dismantle the warheads, the officials said. **********In the last two days, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has visited all four Soviet republics where intercontinental ballistic missiles aimed at the United States are based: Russia, Kazakhstan, Byelorussia and Ukraine. These four states, which have all declared their independence, also make up the core of the new commonwealth that is being formed to replace the Soviet Union. **********American officials said leaders of all four republics had now welcomed Mr. Baker's offer to send teams of American nuclear experts in January. The experts will help begin the process of identifying, collecting, storing and ultimately disabling the nuclear weapons that the Soviet Union is required to eliminate under the recently signed Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start, and under the unilateral cuts that President Bush and President Gorbachev announced in September. **********It is still not clear whether the republics will deliver on the cuts if political disintegration continues, and it is equally unclear at this time who exactly has his finger on the nuclear trigger. **********The last two republics to pledge to honor the agreements on nuclear weapons were Byelorussia and Ukraine, where Mr. Baker visited today, after flying in from Kazakhstan. Leaders of both of these Slavic republics said they wanted to move speedily beyond the nuclear reduction agreements signed by Mr. Gorbachev and become instead, with American help, totally nonnuclear states.  Ukraine Might Move Faster **********With smiles and nods, Ukrainian and Soviet officials today expressed agreement in principle on the first steps for the removal of the estimated 4,000 nuclear arms stationed in the republic.  [ Page A14. ] **********The Ukraine said it was even prepared to destroy its nuclear weapons more quickly than the seven-year period enjoined by the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty. **********"We have presented the United States with a request that U.S. experts come to Ukraine to help solve our problems concerning the destruction of nuclear weapons," Ukraine's President, Leonid M. Kravchuk, said in a news conference with Mr. Baker. **********"We support all those agreements that were struck earlier and we want Ukraine to be a good model of how fast and expeditiously these nuclear weapons can be destroyed," he said. "Our long-cherished dream is to have absolutely no missile silos by the year 2000, but if we succeed in achieving that in five years' time, we will be very happy people." **********Both Byelorussia and Ukraine said they would be prepared to become nuclear-free zones -- even if their powerful neighbor, Russia, retained some nuclear missiles, as it currently plans. This was in contrast to Kazakhstan, which said Tuesday that it would retain some nuclear weapons as long as Russia did, even though the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, declared his desire to see all republics except Russia eventually eliminate their nuclear arms. Kravchuk Stands Firm **********In yet another sign that the new commonwealth that is to be formed to succeed the Soviet Union has still not agreed on certain basic security principles, President Kravchuk reiterated to Mr. Baker today that while he is ready to put his nuclear arms under a single commonwealth control until they are destroyed, he will insist on becoming commander in chief of all conventional armed forces on Ukrainian soil. **********"We stand for the united control and command over strategic nuclear weapons," Mr. Kravchuk said, "but as far as the national armed forces of Ukraine are concerned, I have really proclaimed myself the chief commander." **********This, too, contradicts President Yeltsin's plan presented to Mr. Baker on Monday for the commonwealth to have a defense council, made up of member states and headed by the Defense Minister of the Soviet Union, Gen. Yevgeny I. Shaposhnikov, to oversee all strategic and conventional armed forces of the member states. Key Meeting on Saturday **********The eight republics that have committed to forming the commonwealth will gather in Alma-Ata, Kazakhstan, on Saturday to try to iron out their differences. It is too early to tell how much of what is being declared now is posturing before their meeting, and how much of it involves irreconcilable differences that could bedevil the commonwealth for years. **********Mr. Baker has made adherence by the individual republics to the arms control treaty obligations agreed to by President Gorbachev and President Bush conditions for any American recognition of their independence and foreconomic assistance. **********American nuclear experts will probably be working individually with each republic -- as well as with the central defense council that the new commonwealth is planning to establish -- to help with the dismantling of nuclear weapons. American officials said most of the republic leaders did not have a precise knowledge of the number and type of nuclear missiles they had on their soil, since this was something that was always controlled by the Defense Ministry in Moscow. **********While American officials had no reason to believe that the individual republics would not carry out their respective obligations under arms control agreements forged by President Gorbachev with Washington, it was nevertheless important for Mr. Baker to get their individual assent now that each of these republics has effectively become an independent sovereign state. While American officials wish the republics well in their efforts to become democratic, free-market entities, it is the fate of their nuclear weapons that is the prime concern of the United States at this time. **********The Bush Administration initially opposed the move by Congress two weeks ago to appropriate $400 million to help the Soviets destroy their missiles, but now Mr. Baker is eagerly committing those funds to the republics. **********Some of the republics already have storage sites for their nuclear warheads, but others do not. Some have the ability to transport missiles, others do not. Some have the technical knowledge and the economic resources required to dismantle nuclear warheads and remove the fissionable material, but others do not. **********Under the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, the United States and the Soviet Union agreed to reduce their arsenals of long-range nuclear missiles and heavy bombers by roughly one-third. In the case of the Soviet Union, those cuts would be divided among the four republics with long-range missiles. Since that treaty was signed in July, however, President Bush and President Gorbachev agreed in September to additional unilateral cuts. Both countries agreed to destroy or withdraw from service all of their short-range tactical nuclear weapons, on both land and sea. Deeper Cuts Possible **********While Russia and Kazakhstan are insisting on retaining a certain number of nuclear weapons -- even after the agreed cuts with the United States -- they have signaled Mr. Baker that they are open to discussing even deeper reductions than approved by President Gorbachev. Byelorussia and Ukraine were the two republics most affected by the Chernobyl nuclear reactor accident and the antinuclear movement is very strong in both. **********Moreover, President Kravchuk, who is anxious to meet all of the American military, political and economic conditions for formal recognition by Washington of Ukraine, clearly wanted to give Mr. Baker everything he wanted to hear in their meeting today. Judging from what Mr. Baker said afterward, he appears to have succeeded, and formal American recognition of Ukraine is expected shortly. Said Mr. Baker: "We are very satisfied with what we heard here this evening concerning the commitment of Ukraine to democracy, free markets and nuclear safety." **********Byelorussia, which also sought American recognition from Mr. Baker today, was equally forthcoming. **********"Byelorussia is going to be a nuclear-free zone and a neutral state," said Stanislav Shushkevich, chairman of the Byelorussian Supreme Soviet, in Minsk earlier in the day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/29/world.main_headline: BUSH'S ASIAN TRIP RECAST TO STRESS JOBS AND EXPORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/29/world.print_headline: BUSH'S ASIAN TRIP RECAST TO STRESS JOBS AND EXPORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/29/world.body_text: **********As President Bush departs Monday for Australia and Asia, the trip he had originally scheduled as a good-will tour has changed under political pressures into a blunt sales pitch for American exports and jobs, bringing anger and dismay in Japan. **********Mr. Bush's decision to take with him a group of American business executives to help insist on freer access to Asian markets is born in part of domestic concerns. Those concerns, his advisers say, include the fear that his decision to travel 26,000 miles overseas amid what some are calling the longest recession since the 1930's will only add fuel to Democrats' criticism that the President prefers tackling problems abroad rather than those in his back yard. **********But the announcement that Mr. Bush would take the business executives with him has brought some strenuous negative reactions from business and political leaders in Japan, aggravating tensions between the two economic superpowers as the Japanese Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, is seeing his domestic political problems grow.  Actions by Tokyo **********Japanese and American officials are likely to seek to avoid open confrontation during the Japan segment of the trip. And the Japanese, who enjoy a $41 billion trade surplus with the United States, appear to be reacting in small ways already to the Administration's pressure. **********Officials in Tokyo said Friday that they might agree to reduce their auto exports to the United States next year, a move that seems to nod to the American concerns on Japan's auto imports but would probably have little effect because sales already are declining. **********With the economy wounded and his political rivals scenting the blood, Mr. Bush is taking in tow 21 executives of major American corporations, including the heads of Detroit's Big Three automakers, for the 12-day lobbying tour of Australia, Singapore, South Korea and Japan. Japanese Criticisms **********The stop in Tokyo from Jan. 7-10 is the last and by far the most important stop of the trip. There, Mr. Bush is scheduled to present his delegation to Mr. Miyazawa and local business leaders in what some Japanese newspapers already are calling an exercise in "Japan bashing" at the highest level of the American Government. **********Mr. Bush's advisers insist that the display of American unhappiness is justified by Japan's steadfast refusal to open its markets to American goods, and that their aim is not to embarrass their hosts. **********"I don't think it's going to be done in a high-handed manner," one of the President's political advisers, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said in an interview this week. "We're not going to castigate Japan." **********That adviser nonetheless said that the visit entails "some risk" of generating a diplomatic backlash in Japan, where opinion polls suggest that the United States increasingly is seen as a declining economic power demanding handouts from its more robust Japanese competitors. **********In Tokyo, the mere anticipation of Mr. Bush's tough-talking mission and his corporate delegation has generated a backwash of angry editorials in major newspapers, and even experts who applaud the idea say it might provoke diplomatic and public-relations problems. In a typical comment, Asahi Shimbun, Japan's leading newspaper, said Mr. Bush appeared to be waging "gunboat diplomacy in economic areas." **********On the American side, some public statements have been equally tough. Lee Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, told reporters outside the White House this month that Japanese trade policies are "basically unfair" and deny American manufacturers "a fair shake." **********Joseph T. Gorman, chairman of TRW Inc. and one of the executives making the trip, said in an interview last week that business leaders plan to deliver an unvarnished message to Tokyo. **********"They have to realize that the problem of trade barriers is inescapable, and it's one that's unsustainable, and something has to be done," he said. "That's the point." **********Mr. Bush's Democratic critics have heightened the political stakes, with a group led by the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, threatening legislation that would limit Japanese automobile imports unless the President returned from Tokyo with real trade concession in hand. **********Mr. Bush, in turn, has sought tolower expectations, waying this week only that he would make clear that "They had better do something" about unfair trade practices. **********One senior official, citing White House polling data, said that the public believed the nation's economic problems required long-term solutions, and that Mr. Bush agreed. **********When the journey was first scheduled for late November, it was depicted as a personal visit to two of Mr. Bush's favorite world leaders in Japan and Australia, leavened with a new diplomatic initiative on free trade. But Mr. Bush abruptly canceled the trip on Nov. 5, election night, after returns underscored voters' unhappiness with the economy and the Administration's handling of domestic matters in general. 'Jobs, Jobs, Jobs' **********Since then, Prime Minister Robert Hawke of Australia and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan have been ousted from office, the last vestiges of Soviet military power in Asia have vanished, Mr. Bush's popularity has plummeted and a new team of political and policy advisers has taken command in the White House. And while the thrust of the Asia visit remains the same, its political complexion is considerably changed. **********Mr. Bush has billed the trip as a crusade to create and save "jobs, jobs, jobs" at home by persuading allies to lower trade barriers and buy more American goods. In a news conference this week, he went as far as to suggest that his hopscotch through two continents and two archipelagos was entirely a domestic matter, devoted solely to promoting exports, "working out the final phases of a highly complex Federal budget," and "putting the final touches on a State of the Union" address that will offer new economic meassures. **********In Japan, where he once planned to visit a model high school in Tokyo and play tennis with Emperor Akihito, Mr. Bush now is scheduled to visit an American Toys 'R' Us outlet and invite 18 executives from his business delegation to press Japan's top business and government leaders for trade concessions. **********The shift in emphasis was endorsed by Mr. Bush's new chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner, and his chief campaign advisers, Fred Malek and Robert Teeter, officials said.  Assertions of Pandering **********A second senior Administration official said that the Asian trip had been intended from its origin to underscore the desire for freer trade in the Pacific, but that the political pressures generated by a sagging economy have now cast it in a sharper and less forgiving light. **********"Admittedly, it looks more politically expedient than I wanted," said that official, who insisted on not being identified. **********Some outside experts are accusing Mr. Bush of pandering to domestic politic pressures. **********"It's a hell of a way to pursue domestic policy, by sending the President 26,000 miles," said Seth Cropsey, a scholar at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative Washington research institute, at a recent briefing on the Asia trip for reporters. "We suspect that both he and Barbara will qualify for a free trip to New Hampshire with these miles he's been getting on that." **********But the President's aides insist that the four-nation tour is good politics and good diplomacy. **********"This isn't just a trip to spread diplomatic niceties around to our allies," said one of his advisers. "It's a trip to deal with some of their unfair trade practices and to protect American jobs. If you consider political benefits to be job creation and a better trade balance, then this is a political trip." Bush Government's Help **********The trip also will yield more subtle political benefits for Mr. Bush by allowing his principal campaign fund-raiser, the departing Commerce Secretary, Robert A. Mosbacher, to wield White House clout on behalf of American business interests. **********"Mosbacher wants to signal everybody in the Administration and all the business leaders he's going to have to touch next year that we've got a new relationship -- that business is going to get tangible help from the Government in selling its goods," said a former senior trade official in the Bush Administration, who insisted on not being identified. "And the most tangible evidence of that is this business delegation." **********In a telephone interview today, Mr. Mosbacher called Japanese criticism of Mr. Bush's trip "part of their normal posturing" and said that Tokyo seldom makes concessions in its trade practices until outside pressures force them to do so. **********In taking business executives with him to Asia, he said, Mr. Bush is merely taking his cue from Asian political leaders, who routinely travel abroad with corporate officials. The coming trip allows business and the White House "to speak with one voice" to Tokyo, he said. **********"The Japanese are much too smart and sophisticated to overreact" to that, he said. "We're their No. 1 customer," he continued. "And they know that the President has a very positive attitude toward Japan in general." **********The delegation of corporate executives -- the first ever to accompany a President on a state visit -- is potentially the most productive and most risky facet of the entire tour, Mr. Bush's aides acknowledge. It includes officials of some firms that have penetrated the Asian market, some that are showcases of American manufacturing quality, and some that have failed to make a dent in Japan and the rest of Asia and are openly angry about it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; A Kemper Blanket
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/busin.body_text: **********To emphasize that it makes its customers "feel good," the Kemper Corporation, the financial-services and business company, has covered the outside of a four-page insert with a soft material that feels like a blanket, its symbol. The full-color ad, which was created with the Chicago office of BBDO Inc., uses a technique called flocking, in which short, soft fibers are packed together tightly. The ad will first appear nationally in the April 22 issue of Fortune magazine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/25/busin.body_text: *********** Cuddly, harmless-looking dogs parade through the newest television commercial for Kodak Gold Film, which will be shown for the first time during the telecast of the Academy Awards this evening. In the spot, one of three that the Eastman Kodak Company is to introduce tonight, the dogs pose humorously as the rock song "Wild Thing" plays incongruously in the background. "No other film in the world gives you more ferocious color than Kodak Gold," an announcer says. "Capture the true colors of your wild thing with Kodak Gold." The spot was prepared by J. Walter Thompson.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/04/busin.body_text: **********Among automotive cognoscenti, the Honda Motor Company sits on a tall pedestal for its almost uncanny ability to aim at a market niche and fill it with a wildly popular car. But after Honda's introduction of its Accord station wagon, that pedestal is not quite so high. **********Nearly a year after Honda showed off its first Accord wagons at its Marysville, Ohio, assembly plant, American sales are running at about 2,000 cars a month, well short of the 3,000 cars Honda had hoped for. **********True, a recession in the United States has severely hurt car sales and promises to give Detroit its worst financial beating ever. And true, the station wagon market has been shrinking, badly hurt by the growing popularity of mini-vans. **********But Honda's wagon is also off to a slow start because of its lofty price, its comparatively modest amount of space and a missing feature or two.  Problems of Price and Space **********Honda, for its part, says it is not disappointed with station wagon sales. They will improve, company executives insist, as the model becomes better known and the economy improves. In any event, they say, the plant where the car is built is operating at close to full capacity, partly because Honda is exporting the station wagon to Europe and Japan. **********Honda's first mistake, several Honda dealers said, was in pricing the compact wagon considerably higher than the Honda Accord sedan -- initially more than $2,000 higher. Shoppers quickly noted that the wagon was not all that much bigger than the sedan and concluded that it was not worth the added cost. **********Given what Honda initially wanted for its wagon, ranging from $17,300 to $19,800, many buyers chose roomier competitors like the Subaru Legacy or the Volvo 240 wagon, which costs only slightly more than a fully-equipped Honda wagon. Others just chose the Accord sedan. **********"In the climate we're in, purchase price is a major factor," said Larry Brueshaber, a Honda dealer in Cincinnati. **********Because Honda's wagon is generally less roomy than many other wagons, as well as comparably priced mini-vans and utility vehicles, it is also less useful. With 64.6 cubic feet of cargo room with the second seat folded down, the Accord compares poorly with the midsized Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable wagons (81.1 cubic feet), and import wagons like the Subaru Legacy (71 cubic feet) or the Volvo 240 (76 cubic feet). **********"Honda may have overestimated the potential for a sporty-type wagon without that much space in the back," said Craig Scott, who owns Scott Honda in West Chester, Pa. "And I think Honda has to address the fact that a station wagon is perceived to hold more than four people." **********Although a third adult could squeeze into the back seat, enabling the car to carry five adults, Honda engineers lacked room for a foldaway third seat in the rear similar to the third-seat option offered by Ford on its Taurus and Sable wagons and on the Chevrolet Caprice, Volvo and others. Honda executives have said they are considering adding a third seat, but not until the car is redesigned in 1995 or 1996.  Swayed by a Radio Ad **********Debbie Luciano of Lincroft, N.J., had been planning to buy a 1992 Honda station wagon, and she even put $2,000 on one. Then she heard a radio advertisement that compared its size with that of a Volvo. "I started thinking about these high school kids I drive around," she said. "They are big." **********After comparing the $20,020 price for the well-equipped Honda with the $21,500 cost of the Volvo, she and her husband decided that the extra space was worth the extra money. **********With the 1991 introductory price of $17,300, the basic Accord wagon cost $2,205 more than a comparably equipped Accord sedan. The most expensive wagon had a $19,800 price tag, $2,255 more than the most luxurious Accord sedan. By contrast, prices for a Ford Taurus station wagon start at less than $15,000. **********Honda has since made some pricing changes. For the 1992 model year, it narrowed the price difference between the wagon and the sedan, not by cutting prices but by raising the price of the sedan more than the wagon. Now, the least expensive Honda wagon costs $17,450, compared with $15,825 for the least-expensive sedan, a $1,625 difference. The most expensive wagon costs $20,650, only $655 more than the costliest sedan. **********A Honda spokesman said the value of the station wagon was enhanced this year by the addition of a driver's side air bag as standard equipment. The sedan has featured an air bag since last year. **********Executives of Detroit's Big Three, who have watched glumfaced as Honda's Civic, Accord and Acura models have inexorably devoured their sales since 1973, can barely conceal their glee now that Honda may finally have hit something short of a home run. **********"It surely hasn't measured up to vaunted expectations," said Joel Pitcoff, a research analyst for the Ford Motor Company. "If their strategy was to woo away Taurus and Sable owners, that's going to be a tough struggle." **********The Honda wagon is also struggling in a shrinking market. Throughout the 1980's, mini-vans steadily gained ground as the multipurpose vehicle of choice, while station wagon sales steadily declined. Since 1985, station wagon registrations have plummeted 57 percent, to 390,770 cars in 1990, while mini-van registrations have more than doubled in the same period, to 829,126 units.  Resisting the Mini-Van Trend **********Ford, for example, discontinued its full-sized wagons this year after annual sales had dwindled to less than 15,000 cars. It continues to make the Taurus and Sable wagons. **********But Honda has resisted the mini-van trend, preferring to invest in other projects like its Acura luxury models. The Acura Legend was the first Japanese luxury car to be sold in the United States and quickly captured a niche because it was priced slightly below European luxury brands like Mercedes-Benz and BMW and won more praise from reviewers than American luxury models like Lincoln and Cadillac. **********Since most shoppers consider domestic or foreign brands exclusively, Honda probably did not hope to attract much crossover business from Ford. Still, Honda has to wonder whether the Accord wagon possesses the attributes for its target audience: import buyers who like a sporty vehicle but need a roomier car than a sedan. **********Honda dealers say more changes in the pricing stategy could go a long way toward increasing sales. Generally, Honda cars have been so popular that the company has not offered rebates. But Honda will sometimes subsidize leases or pay incentives to dealers, which can indirectly lower a customer's price.  A Comparison With Subaru **********Mr. Scott, the Pennsylvania Honda dealer, said the Honda wagon "drives and handles like the sedan and has more space, but it still could cost almost $2,000 more," taking into consideration options and incentives. **********"At that price," he said, "people start comparing with the Subaru wagon, which is $3,000 less, or they discover they can get something much bigger for about the same money." **********Last fall, a few months before the Accord wagon was available, John Lewis and Judith Bell-Lewis, his wife, of Lynchburg, Va., were hunting for a station wagon. They bought a four-wheel-drive Subaru Legacy wagon for $15,500. The Honda dealer had told him a comparably equipped wagon might cost $18,000. **********"The Subaru was a great value," Mr. Lewis said. "My wife owned a Honda Accord sedan and loved it, but we have no regrets."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/world.main_headline: Iraq Shows 2 More It Calls U.S. Airmen
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: P.O.W.'S; Iraq Shows 2 More It Calls U.S. Airmen
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/world.body_text: **********Iraq showed what it said were two more captured American airmen on Baghdad television today and sought to link its handling of American captives to Israeli treatment of Palestinian detainees in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********[ Videotape of the captured airmen, broadcast in the United States, identified them as Maj. Jeffrey Scott Tice and Capt. Harry Michael Roberts, both of the Air Force. Two airmen by those names were listed by the Pentagon on Sunday as missing in action. ] **********Baghdad's parading of downed allied airmen has drawn fierce protest in the United States and elsewhere in the West as a violation of the Geneva Conventions on the treatment of war prisoners, which Iraq has signed. **********Apparently in response to the criticism, an unidentified spokesman for President Saddam Hussein was quoted on Baghdad Radio tonight as saying Iraq was "ready to study any document submitted regarding the treatment of prisoners on the basis of the Geneva Conventions, provided this covers the people of Palestine in the occupied territories."  Charges of Double Standards **********The statement did not go further, but seemed another attempt by President Hussein to link the Persian Gulf war to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict and to challenge what Iraq calls Western double standards in its view of Israelis and Arabs. **********It was issued several hours after the Baghdad radio -- virtually the only source of official Iraqi statements -- broadcast what it said today were interviews with two more captured American pilots. **********According to a BBC transcript of the latest interviews, one of the pilots said: "I was flying the F-16E." Asked to name his base of mission, he reportedly said: "Doha, Qatar." Asked about his mission, he said, "I went to attack an oil refinery near Baghdad." **********Asked how his aircraft was shot down, he said, "I was shot down by a surface-to-air missile." The broadcast then became unintelligible.  Dazed and Badly Bruised **********On Sunday, Baghdad television initially showed footage of what it said were seven captured allied airmen. The men seemed dazed and badly bruised as they gave details of their missions, and the film was later seen in the United States. **********If the Iraqi broadcasts of captured airmen prove real -- and American officials who viewed them have called them authentic -- Baghdad would now hold at least five American pilots, including three shown on Iraqi television on Sunday; also in Iraqi hands would be four other allied pilots: two Britons, an Italian and a Kuwaiti. **********The American military says 18 allied warplanes have so far been lost in the first six days of the war, including 9 American aircraft; 24 allied fliers are listed as missing in action, including 13 Americans, the Pentagon says. **********On Monday, the Iraqi authorities announced that more than 20 captured American and other Western pilots would be dispersed as human shields for what it called scientific, economic and other targets, apparently to dissuade the allies from bombing them.  Reports of Allied Wreckage **********Additionally, the Iraqi news agency reported tonight that the Baghdad television had shown "the wreckage of a number of hostile allied air targets shot down by Iraqi air defenses." **********"The film showed a number of hostile planes and rockets blown up by the wind and scattered over our chaste land," the agency reported. The types of aircraft and missiles were not immediately clear. **********The Iraqis have begun offering rewards of up to $30,000 for handing over captured airmen. The authorities have urged Iraqis to photograph anything that seems like a fragment of a downed aircraft or missile.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/14/busin.main_headline: U.S. Vehicle Sales Fell 15.3% in Early September
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/14/busin.print_headline: U.S. Vehicle Sales Fell 15.3% in Early September
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/14/busin.body_text: **********The first 1992 models to reach showrooms failed to improve demand in the flagging United States auto industry, as sales of domestically built cars and light trucks declined 15.3 percent in early September. Analysts predict that auto makers will increase sales incentives on new vehicles if sales do not improve in coming weeks. **********Sales of cars alone dropped 23 percent from the levels of a year earlier. On a seasonally adjusted basis, cars sold at an annual rate of 5.4 million, compared with 7.1 million in the period last year. Analysts had predicted the annual rate would be higher, and said the sales figures showed weak consumer demand. Sales of light trucks fell 1.1 percent. **********"It seems to indicate the rebound that people were expecting might not occur until much later," said Michael Bowyer, an analyst with Duff & Phelps in Chicago. "It will be difficult for the economy over all to generate a sustained recovery without participation by the auto makers," he added.  Rate Cut May Help **********Mr. Bowyer said the Federal Reserve's cut in short-term rates today and the subsequent cut in the prime rate by banks might help sales to some extent. But he added, "I don't think you're going to see really improved car sales until consumers think the recession is over." **********The early September figures showed an unusually sharp drop for two reasons, analysts said. Sales to car-rental companies and other fleet buyers were weak in the recent 10-day period compared with a year earlier. Also, sales incentives were richer last year, when auto makers rushed to clear large dealer inventories after the Kuwait invasion. By comparison, current inventories on dealer lots are near a 20-year low. **********Even after considering those factors, however, "there is no denying that real, underlying demand is exceptionally weak," said Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association. **********Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst with Dean Witter Securities in San Francisco, said he expected sales to pick up soon, given the number of redesigned models on showroom floors, particularly from the General Motors Corporation, the largest auto maker. Also, the plants that produce fleet cars are working overtime, he said. "I have to believe that those sales are going to show up soon," he said. **********G.M. reported a drop in car sales of 24.8 percent for the 10-day period, to 53,162. G.M. models that managed sales increases included its Geo Prizm, Buick Park Avenue and Oldsmobile Ninety Eight. G.M.'s light-truck sales fell 6.8 percent, to 31,312.  Ford Down 25.4% **********The Ford Motor Company sold 27,464 cars, a decline of 25.4 percent. The No. 2 auto maker posted sales of 25,104 light trucks, a drop of 8.9 percent. The only sales increase in its light-truck lineup was for its Explorer four-wheel-drive vehicle. **********Chrysler's car sales, based on estimates by Ward's Automotive Reports, declined 35.6 percent in the period, to 10,300. Light-truck sales, however, were estimated to have increased by 29.4 percent, to 16,500. Chrysler reports sales only at the end of each month. **********Among the Japanese auto makers, the Honda Motor Company reported that sales remained steady at 10,231 United States-built cars, while the Toyota Motor Corporation's car sales rose 3.7 percent. Honda makes cars in Marysville, Ohio, and Toyota operates plants in Fremont, Calif., and Georgetown, Ky. **********Over all, G.M., Ford and Chrysler lost market share in early September, as their portion of sales of North American-built cars fell to 83.7 percent, from 87.5 percent a year ago. The Japanese "transplants" picked up almost 4 points of market share, growing to 16.3 percent of the domestic market for cars, compared with 12.5 percent a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/25/world.main_headline: GERMANY TO HELP SOVIETS OBTAIN AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/25/world.print_headline: GERMANY TO HELP SOVIETS OBTAIN AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/25/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl will meet with Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union in advance of the meeting of the seven leading industrial democracies in July to persuade the Soviet leader to accept free-market reforms bold enough to generate a major infusion of Western aid. **********A Bonn spokesman said today that the two leaders would meet in Kiev on July 5, 10 days before the seven-nation meeting in London. **********Mr. Gorbachev has been invited to London to meet with the seven leaders at the end of their annual conference. Although he has been vague on what he hopes to accomplish, Mr. Gorbachev has indicated that he might seek large amounts of economic help, and Mr. Kohl is likely to be his strongest advocate. **********Earlier, some Soviet officials were talking of needing $100 billion over five years, but more recently, in the face of skepticism in the West, they have said they did not expect specific aid packages to emerge from London. **********The question of aid to Moscow is being debated as Mr. Gorbachev faces a growing challenge from Soviet hard-liners, who charge that moves toward reform are not being reciprocated from abroad.  [ Page A16. ] **********Representatives of the seven nations agreed in principle in London on Sunday that the Soviet Union should be offered a limited role in the International Monetary Fund. Such a move would give the Soviet Union access to technical help on economic reform, but would not bring an immediate infusion of money from the fund, **********Advisers to Mr. Kohl said they believe the seven industrialized nations will agree to a major aid program only if it is detailed and tied to drastic economic reforms. They are hoping that during his visit to Kiev, Mr. Kohl will be able to impress that point on the Soviet leader, and induce him to present a program of sweeping economic change at the summit in London. **********Mr. Gorbachev needs to convince skeptical leaders like President Bush that he is truly prepared to reverse the course of Soviet economic history. Mr. Bush has been reluctant to support major Western aid to the Soviet Union, though he has indicated willingness to provide expert technical advice. Chancellor Kohl's Lobby **********"At first, Gorbachev wasn't going to be invited to the London summit, but various countries spoke up, and after awhile the Americans agreed," said an aide to Chancellor Kohl. "You are going to see the same process at the summit itself. If the right program is presented in the right way, a consensus will develop. **********"I can't guess the size of the package," the aide said. "The public likes gigantic figures, but if the proposal is just to commit $100 billion over five years, no one will accept it. We're looking for a continuing investment program, and as each step is successfully reached, we will help support the next one." **********In public statements and conversations with leaders, Mr. Kohl has already begun lobbying on behalf of the Soviets. **********"It is in our common interests to provide effective help -- aid and self-help -- to the Soviet Union and the young democracies of Eastern Europe in this critical transition phase," he said when he welcomed Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada to Bonn recently. **********Participants in the annual economic conference of the Group of Seven, besides Chancellor Kohl, Mr. Mulroney and President Bush, will be the leaders of France, Britain, Italy and Japan. **********German officials acknowledge that, because of history and geography, Germany has special reasons for wanting to help the Soviets. But they said Germany would only support an aid package that was accompanied by profound economic reforms. Germany has committed itself to about $31 billion in loans, grants and credits to the Soviet Union, in part because of Moscow's assent to the unification of Germany. Much of the money has gone to provide housing and other aid for Soviet soldiers returning home.  'A Partnership of Governments' **********The Germans have traditionally seen large-scale business interests in the East, but besides the profits to be won, they are concerned that a breakdown in the Soviet Union could lead to colossal dislocation, with millions of Soviet and East European refugees. **********"We want to make suggestions, but we can't behave as if we were the World Bank going into Uganda, designing a plan for them and then saying they have to accept or else there is no money," Economic Minister Jurgen Mollemann said in an interview. "It has to be a partnership of governments." **********Mr. Mollemann and other officials said that the emergence of Boris N. Yeltsin had helped Mr. Gorbachev's position by showing the Soviet Union's progress toward democracy, and that overtures to the Baltic republics or an easing of emigration policies in the next few weeks would help even more. **********A Soviet concession to Japan on the disputed Kurile Islands would be necessary before the Japanese Prime Minister could support an aid program, officials here said. **********"The reluctance on the Japanese side is even greater than the reluctance on the American side," said Otto Lambsdorff, who heads the Free Democratic Party and is an important ally of Mr. Kohl. " A London Show-Stealer? **********"Without Mr. Gorbachev, we would not have German unification," he said. "We also know that if there is a serious economic collapse in the Soviet Union, there could be mass migration from East to West that would cause great problems in Germany and other countries of the European community." **********"Unfortunately, the Soviet Union and Mr. Gorbachev have lost six years, and the situation there has become very bad," he continued. "The list of Gorbachev's economic advisers is longer than the list of Italian Prime Ministers over the last 10 years. **********"No money will be given without reforms, but you cannot have reforms without money," Mr. Lambsdorff said. "What Mr. Gorbachev is going to put on the table, nobody knows. One thing for me is clear: he will steal the show at the G-7 summit, because no one is as brilliant at public relations as Mr. Gorbachev."
