https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/08/world.main_headline: A Homeland? White Volk Fence Themselves In
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/08/world.print_headline: ORANIA JOURNAL; A Homeland? White Volk Fence Themselves In
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/08/world.body_text: **********The discredited and dying doctrine of apartheid has found sanctuary in a prairie ghost town where white supremacists dream of carving out an idyllic homeland for Afrikaners fleeing the inevitability of black majority rule. **********"We're in a period of history where we are very anxious to have a plan for the survival of the Afrikaner nation," said Carel Boshoff, 63 years old, a former theology professor who heads the movement committed to creating a "volkstaat," or nation-state, for South Africa's white Afrikaner minority. **********"Orania is a very tiny little 'dorpie'," Professor Boshoff said, using the diminutive Afrikaans word for small town, "but we realize that we should start somewhere." **********Orania, set amid scrubland more hospitable to sheep than people, was built by the Government in the 1960's for whites carrying out irrigation projects that tapped the cocoa-colored waters of the adjacent Orange River. In time, they began pulling out and the weeds and dust encroached on the prefabricated houses. 'You Don't Buy the Passengers' **********Professor Boshoff's movement bought Orania and 1,167 acres on which it sits a few months ago and set to work restoring the dilapidating town. The tidy-up included the eviction of about 500 residents from a mixed-race township just over the hill. Mr. Boshoff wants to convert it into a retirement village for aging Afrikaners. The original tenants, some of whom lived there for 23 years, were trucked to another town more than 100 miles away. **********"They can't understand it, because all these years the white and black people were staying here," said Pieter Fisher, the 46-year-old school principal in the voided township. The removal, he said, hit the children hardest. **********"There will be a great deal of bitterness that will stay for the rest of their life," he said, "and they will never forget it." **********Professor Boshoff's followers contend that they can do what they want with their town, which was reportedly purchased for about $850,000 from a previous owner, who in turn bought it from the Government. **********"When you buy a motorcar, you don't buy the passengers with it, do you?" said Chris Smit, a gaunt 54-year-old with a tattooed chest who was renovating one bungalow. "This is private property." **********His co-worker Pieter Oberholzer, 26, said a black man would be allowed to drive past Orania but not to stop for fuel or food. **********"If his car breaks down, he just will have to push it out of town. Otherwise . . ." Mr. Oberholzer completed his sentence with a brittle laugh. **********People of color are unwanted in Orania even as hired labor. Mr. Boshoff said Afrikaners must learn to cope without their black servants. Quick to Vent Prejudices **********His call for white self-sufficiency would give pause to many whites dependent on black help. Orania's apostles argue that doing one's own chores isn't that bad. **********"To me, good hard work is a privilege," said Mr. Smit, a boilermaker and welder by trade. "It's healthy. It keeps you bodily fit. Because people don't work that hard, that's what makes them fat." **********"You have a black working for you and they mess it up," Mr. Smit said. **********Some other whites were as quick to vent their prejudices. Loudewyk van der Merwe, 56, an electrician who was rewiring the town auditorium, told a rambling tale about how his father, who quit his farm for the mines years ago, left 32 donkeys in the care of a black laborer who later sold them. High Technology in the Veld **********Professor Boshoff, a soft-spoken academic who taught at the University of Pretoria, wanted his nation-state to encompass Namaqualand, Bushmanland and the Karoo, semi-arid regions that he said included 30 percent of South Africa's territory but only 10 percent of its population. Creating a whites-only homeland around Pretoria or Johannesburg, he said, is no longer feasible. **********"To try today to move millions of people is just impossible, so our idea is this," Mr. Boshoff said. **********President F. W. de Klerk has ruled out a white homeland, and the African National Congress has rejected racial partitioning of the country. But Professor Boshoff said he hoped that a black government would accept white secession as an alternative to armed rebellion. **********"As far as I read the signs, it's a small price to pay," he said. **********Mr. Boshoff limned his vision of happy God-fearing whites prospering from a dimly defined high technology that would transform Orania into a sort of Silicon Valley on the veld. **********He predicted that his homeland's population would swell to two million Afrikaners. So far, only 14 families have settled in Orania. **********"There's no work for a man," complained Mr. van der Merwe, who lives in Pretoria. He insisted that he would settle in Orania if he could find a steady job. **********Professor Boshoff, who commutes from Pretoria, said more than 50 of the town's 84 houses had been sold. **********Most Afrikaners show little interest in retreating to a rustic backwater whose brightest attractions are the stars at night. Other South Africans, black and white, have derided Professor Boshoff's project as unrealistic. **********"If they want to protect their Afrikaner culture, they must teach it to their children," Mr. Fisher said. **********Mr. Boshoff, who from 1980 to 1983 headed the Broederbond, a secret society that advanced Afrikaner interests, spoke mystically of his "volk," variously translated as nation or people. A refuge, however remote, for the Afrikaner was preferable to their diaspora, he said. **********"They may live in Argentina, they may live in Chile, they may live in Australia or Canada," he said, "but they would destroy the nation."

[ Page D1. ] **********Traders, dealers and fund managers in markets from equities to foreign exchange said they hoped they were ready for war.  [ D7. ] **********Technology-minded citizens -- from antiwar groups to arms makers -- are turning to personal computers for gulf news.  [ D7. ] **********The company that spread El Al's security system to airlines worldwide is getting more business than it can handle.  [ D7. ] **********Financial exchanges plan to remain open if war comes, but if the Big Board closes, others will follow. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.main_headline: Expert on Bankruptcy To Join Manufacturers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS DIGEST; Expert on Bankruptcy To Join Manufacturers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.body_text: **********As the burden of debts from the 1980's weighs more heavily on corporations, Darla D. Moore, a banker and expert on lending to bankrupt companies, expects an abundance of opportunities. **********She also expects the grass to be greener at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, which she will join on Monday, than at Chemical Bank, where she began her banking career nine years ago. **********Well known in banking for making Chemical the leader in lending to bankrupt companies -- known as debtor in possession, or D.I.P., financing -- Ms. Moore said yesterday that crossing the street to Manufacturers Hanover "moves me up a few levels in responsibility." Manufacturers Hanover is more active than Chemical in dealing with large corporations and earned a reputation in the late 1980's for helping to finance corporate takeovers and other reorganizations. **********"I want to take the network that has been developed though D.I.P. financings and use it for other kinds of recapitalizations," she said. "A lot of companies may not file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, but they do need more capital." And companies that have filed Chapter 11 will need bankers' advice and loans as they reorganize and begin a new life without bankruptcy laws to protect them from their creditors. **********As a managing director at Manufacturers Hanover, Ms. Moore will be in change of D.I.P. loans, as well as providing advice and other assistance to companies trying to reorganize. She will report to Mark G. Solow, head of the global banking group at Manufacturers, who reports to Thomas Johnson, the president. **********When Ms. Moore was introduced to debtor in possession financing in 1984, she recalled that it was an esoteric branch of finance confined to small companies. "Now," she said, "the list of D.I.P. financings reads like a Who's Who of American bankruptcy." **********Big loans in the last 15 months include Allied Stores with two loans totaling $1 billion, Ames Department Stores for $250 million and Carter Hawley Hale Stores for $800 million. The debtor financings are not limited to department stores; the Public Service Company of New Hampshire and Todd Shipyards have also filed for bankruptcy and asked for loans. **********Ms. Moore graduated from the University of South Carolina in 1976 and earned a M.B.A. from George Washington University in 1982. **********For relaxation, Ms. Moore returns to her family's tobacco farm in Lake City, S.C. "Physical labor is the greatest mental therapy," she said. "I like to lose myself on the tractor."

Nearly 20 percent of the people who get career counseling after losing corporate jobs are starting...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/busin.main_headline:
Your Own Account;
Finding Money to Start a Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/busin.print_headline:
Your Own Account;
Finding Money to Start a Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/busin.body_text: **********With bank credit tight and droves of corporate dropouts eager to start their own businesses, finding the necessary capital has become a big hurdle. **********Nearly 20 percent of the people who get career counseling after losing corporate jobs are starting businesses rather than seeking new jobs, according to statistics compiled by James E. Challenger, president of Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., a Chicago outplacement firm. His statistics show that 80 percent of new entrepreneurs are over 40, which indicates that they have business experience. "The rise of the older entrepreneur is one of the most significant trends in the workplace," he said. **********Business experience notwithstanding, many new entrepreneurs have no idea how to raise capital. The first thing they think about is looking for a venture capitalist, according to Carol Rivchun, vice president of marketing for the Greater Cleveland Growth Association, the local chamber of commerce. "And that's the last thing most of them should do," she said. **********Venture capital firms invest the money of pension funds, college endowment funds and wealthy individuals who expect hefty returns in exchange for the high risk they take by investing in small businesses. Most venture capitalists aim for a 20 percent return. Because many of the ventures fail, they expect 40 to 50 percent from those that succeed. **********"Our investors have asked us to seek out the next rapidly growing companies and invest early," says James F. Morgan, chairman of Morgan, Holland Ventures, a Boston firm. "We have to see a chance to build a major business." What that means is a company that will grow to $50 million to $100 million in revenues in five to seven years. **********"Our job is to find the next Digital Equipment, Federal Express or Apple Computer," Mr. Morgan said. "If you want to finance a bed-and-breakfast, please don't come to us." **********Unlike many venture capital firms, Mr. Morgan's will talk to people with start-up ideas, but they must be blockbusters. "We have started 10 companies," he said. "Two or three of them were only at the stage of a dream when we first heard about them." What Mr. Morgan looks for in a start-up is credibility and experience on the part of the entrepreneur. **********For most entrepreneurs, friends, relatives and business contacts are a much better source of cash than venture capital. "There is something between 5 to 10 times as much capital available from friends and relatives than from professional sources," Mr. Morgan said. He provided the example of a man in his mid-50's who left his company after a successful career and raised $650,000 from professional contacts. "He went to all his cronies and got $25,000 or $50,000 from each one," Mr. Morgan said. **********To find this kind of money, an entrepreneur needs to do some networking. One of the best places to start is with the small business division of the local chamber of commerce. For example, Ms. Rivchun has been matching entrepreneurs and investors for 10 years. **********"My Rolodex is famous," Ms. Rivchun says. "I know all the bankers and lawyers and C.P.A.'s in town, and these are the people who know how much money their clients have lying around." **********Most of the money to start small businesses is "raised by people scribbling on the tablecloth at lunch," she said. "In every city there are people like me." **********Somewhere between professional venture capitalists and business cronies is the angel network, wealthy individuals who make equity investments in start-up companies. Finding angels has been made easier by the growth of angel networks like the Venture Capital Network at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass. **********An investor or entrepreneur can sign up for a six-month listing on the network for $250. The entrepreneurs prepare business summaries that are sent to the prospective investors. "The confidentiality of each is maintained until an investor wants an introduction," said Roger Wilson, executive director. Like professional venture capitalists, private investors look at about 100 plans and invest in one or two, he said. **********Because of the credit crunch, the network has recently seen established companies looking for angels, Mr. Wilson said. One of them was the DGH Corporation, a Manchester, N.H., company that computerizes manufacturing. David Dutile and his partner started the company in 1985 with their own funds. By 1987, they needed money to grow, and Mr. Dutile went to the Venture Capital Network. "Within a month, we had five or six people who wanted to come in to see the company," he said. **********Mr. Dutile picked an investor who put in $100,000 at the beginning of 1988. "I have the option of buying him out at the end of 1993 at $300,000," Mr. Dutile said. Although it was an expensive deal, Mr. Dutile is happy with the arrangement. "He has really left us alone to run the company," he said. "What you worry about is that you will sell the stock to someone who will want to come in and be your partner, especially if they know nothing about the business." **********For that reason, if you can start your business without venture or angel capital, you should. "If you can bootstrap your business, you maintain more control, it costs less and you get more market feedback," Mr. Wilson said.A BUSINESS PLAN IS THE FIRST STEP **********Before you make your first call looking for start-up capital, you must have a plan. It should answer these questions: *********** How big is the market for your product or service? Who exactly will buy it and why do they need it? *********** How will you reach them and persuade them to buy it? The best product in the world is worth nothing if people don't realize they need it. "I have this guy with a fabulous computer software program for doing surveys and polls," says Carol Rivchun, vice president of marketing for the Greater Cleveland Growth Association. "The trouble is, there's no way to sell it. If he puts it in the store for $29.95, no one will appreciate it. And he can't sell it to a McKinsey & Company because they want to develop their own." *********** How much money do you need? *********** How long will you need it for? *********** When will you pay it back? **********Put your plan in writing, concisely. "It you've put your thoughts on paper in an orderly way, it convinces people," Ms. Rivchun said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.body_text: **********The Zitel Corporation said that, because of disappointing results, it had begun talks with the Unisys Corporation on ending their co-marketing relationship involving Zitel's disk products designed for use with Unisys's mainframe computers. The company said it did not expect its net sales in its third quarter, which ends on June 30, to be as high as those of the first and second quarters. In the first quarter, Zitel's sales totaled $11.4 million; second-quarter sales were not available. The company's shares lost $2.50 today, to $6, a 29.4 percent drop that was the fourth-largest in percentage terms in over-the-counter trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/20/world.body_text: **********Some of the most striking moments of the World Council of Churches' seventh assembly here have been about women, underlining their increasing influence and inspiring a sort of backlash. **********The Rev. Lois M. Wilson of the United Church of Canada, one of the council's seven departing presidents, electrified this gathering of some 4,000 people the other day by saying that women attending the conference, having received threats from men who are clerics, had cried in the restroom. Shesaid, "These are the politics of the World Council of Churches and they stink to high heaven, and I do not think it was what Jesus had in mind." **********Aruna Gnanadason f the Church of South India, the new director of a women's desk at council headquarters in Geneva, said: "Women are feeling disempowered at this assembly. Men make long speeches but women are frustrated, especially in the plenaries." **********The council, with the admission of the China Christian Council on Monday, now has 317 member churches from more than 100 countries, incorporating nearly all Protestant and Orthodox denominations except Adventismand the Salvation Army. **********The women's movement has increased the sense of isolation of the Orthodox churches, while annoying some of the traditionally male-dominated Protestant ones. **********With some fanfare, the council announced in 1988 an "ecumenical decade of churches in solidarity with women." But "in fact women here face, as in the United States, something of a backlash," said Dr. Janice Love of the United Methodist Church, who is also co-moderator of the Public Issues Committee. **********There is a conflict, she said, between those who want to slow the movementof women into positions of authority in the council "and those who say, 'Slow down from what?' " **********Even the council's general secretary, the Rev. Emilio Castro, did not find it necessary to mention the decade in solidarity with women in his report to the assembly on the council's activities since the last assembly in 1983, angering even women who think the council is doing a reasonably good job on women's matters. **********Although 35 percent of the delegates here are women, up from 31 percent in 1983, the goal for this assembly was 40 percent. **********The desk in charge of women's issues at council headquarters in Geneva was also a source of friction, having been without a director for many months, one reason women staged a sit-in in a recent executivecommittee meeting. **********The ordination of women, almost a given now in many Western churches, has long been controversial among Orthodox members, who regard the priesthood as a masculine affair "by reasons of the Bible, tradition and history," said Bishop Moussa of Egypt's Coptic Orthodox Church. "We were founded by St. Mark, one of the apostles, in the first century," he said in an interview, "and we will stick to our traditions and positions even if others dismiss us." **********Bishop Moussa and other Orthodox delegates said they were even more upset by the increasingly inclusive theology of ecumenicism, which is incorporating traditions of other, originally non-Christian cultures. This melding is sometimes called "inculturation" here, or "syncretism."The argument has focused on a South Korean theologian, Dr. Chung Hyun Kyung of the Korean Presbyterian Church, who gave a presentation on the assembly theme, "Come Holy Spirit -- Renew the Whole Creation." Using Asian dance and other non-Western motifs, she invoked the "Han-spirits" of the martyred and murdered and linked them with the Holy Spirit. **********Dr. Chung, who has a doctorate in theology from the Union Theological Seminary in the United States, said she was among the first of the "post-colonial theologians," and rejected charges of syncretism and paganism. Third world theologies are "the new paradigm, the new wine you can't put in your wineskins," she said. "Yes, we are dangerous, but it is through such danger that the Holy Spirit can renew the church."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/13/world.main_headline: IRAN SAYS IT FEARS 'MASSACRE' IN IRAQ
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/13/world.print_headline: IRAN SAYS IT FEARS 'MASSACRE' IN IRAQ
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/13/world.body_text: **********President Hashemi Rafsanjani said today that Iran could not remain indifferent to a "massive" deployment of Iraqi troops near its southern border and that it would seek the help of the United Nations to prevent "the massacre of innocent Iraqi Shiite civilians." **********In a joint news conference with the Austrian President, Kurt Waldheim, the first Western European head of state to visit Iran since the 1979 revolution, Mr. Rafsanjani said that Iran was trying to avoid a recurrence of tragedy "through legal and diplomatic channels," the Teheran radio said. **********In the last week, Iran's state-run press has reported widespread attacks on Shiite Muslims in southern Iraq by the Iraqi Army, including bombings and the use of helicopters and tanks. The reports have not been independently confirmed. **********After the Iraqi Army crushed an uprising in April, weeks after the end of the Persian Gulf war, hundreds of thousands of Iraqi Shiites fled to the swamplands of southern Iraq. Baghdad Denies Reports **********Iran has repeatedly asserted in recent days that Iraqi troops are preparing a big offensive in the south. Baghdad has denied the reports, describing them as propaganda designed to stir the United Nations to adopt more resolutions against Iraq. **********In a letter to the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday, an Iranian representative reiterated his Government's position, saying that an attack was imminent. **********Teheran said it was issuing the warnings out of humanitarian concern, but also expressed apprehension about sheltering a new wave of refugees. **********Mr. Rafsanjani said the level of foreign aid for refugees who fled to Iran after the Persian Gulf war was "obviously insufficient." Cabinet ministers have talked of the enormous costs of maintaining refugee camps "indefinitely," adding that the country is "ill-prepared" to receive more refugees. **********About 400,000 Iraqis who sought a haven in Iran during the Iraqi crackdown on a Shiite rebellion in the south and a Kurdish uprising in the north have returned to their country, officials say. **********Analysts say that Teheran is trying to draw attention to the Shiites' plight primarily to undermine its main rival in the region, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, who hld onto power despite his country's defeat in the gulf war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/19/busin.main_headline: New Chief and Name For Office Automation
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; New Chief and Name For Office Automation
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/19/busin.body_text: **********Nolan Bushnell, the video game and personal computer pioneer who founded the Atari Corporation, was named chairman of Office Automation Systems Inc., the company said yesterday. Office Automation, which is based in San Diego, also announced that it was changing its name to Octus Inc. **********"Octus is an entirely new kind of company," Mr. Bushnell, 49, said in a statement. "We are, in fact, a start-up being built upon the solid operational foundation of O.A.S., an 8-year-old company with more than 70 employees." Octus is privately held. **********In the next several months, Octus plans to start selling several new data, imaging, electronic mail and facsimile products, all of which can be shared on personal computer networks that use Novell Inc.'s software. Octus will market primarily through existing Novell dealers. **********"Each product will be as simple to use as a toaster or a telephone," Mr. Bushnell said. "For that reason, we are calling them shared-network appliances." **********Best known for kicking off the video game craze with Pong in the early 1970's, Mr. Bushnell founded Atari with $250 in 1972. He sold the company to Warner Communications Inc. in 1976 for $28 million. After taking heavy losses as interest in Atari products faded, Warner in turn sold the company to Jack Tramiel, a former executive of Commodore International Ltd., in 1984. **********After his initial Atari venture, Mr. Bushnell went on to found Chuck E. Cheese Pizza Time Theater, a 250-outlet chain combining video game arcades and restaurants. In 1981, he established Catalyst Technologies, a venture firm. Last year, Mr. Bushnell joined forces with his old rival by heading a multimedia development project for Commodore.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/28/busin.body_text: **********Germany's central bank said today that it would leave its official interest rates unchanged for now, despite recent data showing a rise in inflation. **********The announcement came after a regular meeting here of the Bundesbank's policy council. Financial markets had speculated that the Bundesbank might raise interest rates to curb inflation. But the German discount rate -- the rate at which the Bundesbank buys short-term securities from banks in the open market -- was held at 6.5 percent. **********The Lombard emergency financing rate -- which usually acts as a ceiling for short-term money market rates -- remains at 9 percent. **********Price pressures have picked up since the unification of Germany last year. **********A report on inflation for June showed that prices in western Germany rose 3.5 percent from the year-ago period, up from an increase of 3 percent in May. **********But the Bundesbank's president, Karl Otto Pohl, said the central bank would not change rates in response to a single set of economic statistics.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/17/world.main_headline: Lithuania Promises to Investigate Nazi Cases
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/17/world.print_headline: Lithuania Promises to Investigate Nazi Cases
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/17/world.body_text: **********President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania has assured leaders of American Jewish groups of his Government's determination to conduct a thorough investigation of all Lithuanians suspected of having been Nazi collaborators and agreed to establish an independent commission of inquiry to review the cases. **********The talks, held during a visit in New York this week, were aimed at regaining the confidence of Jewish leaders. The leaders said Mr. Landsbergis had acknowledged oversights in the exoneration process and expressed determination to cooperate with foreign governments and Jewish groups to insure there would be no further mistakes. **********"We are all committed to cooperate in whatever investigation to reveal those culprits who participated in the annihilation of Jews," said Anicetas Simutis, Lithuania's representative to the United Nations, who took part in the meetings. **********In the sessions, the Lithuanian President repeated earlier criticism of press coverage of the issue, singling out a Sept. 5 report from Vilnius that appeared in The New York Times. The article said that the Lithuanian Government had begun to issue thousands of certificates to rehabilitate people who were punished by the Soviets after the war for alleged misdeeds or crimes committed during the years of Nazi occupation. **********"It's not necessary for me to dwell on how unjust were the accusations made in the Western press," said Mr. Landsbergis in a speech on Thursday at the headquarters of the American Jewish Committee. **********He said the reports created an impression that his Government had opened its jails and released thousands of Nazi war criminals. In fact the original article in The New York Times made no reference to people being released from jail. **********A second report from Vilnius published in The Times last month said that after some 35,000 certificates of rehabilitation had been issued, the Lithuanian Supreme Court suspended the process. The article said the court acted after it saw documents indicating that at least five of those rehabilitated had been credibly charged with serious war crimes. **********Mr. Landsbergis said that the Justice Ministry had denied rehabilitation to 500 people because of war crimes. **********Describing the Lithuanian's visit as "a sign of good will," David Harris, executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee, said: "There is more work to be done to insure that the exoneration process does not become a sieve through which those guilty of Nazi war crimes fall through."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/30/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasuries Lower in Light Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/30/busin.body_text: **********Treasury securities traders marked time yesterday, awaiting the terms of next week's quarterly refunding. Tomorrow afternoon, the Treasury is expected to announce the amount of notes and bonds it plans to auction on May 7-9. **********Credit market analysts expect a total of $35.5 billion of Treasury paper will be offered, or $1 billion more than the record amount sold at the last refunding in February. **********Steven R. Ricchiuto, the chief financial economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Inc., projected the second-quarter "financing need will be $27.2 billion, down $25.6 billion from the previous three-month period." He added, "We have also assumed that the Treasury's end-of-quarter operating cash balance will drop by $2 billion, to $30 billion, on June 28." **********Mr. Ricchiuto expects the Treasury to offer $12.5 billion in new three-year notes next Tuesday, followed by $12 billion in 10-year notes the next day and $11 billion in 30-year bonds at the last auction on May 9. After paying off maturing issues, the auctions should raise $16.2 billion in new cash, he said. **********Given the relative scarcity of 10-year Treasury notes, Mr. Ricchiuto projects that most of the $1 billion increase in the total offerings next week may be in that maturity. The Treasury may simply add the $1 billion to existing 10-year notes, rather than create a new issue for the maturity, he said. **********In late dealings yesterday, the outstanding Treasury long notes, the 7 3/4 percent issue maturing in February 2001, were offered at 97 29/32, down by 4/32, so that its yield rose to 8.06 percent, from 8.04 percent last Friday. **********Among the shorter note issues, the new 7 percent notes of 1993 were unchanged at 100 8/32, and a yield of 6.86 percent; the new 7 5/8's of 1996 fell by 2/32, to 99 24/32, with the yield inching up to 7.68 percent, from 7.67 percent at the end of last week. **********Dealers said the divergent price moves in the note sector reflected two basic market views of the economy. Those who hold that the recession will deepen and cause interest rates to decline further seem eager to lock in current short-term yields. **********On the other hand, there is a reluctance to invest in the longer maturities among those who foresee an economic recovery, and with it upward pressure on inflation and interest rates, as well as those who are also concerned about the rising supply of new Treasury borrowings. **********Thus, while the price of the shortest notes was unchanged, the longer notes were weaker. **********The Treasury's bellwether long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue due in February 2021, were offered late yesterday at 96 4/32, down by 7/32, with the yield rising to 8.22 percent, from 8.20 percent last Friday. **********Among the shortest Treasury maturities, discount rates fell at the weekly bill auctions. The average rate on the 90-day bills was 5.60 percent, down from 5.69 percent a week ago, with the six-month bill rate tumbling to 5.68 percent, from an average of 5.79 percent. The one-year bills, meanwhile, rose by a basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, to 5.83 percent. The Treasury plans to auction $11.75 billion in new one-year bills on Thursday.  Federal Funds Rate **********As expected, the Federal Reserve continued its struggle to raise the funds rate that banks and large financial insititutions charge each other for temporary loans. For the seventh time in the last eight business days, the Fed drained reserves from the banking system in order to raise the funds rate to 6 percent, its perceived target level. **********The funds were trading at 5 15/16 percent at midday yesterday, the usual time of Fed intervention, and later rose to close at 6 percent. The funds rate is considered the basic cost of credit because most other loan rates are scaled upward from it, and it is also the Fed's chief tool in money management. **********Following are the details of the Treasury's weekly auctions of 90- and 180-day bills: (000 omitted in dollar figures)           3-Mo.
