https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/05/world.main_headline: Study Set on Abortion Pill's Use in Breast Cancer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/05/world.print_headline: Study Set on Abortion Pill's Use in Breast Cancer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/05/world.body_text: **********The French producer of the abortion pill RU486 will begin a large-scale study of the pill's potency in treating breast cancer next year in Canada, officials of the company said today. **********Word of the study has frustrated researchers in the United States, who have sought to study the drug's effects on breast cancer as well other diseases, but have been turned down by the company because of the political conflict over abortion in the United States. **********Representative Ron Wyden, the Oregon Democrat who is chairman of the House Subcommittee on Regulation and Business Opportunities, said he felt that the company was steering all research on the drug, for abortion and disease, to countries that would be potential markets. Canada is the company's most likely market in North America, company officials have said. 'A Lot to Answer for' **********"If this view is correct, the drug's antagonists have a lot to answer for," said Mr. Wyden, whose panel will hold a hearing on RU486 on Thursday. "They have helped spike life-saving medical research in this country in order to service their own political ends." **********The drug, which can be taken up to nine weeks into a pregnancy, induces the uterus to shed its lining and the fertilized egg, thus causing a very early abortion. The National Right-to-Life Committee opposes that use of the pill but has not opposed other uses of the drug. **********Dr. Ariel Mouttet, director of marketing for hormonal drugs for the company that makes RU486, Roussel-Uclaf, said today that the company had negotiated to carry out a study of perhaps 1,000 women with breast cancer. "We believe we can start next year," she said. "We have had some promising animal studies and trials in a few women." **********Dr. William Regelson of the Medical College of Virginia, an oncologist who has studied uses of the drug, said that among the conditions for which the drug may be useful are Cushing's syndrome, adult-onset diabetes and severe hypertension. Research Requests Denied **********"Why has the company held back on work in this country?" he asked, noting that at least two research centers, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York and the Lombardi Cancer Center at Georgetown University, had asked the company to cooperate in breast cancer studies but were turned down in the last two years. **********Instead, the company has decided to work through Canada's National Cancer Institute to carry out a study of the drug's potential in breast cancer. **********Dr. Mouttet said Roussel-Uclaf had difficulty considering work in the United States because it was unable to understand what the nation "is doing on the abortion issue." She noted with pleasure the announcement on Tuesday by Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York that he and 29 other mayors would support bringing RU486 to the United States both as an abortion drug and as a drug for other uses. **********But she said she was shocked at the Bush Administration's rule barring counselors in federally financed family planning clinics from discussing abortion with clients. **********Because the United States is divided on the issue, she said, the company fears that any entry into the country could trigger boycotts against the company. **********She said that researchers doing small-scale studies in the United States on other uses of the drug would still be supplied with the drug, but that large-scale work was not contemplated. **********Canada, she said, was a more likely country for Roussel-Uclaf to market the drug as an abortifacient because that country is not as polarized on the issue of abortion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/29/busin.main_headline: F.D.A. Gets Tough on Drugs Offered for Unapproved Uses
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/29/busin.print_headline: F.D.A. Gets Tough on Drugs Offered for Unapproved Uses
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/29/busin.body_text: **********At least 400 million of the 1.6 billion prescriptions that American doctors write each year are for treatments that lack the Food and Drug Administration's approval as safe and effective, physicians and Government scientists say. **********Doctors say that research and experience justify their confidence in the benefits of these treatments. But scientists warn that many drugs certified for some uses can have dangerous, unanticipated side effects in other uses, especially over long periods. **********After years of scant Federal enforcement, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, Dr. David A. Kessler, is seeking to prosecute drug companies that promote unapproved treatments and to tighten the general policing of the marketing of prescription drugs.  Big Unauthorized Sales **********These unauthorized uses generate billions of dollars in sales. In some cases, Dr. Kessler recently told a group of the drug industry's lobbyists, "promotional practices, to be blunt, have gotten out of hand." **********But many doctors and drug makers say they are keeping patients alive with treatments that the F.D.A. might take years to approve. Physicians can legally prescribe drugs for uses that the Government has not sanctioned and that the drug companies are not allowed to advocate. Many doctors support the agency's crackdown only if it does not curtail their access to the latest scientific findings, which they often hear about from drug makers. **********"The F.D.A. ought to be very careful not to prohibit widespread and immediate dissemination of important new information that can save lives," said Peter Barton Hutt, an industry consultant and former F.D.A. official. **********The Government itself promotes some unauthorized uses. Researchers at the National Cancer Institute often encourage doctors to try new cancer treatments that lack F.D.A. approval by enrolling their patients in hundreds of test groups around the country. **********Physicians and Government officials estimate that more than half of all cancer prescriptions and 40 percent of those for heart ailments are for drugs approved only for other uses. A Bristol-Myers Squibb drug, Paraplatin, is certified only for treating recurrent cancer of the ovaries. But with current F.D.A.-sanctioned tests already showing that Paraplatin can help treat many other forms of cancer, the institute is encouraging doctors to try these other applications. **********Sometimes, though, treatments the F.D.A. has not authorized can do more harm than good. Dr. Kessler raises the example of calcium channel blockers, approved for treating high blood pressure and angina but also promoted for treating heart attacks. Researchers have found that heart attack patients with congested lungs are actually less likely to survive if treated with calcium blockers than if they received placebos. **********A spokesman for Marion Merrell Dow Inc., which makes Cardizem, a widely used calcium channel blocker, said that after talks with F.D.A. officials earlier this year, the company's sales people had stopped telling doctors about journal articles that appeared to favor treating heart attacks with calcium blockers. Cardizem, Marion Merrell Dow's largest- selling drug, had sales of $750 million in 1990. **********Dr. Kessler, a 39-year-old physician and lawyer who became commissioner last November, promises to speed the approval process even as he tightens enforcement. Dr. Kessler has doubled the F.D.A.'s advertising enforcement staff and ordered it to issue tighter guidelines by December. The F.D.A. has already referred a case involving Johnson & Johnson, the world's largest health-care company, to the Justice Department for possible prosecution.  Retin-A Used for Wrinkles **********Johnson & Johnson confirmed that the United States Attorney for northern New Jersey in Newark had told the company that he was investigating its promotion of Retin-A to prevent wrinkling. Although the drug has F.D.A. approval only to treat acne, half of its $100 million in annual sales are for treating wrinkles, according to Kenneth S. Abramowitz, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. Johnson & Johnson said it had made no improper claims for Retin-A. **********Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, who heads the Public Citizen Health Research Group, a consumer organization, said that he could not recall any prosecutions of unauthorized drug promotion "in my 20 years in Washington." F.D.A. officials say they are considering several more cases for referral to the Justice Department. **********Dr. M. Roy Schwarz, a senior vice president of the American Medical Association, said at least 25 percent of the 1.6 billion prescriptions filled last year were for unapproved treatments. Many of the most popular drugs owe much of their sales to uses the F.D.A. has yet to approve. **********The Upjohn Company's Rogaine has been approved only to treat baldness in men, but some doctors also prescribe it for hair loss in women. In September 1989 the company asked the F.D.A. to approve the drug's broader use. Eli Lilly & Company's Prozac, widely used for depression, is also being prescribed for obesity, a treatment the agency is now considering. Both companies say they do not promote the unapproved treatments. **********Genentech and Eli Lilly say they have tried to prevent their genetically engineered human growth hormone from being used for purposes besides the approved treatment of dwarfism in children. Athletes have used the drug to build muscles, and some doctors have prescribed the hormone to rejuvenate elderly men. **********In other cases of unapproved drug uses, the F.D.A. has tried to curb company promotion efforts. Dr. Kessler said that the Collagen Corporation, producers of Collagen, an animal fiber injection approved for smoothing acne scars, had been promoting its use by cosmetic surgeons for puffing up lips. Under F.D.A. pressure, the company has agreed to stop promoting that use.   Marketing Programs Canceled **********Despite the current tests of Bristol-Myers' Paraplatin, earlier this month the F.D.A. required the company to cancel some of its marketing programs. The company had to write to doctors saying that it had paid for a publication, "Oncology Commentary," that promoted Paraplatin and five other Bristol-Myers cancer drugs for treatments not approved by the F.D.A. **********"Our paid agents included only favorable opinions and data on our products for inclusion in Oncology Commentary," wrote John C. O'Leary, a Bristol-Myers vice president.The company also agreed to get F.D.A. clearance for all its cancer drug promotions over the next two years. **********Jerry Parrott, a Bristol-Myers spokesman, said that even though the F.D.A. had not approved the uses of the cancer drugs, they had won acceptance in physician's reference books and the computerized information service maintained by the National Cancer Institute. **********The F.D.A already permits the wide use of some unapproved drugs being tested for treatment of life-threatening diseases like cancer and AIDS.   Approval Can Take Years **********Most drugs have F.D.A. approval for only one or two narrowly defined uses. Doctors and drug company executives say that winning approval for new uses can take years, while lives may be at stake. The heart of the problem, said Dr. Gerald P. Murphy, an Atlanta cancer surgeon who is the chief medical officer of the American Cancer Society, "is the long time it takes to get something approved." **********Dr. Bruce Chabner, director of cancer treatment at the National Cancer Institute, said that once the F.D.A. approved a drug, further research often suggested additional uses. "We think it's important that those uses become part of the approved menu for a drug," he said. **********Bob Allnutt, an executive vice president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a trade group, said 122 applicaitons for additional drug uses were pending at the F.D.A. Hundreds more are in various stages of F.D.A.-approved testing. **********Many insurers, including many Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans, do not pay for treatments that lack F.D.A. approval. But the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association currently recommends paying for unapproved uses if the National Cancer Institute is testing them. "The bottom line for us is to be sure that the clinical trials for these drugs are covered by insurers," Dr. Chabner said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/05/busin.main_headline: Sharp Rise For Bonds On Jobs Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/05/busin.print_headline: Sharp Rise For Bonds On Jobs Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/05/busin.body_text: **********Bond prices rose smartly yesterday after the Government released a so-so employment report that showed that the economic recovery continued to limp in September. **********"The economy is still moving up, but employment growth is falling short of the norm by a wide margin," said Robert Giordano, director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs. The economy generated just 24,000 non-farm jobs in September, or 224,000 since payrolls hit bottom last April. **********Rates on Treasury bills, on the other hand, barely budged. They had headed down earlier in the week on widespread expectations that the Federal Reserve would ease credit. **********But the Fed apparently did not ease yesterday, sticking to a recent pattern of letting the markets nudge rates down before the central bank steps in. "By hanging fire like this, the Fed isn't threatening the improvement in inflation expectations," said Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers. **********While bond prices rallied over the course of the day, traders said a flurry of selling occurred early in the morning immediately after the employment report. Some traders initially interpreted the downtick in the unemployment rate to 6.7 percent, upward revisions in the numbers of jobs created in July and August, and a rise in the average workweek as signs that the recovery was stronger than had been thought. There was another flurry after President Bush said, in a news conference about a Democratic measure to extend unemployment benefits, that the economy was, indeed, recovering. **********But these selling spurts soon gave way to buying as traders focused on the small rise in the number of payroll jobs in September and an outright decline in jobs in the factory sector -- one of the economy's few bright spots this summer. Further, hourly earnings data for September suggested that inflation pressures remained under control. Hourly earnings were 3.2 percent higher in September than a year earlier, compared with 3.6 percent in June.  30-Year Bond Jumps **********By the close of the New York cash market, the Treasury's 30-year bellwether issue jumped 23/32, to 104, to yield 7.77 percent, a four-and-a-half-year low, and down from 7.83 percent on Thursday. **********Ten-year notes with a 7 7/8 percent coupon rose by 16/32 to yield 7.37. Two-year notes with a 6 1/8 coupon due in 1993 rose 4/32, to 100.15, to yield 5.87. **********Six-month Treasury bills edged down 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.07 percent, while three-month T-bills were flat, with a rate of 5.02 percent. **********Coming on top of slow money growth, traders and economists said, slow job growth points to further easing by the Federal Reserve. That prospect is good for bonds because lower short-term rates would be likely to prompt more investors to shift their funds out of C.D.'s into bonds. **********Many traders expect the Fed to move to push the Federal funds rate down by no more than a notch, from around 5.25 percent to 5 percent this month. The Federal funds rate, the interest rate on overnight loans between banks, fluctuated between a low of 4.75 and a high of 5.18 yesterday. **********The easing could come within a week, said Steven I. Saslow, executive managing director at Carroll McEntee & McGinley, a primary dealer in government securities. "The Fed gets the next week's money supply numbers on Tuesday, and if they are very weak, they may ease that day." **********Not everyone thinks that the Fed will necessarily ease, however, mostly because there have been scattered of signs that business and consumer buying firmed a bit last month. "There's no compelling reason for the Fed to ease," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns. **********According to recently released data, sales of new houses jumped in August. Car and truck buying revived a bit in September after stalling in August. And consumer confidence edged higher in September, according to the University of Michigan survey. In the meantime, factory order backlogs continued to climb in August and commodity prices have stopped falling. **********"What will matter a great deal this month," said Michael Moran, an economist at Daiwa Securities, "are indicators of final demand like retail sales. If these show a pickup, the Fed should hold policy steady for a while."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/17/world.body_text: **********The release of more Western hostages from Lebanon, which seemed imminent a few days ago has become embroiled in complicated negotiations surrounding the logistical details of an exchange, Western diplomats say. **********"Our understanding is that we are in the preliminary stages of the negotiations to determine the logistical arrangements for any trade," a high-ranking Western diplomat in Damascus said. **********The obstacles, however, have not dampened the optimism here that the 10 Western hostages believed to be held in Lebanon will be freed eventually in return for the release of about 300 Arabs under the control of Israel and information on the fate of seven missing Israeli servicemen.  Frenzy of Diplomacy **********Syrian, Israeli, American, German, Lebanese, Iranian and United Nations officials have been scurrying from one capital to another during the last few days to work out agreements. **********The Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, left for Bonn on Sunday for talks with the German Government on the hostage issue. There are two Germans among the 10 hostages. **********Israel's top negotiator, Uri Lubrani, met with the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, on Sunday in Paris, and the Lebanese Foreign Minister is in Teheran for talks about the hostage situation. **********John Kelly, the United States Assistant Secretary of State for Middle East and African Affairs, held talks on Saturday in Beirut with Lebanese officials. **********All those engaged in the face-to-face negotiations insist that a solution is not far away. **********"I'm optimistic there could be something," Mr. Sharaa said. **********The Syrian Foreign Minister said he had no idea whether the next hostage to be released would be British or American, though speculation has centered around a British hostage, Jack Mann, a 77-year-old former airline pilot who had lived in Beirut for 43 years before his abduction on May 12, 1989. **********There are five Americans, two Britons, two Germans and an Italian currently believed to be held by the Party of God, an Iranian-backed militant Shiite group. The Party of God is reportedly the umbrella organization for the kidnappers of most of the hostages. **********When Sheik Abdel Karim Obeid, who was kidnapped from his home in Lebanon by Israeli commandos on July 28, 1989, was not released on Wednesday with 51 Arab prisoners, many in the leadership of the Party of God expressed anger. Israel also turned over the bodies of nine guerrillas. **********Israeli officials insist that it is up to the Party of God to make the next move and have said that the Sheik, arguably Israel's best bargaining chip, would be among the last to be released. **********Mr. Lubrani said that if another hostage was released, Israel would "reciprocate."  Two Held in Germany **********Perhaps one of the thorniest issues revolves around the imprisonment in Germany of two brothers, Mohammed and Abbas Ali Hamadei. **********Mohammed Hamadei was sentenced to life in prison for his part in the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines flight in 1985; Abbas Ali Hamadei was arrested on charges of carrying explosives and ordered to stand trial in the abduction of two Germans in Beirut, who were taken shortly after Mohammed Hamadei was jailed. **********A third brother, Abdul Hadi Hamadei, is in charge of the Party of God's security apparatus in Beirut and is wanted on terrorism charges in the United States. **********The Syrian and German officials who are meeting to discuss the hostage issue in Bonn have rejected demands that the release of the Hamadeis be tied to the freeing of Western hostages. But many Western diplomats expect there will have to be some understanding involving the fate of the two brothers. **********The issue of Iranian hostages is also one that negotiators must solve before any deal is completed, Western diplomats said. **********The Christian Lebanese Forces militiamen captured four Iranians in North Lebanon during the Israeli invasion in July 1982. The men are widely believed to have been killed by their captors, but the Iranians have repeatedly said they would only help to free Western hostages if their own missing were included in any deal. **********Finally, the Israelis continued to demand a complete accounting of all of their missing soldiers. The body of one of the seven, Sgt. Samir Assad, was returned to the Israeli authorities from Syria by a radical Palestinian group in the last week. **********The secretary general of the Party of God said in May that the organization was holding two of the Israelis. The remaining four are believed to be dead, and recent reports out of Lebanon seem to suggest that the other two may also have been killed.                    --------------------       Party Hardens Stand **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 16 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Party of God, in a hardening of its position on freeing the 10 Western hostages believed held in Lebanon, said today that none of the captives would be freed until Israel released Lebanese prisoners -- including Sheik Obeid. **********Sheik Abbas Musawi, the party's secretary general, said the hostage problem can only be solved by the United States' bringing pressure on Israel or an Israeli compromise.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Lockheed Rejects Plan of Simmons
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.body_text: **********Counterproposals by Harold C. Simmons to a plan to limit costs in his proxy war to unseat the board of the Lockheed Corporation were rejected by Daniel M. Tellep, chairman of the big military contractor. Mr. Simmons, who owns 20 percent of Lockheed and lost an expensive proxy contest in 1990, last week accepted Mr. Tellep's proposal that both sides forgo newspaper advertisements to solicit support for their positions. **********But Mr. Simmons's associate, J. Landis Martin, said he had been denied a request for four additional conditions, among which were a $5 million spending cap for each side, a limit of two mailings to small shareholders and a videotaped debate between Mr. Martin and Mr. Tellep. "Prearrangements with regard to the nature, timing and cost of shareholder communications are unnecessary and inappropriate," Mr. Tellep wrote in a letter released today rejecting new conditions. Mr. Martin did not return a telephone call seeking comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/busin.main_headline: Developer Fights Lenders on Control of His Assets
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/busin.print_headline: Developer Fights Lenders on Control of His Assets
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/busin.body_text: **********Peter S. Kalikow, one of New York's biggest developers and publisher of The New York Post, is fighting to keep control of his empire. He is being pressed by some of his lenders to pledge to them almost all of his personal and corporate assets against tens of millions of dollars of unsecured loans, Mr. Kalikow and other people in the talks said this week. **********Under a plan that Mr. Kalikow said he intended to head off even if it meant seeking protection in bankruptcy court, the lenders are trying to force Mr. Kalikow to put the newspaper and nearly everything else he owns into a pool that would be controlled by the banks. The pool would be used to shore up uncollateralized, as well as undersecured, loans to the developer, some of which he has failed to pay off or keep current with interest payments. **********Mr. Kalikow, who has for many years been regarded as one of the richest men in the country, owes more than $1 billion to more than a dozen lenders including the Travelers Companies and some of the nation's largest banks like Citicorp, Chase Manhattan and Manufacturers Hanover. With the sharp decline in New York real estate values, however, the banks believe that Mr. Kalikow owes about $242 million more than his buildings are worth. His latest troubles began when he failed to repay about $50 million in loans that were due at the beginning of the year. **********As for The Post, the lenders want to include it in the pool of assets that might be managed by a group appointed by the lenders. The details of who would manage the assets and the paper have not been discussed, however. **********Under the plan, Mr. Kalikow would wind up with only his Manhattan triplex apartment on Fifth Avenue near the Metropolitan Museum of Art, about $2 million worth of money owed to him as receivables, and his clothing, household furnishings and jewelry.  What Banks Want as Collateral **********Among the things the banks want Mr. Kalikow to put up as collateral for the unsecured debt are his equity in his New York real estate, which includes the office tower at 101 Park Avenue near Grand Central Terminal, his collection of rare cars, a private jet, a 137-foot yacht and a country home. **********Mr. Kalikow said yesterday in an interview that in no instance would he agree to a plan that would let the banks force him to sell The Post. **********"I am not going to be forced to liquidate; otherwise I won't do a deal," Mr. Kalikow said. "The New York Post has been profitable every month since October and will be profitable again in June. It certainly will not be sold as part of any bank plan."  The Creditors' Plan **********Mr. Kalikow expressed confidence that an acceptable compromise plan can be achieved soon that would leave him with more of his personal assets. **********"In the last 10 days we feel it's pulled together to the point where you're dealing in weeks for this thing to be finished," he added. **********The creditors are putting together a plan that would take control of the management of H. J. Kalikow & Company away from Mr. Kalikow and begin an orderly liquidation of some of his assets over the next few years to raise cash. **********In addition to a general pool of collateral, the proposal that was given to Mr. Kalikow yesterday provides for a three- to five-year extension of the due date on most of his loans, with a minimum interest rate payment that has yet to be determined. The balance of interest would accrue at the original contract rate and would be paid out of cash flow. If there were no extra cash flow, then the interest would accrue as principal and would be payable at the maturation date. **********Mr. Kalikow, 48 years old, inherited a company worth tens of millions of dollars from his father and owns about 3,660 New York apartments. He is vowing to file for bankruptcy protection before allowing his lenders to force him to liquidate any assets. **********"Forced liquidation is not preferable to a bankruptcy and it's something I'll never agree to," Mr. Kalikow said yesterday. Another Sticking Point **********Another big sticking point between the banks and Mr. Kalikow is that the developer wants to be released from all his personally guaranteed debt immediately, which the banks are refusing to do. Mr. Kalikow has personally guaranteed debts of about $184.6 million. The Bankers Trust Company holds $55 million of that. And according to Mr. Kalikow's reports, he has about $835.3 million of debt secured by some of his assets. **********In April Mr. Kalikow suggested to the banks that he put up his office towers and most of his apartment buildings as collateral for the unsecured debt. **********"The assets I'm giving are more than enough to cover the banks' liabilities," he said yesterday. **********In addition, Mr. Kalikow also proposed that the banks allow him to receive an annual salary of $2.25 million as part of the restructuring. Several people in the talks said most of the big banks had rejected this request as too high, but it was still too early in the talks to determine how much salary Mr. Kalikow would receive in the event of a restructuring. **********The bank proposal that Mr. Kalikow received yesterday is still a very preliminary volley in the struggle to restructure his empire. There is an enormous amount of friction between those banks that have secured loans and those that lent the developer tens of millions of dollars backed solely by his personal guarantee. In a bankruptcy the lenders without collateral stand to lose the most. **********With the collapse of commercial real estate values nationwide, and a severe shortage of money for developers who need to refinance their properties, battles between builders and banks like that between Mr. Kalikow and his lenders are now commonplace. Although some bankers have said they are confident that the Kalikow negotiations will not disintegrate into a bankruptcy filing, others are less certain. Some of the banks, particularly those with small, unsecured loans to the developer, have threatened to put him into involuntary bankruptcy if their loans are not repaid.  Some Banks Are Suing **********Several banks, including Marine Midland Bank and the European American Bank have already sued Mr. Kalikow and, along with several other banks, demanded immediate payment of loans. Some people involved in the talks suggested that at least one bank, Community National Bank, which is owed $1.7 million, might actually be bought out through some agreement with the other creditors. **********Complicating the restructuring is the confusion over how far real estate values have fallen in New York in the last two years. Mr. Kalikow's assessment of the value of his assets far exceeds the estimates by the banks. This difference has generated what are known in financial argot as deficiency claims, or the difference between what a property is worth and the amount a bank has lent against it. **********In an April proposal that Mr. Kalikow presented to his lenders, he estimated that his assets were worth $1.2 billion if he continued to operate the apartments and about three million square feet of commercial real estate as is. Optimistically, he estimated then that the holdings would be worth $1.4 billion. **********Mr. Kalikow also noted, however, that if the assets were liquidated immediately in a fire sale, they could generate about $926 million. **********In that report Mr. Kalikow also said his equity was worth $194 million after accounting for debt. According to the banks, however, Mr. Kalikow has only $184 million in equity in those assets, after accounting for what he owes on them. But he also owes unsecured debt of more than $426 million (which includes deficiency claims by the banks) that would wipe out his net worth, leaving him with a negative net worth of about $242 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/20/busin.body_text: **********McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said it would buy cellular telephone systems in Florida and Texas for $105.3 million. McCaw, the nation's leading cellular telephone company, said the systems included non-wireline cellular operations in Daytona Beach, Fla., and Waco, Tex. The seller is Crowley Cellular Telecommunications, a Maryland limited partnership. The transaction, which is payable in cash or McCaw class A common stock, will add about 600,000 potential customers to McCaw's current 73.5 million. The company's stock fell 25 cents, to $23.75, in over-the-counter trading today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/29/busin.main_headline: World Series Is a TV Hit, But CBS Still Faces Losses
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/29/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; World Series Is a TV Hit, But CBS Still Faces Losses
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/29/busin.body_text: **********CBS executives expressed delight and relief yesterday at the results of the network's telecasts of the 1991 World Series, saying baseball had redeemed itself as a television sport. Even so, the network expected to lose heavily on its deal with Major League Baseball. **********Sunday night's final game between the Minnesota Twins and the Atlanta Braves scored a huge rating of 32.1 in the nation's 25 largest cities. (Each rating point represents 921,000 homes.) **********CBS's research department estimated that when the official national figures are released today, the entire series would average between a 23 and 24 rating for the seven nights it was broadcast. Such an average would mean the 1991 series would approach the 24 rating scored by the last seven-game series in 1987, which the Twins also won.  Additional Revenue: $35 Million **********CBS took in up to $35 million in additional revenue because the series went the full seven games and because three of the games went into extra innings. **********But that does not mean CBS's enormous $1.06 billion contract for four years of baseball has been vindicated. The network, which wrote down a loss of $170 million on baseball last year, may lose as much or more this year on costs related to baseball and other sports, a media analyst said. **********CBS delayed declaring its third-quarter earnings earlier this month, saying it was waiting for the outcome of the series. Jessica Reif, senior vice president of Oppenheimer & Company, said she expected CBS would write off $200 million or more in losses, based primarily on its expensive contracts with baseball and the National Football League. CBS 'Still in a Hole' **********A senior CBS executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said, "This is what baseball was supposed to do as programming, but we're still in a hole." **********Howard Stringer, the president of the CBS Broadcast Group, called the series "thrilling, about as exciting a series as has ever been played." But he, too, noted that the value of the games could never catch up to the price CBS paid for them. **********"In the face of higher costs and lower revenues," Mr. Stringer said, "this was a hiccup on the road to nowhere." **********But for the most part, CBS executives were buoyant about baseball's performance. George Schweitzer, senior vice president of corporate communications, said: "Baseball is re-energized as sport. We'll start our marketing plan for next year starting next week. We'll be taking around the highlight reel from these games." **********The series was the longest ever played in terms of innings, because three games went into extra innings. As a result, it had more commercials than any previous series. **********In effect, CBS telecast more than seven and a half games. Some of the commercials in the extra innings provided bonus revenue for CBS; the rest went to satisfy other requirements, like filling out the commitments to sponsors who had paid for commercials during pitching changes that did not take place. **********Each of the three additional games added between $10 million and $12 million for CBS, Mr. Schweitzer said. **********The total would have been much higher if not for the the softness of the sports television market, he added. Despite the attractiveness of the late games in the series, CBS was still not able to attract high prices for commercial time in those games because the marketplace was so weak, Mr. Schweitzer said. **********One reason for that weakness was the abundance of sports events on television. Indeed, CBS found itself competing for much of Sunday night against the football game between the New York Giants and the Washington Redskins, carried on the cable channel ESPN. **********"That should have been our game with the N.F.L.," under the network's regular contract, Mr. Stringer said. "Instead we have to compete against it when it plays on cable." CBS research estimated the network lost 1.5 ratings points because so many natural sports viewers, especially in New York and Washington, were watching the football game. **********But the series' average ratings will still be well above the guarantee the network made to advertisers, about 20. **********One advertiser that took full advantage of CBS's success was the General Motors Corporation, which cut a special series of commercials last Thursday to insert in Saturday and Sunday nights' games. Phil Guarascio, the executive in charge of corporate marketing and advertising for G.M., said his company was "extremely satisfied" with its CBS baseball deal because it provided so much exposure for a new incentive program for three G.M. models. **********David F. Poltrack, senior vice president of research for CBS, said the series was "good news for a variety of reasons." Among those he cited: CBS will be able to sell commercial time in next year's series at much higher rates; CBS was able to cement its position as the leading prime-time network, and CBS may be able to increase interest in other coming "event" sports programming, including the Super Bowl and the Winter Olympics. **********"The series reconfirmed the status of event programming," Mr. Poltrack said. "Hopefully it will help create a better atmosphere for selling these events in the future."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.main_headline: Steelmakers' Grim Outlook For the Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Steelmakers' Grim Outlook For the Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.body_text: **********Executives of the nation's largest steel companies attending the annual meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute conference here said today that the industry would lose tens of millions of dollars this year, making 1991 the worst year of industry losses since 1986, when the losses totaled $4 billion. **********The officials said they could do little to reverse the situation, since they had cut costs and trimmed operations almost as much as possible. **********"After four years of positive operating results, steelmakers began posting losses in the third quarter of 1990 and these losses continued through the first quarter of 1991," said David H. Hoag, the president and chief executive of the LTV Corporation, the nation's third-largest steelmaker. "And it appears that most are expecting losses in the second quarter as well." **********Mr. Hoag and other executives added that an industrywide loss would likely occur for all of 1991. Other chief executives said they did not expect any improvement until the end of the year at the earliest and predicted that no large steel company would report a profit for the year.  Calling on White House **********The steel industry leaders, in speeches and interviews here today, urged the Federal Government to assist their industry and called on the Bush Administration to develop a sweeping program to rebuild the nation's highways and bridges. **********They also proposed that the Administration develop environmental trade policies with steel-producing nations that call for pollution controls equivalent to those being undertaken by American steel producers. **********Industry analysts say these proposal are unlikely to be enacted. **********There also were frequent, bitter complaints about the spiraling costs of health care. "Health-care costs are rising faster than any other major cost we face," said Brian W. H. Marsden, the president and chief executive of the Acme Steel Company, the smallest of the leading integrated steelmakers.  Drop in Shipments Seen **********Mr. Hoag painted a bleak picture for the industry for the remainder of the year, particularly concerning steel demand. He predicted that domestic steel shipments would fall to 73 million tons to 76 million tons this year, down from the 85 million tons in 1990. **********"Auto sales in the first quarter of 1991 were the lowest since 1982," he said. "The continuing slump in new-home construction, combined with a drop in contracts awarded for major building projects indicates that the contruction market has yet to hit bottom." **********Car makers buy a quarter of the steel produced in the country, while the construction industry accounts for about 35 percent of demand. **********Mr. Hoag added that shipments of home appliances fell by 25 percent in the first quarter of the year. Appliances like refrigerators and washing machines account for about 7 percent of steel demand.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/25/world.main_headline: Long a Jewel of Europe, It Longs to Glow Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/25/world.print_headline: WEIMAR JOURNAL; Long a Jewel of Europe, It Longs to Glow Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/25/world.body_text: **********One bookstore in this charming old town has a shelf devoted to works by local authors. Goethe, Schiller and Nietzsche are among them. **********Other titans who lived or worked here include Luther, Bach and Liszt. **********The spirit of art and culture that pervades Weimar has been a source of local pride for centuries. Officials now hope it will save the town from the economic collapse that is threatening much of eastern Germany. **********"Weimar does not need and does not want a heavy industrial base," said the newly elected Mayor, Klaus Buttner. "We need new businesses here, but we aren't inviting every speculator from the west who wants to build a video game center. Our real goal is to make Weimar one of Europe's cultural capitals, and we consider it a very realistic goal." **********More than three million tourists visited Weimar last year, and figures for this year will probably show a considerable increase.  Home of Enlightenment **********Unlike many towns in what used to be East Germany, Weimar boasts an attractive downtown marked by well-scrubbed facades. Museums and monuments celebrate its humanistic tradition. **********Homes that once belonged to Goethe and Schiller, separated by only a few blocks, are the city's principal attractions. The enlightened ideals the two men shared, and their devotion to what Schiller called "the spirit of freedom," are cornerstones of Weimar's history. **********At gift shops here, sales clerks are well schooled in local lore. They can tell visitors which enlightened nobleman invited Goethe to come to live in Weimar (Duke Karl August) and how many love letters the great poet wrote to his mistress, Charlotte von Stein (1,700). **********Just beyond the center of town, music spills from the open windows at the Franz Liszt Music School. A bit farther out is the first home of the Bauhaus school of design, which was founded here by Walter Gropius in 1919. The building is now a school of architecture with an international student body. **********The founding of the Bauhaus was not the only momentous event that took place in Weimar in 1919. That year, the German Parliament met here and proclaimed the Weimar Republic. **********The town that produced much of Germany's richest culture, and which represents some of the greatest achievements of the German people, also played a tragic role in the Nazi era. On an incongruously peaceful hillside 10 miles outside of town is the Buchenwald concentration camp, where 65,000 men, women and children died. **********Residents of Weimar speak openly about the camp, and tourist guides encourage people to visit the memorial there. The name Buchenwald, however, is rarely heard here. People refer to the camp simply as "da oben" -- "up there." **********To many people who live here unification has meant what it means for people throughout eastern Germany: sudden economic dislocation, high prices, skyrocketing unemployment and profound insecurity. **********"In the old days, you got your job and a kindergarten space for your kids without even thinking about it," Jakob Wolf, a 57-year-old schoolteacher, said as he walked along Schillerstrasse. "Now you never know if you're going to be called in and fired from one day to the next. Naturally people are upset. They remember that the old system was better in some ways." **********In an upstairs office at the National Theater, Christina Schild, who helped lead protests against the East German Government in 1989, now works as a publicity agent. She resisted appeals that she run for Parliament last year, and now she watches politics as an outsider. 'People Feel Helpless' **********"Unifying Germany was absolutely not our goal when we started the protest movement," Miss Schild said. "We wanted to find some kind of a third way that wouldn't submerge us entirely in the market economy. But that turned out not to be what people wanted." **********"Lots of people feel helpless now. The psychological effect of all these changes has been awful. Now when you meet a friend on the street, the first thing you ask is not 'How are you?' but 'Do you still have a job?' " **********The shock of such change has led some people to quiet frustration, others to petty crime and still others to street attacks on foreigners. But to some people in Weimar, especially the young, German unification has been an undreamed-of blessing, the sudden opening of vast new possibilities. A Student's View **********"My grandmother used to tell me not to think about abandoning East Germany, because the day would come when I'd be free to travel and do whatever I want here," said Gudrun Potke, a 21-year-old student. "I never believed her, but she turned out to be right." **********"I always believed that we had the better system in the east, the better society. Now I see that wasn't true. Everything was better on the other side." **********The German Government, battered by complaints that it is not doing enough for cities and towns in the east, recently announced a package of grants including $65 million for Weimar. Part of it will be spent to refurbish the downtown area, and the rest will be used to build a warehousing and light industry complex in the nearby countryside. Coca-Cola will be one of the tenants. **********"Weimar is one of the few cities in eastern Germany that has a lot worth saving, and we're going to save it all," Mayor Buttner said. "We want to develop, but we want the kind of development that Goethe would approve of."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/01/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; RJR Nabisco Issue Receives Ratings
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/01/busin.body_text: **********Moody's Investors Service assigned a B2 rating yesterday to the preferred equity redemption culmulative stock, or Percs, of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, and it placed the $1.9 billion issue on its review list with the possibility of an upgrade. **********The Standard & Poor's Corporation, meanwhile, gave the issue a BB- rating and also said it would consider an upgrade. **********Moody's said the Percs had "strong equity characteristics," and noted that RJR Nabisco had stated that it hoped to exchange common stock for preferred. **********Moody's also said it wondered whether "this infusion of equity represents an enduring change in the orientation towards financial risk on the part of RJR Nabisco's management." RJR Nabisco has a large amount of high-interest debt outstanding.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/busin.body_text: **********The Economy Minister of Argentina submitted a far-reaching package of tax changes today that includes canceling the income tax for wage-earners. **********The income tax, now 20 percent, would be replaced by levies based on company earnings, the minister, Domingo Cavallo, said at a news conference. But employees would pay nothing, he added. Self-employed professionals would start paying tax on earnings of more than 60 million australs ($6,000) a month. **********Political experts said Mr. Cavallo's tax plans, which are intended to eliminate widespread tax evasion, were likely to pass easily in both the upper and lower houses of Congress. **********Mr. Cavallo, who since taking office in late January has stabilized the shaky austral and tamed rampant inflation, said his package included a plan to enable Argentinians to bring capital held abroad back into the country. All foreign earnings by Argentinians would also become taxable, he added. **********Officials calculate that up to $60 billion is held illegally in foreign bank accounts and other investments by Argentinians who have sought safe havens for their capital to escape economic turbulence at home.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.main_headline: Europeans Are Struggling to Keep Their Diplomatic Initiative Alive
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF; Europeans Are Struggling to Keep Their Diplomatic Initiative Alive
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.body_text: **********In an atmosphere of deepening gloom, European Community governments led by France struggled today to keep alive their efforts to avoid a war in the Persian Gulf despite virtually no evidence that Iraq is interested in dealing with them. **********As France stepped up diplomatic contacts with both Arab and European governments, it was announced that the community's 12 foreign ministers would meet the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, when he stops over in Geneva on Friday en route to Baghdad. **********Italy's Foreign Minister, Gianni De Michelis, said Mr. Perez de Cuellar would offer to send a United Nations force to Kuwait if Iraq withdrew. "It would not include any of Iraq's enemies, such as the Americans, Saudis or Egyptians," Mr. De Michelis said. **********But the European Community was again rebuffed by Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, who seemingly ignored a new invitation to meet three European foreign ministers in Algiers. Mr. Aziz returned directly to Baghdad today after his talks with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in Geneva on Wednesday failed to ease the crisis.  Aziz Refuses Invitation **********Last week, Mr. Aziz was invited to fly to Luxembourg today to discuss the community's ideas for a peaceful resolution with the foreign ministers of Luxembourg, Italy and the Netherlands. But he told them to travel to Baghdad if they wanted a dialogue, a message he repeated Wednesday night. **********According to Mr. De Michelis, however, Mr. Aziz has indicated a willingness to meet a community delegation in Algiers if he obtains Baghdad's approval. The Italian said that "we are ready to meet him on Saturday or Sunday, and even Monday," the day before the United Nations deadline for an Iraqi withdrawal. **********Facing growing public alarm at the prospect of a gulf war, European governments insisted that diplomatic efforts continue. "I do not regard war as inevitable," Britain's Prime Minister, John Major, said on his return from a trip to the gulf. "Saddam Hussein still has time to rethink." **********Italy's Prime Minister, Giulio Andreotti, said Wednesday, "There are six days to go, and let us remember that in six days God managed to create the world and still had a rest on the seventh." **********France's Defense Minister, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, suggested that the United States make the "very small gesture" of agreeing to an international peace conference on the Middle East, "which would allow Saddam Hussein to make a much greater gesture and withdraw from Kuwait." **********But officials close to President Francois Mitterrand stressed that Mr. Chevenement was not speaking for the Government, adding that France shared American opposition to "linkage" between a conference and an Iraqi pullout. **********With fears of war rising, European governments began evacuating their diplomats and citizens from the gulf region. Britain's Ambassador to Iraq and four diplomats left Baghdad by car for Amman today, while Dutch and Belgian officials in Iraq were ordered home. France and Spain plan to send aircraft for their nationals in Jordan, Saudi Arabia and other gulf states.  Soviets Pledge Cooperation **********MOSCOW, Jan. 10 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Soviet Union today reaffirmed its willingness to continue cooperating with the United States in the gulf crisis, and supported continuing efforts to achieve a peaceful solution by Jan. 15. **********The reaffirmation came despite assertions by Communist Party officials that Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze had lost influence with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev since he announced last month that he was resigning. Mr. Shevardnadze, whose date for leaving office remains uncertain, is the Soviet diplomat closely associated with American-Soviet cooperation in the gulf crisis. **********A spokesman for the ministry said today that Moscow continued to support the United Nations resolution authorizing the use of force if Iraq had not withdrawn from Kuwait by Tuesday. **********But in a statement on the gulf, the Foreign Ministry said, "The most vigorous political and diplomatic efforts must be made to ward off a military conflict." **********Secretary of State Baker was on the phone with Mr. Shevardnadze at least twice from Geneva on Wednesday, Soviet officials said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/22/busin.body_text: **********In the first sign that its turnaround efforts are paying off, Varian Associates Inc. today reported sharply higher first-quarter earnings. One of the pioneer Silicon Valley companies, Varian had been sluggish in recent years. **********For the quarter that ended on Dec. 28, Varian had earnings of $12.4 million, or 64 cents a share, up 63 percent from $7.6 million, or 39 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Sales grew 10 percent, to $316.1 million, from $285.4 million in the first quarter of the 1990 fiscal year. **********"The first-quarter earnings progress indicates that our drive to achieve better operating performance is now taking hold in all of our businesses," J. Tracy O'Rourke, Varian's chairman, said in a prepared statement. He said he was encouraged by continued strong orders, particularly in the current recession. **********Three of Varian's four major businesses had double-digit gains in orders, led by semiconductor manufacturing equipment, at 26 percent. **********Varian's stock jumped $2.375 a share today, to $35.75, a high for the year, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Federal Lender Plans Offering
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/busin.body_text: **********The office of finance of the Federal Home Loan Bank system plans to announce the interest rates today for a debt offering totaling $3.6 billion, that consists of five different maturities. **********Investors are being offered $750 million of a three-month issue that matures on Nov. 25, and another $750 million of a six-month issue that matures on Feb. 25, 1992. The financing also includes $1 billion of a one- year issue that matures Aug. 25, 1992; $413 million of a two- year issue due Aug. 25, 1993, and $687 million of a three-year issue due Aug. 25, 1994. **********Interest payments on the three- and six-month issues will be paid at maturity, while the first payments for the one- year, two-year and three-year maturity will be made on Feb. 25, 1992. **********According to the finance office, proceeds from the financing will be used to refinance in part $4 billion in debt that matures on Aug. 26.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/11/busin.body_text: **********Canadian trappers have set up a fur auction house that they hope will succeed where Northbay Fur Sales, which recently declared bankruptcy, failed. "We're starting off small," said Don Rumford, an employee of Fur Harvesters Auction Inc. "We also don't have that big debt that Northbay Fur Sales had to carry." Officials of Fur Harvesters, based in North Bay, Ontario, said they thought that the anti-fur movement was waning and that fur prices are about to rebound. The auction house, which is to be run by trappers, plans to hold its first auction in May and is hoping for sales of $1 million to $1.5 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/14/world.main_headline: House-to-House Fighting in Croatian City Nears End
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/14/world.print_headline: House-to-House Fighting in Croatian City Nears End
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/14/world.body_text: **********Pro-Serb Yugoslav Army troops fought house-to-house gun battles today with Croatian militiamen trapped in the ruins of this Danube River town in what were obviously the last hours of a siege that began almost three months ago. **********"We have no reason to push forward quickly," said Maj. Borivoje Tesic, as army artillery pounded the two remaining Croatian strongholds in Vukovar. "That would only result in more casualties." Croatia's government has for months held up Vukovar as a symbol of resistance to Serbia's and the army's campaign to strip away Serb-populated Croatian lands. **********The defense of the town has been resolute and costly, as the Croatians realize that its capture will cut their access to the river while providing the Serbs with a overland supply route to Serbian populated areas in what was Croatia when the war began. **********"The Croats know it is only a matter of time before Vukovar will fall," the major said, adding that the Croatian units are almost out of ammunition. "Only the most extreme ones are left."  Croatian Setbacks **********A Serbian captain, Rajko Morasevic, added: "We are calling all the time for the Croatian forces to drop their weapons. The rational choice would be for them to surrender." **********Croatian forces also suffered further setbacks in the besieged Adriatic resort city of Dubrovnik today, abandoning their last hillside fortress overlooking the historic Old City and its Baroque churches, monasteries and homes. **********A large ferryboat arrived in Dubrovnik this evening to evacuate European Community observers, journalists and others trapped in the city, which has been bombarded by Yugoslav Army artillery and naval gunships for weeks. The ferry, which can carry 12,000 people, is also expected to bring out pregnant women, children and wounded men. **********Meanwhile, the leader of the European Community's peace effort in Yugoslavia, Lord Carrington of Britain, met separately with Croatian and Serbian leaders today in an attempt to work out a 13th cease-fire in the four-month war, which has claimed well over 2,500 lives, wounded thousands of troops and civilians and driven about 400,000 people from their homes. 'Fingers Crossed' **********"The real problem is getting the cease-fire started," Lord Carrington told reporters after discussions in Belgrade with Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, which failed to produce any agreement. "I think there is a possibility, but keep your fingers crossed." **********Lord Carrington's talks with Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman, which were held in the Austrian city of Graz, also touched on the possible deployment of an international peacekeeping force in Yugoslavia, a Croatian government spokesman said. **********Croatia, which declared itself independent from Yugoslavia on June 25, is fighting to take back lands within its present borders that have been taken over by the pro-Serb forces. The Serbs in Croatia, who claim to be endangered by "Croatian fascists," began an uprising last year that escalated into all-out warfare after the independence declaration. **********Serbs make up about 11.5 percent of Croatia's 4.5 million people. Relentless Shelling **********Lord Carrington, who is scheduled to meet with Yugoslavia's Defense Minister, Gen. Veljko Kadijevic, on Thursday, said again today that no peacekeeping force will be sent to Yugoslavia until a cease-fire is in effect. **********"Once a cease-fire is got going, it must be kept going until the peacekeeping force arrives," Lord Carrington said. **********Backed by relentless artillery bombardments and air strikes, the more numerous and better-armed pro-Serb forces have jammed the 1,000 to 1,500 Croatian troops left in Vukovar into two small pockets along the Danube's western bank. **********It remains to be seen whether the army will push forward from Vukovar and attack the nearby Croatian cities of Vinkovci and Osijek, which have been heavily damaged by months of Serb and army bombardments.  Advancing Street by Street **********"The army will go on only if there are people to welcome it," said Col. Marco Maric, denying that the army is forging ahead in a military campaign to form a Greater Serbia as the Croatian government and several foreign governments assert. "I'm convinced that Yugoslavia will survive, but I don't know what its borders will be." **********As the Yugoslav Army forces advance street by street, pale refugees by the hundreds have begun emerging from the basements beneath the rubble of their homes, which have almost all been destroyed. **********"I lived in the basement for 76 days with my husband and daughter," said Smilja Riman, a 49-year-old Serb woman who worked as a bookkeeper. **********"We were only able to go for water between 6 A.M. and 7:30 A.M.," she said, adding that the fighting in Vukovar always began about 8 in the morning. "When the electricity went out, which was about two months ago, we took all the meat out of our freezers and salted it." 'I Buried Three' **********"We buried neighbors of ours who were wounded in the fighting and died," said her husband, Franjo, a 46-year-old shoe-factory worker. **********"I buried three myself in our garden," he said. "They were shallow graves." **********"We've had estimates that there are many as 10,000 civilians, Croats, Serbs, Hungarians, Slovaks and Ruthenians, still in Vukovar," said Colonel Maric.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/19/busin.main_headline: French Merger to Create A New Electronics Giant
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/19/busin.print_headline: French Merger to Create A New Electronics Giant
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/19/busin.body_text: **********In a daring move to shore up France's ailing electronics industry, the French Government announced today that it would form a high-technology conglomerate by merging some money-losing electronics businesses with a cash-rich producer of nuclear reactors. **********Asserting that this new conglomerate would rival giants like Toshiba of Japan and Siemens of Germany, the Government said it was combining Thomson Consumer Electronics and Thomson's semiconductor activities with the civilian activities of the state-owned Atomic Energy Commission. **********Profits from the commission, the Commissariat d'Energie Atomique, will help finance research and development for semiconductors and high-definition television technolgy. French National Goals **********The administration of Prime Minister Edith Cresson sees this rejiggering as a means for creating an unstoppable international giant. In addition, many industry analysts say the move aims to circumvent the European Community's efforts to stop the French Government from giving huge subsidies to its struggling electronics industry. Today's move would mean that money for research and development in electronics would come from the company's profitable atomic-energy arm, not directly from the Government. **********The energy commission builds nuclear reactors and supplies and processes uranium fuel in France and overseas. **********Today's move would essentially carve Thomson's consumer electronics and semiconductor operations out of their parent company, Thomson S.A. The move leaves Thomson C.S.F., the group's profitable military arm, as a separate entity. **********The new company will be called Thomson-C.E.A. Industrie and will be majority owned by the French Government. It will include the General Electric and RCA consumer electronics businesses that Thomson's parent acquired from the General Electric Company of the United States in 1987. **********As rumors swirled around France in recent days that the Government would announce this plan, some officials from competing companies suggested that the European Community should seek to stop it on the ground that it would circumvent rules against industrial subsidies. Modeled After Toshiba **********Some experts criticized the announcement, questioning whether this new intervention would be any more successful than the Government's earlier efforts to shore up France's electronics industry, which lost more than $1 billion last year. **********But in announcing the plan, Jack Lang, the spokesman for the French Government, said, "This is one of the most important industrial operations since the creation of Elf Aquitaine." That state-owned oil company was created in 1976 through the merger of several smaller French fossil-fuel companies. **********In his announcement, Mr. Lang said the new conglomerate would model itself after the Toshiba Corporation. He said Prime Minister Cresson announced the plan today to her Cabinet, and would seek to carry out the merger in early 1992. **********Today's announcement comes just a few months after other Government officials blocked Mrs. Cresson's ambitious plans to turn France's ministries of finance, industry and the treasury into a giant like Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry. Merger of Money Losers **********Thomson's consumer electronics business lost $498 million last year on revenues of $6.1 billion. SGS-Thomson, the semiconductor joint venture that Thomson has with the IRI group of Italy, lost $97 million last year on revenues of $900 million. That joint venture will continue, though Thomson's stake in it will now be owned by the newly combined French company. **********French officials have long complained that SGS-Thomson is too small to compete with Japan's semiconductor companies. They have felt frustrated that the European Community has fought the French Government's efforts to provide research and devleopment subsidies to Thomson. **********This week, France's industry minister, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, had suggested that there would be an even more sweeping restructuring of the nation's electronics industry, which would have merged two other prominent companies into the high-technology giant: Groupe Bull, France's money-losing computer company, and France Telecom, the nation's highly profitable telephone company. **********Some industry officials said Bull and France Telecom were not included in today's announcement because negotiations were not finished. Another theory: The more ambitious plan was not incuded in today's announcement because France's powerful Finance Minister, Pierre Beregovoy, who generally opposes heavy Government involvement in industry, has clashed with Prime Minister Cresson over the restructuring. **********Last year, the Atomic Energy Commission had $314 million of profits on revenues of $5.55 billion. France Telecom had profits of $1.03 billion in 1990, on revenues of $19.22 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Lockheed Rejects Simmons Proposal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/busin.body_text: **********The stage has been set for another proxy fight for control of the Lockheed Corporation when the company rejected a proposal from the investor Harold C. Simmons to reconfigure its board. On Wednesday, he offered to stop seeking control of Lockheed if the company granted him three seats. But in a letter today directed at Mr. Simmons, Lockheed's chairman, Daniel M. Tellep, declined the offer. **********The possibility seems greater now that Mr. Simmons, a Dallas investor who owns nearly 20 percent of Lockheed, will mount another proxy fight this spring. Last year, he failed to win majority support for a slate he picked. Mr. Simmons and Lockheed have since discussed a number of the investor's proposals, but they have never come to terms. Messages were left late today with Mr. Simmons's office seeking comment but were not returned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/busin.main_headline: The Executive Life; Another Vote on Girls in an Old-Boy World
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/busin.print_headline: The Executive Life; Another Vote on Girls in an Old-Boy World
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/busin.body_text: **********Last month, a furor erupted at Yale University when the 15 seniors in the all-male Skull and Bones broke with a century and a half of tradition by "tapping," or selecting, seven women for the secret society's next "delegation." Stunned, the alumni board of directors padlocked the club's windowless crypt and declared the election void.  No matter, the students countered; their hallowed rites would continue in exile until a compromise could be reached. **********This has caused such consternation that the club's board is expected to meet this Wednesday to determine the future of what is perhaps the nation's most powerful secret society. Will women be accepted? That's "up in the air," said Sidney Lovett, spokesman for the group's parent, the Russell Trust Association, named after the club's founder. **********Whatever the outcome, the brouhaha renews an old debate on the value that secret societies and other clubs have for members. Why, after all, are alums so anxious to preserve the Skull and Bones macho mystique?  Is it truly the ultimate old-boy network? **********"What gave Bones new life in the 80's was the pre-professional, networking aspect of the club," said Bill Essig '92, editor in chief of The Yale Daily News and not a member. "Some people thought it would help them get jobs on Wall Street." **********Perhaps no secret society has a roster superior to that of Skull and Bones. Interested in leveraged buyouts? Call Stephen Schwarzman '69, president of the Blackstone Group, or Peter Lusk '60, chief operating officer of Forstmann-Leff. Commercial banking? Try Dan Davison '49, former chairman of U.S. Trust, or Lewis Lapham '31, former president of Bankers Trust. Corporate finance? Call Vince Van Dine '49, Morgan Stanley's advisory director, or William H. Wright Jr. '82, an associate at Morgan. **********Interested, instead, in the corporate life? Call Vernon Loucks '57, chief executive of Baxter Travenol, the big pharmaceutical company. Or Edmond Thornton '54, recently retired chief executive of the United States Silica Company, a mining and processing corporation in Ottawa, Ill. Or Muhammad Ahmed Saleh '68, head of the alumni board, who is a vice president of the Timex Corporation, the big Connecticut watchmaker. **********Today's most famous Bonesman is, of course, George Bush '48. Then there are Senators John Kerry, David Borin and John Chafee. Yet others:William F. Buckley Jr., McGeorge Bundy and William Sloane Coffin. **********Although President Bush has declined to comment on the issue of a coed Bones, the three Senators have expressed their support for it. But politicians aside, only a few Bonesmen would talk on the record about the club because Bonesmen aren't even supposed to admit they're Bonesmen. If the secret society is mentioned by name, they are expected to immediately leave the room. **********"The importance of any old-boy network is usually overblown, and this is no different," said Charles Buck '69, first vice president for administration at Coldwell Banker in Laguna Hills, Calif. "It's always difficult for people to assess an institution they don't have access to. There tends to be a lot of rumor about this sort of thing, and most of it's usually wrong." **********Said Richard Moser '63, president of R.& D. Funding, a high-technology venture capital firm in Santa Clara, Calif.: "I suppose it's no better or worse an entree than membership in the glee club. There's nothing automatically beneficial about it in the professional world." **********"Of course," he added, "if you're hustling for opportunity, those contacts might be worth something. In my time, it was a real privilege." **********But during the 1980's -- when antidiscrimination suits broke down racial, ethnic and sexual barriers at most exclusive clubs -- the secret society floundered. In a recent letter to alumni, the 1991 delegation declared: "Being a part of Bones is an embarrassment, a source of ridicule." **********Perhaps. Yet membership seems to have its benefits. There is an annual gathering at Deer Island, a resort on the St. Lawrence River owned by the Russell Trust. After it, new initiates reportedly receive a club pin -- a skull and crossbones in 18-karat gold, made by Tiffany and Company -- and a tax-free bonus of $15,000. If one of greatest myths surrounding membership is true, Bonesmen are guaranteed financial security for life -- if only to keep down-and-out alums from selling the society's secrets. Members routinely deny this, along with claims that the club is Connecticut's largest landholder. **********Naturally, sharing secrets fosters a certain closeness. And so it's no surprise that Skull and Bones has spawned several successful business partnerships. The most renowned may be that of William Donaldson and Dan Lufkin, members of "D-121" (delegations are named for the number of years between when they joined and 1832, the club's inception). Six years after graduation, the two men joined up with a chum from Harvard Business School, Dick Jenrette, and lent their names to an upstart brokerage firm. **********As one Bonesman said: "Members are supposed to be selected on the basis of being the best and brightest, so there's a natural affinity to do business together. There's a certain trust, a certain comfort level, they develop in the club." **********That, of course, may be one reason women want into the club. "When you're on campus, being in Skull and Bones isn't that big a deal," said Jodi Wilgoren '92, managing editor of The Yale Daily News and not a member. "But when you get out, suddenly you're part of one of the most exclusive secret societies in the world and the President of the U.S. is a member of it, too."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/31/busin.body_text: **********He was an aggressive investor who built a small Los Angeles company into one of the nation's largest insurers. But now Fred Carr of the Executive Life Insurance Company can be counted as another casualty of the junk bond era. **********In April, the 60-year-old Mr. Carr lost control of his empire when California regulators seized control of Executive Life, the largest subsidiary of the First Executive Corporation. A New Yorksubsidiary was also seized and First Executive was forced to file for bankruptcy court protection. **********Mr. Carr's downfall can be pinned on his strategy of building Executive Life on a foundation of high-risk junk bonds. **********Executive Life, which has about 370,000 customers, invested nearly two-thirds of its assets in junk bonds, a far higher amount than most insurance companies. Mr. Carr, a former Wall Street money manager, believed that, with careful management, he could minimize the inherent risk of junk bonds and produce big returns. **********For a long time the plan worked. But when the bond market turned sour two years ago, First Executive went with it, reporting hundreds of millions of dollars in losses as its portfolio's value plummeted. Customers panicked and fled, and Executive Life nearly collapsed before being seized. **********For Mr. Carr, failure has extracted a heavy price. While he remains chairman of First Executive, he has lost his insurance operations as well as $10.7 million in long-term compensation.
