https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/14/busin.body_text: **********Federal regulators closed down the Columbia Savings and Loan Association today, agreeing to sell off or return to investors the seized institution's $4.76 billion in deposits. But for the first time in such transactions, a large portion of the money will not be disbursed immediately because of problems identifying some customers. **********The action closed a chapter in one of the highest-profile failures of the savings and loan crisis. The Resolution Trust Corporation, the Government agency set up to oversee the bailout of savings institutions, said it had agreed to sell $1.15 billion in insured retail deposits to the American Savings Bank in Stockton, Calif., which is controlled by the Bass group of Fort Worth, for a small premium of $6.1 million. **********Because no buyer could be found for the remaining $3.25 billion in deposits, mainly certificates of deposits sold through brokerage houses, those will be returned to investors as payouts to be mailed to holders. 'Only Feasible Resolution' **********"A combination payoff and insured-deposit transfer was the only feasible resolution for this institution," the agency said. "The lengthy maturity schedule and extraordinarily high cost of its deposits precluded offering potential bidders the option to acquire all deposit liabilities." **********The payout, consisting of $2.8 billion in brokered funds and $450 million in investments sold through Columbia, represents the largest in the history of banking. **********Regulators said the payout was complicated because they were unable to receive lists of customers with brokered accounts. **********Therefore, holders of the insured deposits will experience a delay in getting their money and will not earn interest during the delay, unless brokers pay it, the agency said. A Resolution Trust spokesman said only some of the brokers had been identified, and it could take a week or more before the payout process could begin. **********"This is not being done in the way we prefer to do things," said the spokesman, Steve Katsanos. "We're happy American Savings agreed to take the insured retail deposits." **********"Unfortunately, our efforts to work with the money brokers in advance of this to get their customer lists were unsuccessful" because of fiduciary responsibilities, Mr. Katsanos said. Resolution Trust said it had worked with the Securities Industry Association to obtain a list of specific liaisons at various brokerages. Seized in January **********Columbia Savings, which bought more high-yield junk bonds than any other savings institution, was taken over by the Government in January. The institution, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., had experienced huge losses as the value of its junk-bond portfolio plunged. **********The high-risk bonds are being sold off by Resolution Trust. They were bought mainly from Michael R. Milken, the former financier at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. who pioneered the junk-bond market and is now imprisoned. **********Resolution Trust has estimated the taxpayer cost of bailing out Columbia at $1.2 billion. **********American Savings, which has more than $17 billion in assets and 174 branches, is the surviving offspring of the American Savings and Loan Association, a unit of the Financial Corporation of America that became technically insolvent in 1984, a victim of mismanagement and reckless investments. It was the nation's largest troubled savings institution and got one of the biggest Federal bailouts in history. **********American Savings re-emerged at the end of 1988 as a healthy, pared-down instititution owned by the Bass group. Some later criticized the structure of the Bass deal, contending that the group got far too lenient terms from the Government. American is negotiating a restructuring with Resolution Trust that is not expected to change the terms of the deal materially. **********Resolution Trust said that only insured deposits up to $100,000 would be transferred to American. There may also be some brokered deposits over $100,000. Resolution Trust said the institution had as much as $45 million in uninsured accounts. **********Depositors whose accounts are not insured will receive certificates from Resolution Trust giving them the potential right to share in some money generated from the sale of assets. **********Columbia's 20 branches will reopen on Monday under American's control. American also bought some assets including branches and collateralized loans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.main_headline: U.S. WILL ENHANCE DEALS FOR BUYERS OF S.& L. HOLDINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.print_headline: U.S. WILL ENHANCE DEALS FOR BUYERS OF S.& L. HOLDINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.body_text: **********Conceding that it has been unable to sell its growing inventory of assets taken over from failed savings and loans, the Government said today that it was giving up marketing them piecemeal and would bundle them in a new program intended to attract big investors. **********The sale of these assets is supposed to hold down the already astronomical cost of the savings and loan bailout, which by some estimates could ultimately reach $500 billion over 40 years. But some lawmakers immediately criticized the new plan for terms it offers potential buyers that they said could actually increase the cost of the bailout for taxpayers. **********The plan would offer new incentives to what officials called the nation's 50 to 100 most eligible investors to make bulk purchases of about $100 billion in commercial real estate, bad loans and other poor-quality assets. The Only Way Left **********L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is overseeing the bailout, said the new marketing strategy was the only way left to move the assets that the Government has been unable to sell, which include marinas, uranium mines and dozens of golf courses. **********"If we sold $1 million a day in these kinds of assets, I calculated that it would take us 300 years to sell them all," Mr. Seidman said. "We'll never make it by selling these things piece by piece. The only way to do it is by making large sales to large buyers." **********Under the new marketing strategy, the Government would negotiate a lower down payment on any purchase and in return would receive future payments for the rest of the purchase price out of the earnings on the assets. The arrangement means that the Government would continue to be at risk if a property declined further in value, but it would benefit by managing to obtain at least a potential income when it now has none.  Some Potential for Gain **********"We will continue to have some risk, but we will share with the upside," said David C. Cooke, executive director of Resolution Trust, Mr. Cooke and Mr. Seidman, announced the new marketing strategy at a meeting today of the trust corporation's oversight board, which sets its policy. **********Members of the oversight board include Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; the Housing and Urban Development Secretary, Jack Kemp, and the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. **********Asked after the meeting about the significance of the new sales campaign, Mr. Brady said: "It shows progress. People are going to be getting good deals." **********Officials said the move would reduce the overall cost of the bailout by moving property out of the Government's control and thus keeping down the enormous expenses associated with maintaining them. But some critics and members of Congress said the deals would ultimately add to the costs by further reducing and deferring payments by purchasers. **********'There is no certainty of payment, because payment is tied to performance," said Representative Bruce Vento, Democrat of Minnesota and chairman of a House panel that has been monitoring the bailout. "It lengthens the time of the bailout, and now the cost of it is even more uncertain." He said the new policy would be examined at a hearing next week. **********The lawmakers have already criticized as giveaways deals made by previous savings regulators in 1988 to sell almost 200 savings associations. Today the lawmakers began attacking the new sales strategy as providing preferential treatment to the wealthiest investors.  'Extreme Fire Sale' **********"It's fraught with problems," said Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts and a member of the House Banking Committee. "It has all the markings of an extreme fire sale. The notion of selling more than $80 billion of assets and providing financing through cash flows simply delays the ultimate risks to the taxpayers." **********Mr. Kennedy also objected to the idea of limiting the sales to a group of investors selected by the trust corporation. "It reeks of the potential for real abuses," he said. **********Anticipating those complaints, regulators emphasized today that the plan would include only assets that the Government has been unable to sell after more than six months. **********Mr. Cooke said the list of eligible investors being compiled included the largest real estate developers and investors. He declined, however, to identify any of them. **********Senior officials said that three pending deals would kick off the program, but they declined to disclose details. The three deals are expected be completed in the next few weeks and to cover $1.2 billion in sales of office buildings, hotels and shopping malls around the nation. Speculation on Some Buyers **********But people in the banking industry said the proposed deals are with the General Electric Capital Corporation and with two investment groups, one led by the Tishman family and the other by John Daniels, a founder of Cadillac Fairview, one of the largest Canadian real estate developers with large holdings in the United States. Cadillac Fairview was acquired by the JMB Realty Corporation of Chicago in 1987 for $4.1 billion. The New York-based Tishman Realty and Construction Company built the World Trade Center and many other landmark developments. **********People involved in the three transactions said the General Electric Capital deal was for office buildings, shopping centers and industrial property valued at between $300 million and $500 million, and that the Tishman deal was for $300 million to $700 million in offices and hotels. The proposed $400 million deal being arranged with Mr. Daniels's investment group, Patriot American Investors, is said to involve office and hotel properties. **********In all three of the proposed deals, officials and industry executives said most of the Government's income on the sale of the properties would come from the future earnings of the office buildings, hotels and other assets being sold. Earlier Discounts Offered **********The new marketing strategy affects close to two-thirds of the Government's $162 billion in property seized from failed savings associations. It follows moves over the last year to deeply discount, and even give away, property that cannot be sold and to provide limited Government financing for buyers. The trust corporation has already announced its intention to sell most of its existing residential real estate and good loans as quickly as possible through dozens of sealed bids and auctions around the nation over the next few months. **********Mr. Seidman acknowledged that those moves had had only a limited effect on the rescue effort because the continuing seizures of savings associations have rapidly increased the Government's inventory of assets at the same time that commercial real estate markets have continued to decline.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/02/busin.body_text: **********One route to the top at C& R Clothiers, a California men's clothing chain, is through its ad agency. **********Jack Roth, the president of Admarketing, Los Angeles, C& R's agency, has been named co-chairman and co-chief executive of C& R. He will share those positions with Paul S. Reisbord, who had previously been the retailer's sole chairman and chief executive. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/28/world.main_headline: Colombian Kidnappings Are Gagging the Press
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/28/world.print_headline: Colombian Kidnappings Are Gagging the Press
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/28/world.body_text: **********One recent evening, a remote-control bomb exploded on a street here, killing seven policemen. The next morning, this city's largest-selling newspaper, El Colombiano, carried this front-page lead headline: "Drug Trafficking Study Proposes Decriminalization and Elimination of Extradition." **********At an office here, a businessman looked up from the El Colombiano headline, sipped his morning cup of coffee and commented: "The change in press coverage of drug trafficking has been brutal. There has been a total opening to the idea that the problem must be fixed quickly." **********In a new, perverse form of public relations, Medellin's powerful cocaine cartel has kidnapped nine journalists since August in an effort to end hostile press coverage. By holding the journalists captive, the traffickers are smothering open debate as Colombia's Government seeks to wind down the war on cocaine through truce talks with the traffickers. **********[ On Jan. 25, the police raided a hideaway near Medellin where traffickers were holding two journalists seized last August. Richard Becerra, a television cameraman, was freed. But the kidnappers shot Diana Turbay, a magazine editor, three times in the back, killing her, the police said. ] The Pain Brought Home **********Combined with South America's highest homicide rate of journalists, the kidnappings have dramatically brought the pain of the drug war home to reporters, editors and columnists. **********"The treatment of drug trafficking has been different because the problem of drug trafficking has suddenly come very close to journalists," Juan Gomez Martinez, publisher of El Colombiano, said in an interview at the newspaper's tightly guarded offices here. **********"Before journalists saw the problem as very far away, in Medellin, or happening to someone else," continued Mr. Gomez, who recently served as Medellin's Mayor. **********Today, the menace is never distant. **********Two hours after the interview, a young woman in blue jeans appeared sobbing at the front gate of the El Colombiano building. It was Azucena Lievano, a television news editor, who had just been released by the traffickers.  'A Coercion of the Press' **********Since November, the cartel has released four journalists, all into the care of Mr. Gomez. Seen as open to dialogue with the traffickers, the newspaper publisher offered last November to open his news columns to traffickers complaining of purported police abuses, in return for the release of the journalists. **********El Colombiano's playing down of the police bombing, first thought to be the work of traffickers here, is symptomatic of the newspaper's nonconfrontational approach to the cartels, readers here said. **********In Bogota, one of the released kidnapping victims said in an interview that the traffickers were successfully implanting a form of unofficial censorship in a country with a long tradition of civilian rule and of press freedom. **********"I can't use my press freedom," the editor said during a pause from laying out pages for a news magazine. "The hostages have become a coercion of the press." **********The intimidating effect on news organizations can be seen daily. **********In a country that is the source of 80 percent of the world's cocaine, most newspapers and television stations have stopped assigning reporters to investigate the cocaine trade. Reporters' bylines no longer appear with articles about narcotics. In reports on narcotics cases in courts, the names of judges and prosecutors are not given for their protection. **********"It's a censorship based on terror and it's working," Luis Gabriel Cano, publisher of El Espectador, a Bogota newspaper historically hostile to the traffickers. In 1987, traffickers killed Mr. Cano's brother, Guillermo. In the last 18 months, traffickers have bombed the newspaper's printing plant and news offices in Bogota, murdered three circulation managers in Medellin, and threatened to "execute" the Cano family. **********In September, after a five-month hiatus, El Espectador returned to this city, circulating in semi-clandestine fashion. **********"No one in Medellin dares to rent us a place to work," Mr. Cano said of his fruitless search for an office in this city, Colombia's second largest. In 1990, bombings of studios and radio towers forced two Medellin radio stations to go off the air.  Many Leave the Country **********Fear of violence has forced many journalists to leave Colombia for work in Mexico, in Spain or in Spanish-language news organizations in the United States. **********On Bogota's main thoroughfare, Avenida Septima, the office of the president of the Colombian Association of Journalists stands empty. Late in November, the head of the 5,000-member professional group disappeared after denouncing links between a prominent Medellin lawyer and Pablo Escobar, the fugitive head of the Medellin trafficking cartel. **********"He is afraid that the Medellin cartel will take reprisals against him," Diego Alberto Correa Aristizabal, a television announcer, said of the president, Alejandro Jaramillo. "We think he must be out of the country." **********As many as 100 Colombian journalists are living overseas in "self exile," said Robinson Ricardo Rada Gonzalez, secretary general of the journalists' association.  A Move to Miami **********In the last two years, Colombia has led South America in the number of news employees slain: 7 in 1990 and 19 in 1989. **********To escape the danger, some journalists have tried to maintain a foot in Colombia by moving to Miami. **********"Here in Miami, I feel very close to Colombia," Maria Jimena Duzan, a columnist for El Espectador, said in a telephone interview. Ms. Duzan, the frequent target of threats, moved to Miami after gunmen killed her sister, Silvia Margarita, as she was conducting television interviews in rural Colombia last February. **********"I listen to Colombian radio in the morning and read the Bogota newspapers in the afternoon," said Ms. Duzan, who continues to write a column on Colombian politics for El Espectador. "A lot of politicians come through here and they are much more relaxed for interviews." **********A few journalists continue to insist on speaking their minds inside Colombia. In recent weeks, some courageous voices have dared to heap scorn on the Government's offers of light prison terms for traffickers in exchange for their surrender.  'A Pact With the Devil' **********"This is a pact with the devil," Carlos Lemos Simmonds, a columnist for El Tiempo said in an interview. "This is not submitting the criminals to the law. It is submitting the law to the criminals." **********At the rival daily, El Espectador, Ramiro de la Espriella wrote in a recent column: "Are the drug traffickers really going to turn themselves in? Wouldn't it be more truthful to admit that we are the ones who are surrendering? And in exchange for what? Chamberlain's peace?" **********But most journalists have sidestepped open debate of the issue. They obey the hidden voices described in a recent editorial by the Medellin daily El Mundo. **********"Although it is correct to say that there is no official censorship, everyone knows that a self-censorship endures," the editorial said under the headline, "The Kidnapped Press." "There are forbidden topics. To touch them would be to put a noose around your neck, or to type your own death sentence."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/30/busin.main_headline: ESTIMATE ON GOLD WORSENS OUTLOOK FOR SOVIET UNION
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/30/busin.print_headline: ESTIMATE ON GOLD WORSENS OUTLOOK FOR SOVIET UNION
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/30/busin.body_text: **********In a development that adds more gloom to the Soviet Union's economic outlook, a key economic policy maker has announced that the nation's gold reserves are far smaller than the West believed. **********As the Soviets prepare for a tough winter amid fears of widespread hunger, sharply lower reserves would mean the Government has a far smaller cushion to help make the payments on its $70 billion in foreign debt and to provide for emergency imports of food and other goods. **********Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the architect of plans to move toward a market economy, said Friday that the Soviet Union had 240 metric tons in official gold reserves, worth about $3 billion. That is less than one-fifth of what many Western officials estimated.  Decades of Secrecy **********For decades, there has been official secrecy about the gold reserves, which the Kremlin regarded as a strategic asset. In disclosing figures, Mr. Yavlinsky may have hoped to increase pressure on the West to provide debt relief and food aid. **********Many Western officials have hesitated to support vast economic aid to Moscow because they believe the nation has huge official gold reserves, worth perhaps as much as $25 billion. **********The estimate of $3 billion in reserves is very much at the low end of private Western estimates, most of which have exceeded $10 billion. In Washington, a United States Treasury official who insisted on anonymity said the department could not confirm the accuracy of Mr. Yavlinsky's remarks.  No Decisions From U.S. **********The Treasury official said the United States was reviewing the Soviet Union's debt situation but that no decisions had been made. **********Mr. Yavlinsky, in an interview broadcast on Soviet television, said Moscow had sold two-thirds of its gold reserves last year to help finance imports and pay interest on its debt. Some experts suggested that the Soviet Union had pledged gold reserves as collateral on loans, which could help explain why the price of gold did not shift strikingly last year, as it would have if so much gold had been sold. **********The deepening Soviet economic crisis has been underscored by the grain harvest, which is falling below already pessimistic estimates, and by inflation, which is soaring. **********Food supplies are declining at the same time that Government printing presses are working around the clock to print rubles -- a mixture that is fueling inflationary pressures. Fifty- and 100-ruble notes are being put back in circulation; former Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov, one of the coup plotters, had ordered them confiscated in a ham-handed effort to fight inflation. In addition, some Soviet officials say the Government will soon begin printing 500-ruble notes for the first time. **********Central bank officials say the amount of money in circulation could surge to 240 billion rubles by January, up from 136 billion at the beginning of this year. Increasing the inflationary pressure, the monetary overhang -- the money people are forced to save because there are not enough goods to buy -- soared to 186 billion rubles on Sept. 1, up 40 percent from 132 billion last Janaury.  Unleashing Inflationary Forces **********All this is unleashing explosive inflationary forces. At present, inflation is estimated to be running at 100 to 250 percent, and some economists say it could soar to 1,000 percent, especially if the fraying trade ties between the republics worsen the supply situation. **********The food situation has alarmed Soviet officials. They note that the wheat harvest is running far below last year's levels. The Government said 148.4 million metric tons were harvested by the fourth week of September, down 27 percent from 203.6 million tons at the comparable time last year. **********Soviet officials say the disappointing harvest underlines the urgency of their appeal for $14.7 billion in emergency food aid for the winter. **********"We shall not be able to survive the winter without some Western deliveries," Leonid Abalkin, a senior economic adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said Friday in a speech in New York. **********After forecasting a grain harvest of 190 million tons, many Soviet officials now fear that this year's harvest, scheduled to end in mid-October, will fall below 170 million tons, down sharply from 230 million tons last year. **********Many economists attribute the decline to overall government and economic disarray, as well as poor weather, and the increased difficulties in getting students and soldiers to participate in the harvest. In a nation where statistics cannot always be trusted, some experts suggest that farms are deliberately underreporting their harvest to make it easier for them to hoard grain or to sell it on the black market. **********Compounding the food problem is the system of distributing goods, which is deteriorating rapidly in the wrangle over who has authority over what. One Moscow newspaper cited a K.G.B. document that said St. Petersburg was receiving three-fifths of the food it needed.  Excitement Giving Way to Gloom **********With each passing day, the excitement that resulted from the defeat of last month's coup is giving way to gloom over the economy. In Moscow and other cities, many stores are closed because there is nothing to stock their shelves. In stores that have goods to sell, huge lines fan out onto the sidewalk. **********One factor behind inflation is that banks in the Soviet republics are freely issuing credits to money-losing companies to keep them in business and to meet their payrolls, which has forced the Soviet central bank to print billions of rubles to back those credits. As workers clamor for raises, the Government's budget deficit is expected to soar to close to 300 billion rubles, or 15 percent of the gross national product. **********"Everyone from miners to teachers wants raises and bonuses," Mr. Abalkin said. "If we don't do it there will be a social explosion. We are printing money on three shifts, on weekends, and still don't have time to finish the work. We are even short of the special paper needed for printing money."  Price of Milk Up Sharply **********When milk is available in state stores, it sells for 60 kopecks a liter, a considerable sum in a nation where the average monthly wage for a government worker is about 300 rubles. In the private markets, milk sells for 3 rubles, or five times the rate at the state store. State food stores, where the nation's poor pensioners shop, are finding it increasingly hard to obtain supplies because farmers divert as much produce as possible to private distribution, which pays them far more. **********The surge in inflation will make the conversion to a market economy far more difficult. As happened in Poland, the Soviet Government is likely to have to clamp down on the money supply and raise interest rates to stabilize inflation. But as happened in Poland, that could cause a jolting recession in an already desperate economy. Economic output plunged 12 percent in Poland in 1990, the year the post-Communist Government sought to bring triple-digit inflation under control. **********Most economists predict Soviet industrial output will be down 15 to 20 percent this year from last year. There are numerous factors: government disarray, the initial moves to a market economy, the aging of the nation's capital stock, and the sharp drop in trade with Eastern Europe. **********Many economists say the economic situation will grow worse because of trade frictions between the republics and a lack of economic coordination. **********"I think that in December, national production will be 50 percent of what it was last December," said Anders Aslund, director of the Stockholm Institute of Soviet and East European Economies. "It's no longer so easy to get people to obey orders. One has to ask, for example, whether the railway system will continue functioning."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/11/busin.main_headline: Nintendo to Pay $25 Million In Rebates on Price Fixing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/11/busin.print_headline: Nintendo to Pay $25 Million In Rebates on Price Fixing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/11/busin.body_text: **********Nintendo has agreed to pay up to $25 million in rebates to buyers of its popular video games and $4.75 million in other costs to settle allegations of price fixing, state and Federal officials announced yesterday in Washington. **********The action follows an unusual joint investigation by the Federal Trade Commission and several states into allegations of antitrust violations by Nintendo. **********Under a consent agreement, in which Nintendo denied any wrongdoing, the company will mail $5 coupons good toward the purchase of any Nintendo game bearing the "quality seal" to customers who bought home video games between June 1, 1988, and Dec. 31, 1990. According to the attorneys general of New York and Maryland, that is the period during which the company fixed prices. **********In addition to the rebates, Nintendo of America, a subsidiary of the Nintendo Company of Japan, agreed to pay $1.75 million to New York and Maryland, the two states that handled the investigation in conjunction with the F.T.C. to administer the settlement. **********Also, the company agreed to pay $3 million to be divided by 35 other states that joined the agreement and any other states that choose to join within 75 days. All states are expected to join since a share of the $3 million award is theirs for the asking, according to New York State officials. **********"We decided to enter into this comprehensive and nationwide settlement in order to maintain the good will our company enjoys with millions of consumers who play Nintendo games," said Howard Lincoln, the company's senior vice president. "Rather than risk our company's good will while engaging in costly litigation over a complicated legal issue which could drag on for years, we opted to get this behind the company immediately." **********Robert Abrams, the New York Attorney General, hailed the agreement as "the first state-F.T.C. enforcement action on a vertical price-fixing case" -- one in which the manufacturer dictates price to the retailer -- and the first time in more than a decade that the F.T.C. "has rejoined the battle" against such price fixing. Keeping Track of Dealers **********In explaining the agreement, Mr. Abrams said Nintendo sales representatives had "kept track of retail sales to make sure dealers toed the line on prices." **********"Retailers who resisted Nintendo's pressure were threatened with a slowdown of shipments or a reduction in the number of consoles delivered for sale," Mr. Abrams said. **********Specifically, the charges were that Nintendo required retailers to sell its 8-bit NES video game consoles at $99.95 for a 19-month period through 1990. **********The giant American subsidiary of Nintendo has come to dominate the video-game market, which has moved from arcades into homes in recent years, controlling about 80 percent of the estimated $5 billion domestic market. **********Yesterday's settlement with Nintendo is the fourth such agreement that has been reached in joint ventures by states charging conspiracies by manufacturers to stifle competition. Other settlements had been reached with Mitsubishi, Panasonic and Minolta. **********Traditionally, antitrust investigations are undertaken by individual states or by the F.T.C. **********Nintendo said yesterday that it was providing a toll-free number for owners of Nintendo games to call to see if they are eligible for the $5 rebates. The number is 800-255-3700.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/busin.body_text: **********Japan has not done enough to open its automobile and car- parts markets to American manufacturers and the Bush Administration's patience is wearing thin, a Commerce Department official said today. **********"We have told our Japanese counterparts that we are not satisfied with the progress to date in the opening of the Japanese market," said the official, J. Michael Farren, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade. "We have waited patiently for years, and we don't have much more patience left to offer." **********Mr. Farren's remarks followed two days of talks here between Japanese and American officials on promoting trade in cars and car parts. The talks ended on Wednesday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/busin.main_headline: Ratings Cut On Citicorp By Moody's
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/busin.print_headline: Ratings Cut On Citicorp By Moody's
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/busin.body_text: **********Ratings on Citicorp and its primary banking unit, Citibank, were reduced by Moody's Investors Service yesterday. **********Short-term deposits at Citibank were unchanged at Prime-1, the highest rating, but ratings were reduced slightly for long-term deposits due in more than a year and all other categories of debt. **********Lower ratings were justified, Moody's said, because "deterioration in Citicorp's loan portfolios, particularly commercial real estate, will continue to place considerable pressure on earnings" and limit its ability to increase capital. **********The rating agency said Citicorp's recent moves to reduce expenses and build capital by reducing dividend payments to shareholders were helpful, but not enough to overcome the ill effects of future losses on loans that were delinquent or in trouble. **********The announcement came after the market closed. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Citicorp's shares gained 25 cents, to $13.75. **********At the end of 1990, nearly 19 percent of Citicorp's domestic commercial real estate loans were troubled enough that the company did not expect full payment. The company has a total of $3.4 billion of nonperforming commercial real estate loans and real estate it acquired from bad loans, up from $2.9 billion on Sept. 30 and $1.4 billion a year ago. **********Moody's has already lowered its ratings on Citicorp, in May, and other rating agencies have made similar moves.  Big Size Helps **********Christopher T. Mahoney, an analyst at Moody's, said Citibank's deposit ratings would have been even lower were it not for its position as the nation's largest bank, "and as such it will receive a much higher level of regulatory support" than other banks. He said regulators were willing to force regional banks to accept heavy losses on bad loans but did not exert as much pressure on larger ones. **********As evidence of that, Mr. Mahoney noted that regulators did not require larger banks to set aside reserves for their loans to less-developed countries like Mexico, Brazil and Argentina, even when it was clear by the early 1980's that those loans would not be repaid in full. Before the large banks, including Citibank, set aside reserves in 1987 to cover losses on bad loans to those countries, "the regulators gave the big banks five years to build their capital and reserves," Mr. Mahoney said.  Just Above 'Junk' **********Citicorp's senior debt rating was reduced ot Baa-2 from A-3, while the subordinated debt fell to Baa-3 from Baa-1. The Baa-3 rating is the lowest possible investment-grade rating, ranking just above the "junk" bond category. **********Commercial paper issued by Citicorp fell to Prime-3 from Prime 2, and long-term deposits fell to A-2 from A-1. The A-2 category is a medium-grade rating, well below the Aa and Aaa ratings applied to the strongest banks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/20/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF; War Summary
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/20/world.body_text: **********KEEPING THE MILITARY PRESSURE ON As hopes for a negotiated settlement rose and fell, artillery and warplanes of the American-led coalition blasted targets in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Allied planes flew 2,800 missions, ranging over Baghdad and Basra and striking Iraqi front lines and emplacements of the Republican Guards. As President Bush said a Soviet peace proposal had fallen short, the Pentagon reported that ground forces were "ready now" for an offensive. A single Iraqi Scud missile, the 67th fired to date, hit Israel but caused no casualties. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: No casualites were reported, leaving at 16 the number of American ground troops the United States said have been killed in action. Aircraft: An A-10 Thunderbolt attack plane was lost over Kuwait, raising allied losses to 31, and the pilot was reported missing. It was the 22d American plane lost in combat in the Persian Gulf. Naval Vessels: The American guided missile cruise Princeton, which was hit on Monday by an Iraqi mine, was withdrawn from action because of heavy damage. The helicopter carrier Tripoli, which had a 16-by-20-foot hole blasted in her hull by another mine on Monday, patched the damatge and remained on duty. IRAQI FORCES Troops: There we no new reports of Iraqi prisoners. More than 1,200 Iraqi soldiers are reported in captivity. Aricraft: Central Command reported five Iraqi planes destroyed on the ground. The air-to-air loss tallyfor Iraq remains at 42. No additional aircraft tried to flee to Iran. Other Weapons: The allies said they destroyed 5 Scud surface-to-surface missiles, 6 tanks, 5 artillery pieces, 3 armored personnel carriers, 1 multiple rocket launcher, 15 trucks and 2 ammunition bunkers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/06/world.main_headline: A Soviet Correspondent Goes Home Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/06/world.print_headline: A Soviet Correspondent Goes Home Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/06/world.body_text: **********Viktor A. Linnik arrived in New York City four years ago as a foreign correspondent who sought to immerse himself in United States culture and write articles for his newspaper, Pravda, that described everyday American life for his Soviet readers. **********Roaming across the United States, he sent reports to Moscow about the struggles of farmers in the American heartland and about the immigrants who were flooding into the cities of a country that had fascinated him since his days as an American literature major at Moscow State University. **********But Mr. Linnik's tour of duty in the United States has been cut short, an indirect victim of the failed hard-line coup in the Soviet Union in August. Pravda, the once mighty Communist Party newspaper, has flirted with bankruptcy as it tries to survive at a time when the party has been outlawed and the Soviet economy is in shambles. **********Mr. Linnik, 47 years old, said he has received little money from his editors since August, forcing him to curtail his travels and pushing him nearly $15,000 into debt. With little means to keep up its staff of foreign correspondents, Pravda is closing its New York City office, and Mr. Linnik is to return home this month. **********For now, though, he trying to gather money to pay off his loans so he can board the plane for Moscow. He feels, he said the other day, like a sailor stranded at sea. **********"I've been essentially living on whatever I can manage to scrape here and there," he said in perfect American English with only the faintest of accents. **********"I can't use my car," he added, explaining that he had not been able to make payments on his car insurance in months. "What life is there for a reporter if he can't use his car?" **********Other Soviet correspondents in the United States, like those from Tass, the Soviet press agency, and Izvestia, the Government newspaper, have not been as seriously affected by the fallout from the failed coup. Being the official organ of the Communist Party, Pravda received the brunt of the ire from the Moscow leaders who stood against the coup plotters. President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian federated republic closed the newspaper for a week after the coup. **********Mr. Linnik's voice was tinged with bitterness as he spoke about the upheaval in his country and the shock waves that reached as far as his apartment and office on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Even though he had been a party member since 1977, he said he did not mourn the death of Soviet Communism. But he stressed that the leaders who were empowered after the failed coup were little different from their predecessors. **********"One thing that needs to be understood: the democrats, the reformers back home come from the same roots -- the party," he said. "They have the same vindictiveness, the same unscrupulousness. People now have stopped realizing this." **********Mr. Linnik came to New York in the early days of the reforms instituted by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, when journalists were beginning to test the boundaries of the censorship that had defined the Soviet press for so long. During the cold war, Soviet reporters in the United States usually filed home reports that sought to trumpet the failings of capitalism through reports that emphasized America's problems -- the unemployed, the drugs, the racial strife. **********"What happened after 1985 was another extreme," Mr. Linnik said. "Everything that was written later was shown through rosy glasses. Everything was beautiful about America. This was the ideal country." **********Mr. Linnik does not know what awaits him when he returns to Moscow with his wife and two young daughters. Because of his ties to the party, he fears he may be blacklisted and will be unable to work at Pravda or another newspaper. **********"I'll have to see whether the country is changing for the better," he said. "It's a very depressing time -- for the country, for me personally. We're in a period of great instability, with the worst yet to come." **********But Mr. Linnik said he leaves the United States buoyed by four years of memories. **********"I've learned a lot," Mr. Linnik said of his tour here. "I will miss it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.main_headline: Gorbachev Aide Who Quit Doubts Pledge for a Free Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.print_headline: Gorbachev Aide Who Quit Doubts Pledge for a Free Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's personal economic adviser said today that he resigned this week because of doubts that the Soviet leader would fulfill his promise to introduce a market economy. **********The adviser, Nikolai Y. Petrakov, told the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda that the bureaucracy of the Soviet Union's crumbling planned economy was using "scorched-earth tactics" to sabotage moves toward a market system. **********"I don't want to be a prophet, but I have great doubts that the new Cabinet will follow the path of establishing a market," he said, referring to the new Government reporting to Mr. Gorbachev under Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov, a career Finance Ministry bureaucrat. **********"Prices and taxes are of course economic levers, and Pavlov knows how to manipulate them," Mr. Petrakov said. "But that's not a market." **********"Prices set by the Government are pseudo-prices," he added. "They don't equalize supply and demand, and there aren't any goods anyway. It's a fake."  Plan Was Rejected in Fall **********Mr. Petrakov and Stanislav S. Shatalin, another of Mr. Gorbachev's advisers, were among the principal authors of a much-discussed emergency plan to bring a market economy to the country within 500 days. The plan was rejected last fall in favor of a vaguer but still sweeping program to phase out price controls, tighten the budget and money supply, and permit private investment and ownership of property over a longer period. **********Mr. Shatalin said at the time that he would keep trying to persuade Mr. Gorbachev to move faster, but this week he said he, too, had given up trying to influence economic policy. Both he and Mr. Petrakov were among 30 intellectuals who signed a statement harshly criticizing the decision to send the Soviet Army into Lithuania last Sunday that was published in the weekly Moscow News. **********The partial retreat on the economy and the reliance on the military in Lithuania are among recent steps Mr. Gorbachev has taken that suggest, to many of his former supporters here, a sharp turn away from liberalism and toward conservative reaction. **********The Soviet leader has abolished a presidential council that included some of his key early advisers, including Yevgeny M. Primakov, a Middle East specialist who was his special emissary to Baghdad until last month, and Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, the former Communist Party Politburo member once regarded as Mr. Gorbachev's closest ally. **********The independent Interfax news agency said today that those two men and Deputy Prime Minister Leonid Abalkin, another liberal economist, were being excluded from the Soviet leader's inner circle as well as Mr. Shatalin and Mr. Petrakov. Mr. Petrakov said that Mr. Gorbachev had formally accepted his resignation on Wednesday, the day the statement on Lithuania was published, and that relations between them remained cordial. **********He painted a picture of political indecision and posturing on economic reform that had gone on for years without achieving any real results that people could see in the stores or feel in their pocketbooks. **********"The idea of a transition to the market was conceived in 1987," he said. "From June 1987 to January 1990, the Government -- the Government, of all things -- contrived to increase the money supply by 55 percent! We were saying we were going over to the market, and at the same time we were destroying the monetary system." **********Mr. Gorbachev acknowledged in October that losing control over spending and the money supply had been the worst mistake of his attempt to restructure the Soviet economy. **********Mr. Petrakov blamed "unbridled populism" at all political levels for the corruption of the plan. "They promise all sorts of things," he said. "We won't let the standard of living decline; we'll raise pensions and social benefits and miners' salaries. That requires billions of rubles. Where do they come from? The printing press."  Only Russia Accepted Plan **********As soon as the experts who prepared the 500-day program submitted it to the Parliaments of the country's 15 republics, Mr. Petrakov said, "in all of them, except in the Russian Parliament, they started making amendments, and it all collapsed and crumbled." **********The Russian Parliament, led by the renegade ex-Communist Boris N. Yeltsin, decided to go ahead with the plan, though Mr. Petrakov seemed to suggest it would not work very well unless the other republics moved simultaneously. **********After Mr. Gorbachev dropped the program, Mr. Petrakov and Mr. Shatalin warned that hyperinflation and political paralysis would be the consequence. **********"I got the impression that I no longer have any influence," Mr. Petrakov told Komsomolskaya Pravda. "So staying on would be pointless." **********He said he would work in a new market institute. "If they need me, they know where to find me," he said.
