https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/busin.main_headline: Ziploc Bags Makes Its Point With a Peripatetic Finger
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Ziploc Bags Makes Its Point With a Peripatetic Finger
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/busin.body_text: **********DELLA FEMINA McNAMEE, the agency that created Joe Isuzu, the quintessential lying car salesman of American Isuzu Motors commercials, is hoping its latest oddball spokesman can duplicate that success. **********Those hopes are pinned on Fingerman, who points out the features of Ziploc's new "gripper zipper" plastic storage bag in commercials that began last night. **********The Ziploc commercials are far less complex than those with the prevaricating Joe Isuzu making exaggerated claims, but they are just as offbeat. Ziploc's spokesman in the new commercials is a finger -- an index finger, to be exact, on which a smiley face has been drawn in black ink. He is a wackier, though unanimated, version of the Pillsbury Doughboy, and is the kind of product spokesman who would be at home on David Letterman's show. **********In the commercials, Fingerman, the talented digit of a puppeteer, David Rudman, shows how to close the new Ziploc bags. In one spot, to the fanfare of a toy trumpet, Fingerman hops into view and tells consumers that the new bags are so easy to close he can even do it blindfolded. He zips out of view, returning with a tiny bandage over his eyes. After sealing the bag, the blindfolded Fingerman hops back to center stage and bumps into the camera lens. **********In another, Fingerman appears wrapped up in tiny rope to demonstrate that he can seal the bags with his hands tied behind his back. At the end he frantically pleads to be untied. **********"We obviously wanted to attract attention," said Phil Silvestri, a senior vice president and group creative director at the agency. "But this was also the best way to demonstrate the product's attributes." **********Humor has long been one of Madison Avenue's favorite selling tools, but some industry executives say they are shying away from funny ads that might seem frivolous when juxtaposed with news coverage of the Persian Gulf war. But Jerry Della Femina, the chairman and chief executive of the agency, is not worried about offending people. **********"The country isn't going to stop laughing because of the conflict," he said. "Americans have a great sense of humor, and to lose that would be to lose the war." **********Ann Bastianelli, director of advertising for Dowbrands Inc., a unit of the Dow Chemical Company, said the company had decided to use the Fingerman character because he would be a "good foil for the technical information about the product's innovation." **********In an unusual move, Della Femina McNamee has placed ads in TV Guide magazine telling people to "be on the lookout for Fingerman." The ads list the shows during which the commercials will appear. **********Dowbrands has used mild humor in some of its past Ziploc ads, but Mr. Della Femina said the agency had decided to go for belly laughs because of the increasing competition from Glad-Lock bags, a product of the First Brands Corporation. **********Glad-Lock has been using a humorous campaign for several years. In a recent ad, a woman is asked if she would rather be shut in a telephone booth with a regular bag filled with angry bees, or with a Glad bag that has a green strip showing it is tightly sealed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/29/world.main_headline: Rally Takes Kremlin Terror And Turns It Into Burlesque
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/29/world.print_headline: Rally Takes Kremlin Terror And Turns It Into Burlesque
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/29/world.body_text: **********A fresh snow began falling, bolstering the vast street crowd's remarkable serenity in the face of a show of Kremlin police power that the marchers first took as an insult, then finally mocked as a burlesque of the terror that once made the Kremlin fearful. **********Today, it proved not fearful enough as ordinary Muscovites packed into the streets by the scores of thousands, emboldened, if not enraged, by the ban of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev against political protest rallies. The Gift of Protest **********A snow-dusted paradox was on the move through the city: The people were using the great gift of protest first secured for them by Mr. Gorbachev himself, and they were loudly, publicly protesting what they fervidly saw as his attempt at snatching back the gift. **********"Democracy ends at that line!" a marcher shouted, pointing at one of the corridors of waiting troops on the sideline. **********"It's shameful!" cried an old man, scrambling to keep pace with the protest parade. "Not since Stalin's funeral have I seen such a shameful use of troops to control the people." **********A grinning marcher wore a sandwich-board sign saying: "Is Communism done yet? Or is it going to get worse?" **********A man eyeing the troops all about said: "We're defenseless. Only our self-discipline will save us." **********And it did, by the end of a day that, were Mr. Gorbachev not lately otherwise inclined, the Soviet leader might be entitled to mark as a further sign of popular democracy making its mark on this tortured land. **********In rhythm with their own determined tramping, the marchers shouted slogans in defense of their champion, Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian President, who has scandalized the Kremlin and elated his ever-growing group of supporters by calling for Mr. Gorbachev's resignation. **********The day's tension and its climactic, ebullient, peaceful rally were much involved with the endless political feuding of Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin. **********But far more, the people who moved through the falling snow were savoring the simple act of public assembly. They took pleasure in circumventing an armada of water cannon, military trucks, and combat troops and police of every description in the center of the city, a stunning gathering assembled by the Kremlin in fear of public disorder. Plugging Routes to Kremlin **********This force plugged all routes to the Kremlin, parked and packed into alleyways and courtyards as if in expectation of the resurrection of Napoleon's army rather than a mere show of Muscovites. **********And rather than march into it, the throngs of civilians marched smartly away from it, as if there were better places to gather for denouncing Mr. Gorbachev than right outside his Kremlin walls. **********"This is what shows Gorbachev is a loser, all this force," said a ruddy-faced woman wearing a big photo over her heart of Mr. Yeltsin and his cocky smile. "Gorbachev is afraid of us." **********The crowd moved by the tens of thousands through the snow down Kalinin Prospekt, their backs to the Kremlin. They maintained a strut, their Russian flags and protest signs bristling colorfully through the large snowflakes soothing the gray city. **********"Get your Yeltsin news!" a newspaper dealer cried on the sidewalk, demonstrating the fact that for all his obvious, sometimes ham-handed attempts to diminish the role and power of Mr. Yeltsin, his nemesis, Mr. Gorbachev was only stoking the Yeltsin bandwagon with fresh fuel. **********The crowd, the biggest piece of an ad hoc rally that eventually flooded from three directions into Mayakovsky Square, marched on Kalinin Prospekt up to the city's major Ring Road. There, a traffic policeman was on duty, with none of the wall-to-wall trucks, buses, troops and water cannon to be seen elsewhere. **********The policeman -- a member of a city force from which the Kremlin Interior Ministry took over Moscow law enforcement this week, calling it unreliable -- saw the marchers coming through the snow. He nonchalantly stopped traffic and gave the people the right of way.  Horns Sounded in Solidarity **********Stalled drivers beeped their horns in solidarity. One stuck his hand out his car window, and the traffic cop, walking escort now with the front rank of the marchers, smiled and shook hands. **********More horns sounded. **********"Yel-tsin! Yel-tsin!" the strutting throng responded. **********Even as the crowd marched, the Kremlin was putting out the word that Mr. Gorbachev's ban -- openly defied by the insurgent government in city hall -- was not really being violated. A quiet compromise had been worked out with rally leaders, officials announced, in a bit of news that came far too late for the assembled public and its sense of risk in marching. **********Thus did the Kremlin, after inviting the world's wonder by assembling an enormous single-day task force to guard against its own people, try to deal casually with a face-saving issue: What to do about such an impish violation by such a large crowd of Mr. Gorbachev's initial demand that there be no rallies at all in this city for the next three weeks.  Short-Term Denouements **********And thus did this nation maintain its knack for inventing short-term denouements in the midst of its long-term crisis. **********That the crisis remains long-term was implicit in the rally speeches. Democratic legislators drew cheers from the crowd with vows that the Communist Party must once and for all turn back its vast property holdings to the public. But similar cheers were sounded a year ago at a rally, and the party still has its holdings. **********"The demonstrators were hostages of their situation," the television news controlled by Mr. Gorbachev's ministers contended darkly tonight, offering pictures that avoided the sight of the great crowd strutting through the snow. **********As the news was received at home by this skeptical, marching public, roads leading from the city were clogged with military convoys retreating from the Kremlin. **********The last words at the rally were a mention of how long and strange a day the troops had to put in. "Well, we forgive them," said a speaker and the rally cheered that, too.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/10/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Maxwell Son Assets Are Frozen
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/10/busin.body_text: **********LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 10 -- **********A judge has imposed a freeze on the assets of Kevin Maxwell, the younger son of Robert Maxwell, of up to $:450 million ($815 million), marking one of the first legal actions taken against the sons since the Maxwell publishing empire started unraveling. **********The freeze, imposed on Sunday, suggests that Kevin Maxwell, who is 32 years old and had the leading role in running the Maxwell empire after his father's mysterious death, is under greater suspicion than his older brother, Ian, of having moved assets out of employee pension funds and the two main public companies in the empire: the Mirror Group Newspapers P.L.C. and the Maxwell Communication Corporation. **********In addition, the court also ordered both Kevin and Ian Maxwell to surrender their passports, but a judge early today agreed to allow Kevin Maxwell to leave Britain after Mr. Maxwell argued that he had to fly to New York for crucial talks to save The Daily News. 'Going to New York' **********"I am going to New York," Mr. Maxwell said, when he emerged from the court building after the judge's ruling. "I will be working on the reorganization plan for the Daily News." Last week, The Daily News sought bankruptcy protection from creditors after its owner, one of the Maxwell family's private holding companies, sought similar court protection in Britain. A second holding company in the Maxwell publishing empire sought such protection. Most of the Maxwell holdings are now expected to be sold. The borrowings or transfers are believed at this point to total at least $:763 million ($1.38 billion). They are believed to have been taken as the result of a scheme masterminded by a frantic Robert Maxwell in the four or five months before his Nov. 5 death at sea, according to bankers, advisers to the Maxwells, executives of the empire and Coopers & Lybrand Deloitte, the accounting firm. Coopers conducted a special investigation after Mr. Maxwell was found dead in the water near his yacht off the Canary Islands. Coopers was assisted by N. M. Rothschild & Sons Ltd., a British investment bank. **********Two of the main private holding companies, Headington Investments Ltd. and Robert Maxwell Group P.L.C., filed for the British equivalent of bankruptcy last Thursday. Liquidator Appointed **********A final figure on what is missing will not be known until the current investigations are completed. But The Daily News in New York is believed to have been one of the recipients of the money. **********The court also appointed a provisional liquidator to take control of Bishopsgate Investment Management, a company owned by the Maxwell family that is believed to have been at the heart of the scandal. Two directors of Bishopsgate requested the liquidator be appointed. Regulators and trustees of at least one of the pension funds supported the request. **********The appointment will make it legally easier for the pension funds to try to trace and secure the hundreds of millions of dollars in assets that have been taken from them. It is not yet known what these latest developments mean for The Daily News's chances for survival. Can't Leave Britain **********Under the court order issued Sunday night, Kevin and Ian Maxwell were prohibited from leaving Britain until they provided affidavits to the provisional liquidator that detail their personal assets and provide any information they might have that will help secure the assets. They were given a week to do it. **********But at the hearing early today, the lawyer for Kevin Maxwell asked the judge to allow his client to go to New York, arguing that there was no reason to suspect his client would abscond. He added that his client would give an accounting of his personal assets before leaving. The lawyer also said Mr. Maxwell's wife was prepared to surrender her passport, which the judge did not request. But the judge said Mr. Maxwell must return no later than Firday evening and re-surrender his passport **********Bishopsgate managed about half of five pension funds of public and private companies in the Maxwell empire, whose value totaled nearly $:800 million ($1.45 billion), according to the Investment Management Regulatory Organization, a British regulator. **********At this point, assets worth about $:426 million ($771.5 million) are believed to have been taken from the pension funds. At least $:337 million ($610.3 million) in cash and securities is believed to have been borrowed or transferred from Mirror Group and Maxwell Communication themselves. Cash Flow Problems **********The Mirror Group, one of Britain's leading newspaper publishers, has discovered that at least an additional $:97 million ($175.7 million) is missing from the company. Bankers said the Mirror Group was suffering severe cash flow problems. The company was negotiating with banks today to try to obtain a short-term loan of at least $:35 million ($63.4 million) to see it through the crisis, bankers said. **********In a statement issued Monday night, Ernest Burrington, the Mirror Group's chairman, described the talks as "very constructive," which seemed to imply that the package had not yet been signed. **********Another potential bidder for the Mirror Group emerged when Lonrho P.L.C., the conglomerate whose chief executive is Roland W. Rowland, said it might be interested. Others who declared an interest were an employee group and Pearson P.L.C., a diversified publishing company. **********Assets of the pension funds appear to have been taken by funneling them through a series of investment firms owned by Robert Maxwell, who also oversaw the pension funds. His sons, Kevin and Ian, were also trustees of some of the pension funds and some of the investment firms at various times. **********In May, Mr. Maxwell had ordered the stock portfolio of the pension funds managed by Bishopsgate to be liquidated, which was not illegal in itself, said someone close to the Coopers & Lybrand team that investigated the empire, confirming such reports in British newspapers. "But the proceeds did not go back to the pension funds, which may be illegal if it is not found," the person said. **********He also said that Larry Trachtenberg, who was a director or an executive of some of the investment firms, had told the Coopers team that Mr. Maxwell had ordered him in June to transfer shares belonging to the pension funds into Mr. Maxwell's personal safe. The shares had a value of about $:100 million, or about $160 million at then-prevailing exchange rate. "It wasn't illegal but they weren't there after his death," the person close to the Coopers team said. "They are part of the assets unaccounted for." **********The transfer of the money from Bishopsgate required the signature of at least two of the firm's six directors, who had included Mr. Maxwell, Kevin and Ian Maxwell, Trevor Cook, Ron Woods and Mr. Trachtenberg. Mr. Trachtenberg, an American who had joined the board in September, and the Maxwell brothers resigned last week. **********The Mirror Group has said that the signatures of Mr. Maxwell and at least two other directors have been found on documents authorizing pension fund assets to the private companies but has declined to say whether other signatures were the brothers'. **********The Financial Times said last week that three Mirror Group directors, whom it did not name, had said that the brothers had signed some of the transfer papers. Another British newspaper, The Guardian, said it had been told that Kevin Maxwell's signature was on a document authorizing one such transaction. It quoted two people -- "one on each side of the deal" -- but did not name them. **********Attempts to reach the brothers through the Mirror Group and Maxwell Communication have been unsuccessful. A call to Kevin Maxwell's lawyer was not returned. **********There are other signs that one or both of the brothers have been involved in taking assets from the company in actions that were possibly illegal or of questionable impropriety. **********Maxwell Communication has disclosed that some of its shares in Berlitz International are missing. The discovery is threatening to delay and could conceivably scuttle the completion of Maxwell Communication's $265 million sale of a 56 percent stake in Berlitz to the Fukutake Publishing Company of Japan, depriving heavily indebted Maxwell Communication of badly needed cash. Bank Confirms Deal **********Confirming reports in British newpspapers, a spokesman for the Swiss Volksbank, said that it had received an undisclosed number of Berlitz shares last month -- after Mr. Maxwell's death -- as collateral for a loan to the Robert Maxwell Group. When asked who had authorized the deal, the bank would only say "executives of Robert Maxwell Group," which means it could have been Kevin or Ian Maxwell. **********Shearson Lehman Brothers, the American brokerage, has acknowledged that on Nov. 6 it took possession of 1.9 million Berlitz shares, or a 9.9 percent stake in Berlitz. What appears to have been a Bishopsgate subsidiary provided the shares as collateral for a loan that was not repaid. But the deal was struck before Mr. Maxwell's death, and Shearson declined to say who had signed the documents. **********Commercial and investment banks are believed to have been given a total of $:100 million to $:120 million ($181.1 million to $217.3 million) in shares that came from the pension funds, the Mirror Group or Maxwell Communication, according to the person close to the special investigation. Another person involved in the investigation confirmed that estimate. They said the investigation indicated that those that had received the shares included British, American, French and Swiss banks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/busin.main_headline: La Quinta Accepts Slate of Nominees
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; La Quinta Accepts Slate of Nominees
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/busin.body_text: **********La Quinta Motor Inns Inc. has agreed to nominate five directors proposed by dissident shareholders who include a group led by members of the Bass family of Fort Worth, the company said. The nominees will be voted upon at a special stockholders meeting on July 12. The Bass-led group, which owns nearly 15 percent of La Quinta's common stock, has criticized management's attempts to increase the company's value for shareholders. **********Sam Barshop, La Quinta's chief executive, has agreed to vote his common shares in favor of the nominees. He is the the company's largest investor, with 19 percent of the stock. Six of La Quinta's 11 board members have agreed to resign before the special meeting. Mr. Barshop said a sixth nominee would be found in consultation with the dissident group. La Quinta operates more than 200 motels in 29 states. Its shares fell 12.5 cents today, to $13.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/01/busin.main_headline: UAL Posts Big Deficit In Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/01/busin.print_headline: UAL Posts Big Deficit In Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/01/busin.body_text: **********The UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Airlines, today reported a fourth-quarter loss of $123.5 million and a record quarterly operating loss of $296.6 million. **********"The alarming increase in the price of fuel and a significant softening in the economy took its toll," said Stephen M. Wolf, UAL's chairman. **********United is one of the nation's strongest airlines, but like the rest of the industry, it was hit hard late last year by high fuel costs brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis, just as the economy was slipping into a recession. **********The year-ago fourth-quarter had earnings of $6.8 million, or 31 cents a share, UAL said. **********For the full year, UAL reported net earnings of $94.5 million, or $4.33 a share, down 70.9 percent, compared to net earnings of $324.2 million, or $14.96 a share, for 1989. The company reported an operating loss of $36.3 million in 1990, compared to an operating profit of $464.5 million in 1989. **********Revenues in the 1990 fourth quarter were $2.8 billion, up from $2.37 billion for the same 1989 period. The fourth quarter's results included a one-time gain of $68.1 million in sales of property, including nine airplanes. **********Annual revenues were $11.04 billion in 1990, up from $9.79 billion in 1989. **********Sara Dornacker, United spokeswoman, said the fourth-quarter loss exceeded a previous record loss of $192 million in the second quarter of 1985, which came just after the carrier's pilots began a strike. **********During 1990, the entire airline industry posted record losses, largely because of the high cost of jet fuel. **********"For United, the average price per gallon of jet fuel in the fourth quarter rose to $1.12, versus 69.5 cents and 52.3 cents in the same quarters of 1989 and 1988 respectively," Mr. Wolf said in the statement. **********On the New York Stock Exchange today, UAL's shares slipped 62.5 cents, to $128.75.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/19/world.main_headline: Mexico Closes Giant Oil Refinery To Ease Pollution in the Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/19/world.print_headline: Mexico Closes Giant Oil Refinery To Ease Pollution in the Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/19/world.body_text: **********In a move to combat this city's air pollution crisis, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari today ordered the immediate closing of the city's largest Government-operated oil refinery. **********The decision to close the March 18 Refinery, which sprawls over 430 acres in the north of the city, will cost an estimated $500 million, and will reduce the country's crude-oil refining capacity by more than 100,000 barrels a day. In addition, oil-industry officials said, it will force Mexico to import some kinds of gasoline until new refining capacity can be built. **********But the action will abruptly eliminate what environmentalists have long considered one of the worst sources of pollution in the mountain-ringed capital, which is now suffering under one of the most dangerous periods of contaminated air in its history. Mr. Salinas declared that the giant refinery would be replaced by public parks and other green spaces to help head off a still graver environmental crisis.  Trees Instead of Pipelines **********"The Government is prepared to impose upon itself the most severe measures to protect public health and to respond to social demands," Mr. Salinas said, announcing the decision at a ceremony marking the 53d anniversary of the nationalization of Mexico's oil industry, "Let's plant trees where today there is nothing but pipelines." **********The announcement came after weeks of growing public concern about the health effects of recent pollution levels, which have reached nearly four times maximum limits established by the World Health Organization for major pollutants. It reflected the intense political pressure that the Government has felt as it has tried to cope with the visibly deteriorating air quality in the city, which is home to roughly 15 million people, without bringing its vital industries to a halt. **********In comments to reporters recently, a senior medical official of the Mexican Institute of Social Security, which operates most of the country's public health installations, estimated that the number of patients treated for respiratory illnesses at public hospitals had risen by as much as 20 percent in recent months, confirming the concerns of pediatricians and other doctors who have described a sharp increase in such cases.  More Hospital Patients **********In published interviews, officials of the National Chamber of Hospitals have said the increase in respiratory patients at private hospitals has been even more pronounced, reaching as much as 30 percent over previous levels. And medical authorities from the public and private sector alike described particular problems among children, whose respiratory systems, sinuses and ears are considered more likely to suffer long-term damage from heavy pollution. **********The federal Government, which has consistently resisted providing any formal statistical analysis of the relationship between the city's high pollution levels and health problems, quickly moved to discount such estimates, arguing that there is no proven correlation between respiratory illness and pollution. **********But the scale of the ecological crisis, which has left even healthy adults with nosebleeds, sore throats and stinging eyes, has forced the Government to confront difficult political trade-offs between economic development and public health. **********The director of the state-run energy monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, said today that the giant Mexico City refinery, which opened in 1933, had served as the "backbone of production and distribution of fuels" for the capital, and that extensive studies were made in an effort to keep it open at lower levels of emissions. The refinery accounted for roughly 7 percent of overall national refining capacity, oil officials said. **********But the director, Francisco Rojas, said that Government officials had ultimately concluded that the refinery, which was named in honor of the date on which the oil industry was nationalized in 1938, should be shut down immediately with the exception of minor storage and distribution installations that will be preserved. **********Officials of the energy monopoly, which is commonly known as Pemex, said the refinery currently employed 5,429 workers, 3,206 of whom were directly involved in the refining process. But they said that no workers would be laid off as a result of today's decision and that the company would speed plans to build a new, 300,000-barrel-a-day refinery outside the capital region. **********Although the highest pollution levels in Mexico City are usually associated with thermal inversion layers caused by cold, stagnant weather in late January and early February, ecologists warn that still higher concentrations may lie ahead this year as warming air, sunlight and vehicle exhaust combine to produce ozone, one of the city's most intractable pollutants. **********Government officials have consistently maintained that they are doing all that is possible to reverse the growth of pollution in the capital area. Over the last year, city and federal officials have adopted a broad series of antipollution measures, ranging from tough new restrictions on automobile traffic to replacement of the city's entire bus fleet. They have also promised to bring the city's industrial activity to a halt if pollution levels become intolerably high. **********But labor and industrial leaders have resisted attempts to impose more drastic antipollution measures. And a combination of adverse weather conditions and high continued emissions has produced high daily concentrations of pollutants that some scientists have warned could threaten the city with a so-called "killing fog." **********"If drastic measures are not taken immediately to reduce the pollution at the source, with satisfactory results, we will be on the brink of an ecological catastrophe," declared a recent statement by the Group of 100, an organization of prominent Mexican artists and intellectuals that has taken a leading role in pressing the Goverment to protect the environment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/22/busin.main_headline: All About/Batteries; Keeping a Gadget-Mad Nation Charged Up -- and Safe
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/22/busin.print_headline: All About/Batteries; Keeping a Gadget-Mad Nation Charged Up -- and Safe
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/22/busin.body_text: **********From boom boxes to camcorders, Walkmen to cordless drills, portable power means batteries -- lots and lots of them. Americans now consume 2.7 billion of these household batteries a year. Most end up as trash in landfills and incinerators. **********But many environmentalists and governmental officials are concerned that the metals used in batteries will get into drinking-water supplies as landfills leak or as incinerator-stack emissions fall to the ground. All dry-cell batteries -- different from car batteries, which have a liquid electrolyte -- store electricity through chemical reactions that usually involve two different and often toxic metals. **********According to a draft report prepared earlier this year by the Environmental Protection Agency, household batteries account for 52 percent of the cadmium and 88 percent of the mercury found in trash, though less than 1 percent of all municipal solid waste by weight. Small amounts of the metals, if ingested, can damage the nervous system or increase the risk of cancer. **********As a result, several states, including Connecticut, have recently passed laws requiring that batteries containing cadmium be easily removable from appliances for disposal. Other legislation, much calling for the recycling of materials in batteries, is pending in several states. Several dozen communities, including some in New York, have begun programs to separate batteries from other trash for reclamation. **********The initiatives could shift the balance of power from single-use batteries to rechargeables. Not only can they be used and recharged about 300 to 1,000 times, but their manufacturers seem more agreeable to recycling. **********Single-use batteries are the largest category by far of the $3.3 billion battery market, which is estimated to be growing 4 percent to 5 percent a year. Two companies -- Duracell International Inc., once a unit of the Union Carbide Corporation, and Eveready, a unit of the Raltson-Purina Company -- account for 80 percent of the sector. A number of other companies like Ray-O-Vac, Kodak, Panasonic, Sony and General Electric, fight for the remaining share. **********The environmental issue has made rechargeables the fastest-growing market segment, according to industry executives. The largest producer is Gates Energy Products, a unit of the Denver-based Gates Corporation, a rubber products company. Its batteries are sold under dozens of names by a number of retailers including Radio Shack. Its own brand is Millennium. Gates said the market for rechargeables is about $330 million a year, or 10 percent of the overall market. **********'Green' Batteries  Environmentalists Push Rechargeables **********The makers of single-use batteries, like Duracell and Eveready, say they have defused environmental concerns by removing all but a tiny fraction of mercury from their best-selling alkaline batteries. **********"The ingredient of concern is mercury and all the battery companies have done a lot to remove it from their products," said James J. Donahue, Jr., a spokesman for Duracell. **********Even so, environmentalists say that using batteries once and throwing them away adds to the trash that must be disposed of and contributes to the depletion of the resources that go into them. **********"Based on first principles, you would argue for rechargeables," said Richard Denison, a scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund. "One rechargeable can replace hundreds of disposables." **********Popular guides for environmentally correct consumer behavior, like "50 Simple Things You Can Do to Save the Earth," published by Earth Works Press in Berkeley, Calif., typically recommend rechargeable batteries. The E.P.A. recommends using them in small appliances "whenever possible." **********Producers of single-use cells note that rechargeables tend to lose their charge much faster on the shelf and can hold only about a quarter the power of an alkaline cell of equal size. Prices for rechargeables are two to four times higher than for single-use cells. **********The Cadmium Question  Lingering Problems With Toxic Metals **********The most popular type of rechargeable battery has environmental problems of its own. It is the nickel-cadmium battery found in "cordless" appliances that stay plugged in when not in use. Each year, millions of portable vacuum cleaners, camcorders, shavers, electric drills and flashlights are sold with rechargeable nickel-cadmium batteries.  Most of them are sealed in the appliances at least in part to prevent users from trying to replace failed batteries with conventional ones. Attempting to recharge single-use batteries can cause them to swell up, leak, or even explode. **********This means that each year tens of thousands of rechargeable batteries, containing an estimated 1,200 tons of toxic cadmium, are going into landfills and incinerators as the appliances are discarded. **********To prevent this, three states, Connecticut, Minnesota and Vermont, have passed laws requiring that the batteries be easily removable so they can be discarded separately when they or the appliance wear out. More states are expected to follow with similar rules. The intent is to induce customers to separate the nickel-cadmium units from other batteries so the toxic materials can be recycled. **********The makers of nickel-cadmium rechargeable batteries have broken away from a broad industry group, the Battery Producers Alliance, to form the Portable Rechargeable Battery Association. "Our initial focus is to promote the recycling of nickel-cadmium batteries," said Norm England, the new group's executive director. "We want to do pilot projects so we can figure out the economics" of recycling. **********Since there are no facilities in this country to recover cadmium from batteries, initially they will have to be shipped overseas. And any group collecting batteries in quantity risks coming under E.P.A. hazardous-waste rules, which greatly increases costs. **********As a result the single-use battery producers are cool to recycling efforts. Mr. Donahue said the industry would support recycling if it were economically practical. But the value of the materials, like zinc and manganese, is not high enough to cover the collection and processing costs. "In the absence of recycling, there is no better method of disposal than household trash," Mr. Donahue said. **********A Hydride Substitute It Has Fewer Uses And Costs More **********Putting aside their current enthusiasm for recycling, some makers of rechargeable batteries have tacitly acknowledged that problems associated with cadmium will probably limit the product's use in the future. So they are developing new batteries that use various metal hydrides instead. **********The new battery favored by many manufacturers has many of the same characteristics as nickel-cadmium, without the disposal problem. But its differences may limit its application. **********For example, the hydride battery can hold twice as much power per unit as standard nickel-cadmium, but it discharges in storage at twice the rate. According to Gates, which is developing a hydride substitute, a fully charged hydride battery would lose its charge after standing for two months. The new batteries are also likely to be more expensive than nickel-cadmium batteries, at least when first released. **********The hydride battery also cannot put out power as fast as nickel-cadmium, so it probably will not be suitable for power tools and appliances that drain batteries rapidly. At the moment, that leaves only nickel-cadmium and small, sealed lead-acid batteries for those applications. SAVING THE ENVIRONMENT, AND MONEY **********How do the costs of using rechargeable batteries stack up against those for their disposable counterparts? The difference can be quite dramatic, according to a recent study. **********The analysis -- conducted at Carnegie-Mellon University and cited in the World Wildlife Fund's study "Getting at the Source: Strategies for Reducing Municipal Solid Waste"-- assumed that a cassette player was operated for two hours a day over a three-year period using four batteries. It also assumed alkaline batteries would last five hours, and that the nickel cadmium rechargeables would last two hours. **********After three years the alkaline-battery user would have gone through 876 cells at a cost of $657. The four original rechargeable batteries would still be in use, so that total battery purchase cost was estimated at $11. **********But the rechargeable user faces costs for the recharger and the power consumed in recharging. The study estimated the cost of the recharger at $10 and the power cost for 1,095 recharges at $5. The total cost of rechargeables would be $26, or a savings of $631. **********The environmental savings are just as impressive, according to the study. The disposable batteries would pile up 24,100 grams of trash, including 105 grams of toxic mercury, compared with 90 grams of waste from the rechargeables. The rechargeables would add 16 grams of toxic cadmium to the environment, the study concluded.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/busin.main_headline: Natural Gas Issues Lead Retreat in Stock Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/busin.print_headline: Natural Gas Issues Lead Retreat in Stock Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/busin.body_text: **********The stock market was battered yesterday, largely because of the poor performance of natural gas company issues. **********With volume on the New York Stock Exchange a relatively low 159.7 million shares or slightly above Tuesday's 156.3 million, the few big losers weighed down all the popular indexes. In all, 414 Big Board issues advanced and 1,156 declined. **********By far the largest price drop was posted by Columbia Gas System, which announced it was omitting a dividend payment and was considering bankruptcy. Columbia Gas rallied late in the session and closed down 13 3/4, at 20 3/4. It was the most active Big Board issue, on a turnover of 4.4 million shares. Dow Utility Average Falls **********Columbia's woes depressed other natural gas stocks. Consolidated Natural Gas fell 1 3/4, to 39 1/2; Panhandle Eastern, 1 1/8, to 11 1/4; Transco Energy, 1, to 32 3/8. The combined losses caused the Dow Jones utility average, which is usually linked to interest rate trends, to drop by 9.87, to 197.25, its lowest level since October. **********The Dow industrial average fell 31.31, to 2,955.50; the Standard & Poor's index of 500 shares lost 3.50, at 375.09; the Big Board's composite index declined 1.85, to 205.78; the Nasdaq composite dropped 6.23, to 485.36; the American Stock Exchange's Market Value Index fell 2.67, to 364.73. **********"The market was a bit shaky on overnight weakness in Tokyo stocks and subsequent follow-through selling in London and concern about this Friday's 'triple witching hour' when the news about Columbia Gas hit the screens," said William M. LeFevre, senior vice president for market strategy at Tucker Anthony Inc.  An Exaggerated Effect **********"While the relatively light volume in a weak market was a somewhat positive, it caused a handful of issues to have an exaggerated effect on the averages," Mr. LeFevre said. "For example, only three of the 15 stocks in the Dow utility average are natural gas companies, but we can see what clout the three -- Columbia, Consolidated and Panhandle -- had on the Dow utility average." **********The triple witching hour occurs on the third Friday each June, September, December and March. That is the expiration date for the current S.& P. 500 futures, options on these futures and options on individual stocks. In the past such expiration days have caused severe price volatility in a few hours. **********Yesterday, Standard & Poor's introduced a new index, based on 400 stocks with middle-range capitalization. The index moved between 124.95 and 123.34 and closed at 123.54. **********In any event, the program traders who use these futures and options as prime operating tools were not much in evidence yesterday. According to Birinyi Associates, there was only one major buy program and two sell programs during the session. The programs lasted for a total of 39 minutes, and their net effect was to reduce the Dow industrial average by 5.15 points.  Semiconductor Stocks Decline **********While natural gas stocks dominated market news, the semiconductor sector continued to be buffeted. International Rectifier, for one, plunged 5 5/8, to 16 1/2, and was the Big Board's third-most-active issue, on a turnover of 2.3 million shares. Another weak issue in this group was Intel, which fell a further point, to 47 1/2, in over-the-counter trading . **********Also weighing on the market was an increasing number of brokerage houses that are paring their estimates of corporate earnings for 1991 and next year. **********Estimates of lower earnings were blamed for Procter & Gamble's falling 2 3/8, to 81, on a volume of 1.5 million shares, which placed it seventh on the Big Board list of 10 most active issues. The same factor caused Pepsico, the second most active, on 3.5 million shares, to slip 1/2, to 29 7/8.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/19/busin.body_text: **********By not announcing which of two big-car assembly plants here and in Ypsilanti, Mich., it would close, the General Motors Corporation today put the lives of 3,400 workers here in limbo. **********In saying only that the company intends to close in the next few years 21 assembly, engine and parts plants, Robert C. Stempel, chairman and chief executive of the No. 1 auto maker, set off a likely tug-of-war between the company, the union and local politicians as a decision is reached on which plants should be closed. **********"That work is still ahead of us," Mr. Stemple said, predicting that the transition would occur next year. **********But one thing is clear in this suburban city east of Fort Worth: Only one plant -- either the one here or the Ypsilanti plant, known as Willow Run, near Ann Arbor -- will be closed in the biggest retrenchment ever for General Motors. **********At the Arlington plant, some workers challenged Mr. Stempel's promise that the plants would not be played off against each another to force the deepest possible concessions. But most workers boasted of their productivity. **********"Dealers will tell you they'd rather have an Arlington car than a Willow Run car," said Annette Morrow, a seat builder and trimmer who has worked 15 years for G.M. "Willow Run labor is too militant and they have more salaried people there than we do," she said, referring to the Michigan plant. **********Both plants build big cars, like the Chevrolet Caprice and the Buick Roadmaster. The decision on which to close will come down to which plant can make a better case for cutting costs and improving G.M.'s poor efficiency record so that the maker's cars can be priced more competitively. **********The Michigan plant has lower costs for parts shipments, especially heavy engines and transmissions, compared with the Texas site because of its location near the heart of America's auto-making nerve center and G.M.'s North American supplier network. Yet the Texas plant is closer to suppliers of smaller parts, like wiring harnesses, door assemblies and body trim made in northern Mexico. **********Arlington workers and executives once bragged that the quality of their work was one of the highest of any plant in the G.M. empire, but Mr. Stempel said today that that was no longer an issue. "The differences are so slight" now in quality levels among all G.M. plants, he said. **********Workers at the G.M. plant here were told last week by their manager, Art Hester, and a senior union official, Mike Seiler, not to expect a decision today from Mr. Stempel. Many were stunned and angered by a report today in The Detroit Free Press that the decision to close the Arlington plant had already been made. **********But after Mr. Stempel's remarks to reporters, many renewed their hopes that their plant would prevail in a competition with Willow Run.  Action by Union **********G.M.'s announcement today came as members of United Automobile Workers union Local 276 here voted to give their leaders a virtual blank check to bargain for whatever terms are needed to keep the Arlington plant in business. **********"We need a good vote on this to give us the teeth to go in and negotiate," said Dave Perdue, president of the U.A.W. local. "I feel like we'll win." **********One proposal outlined by the union was to add a third shift at the plant by moving to a four-day workweek of 10-hour shifts for its members. Current shifts are eight hours, five days a week. The change could open jobs for workers transferred from the Michigan plant, Mr. Perdue said. **********Mr. Perdue said the union was not pressured into the concession by Mr.  Hester. "He just lays the situation out on the table, and it's up to us to make some decisions," he said. **********Walter Mays, 45, said the schedule change would help overcome the Arlington plant's smaller production capacity and higher freight costs compared with Willow Run's.  Making a Case **********The workers were told last week that Arlington managers would make their case before G.M. executives in Detroit during the week of Jan. 8, with Willow Run to follow a week later. A decision is expected before Feb. 1. **********Mr. Mays was among those who were skeptical about Mr. Stempel's promise that the two plants were not being "whipsawed," as he put it. **********"I've seen this before," Mr. Mays said of the schedule changes that his union leaders had endorsed. "Six years ago, we were told to vote in the team concept, or the plant would close," he said, referring to a way of reorganizing the work force. "We did, by 86 percent. Willow Run didn't, but they stayed open. I think it's another game to see what they can get. Their decision, whatever it is, has already been made."  Another Blow **********A shutdown of the sprawling, 38-year-old plant here would be yet another blow for the economy of the Fort Worth region, which, with one-third the population of Dallas, has been battered by plant closings and job cutbacks all year. **********Just over a year ago, the Fort Worth area had one of the lowest jobless rates in Texas, at 4.4 percent. But jarring cutbacks in Pentagon budgets, which had an impact on a General Dynamics plant here; a slumping local economy, and rising manufacturing layoffs pushed unemployment to 7.2 percent in October. **********The Pentagon canceled development of the Navy A-12 attack plane in January. And last summer it said that 7,000 jobs would be lost when the nearby Carswell Air Force Base, home to aging B-52 bombers, would be closed. **********Those cutbacks knocked nearly 5 percent from the Fort Worth-Arlington economic base, and the loss of the G.M. plant "would blow away another point and a half," said Don C. Reynolds, a Fort Worth economist and former head of the county's economic development commission. **********Bernard L. Weinstein, another local economist, said the General Motors plant, with a 1990 payroll of $121.5 million and hourly wages ranging between $15 and $25, contributes between $400 million and $500 million in purchasing power to the local economy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/27/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Issues Narrowly Mixed
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/27/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday, a session highlighted by an auction of $11.5 billion of new two-year notes. **********Bids at the auction produced an average yield of 7.15 percent, up substantially from the 6.87 percent average rate at the last two-year note sale on Feb. 20. **********Dealers said the yield at the auction was attractive relative to the Federal Reserve Board's 6 percent target for the overnight Federal funds rate. Reflecting that, by late in the day the new two-year issue was offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.11 percent. **********The Treasury is expected today to sell $8.5 billion worth of new five-year notes. Market participants said the current configuration of interest rates makes the five-year issue even more attractive than the two-year. **********In late trading, the five-year securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.81 percent. **********Economic reports released during the session had little measurable effect on prices. **********The most outwardly startling news was the huge swing in consumer confidence during March, which posted the largest month-to-month gain ever recorded in the history of the Conference Board's survey. **********Analysts said they were not impressed with the results of the survey, which were compiled during the first 18 days of the month, a period when postwar euphoria was probably at its peak. **********"Now we have consumers confidently staying away from showrooms and stores," said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. **********After looking at the report, Mr. Resler said: "It is quite obvious that the end of the war did not produce a sudden shift in making big-ticket purchases. Moreover, the survey shows no change in buying plans, and a further deterioration in attitudes toward current conditions." **********Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said: "People are still very uncertain. And consumer spending is based on employment prospects and rising personal income. Neither are looking very good right now." **********In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 95 10/32 late yesterday, up 5/32, to yield 8.30 percent, down from 8.31 percent late Monday. **********Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 97 18/ 32, up 2/32, to yield 8.11 percent. And the 7 7/8 percent seven-year notes were offered at 99 9/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.01 percent. **********Short-term Treasury bill rates dipped slightly. **********Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.83 percent late yesterday, down 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a basis point, to a late offered rate of 5.82 percent. **********Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was muted, dealers said, and prices of most issues were little changed on the day. **********In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to up 1/8 point, according to market participants. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction of two-year Treasury notes:  (000 omitted in dollar figures) Average Price . . . 99.954 Average Yield . . . 7.15% Low Price . . . 99.954 High Yield . . . 7.15% High Price . . . 99.991 Low Yield . . . 7.13% Accepted at low price . . . 72% Total applied for . . . $29,555,520 Accepted . . . $11,528,920 N.Y. applied for . . . $26,622,880 N.Y. accepted . . . $10,065,920 Noncompetitive . . . $1,244,000 Interest set at . . . 7 1/8%

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/02/busin.body_text: **********British Steel P.L.C. said today that its profit sank 66 percent in the year ended March 30 because of the British recession and intense competition in Europe. **********British Steel reported net profit of $:193 million, or about $311 million, for the year, compared with $:564 million, or $907 million, in the previous year. Sales fell 1.4 percent, to $8.1 billion. **********The company said it took a one-time charge to carry out cost-cutting measures. British Steel, which employs 51,500 people, trimmed 2,000 jobs in the latest year and plans to continue to reduce its costs, a spokesman said. **********The company said an oversupply of steel in Europe, along with the recession in the United States, led to lower prices and increased competition in the European Community. **********Sir Robert Scholey, British Steel's chairman, said any upturn would be steady rather than dramatic and "the prudent view is to assume that the current depressed conditions will persist for a longer rather than a shorter period."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/24/world.main_headline: Kerry Sees Help on Americans Missing in Asia
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/24/world.print_headline: Kerry Sees Help on Americans Missing in Asia
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/24/world.body_text: **********The leaders of Vietnam and Cambodia have renewed pledges of an "open inquiry" to resolve rapidly the fates of Americans listed as missing in action in those Southeast Asian nations, Senator John Kerry said today. **********After a weeklong visit to Vietnam and Cambodia, Mr. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat, said the two Communist countries had promised to allow United States helicopters to take part in the search. They also pledged to welcome Americans making their own inquiries and to give unprecedented access to a newly formed Senate committee investigating the possibility that some of the missing Americans are still alive, he said. **********"I think it is very significant that they are willing to have that kind of intrusion, that kind of open inquiry," Mr. Kerry told a news conference. "It seems to me at first blush that they are extraordinarily committed to make that happen." Met With Many Officials **********During his trip to Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam and Phnom Penh in Cambodia, Mr. Kerry met with Do Muoi, head of Vietnam's Communist Party, Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia and a number of other officials in both countries. **********Mr. Kerry's comments echoed those of United States officials who say that Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos have significantly stepped up cooperation on the issue of 2,273 Americans listed as missing in Southeast Asia. **********Vietnam is eager for diplomatic relations with Washington and the lifting of a United States trade embargo hampering recovery of that country's ruinous economy. **********Mr. Kerry, a highly decorated Vietnam War veteran, said he made the trip to lay the groundwork for an effort by the 12-member Senate committee he heads. Mr. Kerry said he also planned to visit Laos. Did Some Stay Behind? **********Mr. Kerry indicated that he thought a small number of Americans may have stayed behind in Vietnam of their own free will, but he declined to give details. **********"It is very difficult to comprehend the rationale for a government to formally be holding somebody, and I saw nothing while I was there to change my mind about creating a rationale," he said when asked about possible American prisoners of war in Indochina. **********Mr. Kerry said Vietnamese leaders agreed to allow a small United States team, based in Hanoi, which is searching for missing Americans to have more logistical support, including helicopters. He said three to four American helicopters may be sent to Vietnam to assist the search, with the Vietnamese doing the flying. **********He said this would allow quicker movement to areas where "live sightings" of Americans are reported.
